headline: Not Public Financing’s Fault
abstract: The Brennan Center for Justice says Arizona’s Clean Elections Law did not foster extremism.

headline: Vows: Can a Captain Marry Us?
abstract: Hollywood gave a big boost to the myth that captains could legally join couples on the open seas. In New York, Captain Arnold Wonsever, an ordained minister, is making this myth a reality.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood gave a big boost to the myth that captains could legally join couples on the open seas. In New York, Captain Arnold Wonsever, an ordained minister, is making this myth a reality.

headline: Change Your Style, You’ll Survive
abstract: The Flamenco Festival enters its 14th year, larger than ever and with a change in scope and style.
lead_paragraph: This year’s edition of the Flamenco Festival, which opens on Thursday at City Center, comes on the tail of the worst recession Spain has seen since the end of the Franco period. But the festival, now in its 14th year, is larger than ever. It has expanded its scope, adding Los Angeles and San Francisco to its itinerary. In New York, it has spread to six additional spaces. The festival’s organizers are looking to new markets in the Arab world and Asia. Flamenco is one of Spain’s most successful exports.

headline: Rise in Sales for Neiman, Despite Loss
abstract: Neiman’s revenue was $1.43 billion during its second quarter, which ended Feb. 1, an increase from the same period last year, when revenue was $1.36 billion.
lead_paragraph: Neiman Marcus reported a rise in second-quarter sales on Friday, during what was a difficult season for retailers. The company also reported substantial expenses from the sale of the company in the fall.

headline: Hoffman Killed by Toxic Mix of Drugs, Official Concludes
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Heroin', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Sedatives', 'AMPHETAMINES']
abstract: The actor Philip Seymour Hoffman was killed after using not only heroin but also cocaine, amphetamines and sedatives, the New York City medical examiner announced.
lead_paragraph: Philip Seymour Hoffman was killed by a poisonous mix of drugs that included not only heroin but also cocaine, amphetamines and sedatives, the New York City medical examiner announced on Friday.

headline: In Battle for First Base, Mets’ Duda and Davis Impress
abstract: Lucas Duda and Ike Davis each had solid outings in the Mets’ first spring training game, as did the young pitchers Rafael Montero and Jacob deGrom.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — After just one game in the Grapefruit League this spring, the Mets’ competition at first base is already hot. Lucas Duda, inserted as the designated hitter against the Washington Nationals, smacked a broken-bat, ground-rule double. Then Ike Davis smashed a long, two-run home run to right.

headline: Carnival Events Around the World
abstract: Carnival is celebrated not just in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Carnival is celebrated not just in Brazil.

headline: A Big Decision at the Minnesota Orchestra – But What?
abstract: The board said it had come to an agreement on the orchestra’s leadership, but declined to say what it was.
lead_paragraph: The board of the Minnesota Orchestra, which is trying to rebuild itself after a bitter labor dispute and a debilitating 16-month lockout, has found itself facing an unusual choice of whether to side with its musical leadership or its administrative leadership.

headline: No Charges in Death of Alzheimer’s Patient Mistaken for Intruder
abstract: A Georgia man who fatally shot an Alzheimer’s patient he feared was breaking into his house will not be charged with a crime, a prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A man who shot to death an Alzheimer’s patient he feared was trying to break into his house will not be charged with a crime, a Georgia prosecutor said Friday.

headline: McCann and a Prospect Display Power for the Yankees
abstract: The off-season acquisition Brian McCann homered in a spring training win over the Tigers, as did Gary Sanchez, who could succeed McCann at catcher someday.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — Brian McCann’s shot took flight in the second inning, and Gary Sanchez’s came two innings later, a succession of home runs that may presage the succession of Yankees catchers in the years to come.

headline: Rail Inspections Ramp Up in Albany and Buffalo
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Railroads', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety']
abstract: With Albany emerging in the last two years as a key hub for shipping oil from North Dakota to refineries along the East Coast, state regulators conducted a series of inspections to increase rail safety.
lead_paragraph: New York State regulators conducted a series of inspections over the last week at the Port of Albany and on rail tracks in Albany and Buffalo to increase the safety of the surging oil-by-rail business, according to a statement by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: Shepherd of the City’s Rebirth, Rio’s Mayor Feels the Strains, Too
abstract: Mayor Eduardo Paes, whose political fortunes were rising before the street protests, finds himself at the center of increasingly fierce disputes over Rio’s transformation.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — IN his fits of rage, Eduardo Paes, the mayor of Rio de Janeiro, has thrown a stapler at one aide. He threw an ashtray at another. He berated a councilwoman in her chambers, calling her a tramp. Stunning diners at a crowded Japanese restaurant where he was being taunted by one constituent, a singer in a rock band, he punched the man in the face.

headline: Uniqlo’s Parent Said to Seek Deal for J. Crew
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Talks between Fast Retailing and J. Crew’s owners, the private equity firms TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners, are in early stages and could still fall apart.
lead_paragraph: The owners of J. Crew, the fashion purveyor of choice for the likes of Michelle Obama, are in the early discussions to sell the company to Fast Retailing, the Japanese retailer whose holdings include Uniqlo and Theory, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Engineers Allege Hiring Collusion in Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A class-action suit by Silicon Valley engineers against companies including Google, Apple and Intel has revealed details of an agreement among them not to cold-call one another’s employees.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tech companies love new ideas, unless they belong to someone else. Then any breakthroughs must be neutralized or bought. Silicon Valley executives know all too well that a competitor’s unchecked innovation can quickly topple the mightiest tech titan.

headline: E.P.A. Says It Will Fight Mine Project in Alaska
abstract: The agency’s decision makes it unlikely that developers of the huge open-pit project in the Bristol Bay watershed will be able to proceed.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Federal environmental regulators, citing risks to water quality and salmon spawning grounds in one of the world’s richest fisheries, moved on Friday to block the development of a giant open-pit copper mine in the watershed of Bristol Bay in southwest Alaska.

headline: The Bitcoin Blasphemy
abstract: Created to avoid government, the virtual currency won’t survive without it.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I read a story about bitcoin, the virtual currency that has been so much in the news these days, I think about a man named Dee Hock. In the early 1970s, Hock created the credit card system that we now know as Visa. Hock was a man who liked to think grandiose thoughts. When it came to Visa, and credit cards in general, Hock used to describe them not just as a way to get a short-term loan but as a new kind of payment system, an exchange of value that was on par with, and that competed with, cash.

headline: New Health Fix Offers Subsidies for Insurance Policies Bought Outside Exchanges
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: Federal officials said they agreed to provide subsidies retroactively for insurance purchased in the private market because technical problems had prevented consumers from using the online exchanges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would allow some people to receive federal subsidies for health insurance purchased in the private market outside of health insurance exchanges. The sudden shift was the latest in a series of policy changes, extensions and clarifications by federal officials trying to help beneficiaries and minimize political damage to Democrats in this election year.

headline: Archbishop of Cologne, Germany’s Largest Diocese, Retires
abstract: Cardinal Joachim Meisner, the archbishop of Cologne whose conservative positions found him apologizing more than once during the years that he led Germany’s largest and wealthiest diocese, has retired, the archdiocese said Friday.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Joachim Meisner, the archbishop of Cologne whose conservative positions found him apologizing more than once during the years that he led Germany’s largest and wealthiest diocese, has retired, the archdiocese said Friday. Pope Francis accepted Cardinal Meisner’s request to retire, the archdiocese said in a statement. The cardinal, 80, had offered to step down after his 75th birthday but was asked by Pope Benedict XVI to stay on. After he was named to the position in 1988 by Pope John Paul II, he became known for his provocative statements, including comparing abortion to the Holocaust and using the Nazi’s term for the modernist artworks they despised — “degenerate” — to describe art with no religious connection. But he earned respect for refusing to bow to political pressure from Communist-era leaders while he was the leader of the Roman Catholic Church in Berlin and East Germany from 1980 to 1988.

headline: American Envoy to Syria Steps Down
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The United States’ top representative to the Syrian opposition, Robert S. Ford, retired from the Foreign Service on Friday, the State Department said.
lead_paragraph: The United States’ top representative to the Syrian opposition, Robert S. Ford, retired from the Foreign Service on Friday, the State Department said. Lawrence Silverman, the acting deputy assistant secretary for Near Eastern affairs, will serve as his replacement until a successor is chosen. State Department officials said this month that Mr. Ford was expected to retire soon. As the American ambassador to Syria, Mr. Ford played an active role in challenging President Bashar al-Assad’s crackdown on the political opposition. In February 2012, as the security situation in Syria worsened, the American Embassy was closed. Mr. Ford later became the chief American envoy to the moderate Syrian opposition. Mr. Ford played a central role during the first two rounds of the peace talks in Geneva.

headline: President of the Garden Is Replaced by an Executive at Cablevision
abstract: Hank Ratner, who was also the chief executive of Madison Square Garden, is now its vice chairman, and Tad Smith, the president of local media for Cablevision, has succeeded him.
lead_paragraph: In October, Hank Ratner, the president and chief executive of the Madison Square Garden Company, proudly showed off the Garden’s $1 billion renovation. Ratner had become the public face of the project, leading hard-hat tours for the news media while James L. Dolan, the executive chairman of the company, stayed behind the scenes.

headline: Renting Judges for Secret Rulings
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Corporations']
abstract: Delaware courts would resolve business disputes behind closed doors.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — SHOULD wealthy litigants be able to rent state judges and courthouses to decide cases in private and keep the results secret?

headline: President of Sri Lanka Spurns an Inquiry
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: President Mahinda Rajapaksa on Friday rejected calls for an international investigation into accusations of massacres and human rights violations during the final phase of Sri Lanka’s civil war, which ended in 2009.
lead_paragraph: President Mahinda Rajapaksa on Friday rejected calls for an international investigation into accusations of massacres and human rights violations during the final phase of Sri Lanka’s civil war, which ended in 2009. “If there is evidence, let them show us,” Mr. Rajapaksa said. “We will look into it.” Meeting with an association of foreign journalists in Sri Lanka for the first time in three years, Mr. Rajapaksa said that recent resolutions criticizing Sri Lanka at the United Nations Human Rights Council could arise from a hidden agenda. On Thursday, the State Department released a report that was highly critical of the Rajapaksa government, claiming that in 2013 “attacks, harassment, and threats by pro-government loyalists against critics of the government were prevalent, contributed to widespread self-censorship by journalists, and diminished democratic activity.” On Friday, Mr. Rajapaksa likened the friction between the United States and Sri Lanka to “Cassius Clay fighting with a schoolboy,” a reference to the boxer now known as Muhammad Ali. But he said that the two countries were still friends.

headline: Preparing Teachers for the Common Core
abstract: A state oversight panel focuses on a crucial issue in the rollout of educational standards.
lead_paragraph: The panel convened by Gov. Andrew Cuomo to review New York’s troubled rollout of the Common Core learning standards will present its recommendations this spring. Among its most important tasks is to offer ways to remedy the most serious weakness in the state’s Common Core effort — the shortage of high-quality programs that are supposed to train teachers to carry out new Common Core-based curriculums.

headline: The N.F.L. Begins to Wake Up
abstract: There is no reason professional football players should be immune from modern standards of workplace conduct.
lead_paragraph: Last year’s National Football League season was tainted by on-field racial slurs and the bullying of a Miami Dolphins player. Of course, professional football players operate in an emotional, intensely competitive and physically punishing environment. It is obviously not your normal workplace. But, as employees, there is no reason they should be immune from modern standards of workplace conduct.

headline: A Bastion for Israel, Seething Inside
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A dispute over Israel at The New Republic has spilled out of the newsroom and into the public realm, leading to questions over the magazine’s new editorial stance.
lead_paragraph: When John Judis, a longtime senior editor at The New Republic, published a book examining the role of the pro-Zionist lobby in persuading President Harry S. Truman to support the founding of the Jewish state in 1948, he expected strong criticism, and he has certainly gotten it.

headline: De Blasio Picks More Liberal Activists Than Managers for City Posts
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s appointees are like-minded advocates rather than the button-down businessmen favored by former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: In Bill de Blasio’s City Hall, it seems more and more, there is only a left wing.

headline: What Is Russia’s Aim in Ukraine?
abstract: Mr. Putin’s reported tactics in Crimea are sure to backfire.
lead_paragraph: Update March 1, 2014: The Russian Parliament  granted President Vladimir Putin authority to use military force in Ukraine as Russian security forces effectively seized control of the Crimean peninsula.

headline: A Bigger Role for Relatives in N.C.A.A. Transfers
abstract: Ryan Harrow of Georgia State and Trae Golden of Georgia Tech might end up being among the last players granted exceptions to an N.C.A.A. rule that prevents transfers from playing right away.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Mark Harrow supports the Georgia State men’s basketball team from a front-row seat at home games. Although a stroke a year and a half ago weakened his left side, his facial expressions are unrestrained.

headline: Fathers’ Sons and Brothers’ Keepers
keywords: ['Men and Boys', 'Parenting', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: We can and must break the cycles of pain for young men of color, building better boys and repairing broken men.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Douglass once noted, “It is easier to build strong children than to repair broken men.”

headline: Korean Scientist’s New Project: Rebuild After Cloning Disgrace
abstract: Nearly a decade after his downfall for faking research, the South Korean scientist Hwang Woo-suk has won patents for his work in an attempt to resume studying human stem cells.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — No one galvanized South Korea’s national pride as he did, and no scandal in recent years unsettled the country as much as his.

headline: Arizona Sort of Helps Out
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'ABORTION', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: As gay rights have made great strides lately, why have abortion rights lost ground?
lead_paragraph: It’s been quite a week in Arizona. First, the Legislature passed a bill that, in effect, gave businesses the right to discriminate against gay couples. The state’s actual business community was horrified. Everybody from Mitt Romney to Newt Gingrich was ticked off.

headline: Woods Makes Cut, but Barely
abstract: While Tiger Woods survived the 36-hole cut on the number after shooting a 69 on Friday, Rory McIlroy stayed in control at the Honda Classic.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Tiger Woods managed a few grins even as he tried to spin forward a Friday in which he moved backward. He had just missed a 10-foot birdie putt at No. 18, an agonizing yet fitting end to another round in the debate about the worthiness of Woods’s game.

headline: High Tech
abstract: Peer into the future Saturday with a puzzle courtesy of Ian Livengood and the J.A.S.A. Crossword Class.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE— This Saturday puzzle was a collaborative effort constructed by Ian Livengood and the crossword class at the J.A.S.A. (or Jewish Association Serving the Aging). Down below, Ian talks a bit about what the class does and what their creative process is like.

headline: Litigant Against Social Welfare Agency Will Be Its Leader
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York named Steven Banks, a high ranking attorney at the Legal Aid Society who has frequently sued the Human Resources Administration, as its commissioner.
lead_paragraph: For 30 years, Steven Banks has been among the most persistent, consistent and successful thorns in the side of New York City mayors.

headline: End of an Era? Clinton Media Strategy May Be Due for an Overhaul
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton outlasted many of her old combatants from the 1990s and as a senator faced a new wave of reporters unfamiliar with the earlier media battles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Soon after Hillary Rodham Clinton left the State Department, her longtime spokesman talked wistfully about their paradise lost.

headline: Slum Dwellers in Caracas Ask, What Protests?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: While the middle and upper classes have dug in against President Nicolás Maduro’s government, the poor have in large part stayed away.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — On the east side of this capital city, where the rich people tend to live, most children have stayed home from school for more than a week, protest bonfires burn in the streets at night, stores shut early and carnival celebrations have been canceled.

headline: Obama Vows Aggressive Campaign for Party’s Congressional Candidates
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: With an eye toward his legacy, the president tries to ensure he will have friends in Congress for the final years of his term.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama vowed on Friday to wage an aggressive political campaign this year on behalf of Democratic congressional candidates, telling members of the Democratic National Committee that he will work to make the election a choice between “opportunity for a few or opportunity for all.”

headline: Christie’s Plan: To Shift the Public’s Attention From Scandal
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Employees']
abstract: After weeks in the shadow of scandal, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is working to refocus the debate to pensions, not lane closings.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few days, Gov. Chris Christie has reignited a reliably popular battle, crusading against unaffordable perks for public workers and promising “extreme measures” if he does not get his way.

headline: Reynolds and Verducci to Fill McCarver’s Spot as Lead Baseball Analysts on Fox
abstract: Harold Reynolds has worked for ESPN and MLB Network. Tom Verducci has served as a senior writer at Sports Illustrated and a field reporter for TBS.
lead_paragraph: Fox Sports knew last season that it would have to replace Tim McCarver, its lead analyst for Major League Baseball since 1996, who turned 72 during last year’s postseason.

headline: Let the U.N. Unmask the Criminals of Sri Lanka’s War
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Sinhalese (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: As many as 40,000 civilians were killed in the final days of Sri Lanka’s civil war, but no one has been held accountable.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — IN early 2009, as many as 40,000 civilians were killed in the final days of Sri Lanka’s civil war, having been herded into an area about the size of Central Park and subjected to relentless shelling. No one has been held accountable for these crimes, and even now the government in Colombo remains intent on burying the past. Only an international commission of inquiry stands any chance of rectifying this omission. So when the United Nations Human Rights Council meets Monday in Geneva, it should seek an investigation. It would be a decisive step toward justice and reconciliation in Sri Lanka.

headline: General’s Bid for Dismissal of Sex Case Is Countered
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Army officials said that despite concerns about the credibility of the main accuser, they did not doubt her central claim of forced oral sex.
lead_paragraph: In new court papers, Army officials have acknowledged that the lead prosecutor in the court-martial of a brigadier general accused of sexual misconduct believed that the most serious charges would be “very difficult to prove at trial” because of questions about the credibility of the main accuser, a junior officer. But the officials said they did not doubt the woman’s central claim that the general forced her to perform oral sex on him while they were serving in Afghanistan.

headline: 2 Ukrainian Mayors Play Different Hands in Crisis
abstract: The mayors of an eastern and a western city face uneasy constituents, one group pulling toward Russia and the other oriented to the West.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The silver-haired mayor of this raw mining city in eastern Ukraine had just delivered a pep talk to about 100 uniformed police officers, beseeching them to ensure law and order in these turbulent times of revolution, when a bearded man in dark glasses took the microphone.

headline: New York Will Consider Nonlethal Ways to Reduce Swan Population
abstract: After a backlash over a plan to euthanize the state’s population of the invasive birds, the agency will revise its approach.
lead_paragraph: Score one for swan fans.

headline: Sartorial Pluck Has No Place in Washington, the City of Fancy Fridays
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Suits (Apparel)', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: For a town of grand monuments and boulevards, a wardrobe that fails to reflect the gravitas of buildings where treaties were signed and wars were ended is not tolerated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Jared Polis, Democrat of Colorado, wore a purple polo shirt with a silver clip-on bow tie this week when he spoke about a cellphone bill on the floor of the House. His ensemble, which quickly lit up Twitter, so offended the sensibilities of GQ magazine that it offered the congressman a makeover, which Mr. Polis promptly embraced.

headline: Tussling Over Ukraine; Gains and Grave Setbacks for Gay Rights
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The promise and perils of change were evident in the bitter global struggle over equal right for same sex couples.
lead_paragraph: The romance and risk of political upheaval has been a recurring theme of the post-Communist world, as another mass uprising on Kiev’s smoldering Maidan left Ukraine, at least for now, fragmented, threatened and flat broke.

headline: Ukrainian Ex-President Speaks Out From Russia
abstract: Viktor F. Yanukovych, Ukraine’s former leader, called on President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to act, but vowed to oppose military intervention by Russia or anyone else.
lead_paragraph: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — Ukraine’s humiliated fugitive president appeared at a shopping center here on Friday to declare himself the country’s lawful leader, calling on President Vladimir V. Putin to act but vowing to oppose military intervention by Russia or anyone else. He spoke hours after mysterious Russian-speaking gunmen took up positions around two airports in Crimea, prompting Ukraine’s new leaders to announce that an intervention had already begun.

headline: Related Press Release
abstract: A Georgia man who fatally shot an Alzheimer’s patient he feared was breaking into his house will not be charged with a crime, a prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia man who fatally shot an Alzheimer’s patient he feared was breaking into his house will not be charged with a crime, a prosecutor said.

headline: Discovery Leads Yale to Revise a Chapter of Its Black History
abstract: Edward Bouchet has long been recognized as the school’s first African-American graduate, but newly uncovered records suggest another man earned that distinction nearly 20 years earlier.
lead_paragraph: On the campus of Yale University, Edward Bouchet has long been a venerated name. Hailed as the first African-American to graduate from Yale College, in 1874, he went on to be the first African-American to earn a Ph.D. (and only the sixth person nationwide to earn one in physics).

headline: Warriors Soar, Knicks Lag, and Boos Rain Down
abstract: Stephen Curry and the Golden State Warriors raced out to a big early lead over the Knicks, who were too slow, overmatched and confused to come back.
lead_paragraph: With 8 minutes 26 seconds remaining in the first quarter of Friday’s game against the Golden State Warriors, Knicks Coach Mike Woodson called his first timeout. The Knicks already trailed, 13-6, but it was still early, and there was still a game plan. The tone — for either team — could still be determined.

headline: In Rockaways, Infusion of Sand Will Soon Raise Beaches Hit by a Hurricane
abstract: This month, a contractor will start to dredge and spread 2.9 million cubic yards of sand on a six-mile strand in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Finally, the sand is coming back. This month, a contractor will start to dredge and spread 2.9 million cubic yards of sand on the Hurricane Sandy-depleted beaches of the Rockaways, in Queens, significantly expanding and raising six miles of beach. That’s a lot of sand castles or, put another way, enough sand to fill more than two Empire State Buildings.

headline: After Arrest, Pastor Linked to de Blasio Is Under Scrutiny for Tangled Finances
abstract: Bishop Orlando Findlayter, whose arrest prompted a call from Mayor Bill de Blasio to the police, is at the center of a controversy that has raised questions about the pastor and the mayor’s judgment.
lead_paragraph: Within the Caribbean-American community in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, Bishop Orlando Findlayter is widely respected for his involvement in social justice issues and beloved by his congregation for his warmth. As the chairman of a group of politically engaged Caribbean clergymen, he can provide a coveted entree to a network of local leaders.

headline: Alabama: No Prison for Resentenced Rapist
abstract: The State Court of Criminal Appeals on Thursday upheld a judge’s ruling that a man convicted of raping a teenage neighbor should not serve prison time.
lead_paragraph: The State Court of Criminal Appeals on Thursday upheld a judge’s ruling that a man convicted of raping a teenage neighbor should not serve prison time. The man, Austin Clem, was sentenced in December to probation by a judge in Limestone County after the appellate court ruled that his original punishment, which included a stint in a corrections program, was unlawful. Under both sentences, Mr. Clem faced decades in prison if he violated his terms of release. Although the district attorney also sought to have Mr. Clem’s second sentence overturned, the appeals court ruled that the judge acted appropriately.

headline: Politics at the Oscars
abstract: From Michelle Obama to Michael Moore to Marlon Brando (or not Marlon Brando), the Oscars have a long political history.
lead_paragraph: Last year, First Lady Michelle Obama announced the Oscar winner for best picture live from the White House.

headline: Effort to Delay Terror Trial of a Bin Laden Relative Fails
abstract: The terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith will not be delayed despite a claim by his lawyers that authorities may have mixed him up with a detainee at Guantánamo Bay with a similar name.
lead_paragraph: The terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, will not be delayed despite a claim by his lawyers that the government might have mixed up their client with a man who has a similar name.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Feb. 28, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Bratton Not Following de Blasio’s Lead on Parade
abstract: William J. Bratton said he intended to march in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade despite the fact that Mayor Bill de Blasio will not participate because of its history of excluding gay organizations.
lead_paragraph: When William J. Bratton said this week that he intended to march in the St. Patrick’s Day Parade, the declaration came as a bit of a surprise.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Showtime) THE IMPOSSIBLE (2012) Naomi Watts received an Oscar nomination for her role as Maria, an Englishwoman living in Japan, who is spending Christmas 2004 with her husband (Ewan McGregor) and three sons at a luxurious beach resort in Thailand when the tsunami hits. Maria is washed inland with her oldest son (Tom Holland, above, with Ms. Watts), leaving her badly injured and unable to find the rest of her family. “Survivors are also witnesses, and ‘The Impossible’ shows us, through the eyes of one unbelievably lucky family, some terrible things, including mangled bodies and parents in despair,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this second feature from the Spanish director Juan Antonio Bayona, based on a real-life account, which uses digital imagery, sound design and editing techniques to recreate both the violence and desolation that resulted from the natural disaster. “But there is a troubling complacency and a lack of compassion in ‘The Impossible,’ which is less an examination of mass destruction than the tale of a spoiled holiday. You could also say that it is a movie about the consequences of global inequality, but unfortunately only by accident.”

headline: Huber Matos, Comrade of Castro, Then Adversary, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Matos, a commander in Mr. Castro’s army, broke from the Cuban revolution in 1959 over its tilt toward Communism and was imprisoned for 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Huber Matos, a top commander in Fidel Castro’s army who broke from the Cuban revolution in 1959 over its tilt toward Communism, endured a harsh imprisonment for 20 years and became a leader of anti-Castro exiles in Florida, died in Miami on Thursday. He was 95.

headline: Valery Kubasov, 79, Russian Who Helped Bring Cold War Thaw to Space, Is Dead
abstract: Mr. Kubasov was a cosmonaut when a Soyuz spaceship linked with an Apollo capsule in 1975, some 140 miles above the earth.
lead_paragraph: Valery N. Kubasov, who pioneered international cooperation in space when he joined with a fellow cosmonaut in the linkup of Soviet and American spaceships in July 1975 amid the tensions of the Cold War, died on Feb. 19 in Moscow. He was 79.

lead_paragraph: Phyllis Krasilovsky, an author of popular children’s books, died on Wednesday in Redding, Conn. She was 87.

headline: South Korea Assails Japan on Wartime Brothels
abstract: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea urged Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan to acknowledge Japan’s 20th-century aggressions.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Unleashing fresh criticism of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, President Park Geun-hye of South Korea on Saturday urged him to be honest and courageous enough to face his country’s history of aggression in the early 20th century, especially its enslavement of Asian women in Imperial Army brothels.

headline: Ukraine Mobilizes Reserve Troops, Threatening War
abstract: Russia’s move to seize control of Ukraine’s Crimean Peninsula on Saturday led Ukraine to call up its military reserves on Sunday and warn Moscow against further incursions.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Russia’s move to seize control of Ukraine’s Crimean Peninsula on Saturday led Ukraine to call up its military reserves on Sunday and warn Moscow against further incursions as Western powers scrambled to find a response to the crisis.

headline: Document | Venus in Furs
abstract: Chest hair, that 1970s signifier of strength and virility, isn’t the sex symbol that it once was.
lead_paragraph: Chest hair, that 1970s signifier of strength and virility, isn’t the sex symbol that it once was — especially in this youth-obsessed era, when even alpha males are as waxed as a figurine. Ingrid Berthon-Moine plumbs deeper into the matter with “V,” her photo series of hirsute men. The images are cropped so tightly that they resemble female pubic hair. “By using humor, you make a connection,” says the 36-year-old French artist, who has explored — and upended — other beauty and gender tropes, including the masochistic nature of pedicures (in one of her short films she took a cheese grater to her heels) and the male ideal (satirized in a photography project that centered on the anatomy of Greek classical statues). Berthon-Moine knows her work isn’t for everyone. “You have to accept that people will like it or hate it and that is fine,” she says. “Art will not change the world but it can shift the way we look at it.”

headline: Some Tech Interns Make More Than U.S. Workers
abstract: Some interns at tech companies can make more than the median household income in the United States, according to a recent report by the career website Glassdoor.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a quiz for you: Who makes more money, a median American household or an intern at Facebook? If you guessed the latter, the tech company, you’re right.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Space Is the Place
abstract: Just in time for “Gravity”‘s big Oscar moment, a thread of retro-futurism is running through the fall/winter women’s collections.
lead_paragraph: Will “Gravity” get the Oscar for best picture? We’ll have to wait till Sunday to find out — but the fashion world seems to have deemed it a winner, if the astronaut-inspired clothing hitting the runway this season is any evidence. This microtrend hit the catwalk like a rocket at one of the first runway shows in New York: Organic by John Patrick. The designer riffed on the NASA suit with quilted metallic Ts, silver pants and mod boots reminiscent of ’60s space age fashion. Flash forward to Paris, where the designer Gareth Pugh presented a collection of cloudlike white dresses and mirrored silver trousers and tops that sculpted the body like futuristic armor. Finally, at Rick Owens, where the clothing always looks as if it is from the future, the designer showed white quilted motocross pants and high-necked zip-front jackets that winked at Hollywood’s interpretation of space-ship uniforms.

headline: From 1939, Somerset Maugham’s List of Must-Reads
abstract: Good reads, from 1939.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-five years ago, the Paris edition published a list of books recommended by W. Somerset Maugham, the British novelist, to “help you live more fully.” Here is the top 10:

Buffett is whether Berkshire Hathaway, the vast business empire he has built over five decades, can continue to make the sort of large acquisitions that will help it grow at a pace that will sustain his reputation as the nation’s shrewdest investor.

headline: There’s a Place for Us, Just Not the Kitchen
abstract: “What about that thing where you pick them up and they wrap their legs around you and you walk around the apartment doing it?” I asked.
lead_paragraph: I was in bed with my new boyfriend, discussing the bloodshed in Ukraine, Gov. Chris Christie and the quixotic pneumatics of middle-age lust, when the talk turned to movie sex. I think this was because the Academy Awards are coming and we were thinking of having a few people over.

headline: Where Sounds Have No Barrier
abstract: In today’s open work spaces, even small noises can prove distracting and annoying.
lead_paragraph: Open-plan offices are good for several things: saving money, flexibility, collaboration. But they are also hard on our ears — not because they are loud but because they are so very quiet.

headline: Give Fees an Inch, and They’ll Take a Mile
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Mutual Funds', 'Personal Finances', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans']
abstract: In a bulletin for investors, the Securities and Exchange Commission is offering a stark reminder of the impact that investment fees can have on returns.
lead_paragraph: Watch out for investment expenses. They will cut down your return, shrink your nest egg and may well prevent you from achieving your financial goals.

headline: In Search of a Stable Electronic Currency
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Virtual Currency', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Bitcoin has fluctuated wildly in value, but it could indirectly point the way toward a system of better pricing and risk management.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin, an experiment with a radically new kind of electronic money, has exhibited many of the characteristics of a speculative bubble. That was clear long before the collapse of the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox last week.

headline: Rose-Colored Words, but Gray Outcomes
abstract: A new study highlights the correlation between optimism and poor results, this time in the economy and the stock market.
lead_paragraph: When all the words you hear about the economy are bullish, you may want to run in the other direction. This counterintuitive finding — that positive visions of the future precede downturns — appears to be the case both for people and the economy as a whole.

headline: The Third Replacement Phone Wasn’t a Charm
abstract: A smartphone buyer reports an assortment of problems under his pay-as-you-go plan, and asks the Haggler for help in getting a service-charge refund.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: Silicon Oligopsony
abstract: Conversations that end in a conspiracy against the public.
lead_paragraph: This story about top tech firms agreeing not to compete for workers is really amazing. We’re accustomed to the notion that technology firms that win the race to dominate some segment become temporary monopolists; indeed, that temporary monopoly is the reward for successful innovation (although sometimes it ends up being a reward for just establishing an early market lock, rather than being either first or best with the technology.) What isn’t often mentioned is that the top few tech firms dominate certain specialized labor markets, too; this gives them an incentive to collude to hold down wages, and collude they do or at any rate did.

headline: The Rolling Robot Will Connect You Now
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Elderly', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing']
abstract: Telepresence machines may soon become inexpensive enough for more everyday use, as a conduit for virtual visits among family and friends.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the introduction of remote-controlled robots on wheels brought a new dimension to Internet video chats, keeping the conversation going as people moved from room to room. But their costliness has made them a rarity in real life. Now that is changing, and the robots are becoming inexpensive enough that they may soon have many practical uses.

headline: Sheila Talton, on Helping Employees Up the Ladder
abstract: The chief executive of a consulting firm says managers shouldn’t hoard their best workers in their own departments, but should help them advance in their careers.
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Sheila Talton, chief executive of Gray Matter Analytics, a consulting firm for financial services and health care, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Break Up the Bank? It’s Not for You to Ask
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Boards of Directors', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase is trying to stop a shareholder’s proposal from going to a vote at its annual meeting.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is trying to put its troubles behind it. Having agreed to pay a $13 billion settlement to the government for its past mortgage-lending misdeeds, it wants to move on. At the big “Investor Day” meeting with shareholders last week, Jamie Dimon, its chief executive, and his top lieutenants extolled the bank’s strong and diversified position in its four main businesses. “I am so damn proud of this company,” Mr. Dimon exclaimed.

headline: American Austerity, Charted Yet Again
abstract: A disaster to remember.
lead_paragraph: OK, I don’t know why I haven’t done this before.

lead_paragraph: Few trophies, it would seem, are more seductive to tycoons than Claridge’s, the grande dame of luxury London hotels, which has a long history of tempting buyers and provoking gentlemen’s quarrels.

abstract: Increasingly, Silicon Valley companies are fusing their buildings with values of change, productivity and their perceived corporate smarts and quirkiness.
lead_paragraph: Increasingly, Silicon Valley companies are fusing their buildings with values of change, productivity and their perceived corporate smarts and quirkiness.

headline: March 1 Updates on Ukraine Crisis
abstract: The Lede is following events in Ukraine and Russia on Saturday, following a unanimous vote in the upper house of the Russian Parliament approving a request from President Vladimir Putin to send a military force to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Lede is following events in Ukraine and Russia on Saturday, following a unanimous vote in the upper house of the Russian Parliament approving a request from President Vladimir Putin to send a military force to Ukraine until, state media reports from Moscow, the “the socio-political situation in the country is stabilized.” Updates below mix breaking news with dispatches from Times correspondents and firsthand accounts of events on the ground posted on social networks by bloggers and journalists in Crimea and other parts of Ukraine.

headline: CBO Mix-And-Match
abstract: Of r, g, and debt.
lead_paragraph: Floyd Norris makes a really good point in criticizing the Congressional Budget Office; he argues that the office’s latest budget projections aren’t consistent. CBO has marked down its expectations for future growth, but it hasn’t marked down its expectations for future interest rates. And that leads to excessive fiscal pessimism.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: An enigmatic cryptic from Fraser Simpson.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Gather around, code breakers, and bust out your Enigma machines, because our variety puzzle this weekend is a cryptic crossword constructed by Fraser Simpson. Cryptics are usually much trickier than an ordinary puzzle, and this one is no exception.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: February 28, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses pension reform and Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Cities and states across the country are grappling with how to pay for pensions and retiree health care costs. In New Jersey, Chris Christie is proposing a $34.4 billion budget that includes more than $2 billion in pension payments, the largest outlay yet to shore up a retirement plan for public workers that the governor calls a “looming crisis.” This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar discuss why cities and states are facing pension crises and what they can do to solve the problem.

lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Kristy Kaurova (left) and after (right) makeup by Yadim and hair by Eugene Souleiman.

headline: Making Russia Pay? It’s Not So Simple
abstract: President Obama has warned Russia that “there will be costs” for a military intervention in Ukraine. But the U.S. has few options for imposing such costs, and recent history has shown that Russia has been willing to absorb any such fallout.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has warned Russia that “there will be costs” for a military intervention in Ukraine. But the United States has few palatable options for imposing such costs, and recent history has shown that when it considers its interests at stake, Russia has been willing to pay the price.

headline: The Journey to 700 for Jaromir Jagr
abstract: Only six players have scored 700 N.H.L. goals – Gordie Howe, Phil Esposito, Marcel Dionne, Wayne Gretzky, Mike Gartner and Brett Hull. A look at Jagr’s 699 goals by the teams he scored for and against.
lead_paragraph: Only six players have scored 700 N.H.L. goals – Gordie Howe, Phil Esposito, Marcel Dionne, Wayne Gretzky, Mike Gartner and Brett Hull. A look at Jagr’s 699 goals by the teams he scored for and against.

headline: Amid More Signs of Russian Force in Crimea, Delight Mixes With Dismay
abstract: Ethnic Russians in Crimea rejoiced, but the region’s other populations, Muslim Tatars and Ukrainians, mourned a return to an era thought to have ended with the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: BALAKLAVA, Ukraine — Reduced to a ghoulish tourist attraction by the collapse of the Soviet Union, the former pride of the Black Sea Fleet — a top-secret nuclear submarine base burrowed into a rocky hill and worthy of a James Bond villain — was closed on Saturday for “technical reasons,” announced a handwritten note taped to the ticket window.

headline: After Initial Triumph, Ukraine’s Leaders Face Battle for Credibility
abstract: Successful revolutions, as the interim government in Kiev has been learning, are a lot harder to maintain than it can seem in the bright dawn of first victories.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The United States and the European Union have embraced the revolution here as another flowering of democracy, a blow to authoritarianism and kleptocracy in the former Soviet space. But successful revolutions, as the interim government here has been learning, are a lot harder to maintain than it can seem in the bright dawn of first victories.

lead_paragraph: In addressing crises in Ukraine, Syria and elsewhere, President Obama seems to be drawing on the memory of old-time superpower struggles, says Sam Tanenhaus.

lead_paragraph: SUDDENLY the specter of the Cold War is back. Prompted by the political crisis in Ukraine, some conservatives have called for President Obama to stand up to Vladimir V. Putin in the grand tradition of previous American presidents who stared eyeball to eyeball with Soviet leaders from Joseph Stalin to Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: The Downside of Inciting Envy
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Jealousy', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Happiness', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Fomenting bitterness over income differences may be powerful politics, but it injures our nation.
lead_paragraph: THE Irish singer Bono once described a difference between America and his native land. “In the United States,” he explained, “you look at the guy that lives in the mansion on the hill, and you think, you know, one day, if I work really hard, I could live in that mansion. In Ireland, people look up at the guy in the mansion on the hill and go, one day, I’m going to get that bastard.”

headline: Regulating Electronic Cigarettes
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: European lawmakers have adopted strong and balanced rules for nicotine-delivery devices.
lead_paragraph: European lawmakers last week adopted strong tobacco regulations that will increase government oversight of electronic cigarettes. The rules should serve as a model for the Food and Drug Administration, which has said that it also intends to regulate the nicotine-delivery devices.

headline: Brace Yourself for Hillary and Jeb
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: America has 320 million people, so how do we keep ending up with the same two surnames running things?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — OY. By the time the Bushes and Clintons are finished, they are going to make the Tudors and the Plantagenets look like pikers.

headline: Antonin Baudry
abstract: On the similarities between Bach and Metallica, and the lessons of Descartes.
lead_paragraph: Antonin Baudry is the French government’s cultural counselor in the United States. His graphic novel, based on his experiences working for the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is the basis for the farcical film “Quai d’Orsay,” which will open March 21 in the United States, retitled “The French Minister.”

headline: The Terms of Our Surrender
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: What comes after the inevitable ruling on same-sex marriage?
lead_paragraph: IT now seems certain that before too many years elapse, the Supreme Court will be forced to acknowledge the logic of its own jurisprudence on same-sex marriage and redefine marriage to include gay couples in all 50 states.

headline: Fear Mongering With Medicare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Cuts to federal subsidies for private Medicare Advantage plans are sensible and necessary.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s proposed cuts to Medicare Advantage plans — the private insurance plans that cover almost 30 percent of all Medicare beneficiaries — are fair and reasonable. As it happens, they are also mandated by law. Yet Republicans, sensing a campaign issue, are telling older and disabled Americans that the administration is “raiding Medicare Advantage to pay for Obamacare.” The health insurance industry, for its part, is warning that enrollees will suffer higher premiums, lower benefits and fewer choices among doctors if the cuts go into force.

headline: Is Success in Our DNA?
abstract: Readers discuss a writer’s claim that social status is strongly “determined by your lineage.”
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss a claim that social status is strongly “determined by your lineage.”

headline: Support Your Local Slaughterhouse
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Meat', 'Livestock Diseases', 'Slaughterhouses', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Local Food', 'Livestock', 'Cattle']
abstract: If we want to eat local eggs, dairy and meat, good slaughter facilities must be available to all farmers.
lead_paragraph: BOLINAS, Calif. — LATE on Saturday, Feb. 8, news broke of the recall of 8.7 million pounds of beef that had come through a Northern California slaughterhouse. Social media buzzed with tweets and posts pronouncing it the latest example of a dysfunctional industrialized food system incapable of producing safe meat. “Buy local!” “Know your farmer!” “Eat grass-fed beef!”

headline: Arizona Did Us All a Favor
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Corporations']
abstract: Recent legal movements are fraught with trouble for a country founded on the idea that church does not dictate to state.
lead_paragraph: YOU’RE a fundamentalist Mormon — that is, the breakaway sect, not recognized by the main church, with a scary compound in Northern Arizona. Women wear long prairie dresses, men rule with an iron fist. You believe in a host of things that violate civil and even criminal law. But your beliefs are “sincerely held.” They come directly from God.

headline: The Compassion Gap
abstract: Why didn’t readers of a column on the need for early-childhood interventions see a caring mom instead of her old tattoos?
lead_paragraph: SOME readers collectively hissed after I wrote a week ago about the need for early-childhood interventions to broaden opportunity in America. I focused on a 3-year-old boy in West Virginia named Johnny Weethee whose hearing impairment had gone undetected, leading him to suffer speech and development problems that may dog him for the rest of his life.

headline: The Dying Art of Legislating
abstract: Many distinguished lawmakers are walking away in disgust from a very unproductive Congress.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of the current House members were not yet alive when John Dingell first walked onto the floor in 1955. Though he became one of the era’s most consequential legislators over six decades, he endured his share of setbacks, including being ousted as chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee in 2008. But not until this year did he decide the atmosphere was so toxic, so “obnoxious,” that he could not continue serving.

headline: How Did Hungary’s Election Become a Circus?
abstract: In Hungary, the rules on political advertising have been changed quickly to benefit the ruling party.
lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — THE most visible poster on the streets here is not the one advertising the Deep Purple concert at the Papp Laszlo Sportarena. And it’s not the one for “Balkan Kobra,” a theatrical comedy featuring a stubbly hero sporting tight jeans and a Kalashnikov. And it’s definitely not the one for the Budapest Dance Festival.

headline: Sum izzamples of whuddah Filelfian seawns luyk
abstract: (Some examples of what a Philadelphian sounds like.)
lead_paragraph: (Some examples of what a Philadelphian sounds like.)

headline: The Sound of Philadelphia Fades Out
abstract: The Broad Street brogue — soda is sewda, house is hay-ouse — is sadly absent in the movies.
lead_paragraph: THE Philadelphia regional accent remains arguably the most distinctive, and least imitable, accent in North America. Let’s not argue about this. Ask anyone to do a Lawn Guyland accent or a charming Southern drawl and that person will approximate it. Same goes for a Texas twang or New Orleans yat, a Valley Girl totally omigod. Philly-South Jersey patois is a bit harder: No vowel escapes diphthongery, no hard consonant is safe from a mid-palate dent. Extra syllables pile up so as to avoid inconvenient tongue contact or mouth closure. If you forget to listen closely, the Philadelphia, or Filelfia, accent may sound like mumbled Mandarin without the tonal shifts.

headline: Soviet-Era Sex Ed
abstract: My daughter is getting much more detailed information in a school course.
lead_paragraph: A FEW months ago my 15-year-old raised her eyes from her homework and asked me if I knew what smegma was. I had no idea. She explained the term and then invited me to identify the Cowper’s glands on a diagram of the male genitalia. I pointed at something that looked glandish to me. “No, Mom!” she said with a patronizing smile, “that’s a seminal vesicle.”

headline: From the Pyramid to the Square
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: An Oscar-nominated documentary about the revolution in Egypt has resonated with protesters from Cairo to Caracas to Kiev.
lead_paragraph: THE Egyptian strongman Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi was recently in Moscow visiting with Russian strongman Vladimir Putin. Putin reportedly offered Sisi $2 billion in arms — just what a country like Egypt, where half the women can’t read, needs. The whole meeting struck me as so 1960s, so Nasser meets Khrushchev — two strongmen bucking each other up in the age of strong people and superempowered individuals. Rather than discuss arms sales, Sisi and Putin should have watched a movie together.

headline: College, the Great Unleveler
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Income Inequality', 'Student Loans', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Is higher education actually making inequality worse?
lead_paragraph: When the G.I. Bill of Rights of 1944 made colleges accessible to veterans regardless of socioeconomic background, Robert Maynard Hutchins, the president of the University of Chicago, worried that it would transform elite institutions into “educational hobo jungles.” But the G.I. Bill was only the first of several federal student aid laws that, along with increasing state investment in public universities and colleges, transformed American higher education over the course of three decades from a bastion of privilege into a path toward the American dream.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Haider Ackermann Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: George Karl Sees a Talent Adrift as Carmelo Anthony’s Knicks Fade
abstract: Karl, Anthony’s former coach in Denver, believes the Knicks’ star is missing “mental toughness” around him.
lead_paragraph: Let’s assume, for the moment, that Carmelo Anthony will decide to re-sign with the Knicks after what has so far been a dreadful season. That the extra money along with ownership guarantees of a roster upgrade will be enough to quell whatever wanderlust Anthony may have.

headline: By One Measure, 76ers May End Up History’s Worst
abstract: The 76ers were an awful team even before the roster was gutted at the trade deadline in the hope of building for the future.
lead_paragraph: The good news for the Philadelphia 76ers is that the team has no chance of finishing with the worst record in team history. The bad news is that the current team may be just as bad as — or worse than — the 1972-73 team, which produced the lowest winning percentage for an 82-game season in league history, .110.

headline: Red Wings Looking to Sell at Deadline? Don’t Buy It
abstract: With Detroit seeking its 23rd straight postseason berth, General Manager Ken Holland dismissed speculation that his injury-plagued team would deal pending free agents.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Red Wings have been the N.H.L.’s gold standard for a long time: 22 straight seasons in the playoffs, the longest current streak in the major North American sports, during which they have won four Stanley Cups. Six times in that stretch, they have won the Presidents’ Trophy for the league’s best record.

headline: The Cuban Evolution
abstract: As Raúl Castro introduces a dash of private enterprise, a new have/have-not dynamic is rising through the cracks of Communism.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — MAYBE it was the Robin Thicke music video playing on a half-dozen flat-screen TVs, or the black-and-white image of the Brooklyn Bridge splashed above the V.I.P. area, or perhaps it was just the nightclub’s name: Sangri-LA. All I knew, as I sipped my $4 rum, was that this was not the Cuba of Fidel Castro’s 1959 revolution.

headline: An Island Nation Starts to Catch Up
keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Cuba is slowly expanding its private enterprise.
lead_paragraph: Cuba is slowly expanding its private enterprise.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Viktor & Rolf Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: In 20th Season, Hawkins Targets 1,000th Game
abstract: LaTroy Hawkins is the major leagues’ longest-tenured player, having joined in 1995. He has a chance to become the 16th player to pitch in 1,000 games.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The young pitcher looked up from his iPad, jolted by the conversation at the next locker in the Colorado Rockies’ clubhouse. LaTroy Hawkins was talking about his performance at Yankee Stadium on May 17, 1998, when he threw seven decent innings while his opponent, David Wells, pitched a perfect game.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Perfectly Messy Hair at Viktor & Rolf
abstract: Models were made to look romantically disheveled for today’s whimsical show.
lead_paragraph: Models were made to look romantically disheveled for today’s whimsical show.

headline: From One Louisville Neighborhood, Big Leaguers on the Field and in Film
abstract: Shawn Kelley, a pitcher in the Yankees’ bullpen, was childhood friends with the actress Jennifer Lawrence, who is nominated for best supporting actress for her role in “American Hustle.”
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — They ran up and down the residential streets of Indian Hills in metropolitan Louisville, Ky., playing basketball, football and baseball by day and flashlight tag at night. It was a group of friends like so many millions across the nation, just regular youngsters playing regular games.

headline: Responding To Readers, About Blaming Poverty on the Poor
abstract: Debating readers about who’s to blame for poverty.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is an outgrowth of one a week earlier from West Virginia. As the latest column notes, the earlier one triggered a number of responses from people who focused their wrath on a young mom because of her tattoos and weight. Normally, when I write about poverty I look at wonkish evidence-based solutions, but this time I step back and argue that fundamentally what we need is not so much technical solutions as greater compassion and less name-calling.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Pitches 2 Scoreless Innings in Debut for Yankees
abstract: Tanaka, the 25-year-old right-handed starting pitcher from Japan, allowed two singles and struck out three in Saturday’s exhibition game against the Phillies.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When Masahiro Tanaka took the mound at the Rakuten Golden Eagles’ stadium with a complete game on the line in the ninth inning, the public address system blared a song called “Ato Hitotsu” by the Funky Monkey Babys to inspire him.

headline: Attackers With Knives Kill 29 at Chinese Rail Station
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Railroads', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: A group of assailants, dressed in black and wielding knives, stormed into a train station in Kunming in southwestern China, slashing employees and commuters.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A group of assailants wielding knives stormed into a railway station in southwestern China on Saturday, slashing employees and commuters and leaving at least 29 people dead and 130 wounded, according to Xinhua, the official Chinese news agency. The local government indicated that the attackers were Uighur separatists seeking an independent homeland in the Xinjiang region in China’s far west.

headline: Heavy Rains in Los Angeles
abstract: More rain fell in Los Angeles over the course of 12 hours on Friday than had fallen over the last eight months, according to the National Weather Service.
lead_paragraph: More rain fell in Los Angeles over the course of 12 hours on Friday than had fallen over the last eight months, according to the National Weather Service.

headline: The Monuments of Tech
abstract: The workplaces of Facebook, Twitter and Google may look whimsical. But each design is calculated to mirror its company’s values and culture.
lead_paragraph: Big Internet companies love to talk about how they are “disrupting” one thing or another, but they still want what big companies have always wanted: workplaces that memorialize their products and values.

headline: Yearning for the Fields of Summer
abstract: A softball player on Long Island sees the game and its characters as a reaffirmation of community.
lead_paragraph: Something strange appeared in front of my house recently: a little patch of grass and dirt, peeking out from the icy crust that has enveloped Long Island for most of the past two months. A sign of life. On the news, I caught glimpses of David Wright making those loose, easy first throws of training camp. George Harrison’s voice filled my head.

abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

lead_paragraph: The number of missionaries increased in 2013 after the church lowered the minimum age for new missionaries, to 19 from 21 for women and to 18 from 19 for men.

keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)']
abstract: As unmarried Mormon women in Utah get older, they outnumber unmarried Mormon men by wide margins.
lead_paragraph: As unmarried Mormon women in Utah get older, they outnumber unmarried Mormon men by wide margins.

headline: Missions Signal a Growing Role for Mormon Women
keywords: ['Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)', 'Missionaries', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A sharp rise in the number of female missionaries points to a fundamental shift for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
lead_paragraph: DAEJEON, South Korea — Ashley Farr, once Miss North Salt Lake Teen USA, is the first in her family’s long line of Mormon women to become a missionary, and in December she embarked on her new life in this gray corner of Asia. She packed her bag according to the church’s precise instructions: skirts that cover the knee, only one pair of pants, earrings that dangle no longer than one inch, and subtle but flattering makeup, modeled in  photos on the church’s website.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Rangers Rally From Two Down, Then Go Cold
abstract: The Rangers fought back to tie the game Saturday, but the Flyers struck back quickly to cement the 4-2 victory.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Rangers had goalie Henrik Lundqvist back in the net and defenseman Dan Girardi signed and off the trading block, just the formula for a successful Saturday afternoon in Philadelphia. But instead the Rangers stumbled, 4-2, against the Flyers, and found their hold on second place in the Metropolitan Division reduced to a single point.

headline: Jaromir Jagr Gets 700th Goal, and Devils Rout the Islanders
abstract: Jagr, 42, scored in the second period to become the seventh N.H.L. player with 700 goals, and the third to hit the mark at Nassau Coliseum.
lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — Jaromir Jagr was an opposing star for the Pittsburgh Penguins when Wayne Gretzky played his last game, for the Rangers in 1999. Jagr, a 42-year-old Czech, and Gretzky, the N.H.L.’s career scoring leader, now share another milestone: career goal No. 700 at Nassau Coliseum against the Islanders.

headline: British Weather and Nominees at a California Party
abstract: Some Los Angeles bashes have been canceled amid the rain, but not the one celebrating filmmakers from the United Kingdom, like Steve McQueen.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – It’s been raining here. Have you heard?

headline: Ukraine Finds Its Forces Are Ill Equipped to Take Crimea Back From Russia
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: In the autonomous region of Crimea, the Ukrainian military has only a token force with light weapons, and it lacks the country’s advanced battle tanks, a Russian military expert said.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The new government of Ukraine called an emergency session of its national security council on Saturday in the face of the Russian military’s seizure of Crimea, but the leaders are facing a grim reality: Their armed forces are ill equipped to try to reconquer the region militarily.

headline: Helen Mirren Takes on the Gender Gap
abstract: The actress, a host of a Women in Film pre-Oscar party, said much has changed since first worked on most male film sets. But she’s looking forward to more change.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD – “Shut up,” said Helen Mirren, “’cause Mama’s in the house.”

headline: At Rick Owens, Not Your Usual Models
abstract: Mr. Owens cast the women close to him, those who work with him in the atelier, the sales showroom, the office.
lead_paragraph: Rick Owens sees his runways as more of a blank canvas than many of his contemporaries do. He’s a showman, and there’s not a part of the show he won’t rethink if it suits his purpose. His are the rare fashion events at which you truly don’t know what to expect.

headline: At Acne, It’s Hip to be Square
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Heels worthy of the Swedish brand’s young, street-chic clientele.

Not only that, but spaces are still available for the annual Cru dinner. Click on the links for more details.

headline: Rise in Bigotry Fuels Massacre Inside Myanmar
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Discrimination', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Buddhism', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Violence against the Rohingya minority has presented a test for Myanmar’s leaders, who have done little to rein in the ethnic killings even as they pursue broad political and economic reforms.
lead_paragraph: DU CHEE YAR TAN, Myanmar — Under the pale moon of Jan. 13, Zaw Patha watched from her bamboo house as Mohmach, 15, her eldest child, was dragged from the kiosk where he slept as guardian of the family business.

headline: An Eye on Runoffs, Candidates Mind Tactics in Primaries
abstract: The high number of statewide races drawing multiple candidates this year is expected to lead to an unusually large second round after Tuesday’s voting.
lead_paragraph: In the highest-profile races of Tuesday’s primaries, a large number of candidates will be happy to come in second.
