keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Demographic changes may not yet be reflected in the electorate, but candidates want to court both young, more liberal residents and Hispanics once they become more political.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Pro-Hezbollah Song Opens Musical Front in Civil War Over Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Social Media', 'Music']
abstract: Where Sunni and Shiite singers once aimed their barbed lyrics at Israel, they now increasingly target each other.
lead_paragraph: NABATIYE, Lebanon — The insults and threats flow to the singer, Ali Barakat, around the clock. Men call from unknown phone numbers and say nasty things about his mother. Others send him photos of dead bodies and tell him to join them in the grave. Still others threaten to dispatch car bombs and suicide attackers.

headline: Lottery’s Own Personal Watchdog Intends to Remain on Guard
abstract: Since 1993, Dawn Nettles has produced The Lotto Report, which began as a biweekly publication on Texas lottery results.
lead_paragraph: Dawn Nettles chuckled when she talked recently about how her friends and family hated her passion for the Texas Lottery, which has consumed many of her waking hours for more than 20 years.

headline: Popular Tech Gathering Faces Growing Pains
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Some participants have strong opinions about the South by Southwest Interactive Conference and whether it is being true to its high-technology mission, but the people involved defend it — mostly.
lead_paragraph: The 21st annual South by Southwest Interactive Conference, which starts Friday in Austin, is on track to be the most popular edition yet of the technology-oriented festival. More than 30,000 people are expected to descend upon Austin for five days of panels, parties and trade demonstrations. Attendance has nearly tripled since 2009.

headline: ‘Act of Killing’ Film Fails to Stir Indonesia
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Communism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: The film recounts in graphic detail the killings of an estimated 500,000 or more Indonesians during state-sponsored purges of suspected Communists and their sympathizers in 1965 and 1966.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — The American director of the chilling Indonesian documentary “The Act of Killing” has won dozens of awards so far for the film and could add one of the movie industry’s most coveted honors Sunday at the Oscars.

headline: Senator Expresses Concerns About Nuclear-Waste Tanks
abstract: Ron Wyden of Oregon contends that even the newest and sturdiest of tanks at a Washington State site show some of the same construction problems as one that began leaking in late 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most of the youngest and sturdiest of the giant tanks that the Energy Department uses to store high-level radioactive waste at its Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington State show some of the same construction problems as a tank that began leaking in late 2012, according to documents released by Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, whose state is across the Columbia River from the site.

headline: Pakistani Taliban, Announcing Cease-Fire, Urge the Revival of Peace Talks
abstract: The announcement of the truce came just hours after two bombings killed 13 people and wounded 10 in an attack on a polio vaccination team in the northwestern Khyber region.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban announced a monthlong cease-fire on Saturday and urged the government to revive peace talks that broke down last month.

headline: Deal Would Allow Gays to March in Boston’s St. Patrick’s Day Parade
keywords: ['Homosexuality', "St Patrick's Day", 'Parades', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: An advocacy group balked at the terms of the deal, which would ban participants from wearing clothing identifying their sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — South Boston’s St. Patrick’s Day parade, the second-largest in the country after New York’s, could be on the verge of a historic breakthrough — the participation of a gay advocacy group that had been banned from the parade for two decades.

headline: Parnell Takes Positive Step in Return From Injury
abstract: Bobby Parnell faced hitters for the first time since his neck surgery in September. He said his neck felt fine afterward.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — For the first time since July, Bobby Parnell, the Mets’ closer, was on a mound Saturday facing batters. David Wright, Daniel Murphy and Eric Young Jr. rotated in, and, for 36 pitches, Parnell let loose. It was another step in his recovery from the neck surgery he had Sept. 10.

headline: Rubio Proposes Steps U.S. Should Take With Russia
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Russia’s use of its military in Ukraine has given Senator Marco Rubio of Florida an opening to emerge as a new foreign policy voice of the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For months, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a possible contender for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination, has struggled to raise his voice above more senior Republicans on foreign policy even as he has offered a third way between older military traditionalists and newly emerging isolationists.

headline: Troubles at Women’s Prison Test Alabama
abstract: The Tutwiler women’s prison is rife with sexual crimes, the federal government says, but the appetite for costly reform in tough-on-crime Alabama appears minimal.
lead_paragraph: WETUMPKA, Ala. — For a female inmate, there are few places worse than the Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women.

headline: Obama’s New Political Chief Tries to Reassure Democrats
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The ascension of David Simas is meant as a message that the White House is serious about defending the party’s control of the Senate and mitigating losses in the House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — David Simas left nothing to chance when he ran for the Taunton, Mass., school board at the age of 22. He packed the kickoff fund-raiser at the Portuguese-American Civic Club with his extended family, took his mother with him to knock on 5,000 doors and left a handwritten note if no one was home: “Sorry I missed you. David.”

headline: McIlroy Displays Composure in Place Where He Once Lost It
abstract: One year after walking out of the Honda Classic, Rory McIlroy used patience and poise to shoot a 69 and take a two-stroke lead into the final round.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — The putt was for bogey, a 10-footer that Rory McIlroy knew would carry significance. Miss it, and his lead and game might come apart Saturday at the Honda Classic.

headline: Afghan Broadcaster Says U.S. Soldiers Abused Him
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Radio', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A radio station has angered the Taliban by broadcasting pro-government ads, but that did not stop American Special Forces from raiding it.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Qazi Nasir Mudassir said he had expected that if armed men climbed over the walls of his radio station’s compound, they would probably be Taliban insurgents coming to make good on death threats because of his broadcasts.

headline: Lee Lorch, Desegregation Activist Who Led Stuyvesant Town Effort, Dies at 98
keywords: ['Stuyvesant Town (NYC)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Mr. Lorch’s leadership in the campaign to desegregate Stuyvesant Town, the gargantuan housing development in Manhattan, helped make housing discrimination illegal nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Lee Lorch, a soft-spoken mathematician whose leadership in the campaign to desegregate Stuyvesant Town, the gargantuan housing development on the East Side of Manhattan, helped make housing discrimination illegal nationwide, died on Friday at a hospital in Toronto. He was 98.

headline: Big-Money Donors Demand Larger Say in Campaign Strategy
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections']
abstract: In both parties, elite donors who once deferred to “super PAC” leaders to determine the best use of their money are now taking a central role in shaping campaigns.
lead_paragraph: The Republican donors who have financed the party’s vast outside-spending machine are turning against the consultants and political strategists they once lavished with hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Harvard Coach Ties Ivy League Record for Wins; UConn Remains Undefeated
abstract: Kathy Delaney-Smith improved her record to 514-347 over 32 seasons with the Crimson, tying Princeton’s Pete Carril for the most basketball victories by an Ivy League coach.
lead_paragraph: Kathy Delaney-Smith tied Pete Carril for the most basketball victories by an Ivy League coach as visiting Harvard defeated Columbia, 64-51, on Saturday night at Levien Gymnasium.

headline: Antigay Laws Gain Global Attention; Countering Them Remains Challenge
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States, the European Union and the United Nations have made their advocacy of gay rights clear, but officials question how much they can really do to effect change.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — After Uganda criminalized homosexuality, the White House immediately warned that the law would “complicate” the country’s relationship with Washington, and the Netherlands and Norway cut off bits of development aid.

headline: The 2014 Senate Landscape
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Dozens of states are holding Senate primaries this year. Here is a look at the key races in every state.

headline: Carlos Gracida, a Celebrated Member of a Family Dynasty in Polo, Dies at 53
abstract: Mr. Gracida was one of the most accomplished players in the history of polo and a member of a legendary Mexican family in the so-called sport of kings.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Gracida, one of the most accomplished players in the history of polo and a member of a legendary Mexican family in the so-called sport of kings, died on Tuesday after falling from his horse during a match at the Everglades Polo Club in Wellington, Fla. He was 53.

headline: U.N. to Assess Residents’ Risk in Southern Yemen City
abstract: United Nations aid officials are preparing a mission to study the plight of residents of Al Dhale caught in the crossfire between government troops and rebels.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Alarmed by reports of rising civilian casualties in the southern Yemen city Al Dhale, United Nations aid officials are preparing a mission this week to assess the plight of residents caught in the crossfire between government troops and rebels fighting for the south’s secession from the north.

headline: A Player’s Attacks Pay Off at a Tournament in Minsk
abstract: Baadur Jobava of the republic of Georgia won the International Open Tournament, an event held in honor of one of the greatest players of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: It was a fitting finish at the International Open Tournament in Minsk, Belarus, last month, with the title going to a competitor whose style is so similar to that of the legendary champion the event honored.

headline: Lewis Yablonsky, 89, Sociologist Who Learned From the Streets, Is Dead
abstract: A rough childhood in Newark informed his academic work, which combined analysis, experiential research and sometimes direct, unconventional efforts to solve social problems.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Yablonsky carried a switchblade before he became a sociologist.

headline: Home Prices in China May Hurt Families
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Chinese households have an overwhelming share of their assets in their homes, and any slump in prices could lead to widespread anger, findings say.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s banks may not be directly exposed to losses from the country’s soaring housing prices, but any slump in those prices could set off widespread public anger, data from a broad new survey of household finances indicates.

headline: Crimean Tatars Ponder the Return of Russian Rule
abstract: The Tatars, a Muslim ethnic group, were exiled by Stalin, but have lived in relative peace in Crimea since many returned in the early 1990s.
lead_paragraph: KHOSHKELDI, Ukraine — In a narrow convenience store here in Khoshkeldi, a village of about 1,000 ethnic Tatars just outside the Crimean capital, shoppers came in one after another on Saturday, heads drooping, asking the disconsolate clerk if she had heard the latest.

headline: Crimea, the Tinderbox
keywords: ['United States International Relations', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: The West and Russia have a common interest: forestalling civil war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Russian military intervention in Ukraine’s autonomous republic of Crimea has brought relations between the United States and Russia to their lowest level in a quarter century. It has transgressed the sovereignty of one of the most populous countries in Europe, violated the terms of a diplomatic agreement to respect Ukraine’s borders, and placed Russia on a war footing with one of the few states in the post-Soviet world that has managed to hold multiple free elections. It is a military operation that is unsanctioned by any international body, wholly open-ended, and blessed only by the Russian Parliament.

headline: Bernadette DiPrisco, John Kasnicki

Benvenisty of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi David-Seth Kirshner officiated at the Tribeca Grill restaurant in New York.

Glen Davis of Spring, Tex. The Rev. Dwight C. Davis, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Rice University Chapel in Houston.

Garcia and Ernesto Garcia, also of Tenafly. Rabbi Laurie Phillips officiated at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn.

headline: Bolstered by Their Depth, Nets Head Home on the Rise
abstract: The Nets’ reserves scored 54 points in a victory that capped a 4-2 trip and pulled the team within three and a half games of Toronto in the Atlantic Division.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Jason Collins is finally heading to his new home. He will be bringing along an ascending team that continues to play rock-solid basketball.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:30 P.M. (ABC) THE 86TH ANNUAL ACADEMY AWARDS Ellen DeGeneres makes her second appearance as the host of the ceremony, broadcast live from the Dolby Theater in Los Angeles. Oddsmakers are predicting that Matthew McConaughey will take home the Oscar for his portrayal of an H.I.V.-positive man in “Dallas Buyers Club,” and that his co-star Jared Leto will win for supporting actor. In the best actress category, Cate Blanchett is the frontrunner for her portrait of a wealthy socialite fallen from grace after her husband’s financial fraud, while Jennifer Lawrence, as a highly emotional wife in “American Hustle,” is the favorite for supporting actress. And Steve McQueen’s “12 Years a Slave” may squeak by in the best picture category, which is filled out by David O. Russell’s “American Hustle,” Paul Greengrass’s “Captain Phillips,” Jean-Marc Vallée’s “Dallas Buyers Club,” Alfonso Cuarón’s “Gravity,” Spike Jonze’s “Her,” Alexander Payne’s “Nebraska,” Stephen Frears’s “Philomena” and Martin Scorsese’s “Wolf of Wall Street.” Mr. Russell, Mr. Cuarón, Mr. Payne, Mr. McQueen and Mr. Scorsese are also nominated for best director. The countdown begins at 1:30 on E!; at 5 on the TV Guide Channel; and at 6 on Channel 11. Red-carpet coverage begins at 7 on ABC. Postshow coverage follows at 11:30 on E! Above, a worker decorates the front of the theater.

headline: Thousands in Hong Kong Support Wounded Editor
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Assaults']
abstract: Protesters called for respect for the rule of law and justice for a former newspaper editor who is in a hospital after a near-deadly assault.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thousands of Hong Kong residents marched peacefully on Sunday to voice their support for press freedom and to denounce violence after a near-deadly assault on a former newspaper editor who has become a symbol of the pressures squeezing the local news media.

headline: China Blames Xinjiang Separatists for Stabbing Rampage at Train Station
keywords: ['Railroads', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: At least 29 were killed and 143 wounded in a knife attack by a group in Kunming, the regional capital of Yunnan Province.
lead_paragraph: KUNMING, China — The group of about 10 attackers, dressed in black and wearing cloth masks, arrived in front of Kunming Railway Station in southwest China on Saturday night and began slashing at employees and commuters, sometimes repeatedly plunging their long knives and daggers into people too stunned or slow to flee.

lead_paragraph: The following is an interview Philip Roth gave to Daniel Sandstrom, the cultural editor at Svenska Dagbladet, for publication in Swedish translation in that newspaper and in its original English in the Book Review.

headline: How the ‘Trophy for Just Showing Up’ Is Earned
abstract: The participation trophy may be considered a sorry relic of the self-esteem movement. But to me, it represents a season of struggle.
lead_paragraph: My son’s eight soccer trophies are lined up above his bed. One is a fake-metal bobblehead, and one has a little soccer ball that spins. He received each one for merely being on the roster.

headline: At the Indie Spirits, Oscar Warm-Ups and Also-Ran Quips
abstract: Expected winners at the Academy Awards were among the honorees; so were contenders who weren’t likely to get any other prizes this season.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. – “12 Years a Slave” was the top winner at the Indie Spirits here on Saturday, earning best picture, best director, best adapted screenplay and best supporting actress prizes.

headline: Ukrainian Government Rushes to Dampen Secessionist Sentiment
abstract: With Russia in control of Crimea, worries mounted in Kiev that the mostly ethnic-Russian east could be next to fall.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Ukraine’s besieged interim government raced to head off violence that might set off a Russian invasion of its eastern provinces on Sunday, recruiting wealthy eastern businessmen to become provincial governors in an effort to dampen secessionist sentiment there.

headline: Growth and Interest Rates: I Appear To Be Wrong
abstract: When I get new information, I change my mind. What do you do?
lead_paragraph: In my last post I followed Floyd Norris in criticizing the CBO, which has marked down its estimates of future economic growth without marking down its estimates of future interest rates. I still think that’s a fair criticism. But I also offered a hypothesis: that interest rates fall more than one-for-one with slower growth, so that the crucial difference r-g — interest rate minus growth rate — actually falls, making debt easier, not harder, to handle.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: War Among The Economists
abstract: Salt on the roads, salt in my mind.
lead_paragraph: I have real doubts about whether this class — at 8:30 AM tomorrow — is going to happen. I guess I’ll be up at 6 shoveling out my driveway so I can get out if it does happen. Anyway, slides for the lecture (pdf) are posted.

lead_paragraph: Alain Resnais, the French filmmaker who helped introduce literary modernism to the movies and became an international art-house star with nonlinear narrative films like “Hiroshima Mon Amour” and “Last Year at Marienbad,” died on Saturday in Paris. He was 91.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the fourth time in a decade, Taliban insurgents have escaped from the heavily guarded Sarposa Prison in Kandahar, Afghan officials confirmed on Sunday.

But this weekend, music lovers in the New York area had rare opportunities to hear this historic player-run ensemble in its other official capacity: the pit band of the Vienna State Opera.

headline: Liam Neeson Tops Box Office Once Again With ‘Non-Stop’
abstract: “Non-Stop,” the latest action film starring Liam Neeson, finished in first place at the North American box office over the weekend, with an estimated $30 million.
lead_paragraph: “Non-Stop,” over the weekend leading into the Oscars, became the latest successful action movie starring Liam Neeson, taking in an estimated $30 million, for first place at the North American box office. Mr. Neeson, 61, improbably became one of Hollywood’s leading action stars with “Taken” in 2009 after a career largely spent in higher-brow movies like “Kinsey” and “Schindler’s List.”

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Western governments scrambled on Sunday to respond to the Russian military advance in Ukraine, Secretary of State John Kerry made plans to visit Kiev on Tuesday in a gesture of support for the new Ukrainian government, a senior American official said.

headline: Ukraine Turns to Its Oligarchs for Political Help
abstract: The interim government, worried about Russian efforts to destabilize or seize regions in eastern Ukraine, is recruiting the country’s wealthy businessmen to serve as regional governors.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As tensions rose on the streets of the Russian-speaking eastern portion of Ukraine, the response of the new government in the capital on Sunday was not to send troops, but to send rich people.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Feeling Blue at Kenzo
abstract: Cobalt eyeliner and nail polish complemented a David Lynch-designed set and soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Kenzo, Aaron de Mey pulled his references from the world of David Lynch, who orchestrated the label’s runway set design and soundtrack. “It’s inspired by the cinema, by Sherilyn Fenn, by ‘Blue Velvet,’” de May explained of the brilliant blue eye. “I’m giving it a ‘50s feel with an arched eyebrow, and using an Yves Klein blue gel liner.” That would be MAC Chromaline in Marine Ultra, boldly painted on in a thick stripe, with a lifted edge, using a small-angled MAC 263 brush. The eye area was otherwise untouched: lashes left uncurled, no mascara. For the rest of the face, de Mey applied pearlized cream highlighter on the cheekbones, Cupid’s bow and bridge of the nose; last, he misted the visage for a dewy finish. To match the eyes, the models’ nails were painted electric blue, using a velvet flocking-finish varnish that the manicurist had brought over from Japan.

headline: As One of Few Americans Left in England, Cameron’s Stock Is Rising
abstract: The versatile defender Geoff Cameron has become a vital cog for his club, Stoke City, and the United States national team.
lead_paragraph: Since the inception of Major League Soccer in 1996, the league has served as a place for top young American players to begin their careers before eventually moving overseas to the elite leagues of Europe. The past year has seen a sharp departure from this pattern: several top Americans have elected to either sign new deals to remain in M.L.S. while others, like Michael Bradley and Clint Dempsey, have returned stateside while still in their prime.

headline: Clashes Between Fans and Players Draw Greater Scrutiny
abstract: A melee involving New Mexico State players and Utah Valley fans was the most recent in a series of confrontations, prompting at least one conference to consider changes.
lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — When New Mexico State left the court Saturday night, nobody ran for his life. When the buzzer sounded on a comfortable 72-57 victory over California State-Bakersfield before several hundred fans in a 10,000-seat arena, the host Aggies shook hands with their opponents and walked single file toward their locker room to the applause of a few friends and family members.

lead_paragraph: The Times live-blogged the 86th Academy Awards, with interviews from the red carpet and backstage, video updates from David Carr and A. O. Scott, live commentary during the telecast, reviews of the night’s best and worst looks and star turns, social media features and more.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Knit One, Curl One
abstract: For all its monster themes, Rei Kawakubo’s new collection for Comme des Garçons seems approachable; the women strong, happy and, in some cases, surprisingly beautiful.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Like a Medusa’s head entwined with serpents, the body was covered from neck to thighs with fat twists of wool. The skeins were wrapped like sausages around the neck, shoulders and arms — maybe even the head. They finished at the point where pretty, patterned hose appeared, or where a pair of sparkly underpants peeped out.

headline: Rare Mutation Kills Off Gene Responsible for Diabetes
abstract: Pfizer and Amgen teamed to develop drugs to mimic the effect, though it may take a decade or more before it is available to the public.
lead_paragraph: A new study based on genetic testing of 150,000 people has found a rare mutation that protects even fat people from getting Type 2 diabetes. The effect is so pronounced — the mutation reduces risk by two-thirds — that it provides a promising new target for developing a drug to mimic the mutation’s effect.

headline: Hundreds Face Arrest at Anti-Pipeline Protest
abstract: Police arrested 372 opponents of the Keystone XL pipeline, most of them college students, who engaged in civil disobedience at the White House.
lead_paragraph: Updated, March 5, 11:26 a.m. | The United States Park Police on Sunday afternoon arrested hundreds of demonstrators participating in an act of civil disobedience in front of the White House to protest the proposed Keystone XL pipeline.

headline: It’s the Gas Gas Gas
abstract: Don’t get pumped up about inflation.
lead_paragraph: Mostly a note to myself: short-run fluctuations in the inflation rate are more or less entirely about gasoline prices, which affect headline and even, to some extent, core inflation via their impact on costs. The picture:

abstract: Golly gee, no obscenities.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while it seems necessary to put out a reminder of what you should and shouldn’t be doing if you comment on this blog, or indeed anywhere at the Times.

headline: Knicks Out of Answers as Fan Offers Suggestion
abstract: The Bulls raced out to a 21-point first-quarter lead, and the Knicks never got close as their sputtering playoff hopes were dealt another blow.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Carmelo Anthony was stuck in the present when he saw a sign Sunday afternoon that predicted his future: “Melo to Chicago.” It was held by a fan of the Bulls, a team that was in the process of joining a conga line of opponents that have humiliated the Knicks this season.

headline: Between the Liquid and Solid

lead_paragraph: There’s a new jazz group called the Spring Quartet, and that’s spring as in the season’s muddy, generative part, not the pale and pretty part.

headline: A Landmark Oscar Win for ‘12 Years a Slave’
abstract: Steve McQueen’s film won best picture, the first time Hollywood has so honored the work of a black director. “Gravity” won seven Oscars, including best director for Alfonso Cuarón.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a triumph long deferred, “12 Years a Slave” won the best picture Oscar at the 86th Academy Awards on Sunday night, the first time Hollywood conferred its top honor to the work of a black director.

headline: Echo, Echo
abstract: Listen for the echo in this Monday puzzle from Andrea Carla Michaels and Michael Blake.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Happy Monday, everyone. Who’s ready to get this week started?

headline: Cameras Shooting in Battle: Five Auteurs and Their World War II Films
abstract: In “Five Came Back,” Mark Harris, an Entertainment Weekly columnist, examines the wartime lives and work of John Huston, Frank Capra, John Ford, George Stevens and William Wyler.
lead_paragraph: Mark Harris, a columnist at Entertainment Weekly and the author of the marvelous “Pictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood,” from 2008, bets again on his lucky number for an excursion into a very different motion picture revolution. “Five Came Back,” modestly subtitled “A Story of Hollywood and the Second World War,” is a tough-minded, information-packed and irresistibly readable work of movie-minded cultural criticism. Like the best World War II films, it highlights marquee names in a familiar plot to explore some serious issues: the human cost of military service, the hypnotic power of cinema and the tension between artistic integrity and the exigencies of war. Mr. Harris shows how — more than Technicolor, CinemaScope or even the collapse of the Production Code — World War II changed the way Americans looked at the movies.

headline: Explorations With Moves and Words
abstract: Liz Casebolt and Joel Smith mixed their choreography with commentary at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: Liz Casebolt and Joel Smith, two amiable Los Angeles choreographers who have worked together since 2006, have a mission: to demystify the choreographic process and make dance accessible. They strive to appeal, as Mr. Smith explained to an audience on Friday, to “non-highfalutin dance communities.”

headline: Report Calls for Better Backstops to Protect Power Grid From Cyberattacks
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: The report, from leading security experts, also found that while the government has focused on the high-voltage power grid, less work has been done on the lower-voltage distribution system.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite rising anxiety over the possibility of a cyberattack on the power grid, the industry and government are not set up well to counter the threat, according to a report produced by leading energy security experts. Companies are reluctant to share information with one other, a critical step in reducing vulnerability, because they are afraid of being accused of failing to comply with cybersecurity rules, committing antitrust violations or giving away proprietary information, the report found.

headline: An Added Helping of Murder
abstract: “Those Who Kill,” a new police procedural with Chloë Sevigny and James D’Arcy, joins “Bates Hotel,” with Vera Farmiga and Freddie Highmore, on A&E on Mondays.
lead_paragraph: Television networks love theme nights — crime-time Tuesdays, comedy Thursdays, cartoon Sundays. Beginning this week, the cable channel A&E joins the fun by packaging one of TV’s most popular genres into serial-killer Mondays.

headline: Russia’s Aggression
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Putin government ignites the world’s condemnation with each move against Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: There was a lot to criticize about the way President Viktor Yanukovych’s government was thrown out in Ukraine and hurriedly replaced with an interim team. The victorious opposition should have known how critical it was to reassure all groups in that country that their rights would be respected in any new order; instead, one of the Parliament’s first actions was to abolish a law that ensured a legal status for Russian and other minority languages, thus raising fears among Russian speakers that Ukrainian nationalists were taking over.

headline: In a Decadent Vienna, Constancy Is Shown the Doors
abstract: Even the jerks become likable in Fiasco Theater’s charming production of “Measure for Measure,” one of Shakespeare’s creepiest plays.
lead_paragraph: So many doors, each opening on to what God only knows. What do you think is behind, say, this one, with the grill? A treat or a trick? A lady or a tiger? Mercy or mortality?

headline: Swan Song Scripted for Two
abstract: Janie Taylor and Sébastien Marcovici danced their final performances on Saturday with New York City Ballet in Robbins’s “Afternoon of a Faun” and Balanchine’s “La Valse.”
lead_paragraph: When dancers retire, most are still young, with much of their working lives only then beginning. Janie Taylor and Sébastien Marcovici, husband and wife, gave their farewell performance together on Saturday with New York City Ballet and have careers ahead of them. She is already a costume designer; on Thursday and Friday, performances by Tom Gold Dance will feature new costumes by her. He is becoming a ballet master with L.A. Dance Project. And yet from now on, many people will think of them as figures from the past, remembered chiefly from the lives they led onstage in City Ballet’s repertory.

headline: The Philharmonic and Friends Go for a Ride in the Country
abstract: Mary Chapin Carpenter songs were given orchestral arrangements for her two-night engagement with the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic is no honky-tonk band. On paper, that might make it an odd partner for Mary Chapin Carpenter, the singer and songwriter who won country music Grammys every year from 1992 to 1995, and who sang with the orchestra on Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, in a concert repeated Saturday. But Ms. Carpenter has long since left behind the demands of country radio to write quiet, thoughtful songs that seek transcendence in the everyday.

headline: Ukrainian Activists Work to Counter Russian Narrative on Social Networks
abstract: Faced with what they call misleading reports on Russian state television that ethnic-nationalist violence is sweeping Ukraine, Internet-savvy Ukrainian activists drew attention on Sunday to social media images to counter that narrative.
lead_paragraph: Faced with what they call misleading reports on Russian state television that ethnic-nationalist violence is sweeping Ukraine, Internet-savvy Ukrainian activists drew attention on Sunday to video and images posted online that showed street protests in support of the new government in Kiev, and acts of violence instigated by men waving the Russian flag.

headline: Diana Ross to Lead Montreal Festival Lineup
abstract: Ms. Ross will headline the 35th annual Montreal Jazz Festival this summer along with the singer-songwriters Rufus Wainwright and Bobby McFerrin and the Canadian crooner Michael Bublé.
lead_paragraph: Diana Ross will headline the 35th annual Montreal Jazz Festival this summer along with the singer-songwriters Rufus Wainwright and Bobby McFerrin and the Canadian crooner Michael Bublé. It will be Ms. Ross’s first appearance at the festival, and in addition to performing, she will be the recipient of the Ella Fitzgerald Award, which celebrates the repertory, range and versatility of international jazz singers. Other acts include the pianist  Alain Lefèvre, who will be accompanied by the Montreal Symphony Orchestra; and the singer-songwriter  Ben Harper with the blues harmonica player Charlie Musselwhite. The festival is to be held from June 26 to July 6. For a full lineup: montrealjazzfest.com.

headline: Taliban Move Brings Halt to Airstrikes in Pakistan
abstract: The Pakistani government, in response to a Taliban cease-fire, suspended its airstrike campaign, but reserved the right “to effectively respond to acts of violence.”
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani government on Sunday suspended its airstrike campaign against militants in the country’s northwestern tribal regions in response to a Taliban cease-fire, raising the prospect that peace talks between the two sides will be revived.

headline: Tibet’s Enduring Defiance
abstract: There have been far fewer self-immolations. But it would be wrong to see this as a sign that Beijing has gained the upper hand.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 27, 2009, three days into the Tibetan New Year, a 24-year-old monk in his crimson and yellow robe emerged from the confines of the Kirti Monastery into the streets of Ngawa, in a the Tibetan area of southwestern China. There, in the shadow of a 98-foot-tall monument to the gods of longevity, the man burst into flames — thus sparking the first of many self-immolations that spread across the Tibetan regions of China.

headline: Archie Comic Picks Film and TV Writer for Top Creative Post
abstract: Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, the new chief creative officer at Archie Comic Publications, has a long history with comics and Archie, some of it bumpy.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa is adding a feather to his cap: chief creative officer of Archie Comic Publications. Mr. Aguirre-Sacasa, who has also written for film and television, will be working closely with the Archie team in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to figure out the best way to exploit the company’s characters in comics, of course, but also in other media.

headline: Yankees May Finally Come Out Ahead in the Trade for Pineda
abstract: Michael Pineda, acquired from Seattle in 2012 for catcher Jesus Montero, showed signs Sunday of the power pitcher the Yankees thought they had traded for.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — At the time of the trade, one of the biggest of the winter before the 2012 season, both teams had every reason to be excited. The Seattle Mariners, in need of a hitter, had picked up Jesus Montero, the Yankees’ top prospect at the time, who many felt was a certain All-Star. The Yankees received Michael Pineda, a big, hard-throwing starting pitcher who had made the All-Star team as a rookie in 2011.

headline: Asylum Claims: Dealing With Fraud and Backlogs
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Human Rights First and an immigration lawyer react to an article about a crackdown on asylum fraud.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Foreign Buyers Eyeing Forbes Magazine, a Chronicler of the World’s Wealthiest
abstract: All good things come to an end, even for the rich, and sometime this month, Forbes will probably pass out of family control and into the hands of a foreign owner.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the Midwest, my idea of rich was my dentist, who lived a few blocks away and had a split-level that was bigger than the rest of ours and a Cadillac in the driveway. Then I saw a copy of Forbes in his office and realized there was a different sort of wealth, a gossamer existence beyond my wildest imaginings.

headline: A Reprieve for Bristol Bay
abstract: The Obama administration is headed in the right direction as it puts the brakes on a massive gold and copper mine proposed for Alaska.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration announced on Friday that it was putting the brakes on a massive gold and copper mine proposed for the headwaters of Alaska’s Bristol Bay while it decides whether to prohibit it permanently. This sounds like the death knell for a project, known as the Pebble Mine, that by any measure is an environmental disaster waiting to happen. The mine would gravely threaten one of the richest salmon fisheries in the world and disrupt a delicate marine environment prized by conservationists, native tribes and commercial fishing interests alike.

headline: After One Spouse Loses a Job, Finding a New Balance in a Marriage
abstract: Joblessness and underemployment often affect relationships in ways that are hard to predict or quantify, disordering routines, fueling quarrels and widening the distance between couples.
lead_paragraph: Eliza Stoker breezed in from the office that evening in September, ready for a drink and a quiet dinner. Then she saw her husband slumped on the couch and she knew. She could see it in his face. She could feel it in the air.

headline: Ultra-Orthodox Jews Clog Jerusalem Streets to Protest a Draft Bill
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Demonstrators railed against a government plan that could conscript yeshiva students and holds the threat of arrest for those who dodge the draft.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In a formidable show of force, at least 300,000 ultra-Orthodox Jewish men flooded the streets around the main entrance to Jerusalem on Sunday, bringing much of the city to a standstill with a protest against a government plan that aims to conscript more of their numbers for military service and holds out the threat of arrest for religious draft dodgers.

headline: Tiny Digital Publisher to Put Newsweek Back in Print

lead_paragraph: The Graham family, longtime newspaper publishers, gave up and sold it for a dollar. The media mogul Barry Diller spent tens of millions trying to revive it, only to throw in the towel. Even Mr. Diller’s star editor, Tina Brown, could not stop it from going out of print.

abstract: Is a romantic relationship between a man and a machine possible?
lead_paragraph: Set in the not-too-distant future, Spike Jonze’s film “Her” explores the romantic relationship between Samantha, a computer program, and Theodore Twombly, a human being. Though Samantha is not human, she feels the pangs of heartbreak, intermittently longs for a body and is bewildered by her own evolution. She has a rich inner life, complete with experiences and sensations.

headline: Home Fires Are Burning Out
abstract: Alexandra Silber plays the blinkered heroine at the center of the solo musical “Arlington.”
lead_paragraph: An Army wife sings herself to the brink of a nervous breakdown in “Arlington,” a musical for solo voice and piano that opened on Sunday night at the Vineyard Theater. With book and lyrics by Victor Lodato, and music by Polly Pen, the show lasts just an hour as it charts the restless wandering of the heroine’s mind as she muses lightly on her past and more darkly on the war and its impact on her husband. But the long day of Sara Jane, flawlessly portrayed by the gifted singer Alexandra Silber, translates into a pretty long hour for the audience.

lead_paragraph: Arun Sundararajan is a professor and NEC Faculty Fellow in the Stern School of Business at New York University, where his research studies how digital technologies transform business and society. His research has been supported by organizations that include Google, IBM, Microsoft and Yahoo.

headline: E.P.A. Set to Reveal Tough New Sulfur Emissions Rule
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Sulfur and Sulfur Compounds', 'Refineries', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency regulation would force oil refiners to strip sulfur out of American gasoline blends and automakers to install cleaner-burning engine technology.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency plans to unveil a major new regulation on Monday that forces oil refiners to strip out sulfur, a smog-forming pollutant linked to respiratory disease, from American gasoline blends, according to people familiar with the agency’s plans.

headline: New All-Digital Curriculums Hope to Ride High-Tech Push in Schoolrooms
abstract: Amplify, part of News Corporation, is one of many companies releasing all-digital curriculums for sale to school districts.
lead_paragraph: English language curriculums built entirely on a digital platform — replacing written textbooks, worksheets or printed study guides — are about to enter the market from several companies, with promises that they will change the nature of classroom learning across the country.

headline: Eddie O’Brien, Who Played for Pirates With His Twin, Dies at 83
abstract: Though only 5 feet 9 inches, O’Brien and his brother Johnny were also basketball stars at Seattle University.
lead_paragraph: Eddie O’Brien and his twin, Johnny, were basketball and baseball stars at St. Mary’s High School in South Amboy, N.J., but when they graduated in 1948, their athletic careers seemed to be over. They were only 5 feet 9 inches tall, and no college program wanted them.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (AMC) ROCKY (1976) It’s all Rocky all night long, starting with this Oscar winner for best picture, written by and starring Sylvester Stallone (below) as Rocky Balboa, an amateur boxer in Philadelphia who gets a shot at fighting Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers), the world heavyweight champion. “Rocky II” (1979), in which Apollo seeks a rematch, follows at 8; “Rocky III” (1982), in which Rocky defends his title against the zealous Clubber Lang (Mr. T), at 11; “Rocky IV” (1985), in which he goes up against a Soviet boxer named Drago (Dolph Lundgren), at 1:30 a.m.; and “Rocky V” (1990), in which the former champion, now brain-damaged and broke, shows a young boxer (Tommy Morrison) the ways of the ring, at 3:30.

headline: Staking a Claim on Social Causes
abstract: Gay rights held Hollywood’s attention at the Oscars, but Ellen DeGeneres, the host, was more lighthearted about the issue.
lead_paragraph: “12 Years a Slave” won best picture, but for much of the evening, it was gay rights, not race, that held Hollywood’s attention at the Oscars. Jared Leto dragged the real world into Sunday night’s celebration of make-believe. After winning the best supporting actor for portraying a transgender AIDS patient in “Dallas Buyers Club,” Mr. Leto voiced support for protesters in Ukraine and Venezuela. He championed gay people. “To those of you out there who have ever felt injustice because of who you are or who you love, tonight, I stand here in front of the world with you and for you.” Hollywood is so righteous, suddenly, about gay rights, and that’s a little puzzling because for so long, movies were part of the problem. Professional basketball has its first openly gay player, Jason Collins, but it’s still hard to think of romantic leads — male or female — who are A-list Hollywood movie stars and also openly gay.

headline: The 86th Academy Awards
abstract: “Gravity” dominated the awards, winning seven Oscars, but “12 Years a Slave” was named best picture.
lead_paragraph: “Gravity” dominated the awards, winning seven Oscars, but “12 Years a Slave” was named best picture.

headline: Tennent H. Bagley, Who Aided, Then Mistrusted a Soviet Spy, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Bagley’s case caused a war within the national security complex over whether the defector he encouraged, Yuri Ivanovich Nosenko, was a Soviet agent sent to trick the Americans.
lead_paragraph: Tennent H. Bagley, a former C.I.A. officer who helped a mysterious Soviet spy betray his country, then tried for a half-century to prove that the defector was actually a Russian double agent, died on Feb. 20 at his home in Brussels. He was 88.

headline: Ralph Bahna, Travel Industry Innovator in Air and on Sea, Dies at 71
abstract: Mr. Bahna created one of the first luxury business classes on an airline, turned around the fortunes of the Cunard Line and was the chairman of Priceline.com.
lead_paragraph: Ralph M. Bahna, who is credited with creating one of the first luxury business-class services on a major airline and later became chairman of Priceline.com, died on Feb. 24 in Manhattan. He was 71.

headline: U.N. Security Council Condemns ‘Terrorist Attack’ in Kunming
abstract: As the United Nations Security Council condemned the attack in China’s Kunming train station that left at least 29 dead, the authorities moved to delete social media posts that called on leaders to allow open discussion of the situation in Xinjiang, where tensions are running high.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council has condemned as a “terrorist attack” the slashing rampage Saturday night in a train station in the southwestern city of Kunming, in which a group of black-clad assailants with knives and daggers killed at least 29 people and wounded 143. Hong Kong news outlets said about 75 of those may be severely injured.

headline: No Great Surprises for Oscar Night
abstract: There were no big Oscar surprises, but this year’s Academy Awards show featured an engaging host and a best picture winner that even a critic can love.
lead_paragraph: There were no big Oscar surprises, but this year’s Academy Awards show featured an engaging host and a best picture winner that even a critic can love.

headline: Witness in Pistorius Trial Tells of Screams and Gunshots
abstract: At the murder trial of Oscar Pistorius, the South African double-amputee track star, a witness described “bloodcurdling screams” on the night he is alleged to have killed his girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: PRETORIA, South Africa — The trial of Oscar Pistorius on murder charges began Monday, with a neighbor of the South African double-amputee track star saying that she heard “bloodcurdling screams” shortly before Mr. Pistorius’s girlfriend was shot and killed.

headline: Fatal Attack Rattles Court Complex in Pakistani Capital
abstract: A senior judge was among those killed in the attack in Islamabad, shaking Pakistan’s government just as prospects for talks with the Taliban seemed to be improving.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — In a rare strike in the heart of Pakistan’s capital, Islamabad, militants killed at least 11 people at the district court complex on Monday, shaking the government just as prospects for talks with the Taliban seemed to be improving.

headline: Report People From Xinjiang, Police Say After Deadly Attack
abstract: A police station in the southern region of Guangxi has called on citizens to report any people from Xinjiang in their midst, after attackers believed to be from the far western region killed at least 29 people on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Chinese citizens should report any people from Xinjiang in their midst, reads a notice issued by a local police office on Sunday, a day after an attack in which knife-wielding assailants the government says were terrorists from the far western region of Xinjiang killed at least 29 people and wounded 143.

headline: Do You Ever Eavesdrop?
abstract: Do you ever take “mini vacations” into other people’s lives?
lead_paragraph: We watch movies, read books and listen to music to take a break from our own lives and enter another world. But sometimes a quick escape is just within easy earshot.

headline: Where Lush Beauty Conceals Dread
abstract: The community spirit that Andrea Bruce knew from her grandfather’s farm was nowhere to be found in India, where the widows of farmers who commit suicide confront creditors and ostracism.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment, soon after  Andrea Bruce began photographing the widows of Indian farmers last fall, when she sensed the quiet menace that would become her main subject.

headline: War Deaths Top 13,000 in Afghan Security Forces
abstract: The figures suggest that many more Afghan soldiers and police officers have been killed during the war than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — More than 13,000 Afghan soldiers and police officers have been killed during the war here, far more than previously known, according to Afghan government statistics.

headline: Hong Kong Businessman Found Guilty of Money Laundering
abstract: Carson Yeung, the owner of the Birmingham City soccer club, faces a maximum of seven years in jail for five counts in the laundering of a total of nearly $100 million.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A former Hong Kong hairstylist whose rapid rise to wealth culminated in the takeover of the British soccer team Birmingham City was convicted on Monday of five counts in the laundering of a total of nearly $100 million from entities including casinos and people the authorities have described as gang members.

headline: New York Today: Slightly Snowy

lead_paragraph: Video emerged on Youku, the Chinese video-sharing service, on Monday afternoon, apparently showing scenes from the knife attack in the Kunming train station on Saturday that left at least 29 people dead and 143 wounded.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Nathaniel Rich on the Truth About Corgis and Synthetic Biology
keywords: ['Biotechnology', 'Cloning', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Science and Technology', 'Synthetic Biology', 'Woolly Mammoths']
abstract: Nathaniel Rich argues that the natural world, as we know it, is already a distant knock-off of what existed before we got here.
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel Rich, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about efforts to bring animals like the passenger pigeon and the woolly mammoth back from extinction. Rich is the author, most recently, of the novel “Odds Against Tomorrow.” He last wrote for the magazine about hunting for the best goat stew in Los Angeles.

headline: The Mystery of Chinese New Year, Solved
abstract: A little more than a week into the New Year, our whole team returned to us — including one particular employee with a heartwarming story.
lead_paragraph: In a recent post, I discussed an issue many Chinese companies cope with after New Year’s break: the loss of staff members. In 2012, my auction company, iPai, lost two staff members. In 2013, we lost three. In a small company, that can be a significant loss.

headline: Daily Report: Lax Data Security a Problem for Many Start-Ups

headline: Kiev Cites Campaign of Pressure by Russia
abstract: The new government of Ukraine accused Russia of deploying 16,000 troops to Crimean Peninsula and demanding that it surrender or face armed assault — a claim Russia denied.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The embattled new government of Ukraine accused Russian forces of a major escalation in military pressure over control of the Crimean Peninsula on Monday, saying Russia had deployed 16,000 troops in the region over the last week and had demanded that Ukrainian forces there surrender within hours or face armed assault.

headline: March 3 Updates on Ukraine Crisis
abstract: The situation in Crimea remained one of a tense standoff Monday, with Russian troops surrounding Ukrainian bases, while European Union foreign ministers prepared to meet over the crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Lede is following events in Ukraine and Russia on Monday, as military standoffs around Ukrainian bases continued in Russian-controlled Crimea after Russia dispatched more forces and tightened its grip on the peninsula. Updates below mix breaking news with dispatches from Times correspondents and firsthand accounts of events on the ground posted on social networks by bloggers and journalists in Crimea and other parts of Ukraine.

headline: A Record Profit for Berkshire
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway posted a record profit in 2013. | Tensions in Ukraine rattle global financial markets. | A Mexican unit of Citigroup was defrauded of as much as $400 million. | A JPMorgan Chase shareholder has introduced a proposal to break up the bank. | Mt. Gox and a steady erosion of faith in the Bitcoin community.
lead_paragraph: Berkshire Hathaway, run by Warren E. Buffett, released its annual report on Saturday, disclosing a record profit in 2013 of $19.5 billion, a 32 percent increase from $14.8 billion in 2012. Berkshire’s book value per share — the measure Mr. Buffett uses to assess the company’s performance — rose 18.2 percent in 2013, much less than the 32.4 percent rise in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index. But even as Berkshire posts handsome results, it remains to be seen whether it can continue to make large acquisitions that will help it sustain its reputation as the nation’s savviest investor, Peter Eavis and Rachel Abrams write in DealBook.

lead_paragraph: In the days and weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, a Kuwaiti-born cleric, Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, became a familiar figure in propaganda videos for Al Qaeda, appearing in some with Osama bin Laden, and other times alone, issuing blistering threats against the United States.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell promised a more open floor if he were majority leader, and while he would not commit to reversing limits on filibusters, he said the idea would be on the table.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell still has a few obstacles to overcome to become Senate majority leader next year. First, he has to win his own primary and general election back in Kentucky, where his popularity has suffered. Then his fellow Republicans have to pick up at least six seats for the party to take over the Senate for the first time since 2006.

headline: A Hidden Space for the Dreams, Lofty or Not, of Mayoral Kin
abstract: The spacious attic of the mayoral residence in New York has served many purposes over the years: a children’s playroom, a workout room and a chef’s apartment.
lead_paragraph: The spacious wooden-beamed attic of Gracie Mansion has served many purposes over the years: as a playroom, a workout room and a secret lair where a mayoral child experimented with cigarettes. But for Mitchel London, the gruff but affable restaurateur who these days runs the Fairway Café on the Upper West Side and several other Manhattan eateries, it was home.

headline: Undoing the Structural Damage to Potential Growth
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The recession put the United States on a path to lower economic growth, but bolder policies could help revive the labor market and raise the growth path without excessive inflation, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Roasted Winter Vegetable Medley
abstract: A sweet mixture of winter vegetables that works on its own as a side or as part of a few different kinds of main dishes.
lead_paragraph: This is a sweet mixture of comforting winter vegetables that you can serve on its own as a side dish, or use as the component of a polenta, big bowl, frittata or omelet, or pasta. I roast the squash in one pan and the other vegetables together in another. If you have a small oven, roast the squash first, then the other vegetables. Or you can use two shelves and switch the trays top to bottom halfway through the roasting.

headline: Roasted Root Vegetables With Polenta
abstract: A comforting main dish that combines savory oven-baked polenta with sweet oven-roasted root vegetables.
lead_paragraph: In this comforting, perfect winter dinner I roast the vegetables and make the polenta in the oven at the same time. To accommodate the temperature requirements of each element of the dish, I use a slightly higher temperature than I usually use for polenta and I roast the vegetables at a lower temperature for longer. I top the polenta with a ladleful of marinara sauce, and spoon the vegetables on top. You could serve the polenta with only the roasted vegetables as well, so I have made the marinara sauce optional.

headline: Omelets With Roasted Vegetables and Feta
abstract: With roasted vegetables on hand, this satisfying meal comes together in minutes.
lead_paragraph: If you have roasted vegetables on hand an omelet is a wonderful vehicle for them. Omelets are so quick to make, and so satisfying, whether you make them for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. You can cut up your roasted vegetables into slightly smaller pieces if you want a less chunky omelet.

headline: Roasted Brussels Sprouts and Mushrooms With Gremolata and Quinoa
abstract: Two roasted vegetables that are delicious with a variety of grains.
lead_paragraph: When I discovered how delicious Brussels sprouts are when the edges are lightly browned, whether by pan-roasting or oven-roasting, they became a top winter vegetable in my house. Both the Brussels sprouts and the mushrooms roast quickly in a hot oven. I roast them separately so that the juice from the mushrooms doesn’t prevent the Brussels sprouts from browning properly. You can serve the roasted vegetables with quinoa but I also love them with polenta, pasta and other grains.

headline: Roasted Carrot, Parsnip and Potato Soup
abstract: A creamy, comforting winter soup that is simple to make.
lead_paragraph: This is a creamy, comforting winter soup that is incredibly simple to make. All you need to do is blend together broth and roasted vegetables and heat through. You can make the soup with other roasted vegetables as well, but I love the sweet combination of the carrots and parsnips. If you’ve got roasted vegetables on hand, you’ll need about 4 cups.

headline: Parts of Pompeii Crumble Under Heavy Rains

headline: Children’s Museum to Showcase Harlem’s Role in Jazz
abstract: The exhibition “Jazzed! The Changing Beat of 125th Street” will open in May at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Jazz – its history, its talents, its sounds – is the subject of a new exhibition at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan that will run May 23 through Oct. 19, in partnership with the National Jazz Museum in Harlem. “Jazzed! The Changing Beat of 125th Street” is an interactive, multimedia exhibition that will make use of jazz artifacts, music education workshops and live performances each day.

headline: Henk Tijms and the Devil’s Penny
abstract: Open as many cash-filled boxes as you’d like and keep what’s inside — unless you open the box with the Devil’s Penny.
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Henk Tijms, a Dutch mathematician and emeritus professor at the VU University Amsterdam. The puzzle is based on Devil’s Penny, a game created by Dr. Tijms for a study on successful aging that showed older people recovered from an encounter with the Devil’s currency more easily than younger people did. (Read more in The Neurological Roots of Lingering Regret.)

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: The Chase for a Top Seed
abstract: The San Antonio Spurs and the Miami Heat, who will meet on Thursday night, are the reigning conference champions and in hot pursuit of the top seed in their conferences.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Bitcoin Loss Highlights Elusive Paths of Regulation
abstract: The collapse of Mt. Gox and the loss of $450 million in Bitcoins is pushing governments to enhance regulation of virtual currencies, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Can nearly $450 million go missing without a crime taking place? That is only one of the questions stemming from the collapse of the Bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox that present a host of challenges for governments worldwide that are struggling to regulate virtual currencies.

headline: Image of the Day: March 3
abstract: A girl in Mayong village in Assam trying to pull a boat ashore.

headline: Buffett’s ‘Three T’s’ Open Up on CNBC
abstract: The Berkshire executives Ted Weschler, Todd Combs and Tracy Britt Cool gave a rare interview on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ted Weschler first met Warren E. Buffett over dinner. A very, very expensive dinner.

headline: The Best Investment Strategy? Getting Out of Our Own Way
abstract: The average investor tends to buy high and sell low; less well-intentioned action would help close the behavior gap, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: We’re still making the same old mistake of buying investments when prices are high and selling them once their prices have fallen.

headline: In Rhode Island, a Celebration of Portugal
abstract: The Castle Hill Inn in Rhode Island is hosting the New Portugal Food and Wine Week.
lead_paragraph: While bacalao may not be the first thing that comes to mind when planning a trip to Rhode Island, a Newport hotel is trying to change that with a week’s worth of Portuguese food and wine, aimed at promoting the heritage of the state’s large population of Portuguese descendants.

abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Times Minute | Ukraine in Context
abstract: A look at the situation in Ukraine. The current scene in Crimea, what's at stake in Ukraine for diplomats, and the relationship between the United States and Russia.
lead_paragraph: A look at the situation in Ukraine. The current scene in Crimea, what's at stake in Ukraine for diplomats, and the relationship between the United States and Russia.

headline: Andreessen Defends His Behavior on eBay’s Board
abstract: In a post on the blog of his venture capital firm, Andreessen Horowitz, the technology investor Marc Andreessen defended his conduct as an eBay director in the face of repeated criticism from Carl C. Icahn.
lead_paragraph: After enduring a week of attacks by Carl C. Icahn about his tenure on the board of eBay, the technology investor Marc Andreessen has delivered his most direct response yet to the hedge fund manager’s criticisms.

abstract: A look at the situation in Ukraine. The current scene in Crimea, what’s at stake in Ukraine for diplomats and the relationship between the United States and Russia.
