headline: Paris Fashion Week: Kenzo Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: Caesars Entertainment Sells Casinos to Affiliate
abstract: Caesars Growth Partners is buying four casinos for $2.2 billion, in a deal intended to help the Caesars Entertainment Corporation gain access to cash it needs to service its huge debt load.
lead_paragraph: The Caesars Entertainment Corporation said on Monday that it would sell four casinos to its spinoff, Caesars Growth Partners, for $2.2 billion.

headline: Ad Attacks House Republicans on Immigration
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An advocacy group backed by Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg is adopting a sharper tone in a new 60-second spot to urge Republicans to overhaul the immigration system.
lead_paragraph: A new, 60-second ad aimed squarely at Republican lawmakers seeks to compel them to push through a broad overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws. Adopting a sharper tone, the ad blames House Republicans for holding up the immigration legislation that has currently stalled in Congress.

headline: New Director Named for Weeksville Heritage Center
abstract: Tia Powell Harris will take charge of the center, in Brooklyn, which is focused on a free black community that had been established in 1838.
lead_paragraph: The Weeksville Heritage Center in Crown Heights in Brooklyn, which preserves the documents, artifacts and houses that are the remnants of a free black community established in the area in 1838, has a new director, Tia Powell Harris. Ms. Harris, who was director of artistic affairs at the Duke Ellington School of the Arts in Washington, will take over on March 17, the center’s board of directors is to announce on Tuesday.

headline: The Read Around: Roddy Doyle
abstract: Roddy Doyle discusses how the “daily humiliations of getting older” inform the characters in his new book, “The Guts.”
lead_paragraph: Roddy Doyle discusses how the “daily humiliations of getting older” inform the characters in his new book, “The Guts.”

headline: Over Puccini, Diva Bonds With Conductor
abstract: Anna Netrebko sings the title role in Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut” during a run at the Rome Opera.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Anna Netrebko, the Russian prima donna, treats her career like a contact sport, with a refreshing quantity of nerve. She has lately been adding to her repertory at a furious pace, but that alone might not have been providing enough excitement for her, and she raised the bar here last week. Her first performance in the title part of Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut” on Thursday was a threefold debut: role, Rome and Riccardo.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Roddy Doyle
abstract: Mr. Doyle discusses the inspiration for his new novel, “The Guts,” which revisits a character from “The Commitments.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Roddy Doyle talks about why he chose to revisit the character of Jimmy Rabbitte from “The Commitments” for his new novel, “The Guts,” and how the “daily humiliations of getting older” worked their way into the book.

headline: Train Station Rampage Further Strains Ethnic Relations in China
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Terrorism', 'Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Relations have never been easy between the Han majority and Uighurs, but after an attack on Saturday, many Chinese are saying the mood is worsening.
lead_paragraph: KUNMING, China — Even with the objects of his ire in earshot, the landlord barely lowered his voice to describe his Uighur neighbors, who also happened to be his tenants.

headline: Post-Oscars Diversity Downer
abstract: Race and gender disparities still mar the film industry.
lead_paragraph: Sunday night’s Academy Awards were a model of diversity. They were hosted by Ellen DeGeneres, a lesbian; Lupita Nyong’o, who is black, won the best supporting actress category; and “12 Years a Slave” won for best picture, marking the first time the top prize went to the work of a black director, Steve McQueen. Mr. McQueen did not win the best director prize, which was awarded instead to the Mexican filmmaker Alfonso Cuarón.

headline: The Challenges of Hiring and Working With Developers
abstract: A group of business owners compare notes on the best strategies for hiring technical talent.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners discussed strategies for hiring technical staff and contractors.

headline: Playwrights Horizons Season to Include New Bruce Norris Play
abstract: The season will include new plays by Mr. Norris, Samuel D. Hunter and Melissa James Gibson, as well as Robert O’Hara’s “Bootycandy.”
lead_paragraph: New plays by Bruce Norris (a Pulitzer Prize winner for “Clybourne Park”), Samuel D. Hunter (“The Whale”), Melissa James Gibson (“This”) and three others will make up the 2014-15 season at Playwrights Horizons, the Off Broadway theater announced on Monday.

headline: A Successor to Sagan Reboots ‘Cosmos’
abstract: Hosted by Neil deGrasse Tyson, the series, on Fox, invites viewers to take a communal journey from earth to the observable universe.
lead_paragraph: A poignant moment occurs near the end of the first episode of “Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey,” a rollicking 13-part tour of the universe to be broadcast on Fox starting on Sunday.

headline: New York Public Library to Offer Lunch-Hour Readings
abstract: The library’s series will include readings by P.J. O’Rourke, Joyce Carol Oates, Colm Toibin and Michael Cunningham.
lead_paragraph: The average book club meeting or evening literary gathering may be a languorous affair carried along on a stream of wine and chatter. Now, a new free lunch-time reading series at the New York Public Library aims to give busy book lovers something of an espresso-bar option.

headline: Climbing Mt. Everest? Nepal Says Bring Back Garbage
abstract: With an estimated 50 tons of trash left behind by climbers littering Mount Everest, Nepal declared that all climbers must carry down 18 pounds of garbage or face stiff penalties.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Hoping to clean a trash-strewn pathway to the world’s highest peak, Nepal’s tourism authority declared Monday that those climbing Mount Everest must return from the trip with an extra 18 pounds of garbage.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: February 28-March 2, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A man who fatally shot and killed an elderly man on his property in rural Georgia last fall will not face charges. After wandering the Chickamauga area for hours, Ronald Westbrook, 72, who had Alzheimer’s disease, walked onto the property of Joe Hendrix at around 2:30 a.m. on Nov. 27. Hendrix’s fiancée called 911, but before police arrived, Hendrix, 35, grabbed his .40-caliber handgun and fired several shots at Westbrook, one of which hit him in the chest.

headline: Supreme Court Agrees to Weigh an Inmate’s Right to Grow a Beard for Religious Reasons
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Beards and Mustaches', 'Religion and Belief', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A prisoner in Arkansas, contending that his Muslim faith requires him to wear a beard, is challenging a ban on long facial hair that state prison officials say is needed to promote hygiene and deter the concealment of contraband.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to decide whether prison officials in Arkansas may prohibit inmates from growing beards in accordance with their religious beliefs.

headline: Bookshelf | A Poet’s Ode to His Late Father
abstract: In “Book of Hours,” Kevin Young crafts a moving narrative of loss.
lead_paragraph: On the jacket cover of Kevin Young’s forthcoming collection of poems “Book of Hours” (Alfred A. Knopf, out tomorrow), tears fall from the all-seeing eye; inside, in a piece called “Rosetta,” he writes that “The grammar of grief gets written each day.” This is just what Young conveys in these new pages, where no sorrow is spared.

headline: Springtime for Ticks
abstract: Do deer in the yard in winter mean tick bites in the spring? Not definitely, but be wary anyway.
lead_paragraph: Q. Five deer roamed my snow-covered front yard. Will there be ticks there when the snow melts this spring?

headline: U.S. Uniform at the World Cup: Red, Mostly White and Blue
abstract: Nike unveiled the United States’ home uniform that will be worn at the World Cup, and by the women’s national team in coming games.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps it is appropriate that the United States men’s national soccer team headed for the World Cup in Brazil in June has adopted the unmistakable look of one of the most famous teams of the 1950s and 1960s and its renowned player Pelé. Not to mention that Brazil was the site of the most famous World Cup win in American soccer history.

headline: Scenes From the Governors Ball
abstract: Images from the annual post-Oscars celebration.
lead_paragraph: Images from the annual post-Oscars celebration.

headline: Recently Attributed Leonardo Painting Was Sold Privately for Over $75 Million
abstract: Leonardo’s oil-on-panel “Salvator Mundi” was last year sold to an unidentified collector for a price between $75 million and $80 million.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A Leonardo da Vinci painting discovered by a dealer at an American estate sale was sold last year in a private transaction for more than $75 million.

headline: Egyptian Graft Investigator Accuses Officials of Retribution
abstract: Lt. Col. Moatassem Fathi says he has been demoted since a top official he accused of sabotaging corruption investigations was rehabilitated by the military-led government.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian corruption investigator said Monday that he had filed a complaint charging that the government had demoted him in retribution for raising accusations of cronyism and self-dealing by Egypt’s chief spy and other senior officials.

headline: Envy Versus Anger
abstract: Not the same thing.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, or so it seems, inequality has surged into public consciousness — and neither the one percent nor its reliable defenders seems to know how to cope.

headline: Holder and Republicans Unite to Soften Sentencing Laws
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and libertarian-leaning Republicans have found common cause on eliminating mandatory minimum prison sentences for nonviolent drug offenders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after Senator Rand Paul filed suit last month against the Obama administration to stop its electronic dragnet of American phone records, he sat down for lunch with Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. in his private dining room at the Justice Department.

headline: Buffett and Icahn: Birds of a Feather?
abstract: The styles of the two investors could not be more different. But Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews notes that both men beat the market by betting on America, playing hardball and trading on personal brands.
lead_paragraph: Warren E.  Buffett and Carl C. Icahn are inverse investors who correlate in more ways than one. In recently released letters to shareholders, the two billionaires talk up their returns and approaches to deploying capital. Their styles couldn’t be more different, but both beat the market by betting on America, playing hardball and trading on personal brands. Yet their greatest common bond is that neither can be easily replicated.

headline: French Cable Operator May Make $20 Billion Bid for Vivendi Mobile Unit
abstract: The French cable operator Numericable and its largest shareholder, Altice, are said to be preparing a bid of up to $20 billion for SFR, the mobile unit of the conglomerate Vivendi, though it is unclear when an offer may be formally made.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Deal makers are once again circling Europe’s telecommunications industry looking for big buys.

headline: Pro-Russia Forces Storm Ukraine Offices
abstract: Protesters supporting Russia rallied outside Ukraine’s government buildings in Odessa and Donetsk.
lead_paragraph: Protesters supporting Russia rallied outside Ukraine’s government buildings in Odessa and Donetsk.

headline: Carmakers Say Sales Were Sluggish in Chilly February
abstract: Sales figures for some trucks remained strong, but G.M., Ford, Toyota and Volkswagen all said severe winter weather had taken a toll on American sales of new cars.
lead_paragraph: Severe cold weather across much of the country stalled new-vehicle sales in February, even as sales of some trucks and sport utility vehicles remained strong, automakers reported on Monday.

headline: Top British Prize for Grand Theft Auto Makers
abstract: Rockstar Games, the video game studio behind the hugely successful Grand Theft Auto series, is to be awarded a British Academy of Film and Television Arts Academy Fellowship Award next week.
lead_paragraph: Rockstar Games, the studio behind the hugely successful Grand Theft Auto video game series, is to be awarded a British Academy of Film and Television Arts Academy Fellowship Award next week. This lifetime achievement award is the academy’s highest honor, presented for outstanding achievement in film, television or games. Bafta said that Rockstar had earned the award for its “revolutionary approach” to game development.

headline: Pro-Russia Protesters Storm Odessa
abstract: Protesters supporting Russia rallied outside of Ukraine's government buildings in Odessa and Donetsk.
lead_paragraph: Protesters supporting Russia rallied outside of Ukraine's government buildings in Odessa and Donetsk.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Giambattista Valli Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: At Audi’s Party, Ducati Unveils a Redesigned Diavel
abstract: Already a model with no-nonsense looks, the updated Diavel broadcasts a message of “get out of my way.”
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — When the German carmaker Audi acquired the Italian motorcycle manufacturer Ducati for about $1 billion in 2012, many in the auto industry wondered how Ducati might fit into Audi’s business plans.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o Dancing With Bill Murray and Other Party Memories
abstract: The best supporting actress winner was the star of the room.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. – The annual Vanity Fair afterparty retains its status as a must-stop for Oscar winners and nominees and plain old ultra-famous, ultra-beautiful people. But in a crowd that included gold medal winners (the ice dancers Charlie White and Meryl Davis), world’s richest artists (Jeff Koons) and Lady Gaga, there was no mistaking who was the queen of the night.

headline: Big Data Means Big Questions on How That Information Is Used
abstract: At a conference held at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, academics and government officials addressed the tricky questions posed by the harvesting of large quantities of information.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — With the success of its free open online course system, called MITx, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology finds itself sitting on a wealth of student data that researchers might use to compare the efficacy of virtual teaching methods, and perhaps advance the field of Web-based instruction.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Open House'
abstract: A scene from Will Eno’s new play at the Signature Center.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Will Eno’s new play at the Signature Center.

headline: On GrubHub and Seamless, Restaurants Pay for Placement
abstract: Restaurants that pay bigger commissions end up higher in search results.
lead_paragraph: Controversies about Internet search results are probably as old as the first Internet search. Google competitors Microsoft and Expedia, for example, have long accused the search giant of anticompetitive behavior. Now comes news that the food delivery services GrubHub and Seamless place restaurants that pay them bigger commissions higher in search results without making this fact clear to users.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Sacai Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

abstract: Downloading free apps or other content from Apple’s stores doesn’t require having a credit card on file.

abstract: For-profit hospices are more likely than nonprofits to serve patients in institutions and to exceed Medicare cost limits, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: People who pay attention to hospice care, so often a godsend for the dying and their families, have noticed and wondered about two trends in recent years:

headline: Your Imported Beef Is Served
keywords: ['Beef', 'Meat', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Restaurants', 'Butchers and Butchering']
abstract: Move over Blonde d’Aquitaine, make way for Black Angus.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s easy to spend a lot of money here on a mediocre steak.

headline: ‘12 Years’ Enjoys a Seemingly Narrow Victory
abstract: The Academy Awards finally handed cinema’s most prestigious prize to a movie by a black filmmaker, the British-born Steve McQueen, but the win had all the earmarks of a true squeaker.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood made history on Sunday night — barely.

headline: LSD, Reconsidered for Therapy
keywords: ['LSD (Lysergic Acid Diethylamide)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: In Switzerland, the first controlled trial of the drug in more than 40 years found that it eased anxiety in people nearing the end of their lives.
lead_paragraph: He heard about the drug trial from a friend in Switzerland and decided it was worth volunteering, even if it meant long, painful train journeys from his native Austria and the real possibility of a mental meltdown. He didn’t have much time, after all, and traditional medicine had done nothing to relieve his degenerative spine condition.

headline: How a Lizard Gets Rid of a Suitor
abstract: A study showed that in selecting mates, male dragon lizards preferred females with orange patches on their underbellies, a sign that they were fertile.
lead_paragraph: Female dragon lizards in Australia develop orange patches on their underbellies when they are fertile; the patches disappear only after they lay their eggs.

headline: Far More Than a Lady With a Lamp
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Hospitals', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: How a pioneering nurse remains important long after her death.
lead_paragraph: In medical school, as one of only 10 female students, I ignored Florence Nightingale assiduously. I didn’t want to play any of the roles I thought she modeled for women — obedient wife, caring sister, modest daughter.

headline: Out of Siberian Ice, a Virus Revived
abstract: A team of researchers has found something new, with potential implications for evolutionary theory and health, in permafrost more than 30,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: Siberia fills the heads of scientists with dreams of resurrection. For millions of years, its tundra has gradually turned to permafrost, entombing animals and other organisms in ice. Some of their remains are exquisitely well preserved — so well, in fact, that some scientists have nibbled on the meat of woolly mammoths.

headline: Vanity Fair Oscar party
abstract: Red carpet arrivals at Graydon Carter’s Vanity Fair Oscar after party.
lead_paragraph: Red carpet arrivals at Graydon Carter’s Vanity Fair Oscar after party.

headline: Backstage Beauty Report | Bushy Brows at Giambattista Valli
abstract: The designer’s short, ladylike frocks and coats were complemented full, boyish eyebrows.
lead_paragraph: The makeup artist Val Garland complemented Giambattista Valli’s whimsical frocks and ladylike coats with an everyday beauty look centered on a bushy, boyish eyebrow. She brushed on M.A.C. Brow Set Gel for a darker color and hold, and used an eyebrow pencil to drawn in a stronger arch when necessary. Then right before the models stepped out on the runway, their dewy cheeks were pinched “to get a natural blush coming through,” she explained. The minimal look was fresh-faced overall, or what Garland described as “back to reality.”

headline: Poetry Profiles: Black Ocean
abstract: Carrie Olivia Adams, the poetry editor of Black Ocean, talks about the publisher’s work.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Carrie Olivia Adams, Black Ocean’s poetry editor.

headline: Wimpy Sparrows Welcome Here
abstract: Males of a certain sparrow species will help their neighbors fend off intruders, but only under certain conditions.
lead_paragraph: Male chipping sparrows seem to have a curious motto: Love thy neighbor, as long as he is a weakling.

headline: Heart Problems Linked to Those Born With H.I.V.
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Babies and Infants', 'Heart']
abstract: Even if they are treated early with antiretroviral drugs, children born with the infection were found to be at greater risk.
lead_paragraph: Children born with H.I.V. are more likely to have heart problems later in life, even if they are treated early with antiretroviral drugs, a recent study has found.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Derails the Earnhardt Express
abstract: Kevin Harvick defeats Dale Earnhardt Jr. at Phoenix Sprint Cup event; Kyle Busch wins Nascar Nationwide Series race.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Harvick held off Dale Earnhardt Jr., this year’s Daytona 500 champion, to score the victory on Sunday in the Nascar Sprint Cup event at Phoenix International Raceway. Although it was the first victory for Harvick with his new team, Stewart-Haas, it was the fifth time he had won at the Phoenix oval.

headline: Ukraine’s Impact on the Markets
abstract: Financial experts weigh in on how the crisis in Ukraine will affect the international markets.
lead_paragraph: Financial experts weigh in on how the crisis in Ukraine will affect the international markets.

headline: Out of Uganda, In the Midwest
abstract: In “All Our Names,” the novelist Dinaw Mengestu writes a love story about an African exchange student and the social worker who befriends him.
lead_paragraph: Dinaw Mengestu’s deeply moving new novel, “All Our Names,” takes place in the early 1970s in two worlds that could not be farther apart: a quiet, semirural town named Laurel in the American Midwest, and Kampala, the capital of Uganda, where bright hopes of independence have given way to violence, corruption and brutal government crackdowns. The young African man who transits these two worlds is named Isaac — or at least that is the name on the passport he carries. He has arrived in Laurel with a one-year student visa and is introduced to a social worker named Helen, who is supposed to be “his chaperone into Middle America — his personal tour guide of our town’s shopping malls, grocery stores, banks and bureaucracies.”

headline: Travolta Trips Up and Other High Points
abstract: That was just one of the moments that sent Twitter into overdrive. Pizza, anyone?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – With its high point arguably being a retweeted selfie, the Oscars this year were meme-ready. Yes, you can already insert yourself into that photo, which host Ellen DeGeneres took and which Liza Minnelli didn’t quite make it into. (It was the most shared tweet of all time.)

headline: Strong Starts for Two Broadway Musicals
abstract: “Aladdin” and “Les Misérables” sold well in their first week of previews, while other musicals struggled.
lead_paragraph: Two new Broadway productions, the Disney musical “Aladdin” and the latest revival of “Les Misérables,” got off to strong starts at the box office last week, while several other musicals had a harder time gaining traction, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, the trade group of theater owners and producers.

headline: A Verdict of Murder
abstract: With the help of DNA analysis and a body scan of a mummy, scientists say that they have determined the cause of death of an Inca woman who lived centuries ago.
lead_paragraph: Scientists who have examined the mummy of a young Inca say that her death was most likely a homicide and that it was not because of Chagas disease, the tropical parasitic infection that she had. The 20- to 25-year-old Inca, who lived three to five centuries ago, had massive skull trauma and severe face and frontal skull destruction, the researchers report in PLOS One. They used DNA, tissue and isotope analysis and a full body CT scan to study the mummy.

headline: Ode to Trilobites Lost
abstract: Nigel Hughes, a professor at the University of California, Riverside, sings an ode to a creature long vanished in "Lament for the Passing of the Trilobites."
lead_paragraph: Nigel Hughes, a professor at the University of California, Riverside, sings an ode to a creature long vanished in "Lament for the Passing of the Trilobites."

headline: Finally, Cartman Can Come Out to Play
abstract: South Park: The Stick of Truth, this show’s long-awaited and often delayed video game, arrives on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Since the premiere of “South Park” in 1997, fans of the show have wanted to play a quintessential companion video game. But early licensed attempts were deemed failures by game critics and players and by Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the show’s creators. This time, they say, will be different.

headline: Fairy Tale Ballet, Tailored for Short Attention Spans
abstract: New York Theater Ballet, which consolidates the classics into hourlong productions for children, revived its “Cinderella,” a staple of its repertory since 1991.
lead_paragraph: For all their childlike wonder, most story ballets don’t cater to the average kid’s attention span. With its long-running Once Upon a Ballet Series, New York Theater Ballet consolidates the classics into hourlong productions for the under-10 crowd and puts parents’ minds at ease: Yes, your children will be able to sit through this show. And in inevitable moments of boredom, fidgeting is acceptable.

headline: He Cried Out ‘Black Power,’ Then Left for Africa
abstract: With “Stokely: A Life,” the historian Peniel E. Joseph says he set out to “recover” Stokely Carmichael, who popularized the phrase “black power.”
lead_paragraph: With “Stokely: A Life,” the historian Peniel E. Joseph says he set out to “recover” Stokely Carmichael, the man who popularized the phrase “black power” and led the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, known as SNCC, a man whose diminished historical footprint, Mr. Joseph writes, “impoverishes our understanding of the most important movement in our national history.”

headline: My (Feeble) Attempt at Lucas Till’s Workout
abstract: What is it like to train like a Hollywood action star? Alex French, who wrote about the changing action hero economy, finds out.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, shortly after I began reporting “The Last, Disposable Action Hero,” I drove to an office park in Cherry Hill, N.J., to visit Steve Saunders, who makes his living training pro-football and hockey players at his gym, PowerTrain Sports Institute.

headline: Obama: Russia Broke International Law
abstract: President Obama, speaking at the White House, said Monday that Russia had violated international law in its military intervention in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Obama, speaking at the White House, said Monday that Russia had violated international law in its military intervention in Ukraine.

abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway. Today’s pick: Graphic double-decker platforms.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

abstract: Graydon Carter’s hosts annual bash after the 85th Academy Awards.

headline: The Breast Cancer Racial Gap
abstract: The latest analysis shows that the chance of surviving breast cancer is much greater for white women than for blacks, and the divide is widening.
lead_paragraph: A troubling racial divide in breast cancer mortality continues to widen in most major cities around the country, suggesting that advances in diagnosis and treatment continue to bypass African-American women, according to new research.

headline: Justices Hear Florida Case on Measuring Inmates’ Mental Disabilities
abstract: The Supreme Court debated a case in which the standard I.Q. cutoff of 70 is challenged as too rigid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A majority of the Supreme Court seemed skeptical on Monday of how Florida decides who is eligible to be spared the death penalty on account of intellectual disabilities. The state uses an I.Q. of 70 as a rigid cutoff, and several justices suggested that it should take account of a standard margin of error or consider additional factors.

headline: The Many Faces of Alex Katz
abstract: The 86-year-old New York-based artist fills the Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac Paris Pantin with his signature colorful portraits from the past 45 years.
lead_paragraph: “I always liked faces,” the New York-based artist Alex Katz says. But perhaps none as much as his wife’s, Ada’s, which he has been painting throughout his career that spans almost half a century. His depictions of her are included in the 100-odd pieces that make up the 86-year-old’s new show, “Alex Katz: 45 Years of Portraits; 1969-2014,” which opened yesterday at the Galerie Thaddaeus Ropac Paris Pantin. With a catalog featuring essays on the artist by Adrien Goetz and Suzy Menkes, it will come as no surprise if the fashion flock fills the gallery’s halls during these last few days of Paris Fashion Week.

abstract: Sergey Ponomarev has been covering the unrest in Ukraine since early December for The New York Times, first from Kiev and now from Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Sergey Ponomarev, 33, is a freelance photographer covering the conflict in Ukraine on assignment for The New York Times. He grew up in Moscow and also in Ireland, where his father worked as a journalist for Itar-Tass. He previously worked for The Associated Press. He spoke to James Estrin from Crimea on Sunday evening Eastern time. The conversation has been edited.

headline: When Trilobites Ruled the World
abstract: The remains of trilobites, a diverse group of marine animals much older than dinosaurs, are remarkably well preserved, providing fresh insights of their anatomies and social behavior.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Trilobites may be the archetypal fossils, symbols of an archaic world long swept beneath the ruthless road grader of time. But we should all look so jaunty after half a billion years.

headline: Even Among the Stars, the Corps Stands Out
abstract: This winter season, the true triumph of New York City Ballet lay in the way its corps de ballet danced some works by its co-founder George Balanchine.
lead_paragraph: The true triumph of the New York City Ballet’s winter season lay in no individual performance — exciting though several certainly were — but the way its corps danced some works by its co-founder George Balanchine. It’s not hard to see how Balanchine’s choreography motivates a corps. As the geometries keep shifting, every participant’s role becomes crucial; and everything is so inspiringly dancey. But the corps’ current display of exhilaration is something that has been steadily rising over the last five or six years.

headline: A Violinist and a Pianist Time Travel, Guided by a Virtuoso’s Whims
abstract: The violinist Leonidas Kavakos and the pianist Enrico Pace are performing the complete Beethoven Violin Sonatas in three concerts as part of Carnegie Hall’s Vienna: City of Dreams festival.
lead_paragraph: The cover of a recent Decca recording of the Beethoven Violin Sonatas features a large photo of the violinist Leonidas Kavakos. His name, rendered prominently, overshadows that of his pianist, Enrico Pace, demurely inserted below. It’s a puzzling image, not only because Beethoven scored these works for equal partners but also because, as their recital on Sunday evening at Zankel Hall demonstrated, these musicians are masters of balanced ensemble playing.

headline: New Website for Books at Least a Year Old
abstract: Simon & Schuster created the site, offtheshelf.com, to inform readers about books they may have missed.
lead_paragraph: Simon & Schuster has created a website intended to drive readers to discover books, the publisher said on Monday. The site, offtheshelf.com, includes reviews, interviews and articles about books, focusing on titles that are at least one year old. Carolyn Reidy, chief executive of Simon & Schuster, said in a statement that the website is meant to inform readers about a “book that you may have missed in the often overwhelming number of titles that get published every year.” It features books released by an array of publishers.

headline: A Former Police Diver Claims Other Officers Racially Taunted Him
keywords: ['Diving and Divers', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: An African-American officer says he was taunted about his race for the seven years he spent in the scuba-diving unit of the New York Police Department.
lead_paragraph: As a member of the Police Department’s elite scuba-diving unit, Oscar Smith probed the waterways of New York, his tasks both dramatic and painstaking. He has dived into the water in search of helicopter crash victims, and has sifted through the foot-deep muck at the bottom of the East River, looking for murder weapons thrown from bridges.

headline: Unilever Drops Ad That Angered Some in New Jersey

lead_paragraph: After getting an earful from New Jersey residents over a planned billboard that referred to the state as an armpit, Unilever has announced that it will not use the ad after all.

headline: Making Connections Across the Globe, via Opera

lead_paragraph: I HAVE traveled extensively most of my adult career. When I started my own company, Urban Planet, which develops and distributes mobile education products, my idea was to build a global company, and although I was used to traveling a lot, I missed the detail that to build a global company I would have to travel, well, globally.

lead_paragraph: What, in Newton's name, would make a chain of beads rise and fall like water under pressure?

headline: After Hours | Tears of a Clown
abstract: In a new puppet play, “Hobo Grunt Cycle,” the political is personal.
lead_paragraph: Political puppet theater, of the Bread and Puppet variety, is by its nature not very subtle. What packs a surprising punch out on the street can often feel like getting hammered with the pious and the obvious in a stage setting. That’s a major drawback of “Hobo Grunt Cycle,” a work by the Lone Wolf Tribe founder Kevin Augustine at Dixon Place through March 15, which marries extraordinary life-size puppets and Chaplinesque antics to show how we use soldiers, fighting pit bulls and clowns for our own various gratifications, then kick them to the curb, wounded and forgotten. Augustine, who possesses formidable puppet-making and pantomime talents, is our main hobo clown — a genre, we learn, at the bottom of the clown “chain of command,” well below patrician whiteface and the middle-rank, red-nosed “Auguste.” He is not only forced to become a military fighting machine, trained to shoot and bayonet to kill (the work employs considerable World War I imagery), he also tenderly nurses a badly injured pit bull, another creature raised to fight on command, and even helps a delicate little (puppet) bird convalesce. Amid all this arrive a few theatrically unbearable moments. At one point, we hear two parents, on the other side of a locked door, as they wail for their (puppet) war-vet son, an amputee and PTSD sufferer, who has apparently killed himself in his bedroom. It’s just too much.

headline: Waiting for an Invasion
abstract: As Russia reportedly threatened to take over military installations in Crimea, Ukrainian soldiers prepared for a cold night with an uncertain end.
lead_paragraph: As Russia reportedly threatened to take over military installations in Crimea, Ukrainian soldiers prepared for a cold night with an uncertain end.

lead_paragraph: Usually, physics research starts with a known problem. There are surprises, of course, but they don’t often come from Internet videos, as happened with the case of the mysterious chain fountain.

headline: Carlyle Insiders to Sell Some of Their Stock

lead_paragraph: Executives of the Carlyle Group are preparing to sell shares in the private equity firm for the first time since it went public two years ago.

headline: An 84-Year-Old Ceramist’s New York Moment
abstract: Best known for working with her husband, the California ceramic artist Magdalena Suarez Frimkess steps into the spotlight with a solo show at White Columns.
lead_paragraph: Though Magdalena Suarez Frimkess’s ceramics collaborations with her husband, Michael Frimkess, have drawn a following for many years — they’re in the collections of a number of institutions, including the Museum of Arts and Design and the Smithsonian — the 84-year-old Venice, Calif.-based artist has rarely exhibited her own work. But as her debut New York solo show, opening tonight at White Columns, demonstrates, her talent is as singular as the life she has led.

headline: Frayed Nerves in Crimea as Rumors of War Spread
abstract: Rumor and raw nerves over Russia’s intentions reverberated on Monday throughout Crimea.
lead_paragraph: SEVASTOPOL, Ukraine — Rumors and raw nerves over Russia’s intentions reverberated on Monday throughout Crimea and especially this Black Sea port, where dozens of Ukrainian sailors donned orange construction helmets and draped mattresses over the side of their ship in response to what they feared was a Russian ultimatum to vacate the vessel.

abstract: Russian propaganda says we are split. My country knows different.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — A few days ago a member of the German Green Party came to Lviv. I am a novelist and journalist, as well as a translator in German and Polish, and I sometimes write in those languages. He had read one of my articles, and he asked me to help him understand Ukraine: Too much of the reporting in the German press, he said, was biased by pro-Russian propaganda.

headline: Mr. Ryan’s Small Ideas on Poverty
abstract: A report from the chairman of the House Budget Committee finds flaws with almost every attempt the government has made to relieve poverty and its effects since the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin, the House Budget Committee chairman, has an important role to play within the Republican Party. He provides polished intellectual cover for his party to mow down as many antipoverty programs as it can see. Most Congressional Republicans would love nothing more than to eviscerate programs like Medicaid, Head Start and food stamps. But so as not to appear cruel and uncaring, they need a high-minded excuse to do so.

headline: Putin Can’t Stop

So as he has been throwing his weight around the world, Vladimir Putin has been careful to quote Russian philosophers from the 19th and 20th centuries like Nikolai Berdyaev, Vladimir Solovyov and Ivan Ilyin.

lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Since Saturday, the headquarters of the government of Crimea — an autonomous region of Ukraine — have been occupied by special forces whose uniforms are unmarked but whose identity is a mystery to no one here.

headline: Frustration With Afghanistan

abstract: Despite threats to leave, the United States and NATO may still prefer to keep a residual force.

headline: Biting Words but No Action at Security Council Meeting
abstract: The United Nations Security Council’s emergency meeting was its third in four days on Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — As the Security Council jousted in an emergency session over Russian military action in Ukraine on Monday, Ukraine’s United Nations ambassador sent a three-page letter to every member state, accusing Russian forces of using stun grenades against Ukrainian soldiers, trespassing in Ukrainian airspace and deploying 16,000 troops to the Crimean peninsula.

headline: Fake Outrage in Kentucky
abstract: The frontlines of the country’s biggest Senate race are occupied by spokeswomen competing to be heard.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky may be home to the country’s most closely watched Senate race, but it is no place for loose talk about Nazis. That, at least, is something Kelsey Cooper feels very strongly about. So when Cooper, the spokeswoman for the state’s Republican Party, heard that a supporter of Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democratic candidate, compared the defeat of the incumbent, Mitch McConnell, to the liberation of Europe, the young operative snapped into peak indignation mode. Cooper issued a statement calling it “completely inappropriate” and “appalling.” “That kind of hateful rhetoric,” Cooper said, “has no place in public discourse in our beloved Commonwealth.” She demanded a “heartfelt apology” from Grimes.

headline: From Politics to Advising Microsoft’s Chief, Not Without Noise
abstract: Mark Penn has spent years spinning for politicians. Now his own career is the subject of spin at Microsoft, where he has been named chief strategy officer.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Mark Penn has spent years spinning for politicians in Washington. Now his own career is the subject of spin here at Microsoft, where he has been handed a fresh role under its new chief executive.

headline: Yankees Want No Room for Misinterpretation
abstract: The Yankees were trying to head off communications problems between their Japanese- and English-speaking players early on.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — George Rose, the Yankees’ liaison for all things Japan, handed out yellow boxes containing Living Language kits to all four Japanese players in the Yankees’ camp this week. The idea is to assist the players in their efforts to learn English, a task as challenging as throwing or hitting a baseball.

headline: Celebrity Guests Populate Yankees’ Camp
abstract: Joe Namath, Rex Ryan and Reggie Jackson were just some of the people on hand Monday.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — There was a green hue to the Yankees’ camp Monday, as the Hall of Fame quarterback Joe Namath threw out the first pitch and served as co-manager of the game, alongside Joe Girardi. Also in attendance was Rex Ryan, the Jets’ head coach.

headline: Crackdown Proposed to Prevent Illegal Immigrants From Obtaining Medicare
abstract: In his 2015 budget, President Obama will propose removing illegal immigrants from the Medicare rolls and require citizenship or lawful presence in the country as a condition of getting benefits.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON —  The Obama administration is planning new steps to prevent people in the country illegally from obtaining Medicare after finding that tens of thousands were improperly receiving benefits.

headline: Obama Budget Would Expand Low-Income Tax Break
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Poverty']
abstract: President Obama will propose expanding a tax break for workers who are childless, which the White House estimates will help 13.5 million Americans who hold jobs yet remain poor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama releases his proposed annual budget on Tuesday, he will grab his best opportunity of the year to show, in one comprehensive package of hard numbers and precise detail, how he would have the government address what he has called “the defining challenge of our time” — economic inequality.

headline: When Dad Gets Mad, Learn to Disappear
abstract: A fractious family stages an uncanny disappearing act in “The Open House,” Will Eno’s new play, at Signature Theater.
lead_paragraph: Families have been falling apart on American stages ever since the country’s theater came to maturity back in the early decades of the last century. Fathers alienate sons. Wives excoriate husbands. Generation gaps yawn; alcohol plays the dual role of salve and fuel; lives are irrevocably destroyed.

headline: Spirit of Experiment
abstract: An inspired Tuesday puzzle from Bruce Haight and Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Bifocals, the lightning rod and the odometer. These are just a few of the everyday objects that BENJAMIN FRANKLIN invented when he wasn’t busy with his other hobbies. Like publishing Poor Richard’s Almanac. Or developing the postal service. Or, oh yeah, fostering American independence. Reading his full roster of accomplishments will make you feel like a dolt.

headline: Deal Is Reached on Redevelopment of Brooklyn Sugar Refinery
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The compromise on the redevelopment of the former Domino Sugar plant includes more units of affordable housing and taller buildings.
lead_paragraph: A waterfront-altering redevelopment of the Domino Sugar refinery in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is poised to be approved by the city this week after the de Blasio administration struck a deal Monday to include more affordable housing units in the project.

headline: Noah Syndergaard, Mets’ Prized Prospect, Passes ‘Big Test’
abstract: Syndergaard pitched two scoreless innings in the Mets’ 6-2 victory, striking out two, allowing one single and issuing no walks. His fastball touched 98 miles per hour.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — For a brief moment, as Noah Syndergaard took the mound on Monday for his first Grapefruit League game, his focus was interrupted. He heard Mets fans cheering for him, calling his name, yelling out his nickname: “Thor! Thor!”

headline: Cities Mobilize to Help Those Threatened by Gentrification
keywords: ['Gentrification', 'Property Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: While still eager to have young professionals move to blighted areas, cities are recognizing the toll that rising tax assessments can have on longtime working-class residents.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Cities that have worked for years to attract young professionals who might have once moved to the suburbs are now experimenting with ways to protect a group long deemed expendable — working- and lower-middle class homeowners threatened by gentrification.

headline: Reactions Are Mixed in Canada as Chrysler Bluntly Calls for More Help
abstract: Chrysler, which received a 2.9 billion Canadian dollar bailout in 2009, is again asking for help, but the response has been more divided this time.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Five years after Chrysler received 2.9 billion Canadian dollars from Canada’s government to help it stay in business, the automaker is looking for more help. This time, it is in the form of financial assistance that it says it must have to continue producing minivans and other vehicles in Canada.

headline: Domestic Crude Oil Drives a Cautious Refining Revival
abstract: American refiners are refurbishing old plants or planning new ones to take advantage of new supplies of domestic crude.
lead_paragraph: NIXON, Tex. — Since its construction in 1980, the small hard-luck refinery on the outskirts of this little cattle town has been locked shut for more years than it has been open.

headline: In Yet Another Act, Larry Brown Writes a Winning Script
abstract: After two burnouts in the N.B.A., Brown has led Southern Methodist to a top-25 ranking for the first time since 1985 in his second year there.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — The game was five minutes old. The score was 2-0. Southern Methodist’s point guard, Nic Moore, brought the ball up in transition and quickly launched an unsuccessful 3-point attempt.

headline: Antidote And Encore To a War
abstract: “The Happiest Song Plays Last,” the third in a trilogy of plays by Quiara Alegría Hudes, is a diffuse but warm-blooded drama.
lead_paragraph: Life will probably never again be a matter of “Forward, march” for Elliot (Armando Riesco), the ex-Marine whose life keeps spinning off new challenges and surprises in “The Happiest Song Plays Last,” the third in a trilogy of plays by Quiara Alegría Hudes focusing on Elliot’s search for purpose after returning from duty in Iraq. Moving ahead will also be a matter of zigging and zagging for his cousin Yaz (Lauren Vélez), the music professor who is the other central character in this play and its predecessor, the Pulitzer Prize-winning “Water by the Spoonful.”

headline: Pistorius Murder Trial Starts
abstract: The South African track star Oscar Pistorius pleaded not guilty in Pretoria to murdering his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.
lead_paragraph: The South African track star Oscar Pistorius pleaded not guilty in Pretoria to murdering his girlfriend, Reeva Steenkamp.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 3, 2014

headline: Bill Adler, Author, Editor and Compiler, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Adler collected and published letters children had written to President John F. Kennedy and helped popularize novels written by political, entertainment and sports celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Bill Adler, who pursued his goal of being the P. T. Barnum of books by conceptualizing, writing, editing, compiling and hustling hundreds of them — prompting one magazine to anoint him “the most fevered mind” in publishing — died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 4, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, March 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “We feel the people who toughed it out should be rewarded.”

headline: Selfies, Pizza and Promoting Brands at the Oscars
abstract: Ellen DeGeneres used a Samsung phone, an Oscar sponsor, for a star-studded selfie, but an iPhone to post from backstage. And that Coca-Cola emblazoned pizza delivery box rankled PepsiCo.
lead_paragraph: IN recent years, it appeared that the Academy Awards was becoming increasingly desirable as a marketing platform, perhaps even approaching the biggest day of the year for advertising, the Super Bowl. After the Oscars broadcast on ABC on Sunday night, that now seems self-evident — or should that be selfie-evident?

headline: Federal Prosecutors Looking Closely at Christie Aides, Court Papers Show
abstract: A lawyer for Gov. Chris Christie’s former campaign manager, Bill Stepien, revealed that federal investigators visited Mr. Stepien’s home in New Jersey and questioned his landlord.
lead_paragraph: Court papers filed by a lawyer for Gov. Chris Christie’s former campaign manager indicate that federal prosecutors are moving aggressively to investigate the role of the governor’s aides in the George Washington Bridge lane closing scandal.

headline: Court Says BP’s Spill Agreement Is Binding
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal appeals panel ruled that BP must pay gulf companies for damages without requiring proof of harm by the Deepwater Horizon spill.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In a setback for BP as it deals with the aftermath of the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill, a federal appeals court on Monday ruled that the company would have to stick to its agreement and pay some gulf businesses for economic damage without their having to prove it was caused by the spill.

headline: Corrections: March 4, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 4, 2014
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Leader’s Words Don’t Tell the Real Story
abstract: United States Senator Cory A. Booker talks about his regard for Newark often in speeches, but a corporation he championed pilfered from the city’s coffers right under his nose.
lead_paragraph: United States Senator Cory A. Booker talks of his adopted city of Newark as if it were his very own Wild West. As mayor, he ran toward gunshots “that sounded like cannon fire,” cradled a dying boy whose mouth “foamed red” with blood, and learned as much from a plain-spoken woman in the projects “as from any professor.”

headline: Before Sellout Crowd on Special Night, Nets Return to .500
abstract: Jason Collins entered to a standing ovation and played the last 2 minutes 41 seconds, having little impact on the result but a large influence on the game’s emotional tenor.
lead_paragraph: It was only a few minutes into the game Monday when the fans behind the Nets’ bench began chanting Jason Collins’s name. The chant popped up again periodically, louder each time, late into the night.

headline: Chandler’s Season of Frustration Shows No Letup
abstract: It was more of the same for the Knicks, who lost for the 13th time in their last 15 games, this time at the hands of the Pistons.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — In his quest to resuscitate the Knicks’ dying playoff hopes, Coach Mike Woodson shuffled his starting lineup Monday night before the team faced the Pistons here at the Palace of Auburn Hills. In: Amar’e Stoudemire and J. R. Smith. Out: Iman Shumpert and Pablo Prigioni. “We’re searching,” Woodson said.

headline: Reservoir’s Neighbors Want More Than Return of Their Water Views
abstract: The Jerome Park Reservoir, which has been empty for years, is to be refilled as a water filtration plant nears completion, but it will still be off-limits to the public.
lead_paragraph: For the past five years, the Jerome Park Reservoir — an important link in New York City’s water supply system — has been dry. Residents have missed the radiant blue of the 94-acre basin, not to mention the cooling breeze that comes off it in summer.

headline: In Crimea, Mother Russia Looms Large
abstract: As Ukraine is tugged by the East and the West, many in Crimea welcome Russia’s aggressive stance, hoping Moscow will secure their place in a fractured future.
lead_paragraph: As Ukraine is tugged by the East and the West, many in Crimea welcome Russia’s aggressive stance, hoping Moscow will secure their place in a fractured future.

headline: Variety of Projects Vying for Grants From $19.5 Million Oil Spill Fund
abstract: The first awards from the fund, part of a settlement between ExxonMobil and the state for a spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, are to be announced this week.
lead_paragraph: For decades, oil seeped from the refineries that once occupied parts of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and pooled under nearby homes and businesses, into a plume roughly the expanse of 50 football fields.

headline: U.N. Debates the Breadth of a Mission in the Central African Republic
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, recommended up to 10,000 soldiers, plus 1,820 police officers to protect civilians.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The world is watching: That has been the resounding message of world powers in the face of deadly sectarian strife in the Central African Republic.

headline: Japan: Informal Talks Held With North Korean Envoys
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Diplomats from Japan and North Korea talked for two hours on Monday in an informal meeting that could be a first step toward the reopening of an official dialogue between the countries.
lead_paragraph: Diplomats from Japan and North Korea talked for two hours on Monday in an informal meeting that could be a first step toward the reopening of an official dialogue between the countries. Japan and North Korea do not have formal diplomatic ties and have not held government-to-government talks since late 2012. The diplomats met for two hours in the Chinese city of Shenyang on the sidelines of talks between the Red Cross societies of both nations to discuss the return of the remains of Japanese who died in Korea at the end of World War II. Japanese officials declined to disclose details of the diplomats’ talks, the first since an official dialogue was suspended after North Korea tested a rocket in December 2012.

abstract: A growing number of “protest tourists” in Ukraine. Also on the Minute, new research on military suicides and an advantage of Multiple Sclerosis.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of “protest tourists” in Ukraine. Also on the Minute, new research on military suicides and an advantage of Multiple Sclerosis.

headline: A Conversation With Venture Capitalist Ben Horowitz on the ‘Hard Things’
abstract: An interview with Ben Horowitz, the co-founder and general partner of Andreessen Horowitz, about managing and his new book, “The Hard Thing About Hard Things.”
lead_paragraph: Ben Horowitz is the co-founder and general partner of Andreessen Horowitz, a well-known Silicon Valley venture firm that has invested in Facebook, Foursquare, Box, Jawbone and dozens of highly successful start-ups.

headline: Tax Reform’s Hard-to-Find Payoff
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Much ballyhooed tax reform legislation generally makes little difference to the economy, and the most recent proposal is unlikely to change that, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

abstract: This word has appeared in 38 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: indeterminate •\ˌin-di-ˈtərm-nət, -ˈtər-mə-\• adjective

headline: Familiar Questions at 3rd Trial in Killing of Psychologist
abstract: Lawyers for David Tarloff argued again that he was too delusional to understand his actions when he fatally stabbed Kathryn Faughey in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after his most recent trial ended in a hung jury, a schizophrenic man accused of killing a psychologist on the Upper East Side went on trial a third time on Monday, and the opening arguments underscored what again will probably be the central question: When David Tarloff committed murder, was he sane enough to know right from wrong?

headline: In Job, Appointee Profits and Christie Gains Power
abstract: Since Gov. Chris Christie named David Samson to lead the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the governor’s power has grown and Mr. Samson’s law firm has prospered.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Chris Christie pushed to expand financial incentives to keep businesses in New Jersey, one of the first companies to benefit was a client of David Samson, a lawyer with a long and close relationship to the governor.

headline: United Nations Secretary General’s Report Recommending a Peacekeeping Mission to the Central African Republic
abstract: The secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Monday issued his recommendations: up to 10,000 soldiers, plus 1,820 police officers to protect civilians from armed militias, along with a civilian team to rebuild the state machinery, practically from scratch.
lead_paragraph: The secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, on Monday issued his recommendations: up to 10,000 soldiers, plus 1,820 police officers to protect civilians from armed militias, along with a civilian team to rebuild the state machinery, practically from scratch.

headline: In Honduras, Going From Door to Door to Prosecutors
abstract: In Honduras, a nonprofit group investigates crime where the police force and criminal justice system cannot or will not.
lead_paragraph: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — The only way Andy Díaz could find a witness to a murder was to pick up a Bible. Mr. Díaz, a private investigator, posed as a Christian evangelist and spent a month knocking on the doors of hillside shacks with only a rumor and a description to guide him.

headline: Don Singleton, 77, Dies; Daily News Reporter Examined Corruption
abstract: Mr. Singleton, who worked for The Daily News in New York for four decades, wrote about gamblers and tax evaders as well as corruption in the Fire Department and its unions.
lead_paragraph: Don Singleton, a former reporter whose byline was familiar to readers of The Daily News in New York for four decades, often on investigative articles that examined corruption in high places, died on Sunday in Hoboken, N.J. He was 77.

headline: Justin Kaplan, Prize-Winning Literary Biographer, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Kaplan was a biographer of Mark Twain, Walt Whitman and Lincoln Steffens, and an editor of Bartlett’s Familiar Quotations.
lead_paragraph: Justin Kaplan, a Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer renowned for his lives of Mark Twain, Walt Whitman and Lincoln Steffens, and who was later known as the editor of Bartlett’s Familiar Quotations — a job akin to running the admissions committee of the most selective college in the world — died on Sunday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.

headline: Rikers Island Guards Are Found Not Guilty in Prisoner Assault Case
keywords: ['Guards', 'Assaults', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The trial of Louis Pinto Jr. and Kevin Gilkes escalated tensions between the city and the correction officers’ union.
lead_paragraph: Two Rikers Island guards accused of assaulting a prisoner and covering up their actions were found not guilty Monday on all charges, after a trial that escalated tensions between the city and the correction officers’ union.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13) STEVE MARTIN AND THE STEEP CANYON RANGERS FEATURING EDIE BRICKELL IN CONCERT Mr. Martin, above, with Ms. Brickell, shows off his lightning-fast fingers and quips in this “Great Performances” presentation, taped last fall in Riverside, Calif. The playlist features works from “Love Has Come for You,” his album with Ms. Brickell; “Rare Bird Alert,” his collaboration with the Steep Canyon Rangers; and his Grammy-winning recording, “The Crow: New Songs for the Five-String Banjo.”

headline: After Prodding, U.S. State Department Labels Kunming Attack ‘Terrorism’
abstract: Questioned by reporters, a State Department spokeswoman, Jen Psaki, called the deadly attack in Kunming a terrorist attack, after the Chinese state news media accused overseas news agencies of failing to do so.
lead_paragraph: After the killing of 29 people by knife-wielding attackers in a Kunming train station Saturday, articles in the Chinese state news media accused overseas news agencies of failing to label the attack as terrorism. There was also criticism of some foreign governments who were said to have failed, or been slow, to label violent attacks in China as terrorism, when they might do so quickly at home.

headline: Graffiti Artists in Srinagar Aim to Go Beyond Vandalism
abstract: The young men who secretly paint on the city’s walls focus less on bashing India and more on the daily problems plaguing Kashmiri society.
lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — When Ali gets ready to paint, he puts on a mask, an occupational necessity, and not just because of the fumes from the spray can.

headline: Q. & A.: Albert Ho on Democracy and Civil Disobedience in Hong Kong
abstract: The pro-democracy legislator and lawyer says that he and many others are ready to go to jail in protest should China set conditions on who can run for chief executive of Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s government buildings have flown the Chinese flag since 1997, but the territory is governed separately from the mainland, retaining a legal system inherited from the British and a wide range of civil liberties. One of those liberties, freedom of assembly, may be on display later this year. Advocates for popular elections of Hong Kong’s top leader — the chief executive — plan sit-in demonstrations in the heart of the city, one of the world’s most important financial hubs, should China’s national legislature set conditions that limit voters’ choices.

headline: Assailing U.S. and Kiev, Putin Keeps Open Option of Force
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia described events in Ukraine as an unconstitutional coup, expressed contempt toward the United States and called any potential use of military force “a last resort.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia broke his silence over the Ukraine crisis on Tuesday for the first time since it boiled over, asserting that he saw no reason for his forces to intervene but leaving open the possibility of military action if Russian speakers in the country’s south and east are endangered.

abstract: Stripping away the usual hot colors of the Caribbean, Pablo Delano has captured Trinidad’s Carnival culture at its essence.
lead_paragraph: As a photographer who teaches at Trinity College, perhaps Pablo Delano was fated to go to Trinidad.

abstract: What experiences have shaped who you are as a person?

headline: Michelle Obama to Stress Education on China Trip

lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama, the American first lady, will travel to China this month for a visit that will focus on “the power and importance of education” and include a meeting with Peng Liyuan, the wife of President Xi Jinping of China, the White House has  said.

headline: Markets Rebound on Hopes of Tension Easing in Ukraine
abstract: The Russian benchmark index gained 5 percent on Tuesday after a 10.8 percent decline the day before, and stock markets elsewhere made up lost ground.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Global markets calmed on Tuesday on hopes of a cooling of tensions between Russia and Ukraine, helping stocks recover some of their losses from a sell-off on Monday.

headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills 2 Palestinians in Gaza
abstract: A spokesman for the Israel Defense Forces said the strike eliminated a “real-time threat” from a group that was preparing to launch rockets into southern Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli airstrike killed two Palestinian men in the Gaza Strip and wounded two children on Monday evening, according to the Israeli military and Palestinian health officials, continuing the increased violence between Israel and Gaza this year.

headline: Ethan Stiefel to Leave Royal New Zealand Ballet
abstract: Mr. Stiefel became the director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Ethan Stiefel, the former American Ballet Theater principal dancer who became the artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet in 2011, has announced that he will leave his post on Sept. 1, the company announced on Tuesday. In a statement on the company’s website, Mr. Stiefel cited both personal and professional reasons for leaving, saying that he had found it difficult to be far from family and friends, and that the distance made it hard for him to pursue other professional projects.

headline: New York Today: Colder Than Montana
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: another frigid day, a peek in the attic of Gracie Mansion, and a chance to sling hot dogs at Nathan’s.
lead_paragraph: Good Tuesday morning to you.

headline: Daily Report: Mixed Responses at Microsoft to Rise of New Strategy Chief
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Mark Penn has spent years spinning for politicians. Now his own career is the subject of spin at Microsoft, where he has been named chief strategy officer.
lead_paragraph: Mark Penn has spent years spinning for politicians in Washington. Now his own career is the subject of spin here at Microsoft, where he has been handed a fresh role under its new chief executive, Nick Wingfield reports from Seattle.

headline: Mixcloud: A Streaming Service for Mixtape Lovers
abstract: Have a friend with great taste who used to make music mixes for you? A London company has moved to New York with a service that makes those mixtapes digital.
lead_paragraph: Music streaming services are great when you know exactly which songs or albums you want to hear. But for people who have always been a bit more inclined to make or listen to mixtapes, those services tend to come up short.

headline: What I Learned (the Hard Way) About Outsourcing
keywords: ['Engineering and Engineers', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Outsourcing', 'Small Business', 'Start-ups']
abstract: The founder of a tech company has tried almost every form of outsourcing, with results ranging from catastrophic to exceptional.
lead_paragraph: Many businesses outsource work to other countries. But outsourcing can be scary. How do you know you’re not going to be ripped off, with a job that will return half-baked or not at all?

headline: Indian Cricket Team’s Problems Boil Down to Bowling, Experts Say
abstract: India’s recent emotional loss against Pakistan comes on the heels of series defeats against South Africa and New Zealand, but cricket analysts say it’s too early to write the team off.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Cricket contests between India and Pakistan are always an emotional affair, and it was no different on Sunday in Mirpur, Bangladesh, when the two sides met during the Asia Cup.

headline: Kerry Takes Offer of Aid to Ukraine and Pushes Back at Russian Claims
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Kiev with an offer of $1 billion in American loan guarantees and pledges of technical assistance.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In a demonstration of support for Ukraine’s fledgling government and a new swipe at Russia, Secretary of State John Kerry visited Kiev on Tuesday with an offer of $1 billion in an American loan guarantee and pledges of technical assistance.

headline: Crimean Premier Says Ukrainian Military Units Have Started to Surrender
abstract: The prime minister of the autonomous region, Sergei Aksyonov, said most Ukrainian military units on the peninsula had pledged allegiance to his pro-Russia government.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — The prime minister of Crimea, the autonomous Ukrainian republic seized by Russian military forces, said Tuesday that most Ukrainian military units on the Crimean Peninsula had surrendered and pledged allegiance to his pro-Russian government, and that local officials were working to speed up a referendum on independence from Ukraine.

headline: A Calming of Global Markets
abstract: Market tensions ease after Russia appears to back away from further action in Ukraine. | A Citigroup affiliate in Los Angeles receives a federal subpoena. | A small-business owner continues his battle against U.S. Bancorp. | Men’s Wearhouse and Jos. A. Bank reach a nondisclosure accord, paving the way for a merger.
lead_paragraph: GLOBAL MARKETS RISE AFTER UKRAINE TENSIONS COOL  |  Global markets calmed on Tuesday after Russia appeared to back away from further action in Ukraine, with President Vladimir V. Putin calling an end to a military exercise he ordered last week. The crisis in Ukraine had caused turmoil in the global financial markets on Monday, hitting stocks and driving up energy prices. Analysts maintained that there was little risk of damage to Western economies, but the rising tension nevertheless unsettled investors, who were already concerned about emerging markets, David Jolly writes in The New York Times.

headline: Physician, Review Thyself
abstract: Yelp and others involved in online reviewing say medical professionals are increasingly being caught faking customer reviews.
lead_paragraph: So you’re on the road and suddenly have this horrible pain in your lower middle. In the old days, your hotel would have a doctor, but those went the way of elevator operators. Your options now are the emergency room or an urgent care clinic.

headline: Republican Hypocrisy on the Minimum Wage
abstract: Republicans say they don’t want to raise the minimum wage because we have to preserve jobs. But they don’t seem to care about jobs when they’re cutting food stamps or unemployment benefits.
lead_paragraph: There are no good economic arguments against raising the federal minimum wage.

headline: Flimflam, The Next Generation
abstract: Assertions and evidence, unrelated.
lead_paragraph: I took Paul Ryan’s measure almost four years ago, back when everyone in Washington was determined to see him as the Serious, Honest Conservative they knew had to exist somewhere. Everything we’ve seen of him since then has confirmed that initial judgment. When you see a big report from Ryan, you shouldn’t ask “Is this a con job?” but instead skip right to “Where’s the con?”

headline: RadioShack Posts $400 Million Loss for 2013 and Plans to Close 1,100 Stores
abstract: The electronics retailer reported a loss of $191.4 million for the fourth quarter of 2013, compared with a loss of $63.3 million a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: RadioShack said on Tuesday that it would close about 1,100 of its stores in the United States, as losses piled up during a dismal holiday shopping season.

headline: Wheelies: The Corvette Resurrection Edition
abstract: The National Corvette Museum began rescuing the eight cars swallowed by a sinkhole last month; the E.P.A. issues rules for sulfur levels in gasoline.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Busch Will Try an Indy-Nascar Doubleheader
abstract: Kurt Busch, 35, hopes to become the fourth driver, but the first in 10 years, to try the doubleheader: the Indy 500 in the day on May 25 and the Coca-Cola 600 in North Carolina at night.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since 2004, a driver will try the single-day feat of racing in the Indianapolis 500 and the Coca-Cola 600.

headline: Park Hyatt Flagship Is Set for New York
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Pritzker Prize', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Park Hyatt New York, the brand’s flagship property, is scheduled to open this summer.
lead_paragraph: Park Hyatt New York, the flagship property of the Park Hyatt brand, is opening this summer in the One57 skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan near Carnegie Hall.

headline: Cevian Capital Increases Its Stake in ThyssenKrupp
abstract: The activist investment firm Cevian Capital has been gradually increasing its position in the troubled German conglomerate ThyssenKrupp.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Cevian Capital, an activist investment firm, said on Tuesday that it had increased its stake in the German conglomerate ThyssenKrupp to more than 15 percent from 11 percent last year.

headline: Apple Says Its Chief of Finance Will Retire
abstract: The executive, Peter Oppenheimer, will be replaced by Luca Maestri, a vice president at the company.
lead_paragraph: Peter Oppenheimer, Apple’s senior vice president and chief financial officer, plans to retire in September, after an 18-year career at the technology giant.

headline: Herszenhorn on the Latest in Crimea
abstract: The New York Times' David Herszenhorn reports on the latest in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times' David Herszenhorn reports on the latest in Crimea.

headline: What’s It Like Reading ‘Peyton Place’ Today?
abstract: Grace Metalious, whose “Peyton Place” was a publishing sensation, died 50 years ago. Thomas Mallon and Anna Holmes talk about how the novel holds up today.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and Anna Holmes discuss what it’s like reading “Peyton Place” today, 50 years after the death of its author, Grace Metalious.

headline: Steve McQueen on ’12 Years a Slave’
abstract: The director spoke with Melena Ryzik of The Times on the red carpet before the Oscars, where his film was named best picture of the year.
lead_paragraph: The director spoke with Melena Ryzik of The Times on the red carpet before the Oscars, where his film was named best picture of the year.

headline: A Wide-Ranging Season at Kennedy Center
abstract: The 2014-15 season at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts will have several international offerings.
lead_paragraph: Something for everyone is how the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington could describe its 2014-2015 season of 2,000 performances from September to August.

headline: Final Rules, and a Warning, on Banker Bonuses in Europe
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Executive Compensation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The European Commission has adopted final rules for limits on banker bonuses, and a top official warned banks against pushing too far in trying to “circumvent remuneration rules.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The European Commission adopted rules on Tuesday that finalize the details for limits on banker bonuses, and a top official cautioned against efforts that have cropped up to circumvent the new restrictions.

headline: A Genetic Entrepreneur Sets His Sights on Aging and Death
abstract: J. Craig Venter says his new company, Human Longevity, will focus on figuring out how people can live longer and healthier lives and will be the world’s largest human DNA sequencing operation.
lead_paragraph: J. Craig Venter is the latest wealthy entrepreneur to think he can cheat aging and death. And he hopes to do so by resorting to his first love: sequencing genomes.

headline: Paris Fall 2014: Elements | Shape
abstract: A thematic visual diary of Paris Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.
lead_paragraph: A thematic visual diary of Paris Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: Learning the Rules of the Preschool Application Game
abstract: In the world of elite Manhattan preschool applications, you have to find a way to play the game without letting the results matter too much — to you, or to your child.
lead_paragraph: Talk! I silently signaled to my 2-year-old from across the classroom. At home, Zee was a sophisticated chatterbox, impressing friends with run-on sentences and words like “bougainvillea.” But at this distinguished preschool complete with ceramics atelier, science lab and dance program, she plopped herself in the doll corner, plunking babies in strollers. At least show curiosity, I noiselessly begged. Go to the Play-Doh.

headline: Chanel’s Supermarket Chic
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld transformed the Grand Palais in Paris into a supermarket to present his autumn/winter 2014 ready-to-wear collection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Not since Marie Antoinette played milk maid on her farm at Versailles has there been such a conjunction of high and low. But this time the milk — like everything else in the supermarket — was marked with the double C’s of Chanel.

headline: For the Moderate Thirst (or Budget)
abstract: Mini-cocktails, known by some as shorts, are offered at a few bars in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: If you like wine but aren’t feeling up to a whole glass, a number of New York wine bars (including the Terroir chain) sell half-servings. If you thirst for beer but want to try a few different brews without emptying your wallet and clouding your brain, half-pints are common at many beer halls including, yes, the Half Pint in Greenwich Village.
