And if you are curious about an unfamiliar brand of whiskey, you can buy one-ounce pours in places like Char. No. 4 in Brooklyn and St. Andrews Restaurant and Bar in Midtown.

headline: Obama’s Budget Is a Populist Wish List and an Election Blueprint
abstract: President Obama called for ending tax breaks to pay for new spending, instead of cutting the budget, but Republicans are unlikely to go along.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama sent Congress a $3.9 trillion budget request on Tuesday that stands as a platform for Democrats to run on in this election year, full of policies intended to invite contrasts with Republicans rather than offer compromises as he did last year, without success.

headline: WWS 594, Economics of the Welfare State: Fighting Poverty
abstract: In praise of Mollie Orshansky.
lead_paragraph: Slides for tonight here (pdf)

headline: Will We Be Calling It the ‘12 Years’ Effect?
abstract: If the Academy’s efforts to diversify are slow, they are speeding up connections between filmmakers like John Ridley and Ryan Coogler.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – “Never listen to me.”

headline: Immelt Spends His Cash Bonus on G.E. Stock
abstract: Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, bought about 105,000 shares on Tuesday for a little more than $2.6 million, according to a company filing.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey R. Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, says he spent his whole 2013 cash bonus on G.E. stock.

headline: In Performance: Mark Padmore
abstract: In a video, the tenor Mark Padmore performs the prologue from Britten’s “Billy Budd.”
lead_paragraph: The tenor Mark Padmore, who performed recently with the Berlin Philharmonic in a new staging of Bach’s “St. John Passion,” was in New York just weeks ago, portraying Captain Vere in a production of Britten’s “Billy Budd” from Glyndebourne Festival Opera at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Here, Mr. Padmore performs the prologue from “Billy Budd.”

headline: Times Minute | How to Edit DNA
abstract: A new enzyme that can conceivably fix genetic mutations. Also on the Minute, the standoff in Ukraine's Crimean region and a plan by several American cities to help those threatened by gentrification.
lead_paragraph: A new enzyme that can conceivably fix genetic mutations. Also on the Minute, the standoff in Ukraine's Crimean region and a plan by several American cities to help those threatened by gentrification.

headline: Egyptian General Moves to Formalize Presidential Bid
abstract: “I cannot turn my back when the majority wants me to run for president,” Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi said, saying he would finalize procedures soon.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Field Marshal Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi edged closer on Tuesday to formalizing his all-but-declared candidacy for president, telling a military academy audience that “procedures will be finalized over the coming days.”

headline: Chanel’s Super Shopper Sneakers
abstract: Supermarket shelves stocked with the brand’s own food and cleaning products set the scene for the designer’s fall/winter 2014 collection.
lead_paragraph: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.

headline: Times Minute | How to Edit DNA
abstract: A new enzyme that can conceivably fix genetic mutations. Also on the Minute, the standoff in Ukraine’s Crimean region and a plan by several American cities to help those threatened by gentrification.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Saint Laurent’s Teen Spirit
abstract: Hedi Slimane has long brought a bit of bad girl attitude to the Parisian fashion house. He does so even more convincingly for the fall/winter collection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — At Saint Laurent, the designer Hedi Slimane became one of the first to drag fashion across the screen and take it downtown. Even when the clothes in his winter 2009 show were tailored and smartened up, the models acted like young women with a “don’t care” attitude.

headline: Image of the Day: March 4
abstract: Women in a village in Gujarat sorting out red chillies to dry.

headline: Big Victory for Chevron Over Claims in Ecuador
abstract: The oil company had sued a Manhattan lawyer leading the pollution case and his associates on fraud and conspiracy allegations.
lead_paragraph: Since losing a $19 billion judgment in an Ecuadorean court three years ago, Chevron has drawn the condemnation of human rights and environmental activists by refusing to pay anything in fines or accept blame for polluting the Ecuadorean rain forest.

headline: Syria Speeds Its Deliveries of Chemicals for Disposal
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons said that Syria delivered two consignments of chemical weapons last week and that another significant shipment was expected this week.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Syrian government, which missed its original Dec. 31 deadline for shipping its most toxic chemical weapons overseas for destruction, has sped up deliveries recently and has proposed finishing the job by the end of April, the international group monitoring the process reported on Tuesday.

headline: Model-Morphosis | Josephine van Delden at Valentino
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Josephine van Delden (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: St. Louis Symphony’s Music Director Extends Contract
abstract: David Robertson has extended his contract as the music director of the St. Louis Symphony through the 2017-18 season, the orchestra announced Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: David Robertson has extended his contract as the music director of the St. Louis Symphony through the 2017-18 season, the orchestra announced on Tuesday.

headline: Putin’s First Remarks on Ukraine Crisis
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin, in his first comments since the crisis in Ukraine boiled over, said on Tuesday that Russia reserved the right to use all means in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin, in his first comments since the crisis in Ukraine boiled over, said on Tuesday that Russia reserved the right to use all means in Ukraine.

headline: Travel’s Photo Feed
abstract: Exploring the globe through the lens of recent Travel photography.
lead_paragraph: Exploring the globe through the lens of recent Travel photography.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces First Round of Programming
abstract: New films about Susan Sontag, New York City Ballet and the fashion brand Christian Dior are among the competition film announced for the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Films about Susan Sontag, New York City Ballet and the artistic director of Christian Dior are among the works in competition at the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced Tuesday. The world narrative and documentary competition categories will include 12 films each, while 22 films will be featured out of competition in the Viewpoints series.

headline: Huffington Post Business and Global News Editor Is Leaving for International Business Times
abstract: Peter Goodman was named the editor in chief of International Business Times on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Peter S. Goodman, the executive business editor and global news editor of The Huffington Post, is leaving the website to become editor in chief of International Business Times.

headline: Culture Lab Detroit to Focus on Regenerative Design
abstract: A group of outside designers and artists will conduct classes and portfolio reviews with locals in April.
lead_paragraph: Culture Lab Detroit, which began last year as a program to recruit well-known designers and artists to collaborate with their peers in Detroit, announced a series of events for its second year, which will feature the British architect David Adjaye; the Chicago artist and community activist Theaster Gates; and the Brazilian designers Fernando and Humberto Campana.

headline: Celeste E Verde
abstract: Maryam Nassie Zadeh collaborated with the independent filmmaker Alexa Karolinski to create a short about Zadeh’s latest makeup collection.
lead_paragraph: Maryam Nassie Zadeh collaborated with the independent filmmaker Alexa Karolinski to create a short about Zadeh’s latest makeup collection.

headline: Is Breast-Feeding Really Better?
abstract: A new study suggests that many of the long-term benefits attributed to breast-feeding may be an effect not of breast-feeding or breast milk itself but of the general good health and prosperity of women who breast-feed.
lead_paragraph: Many women who are unable to breast-feed feel guilty about it and worry they may be depriving their children of a range of benefits. Groups like the American Academy of Pediatrics and the World Health Organization recommend six months of exclusive breast-feeding for all infants, citing studies that show breast milk is easily digestible and has nutrients that are superior to or absent from infant formulas, including immunological substances that reduce rates of infection and fatty acids important in brain development.

headline: Putin’s First Remarks on Crisis
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in his first comments since the Ukrainian crisis escalated, said on Tuesday that Russia reserves the right to use all means necessary in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in his first comments since the Ukrainian crisis escalated, said on Tuesday that Russia reserves the right to use all means necessary in Ukraine.

headline: British Official’s Arrest a Blow to Cameron Government
abstract: The arrest of an aide to Prime Minister David Cameron, who has been accused of cronyism, raises new questions about his appointees.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The arrest of a British government aide accused of possessing “child abuse imagery” has dealt a blow to Prime Minister David Cameron, who has already faced criticism over his choice of advisers.

headline: Valentino: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Steven Ballmer Reflects on Missteps and Ponders the Future of Microsoft
abstract: Speaking to students at the University of Oxford, the former Microsoft chief executive tempered his usual theatrics with a discussion of what Microsoft did right and wrong during his tenure.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England –- A month after stepping down as Microsoft’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer hasn’t lost any of his energy.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Smaller Army
abstract: William D. Hartung of the Center for International Policy calls for a debate on the kind of armed forces we need to face 21st-century threats. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Now Facebook Has a Drone Plan
abstract: Facebook is in discussions to acquire a manufacturer of high-altitude drones for about $60 million. The purchase would allow the social network to advance its ambitions of connecting everyone in the world to the Internet.
lead_paragraph: With all his talk of better data compression and more efficient phone chips, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has had a bit of trouble getting people excited about Internet.org, his ambitious plan to get everyone in the world onto the Internet.

headline: Where There’s Smoke, There’s Scrutiny
abstract: While a combination of Reynolds American and Lorillard may make strategic and financial sense, antitrust and other watchdogs could still act as spoilers, Kevin Allison writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The tobacco giant Reynolds American may be considering a bid for its smaller rival Lorillard, apparently to investors’ pleasure. Shares of the possible target, which specializes in menthol cigarettes, leaped more than 9 percent after The Financial Times indicated that Lorillard might attract an offer of more than $20 billion.

headline: Geneva, Day 1
abstract: Jerry Garrett takes a look at some highlights of the first day of press previews at the Geneva Motor Show.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Garrett takes a look at some highlights of the first day of press previews at the Geneva Motor Show.

headline: Today in Small Business: Kitchen Incubators
abstract: What to ask a potential buyer of your business. And entrepreneurs to follow on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

headline: Anna's Espresso
abstract: Anna Agovino has been making espresso in the Morris Park section of the Bronx for 14 years. She describes the drink as her “gasoline.”
lead_paragraph: Anna Agovino has been making espresso in the Morris Park section of the Bronx for 14 years. She describes the drink as her “gasoline.”

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Chanel Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Espresso’s Disciples Worship Here
abstract: A barista with a magic wrist tends the faithful in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: You can travel to La Casa del Caffe, on Morris Park Avenue in the Bronx, and try to coax Anna Agovino into spilling some of the secrets behind making a perfect cup of coffee. She will shoot you that Fellini-worthy smile of hers, and she’ll be patient with your questions. For a minute or two.

headline: Gunmen Kill 7 in Attack on Iraqi Government Building
abstract: The attack in Samarra, north of Baghdad, left 35 people wounded and five assailants dead in a two-hour battle with police.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Gunmen wearing suicide belts raided a local government building in Samarra on Tuesday, killing four government employees and three police officers in a two-hour battle with security forces, Iraqi officials said. Four of the gunmen died in the fighting, and a fifth blew himself up inside the building, the officials said.

headline: Injections Providing Protection Against AIDS in Monkeys, Studies Find
abstract: Versions of already approved drugs kept the monkeys infection-free for weeks, and researchers hope that a dose every three months could work in humans.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Researchers are reporting that injections of long-lasting AIDS drugs protected monkeys for weeks against infection, a finding that could lead to a major breakthrough in preventing the disease in humans.

headline: Apple’s New CarPlay Is Almost a Step in the Right Direction
abstract: CarPlay system brings voice control, an iOS-like interface, maps and messaging into certain cars.
lead_paragraph: Apple this week announced Apple CarPlay, a new system for integrating an iPhone into certain cars. This is not the first time Apple has tried its hand at in-car integration, and while I’m not interested in a proprietary car, it’s a good step toward a driving future I am interested in: one where you bring your own phone into your car’s dashboard for mapping, messaging, voice controls and more.

headline: Apple’s Departing Finance Chief Is Goldman’s Newest Director
abstract: With his newly announced role at Goldman Sachs, Peter Oppenheimer, who plans to retire as Apple’s finance chief in September, deepens the longstanding ties between the investment bank and the technology giant.
lead_paragraph: The newest member of Goldman Sachs’s board will soon have some free time on his hands, after he leaves his job as the chief financial officer of Apple.

headline: California Driver’s License Program Hits an Unexpected Hurdle
abstract: Some immigrants who are in the country illegally are reluctant to apply for the licenses, fearing that the government might use the documentation to establish their identities and deport them.
lead_paragraph: BELL, Calif. — The auditorium was packed. There were single mothers, day laborers, grandparents pushing infants in strollers and teenagers interpreting for parents. All of them faced a potentially life-changing prospect: Within a year, California will start offering driver’s licenses to immigrants who are living in the country illegally.

headline: Confrontation in Crimea
abstract: At the Belbek military installation in Crimea on Tuesday, Ukrainian soldiers refused to surrender to Russian troops and instead marched, unarmed, to confront them in the face of warning shots.
lead_paragraph: At the Belbek military installation in Crimea on Tuesday, Ukrainian soldiers refused to surrender to Russian troops and instead marched, unarmed, to confront them in the face of warning shots.

headline: Some Who Fled Cuba Are Returning to Help
abstract: Some members of the first Cuban families to leave after Fidel Castro took over are coming back, reuniting with the island and partnering with Cubans in direct new ways.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — The business ideas have ranged from a bikini franchise to a peanut farm, restaurants, and design firms for software and home interiors. But even more novel than the pitches — in a country where entrepreneurship used to be illegal — is the financial muscle behind them: Cuban-Americans whose families lost their previous ventures to Cuba’s Communist government.

headline: Martin Amis and Lydia Davis on the Bill for PEN World Voices Festival
abstract: The 10th PEN World Voices Festival in New York will include more than 100 writers and artists from 30 countries.
lead_paragraph: The British novelist Martin Amis, the American short story writer Lydia Davis, the former Polish dissident journalist Adam Michnik, the Iranian artist Shirin Neshat, and the Syrian poet Adonis will be among the more than 100 writers and artists from 30 countries that will gather in New York for the 10th annual PEN World Voices Festival.

headline: Obama’s Calculations on the Deficit and Debt
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The White House budget proposal points to smaller deficits fueled by increased taxes and reduced spending, along with the presumption of solid economic growth.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, the Obama administration released an interesting if dead-on-arrival 2015 budget. The big message is that the White House wants to bolster support for the poor and middle class, paying for such measures with increased taxes on high-income households.

headline: Moelis & Company Files for an I.P.O.
abstract: Moelis & Company filed for an initial public offering on Tuesday, a move that would make it one of a handful of independent investment banks that trade on the public stock markets.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:57 p.m. | Since leaving UBS in 2007, the veteran investment banker Kenneth D. Moelis has dreamed of running a firm that could rival his former employer.

headline: U.S. Seeking to Keep ‘Potentially Inflammatory Topics’ Out of Terrorism Trial
abstract: As jury selection continues in the trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, Osama bin Laden’s son-in-law, the government asked the judge to bar the defense from referring to topics such as national security.
lead_paragraph: In the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, who prosecutors say was a top adviser to Osama bin Laden, the specter of the Sept. 11 attacks has naturally loomed heavily during jury selection, which resumed on Tuesday morning.

headline: A Downtown Fashion Sage Turns Her Eye to Makeup
abstract: The designer and retailer Maryam Nassir Zadeh collaborates with the emerging beauty label MAKE on a vivid range of spring colors.
lead_paragraph: Through her Lower East Side store, her eponymous clothing line and her styling work, Maryam Nassir Zadeh has built a cult following by curating clothing and accessories in vivid, unusual color combinations. Now, she’s lending her creative prowess to the one-year-old cosmetics label Make for a rich new assortment of spring makeup shades inspired by Antonioni’s 1964 Technicolor film, “Red Desert.” Zadeh is part of a larger artist collaboration project set forth by Make, which has also commissioned the furniture designer Faye Toogood and the photographer/filmmaker Erik Madigan Heck to create palettes. In Zadeh’s case, her collection, called “Celeste e Verde,” was not only realized through color, but also through the medium of film.

headline: Kerry Condemns Russian Action in Crimea
abstract: Speaking in Kiev on Tuesday, Secretary of State John Kerry also defended Ukraine’s fledgling government.
lead_paragraph: Speaking in Kiev on Tuesday, Secretary of State John Kerry also defended Ukraine’s fledgling government.

headline: Obama Responds to Putin's Comments
abstract: President Obama reacted to Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s earlier statements on the situation in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Obama reacted to Russian President Vladimir V. Putin’s earlier statements on the situation in Ukraine.

headline: Orpheus Chamber Orchestra to Debut New Works at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The orchestra will present new works by Timothy Andres, Anna Clyne and Fazil Say, and play a series of concertos with prominent soloists.
lead_paragraph: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra will debut works by Timothy Andres, Anna Clyne and Fazil Say, and play concertos with prominent soloists, over the course of four concerts next season at Carnegie Hall, the orchestra announced on Tuesday.

headline: Convoy With NATO Supplies Is Attacked in Pakistan
abstract: A government official said that one driver was killed and two others were wounded when gunmen opened fire in the Khyber tribal region on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Gunmen in the Khyber tribal region in Pakistan, which borders Afghanistan, opened fire Tuesday on a two-truck convoy carrying NATO supplies, killing one driver and wounding two others, a government official said.

headline: Life Lived on Flip Side of Sports Page
abstract: In “His Ownself: A Semi-Memoir,” the sportswriter Dan Jenkins recounts in anecdotes a busy, lucky and friend-filled existence, despite views for which he makes no apology.
lead_paragraph: Dan Jenkins has been among America’s best and funniest sportswriters for more than six decades, writing for Sports Illustrated and then Golf Digest. But he’s best known to many as the author of “Semi-Tough” (1972), a shaggy novel about professional football that became a movie starring Burt Reynolds and Kris Kristofferson.

headline: The Gun Report: March 4, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Baptist Convention is leading so-called Second Amendment Celebrations, in which churches around the state give out guns as door prizes to lure new devotees. The goal is to “point people to Christ,” the church said. Its own spokesperson calls it “outreach to rednecks.”

headline: Obama Unveils Budget
abstract: President Obama unveiled his $4 trillion budget for the 2015 fiscal year, which proposed tax credits for the working poor and increased spending for early-childhood education.
lead_paragraph: President Obama unveiled his $4 trillion budget for the 2015 fiscal year, which proposed tax credits for the working poor and increased spending for early-childhood education.

headline: The Real Poverty Trap
abstract: It’s not Ryan’s hammock.
lead_paragraph: Earlier I noted that the new Ryan poverty report makes some big claims about the poverty trap, and cites a lot of research — but the research doesn’t actually support the claims. It occurs to me, however, that the whole Ryan approach is false in a deeper sense as well.

headline: ‘Wait Wait’ Tells Us: Carl Kasell Is Stepping Down
abstract: The Official Judge and Scorekeeper of the radio show will continue to handle the prizes: custom voicemail greetings.
lead_paragraph: Carl Kasell, the longtime National Public Radio morning newscaster who found an improbable second career as Official Judge and Scorekeeper of the call-in comedy quiz show “Wait Wait … Don’t Tell Me!,” will step down from the show sometime in the spring, the network said Tuesday.

headline: Notes for a History Lesson
abstract: The Ensemble ACJW played works by Georg Friedrich Haas, Mozart and Schoenberg on Friday as part of Carnegie Hall’s Vienna: City of Dreams festival.
lead_paragraph: Vienna: City of Dreams, Carnegie Hall’s three-week, citywide festival, is aiming for the broadest possible representation of Viennese music and, to some extent, Viennese culture in general. As a small part of the festival (small, at least, in contrast to the Vienna State Opera’s concert performance of Berg’s “Wozzeck,” which was taking place at the same time in Carnegie’s Stern Auditorium), the concert of the Ensemble ACJW on Friday in Weill Recital Hall offered a fascinating cross-section of the city’s incomparable musical history.

headline: Cuomo Vows to Defend Charter Schools, Setting Up Another Battle With de Blasio
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, at a rally in Albany, offered a sharply different vision for charter schools than Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has vowed to slow the growth of such schools.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, standing shoulder to shoulder in Albany with thousands of parents and students who rallied in support of charter schools, vowed on Tuesday to defend the movement and offered a sharply different vision for their place in the educational system than Mayor Bill de Blasio’s.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Stella McCartney Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Eating Lionfish, Green Tea Cookies, Bread From She Wolf Bakery and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of March 4.
lead_paragraph: To Catch: Eating This Fish Will Save Other Fish

headline: ‘Baby Jeep’ Introduced in Geneva
abstract: Jeep says its compact, Fiat-based Renegade is “designed in America and built in Italy.”
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Jeep introduced its Renegade subcompact sport utility vehicle here Tuesday on the opening day of press previews for the 84th Geneva Motor Show. Information about the new “baby Jeep” had been leaked Sunday on the Internet, and multiple media outlets followed suit and posted photos and details about the model on Monday.

headline: The First Important New Record of 2014
abstract: The first very important record of the year is “Atlas,” by Real Estate.
lead_paragraph: In the days before a new album was released practically every second, March was the month when the rollout of the year’s major music releases would start. So in that spirit, and to accompany the resurgence of vinyl (even Target is selling it now), here is the first Very Important Record of 2014 (with apologies to Pharrell Williams): “Atlas,” the third album by Real Estate.

headline: Unexpected Africa: Investigating New Ways to Think About the Continent
abstract: In this lesson, we seek to challenge preconceptions with articles that offer new perspectives and defy stereotypes. From poverty and war to arts and entertainment, the world’s second largest continent is far more complex than it may seem.
lead_paragraph: What do you think of when you hear the word “Africa”? In this lesson, we seek to challenge preconceptions with articles that offer new perspectives and defy stereotypes. From poverty and war to arts and entertainment, the world’s second largest continent is far more complex than it may seem — or than front-page headlines may reveal.

headline: Deal Between Dish and Disney Seen as a Win for Both
abstract: The long-term agreement ends fighting over a controversial ad-skipping feature and includes advances in how digital television rights are handled.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Media analysts and investors on Tuesday cheered a newly signed accord between the Walt Disney Company and Dish, the nation’s No. 3 pay-TV provider, that ends fighting over a controversial ad-skipping feature and includes advances in how digital television rights are handled.

headline: Apple’s CarPlay Captivates the Auto Industry
abstract: CarPlay links an Apple 5, 5c or 5s iPhone with the car’s infotainment system, letting the car use Apple’s apps.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Ferraris are fast on the road, and they are no slouch when it comes to electronic gadgetry, apparently. The automaker says it is first to the market with CarPlay, Apple’s new control system for in-car infotainment.

headline: A New Chef at Le Cirque
abstract: Raphael Francois joins a long and impressive line of chefs who have brought luster to the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Obama Discusses Budget for 2015
abstract: The president unveiled his $4 trillion budget for the 2015 fiscal year, which proposes tax credits for the working poor.
lead_paragraph: The president unveiled his $4 trillion budget for the 2015 fiscal year, which proposes tax credits for the working poor.

headline: Shops and Sweets in Portland, Ore.
abstract: The West End neighborhood has produced a wave of boutiques and dining spots that exemplify the city’s youthful, eclectic spirit.
lead_paragraph: Nestled just west of Portland’s downtown and south of its popular Pearl District, the West End began transforming from vacant lots and decaying buildings into the city’s hottest new neighborhood with the arrival of the hip Ace Hotel on Southwest Stark Street in 2007. Coupled with an explosion of food carts around the corner on 10th Avenue (not to mention Powell’s Books’ mammoth flagship store holding court less than two blocks away), the West End has produced a wave of boutique shops and trendy dining spots that exemplify the city’s youthful, eclectic spirit.

headline: In Search of the ‘Real Africa’ in Mozambique
abstract: Friendly prices — and people — greeted the Frugal Traveler on a visit to the country’s chaotic but manageable coastal capital.
lead_paragraph: I assumed it was luck that within two minutes of clearing customs in Maputo, I found myself sharing a cab with Darcio Arsénio Novela (stage name Mr. Arssen), one of Mozambique’s top hip-hop personalities. And that he gave me his cellphone number, and a rundown of the top cultural hot spots in town. And that we went out that night for beers with his friends at Núcleo de Arte, a bar and fine-arts work space, and that the next night he texted me about an event at the Mozambique-Germany Cultural Center — even though he wouldn’t be making it himself.

headline: Crisis in Ukraine Threatens Russia as Market for Auto Sales Growth
abstract: Relief about an incipient recovery of the European auto market was clouded by larger economic worries stemming from the crisis in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — This year’s Geneva car show should have been the most upbeat in years. But among auto executives who gathered here on Tuesday, relief about an incipient recovery in the European auto market was clouded by the crisis in Ukraine and the fear that Russia might no longer serve as the source of sales growth it had in the recent past.

headline: Richard Gere Not the Only Star at the Bedford Post Inn
abstract: Michael White’s Altamarea Group will take over the food and beverage service at the inn.
lead_paragraph: Westchester County is becoming a magnet for marquee chefs. Michael White’s Altamarea Group, which owns Ristorante Morini, Costata and others in Manhattan, will take over the food and beverage service of the Bedford Post Inn, a Relais & Chateaux property in Bedford, N.Y., owned by Richard Gere and Russell Hernandez.

headline: Five Theses on Ukraine
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The implications of Vladimir Putin’s Crimean adventure.
lead_paragraph: 1) It probably wasn’t rhetorically helpful, but John Kerry was entirely correct when he called Vladimir Putin’s quasi-invasion of Ukraine the work of “somebody who is acting out of weakness.” Putin’s aggression doesn’t undermine anything I wrote a week ago about the limits of Russian power and the essential implausibility of the Kremlin’s grand ambitions; this gambit is a salvage operation following a major political setback, not a plausible stepping-stone toward some sweeping long-term objective. The echoes of earlier Russian aggressions are real, but the comparison to Czechoslovakia in 1968 and Hungary in 1956 should be illuminating: In those cases, Russia was projecting power well beyond its borders, and using force to keep a relatively-vast sphere of influence intact, whereas in this case it’s projecting power … in the Russian-speaking regions of a former Soviet republic/czarist province. You can make the case that Putin is playing as well as he can with a losing hand, or you can make the case that he’s out of touch with reality and stumbling into an epic disaster. But either way, what we’re witnessing isn’t the re-emergence of Russia as a major geopolitical threat to the United States and our allies, unless by “major geopolitical threat” you mean “weakened ex-empire struggling to control its own periphery.”

headline: U.S. Activist Says Egyptian Police Assaulted Her
abstract: Medea Benjamin, a leader of the Code Pink protest group, said she was assaulted by the authorities while she was trying to travel to Gaza.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Medea Benjamin, a co-founder of the American protest group Code Pink, which opposes United States military actions, said Tuesday that she had been detained in the Cairo airport and assaulted by the Egyptian police while trying to travel to Gaza for a meeting opposing Israeli incursions and restrictions there.

headline: Bright Young Things
abstract: A limited-edition collection of handmade and affordable sunglasses from the new Swedish company Sun Buddies will arrive at Dover Street Market next month.
lead_paragraph: “Sun Buddies sounds like something crappy you’d find at Walmart, but it’s quite the opposite,” says Hannes Hogeman, the 33-year-old Swedish owner of the new quirky-chic line of sunglasses that he founded with his younger brother Simon. An outgrowth of their hyper-cool boutique Très Bien, Sun Buddies employs handmade techniques to mold and finish their acetate frames and sources lenses from master Carl Zeiss Vision, with the hope of becoming an affordable alternative to iconic brands like Persol and Moscot. A limited-edition collection, created in partnership with Dover Street Market, will be available next month.

headline: Guggenheim Poaches Tech Banker from Evercore
abstract: Eric Mandl, who specialized in cloud computing and big data deals at Evercore, jumped to Guggenheim Securities on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Eric Mandl, one of Evercore’s most productive technology bankers, jumped to Guggenheim Securities on Tuesday.

headline: Why Must the News Be So Newsy?
abstract: Alain de Botton talked about his latest book, “The News: A User’s Manual,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Juxtaposing photos from a celebrity gossip tabloid and a newspaper, the writer Alain de Botton, speaking at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Monday night, said that “the tension between Taylor Swift’s legs and the Arctic melt is not just a journalistic problem, it’s a problem for our society.”

headline: Brazilian Rhythms, With Hip-Hop Moves
abstract: Companhia Urbana de Dança, a Brazilian dance troupe composed of young people, is so wonderful that it seems miraculous.
lead_paragraph: Companhia Urbana de Dança sounds like a bad idea. It is a Brazilian dance troupe composed of young people, mostly men of African descent, mostly from the favelas, or slums, of Rio. But it is led and choreographed by Sonia Destri Lie, a white woman not from the favelas. She is trained in ballet and American and European contemporary dance, yet the works are based in hip-hop, somehow refined. Exploitation, condescension: Pitfalls abound.

headline: Organization Help for Turning Phone Photos Into Albums
abstract: There are several apps, mostly free, to organize the numerous photos on your phone.
lead_paragraph: THEY say the best camera is the one you have with you. Nowadays, that’s probably your cellphone’s camera.

headline: App Smart: Organizing Photos
abstract: The Times’s Kit Eaton examines three apps that can help you sort your many cellphone pictures into digital albums.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Kit Eaton examines three apps that can help you sort your many cellphone pictures into digital albums.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
abstract: Russia and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Russia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: In Butler’s Trying Season, a Coaching Link to Past Success
abstract: Brandon Miller, a former player and assistant at Butler, is 12-16 as head coach there after taking over for Brad Stevens, who reached two national finals before leaving to coach the Celtics.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Soon after Butler Coach Todd Lickliter was named Division I coach of the year in 2007, he left to take over Iowa’s program. The university’s athletic director, Barry Collier, in need of a replacement, settled on a Butler assistant named Brad Stevens, a 30-year-old with no previous head coaching experience.

headline: The Ratings, the Ads, the Backstage Emotions
abstract: Host Ellen DeGeneres recorded a 6.4 increase over the previous year, among other news.
lead_paragraph: The Oscars have been handed out, but there’s still news trickling in:

headline: A Miami Congressman Adamantly Defends Isolating Cuba
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Cuban-Americans', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Representative Mario Díaz-Balart says American policy toward Cuba should focus on human rights, not on using private enterprise to move Cuba away from dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: As more Cuban-Americans find ways to engage with Cuba — through travel, helping families with new businesses, and now business training — they have increasingly come into conflict with Cuban-American lawmakers who insist that isolation, through the United States trade embargo, is the best and only acceptable approach when dealing with Cuba.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Russia, Ukraine, Spain and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Russia, Ukraine, Spain and France.

headline: E-Cigarettes, by Other Names, Lure Young and Worry Experts
abstract: Products virtually identical to e-cigarettes are known by names like e-hookahs or vaping pens, thwarting efforts by health officials to track their use, especially among young people.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Olivia Zacks, 17, recently took a drag of peach-flavored vapor from a device that most people would call an e-cigarette.

headline: A Rapper Whittling Down, in His Waist and Elsewhere
abstract: The rapper Rick Ross retreats a bit from his maximalist peak in his new album, “Mastermind.”
lead_paragraph: Rick Ross came out on the Best Buy Theater stage on Monday night somewhere in the past — the 2010-11 era, specifically. That was the moment of his greatest triumph, when he made songs that sounded like gladiator calls, when the fictions he had written to transform himself into one of hip-hop’s kingpins were beginning to breathe life.

headline: In Newark Airport Lounge, Israeli Art
abstract: “Art & Lounge” at Newark Liberty International Airport is a gallery displaying the work of Israeli artists, and a place where kosher food is served.
lead_paragraph: A new lounge at Newark Liberty International Airport is providing an artistic – -and kosher — respite for travelers to Israel who might be looking for more than just free Wi-Fi and contemporary furniture while they wait.

headline: Slurp Worthy: The Top 10 Ramen Destinations in New York
abstract: A list of New York’s most delicious ramens.
lead_paragraph: The ramen belt, once tightly buckled around the East Village, now loops from Fort Lee, N.J., to Queens and Brooklyn. Following are my picks for New York’s most delicious ramens, ranked in descending order. All outlets are open for lunch and dinner unless otherwise noted.

headline: City at Halfpipe King’s Feet
abstract: Leaving behind paparazzi in Zurich, Iouri Podladtchikov, the Olympic gold medalist known as I-Pod, recently visited Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Leaving behind the paparazzi and requests from eager sponsors in Zurich, Iouri Podladtchikov, who is known as I-Pod, recently spent a few days in New York. Even though he upset Shaun White to win the men’s halfpipe in snowboarding at the Sochi Games last month, he was able to glide through the streets of Manhattan in anonymity.

headline: Ramen’s Big Splash
abstract: Hunting down the best, as New Yorkers bend to the noodle’s late-night lure.
lead_paragraph: The first rule of the serious ramen hunter: look everywhere, even in places that don’t look like ramen shops. This is how, in January, I found myself inhaling noodles at a cluster of tables shoved into the center of a bagel shop in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: It’s Harder to Age in Hollywood. Where Is It Harder to Raise Kids?
abstract: Hollywood makes going to extremes to maintain even the false illusion of a youthful face seem natural. Do some parts of the country push us to similar extremes when it comes to raising families?
lead_paragraph: It has been hard for Oscar watchers to let go of the sight of Kim Novak, puffed and padded into a pseudo-youthful effigy of an 81-year-old woman. As Amanda Hess wrote on Slate’s XXFactor blog, Hollywood is a “horrible” place to be an old woman. It’s not just Hollywood — a few years ago, Dominique Browning wrote of her cohort: “We’ve reached a stage where cosmetic surgery is so readily available that in certain circles it is expected of women and men to avail themselves of these age-deniers. If you choose not to partake of the benefits of needle and knife, you are judged to be making a statement. You are taking a position against the current standards of beauty.”

headline: Financial Regulator Calls Obama Budget ‘Woefully Insufficient’
keywords: ['Commodities', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Bart Chilton, a commissioner on the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, said President Obama’s $280 million request for the agency in the next fiscal year was inadequate for the agency’s expanded mission.
lead_paragraph: The country’s top derivatives regulator is making clear that it is unhappy with President Obama’s 2015 budget proposal.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Paris Fall/Winter 2014 Women’s Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what gals are wearing this season.

headline: L.B.J., Civil Rights and Dramatic License
abstract: Thousands may leave the theater believing that Johnson weakened the Civil Rights Act’s voting provisions.
lead_paragraph: “All the Way,” the hit play about Lyndon B. Johnson’s first year in office that’s now in previews on Broadway, revels in the historical details of Washington politics, with large chunks of dialogue taken directly from the Congressional Record and Johnson’s voluminous phone transcripts.

headline: Basquiat Estate Sues Christie’s, Saying Some Works For Sale May Not Be Real
abstract: The estate of the artist Jean-Michel Basquiat sued Christie’s, saying the auction house was selling works as Basquiats without sufficient evidence.
lead_paragraph: Two sisters of the artist Jean-Michel Basquiat filed a $1 million lawsuit against Christie’s on Tuesday, accusing the auction house of trying to sell possibly fake Basquiats and falsely suggesting that they had been authenticated by his estate.

headline: Silk Road, Shut Down in Fall, Had Digital Outpost in Pennsylvania
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A staff member of Lafayette College in Pennsylvania played a small role in the investigation that resulted in the shutdown of Silk Road, the online marketplace where drugs and weapons could be bought with Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: A staff member in the electrical engineering department of a liberal arts college in eastern Pennsylvania played a small role in the investigation that resulted in the shutdown last fall of Silk Road, the online marketplace where drugs and weapons could be bought with Bitcoin.

headline: At Disney, a Celebration That Was a Long Time Coming
abstract: Walt Disney Animation won its first animated-feature Oscar on Sunday for “Frozen,” and with it a new lease on life after a difficult transition to computer-aided filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — The gathering at Walt Disney Animation here was supposed to be a giddy celebration. The studio had achieved the ultimate validation for its hard-fought creative rebirth: “Frozen,” its Nordic tale of two sisters and a wisecracking snowman, won two Oscars on Sunday, the same day the film crossed $1 billion at the global box office.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: In Indianapolis, a Bike Path to Progress
abstract: The Indianapolis Cultural Trail, unveiled last May, has drawn visitors and helped spark a sluggish local economy.
lead_paragraph: For an old car town, Indianapolis has been doing a lot for biking lately. A new eight-mile landscaped bike and pedestrian pathway is helping residents rediscover their city and reshaping how outsiders view it. The trail is putting Indianapolis on the map as a place to see bold innovation, along with the Colts and some car races in a town long known as an international racing capital, home to the Indy 500 and the Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

headline: A Heavy Bass Beat, a Wreath of Smoke, an Aura of Sweat
abstract: This film creates a piece of social and sexual history by reshooting segments of the 1980 film “Cruising” that were lost after being cut.
lead_paragraph: The man in the black leather vest looks nervous. All around him, glistening half-naked men dance to the disco beat as smoke curls in the air. They writhe, touch and kiss, skin against skin, leather against leather. A guy in chaps pauses and locks his eyes on our nervous man. Here, looking is cruising, an overt exchange of desire: It’s about watching and waiting, and being conspicuously out of the closet and the thrilling promise of something more. Then the scene stops and the actors wait as James Franco and Travis Mathews, the directors choreographing this bacchanalia, plot their next move.

headline: Street Stops Still a ‘Basic Tool,’ Bratton Says
abstract: The New York police commissioner, William J. Bratton, told a business group that the department would focus on fighting low-level crime, citing the “broken windows” theory of policing.
lead_paragraph: The New York police commissioner, William J. Bratton, said on Tuesday that the practice of stopping people for questioning on the street would “remain a very basic tool” of his department and that he intended for his officers to aggressively enforce the law against low-level offenders to ensure that public places feel safe.

headline: Punch, Crunch and Plié
abstract: Classes combine moves used in Pilates, boxing and dance. Pilates purists do not approve.
lead_paragraph: During a recent fitness class at the Flatiron branch of the New York Health & Racquet Club, 20-odd women wearing pink one-pound weighted gloves did rounds of uppercuts, side jabs and fancy footwork before slowing down for pliés and leg lifts.

headline: A Young Composer in a Swirl of Life, Love and, Finally, Disillusionment
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s ballet “Lost Illusions,” performed by the Bolshoi in Moscow and being screened at a Manhattan movie theater, adapts Balzac’s novel of the same title.
lead_paragraph: The enigma of the internationally prestigious and prolific choreographer Alexei Ratmansky continues. Most of his works show you that he has the finest mind among creators of ballet today. Seldom, however, do they show this consistently.

headline: Thinking Outside the Borders
abstract: The band La Santa Cecilia, children of immigrants who began as buskers in downtown Los Angeles, has somehow become a strong voice for immigration reform.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They began as buskers on downtown Olvera Street here, immigrant and working-class Latino kids singing “Besame Mucho” and “Sabor a Mí” for tourists. So when the members of the band La Santa Cecilia took to the stage of the Staples Center five weeks ago to receive the Grammy Award for best Latin rock or alternative recording, they had come a lot further than just a couple of miles.

headline: Bragging Rights for St. Albans, Queens
abstract: Covering three square miles with a population of about 34,900, St. Albans was once home to luminaries including Babe Ruth and Ella Fitzgerald.
lead_paragraph: Given the list of gifted public figures who once called it home, St. Albans has bragging rights, even by New York standards. But beyond their role as window dressing, these long-gone luminaries — among them Ella Fitzgerald, Count Basie, John Coltrane and Lena Horne — have helped provide a sense of communal identity.

headline: Netanyahu Warns Against Iran at Aipac
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel urged world powers to prohibit Iran from enriching uranium.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel urged world powers to prohibit Iran from enriching uranium.

headline: To Scientists in Pursuit, a Bit of Matter Is No Small Matter
abstract: “Particle Fever” is a Mark Levinson documentary that goes into detail about the Higgs boson particle and the structure of the universe.
lead_paragraph: A description of “Particle Fever” — Mark Levinson’s mind-blowing new documentary — must grapple with some issues of scale. This is a modest, compact movie about the largest imaginable subject: the structure of the cosmos.

headline: N.S.A. Director Says Snowden Leaks Hamper Efforts Against Cyberattacks
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Gen. Keith B. Alexander said the disclosures by Edward J. Snowden had slowed the push to protect the country against attacks on civilian targets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gen. Keith B. Alexander, the director of the National Security Agency, said Tuesday that the leaks by the former agency contractor Edward J. Snowden had slowed the effort to protect the country against cyberattacks on Wall Street and other civilian targets.

headline: This Is About Killing Much More Than Kenny
abstract: While there have been other “South Park”-themed video games, South Park: The Stick of Truth is the first to be written and voiced by the TV show’s creators.
lead_paragraph: By the standards of efforts by Trey Parker and Matt Stone to bring the comedy they have perfected for 17 seasons on television to new mediums, South Park: The Stick of Truth is a disappointment.

headline: Repurposing Closed Hospitals as For-Profit Medical Malls
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: While the new use removes blight, restores health care services and creates jobs, critics worry these facilities are no substitute for the hospitals they’ve replaced.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey has been losing hospitals for more than two decades; 26 have closed in that time, many in poor, urban neighborhoods that are left with an empty shell where a hospital once stood.

headline: Cruising the History of Biker Jackets
abstract: At the Museum at New York’s Fashion Institute of Technology, graduate students explore the life of fashion’s most rebellious article of clothing.
lead_paragraph: Opening today at the Museum at F.I.T., the exhibition “Beyond Rebellion: Fashioning the Biker Jacket” explores the utilitarian genesis of the biker jacket and its evolution into a high-fashion garment. Its outlaw mystique is traced through time while displaying designer interpretations from the likes of Jean Paul Gautier and Yves Saint Laurent.

headline: Tax Program Aims to Reverse Decades-Long Decline in Allentown
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Enterprise Zones', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Aided by public dollars, developers are offering more than 600,000 square feet of new office and retail space at attractive rents in the center of the Pennsylvania city.
lead_paragraph: ALLENTOWN, Pa. — More than 600,000 square feet of office and retail space is being built in the long-depressed center of this city, spurred by an unusual state-sanctioned project that permits revenues from tenants’ tax bills to be used to pay down some of the debt incurred during construction.

headline: When the Battle Is Over, What Remains Is ... Art
abstract: When the dust settles from the Oscar slugfest, an opportunity opens for ruminations on work and sacrifice.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Never listen to me.”

headline: ‘The Man I Am, the Man I’m Not, the Man I Want To Be’
abstract: David Hilliard’s multipanel images are “visual possibilities of what could be,” while exploring his masculinity through his subjects.
lead_paragraph: David Hilliard’s multipanel images are “visual possibilities of what could be,” while exploring his masculinity through his subjects.

headline: Justices Unite on Key Point in Chase Ending in Fatal Police Shooting
abstract: The Supreme Court seemed to have little trouble concluding that Arkansas police officers who had used deadly force to end a car chase could not be sued by the family of the driver.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court seemed to have little trouble concluding during an unusually one-sided argument on Tuesday that Arkansas police officers who had used deadly force to end a high-speed car chase could not be sued by the family of the driver.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: Recent Sale

headline: In Change, Tourre Won’t Be Teaching University of Chicago Course
abstract: The former Goldman Sachs trader had been scheduled to teach an undergraduate course on economic analysis beginning March 31. But a University of Chicago spokesman said on Tuesday that he would no longer be an instructor.
lead_paragraph: The University of Chicago may have had a change of heart about Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader who was found liable of securities fraud last year.

headline: A New Form of Shareholder Activism Gains Momentum
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Court battles over appraisal rights can be risky and expensive, but they also have benefits for hedge funds with a lot of money, Steven Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The aftermath of the Dole Food management buyout is showing that the new, new thing on Wall Street is appraisal rights. The battle being waged by hedge funds over appraisal rights in the Dole buyout just may be the tipping point, as hundreds of millions of dollars flow to the funds to pursue these actions.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: 100 Days
abstract: Counting down day by day to the start of the 2014 World Cup with news and tidbits from around the world.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Comcast Indefinitely Extends Low-Cost Broadband for Poor Families
abstract: Comcast, which is preparing to ask federal regulators to approve its proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable, said Tuesday it would continue a program that gives low-cost broadband service and computers to poor families and give $1 million in neighborhood grants to support digital literacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – Comcast, which is preparing to ask federal regulators to approve its proposed takeover of Time Warner Cable, said Tuesday it would extend indefinitely its program that provides low-cost broadband service and computers to poor families and give $1 million in neighborhood grants to support digital literacy.

headline: Inside the Brothels
abstract: Seven unforgettable stories in the battle against sex trafficking, collected over two decades of reporting. Curated by Nicholas Kristof.
lead_paragraph: Seven unforgettable stories in the battle against sex trafficking, collected over two decades of reporting. Curated by Nicholas Kristof.

headline: Cyberattacks Rise as Ukraine Crisis Spills to Internet
abstract: Security experts say that they are currently witnessing unusually large denial-of-service attacks directed at both pro-Western and pro-Russian Ukrainian news sites.
lead_paragraph: The crisis in Ukraine has spread to the Internet, where hackers from both sides are launching large cyberattacks against opposing news organizations.

headline: The Writer Behind @GSElevator Speaks Out
abstract: Remaining anonymous as he posted on Twitter under the handle @GSElevator was simply a “device” that allowed him to paint a broader picture of life on Wall Street, John LeFevre said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Remaining anonymous as he posted on Twitter under the handle @GSElevator was simply a “device,” John LeFevre said on Tuesday, that allowed him to paint a broader picture of life on Wall Street.

headline: Karen Mulligan of Pret-à-Surf’s Whirlwind Oscars Week
abstract: The surf wear designer (and studio manager to the photographer Annie Leibovitz) shares tales of a glamorous week in L.A.
lead_paragraph: When they’re not designing their New York-based beachwear label Pret-à-Surf, Karen Mulligan and Jillian Demling are busy with their high-powered 9-to-5s (Mulligan is the studio manager for the photographer Annie Leibovitz; Demling is an editor at Vogue). Last week, on the occasion of Taschen’s release of Leibovitz’s self-titled book, Mulligan had the chance to hit some Oscars-week festivities in high style.

headline: Sherwin B. Nuland, Author of ‘How We Die,’ Is Dead at 83
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Dr. Nuland’s book, which won the National Book Award in 1994, depicted death as messy and often humiliating, and it urged readers to approach late-life care with tempered expectations.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sherwin B. Nuland, a surgeon and author who drew on more than 35 years in medicine and a childhood buffeted by illness in writing “How We Die,” an award-winning book that sought to dispel the notion of death with dignity and fueled a national conversation about end-of-life decisions, died on Monday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 83.

headline: G.M.’s Barra Promises to Investigate How Recall Was Handled
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Mary T. Barra, General Motors’ C.E.O., announced she was leading the company’s recall of 1.6 million vehicles to fix defective ignition switches.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors’ chief executive, Mary T. Barra, told employees on Tuesday that she had personally taken charge of the company’s recall of 1.6 million vehicles to fix defective ignition switches.

headline: Examining the Options for Ukraine
abstract: Readers offer various ideas for dealing with the crisis.

headline: Morning Show for Weather Channel
abstract: The Weather Channel is adding a morning news show called “AMHQ With Sam Champion,” a program that advertisers suggested the company create to give the network regularly scheduled programming.
lead_paragraph: AS the Weather Channel continues to add regularly scheduled programming to its lineup — like a flagship morning show with news, sports and entertainment reports as well as a documentary series devoted to investigative journalism on subjects like homelessness and climate-change denial — Madison Avenue might be prompted to ask, “Whither the weather?”

headline: How We Diagnose and Treat A.D.H.D.
abstract: Readers discuss the rising rate of A.D.H.D. diagnoses.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mark Willis
abstract: Mr. Willis is the chief executive of Keller Williams Realty, a real estate brokerage firm based in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Willis, 52, is the chief executive of Keller Williams Realty, a real estate brokerage firm based in Austin, Tex. The company has about 700 franchise offices with more than 95,000 agents worldwide, including Keller Williams New York City, which opened in April 2011.

headline: How to Define ‘Fair Use’
abstract: A lawyer discusses legal issues surrounding the use of copyrighted art.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Chrysler Backtracks on Asking Canada for More Cash
abstract: In a surprise move, the automaker, which had insisted it needed help to continue minivan production in Ontario, dropped the request, leaving supporters and critics wondering.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — After widespread criticism of its demand linking continued minivan production in Canada to more government assistance, Chrysler unexpectedly withdrew its request on Tuesday. The automaker said that it would go ahead with significant investments in two Canadian factories without financial aid.

headline: Effort to Honor Eliot Ness in Nation’s Capital Finds Trouble in Chicago
keywords: ['Organized Crime', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Three senators have suggested naming a federal building after the Prohibition-era federal agent, but some Chicago officials say he doesn’t deserve it.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The bootleg-busting exploits of Eliot Ness, an incorruptible federal agent often credited with taking down the mobster Al Capone in the 1930s, have been immortalized in a book, “The Untouchables,” and a television show and movie by the same name.

headline: Kentucky Law Official Will Not Defend Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Jack Conway, the attorney general of Kentucky, became the latest in a group of Democratic state prosecutors to refuse to defend laws prohibiting gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Steven L. Beshear of Kentucky said on Tuesday that the state would hire an outside lawyer to defend a same-sex marriage ban after a fellow Democrat, the state attorney general, declined to do so.

headline: Annemijn Dijs Transforms Backstage at Alexander McQueen
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Fall 2014 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Annemijn Dijs (left) and after (right) makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Guido Palau.

headline: Chaos at Home, but Ukraine Arrives to Play U.S.
abstract: Until Tuesday, with the crisis unfolding in Crimea, it was not clear that the United States team would have an opponent to face when it landed in Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: LARNACA, Cyprus — When the plane carrying the United States men’s soccer team touched down Tuesday in Cyprus for an exhibition against Ukraine on Wednesday, it was not even certain that the Americans would have an opponent to face. Then they spotted an Air Ukraine jet on the tarmac at Larnaca Airport. That was at least a good sign.

headline: Knicks Can’t Win, Even if They Play to Lose
abstract: Because they owe their first-round draft pick to the Denver Nuggets, the Knicks cannot even benefit from additional losses that would set them up for a favorable draft position.
lead_paragraph: Joel Embiid and Andrew Wiggins, the star Kansas players who are likely to be two of the first three picks in the 2014 draft, are from Cameroon and Canada, respectively. Jabari Parker, a Duke freshman standout who is also likely to go in the top three, grew up in Chicago. How the Knicks play over the remaining 21 games of the season will probably determine whether one of them ends up in Denver.

headline: Are Alt Weeklies Over?
abstract: Independent newspapers still have a role to play in urban life.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — WHEN the Baltimore Sun Media Group recently announced that it was buying the Baltimore City Paper, the local alternative weekly where I work as an editor, the prognosis for aggressive, independent journalism in Baltimore was pretty grim. Tom Scocca, a reporter who used to work at City Paper, declared that the city was now one step closer to being a “zero newspaper town.”

headline: Time to Try Compassion, Not Censure, for Families
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Income Inequality', 'Poverty', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Parenting', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: If an objective is to help poor children and young people achieve better lives, it may be time to stop trying to reshape families into a platonic ideal.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years ago, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, assistant secretary of labor for President Lyndon B. Johnson, noted that nearly a quarter of African-American children were born to single mothers and proposed that this “deterioration of the Negro family” was “at the heart of the deterioration of the fabric of Negro society.”

headline: Effort to Decriminalize Small Amounts of Marijuana Gains in District of Columbia
abstract: The proposal, which attracted broad support on the City Council, is aimed at better regulating use of the drug and reducing penalties that disproportionately punish black residents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — District of Columbia lawmakers voted on Tuesday to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of marijuana, in what advocates of more lenient marijuana laws hope is another step toward legalizing the drug outright.

headline: Emerging, but No Longer a Mother Lode of Profits
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: Multinational corporations that crowed for years about their presence in booming emerging markets are now blaming turmoil in those regions for dents in their bottom lines.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to investing in emerging markets, few companies have been as gung-ho as Diageo, the British maker of the Guinness, Johnnie Walker and Smirnoff brands. But now that troubles are cropping up in many such countries around the world, Diageo has turned from cheerleader to excuse-monger.

headline: Some Progress on Eating and Health
keywords: ['Labeling and Labels', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Obesity', 'Food', 'Sugar', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Let’s be thankful for the decline in obesity rates, curbs on food marketing and transparency in packaged food — and then let’s push for more.
lead_paragraph: For those concerned about eating and health, the glass was more than half full last week; some activists were actually exuberant. First, there was evidence that obesity rates among pre-school children had fallen significantly. Then Michelle Obama announced plans to further reduce junk food marketing in public schools. Finally, she unveiled the Food and Drug Administration’s proposed revision of the nutrition label that appears on (literally, incredibly) something like 700,000 packaged foods (many of which only pretend to be foods); the new label will include a line for “added sugars” and makes other important changes, too.

headline: Arkansas House Votes to Extend Health Insurance Program
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The plan, which uses federal Medicaid expansion funds to buy private insurance for poor people, is being closely watched by other states.
lead_paragraph: The Arkansas House of Representatives voted Tuesday to let the state keep taking federal money for the expansion of Medicaid under President Obama’s health care law and using it to buy private insurance for poor people.

headline: Why Putin Doesn’t Respect Us
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Crimea is reflective of how Putinism used to just be a threat to Russia but is now becoming a threat to global stability.
lead_paragraph: Just as we’ve turned the coverage of politics into sports, we’re doing the same with geopolitics. There is much nonsense being written about how Vladimir Putin showed how he is “tougher” than Barack Obama and how Obama now needs to demonstrate his manhood. This is how great powers get drawn into the politics of small tribes and end up in great wars that end badly for everyone. We vastly exaggerate Putin’s strength — so does he — and we vastly underestimate our own strength, and ability to weaken him through nonmilitary means.

headline: Arizona: Bill Advances to Allow Surprise Inspections of Abortion Clinics
abstract: The State House on Tuesday approved the measure for inspections that now require warrants, and Democrats argued that the legislation would empower officials to harass abortion providers.
lead_paragraph: The State House of Representatives on Tuesday approved a measure that would allow state health department officials to conduct unannounced inspections of abortion clinics. The clinic inspections now require warrants, and Democrats argued that the legislation would empower public officials to harass abortion providers. Republicans said the bill would ensure that abortion providers were following state and federal laws. The bill was approved on a nearly party-line vote, with one Republican voting against and one Democrat voting in favor. The measure heads to the Senate, where it has strong support from the Republican majority. The bill was drafted by the Center for Arizona Policy, a Christian organization that championed a recent bill that would have allowed business owners to cite religious beliefs in refusing to conduct business with gays and others. Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, vetoed that bill.

headline: Setting Up a Better Domino Plan
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Zoning', 'Editorials', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: In a good start, Mayor Bill de Blasio closed a deal with developers that would add more affordable housing in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Updated March 5, 2014: The City Planning Commission on Wednesday approved the proposal to redevelop the old Domino Sugar refinery.

headline: Massachusetts: Report Chides Drug Laboratory for Lapses
keywords: ['Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Forensic Science', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: A report by the Massachusetts inspector general found that a chemist who may have compromised tens of thousands of criminal cases was the “sole bad actor” at the drug lab where she worked.
lead_paragraph: A report conducted by the Massachusetts inspector general, Glenn A. Cunha, found that a chemist who may have compromised tens of thousands of criminal cases was the “sole bad actor” at the drug laboratory where she worked, but took its management to task for lapses that it said had created an atmosphere that enabled her actions. The chemist, Annie Dookhan, admitted last fall that she falsified test results at the Hinton State Laboratory Institute in Boston, and is serving up to five years in prison. The laboratory has since closed. Mr. Cunha’s report, which was made public on Tuesday, said that the laboratory lacked important protocols and adequate oversight and that investigators were retesting drug samples in more than 2,000 additional cases.

headline: Australia Puts Green Credibility to the Test
abstract: Critics say Australia’s new conservative government, in wooing investment, has exposed parts of the country’s fragile environment to danger.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Since Australia’s conservative government took office almost six months ago, Prime Minister Tony Abbott has declared the country open for business.

headline: The What-Might-Have-Been Budget
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Poverty', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: President Obama’s proposal for 2015 shows how many national goals could be won by cutting unnecessary and unfair tax breaks for the rich.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s 2015 budget won’t survive the solid wall of Republican opposition in Congress, but that doesn’t mean it’s a useless document. Virtually every section is an important illustration of how many national goals — in particular, reducing inequality and rebuilding the economy — could be achieved if Congress would end unnecessary and unfair tax breaks for the rich.

headline: Stubborn Blanket of Snow in New York Region
abstract: Repeated storms followed by freezing temperatures have kept snow on the ground in much of the region.
lead_paragraph: Repeated storms followed by freezing temperatures have kept snow on the ground in much of the region.

headline: Governor Declares Florida Better, and Takes Credit
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott focused his State of the State address on tax cuts, job creation and the progress he said he was making in tackling his state’s hardships.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In a surprisingly personal speech reflecting his campaign for a second term, Gov. Rick Scott of Florida focused his State of the State address Tuesday on tax cuts, job creation and his contention that he was making significant progress in tackling the hardships that Florida families face.

headline: Finding New Worlds in New York City’s Old Snow Piles
abstract: A polar geophysicist digs into the city’s depressingly familiar snowpack to reveal a crystalline realm.
lead_paragraph: The view inside the snow globe has gotten pretty old here in New York. Snow falls. It sits there. It turns gray. More snow falls and turns gray.

headline: A Rational Response to Ukraine’s Crisis
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Isolation and economic pressure will be more effective against Russia than saber-rattling.
lead_paragraph: The tensions over Ukraine eased somewhat after President Vladimir Putin of Russia halted military maneuvers on the Ukrainian border and declared at a news conference on Tuesday that there was no immediate need to send troops into eastern Ukraine. The conciliatory talk prompted Russian financial markets to rebound from their plunge on Monday. The markets reward peaceful behavior.

headline: Market and Rates Helped Private Equity Chiefs Thrive Last Year
abstract: Lucrative payouts were helped greatly by the combination of low interest rates and high stock prices, which was ideal for selling investments.
lead_paragraph: Payouts for the top executives in private equity have rocketed into the stratosphere, thanks to a soaring stock market and shrewd maneuvers by their firms in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

headline: With Roberts, Yanks Hope Imperfect Piece Is Good Fit
abstract: The Yankees hope to piece together replacements for Robinson Cano at second base and Alex Rodriguez at third. The player they are counting on most is the former Oriole Brian Roberts.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Maybe it was the cluster of Yankees championships in the late 1990s, or maybe the creation of their own cable network a few years later. Probably, it was the explosion of their payroll, demonstrated again with their $500 million off-season.

headline: Frozen in a Niche?
abstract: When will Hollywood accept that the world is curvy, and the curvy world can be profitable?
lead_paragraph: As the statuesque Cate Blanchett clutched her statuette, she sent an acid air kiss Sandra Bullock’s way.

headline: Judge Won’t Dismiss Sexual Assault Charges Against General
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: A rejected defense motion to dismiss charges against Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair alleged that the lead prosecutor had raised questions about the credibility of the general’s main accuser.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — A military judge on Tuesday rejected a defense motion to dismiss charges against Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, the decorated former deputy commander of United States forces in southern Afghanistan, who has been charged with sexually assaulting a junior officer. The judge’s move clears the way for General Sinclair’s long-awaited trial before a jury of generals, possibly starting on Thursday.

headline: Putin, Flashing Disdain, Defends Action in Crimea
abstract: In his first public remarks on the political upheaval in Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin sought to defend Russia from the fury of global criticism while rallying support at home.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — He sat alone in an armchair, alternately slouching, his legs spread wide in confidence, and squirming uncomfortably. He displayed flashes of sardonic wit, anger and palpable disdain, especially toward the Americans and Europeans but also toward the leaders of a country, Ukraine, he made clear was a political neophyte, unable to govern itself.

headline: Fighting Afghan Terrorism, Without Troops
abstract: If the U.S. and NATO pull all troops out, how can the international community minimize the risk of a terrorist resurgence?

headline: Wheeler’s Potential Is on Display in His First Spring Start
abstract: Zack Wheeler, a 23-year-old right-hander, will try to further establish himself in his first full major league season as one of the Mets’ top power pitchers.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Only one of the Mets’ three young power arms will be pitching for the team when the season starts. Noah Syndergaard will probably be called up around midseason, and Matt Harvey could return by September. In the meantime, Zack Wheeler, the 23-year-old right-hander, will try to further establish himself.

headline: No Easy Way Out of Ukraine Crisis
abstract: White House officials are weighing their options, knowing that reversing the occupation of Crimea would be difficult, if not impossible, in the short run.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For all his bluster and bravado, President Vladimir V. Putin’s assurance on Tuesday that Russia does not plan, at least for now, to seize eastern Ukraine suggested a possible path forward in the geopolitical crisis that has captivated the world. Global markets reacted with relief, and the White House with cautious optimism.

headline: Group Close to Obama Says It Erred on Donation
abstract: The group, Organizing for Action, also said that on three occasions its fund-raisers or other employees had tried to steer potentially controversial donations to allied liberal groups that did not disclose their donors.
lead_paragraph: A political advocacy group backed by President Obama acknowledged Tuesday that its executive director had set up a White House meeting for a New Jersey businessman entangled in a lawsuit with a federal agency, who then pledged to raise $100,000 for the group one day after the meeting.

headline: Nets See .500 as Just a Stop on Playoff Drive
