abstract: The team has plenty to be happy about, having gone 19-8 since hitting a low point of 11 games under .500 on New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: There was a buoyant ambience on the practice court at Barclays Center on Tuesday afternoon, a day after the Nets re-established equilibrium to their win-loss record.

headline: Viral Post Draws Attention to Plight at a Brooklyn School
abstract: A parent’s protest on the website Humans of New York was shared widely, drawing attention to students without a much-needed foreign-language teacher.
lead_paragraph: Annette Renaud was riding the C train last weekend when a man approached and asked to take her picture. It was Brandon Stanton, of the popular website Humans of New York, and as usual, he asked what was on her mind. That’s when Ms. Renaud, a parent who is on the School Leadership Team at the Secondary School for Journalism, a high school housed in the John Jay educational campus in Brooklyn’s Park Slope neighborhood, let loose.

headline: Just Right Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Income Tax', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Executive Compensation']
abstract: Where is the line between innovation and economic development on one hand and the creation of a permanently disadvantaged class on the other?
lead_paragraph: If we can’t have (and don’t actually want) total equality or total inequality, what is the right amount of inequality?

headline: Inspired by Woods; Now Inspiring Others
abstract: Victor Dubuisson, 23, of France, the runner-up at the World Golf Championships match-play final, has risen to No. 23 in the world rankings.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — French basketball royalty is in Victor Dubuisson’s blood. His uncle Hervé was a prolific scorer for the French national team and participated in the 1984 Summer Olympics.

headline: Being and Nothingness
abstract: A Wednesday from Evan Birnholz that will have you drawing blanks.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Alert! Do you enjoy constructing crossword puzzles? Looking to contribute to a fresh venue? The Chronicle of Higher Education is accepting submissions. Send your puzzles or even your theme ideas to editor Jeffrey Harris at xwords@chronicle.com. You can read the specifications by clicking here and scrolling down to the bottom of the page.

headline: A Standoff of Lawyers Veils Madoff’s Ties to JPMorgan Chase
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes']
abstract: A new document regarding Bernard L. Madoff’s relationship with JPMorgan Chase reveals that the bank and federal regulators fought over access to bank employee interviews, eventually pitting the Justice Department against the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, in trying to determine the bank’s role in the fraud.
lead_paragraph: It remains one of Wall Street’s most puzzling mysteries: What exactly did JPMorgan Chase bankers know about Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme?

headline: Pointing Fingers Over Heavy Death Toll at an Indonesian Zoo
abstract: The municipal zoo in Surabaya, Indonesia’s second-largest city, where more than 100 animals have died since last summer, has drawn calls for its closing.
lead_paragraph: SURABAYA, Indonesia — A gaunt, malnourished white tiger died of pneumonia in mid-February. A lion died of strangulation in January when its neck became entangled in the cable that opened and closed the door of its cage. More than 100 other animals have perished since last summer, including a rare Komodo dragon found dead in its enclosure last month.

headline: Bangalore Welcomes a Later Last Call
abstract: The young professionals of the city say it’s about time that the government allowed bars and restaurants to close at 1 a.m., instead of 11:30 p.m.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE — As India’s hub of globalization, Bangalore has long had one major obstacle in its quest to be a truly cosmopolitan city: a lack of nightlife, thanks to a stringent city ordinance mandating an 11:30 p.m. closing time for its many bars and restaurants.

headline: Texas G.O.P. Beats Back Challengers From Right
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: Senator John Cornyn, Representative Pete Sessions and several other congressional Republicans seeking re-election beat primary challengers inspired by Senator Ted Cruz and the Tea Party.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — Establishment Republican leaders on Tuesday defeated challenges from the right in a statewide primary election as conservatives inspired by Senator Ted Cruz largely failed to topple mainstream incumbents, and a race for lieutenant governor headed for a runoff.

headline: No Bloodshed in a Standoff at an Airfield in Ukraine
abstract: After a standoff, heavily armed Russians allowed several members of an unarmed Ukrainian Air Force unit in Belbek to return to their usual posts.
lead_paragraph: BELBEK, Ukraine — Unarmed and uncertain of what they would face from the Russian soldiers deployed ahead of them, the men of the 45/15 air force unit marched through the gloomy morning up the road to the military airfield here, determined to take back the guard posts they usually operate.

headline: What Putin Really Wants
abstract: Russia’s goal isn’t annexation of Crimea. It wants to keep a thorn in the side of Ukraine’s new government.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The decision of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, to send forces into Crimea provoked a hysterical reaction, but his motives are less ambitious than is commonly assumed.

headline: De Blasio and Operator of Charter School Empire Do Battle
abstract: Eva S. Moskowitz, who built a chain of charter schools during the Bloomberg administration, saw plans for three more canceled by Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: She was a darling of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s administration, given free space to expand her charter schools from a single one in Harlem into a network larger than many New York State school districts. Along the way, her Success Academy empire became a beacon of the country’s charter school movement, its seats coveted by thousands of families as chronicled in the film “Waiting for ‘Superman.’ ”

headline: Brodeur Earns Win in What May Be His Devils Finale
abstract: Martin Brodeur stopped 20 shots in a win over Detroit in the Devils’ last game before Wednesday’s trade deadline, when they could try to move Brodeur, their longtime star who has become an occasional backup.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Martin Brodeur stood smiling, a Devil for at least one more night.

headline: A New Magazine for Fans of the Vatican’s Biggest Star
abstract: A testament to Pope Francis’ continuing popularity, Il Mio Papa (My Pope) will offer a glossy medley of papal pronouncements and photographs, and peeks into his personal life.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Just a few days short of the first anniversary of Pope Francis’ election, there is fresh evidence that his honeymoon with the public persists: He is getting his own magazine.

headline: One Killed in Gas Explosion at Condo Complex
abstract: An explosion at a condo complex in central New Jersey killed a woman and damaged dozens of homes, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A gas explosion at a condominium complex in central New Jersey on Tuesday killed a woman and damaged dozens of homes, officials said.

headline: How Agencies Clashed on Bank’s Madoff Files
abstract: A new document reveals that JPMorgan Chase and federal regulators fought over access to bank employee interviews, eventually pitting the Justice Department against the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.
lead_paragraph: A new document reveals that JPMorgan Chase and federal regulators fought over access to bank employee interviews, eventually pitting the Justice Department against the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.

headline: Parents’ Fight Against Sepsis Reaches C.D.C.
abstract: After their son died, Ciaran and Orlaith Staunton began pushing for hospitals nationwide to adopt techniques for early identification and treatment.
lead_paragraph: There it was: an A to Z index on the website of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. One morning, Ciaran and Orlaith Staunton of Queens turned to the S page. Somewhere between seasonal flu and sexual health, they were sure, they would find sepsis. It is among the leading causes of death in the United States, taking far more lives than the best-known cancers or heart attacks or criminal violence.

headline: Impaired-Driving Case Took Toll, Kennedy Says
abstract: Although Kerry Kennedy on Friday was found not guilty of driving while drugged, she said the 20-month-long prosecution distracted her from her human rights work and her family.
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, N.Y. — Leaning back on a bone-white sofa, her glasses perched on her head, Kerry Kennedy spoke of her 20-month-long prosecution for driving while drugged that ended last week, when she was acquitted after an hour by a six-person jury.

headline: Bond Market in China May See First Local Default
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Government Bonds', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: A small solar company in Shanghai has said it is unlikely to meet a Friday deadline for an annual interest payment owed to investors.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:18 p.m. |

headline: Chinese Officials Seek to Shift Attention From Rampage
abstract: Days after knife-wielding assailants killed 29 people and injured 143 at the train station in Kunming, Chinese authorities appeared eager to change the subject.
lead_paragraph: KUNMING, China — After knife-wielding assailants dressed in black killed 29 people and injured 143 at the train station here on Saturday, shocking the nation with an act of unfathomable terror, Chinese authorities appeared eager to change the subject.

headline: At Retrial, Therapist Retraces Grisly Scene
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Schizophrenia']
abstract: For the second time in a year, Dr. Kent D. Shinbach took the witness stand at the retrial of David Tarloff to describe the nightmarish attack on him.
lead_paragraph: The story would not be an easy one to tell even once: how a man tried to kill you, swinging a cleaver mercilessly at your face, while your colleague lay bloodied and dying a few feet away.

headline: C.I.A. Employees Face New Inquiry Amid Clashes on Detention Program
abstract: An inquiry into the conduct of Central Intelligence Agency employees began after lawmakers complained that the agency was improperly monitoring the work of staff members of a Senate committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Central Intelligence Agency’s attempt to keep secret the details of a defunct detention and interrogation program has escalated a battle between the agency and members of Congress and led to an investigation by the C.I.A.’s internal watchdog into the conduct of agency employees.

headline: Head of Port Authority Police Union Questioned in Bridge Inquiry
abstract: The relationship between Paul Nunziato and David Wildstein is under scrutiny as investigators piece together events that led to the lane closings near the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: The two men have met almost weekly since 2012, sometimes in a government office, but also in New Jersey diners and Manhattan bars, including a Gilded Age tavern replete with marble and mahogany, and a watering hole that once served as a gathering place for fashion models.

headline: In A.T.V. Case, a Police Sketch but No Suspect
keywords: ['ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES (ATV)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The police, after a mistaken arrest, are still looking for the driver of an A.T.V. who sped away on Sunday while dragging an officer 200 feet down a busy Brooklyn street.
lead_paragraph: What began over the weekend as a simple traffic stop has escalated into a manhunt for the driver of a four-wheel all-terrain vehicle who ran down a New York City police officer and dragged him nearly 200 feet down a busy Brooklyn street.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 4, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 4, 2014

headline: De Blasio on Eva Moskowitz
abstract: Long before he was elected mayor, Bill de Blasio made it clear that he had little time for Eva S. Moskowitz, the leader of a charter school network.
lead_paragraph: Long before he was elected mayor, Bill de Blasio made it clear that he had little time for Eva S. Moskowitz, the leader of a charter school network.

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Because of Ash Wednesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Because of Ash Wednesday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Wednesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Netanyahu Promotes Efforts Toward a Peace Deal
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel suggested that he had listened to President Obama’s plea to sign on to a framework being drafted by Secretary of State John Kerry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A day after meeting with President Obama, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Tuesday made an uncharacteristically enthusiastic pitch for a peace accord with the Palestinians, saying it would enable Israel to tighten ties with its Arab neighbors and “catapult the region forward” on issues like health, energy and education.

headline: Fight Club
abstract: A brief look at the fabulous life of the boxing champ Floyd Mayweather Jr.
lead_paragraph: At 37, Floyd Mayweather Jr. is the biggest name in boxing, with a spotless 45-0 record and a supersize personality to match. His taste for excess is the stuff of legend. Six-figure blackjack bets. A $10 million watch collection. A massive entourage he calls the Money Team, with Lil Wayne and Justin Bieber as honorary members. And last year, despite having zero endorsement deals, he still made a whopping $90 million — making him far and away the world’s highest-paid athlete. (LeBron James, by comparison, made around $60 million.) Mayweather is also a ruthless competitor, known for pummeling his opponents both in the ring and in the press. And when his next fight comes around on May 3, you can bet everything you have that he’s going to extend his streak. It’s what Mayweather would do, anyway. Here, a brief look at the fabulous life of the boxing champ.

headline: Word of the Day | senility
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: senility •\si-ˈni-lə-te also se-\• noun

headline: The Economics of Randomized Experiments
abstract: Market-based recruitment of participants in field studies might improve the quality of research, a economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Times Minute | Natural Gas in Ukraine
abstract: A look at natural gas in Ukraine, Russia’s and Ukraine’s points of leverage, and the United States’ role in the situation.
lead_paragraph: A look at natural gas in Ukraine, Russia’s and Ukraine’s points of leverage, and the United States’ role in the situation.

headline: How Fat May Hurt the Brain, and How Exercise May Help
abstract: Obesity may have harmful effects on the brain, and exercise may counteract many of those negative effects, new studies in mice suggest.
lead_paragraph: Obesity may have harmful effects on the brain, and exercise may counteract many of those negative effects, according to sophisticated new neurological experiments with mice, even when the animals do not lose much weight. While it’s impossible to know if human brains respond in precisely the same way to fat and physical activity, the findings offer one more reason to get out and exercise.

abstract: A look at natural gas in Ukraine, Russia and Ukraine’s points of leverage and the United States’ role in the situation.

headline: Mexico Targets Gang That Infiltrated the Mining Industry
abstract: The smuggling of lucrative iron ore is an example of the way Mexican organized crime groups have expanded beyond drug trafficking into a diverse range of rackets.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Mexico has stepped up its effort to crack down on one of the most powerful and feared criminal organizations in the country, with arrests and seizures this week aimed not at drug trafficking or extortion but at the gang’s lucrative infiltration of mining and smuggling iron ore to China.

headline: China Announces 12.2% Increase in Military Budget
abstract: China announced that it was increasing its military budget for 2014 to almost $132 billion. The expansion is being closely watched by other nations in the region and by the United States.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China announced on Wednesday that it would increase its military budget for 2014 to almost $132 billion, a 12.2 percent rise over last year. The rapid growth in defense spending is another sign of the country’s goal of becoming a dominant military presence in the Pacific, with a navy able to project power across the region.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Bravo) FLIPPING OUT This Season 7 opener finds the ever-energetic Jeff Lewis, above center, settled into his newly refurbished Los Angeles home and juggling a roster of high-profile clients, including George Eads, of “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,” and his wife, who are undertaking a major renovation of their own. And Mr. Lewis scrambles to plan around Jenni Pulos-Nassos’ maternity leave.

headline: U.S. Takes Training Role in Africa as Threats Grow and Budgets Shrink
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The American military’s involvement in Niger illustrates how the Pentagon is trying to juggle two competing missions in Africa: contain the spread of Islamist militancy without having to pour a lot of soldiers or money into the region.
lead_paragraph: DIFFA, Niger — Across Africa, affiliates of Al Qaeda and other Islamist militants are proving resilient and in some cases expanding their influence, from Nigeria to Libya to Somalia, Western and African counterterrorism officials say.

headline: For Rich, ’13 Was Good for Making, and Spending, Money
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'United States Economy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Three-quarters of those with $30 million or more in assets said they got wealthier, while only 4 percent lost assets, according to a survey.
lead_paragraph: You guessed it: The rich are getting richer. And — shocker! — they are having a pretty good time spending their money.

headline: Japan Said to Be Ready to Impose Bitcoin Rules
abstract: The new guidelines, which ban banks and securities firms from handling Bitcoin, will reportedly treat Bitcoins as a commodity rather than a currency.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan is drawing up a plan to regulate Bitcoin, officials said on Wednesday, including clauses the Nikkei business daily said would tax Bitcoin transactions and ban banks and securities firms from handling the digital currency.

headline: India’s 814 Million Voters Get Their Polling Dates
abstract: Over nine election days in April and May, Indians will choose their representatives for the Lok Sabha, the lower house or Parliament.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:35 p.m. | NEW DELHI — The Election Commission of India announced Wednesday the dates on which India’s 814 million voters will go to the polls to choose representatives for the Lok Sabha, or lower house of Parliament.

headline: China Declares ‘War Against Pollution’
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Land Use Policies', 'Science and Technology', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Facing growing dissatisfaction from citizens about high pollution in China, the premier, Li Keqiang, declared in his work report Wednesday that the government he leads would “declare war” on pollution.
lead_paragraph: The first year of President Xi Jinping’s administration, Prime Minister Li Keqiang said at the opening of the National People’s Congress on Wednesday, was: “Arduous.” “Complex.” “Difficult.” “Downward pressure on the economy increased.” “Natural disasters occurred frequently.”

headline: Corrections: March 5, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 5, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Stealth Changes for China’s Stealth Fighter
abstract: The maker of the J-20 stealth fighter, Chengdu Aerospace Corporation, appears to be upgrading the aircraft as it tests it, based on photos circulating this week.
lead_paragraph: When China unveiled its J-20 stealth fighter in 2011, analysts noted the aircraft’s potential to shift the regional balance of power further in the favor of the People’s Liberation Army Air Force. And the country is clearly committed to investing in military hardware. On Wednesday, China announced it was increasing its defense spending in 2014 to 808.23 billion renminbi, or about $132 billion, a rise of 12.2 percent.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, March 5, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the 2012 salary of National Football League commissioner Roger Goodell if given his 2011 salary and the percentage increase between the two years?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Paris Opera Ballet Announces New Season
abstract: The season is the final one to be programmed by the current director, Brigitte Lefèvre, who will retire on Oct. 31.
lead_paragraph: New works by John Neumeier and Pierre Rigal and visits from the Tanztheater Wuppertal and the Royal Swedish Ballet are some of the highlights of the Paris Opera Ballet’s 2014-15 season, which the company announced on Tuesday. The season is the final one to be programmed by the current director, Brigitte Lefèvre, who will retire on Oct. 31, making way for Benjamin Millepied, the former New York City Ballet principal who will take up the reins as director of dance on Nov. 1. Ms. Lefèvre’s public farewell will take place on Oct. 4 with a performance that includes Harald Lander’s “Études,” and William Forsythe’s “Woundwork” and “Pas/Parts,” both commissions from Ms. Lefèvre for the Paris Opera in 1999.

headline: Imerys Raises Offer for Amcol International, Again
abstract: The French industrial materials company Imerys said it would pay $45.25 a share in cash for Amcol International, valuing the Illinois-based company at $1.7 billion, including the assumption of debt.
lead_paragraph: The French industrial materials company Imerys has raised its offer for the second time in less than a month as it seeks to acquire Amcol International.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A New ‘Cosmos’ for a New Generation
abstract: Why, according to this writer, might this new “Cosmos” show help us decide big issues as a society?
lead_paragraph: In “A Successor to Sagan Reboots ‘Cosmos’,” Dennis Overbye writes about a new “rollicking 13-part tour of the universe” that will begin on television this Sunday.

headline: Voting Dates Are Set for National Elections in India
abstract: The vote — the world’s largest, with 814 million people eligible to cast ballots — is considered to be India’s most consequential since 1977.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — India’s national elections will begin on April 7 and continue on nine separate dates until May 12, with results expected to be announced on May 16, the Election Commission of India announced Wednesday.

headline: Arundhati Roy, the Not-So-Reluctant Renegade
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The writer has turned again to fiction. But will her politics get in the way?
lead_paragraph: “I’ve always been slightly short with people who say, ‘You haven’t written anything again,’ as if all the nonfiction I’ve written is not writing,” Arundhati Roy said.

headline: ‘The Man I Am, the Man I’m Not, the Man I Want To Be’
abstract: David Hilliard’s multipanel images are “visual possibilities of what could be,” while exploring his masculinity through his subjects.
lead_paragraph: At first, our choices are easy: whether to sit or stand, run stutter-step through the afternoon light or rest sweetly in our mother’s lap. As we age, we enter the twilight of limitless possibility. Despite our best intentions, we accept that there are fewer possible selves.

headline: Michael Ford’s Homeplace: Mississippi in the 1970s
abstract: The filmmaker Michael Ford found a home and life lessons in unexpected terrain — a blacksmith shop in Oxford, Miss., where all people, “young, old, black, white, drunk, sober,” were treated equally.
lead_paragraph: Correction appended.

headline: What Challenges Have You Overcome?
abstract: The Times is full of articles every week about people who have overcome challenges of all kinds and have learned from failure. What challenges have you overcome?
lead_paragraph: The Times is full of articles every week about people who have overcome challenges of all kinds and have learned from failure.

headline: Israel Says It Seized Ship in Red Sea With Load of Iranian Rockets Headed to Gaza
abstract: Israeli commandos boarded the ship in international waters as it headed to Port Sudan.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel demonstrated its long reach early Wednesday when its navy commandos boarded and seized a merchant ship in the southern Red Sea carrying an Iranian shipment of advanced weapons destined for Palestinian militant groups in Gaza, according to senior Israeli officials.

headline: New York Today: A Winter to Remember
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: A hard winter in review, seeing old snow with new eyes, and ashes — to go.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Ash Wednesday.

abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.

headline: U.S. Effort to Broker Russia-Ukraine Diplomacy Fails
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart said there would be more discussions, as the European Union offered aid worth as much as $15 billion over the next two years.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — An effort by the United States to broker the first face-to-face diplomatic meeting between Russia and Ukraine over the Crimea crisis failed on Wednesday, but Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart announced more discussions in the days ahead.

headline: What I’m Still Learning About Managing Cash Flow
abstract: If you don’t pay attention to details, it can be easy to let a bank or insurance company take your equity hostage.
lead_paragraph: I learned years ago that there is a big difference between cash flow and profit. You always need cash flow to stay in business, which is why you often hear the phrase “cash is king.” But you eventually need profit to have a successful business, which is why I wrote a blog post several years ago called “Why Cash Is NOT King.”

headline: Daily Report: Chief of Finance at Apple to Retire
abstract: The executive, Peter Oppenheimer, will be replaced by Luca Maestri, a vice president at the company.
lead_paragraph: Peter Oppenheimer, Apple’s senior vice president and chief financial officer, plans to retire in September, after an 18-year career at the technology giant, Rebecca Ruiz reports.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The British central bank also released minutes of meetings that indicated that there were concerns about possible currency market manipulation as early as July 2006.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:00 p.m. | The Bank of England said on Wednesday that it had suspended an employee as it escalated a review into whether bank officials had known about or condoned potential manipulation of the currency markets.

headline: Opposing Narratives in Piecing Together Kunming Attackers’ Motives
abstract: Were the assailants who slashed to death 29 people and wounded 143 others at a train station in China last Saturday aspiring jihadists or would-be refugees seeking to flee the country?
lead_paragraph: Were the assailants who slashed to death 29 people and wounded 143 others at a train station in southwestern China last Saturday aspiring jihadists or would-be refugees seeking to flee the country?

headline: Italy Fines Novartis and Roche in Collusion Case
abstract: The Swiss drug companies were ordered to pay a total of $250 million for trying to keep doctors from prescribing a relatively inexpensive eye treatment.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Italian antitrust authorities said on Wednesday that they had fined two Swiss pharmaceutical companies, Novartis and Roche Holdings, a total of $250 million for colluding to keep doctors from prescribing a relatively inexpensive eye treatment in favor of a more expensive drug.

headline: With Close Ties to Russia, China Sets a Cautious Tone on Ukraine Crisis
abstract: China has joined international voices calling for peace and stability in Ukraine, while continuing to withhold criticism of Russia, its traditional partner.
lead_paragraph: China has joined international voices calling for peace and stability in Ukraine, while continuing to withhold criticism of Russia, its traditional partner.

headline: Lowflation and the Two Zeroes
abstract: Europe: worse than Japan, even if it isn’t deflation yet.
lead_paragraph: Via the always invaluable Mark Thoma, the IMF blog — yes, the IMF has in effect become an econblogger — has a terrific piece on the problem with low inflation in Europe. It’s the perfect antidote to the do-nothing voices insisting that there’s no problem, because we don’t see actual deflation yet.

headline: British Floods Could Be a Harbinger
abstract: The county of Somerset may be a microcosm for the dilemmas that nations are likely to face in the future, as climate change accentuates unusual weather.
lead_paragraph: BURROWBRIDGE, England — Just outside this pretty village in southwest England is a steep, grassy mound called Burrow Mump. From the ruined church on the top, you can see miles of what look like shallow lakes but what are really submerged wheat fields and pasture.

headline: A New Word for Filthy Snow
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: After rejecting words like frobage and frounds, a couple coined a word to describe filthy mounds of city ice.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: An Architect and a Sociologist to be Honored at Swiss Pavilion in Venice
abstract: The work of the economist and sociologist Lucius Burckhardt and the British architect Cedric Price will be the subject of the pavilion at the 14th International Architecture Exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The work of the Swiss economist and sociologist Lucius Burckhardt and the British architect Cedric Price will be the subject of the Swiss Pavilion at the 14th International Architecture Exhibition at the Venice Biennale, which runs from June 7 to Nov. 23. The show, “A stroll through a fun palace,” is being organized by Hans-Ulrich Obrist, a director of the Serpentine Galleries in London.

headline: A Legal Standoff in the Madoff Case
abstract: A document sheds light on how a legal standoff has kept Bernard L. Madoff’s ties to JPMorgan’s shrouded in mystery. | Moelis & Company files for an I.P.O. | Wall Street’s latest hot thing could be appraisal rights. | The Supreme Court to hear arguments that could reshape securities fraud cases. | The website Silk Road had a digital outpost in Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Even after five years, it is still unclear what exactly JPMorgan Chase bankers knew about Bernard L. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme. A newly obtained government document does not provide the answer, but does shed some light on why the mystery remains, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. The document reveals that JPMorgan and federal regulators fought over access to bank employee interviews, eventually pitting the Justice Department against the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency.

headline: Irish Tycoon Wins a Round in Claridge’s Takeover Fight
abstract: Patrick McKillen, backed by a California-based private equity firm, has staved off an effort by rivals to buy him out of a storied London hotel.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Patrick McKillen, the Irish property tycoon locked in a fierce takeover struggle involving Claridge’s and its two sister landmark hotels in London, has won the latest round in his battle with rival British magnates.

headline: Book on Losing British Generals Wins American History Prize
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']
abstract: Andrew Jackson O’Shaughnessy’s “The Men Who Lost America” is the winner of the New-York Historical Society’s annual American history book prize.
lead_paragraph: The British may have lost the colonies in 1781. But the tale of their defeat has just won a prestigious literary honor, thanks to Andrew Jackson O’Shaughnessy’s study “The Men Who Lost America: British Leadership, the American Revolution, and the Fate of the Empire,” which has been awarded the New-York Historical Society’s annual American history book prize.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Alexander McQueen Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Morgan Stanley Is Said to Weigh Sale of Its Swiss Private Bank
abstract: Morgan Stanley is in the early stages of a strategic review of its private banking business in Switzerland, and the options it is exploring include selling the unit, according to a person familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Morgan Stanley is in the early stages of a strategic review of its Swiss private banking business, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: How a Campaign Organization Became a ‘Social Welfare’ Group
abstract: Obama for America underwent a tax-code morph. Now it’s Organizing for Action.
lead_paragraph: After Barack Obama was re-elected, his campaign organization, Obama for America, underwent a tax-code morph and became a “social welfare” group called Organizing for Action, intended to support the president’s initiatives. It kept the same initials, the same circular logo, and many officials who had worked on the campaign and in the Obama White House. Their website is called barackobama.com.

headline: Israel Says It Seized Iranian Shipment of Rockets Headed for Gaza
abstract: Israeli commandos boarded the ship in international waters as it headed to Port Sudan.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli naval commandos intercepted and boarded a civilian ship in the southern Red Sea early Wednesday, preventing an attempt to smuggle an Iranian shipment of advanced rockets to Gaza, according to senior Israeli officials.

headline: ‘Veronica Mars’ Fans Are Happy to Finance a Reunion
abstract: Kristen Bell stars in “Veronica Mars,” a film partly paid for with funds raised on the website Kickstarter.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hardly a week after Cyrus and Ina Chung had moved to Providence, R.I., to start new jobs, this married couple were standing here in a parking lot, dressed in formal clothes with the Southern California sun bearing down on them in late June, having paid a total of $3,000 for the privilege of being extras in the “Veronica Mars” movie.

headline: Peek.com Raises $5 Million in New Financing
abstract: Peek.com, a start-up that plays both travel agent and tour guide, plans to announce on Wednesday that it has raised $5 million in a new fund-raising round.
lead_paragraph: Start-ups like Uber and Airbnb have succeeded in moving traditionally offline businesses like taxis and apartment subletting to the Internet.

headline: The Lady With the Lamp and the Angel of the Battlefield
abstract: New biographical picture books about Florence Nightingale and Clara Barton, two great heroines of 19th-century nursing.
lead_paragraph: Florence Nightingale and Clara Barton, two great heroines of 19th-century nursing, were born a year apart but in utterly different circumstances. Nightingale was born in the spring of 1820 to a wealthy British family living in Italy. They returned to England shortly after, entertaining the beau monde of the day at Embley Park, their estate near London. Barton, born on Christmas Day in 1821, was the youngest of five children in a farming family in North Oxford, Mass. Her mother and sister Dolly seem to have suffered from mental illness; Clara was raised, in large part, by her brother Davie. She became a teacher at the age of 15.

headline: At Trade Center Transit Hub, Vision Gives Way to Reality
abstract: Clunky fixtures and some rough workmanship in the underground mezzanine detract from what is meant to be breathtaking grandeur.
lead_paragraph: How can a $3.94 billion building be made to look cheap?

headline: E.U. Offers Billions in Aid to Ukraine
abstract: The European Union said it would offer an aid package to Ukraine worth as much as 11 billion euros (approximately $15 billion) over the next two years.
lead_paragraph: The European Union said it would offer an aid package to Ukraine worth as much as 11 billion euros (approximately $15 billion) over the next two years.

headline: Image of the Day: March 5
abstract: Former Australian cricketer Brett Lee with the ICC Cricket World Cup 2015 trophy in New Delhi.

headline: Can’t Get a Bank Loan? The Alternatives Are Expanding
keywords: ['Small Business', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: New alternative lenders are offering a path between banks, which lend primarily to the most creditworthy small businesses, and cash advance lenders, which thrive on subprime candidates.
lead_paragraph: Ivan Rincon’s products may have been skimpy, but he was convinced his growth prospects were not. Orchid Boutique, the online swimwear shop he founded six years ago in Miami with his wife, Mayra, was approaching $3 million in annual sales. It had been profitable since 2010, he said, with margins that ran between 10 and 15 percent. But the business was highly seasonal, leaving him scrambling for cash in the off-season when he needed to place orders.

headline: Westchester Leader Opens Bid to Deny Cuomo a Second Term
abstract: Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, said he would seek the Republican nomination to challenge Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Entering a field devoid of formidable Republican contenders, Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, formally announced his candidacy for governor on Wednesday, beginning a campaign to unseat Andrew M. Cuomo, the popular and well-funded Democratic incumbent.

headline: Louis Vuitton: A Debut With Desire
abstract: Nicolas Ghesquière’s first collection for the label was a success — for its modernity, its clarity, its decency — and its respect for women.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Tweet the message from Paris to Shanghai: The Louis Vuitton show on Wednesday was a success — for its modernity, its clarity, its decency — and its respect for women.

headline: California’s Last Slave Case
abstract: How emancipation finally came to the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: In January 1864, African-Americans across California celebrated the one-year anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation with midnight church services, rallies and parades. Although California was a free state with an antislavery constitution, and was distant from the battlefields of the Civil War, most black Californians linked the national conflict over slavery to their own freedom struggle on the Pacific Coast.

headline: Another Way to Do the Math for Social Security Reform
abstract: Whether Social Security’s financial future is secured by increasing taxes or by slowing benefit growth, the net impact will be the same, with high earners bearing the largest burden, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Target Executive Resigns After Breach
abstract: Beth Jacob, the chief information officer since 2008, was the first high-level executive to leave after the widespread customer data theft at the retailer.
lead_paragraph: The highest-ranking technology executive at Target has resigned, the company said on Wednesday, just one week after it revealed how badly its profits had been hurt during the holiday season by an enormous breach of its system that exposed customer information.

headline: An End to Polio in India?
abstract: The success of an immunization effort has turned it into a blueprint for large-scale health campaigns.
lead_paragraph: ALIGARH, INDIA — On Jan. 13, 2011, a case of polio was discovered in the Indian state of West Bengal. India has been a hotbed of polio, often exporting strains to polio-free countries such as China. What’s remarkable is that this case, three years ago, may be the last ever discovered in India. This year, the World Health Organization (W.H.O.) will officially remove India from its list of polio-endemic countries, leaving just Afghanistan, Pakistan and Nigeria.

headline: Italy Moves to Speed Up Maintenance at Pompeii After Collapses
abstract: The Italian culture minister says he will free up nearly $3 million for Pompeii, where structures were damaged after heavy rains.
lead_paragraph: After heavy rains damaged several structures at the archaeological site of Pompeii over the weekend and on Monday, Italy’s culture minister has moved to speed up spending on maintenance at the heavily visited attraction, according to the BBC.

headline: Russia’s Defense Minister Calls Evidence of Troop Presence in Crimea ‘Complete Nonsense’
abstract: Russia officials denied on Wednesday that there were any Russian troops among the large contingent of masked men in armored vehicles with Russian military plates blockading Ukrainian military installations in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s defense minister and foreign minister both denied on Wednesday that there were any Russian troops among the large contingent of masked men in armored vehicles with Russian military plates blockading government buildings and Ukrainian military installations in Crimea.

headline: Listen Up | Avey Tare’s New Trio Puts On a Puppet Show
abstract: The Animal Collective singer channels the Muppets in a new video from his trio, Avey Tare’s Slasher Flicks.
lead_paragraph: Though he’s best known for having been a member of the experimental indie-rock band Animal Collective for more than a decade, David Portner also has a long history of collaborating with other musicians. Last year, the 34-year-old, who performs as Avey Tare, formed a trio, Avey Tare’s Slasher Flicks, with the ex-Dirty Projectors member Angel Deradoorian and the former Ponytail drummer Jeremy Hyman. Now, the group is poised to release its debut album, “Enter the Slasher House” (April 8, Domino Records), which features some of the most precise and straightforward compositions Portner has ever written.

headline: Researching a Snowboarding Trip
abstract: Throughout the past six years, Jeremy Jones has traveled to Alaska to snowboard new zones under his own power. With each trip, he has refined how he researches these areas.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the past six years, Jeremy Jones has traveled to Alaska to snowboard new zones under his own power. With each trip, he has refined how he researches these areas.

headline: Video: Snowboarder Blends Exploration With Research
abstract: In his trips to Alaska, Jeremy Jones has refined how he researches the areas he snowboards, which are often shrouded in mystery and filled with danger.
lead_paragraph: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the Teton Gravity Research crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: A Deal Maker’s Deal of a Lifetime
abstract: I.P.O. investors will be granting Ken Moelis, founder of the investment bank Moelis & Company, an exceptional degree of control for the opportunity to ride his coattails, Antony Currie writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Ken Moelis has engineered the transaction of his lifetime. The veteran investment banker is taking his eponymous seven-year-old advisory firm public.

headline: Beauties, Beasts and Movie Posters
abstract: Poster images from the gallery show “Nothing’s Impossible,” featuring newly designed movie posters for Disney films.
lead_paragraph: What would posters for “The Lion King” and “Beauty and the Beast” look like today? Mondo, an offshoot of the Austin, Tex., theater chain Alamo Drafthouse, has one answer. In collaboration with Disney, it has commissioned new versions of posters for those and other films, all hand-drawn by artists. They will be on display at a show, titled “Nothing’s Impossible,” opening on Friday in Austin, timed to the beginning of the South by Southwest film festival. You can see some of the selections in this slide show, featuring work by Martin Ansin, Tom Whalen, Anne Benjamin and more. Additional images are at the Disney-owned blog Oh My Disney.

headline: In Banking Overhaul Fight, a Ruckus Over an Obscure Product

abstract: The banking industry has been making loud noises about the regulation of collateralized loan obligations, an little-known but risky financial product, Jesse Eisinger writes in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: First, there was the TruPs crisis, as everyone surely recalls.

headline: Hitting High Velocity Without the Meth
abstract: Aaron Paul takes up a role far removed from his “Breaking Bad” character in the automotive action picture “Need for Speed.”
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Among the downsides of making and selling crystal meth are all the ancillary chores one must attend to. As Jesse Pinkman, one-half of the drug-dealing pair on the AMC series “Breaking Bad,” Aaron Paul had to dissolve a corpse in acid, help babysit a D.E.A. informant shackled in his basement and endure a vicious beat-down by a crazy guy named Tuco. And that, as any dedicated “Breaking Bad” fan can tell you, was just in the first season.

headline: With Move to Limit Gun Sales, Facebook Is Caught in Debate
abstract: Under pressure from law enforcement and advocacy groups, Facebook took steps Wednesday to regulate gun sales on its site as well as on its photo-sharing app Instagram.
lead_paragraph: Facebook wants to unite the world so everyone can talk about everything. One of the big things people want to talk about, it seems, is guns.

headline: Classical Playlist: Stephanie Blythe, Eva-Maria Houben, Nicholas Phillips and More
abstract: Critics for The Times share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘AS LONG AS THERE ARE SONGS’Stephanie Blythe, mezzo-soprano; Craig Terry, pianist(Innova)The mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe has one of the most naturally big, rich and penetrating voices in opera. Yet she is a vocal artist with keen sensitivity to the expressive nuances of music and the texts she sings. She has proved an engaging and stylish performer of American standard and musical theater songs, as on this recording, released last fall, titled “As Long as There Are Songs.” With the pianist Craig Terry, she gives alternately tender and sassy, swinging and melting accounts of “Always,” “A Star Is Born: The Man That Got Away,” “How Deep Is the Ocean?” and 11 others songs. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Brother of Afghan Leader Expected to Drop Out of Election
abstract: Reports of Qayum Karzai’s expected withdrawal follow what officials have described as months of behind-the-scenes pressure from President Hamid Karzai.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai has vowed to stay out of Afghanistan’s presidential race, and not to show preference or prejudice toward any of the 11 contenders, but it is now clear that he has made an exception in at least one case: his own brother.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | New York State’s top banking regulator is raising questions about the capabilities of the mortgage servicing firm Nationstar Mortgage Holdings, demanding details about the company’s staffing levels, modification procedures and affiliated businesses.

headline: Rangers Trade Callahan and Are Dealt a Defeat
abstract: The Rangers fell to the Toronto Maple Leafs in overtime on the day that Ryan Callahan, the Rangers’ captain, was sent to the Lightning for Martin St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: The newest Ranger, Martin St. Louis, only 5-foot-8 but a two-time N.H.L. scoring champion, stood before reporters at the end of a long day Wednesday and talked about why he had asked to end his 13-season career with the Tampa Bay Lightning and be traded to the Rangers.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: A Stray Swastika, and a Delay, for ‘South Park’ Video Game
abstract: The video game’s publisher, Ubisoft, said in a statement that the appearance of one Nazi swastika in South Park: The Stick of Truth had forced the company to stop distribution in Germany and Austria until the symbol could be removed.
lead_paragraph: “South Park” is known for humor that pushes the boundaries of taste on television, and the new video game South Park: The Stick of Truth — released on Tuesday in North America — is no different.

headline: Her Beloved Beast, Loved Just as He Is
abstract: The performance and burlesque artists Julie Atlas Muz and Mat Fraser are appearing in “Beauty and the Beast.” But don’t expect G-rated material.
lead_paragraph: Their previous collaborations include “The Freak and the Showgirl” and “Apocastrip Wow!” Now the performance and burlesque artists Julie Atlas Muz and Mat Fraser are appearing at the Abrons Arts Center under the more family-friendly title “Beauty and the Beast.” But don’t expect G-rated material. Staged by Phelim McDermott (“Shockheaded Peter,” and productions of “Satyagraha” and “The Enchanted Island” at the Metropolitan Opera), this production uses pageantry, puppetry and two daring stars to explore the totems and taboos of our notions of physical attractiveness.

headline: The Sock’s Dirty, but He’s Keeping It
abstract: The playwright Robert Askins talks about the Off Broadway return of his black comedy “Hand to God,” featuring a potty-mouthed sock puppet, with a more “mature” ending.
lead_paragraph: Jason’s idea of a fun Saturday night is rehearsing the old “Who’s on First?” vaudeville routine, while Tyrone prefers demolishing as many commandments as possible. The two Texas churchgoers make for an unlikely duo, but in “Hand to God,” which opens Monday at the Lucille Lortel Theater, they are joined at the hip. Or, rather, at the wrist.

headline: Sally Beauty Investigating Possible Credit Card Theft
abstract: Sally Beauty Holdings said that it was investigating a security breach after a blogger said that hundreds of thousands of new credit cards had appeared in the underground market, some used recently at the beauty supply company.
lead_paragraph: In what may be the latest cyberattack on an American retailer, Sally Beauty Holdings said Wednesday that it had been investigating a security breach that others say may have resulted in hundreds of thousands of stolen customer credit cards.

headline: E-Cigarettes Versus E-Hookahs
abstract: The New York Times’s David Gillen describes the difference between e-cigarettes and e-hookahs.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s David Gillen describes the difference between e-cigarettes and e-hookahs.

headline: In Eastern Ukrainian City, a Tug of War for More Autonomy
abstract: Pro-Russian demonstrators in Donetsk overcame riot police and occupied the regional government’s administration building for a second time this week.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Pro-Russian demonstrators demanding greater independence from the central government overcame riot police in this eastern Ukrainian city and poured into the regional administration building here on Wednesday evening, retaking it for a second time this week in a tug of war with the local police.

headline: Hermès: Fall 2014 RTW
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Democrats in Senate Reject Pick by Obama
abstract: Lawmakers rejected the Justice Department nomination of Debo P. Adegbile, who was associated with the defense of Mumia Abu-Jamal decades after his conviction in the killing of a police officer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Wednesday rejected President Obama’s nominee to lead the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division in an embarrassing rebuke of the president on the choice of a key legal adviser and one that left senior White House officials “furious” with members of their own party.

headline: Big Data Picks Up the Pace
abstract: Announcements from SAP, GoodData, Splunk and Tableau Software show how fast things are moving in the business of analyzing large amounts of data for companies.
lead_paragraph: We may be heading into the next phase of big data. The early bets and stand-alone products seem to be moving rapidly into more sophisticated uses and broader corporate alliances.

headline: Prada’s Artful Pouches
abstract: The label introduces a micro version of its coveted printed fur coats with this capsule collection of bags available exclusively at Bergdorf Goodman.
lead_paragraph: The printed fur jackets from Prada’s spring/summer 2014 collection, with their abstract faces rendered in bold pops of color, are some of the most talked-about items of the season. They’re also some of the most expensive and hard to get. But fear not: There is now a way to have a touch of that Prada art-you-can-wear in your spring wardrobe. The label has repurposed its face print for a small set of fur and leather zip pouches, now available exclusively at Bergdorf Goodman. And for those in love with the collection’s aesthetic but not quite ready to carry such a traffic-stopping clutch, Prada has installed art from its runway show in the department store’s Fifth Avenue windows, complete with murals by the artist El Mac, on view though March 10.

headline: Plaintiffs in Suit Seek to Freeze Mt. Gox’s U.S. Assets
abstract: Plaintiffs in a class-action lawsuit filed a motion on Thursday seeking a temporary injunction to keep the bankrupt Bitcoin exchange and its chief executive, Mark Karpeles, from moving any money outside of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Customers of Mt. Gox are trying to freeze assets in the United States of the bankrupt Bitcoin exchange and its chief executive, Mark Karpeles.

headline: The Man Onstage Who Wasn’t There
abstract: Billed as a comedy, “The Shape of Something Squashed” means in part to gibe the ruthless self-absorption of successful artists, but it also offers a portrait of an actor as an almost invisible man.
lead_paragraph: A lanky, soft-spoken older man whose name matches his timidity, Douglas Whymper is living a variation on the actor’s nightmare.

headline: Quebec’s Separatist Premier Calls a Snap Election for April
abstract: Pauline Marois, the province’s separatist premier, dissolved its Legislature and said voters could choose a new one on April 7.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Less than 18 months after gaining a tenuous hold on power, Pauline Marois, the separatist premier of Quebec, on Wednesday called a snap election.

headline: Behind Closed Doors, Microsoft’s Board Reportedly Battled Chief Over Nokia Deal
abstract: In its latest issue, Bloomberg Businessweek reports that Steven A. Ballmer, then Microsoft’s chief executive, chafed when fellow directors questioned the wisdom of buying any part of Nokia’s hardware operations.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced last fall that it would buy Nokia’s handset business for $7.2 billion, jaws dropped across Wall Street.

headline: 3 Gulf Countries Pull Ambassadors From Qatar Over Its Support of Islamists
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain took the step in protest over Qatar’s continued support of the Muslim Brotherhood and other Islamists in the region.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Tensions between Qatar and neighboring Persian Gulf monarchies broke out Wednesday when Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain withdrew their ambassadors from the country over its support of the Muslim Brotherhood and allied Islamists around the region.

headline: Hermès: Gentle End to Hectic Week
abstract: The velvet curtains at Hermès told the story before an elegant foot had been put on the wood-paneled runway.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Sturm und Drang of four weeks of international collections ended Wednesday on a gentle note as Hermès closed the autumn/winter 2014 shows in Paris, where changes in designers at established brands have been paramount.

headline: Revisiting Nicaragua, This Time as a Tourist
abstract: More than 25 years after arriving in Managua during the Sandinista-contra conflict, the author returns, finding contrasts between her memories and today’s Nicaragua.
lead_paragraph: Managua’s airport doesn’t look anything like it did the day I first arrived there with an ill-considered buzz cut, two donated microscopes and a mind brimming with untested idealism. That was in 1985, when the Sandinista revolution and the American-backed contra campaign opposing it were in full swing. I had taken a leave from college to see the revolution up close, to lend my hand in whatever way I could, including teaching, and ended up staying for nearly three years. At the immigration counter, a compañero in fatigues insisted, in Spanish, that I redo my forms. Leafing through my American passport, he noted that I was born in Germany, but he seemed disappointed that my birthplace was in the western half of the country, not in socialist East Germany. To tell the truth, I was a little disappointed, too, and all the more so when my microscopes, destined for a rural health clinic, were seized by customs.

headline: Hotel Review: the Guest House in Vienna
abstract: This 39-room property, which opened in October, is one of the few new hotels in the city to emphasize true livability.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: La Madame in San Sebastián, Spain
abstract: In one of the world’s great dining destinations, an American expat chef mixes in a taste of the States.
lead_paragraph: With its packed pintxos bars and Michelin-starred temples of avant-garde gastronomy, San Sebastián is one of the world’s great dining destinations. Even with all that Basque bounty, though, sometimes a traveler gets a hankering for home. New Yorkers might find their fix at La Madame, which opened two years ago a block in from the beach, offering a rare taste of the States.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Valentino Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Senior U.N. Envoy Threatened at Gunpoint in Crimea
abstract: The envoy, Robert Serry, had arrived a day earlier to assess the crisis in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A senior United Nations diplomat who was sent to the Crimea region of southern Ukraine to assess the Russian military takeover there was threatened by armed men at gunpoint on Wednesday, and aborted his visit a day after it had begun.

headline: A Moose Mystery
abstract: Moose in Minnesota are dying at an alarming rate, and biologists are racing to understand what's behind the rapid decline.
lead_paragraph: Moose in Minnesota are dying at an alarming rate, and biologists are racing to understand what's behind the rapid decline.

headline: Minnesota Mystery: What’s Killing the Moose?
abstract: In the 1980s, moose numbered about 4,000 in the northwest part of the state; today, there are about 100, and the reasons for their deaths vary.
lead_paragraph: GRAND PORTAGE, Minn. — For moose, this year’s winter-long deep freeze across the Upper Midwest is truly ideal weather. The large, gangly creatures are adapted to deep snow: Their hollow fur insulates them like fiberglass does in a house. And the prolonged cold helps eradicate pests that prey on moose, like ticks and meningeal worm, or brain worm. Yet moose in Minnesota are dying at an alarming rate, and biologists are perplexed as to why.

headline: The Man on Horseback
abstract: Brooks and Collins on Putin, Ukraine and how much one person can shape history.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks: Gail, I’m not a big believer in the theory that if women ran the world everything and everyone would be peaceful and cooperative, but I have to admit it is hard to imagine a female version of Vladimir Putin.

headline: Emma Thompson Tackles ‘Sweeney Todd’
abstract: The actress Emma Thompson and the director Lonny Price talk about preparing for the New York Philharmonic’s concert stagings of the musical “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.”
lead_paragraph: The actress Emma Thompson and the director Lonny Price talk about preparing for the New York Philharmonic’s concert stagings of the musical “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.”

headline: Syria and Security Council Criticized by Rights Panel
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A report singles out the government and its allied militias for offenses while pointing a finger at the Council for allowing both sides in the war to break international laws with impunity.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A commission of inquiry established by the United Nations to investigate human rights abuses in Syria singles out the government and its allied militias for “systematically committing murder, torture, rape and enforced disappearance,” while pointing a sharp finger at the Security Council for allowing both sides in the three-year-long war to continue breaking international laws with impunity.

headline: Convicted SAC Trader Loses His Business School Degree
abstract: Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader convicted of insider trading in February, can no longer say he has a degree from Stanford Graduate School of Business. The business school now says it has not awarded a degree to Mr. Martoma.
lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader convicted of insider trading in February, can no longer say he has a degree from Stanford Graduate School of Business.

headline: A Penchant for Privacy in Williamsburg
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Nicki Shamel and Hannah Welch hoped to rent a place Brooklyn with nonadjacent bedrooms.
lead_paragraph: Since her arrival in New York nearly four years ago after graduating from Loyola University Chicago, Nicki Shamel has had good luck finding roommates and apartments via Craigslist.

headline: A New SAT Aims to Realign With Schoolwork
abstract: The College Board said it would eliminate obligatory essays and cut obscure vocabulary words in an effort to make its college admission exams focus on important academic skills.
lead_paragraph: Saying its college admission exams do not focus enough on the important academic skills, the College Board announced on Wednesday a fundamental rethinking of the SAT, ending the longstanding penalty for guessing wrong, cutting obscure vocabulary words and making the essay optional.

headline: Steppenwolf Theater to Present New Lisa D’Amour Play
abstract: Ms. D’Amour’s dark comedy “Airline Highway” and works by Conor McPherson and David Adjmi will be part of the theater’s 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: A New Orleans parking lot, a suburban British home, a Dublin flat, and the court of Marie Antoinette are the diverse settings for the next round of plays at Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago, which announced its 2014-15 season lineup on Wednesday.

headline: On Twitter, ITV Editor Reports U.N. Envoy’s Ordeal in Crimea as It Unfolds
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'International Relations', 'Kidnapping']
abstract: The senior diplomat sent to Ukraine’s Crimea region to assess the Russian military takeover there was threatened by armed men.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Somini Sengupta reported from the United Nations, 10 to 15 unidentified armed men threatened a U.N. special envoy, Robert Serry, as he left a meeting at a naval base in Crimea, ordering him to go to the airport and leave the peninsula, the deputy secretary-general, Jan Eliasson, said.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Miu Miu Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Suspensions for Students Who Rooted Against India
abstract: Kashmiri students at a university in India were punished after they cheered for the Pakistani team during a televised cricket match against India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Kashmiri students at a private university in northeastern India were suspended indefinitely and removed from their dorms on Monday after they cheered for the Pakistani team during a televised cricket match against India.

headline: For Bitcoin, Secure Future Might Need Oversight
abstract: Some backers of the digital currency are calling for human oversight to guard against more losses like the $470 million collapse of Mt. Gox.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a billion dollars has gone missing, and nobody knows how. Some say there was outright theft. Others suspect fraud. Many blame lax controls, poor oversight and, above all, a reckless, globe-spanning, Wild West culture — a culture that everyone agrees is ripe for wholesale reform.

headline: The Gun Report: March 5, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: This afternoon, New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman announced an agreement with Facebook to monitor and eliminate illegal gun sales on its sites, calling it “the strongest step ever taken to end illegal sales of firearms on social media sites.” Facebook and its photo-sharing platform, Instagram, are not e-commerce sites, but they have been called out in recent months for hosting pages that boast background check-free gun sales across state lines to minors, felons and those with mental disabilities.

headline: U.S. Hopes Boom in Natural Gas Can Curb Putin
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Natural Gas', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Obama administration is seeking to deploy the vast new supply of natural gas in the United States as a weapon to undercut the influence of President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The crisis in Crimea is heralding the rise of a new era of American energy diplomacy, as the Obama administration tries to deploy the vast new supply of natural gas in the United States as a weapon to undercut the influence of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, over Ukraine and Europe.

headline: Andris Nelsons to Open Boston Symphony Season With a Flourish
abstract: Mr. Nelsons’s first season as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra is to open with a gala featuring his wife, the soprano Kristine Opolais, and the tenor Jonas Kaufmann.
lead_paragraph: The Andris Nelsons era at the Boston Symphony Orchestra will begin in earnest on Sept. 27 when he opens his first season as its music director with a gala concert featuring Kristine Opolais, a rising soprano who happens to be his wife, and the tenor Jonas Kaufmann.

headline: Geneva, Day 2
abstract: Jerry Garrett offers some highlights of the second day of press previews in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Garrett offers some highlights of the second day of press previews in Geneva.

headline: A Top Model’s Online Wishing Well
abstract: The fashion fixture and Cambridge graduate Lily Cole launches her digital sharing platform, The Impossible, stateside.
lead_paragraph: In fiercely competitive world of tech start-ups, the idea of a website devoted to doing things out of the kindness of one’s heart may seem counterintuitive. But that’s just what the 26-year-old British model, actress and Cambridge graduate Lily Cole has put forth with her new online social platform and app, Impossible. The site, which debuted last year in the U.K. but launches stateside this month, functions as a real-life, high-tech giving tree of sorts. Users can post their wishes — for goods or services, for skills like learning to play the piano or for loftier goals like curing disease or ending prejudice — and grant those of others. Once a wish is granted, users post thank-you notes, taking the site’s warm-and-fuzzy factor even further.

headline: Last Looks at Lost Species
abstract: In the book, “Lost Animals: Extinction and the Photographic Record,” Errol Fuller collects the last known photographs of extinct animals.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the magazine published Nathaniel Rich’s article about de-extinction, a book of the last known photographs taken of extinct animals circulated around the sixth floor. Errol Fuller’s “Lost Animals: Extinction and the Photographic Record,” is a sad and moving collection of passenger pigeons, heath hens, Tasmanian tigers and other vanished animals.

headline: Music Born of Magical Thinking
abstract: Jonatha Brooke talks about her mother’s descent into Alzheimer’s disease, the basis of her one-woman show, “My Mother Has 4 Noses.”
lead_paragraph: Outside, the sleet came down like needles, a perfect night for slipper socks and 1940s weepers on Turner Classic Movies. But no: I have tickets to “My Mother Has 4 Noses,” a one-woman musical written and performed by the singer/songwriter Jonatha Brooke about the harrowing years when she saw her mother through the final stages of Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Where It Began
keywords: ['Zionism', 'Books and Literature', 'Jews and Judaism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Looking at the history of the United States and Israel, John B. Judis considers the emergence of the Zionist lobby.
lead_paragraph: “I received about 35,000 pieces of mail and propaganda from the Jews in this country,” Harry Truman told Senator Claude Pepper in 1947. “I put it all in a pile and struck a match to it.” The man destined to be canonized by American Jews as a champion of Israel felt exhausted and outmatched by the young but influential Zionist lobby.

headline: Was a Post on Russia Today’s Abby Martin a ‘Hit Piece’?
abstract: Some readers say information about the news host’s past activities was irrelevant and disparaging.
lead_paragraph: The clip from Russia Today’s “Breaking the Set” was riveting, and the moment unforgettable. The show’s host, Abby Martin, stepped closer to the camera and — dropping any pretense of journalistic distance or impartiality — said exactly what she thought about the Russian government’s action in Ukraine.

headline: How Can I ‘Talk to My Kids About Vaping’ if I Don’t Really Know What That Means?
abstract: I thought I needed to talk to my children about e-cigarettes, but I don’t even have the name right. In fact, I don’t even know the right verb.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, I’m setting out to buy a vape pipe. Or possibly a hookah pen, or an e-hookah.

headline: At Every Performance, a Sweet Job Opening
abstract: The World Queen of the Cocoa Bean seeks a successor in “The Chocolate Show!,” an interactive production at 47th Street Theater best suited to 8- to 12-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: At first, I thought the fix was in.

headline: Iconoclasm Out of Austria
abstract: The Talea Ensemble performed works by the modern composers Pierluigi Billone, Bernhard Gander and Olga Neuwirth as part of the Vienna: City of Dreams festival.
lead_paragraph: Since the Austrian Cultural Forum opened the doors of its tall, narrow East 52nd Street headquarters to the public in 2002, this vital, eager institution has teemed with illuminating exhibitions, lectures and concerts, presented free, week in and week out. It makes sense, then, that the forum is among the key participants in Vienna: City of Dreams, Carnegie Hall’s latest elaborate arts festival.

headline: In Queens Raid, Federal Agents Seize Artifacts They Suspect Were Looted
abstract: Federal agents searched a warehouse in Queens on Tuesday and seized a number of artifacts that they suspect were looted from India and Southeast Asia.
lead_paragraph: The hunt for Indian antiquities allegedly smuggled into New York by Subhash Kapoor, a former Manhattan gallery owner accused of overseeing a $100 million art trafficking ring, led to a Queens warehouse Tuesday where federal officials seized hundreds of Southeast Asian and Indian items that they valued at $8 million.

headline: What the Real George Smiley Thought
abstract: John le Carré recently answered a critic who said the real-life inspiration for the fictional spy George Smiley deplored Mr. le Carré’s view of the intelligence services.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years after the novelist John le Carré revealed John Bingham as one of the real-life models for his famous fictional spy George Smiley, he is answering a critic who says Bingham detested Mr. le Carré’s opinions of the espionage game.

headline: Turn Down the Volume: Researching the Science of Sound and Noise-Induced Hearing Loss
abstract: In this lesson, we offer several ways to learn about hearing and hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: Why are a growing number of teenagers suffering from hearing loss? How can the noise in our lives be dangerous? How do our ears and our brain work together to detect sound?

headline: Testimony at Hacking Trial Gives Peek Into British Tabloids
keywords: ['Newspapers', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Rebekah Brooks, in her phone hacking trial, gave a rare view into the skating-on-the-edge culture of the popular press.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Rebekah Brooks first entered the witness box in Britain’s phone hacking trial, her lawyer reminded the jury that she was not on trial for running Rupert Murdoch’s tabloid newspapers.

headline: Schoolboy Q Tops Chart for Top Dawg
abstract: Schoolboy Q’s album “Oxymoron” is the first No. 1 hit for the independent label Top Dawg.
lead_paragraph: The success of the rapper Kendrick Lamar over the last year or so has turned the music industry’s attention to his record label, Top Dawg Entertainment. A small independent based in Los Angeles, the label released Mr. Lamar’s “good kid, m.A.A.d city” in October 2012 through a distribution deal with the Interscope Records, and the album went to No. 2 and earned Mr. Lamar seven Grammy nominations (though he won none).

headline: Obama Budget Seeks to Eliminate Inversions
abstract: Deep in President Obama’s $3.9 trillion budget request is a proposal that would essentially forbid so-called inversions, a popular maneuver that allows United States companies to relocate and avoid paying millions of dollars in taxes.
lead_paragraph: Buried in the $3.9 trillion budget request that President Obama sent to Congress on Tuesday is a clause that has Wall Street tax advisers on edge.

headline: Barclays Chief Defends Contentious Increase in Bonus Pay
abstract: Barclays’ chief executive, Antony Jenkins, said in a newspaper interview that he decided to increase bankers’ pay last year in spite of falling profits to avoid a “death spiral” in the investment bank unit.
lead_paragraph: Barclays’ chief executive, Antony Jenkins, told the Telegraph newspaper in Britain that he decided to increase bankers’ pay last year in spite of falling profits to avoid a “death spiral” in the investment bank unit, where the rate of attrition among senior bankers last year doubled.

headline: Pro-Russian Forces Regain Donetsk Center
abstract: Pro-Russian protesters recaptured the administrative headquarters of the eastern Ukrainian city of Donetsk just hours after Ukrainian authorities managed to take back control.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Russian protesters recaptured the administrative headquarters of the eastern Ukrainian city of Donetsk just hours after Ukrainian authorities managed to take back control.

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Moncler Gamme Rouge Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Valerio Mezzanotti.

headline: Ex-Trader Kerviel Takes the Long Way Home
abstract: Just weeks before a French court is to rule on his final appeal, Jérôme Kerviel, who caused billions in losses at Société Générale, is walking from Rome to Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Pilgrimage of penance — or Hail Mary publicity stunt?

headline: Brooklyn to the Big Time, but First a Stop in Mississippi
abstract: Three basketball players at Jones County Junior College in Ellisville, Miss., have a few things in common: hoop dreams, academic realities and an upbringing in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: ELLISVILLE, Miss. — The energy in the home locker room at A.B. Howard Gymnasium was slightly more charged than usual on a cold Monday night last month. The men’s basketball team at Jones County Junior College, a two-year school in this small farming community, miles from nowhere, was minutes from the opening tip of a big game against Pearl River Community College, and Coach Jay Ladner was dusting off some of his finest material.

headline: Theater Producers Lobby for an Upstate Tax Credit
abstract: A group of producers and tour operators are proposing a New York tax credit to encourage more work in the state.
lead_paragraph: A group of Broadway producers and theatrical tour operators, on a lobbying trip to Albany on Wednesday, proposed a new state tax credit that would aim to entice producers to prepare national tours of Broadway shows in Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and other upstate cities rather than go to states that already have such tax breaks.

headline: Consumers Allowed to Keep Health Plans for Two More Years
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The action helps Democrats in tight midterm election races, because it avoids the election-year cancellation of insurance policies that do not comply with the new health law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, grappling with continued political fallout over its health care law, said Wednesday that it would allow consumers to renew health insurance policies that did not comply with the new law for two more years, pushing the issue well beyond this fall’s midterm elections.

headline: With Eye on Midterms, Obama Pushes Rise in Minimum Wage
abstract: During a visit to Connecticut, the president praised four New England governors who have pushed to increase minimum wages in their states.
