lead_paragraph: NEW BRITAIN, Conn. — Flanked by four like-minded New England governors, President Obama took his campaign for a higher federal minimum wage to this rough-hewed city on Wednesday, declaring that “nobody who works full time should ever have to raise a family in poverty.”

headline: The Senate’s Hierarchy of Victimhood
abstract: Debo Adegbile did his job, and for that he was deemed unfit to become the head of the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division.
lead_paragraph: Debo Adegbile did his job, and for that he was deemed unfit by the Senate to become the head of the Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division. His misstep, specifically, was helping represent a death-row inmate while he was director of litigation at the NAACP Legal Defense Fund.

headline: Early Treatment Is Found to Clear H.I.V. in a 2nd Baby
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Babies and Infants', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Clinical Trials']
abstract: Another baby born with H.I.V. and treated with drugs shortly after birth is now 9 months old and apparently H.I.V.-negative. The success of the treatment raises hopes for a path to rid babies of the virus that causes AIDS.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When scientists made the stunning announcement last year that a baby born with H.I.V. had apparently been cured through aggressive drug treatment just 30 hours after birth, there was immediate skepticism that the child had been infected in the first place.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: Ms. Post answers questions about guest lists.
lead_paragraph: Rehearsal Dinner Invites

headline: Housing Hunting in ... Croatia
abstract: Because development in Croatia ground to a halt during the financial crisis, brokers today are working with a very limited inventory.
lead_paragraph: A SIX-BEDROOM VILLA ON KOBAS BAY IN CROATIA

headline: K.K.R. Raises $2 Billion Energy Fund
abstract: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is making a bigger push into the North American energy business.
lead_paragraph: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is making a bigger push into the North American energy business, with a fresh $2 billion fund to invest in oil and gas assets.

headline: E.M.T.s With a Funny Bone
abstract: “Sirens,” Denis Leary’s new USA series about E.M.T.s, is the network’s first original half-hour comedy.
lead_paragraph: In seven seasons of “Rescue Me,” Denis Leary proved he could do drama with humor. In his new show, “Sirens,” he changes it up, proving he can do comedy without humor. It’s not clear why you would want to do this, but there it is.

headline: A Virtuous Divorced Man, Pestered to Date Again
abstract: In “Saint George,” a wearying new sitcom, George Lopez plays a divorced father with a hovering ex-wife whose family prods him to start meeting new people.
lead_paragraph: At times over the last dozen years, George Lopez has often seemed as if he were waging a one-man crusade against the dismaying underrepresentation of Latinos on mainstream English-language television in the United States. First there was his long-running sitcom “George Lopez.” Then came “Lopez Tonight,” his spunky late-night talk show.

headline: It’s the End of a Travoltified Season
abstract: Now that travoltifying your name is a thing, it’s time for the Carpetbagger to sign off.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What was that we were saying about cynicism?

headline: Amid the Slush Piles and Proofs Lurks a Page-Turner With a Dirty Secret
abstract: In “The Accident,” by Chris Pavone, a media mogul whose ethics are in the gutter could be brought even lower by a secret that is about to be published.
lead_paragraph: Chris Pavone managed to turn his experience in book editing and living in Luxembourg into an Edgar-winning spy novel, “The Expats.” With “The Accident,” he matches that first novel’s nail-biting level of excitement while continuing to write about what he knows. “The Accident” is a thriller about publishing, and if that sounds like an oxymoron, Mr. Pavone is very good at rendering it wildly dramatic. He’s also good at diverting close scrutiny about where any holes in his story may be. He just keeps the shocks coming and leaves the head scratching for later.

headline: Study Gives Hope of Altering Genes to Repel H.I.V.
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: A pilot study involving 12 people found that immune cells could be “edited” safely and that doing so sometimes helped fight infection.
lead_paragraph: The idea of genetically altering people’s cells to make them resist the virus that causes AIDS may seem like a pipe dream, but a new report suggests it can be done.

headline: No ‘Messiah,’ but It Does Bring the House Down
abstract: The American Classical Orchestra performed Handel’s oratorio “Samson” as part of Handelfest at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Handel, in his late 50s, was on a roll. His oratorio “Samson” had its premiere in February 1743, less than a year after “Messiah.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, South Africa, France and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, South Africa, France and China.

headline: News Flash: John Cornyn Is Really Conservative
abstract: Steve Stockman tried, and failed, to convince Texans that their senator was insufficiently right-wing.
lead_paragraph: Steve Stockman, the fringe-right congressman from Texas, spent the last few weeks trying to make the case that Senator John Cornyn was insufficiently conservative. He lost Tuesday’s Republican primary in part on his own merits — Texans expect their candidates to show up for a campaign — but also because the effort was unnecessary. Mr. Cornyn gave in to the Tea Party a long time ago.

headline: LinkedIn Co-Founder Defends EBay Against Icahn
abstract: In a post on LinkedIn, Reid Hoffman criticized Carl C. Icahn’s campaign against eBay, arguing that the assault is rooted in short-term thinking that runs counter to Silicon Valley’s focus on long-term growth.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn’s battle against eBay has drawn a number of boldface names into the fray. The latest entrant happens to be one of the most prominent executives in Silicon Valley at the moment: the LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman.

headline: Stark Drama That’s Found in Real Life
keywords: ['Television', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: CNN presents new eight-part documentary series — “Chicagoland,” about imperiled schools, and “Death Row Stories,” about defendants unfairly tried — both with Robert Redford as executive producer.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir V. Pozner, the Russian talk-show host who more than two decades ago spun the Cold War, is back on American television, warning CNN viewers not to believe everything they hear about Ukraine in the American news media.

headline: Raising, and Understanding, the Class Clown
abstract: Making people laugh makes my son feel good, and feeling good is better than feeling uncomfortable when you don’t know what to do or how to do it. I know, because I do the same thing.
lead_paragraph: “Look – he’s under there,” the teacher said, pointing.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Russia, South Africa and France.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Russia, South Africa and France.

headline: What You Get for ... $700,000
abstract: This week’s homes include a rowhouse in Washington, D.C.; an adobe in New Mexico; and a 1902 home in Washington State.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, D.C.

headline: Ives’s Study Resurrected, Inch by Inch
abstract: Charles Ives’s study from his Connecticut house has been reconstructed item by item at the American Academy of Arts and Letters in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: There was much hand wringing in the classical music world in the summer of 2012 when word emerged that Charles Ives’s house in West Redding, Conn., was up for sale, and it seemed possible — likely, even — that this iconoclastic composer’s retreat faced imminent destruction. The asking price for the 18.5-acre property was $1.5 million, and developers were said to be eager to tear down the modest house in Fairfield County where Ives lived from 1914 until his death in 1954.

headline: Rihanna Gets Checked Out at Paris Fashion Week
abstract: The singer took the prize as the week’s most inescapable front-row presence.
lead_paragraph: The singer took the prize as the week’s most inescapable front-row presence.

headline: Rihanna Gets Checked Out
abstract: The Chanel show was just the latest appearance by Rihanna during Paris Fashion Week, as she clearly took the prize as the week’s most inescapable front-row presence.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Wait, was that Rihanna going by in a shopping cart?

headline: Musical Allies and Brothers in Song
abstract: Paul Simon and Sting reveal both their kinship and their differences on a tour together.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing for two longtime stars to share a double bill that pools their audiences and lets them play larger places. It’s another to do what Paul Simon and Sting are doing on their arena tour together: actually to team up for about one-third of the concert, sharing songs and mingling the 14 backup musicians from their bands, displaying mutual respect without undue deference. (The tour has two T-shirts: one that reads “Paul Simon & Sting on Stage Together,” the other vice versa.)

headline: At the End, a New Start
abstract: For many in the crowd, Nicolas Ghesquière’s debut collection for Louis Vuitton was the return of the prodigal son after his sudden and bitter departure from Balenciaga.
lead_paragraph: For many in the crowd, Nicolas Ghesquière’s debut collection for Louis Vuitton was the return of the prodigal son after his sudden and bitter departure from Balenciaga.

headline: At the End, a New Start
abstract: Nicolas Ghesquière, the former Balenciaga designer returns to the runway with his debut collection for Louis Vuitton, which caps a monthlong fashion whirlwind.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Wednesday morning, the last day of Paris Fashion Week, a throng of attendees arrived at the Cour Carrée of the Louvre a half-hour early to wait in line for Nicolas Ghesquière’s debut collection for Louis Vuitton.

headline: Gold Coast Congress Shows Upside of Being Down Under
abstract: A lot of top players compete in the Gold Coast Congress in Australia, but the social side is almost as important.
lead_paragraph: If you are planning a trip to Australia, it would be a good idea to visit the Gold Coast, south of Brisbane in Queensland, in February. That is when the eight-day Gold Coast Congress is held. A lot of top players compete, making the bridge excellent, but the social side is almost as important.

headline: Kerry Continues Talks on Ukraine Crisis
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry said he and his counterparts from Russia, France, Germany, Britain and Ukraine met in Paris and agreed to continue talks on how to stabilize Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry said he and his counterparts from Russia, France, Germany, Britain and Ukraine met in Paris and agreed to continue talks on how to stabilize Ukraine.

headline: New Trips for Cycling in the City
abstract: Bicycle Adventures has new four-day trips in Seattle; Portland and Bend, Ore.; and New York City.
lead_paragraph: If bicycling along the scenic countryside is getting a little ho-hum, Bicycle Adventures offers an alternative. The outfitter just began the Urban Adventure Series, four-day trips designed for the city lover — this year in Seattle; Portland and Bend, Ore.; and New York City.

headline: Player Ratings: Ukraine 2, U.S. 0
abstract: Analyzing the performance of American players in Wednesday’s 2-0 loss to Ukraine in an international friendly match played in Cyprus.
lead_paragraph: In a game that offered little comfort to Coach Jurgen Klinsmann 99 days before the start of the World Cup in Brazil, the United States lost decisively to a team from Ukraine that appeared inspired in the face of the international crisis gripping its country.

headline: A France Made of More Than Whimsy
abstract: From “The Marchers” to “School of Babel” to “The Apaches” and more, this year’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema festival spotlights less traditional, more rough-edged films.
lead_paragraph: Paris is no longer the center of the universe. L’amour no longer makes the world go ’round. And Catherine Deneuve, that regal symbol of eternal beauty and Gallic composure, has stepped down from her pedestal. Those are among the significant deviations from tradition in the 19th edition of Rendez-Vous With French Cinema, the annual showcase of recent French movies presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and Unifrance Films.

headline: Travel Essentials | Tokyo
abstract: Pop art superstar Takashi Murakami and the Scandinavian caffeine junkies behind one of Tokyo’s hottest coffee shops share their favorite places to eat and drink in the Japanese capital.
lead_paragraph: Where to eat, drink and caffeinate in Shibuya and the surrounding areas, courtesy of Takashi Murakami and the Scandanavian trio behind the coffee shop Fuglen.

headline: Food Matters | Culture Klatch
abstract: The Japanese artist Takashi Murakami has teamed up with a trio of Scandinavian coffee and design aficionados to open Bar Zingaro, the coolest new cafe in Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese artist Takashi Murakami has teamed up with a trio of Scandinavian coffee and design aficionados to open Bar Zingaro, the coolest new cafe in Tokyo.

headline: The Mystery Car of the Geneva Motor Show
abstract: It looks like a Hispano-Suiza and wears a Pic-Pic badge, but its pedigree is as convoluted as its history.
lead_paragraph: The mystery car tooling around at the Geneva Motor Show this week, acting as a kind of V.I.P. shuttle, is itself a special vehicle. It is – more or less – a Hispano Suiza. But it is also something else. The car wears the badge “Pic-Pic,” which Geneva claims as its one and only hometown automaker.

headline: Beethoven Sonatas for Two, With Violin and Piano Precisely Balanced
abstract: The Greek violinist Leonidas Kavakos and the Italian pianist Enrico Pace presented the second installment of their three-part traversal of the complete Beethoven Sonatas for piano and violin at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: On Monday evening, the Greek violinist Leonidas Kavakos and the Italian pianist Enrico Pace presented the second installment of their three-part traversal of the complete Beethoven Sonatas for piano and violin at Zankel Hall. It was, in many ways, a seductive performance.

headline: A Hip-Hop Everyman, Pumped Up for a Star Turn With a Top Album
abstract: The Los Angeles rapper Schoolboy Q, whose major-label debut album just topped the Billboard chart, performed at Best Buy Theater on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: Not all second bananas are sidekicks. Take Schoolboy Q, the Los Angeles rapper and longtime running mate of Kendrick Lamar, one of hip-hop’s ascendant stars. The two share a label, Top Dawg Entertainment, and they recently shared the cover of Billboard. Without a doubt, though, the stronger wind belongs to Mr. Lamar, an inventive stylist and mercurial personality loved by purists and progressives.

headline: All the Glamour, With No Acceptance Speeches
abstract: The Vanity Fair after-party draws a gold-plated crowd.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — “I’ve been here since 5,” said Tom Ford, his hands encircling Anne Hathaway’s slim waist at the entrance to the Vanity Fair Oscars after-party on Sunday. It was nearly midnight. He waggled a finger at the bow tie worn by Ms. Hathaway’s husband, Adam Shulman, who didn’t seem to mind.

headline: SAT Scores of the Rich and Famous
abstract: An overhaul of the SAT is no longer relevant to these famous figures who shared their test scores in past interviews.
lead_paragraph: The College Board announced today that it will fundamentally change the SAT exam and return to the old 1,600 grading scale, which prompted a wave of people tweeting their SAT scores, followed by a wave of people tweeting their annoyance about the tweeting of SAT scores.

headline: Escaping Winter in New York
abstract: Have you forgotten what warm, sunny weather feels like? You are certainly not alone. Here is a look at a few places that other New Yorkers have turned to for respite.
lead_paragraph: We have been through so much in this seemingly unending and often brutal winter.

headline: Repairing History and Other Dog Tricks
abstract: “Peabody’s Improbable History,” a segment on the Bullwinkle and Rocky shows in the 1950s and ’60s, inspired the new film “Mr. Peabody & Sherman.”
lead_paragraph: The setup for “Peabody’s Improbable History” was simple: It featured the cartoon tales of a dog and his adopted boy (who just happened to share a time machine). Sherman, the boy, played the panting straight man to the dog, Mr. Peabody, rather than the lad in danger, like Timmy did with that brave collie Lassie. And while Lassie had her fine points, she was a tongue-lolling dunce when compared to Mr. Peabody.

headline: Heavy Petting Is Allowed
abstract: Whether real or faux, fur trumps for fall; re-imagined takes on socks and album tees; and a new line of clothing with a military slant.
lead_paragraph: If you want to be in vogue next fall, you had best start saving now, for there was fur on the runway in show after show, especially in softer colors. At Marc Jacobs, there were ombré pastel jackets; at the up-and-comer Kaelen, pretty pink stoles; at Gucci, shaggy toppers in pinks and blues. Fashion week showgoers appeared hip to what they would see on the catwalk, as they, too, bundled up in chalky furs. Already, there are furry bits for spring in the stores: offbeat shearling lace-up oxfords from Amélie Pichard and faux-fur clutches and jackets from the English label Shrimps, any of which are sly options for getting the look. As are these cheerfully surreal earrings, a collaboration between Fendi and the jeweler Delfina Delettrez, for whom an eye is a signature motif.

headline: Events and Sales Starting the Week of March 6
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Sunglasses', 'Hats and Caps']
abstract: Beat the polar vortex blues with spring focused pop-ups, sample sales and more.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: Paris Fashion Week: Hermes Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Catering to the Refined Ruffian
abstract: Kinfolk, a men’s wear boutique in Brooklyn with pieces suitable for dinner (with mussed hair).
lead_paragraph: A THUG AGES. Slows down. Softens. Begins to look both ways when crossing the street. Walks a little more slowly around older people. Looks babies in the eye, and smiles.

headline: Dutiful, Beautiful, Morning and Night
abstract: When it comes to beauty products, the actress and singer Zoë Kravitz is all about maintaining a luxuriously bohemian regimen.
lead_paragraph: Zoë Kravitz, 25, the daughter of the singer Lenny Kravitz and the actress Lisa Bonet, has pursued both of her parents’ professions. Her new projects include a supporting role in the soon-to-be-released “Divergent,” an action movie based on the first book in a trilogy of young-adult novels by Veronica Roth. Born in the Venice section of Los Angeles, Ms. Kravitz, who is also a member of the rock band Lolawolf, now lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, with the kind of luxuriously bohemian beauty regimen common to each neighborhood.

headline: One Part Mr. Peanut, One Part Hipster Chic
abstract: Not everyone can carry off wearing a monocle, but those who can stand out.
lead_paragraph: The one-lensed eyepiece, an item favored by 19th-century military men, robber barons and Mr. Peanut, is finding itself wedged anew into the ocular sockets of would-be gentlemen seeking to emulate the stern countenances of their stuffy forebears.

headline: Envy, Anger and the 1 Percent
abstract: Readers take issue with a Sunday Review essay by Arthur C. Brooks of the American Enterprise Institute.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Redoing a Nest for Bird-Watchers
abstract: An 18th-century farmhouse at the Norman Bird Sanctuary in Rhode Island has been refurbished for retreats.
lead_paragraph: The Norman Bird Sanctuary is 325 acres of startling geography overlooking the Atlantic Ocean and the Sakonnet River in Middletown, R.I. Its benefactor was Mabel Norman Cerio, a local artist who lived in its farmhouse in the late 19th century and bequeathed the property “for the propagation, preservation and protection of birds.” Since 1949, the sanctuary has done just that, but Ms. Cerio’s 18th-century house has been slowly rotting away. In a collaboration between the Urban Design Group of Bristol, R.I., and Foster Associates of Portsmouth, R.I., the place was taken down to its studs and meticulously reconstructed. It’s spare, though not spartan, so the emphasis is on the architectural details and the views. The farmhouse has seven bedrooms and sleeps 16 (there are three bunk beds in one bedroom); it is open for retreats of all sorts, from family weekend “roosts” to yoga retreats. Natasha Harrison, executive director of the Norman Bird Sanctuary, said that next year she hopes to host artists’ residencies, too. Information: 401-846-2577 or normanbirdsanctuary.org.

headline: Architecture to Promote Healing and Comfort
abstract: “Maggie’s Centres: A Blueprint for Cancer Care” displays facilities by eminent designers.
lead_paragraph: In 1995, Maggie Keswick, an expert on Chinese gardens who was terminally ill with breast cancer, founded an organization with her husband, the architecture critic Charles Jencks, to provide free information and support for people with cancer and their families. The first Maggie’s Centre opened in Edinburgh in November 1996, a year after her death, with services that included guidance in navigating the medical system and advice on where to buy a wig. Now there are 16 centers in Britain and one in Hong Kong. All are on the grounds of cancer hospitals, and share a reliance on design to promote healing and comfort. “Architecture amplifies the message,” Mr. Jencks said. “Maggie’s Centres: A Blueprint for Cancer Care,” on view from Friday through April 25 at the New York School of Interior Design, features centers designed by Frank Gehry (in Dundee), Rem Koolhaas, Richard Rogers, Steven Holl, and Piers Gough with Paul Smith. Information: 212-472-1500 or nysid.edu.

headline: Tapping Into a Goodnight
abstract: The wide-awake look to smartphones and apps to make it through the night.
lead_paragraph: Insomnia is always a miserable experience, but at least it used to be an eclectic one. On long nights, a sleepless soul had options: toss and turn, pour a drink, smoke a cigarette, organize shoes, watch TV, count sheep, look out the window. Evelyn Waugh sipped a mixture of bromide and crème de menthe; William Styron stared straight ahead into the darkness.

headline: Nordic, for Outdoors
abstract: The first collection of outdoor furniture developed exclusively for Design Within Reach was designed by Danes inspired by Danes.
lead_paragraph: It may seem counterintuitive to ask a couple of guys from Scandinavia to design outdoor furniture, but that is the brief Design Within Reach gave to Jonas Bjerre-Poulsen and Kasper Ronn of NORM Architects in Copenhagen. “We can really only use it six months a year; it’s so snowy and rainy,” Mr. Bjerre-Poulsen said. But who else can be counted on to draw from the serene midcentury modern aesthetic of Danish designers like Finn Juhl? The nine-piece group, which is called Finn after Mr. Juhl and is the first outdoor furniture collection developed exclusively for Design Within Reach, includes tables, chairs and recliners, below. The pieces are framed in teak with seats of Serge Ferrari mesh or Sunbrella upholstery. Prices range from $375 for a side table to $1,985 for a dining table. Information: 800-944-2233 or dwr.com.

headline: Sales at Ann Gish, Artek and More
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Discount Selling', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Deals at bed linens, furniture and others.
lead_paragraph: Ann Gish is discounting some sample bed linens by up to 80 percent through Saturday (a king-size quilted silk charmeuse coverlet, usually $1,200, is $240); 4 West 20th Street (Fifth Avenue), 212-727-2122, anngish.com.

headline: Should I Replace Fake Wood Paneling?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Yes, unless you want to attract prospective buyers wh0 only feel at home in rec rooms.
lead_paragraph: Q. Some of the walls in our house are covered in fake wood paneling. Should we replace it?

headline: Getting Contractors to Man Up
abstract: Adam Carolla is host of “Catch a Contractor,” a new TV series that promises to force unscrupulous contractors to make amends.
lead_paragraph: When stories about home renovation end in tears, the villain, likelier than not, is the contractor. Now a reality show purports to find the bad eggs and bring them to justice. “Catch a Contractor” starts Sunday on Spike TV, hosted by the comedian, author and radio personality Adam Carolla. For the series, Mr. Carolla, who is 49 and had a previous career in carpentry, teams up with Skip Bedell, a general contractor, and Mr. Bedell’s wife, Alison, a private investigator. Their mission: track down negligent contractors, return them to the scene of the crime and assist them in making amends. (This interview was edited and condensed.)

headline: Our Homes, Our Selfies
abstract: Celebrities photograph their cribs in “Behind Closed Doors: The Private Homes of 25 of the World’s Most Creative People.”
lead_paragraph: What a clever conceit the British designer and journalist Rob Meyers had to mail disposable cameras to musicians, artists, designers and bloggers, asking if they would snap pictures of their homes. “They seemed to like the idea that it was non-intrusive,” Mr. Meyers writes in the introduction to his new book, “Behind Closed Doors: The Private Homes of 25 of the World’s Most Creative People” ($29.95, Hardie Grant).

headline: Salad Bowls and Servers: Croutons Optional
abstract: If you want to teach kids to eat their greens, attractive tableware can’t hurt your cause.
lead_paragraph: As the executive director of Edible Schoolyard NYC, it is Kate Brashares’s job to help children learn how to grow and prepare their own food.

headline: Russian Channel’s War Coverage Continues to Cost It Journalists
abstract: Russia Today, a government-funded English language news channel, has been rocked in recent days by two of its anchors protesting its coverage of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russia Today, a government-funded English language news channel that says it is available to 644 million people worldwide and 85 million in the United States, has been rocked in recent days by two of its anchors protesting its coverage of Ukraine.

headline: Scratching a Niche
abstract: Three landscape designers offer visions for filling a neglected 10-by-10-foot plot.
lead_paragraph: I recently asked a distinguished garden designer what I should plant in the blank space next to my garage, and he said a wheat field. Interesting choice. But then I’ve read that “heritage grains” are fashionable in that obsolete kind of way: like landlines and pencils and romantic love.

headline: A Keen Eye on the Fitness Scene
abstract: Fitness devotees are eager readers of Well&Good NYC, a website that appraises beauty products, workout studios and so-called health food.
lead_paragraph: As beginnings go, Well&Good NYC’s wasn’t exactly auspicious, with posts such as “Keeping Your Runner’s High in High Temperatures” and “Does Your Apartment Need a Master Cleanse?” Even the website’s November 2009 missive about the “heinous karmic crime” of TriBeCa yogis stealing their studio’s $70 mats — which put Well&Good on the map when New York magazine picked it up — today makes its founders, Alexia Brue and Melisse Gelula, cringe as if they were confronting old yearbook photos.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: 99 Days
abstract: Brazil defeated South Africa, 5-0, in a friendly match on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Through Van Noten’s Eyes
abstract: What’s notable about a new show on Dries Van Noten is how much in it is not by him.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The most surprising thing about the new Dries Van Noten exhibition, which runs through Aug. 31 at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs here, is twofold: how much Dries Van Noten there is in it, and how much Dries Van Noten there isn’t in it.

headline: Laws in California Governing Chicken Farms
abstract: Readers including Bruce Friedrich of Farm Sanctuary respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sean Potts, 83, Master of the Tin Whistle and a Founder of the Chieftains, Dies
abstract: Mr. Potts learned to play the tin whistle from his grandfather in the 1930s and took stirring solos onstage as a member of the traditional Irish band.
lead_paragraph: Sean Potts, who learned to play the tin whistle from his grandfather in the 1930s and for a time made an international career out of it as a founding member of the traditional Irish band the Chieftains, died on Feb. 11 in Dublin. He was 83.

headline: The Digital Classroom
abstract: A parent writes that children need to experience “a more deliberate type of learning.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Michael Ford’s Homeplace: Mississippi in the 1970s
abstract: The filmmaker found a home and life lessons in unexpected terrain — a blacksmith shop in Oxford, Miss., where all people, “young, old, black, white, drunk, sober,” were treated equally.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker found a home and life lessons in unexpected terrain — a blacksmith shop in Oxford, Miss., where all people, “young, old, black, white, drunk, sober,” were treated equally.

headline: Drug Arrests and Race
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Marijuana', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The American Civil Liberties Union says racial injustice should be considered in the debate over marijuana legalization.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: His Profile, and His Plumage, Grow Ever More Bold
abstract: Johnny Weir knows when someone cuts a sharp figure.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday, at a soundstage in Los Angeles, the only article of clothing Johnny Weir didn’t change five times was a pair of Versace underwear.

headline: Federal Truck-Size Limits
keywords: ['Trucks and Trucking', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Bridges and Tunnels']
abstract: Joan Claybrook, a former National Highway Traffic Safety administrator, responds to an online Retro Report.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Criminal Charges Expected for 3 Former Dewey & LeBoeuf Executives
abstract: Three former top executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the giant law firm that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2012, are expected to be charged with misleading other lawyers and lenders about the financial health of the firm.
lead_paragraph: Three former top executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf, the giant law firm that filed for bankruptcy protection in 2012, are expected to be charged on Thursday with misleading other lawyers and lenders about the financial health of the firm.

headline: Stairs, an East Village Gay Club, Opens
abstract: A former Italian restaurant has turned into a two-level gay club.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the East Village gay bar scene has diminished as places like the Slide, the Hose and the Urge have closed. So neighborhood gays were curious when a new club called Stairs opened in January.

headline: For the Infamous, More Than 15 Minutes
abstract: Gina Rodriguez, an ex-porn actress, carved out a career representing tabloid names laden with scandal.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t mind calling them D-listers,” said Gina Rodriguez, the former pornographic-film actress from Los Angeles, who has carved out an unlikely second career representing tabloid fodder like Anthony Weiner’s ex-sexting gal pal, Sydney Leathers; the parents of Lindsay Lohan, and various cast members from Bravo’s “Real Housewives” series.

headline: Coal Firm to Pay Record Penalty and Spend Millions on Water Cleanup in 5 States
abstract: Alpha Natural Resources and 66 of its subsidiaries agreed to reduce pollution from coal mines in Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s biggest coal companies will pay a record civil penalty and will spend tens of millions of dollars to clean up water flowing from mines in five states, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Justice Department announced on Wednesday.

headline: Notes Composed for the Nose
abstract: Fabio Luisi, principal conductor for the Metropolitan Opera in New York, is seduced by the magic of creating his own scents.
lead_paragraph: The city was blanketed in winter, but in a kitchen with a bird’s-eye view of Central Park, Fabio Luisi was conjuring up spring.

headline: This Old Thing Is Turning Heads
abstract: An antiques-show dress overshadows any looks from the runway shows.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most captivating fashion statement this season in New York was not on the runway or the street, but at the Winter Antiques Show: a modest black and white vintage dress, in mint condition and priced at $135,000, displayed by Allan Katz Americana, that was vigorously photographed, shared on Instagram and Facebook, and pinned on Pinterest.

headline: Infections Linked to Chinese Seafood Markets in New York
keywords: ['Seafood', 'Skin', 'Infections', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning']
abstract: Health officials warned people to take precautions when handling raw fish after at least 30 people who bought seafood in Chinese markets contracted a rare skin infection.
lead_paragraph: At least 30 people have contracted a rare skin infection after buying seafood at markets in Chinese neighborhoods across New York City, prompting health officials to issue a warning to consumers and market workers to take precautions when handling raw or live fish.

headline: Wisconsin and the Unions
abstract: Readers respond to “The Wisconsin Legacy” (Feb. 23).
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin and the Unions

headline: The Wildebeest in the Room
abstract: The “lovely-weird” visual style of Wes Anderson’s movies is finding its way into home décor and even weddings.
lead_paragraph: Paige Joost likes the “awkward, naïve, but dark quality” she sees in the themes of Wes Anderson, the fabulist moviemaker, and she loves the washed-out Polaroid palette he often works in, which reminds her of the 1970s, a place she has never visited.

headline: Justices May Limit Securities Fraud Suits
abstract: The justices seemed to be leaning toward setting a higher bar for groups of investors to pursue claims they were misled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday seemed ready to impose new limits on securities fraud suits that would make it harder for investors to band together to pursue claims that they were misled when they bought or sold securities. But the justices did not seem inclined to issue a ruling that would put an end to most such suits.

headline: Examining a Generation Tied to Smartphones
abstract: AT&T is introducing a major effort that highlights how connected young Americans are to their devices.
lead_paragraph: SO attached to their cellphones are 18- to 24-year-olds that 61 percent of them sleep next to their devices, compared with just 22 percent of cellphone owners over 65 who do so, according to the Pew Research Center. While that might depress those who yearn for simpler times, such devotion delights AT&T, and now the phone carrier is introducing a major effort that highlights how connected young Americans are to their devices.

headline: Massachusetts: Ruling Favors Man Accused of Taking ‘Upskirt’ Images
abstract: The State Supreme Judicial Court ruled Wednesday that a law prohibiting the secret photographing of nude or partly nude people who could reasonably expect privacy does not apply to “upskirt” photos taken of clothed people in public.
lead_paragraph: The State Supreme Judicial Court ruled Wednesday that a law prohibiting the secret photographing of nude or partly nude people who could reasonably expect privacy does not apply to “upskirt” photos taken of clothed people in public. The court ruled in the case of Michael Robertson, who was arrested in 2010 and accused of taking cellphone photos and videos of women’s crotches on the Boston subway. The ruling reversed a lower court’s denial of his motion to dismiss the case. House Speaker Robert A. DeLeo pledged to update state law “to conform with today’s technology.”

headline: Break It and No Allowance
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Art', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: A family home where children and an extensive art collection can peacefully coexist.
lead_paragraph: In one corner of the room, playing on a thin glass screen dangling from the ceiling by wires, was a moody animated video from “The Last Clown” installation by the artist Francis Alys on a continuous loop: a solitary man making his way along a path in an anonymous park.

headline: De Blasio Drops Challenge to Law on Police Profiling
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said New York City was abandoning a lawsuit against the City Council to block a 2013 measure intended to curb profiling.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Wednesday that his administration would drop a lawsuit against the City Council, brought in the waning months of the Bloomberg administration, that sought to block a new law intended to prevent police profiling in New York.

headline: Illinois: Council Goes on Record to Oppose Honor for Eliot Ness
abstract: Passing a symbolic resolution Wednesday, Chicago’s City Council unanimously opposed naming a federal building in Washington after Eliot Ness, the prohibition-era agent whose team of lawmen in Chicago inspired “The Untouchables” book, movie and television series.
lead_paragraph: Passing a symbolic resolution Wednesday, Chicago’s City Council unanimously opposed naming a federal building in Washington after Eliot Ness, the Prohibition-era agent whose team of lawmen in Chicago inspired “The Untouchables” book, movie and television series. Three United States senators have proposed naming the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives headquarters after Ness, who is often credited with bringing the mobster Al Capone to justice. Critics of the plan say Ness does not deserve the honor because his role in imprisoning Capone, who was convicted of tax evasion, has been exaggerated.

headline: After a Dazzling Early Career, a Star Trader Settles Down
abstract: While Paul Tudor Jones II can still claim long-term annual returns of close to 19.5 percent in his $10.3 billion flagship fund, Tudor BVI Global, it has been 11 years since he last hit that level.
lead_paragraph: When Paul Tudor Jones II began his career as a Wall Street trader in the 1980s, some colleagues spoke admiringly of his ability to “shoot the lights out” by scoring huge profits on big market swings.

headline: Banned in Bangalore
abstract: What the controversy around my book says about modern India.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — LAST month a retired Hindu schoolteacher named Dinanath Batra, who had brought a lawsuit against me and Penguin Books, India, succeeded in getting my book, “The Hindus: An Alternative History,” withdrawn from publication in India. The book, the court agreed, was a violation of India’s blasphemy law, which makes it a crime to offend the sensibilities of a religious person.

headline: Yankees Will Assess Tanaka and Teixeira (and Technology)
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka will start Thursday, Mark Teixeira will play first base for the first time in almost nine months, and the team will get its first taste of the new instant replay rule.
lead_paragraph: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — Spring training usually signals several firsts for clubs, and for the Yankees it will be no different Thursday.

headline: Florida: Woman Drives Van With Children Into Ocean
abstract: The authorities in Daytona Beach are investigating an episode in which a pregnant woman drove her minivan into the Atlantic Ocean with her three children strapped in the back seat.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Daytona Beach are investigating an episode in which a pregnant woman drove her minivan into the Atlantic Ocean with her three children strapped in the back seat. Sheriff Ben F. Johnson of Volusia County said officials would interview the woman, who was in the hospital Wednesday and would undergo a mental health evaluation, before determining whether there was criminal intent or a mental health crisis in the episode on Tuesday. Her children were in state custody. Video showed the woman walk away as bystanders and rescuers rushed to pull her children to safety while the van bobbed in the surf. No one was seriously injured.

headline: In Health Care, Choice Is Overrated
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Narrow insurance networks are not the problem. The problem is that not all networks are of high enough quality.
lead_paragraph: LAST spring, a 48-year-old mother of two young girls in Colorado discovered that she had colon cancer. Her surgeon and oncologist disagreed about whether she needed chemotherapy. So a friend recommended she go to MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston for a second opinion. Just before she booked her plane ticket, a representative from MD Anderson called, informing her that its oncologists were outside her insurance company’s network and that she should bring $10,000 for the consultation.

headline: Heroin Scourge Overtakes a ‘Quaint’ Vermont Town
abstract: Bennington exudes an early American gentility, but the 21st century drug scourge is evident in the faces of some of the young people hanging out on Main Street.
lead_paragraph: BENNINGTON, Vt. — Stephanie Predel, a stick-thin 23-year-old freshly out of jail, said she was off heroin. But she knows precisely where she could get more drugs if she ever wanted them — at the support meetings for addicts.

headline: A Call for General Motors to Fill Gaps in Safety Inquiry
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Defective Products', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A national safety agency sent the automaker a list of 107 compulsory questions about a defective ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths and the recall of 1.6 million cars.
lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators indicated on Wednesday that General Motors had yet to turn over significant information related to a defective ignition switch that has been linked to 13 deaths and the recall of 1.6 million cars.

headline: Governing Party Candidate Pulls Out of Costa Rica’s Presidential Campaign
abstract: Sinking in the polls a month before Costa Rica’s presidential election, Johnny Araya, the candidate for the country’s governing party, pulled out of the campaign on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Sinking in the polls a month before Costa Rica’s presidential election, Johnny Araya, the candidate for the country’s governing party, pulled out of the campaign on Wednesday. Although his name remains on the ballot, Mr. Araya effectively conceded the election to Luis Guillermo Solís, a history professor and former Foreign Ministry official from the progressive Citizens Action Party. Under President Laura Chinchilla, the centrist National Liberation Party had become deeply unpopular over corruption scandals and increasing crime.

headline: Tracy McGrady Hopes to Trade Slam Dunks for Sliders
abstract: McGrady, a seven-time N.B.A. All-Star who retired last year, is trying to make the switch to baseball. “This is not a gimmick,” he said. “I do know the sport.”
lead_paragraph: SUGAR LAND, Tex. — Tracy McGrady’s training began in early November, but it was not geared toward a return to the basketball court — it was to fulfill a nagging dream of playing professional baseball.

headline: Republicans Place the Wrong Bet
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conservatives, grasping at straws and straining credulity, paint a picture of a president who is domestically dictatorial but internationally anemic.
lead_paragraph: Republicans may have bet too heavily on the wrong issue going into the midterm elections.

headline: Army General Offers Plea to Narrow Assault Case
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair offered to plead guilty to other, less-serious counts of misconduct, but still wants to face in court his accuser, a junior officer who says she was sexually assaulted.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — Hoping to narrow his court-martial to a showdown with a woman who accused him of sexual assault, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair said on Wednesday that he would plead guilty to less serious counts of misconduct, including adultery, soliciting explicit images and impeding an investigation.

headline: Billion Dollar Babies
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: An oligarch here. An oligarch there. Here an oligarch. There an oligarch. Everywhere an oligarch.
lead_paragraph: The Koch brothers are in the news more than Justin Bieber.

headline: Cat in Albany Is Outfoxing New York City’s Mouse
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is outmaneuvering Mayor Bill de Blasio in the debate over financing for prekindergarten education in New York City and charter schools.
lead_paragraph: Maybe the problem was with the metaphor.

headline: Pakistan’s Talks With Taliban Resume
abstract: Public contact between the representatives of the Taliban and Pakistani government resumed on Wednesday as Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif made another push to put a wavering peace dialogue back on track.
lead_paragraph: Public contact between the representatives of the Taliban and Pakistani government resumed on Wednesday as Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif made another push to put a wavering peace dialogue back on track. Mr. Sharif has invited a team of Taliban representatives to his official residence in Islamabad on Thursday, according to government officials. Maulana Sami ul-Haq, a religious leader who represents the Taliban, said he has accepted the invitation and would discuss ways to carry the peace talks forward. Earlier, committees representing the government and the Taliban met at Mr. Haq’s seminary in northwestern town Akora Khattak, the first such meeting since Feb.17, when talks were suspended after a faction of the Taliban claimed responsibility for the killing of 23 paramilitary soldiers. Despite a Taliban announcement of a cease-fire, terrorist attacks have continued across the country in recent days and have been claimed by obscure militant groups. The latest attack occurred Wednesday in northwestern Hangu district where a roadside bomb killed six paramilitary soldiers and wounded eight others.

headline: Who’s the Villain Here?
abstract: When Republicans slam President Obama for Ukraine’s crisis and demand that something be done, it’s childish and dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Shrewd reporting about the Ukraine crisis comes from The Onion, which declared that American reaction is evenly divided — between the “wholly indifferent” and the “grossly misinformed.”

headline: Two Arrested at Brooklyn Bank With A.T.M. Fraud Device
abstract: Two Romanians were suspected of trying to steal the card numbers and PINs of customers at a Chase branch on the northern edge of Park Slope.
lead_paragraph: It was meant to be a quick crime, the police said: Place a skimming machine over the card reader outside a Chase branch after dark, stick a couple of cameras above the keypads on the cash machines inside and wait to collect the numbers from unsuspecting customers.

headline: Ukraine Defeats United States in an Exhibition With Deeper Meaning
abstract: The United States players in an international friendly soccer match in Cyprus were hoping to earn a ticket to the World Cup. The Ukrainian team had much more on its mind.
lead_paragraph: LARNACA, Cyprus — It is often said that exhibition matches are played only for pride, but that is rarely true. Someone is always playing for something.

headline: Israel’s Choice
abstract: Does Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have an alternative to a two-state solution?
lead_paragraph: In Washington this week, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel sounded two different notes about peace negotiations with the Palestinians, which are nearing a critical juncture. In a speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the pro-Israel lobby, he enthusiastically advocated a peace agreement as a means to improve Israel’s ties with its Arab neighbors and “catapult the region forward” on issues like health, energy and education.

headline: Video of Pregnant Woman Who Drove Minivan Into the Atlantic
abstract: A woman who drove into the ocean in Florida with three children in her minivan seemed to suffer mental health issues and feared for her safety, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A pregnant woman who was captured on video driving her minivan with three children in it into the Atlantic Ocean in Daytona Beach, Fla., remained in the hospital Wednesday, undergoing a mental health evaluation, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Snow Mania
abstract: Growing up hungry in rural China in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: What did Spring Festival mean to a child like me, growing up in rural China in the early 1970s, in the aftermath of the Cultural Revolution? Chocolate? Not at a time when even table sugar was a luxury good. We hadn’t even heard of chocolate. Candy? Impossible. How could a poor family like ours, which was never even issued the official ration coupons, purchase it? Rice, then? No, not even that.

headline: Bin Laden Aide Began Qaeda Propaganda Day After 9/11, U.S. Says
abstract: A federal prosecutor in the trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith in Federal District Court in Manhattan said that Osama bin Laden had asked Mr. Abu Ghaith to help recruit new suicide bombers.
lead_paragraph: It was just hours after the Sept. 11 attacks when Osama bin Laden turned to an associate for help in rallying his troops and recruiting new suicide bombers and other fighters, a federal prosecutor told a jury on Wednesday.

headline: To Spur Traffic at News Sites, Just Travoltify
abstract: John Travolta’s mispronunciation of a name at the Oscars led the website Slate to create a feature to do the same with anyone’s name — the kind of interactive game now driving Web traffic.
lead_paragraph: Which of the following interactive features drove record traffic to its respective news sites in recent months: a) How Much Time Have You Wasted on Facebook? for Time; b) The interactive dialect quiz for The New York Times; c) The Adele Dazeem Generator: Travoltify Your Name, which appeared on Slate; or d) all of the above?

headline: Jail Sentence in France Over ‘Cyber Jihad’
abstract: A French convert to Islam was convicted of using the Internet to disseminate terrorist propaganda and promote participation in terrorist acts and was sentenced by a Paris court to one year in prison and two more on probation late Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A French convert to Islam was convicted of using the Internet to disseminate terrorist propaganda and promote participation in terrorist acts and was sentenced by a Paris court to one year in prison and two more on probation late Tuesday. The case is the first using a law passed in 2012 that makes “cyber jihad” a crime and potentially has serious consequences for freedom of expression in France. The law was passed in response to the attacks in Toulouse by Mohammed Merah, who killed seven people including three children and apparently was inspired in part by extremist Internet postings. The maximum sentence in Tuesday’s case could have been five years in prison, and the relatively light term given to Romain Letellier, 27, suggested that both prosecutors and judges were still considering how to apply the new law. The prosecutor said that the trial was happening in a context where young people become radicalized rapidly after reading material on the Internet.

headline: China Remodels an Ancient Silk Road City, and an Ethnic Rift Widens
abstract: China has razed thousands of traditional homes as it modernizes Kashgar, and the results underscore the divide between the government and the Muslim ethnic minority, the Uighurs.
lead_paragraph: KASHGAR, China — Visitors walking through the mud-brick rubble and yawning craters where close-packed houses and bazaars once stood could be forgiven for thinking that the ancient Silk Road city of Kashgar had been irrevocably lost to the wrecking ball. A billboard looming over the ruins tries to counter that impression: “Inherit and preserve the historical culture to showcase a brand new Kashgar.”

headline: Saratoga Springs Voices Opposition to Casino Law
abstract: The City Council of the gambling-rich upstate enclave passed a resolution this week opposing a New York State law that could permit a full-scale casino in the town.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In a symbolic rebuke from the leaders of a gambling-rich upstate enclave, the Saratoga Springs City Council unanimously passed a resolution this week declaring its opposition to a new state law that could permit a full-scale casino in their town.

headline: Colluding Against Programmers
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A class action lawsuit against employers in Silicon Valley, including Apple and Google, has lifted the curtain on secret, anti-competitive deals.
lead_paragraph: A class action lawsuit brought on behalf of software programmers and other technical professionals against seven large employers in Silicon Valley, including Apple and Google, has lifted the curtain on secret, anti-competitive deals that would warm the hearts of robber barons from the Gilded Age.

headline: Officials Investigating Spending by Director of Queens Library
abstract: An inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation will examine spending over the past three years by Thomas W. Galante, including a renovation to his office that cost a reported $140,000.
lead_paragraph: The director of the Queens Library system is under investigation after reports that he may have improperly used money designated for improving the libraries in the system for costly renovations to his personal office, including a private outdoor deck, and steered contracts for the work to a friend.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for March 5, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 5, 2014

headline: One Year After Chávez’s Death, a Divide in Venezuelans’ Fervor
abstract: Memorial events for Hugo Chávez served as a distraction from weeks of antigovernment protests and demonstrations against Venezuela’s deeply ingrained problems.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In the year since the death of Hugo Chávez, this country’s longtime socialist president, one thing has remained constant: He is still loved and hated with almost equal fervor.

headline: Venezuela Honors Chávez One Year Later
abstract: Venezuelans marked the first anniversary of the death of Hugo Chávez with a military parade in Caracas.
lead_paragraph: Venezuelans marked the first anniversary of the death of Hugo Chávez with a military parade in Caracas.

headline: After the Veto
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Religion-State Relations', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: The corporate identity of new claimants to religious protection is troubling when the Supreme Court seems intent on enhancing corporate power.
lead_paragraph: Once Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona yielded to the country’s political, business and sports establishment last week and vetoed the nasty measure known as S.B. 1062, the furor died down. The bill would have offered a legal defense for business owners who claim a religious reason for failing to abide by nondiscrimination laws in their dealings with the public. But the question remains what lesson to draw from the outcome of this particular effort to privilege claims of religious conscience over the general societal principle of nondiscrimination.

headline: Shakespeare Hits the Beach
abstract: Tarell Alvin McCraney’s squishy, misbegotten “Antony and Cleopatra” resets Shakespeare’s tragedy on the island of Hispaniola during the reign of the French.
lead_paragraph: You know that Caribbean vacation you’ve been dreaming about in these last draggy days of winter? Well, you may want to rethink such fantasies after you see the Tarell Alvin McCraney’s squishy, misbegotten “Antony and Cleopatra,” which resets Shakespeare’s tragedy on the island of Hispaniola during the reign of the French.

headline: Scrub Up
abstract: A zesty Thursday puzzle from Daniel Raymon.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Erno RUBIK, the Hungarian architect who is best known for inventing the Rubik’s Cube, once said that “the problems of puzzles are very near the problems of life.”

headline: Time for David Samson to Go
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Editorials']
abstract: The chairman of the Port Authority has too many troubling conflicts of interest to remain in the post.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey fired two associates involved in creating a four-day traffic jam at the George Washington Bridge to punish Fort Lee’s Democratic mayor, apologized for the mess and agreed to cooperate with various related investigations.

headline: Computer Searches at Center of Dispute on C.I.A. Detentions
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Detainees']
abstract: An office is at the center of an escalating fight between the spy agency and its congressional overseers, and an investigation by the C.I.A.’s inspector general.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For four years, investigators working for the Senate Intelligence Committee toiled away at a secret facility in Northern Virginia, poring over C.I.A. documents in an attempt to compile a history of the agency’s detention and interrogation program. Outfitted with secure computers and encrypted locks, it was set up by the C.I.A. so that the committee staff members could review millions of highly classified documents and stitch together a report that would eventually grow to 6,000 pages.

headline: StubHub to Penalize Ticket Sellers Trying to Cash In on Jeter
abstract: Ticket sellers who canceled sales to Yankees home games, particularly for the final home game of the regular season, and then tried to resell the same tickets for far more will face penalties.
lead_paragraph: Cashing in on Derek Jeter just got more expensive.

headline: Court Says Massachusetts Law Doesn’t Ban Photos Up Skirts
abstract: The state’s highest court ruled that “upskirting” isn’t covered by a law against secretly photographing partly nude people.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Massachusetts’ highest court ruled Wednesday that a law prohibiting the secret photographing of nude or partly nude people does not apply to “upskirting” — taking photos of areas beneath people’s clothes — in public.

headline: In Iraq, Celebration and Then Violence
abstract: While Iraqis were enjoying the victory of the national soccer team with celebratory gunfire, gunmen took advantage of the sounds of the shooting and opened fire on three police checkpoints in Baghdad, killing seven officers, according to police sources.
lead_paragraph: While Iraqis were enjoying the victory of the national soccer team with celebratory gunfire, gunmen took advantage of the sounds of the shooting and opened fire on three police checkpoints in Baghdad, killing seven officers, according to police sources. Iraq’s national soccer team had just defeated China, 3-1, to advance in the Asian Cup championship in Australia. Earlier Wednesday, the city witnessed a wave of six car bombings that killed at least 18 civilians and wounded more than 50 in public markets in Shiite neighborhoods, security forced said. In Anbar Province, two suicide bombers drove into two security checkpoints and killed at least ten officers, the government said.

headline: Now Wearing No. 13 for the Mets, Another Mazzilli
abstract: L. J. Mazzilli, the son of Lee Mazzilli, who helped the Mets win the 1986 World Series, is in his first spring training camp since being drafted last June.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When L. J. Mazzilli arrived at the Mets’ minor league complex for spring training last week, his blue jersey was already hanging in his locker. Mazzilli, No. 13, it read. He had not known that his name would be on it. And that he would be wearing one of his father’s old numbers, for one of his father’s old teams. And that it would be a real number, not some absurdly high one, like 75 or 63, that rarely shows up in the regular season. Ecstatic, he snapped a photo and sent it to his parents.

headline: No Longer Clashing, Wearable Tech Embraces Fashion
abstract: The days of chunky, loud-colored straps may be waning as the fashion industry tackles wearable gadgets.
lead_paragraph: WEARABLE electronics have been stuck in a design rut. Bulky watches, bright wristbands and Roman-gladiator-meets-the-Jetsons arm straps have been the go-to look for manufacturers like Nike and Jawbone.

headline: A Smartwatch Gains Some Style, but Few New Tricks
abstract: The Pebble Steel is a more elegant upgrade of the Pebble smartwatch, with many of the original’s drawbacks.
lead_paragraph: THE Pebble smartwatch ignited interest in watches that put the functions of your phone — texts, calls, emails, calendar and even apps — on your wrist. The second version of the Pebble, called Pebble Steel, is at once more grown-up and less useful than it should be.

headline: New Democratic Strategy Goes After Koch Brothers
abstract: Democrats are embarking on a broad effort that aims to unmask Charles G. and David H. Koch, the billionaire brothers who are perhaps the best-known patrons of conservative Republican politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Charles G. and David H. Koch, the billionaire brothers who are perhaps the best-known patrons of conservative Republican politics, are bespectacled and in their 70s. They look genial enough.

headline: 10 Students Who Overcame Odds Are Awarded Times Scholarships
abstract: The seniors at New York City high schools, of varying ethnicities and ambitions, have similar stories of outpacing the burdens of limited resources, and worse.
lead_paragraph: Most of Brianna Albanese’s goals sound like those of other promising, bright-eyed students headed for college next year: A lover of science fiction and a writer for her high school literary magazine, she wants to study psychology and literature in college. Someday, she said, she will write her own books.

headline: When the Doctor Is No Longer the Boss
abstract: Do large hospital systems’ economies of scale benefit all involved, or are there downsides for patients, physicians or others?

headline: Islanders Deal Vanek at N.H.L. Trade Deadline, but Devils Keep Brodeur
abstract: Thomas Vanek was traded to the Montreal Canadiens, his third team this season, in exchange for a conditional second-round draft pick and the prospect Sebastian Collberg.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders traded the high-scoring left wing Thomas Vanek to the Montreal Canadiens on Wednesday, just over four months after acquiring him from the Buffalo Sabres.

headline: Debate Over Who, in U.S., Is to Blame for Ukraine
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Washington’s partisan debaters have wasted little time in trying to frame the crisis in Eastern Europe as an indictment of their political opponents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Moscow, especially in the not-so-good old days, the question almost always asked is kto vinovat: “Who is to blame?” The American capital now finds itself engaged in that very Russian exercise ever since President Vladimir V. Putin’s troops entered Ukraine.

headline: Kevin Love Continues to Put Up Big Numbers
abstract: Love, a three-time All-Star who figures to be a coveted free agent in 2015 or 2016, improved his standing with a spectacular February for the Minnesota Timberwolves.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — More than three years ago, on the night of his greatest triumph as an N.B.A. player, Minnesota Timberwolves forward Kevin Love walked into the Loon, a sports bar down the street from the Target Center, to a conquerer’s welcome.

headline: For Russian TV Channels, Influence and Criticism
abstract: Russia’s government-operated networks are led by executives who have helped promote President Vladimir V. Putin’s agenda, but they are facing fact-checking over coverage of Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The conflict in Ukraine can be difficult to sort out, but on the most recent edition of “Vesti Nedeli,” Russia’s most popular evening news program, a sober-voiced announcer broke it down into very simple terms. “Experts,” he intoned, “are more and more comparing the actions of these nationalists with those who came to power in Germany in the 1930s.”

headline: Nets Burst to an Early Lead, Then Cruise Past .500
abstract: The Nets can finally call themselves a winning team after a victory over Memphis pushed their record to 30-29. They also signed Jason Collins to a second 10-day contract.
lead_paragraph: The Nets have worked relentlessly to dig themselves out of the hole they created early in the season. On Wednesday night, with a 103-94 win over the Memphis Grizzlies at Barclays Center, they can finally call themselves a winning team, with a record of 30-29.

headline: An Evacuation of Jews, With Help From Japan
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Visas', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Grand Central Terminal (NYC)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: As Japan Week begins in New York City, a video about the roles of a diplomat and a tourist-bureau employee in saving Jews from the Nazis will be shown at Grand Central Terminal on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: It is not the usual subject for a tourism video: how Japanese officials — including a Japanese diplomat in Lithuania and an employee of a tourist bureau — helped Jews flee the Nazis just before World War II.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: A Fake Rock and a Fake Relationship (or Two)
abstract: The spy gadget that your mother and father can remember from grade school.
lead_paragraph: So last season “The Americans” offered up a camera hidden in a bra, and in Season 2’s latest episode, it goes a step further with what is perhaps the hoariest of spy gadgets: the hollow, fake rock carrying secret data.

headline: Knicks End Skid, but It’s Still a Struggle
abstract: The Knicks nearly blew a double-digit lead in the second half before holding off Minnesota and ending a torturous seven-game losing streak.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — In the midst of an introspective interview at the morning shootaround Wednesday, in which he maintained he was still the right man to coach the Knicks, Mike Woodson succinctly broke down his nose-diving team’s biggest problem.

headline: Pope Moves to Deflate Breathless Portrayals of Stardom
abstract: Ahead of the first anniversary of his election to the papacy, Francis used a newspaper interview to depict himself as a normal person.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Declaring his frustrations with being portrayed as a superman or a star, Pope Francis used an interview to depict himself as a normal person who laughs, cries and misses his ailing sister, while defending the Roman Catholic Church’s handling of the clerical sexual-abuse scandal and reiterating his belief that women should play a larger role in church decision making.

headline: Mystery Men at De Facto Crimean Border Help Fuel Suspicion and Dread
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Russian Language', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Soldiers gathered at the sliver of land separating Crimea and the rest of Ukraine leave little doubt that they have dug in for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: ARMYANSK, Ukraine — If anyone wonders if Russia and its supporters in Crimea are serious about holding on to territory that is still formally part of Ukraine, the de facto border checkpoint near this shabby garrison town on the northern edge of the peninsula dispels any doubt.

headline: Tea Party in Texas Sees Silver Linings in G.O.P. Primaries
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: While establishment candidates in some of the top races were successful, Texas Republicans continued to tilt ever further right.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — There was no Ted Cruz, coming out of nowhere in a blaze of Tea Party fervor, to upend the establishment in a marquee race when Texas Republicans went to the polls Tuesday in the nation’s first round of 2014 primaries.

headline: Friends. New Yorkers. Countrymen.
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio praise each other publicly, insisting that they disagree only on the means to achieve more prekindergarten education for New York, not upon the ends.

headline: Golfers’ Will to Win Gets a Boost From Pit Crews for Aching Bodies
abstract: As technology has become more unforgiving and players’ schedules more unrelenting, a cottage industry of pit crews employed to work on golfers’ bodies has taken root.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Winning multiple PGA Tour titles is hard, even if Tiger Woods made it look ridiculously easy as recently as last year, when he collected five titles in 16 starts to raise his career total to 79. The Australian Jason Day, a two-time tour winner, suggested that Woods, in his drive to become golf’s career leader in tour wins and major championships, developed an automatic pilot that few athletes could access.

headline: A Post-Fashion-Week Pampering Getaway
abstract: At a luxe new Tulum spa, Mayan treatments soothe the stressed-out style set.
lead_paragraph: Tulum, a walled seaside city on the southern edge of Mexico’s Riviera Maya, has long been a popular getaway for the fashion set and yoga enthusiasts. Now, serious spa devotees are also flocking to the luxe oceanside hotel there, Be Tulum, thanks to the recent opening of Yaan Energy Wellness Spa. Guests like Demi Moore, Sting and his wife, Trudie Styler, have been among the first to receive massage, Mayan healing and energy treatments in one of the five new personal cabins on-site, which are situated across from the hotel on the jungle side of the road. “A designer friend says it looks like some extraterrestrials came to Tulum to do a co-venture with the Mayans,” says Sebastian Sas, an Argentinian architect and Be Tulum’s owner.

Yanukovych from power, he and his friends had fortified their barricades anew.

headline: Francis Has Changed American Catholics’ Attitudes, but Not Their Behavior, a Poll Finds
abstract: Most Catholics say Pope Francis represents a change for the church, but his popularity has not inspired more Americans to attend Mass or identify as Catholic, a poll found.
lead_paragraph: One year into the era of Pope Francis, a new poll has found that a broad majority of American Catholics say he represents a major change in direction for the church, and a change for the better. But his popularity has not inspired more Americans to attend Mass, go to confession or identify as Catholic — a finding that suggests that so far, the much-vaunted “Francis effect” is influencing attitudes, but not behavior.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:40 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE LADY (2012) In this biopic from the director Luc Besson, Michelle Yeoh, left, portrays the Burmese opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize winner Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, who was elected to Parliament in April 2012 after more than 20 years of house arrest. She came from her home in England in 1988 to what is now Myanmar to tend her dying mother. When asked, she refused to leave the country and was arrested. “Though she is isolated in her family’s compound in the capital, Suu is not alone in ‘The Lady,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “While it is a chronicle of political courage, the film is also a love story, illuminating the remarkable relationship between Suu and her husband, a British academic named Michael Aris,” (David Thewlis), who has received a terminal cancer diagnosis. “Tears are shed, but no inkling of doubt or tension is allowed to penetrate the aura of idealistic selflessness that shrouds Suu and Michael,” Mr. Scott added. “One result is a film that is programmatically inspirational but not quite as inspiring as it should be.”

lead_paragraph: With blue skies, sunshine and clean air in Beijing this week — all rare commodities now that oppressive smog has become the new normal — a joke is making the rounds that has many Chinese chortling.

headline: Crimea Vote Deepens Crisis and Draws Denunciations
abstract: With Russian armed forces holding a tight grip on the Crimean Peninsula, Parliament scheduled a public referendum on secession for March 16.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — The pro-Russian regional Parliament in Crimea voted behind closed doors on Thursday to secede from Ukraine and become part of Russia — an aspirational, even quixotic, gesture that had no immediate practical effect but deepened the political crisis here, drawing swift denunciations from the West and from the fledgling national government in Kiev.

headline: Beijing Goes Quiet on Rise of Local Security Budgets
abstract: Saying the data “is still being collected,” the Chinese Finance Ministry has declined to release figures on local security spending, a major component of a domestic security apparatus that has grown bigger than the military.
lead_paragraph: Xie Yue is a political science scholar at Tongji University in Shanghai who has spent years studying the budgets and expenditures of local governments in China. More people are scrutinizing such figures, because the financial practices of local governments can have profound effects on the structural integrity of the Chinese economy, the lives of ordinary Chinese and the legitimacy of the Communist Party.

headline: Chinese Workers at IBM Factory on Strike Amid Company Sale
abstract: More than 1,000 workers from a Shenzhen site being sold to Lenovo took to the streets in the latest sign of growing labor activism in China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — More than 1,000 workers have gone on strike this week at an IBM factory in southeastern China in the latest sign of labor activism as companies’ acute shortage of blue-collar workers makes employees increasingly willing to take to the streets.
