headline: Hilary Mantel Stage Adaptations Headed to the West End
abstract: The plays about Thomas Cromwell will transfer from Stratford to the West End here on May 1.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Shakespeare Company’s stage adaptations of Hilary Mantel’s award-winning novels about Thomas Cromwell will transfer from Stratford-upon-Avon to the West End here on May 1, the Royal Shakespeare Company and Playful Productions announced today. Ms. Mantel’s historical novels, “Wolf Hall” (2009) and “Bring Up the Bodies,” (2012), which earned her two Man-Booker prizes, chart the rise to power of Cromwell, Henry VIII’s deal-maker and right-hand man. They have sold close to two million copies in the U.K, and their stage adaptation, by Mike Poulton, has attracted packed houses since the Royal Shakespeare Company began to perform the plays, directed by Jeremy Herrin in December last year. The Stratford-upon-Avon run closes on Mar. 29. “A bright, bustling political soap opera that, condenses more than a thousand pages of fiction into two plays and a brisk six hours of stage time,” Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic, wrote in his review in The New York Times.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Major Changes in SAT Announced by College Board
abstract: What is your reaction to the announced changes to the exam?
lead_paragraph: In “Major Changes in SAT Announced by College Board,” Tamar Lewin reports on a new redesign for the college entrance exam.

headline: The Story Behind the SAT Overhaul
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Grading of Students', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Education']
abstract: How the College Board revolutionized the most controversial exam in America.
lead_paragraph: In July 2012, a few months before he was to officially take over as president of the College Board, David Coleman invited Les Perelman, then a director of writing at M.I.T., to come meet with him in Lower Manhattan. Of the many things the College Board does — take part in research, develop education policy, create curriculums — it is perhaps most recognized as the organization that administers the SAT, and Perelman was one of the exam’s harshest and most relentless critics. Since 2005, when the College Board added an essay to the SAT (raising the total possible score from 1,600 to 2,400), Perelman had been conducting research that highlighted what he believed were the inherent absurdities in how the essay questions were formulated and scored. His earliest findings showed that length, more than any other factor, correlated with a high score on the essay. More recently, Perelman coached 16 students who were retaking the test after having received mediocre scores on the essay section. He told them that details mattered but factual accuracy didn’t. “You can tell them the War of 1812 began in 1945,” he said. He encouraged them to sprinkle in little-used but fancy words like “plethora” or “myriad” and to use two or three preselected quotes from prominent figures like Franklin Delano Roosevelt, regardless of whether they were relevant to the question asked. Fifteen of his pupils scored higher than the 90th percentile on the essay when they retook the exam, he said.

headline: Deutsche Telekom and Orange Post Weaker Quarterly Pretax Earnings
abstract: Deutsche Telekom of Germany said pretax income fell 31 percent, while French operator Orange reported an 8.5 percent fall, as the sector grapples with a new round of consolidation.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two of Europe’s largest telecommunications companies, Deutsche Telekom and Orange, reported declines in their quarterly pretax profits on Thursday, as the industry grapples with a new round of consolidation and ongoing regulatory uncertainty.

headline: A Call From My Friend in Afghanistan
abstract: What the American withdrawal means for the price of parsley.
lead_paragraph: About once a month, when he has a little extra money, my friend Daoud calls me from Kabul. He always asks the same question: “What is America going to do in Afghanistan after 2014?” He thinks I must know more than he does, because I live in the United States.

headline: Iris van Herpen: Fearless and Approachable
abstract: The Dutch designer mixes what she calls “the artisanal and the technical,” experimenting with advanced fabrics.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The discomfiting sight of three women, each laid vertically inside a giant hanging plastic bag, legs squirming and head thrown back to gasp the air pumped from a hefty pipe, was the overwhelming image of Iris van Herpen’s show in Paris. The scene sucked the attention away from the clothes, yet at the same time the images of the three figures seemed mesmerizing.

headline: Making Cloud-Computing Systems More Efficient
abstract: People aren’t the only things that are predictable — so are the computer programs they write. A team of researchers at Stanford says predictability can be used to make large-scale systems work three times more efficiently by removing the human guesswork about computing resources from the system.
lead_paragraph: Computer scientists at Stanford have developed software that works like the recommendation engines for Amazon shoppers and Netflix movie subscribers, only for the distribution of workloads across large computing environments. The results, they say, can triple the efficiency of cloud-computing systems.

headline: M.B.A. Students Hit the Road to Help Small-Business Owners
abstract: Students who join MBAs Across America travel across the country and offer free assistance to business owners.
lead_paragraph: At a party in the fall of 2012, Casey Gerald, Michael Baker, Amaris Singer and Hicham Mhammedi Alaoui — all first-year students at Harvard Business School — were talking about potential summer jobs. “We thought, ‘What if we ditch the cubicle and spend the next summer on the road learning from and working with entrepreneurs?’ ” Mr. Gerald said.

headline: Bank of England Keeps Benchmark Rate at Record Low
abstract: Britain’s central bank said it would keep its key interest rate at 0.5 percent, where it has been since March 2009. The bank also left its bond purchasing program unchanged.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday decided to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low, as Britain’s economic recovery continues and inflation appears to be stable.

headline: Daily Report: To Ensure a Secure Future, Bitcoin Might Need Oversight
abstract: Some backers of the digital currency are calling for human oversight to guard against more losses like the $470 million collapse of Mt. Gox.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half a billion dollars has gone missing, and nobody knows how, Farhad Manjoo reports. Some say there was outright theft. Others suspect fraud. Many blame lax controls, poor oversight and, above all, a reckless, globe-spanning, Wild West culture — a culture that everyone agrees is ripe for wholesale reform.

headline: More Trouble For a Once-Mighty Law Firm
abstract: Three former executives of Dewey & LeBoeuf are expected to face criminal charges. | The Bank of England suspends a staff member in connection with a foreign exchange inquiry. | Paul Tudor Jones II is no longer seeing the mind-boggling returns he once did. | Cerberus’s deal for the Safeway grocery chain gets complicated.

lead_paragraph: There’s no question that residents of California and much of the West face a collision between high water demands driven by growth and outdated policies and a limited and highly variable water supply.

headline: A Dog and His Boy Take a Joy Ride Through History
abstract: A supersmart dog and his adopted human son set out for time-traveling adventures in “Mr. Peabody & Sherman,” the 3-D, big-screen adaptation of Jay Ward’s animated cartoon.
lead_paragraph: If you think of “Mr. Peabody & Sherman” as the latest attempt to turn small-screen baby boomer nostalgia into big-screen fun, you have plenty of reason to be afraid. Hollywood’s obsession with cashing in on old television shows has yielded a grim harvest — remember Nicole Kidman in “Bewitched”? Sorry to have reminded you — and the work of Jay Ward has been singled out for particular abuse.

headline: Let the Conservative Circus Begin!
abstract: Panel discussions at this year’s CPAC include “What’s the Deal With Global Warming?” and “The American Dream vs. the Obama Nightmare.”
lead_paragraph: Did you wake up this morning wondering what would happen at the Conservative Political Action Conference? No? Good, you’re a normal person. CPAC, like Christmas, only comes once a year. It’s an occasion for far-flung conservatives to come together in the Washington, D.C., area and snuggle in that big tent they’re always talking about. At CPAC, conservatives take stock of all things right wing and set the tone for the year ahead. There’s nothing like it on the liberal side, unless you count Burning Man.

headline: Bittersweet Chocolate on the Pillow
abstract: On its surface, “The Grand Budapest Hotel” is a caper, but this Wes Anderson film is also concerned with a complicated slice of 20th-century European culture with some very ugly history.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tough choice, but if I had to pick the most Wes Anderson moment in “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” it would be the part when inmates escape from a prison using tiny sledgehammers and pickaxes that have been smuggled past the guards inside fancy frosted pastries. This may, come to think of it, be the most Wes Anderson thing ever, the very quintessence of his impish, ingenious and oddly practical imagination. So much care has been lavished on the conceit and its execution that you can only smile in admiration, even if you are also rolling your eyes a little.

headline: Young Using E-Cigarettes Smoke Too, Study Finds
abstract: Some experts disputed the researchers’ conclusion that the devices encouraged conventional cigarette use by adolescents.
lead_paragraph: Middle and high school students who used electronic cigarettes were more likely to smoke real cigarettes and less likely to quit than students who did not use the devices, a new study has found. They were also more likely to smoke heavily. But experts are divided about what the findings mean.

headline: Lisa Falzone of Revel Systems on the Thrill of Entrepreneurship
abstract: The chief executive of the maker of point-of-sale payments systems says remaining composed in front of employees is an important key to leading them effectively.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Lisa Falzone, the C.E.O. of Revel Systems, a maker of point-of-sale payment systems for restaurants and retailers, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘There Are Birds Here’
abstract: The poem “There Are Birds Here” by Jamaal May and the article “A Picture of Detroit Ruin, Street by Forlorn Street” by Monica Davey appear in this poetry pairing.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “There Are Birds Here” by Jamaal May and “A Picture of Detroit Ruin, Street by Forlorn Street” by Monica Davey.

headline: 4 Accused in Law Firm Fraud Ignored a Maxim: Don’t Email
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Bankruptcies', 'Legal Profession', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: It is nearly unheard-of for prosecutors to contend that the top brass of a law firm, especially a once-storied firm like Dewey, was effectively running a corrupt organization.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:07 p.m. | Several former leaders of the once-high-flying law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf apparently violated a cardinal rule that lawyers always tell their clients: Don’t put anything incriminating into an email.

headline: Today in Small Business: Cheese Fight
abstract: Which social media platform is best for your business?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today:

headline: Senate Rejects Blocking Military Commanders From Sexual Assault Cases
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Courts-Martial']
abstract: The measure, pushed by Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, received 55 votes — five short of the 60 votes needed for advancement to a floor vote.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday rejected a controversial bipartisan bill to remove military commanders from decisions over the prosecution of sexual assault cases in the armed forces, delivering a defeat to advocacy groups that argued that wholesale changes are necessary to combat an epidemic of rapes and sexual assaults in the military.

headline: Why This Isn’t China’s ‘Bear Stearns Moment’
abstract: If the analogy with the crisis of 2008 has any use, writes Peter Thal Larsen of Reuters Breakingviews, it is as a reminder of which mistakes to avoid.
lead_paragraph: Once again, investors are facing warnings about China’s “Bear Stearns moment.”

headline: 36 Hours in Raleigh, N.C.
abstract: North Carolina’s capital is awash with entrepreneurial energy, from clothing labels to craft breweries to ambitious restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Raleigh has traditionally been lumped with Durham and Chapel Hill as part of the Research Triangle — the land of science, technology and, in the run-up to this month’s N.C.A.A. tournament, college basketball. But this geographic shorthand has become increasingly outdated in recent years, as each city has developed a distinct personality. Today, North Carolina’s capital is awash in entrepreneurial energy from homegrown clothing labels and converted art galleries to craft breweries and ambitious restaurants. More than merely one of the Triangle’s three vertexes, Raleigh is now defining itself as a destination worth exploring on its own merits, regardless of what lies beyond the city limits.

headline: ‘King Kong’ Out, ‘On the Town’ In, at Foxwoods Theater – Now Renamed the Lyric
abstract: The 1,900-seat Foxwoods theater will be renamed the Lyric, and will become home to a revival of “On the Town,” instead of the new musical “King Kong.”
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s next mega-budget show, the Australian musical “King Kong,” will no longer open as planned at the Foxwoods Theater next winter, which will instead become home to a revival of the musical comedy “On the Town,” the producers of both shows said in separate statements on Thursday. At the same time, the theater’s new leaseholders announced they were renaming the 1,900-seat house – one of Broadway’s biggest – to the Lyric.

headline: Experiencing New Orleans With Fresh Eyes and Ears
abstract: Artists who have moved to the Big Easy reflect on the influences and inspiration they find in their adopted home.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday night the usual suspects gathered at BJ’s, a dive in the Ninth Ward of New Orleans. They were there, as many are every Monday, to see one of the city’s premier bands, King James & the Special Men. Grizzled rockers in leather jackets leaned against the worn walls, smoking. Regulars hunched over the sticky bar drinking cheap draft beer. A group of clean-cut guys on a bachelor party binge swayed unsteadily near a vat of free red beans and rice and eyed a klatch of college girls in fluorescent hair and fishnets.

headline: Kashmiri Students Briefly Charged With Sedition for Rooting for Wrong Cricket Team
abstract: The police in northern India filed and then withdrew charges against 67 students after some cheered for the Pakistani cricket team in a televised match with India.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The police in northern India briefly filed sedition charges against 67 Kashmiri students after some of them cheered for the Pakistani cricket team during a televised match with India on Sunday night.

headline: Issa Cuts Off Microphone of Democrat
abstract: Representative Darrell Issa, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight, and Representative Elijah Cummings, the committee’s senior Democrat, had an exchange during a hearing on the I.R.S. scandal.
lead_paragraph: Representative Darrell Issa, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight, and Representative Elijah Cummings, the committee’s senior Democrat, had an exchange during a hearing on the I.R.S. scandal.

headline: Image of the Day: March 6
abstract: Vehicles to be used for political campaign in the upcoming general election are given final touches in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Issa Hands Democrats Weapon to Use on Him
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Darrell Issa’s silencing of the microphone of his committee’s ranking Democrat may have provided the chance to paint him as an overzealous inquisitor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since Republicans took control of the House in 2011, Representative Darrell Issa has tried gamely to play the thoughtful, even-tempered investigator, even as he has accused the Obama administration of the most heinous crimes: thuggery, political witch hunts, even homicide, in the case of Benghazi.

headline: On View | The Private Works of a Gallerist Who Changed Art Forever
abstract: The personal collection of the influential art dealer Alexander Iolas goes on view at New York’s Paul Kasmin Gallery.
lead_paragraph: These days, art dealers are almost as important as the artists whose careers they cultivate. But just one — Alexander Iolas — can be credited with mounting Andy Warhol’s first and last gallery show in his lifetime, bringing Surrealism to the United States and introducing the East Coast to Ed Ruscha. Unlike Iolas’s contemporaries — who included Ileana Sonnabend, Leo Castelli and Bruno Bischofberger — Iolas’s legacy has nearly faded into obscurity after he succumbed to AIDS in 1987 at 80, but a new exhibition may change that.

headline: Futures Commission Appointees Talk With Senate Panel
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Futures and Options Trading', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The nominees — Timothy Massad, who would become chairman, and Sharon Bowen and Christopher Giancarlo — now await a vote from the panel and full confirmation by the Senate.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:08 p.m. | The Senate Agriculture Committee heard testimony on Thursday from President Obama’s three nominees for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, a market watchdog that the president has called “small but mighty.”

headline: Paris Fall 2014: Elements | Character
abstract: A thematic visual diary of Paris Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.
lead_paragraph: A thematic visual diary of Paris Fashion Week inspired by the essential building blocks of fashion and style.

headline: Top Official Can’t Rule on Cable Merger
abstract: The Justice Department official, William Baer, represented NBCUniversal during its takeover by Comcast and is therefore forbidden from considering the merger.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s lead antitrust official will not participate in the review of Comcast’s proposed $45 billion takeover of Time Warner Cable, the department said on Thursday.

headline: Interactive Unit at Disney Cuts a Quarter of Its Staff
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Social Media', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: The layoffs came as a result of Disney’s decision to combine two businesses: booming mobile games and sagging social games.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif. — Disney’s struggling video game and Internet division laid off roughly 700 employees on Thursday, or 26 percent of its global staff, in a major retrenchment that includes a shift in advertising strategy at Disney.com.

headline: De Blasio, in Radio Interview, Defends His Position on Charter Schools
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio appeared on the hip-hop station Hot 97 on Thursday, arguing that his policies on New York City charter schools were being distorted.
lead_paragraph: Battered in the press over his position on charter schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday took to a friendly news outlet to defend himself and argue that his actions were being distorted.

headline: Red Bull Music Academy to Return to New York
abstract: The innovative series releases a list of 15 events, including concerts, lectures, workshops and D.J. sets, from the first day of May to the last.
lead_paragraph: It turns out New York won’t have to wait long for the next Red Bull Music Academy, an innovative and semi-educational series of concerts, lectures, workshops, D.J. sets and other happenings that takes root in a different city every year, and came to New York last May. It will happen again here this spring, according to a spokeswoman for Red Bull Music Academy, which on Thursday released a list of 15 events from the first day of May to the last.

headline: Russia Today Anchor Resigns On Air
abstract: Liz Wahl, a Washington-based anchor from Russia Today, resigned on air, saying she could “not be part of a network funded by the Russian government that whitewashes the actions of Putin.”
lead_paragraph: Liz Wahl, a Washington-based anchor from Russia Today, resigned on air, saying she could “not be part of a network funded by the Russian government that whitewashes the actions of Putin.”

headline: Times Minute | Overhauling the SAT
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'News and News Media', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: Also on the Minute, a look at how Russian TV is covering the crisis in Ukraine and news sites are generating online traffic with interactive games and quizzes.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a look at how Russian TV is covering the crisis in Ukraine and news sites are generating online traffic with interactive games and quizzes.

abstract: Also on the Minute, a look at how Russian TV is covering the crisis in Ukraine and news sites are generating online traffic with interactive games and quizzes.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 98
abstract: The Ecuador national soccer team will have to reinstate Christian Benítez’s No. 11 jersey number for use in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins June 12 when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the soccer tournament each day with a relevant news or feature item.

headline: Teju Cole: By the Book
abstract: The photographer and author of “Open City” and “Every Day Is for the Thief” says the novel is overrated. “The writers I find most interesting find ways to escape it.”
lead_paragraph: The photographer and author of “Open City” and “Every Day Is for the Thief” says the novel is overrated. “The writers I find most interesting find ways to escape it.”

headline: Caucus Click: Coburn’s Got a Gun
abstract: Senator Mitch McConnell gave Senator Tom Coburn a rifle at the Conservative Political Action Conference.

headline: A Silent Killer of Women — Suicide
abstract: There is an epidemic of young women ending their lives in Nepal and India. So why is no one talking about it?
lead_paragraph: There is an epidemic silent killer of women and girls in the developing world that nobody is talking about and it’s not malaria, HIV, or childbirth. The leading killer of girls and women of childbearing age (15-49) in countries like India and Nepal is, actually, suicide. A 2013 British Medical Journal analysis estimates a 126 percent rise in suicide among women between 1990 and 2010.

headline: Living With Cancer: Finding Calm in the Storm
abstract: While cancer proves that we cannot control our bodies, my support group continually reminds me, we can try to guide our minds and spirits.
lead_paragraph: Every Sunday evening, I phone a friend in another college town who has not yet found a cancer support group in her community. Let’s call her Melanie. Melanie had recovered from surgery and completed chemotherapy. Physically, she had gained strength. Yet she continued to feel overwhelmed by negative thoughts.

headline: Russia Today Anchor Resigns on Air
abstract: A Washington-based anchor from Russia Today, Liz Wahl, resigned on air, stating that she could “not be part of a network funded by the Russian government that whitewashes the actions of Putin.”
lead_paragraph: A Washington-based anchor from Russia Today, Liz Wahl, resigned on air, stating that she could “not be part of a network funded by the Russian government that whitewashes the actions of Putin.”

headline: On Persecution
keywords: ['Atheism', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Homosexuality', 'Mosques', 'Muslim Americans', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Intolerance, pluralism, and the places in the between.
lead_paragraph: In my Sunday column, I wrote about the possible culture-war scenarios that await us once same-sex unions are recognized as marriages from sea to shining sea, and contemplated the kinds of pressure, legal and otherwise, that might be brought to bear against individuals and institutions that hew to the older understanding of matrimony. (This contemplation was occasioned by Jan Brewer’s veto of Arizona’s religious-liberty bill last week, which followed a massive and massively misleading media campaign against the legislation.) Along the way, I included the following comment, trying to contextualize the kinds of pressure that religious conservatives could face:

headline: Greek Bank Set to Be First in 5 Years to Tap Capital Markets
abstract: Piraeus Bank, Greece’s largest lender, is planning to issue a bond that will be a significant test of investor interest.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Piraeus Bank, Greece’s largest lender, is set to became the first Greek bank to tap the capital markets since the euro zone crisis erupted five years ago.

headline: Tunisia Lifts 3-Year State of Emergency
abstract: President Moncef Marzouki lifted the state of emergency that had been in force since the country’s 2011 uprising.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — President Moncef Marzouki of Tunisia lifted a state of emergency on Thursday that had been in force since the 2011 uprising, in a sign of growing confidence in the country since political accords were reached in December.

headline: President Obama and Aide Speak on Ukraine
abstract: Saying that “the world can see that we are united with our allies,” President Obama talked about efforts to lessen tensions in Ukraine but also to sanction that country’s pro-Russia leaders.
lead_paragraph: Though Western allies are divided over whether to bring to bear heavy pressure on Russia or take a more conciliatory path toward encouraging Moscow to reverse course in the occupied Crimea, President Obama said during a brief address to journalists at the White House that “the world can see that we are united with our allies.”

headline: The Gun Report: March 6, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Cities, which are often home to the worst gun violence, are losing their power to regulate firearms, the Atlantic reports. For instance, a Sedgwick County, Kan., law bans guns, concealed or not, from all bars, but in 2007, the state legislature quietly stripped municipalities of their authority to regulate most aspects of gun ownership and use.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Contradiction
abstract: Despite himself, Mr. Ryan made the liberal argument for the social safety net at the annual conservative conference.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md. – The G.O.P. may look, to outsiders, as if it’s sharply divided between establishment politicians and Tea Party upstarts willing to defy Ronald Reagan’s so-called Eleventh Commandment (don’t speak ill of fellow Republicans) even at the risk of losing very winnable Senate contests — as they did in 2012.

headline: Allergies Are Everywhere
abstract: People hoping to find an allergy-free haven may be out of luck. A new study has found that no region of the United States is allergy-free, but the kind of allergy people are likely to suffer from varies by region, race and socioeconomic status.
lead_paragraph: People hoping to find an allergy-free haven may be out of luck. A new study has found that no region of the United States is allergy-free, but the kind of allergy people are likely to suffer from varies by region, race and socioeconomic status.

headline: Providers of Medical Marijuana Face New Fears
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: With the advent of recreational marijuana in Washington State, new rules for medical providers could shut down dispensaries.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — There should be, one might think, a note of triumph or at least quiet satisfaction in Muraco Kyashna-tocha’s voice. Her patient-based cooperative in north Seattle dispenses medical marijuana to treat seizures, sleeplessness and other maladies. And with the state gearing up to open its first stores selling legal marijuana for recreational use, the drug she has cultivated, provided to patients and used herself for years seems to be barreling toward the mainstream.

headline: As Expected, President Karzai’s Brother Exits Afghan Election
abstract: Qayum Karzai said he was throwing his support behind a candidate believed favored by the president: Zalmay Rassoul, a former foreign minister.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Qayum Karzai, a brother of President Hamid Karzai, announced Thursday that he was pulling out of the campaign for president of Afghanistan and throwing his support behind a candidate believed favored by the president, Zalmay Rassoul, a former foreign minister.

headline: Branded Saloon Offers Bits of Texas and Bytes of Music
abstract: Deep in the heart of Brooklyn, Western saloon culture will make room for electronic chiptune music; Jaron Lanier will speak at Cooper Union.
lead_paragraph: The Miser can’t decide whether 21st-century Brooklyn’s peculiar predilection for mastering “country” traditions (the old-time Appalachian music preserved at the Jalopy Theater and the Texas tastes of the Hill Country franchise, for example) is just baffling or makes perfect sense.

headline: Four People Dead After Jersey City Fire
abstract: A Pentecostal bishop, his wife and their two sons were killed in an early-morning blaze that damaged four homes and a basement church.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Four people died on Thursday in an early morning fire in Jersey City in which firefighters were sent to a wrong address first, officials said.

headline: How to Choose an Auditor
abstract: Emails shed light on the search for a “clueless” audit partner at the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf.
lead_paragraph: One unfortunate fact about the auditing business is that those who depend on the audit — investors, lenders and customers — are not the ones who choose the audit firm. At the places where an audit is most needed, the people choosing the auditor may be the ones who have the most to fear from a good audit.

headline: Mu Ramen on Temporary Hold
abstract: All reservations, current and future, have been canceled at Mu Ramen until further notice.
lead_paragraph: Mu Ramen has always been elusive. When Joshua and Heidy Smookler were serving noodle soup by night inside Bricktown Bagels in Long Island City, Queens, the hours and reservations policy seemed to change week to week. Then the location changed, as the Smooklers began serving guests in their apartment or at other addresses that were disclosed upon making a reservation.

headline: ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Returning to Broadway (In Case You Missed It the 5 Previous Times)
abstract: A fifth Broadway revival of “Fiddler on the Roof” has been announced for the fall of 2015.
lead_paragraph: “Fiddler on the Roof,” one of the most frequently revived musicals on Broadway, will have its fifth revival in the fall of 2015 under the direction of the Tony Award winner Bartlett Sher (“South Pacific”), the producers Jeffrey Richards and Jerry Frankel announced on Thursday.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s  ‘Hamilton’ Heading to Public Theater
abstract: The new musical “Hamilton,” by the creator of “In the Heights,” is having its world premiere at the Public Theater next winter.
lead_paragraph: “Hamilton,” a much-anticipated new musical by Lin-Manuel Miranda (“In the Heights”), who sets the story of Alexander Hamilton and the founding fathers to contemporary hip-hop, will have its world premiere next winter at the Public Theater, executives there announced Thursday. Mr. Miranda won the 2008 Tony Award for best score for “In the Heights,” a Broadway hit that also won the best musical Tony and ran for three years, with Mr. Miranda starring as a bodega owner besotted with his Washington Heights neighborhood.

headline: High-Jump Stars Aim for a Venerable Record
abstract: Several very different jumpers are trying to clear 8 feet and set a world record at this weekend’s indoor world championships in Sopot, Poland.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — It has been an indoor season for beating gravity and venerable world records, and with the once-supreme pole vaulter Sergei Bubka already relegated to second place, the still supreme high jumper Javier Sotomayor could be next.

headline: Obama Affirms Support for Ukraine
abstract: The president said: “Any discussion about the future of Ukraine must include the legitimate government of Ukraine.”
lead_paragraph: The president said: “Any discussion about the future of Ukraine must include the legitimate government of Ukraine.”

headline: Sodden Savages in Their First Flush
abstract: The release of an audio recording of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” with the original Broadway cast pulls back the curtain on one of the seminal theatrical events of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Probably the last two people you’d want to invite into your living room for a spell are the husband and wife who stage a three-act war in their own in Edward Albee’s classic 1962 play “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” George, the defeated academic, and Martha, his bellowing harpy of a wife, engage in the kind of take-no-prisoners warfare that leaves total destruction in its wake. And yet, theater lover, I hereby urge you to tuck away the delicate china, remove breakables from exposed surfaces, lock up the liquor cabinet and fling open your doors to these two majestic monsters, a feat that can now be accomplished with just a click or two at the computer.

headline: Egypt Pulls Ambassador From Qatar
abstract: The move made Egypt the fourth Arab state in two days to withdraw its ambassador from Doha over Qatari support for Islamists around the region.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt on Thursday became the fourth Arab state in two days to pull its ambassador from Qatar over its support for Islamists around the region, including the deposed Egyptian president Mohamed Morsi and his supporters in the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Paris Fashion Week Street Style
abstract: Street-style photos from our NYTimesFashion Instagram account.
lead_paragraph: Craig Arend of Altamira NYC takes over our Instagram account for Paris Fashion Week. Check out NYTimesFashion on Instagram for more.

headline: Facebook’s Gun Sale Changes Could Be Hard to Enforce Around the World
abstract: The social media company’s new rules have riled both gun enthusiasts and gun-control advocates in the U.S. In other countries, a tangle of regulations will complicate matters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Facebook is clamping down on gun sales on its site.

headline: Bitcoin Is a Protocol. Bitcoin Is a Brand.
abstract: The existence of Internet-based currencies following in the wake of Bitcoin says a lot about what makes the new kind of money successful, and points to a hazard common to open-source software.
lead_paragraph: Updated with additional reporting. | So it appears the creator of Bitcoin may not have been a young Japanese mathematical wizard as had been long rumored. Instead, as Newsweek has first reported, he is believed to be a 64-year-old Japanese-American man named Satoshi Nakamoto who clearly does not care for attention.

headline: Chris Christie Speaks at CPAC
abstract: The governor of New Jersey gives a speech at the 2014 Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington, a year after he was denied a slot at the same event.
lead_paragraph: The governor of New Jersey gives a speech at the 2014 Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington, a year after he was denied a slot at the same event.

headline: Back in Spotlight, Christie Offers G.O.P. Subtle Advice
abstract: At the Conservative Political Action Conference, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey urged the Republican Party to broaden its electoral appeal.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — In a return to the national political stage, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey sought Thursday to both ingratiate himself with conservative activists and press them to broaden the appeal of the Republican Party, warning that “we’ve got to start to talk about what we are for and not what we are against.”

headline: American Ends Bereavement Fares
abstract: After its merger with U.S. Airways, American Airlines will no longer offer bereavement fares.
lead_paragraph: American Airlines has ended its practice of offering discounted “bereavement fares” to customers booking last minute travel because of a family member’s emergency medical problem or death.

headline: Westchester Leader Begins Campaign for Governor
abstract: Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, began his bid to unseat Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, in a heavily Democratic borough of New York City: the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Rob Astorino’s first day campaigning for governor started on Thursday in the freezing cold in the Bronx, paused because of a fuel truck at La Guardia Airport and wound up at a biotechnology laboratory where everyone donned white lab coats and, at least for a moment, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was not discussed.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces Spotlight Films
abstract: New films from Ira Sachs, Kelly Reichardt and Courteney Cox will screen as part of the Spotlight series at the Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: New films from the directors Ira Sachs and Kelly Reichardt and the actress Courteney Cox will screen as part of the Spotlight series at the Tribeca Film Festival, organizers announced Thursday.

headline: How to Raise Both Take-Home Pay and Tax Fairness
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Income Tax', 'Poverty', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Expanding the Earned Income Tax Credit to childless adult workers would help pull more people out of poverty and add tax fairness, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Test Your SAT Essay Writing Skills
abstract: The College Board is rethinking the SAT and will, among other things, make the essay optional. Show us your writing skills by answering one of two essay questions in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: Pencils up, everybody.

headline: Stamping With a Smile of Approval
abstract: At Sushi Katsuei in Park Slope, each of the three chefs offers the same pristine pieces of fish, delivered with, just possibly, a hint of a grin.
lead_paragraph: Three chefs stand behind the counter at Sushi Katsuei, neckties tucked inside white coats, eyes downcast. The rest of the room clatters, but they work in silence, as if of one clear mind. There is no hierarchy, no need for diners to jockey for position in front of one or another. From each chef will come the same pristine pieces of fish, sliced, patted and delivered with an economy of motion and, just possibly, a slip of a smile.

headline: The Cost of Not  ‘Looking Backwards’ at Torture
abstract: President Obama’s policies will result in more secrecy, less information, and, of course, no accountability.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, Americans were treated to an appalling battle between the Central Intelligence Agency and its Congressional overseers over the Senate’s attempt to investigate the C.I.A.’s post-9/11 detention and interrogation practices. The fight is over two still-secret documents – a 2009 C.I.A. inspector general’s report on those practices, and a four-year-long investigation by the staff of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

headline: Guardian to Make Management Changes
abstract: Janine Gibson, the paper’s editor in chief of its United States operations, will return to London and will be replaced by Katherine Viner.
lead_paragraph: The Guardian will make broad changes among its most senior editors this year, the newspaper said Thursday, announcing that Janine Gibson, the editor in chief of its operations in the United States, will return to London.

headline: Abortion Law Pushes Texas Clinics to Close Doors
abstract: The last abortion clinics in two poor and working-class regions were closing, and the number of Texas clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.
lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Tex. — Shortly before a candlelight vigil on the sidewalk outside, employees of the last abortion clinic in the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas shut the doors early Thursday evening, making legal abortion unavailable in the poorest part of the state in the wake of tough new restrictions passed last year by the Texas Legislature.

headline: Assemblyman Is Convicted in Second Corruption Trial
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: William F. Boyland Jr., an assemblyman from Brooklyn, was found guilty of bribery and several other federal crimes.
lead_paragraph: William F. Boyland Jr., an assemblyman from one of Brooklyn’s most prominent political families, was convicted on Thursday of bribery and several other federal crimes.

headline: More Than One Way to Buy a Plan
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Private websites are offering alternatives to HealthCare.gov for buying health plans.
lead_paragraph: When the federal online marketplace for the Affordable Care Act stumbled out of the gate last fall, leaving would-be applicants unable to sign up for care or even to view their plans, three young programmers thought they might be able to help frustrated users. In October, they packaged reams of publicly-available data into a website, healthsherpa.com, that allowed users to immediately view exchange plans in their area. But the site was intended for research only; users still had to purchase them through the federal and state health exchanges or, in some cases, directly through insurers.

headline: Obama Delivers Statement on Ukraine
abstract: President Obama said, “Any discussion about the future of Ukraine must include the legitimate government of Ukraine.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama said, “Any discussion about the future of Ukraine must include the legitimate government of Ukraine.”

headline: The Hurdles in Getting Past a Wall of Silence
keywords: ['Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Justice Department may have feared reopening the debate about whether it adequately respects attorney-client privilege if it allowed regulators to pursue notes by JPMorgan Chase’s lawyers on the bank’s ties to Bernard L. Madoff, Peter J. Henning writes.
lead_paragraph: Attorney-client privilege and protection for attorney work product are often seen as the core of the relationship of trust between lawyers and their clients. But that shield of confidentiality can be enormously frustrating in an investigation of possible wrongdoing because it puts a wall around potentially valuable evidence.

headline: Getty to Let Bloggers and Others Use Photos Free
abstract: The photo agency has decided to allow noncommercial websites and social media users to publish its images at no cost using an “embedding” tool.
lead_paragraph: In a move that promises to increase the use of photography across the Internet, the Getty Images photo agency announced that it would allow noncommercial websites and social media users to publish the agency’s images at no cost using an “embedding” tool.

headline: Poll Finds Shaheen With Big Lead in New Hampshire Senate Race With Brown
abstract: If the election were held today, Senator Jeanne Shaheen would defeat Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts senator, a Suffolk University poll found.
lead_paragraph: The latest polling in New Hampshire shows that Scott Brown, the former Massachusetts senator, would lose to Senator Jeanne Shaheen by a hefty 13 percentage points.

headline: Book Deal Falls Apart for Parodist of Goldman
abstract: John LeFevre, the man behind the @GSElevator Twitter account, has lost his book deal after his true identity came to light.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:19 p.m. | Two weeks ago, with a huge online following and a new six-figure book contract, John LeFevre was riding as high as some of the Wall Street traders he parodied in his Twitter account, @GSElevator.

headline: Jack Griffin Appointed Chief of Tribune Publishing
abstract: Mr. Griffin, who was ousted as chief executive of Time Inc. in 2011, will become the new head of Tribune Publishing in mid-April.
lead_paragraph: Jack Griffin, who was ousted as chief executive of Time Inc. in 2011, will become the new head of Tribune Publishing in mid-April, the Tribune Company announced Thursday.

headline: The Journalist and the Masquerader
abstract: Walter Kirn, who was duped by an impostor known as Clark Rockefeller, examines their complicated relationship.
lead_paragraph: With its lurid title and bloodstained cover, Walter Kirn’s latest book is bound to be shelved in the crime section. But it’s actually about class. A novelist, journalist and memoirist, Kirn is his generation’s aspirational Midwesterner, a boy who goes East and sneaks into the magic circle of the American aristocracy. But no matter how close to the center he gets, he still feels like the little match girl, nose pressed against the window.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: obesity and exercise, H.I.V. and electronic cigarettes. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: obesity and exercise, H.I.V. and electronic cigarettes. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Facing Sexual Assault Trial, General Pleads Guilty to Misconduct
keywords: ['Courts-Martial', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'ADULTERY']
abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair and his lawyers pursued a strategy of pleading guilty to lesser charges to focus his court-martial on the credibility of his accuser.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — An Army judge on Thursday accepted guilty pleas from Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair to misconduct charges, including possession of pornography and inappropriate relationships with female soldiers. But the general, a former deputy commander of American forces in southern Afghanistan, still faces court-martial on charges that he sexually assaulted a junior officer with whom he had an extramarital relationship.

headline: Reading Into a Murky Past
abstract: Walter Kirn sees the subject of his new book, Clark Rockefeller, through a literary lens. “It’s hard not to think of Dostoyevsky when one thinks of Clark.”
lead_paragraph: Walter Kirn’s new book, “Blood Will Out,” reviewed by Nina Burleigh this week, details his friendship with Clark Rockefeller. Rockefeller was eventually unmasked as Christian Gerhartsreiter, and in 2013 was convicted of a murder that had occurred nearly 30 years earlier. He confessed to Kirn that the inspiration for his alter ego came from “The Great Gatsby.” “Surprisingly, he told me he didn’t identify with the character of Gatsby so much as he did with Nick, the narrator,” Kirn said in an email interview. “I think he was lying about this. I think he knew that I, like Nick, and like Fitzgerald, had grown up in Minnesota; he wanted to get in good with me by creating a sense of having something in common.”

headline: The Long Road Home
abstract: In the stories in “Redeployment,” Phil Klay, a former Marine who served in Iraq, shows what the war did to people’s souls.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: MoMA to Show Jasper Johns’s ‘Regrets’ Series
abstract: A new series of works by Jasper Johns — who was inspired by a 1960s photograph of Lucian Freud — is coming to the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: JASPER JOHNS’S ‘REGRETS’

headline: Letters: Bad Boys, Heschel and Kennan’s Diaries
abstract: Readers respond to recent essays about William S. Burroughs and reviews of “Abraham Joshua Heschel: The Call of Transcendence” and George F. Kennan’s diaries.
lead_paragraph: Bad Boys and Others

headline: She Walked Into My Office on a Tuesday, Dressed in Chandler
abstract: The Booker Prize-winning Irish author John Banville, writing under his Benjamin Black pen name, creates a new mystery in Los Angeles for Philip Marlowe.
lead_paragraph: Among the tentative book and story titles that Raymond Chandler left behind were “The Diary of a Loud Check Suit,” “The Man With the Shredded Ear,” “Stop Screaming — It’s Me” and “The Black-Eyed Blonde.” So we can be glad that last one became Chandler’s latest gift from beyond the grave: a much slinkier moniker that summons Chandler’s Philip Marlowe and the kinds of women who matched wits with him, slyly wrapping him around their dainty, lacquered fingers.

headline: What Lou Reed Taught Me About Love
abstract: When another person takes the place of a looking glass to reveal who you really are.
lead_paragraph: When Lou Reed died last year, I learned via Facebook just how many friends had chosen “I’ll Be Your Mirror” as their wedding song. I wasn’t one of them, but that song, more than any other, taught me about love.

headline: Wheelies: The Anxious AAA Edition
abstract: AAA expresses concern over Apple’s new CarPlay infotainment control system; BMW says it will expand its car-sharing program to new cities.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Mothers and Sons
abstract: Advice on an over-texting mother, a party joke gone bad and too much bowling advice.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend and I are in our mid-20s. We’ve been together for five years and just moved in together. His mother texts him incessantly, even on Saturday nights, to find out where he is and what he’s doing. If she does not receive a prompt reply, she becomes indignant and follows up with more texts until he responds. I often feel as if she’s with us wherever we go. My boyfriend is also bothered by her stalker-ish behavior, though not as much as I am. I appreciate the importance of family, but how do we set some boundaries?

headline: Like the Common Core? Then You’ll Like the New SAT
keywords: ['ACT (Examination)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Parenting', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Both the Common Core standards and the changes to the SAT exam are based on good intentions. They’re also riddled with hidden motivations and paths to unintended consequences, and that makes them hard to see clearly.
lead_paragraph: The SAT is undergoing a major redesign, ending its longstanding reliance on knowledge of obscure vocabulary words as well as the penalty for guessing wrong, and removing the essay requirement added in 2005. It is returning to the old 1,600-point scale and reinstating the bragging rights of generations of parents who found their high scores reduced to apparent mediocrity when an additional 800 points were tacked onto the exam taken by their children.

headline: 10 Lies? Russians Fire Back
abstract: The Foreign Ministry was not amused by the State Department’s point-by-point knockdown of President Vladimir V. Putin’s assertions about Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs was not amused by the unorthodox statement from the State Department under the title “President Putin’s Fiction: 10 False Claims About Ukraine,” which rebutted a series of assertions by the Russian president in the eye-catching format of a top-10 list.

headline: A Restless Spirit Spans Generations
abstract: More than half a century ago, Paul Taylor was a promising new talent in the emerging field of modern dance.
lead_paragraph: More than half a century ago, Paul Taylor was a promising new talent in the emerging field of modern dance. Today, he is the last living patriarch of a diverse and thriving art form, celebrating his company’s 60th anniversary for three weeks at Lincoln Center. The program showcases an eclectic selection of works — some playful, some disquieting — from his trove. Among them is a world premiere, because at 83, Mr. Taylor is still looking forward. (Tuesday through March 30, David H. Koch Theater, 212-496-0600, ptdc.org.)

headline: The Reality Behind the Stock-Picking Prowess of S.E.C. Staff Members
keywords: ['Insider Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: News reports have suggested that staff members of the S.E.C. were profiting from stock sales. But the employees were just lucky rather than sharp insider traders, writes Steven M. Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Is the Securities and Exchange Commission a warren for insider trading? If you’ve read recent headlines like “The Incredible Stock-Picking Ability of SEC Employees,” you’d think so.

headline: Bitcoin’s Mysterious Creator Is Said to Be Identified
abstract: A Newsweek article contends that a man in Southern California named Satoshi Nakamoto was the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many people say they are unconvinced.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:31 p.m. | Even as it has grown into a new type of digital money worth billions of dollars, Bitcoin has always retained an air of mystery.

headline: ‘True Detective,’ ‘Lost’ and the Problem of Endings
abstract: Can mythology-permeated, allusion-rich TV actually deliver full satisfaction?
lead_paragraph: Even though it’s replaced “Breaking Bad” as my Sunday night obsession, I haven’t dipped a toe into the debate about HBO’s “True Detective” — is it philosophically-rich or a philosophically-pretentious? baldly misognyistic or a critique of toxic masculinity? a retread of the anti-hero genre or a brilliant refashioning of detective-genre cliches? — in part because I find myself torn between its critics and its fans. I’m unapologetically addicted, but I can read a good takedown and find myself nodding along to some of its points.

headline: Serious Silliness:  High School Reading and Writing Inspired by Dr. Seuss
abstract: Despite his success, Dr. Seuss’ work is not a staple of high school curriculum. In this lesson, we suggest some places for the cat in the hat, green eggs and ham, and Horton in secondary schools as well.
lead_paragraph: This week marks the 110th anniversary of Theodor Seuss Geisel’s birth, and the 17th annual Read Across America event that celebrates the day.

headline: A Nation’s Soul, Tapping and Twirling
abstract: “Dancing the Dream,” an exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery, surveys dance in the United States over the last century as captured in photographs, film clips and posters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What’s the uniting factor here? A Richard Avedon photograph of a nude Rudolf Nureyev; an astonishing film clip of the Nicholas Brothers in “Stormy Weather”; a surreal photo of the tap virtuoso Ann Miller, hilariously placed amid a garden of violins? All appear in “Dancing the Dream,” an exuberantly diverse exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery that surveys dance in America over the last 100 years.

headline: Let Them Eat Dignity
abstract: Paul Ryan lectures the poor.
lead_paragraph: We’re getting reports about Paul Ryan’s performance at CPAC, the big conservative gathering — and they’re actually kind of awesome, in the worst way.

headline: West Point Sergeant Pleads Guilty to Videotaping Female Cadets
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Peeping Toms', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Sgt. First Class Michael McClendon will serve a 33-month sentence and will be dismissed from the Army after being reduced in rank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A sergeant responsible for advising students at the United States Military Academy in West Point, N.Y., has pleaded guilty in a case that included accusations that he secretly videotaped female cadets, some as they undressed in the locker room, and will serve a 33-month sentence, the Army said Thursday.

headline: Wait Until Wages Start Rising
abstract: And then wait some more.
lead_paragraph: And then wait some more — a lot more.

headline: Cerberus in $9 Billion Deal for the Safeway Grocery Chain
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: The private equity firm has announced a deal to acquire Safeway and says it will combine the chain with Albertsons.
lead_paragraph: A group led by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management agreed on Thursday to buy Safeway in a deal worth more than $9 billion, giving it control of the big grocery store chain in the largest leveraged buyout this year.

headline: 12 Ways to Move Grapefruit Beyond Breakfast
abstract: Salads, sauces and stir-fries can all benefit from a bright hit of sweet and sour.
lead_paragraph: Salads, sauces and stir-fries can all benefit from a bright hit of sweet and sour.

headline: Opera Star Fills Same Role for 2 Companies in a Week
abstract: After the baritone Thomas Hampson withdrew, the Metropolitan Opera summoned help from Matthias Goerne, who sang the role last Friday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: There is never a good time to lose your leading man to illness on the eve of opening night, particularly when the work in question is Alban Berg’s early-20th-century masterpiece “Wozzeck,” which is not exactly a staple of many singers’ repertoires.

headline: First to Die in ‘Sweeney Todd’: Decorum at the Philharmonic
abstract: A concert staging of “Sweeney Todd” stars the opera bass-baritone Bryn Terfel as the bloodthirsty barber and the Oscar-winning Emma Thompson as his adoring helpmate.
lead_paragraph: Despite the body count to rival an action movie, the scenes of human flesh put through a sausage grinder, and the protagonist who announces in ringing tones that we all deserve to die, “Sweeney Todd” has an uncanny way of sending musical theater audiences into raptures of glazed-eyed bliss. That was certainly the case on Wednesday night, when the New York Philharmonic presented a starry concert version, featuring the opera luminary Bryn Terfel as the bloodthirsty barber and the Oscar-winning Emma Thompson as his adoring helpmate, the meat-pie-making Mrs. Lovett.

headline: Bombings Kill at Least 30 in Iraq
abstract: The attacks in Hilla, in southern Iraq, and Baghdad, the capital, also wounded at least 70 people, the police said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A series of bombings in Iraq on Thursday killed at least 30 people, according to security officials.

headline: Man in Subway Is Injured in Antigay Attack, Police Say
abstract: The police said a man yelling homophobic slurs on a subway platform in Greenwich Village asked a couple if they were gay, and then punched one of the men.
lead_paragraph: A man yelling antigay slurs accosted a couple on a subway platform this week in Greenwich Village and punched one of the men in the face, the police said on Thursday.

headline: Classic Stage Season to Begin With Rodgers and Hammerstein’s ‘Allegro’
abstract: The Classic Stage Company will open the 2014-2015 season with a production in October of Rodgers and Hammerstein’s “Allegro,” directed by the Tony winner John Doyle.
lead_paragraph: The Classic Stage Company added musicals to its roster of revivals last year and this year it is continuing the tradition, kicking off its 2014-2015 season with a production in October of Rodgers and Hammerstein’s “Allegro” directed by the Tony winner John Doyle.

headline: The Trippy ’60s, Courtesy of a Master
abstract: For its seventh season, starting in April, “Mad Men” enlisted the renowned graphic artist Milton Glaser (I ♥ NY) to design promotional ads with a late ’60s aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: IN the world of “Mad Men,” whose seventh season begins on April 13 on AMC, one of the central dramatic devices is the client meeting, the scene where the advertising gurus and the people who pay them gather in their glassed-office agora to wrestle over the nature of commerce, persuasion, art and desire.

headline: United Nations to Consider Large Peacekeeping Force for Central African Republic
abstract: France said it would soon propose a resolution to establish a large, robust United Nations peacekeeping force, and the United States expressed support.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The violence in the Central African Republic jolted the United Nations Security Council into rare accord on Thursday, with France announcing that it would soon propose a resolution to establish a large and robust United Nations peacekeeping force and the United States expressing full-throated support.

headline: 2 Senior Citigroup Executives Retiring
abstract: Eugene McQuade, the chief executive of Citibank, the entity that holds 70 percent of the company’s assets and runs its international businesses, is leaving, as is Cece Stewart, who runs Citigroup’s consumer and commercial banking operations in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Two senior executives are retiring from Citigroup, the company said Thursday, leading to changes at the top of the bank’s international and consumer banking operations.

headline: A Texas Painter Worked Under the Radar in New York
abstract: Julian Onderdonk, renowned for his Texas bluebonnet landscapes, painted under pseudonyms while working in New York, the author of a new book suggests.
lead_paragraph: Early-1900s paintings signed with variations on the name Chas. Turner are potentially very valuable.

headline: Trips from Outside Magazine
abstract: Outside magazine and the travel firm Uncharted Outposts have created a new company called Outside Go that offers trips and itineraries.
lead_paragraph: Outside magazine has long taken readers on armchair trips. Now the monthly, which covers adventure, has linked up with travel outfitter Uncharted Outposts to create a new travel company called Outside Go.

headline: Official at Helm of Federal Health Marketplace Is Resigning
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Before the troubled rollout of HealthCare.gov, Gary M. Cohen repeatedly told Congress that it would work well.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gary M. Cohen, the official in charge of the federal health insurance marketplace, who repeatedly told Congress before its troubled rollout that it would work well, said on Thursday that he was resigning.

headline: Harvard and Yale Pick Up the Pace, Reshaping Ivy League Basketball
abstract: Harvard is looking for another title; Yale hopes to force a playoff; Columbia is winning; Brown is running — all in a league once dominated by Penn and Princeton.
lead_paragraph: Forty minutes before the start of another late-season game with Ivy League title implications at the Palestra, Yale Coach James Jones strolled through the building’s concourse looking at exhibits celebrating Pennsylvania’s storied basketball history.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, India and Britain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, India and Britain.

headline: Republican’s Tax Plan Awkwardly Aims at Rich
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Taxation', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The Tax Reform Act of 2014 proposed by Dave Camp, a Michigan Republican, contains provisions to take away benefits from some taxpayers simply because they make too much money.
lead_paragraph: Tax the rich.

headline: Lamenting a Rejection by the Boss’s Daughter
abstract: Matthias Goerne, with Christoph Eschenbach on piano, performed Schubert’s “Die Schöne Müllerin” song cycle at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The vast cavern of Carnegie Hall is a tough space in which to present Schubert’s “Die Schöne Müllerin” (“The Beautiful Maid of the Mill”), an intimate song cycle better suited to a smaller hall. But on Wednesday evening, the baritone Matthias Goerne and Christoph Eschenbach, the conductor who often performs as a pianist, drew in listeners with an exemplary performance that traversed the myriad shades of optimism and despair.

headline: It’s Obama’s Fault. But Ignore That.
abstract: Whatever else might divide them, the speakers at the Conservative Political Action Conference today seemed united on the important matter of what to say at the Conservative Political Action Conference.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md.—Whatever else might divide them, the speakers at the Conservative Political Action Conference today seemed united on the important matter of what to say at the Conservative Political Action Conference.

headline: Companies Test Plans to Cut Their Health Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'States (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Corporations']
abstract: Some employers are offering as many as 25 health care plans to employees from a variety of insurers, including Blue Cross and UnitedHealthcare, to lower their costs for the benefit.
lead_paragraph: At Walgreen, the giant drugstore chain, employees now have a much broader choice of insurers and plans. Once limited to two options, either from a local Blue Cross plan or UnitedHealthcare, workers can now choose among as many as 25 plans from five insurers, depending on where they live, including Kaiser Permanente, the well-known California-based H.M.O.

headline: A Former Phenom Belts Her Way Back
abstract: Karen Wyman, a singer who rose to early fame in the late 1960s, is on the comeback trail.
lead_paragraph: Karen Wyman has the kind of old-fashioned belter’s delivery associated with her idol Eydie Gorme, who, like Ms. Wyman, was born in the Bronx and came from a Sephardic Jewish background. Lainie Kazan and Pia Zadora share the same sock-it-to-’em approach.

headline: Julia Rommel: ‘The Little Match Stick’
abstract: Ms. Rommel’s second solo at Bureau is an unexpected throwback to the early days of post-painterly abstraction.
lead_paragraph: Bureau

headline: Yishay Garbasz: ‘Ritual and Reality'
abstract: These eerily matter-of-fact videos were made during a tour of the so-called “exclusion zone” around the nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan.
lead_paragraph: Ronald Feldman Fine Arts

headline: Lauren Silva: ‘I tried to catch the fog. I mist.’
abstract: Ms. Silva’s big, boisterous semiabstract canvases exude an impressive confidence.
lead_paragraph: ZieherSmith

headline: Roe Ethridge: ‘Sacrifice Your Body’
abstract: Mr. Ethridge takes slick, seductive conceptualism and injects it with gritty digitalism and personal references.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kreps Gallery

headline: ‘Half Drop’
abstract: A strong candidate for best drawing show of the year, “Half Drop” benefits from focusing on artists obsessed with the medium or its close relatives.
lead_paragraph: Kerry Schuss

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, India and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Greece, India and South Korea.

headline: Off With the Face Paint
abstract: The stripping of paint from one of five West 78th Street Guastavino rowhouses has met with mixed reviews.
lead_paragraph: In the suburbs they say “good fences make good neighbors”; in Manhattan the corollary is “good party walls.”

headline: Financing for Foreclosed Homes
abstract: Buyers looking for a deal on a foreclosed property may find the best deals from Fannie Mae.
lead_paragraph: Buyers looking for a deal on a foreclosed property have good reason to scroll through the thousands of homes listed by Fannie Mae. In addition to low-down-payment financing and priority status for owner-occupants, the government-controlled mortgage giant has begun offering closing-cost assistance to qualified buyers.

headline: As if the River Itself Were Alive
abstract: “The Island of St. Matthews” tells the story of the flooding on the Tombigbee River near Columbus, Miss., in 1973.
lead_paragraph: Something about a flood must call to experimental filmmakers. In January, Bill Morrison explored the 1927 calamity along the Mississippi River in “The Great Flood,” a lovely, wordless documentary with a jazz score by Bill Frisell. And now, from Kevin Jerome Everson, comes “The Island of St. Matthews,” an even more unorthodox look at 1973 flooding on the Tombigbee River near Columbus, Miss.

headline: Earthlings and Martians in a Rematch
abstract: The animated feature “War of the Worlds: Goliath” imagines humans fighting invaders in 1914 New York.
lead_paragraph: Considering that the fate of humankind is at stake, “War of the Worlds: Goliath” is remarkably uninvolving.

headline: Creatures of the Wind Take Paris
abstract: The white-hot designers share stories and photos from their fashion-week trip to the City of Light.
lead_paragraph: Like many American designers, Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters of Creatures of the Wind travel to Paris each season for sales appointments with international buyers. This time around, they arrived early to present their collection for judging as finalists for the LVMH Young Fashion Designer Prize. Here, they share highlights from their nine days of fashion, food and fun.

headline: Danger Undercover
abstract: “Special ID,” a martial arts film from Hong Kong, centers on a detective who flees from underworld killers.
lead_paragraph: You know there’s something wrong with a martial arts movie when the only character worth caring about is the hero’s mother. Making sense in the sea of nonsense that is “Special ID,” this middle-aged woman (played by the talented Paw Hee-ching) has very little screen time — and spends most of it getting her hair shorn and her kisser punched — but at least we understand her.

headline: On the Piers, Armory Show Evokes Cut and Paste
abstract: An international roster of 205 exhibitors, separated into Modern and Contemporary art, display works that trigger a comparison to working on Microsoft Windows.
lead_paragraph: After nearly four hours of scanning thousands of artworks displayed by the Armory Show’s international roster of 205 exhibitors, I had an epiphany. A hypothesis about the nature of art making in the industrialized world took shape in my exhausted, overstimulated brain. I call it the “cut-and-paste” theory, which has to do not with actual scissors, paper and glue but with the actions people perform on Windows-equipped computers.

headline: Warning: Teenagers May Like These Movies
abstract: The 2014 edition of the New York International Children’s Film Festival opens on Friday and runs for four consecutive weekends at six Manhattan theaters, with a hundred films.
lead_paragraph: IN 1999, Eric Beckman ran into a teenage neighbor in the elevator. Eager to promote his growing venture, the New York International Children’s Film Festival, he gave the girl a brochure. “She looked at it, saw the word ‘children,’ curled her nose and handed it back,” he said with a laugh.

headline: In Blue-Chip Precincts, a Shout-Out for the Undersung
abstract: The Art Show at the Park Avenue Armory features some striking booths centering on work by female artists from the historical past and the present.
lead_paragraph: In catering to established tastes, art fairs tend to mirror or even exacerbate the art world’s imbalances. And of all the art fairs that visit New York in March, the Art Show, organized by the Art Dealers Association of America, is normally the safest and most blue-chip of the bunch (that is, heavily white and male).

headline: Alejandro Zaffaroni, Entrepreneur on Biotech Frontier, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Biology and Biochemistry', 'Nicotine', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: The Uruguayan-born biochemist started more than a dozen companies and had a role in the development of the birth control pill, the nicotine patch and the DNA chip.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro Zaffaroni, a prolific biotechnology entrepreneur and Silicon Valley legend who played a significant role in the development of the birth control pill, the nicotine patch, the DNA chip and corticosteroids, died on Saturday at his home in Atherton, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Russia Experts See Thinning Ranks’ Effect on U.S. Policy
abstract: With the end of the Cold War, Russia ceased being a concentration of choice among future foreign policy professionals. The dearth is being felt now.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “I have to do a TV broadcast now, can I call you back in maybe an hour?” Angela Stent, the director of the Russian studies department at Georgetown University, said when she picked up the phone. An hour later she apologized again. “I’m afraid I’ll have to call you back.”

headline: One Last Dance in the Old Place
abstract: The 2014 Whitney Biennial survey of American art features 103 participants, reflecting some interesting choices, some new faces and three quite different shows under one roof.
lead_paragraph: For its 2014 Biennial, the last before taking the plunge downtown, the Whitney went a little wild with the recipe. It picked three curators from outside the museum and outside New York. (One just recently arrived.) It gave each of them free rein on a floor in the museum’s Breuer building to work solo, with no cross talk required, though, of course, there was some, and some space sharing, too.

headline: An Art Fair That Tries to Be Something Else
abstract: At the Independent art fair, which takes pride in its unconventional identity, there is plenty of work that looks old but is actually new, and vice versa.
lead_paragraph: In its fifth year, the Independent continues to assert its maverick identity. It’s an art fair that pretends not to be an art fair. And because it takes place in Dia Art Foundation’s former exhibition space, you’re almost convinced. If fairs are part of the new necessary evil for small galleries to stay afloat, this one offers a good concentrated roundup of artists and exhibitors: nonprofit institutions, alternative spaces along with a few commercial galleries that might be barely paying their bills.

headline: A Couple’s Getting-to-Know-You Phase Takes a Chilling Wrong Turn
abstract: Set in rural Ireland, this tightly wound siege movie, directed by Jeremy Lovering, unfolds almost entirely inside a moving vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Considering that “In Fear” unfolds almost entirely inside a moving vehicle, it’s remarkable how firmly it grasps our attention. Economical in the extreme — but without appearing cash-poor — this tightly wound thriller proves that minimal resources can sometimes produce more than satisfying results.

headline: Chris Christie Speaks to Conservatives
abstract: The governor of New Jersey addresses the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington, a year after he was denied a slot at the same event.
lead_paragraph: The governor of New Jersey addresses the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington, a year after he was denied a slot at the same event.

headline: Arundhati Roy on Gandhi, the Bomb and Being a Woman
abstract: A collection of provocative statements by novelist and not-so-reluctant renegade Arundhati Roy.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s magazine, Siddhartha Deb writes about the novelist-turned-activist Arundhati Roy, whom some call a provocateur, others courageous. (She makes no claim to heroism and prefers to think of herself as “naughty.”) Below, a sample of some of her more memorable statements may help you decide which adjective you prefer.

headline: Events in Westchester for March 9-15
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Theater Listings for March 7-13
abstract: A selected guide to theater performances in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Comedy Listings for March 7-13
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Strollers Not Welcome
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cooperatives', 'Baby Carriages, Strollers and Carriers']
abstract: Subjects include limits on stroller use in a co-op elevator; New York State’s mansion tax; and rules on maintenance and fees charged to shareholders who sublet.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Movie Listings for March 7-13
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in New York City, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Last Day for Last Abortion Clinic in the Rio Grande
abstract: The last clinics in two poor and working-class regions of Texas were shutting down, and the number of clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.
lead_paragraph: The last clinics in two poor and working-class regions of Texas were shutting down, and the number of clinics, once at 44, is expected to fall to six.

headline: Keeping Your Insurance Policy
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: A political maneuver allows people to renew their plans, but will they want to?
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration announced a new policy on Wednesday that will allow many people to renew their existing insurance policies for two more years even though the policies don’t provide the comprehensive coverage and consumer protections required by the Affordable Care Act. The move is designed to provide political cover for Democratic senators facing tough re-election campaigns in Republican-leaning states where the president is especially unpopular.

abstract: Harley unveiled a new model based upon a 1977 favorite, the Low Rider, as well as a lightweight touring bike called the SuperLow 1200T.
lead_paragraph: Although retro motorcycles have become all the rage over the past few years, retro style has long been part of Harley-Davidson’s image. The motorcycle manufacturer released two models Thursday that it promised would deliver old-school attitude paired with modern-day performance: the Low Rider and the SuperLow 1200T.
