YOU AND ME’ (Saturday, Sunday and Tuesday) Those who grew up in the 1970s — as well as pop culture mavens — will probably know this Emmy Award-winning after-school television special with the message that everyone is capable of achieving great things.

headline: Art Matters | At the Armory Show, China Takes the Spotlight
abstract: The annual art fair, which opens today, includes exhibitions and programming focused on the Far East.
lead_paragraph: The Armory Show anchors what has held on as a robust art week for New York, in spite of similar events organized in the city during the milder month of May. The art fair on Piers 92 and 94 on the West Side Highway opened to the public this morning, and while one might say its theme is the same as ever — to make as much money as possible in five days selling contemporary (and modern) art — each year is more distinctively characterized by a regionally driven focus as well, and 2014’s is China.

headline: Many to Lust For, and Some You Might Afford
abstract: Rising sales bring optimism to this year’s Geneva Motor Show, even as a crisis erupts in an important auto market.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The mood was exuberant as the Palexpo convention center here opened on Tuesday for two days of press previews that served up a generous helping of important new production models as well as some intriguing design studies.

abstract: The New York Times film critics on "The Grand Budapest Hotel," "The Face of Love" and "Bethlehem."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on "The Grand Budapest Hotel," "The Face of Love" and "Bethlehem."

headline: And a Child Will Lead Them
abstract: Two new dramas — “Resurrection,” on ABC, and “Believe,” on NBC — feature children with supernatural traits.
lead_paragraph: Unlike Vladimir V. Putin, Americans would rather be liked than feared.

headline: A Mentor Recalled by Talking Pianos
abstract: A Mary Lou Williams tribute at the Harlem Stage Gatehouse on Wednesday featured young pianists in a concert that was a curtain raiser for a larger celebration next week.
lead_paragraph: Mary Lou Williams, who was born in 1910 and died in 1981, was a jazz pianist, composer and arranger of trailblazing accomplishment, and a bighearted mentor to countless others who sought her counsel. It’s hard to imagine she would have been anything but pleased by “Mary Lou Williams Tribute: The Next Generation,” an admirably focused concert held on Wednesday night at Harlem Stage Gatehouse, as the curtain raiser for a larger celebration that runs from Thursday through next Saturday.

headline: Curtain Call | Paris Fashion Week
abstract: To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of select fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows of select fashion visionaries.

headline: Jerry Brown’s Revenge
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The California turnaround — projected surplus, new jobs, even some much-needed rain — offers a look beyond the binary bind of our politics.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Ca. — Let’s review. Just a few years ago California was a punching bag for conservative scolds — a failed state, profligate with its spending and promiscuous with its ambition. Ungovernable. And everybody’s leaving.

headline: Venezuela in Black-and-White
abstract: Though famed for chromatic installations, Carlos Cruz-Diez was first taken by the magic of light as a young photographer documenting Venezuela’s emergence as a modern state.
lead_paragraph: Though famed for chromatic installations, Carlos Cruz-Diez was first taken by the magic of light as a young photographer documenting Venezuela’s emergence as a modern state.

headline: Not the Kind of Bonding a Father Might Have Wanted
abstract: Brothers bond in weird ways after their father dies in “Awful Nice,” a comedy from Todd Sklar.
lead_paragraph: “Awful Nice” is a crass bro comedy about brothers. When the responsible Jim (James Pumphrey) seeks out the errant Dave (Alex Rennie) to tell him their father has died, he finds Dave passed out and naked in a tepee. They have inherited a vacation home in Branson, Mo., but Dave refuses to sign the deed unless they have a bonding experience while repairing the house and their relationship.

headline: Save Us From the SAT
abstract: The SAT is a mind-numbing, stress-inducing ritual of torture.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — I WAS in trouble. The first few analogies were pretty straightforward — along the lines of “leopard is to spotted as zebra is to striped” — but now I was in the tall weeds of nuance. Kangaroo is to marsupial as the giant squid is to — I don’t know, maybe D) cephalopod? I looked up for a second at the back of the head of the girl in front of me. She had done this amazing thing with her hair, sort of like a French braid. I wondered if I could do that with my hair.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Fashion Week Take Their Bows
abstract: To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 15 fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 15 fashion visionaries.

headline: Spain Struggles to Halt Migrants at Two Enclaves
abstract: Spain’s interior minister said the growing number of people trying to enter the country’s African enclaves was a problem for all of Europe.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — About 80,000 African migrants are heading for Spain’s two enclaves along the Moroccan coast, leaving Spain struggling to contain the efforts that are coming in larger and increasingly coordinated surges in recent days.

headline: Raging Hormones, an Unsettling New Home and Ghostly Wrath
abstract: Creepy goings-on can’t be ignored in a cursed home that was the scene of a massacre in “Haunt,” directed by Mac Carter.
lead_paragraph: For a red-blooded teenage boy, the unexpected bedtime appearance of a willing young woman whispering, “Protect me!” is bound to send hormones ricocheting. And so it is with Evan (Harrison Gilbertson), the moody center of “Haunt” and middle child of the Asher family, recent buyers of a cursed home whose previous residents have been virtually wiped out.

headline: Lone Star Loyalists Connect in Washington
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Despite the Washington’s buttoned-up atmosphere, many Texans have flocked here for government posts and lobbying jobs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ask a Texas transplant about living in the nation’s capital, and you are likely to get an answer involving a wistful memory about the Lone Star State, sometimes one embedded in a complaint.

headline: Bullet Train Failed Once, but It’s Back
abstract: Texas tried to establish a high-speed rail line before, but a lot has changed since 1989, and the newest effort, by Texas Central Railway, may have much better luck.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, former Lt. Gov. Ben Barnes joined a group of investors hoping to develop a bullet train in Texas.

headline: Dodging the Bullets of Loyalty, Terror and Death in Mideast
abstract: The Israeli director Yuval Adler and his screenwriting partner, Ali Waked, an Arab journalist, aren’t selling the usual lessons in the usual way in “Bethlehem.”
lead_paragraph: As its title suggests, “Bethlehem,” a tightly wound thriller about an Israeli secret-service officer and his Palestinian informant, has a biblical undertow. A story of attraction and repulsion evocative of Cain and Abel, it pivots on intimate antagonists who, in another world and geopolitical time, might have been brothers. Razi (Tsahi Halevy) is an Israeli operative working in an antiterrorism unit; Sanfur (Shadi Mar’i) is a 17-year-old Palestinian whose older brother, Ibrahim (Hisham Suliman), is a warrior or militant or terrorist. (Take your pick.)

headline: F.C.C. Seeks Limits on TV Stations, to Curb Cable Costs
keywords: ['Television', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Stations have been trying to get around rules that limit the ownership of multiple broadcasters in a single metropolitan market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to address what critics say is one of the biggest contributors to the ever-rising price of cable television subscriptions, the Federal Communications Commission said on Thursday that it would consider new rules that prevent local broadcasters from working together to negotiate deals with cable companies and advertisers.

headline: Chinese Governor Signals Crackdown on Separatists
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Han Chinese (Ethnic Group)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The remarks by the governor of Xinjiang signaled that the Communist Party would tighten security throughout the region in reaction to a knife attack that killed 29 civilians.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A government leader in the western region of Xinjiang said Thursday that officials would “rigidly crack down” on separatist groups in the area and that “foreign forces” were behind the separatist activities.

headline: David Barrett, Dogged Graft Investigator in Washington, Dies at 76
keywords: ['Special Prosecutors (Independent Counsel)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Barrett led an inquiry concerning Henry G. Cisneros, who was accused of lying about payments to a former mistress while he was mayor of San Antonio.
lead_paragraph: David M. Barrett, a Washington lawyer with Republican ties, was one of six so-called independent counsels sworn in during the Clinton administration to investigate allegations of wrongdoing by government officials. His inquiry concerned Henry G. Cisneros, the secretary of housing and urban development, who was accused of lying in 1993 during an F.B.I. background check about payments he had made to a former mistress while he was mayor of San Antonio.

abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Double Time: Seeing a Ghost, Romantically
abstract: In “The Face of Love,” Annette Bening plays a widow who sees a man, played by Ed Harris, who’s a double for her dead husband.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it’s best to forget a movie’s story and concentrate on whatever else you can. If the camera movements don’t seduce, something else might. Because while a director may not leave much of an impression narratively or visually, he or she can edge into your consciousness with how well the actors are making the thing work, despite its frayed, disjointed pieces. In the case of “The Face of Love,” the main attractions are Ed Harris and a deeply appealing Annette Bening as two — actually, make that three — characters brought together by fate and a screenplay that promisingly flirts with fantasy only to come crashing down to bummer earth.

headline: Five Years Later, Tea Party Is a Faction Republicans Must Court
abstract: It is all but impossible to find a Republican in Texas who does not court the Tea Party, which has become a label for the most energetic faction of conservatives.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Okapi Partners, a Proxy Solicitor, Adds a Senior Executive
abstract: The addition of Michael Fein, the founder of an investment firm, comes as Okapi continues to expand and compete against more established rivals in the proxy solicitation industry.
lead_paragraph: Okapi Partners, one of the younger players in the business of advising companies and hedge funds in proxy contests, plans to announce on Friday that it has hired Michael Fein as a senior managing director.

headline: Angel of Mercy, Angel of Death
abstract: In “Honey,” a fiercely free-spirited woman makes the shadowy business of assisted suicide her personal mission.
lead_paragraph: Figures observed through frosted glass as they engage in semi-audible conversation: That mysterious tableau, which begins Valeria Golino’s film “Honey,” defines the detached sensibility of the title character. “Honey” (“miele” in Italian) is the code name for Irene, a fiercely free-spirited woman in the shadowy business of assisted suicide.

headline: N.Y.U. Women Are Back in Bracket
abstract: Rejuvenated by Coach Lauren Hall-Gregory, the Division III Violets will face New England on Friday in their first N.C.A.A. tournament game since 2009.
lead_paragraph: In her second season at New York University, Coach Lauren Hall-Gregory has helped invigorate the women’s basketball program, which was once a Division III powerhouse. Among those most impressed were opposing coaches and the N.C.A.A. committee that granted N.Y.U. an at-large tournament slot this year.

headline: Foreign Influx Gives Annual Tech Event an International Flavor
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Many Silicon Valley companies aren’t making the trip to Austin, Tex., for the South by Southwest festival this year, but there are plenty of replacements from all over the globe.
lead_paragraph: Going to the South by Southwest technology, music and film festival has long been about discovering the next big thing.

headline: Stage Fright, and Then Some, at a Soloist’s Do-or-Die Recital
abstract: The thriller “Grand Piano” centers on a concert pianist who is threatened with death should he play one wrong note onstage.
lead_paragraph: In Eugenio Mira’s gaudy, amusingly preposterous new thriller, “Grand Piano,” the world’s foremost young classical pianist returns to the concert stage after a five-year sabbatical and finds himself in a deadly line of fire. A perfectionist prone to stage fright, Tom (Elijah Wood) discovers a warning scrawled in red ink inside his piano score: “Play one wrong note and you die.”

headline: New Hampshire: Brown, Not in Race, Behind in Poll
abstract: he latest polling in New Hampshire shows that Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, would lose to Senator Jeanne Shaheen by 13 percentage points if the election were held today.
lead_paragraph: The latest polling in New Hampshire shows that Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, would lose to Senator Jeanne Shaheen by 13 percentage points if the election were held today. The poll, by Suffolk University in Boston, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points. Mr. Brown, a Republican who represented Massachusetts in the Senate for three years, has been toying with challenging Ms. Shaheen but, despite increasing pressure from Republicans, has not indicated whether he will jump in. He has owned a home in New Hampshire for several years, recently moved there full time and must decide by June 13 whether to enter the race.

headline: NBCUniversal to Combine ‘Upfront’ Presentations for Its Cable Channels
abstract: For the big television industry event called upfront week, NBCUniversal will borrow a page from the playbook of its parent, Comcast, and bundle together its cable channels.
lead_paragraph: THIS year, for the big television industry event called upfront week, NBCUniversal will borrow a page from the playbook of its parent, Comcast, and bundle together its cable channels.

headline: Massachusetts: Bill Passes Banning ‘Upskirt’ Images
abstract: The State Legislature passed a bill on Thursday prohibiting “upskirting,” or secretly photographing up someone’s clothing in public without his or her consent.
lead_paragraph: The State Legislature passed a bill on Thursday prohibiting “upskirting,” or secretly photographing up someone’s clothing in public without his or her consent. The move came one day after the state’s highest court ruled that an existing law prohibiting secret photographing of nude or partly nude people did not apply to the case of Michael Robertson — who was arrested in 2010 and accused of using his cellphone to take images of women’s crotch areas on Boston’s public transit — because the women he photographed were dressed. The measure would make the secret photographing or videotaping of “sexual or intimate parts,” either naked or clothed, when a person could reasonably expect them not to be visible to the public, punishable by more than two years in prison and/or a $5,000 fine.

headline: He’s Glad She Came Along
abstract: In his new film, “Journey to the West,” Stephen Chow returns to the same 16th-century adventure of “A Chinese Odyssey.”
lead_paragraph: One rule of comedy is to make it big. Instead of a single pie to the face, try a fusillade and a slippery shoving match. Rather than a couple of anchormen trading insults, why not a street fight? And when it comes to a battle royal, you really can’t top Buddha for administering a beat down.

headline: Saving Daylight, at What Cost?
abstract: Does daylight saving time do more harm than good?

headline: On the Brink of Eviction
abstract: Kevin McCrary, the son of radio and television celebrities of the 1950s, is practically famous for his hoarding.
lead_paragraph: Kevin McCrary, the son of radio and television celebrities of the 1950s, is practically famous for his hoarding.

headline: The Archipelago of Pain
abstract: Solitary confinement is arguably less humane than flogging. Our prisons need to reform solitary laws.
lead_paragraph: We don’t flog people in our prison system, or put them in thumbscrews or stretch them on the rack. We do, however, lock prisoners away in social isolation for 23 hours a day, often for months, years or decades at a time.

headline: New Hampshire Senate Votes to Expand Health Insurance Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: New Hampshire moved to join states like Arkansas and Iowa in the way it is choosing to use money available under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — The state’s Republican-dominated Senate voted Thursday to expand health care coverage to an estimated 50,000 adults using Medicaid funding made available through the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Hacked Heads, Hot Sex and a Whole Lot of Sea
abstract: Greece is again in danger from invaders in this “300” sequel, directed by Noam Murro, but the battles this time center on the sea.
lead_paragraph: Classical historians disagree, but it was probably Herodotus who first posed a question that would ring out across the ages, unanswered till now: Wouldn’t Eva Green look awesome kissing the severed head of an insolent captive? “300: Rise of an Empire” puts the issue to rest (the answer: yes, but it’ll never last) and strives to uphold the rah-rah style of visuals and rhetoric established by its popular predecessor, “300.”

headline: The Hammock Fallacy
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Welfare (US)', 'Research', 'Food Stamps', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The big new poverty report from the House committee led by Representative Paul Ryan is yet another con job.
lead_paragraph: Hypocrisy is the tribute vice pays to virtue. So when you see something like the current scramble by Republicans to declare their deep concern for America’s poor, it’s a good sign, indicating a positive change in social norms. Goodbye, sneering at the 47 percent; hello, fake compassion.

headline: A 47-Foot St. Patrick’s Day Parade That’s Long on Fun
abstract: An Beal Bocht, a Bronx pub, is holding its second annual parade, from one door of the cafe to the other.
lead_paragraph: Sipping a drink at a fine pub in the Bronx, and reading a magazine article, Pat Gilheany was struck by a lightning bolt. Hot Springs, Ark., he read, holds an annual St. Patrick’s Day parade that it claims is the world’s shortest. It runs along Bridge Street in Hot Springs, which is 98 feet from top to bottom.

headline: In an Industrial Space, Homemade Pies
abstract: A three-month-old Italian restaurant features warm service and three wood-burning ovens imported from Italy.
lead_paragraph: The word “fabbrica” means factory in Italian, and Pizza Fabbrica, a three-month-old restaurant in Hicksville, looks the part. In its spacious dining room, stainless-steel industrial lights hang from a ceiling with exposed heating ducts. The open kitchen has three large, wood-burning, volcanic-rock pizza ovens imported from Italy. Covered with tile, they bear the surnames of the owner, Paul Presta, and his two associates, John LaForte and Charles Fusco. Mr. Presta has a background in the construction business and was involved in the building of the restaurant, and Mr. LaForte and Mr. Fusco have run pizzerias.

headline: Red Lights Dim in China’s Sin City
abstract: China is in the throes of the harshest anti-vice campaign in years, and the crackdown is taking a toll on the economy of Dongguan, a southern city of more than eight million people.
lead_paragraph: DONGGUAN, China — His cellphone is not ringing. His online chat programs sit idle. His condoms stay wrapped. People are no longer approaching Denny to pay for sex.

headline: Russian ‘Riot Grrrls’ Assaulted on Camera
keywords: ['Assaults', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The two best-known members of the protest group Pussy Riot were assaulted by six men who hit them and tossed acidic liquid and green dye on their faces while cursing at them.
lead_paragraph: The two best-known members of the Russian protest group Pussy Riot were assaulted on Thursday by six young men who hit the women and tossed acidic liquid and green dye on their faces while cursing at them for coming to the city of Nizhny Novgorod, five hours east of Moscow.

headline: Where Mexico Befriends Peru
abstract: El Tule explores the cuisines of Mexico and Peru, offering the high-low hybrid of folksy atmosphere and a sophisticated menu.
lead_paragraph: With 12 tables and a collection of Latin American folk art tucked into a dining area not much larger than some suburban living rooms, the restaurant El Tule would be easy to mistake for just another outpost of uninspired ethnic fare.

headline: Why Darrell Issa Turned Off the Mic
keywords: ['Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When politicians in the House majority resort to silencing their critics, you know they’ve lost the argument.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans were in the minority for many decades, and those who remember that long period know what it was like to be regularly steamrollered by Democratic leaders. For the most part, they’ve agreed to a basic understanding in the House that members of the minority have a right to speak up in disagreement. They can be ignored, and they usually are, but if they’re muzzled, it makes the majority look like a bunch of insecure authoritarians. And it could come back to haunt them if the majority shifts again.

headline: A Hobbit House, With Chickens
abstract: The Vander Ende-Onderdonk House, said to be the oldest Dutch colonial stone house in New York City, and the Bun-Ker Vietnamese restaurant can be found tucked away in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Double-takes and disbelief are common reactions to the white stone farmhouse with green shutters at 18-20 Flushing Avenue in Ridgewood on the Queens-Brooklyn border. The Dutch Colonial Vander Ende-Onderdonk House materializes like Brigadoon on what is otherwise a dreary corridor of squat warehouses.

headline: Then and Now, a Test That Aims to Neutralize Advantages of the Privileged
abstract: The people who first designed the SAT decades ago wanted to identify a new elite based on brains rather than heredity, not necessarily to expand access to college.
lead_paragraph: When the College Board announced Wednesday that it was overhauling the SAT in ways that would curb the advantages enjoyed by affluent students, it sounded a bit like the people who first designed and popularized the test decades ago.

headline: Need for Full-Day Kindergarten Is Lost in Pre-K Debate, Critics Say
abstract: Amid the push to expand full-day preschool in New York, some parents say kindergartners who are in school for only a few hours a day are being overlooked.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, N.Y. — Jennifer Simon has paid thousands of dollars for private preschool, she said, and it was worth every penny.

headline: New York City’s Jobless Rate Drops to Lowest Level in 5 Years
abstract: The city’s unemployment rate, which fell to 7.8 percent in January, is still significantly higher than the nation’s.
lead_paragraph: In Mayor Bill de Blasio’s first month in office, New York City’s unemployment rate continued its long, gradual decline, falling below 8 percent for the first time in five years.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 6, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 6, 2014

headline: The Sweet, Streaming Sound of Data
keywords: ['Music', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: With the music industry turning digital, music companies can now understand their customers’ listening habits in greater depth than ever before.
lead_paragraph: Once, all you needed to succeed in the music business were a pair of golden ears and some hustle. Now, it also takes mountains of data.

headline: A Smart Retreat on Immigration
abstract: South Carolina moved closer to acknowledging the futility of oppressive immigration laws when it abandoned key parts of its harsh law.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina has just abandoned key parts of its harsh, Arizona-style immigration law. It’s a setback for devotees of the state-by-state, do-it-yourself approach to immigration enforcement, and good news for those who have been fighting to turn back that toxic legislative tide.

headline: World’s Biggest Arms Importer, India Wants to Buy Local
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The country recently rolled out its own fighter jet and tank and several ships, a defense lineup that could put Russian arms exports in trouble.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Of the 30 countries that attended a defense exposition last month to sell weapons to India, the world’s largest arms importer, only the Russians had the chutzpah to dress up their tanks and guns with women in tightfitting camouflage.

headline: Natural Gas as a Diplomatic Tool
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Natural Gas', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Obama administration should use exports as a component of a broader energy strategy to undercut Russia’s influence over Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In response to the crisis in Ukraine, some American lawmakers and energy companies are urging the United States to export natural gas to Europe in an effort to undercut Russia’s influence over the Continent. The Obama administration should move to increase exports, which would help allies like Germany, Turkey and Britain, but the effects of such exports would likely be modest and wouldn’t be realized for several years.

headline: Knicks Fans, Do You Believe in ... 1999?
abstract: The Knicks may be 22-40, but there’s always hope. Remember the team of Patrick Ewing, Allan Houston and Larry Johnson that advanced to the N.B.A. finals as an eighth seed?
lead_paragraph: The Knicks broke a seven-game losing streak and picked up a game on the Atlanta Hawks by notching their 22nd victory Wednesday. Inside their front office, Larry Johnson bent his arms in tribute to James L. Dolan’s middle initial and told Dolan, the Madison Square Garden chairman, “It’s all happening.”

headline: Latin Atmosphere With a Carefree Message
abstract: The scents of Latin American home cooking and the rhythms of dance music fill the dining room of Mambo 64.
lead_paragraph: From the moment you enter its small, softly lit dining room, Mambo 64 grabs you with its warm hospitality, the mouthwatering scents of Latin home cooking and the rhythms of dance music.

headline: U.N. Voices Concern Over Reports of Excessive Force in Venezuela
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The report comes as a soldier and a civilian were shot and killed in Caracas during an extended confrontation between residents, government supporters and troops.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A group of United Nations human rights experts voiced concern on Thursday over reports of excessive use of force against protesters and journalists during the recent wave of antigovernment demonstrations that has spread across the country.

headline: Ukraine Weighs Boycott of Paralympics in Russia
abstract: With turmoil in their own country, Ukrainian Paralympic officials said they would announce on Friday whether their team would compete in the Games.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — The chant echoed throughout the plaza of the Paralympians’ mountain village here, and it grew only louder as the Ukrainian delegation marched on. “Peace for Ukraine,” its members shouted in their native language, again and again, their words grounded more in hope than in confidence.

headline: 2 Marines Disciplined After 4 Die at Pendleton
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: An explosion that killed four Marines last year was most likely caused by a dropped or kicked grenade, and two Marines were relieved of duty as a result, officials said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — An explosion during a training exercise that killed four Marines at Camp Pendleton last year was most likely caused by a dropped or kicked grenade, and two Marines have been relieved of duty as a result, military officials announced Thursday.

headline: Pitfalls Seen in a Turn to Privately Run Long-Term Care
keywords: ['Long-Term Care Insurance', 'Medicaid', 'Elder Care', 'Nursing Homes', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: New York is one of at least 26 states rolling out managed long-term care programs under Medicaid, but the widely praised version in Tennessee has had problems.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Even as public attention is focused on the Affordable Care Act, another health care overhaul is underway in many states: an ambitious effort to restrain the ballooning Medicaid cost of long-term care as people live longer and survive more disabling conditions.

headline: Decades After London Racial Killing, Inquiry Shows Police Spied on Victim’s Parents
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: As a family campaigned for a thorough murder investigation, an undercover officer was recording the details of their personal lives, progress and decisions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More than 20 years after the murder of a young black man became a symbol of Britain’s troubled race relations, an inquiry published Thursday disclosed that undercover officers spied on the victim’s parents as they campaigned for a thorough investigation into their son’s killing.

headline: For Nets, New Scoring Threat Proves a Bargain
abstract: Acquired in a trade for Reggie Evans and Jason Terry, Marcus Thornton has proved to be powerful off the bench.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes even the smallest trade can make a big difference. The Nets have found that out quickly with Marcus Thornton, a 26-year-old guard, who has established himself as a go-to scoring option off the bench.

headline: Canadian Oil Will Take New Route Across U.S.
abstract: A pipeline through which oil once flowed west will instead take diluted bitumen and conventional oil from western Canada to Montreal, traversing the United States in the process.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canada’s energy producers received a rare boost in their efforts to expand the market for oil sands bitumen on Thursday when the country’s National Energy Board approved the reversal of a Canadian pipeline.

headline: Trying to Revive His Prospects, Rubio Pushes Strength Abroad
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: After being attacked by conservatives for supporting immigration reform, Senator Marco Rubio is trying to become the leading voice for a muscular brand of foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — Alarmed by the rise of noninterventionist voices in his party, Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, is aiming to revive his political prospects in an unlikely way: trying to become the leading voice for a muscular brand of foreign policy.

headline: Serving Southern Hospitality
abstract: A 10-month-old restaurant in South Norwalk hopes to fill a gap in a state’s restaurant scene with Southern food.
lead_paragraph: Somehow I expected to find Mama’s Boy Southern Table and Refuge, a 10-month-old restaurant in South Norwalk, in a homier setting than the ground floor of a commercial building on North Water Street, diagonally across from the Norwalk Maritime Center.

headline: Paramount’s ‘Noah’ Is Said to Face Ban in Middle East
abstract: The Hollywood Reporter said the film had been banned in Qatar, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates for its portrayal of Noah.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With the help of its newly added disclaimer acknowledging artistic license in its biblical storytelling, Darren Aronofsky’s “Noah” might make peace with religious viewers at home. But the film has a new headache: censorship in the Middle East.

headline: Heralding War With Springy Step
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Alfred Hitchcock’s “Foreign Correspondent” (1940) has been newly released on Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 21, 1939, only weeks into World War II, Alfred Hitchcock — recently imported from Britain by the mighty David O. Selznick to direct “Rebecca” — was taken to lunch by the independent producer Walter Wanger. The meeting went swimmingly.

headline: TV Time
abstract: A TV-themed Friday from Matt Ginsberg.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — For a puzzle whose theme revolves around television shows, this Friday crossword from Matt Ginsberg draws a lot of material from the classical world.

headline: Supernatural? Magician Has Doubts
abstract: “Nothing on Earth Can Hold Houdini” tells of the magician’s crusade to debunk mediums.
lead_paragraph: Harry Houdini was apparently a complex fellow, and the Axis Theater Company gives him a complex treatment in “Nothing on Earth Can Hold Houdini,” by Randy Sharp. Like Ms. Sharp’s look at the Dust Bowl, “Last Man Club,” produced by the company in 2012, it is a play that bracingly refuses to be a straightforward historical treatment.

headline: Washington Power Play
abstract: Bryan Cranston stars in “All the Way,” about President Lyndon B. Johnson’s push for the Civil Rights Act.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not personal, Dick, it’s just politics,” Lyndon Johnson says to a good friend who has suddenly turned into a vanquished foe in the new play “All the Way,” by Robert Schenkkan. Johnson, played by Bryan Cranston in the mighty slab of history that opened at the Neil Simon Theater on Thursday night, infuses that glib phrase with palpable urgency and a whisper of tenderness. There’s no question that he really means what he’s saying.

headline: Robert Ashley, Opera Composer Who Painted Outside the Lines, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Ashley stretched the boundaries of opera, choosing not to hew too closely to tradition in his work.
lead_paragraph: Robert Ashley, an American composer who helped wrestle opera into the 20th century and in so doing broadened the genre in strange, unexpected ways, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: With Netanyahu, Obama Plays Bad Cop to Kerry’s Good Cop
abstract: President Obama has fixed ideas about how best to pursue peace in the Middle East, and a far less solicitous style than his secretary of state, John Kerry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An icy snowstorm was blowing in when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel landed here on Sunday night for a meeting with President Obama. But the weather was mild compared with the wintry welcome he got from the White House.

headline: A Record of Courage May Add a New Mark
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Coaches and Managers', 'Women and Girls', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: With one more victory, the Harvard women’s basketball coach Kathy Delaney-Smith would pass the former Princeton men’s coach Pete Carril for the most basketball victories by an Ivy League coach.
lead_paragraph: Coach Kathy Delaney and her Westwood High School girls basketball team returned from a road game in the mid-1970s to find their locker room occupied by a visiting boys squad. The girls, tired, sweaty and eager to retrieve their belongings, were told to wait.

headline: Iran Disputes Israeli Arms Claim
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Iran accused Israel on Thursday of falsifying claims that it had seized an Iranian shipment of weapons bound for Palestinian militants in Gaza aboard a merchant ship.
lead_paragraph: Iran accused Israel on Thursday of falsifying claims that it had seized an Iranian shipment of weapons bound for Palestinian militants in Gaza aboard a merchant ship. Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, said that Israel’s assertion, made Wednesday, was suspiciously timed, coming during a meeting in Washington of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the powerful pro-Israel lobbying organization that is one of Iran’s most influential critics in American politics. The Israeli military said a Panamanian-flagged ship was seized by Israeli commandos 1,000 miles from the southern Israeli city of Eilat and was carrying dozens of Syrian-made M-302 rockets that Iran had helped to transport to Iraq, where the ship had loaded them. “An Iranian ship carrying arms for Gaza. Captured just in time for annual AIPAC anti-Iran campaign,” Mr. Zarif said on Twitter.  “Amazing Coincidence! Or same failed lies.”

headline: Free Options for Filing Your Income Tax Return Electronically
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: For low- and moderate-income taxpayers, commercial software companies provide free online tax software. But anyone can use the I.R.S.’s online forms.
lead_paragraph: If you have low to moderate annual income, you’re most likely eligible for a variety of free or reduced-rate options for completing and electronically filing your federal income tax return.

headline: New York City Comptroller’s Office Names Chief Diversity Officer
abstract: Carra Wallace’s ultimate goal is to increase the number of contracts and subcontracts awarded to businesses owned by female and minority contractors.
lead_paragraph: Faced with a decreasing percentage of city money going to businesses owned by female and minority contractors, the New York City comptroller’s office has named a new official and also announced that it will grade city agencies on how much they spend with these certified businesses.

headline: Turkish Court Backs General’s Appeal
abstract: The Constitutional Court on Thursday ruled in favor of a former army chief who was appealing the legality of his initial detention in 2012 in a case that resulted in his conviction and life sentence last year for plotting a coup against the government, according to a written statement posted on the court’s website.
lead_paragraph: The Constitutional Court on Thursday ruled in favor of a former army chief who was appealing the legality of his initial detention in 2012 in a case that resulted in his conviction and life sentence last year for plotting a coup against the government, according to a written statement posted on the court’s website. The ruling, which said that the rights of the former officer, Gen. Ilker Basbug, who served as military chief of staff from 2008 to 2010, had been violated, paved the way for his possible release from an Istanbul prison. The Constitutional Court said the lower court that held the five-year trial failed to publish its detailed reasoning for its verdict and send it to the appeals court, obstructing the defendant’s right to an appeal and violating a constitutional clause concerning personal freedom. The ruling could also be used as a precedent for the release of many of the more than 270 defendants who spent several years in prison before their convictions last year in the case known as the Ergenekon affair. The government’s prosecution of that case was seen as an effort to curb the role of Turkey’s military in politics, but it was also criticized for ensnaring people who were opponents of the government, including politicians, academics, journalists and writers.

headline: U.S. Seems Unlikely to Accept That Rights Treaty Applies to Its Actions Abroad
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Torture', 'Treaties']
abstract: A panel in Geneva disagrees with the position of the United States that it has no obligations under a global rights treaty when operating abroad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 1995, Conrad Harper, the Clinton administration’s top State Department lawyer, appeared before a United Nations panel in Geneva to discuss American compliance with a global Bill of Rights-style treaty the Senate had recently ratified, and he was asked a pointed question: Did the United States believe it applied outside its borders?

headline: Witness Says Defendant Spoke to Qaeda Trainees
abstract: The testimony of Salim Alwan seemed intended to support the government’s contention that Sulaiman Abu Ghaith played an important role for Al Qaeda before the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: A Buffalo-area man who went to Afghanistan and received military training at a camp run by Al Qaeda in the months before the Sept. 11 attacks testified on Thursday that he saw Sulaiman Abu Ghaith at a Qaeda guesthouse telling trainees about the concept of swearing an oath of loyalty, or giving “bayat,” to Osama bin Laden.

headline: How de Blasio’s Narrative Got Hijacked
abstract: The battle over charter schools between Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is also a fight over marketing, with incomplete truths on both sides.
lead_paragraph: Last week on the 64th day of his mayoralty, Bill de Blasio, criticized for his too hardy approach to snow days, for the slow pace of his appointments, for displays of petulance, achieved a predicted but still significant victory. The City Planning Commission unanimously approved a reimagining of the Domino Sugar refinery on the Brooklyn waterfront, which the de Blasio administration had worked to ensure would have a greater number of apartments priced below market rate than had originally been proposed. Proving that he could compromise with developers, that he could alienate factions of a left that find excessive height distasteful as they clamor for more affordable housing, the mayor permitted the project’s buildings to go to 55 stories, rather than 30 or 40.

headline: De Blasio and Dolan Announce a Push for More Pre-K Classes
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio gained a high-profile partner in Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan as he raced to find classroom space in New York City for 24,000 4-year-olds by the fall.
lead_paragraph: They exchanged chitchat about Michelangelo with 4-year-olds, spoke about the promise of early childhood education, and joked about which one of them should field a question directed at Your Eminence.

lead_paragraph: The State Department’s former top lawyer, Harold Koh, concluded in October 2010 that the “best reading” of the accord is that it does “impose certain obligations on a State Party’s extraterritorial conduct.”

lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — As rain pounded and smartphones buzzed with tornado warnings, fans fretted that there would be no game Thursday, while the Yankees cooled their cleats at their Tampa clubhouse, waiting for the word to make a 20-mile spring training trip.

headline: To Change India’s Preference for Sons, Start With the Women
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Families and Family Life', 'Gender', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Rural Areas', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The author of “Gender Equality and Inequality in Rural India: Blessed With a Son” says her studies show that using education and employment to help girls get on an equal footing with sons would help reduce gender bias.
lead_paragraph: I first visited India as a tourist in 1971 at the age of 27. I spent six months backpacking through the country and was surprised to find so many people everywhere, even in the remote countryside. Mothers were always surrounded by small children, only a year or so apart in age.

headline: Frank Jobe, Surgeon Who Saved Pitchers’ Careers, Dies at 88
abstract: Dr. Jobe was renowned as the father of Tommy John surgery, a procedure that has been duplicated thousands of times in sports medicine.
lead_paragraph: On a July night in 1974, Dr. Frank Jobe, the orthopedist for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was sitting in the stands at Dodger Stadium watching the ace left-hander Tommy John face the Montreal Expos.

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Rahm Emanuel, the mayor of this Midwest metropolis, spoke of opening parks and libraries and renovating playgrounds. Eric Garcetti, the mayor of Los Angeles, boasted that he monitored Hollywood parking spaces in real time on his iPhone.

headline: Cakes Galore at Bakery
abstract: Mrs. Maxwell’s Bakery in Brooklyn usually has about 240 finished cakes on display at a time.
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Maxwell’s Bakery in Brooklyn usually has about 240 finished cakes on display at a time.

headline: Your Next Word Is ‘Sardonic’
abstract: “Bad Words,” directed by and starring Jason Bateman, is a comedic contortion of earlier films about spelling bees.
lead_paragraph: The most delicious language in “Bad Words,” Jason Bateman’s debut as a feature-film director, has no place near tender ears. But the film’s premise is as wholesomely all-American as the tradition it skewers: Guy Trilby, a misanthrope with a serious case of lingering adolescent angst, played by Mr. Bateman, tries to earn some respect by wheedling his way onto the spelling bee circuit and stringing together letters into luxuriant polysyllabic parts of speech — all the way to nationals.

headline: A Brooklyn Bakery Named for No One
abstract: The name Mrs. Maxwell’s was inspired by Maxwell House coffee and a high school. The owners of the bakery added “Mrs.” to the name to appear as if “a little old lady” were making the cakes.
lead_paragraph: It was a peaceful late Sunday morning at Mrs. Maxwell’s Bakery in East New York — but not for long. Services at the Brooklyn neighborhood’s churches were about to conclude. “We got crowd control ropes, so we’re ready,” said Jenny Laruy, 57, who works the counter. And then a procession of cars and minivans began to stream into the bakery’s parking lot. Doors slammed, and an army of well-dressed women in hats headed purposefully for the door.

headline: The Mets’ Big Game: Four Batters, Three Pitchers
abstract: Bartolo Colon and Jon Niese had mixed results pitching in a simulated outing on Wednesday along with Bobby Parnell.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Tradition Field was almost empty. The clubhouse was mostly cleared out. The majority of the Mets were scheduled to play in two games in Kissimmee, Fla., against the Astros. But here, on Thursday morning, there was to be a third game, if you could call it that. It consisted of Bartolo Colon, Jon Niese and Bobby Parnell taking turns facing live batters, in a gamelike situation, with no fans in the stands.

headline: Japan Won’t Impose Banking Laws on Bitcoin

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Bitcoin trading platforms can, for now, operate freely under Japanese law, the government said Friday in a note that signaled a hands-off approach to the virtual currency.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) FRIDAY NIGHT SPOTLIGHT: FOOD IN THE MOVIES A visual feast begins with “Eat Drink Man Woman” (1994), above, Ang Lee’s Oscar-nominated drama for best foreign-language film about a father, Mr. Chu (Sihung Lung) — the greatest chef in Taipei — who has lost his joie de vivre, and his three beautiful star-crossed daughters (Chien-Lien Wu, Kuei-Mei-Yang and Yu-Wen Wang), who cannot escape his spell. Tensions are so high that at their extravagant Sunday dinners, the family can barely eat. And so he begins to supply spectacular lunches to the daughter of a family friend, who is too young to realize that his cooking is flawed: He has lost the use of his taste buds. “Wonderfully seductive, and nicely knowing about all of its characters’ appetites, ‘Eat Drink Man Woman’ makes for an uncomplicatedly pleasant experience,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “This film’s use of food is both voluptuous and serious, amplifying the story even as it offers an irresistible diversion. The film succeeds in presenting Mr. Chu’s intricate cooking (rendered for the camera by three amazingly artful chefs) as an expression of larger traditionalism and as an endangered art.” Of the title, she added: “ ‘Food and sex,’ one character says succinctly, amplifying that four-ideogram phrase. ‘Basic human desires. Can’t avoid them.’ ” In “Mostly Martha” (2002), at 10:15, Martha (Martina Gedeck), a single, workaholic chef in Hamburg, Germany, finds her carefully organized life in disarray when she must care for her dead sister’s 8-year-old daughter (Maxime Foerste). Enter Mario, the Italian sous-chef (Sergio Castellitto) who can charm everyone but Martha. “The movie succeeds because the writer and director, Sandra Nettelbeck, seems as obsessive as her titular heroine,” Elvis Mitchell wrote in The Times. “The final confection is extremely enjoyable, though a few degrees shy of perfection.”

headline: Default Signals Growing Maturity of China’s Corporate Bond Market
abstract: The government did not intercede to prevent a solar panel producer from defaulting on a bond interest payment, suggesting that Beijing is serious about a financial overhaul.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A small producer of solar panels on Friday became the first company in recent history to default in China’s domestic bond market. The development was welcomed by analysts as a sign that the nation’s huge but protected corporate debt market may be growing up.

headline: For First Time, Kremlin Signals It Is Prepared to Annex Crimea
abstract: Leaders of both houses of Russia’s Parliament said that they would support a vote by Crimeans to break away from Ukraine, ignoring sanctions threats and warnings from the U.S. and other countries.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia signaled for the first time on Friday that it was prepared to annex the Crimea region of Ukraine, significantly intensifying its confrontation with the West over the political crisis in Ukraine and threatening to undermine a system of respect for national boundaries that has helped keep the peace in Europe and elsewhere for decades.

headline: Adding Elders and Children to a Domestic Violence Law
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Domestic Violence', 'Elder Abuse', 'Law and Legislation', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: As a proposed law against domestic violence slowly works its way through the legislative process, a scholar and deputy to the National People’s Congress says it must include protections for the elderly and children, as well as spouses.
lead_paragraph: A long-awaited law against domestic violence in China must address elder abuse, which happens “quite a lot” despite China’s cultural tradition of respect for the elderly, said Sun Xiaomei, a delegate to the National People’s Congress, which is meeting now in Beijing.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | E-Cigarettes, by Other Names, Lure Young and Worry Experts
abstract: What are “hookah pens,” “e-hookahs” or “vape pipes”?
lead_paragraph: In “E-Cigarettes, by Other Names, Lure Young and Worry Experts,” Matt Richtel writes about a subgenre of the fast-growing e-cigarette market that is being shrewdly marketed to young people.

headline: Venezuela in Black-and-White
abstract: Though famed for chromatic installations, Carlos Cruz-Diez was first taken by the magic of light as a young photographer documenting Venezuela’s emergence as a modern state.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Cruz-Diez is known for his work with color — paintings where tightly packed stripes seem to vibrate as the viewer shifts perspective, light chambers where participant-observers saunter through drenching color lights. But an exhibit at the Americas Society in New York puts the artist himself in a new light, showcasing his early fascination with photography.

headline: How Much Does the SAT or ACT Matter in Your Life?
abstract: Do you believe the SAT or ACT will provide an accurate measure of how well you will perform in college?
lead_paragraph: For millions of high school students, the SAT or ACT serves as a gatekeeper helping to determine where they go to college. Some families spend thousands of dollars on test preparation courses or private tutors because they think so much is riding on test scores.

headline: London’s Laundry Business
abstract: Britain is ready to betray Ukraine to protect its cut of Russia’s dirty money.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — THE city has changed. The buses are still dirty, the people are still passive-aggressive, but something about London has changed. You can see signs of it everywhere. The townhouses in the capital’s poshest districts are empty; they have been sold to Russian oligarchs and Qatari princes.

headline: New York Today: Art Abounds
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: art fairs galore, a spot of warmer weather, and a six-figure fortune-telling scheme.
lead_paragraph: Good Friday morning. The temperature is climbing. But it’s still pretty cold — 32 degrees.
