keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Bank of America Merrill Lynch and BNP Paribas have suspended two traders, according to people familiar with the matter. More than 20 traders have been suspended or fired amid inquiries into potential manipulation of the currency markets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Two more banks have suspended employees in the latest escalation of an investigation into potential manipulation of the $5 trillion-a-day foreign exchange markets, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: The Macho Cops of Honduras
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Police', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The most violent country in the world is not getting any safer.
lead_paragraph: SAN SALVADOR — WHEN Honduras’s new president, Juan Orlando Hernández, took office a little more than a month ago, he promised to apply mano dura — the iron fist — against criminals. His plans include granting police officers more freedom to arrest suspects and greater use of the army for public safety. This strategy is a continuation of the hard-line policies of the last few years, which have done nothing to change the fact that Honduras still has the world’s highest homicide rate.

headline: Censors Hit Delete on a Party Chief’s Censorship Remarks
abstract: It seems that comments on microblogs about Internet censorship, even by senior Communist Party officials, can fall prey to China’s army of online minders.
lead_paragraph: The question runs through the minds of many Chinese microblog users: What catches the eye of an online censor on any given day?

headline: Thoughts That Can’t Be Spoken
abstract: After a stroke, my mind raced ahead of my mouth.
lead_paragraph: MONDION, France — ONE early evening a week before last Christmas, I sat down at my desk to answer a letter. But just as I was about to write the first words, I felt as if they were escaping me, vanishing into air before reaching the paper. I was surprised but not concerned. I was very tired and promised myself to stop work after finishing the note.

headline: For Entrepreneur in Conflict Resolution, Business Is Good
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Small Business']
abstract: The company’s speciality is designing meetings — never an easy task, but even more difficult when participants are torn apart because of opposing religious, cultural or political views.
lead_paragraph: In January, Alma Abdul-Hadi Jadallah was in Geneva, helped run a meeting of Syrian women for the United Nations. Last year, she took four or five trips to Yemen, to assist in talks to create the country’s new political system. Before that, she developed processes to ease religious tensions in Iraq.

headline: Daily Report: Mystery Swirls Around Unmasking of Bitcoin Inventor
abstract: A Newsweek article contends that a man in Southern California named Satoshi Nakamoto was the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many people say they are unconvinced.
lead_paragraph: Central to Bitcoin’s cachet has been the mythic status of the system’s creator, Nathaniel Popper and Rachel Abrams report. Its developer went by the name Satoshi Nakamoto, but that is all that Bitcoin’s adopters seemed to know — or wanted to know. After all, Bitcoin was a project dedicated in part to making it easier to avoid the all-seeing gaze of the government and corporate America.

headline: As Kerry Visits Jordan, Abbas Holds His Ground
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry made an unannounced visit to consult King Abdullah II even as the Palestinian president restated positions that underscored the challenge Mr. Kerry faces.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State John Kerry made an unannounced visit to Jordan on Friday to consult King Abdullah II about the Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations, even as the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, reiterated positions that underscored the challenge Mr. Kerry faces in trying to shrink gaps between the two sides.

headline: In Kolkata, Reminders of Why We Help the ‘Last Girl’
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Education (K-12)', 'Human Trafficking', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Prostitution', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: To the women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem, the bright, hopeful youths from the red-light district illustrate the need to follow Gandhi’s standard of making a difference in the life of the weakest.
lead_paragraph: The women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem kept a diary of their travels throughout India as they met the country’s young feminists, writers and thought leaders (previous posts are here, here and here). In this installation for India Ink, Ms. Gupta and Ms. Steinem visit Kolkata, the capital of West Bengal.

headline: Cerberus and Safeway Strike $9 Billion Deal
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management agreed to acquire Safeway in a deal worth more than $9 billion. | A Newsweek article claims to have unmasked the creator of the virtual currency Bitcoin, but many remain unconvinced. | Four former leaders at the once-mighty law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf were charged by New York prosecutors with larceny and securities fraud. | S.E.C. employees are likely to be no better at trading stocks than the rest of us, the Deal Professor says.
lead_paragraph: SUPER DEAL: CERBERUS TO BUY SAFEWAY FOR $9 BILLION  |  In one of the largest leveraged buyouts since the financial crisis, a group led by the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management agreed on Thursday to acquire Safeway in a deal worth more than $9 billion, Michael J. de la Merced and William Alden write in DealBook. The deal, which will be financed by $7.6 billion worth of borrowed money, is the biggest leveraged buyout so far this year. Cerberus plans to merge Safeway with Albertsons, a smaller grocery store chain that it owns.

headline: Digital Trade School Raises $35 Million in Financing Round
abstract: General Assembly, the three-year-old academy for digital business skills, said on Friday that it had raised more than $35 million in a new round led by Institutional Venture Partners, as it seeks to build out its global ambitions.
lead_paragraph: With more people looking to jump into the Internet economy, General Assembly, a school of sorts for digital business skills, is growing as well.

headline: Police Detain Government Employee in Beating of Nurse
abstract: The police in Nanjing have detained a government employee after a video of the beating of a nurse generated widespread outrage online.
lead_paragraph: The police in Nanjing have detained a government employee after a video of the beating a nurse generated widespread outrage online, the state news media reported.

headline: U.N. Women’s Rights Group Seeks Men’s Support
abstract: The campaign encourages men to stand up for the rights of the women of the world who are their mothers, sisters and daughters.
lead_paragraph: In a campaign from the United Nations that seeks to promote women’s rights, there is not a woman in sight – and that is deliberate.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | February 2014
abstract: The latest monthly collection of articles about young people published in The Times.
lead_paragraph: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson “Teaching With ‘Teenagers in The Times.’ ”

headline: A Deeper Conversation on Women in Hedge Funds
abstract: Readers offer their own experiences and suggestions in response an Another View column by Whitney Tilson that described the problem of having too few women in hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Tilson is the managing partner of the hedge fund firm Kase Capital Management, which he founded more than 15 years ago. Mr. Tilson is also the co-founder of Value Investor Insight, an investment newsletter, and the Value Investing Congress, a biannual investment conference.

headline: As Job Creation Increases in February, Economists See Signs of a Spring Thaw
abstract: The American economy added more jobs in February than in either of the two months preceding it, suggesting winter weather had been the primary obstacle to growth.
lead_paragraph: The American economy appeared to emerge from a winter hibernation in February, creating more jobs than in either of the previous two months and suggesting that momentum in the labor market might gradually build with the arrival of spring.

headline: Coffee Comeuppance
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young lawyer, eager to impress his colleagues at a restaurant, got a quick response over a demitasse.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A.C.P.T. 2014: On Your Marks … Get Set …Wait! First, There’s Work To Do
abstract: Kicking off our tournament coverage with an interview with the puzzle master Will Shortz on exactly how those puzzles get to the tournament. Also, some breaking news on the future of the competition.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Molo, sawubona and hallo! I just spent some time in Cape Town, South Africa, and I honestly think I left my heart there. What a beautiful, lively place: it’s a city abuzz with artistic energy that just happens to be nestled luxuriously between captivating mountains and the sea. Most of all, it’s warm there, which is definitely a plus these days.

headline: What the Jobs Report Means for the Fed
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: February’s employment numbers were decent, and it is increasingly clear that Federal Reserve officials are not going to modify their scheduled retreat from bond-buying unless they must.
lead_paragraph: The February jobs report doesn’t change the strong likelihood that the Federal Reserve will cut monthly bond purchases by another $10 billion later this month.

headline: Judge Dismisses Charges Against Whistle-Blower in Sexual Abuse Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: Samuel Kellner had been accused of trying to extort money from the family of Baruch Lebovits, an accused molester, and bribing a young man to testify falsely.
lead_paragraph: In a case that riveted the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn, a judge on Friday dismissed all charges against Samuel Kellner, a whistle-blower who had been charged with trying to extort money from the family of an accused molester and bribing a grand jury witness to testify falsely.

headline: A Rare Government Success Story for Women’s Empowerment in Kerala
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Poverty', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: From a few thousand women, the Kudumbashree program in the southwestern state of Kerala has grown into a giant community enterprise with 3.7 million members.
lead_paragraph: ERNAKULAM, Kerala — In a country that has been criticized as lacking commitment to women’s rights, one program in the southwest state of Kerala has been quietly serving as an example that a government can indeed successfully empower women, both economically and socially.

headline: Nation of CRINOs
abstract: We’re mostly not right.
lead_paragraph: A term we really need: Center-Right In Name Only.

headline: Plácido Domingo, by the Numbers
abstract: One of the world’s most famous tenors has continued performing into his 70s by expanding his repertoire. A look back at his career highlights.
lead_paragraph: One of the world’s most famous tenors has continued performing into his 70s by expanding his repertoire. A look back at his career highlights.

headline: More On Wages And Monetary Policy
abstract: Too low and not rising means wait.
lead_paragraph: Today’s employment report gives us another data point on private-sector wages, which continue to run well below pre-crisis levels:

headline: Into the Mouths of Babes
abstract: About that brown bag.
lead_paragraph: Oh, my — not only was Paul Ryan’s hunger=dignity speech appalling on the merits, the anecdote he used to make his point was fake — a distortion of a real story with a completely different point.

headline: Court Orders Kansas Legislature to Spend More on Schools
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'State Legislatures', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Education (K-12)', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: The issue of increasing base aid per student was politically charged because as lawmakers were refusing to increase funding, they passed the largest tax cuts in state history.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Kansas’s highest court ruled on Friday that funding disparities between school districts violated the state’s Constitution and ordered the Legislature to bridge the gap, setting the stage for a messy budget battle in the capital this year.

headline: Ukrainian Team Remains at Paralympics, for Now
abstract: Ukraine said on Friday that it would compete in the Paralympics instead of withdrawing in protest of Russia’s intervention in the Crimean Peninsula.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — Citing a desire to promote peace, Ukraine’s delegation to the Paralympics said Friday that it would compete in the Games instead of withdrawing in protest of Russia’s intervention in the Crimean Peninsula. But the leader of its delegation cautioned that Ukraine would return home immediately if the conflict in Crimea intensified.

headline: Domingo Undimmed
abstract: Through a remarkable switch to baritone roles, Plácido Domingo continues to command stages at leading opera houses at the age of 73.
lead_paragraph: Plácido Domingo’s day began with a morning dress rehearsal on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, where he traded jokes with the cast and crew at a theater where he has been singing for nearly half a century, and then, in full regalia as the sea god Neptune, ran through a new Handel aria he was learning for the revival of “The Enchanted Island,” a Baroque pastiche.

headline: Rising Rents Leave New York Artists Out in the Cold
keywords: ['Art', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gentrification']
abstract: As artists’ creative spaces in New York have shrunk, so, too, has their art — if, that is, they still make art.
lead_paragraph: Artists have wedged their canvases and supplies into their apartments. Others are working in hurricane-torn basements or in temporary, borrowed spaces. As their creative spaces have shrunk, so, too, has their art — if, that is, they still make art.

headline: Don’t Blink, You’ll Miss the Scenery
abstract: The play “Love and Information” is really 57 short plays that require separate sets. The people behind this New York Theater Workshop production discuss how they do it.
lead_paragraph: Chat with the people behind “Love and Information,” the new play by the British playwright Caryl Churchill, and they sound like game geeks, not theater makers.

headline: In Our Pages: March 8
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Girl Poses As Boy to Join Navy

headline: Incomplete Recovery for Working-Age Men
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The employment rate for men has rebounded from its recession low, but is not even halfway back to its 2008 level.
lead_paragraph: Men between the ages of 25 and 54 are in their prime working years. Generally speaking, they’re too old for college and too young for retirement.

headline: Whose Anxiety Is It?
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Children and Childhood', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: What does a parent — who happens to be a mental health reporter — do when she’s concerned about her son? Dives headfirst into the D.S.M., of course. He could have Social Anxiety Disorder. Or maybe Social Phobia. Perhaps Generalized Anxiety Disorder? Or he could just be shy.
lead_paragraph: One morning, after the superintendent closed our town’s schools for the third snowstorm of the season, I looked out my kitchen window to see packs of neighborhood kids dragging brightly colored sleds down our cul-de-sac. No doubt they were heading for Hospital Hill, the favorite sledding mecca of the local orthopedists’ union.

headline: For Pessimist or Optimist, Jobs Report Is More of the Same
abstract: Whether the February jobs report is good news or bad news depends on your own predilection for optimism or pessimism.
lead_paragraph: In these last three years, there have been countless times when a couple of months in a row of surprisingly good or surprisingly bad jobs readings have given a false signal, prompting either a sense of glum disappointment or (with hindsight) misplaced optimism about whether a meaningful economic recovery is underway. It has made fools of many good economic analysts who have been too quick to detect turning points.

headline: Behind Barclays’ About-Face on Bonuses
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'Executive Compensation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The chief of the British bank said that after the bank cut pay at its investment bank to below-market levels in 2012, it ended up losing top bankers. But Barclays’ own numbers throw a different light on the subject.
lead_paragraph: Barclays wants you to know that it tried.

headline: Chancellor Says She Regrets Remarks About a Harlem Charter School
abstract: The New York City schools chancellor, Carmen Fariña, said she would work to accommodate students affected by a decision to deny public classroom space to a Harlem school.
lead_paragraph: The New York City schools chancellor, facing criticism for denying public classroom space to a Harlem charter school, said on Friday that she would work to find space for about 200 children affected by the decision.

headline: Fiction in Translation
abstract: New books by Dorthe Nors, Dimitri Verhulst, Guillermo Rosales and Takashi Hiraide.
lead_paragraph: KARATE CHOP  Stories  By Dorthe Nors. Translated by Martin Aitken.A Public Space/Graywolf, paper, $14.

headline: Blood Relations
abstract: Maria Hummel’s novel about middle-class Germans in the 1940s is inspired by her own family.
lead_paragraph: In early 1945, a German radiologist left his post at a hospital in Weimar and attempted to make his way across the war-ravaged countryside to his family. Before entering the American zone, he buried his gun and, while sheltering in an attic, hid letters from his new wife urging him in coded language to desert. During a home renovation in the 1980s, the bundle of letters was discovered, hidden in a wall, and returned to the doctor’s family. The correspondence revealed the trials of a young woman raising the three sons from her husband’s first marriage. That the soundtrack to her struggle was the whine of air-raid sirens and the thud of bombs made it all the more remarkable.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BOY, SNOW, BIRD,  by Helen Oyeyemi. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Taking “Snow White” as a cultural touchstone, Oyeyemi’s novel offers up a cautionary tale on post-race ideology, racial limbos and the politics of passing.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: WHY PRIESTS?: A Failed Tradition,  by Garry Wills. (Penguin, $16.) Wills — who as a young man spent more than five years in a Jesuit seminary — finds only a dubious foundation for the Roman Catholic priesthood, and its religious powers, in the books of the New Testament. Using his linguistic skills and his impressive command of both secondary literature and patristic sources, the author doesn’t advocate its elimination, but asks, “Why did the priesthood come into a religion that began without it and, indeed, opposed it?”

headline: Strangers to Themselves
abstract: From 1990s China to present-day America, three friends are haunted by a decades-old mystery in Yiyun Li’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: On a quiet side street in a dusty, unremarkable Beijing neighborhood in the last days of autumn, 1989, a young woman named Shaoai drinks a glass of Tang — an exotic delicacy — and becomes strangely ill. Taken to the hospital, she slips quickly into a coma. At home, waiting anxiously for her return, are her parents (here simply called Uncle and Aunt); a distant teenage cousin, Ruyu, who lives with them and shares a room with Shaoai; and two intimate friends of Ruyu’s, Moran and Boyang.

headline: A Walk Through Time
abstract: Patrick Leigh Fermor’s European travel trilogy draws to a close.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1933, an 18-year-old named Patrick Leigh Fermor set out from the Hook of Holland to cross Europe on foot. His goal was Istanbul, which he bookishly insisted on calling Constantinople. He had little more in his rucksack than a volume of Horace and a few blank notebooks. He also had a bad reputation: The masters who expelled him from school — for a flirtation with a local girl — saw only “a dangerous mixture of sophistication and recklessness.” He spent the next year charming his way through a doomed prewar landscape of landed aristocrats, feudal peasants and benevolent monks, sleeping alternately in schlosses and hayricks. It was a journey that would become legendary, not so much for the extraordinary things he saw and recorded as for his prose — an utterly unique, hybrid vehicle that combines youthful exuberance with a dense, dauntingly erudite display of verbal artifice. Unlike most authors of travel literature (a rattlebag genre that doesn’t really do him justice) Leigh Fermor does not confine his role to that of camera obscura. He builds dense whorls of wordplay to echo the carvings in an old church door; he slips into baroque historical fantasias, scattering a shrapnel of words like “gabions,” “hydromel,” “eyot” and “swingle­trees” at the unsuspecting reader. In between salvos, there are moments of ferocious humor and quiet, lyrical beauty.

headline: Shrinking Governments: Good or Bad?
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The number of government workers in February was down from a year earlier. That has been true every month since the summer of 2009.
lead_paragraph: One accomplishment — well, to the Tea Party it would seem to be an accomplishment — of the Obama administration is the recession in government hiring.

headline: The Deconstructionist Deconstructed
abstract: A study of a literary scholar who was also a World War II collaborator, bigamist and con man.
lead_paragraph: Stories about charming scoundrels have a built-in appeal, especially if the scoundrel is young and handsome — and of course he must be very smart. Think of Leonardo Di Caprio in “Catch Me if You Can,” or of Thomas Mann’s comic con man Felix Krull. How do they fool so many people for so long?

headline: A Life in Pieces
abstract: A memoir in excerpts from letters, conversations and dreams.
lead_paragraph: Which feels more true: a memoir told in fits and starts, stutters and sighs, a blend of sensual details and analytic asides? Or one that hews to the conventions of narrative with a beginning, middle and end? All memoirists know order is a contrivance, but readers also rely on the writer to create art by organizing the mess of life.

headline: A Suspect With an Incriminating Tattoo Saves Face
abstract: After a crime on Staten Island, a face tattoo of a red lightning bolt led the police to a man in Detroit, who offered proof that they had the wrong man.
lead_paragraph: The robbery case, now two years old, at first had seemed pretty open-and-shut.

headline: In Over His Head
abstract: Justin Hocking on riding the waves at Far Rockaway.
lead_paragraph: The surf at Far Rockaway, Queens, is typically small, wind-tattered and weak, and for most of the year it’s freezing cold. Yes, there are days when the waves are passably good, and rare days when they are powerful and shapely, but that’s true of breaks in the Great Lakes and Italy. What sets Far Rockaway apart is that it’s a subway ride away from Manhattan, a fact recently rediscovered by a younger crop of culture workers who took up surfing and by dint of beginner’s zeal have added a wholesome, sun-spangled dimension to the hard-soled, mean-streets experience of life in New York, retrofitting Far Rockaway with smoothie stands and half-million-dollar surf shacks among the grim low-income high-rises.

headline: The Bailey Bunch
abstract: A noted biographer turns his lens on his own dysfunctional family.
lead_paragraph: Think of the opening sections of “The Splendid Things We Planned,” Blake Bailey’s achingly honest memoir, as a kind of personality test or perhaps an obstacle course. Not every reader is going to pass, but then again, not every reader is entitled to such a fearless, deeply felt and often frightening book.

headline: Devil’s Deeds
abstract: Fred D’Aguiar’s novel reimagines the 1978 murder-suicide ritual in Jonestown, Guyana.
lead_paragraph: In the three decades since the Jones­town mass murder-suicides left 918 dead in Guyana, journalists and academics have struggled to make sense of the senseless tragedy, producing hundreds of books, articles and scholarly papers on the topic. Recently, the F.B.I. released its Jonestown files — almost 50,000 pieces of paper and 1,000 audiotapes that agents collected from the compound after the massacre — giving researchers a trove of primary sources that document the fatal downward spiral of Jim Jones and his “promised land.”

headline: Dreaming in Code
abstract: Having already explored the possibilities of space travel and nanotechnology, Michio Kaku turns his attention to the human mind.
lead_paragraph: In June of this year, the World Cup in Brazil will begin not with a flashy musical number or a team of flying acrobats but with a simple scientific demonstration. A paralyzed teenager will make the ceremonial first kick. This feat will be accomplished through an “exoskeleton” directly controlled by the teenager’s thoughts and read through a helmet-mounted EEG machine. That kick, guided by an extraordinary brain-to-machine interface, may be our initiation into our post-human future. In that brave new world our memories will be recorded and swapped like old videotapes, self-aware robots will be our companions, and our consciousness, downloaded onto machines, will live forever. It’s a future Michio Kaku, the string theorist turned popular scientist, believes is inevitable and closer than we think.

headline: Mouths to Feed
abstract: A dark satire of corruption and poverty in 1980s Mexico.
lead_paragraph: The story goes that when André Breton visited Mexico in 1938, he was struck by the beautiful handicrafts and asked an artisan to make him a chair. Breton sketched a design in crude perspective, with a fourth leg hidden by the square of the seat. The artisan built a splendid chair, with only three legs. Breton proclaimed Mexico “the most surrealist country in the world.” Salvador Dalí supposedly agreed and swore he would never return to a country more surrealist than his paintings.

headline: Too Many Cooks
abstract: A novel about sibling rivalry in the restaurant business.
lead_paragraph: Nothing on the dessert menu is really working for Leo, one of the owners of Winesap, an upscale restaurant in the economically struggling, fictional Pennsylvania town of Linden. But there’s one item in particular that’s really killing him: the individual chocolate cake in crème anglaise. “It had been years since the dessert was new,” he realizes, “and whether restaurants called it mi-cuit or chocolate lava . . . it didn’t change the fact that this little round cake now crushed Leo with a mighty ennui, nor that Winesap sold as many of them as the kitchen could make.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: One story in Lorrie Moore’s collection “Bark,” which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 13, was written as a direct tribute to Nabokov.
lead_paragraph: The Nabokov Code: Lorrie Moore’s new story collection, “Bark,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 13 — her third consecutive best seller, after the novel “A Gate at the Stairs” (2009) and the collection “Birds of America” (1998). Reviewing “Bark” on the cover of the Book Review a few weeks ago, David Gates noted that Moore shares Vladimir Nabokov’s affinity for obsessive wordplay, although her outlook is darker; she is, he wrote, “the most Beckettian of Nabokovians.” What Gates didn’t mention (but surely knew) was that “Bark” contains a direct tribute to Nabokov: Moore’s story “Referential,” about a couple visiting the woman’s son in a mental hospital, borrows its premise and some of its language from Nabokov’s 1948 story “Signs and Symbols,” in which the patient “imagines that everything happening around him is a veiled reference to his personality and existence.” A story about a story about a man who thinks everything is about him: How’s that for referential?

headline: F.D.R. Makes the Case for the Minimum Wage
abstract: “No business which depends for existence on paying less than living wages to its workers has any right to continue in this country.”
lead_paragraph: In the more than 75 years since Congress first enacted a federal minimum wage — at 25 cents an hour — lawmakers have increased it nine times, reaching the current level of $7.25 an hour in 2009. And with every increase the same objections have been raised.

headline: DNA of a Polymath, Restlessly Mutating
abstract: “Mutations,” Vijay Iyer’s first classical release, is a typically bold mix of genres and idioms.
lead_paragraph: Not long into the New York premiere of Vijay Iyer’s “Time, Place, Action” at the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan last weekend, there came a moment of deep, transfixing confluence between the composer and his partners for the evening, the Brentano String Quartet. It arrived in a largely improvised second movement, as a single sustained note slowly morphed into something as layered and ephemeral as a rolling cloud bank. Mr. Iyer’s first piano chord brought a bolt of clarity, and with it a blush of instant communion.

headline: New Cold War Would Differ From Old
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Cold War Era', 'Russian Language']
abstract: Unlike the Soviet Union, today’s Russia has substantial trade ties with Western Europe, and it and the West are more dependent on each other than they were in decades past.
lead_paragraph: RUSSIA had some real economic problems even before the Ukrainian crisis led the United States and European countries to threaten sanctions on the country after the Russian flag was raised in Crimea, a part of Ukraine, and troops who spoke Russian appeared to take over a significant part of the region.

headline: Skills Practice | Proofreading and Fact-Checking
abstract: How carefully do you read? Do you catch errors in your own work? In published pieces? Take our quiz and see if you can find 14 errors that were inserted into recent Times articles.
lead_paragraph: How carefully do you read? Do you catch errors in your own work? In published pieces?

headline: BlackBerry Boss Says Company Must Be About More Than Phones
abstract: The chief executive of BlackBerry, John S. Chen, says his company must stay in phones, but needs to focus on addressing specialty markets. His inspiration for the non-consumer approach? Steve Jobs.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — John S. Chen has signed a five-year contract to be chief executive of BlackBerry, and has a plan that runs just about that length of time.

headline: RuPaul’s House of Mirrors
abstract: A low-fat brandy Alexander; hangin’ with the Osmonds.
lead_paragraph: A low-fat brandy Alexander; hangin’ with the Osmonds.

headline: Reply All: The 2.23.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: ON THE ROAD ACROSS SOUTH AMERICA

headline: The Guardian’s Alan Rusbridger: ‘It’s Essential to Be Paranoid’
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: The newspaper editor on Edward Snowden, the piano and patriotism.
lead_paragraph: You’ve played piano since you were a child, and you’ve written about parallels between this pursuit and digital news. Can you explain that? Amateur music-making used to be very commonplace and was valued in its own right. When recorded sound came along, most people became the passive receivers of other people’s music. I do think that mirrors something that’s going on in journalism at the moment, which is that anybody can blog, anybody can tweet, anybody can write and publish.

headline: Who Made That Progress Bar?
abstract: A more relaxing way to wait.
lead_paragraph: “People wait for all sorts of things every day, sometimes more happily than others,” wrote the interface designer Bob Stahl in a 1986 article for Computerworld. “The problem is how the user feels about waiting.” At the time, machines were often slow and unreliable, and users didn’t always know when their programs crashed. A “progress bar” might mitigate frustration, Stahl suggested, by signaling that bits were flipping with a purpose somewhere deep inside the C.P.U.

headline: All the Single Ladies
abstract: It was my best friend’s wedding, but I desperately didn’t want to catch her bouquet.
lead_paragraph: The day had been hot and long, beginning on the Cape Cod beach where we watched the bride marry her now-husband as the tide came in a few minutes too soon — or, more likely, the wedding happened just a few minutes too late — despite careful timing based on the lunar calendar. Afterward, a string quartet led us through the tall sand grass and up into the dunes to the country club, where we ate and drank and drank some more in celebration of our friend, who was now a wife.

headline: Domestic Surveillance?
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Tips and Tipping', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: The rights and responsibilities of a celebrity house.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, my wife and I drove around Palm Springs to look at houses designed by famous architects. At the entrance to one house was a sign with fairly threatening language regarding trespassing. It made us feel like we were invading someone’s privacy, which leads me to my question: Does a person who buys a home of historic or architectural significance have a different relationship to the public than a person who owns a home of no significance? MIKE MILEY, METAIRIE, LA.

headline: Yoga Poses in Israel
abstract: Photographs from a studio for Orthodox Jews.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Rachel Kolberg was newly married, pregnant and living in Tel Aviv when she went to her first yoga class. It was a revelation. Her husband, Avraham, soon began practicing with her. “I was looking for some spiritual support,” he says. “Yoga gave that to me.” Seven years later, the couple opened their own studio, determined to introduce yoga to fellow Orthodox Jews in Beit Shemesh. They teach Iyengar yoga, a discipline that encourages the use of props to assist with poses. While yoga is increasingly popular in Israel, Avraham says, it is “revolutionary” in their neighborhood. Their students, taught in single-sex classes, are encouraged to come as they are, even in day clothes or long skirts, if necessary. The Kolbergs say yoga helps people who spend long days in prayer and study and aren’t physically active. But, Rachel says, “in our studio, we will never have practices that contradict our religion, such as mantras and chanting.” Julie Bosman

headline: Animating Owen
abstract: Roger Ross Williams, the Academy Award-winning filmmaker, spent time with Ron Suskind and his son, Owen, who has autism, to show how they learned to communicate using dialogue from Disney movies.
lead_paragraph: Roger Ross Williams, the Academy Award-winning filmmaker, spent time with Ron Suskind and his son, Owen, who has autism, to show how they learned to communicate using dialogue from Disney movies.

headline: Malaysian Opposition Leader Sentenced in Sodomy Case
abstract: An appeals court gave Anwar Ibrahim a five-year term a week before he was expected to register for elections.
lead_paragraph: A Malaysian appeals court sentenced Anwar Ibrahim, the country’s opposition leader, on Friday to five years in prison on charges of sodomy, a conviction that critics described as an attempt to block the opposition’s ascendancy at a time when the governing party’s popularity is waning.

headline: Peeling Back the Layers of Naxos, Greece
abstract: As episodes from her life story are written there, an outsider develops a tremendous closeness to the island.
lead_paragraph: At dusk we walked up a path along the stream that stitches together Pano Potamia and Kato Potamia, two villages in the most fertile part of Naxos, the Greek island. While most of the other Cycladic islands are as dry as toast, Naxos is covered in verdant valleys and mountain villages, clusters of whitewashed houses nestled into a Bruegel-like landscape.

headline: Following an 8-Year-Old to Atlantis
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Families and Family Life', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: “We gotta go,” said their young son. And so they did, heading to Atlantis on Paradise Island in the Bahamas, where they would do everything from feed a dolphin to race remote-control cars.
lead_paragraph: The warm drizzle swelled the corridors and shops and casino with teenagers in dripping beachwear and toddlers splashing their wet, bare feet on the marble as their parents trailed along at an unconcerned pace. Still, sun blasted through the windows and bathed the gilded statues of heroes from a mythical island in a soft, golden hue.

headline: George Takei Reflects on Travel, Both Painful and Pleasurable
abstract: The actor talks about going back to Arkansas, where his family was interned during World War II, and traveling to spots in Japan he loves to visit.
lead_paragraph: George Takei is a man of many speaking engagements. He talks at “Star Trek” conventions about his role as Mr. Sulu. He tells soldiers and students about the role of Japanese-Americans during World War II, a subject in which he is well versed. In a new musical, “Allegiance,” based on his family’s experience living in internment camps during the war, he actually sings the story.

headline: Home Tweet Home
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Stop dreaming of a butler. High-tech gizmos, those communications whizzes, virtually wait on you hand and foot.
lead_paragraph: They are questions that can upend a workday without warning: did you remember to turn the stove off? Did you leave the air-conditioning on? Did the house burn down? These quotidian worries, banal but sometimes all-consuming, have nagged at generations of homeowners and renters.

lead_paragraph: Savory pastries — pies, tarts, quiches, tortas and the like — are so inherently appealing that it doesn’t really matter what you fill them with.

headline: Pensive Trumpet, Long on Nuance
abstract: The 31-year-old trumpeter and composer Ambrose Akinmusire brings a watchful, simmering, hazy-beauty sensibility to his interactions with the post-bop lineage.
lead_paragraph: The 31-year-old trumpeter and composer Ambrose Akinmusire brings a watchful, simmering, hazy-beauty sensibility to his interactions with the post-bop lineage, where lines often tend to be more sharply drawn. His second album on Blue Note, “the imagined savior is far easier to paint,” is full of moments that lean toward the expressionistic, sometimes featuring a string ensemble or a vocalist delving into what amounts to art song.

headline: Islamic Accents in Dutch Décor
abstract: “Carpets of the East in Paintings from the West,” which opens Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a small show drawn from the museum’s collection.
lead_paragraph: “Carpets of the East in Paintings from the West,” which opens Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a small show drawn from the museum’s collection that delves into the pictorial effects of the European taste for Islamic carpets, which dates from the 14th century. These textiles became staples of artists’ studios, initially in religious paintings, especially to spruce up settings for Madonna and child images. One kind of boldly bordered rug appeared so often in the 16th-century paintings of Lorenzo Lotto that it came to be known as the Lotto pattern.

headline: Art of Variations, Debussy to Berio
abstract: Classical music in New York is full of tough choices.
lead_paragraph: Classical music in New York is full of tough choices. On Monday, while the star pianist Evgeny Kissin plays Carnegie Hall, two rising soloists with wide-ranging tastes will have recitals of their own. Upstairs, at Carnegie’s Weill Recital Hall, the adventurous cellist Jay Campbell will be joined by the pianist Conor Hanick and the percussionist Mike Truesdell. Their program, presented by the Concert Artists Guild, includes Debussy’s Sonata in D Minor for Cello and Piano,” Stravinsky’s “Suite Italienne,” a new piece by David Fulmer and recent works by Matthias Pintscher and Simon Steen-Andersen. (7:30 p.m., 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: A Cheesy Hercules, A Slasher and More
abstract: A lot has happened since “Conan the Destroyer“ came out in 1984.
lead_paragraph: A lot has happened since “Conan the Destroyer“ came out in 1984. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who played the title role, has completed one of the weirdest circles in movie history, from monosyllabic star to governor and back to monosyllabic star. The genre — muscles, swords and skimpy outfits — has found new life on pay-cable television. And the film’s director, Richard Fleischer, who died in 2006, has come to be appreciated for his versatility, if not always for his quality.

headline: Russia Has Already Lost the War
abstract: The biggest danger for Vladimir V. Putin is that Ukraine’s revolution will eventually spread toward Russia.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — OVER the past two weeks, residents of Kiev have lived through its bloodiest conflict since the Second World War, watched their reviled president flee and a new, provisional team take charge, seen Russian troops take control of part of the country, and heard Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, assert his right to take further military action. Yet the Ukrainian capital is calm.

Mr. Chisic, who is in the diamond business and lives in Tel Aviv, had a better idea: call Dylan Pichulik, the chief executive of XL Real Property Management, who manages the apartment for him.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Winter Blues (and Pinks)
abstract: Two popular color trends brightening this drawn-out winter are sapphire blue and dusty pastels.
lead_paragraph: WINTER BLUES (AND PINKS) Two popular color trends brightening this drawn-out winter are sapphire blue, which popped up last fall and came into full flower in February (complete with blue-eyed Eskimo dogs), and dusty pastels, in soft pinks and sweet-pea shades of blue, green and mauve. Those pastels owe a lot to the many Asian women attending the February fashion shows in colors much subtler than the shocking pinks prevalent in the West.

headline: After the Deluge, It’s Back to the Stage
abstract: After millions of dollars in damage from flooding, the Martha Graham Dance Company struggles to regain its balance.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Oct. 29, 2012, the basement storage of the Martha Graham Dance Company was overrun with water from the nearby Hudson River, pushed across the West Side Highway by Hurricane Sandy. The company had moved into its new studios at the Westbeth artists’ complex in the West Village three months earlier, taking possession of what had for decades been the home of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. Costumes and sets dating back to the 1940s and ’50s, some designed and worn by Graham herself, lay in grimy water for days. Starting on March 19, at City Center, nearly 16 months later, the Graham troupe will present its second New York season since the storm.

headline: Martha Graham: Myth and Transformation
abstract: After losing costumes and sets to Hurricane Sandy, the Martha Graham Dance Company rebuilds, recreates and reinvents itself.

abstract: New York can feel like a tough place to live sometimes, but there are also moments of kindness that restore your faith in it. What moments have lifted you up, City Room readers?
lead_paragraph: As I descended the subway staircase at 28th and Broadway just before 8 a.m., I experienced that moment every New Yorker fears: The woman in front of me suddenly ran toward the turnstiles as soon as she reached the bottom of the stairs, suggesting a train was at the platform. I was about to do The Sprint, sure to leave me with either just-made-it glory or just-missed-it agony.

headline: An It Artist Makes Her Mark on Smythson’s Storied Leather Goods
abstract: The venerable British stationer collaborated with Quentin Jones on an accessories line full of winking cats and graphic eyes.
lead_paragraph: After being commissioned last fall by the British leather goods and stationery maker Smythson to make a series of collages for its London Fashion Week presentation, the mixed-media artist and filmmaker Quentin Jones is returning to the brand, this time applying her work directly onto the label’s signature stationery and accessories. The collaboration, available Monday at Colette in Paris and at smythson.com beginning March 31, features pouches, bags and notebooks from the brand’s Panama Legacy collection, designed by Rory O’Hanlon. These, together with coordinating keychains, bear the whimsical, surrealist illustrations and calligraphy that the 30-year-old Jones has become renowned for in the worlds of art and fashion. “I thought about my favorite examples of artists who work with pure lines: Miro, Picasso, early Hockney and Ben Nicholson,” says Jones of her approach to the visuals. Smythson’s classic Soho notebook has been rebelliously tagged in gold with the phrases “Soho Saint” and “Soho Sinner”; a winking cat adorns a zippered pouch and cross-body bag; a sharp white leather tote bears a cluster of floating eyes. And starting on March 31, the brand’s Panama notebooks can be custom-embossed with Jones’s motifs in Smythson’s New York store. “It is so fun for me to work in 3-D,” says Jones, “and to make things that I want to own and wear myself.”

But now, this tiny community is dealing with its most unsettling threat yet: It could run out of water by summer.

headline: As General’s Sex Assault Trial Opens, Accuser Describes Violence and Threats
keywords: ['Courts-Martial', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: “He told me that if I ever said anything to her or anyone else about he and I, he would kill me,” an Army captain testified.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — At one point putting her head in her hands and sobbing, the Army captain who has accused Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair of sexual assault took the witness stand on Friday on the first day of his closely watched court-martial. During five hours of testimony, the 34-year-old captain chronicled in detail a three-year affair that included casual sex at an operating base in Iraq and in a hotel room in North Carolina, but also, she said, violent moments where he forced her to perform oral sex and threatened to kill her if she disclosed their relationship.

headline: Art Matters | A Biennial With Another Whitney in Mind
abstract: The artist C. Finley curates a ladies-only exhibition in Dumbo named after the late pop star Whitney Houston.
lead_paragraph: The idea began with a joke. “I imagined that if I was tapped as the curator of the Whitney, I would show three floors of women artists,” says the artist Christine Finley, known professionally as C. Finley. “When I told this to my friend” — the artist Eddy Segal — “she immediately blurted out, ‘The Whitney Houston Biennial!'” Finley laughed — hard — but couldn’t quite shake the idea. Deriving inspiration from Phong Bui’s “Surviving Sandy” show, Antony Hegarty’s handwritten future-feminist manifesto and, naturally, Whitney Houston’s live performance of “One Moment in Time” from the 1989 Grammy Awards, Finley set about to design an exhibition that would showcase a wide swath of work from New York’s female artists. She culled a dream list of more than 80 local women whose art she admired, paying special attention to include a cross-section of mediums.

headline: Popcast: Vijay Iyer, Jazz Weather Vane

lead_paragraph: The pianist Vijay Iyer, 42, has established himself through the last decade as a weather vane in the practice and theory of jazz. Not the only one, and not one of use to everybody — especially musicians who prize more traditional or popular virtues, some of whom resent his success — but a weather vane all the same.

headline: For G.O.P., Hard Line on Immigration Comes at a Cost

But he had also done something else: delivered African-American votes to Democrats in overwhelming proportions.

headline: In Safeway Buyout, a Reminder of a Painful Takeover Years Ago
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Two decades ago, Safeway was a symbol of the human toll sometimes extracted when private equity used large amounts of debt to take over a company. This week, another private equity firm is taking over the grocery chain, with none of the uproar of the earlier saga.
lead_paragraph: Safeway, the latest target of a big private equity buyout, once caused a huge headache for the private equity industry.

headline: Higher Prices Migrate to Far Upper East Side
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Subways']
abstract: Condo sticker shock is likely to fade once the Second Avenue subway opens.
lead_paragraph: Third Avenue has long been a dividing line on the Upper East Side. “West of Third” serves as shorthand for the stylish neighborhood in the TV show “Gossip Girl,” where private-school girls live in stately Park Avenue co-ops and shop in boutiques along Madison Avenue. “East of Third” refers to the delis and bagel shops that make up many of the storefronts around York Avenue, and the tenement style walk-ups filled with recent college graduates who flock to the cheap rent.

headline: Big Ticket | Sophisticated Estate Orphan at $19 Million
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A full-floor Upper East Side apartment owned by Charles R. Bronfman when he was married to his third wife was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor apartment at the exclusive 810 Fifth Avenue co-op that the billionaire Charles R. Bronfman bought for $21 million in 2010 sold for $19 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Stopping Ads From Slowing Down NYTimes.com
abstract: Eitan Konigsburg explains how we addressed ads in order to improve article page performance.
lead_paragraph: A major goal of the recent redesign of NYTimes.com article pages was to improve page load speed and perceived performance. We focused on one of the more challenging sources of slow performance: third-party code, and, in particular, ads. Ads often load JavaScript files, which block the browser from loading other files until the script finishes executing. Combine that with the fact that ads are often placed near the top of the page and we have a recipe for a lot of blocked loading that will slow things down. By addressing the ad problem, we were able to make our new articles about 50 percent faster (these changes aren’t on the home page yet, but they will be soon).

headline: Vodafone Said to Submit Tentative Bid for Ono
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The British telecommunications giant has submitted a tentative offer for the Spanish cable company Ono that values it at around 7 billion euros, or $10 billion, according to people with direct knowledge of the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Vodafone is turning out to be a persistent suitor.

headline: With New Antipoverty Initiative, Salesforce C.E.O. Puts Silicon Valley on Spot
abstract: Many have heard of the backlash against the tech industry in San Francisco. Now one executive is trying to convince his peers that charity should come with profits.
lead_paragraph: For all the  tension and media coverage of San Francisco’s rising rents and tech shuttle buses, there have not been a whole lot of people stepping forward with solutions.

headline: Clinton Highlights Record on Women’s Rights at U.N.
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday spoke about her new “No Ceilings” initiative as part of her tour of speaking engagements related to women’s rights.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Hillary Rodham Clinton continued her tour of speaking engagements and events related to women’s rights on Friday, with a panel discussion at the United Nations in New York.

headline: Online Map Tracks Frauds Against Older Americans
abstract: An interactive map created by AARP provides alerts from state authorities and reports by consumers of their own experiences.
lead_paragraph: David Burdette, a retired executive in Concord, N.H., narrowly missed becoming a victim of financial fraud last summer after criminals were apparently able to crack the password to an online account that he used to manage his telephone service.

headline: When You Evaluate a Fund Manager, Look Beyond Results
abstract: Five years after a low point of the recession, it’s still important to judge managers not only on their performance, but their strategies and style.
lead_paragraph: THIS Sunday will be five years to the day since the low point for the Standard & Poor’s 500 stock-index during the Great Recession. Since bottoming out on March 9, 2009, at 676.53, the index has risen some 170 percent.

headline: Working Copy of Welles’s ‘Citizen Kane’ Script Auctioned for $164,000
abstract: The mimeograph typescript, written by Welles with Herman J. Mankiewicz and John Houseman, brought much more than its estimate at Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: Orson Welles’s personal copy of the working draft script for “Citizen Kane” was sold at auction by Sotheby’s in London on Thursday. The mimeograph typescript, written by Welles with Herman J. Mankiewicz and John Houseman, was estimated to bring between 15,000 and 20,000 British pounds (about $25,000 to $33,000) but went for for a final price, with the buyer’s premium, of 98,500 pounds (about $164,000).

headline: Congolese Militia Leader Convicted in Attack on Village
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The militia leader, Germain Katanga, was found guilty at the International Criminal Court of complicity in organizing an attack in 2003 that left more than 200 people dead.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The International Criminal Court on Friday convicted a militia leader from the Democratic Republic of Congo in an attack on a Congolese village in 2003 in which more than 200 people were shot and hacked to death, and women were raped and abducted to serve as sex slaves.

headline: New Yorkers: Earl Strickland
abstract: The legendary pool professional’s career declined such that he now performs trick shots free at Steinway Billiards in Astoria, Queens.
lead_paragraph: The legendary pool professional’s career declined such that he now performs trick shots free at Steinway Billiards in Astoria, Queens.

headline: It’s Unclearly Defined, but Telecommuting Is Fast on the Rise
abstract: Aided by technology, telecommuting is becoming more common, and while it has its challenges, studies show that it tends to create happier, better workers.
lead_paragraph: WE all know what telecommuting is and who does it. It’s working from home (or maybe a Starbucks), and it’s usually done by someone in their 20s, or a mother with small children.

headline: In California, Worries Over Water
abstract: As a deep drought continues, Lake of the Woods, Calif., and other rural communities in the state are facing a threat to their drinking water.
lead_paragraph: As a deep drought continues, Lake of the Woods, Calif., and other rural communities in the state are facing a threat to their drinking water.

headline: Women Made Jobs Gains in February
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Women have more than made up their losses in the recession, gaining 2.5 million jobs in the recovery. But that does not mean that women are coming out ahead.
lead_paragraph: After losing jobs in January, women took the majority of the new jobs in February, gaining 99,000 jobs to men’s 76,000. Women have more than made up their losses in the recession, gaining 2.5 million jobs in the recovery, compared to 2.1 million jobs lost, while men have been struggling more, gaining 4.2 million jobs after losing 5.3 million in the downturn.

headline: Fact-Finding Envoys in Crimea Face Hostility
abstract: An envoy from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said she faced threatening crowds in Crimea, similar to the hostility that confronted a senior United Nations envoy.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — As the United Nations sent an eight-member human rights fact-finding mission to Ukraine on Friday, an envoy with the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe said she had faced noisy, threatening crowds chanting pro-Russian slogans in the Crimea regional capital of Simferopol earlier this week and had been forced to cut short her visit.

headline: The Shapes of Things to Come
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Fashion Shows', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Paris Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'London Fashion Week']
abstract: The recent fall collections offered a wealth of surprising new looks and three clear trends emerged.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Zaha Hadid took to her drafting table to create a pair of shoes. Chrome and rubber platforms that were conceived with her fellow starchitect Rem Koolhaas, they looked like nothing so much as a Slinky, its serpentine coils neatly fused.

headline: French Court Convicts 3 Who Tried to Join Militants in Syria
abstract: The three men were arrested in 2012 as they were boarding a flight to a Turkish airport not far from Syria and charged with criminal association with the intent to commit terrorist acts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Paris court on Friday sentenced three men to prison terms of up to five years for trying to join the rebellion in Syria, the first such convictions in France.

headline: Big Fish, Small Pool
abstract: Earl Strickland, who has won a slew of national and world pool titles, has been called the “Michael Jordan of pool.” He described himself as the mascot of a tiny pool hall in Queens.
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon, a lithe man with a blond mustache and a Southern twang leaned over a pool table under a pair of hanging lamps at Steinway Billiards Cafe in Astoria, Queens.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Sweating It Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 25-year-old man who can’t stop vomiting until he takes a hot shower.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a 25-year-old man who had recently given up heroin, cocaine and marijuana had a sudden attack of nausea and vomiting so severe that he had to go to the hospital. Two big clues were provided. His nausea and vomiting eased when he took a hot shower, and he regularly used an herbal product that he bought in a neighborhood store called Spice, said to be synthetic marijuana.

headline: When May Catches Up to December
abstract: When they first met and fell in love in 1986, the timing wasn’t right.
lead_paragraph: When Tony Perkins moved to New York from Leakesville, Miss., in April 1986, he wasn’t looking for love. Like most, he came in pursuit of a dream: a career in fashion and a life that his one-stoplight hometown could not offer.

headline: Just Another Great Role for What’s-Her-Name
abstract: Lindsay Duncan’s latest film, “Le Week-End,” arrives in America the same way she has built a sterling career in Britain: with good word of mouth.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Lindsay Duncan was freezing. She had just spent an hour on Primrose Hill, having her portrait taken.

headline: Donna Tartt and Eleanor Catton Among Nominees for Women’s Fiction Prize
abstract: The Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction was known as the Orange Prize until last year.
lead_paragraph: Donna Tartt, the author of the widely acclaimed novel “The Goldfinch,” and Eleanor Catton, whose novel “The Luminaries” has already won the 2013 Man Booker Prize, are among the 20 women nominated for the Baileys Women’s Prize for Fiction. The award, which honors works written in English by women, was known as the Orange Prize until last year, when the liquor company Bailey’s took over as sponsor.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 97
abstract: With 97 days to go, recalling England’s 97th international match, played in 1993.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: A Love Not Strong Enough to Climb Barriers
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: A financial disaster, an indiscretion and a marriage falls apart with little communication between the couple.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, John Reid, now 55, met Patty Reid, 52, in a San Francisco bar. Less than an hour later, Mr. Reid announced his intention to marry her. Twenty years later, a financial misstep led to the breakup of the couple.

headline: Automakers Talk Optimistically About Electric Cars in Geneva
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Geneva International Motor Show', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: Although automakers are no longer overtly bullish about electric car sales, new models like the BMW i3 show potential for success in the segment.
lead_paragraph: Automakers do not talk about electric cars with quite the same bravado they did a few years ago. But judging from the talk at the Geneva Motor Show this year, at least some remain bullish on the future of plug-in vehicles.

headline: On Money and Marriage
abstract: A therapist considers the universal issues raised in an Unhitched column.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Unhitched column, John and Patty Reid discussed issues that led to their divorce after 26 years of marriage, including a failed attempt to go into business with her sister’s family. We asked a therapist about dealing with money issues in marriage. Did you face a similar issue in your divorce? Or were you faced with other challenges? If so, we’d like to hear from you for this series.

headline: Geriatricians Question Five Common Treatments
abstract: The American Geriatrics Society says medical evidence is scant for five common treatments in the elderly.
lead_paragraph: It tells you something about American health care that scores of medical societies have joined a major campaign aimed at telling patients and doctors what not to do.

headline: Safeway Customers May Be Big Winners With Cerberus
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: Cerberus will realize a lot of cost savings by combining Safeway with its Albertsons chain. But competition from the likes of Walmart means cost savings may need to go to shoppers, not investors, writes Robert Cyran in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Could Cerberus pay more for Safeway than the $9.4 billion it has offered? Based on the A.&P.-Pathmark merger in 2007, the synergies could be worth well over $5 billion to Cerberus, since it plans to combine the chain with its Albertsons operations. In theory that leaves room for a higher offer. But competition from the likes of Walmart means cost savings may need to go to shoppers, not investors.

headline: There’s Been a Change in River City
abstract: A new production of the Broadway classic “The Music Man,” about a con man who falls for a small-town librarian, will feature an all-black cast.
lead_paragraph: Robert O’Hara, an Obie Award-winning playwright and director, has seen only the movie version of the Broadway classic “The Music Man,” not the theatrical production. He knows, though, that the concert version he will direct this month, “Meredith Willson’s The Music Man,” at Two River Theater, in Red Bank, and the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, in Newark, will look different from the one most theatergoers are accustomed to. And he does not plan to offer any explanations.

headline: After Debit Card Fraud, a Chicago Bank Feels Its Customers’ Frustration
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Debit Cards', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: First American Bank in Chicago got publicity but little satisfaction after it identified a source of debit card theft and tried to stop it.
lead_paragraph: People should no longer use debit or credit cards in Chicago taxicabs. Bank of America should shut off the card-swiping terminals in the back of those cabs. And MasterCard ought to learn to share more information with its customers.

headline: Is There a Doctor in the House? Yes, 17. And 3 in the Senate.
keywords: ['Doctors', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: A heightened political awareness, and a healthy self-regard that they could do a better job, are drawing a surprisingly large number of doctors to the power of elective office.
lead_paragraph: LAKE OSWEGO, Ore. — First thing on a recent Monday, Monica Wehby could be found in the operating room performing brain surgery on a child. But the Saturday before, she was shooting guns, because sometimes that’s what you do when you’re running for office.

headline: What an Israeli-Palestinian Peace Framework Might Look Like
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: After all this time, the core issues have been well staked out. But Israeli and Palestinian leaders have usually not encouraged an open dialogue on the specifics.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration will soon publish a set of principles that is intended to serve as the basis for negotiations on an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement.

headline: With Its Stock Riding High, FireEye Sells More Shares for $1.1 Billion
abstract: Taking advantage of a fourfold increase in its stock price since its market debut, the cybersecurity company raised $1.1 billion for itself and some of its backers with a secondary offering.
lead_paragraph: With the Target hacking scandal, Edward Snowden and Chinese cyberattacks all in the news, there could hardly be a better environment for FireEye, the security software company that went public last fall.

headline: Film Society of Lincoln Center Names New Director
abstract: Lesli Klainberg has been serving in the post on an interim basis since December.
lead_paragraph: The Film Society of Lincoln Center on Friday announced the appointment of Lesli Klainberg as its new executive director.

headline: Evening Hours | Revelers With a Cause
abstract: Galas for dance companies, museums and babies.
lead_paragraph: Galas for dance companies, museums and babies.

headline: Guy Hands Drops Lawsuit Against Citigroup in U.S.
abstract: The British financier Guy Hands has agreed to end a lawsuit against Citigroup in the United States, though the legal battle over the 2007 buyout of EMI may continue in England.
lead_paragraph: The British financier Guy Hands has agreed to end a lawsuit against Citigroup in the United States, though the legal battle may continue in England.

headline: Few Are Expected to Mourn the Loss of a Gilded Age Building
abstract: Work to convert a brownstone on Fifth Avenue, which dates to soon after the start of the Civil War, into condominiums will bring a new iteration to a building that has had so many renovations over the years that little remains of its original design.
lead_paragraph: The brownstone may be the oldest building on Fifth Avenue — a 143-year-old townhouse that witnessed the dawn of the Gilded Age, the completion of Central Park and an unsolved murder. But even the Landmarks Preservation Commission did not raise much objection when a developer proposed demolishing most of it for a highrise.

headline: Painting a Picture of Creative Growth
abstract: The art center renowned for supporting adults with developmental disabilities is celebrating its 40th anniversary with a first-ever retrospective exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Time changes nothing; time changes everything. You can align with either axiom, but for Creative Growth Art Center, celebrating its 40th anniversary this month, there’s a case to be made for both. What began in 1974 as the first arts facility dedicated to adults with developmental, mental and physical disabilities has since become a testament to the power of imagination, with a singular vision: when it comes to art, there is no right or wrong.

headline: Former Trader at Jefferies Found Guilty of Fraud
keywords: ['Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: A jury convicted Jesse C. Litvak, a former senior trader at the Jefferies Group, of securities fraud for misrepresenting the prices of mortgage-backed securities he sold to brokerage clients after the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury on Friday found Jesse C. Litvak, a former senior trader at the Jefferies Group, guilty of deceiving his customers about the prices of mortgage-backed securities he sold to them after the financial crisis.

headline: Ukraine and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photographs from Ukraine, Syria, South Africa and Siberia.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Ukraine, Syria, South Africa and Siberia.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, India and Russia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, India and Russia.

headline: M.L.S. to Open Season With Replacement Referees Amid Lockout
abstract: The organization that supplies Major League Soccer with its on-field officials announced that it was locking out referees because of a labor dispute.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer will open its 19th season Saturday, but with replacement referees, after the organization that supplies the league with on-field officials announced Friday that it was locking them out because of a labor dispute.

headline: The Hot Accessory: A Real, Live Pop Star
abstract: Pop stars at ringside and runway concerts have become a status symbol at fashion shows.
lead_paragraph: Here, there and everywhere throughout Paris Fashion Week, like Zelig in face-masking shades, was the pop starlet Rihanna. On Thursday, she was front row at Lanvin. On Friday, Dior. Saturday afternoon, Comme des Garçons. At Chanel, she hopped gamely into a shopping cart for a spin around Karl Lagerfeld’s Costco-size supermarket set.

headline: The Gun Report: March 7, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Harold Mitchell, the chairman of South Carolina’s Legislative Black Caucus, has introduced a bill to repeal the state’s Stand Your Ground law, The State reports. The bill, which has 17 co-sponsors, would eliminate the controversial legal defense employed by those who kill or wound people in public places, then claim they feared for their lives. But it would not do away with the right to defend yourself inside your home, vehicle or business.

headline: The Technology of Voting
abstract: A Spanish start-up is behind the technology that allows New Yorkers to cast votes from overseas.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — When New York overseas voters cast ballots in elections, few likely know they’re relying on a small tech company based in Barcelona, Spain.

headline: The Doctor With a Razor Blade in India
abstract: The ancient practice of bloodletting as a medical treatment continues in India. Despite their access to modern medical care, some patients believe it is the best cure.
lead_paragraph: The ancient practice of bloodletting as a medical treatment continues in India. Despite their access to modern medical care, some patients believe it is the best cure.

headline: French Beauty
abstract: Said to have been displayed at the 1939 World’s Fair in Queens, this 1937 Delahaye roadster was the object of one collector’s boyhood dreams.
lead_paragraph: Said to have been displayed at the 1939 World’s Fair in Queens, this 1937 Delahaye roadster was the object of one collector’s boyhood dreams.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Celebrities Behaving Well
keywords: ['Celebrities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'News and News Media', 'Writing and Writers', 'Sex']
abstract: The days of our unqualifiedly celebrating the rowdy, libidinous, self-destructive artist may be drawing to a close.
lead_paragraph: Justin Bieber’s rap sheet over the past year would have been an afternoon’s work for Keith Richards.

headline: The Playground Set Gets Its Own Bras
keywords: ['Lingerie and Underwear', 'Children and Childhood', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Bralettes — half camisoles with narrow straps — are catching on with young girls.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Stephanie Sorkin, an author of children’s books who lives in Roslyn, N.Y., was faced with an unexpected request from her daughter Lea, then age 5.

headline: In West Chelsea, a Temporary Emporium
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: The sales office for a condo development is built from scratch and will be rented out after the building is sold out.
lead_paragraph: The sales offices that woo buyers while condominium projects are still clanging construction sites are generally tucked inside other structures, whether office towers, art galleries or storefronts.

headline: No, His Name Is Not Ted
keywords: ['TED Conference', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Social Media']
abstract: Chris Anderson, the top man at TED, continues to build a brand, even as critics try to tear it down.
lead_paragraph: Chris Anderson was sitting in a very low-power pose. Off to the side at an all-staff meeting at TED’s Hudson Street headquarters in January, he was folded forward with his hand on his neck, a posture that communicates self-protection according to the 2012 TED Talk on body language by the social psychologist Amy Cuddy (15.7 million views).

headline: The Herald Above the Reeds
abstract: Some red-winged blackbirds regularly overwinter in New York, which after this cold and snowy season may have cost many their lives.
lead_paragraph: The call of the red-winged blackbird announces spring while the snow still falls. As black as pitch, with flame orange shoulders, the male perches on tall grasses and leafless branches high above New York’s bleak winter marshes. He is an unlikely herald, but he is one of the most reliable signs of spring. His call — a powerful “conk-a-ree-e” — trails off and settles over the reeds, embodying the ancient promise that spring will return.

headline: The McDonald’s Beef With Moschino, Chanel’s Rising Prices and Mary-Kate Olsen’s Big New Bling
abstract: Plus, who put Anna Wintour in the second row, how many Swarovski crystals it took to create the Oscars set and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Review: 2014 BMW 335i GT
abstract: The latest version of BMW’s highly successful 3 Series is the GT. It stands for Gran Turismo, but it could mean “giant trunk,” since this 335i is a hatchback.
lead_paragraph: The latest version of BMW’s highly successful 3 Series is the GT. It stands for Gran Turismo, but it could mean “giant trunk,” since this 335i is a hatchback.

headline: Weather and the Jobs Report
abstract: To what extent should weather be blamed or credited for the employment figures in February?
lead_paragraph: Rah, rah, rah. That was the dominant feeling among Wall Street analysts after the jobs report exceeded expectations despite the dismal winter we’ve been having. Employers added 175,000 jobs even though the week covered by the jobs survey, Feb. 9 through 15, was perfectly nasty.

headline: City Ballet Dancers Agree to New Contract
abstract: The dancers and stage managers of New York City Ballet, who have been working under an expired concert since the summer of 2012, have ratified a new labor agreement, according to their union, the American Guild of Musical Artists.
lead_paragraph: The dancers and stage managers of New York City Ballet, who have been working under an expired concert since the summer of 2012, have ratified a new labor agreement, according to their union, the American Guild of Musical Artists.

headline: ‘Wozzeck’
abstract: Listen to the orchestral interlude from Act III of “Wozzeck.”
lead_paragraph: Listen to the orchestral interlude from Act III of “Wozzeck.”

headline: Turkey’s Leaders Spar Over Plan to Muzzle Social Media
abstract: President Abdullah Gul said he would not go along with a pledge to shut down Facebook and YouTube by Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who is facing a corruption inquiry.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Just hours after the prime minister of Turkey threatened to shut down Facebook and YouTube, the country’s president voiced reassurance on Friday that reversing course on civil liberties was “out of the question.”

headline: Some Amelia Auction Cars May Bring 7-Figure Prices
abstract: As usual, RM Auctions will be bringing a few thoroughbreds to its sale on Saturday, and a few of them could come close to the $2 million mark.
lead_paragraph: Not far from the gleaming trailer queens treated to the white glove touch at the Amelia Island Concours d'Élégance in North Florida, an eclectic assembly of autos and motorcycles will cross the block on Saturday at the RM Auctions sale.

headline: Whistle-Blower Gets $63.9 Million as a Result of JPMorgan Settlement
abstract: A Louisiana man who once worked for JPMorgan in its government insurance unit helped federal prosecutors make their case against the bank.
lead_paragraph: A Louisiana man who helped federal prosecutors make their case against JPMorgan Chase’s mortgage lending practices has earned $63.9 million for his efforts.

headline: Icahn Discloses He’s Now on Facebook
abstract: The billionaire investor said in a regulatory filing on Friday that he planned to start using the social network as another platform for his activism campaigns. He is already on Twitter and has his own corporate blog.
