lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn is liking Facebook a bit more these days.

headline: A London Hotel Has a Focus on Sustainability
abstract: The Draycott Hotel in London emphasizes eco-friendly travel.
lead_paragraph: According to London’s Draycott Hotel, encouraging guests to just reuse towels doesn’t cut it anymore when it comes to being eco-friendly. Its new “Keen to be Green” initiative is part of an effort to become the most sustainable boutique hotel in the city, including finding creative ways for travelers to reduce their carbon footprint.

headline: Video: BMW’s Balloon-Backed 3 Series GT
abstract: Offering hatchbacks is risky business in the American car market, but BMW has taken the plunge.
lead_paragraph: The latest version of BMW’s highly successful 3 Series is the 335i GT. Although GT stands for Gran Turismo, it could mean giant trunk in this case, since – hide the children, folks – this 335i is a hatchback.

headline: Perceptions of Beauty, and Their Cost
abstract: An exhibition called “Thinner Than You” presents views of women’s bodies amid social pressure to be thin. The provocative images open the door to discussion and perhaps healing.
lead_paragraph: A dress stretched so tightly on a rack that it could not fit even the skinniest of women is the first piece a visitor is likely to spot upon entering the Amelie A. Wallace Gallery at State University of New York College at Old Westbury. Called “Thinner Than You,” it is one of the works in an art exhibition, “Body Conscious,” that explores women’s concerns about their size and weight, including dieting, obesity and eating disorders.

headline: Rand Paul’s Style
keywords: ['Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Paul, quoting Pink Floyd, talked like a guy in jeans – albeit a guy in jeans in 1975.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md.—The idea that Rand Paul is the 2016 Republican front-runner, advanced recently by Peter Beinart in The Atlantic, seems dubious. (There is no front-runner.) But the libertarian was the favorite at the Conservative Political Action Conference, where he spoke to a packed audience. Young people in suits who could not find seats milled around the back of the room.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lake Street Dive
abstract: Smooth, indeed.
lead_paragraph: OK, I’m way behind the curve here — they’ve already been on Colbert and Letterman, and their upcoming concerts in New York are sold out (alas). But that’s no reason not to share 3 minutes and 51 seconds of happiness:

headline: The Nearby Wozzeck Changes His Address
abstract: The baritone Matthias Goerne, who performed the title role in “Wozzeck” in concert at Carnegie Hall, was called on days later to take the part at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: Last-minute cast changes happen routinely in opera, but seldom with the mix of anxiety and, in the end, triumph that took place on Thursday when the Metropolitan Opera revived its 1997 production of Berg’s “Wozzeck.”

headline: Art Matters | At the Independent Art Fair, Thinking Outside the White Box
keywords: ['ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)', 'Art']
abstract: The fifth edition of the alternative show offers an intimate scale and collaborative environment.
lead_paragraph: When Elizabeth Dee and Darren Flook founded the Independent Art Fair in 2010, the art landscape in New York was a different place. Frieze had yet to enter the American market, and the vast Armory Show dominated the fair scene. “There was really a need for something more than the model that was imposed on us,” says the fair’s director, Laura Mitterrand.

headline: Drones, Notes of Discord and a Sip of Cognac
abstract: Charlemagne Palestine made his debut performance as an organist in New York City, after decades of recognition since the 1960s, as a leading Minimalist composer and visual artist.
lead_paragraph: The organ was already playing when Charlemagne Palestine sat down to the keyboards of the Aeolian-Skinner instrument at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn Heights on Thursday night. Flat wooden pegs had been wedged under a few keys, creating a hovering tone cluster, a drone that seemed (as an acoustic phenomenon) to ripple gently as its overtones reverberated around the church. For the next hour or so, Mr. Palestine, in a concert presented by the Issue Project Room, filled the room with one continuous piece, changing gradually but thoroughly, luxuriating in the organ’s infinite sustain and tonal depth.

headline: Russia Backs Rally in Support of Crimea
abstract: A huge crowd gathered at a government-sanctioned rally in Moscow's Red Square in support of the Crimean people.
lead_paragraph: A huge crowd gathered at a government-sanctioned rally in Moscow's Red Square in support of the Crimean people.

headline: Western Businesses in Russia, Watchful and Wary
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: American players including Pepsi and McDonald’s are active in Russia. But for many West European businesses, that market is even more crucial.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shortly after pro-Russian troops infiltrated Crimea last weekend, the phone in Alexis Rodzianko’s Moscow office started ringing. He is president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Russia, and local managers for some of the world’s biggest brands were calling to discuss the safety of their operations and the risks that might arise if the West were to impose sanctions.

headline: Time to Stop and Drink the Wine
abstract: Often away for work, Judith Rodin, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, enjoys meals out and at home with her husband, Paul R. Verkuil, who works in Washington.
lead_paragraph: As president of the Rockefeller Foundation, which focuses on issues like environmental protection and urban planning, Judith Rodin often has to travel for business on Sunday evenings. But when in town for the day, Dr. Rodin, 69, enjoys setting out into the city from the Midtown Manhattan apartment she shares with her husband of 20 years, Paul R. Verkuil, chairman of the Administrative Conference of the United States, an independent government agency. Mr. Verkuil, 74, takes the train to Washington on Mondays and returns Thursday night or Friday; Sunday is important together time.

headline: Cartoon Network Aims at Devices With Its ‘Micro-Network’ Launch
abstract: In the age of the mobile device, a television network may need to rethink the size of its content. Clips may be better than episodes.
lead_paragraph: Cartoon Network will release an app later this year that will deliver original 15-second content bites — videos, games, polls, and trivia — solely to mobile devices, the company said Friday.

headline: Hitchhiking in a Starry Reboot of a Journey Through the Universe
abstract: In “Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey,” premiering on Sunday, the astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson takes the guide-to-the-universe role filled in the original “Cosmos” by Carl Sagan.
lead_paragraph: It’s like trying to remake “Citizen Kane.”

headline: Let’s Get Lost
abstract: The YouTube filmmaking sensation Casey Neistat takes his teenage son to Africa, documenting every hashtag-worthy moment along the way.
lead_paragraph: By chasing a gonzo new adventure every summer, the viral filmmaker Casey Neistat and his son, Owen, embrace the unfamiliar and forge a closer bond.

headline: A Rare Opera Whose Dance Is in Step With Its Drama
abstract: The dance in the Metropolitan Opera’s production of Borodin’s opera “Prince Igor” may be minimal, but it serves the narrative.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Borodin’s opera “Prince Igor” is pervaded by contrasts and dualisms. While it features, in its long Polovtsian scene, some of the most famous dance music ever written, much of its overall stage action is remarkably inactive. My most visceral response to it is prompted by nothing visual: Many of its melodies affect me so powerfully that it’s hard for me to sit still, even when nobody is moving onstage.

headline: Realism Splashing a Screen Near You
abstract: Most vomiting scenes were once handled with a character’s discreet disappearance to another room. No more.
lead_paragraph: The HBO series “Girls” may have its cutting-edge moments, but what comes out of the mouth of its star early in Sunday’s episode is increasingly a television cliché. It’s vomit, straight from Lena Dunham’s lips into your living room, the latest example of a TV trend that deserves to die.

headline: When Studies Are Wrong: A Coda
abstract: Are some scientific fields, like physics. less prone to faulty research?
lead_paragraph: My first Raw Data column, published in January, was about the controversy over irreproducibility — experiments whose outcomes cannot be verified independently by another lab. Featured in the piece was a study by Dr. John P.A. Ioannidis that has been a source of contention since it appeared in 2005. It was called “Why Most Published Research Findings Are False.”

headline: Rhythmic Flourishes, Poise, Posture and the Forceful Whirl of Skirts
abstract: To begin the Flamenco Festival at City Center, a Gala Flamenca on Thursday evening featured Karime Amaya and Jesús Carmona.
lead_paragraph: New York’s Flamenco Festival is back with us. The crowd that thronged City Center on Thursday for the first of two Gala Flamenca evenings abounded in Spanish speakers and flamenco aficionados. The performers onstage, most of them strongly individual, all won eager applause.

headline: Ordinary People, Extraordinary Detail
abstract: Jerome Liebling dug deeply into his subjects, using still photography almost like film; an exhibition of his work will run starting March 13.
lead_paragraph: We know you’re busy, but try to slow down for a moment. The city captured on this page by Jerome Liebling, who died in 2011, doesn’t reveal itself right away. Mr. Liebling, who became known as a member of the Photo League, a group of socially minded photographers that disbanded in 1951, dug deeply into his subjects, using still photography almost like film, to explore a condition rather than an instant. “He and his subjects are looking at each other,” said Rachel Liebling, who curated an exhibition of her father’s work, which is to run at the Steven Kasher Gallery from March 13 to April 19. “They’re looking at him and he’s looking at them. He felt the regular people were the superstars. Those portraits are about that.”

headline: Study Finds a Gender Gap at the Top Museums
abstract: Women run just a quarter of the biggest art museums in the United States and Canada, and they earn about a third less than their male counterparts, according to a report.
lead_paragraph: Women run just a quarter of the biggest art museums in the United States and Canada, and they earn about a third less than their male counterparts, according to a report released on Friday by the Association of Art Museum Directors, a professional organization.

headline: Disappearing Act at the Gold Coast Congress
abstract: The winners of the main team event at the Gold Coast Congress in Queensland, Australia, last month were from Australia, Ireland and New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the main team event at the Gold Coast Congress in Queensland, Australia, last month were Fiona Brown, Tony Nunn and Matthew Thomson from Australia; Hugh McGann from Ireland; and Geo Tislevoll and Michael Ware from New Zealand.

headline: Stilts Aren’t the Only Way to Rise Above It All
abstract: Aki Sasamoto’s “Sunny in the Furnace” uses visual and verbal wit to tell a story of what may, or may not, be a friend’s suicide.
lead_paragraph: Shows by the performance and installation artist Aki Sasamoto have a signature smell. It’s the chemical fragrance of the felt-tip markers she uses to write out key words as she, annoyed and amused, shares her observations and theories about people. Her shows also have a signature image: Ms. Sasamoto inside or under or atop one of the many sculptural objects that litter the stage, talking away as if there were nothing unusual about her predicament.

headline: In Debt to Art? So Actor’s Piggy Bank Attests
abstract: To beat the high cost of her art, Cynthia Hopkins is the cast and (largely) the crew in “A Living Documentary” at New York Live Arts in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: “A Living Documentary,” Cynthia Hopkins’s new one-woman show at New York Live Arts, is small-scale and stripped down, with a barely-there set and minimal technical accouterments. It’s a departure from some of her recent, more involved productions; Ms. Hopkins’ s name is the only one in the program.

headline: New Jersey Images, Unbound by Galleries
abstract: Robert Smithson’s earthworks record the suburban landscape he was surrounded by as a boy in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: In December 1967, Robert Smithson published a photographic essay in Artforum magazine that would become a landmark of 1960s art. Not only did the essay, “The Monuments of Passaic,” signal a shift by artists to making and showing art outside galleries — including the “exhibition” space of a mass-produced, illustrated magazine — but it also put the artist in the unusual role of writer, a position usually reserved for critics and historians. Smithson’s essay was a clever combination of genres: travelogue, science fiction and philosophical tract. But it was also a poignant meditation on time and entropy (one of his favorite terms) in postindustrial suburbia.

headline: Life and Happiness in Siberia’s Cold
abstract: Departing from the images of frozen exile and gulags, a group of Russian photographers has complied a nuanced portrait of a legendary, if misunderstood, region.
lead_paragraph: Departing from the images of frozen exile and gulags, a group of Russian photographers has complied a nuanced portrait of a legendary, if misunderstood, region.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 7
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes ice boaters, Ash Wednesday and a fatal fire.
lead_paragraph: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Ned O’Gorman, 84, Dies; Poet Founded Innovative Harlem School
abstract: Mr. O’Gorman started his “liberation camp,” the Children’s Storefront, on a dare in 1966 because he wanted to stir students’ imaginations.
lead_paragraph: Ned O’Gorman, an award-winning poet who gained his widest attention for starting a storefront school in Harlem — a “liberation camp,” he called it — to bring literature, Latin and love to disadvantaged children, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: A New Verdict on Tammany Hall
abstract: Terry Golway of Kean University looks at the role of the Irish-dominated Democratic group in the 19th century; other authors explore getting an entertainment job and a notorious murder case.
lead_paragraph: Drawing on earlier books by Leo Hershkowitz and Kenneth D. Ackerman,  Terry Golway’s “Machine Made: Tammany Hall and the Creation of Modern American Politics” (Liveright) delivers a refreshingly revisionist verdict on the Irish-dominated Democratic organization whose ring reverberated mightily in the late 19th and early 20th centuries and then faded into a faint echo.

headline: A Discussion About ‘Bright Lights, Big City’
abstract: Join us for the online discussion of the novel “Bright Lights, Big City” by Jay McInerney on March 10 at 6:30 p.m.
lead_paragraph: This time we outsourced our selection for the Big City Book Club to the writer and satirist Gary Shteyngart. We asked him to pick his favorite book about New York, and he did not demand that we read his own newly published memoir, “Little Failure,” about his upbringing as a Russian émigré in Queens. Instead, he selflessly selected “Bright Lights, Big City,” Jay McInerney’s touchstone novel of the hedonistic ’80s life on the other side of the East River. Join us for the online discussion of the novel with Mr. Shteyngart on Monday, March 10, at 6:30 p.m. on The Times’s City Room blog.

headline: A Name and a Spirit From the Dead
abstract: The goal of Garcia’s, a lobby bar at the Capitol Theater named after the Grateful Dead’s Jerry Garcia, is to breed talent that can open for acts like Bob Dylan and then go on to be the headliner.
lead_paragraph: Tom Bailey, general manager of the Capitol Theater in Port Chester, sat nursing a beer at Garcia’s, the theater’s lobby bar, on a recent Tuesday evening. But like the 50 or so patrons who filtered in from the cold outside to join him, he wasn’t there just for the beer.

headline: $66,400 Answer, but What’s the Question?
abstract: The K900 exemplifies Kia’s ongoing move toward larger models. But unlike the German automakers it seeks to emulate, the K900 four-door sedan puts passenger comfort ahead of driver engagement.
lead_paragraph: Kia’s start in America was clandestine. It built the forgettable Festiva two-door hatchback for Ford, using plans cribbed from Mazda. With its front wheels powered by a 58-horsepower 4-cylinder engine, that 1988 Festiva wasn’t much more than a stripped-down, 1,800-pound, 12-foot-long penalty box on four 12-inch wheels. According to Car and Driver magazine, it shuddered from 0 to 60 miles per hour in a lugubrious 12.5 seconds. But at least its base price was only $5,765.

headline: Art Matters | The Whitney Biennial’s Last Upper East Side Hurrah
abstract: This year’s show opened to the public today and boasts a slew of new artists and genres.
lead_paragraph: After almost a week of previews and vernissages, today 945 Madison Avenue opened its doors for the public to descend upon the last Whitney Biennial to take place on the Upper East Side. Two years from now, the Whitney Museum of American Art will have settled into its new building beside the High Line, and the days of several hundred people in “festive attire” snaking all the way down to Park Avenue as they wait to ooh, aah and roll their eyes at the latest and greatest in ostensibly American art will be a thing of the past. In the future when the museum is at capacity, all the excess people will be pushed into the Hudson River.

headline: Head of Retail Investing Departs K.K.R.
abstract: Michael M. Calbert, a 14-year veteran of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts who led the team that invests in the retail industry, is retiring and has been succeeded by Nathaniel H. Taylor, a K.K.R. partner.
lead_paragraph: Michael M. Calbert, a 14-year veteran of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts who led the team that invests in the retail industry, has left the private equity giant, a spokeswoman said on Friday.

headline: A Mixed Breed Gets a Pedigree
abstract: Ford will build its 2016 F-650 and F-750 medium-duty trucks with fully integrated powertrains and chassis, and move production from Mexico to Ohio.
lead_paragraph: For years, buyers of large work trucks have pieced together their vehicles from a variety of suppliers, ordering engines, transmissions and even minor components on an à la carte basis from lengthy menus. That practice is about to fade from Ford Motor’s commercial-vehicle dealerships, a result of the automaker’s push to streamline manufacturing and offer more efficient packages.

headline: A World’s Fair Visit, Not Over Yet
abstract: A 1937 Delahaye roadster once owned by the collector Malcolm Pray went for a weekend record of $6.6 million at RM’s auction in Amelia Island, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Malcolm Pray told the story over and over again.

headline: Nissan Mirror Is Also a Monitor for Rear Camera
abstract: Nissan has developed a rearview mirror that serves double duty as an LCD screen for a rear-facing camera mounted on the back of the car.
lead_paragraph: Nissan has developed a rearview mirror that lets the driver see around the sloping rooflines and chunky roof pillars that are in vogue in today’s car designs.

headline: I Didn’t Recognize You From Behind
abstract: In recent years there seems to be a trend — especially pronounced among midsize and full-size sedans — toward generic, nearly interchangeable taillights.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when cars could be identified at night, even from a distance, by the shape of their taillights. Buicks often wore horizontal red bands stretching from fender to fender, Chevrolet designers favored circles in pairs or threes and Cadillac has kept finlike vertical blades to the present day, decades after it retired the tailfins it started wearing after World War II.

headline: Under Cover: Visualizing Changes to the SAT
abstract: In making the cover for this week’s magazine, the art department paid special attention to eraser shavings, pencil marks and other details.
lead_paragraph: What better way to signal the sea change coming to the SAT — the subject of this weekend’s cover story — than with the telltale signs of an erased word: faded, but still visible, with eraser shavings scattered about?

headline: Wing Cracks Delay Boeing 787 Assembly
abstract: The hairline cracks are tied to a change in the manufacturing process of the carbon composite wings by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in Japan, and do not affect planes in use, Boeing says.
lead_paragraph: Boeing said on Friday that it had discovered tiny cracks in the wings of about 40 Dreamliners currently in production. It was the latest setback for the advanced airliner, though the plane maker said it was confident the problem did not involve any of the 787s in service.

headline: Looking Back on a Double Life
abstract: Noël Coward weighed ethical and emotional ramifications of his closeted existence in what he called his most serious play.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, when Noël Coward wrote “A Song at Twilight” for the London stage, the words “out” and “closeted” did not mean what they do today. How could they? Homosexual sex was still a criminal offense under English law, and being openly gay could — and did — land people in jail. But the ethical and emotional ramifications of a life lived in secret, especially for a writer’s life, are at the heart of this very late work by a playwright whose homosexuality was well-known but never acknowledged.

headline: The Holdouts on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Discrimination', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Readers take issue with a column by Ross Douthat, “The Terms of Our Surrender.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Movin’ On Up
abstract: How far can a brand extend itself? With the K900, a new luxury sedan, Kia explores the limits.
lead_paragraph: How far can a brand extend itself? With the K900, a new luxury sedan, Kia explores the limits.

headline: Drew Barrymore and Robert Osborne on Classic Movies
abstract: The unlikely host and co-host of TMC’s “The Essentials,” which begins a new season this month, discuss their shared love of film.
lead_paragraph: As far as on-screen duos go, Robert Osborne and Drew Barrymore seem like an unlikely pair. He was raised in the small town of Colfax, Wash. (population 2,800) during the ’40s and amused himself with reading books while his parents worked. She grew up amidst the glitz and glamour of Hollywood in the ’80s, the youngest in a long family line of legendary actors, and made her first television appearance before she was even a year old. But they share an almost obsessive love for movies, particularly black-and-white films made decades ago. It’s this connection that makes Osborne and Barrymore light up together as the host and co-host, respectively, of TCM’s “The Essentials.” The show, which premiered in 2001 and airs on Saturday nights, puts timeless, classic films in the spotlight with commentary and fun bits of trivia supplied by the hosts (in the past those duties have been taken up by everyone from Rob Reiner to Alec Baldwin). This season marks Barrymore’s third as Osborne’s wingwoman, and the two clearly enjoy the back-and-forth banter — as well as the goofy handshakes, thumb wars and screwball comedy moments that often happen after the cameras stop rolling. T caught up with the actors on set to talk about the films that forever changed them, the characters they’ve admired and crushed on, and what’s missing from the box office today.

headline: Among the Wounded in Syria’s War: Ancient History
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']
abstract: Archaeologists, long kept from their work in Syria, now hear reports of fighting and theft at historical sites and museums.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the French archaeologists Pierre Leriche, 73, and Jean-Claude Margueron, nearly 80, who both spent decades uncovering Syria’s rich past, it is almost too painful to look at its grim present.

headline: New Rules to Reshape Telecom in Mexico
keywords: ['Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Wireless Communications', 'Television']
abstract: The country’s recently created telecommunications regulator issued tough new conditions that could break up virtual monopolies in phone service and television broadcasting.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a ruling intended to break virtual monopolies in Mexican telecommunications and television broadcasting, a recently created regulator issued tough new conditions for two of the country’s largest companies, the wireless carrier América Móvil and the media company Televisa.

headline: Into the Provinces of Angels and Ladies Powdering Noses
abstract: Principal dancers from New York City Ballet and American Ballet Theater adorn the Tom Gold Dance engagement at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater.
lead_paragraph: One way to create a ballet is to take a familiar subject and replicate it as directly as possible onstage. This seems to be the preferred approach of Tom Gold, a former New York City Ballet soloist who founded his own company, Tom Gold Dance, in 2007. On Thursday at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater, in a triple bill featuring two premieres, those subjects included angels (“Urban Angels”), a beach party (“La Plage”) and women convening in the powder room (“The Ladies’ Room”) to divulge their deepest secrets.

headline: Making City Streets Safer: A Design Solution
abstract: A professor says we should focus on redesigning roads and traffic lights, not law enforcement.

headline: Maidan Faces Its Future
abstract: Weeks after protesters drove President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine from power, Maidan protesters in Kiev’s Independence Square mourn the dead and ponder where their revolution has left them.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after protesters drove President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine from power, Maidan protesters in Kiev’s Independence Square mourn the dead and ponder where their revolution has left them.

headline: M.L.S. Talking Points: New Stars for Toronto, New Expectations for Red Bulls
abstract: Other major story lines for the coming season include possible World Cup disruptions and Landon Donovan’s bid to become the league’s career scoring leader.
lead_paragraph: Chivas USA and Toronto F.C. are separated by thousands of miles but are united in mediocrity.

headline: The Heroin Epidemic, in Vermont and Beyond
abstract: Experts on policy, drug addiction and the law respond to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Access to Justice for All
abstract: The New York City Bar Association says even despised defendants are entitled to a lawyer’s assistance.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Making a Case for the Trans-Pacific Partnership
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Intellectual Property']
abstract: Two dissents from a column by Paul Krugman.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Meat Makes the Planet Thirsty
abstract: Alfalfa, grown for Asian cattle, is worsening California’s drought.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — CALIFORNIA is experiencing one of its worst droughts on record. Just two and a half years ago, Folsom Lake, a major reservoir outside Sacramento, was at 83 percent capacity. Today it’s down to 36 percent. In January, there was no measurable rain in downtown Los Angeles. Gov. Jerry Brown has declared a state of emergency. President Obama has pledged $183 million in emergency funding. The situation, despite last week’s deluge in Southern California, is dire.

headline: Ukrainian Officials in East Act to Blunt Pro-Russian Forces
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Arrests and new appointments are likely to increase Kiev’s control and help avert a situation similar to the one taking place in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Officials loyal to the new central government in Kiev, Ukraine’s capital, have mobilized here in the country’s east to end a pro-Russian protest movement that has called for greater regional autonomy from Kiev and has raised the specter of separatism in the largely Russian-speaking regions of Ukraine.

headline: Civil Rights Sermon Is Mislaid but Not Forgotten
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Methodist Church', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: A search for a Mississippi minister’s 1964 sermon denouncing bigotry did not yield the original copy, but a scholar found that the message resonates deeply.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Bishop Clay F. Lee knelt down in his study on Thursday and peeled the lid off a plastic bin labeled “Sermons A-Z.” Then he beheld the contents, nearly a half-century of his homily manuscripts. His wife, Dot, had spent weeks assembling them in alphabetical order, partly in anticipation of their guest on this particular afternoon.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Reshaping the Military
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Readers discuss what kind of armed forces we need to face the threats of the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss what kind of armed forces we need to face the threats of the 21st century.

headline: Snowden Says He Reported N.S.A. Surveillance Concerns Before Leaks
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden said that he initially told officials of his concerns about the National Security Agency’s surveillance operations, but that none “took any action.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who leaked a trove of documents revealing the agency’s surveillance operations, said he raised his concerns to more than 10 officials, “none of whom took any action to address them,” before he decided to give the documents to journalists.

headline: Course and Conditions Do a Number on Scorecards
abstract: Winds gusted at more than 30 miles per hour and only four players shot under par at the second round of the World Golf Championships event in Doral, Fla.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Donald Trump described the reconstructed Blue Monster course at the Doral resort that bears his name as a layout worthy of being named among the top 10 in the world, as it was by a European magazine, he said. The four-time major winner Ernie Els described it as “a masterpiece,” Trump said, adding, “I think our players are blown away.”

headline: Breaking Out of the Library Mold, in Boston and Beyond
abstract: With physical and virtual visits “off the charts,” libraries across the country are thinking up innovative ways to keep users happy.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — An old joke about libraries goes like this: A boy walks into a library and asks for a burger and fries. “Young man!” the startled librarian reprimands. “You are in a library.” So the boy repeats his order, only this time, he whispers.

headline: After Shots, Pistorius Kept Quiet, Guard Says
abstract: On the fifth day of Oscar Pistorius’s trial on charges of murdering his girlfriend, a security guard testified that the South African track star told him that “everything is fine.”
lead_paragraph: A security guard testified on Friday that Oscar Pistorius, the South African double-amputee track star, insisted that “everything is fine” just minutes after the shots that killed the girlfriend he is accused of murdering in the early hours of Feb. 14, 2013.

headline: Newsweek Returns to Print and Sets Off a Bitcoin Storm
abstract: The magazine’s story claiming to have uncovered the founder of the digital currency drew a wave of attention, much of it negative.
lead_paragraph: After being out of print for 14 months, Newsweek wanted its return to the newsstands to land with a splash. So it put out an issue with a darkened cover featuring a theatrical silver mask, and made an explosive claim: It had uncovered the mysterious founder of the digital currency Bitcoin.

headline: The Self(ie) Generation
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Youth']
abstract: We seem to be experiencing a wave of liberal-minded detach-ees, a generation in which institutions are subordinate to the individual.
lead_paragraph: A fascinating new survey by the Pew Research Center finds that millennials (defined by Pew as Americans ages 18 to 33) are drifting away from traditional institutions — political, religious and cultural.

headline: Malaysia Airlines Loses Contact With Jet Carrying Over 200
abstract: Malaysia Airlines said Saturday morning that it had lost contact five hours earlier with a flight carrying at least 239 people to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur, and had activated a search-and-rescue team.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Malaysia Airlines announced Saturday morning that it had lost contact five hours earlier with one of its flights, which was carrying at least 239 people to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur, and had activated a search-and-rescue team.

headline: Martin Gottfried, 80, Theater Critic and Scholar
abstract: Mr. Gottfried was a defender of nontraditional plays, a biographer of figures like Bob Fosse, George Burns and Arthur Miller, and an influential historian of the Broadway musical.
lead_paragraph: Martin Gottfried, a drama critic and the author of several biographies of entertainers and playwrights as well as two influential studies of the Broadway musical, died on March 6 in Manhattan. He was 80, and had homes in Manhattan and Amagansett, N.Y.

headline: Art Week in New York
abstract: This is the weekend when art lovers crowd New York to attend the panoply of art fairs throughout Manhattan. Follow the reviews by The Times’s critics.
lead_paragraph: This is the weekend when art lovers crowd New York to attend the panoply of art fairs throughout Manhattan. There are the Art Dealers Association of America Art Show, at the Park Avenue Armory (at 67th Street), and the sprawling Armory Show, at Piers 92 and 94 (12th Avenue and 55th Street in Clinton) and the Independent Art Fair (548 West 22nd Street in Chelsea). They draw hundreds of participating galleries, and this year there is an added attraction for contemporary-art fans: The Whitney Biennial has opened, the last Biennial at the museum’s Marcel Breuer home. Follow the reviews by the New York Times critics Holland Cotter, Ken Johnson, Karen Rosenberg and Martha Schwendener:

headline: A Revolutionary Surgery, Now as Typical as a Sinker
abstract: With pitchers facing more stress on their elbows, the need for Tommy John surgery, the procedure pioneered by Frank Jobe, has never been more pronounced.
lead_paragraph: Pitchers who had Tommy John surgery might have felt like raising a toast to Dr. Frank Jobe on Thursday night. But that very motion might not have been possible, at least without triggering elbow pain, if not for Jobe’s pioneering technique.

headline: Recall at G.M. Is Early Trial for New Chief
abstract: Facing the recall of 1.6 million cars weeks into her tenure as chief executive, Mary T. Barra has taken the lead role in handling the crisis, starting an internal inquiry and ordering a rare public apology.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Only weeks into her tenure as chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra has been increasingly consumed by a crisis over the recall of 1.6 million defective cars linked to 13 deaths.

headline: Cloudy and Cold
abstract: Two more abortion clinics were forced to close in Texas, and the state is moving on to the next phase of pressuring clinics.
lead_paragraph: People, have you noticed that the news has been really depressing lately? These are the times when you come to understand why there’s so much interest in watching kitten videos. Do you think it’s the weather?

headline: Carmen Berra, Yogi’s Wife, Dies at 85
abstract: The two met in 1947 — early in the Yankees career of the beloved catcher Yogi Berra — when she was working as a waitress in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Berra, Yogi’s companion for nearly 70 years, was one of the famous Yankees baseball wives who could be identified by their first names, like Eleanor (Gehrig), Merlyn (Mantle) and Cora (Rizzuto).

headline: Border Patrol Instructed to Show Restraint
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The instructions, from the patrol’s chief, came after a series of fatal shootings by agents provoked outrage from human rights activists and the Mexican government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Border Patrol on Friday instructed its agents to show restraint when people on the border throw rocks or flee in cars, after a series of fatal shootings by agents provoked outrage from human rights activists and the Mexican government.

headline: Car Designs at the Geneva Auto Show
abstract: Driverless cars and futuristic 3-D printing-inspired designs were just some of the vehicles on display in Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: Driverless cars and futuristic 3-D printing-inspired designs were just some of the vehicles on display in Switzerland.

headline: Oh, Man
abstract: The men in this issue raise the question of what the value is in conforming to any particular masculine ideal, whichever one it may be.
lead_paragraph: If this magazine is any indication, the idea of masculinity is a bit of a ruse, or at least a fluid social construct that shifts around quite a bit over time and depending on who’s talking. The issue begins with an essay by Troy Patterson examining the meaning behind a man’s bag — be it a backpack, briefcase or messenger — and ends with a photo series of hairy chests. A briefcase certainly doesn’t convey the security and power it once did, and whether you find chest fuzz sexy or gross, this totem of Burt Reynolds-era manliness is certainly not what it was before “manscaping” entered our lexicon.

headline: Offering More Than Luxury, Supercars Draw a Crowd of Makers and Buyers
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: While mass-market carmakers are struggling in Europe, some builders of high-performance supercars are selling their models faster than they can build them.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — European automakers are having a tough time moving their $15,000 models off the lot these days. But selling a $200,000 car seems to be getting easier and easier.

headline: Saudis Put Terrorist Label on Muslim Brotherhood
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s decree appeared to begin an effort to quell the Muslim Brotherhood, reflecting a divide in the Middle East after the military takeover in Egypt last year.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Saudi Arabia on Friday declared the Muslim Brotherhood a terrorist organization, escalating a new campaign against the group across the region with a sweeping ban that imposes lengthy prison sentences for even expressing sympathy with it.

headline: Shortchanging New York’s Environment
abstract: Money for clean air, water and open space dwindles even as needs grow.
lead_paragraph: A mere $250 million a year to protect air and water quality, manage solid waste, conserve open space and save family farms is a trifle in New York State’s enormous annual budget. Yet that modest sum was the prerecession high point for the Environmental Protection Fund, the state’s main source of revenue for these and other important purposes.

headline: The Sulfur Rule, Tardy but Welcome
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Sulfur and Sulfur Compounds', 'Air Pollution', 'Editorials']
abstract: The E.P.A.’s new rule requiring refiners to reduce the sulfur in gasoline by two-thirds is a commendable initiative.
lead_paragraph: To its commendable list of clean air initiatives, the Obama administration can now add one more: a new rule requiring refiners to reduce the sulfur content in gasoline by two-thirds. The rule will impose manageable costs on industry while bringing big benefits to the public by enhancing the effectiveness of catalytic converters, which trap pollution, in both old and new cars. This will further reduce harmful tailpipe emissions, associated with a range of heart and respiratory diseases.

headline: Gun Safety on Facebook
abstract: The fact that the company acknowledged some responsibility to act against illegal firearm sales is encouraging.
lead_paragraph: Facebook, the social media powerhouse, is attempting some new controls to deal with growing complaints that it is being used to facilitate dangerous and illegal gun sales, particularly to minors. With more than a billion users engaged in endless communications, Facebook won’t have an easy task.

headline: Jobs at a Turning Point
abstract: The employment rate will not improve on its own, but there is little help in sight from policy makers.
lead_paragraph: Measured against low expectations, the employment report for February was a relief. The news that the economy added 175,000 jobs last month was better than anticipated, and much better than the dismal reports in December and January. That has raised hopes for a spring bounce, a safe bet given the probable hit to employment in the past few months from bad winter weather.

headline: In Gay Marriage Suit, a Battle Over Research
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sociology', 'Families and Family Life', 'ADOPTIONS']
abstract: A federal trial in Detroit drew unusual national attention for its focus on the lessons of social science research into family structure and child welfare.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was, like a dozen others in recent months, a court battle over gay marriage. But this one was punctuated by charges of scholarly groupthink, the public repudiation by a university department of its own tenured professor, a reference to witch-burning and an economist’s assertion that in his view, those engaging in homosexual acts are destined for hell.

headline: Spring Men’s Fashion Issue
abstract: In the spring 2014 men’s fashion issue, T looks at the changing face of masculinity.
lead_paragraph: T’s spring men’s fashion issue looks at the changing face of masculinity in 2014. On the cover is the chameleonic actor Benedict Cumberbatch, whose unconventional looks, unassuming personality and ability to embody any role (he got his start playing women’s parts in Shakespeare) have made him an unlikely megastar. We visit estates in Austria and Ireland, where, respectively, the mischievous sculptor Erwin Wurm and the reclusive novelist J.P. Donleavy are living out their idiosyncratic visions. We also dive into the supersize life of the boxing champ Floyd Mayweather Jr., whose taste for excess and bold proclamations are a throwback to the days of Muhammad Ali. And we round things out with a group of men unafraid to share their passions and opinions: Gary Shteyngart and CeeLo Green, who consider Justin Bieber socks and bathe with beer soap; the writer Troy Patterson, who waxes poetic about the many meanings of man bags; and the designer Dries Van Noten, whose original collage lays bare the inspirations that have shaped his 30-year career. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Havana Highball
abstract: A Saturday offering by David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m going to open today’s discussion with a couple of questions: Why is it so hard to get restaurants in countries that are not the United States to put an ice cube in a drinking glass? Also, how is it that these same countries, with their high standards of education, do not understand the singular concept of “Diet Coke”?

headline: Disgraced Musician Faces an Angry Japan
abstract: Mamoru Samuragochi, who was hailed as a deaf musical genius, said he knew his deception would be revealed one day.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A man once hailed as Japan’s deaf musical genius and likened to Beethoven faced the wrath of his nation on Friday, appearing in public for the first time since he was exposed as a fake.

headline: For St. Anthony, Lack of Home Court Is Least of Its Problems
abstract: The St. Anthony Friars basketball team, under Coach Bob Hurley Sr., is attempting to win a 28th state title, despite the loss of its home court to flooding and the financial pressures on the Catholic school.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — The only indicator that the Hall of Fame coach Bob Hurley Sr. had just won his 1,100th game was the bigger-than-average milk chocolate bar sitting on the scorer’s table that displayed the win total in white chocolate.

headline: Mets Confront Replay System; It’s Not as Easy as It Looks
abstract: Terry Collins did not challenge a close play in the third inning of a spring training game, bringing to light some of the vagaries in the new replay system.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets were playing the Cardinals at Tradition Field on Friday when, with two outs in the bottom of the third, Eric Young took off for second base. He slid and appeared to be safe, but he was called out. The Cardinals started jogging off the field.

headline: Russia’s Move Into Ukraine Said to Be Born in Shadows
abstract: The Kremlin’s strategy emerged haphazardly as an emotional President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia acted out of what officials called a deep sense of betrayal and grievance.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The day after he returned from the Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia gathered the 12 members of his national security council for a crisis meeting to manage a political implosion in Ukraine that, by all accounts, had surprised Russia’s political and military elite and, above all, infuriated Mr. Putin himself.

headline: Costs Have Piled Up Along With the Snow of a Difficult Winter
abstract: A long, cold and snowy winter has brought a flurry of extra expenses for car repairs, higher heating bills and replacement of lost mittens, expenses that have piled up along with the snow.
lead_paragraph: This has been not only a long, cold winter, but also an expensive one. Replacing lost mittens, buying a snow shovel, having a car towed or paying higher heating bills may not seem like a significant expense, but the costs — some of them unexpected — have kept piling up, as relentless as the snowstorms.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 7, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 7, 2014

headline: The President Does Not Drop Out of Sight, but Does Get Out of Town
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama continued to keep abreast of developments in Ukraine and would most likely abandon his “recreational amenities,” should events become more volatile, a spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: KEY LARGO, Fla. — President Obama and his family disappeared behind the gates of a lush oceanfront resort here on Friday afternoon to begin a weekend getaway that was in doubt until the evening before because of the tumultuous events in Crimea and Ukraine.

headline: Ukraine, Bibi and, of Course, the Oscars
abstract: Hard power may not be what the United States is about anymore. But American soft power ruled the world at the annual Academy Awards.
lead_paragraph: The public debate in past days was rich in Cold War talk of confrontation, credibility, punishment, sanctions, winners and losers. Senator John McCain’s blast that the crisis in Ukraine was another result of a “feckless” American foreign policy — made at the annual convention of Aipac, the conservative pro-Israel lobby, where the dominant talk was of tough sanctions against Iran — was widely cited.

headline: Seeking to Bridge the Arab-Jewish Divide With Music
abstract: David Broza, an Israeli singer-songwriter, employs a universal language on his regular visits with young people at the Shuafat Refugee Camp in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — TRILINGUAL since he was a teenager, the Israeli singer-songwriter David Broza has for nearly four decades performed in Hebrew, Spanish and English. But his latest project, in the forlorn Shuafat Refugee Camp here, employs a more universal language: boys banging on things.

headline: Richard Boone, Johnson Aide and Advocate on Poverty, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Boone led private liberal groups pursuing political and social change.
lead_paragraph: Richard W. Boone, who played a central role in President Lyndon B. Johnson’s war on poverty in the 1960s and led private organizations pursuing political and social change, died on Feb. 26 at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Ted Turner Expected to Undergo Emergency Medical Treatment in Argentina
abstract: Ted Turner, the American media magnate, was expected to undergo emergency medical treatment in Buenos Aires, Argentina’s national news agency reported Friday.
lead_paragraph: Ted Turner, the American media magnate, was expected to undergo emergency medical treatment in Buenos Aires, Télam, Argentina’s national news agency, reported Friday.  Mr. Turner, 75, who founded CNN and is worth $2.2 billion, according to Forbes, had been at a ranch he owns in southern Argentina, local news media reported. He was taken to a private clinic in the city of Bariloche early Friday morning after he complained of a sharp pain in his abdomen, an official at the clinic told Télam. After a brief stay, Mr. Turner was moved to Buenos Aires.

headline: Missing 26 3-Point Shots, Nets Fail to Add to Streak
abstract: In Paul Pierce’s second return to TD Garden, the Nets shot 4 of 30 from 3-point range as Boston, despite 28 turnovers, ended their winning streak at four.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Nets’ status as a winning team lasted one game. Having finally risen above .500 on Wednesday — and with an excellent opportunity to win again Friday against the Boston Celtics, a team bound for the draft lottery — the Nets reverted to their 2013 ways and dropped a 91-84 decision at TD Garden.

headline: Pre-K Special Education Contractor Pleads Guilty to Fraud Charge
abstract: In a plea deal, Cheon Park agreed to pay $2.1 million in restitution to the city’s Education Department and accept a sentence of 51 to 63 months in prison.
lead_paragraph: A man who ran preschool programs for developmentally disabled children pleaded guilty on Friday in a case that became a showcase example of corruption in New York State’s special education financing system.

headline: Behind Clash Between C.I.A. and Congress, a Secret Report on Interrogations
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Interrogations', 'Detainees', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A dispute over a classified C.I.A. report has led to a bitter fight between the agency and the Senate Intelligence Committee, with each side accusing the other of spying on it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was early December when the Central Intelligence Agency began to suspect it had suffered what it regarded as an embarrassing computer breach.

headline: Eyes Are Off the Court as the Knicks Get a Rare Win on It
abstract: With speculation that Carmelo Anthony was leaving and Phil Jackson was coming, the Knicks still managed to craft a victory over the lowly Utah Jazz.
lead_paragraph: Basketball again felt like a backdrop for the Knicks on Friday. The team, one of the N.B.A. leaders in off-court distractions, was preparing for a game against the Utah Jazz, but the focus was instead on whether Carmelo Anthony might be headed to Chicago and Phil Jackson might be headed to New York.

headline: Judge Declares Mistrial in Hip-Hop Manager’s Trial
abstract: The jury deadlocked on four counts in a federal indictment against a man accused of ordering the murder of one of 50 Cent’s associates.
lead_paragraph: A judge in the federal trial of a hip-hop manager accused of ordering the murder of one of 50 Cent’s associates declared a mistrial on Friday, the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan said.

headline: Yankees Like What They See From Pineda, So Far
abstract: Michael Pineda, 25, who missed the past two seasons after shoulder surgery, threw two scoreless innings Friday in his spring training debut.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — All the attention on whether Masahiro Tanaka can find the same success in the majors as he did in Japan has taken some of the focus off Michael Pineda.

headline: In South Bronx, Visions of a Bustling Shoreline
abstract: The borough aims to transform a desolate strip along the Harlem River into an esplanade that includes a park, retail stores and residential towers.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem River flows along the western edge of the South Bronx, much of it hidden behind rambling warehouses and metal fences topped with barbed wire.

headline: An A.T.V. Driver Is Accused of Running Down an Officer
keywords: ['ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES (ATV)', 'Attacks on Police', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The police arrested a man suspected of hitting a New York City police officer on a four-wheel all-terrain vehicle and dragging him down a Brooklyn street.
lead_paragraph: After a five-day manhunt, the police on Friday arrested a Queens man suspected of running down a New York City police officer on a four-wheel all-terrain vehicle and dragging him nearly 200 feet down a Brooklyn street.

headline: Juror Loses Job for Serving in Terror Trial
keywords: ['Jury System', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Terrorism', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: A juror in the trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, has notified the court that she has been laid off from her job because of her service on the jury.
lead_paragraph: To be chosen as one of the jurors in the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama Bin Laden, would understandably cause some unease.

headline: Florida: Mother Faces Charges for Driving Van Into Ocean
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Authorities in Daytona Beach have charged a pregnant South Carolina woman with attempted murder for driving her minivan into the ocean with her three children strapped in the back seat.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in Daytona Beach have charged a pregnant South Carolina woman with attempted murder for driving her minivan into the ocean with her three children strapped in the back seat. The Volusia County sheriff arrested the woman, Ebony Wilkerson, 32, on Friday at Halifax Health Medical Center, where she had been taken for a mental health evaluation after the episode on Tuesday, which the sheriff said was premeditated. Ms. Wilkerson faces three counts each of first-degree attempted murder and child abuse. Her children, ages 3, 9 and 10, are in state custody until they can be released to family members.

headline: Ukraine-Russia Ties, Explained
abstract: To understand the current conflict between Ukraine and Russia, look to the interconnected history of the two countries.
lead_paragraph: To understand the current conflict between Ukraine and Russia, look to the interconnected history of the two countries.

headline: Ramp to Tappan Zee Will Close for 4 Years
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Tappan Zee Bridge', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The ramp will be used as a staging area in the construction of a $3.9 billion, twin-spanned bridge going up parallel to the current bridge.
lead_paragraph: Tarrytown is in for some traffic problems. Another ramp to another bridge is about to be closed, but New York State officials reject any suggestions that this might be a sequel to the infamous lane-closing gridlock in Fort Lee, N.J., last September.

headline: Debate Over Park Eateries Is Older Than Aged Wine
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Restaurants', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: There are more than a dozen restaurants in New York City parks, but a recent fight over one in Union Square Park is only the latest in a decades-old debate.
lead_paragraph: The recent kerfuffle over a planned restaurant for Union Square Park seemed to have a singular set of issues. The restaurant, which received a green light from the state Court of Appeals last month, was proposed for an unusually small park in a part of Manhattan that has seen the arrival of an unusually large number of restaurants.

headline: Corrections: March 8, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 8, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Showtime) QUARTET (2013) Four former opera singers — above, from left, Billy Connolly, Maggie Smith, Tom Courtenay and Pauline Collins — who performed together in Verdi’s “Rigoletto” at the height of their careers, reunite, against their better judgment. They’re to sing that opera’s third-act quartet at the gala meant to keep their palatial retirement home from financial ruin. Michael Gambon plays the maestro who oversees the annual affair, held on Verdi’s birthday. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called this film, the first feature directed by Dustin Hoffman, “a sincere but sloppy piece of work.” Mr. Hoffman “dotes on his cast of first-rate British actors of a certain age,” Mr. Scott added, “and invites us to savor their energy and professionalism. This is not difficult, though the efforts of these fine actors might have yielded greater delight if they had been given more to do.”

headline: China’s Hard Line: ‘No Room for Compromise’
abstract: Wang Yi took a strong stand Saturday on China’s territorial disputes, saying it will “never accept unreasonable demands from smaller countries.”
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese foreign minister took a strong stand Saturday on China’s growing territorial disputes with neighboring nations, saying that “there is no room for compromise” with Japan and that China would “never accept unreasonable demands from smaller countries,” an apparent reference to Southeast Asian nations.

headline: Passport Theft Adds to Mystery of Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet
abstract: At least two passengers used stolen passports to board a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared Saturday between Kuala Lumpur and Beijing with 239 people aboard, raising the unsettling possibility of foul play.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Investigators trying to find out what happened to a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared en route to Beijing on Saturday morning were examining the usual causes of plane crashes: mechanical failure, pilot error, bad weather. But the discovery that two of the passengers were carrying stolen passports also raised the unsettling possibility of foul play.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2014: Retail Therapy to Soothe the Nerves
abstract: Tournament solvers ease into competition by indulging in a bit of retail therapy.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — When you’re getting ready to speed solve seven difficult crossword puzzles against hundreds of hardcore solvers, your nerves can get the best of you. Some people deal with this by getting a good night’s sleep. Others indulge in a little retail therapy.

headline: A Finger Lakes Women’s History Focus
abstract: In March, women’s history is a focus of tours in the Finger Lakes region of New York.
lead_paragraph: It’s the wineries of New York’s Finger Lakes that usually get the most attention from tourists, but a trail of restored homes, parks and museums may have visitors picking up a bit of women’s history with their cabernet franc.

headline: Plane’s Landing Gear Catches Fire After a Landing in Nepal
abstract: Only one minor injury was reported among the 182 passengers and crew members on the Air Indigo flight.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — The rear landing gear of an Indian airliner caught fire shortly after the plane landed here at Tribhuvan International Airport on Saturday afternoon. One person among the 182 passengers and crew members aboard the Air Indigo flight sustained a minor injury as he rushed to escape the aircraft.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, March. 9
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “Those at the top of the firm directed employees to hide the firm’s true financial condition from creditors, investors, auditors and even partners of the firm.”

headline: Jeff Lawson of Twilio: When Ideas Collide, Don’t Duck
abstract: “Conflict shouldn’t be taboo,” says the chief executive of a cloud communications company. “In fact, resolving conflict is one of the key things companies do.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Jeff Lawson, chief executive of Twilio, a cloud communications company in San Francisco, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: How Big Business Can Take the High Road
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In “The Evolution of a Corporate Idealist,” a former BP employee sees globalization and the Internet as pushing more companies to social responsibility.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a long time — maybe never — since I’ve read a book that made me feel proud or even a little encouraged about the moral compass of the world’s largest companies. Corporations, after all, exist to make money. Last I checked, doing good deeds is not listed as a fiduciary duty. But Christine Bader’s thought-provoking book, “The Evolution of a Corporate Idealist: When Girl Meets Oil” (Bibliomotion, 264 pages), argues that this may be changing, at least among some of the people who work at these companies.

headline: Reaching Out, via the Kitchen
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Homeless Persons', 'Soup Kitchens']
abstract: A former Army cook now uses his training to feed the homeless in Bethesda, Md.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence Blake, 61, works for Bethesda Cares, a community outreach program in Maryland for the homeless.

headline: Beauty Tips an Employee Can Do Without
abstract: A reader’s sister faces constant pressure from her boss to dye her hair, and even get Botox treatment, to achieve a more professional appearance.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: For Nonprofits, a Bigger Share of the Economy
abstract: Growth in the number of nonprofit organizations has vastly outpaced that for-profit businesses, according to data from the Urban Institute.
lead_paragraph: The overall economy has been expanding slowly, but at least one sector is vibrant: nonprofits, which have been growing at a breakneck pace.

headline: Beware the Market Whiplash of Geopolitics
abstract: Ukraine’s crisis illustrates the risks of short-term investing in many emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: Investing is hard enough when you’re focused on fundamentals like earnings, debt loads and cash flow.

headline: A Top-Heavy Focus on Income Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Poverty', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Outrage at the very wealthy may be impeding a national discussion of how to raise the living standards of the bottom 20 percent, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: I worry about growing income inequality. But I worry even more that the discussion is too narrowly focused. I worry that our outrage at the top 1 percent is distracting us from the problem that we should really care about: how to create opportunities and ensure a reasonable standard of living for the bottom 20 percent.

headline: A Whistle That’s Lost in the Crowd
keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Mortgages']
abstract: A bank loan investigation may yield no reward for the underwriter who sounded the alarm.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, deep in the annual financial statement filed by SunTrust Banks — on Page 197, to be exact — there was this nugget of news: The Justice Department is investigating mortgages that SunTrust, a large bank holding company operating in the Southeast, underwrote and sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the home loan finance giants.

headline: On Instagram, a Bazaar Where You Least Expect It
abstract: Though not designed as an e-commerce site, Instagram can offer shoppers the thrill of discovery.
lead_paragraph: Instagram, the photo-sharing app owned by Facebook, is my favorite place to skim through pictures of friends. I like to see them celebrating their birthdays, eating at lavishly decorated dinner tables and enjoying their midday coffees.

headline: The Youngest Technorati
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Teenage designers of apps and games have many incentives — financial and otherwise — to forget about their schoolwork.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Orbuch, 16 years old, rolled a suitcase to the front door of his family’s house in Boulder, Colo., on a Friday morning a year ago. He was headed for the bus stop, then the airport, then Texas.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2014: And Away We Go
abstract: And away we go.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — It’s 11:00 a.m. on a Saturday, a time when most normal people are either just rousing after sleeping in, or perhaps getting ready for a relaxing brunch. Here at the Brooklyn Bridge Marriott, however, a large group of crossword lovers are making sure their pencils are sharp. The first puzzle of the annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament is about to drop.

headline: Silence of Knicks’ Mills Veers From Early Plan
abstract: Knicks General Manager Steve Mills has not spoken publicly since the season began, continuing the front office’s practice of not explaining to fans what it is doing.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when Steve Mills was forthcoming about his role as general manager of the Knicks. He had big plans, and he wanted to tell the world all about them.

headline: Investment Fees and Expertise
abstract: A readers respond to “Give Fees an Inch, and They’ll Take a Mile” (Strategies, March 2).
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: The Architects’ Role
abstract: A reader responds to “Monuments of Tech” (March 2).
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: The Plot to Kill Jeff Davis
abstract: The story behind one of the Union’s most daring raids on Richmond, Va.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Kingston, a Union soldier and prisoner of war, languished in a dungeon on a late winter’s day in March 1864. The cell was in the basement of infamous Libby Prison in Richmond, Va., the capital of the Confederacy. A severe cough and cold racked his body. His cellmates were similarly affected. Ten in all, they were crammed into a dank, drafty cell not much larger than a common tent. Rebel guards provided Kingston and the others with nothing more than scraps of food for subsistence and an open bucket for a toilet. If some of the guards had had their way, the prisoners would be left to rot in the filth and cold of the converted brick warehouse.

headline: Variety: An Expressive Acrostic
abstract: An expressive acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I liked this look into the history of speech etiquette, especially since I tend to lean toward the casual side as a writer (you might not have noticed.)

headline: A Body of Work R. A. Dickey Prefers as His Legacy
abstract: Dickey, entering his second season pitching for the Toronto Blue Jays, hopes to rebound from a mediocre 2013 season.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — He knows what is coming from the way the mail feels in his hands. About two of three letters to R. A. Dickey have the telltale pieces of cardboard inside. Those are baseball cards fans want him to sign. The ones without the cardboard seek something more important.

headline: Out, and Serving
abstract: Images and interviews attest to the struggles and triumphs, the dignities and indignities, of gay and lesbian service members.
lead_paragraph: Images and interviews attest to the struggles and triumphs, the dignities and indignities, of gay and lesbian service members.

headline: Tensions Remain High in Crimea Amid Renewed Effort to Mediate
abstract: Russia and Ukraine signaled a willingness to seek a diplomatic resolution, but Russia raised the possibility of suspending nuclear inspections, citing NATO operations.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Even as Russia and Ukraine signaled a modest willingness to seek a diplomatic resolution to the widening crisis over Crimea on Saturday, there were new reports of Russian reinforcements there, and Russia raised the possibility of suspending inspections required under arms control treaties because of stepped-up operations by NATO.

headline: Mercy and Social Media Slow the Noose in Iran
abstract: Public hangings still attract hundreds of onlookers, but Iran’s enormous middle class is turning against capital punishment.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Born into a poor family in one of Tehran’s most desolate neighborhoods, at age 17 Safar Anghouti had little to look forward to beyond a lifetime in his father’s business — rummaging through trash on the streets of the city for bottles, cans and anything else of value.

headline: Partnerships on Powder
abstract: Visually impaired downhill skiers and their guides on the slopes at the Paralympics in Russia have worked for years to forge a close bond.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — During his race Saturday morning, Mac Marcoux rocketed down the slope at nearly 75 miles per hour.

headline: Reconstructing a Recall
abstract: General Motors is recalling more than 1.6 million vehicles because of defective ignition switches in six different models.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling more than 1.6 million vehicles because of defective ignition switches in six different models.

headline: Sheila MacRae, Wife in ’60s ‘Honeymooners’ Sketches, Dies at 92
abstract: Ms. MacRae, an actress, singer and dancer, was best known for portraying a long-suffering Alice Kramden opposite Jackie Gleason.
lead_paragraph: Sheila MacRae, the actress and singer best known for playing Alice Kramden in the 1960s version of “The Honeymooners,” died on Thursday in Englewood, N.J. She was 92.

headline: To Ensure Future Fans, Anaheim Ducks Grow Hockey Players
abstract: The Ducks have spent $12 million over the last six years on initiatives to grow hockey in southern California.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — What would Alex Kalau know of the way his parents grew up, one in speck-on-the-map Milk River, Alberta, and the other in quaint Antigonish, Nova Scotia?

headline: The Pressure Test
abstract: No matter how many times a golfer visualizes closing out a PGA Tour victory or how thoroughly he prepares for it, there is no way of knowing how he will react until he is in the situation.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — Closing out a PGA Tour victory is like starting a family. Many dream of doing it, but the reality is often more stressful than imagined. No matter how many times a golfer visualizes it or how thoroughly he prepares for it, there is no way of knowing how he will react until he is in the situation.

headline: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration Documents
abstract: Letters from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to consumers and then-Representative Barney Frank.
lead_paragraph: Letters from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to consumers and then-Representative Barney Frank.

headline: Auto Regulators Dismissed Defect Tied to 13 Deaths
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Law and Legislation', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off, but they declined to investigate the problem.
lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators received more than 260 complaints over the last 11 years about General Motors vehicles that suddenly turned off while being driven, but they declined to investigate the problem, which G.M. now says is linked to 13 deaths and requires the recall of more than 1.6 million cars worldwide.

headline: Sleeves Hurt LeBron James but Not Most Shooters
abstract: The N.B.A.’s short-sleeve jerseys are not hurting shooters over all, but they do seem to give James trouble.
lead_paragraph: N.B.A. players have spent their entire lives working on jump shots. They hold the ball in a certain way, try to replicate the same release time and again, and resist any attempts to change their mechanics, even if they are in a slump.

headline: U.S. Paralympic Skier Is Stable After Crash
abstract: Tyler Walker of Aspen, Colo., tumbled several times and lay motionless before members of the medical staff rushed to his side.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — An American skier was stable and conscious Saturday at a hospital, where he was taken by helicopter after he crashed during the men’s sitting downhill competition at the Paralympic Games. The skier, Tyler Walker of Aspen, Colo., tumbled several times and lay motionless before members of the medical staff rushed to his side.

headline: The ‘Boys’ in the Bunkhouse
abstract: For decades, dozens of men with intellectual disabilities lived in an old schoolhouse and worked in a turkey plant. No one knew just what they endured.
lead_paragraph: For decades, dozens of men with intellectual disabilities lived in an old schoolhouse and worked in a turkey plant. No one knew just what they endured.

headline: With Medium, Evan Williams Is Tackling the Future of Writing Online
abstract: Medium, which will introduce a mobile app next week, is an effort by a founder of Twitter and Blogger to strike a balance between the old world, where professional editors were gatekeepers, and the new one, where anyone can post anything online.
lead_paragraph: As a founder of both Blogger and Twitter, Evan Williams helped change the way people write online. Now, with his latest start-up, Medium, he is trying to figure out how we will write in the future.

headline: The Men of Atalissa
abstract: For decades, a group of men with intellectual disabilities seemed happy living in a small Iowa town. Then their neighbors found out the truth.
lead_paragraph: For decades, a group of men with intellectual disabilities seemed happy living in a small Iowa town. Then their neighbors found out the truth.

headline: Hall of Famer Whose Pen Charted Path for Jackie Robinson
abstract: Wendell Smith, a reporter for a black newspaper, advised and pressed Branch Rickey in numerous private letters on the signing of Robinson.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Robinson had a stellar 1945 season with the Kansas City Monarchs of the Negro leagues but was virtually unknown to most of America. That fall, he picked up a pen to write a letter to the sportswriter Wendell Smith, whose name he spelled with one L.

headline: The Teeth of Memory
keywords: ['Nursing Homes', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Elder Care']
abstract: An unwitting return to a nursing home proves repellent.
lead_paragraph: WEST CORNWALL, Conn. — WHEN I was 18, I worked for a summer as a dishwasher at a retirement and nursing home, in the hills above the Santa Clara Valley, in Northern California. I remember the friend who got me the job, Nancy, who waitressed there, telling me one evening that an old man cried that day when she informed him there were no more bananas.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Stop Glorifying Hackers
abstract: Stealing my passwords doesn’t make you the Sundance Kid.
lead_paragraph: I WAS at the Museum of Modern Art in New York not long ago, soaking in Edward Hopper’s retro downer mystique, when I got a call that opened up brave new all-night-diners of doom and gloom.

headline: California’s Smart Egg Rules
keywords: ['Eggs', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Factory Farming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Salmonella (Bacteria)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: Courts should dismiss Missouri’s case against regulations that would give hens more space.
lead_paragraph: California voters and lawmakers have decided that, starting next year, all eggs sold in that state must come from hens that can stand up, lie down and extend their wings fully without touching another bird. This is a perfectly reasonable effort to improve, at least for one creature, the deplorable conditions associated with modern industrial farming. It could also improve public health. Astonishingly, the attorney general of Missouri, Chris Koster, has decided to sue to overturn the rule in federal court. The court should dismiss the case.

headline: The Fat Drug
abstract: How humankind unwittingly joined an experiment on antibiotics and weight gain.
lead_paragraph: IF you walk into a farm-supply store today, you’re likely to find a bag of antibiotic powder that claims to boost the growth of poultry and livestock. That’s because decades of agricultural research has shown that antibiotics seem to flip a switch in young animals’ bodies, helping them pack on pounds. Manufacturers brag about the miraculous effects of feeding antibiotics to chicks and nursing calves. Dusty agricultural journals attest to the ways in which the drugs can act like a kind of superfood to produce cheap meat.

headline: To End the Abuse, She Grabbed a Knife
abstract: Violence in the home is quietly killing American women. It’s time to start talking about it.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — WHAT strikes one American woman in four and claims a life in the United States every six hours?

headline: Francisco Costa
abstract: The Calvin Klein designer’s influences are tied to his house, his hometown and his own intuition.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Costa is a Brazilian-born fashion designer and the creative director for women’s wear at Calvin Klein.

headline: Eulogy for a Source
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Archives and Records', 'Museums', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: Jiri Fiedler, murdered in Prague, was entranced by Jewish history.
