lead_paragraph: “EACH piece of reportage has many authors and it is only thanks to long-established custom that we sign the text with a single name,” wrote the literary journalist Ryszard Kapuscinski.  “They arrange contacts, lend us their homes, or quite simply change our lives.”

headline: Lodestars in a Murky Media World
keywords: ['Journalism Schools', 'News and News Media', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Newspapers', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: Though the business model for journalism is shifting, young journalists can rest assured that some values will endure.
lead_paragraph: ARE today’s college-age journalists doomed, entering a business in free fall that is incapable of allowing most of them to earn a living? Or are they lucky, coming into a media world bursting with new possibilities?

headline: Great Hope for Babies With H.I.V.
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Clinical Trials', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new protocol of early treatment could save many young lives.
lead_paragraph: America’s National Institutes of Health will soon sponsor clinical trials abroad to evaluate whether early and very aggressive drug treatments for babies infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, can effectively clear the virus from their bodies. The hope is that such treatments might “cure” at least some of them, as seemingly happened in one famous case in the United States. But no one yet knows whether such therapy can be successful on a broad scale.

headline: Can We Learn About Privacy From Porn Stars?
abstract: A public identity is just one side of a whole person.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — I DIDN’T expect to become a porn star. People rarely do. I was 19 years old, and my photographer roommate had an offer from a website to buy some nude pictures. We did a shoot and then waited two weeks in case I woke up in a panic over the idea of releasing naked photos of myself into the world. But I didn’t, and so I turned to the required paperwork. One of the boxes to fill in read “Stage Name (if applicable).”

headline: Don’t Quote Me on This
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: How can we be more self-reliant online?
lead_paragraph: “I HATE quotation. Tell me what you know,” Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote in his journal one spring day in 1849. He was talking about a very specific tendency. When we’re faced with an issue that’s meant to be thought provoking (in this particular case, immortality), we reach for the easy way out. “I notice,” he writes, “that as soon as writers broach this question, they begin to quote.” Quotation becomes a way not to add depth to your thinking, but to avoid thinking in the first place.

headline: Four Factions, No Favorite
abstract: It’s not just the Tea Party vs. the establishment this time, and, in fact, it never was.
lead_paragraph: THIS is a season of possibility for Republican politicians. Their party is poised to do well in November. Their Democratic opponents are stuck in neutral — waiting for Hillary, praying for Obamacare. And thanks to a few strategically placed traffic cones, there is no front-runner for the G.O.P. nomination in 2016, which means that more prominent Republicans than usual are dreaming the presidential dream.

headline: When Health Costs Harm Your Credit
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Credit Scores', 'Medicine and Health', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Consumer Protection', 'Law and Legislation', 'Debt Collection', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies']
abstract: A minor medical bill could block your mortgage.
lead_paragraph: LIKE most people, I am generally vigilant about paying my bills — credit cards, mortgage, cellphone and so on. But medical bills have a different trajectory. I (usually) open the envelopes and peruse the amalgam of codes and charges. I sigh or swear. And set them aside for when I have time to clarify the confusion: An out-of-network charge from a doctor I know is in-network? An un-itemized laboratory bill from a doctor I’ve never heard of? A bill for a huge charge before my insurer has paid its yet unknown portion of a hospital’s unknowable fee?

headline: Little R-S-P-E-C-T
abstract: Pooty-Poot and his own party are socking it to Bam.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IF you can’t spell it, you can’t get it.

headline: The Men of Atalissa
abstract: For decades, a group of men with intellectual disabilities seemed happy living in a small Iowa town. Then their neighbors found out the truth. This film is being shown in collaboration with POV.org.
lead_paragraph: For decades, a group of men with intellectual disabilities seemed happy living in a small Iowa town. Then their neighbors found out the truth. This film is being shown in collaboration with POV.org.

headline: Global Warming? Not Always
abstract: California’s drought isn’t human-induced.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — CALIFORNIA is now in the midst of the third year of one of its worst droughts on record. As our planet gradually warms from our rampant burning of fossil fuels, it’s only natural to wonder what role climate change has played in California’s troubles.

headline: No Quick or Clear Solution in N.F.L. Settlement
abstract: Judge Anita B. Brody said she wants more proof that the $765 million in a proposed settlement for retired N.F.L. players will last 65 years.
lead_paragraph: When the N.F.L. and the lawyers for the 4,500 retirees who sued the league said in August that they had reached a $765 million deal to end their dispute, there was hope on all sides that a resolution to the standoff would come soon.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 96
abstract: Edin Dzeko, a star for Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Coach Safet Susic had a disagreement last week that spilled into the news media.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: The Uninhibited Press, 50 Years Later
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Libel and Slander', 'Editorials', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: A groundbreaking Supreme Court ruling remains a bulwark of American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no one understood both the necessity and the costs of a free press better than Thomas Jefferson. In a 1787 letter to a friend, he wrote, “Were it left to me to decide whether we should have a government without newspapers, or newspapers without a government, I should not hesitate a moment to prefer the latter.”

headline: The Bamian Buddhas
abstract: An inside look at the site of the destroyed Buddhas of Bamian in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: An inside look at the site of the destroyed Buddhas of Bamian in Afghanistan.

headline: Once Heir Apparent at Shortstop, Nunez Joins Crowd at Second and Third
abstract: Eduardo Nunez is no longer considered exclusively a shortstop as the Yankees have big openings to fill at second and third base.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The line forms to the right, and also to the left, of the Yankees’ infield.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 9
abstract: Ukraine and the Crimea region continue to dominate the headlines and will drive the conversation on the Sunday shows, with guests set to discuss the tense relationship between the United States and Russia.
lead_paragraph: Crimea’s future remains uncertain even as Russia and Ukraine signaled a willingness to seek a diplomatic resolution on Saturday. The day before, Russian parliamentary leaders said they would support an annexation of Crimea, and the Kremlin allowed a large pro-secession rally in Moscow’s Red Square.

headline: Who Is Susceptible to Concussions?
abstract: New findings, in simplified form: Short hockey players, defensemen or those who take a lot of penalties have a higher risk of head injuries.
lead_paragraph: They are not the kind of statistics anyone likes to keep, but several seasons’ worth of data have begun to give researchers an idea of which elite hockey players are more likely to sustain concussions. The profile, in simplified form: short players, defensemen or those who take a lot of penalties.

headline: Gary Thorne in Full Voice for High School Event
abstract: Thorne, the veteran TV play-by-play man, took time out from calling Baltimore Orioles games to do a high school hockey tournament in Minnesota.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — In the television booth at the top of Xcel Energy Center on Friday night, the broadcaster Gary Thorne had everything he needed in sight. A cup of coffee. Lozenges for his throat. And a spirited hockey game on the ice far below.

headline: The Somewhat Inside Story of the U.S. Team
abstract: The five-episode series on ESPN, “Inside: US Soccer’s March to Brazil,” will follow the national team as it trains for the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Hock does not want anyone to confuse his coming ESPN series about the United States men’s soccer team with “Hard Knocks” on HBO.

headline: Sovereignty vs. Self-Rule: Crimea Reignites Battle
abstract: The showdown in Ukraine has revived a centuries-old debate over when secession is legitimate. Nations’ views vary greatly, depending on their own alliances and interests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They wanted to break away from a country they considered hostile. The central government cried foul, calling it a violation of international law. But with the help of a powerful foreign military, they succeeded in severing ties.

headline: Redistribution and the Lesser Depression
abstract: Not what the right thinks.
lead_paragraph: I’ve finally gotten around to a careful read of the new IMF paper on redistribution and growth (pdf) — which concludes that there is no negative effect of redistributionist policies, at least within the range we normally see, and quite possibly a positive effect from the reduction in inequality. I like this conclusion, politically — which is a good reason to kick the tires, and I’ll present some cautions in a later post. For now, however, a quick-and-dirty piece of data analysis inspired by the paper’s method.

headline: Readers Commenting on Domestic Violence
abstract: Comments on my Sunday column about domestic violence and how to curb it.
lead_paragraph: When I lecture about our book “Half the Sky,” which focuses on women’s rights in the rest of the world, I’m always asked about gender issues here in the United States. And I answer that the two most serious issues are probably two that don’t get as much attention as they should: domestic violence and human trafficking. Today my column is about domestic violence, but it’s something that we in the news business don’t cover enough–considering that it strikes one American woman in four, and a higher share of women worldwide. It’s a complicated issue, but it’s also one where I think we have the tools to do much, much better. Police are attentive in some jurisdictions, but not nearly enough in others, and that’s a crucial step to reduce the toll.

headline: De Blasio, Critic of Taxi Commission, Picks Its Ex-Counsel to Lead It
abstract: Meera Joshi was nominated by Mayor Bill de Blasio despite her role in expanding street hail service and the Taxi of Tomorrow, policies he attacked during the mayoral campaign.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Saturday that he would nominate a veteran of the Taxi and Limousine Commission as its chairwoman, moving to fill a lingering vacancy at the agency, which he chided frequently during the mayoral campaign.

headline: Plaintiff in Police Lawsuit Is Ordered to Pay New York City’s Legal Fees
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A young man who sued two officers and New York City claiming police brutality was ordered to pay the city’s legal fees for making “obviously fictitious allegations,” a judge wrote.
lead_paragraph: Initially, the case sounded reminiscent of the police brutality scandals that have haunted the New York Police Department for years. A young man returning from celebrating his birthday at a Brooklyn bar had a tart exchange with two police officers, who he said then handcuffed him and slammed his head onto the hood of their car.

headline: Gators Overwhelm Wildcats to Cap SEC’s First 18-0 Season
abstract: Patric Young scored 18 points and Casey Prather had 15 as the Gators led from start to finish, extending their team-record winning streak to 23 games.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — The timeout came with 36.9 seconds to play and history convincingly secured. Fittingly, four Florida seniors huddled and headed to the bench one last time at home, having stamped their legacy on the Gators’ record-setting season.

headline: Ukraine’s Fight to Fix Economy Is Also a Fight for Legitimacy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Pavlo Sheremeta, Ukraine’s new minister of economy, said the new government’s urgent priority was cash in the banks, and the second priority is “safety and security in the streets.”
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Young men in fatigues, bulletproof vests and masks patrol one of Kiev’s better hotels, the Dnipro, and they have occupied several floors. Armed with clubs, pistols and even slingshots, they are the militant Ukrainian nationalists of Pravy Sektor, or Right Sector.

headline: For Families of Missing on Airliner, Memories Mix With Fading Hope
abstract: By Saturday night, the families of the passengers aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 had few answers about what happened and dwindling hope that they would see their loved ones again.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian couple returning from vacation in Vietnam. An American who worked in Asia for IBM. A group of Chinese calligraphers who had attended an exhibition in Malaysia.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2014: After the First Four Puzzles
abstract: The top solvers start to leave the rest behind.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — After the first four puzzles, we have reigning champ Dan Feyer in the lead with 6,150 points and a tie for second place between Anne Erdmann and former champ Tyler Hinman with 6,125 points each. “Jeopardy!” champion Joon Pahk is in third place with 6,075 points.

headline: Mets’ Top Prospect Has Shaky Outing but Remains Upbeat
abstract: Over three innings, Noah Syndergaard issued three walks, allowed two hits and surrendered two runs.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — This was a reminder that the Mets’ top prospect, Noah Syndergaard, is not invincible, that he is just 21 years old and that this is only spring training.

abstract: Julia Khanbalinova always wished she would walk out of work one day and walk into her future husband. She walked into his mother instead.
lead_paragraph: Julia Khanbalinova always wished she would walk out of work one day and walk into her future husband. She walked into his mother instead.

headline: For Ski Break Without Crowds (or Rebels), an Afghan Town Beckons
keywords: ['Skiing', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Despite the war that rages on elsewhere in Afghanistan, some intrepid tourists are finding their way to Bamian, a mountainous area formerly known for its ancient Buddhas.
lead_paragraph: BAMIAN, Afghanistan — It will be a long time before anyone calls this mountain town a tourist trap, especially at 9,000 feet when lows in the winter can plunge to 20 degrees below zero.

headline: Florida Election a Crash Course for Midterm Races
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Both Republicans and Democrats see the special election Tuesday as a potential harbinger, particularly with regards to the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: MADEIRA BEACH, Fla. — Pinellas County, with its off-the-clock retirees and gentle Gulf Coast beaches, cultivates a life of flip-flops and easy breathing.

headline: When Employees Confess, Sometimes Falsely
keywords: ['Confessions', 'Interrogations', 'Shoplifting and Employee Theft (Retail)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: In a drive against in-house theft, retailers’ interrogation tactics have come under fire.
lead_paragraph: When an AutoZone investigator approached Chris Polston, asking for his help investigating a theft, Mr. Polston was happy to oblige.

headline: Nosy Nonsense
abstract: A punny offering from Brendan Emmett Quigley.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s Sunday offering is a nice, tight theme set where the “zee” sound (using different spellings) is added to familiar phrases and clued in a punny way. Of course, the ensuing hilarity is just what you would expect in a Brendan Emmett Quigley puzzle, and this one doesn’t disappoint. It also happens to be an exceptionally clean grid for its size and, as a special bonus, Mr. Quigley has been kind enough to keep the under-the-radar music references out of this puzzle, which shows a good understanding of his audience.(But if you would like to delve further into his indie puzzles and all that that implies, you can have a taste of them here. Please help support your constructors, who are generally freelancers, and think about throwing a few shekels his way if you like what you see.)

headline: Kerry Warns Russia Against Annexation of Crimea
abstract: The secretary of state said that any steps by Russia to annex Crimea would bring diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis in Ukraine to a halt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry warned his Russian counterpart on Saturday that steps by the Kremlin to annex Crimea would “close any available space for diplomacy,” a State Department official said.

headline: Rio’s Race to Future Intersects Slave Past
abstract: With a building spree tearing apart sections of Rio de Janeiro, archaeological finds are giving new insight into its old role as a slave trade center.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Sailing from the Angolan coast across the Atlantic, the slave ships docked here in the 19th century at the huge stone wharf, delivering their human cargo to the “fattening houses” on Valongo Street. Foreign chroniclers described the depravity in the teeming slave market, including so-called boutiques selling emaciated and diseased African children.

headline: Long Wielding Power Behind the Scenes, Now Taking Her Leave
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Alyssa Mastromonaco will leave the White House staff in May, the last to depart of the Obama aides who were there from the early days.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not so long ago, when Alyssa Mastromonaco was still in her 20s, she had retreated to her apartment after two nonstop years as the scheduler for Senator John Kerry’s 2004 presidential campaign, when her phone rang from an unfamiliar number. She let the caller go to voice mail — and only later heard the job offer she had been waiting for.

headline: A Rocking Farewell From a Band in the Homestretch
abstract: New York is losing a March tradition at the Beacon, one that on Friday night saw each of the Allman Brothers Band’s members performing in service to the others.
lead_paragraph: Early in January, the guitarists Warren Haynes and Derek Trucks announced that they would be leaving the Allman Brothers Band at the end of this year. That means the end of a 25-year run for Mr. Haynes, who joined the group when he was 28, and a 15-year run for Mr. Trucks, who joined when he was 19. A bit later that month, Gregg Allman, the band’s singer, keyboardist, and nominal leader, announced that the group as a whole would stop its regular touring after 2014.

headline: Ruling Clears Way for Skakel Libel Suit
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Libel and Slander', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: A federal judge denied a motion to dismiss Michael C. Skakel’s libel claim over comments made by Nancy Grace and her associates falsely suggesting that DNA evidence tied him to Martha Moxley’s 1975 killing.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge ruled that Michael C. Skakel’s libel claim could proceed against the television personality Nancy Grace and her associates over comments made on her current affairs show that falsely suggested DNA evidence tied him to Martha Moxley’s 1975 murder.

headline: Farm Bill Reflects Shifting American Menu and a Senator’s Persistent Tilling
keywords: ['Farm Bill (US)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Hemp', 'Organic Foods and Products', 'Fruit', 'Vegetables', 'Food Stamps', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Local Food']
abstract: As one congressman put it, “There is nothing hotter than farm to table.” The bill’s champion, Senator Debbie Stabenow, made sure the trend got a boost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The farm bill signed by President Obama last month was at first glance the usual boon for soybean growers, catfish farmers and their ilk. But closer examination reveals that the nation’s agriculture policy is increasingly more whole grain than white bread.

headline: Texas Voters Seem to Have Kicked One Habit
abstract: The results in the recent Democratic primary may or may not bode well for Senator Wendy Davis, but the day’s turnout did establish one thing.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: As SXSW Begins, Eyes Are on the Local Bands
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Music']
abstract: Despite its size, South by Southwest remains one of the best places to find your new favorite band, which could hail from Chile, Israel, Japan, Russia or, more likely, Texas.
lead_paragraph: The South by Southwest Music Festival has 2,200 acts playing 110 stages across six days, and the numbers do not include the slew of unofficial showcases and corporate parties.

headline: Rand Paul Wins Conservative Straw Poll
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The straw poll, conducted at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference, reflects the enthusiastic reception that Mr. Paul, a libertarian senator, received at the event.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, won a presidential straw poll at a prominent conservative conference here on Saturday, capturing 31 percent of the vote among no fewer than 10 potential candidates.

headline: Drought Hastens End of a Region’s Hydropower Era
keywords: ['Hydroelectric Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Levees and Dams', 'Rivers', 'Wind Power']
abstract: The yearslong drought in Central Texas could eventually snuff out a renewable power source that fueled the region’s early growth: hydropower.
lead_paragraph: The yearslong drought in Central Texas could eventually snuff out a renewable power source that fueled the region’s early growth: hydropower.

headline: Libyan Militia Selling Oil, Defying the Government
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The weak transitional government appeared powerless to stop a militia group from selling oil, an indication that the nation may be at risk of coming apart at the seams.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A militia group that has blockaded Libya’s main oil ports for more than six months began on Saturday to sell the oil for its own accounts as the weak transitional government appeared powerless to stop it.

headline: Years After Hurricane, Political Storm Still Blows Over Claims
abstract: It has been five and a half years since Hurricane Ike pounded the Gulf Coast, killing dozens of people, pushing homes off their slabs and inflicting tens of billions of dollars in damage.
lead_paragraph: It has been five and a half years since Hurricane Ike pounded the Gulf Coast, killing dozens of people, pushing homes off their slabs and inflicting tens of billions of dollars in damage.

headline: Reed Leads Tight Field as Doral Shows Soft Side
abstract: Patrick Reed shot a 69 to take a two-stroke lead over Jason Dufner and Hunter Mahan after three rounds of the World Golf Championships event at Doral. Tiger Woods was three back.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — If the reconstructed course at Doral had not kept its nickname, it could have gotten a new one this past week: Sybil. In the first three days of its relaunch at the World Golf Championships event here, the 7,481-yard Blue Monster has flashed multiple personalities, from bloated on Thursday to plundering on Friday to all sweetness and light on Saturday.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: March 7, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses Ukraine’s economic ties to Europe and Russia.
lead_paragraph: As the political crisis escalates in Ukraine, it’s worth remembering that a debate over trade was a major contributor to the uprising that led to recent turmoil. Should the country develop closer economic ties with Europe and the West, or with Russia, its neighbor to the East? This week on Money Talking, Joe and Rana Foroohar examine the economic backdrop of a political crisis iand what it means for the world economy.

headline: Leading Republicans Move to Stamp Out Challenges From Right
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: This election season, Republicans are challenging conservative advocacy groups head on in an aggressive effort to undermine their credibility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As conservative activist groups stirred up trouble for establishment Republican Senate candidates in 2010 and 2012, party leaders in Washington first tried to ignore the insurgents, then tried to reason with them, and ultimately left it to primary voters to settle the matter.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2014: After Puzzle 6
abstract: Howard Barkin rises in the standings as we go into Puzzle 7.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — At the end of the sixth puzzle, Howard Barkin has risen in the standings to a strong third place. He displaces Anne Erdmann, who fell in the rankings after the infamous Puzzle 5, and Mr. Barkin now defends his third place against Joon Pahk, who needs to recover two minutes in order to beat him.

headline: Suspicion Falls on Russia as ‘Snake’ Cyberattacks Target Ukraine’s Government
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Cyberwarfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: No one can quite pinpoint who is behind a series of cyberattacks that began long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, though some suspicion is falling on Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since the first major protests in Kiev that triggered the current crisis with Moscow, American intelligence agencies have been on high alert for cyberattacks aimed at the new government in Ukraine. They were a bit late: the attacks started long before President Viktor F. Yanukovych was forced from office, and as might be expected, no one can quite pinpoint who is behind them, although some suspicion is falling on Russia.

headline: League Play Pays Off for a Former Champ, Too
abstract: Viswanathan Anand has a special relationship with Germany’s Budesliga, a lucrative source of income for players trying to earn a living at chess.
lead_paragraph: Earning a living at chess is not easy, and only a handful of elite competitors can count on a steady income. Many of the others teach, or work as assistants to their better-ranked peers.

headline: Shockers Are in Rarefied Air, but History Offers Lesson: Don’t Breathe Easy
abstract: As Wichita State reached the Missouri Valley Conference title game and a 33-0 record, its story got bigger and the pressure continued to mount.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — As the seconds ticked down Saturday afternoon at Scottrade Center, the scoreboard told a familiar story: Wichita State defeated Missouri State, 67-42. The Shockers have played 33 games this season. They have won them all.

headline: Tough Outing for Banuelos, but Good Sign for Yankees
abstract: Manny Banuelos, who had Tommy John elbow surgery on October 4, 2012, gave up three runs in two-thirds of an inning, but the Yankees have not forgotten how impressive he was in early 2011.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — It had been 659 days since Manny Banuelos last pitched in a game, so just seeing him on a mound, throwing against an opponent, was enough for the Yankees.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 8, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 8, 2014

headline: Scorned but Still in Love, Cleveland Beckons James
abstract: LeBron James was at a Cavaliers home game on Saturday to honor a former teammate, but his visit fueled speculation about a possible return to the team he left in 2010.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — LeBron James returned home Sunday for an enthusiastic celebration not meant for him, but that did not keep many at Quicken Loans Arena from fantasizing that he might rejoin the team he once rejected.

headline: Queens Man, 64, Dies After Being Struck in Hit-and-Run
abstract: Kumar Ragunath was hit by a Chevy Blazer when he stepped into the westbound lanes of Northern Boulevard, the police said. The driver has not been found.
lead_paragraph: A 64-year-old man died on Saturday after he was struck in a hit and run in Queens the night before, the police said.

headline: Knicks Win Third Straight and Gain Ground in East
abstract: Carmelo Anthony scored 26 points as the Knicks beat the Cavaliers and moved into a tie with Cleveland for 10th in the conference, three and a half games behind eighth-place Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Break up the Knicks. Their third straight victory, a 107-97 triumph Saturday night in Cleveland, moved them into a tie with the Cavaliers for 10th place in the woebegone Eastern Conference and left them three and a half games behind the free-falling Atlanta Hawks for the conference’s eighth and final playoff spot.

headline: To Have and to Hold
abstract: Once upon a time, a man’s bag indicated his trade. But these days, men have an increasingly complicated relationship with the things they carry their things in.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, a man’s bag indicated his trade. But these days, men have an increasingly complicated relationship with the things they carry their things in.

headline: The Shape Shifter
keywords: ['Art', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The dissonant humor and beauty of the sculptor Erwin Wurm’s biomorphic riffs are also present in his home, where blue-chip art, grand architectural space and his own whimsical work create an odd harmony.
lead_paragraph: The dissonant humor and beauty of the sculptor Erwin Wurm’s biomorphic riffs are also present in his home, where blue-chip art, grand architectural space and his own whimsical work create an odd harmony.

headline: Fabric of Thought
abstract: The designer Dries Van Noten creates an original collage inspired by his upcoming museum exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The designer Dries Van Noten creates an original collage inspired by his upcoming museum exhibition.

headline: Sarah Conde and Jeffrey Marcus
abstract: The bride is to join the legal department at Providence Equity Partners; the groom is a vice president of Israel Discount Bank.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Nicholson Conde and Jeffrey Lee Marcus were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerk’s office officiated. On Saturday, Justice William P. Robinson III of the Rhode Island Supreme Court led another ceremony for family and friends at the Yale Club of New York.

headline: Pamela Blechman, Alec Ellison
abstract: The bride works for a nonprofit organization; the groom is in investment banking.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Jean Blechman and Alec Lindsay Ellison are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Gordon Tucker at Locanda Verde, a restaurant in New York.

headline: Deirdre Foley-Mendelssohn, Peter Stella
abstract: The bride is the senior editor at Harper’s Magazine and the groom is a doctor.
lead_paragraph: Deirdre Jane Foley-Mendelssohn, the daughter of Kathy Foley and Roy Mendelssohn of Santa Cruz, Calif., is to be married Sunday to Dr. Peter Alexander Stella, a son of Dr. Harriet E. McGurk and the artist Frank Stella of New York. Mary-Beth Holland, a Universal Life minister and friend of the groom’s family, is to officiate at the home of the groom’s parents.

headline: Hilary Falb and Philip Kalisman
abstract: The bride is a doctoral student at the University of California, Berkeley; the groom is a postdoctoral fellow studying in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Hilary Bell Falb and Philip Taubman Kalisman were married Saturday evening at the Boston Public Library. Rabbi Carl M. Perkins officiated.

headline: Michele Zatzkis, Matthew Slaine
abstract: The bride and groom work in publishing, she at Hearst Magazines and he at Progressive Business Media.
lead_paragraph: Michele Elaine Zatzkis and Matthew Justin Slaine were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton in New Orleans. Rabbi Alexis Berk officiated.

headline: Sascha Weiss and Scott Simpson
abstract: The bride is a freelance producer of documentaries; the groom is a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Sascha Aibel Weiss and Scott Evan Simpson were married Saturday in a ceremony that incorporated Jewish traditions at the Landmark Loew’s Jersey Theater in Jersey City. Taylor Asen, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Julia Khanbalinova, Justin Leventhal
abstract: The bride sells beauty products; the groom, cars.
lead_paragraph: Julia Khanbalinova, the daughter of Kamilla R. Khanbalinova of West New York, N.J., was married on Friday to Justin Alan Leventhal, a son of Denise A. Leventhal and Alan H. Leventhal of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Ugo R. Nacciarone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

headline: Jessica Karr, Jeffrey Gurtman
abstract: The bride is the manager of Bloomingdale’s mobile and e-commerce sites; the groom is the managing director at a hospitality research firm and is a travel commentator.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Rae Karr and Jeffrey Samuel Gurtman were married Saturday evening at the Amáli Restaurant in New York. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated.

headline: Alissa Grad and Michael Kestenbaum
abstract: A wedding at the New York Public Library.
lead_paragraph: Alissa Tara Grad and Michael Ari Kestenbaum were married Saturday evening at the New York Public Library. Judith S. Kaye, a former chief judge of the State of New York, officiated.

headline: Joshua Gold, Joseph Harris
abstract: Mr. Gold is a theatrical director; Mr. Harris is a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Joshua Chase Gold and Joseph Harris were married Saturday at the Brooklyn Winery. Elizabeth A. Harris, the sister of Mr. Harris, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated with Mr. Gold’s sister, Jennifer G. Clark, taking part.

headline: Pamela Segal and Jason Shedlock
abstract: The bride is an assistant professor at Towson University; the groom is a national security specialist.
lead_paragraph: Pamela Hope Segal and Jason Alan Shedlock were married Saturday at the Wakefield Chapel in Annandale, Va. The Rev. Michael J. Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Harold White taking part.

headline: Elizabeth Wilson and Michael Brown Jr.
abstract: The bride is the chief executive of an online furniture consignment service; the groom is the founder of a venture capital firm.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Burns Wilson, the daughter of Patricia E. Wilson and G. Larry Wilson of Palm Beach, Fla., was married there Saturday evening to Michael Charles Brown Jr., the son of Marianne Brown and Mr. Brown Sr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Robert S. Norris, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel.

headline: Finally Arriving at Romance
abstract: The couple are second-year residents, the bride in pediatrics, the groom in orthopedic surgery.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Diana Cristina Montoya-Fontalvo, a daughter of Miryam I. Fontalvo-Montoya and Luis F. Montoya of Gainesville, Fla., was married there Saturday evening to Dr. Brendan Alexander Williams, the son of R. Kay Tolle and Wendell S. Williams of Silver Spring, Md. Dr. Daphna Yasova Barbeau, a Florida notary, officiated, with the Rev. Alberto Esposito, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part in the ceremony, at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Intrigue Over Jackson Continues to Percolate
abstract: Phil Jackson won 11 championships as a coach but has never been a front-office executive. That could change.
lead_paragraph: As far back as 15 years ago, the Knicks looked to Phil Jackson to help rescue them. Now, after all these years of yearning, it seems possible that he will rejoin the team, with whom he was a championship player more than 40 years ago.

headline: Corrections: March 9, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 9, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: North Korea Uses Election To Reshape Parliament
abstract: North Korea’s leader was expected to use the polls and a newly elected legislature to elevate officials close to him and consolidate his power.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Sunday held its first parliamentary elections under the leadership of Kim Jong-un, who was expected to use the polls and a newly elected legislature to elevate officials loyal to him and further consolidate his power.

headline: Search for Jet Compounds the Mystery
abstract: Planes and ships from a half-dozen countries joined the search for the plane that vanished with 239 people, including two who apparently used stolen passports to board.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — More than 48 hours after Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 vanished, the mysteries over its fate have only multiplied.

headline: The Languages of Twitter Users
abstract: Gnip, a provider of social media data, tracked the primary languages chosen by Twitter users.
lead_paragraph: Twitter styles itself as the “global town square” for public conversations — a place for fans to gossip about an actress falling at the Academy Awards and for critics of Tunisia’s government to publicly decry the death of an opposition leader.

headline: Gerard Mortier, Opera Visionary and Patron of New Work, Dies at 70
abstract: His bold theatricality and updating of classical works marked his four-decade career as the leader of some of the world’s most important opera companies.
lead_paragraph: Gerard Mortier, a visionary opera company leader whose bold theatricality and updating of the canon helped define the art form’s modern history, died on Saturday at his home in Brussels. He was 70.

headline: Out of the Shadows, a Tech Hub in Luxembourg
abstract: Technoport, the national tech-oriented incubator, is taking shape in a former industrial area 20 kilometers from Luxembourg City.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG — The towering, rusty blast furnaces of the industrial wasteland in Belval stand in stark contrast with Luxembourg’s fairy-tale image of wealth and stability. But the former industrial area about 20 kilometers south of Luxembourg City is undergoing a radical metamorphosis. Where the country’s largest steel works once spewed smoke into the sky above the French border, the government has been erecting an entire new neighborhood, aiming to position Luxembourg as Europe’s next hub for technological innovation.

headline: The Cleft-Lip Smile I Never Knew I’d Miss
abstract: I love the face my son was born with, cleft lip and palate and all. I’m certain we did the right thing by correcting it, but I ache as I miss his triangular “before” smile.
lead_paragraph: We knew from ultrasound photos that our son Dylan would arrive in this world with the same birth defect as the babies we’ve all seen in those Smile Train ads, the ones featuring children with faces and stories so desperate and concerning that they compel people to donate. I never imagined having a baby with a face like that in the same way that one doesn’t foresee giving birth to a child with an unexpected birthmark or color of hair. I also never pictured growing to love a “defect” so intensely that I would feel crushed when the time came to let it go.

headline: Welfare States in the Euro Crisis
abstract: No link, again.
lead_paragraph: A followup on my last post, on redistribution and its role or lack thereof in the economic crisis. One thing we can do instead of looking at measures of redistribution — which is, in a way, the output of the welfare state — is look at social expenditures, which are in effect the input. And this gives us data on a few more countries. If we look at the relationship between social expenditures in 2007, on the eve of the crisis, and performance in the next five years, we get this:

headline: The French Comparison
abstract: Similar capabilities, different choices.
lead_paragraph: I promised that I would share some nagging concerns about the Ostry et al paper on redistribution and growth (pdf); I think I can usefull phrase my concerns in terms of my favorite comparison on these matters, which is between the United States and France.

headline: Clashes in Ukraine as Rallies Take a Turn
abstract: In Sevastopol, a pro-Ukraine rally of hundreds was attacked by pro-Russia supporters, who had their own rally there, while Ukraine celebrated the birth of its greatest poet in the Crimean capital.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Rival rallies turned violent in Crimea on Sunday, as Ukraine celebrated the 200th anniversary of the birth of its greatest poet and the White House announced that President Obama would host the Ukrainian prime minister just days before a controversial referendum on Crimean secession next week.

headline: In Our Pages: March 10
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Queen Victoria Visits Biarritz

headline: Mourinho's Coaching Moves Lift Chelsea Again
abstract: Without playing anywhere near its best, Chelsea rolled over Tottenham Hotspur and looks to be the team to beat in the Premier League.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Chelsea appears to be moving inexorably, almost reluctantly toward another Premier League title.

headline: You Talking to Me?
abstract: Dropcam is like a nanny cam for your dog. With it, it’s easy to communicate with your pet remotely — but obedience is not included.
lead_paragraph: Dropcam is like a nanny cam for your dog. With it, it’s easy to communicate with your pet remotely — but obedience is not included.

headline: Every Dog Has Its Data
abstract: Wearable devices to track biometric activity are increasingly popular with humans, so it’s not surprising that people are also putting them on their dogs.
lead_paragraph: A half-century ago, dogs lived in barns or backyards, domiciled in shabby little doghouses. Now they have the run of our houses and apartments. They sleep in our beds (full disclosure). In some cases, they are considered by their owners to be like children, and possibly a bit cleaner.

headline: ‘300’  Sequel Adds Up to $45.1 Million
abstract: “300: Rise of an Empire” leads the pack at the weekend movie box office.
lead_paragraph: “Ram them!” With that cheese-tastic command, navies collide on computer-generated waves in “300: Rise of an Empire,” but the words could just as easily have come from Warner Brothers marketers, who aggressively advertised the R-rated sequel and were rewarded with $45.1 million in North American ticket sales over the weekend.

headline: Aska to Close, for a Move
abstract: The chef Fredrik Berselius has decided to close his Brooklyn restaurant in order to move it to a still-to-be-found location later in the year.
lead_paragraph: Fredrik Berselius, an acclaimed New York chef whose cooking is linked to the ideals and ingredients of the New Nordic movement, has decided to close his Brooklyn restaurant, Aska, in order to move it to a still-to-be-found location later in the year.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2014: Striding Up to the Big Boards
abstract: Heading into the 2014 A.C.P.T. finals.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — David Kahn’s Puzzle 7, the last to be solved by all of the competitors, is completed, and the weary solvers straggle into the lobby with a palpable sense of relief. That won’t last long for nine of the solvers, who will be competing in the final round of the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2014: For All the Money
abstract: 2014 belongs, once again, to Dan Feyer!
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The A Division clues are the hardest, so the best solvers in the world get an extra five minutes to solve, for a total of twenty minutes.

headline: Among de Blasio’s Priorities, Minimum Wage Waits Behind Pre-K
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has vowed to set a minimum wage for New York City, but state legislators say the plan has no chance of succeeding this year.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Guzman was savoring a quiet evening with his wife and two boys in their Harlem apartment last month when the news flashed across his television screen. Mayor Bill de Blasio was vowing to create a new city minimum wage so that full-time workers weren’t “relegated to the ranks of the poor.”

headline: Basquiat Auction by Christie’s Is Postponed
abstract: After a lawsuit, the auction house has decided to delay an online sale of Jean-Michel Basquiat works owned by a former roommate.
lead_paragraph: Christie’s auction house has postponed an online auction of Jean-Michel Basquiat works owned by a former roommate of his after Basquiat’s sisters filed a federal lawsuit last week, arguing that some of the items may not be authentic. After initially saying that the auction would proceed, Christie’s quietly reversed itself, posting a notice on its website: “Our goal is to allow time for all parties involved to reach an equivalent level of confidence in the validity of these items, so that the sale may resume at a later date.”

headline: Warlord Who Tamped Conflicts as Afghan Vice President Dies
abstract: The death of Vice President Muhammad Qasim Fahim, who played a crucial role in ousting the Taliban, created a rift in the political power structure less than a month before Afghans were to elect a new leader.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Vice President Muhammad Qasim Fahim of Afghanistan, a formidable power broker and former warlord who played a crucial role in ousting the Taliban and shaping the political order that followed, died on Sunday, less than a month before Afghans are to elect a new leader.

headline: 2016 Republican Prospects Spar Over Ukraine
abstract: Three Republicans said to be considering presidential runs tried to distinguish themselves on Russia’s invasion of the Crimean Peninsula in television appearances.
lead_paragraph: Three Republicans said to be considering presidential runs tried to distinguish themselves on Russia’s invasion of the Crimean Peninsula, previewing their approaches to foreign policy in television appearances on Sunday.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 45 at Checkpoint in Southern Iraq
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The attack hit a security checkpoint in Hilla, setting fire to more than 30 cars waiting to be searched.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber driving a truck loaded with explosives attacked a security checkpoint in the southern Iraqi city of Hilla on Sunday, killing at least 45 people and wounding more than 100, security officials said.

headline: ‘No Guarantee’ of Final Nuclear Deal With Iran, E.U. Official Says
abstract: The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said that reaching a final comprehensive deal would be difficult and challenging.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The European Union’s foreign policy chief, Catherine Ashton, said Sunday that there was “no guarantee” that Iran and world powers would be able to reach a final, comprehensive agreement over Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: Friends Return, but Can’t Go Back
abstract: “Shotgun Lovesongs,” Nickolas Butler’s debut novel, is set in Wisconsin and revolves around old friends brought together for a wedding.
lead_paragraph: “Shotgun Lovesongs” is about a hometown in Wisconsin and the close band of friends who will always feel its magnetic pull. Its first-time author, Nickolas Butler, was raised in Eau Claire, which is mentioned in the book as a nearby and even more cosmopolitan place than the tiny, fictitious Little Wing.

headline: A Pakistani Fiancé Meets the Indian Parents
abstract: In “Total Siyapaa,” an Indian woman brings her fiancé home to meet her family, a crew that seems more malicious than madcap.
lead_paragraph: Can a Pakistani boy and an Indian girl find happiness together? That’s the serious question posed by the Bollywood comedy “Total Siyapaa.” At least it would be, if the movie, directed by E. Nivas and written by Neeraj Pandey, didn’t smother its story in uninspired high jinks.

headline: Roller Coasters of Emotion, but Keeping a Tight Grip
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center explored extremes of emotion in works by Dvorak, Schumann and Dohnanyi.
lead_paragraph: “Emotion Unbound” was the title of a program of works by Dvorak, Schumann and Ernst von Dohnanyi that the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented on Friday at Alice Tully Hall. The society has grown fond of such Harlequin Romance-like titles (up next: “Russian Twilight”), and no doubt a certain amount of simplification is inevitable in marketing.

headline: Bringing Vocal Life to a Scholarly Endeavor
abstract: In its program “The Phoenix Rising,” the early-music group Stile Antico paid tribute to the 1920s compendium “Tudor Church Music.”
lead_paragraph: In the acclaim that is doled out to composers and musicians, editors tend to fall through the cracks. But the contributions of these hardworking, often anonymous individuals — who pore over manuscripts, adjudicate divergent details and create playable written versions — should not be underestimated, nor should their role in creating the musical canon. What is performable, after all, tends to overlap significantly with what is performed.

headline: William Clay Ford, Auto Family Scion and Detroit Lions Owner, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Ford, who never got to run the Ford Motor Company, was the last family member to be a confidant of Henry Ford, the American legend who made the automobile accessible to the masses.
lead_paragraph: William Clay Ford, who once steered a car from his grandfather Henry Ford’s lap but, overshadowed by his brash older brother Henry II, never got the chance to run the family business, died on Sunday at his home in Grosse Pointe, Mich. Ford’s last surviving grandchild, he was 88.

headline: Forget Your Troubles With Songs of Hollywood
abstract: Jim Caruso and his sidekick, Billy Stritch, are true believers in old-fashioned vaudeville-descended entertainment as panacea and escape.
lead_paragraph: If you’re nostalgic for those perky TV variety shows when celebrities “dropped in” to chat and share a song and dance, “Jim Caruso’s Cast Party,” a decade-long Monday evening series at Birdland, is a welcoming oasis of traditional show business bonhomie. Its subliminal message: Yes, you can go home again.

headline: Barely Keeping Up in TV’s New Golden Age
abstract: The vast wasteland of television has been replaced by an excess of excellence that is fundamentally altering my media diet and threatening to consume my waking life in the process.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a friend at work told me I absolutely, positively must watch “Broad City” on Comedy Central, saying it was a slacker-infused hilarity.

headline: Inhabiting a Mentor and Heroes of the Stage
abstract: In this solo show at Urban Stages, Jim Brochu recalls Zero Mostel and other Broadway actors who were recognizable if not household names.
lead_paragraph: A few years back, Jim Brochu had a hit with his one-man show, “Zero Hour,” in which he reincarnated the great Zero Mostel. Now, in “Character Man,” a blend of cabaret, theater and scrapbook, he pays homage to a much larger lineup of actors and produces a solidly satisfying evening.

headline: English Team Wins the Junior Camrose
abstract: The Junior Camrose event was held in the La Mon Hotel on the outskirts of Belfast.
lead_paragraph: The more we encourage young players, the better. The British hold two annual junior international events. The Junior Camrose is for players under 25 on Jan. 1. The Peggy Bayer is for under 20s.

headline: After a Lover Flits Away, a Lifetime Spent Waiting
abstract: In “The Red Dress,” a dance performance by the China Ningbo Performance & Arts Group, a woman is left behind with dreams of a marriage that never comes to pass.
lead_paragraph: Fantasies of love vary across time and culture. What seems a dream to some may seem a nightmare to others. Aesthetic ideals vary similarly. When the China Ningbo Performance & Arts Group first presented “The Red Dress” in China, audiences were apparently rapturous. But when I saw the same dance spectacle at the David H. Koch Theater on Friday, my response was much more subdued.

headline: ECO 348, The Great Recession: The Spread of the Crisis
abstract: Europe and America, together at last.
lead_paragraph: Slides here (pdf).

headline: After Prison, Finding Bumps on the Road to Normalcy
abstract: After a stint in prison, Bill is readjusting to freedom in Oklahoma in Emily Schwend’s “Take Me Back,” playing at Walkerspace.
lead_paragraph: The word “good” comes up often in Emily Schwend’s incisive “Take Me Back,” now at Walkerspace, almost always when applied to Bill (James Kautz), an ex-convict living with his mother, Sue (Charlotte Booker), in Muskogee, Okla. She believes in him; after all, he grudgingly dotes on her, urging her to pursue a healthier diet. His high school sweetheart, Julie (Boo Killebrew), has faith in him, too. Married now but disillusioned with her husband, she’s up from Garland, Tex., for her brother’s wedding, and susceptible to the passion that once possessed her and Bill.

headline: Revisiting a Scholar Unmasked by Scandal
abstract: “The Double Life of Paul de Man,” by Evelyn Barish, is the first full biography of the Yale literary theorist who helped turn deconstruction into an insurgent force in American intellectual life.
lead_paragraph: When the Yale literary theorist Paul de Man died in 1983, he was hailed as a brilliant teacher who had helped turn deconstruction, the critical approach originated by Jacques Derrida, into an insurgent force in American intellectual life.

headline: Glimpsing a Lost Paris, Before Gentrification
abstract: Charles Marville, the 19th-century photographer who documented old parts of Paris destined for demolition, turns out to be a man for our time.
lead_paragraph: You might almost think of Charles Marville, the 19th-century photographer, as akin to the guys who drive around mapping streets for Google. He was a hired hand, an illustrator turned photographer near the dawn of the medium. Paris officials enlisted him to document, among other things, new parks and squares but also the streets, shops and tenements scheduled for demolition — to make, in essence, a historical record of a city soon to be lost.

headline: Models Preserve Wright’s Dreams
abstract: A vast Frank Lloyd Wright archive relocated to New York is starting to yield new knowledge about him, including his thinking behind Broadacre City, a vision of a utopian metropolis.
lead_paragraph: Broadacre City was Frank Lloyd Wright’s vision of a utopian metropolis, an orderly version — some would say omen — of the suburban sprawl that would ultimately spring up around American cities starting in the 1950s.

headline: Lazy Scrabble Players, Here’s Your Book
abstract: Stephin Merritt, the songwriter for the Magnetic Fields, has channeled his side passion for Scrabble into a book chronicling all the two-letter words allowed in the game.
lead_paragraph: Stephin Merritt, the songwriter for the Magnetic Fields, has channeled his side passion for Scrabble into a book chronicling all the two-letter words allowed in the game. “101 Two-Letter Words,” to be published in October by W. W. Norton, is a collection of four-line poems by Mr. Merritt, with color illustrations by Roz Chast. “My mother is a former English teacher who always expected me to write the Great American Novel, thunderous and profound, so she was not impressed to learn that my first book is going to be amusing light verse,” Mr. Merritt said by email. “But now that I’ve got her hooked on Words With Friends, she sees the immense value of remembering the two-letter words, and what fascinating little oddities they are, so she’s begging for a copy of the book.”

headline: Some Renewals on Fox
abstract: Fox announced that it had renewed four shows for next season: “The Following,” “New Girl,” “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” and “The Mindy Project.”
lead_paragraph: Fox announced that it had renewed four shows for next season: one drama, “The Following,” and three comedies, “New Girl,” “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” and “The Mindy Project.” The ratings for “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” have been low — its last four episodes averaged only 2.8 million total viewers — but the show won two Golden Globes in January, for best comedy and best leading comedy actor (Andy Samberg). “The Following” and “New Girl” have also struggled when judged by traditional ratings of viewers who watch programs live, but both shows continue to rank among the best in broadcast programming when including viewers in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic who watch using DVRs. The renewal for “The Mindy Project” is more of a surprise. This season it has averaged 2.6 million total viewers, and it is now on a two-month hiatus. It is scheduled to return with new episodes on April 1.

headline: President Xi Strikes Back
abstract: Playing Whack-a-Separatist in China’s Far West.
lead_paragraph: Playing Whack-a-Separatist in China’s Far West.

headline: Lineup Announced For ‘Encores! Off-Center’

lead_paragraph: As a referendum on the future of Crimea approaches, demonstrators in Ukraine and elsewhere in Europe gathered. Some waved Russian flags while others compared Vladimir V. Putin to Hitler.

headline: Get Comfortable
abstract: Kelly Clark returns.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, the big boards of the 37th A.C.P.T. have been put away until next year, and solvers from all over the country are on their way home. If you’re thinking of attending next year, you can always start your training early with this smooth puzzle by Kelly Clark. Ms. Clark offers us a theme that has been seen before (as she mentions in her notes below), but what I liked about her puzzle was the Monday morning smoothness that is so crucial to my solving self-esteem. It reminds me of the kind of flow we experience with an Andrea Carla Michaels puzzle.

headline: Is the Wolf a Real American Hero?
abstract: How an ecological myth obscures the story of Yellowstone.
lead_paragraph: FOR a field biologist stuck in the city, the wildlife dioramas at the American Museum of Natural History are among New York’s best offerings. One recent Saturday, I paused by the display for elk, an animal I study. Like all the dioramas, this one is a great tribute. I have observed elk behavior until my face froze and stared at the data results until my eyes stung, but this scene brought back to me the graceful beauty of a tawny elk cow, grazing the autumn grasses.

lead_paragraph: The Syrian civil war’s impact on the health of Syria’s children is far more insidious than has been widely understood, a leading children’s advocacy group reported Sunday, with large numbers dying or at risk from chronic and preventable diseases that have flourished because the country’s public health system has basically collapsed.

headline: Canada Challenges Erotic TV on Level of Domestic Content
abstract: The regulator contends AOV Adult Movie Channel, AOV XXX Action Clips and AOV Maleflixxx have not ensured that 35 percent of their programming is Canadian, as required.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canada’s broadcasting regulator says that its rules mandating minimum levels of Canadian programming are related to “Canadian artists having access to Canadian airwaves.” An order it issued last week suggests that it has a broad view of what might constitute art.

lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — When it was over, the Wichita State players stood on a podium and looked up as the scoreboard at Scottrade Center played highlights from the Shockers’ run to the Missouri Valley Conference tournament title.

headline: Bridge Scandal Relegates ‘Traffic Study’ to Punch Line
abstract: The scandal surrounding the closing of lanes to the George Washington Bridge in September has sullied the image of the once-staid transportation tool.
lead_paragraph: The slights can come from anywhere now, engineers say, on once-sleepy conference calls and at increasingly charged community meetings, at the dinner table where relatives had typically cared little for details of the job and, unflinchingly, on late-night television.

headline: Liberty, Equality, Efficiency
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Poverty', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Taking action to reduce inequality would probably increase, not reduce, economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Most people, if pressed on the subject, would probably agree that extreme income inequality is a bad thing, although a fair number of conservatives believe that the whole subject of income distribution should be banned from public discourse. (Rick Santorum, the former senator and presidential candidate, wants to ban the term “middle class,” which he says is “class-envy, leftist language.” Who knew?) But what can be done about it?

headline: Little-Known Health Act Fact: Prison Inmates Are Signing Up
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Inmates are taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults — a major part of the prison population.
lead_paragraph: In a little-noticed outcome of President Obama’s Affordable Care Act, jails and prisons around the country are beginning to sign up inmates for health insurance under the law, taking advantage of the expansion of Medicaid that allows states to extend coverage to single and childless adults — a major part of the prison population.

keywords: ['Horses', 'Carriages', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Celebrities']
abstract: Liam Neeson joined supporters of New York City’s horse carriages as he spoke in favor of the industry at Clinton Park Stables.
lead_paragraph: In terms of star wattage, the animal-rights activists fighting to drive horse carriages out of Central Park for good would seem to have the advantage: Alec Baldwin, Gloria Steinem, Lea Michele and Miley Cyrus have all lined up in support of a ban.

headline: Nuns Released by Syrians After Three-Month Ordeal
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Nuns', 'Kidnapping', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Syrian insurgents released 13 nuns and three attendants who disappeared three months ago from their monastery in the ancient Christian town of Maaloula, Lebanese and Syrian officials said early Monday.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian insurgents released 13 nuns and three attendants who disappeared three months ago from their monastery in the ancient Christian town of Maaloula, Lebanese and Syrian officials said early Monday, ending a drama in which rebels said they were protecting the women from government shelling and Syrian officials said they were abducted in an act of intimidation against Christians.

abstract: A newly released trove of internal emails and documents, mostly from 2006 and 2007, paint a troubling picture of how Credit Suisse operated as the housing bubble inflated.
lead_paragraph: The email from a Credit Suisse executive was blunt: The bank seemed to be pushing through risky home mortgages from questionable applicants.

headline: Louisville Confronts Elephant in Its Room
abstract: The Cardinals’ women’s basketball team has made great strides, but it cannot ignore the mammoth task before it: Overcoming a dominant Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: UNCASVILLE, Conn. — For all the strides the Louisville women have made in becoming a perennial basketball power, the climb to the top remains daunting. Connecticut, the Cardinals’ opponent in the final of the American Athletic Conference tournament Monday night, has won 14 straight against them.

headline: China’s Disturbing Defense Budget
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The hefty increases raise legitimate concerns about the country’s intentions that Beijing should seek to dispel.
lead_paragraph: China is causing new anxieties in Asia with a defense budget for 2014 that totals $132 billion, up 12.2 percent over the previous year. These numbers should not be used as an excuse to ratchet up America’s military spending. But they do raise legitimate concerns about China’s motives that Beijing should seek to dispel, especially at a time when regional tensions are rising.

headline: An Expensive and Unnecessary Election
abstract: The extra New York State primary will cost state taxpayers $50 million for their trouble.
lead_paragraph: New York State is poised to put voters through another needlessly expensive election year. Instead of taking the sensible route — one primary to pick party candidates and one general election to pick ultimate winners — New York is scheduled to have an extra primary. That means three elections when two are enough. The extra primary will cost state taxpayers $50 million for their trouble.

headline: Good Steps Against Unpaid Internships
keywords: ['Internships', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: New York University and Columbia are setting a good example by tightening their policies on employers.
lead_paragraph: The National Association of Colleges and Employers reported last year that nearly half of the internships taken by college students in the class of 2013 were unpaid. Many of these arrangements (often temporary, low-level jobs with dubious educational merit) may violate federal labor guidelines, which say that unpaid internships at for-profit companies must be “for the benefit of the intern” and that the employer may not derive an “immediate advantage from the activities of the intern.” Yet colleges, through their career sites, frequently end up promoting internships that disregard these guidelines.

headline: A Sentencing Commission for California
abstract: The state should follow a proven path to clearing out its overcrowded prisons and permanently fix its penal system.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, California voters overwhelmingly passed the “three strikes” law that has come to symbolize America’s deeply irrational and misguided obsession with harsh and inflexible sentencing. It set a life sentence for anyone with a third felony conviction, no matter how minor or nonviolent — even for stealing a pair of socks.

headline: Emails Show Shared Concern of False Testimony in Army Sexual Assault Case
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Courts-Martial', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Emails released by military prosecutors indicated that other officers discussed whether the chief accuser of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair might have testified untruthfully.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers defending Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on sexual assault charges are renewing claims that the case against him has been tainted by the influence of senior officials in the Pentagon, citing emails that military prosecutors turned over during the weekend.

headline: Mexican Drug Lord, Thought Dead in 2010, Is Reported Killed
abstract: Nazario Moreno González, a leader of a powerful criminal gang now known as the Knights Templar, was likely killed in a shootout with federal forces, Mexican officials said.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In the annals of the Mexican criminal underworld, the son of a powerful drug lord was announced captured and paraded before cameras only for the authorities to later discover they had the wrong guy. Another gang leader was killed, but then associates stole the body. On Sunday, a kingpin presumed dead for more than three years reappeared in the news, to be declared really dead this time.

headline: Deconstructing God
abstract: Can reading abstruse French theory lead to religious belief?
lead_paragraph: This is the third in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is John D. Caputo, a professor of religion and humanities at Syracuse University and the author of “The Prayers and Tears of Jacques Derrida: Religion Without Religion.”

headline: What a Way to Make a Living
abstract: Is the 9-to-5 approach to "full time" still ideal for employers and workers, or is it just a relic?

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The Albany lacrosse coaches stared at a small projector screen, searching for the black streak of a three-foot-long ponytail swooping toward the goal.

headline: Jackson Mourns Mayor With Militant Past Who Won Over Skeptics
abstract: When Jackson, Miss., said goodbye to Mayor Chokwe Lumumba this weekend, blacks and whites, for a change, largely united in mourning.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Many people here still do not entirely know what to make of the mayor with the unusual name and even more unexpected résumé, who proudly embraced the term “militant” and to many was still the same dashiki-wearing firebrand who first came to prominence advocating an independent black nation in the South in the early 1970s.

headline: Dressed Like Woods, but With Better-Looking Swing, Reed Wins at Doral
abstract: Patrick Reed, wearing red and black, held off Bubba Watson and Jamie Donaldson to finish at four under and win by one shot at the World Golf Championships event in Doral, Fla.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — From his first shot on the practice range to his final stroke in a par 72, the man in red and black was dialed in Sunday at the World Golf Championships at Trump National Doral. Patrick Reed had decided to adopt Tiger Woods’s signature Sunday outfit after he took his first 54-hole lead in a PGA Tour event, at last year’s Wyndham Championship.

keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Landlords']

lead_paragraph: For years, tenants have complained that the city board that sets rents for about one million New York apartments has favored landlords.

headline: New York Public Radio Receives Grant for $10 Million
abstract: The public radio entity will use most of its gift from the Jerome L. Greene Foundation to support the development of digital operations, including a new feature on the WNYC mobile app.
lead_paragraph: New York Public Radio will announce on Monday that it has received a $10 million grant from the Jerome L. Greene Foundation, which it says is the largest single gift ever made to a public radio station.

headline: Nets Shrug Off More Injuries to Rise Above .500 Again
abstract: The Nets bounced back from a poor performance in Boston with a home win against Sacramento, but Paul Pierce and Andrei Kirilenko were injured.
lead_paragraph: The Nets bounced back from an unsightly loss with a 104-89 win over the Sacramento Kings at Barclays Center on Sunday, but they lost forwards Paul Pierce and Andrei Kirilenko to injuries in the process, raising more concerns about the health of some of their veterans as the regular season enters its final stretch.

headline: Lessons From Fukushima
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Three years after a meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant, the crisis is still unfolding. In the United States, the disaster served as a warning to the nuclear industry.
lead_paragraph: Three years after a meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant, the crisis is still unfolding. In the United States, the disaster served as a warning to the nuclear industry.

headline: After Fukushima, Utilities Prepare for Worst
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Exelon, which operates 17 of the 100 commercial power reactors in the United States, will spend $400 million to $500 million in post-Fukushima fixes.
lead_paragraph: PEACH BOTTOM, Pa. — Stored near the twin nuclear reactors here, safely above the flood level of the Susquehanna River, is a gleaming new six-wheel pickup truck with a metal blade on the front that can plow away debris from an earthquake or other disaster. Attached to the back is a trailer that carries a giant diesel-powered pump that can deliver 500 gallons of water a minute.

headline: Game With No Winner Ends in Shared Title
abstract: After regulation, seven overtimes and a 1-1 tie, the Ohio high school hockey state championship game was halted by state officials and the competing teams were declared co-champions.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — As each overtime gave way to the next, the expectation for a thrilling and historic conclusion multiplied during the Ohio high school hockey state championship Saturday night in Columbus.

headline: Now Comes Hard Part for G.M.: The Repairs
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: General Motors’ recall of 1.6 million cars is a time-consuming process with many steps, including designing and testing the new parts, finding and informing owners, then fixing the vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month after General Motors announced it would recall 1.6 million cars because of a defective ignition switch, the automaker now faces an arduous task: fixing the cars.

abstract: Young people who want to choose their own mates face the harsh reality that strict social traditions still trump new laws and expanded rights — and that honor killings in such cases remain endemic.

lead_paragraph: Mohammad Ali, 21, fears for his life after publicly declaring his love for Zakia, 18.

keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Software']

lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s plans to retire its Windows XP operating system have raised concerns in China, which has been slow to upgrade its computers.

headline: Manhattan Community Papers Revamped Under New Editor
abstract: Kyle Pope, Pulitzer Prize winner and former top editor of The New York Observer, is now running five small community newspapers in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Pope once shared in a Pulitzer Prize at The Wall Street Journal and served as the top editor of The New York Observer. So when he recently took a job running five small community newspapers in Manhattan, it raised eyebrows in New York’s gossipy and insular media world.

headline: In the Details of Passengers’ Lives, Signs of Hope and Prosperity
abstract: The passengers bound for China on Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 represented a vivid cross-section of a nation well into an economic transformation: artists and corporate salespeople, foreign businesspeople and technology firm employees.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It was one of his first trips abroad, maybe even the first. Wang Moheng was just shy of his second birthday. His parents took him and two of his grandparents to the tropics of Malaysia, with its sunshine and moist air and blue skies.

headline: Dreams of a More Streamlined Car-Buying Process, With Technology as Facilitator
abstract: The industry model is changing, as consumers no longer depend on dealers to learn about cars, and automakers try to sell their vehicles more directly.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — For generations, the auto dealer has been the primary avenue for carmakers to sell vehicles to consumers.

headline: The Intrepid Paralympic Racers on Their Skiing Machines
abstract: Mono-skiers competing in the sitting super-G are comparable to bicyclists riding on snow slopes.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — Heath Calhoun was disappointed by how he fared in his ski race at the Paralympic Games on Sunday. He was hoping to win a medal. He was expecting to win a medal. He did not. He came in fourth. He was not satisfied, but in one way he was, because he crossed the finish line.

headline: Medals, With Little Guidance
abstract: Mark Bathum and Mac Marcoux won silver and bronze in their visually impaired Paralympic super-G race despite trouble in finding and hearing their guides.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — It was difficult to determine the greater accomplishment Sunday: that Mark Bathum and Mac Marcoux won silver and bronze in their visually impaired super-G race at the Paralympic Games, or that they made it safely down the course at all.

headline: Warm Weather Brings Out Banned Vehicles, and Officers Pounce
keywords: ['ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES (ATV)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']

lead_paragraph: Legions of dirt bikes and all-terrain vehicles descended on Upper Manhattan over the weekend, their engines howling on bridges to and from the Bronx and echoing through the residential corridors of Harlem.

headline: El Salvador’s Presidential Election Close at the Wire
abstract: With almost all the vote counted, the governing party’s candidate, Salvador Sánchez Cerén, was fewer than 6,500 votes ahead of his opponent, Norman Quijano.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — El Salvador’s presidential race ended in a razor-close finish Sunday, a surprising turn after opinion polls had given the governing party’s candidate, Salvador Sánchez Cerén, a double-digit lead.
