lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Last century, it was Microsoft versus Apple. A decade ago, it was Google against Yahoo.

headline: House Republicans Balk at Wording in Obama Emergency Aid Package for Ukraine
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: The administration’s proposal would extend a billion-dollar package of loans from the International Monetary Fund to $1.6 billion by expanding loan limits for countries like Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An emergency aid package for the beleaguered Ukrainian government has become entangled in a partisan dispute over the International Monetary Fund, with House Republicans resisting President Obama’s personal pleas to extend the reach of a Ukraine rescue plan by including long-sought changes to the fund’s structure.

headline: McMartin Preschool: Anatomy of a Panic
abstract: In 1984, news reports that hundreds of children had been abused at a California preschool helped spread panic across the nation. But the case was not all it seemed and its impact continues to be felt.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, news reports that hundreds of children had been abused at a California preschool helped spread panic across the nation. But the case was not all it seemed and its impact continues to be felt.

headline: Spalding’s Australian Baseball Tour
abstract: Some 125 years ago, in October 1888, Albert Spalding, a former player and part owner of the Chicago White Stockings arranged for two teams to embark on a round-the-world tour.
lead_paragraph: Some 125 years ago, in October 1888, Albert Spalding, a former player and part owner of the Chicago White Stockings arranged for two teams to embark on a round-the-world tour.

headline: Ex-President Wins a Seat in Colombia
abstract: Álvaro Uribe, one of the most vocal critics of peace negotiations between the government and the country’s main guerrilla group, was elected to the Senate.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Voters in Colombia on Sunday elected former President Álvaro Uribe to the Senate, increasing the influence of one of the most vocal critics of peace negotiations between the government and the country’s main guerrilla group.

headline: The Trial That Unleashed Hysteria Over Child Abuse
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The McMartin Preschool trial began in 1987 after accusations of sexual abuse and satanic rituals from a mother whose mental instability later became an issue in the case.
lead_paragraph: Early in the 19th century, two unmarried women who ran a school for girls in Edinburgh found themselves accused by a student of being lesbians. The charge, quite grave in that era, was baseless, and in time the women won a libel suit. But not before they had lost everything, including their school. If this story rings a bell, it may be because Lillian Hellman used it as a starting point for “The Children’s Hour,” her 1934 play about a couple of schoolteachers whose lives similarly come unraveled after a malicious student falsely accuses them of lesbianism.

headline: Australia, Baseball’s Diamond in Rough
abstract: The Diamondbacks and the Dodgers will play two exhibition games and a two-game, season-opening series in Sydney, but it is not the first time professional American baseball journeyed to Australia.
lead_paragraph: When Albert Spalding arranged a world tour for his Chicago White Stockings and a team of all-stars that included stops in Australia in December 1888, the baseball writer Henry Chadwick hailed it as “the great event in the modern history of athletic sports.”

headline: 6-Foot-8 Pitcher Finds New Role in Comeback
abstract: Dellin Betances, once a part of a trio of Yankees starting pitching prospects dubbed the “Killer B’s,” is attempting to reinvent himself as a reliever and break into the Major League club.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Headlines do not come looking for Dellin Betances anymore. Not as they did two years ago, when there was so much to like and so much to write about.

headline: ‘Girls’ Recap: Hannah Tries on a  Wig, Lingerie and Campy Dialogue
abstract: Hannah’s relationship with Adam officially enters the doldrums.
lead_paragraph: “Girls” has been touted for mirroring the socio-sexual landscape twenty-somethings navigate these days: porn-influenced liaisons, bleak job prospects, millennial entitlement.

headline: Jack Belliveau, Explorer of the Brain Using M.R.I., Dies at 55
abstract: Dr. Belliveau was a Harvard scientist whose quest to capture the quicksilver flare of thought inside a living brain led to the first magnetic resonance image of human brain function.
lead_paragraph: Jack Belliveau, a Harvard scientist whose quest to capture the quicksilver flare of thought inside a living brain led to the first magnetic resonance image of human brain function, died on Feb. 14 in San Mateo, Calif. He was 55.

headline: Little Choice but to Hope Tejada Can Handle Job
abstract: Ruben Tejada is a subject of intense focus in spring training as the Mets try to determine if he can handle the starting job at shortstop.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Perhaps no Met has been scrutinized more during this year’s spring training than Ruben Tejada.

headline: A Kiev Question: What Became of the Missing?
abstract: Since protests began in Ukraine last December, 661 people have been reported missing, and the fates of 272 of them remained unknown late last week.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Volodymyr Danyluk was a Soviet Army veteran who joined demonstrations against Ukraine’s government last year. He was 55 years old, separated from his wife and mostly out of contact with his family, who saw him on live television during a winter of protests.

headline: N.C.A.A. Men’s Conference Tournament Previews
abstract: For a number of teams, an invitation to the N.C.A.A. tournament will rely upon a strong showing in this week’s conference tournaments.
lead_paragraph: With Selection Sunday right around the corner, here is a look at some of the top story lines at this week’s conference tournaments and who should be moving on to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Fears of Impending Change Darken Normally Lighthearted Odessa
abstract: As Crimea prepares for a referendum on joining the Russian Federation, residents in Odessa and in other Russian-speaking areas throughout the south and the east of Ukraine find themselves swaying, to greater and lesser degrees, between east and west.
lead_paragraph: ODESSA, Ukraine — In a joke making the rounds in this city famous for its humor, wry and dark at the best of times, two condemned prisoners are talking on death row. One suggests they try to run away, but the other says, “No, that will only make things worse.”

headline: After Big Bet, Hedge Fund Pulls the Levers of Power
abstract: The activist hedge fund manager William A. Ackman bet a billion dollars on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, then launched an extraordinary campaign to hasten that development.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a Midtown Manhattan steakhouse last June, William A. Ackman, the activist hedge fund manager who had bet a billion dollars on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, offered his latest evidence to a handful of other hedge fund managers about why the company’s stock could soon plummet.

headline: Orthodox New York City Jews Protest Proposed Israeli Draft
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews gathered in Lower Manhattan on Sunday to protest Israel’s proposal to include strictly religious citizens in its military draft.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews gathered in Lower Manhattan on Sunday to protest Israel’s proposal to include strictly religious citizens in its military draft.

headline: New Movie Studio Is Formed, With China and Self-Distribution in Mind
abstract: A group is looking to make $40 million movies with big stars, as an alternative to the blockbusters now favored by Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, the Hollywood producer Robert Simonds Jr. began thinking about how a movie studio for today’s age — with the ascendance of China and a dizzying array of distribution channels — should look.

headline: Use of Public Transit in U.S. Reaches Highest Level Since 1956, Advocates Report
abstract: Crediting economic growth and better service, a trade group reported 10.65 billion passenger trips last year despite a drop in gasoline prices.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — More Americans used buses, trains and subways in 2013 than in any year since 1956 as service improved, local economies grew and travelers increasingly sought alternatives to the automobile for trips within metropolitan areas, the American Public Transportation Association said in a report released on Monday.

headline: Letter From Linda Sánchez
abstract: Representative Linda T. Sánchez, Democrat of California, sent a letter to the F.T.C. asking it to investigate Herbalife. Mr. Ackman obtained a copy of the letter before it was made public.
lead_paragraph: Representative Linda T. Sánchez, Democrat of California, sent a letter to the F.T.C. asking it to investigate Herbalife. Mr. Ackman obtained a copy of the letter before it was made public.

headline: Five Nearly Identical Letters
abstract: Five people in Connecticut sent letters with very similar language urging the Federal Trade Commission to open an investigation into Herbalife.
lead_paragraph: Five people in Connecticut sent letters with very similar language urging the Federal Trade Commission to open an investigation into Herbalife.

headline: A Grassroots Video, With Help From a Billionaire
abstract: Make the Road New York, a nonprofit advocacy group for Latinos, promoted this video showing people who said they were hurt by Herbalife.
lead_paragraph: Make the Road New York, a nonprofit advocacy group for Latinos, promoted this video showing people who said they were hurt by Herbalife.

headline: A Senator’s Letter, and a Stock’s Fall
abstract: On Jan. 23, Senator Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts sent letters asking the F.T.C. and S.E.C. to look into Herbalife. The letters were based at least in part on research that William A. Ackman’s firm provided. Herbalife stock fell by 14 percent.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 23, Senator Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts sent letters asking the F.T.C. and S.E.C. to look into Herbalife. The letters were based at least in part on research that William A. Ackman’s firm provided. Herbalife stock fell by 14 percent.

headline: A Ski Race With Horsepower
abstract: Horse culture meets ski culture at the self-proclaimed world skijoring championships in Whitefish, Mont. The event touts itself as the “biggest party on snow.”
lead_paragraph: When the tans and browns of the cowboy intermingle with the neon and pastel of the powder hound, it signals the start of the self-proclaimed world skijoring championships in Whitefish, Mont. One finds glory in the dirt, and the other bravery in the snow. For two days in January, they unite as a team of horse, rider and skier to prove who is fastest.

headline: Seeking a Killer and a Benign Universe
abstract: The eight-part story in the first season of “True Detective” concluded with philosophical questions answered for its heroes, played by Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson.
lead_paragraph: As is so often the case on crime shows, the two partners in “True Detective” followed a hunch and went straight into the killer’s lair on their own, without backup. They had each other’s backs.

headline: Photo Replay: March 2-8
abstract: This week’s criteria: simply beautiful, as in elegant compositions, extraordinary light, singular moments.
lead_paragraph: This week’s criteria: simply beautiful, as in elegant compositions, extraordinary light, singular moments.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Facebook usage remained constant at 58 percent from 2013 to 2014, while Instagram grew from 12 to 19 percent overall. Snapchat surged 10 points to 13 percent penetration, and is used by 46 percent of younger users.
lead_paragraph: Facebook usage remained constant at 58 percent from 2013 to 2014, while Instagram grew from 12 to 19 percent overall. Snapchat surged 10 points to 13 percent penetration, and is used by 46 percent of younger users.

headline: Nigerians Ask Why Oil Funds Are Missing
abstract: In recent years, government commissions, parliamentary inquiries and civil society groups have all pointed to serious shortfalls in the disbursement of oil revenues.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — Even in a country where untold oil wealth disappears into the pockets of the elite, the oil corruption scheme he was investigating seemed outsize — and he threatened to lay it bare at a meeting with Nigeria’s top bankers.

headline: Times Minute | Details for Flight MH370
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Lacrosse', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'College Athletics', 'Football (College)']
abstract: Also on the Minute, Edward J. Snowden is set to make an appearance at SXSW, and three relatives dominate in college lacrosse.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Edward J. Snowden is set to make an appearance at SXSW, and three relatives dominate in college lacrosse.
