headline: BlackRock Hires New Head of China Equities
abstract: BlackRock, the world’s largest asset-management company, said it had hired Helen Zhu, a former Goldman Sachs executive, as a managing director and head of its China equities business.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — BlackRock, the world’s largest asset-management company, said on Monday that it had hired Helen Zhu as a managing director and head of its China equities business.

headline: Corrections: March 10, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 10, 2014
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Night of Song, Delivered With Passion and Heart
abstract: Vittorio Grigolo sang expressively and with solid technique throughout his Sunday recital at the Met, although sometimes his melodramatic effects resulted in uneven phrasing.
lead_paragraph: After finishing his recital at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday evening, the tenor Vittorio Grigolo sank to one knee while acknowledging the applause, then tossed his handkerchief into the audience. “I’m crying inside,” he said from the stage, adding, “I am trying to give you all of my heart.”

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (NBC) BELIEVE Alfonso Cuarón, who just won the Oscar for best director for “Gravity,” created this faith-based series, which counts J. J. Abrams among its executive producers. The story follows Bo (Johnny Sequoyah, above), a lovely 10-year-old girl with Christlike powers and a cult following of adults, led by Milton Winter (Delroy Lindo) and a wrongfully imprisoned death-row convict named Tate (Jake McLaughlin), intent on protecting her from those — among them, the tycoon Skouras (Kyle MacLachlan) — who would use her talents for evil. “Mr. Cuarón directed the pilot, and the opening scene, a car crash shot from the passengers’ point of view, is genuinely shocking,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “But the characters don’t live up to the swirling, often violent action that surrounds them.”

headline: The Red Faces of the Solar Skeptics
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: Solar energy is becoming more economically viable, with happy consequences for consumers but not for the fossil fuel industry, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is professor emerita of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Word of the Day | untenable
abstract: This word has appeared in 118 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: untenable •\ˌən-ˈte-nə-bəl\• adjective

headline: Life’s Guarantees: Death, Taxes and 7.5% Chinese G.D.P. Growth
abstract: A researcher at China’s economic planning agency is offering what Prime Minister Li Keqiang won’t: a guarantee that the country’s economy will hit its growth target this year.
lead_paragraph: Few things in life are guaranteed, but a researcher at China’s powerful economic planning agency says one thing is assured: 7.5 percent growth this year.

headline: ‘Cleanest Village’ Questions Its Blessings Amid Influx of Visitors
abstract: Mawlynnong, a village in the northeastern state of Meghalaya, struggles to maintain its reputation as a pristine ecotourism destination against an onslaught of tourists.
lead_paragraph: MAWLYNNONG, India — Anshuman Sen was barely a year out of college when, in 2005, he traveled to Meghalaya, a hilly northeastern state distant both in miles and cultural resemblance from what the locals call “mainland India.”

headline: Managing the Discussion of the Missing Malaysian Jet
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: China’s authorities are juggling public grief and anger over the disappearance of a Malaysian airliner with what they really want high in the public mind: the current session of the National People’s Congress.
lead_paragraph: As frustration and anger deepened in China over the unexplained disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 with 239, mostly Chinese, people on board, the Chinese government sought on Monday to balance a swirl of imperatives:

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Airplane Goes Missing in Malaysia
abstract: What avenues are investigators pursuing as they search for the missing airplane in Malaysia?
lead_paragraph: In “Passport Theft Adds to Mystery of Missing Malaysia Airlines Jet,” Thomas Fuller and Eric Schmitt write about a Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared en-route to Beijing on Saturday morning. In “Search for Jet Yielding Only More Mystery,” Thomas Fuller writes about the subsequent search efforts.

headline: Japan Won’t Alter Apology to World War II Sex Slaves
abstract: After rising criticism from South Korea, where many of the women came from, a top official said the government had no intention of rethinking the 1993 statement.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan will not revise a landmark apology to women forced to work in military brothels during World War II even as it moves ahead with a review of the testimony used to create that apology, a spokesman for the Japanese government said Monday.

headline: How Much Time Do You Spend Outdoors?
abstract: How often do you go for a walk, jog or bike ride in your community?
lead_paragraph: With spring just around the corner, people will soon be spending more time outdoors.

headline: Chiquita Buys Ireland’s Fyffes to Go Global in Banana Business
abstract: The combined companies, which will be named ChiquitaFyffes, will be the world’s largest producer and distributor of bananas and will have about $4.6 billion in annual revenue.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:39 p.m. | The banana is the king of fruit, outselling apples, oranges and all the rest. And now the king of bananas will be Chiquita Brands International.

headline: Test Yourself | E.L.L. Practice, March 10, 2014
abstract: Fill in the blanks in a passage from an article about a contemporary artist.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Unilever Acquires Majority Stake in Chinese Water-Purification Company
abstract: The deal for Qinyuan Group represents Unilever’s largest acquisition in China in more than a decade. The maker of water purifiers and other drinking water equipment had annual sales of about $200 million last year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British-Dutch consumer goods giant Unilever said Monday that it had acquired a majority stake in the Chinese water purification company Qinyuan Group, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Life and Happiness in Siberia’s Cold
abstract: Departing from the images of frozen exile and gulags, a group of Russian photographers has compiled a nuanced portrait of a legendary, if misunderstood, region.
lead_paragraph: For outsiders, Siberia evokes images of harsh winters, political exile and a lone railway that winds through the mysterious landscape. But as Anton Chekhov once said, “Even in Siberia, there is happiness.”

headline: Ackman vs. Herbalife, a History
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A look at some of the crucial events in William A. Ackman’s fight over the nutritional supplements company Herbalife.
lead_paragraph: William A. Ackman’s giant financial bet against Herbalife is being played out in the corridors of government, Michael S. Schmidt, Eric Lipton and Alexandra Stevenson report in The New York Times. The reporters found that Mr. Ackman’s team had “organized protests, news conferences and letter-writing campaigns in California, Nevada, Connecticut, New York and Illinois, and several of the people who signed the letters to state and federal officials say they do not remember sending them.”

headline: GlaxoSmithKline Increases Stake in Indian Pharmaceutical Unit
abstract: The British drug giant GlaxoSmithKline said it paid about $1.05 billion to increase its stake in GlaxoSmithKline Pharmaceuticals Limited to 75 percent from 50.7 percent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – GlaxoSmithKline said on Monday that it had increased its stake in its Indian pharmaceutical subsidiary to 75 percent, in a transaction valued at more than $1 billion.

headline: Left Hand Among Bones
abstract: Two children of the disappeared know the nature of endless loss.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — In the end it was his father’s left hand, found a couple of years ago in a pile of charred bones outside La Plata, that enabled Gonzalo Reggiardo Tolosa to know for a fact the man he never knew was dead. This was physical knowledge, different from the almost-certain supposition with which he had lived ever since he discovered as a boy in the late 1980s that the couple who raised him and his twin brother Matías were not his parents.

headline: 10 Words Entrepreneurs Should Use With Caution
abstract: Sprinkle these words through any conversation about entrepreneurship, and you will sound progressive. But think about what you are really saying.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I did a workshop with some young entrepreneurs — mostly, I would say, between 24 and 38 — and I soon realized that in this new and enlightened age, every conversation about entrepreneurship seems to include the same 10 words, words that have become a new jargon. At the same time, one very important but old-fashioned word seems to have been all but forgotten.

headline: Visualizing the Dynamics of the Labor Market
abstract: A new graphical tool from the New York Fed allows users to study eight aspects of the labor market, including the mismatch between job skills and openings.
lead_paragraph: Since the end of the recession in 2009 and through the long stop-and-go recovery, the labor market has emerged as one of the most closely watched, not to mention worrying, parts of the economy.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 10, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Update: March 11

headline: Reckitt Benckiser Buys K-Y Lubricants Brand From Johnson & Johnson
abstract: The British consumer goods company Reckitt Benckiser, which owns the Durex brand of condoms, said no fixed assets or employees were included in the deal, which is expected to close in mid-2014.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British consumer goods company Reckitt Benckiser said on Monday that it had acquired the rights to the K-Y brand of personal lubricants from Johnson & Johnson.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft Pins Hopes for Xbox One on Titanfall
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: The company is betting that a new science-fiction shooting game will be enough of a hit to improve sales of the Xbox One and secure its influence in the video-game market.
lead_paragraph: A video game that depicts a battle between corporate mercenaries and local brigands in far-off space colonies has already won the hearts and minds of Microsoft executives. Now those Microsoft bosses hope the game, Titanfall, will win over enough consumers to pump up sales of Xbox One, the company’s flagship gaming console. Xbox One sales are trailing those of a machine from Sony, Microsoft’s main rival, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: HGGC to Buy Serena Software From Silver Lake
abstract: The financial terms of the transaction were not disclosed, but people briefed on the matter said HGGC paid about $450 million for the enterprise software maker. That price is substantially less than the $1.2 billion Silver Lake paid in 2006.
lead_paragraph: After eight years, Serena Software has found a new home.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Todd Balf on the Coming Changes to the SAT
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'E-Learning', 'Parenting', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Long before the College Board announced that it was changing the SAT, Todd Balf was reporting on why and how they were overhauling the exams.
lead_paragraph: Todd Balf wrote this week’s cover story on the College Board’s decision to overhaul the SAT. Balf is the author of several books, including “Major,” the story of Marshall Taylor, one of the first African-American athletes to become internationally famous.

headline: New York Today: Spending Those Daylight Savings
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: evening light returns, cloudy skies, and the city is sued over charter schools.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning to you.

headline: Live Reporting on Autopsy Banned at Pistorius Trial
abstract: Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star, was reported to have vomited during a pathologist’s testimony.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star accused of murdering his girlfriend, vomited repeatedly in the courtroom on Monday as a pathologist gave graphic evidence about her injuries. News coverage of the testimony was restricted by a sweeping ban on live broadcasting or reporting on Twitter.

headline: Ackman’s Battle to Bring Down Herbalife
abstract: William A. Ackman and his lobbying effort to bring down Herbalife. | Documents point to mortgage lapses at Credit Suisse. | A judge rules against R.B.C. over the lender’s advice in a 2011 buyout. | Bankers go to great lengths to get credit for deals, even if they did not advise on them.
lead_paragraph: After staking $1 billion on the collapse of the nutritional supplement company Herbalife, William A. Ackman’s activist hedge fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, has been lobbying aggressively to bring it down, Michael S. Schmidt, Eric Lipton and Alexandra Stevenson write in The New York Times. Others have criticized the business practices of Herbalife, which sells vitamins and other supplements through independent distributors, but Mr. Ackman’s attack is “unprecedented in its scale,” they write. For its part, Herbalife continues to strongly deny his accusations that the company is a pyramid scheme.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: The footwear brand Sanuk selected Ignited and Johnson & Wales University in Providence, R.I., hired Fuseideas as agencies of record.
lead_paragraph: Bailey Lauerman, Omaha, was chosen to handle four accounts. The new clients are the Branson/Lakes Area Convention and Visitors Bureau, Branson, Mo.; IMG Academy, Bradenton, Fla.; the Mutual Fund Store, Overland Park, Kan.; and Panda Express, Rosemead, Calif. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: FMC to Split Up by Spinning Off Its Minerals Division
abstract: The move by the FMC Corporation, a chemical maker, is the latest by a company to try to create more value for its shareholders by spinning off nonessential divisions.
lead_paragraph: The FMC Corporation, a chemical maker, said on Monday that it planned to divide itself in two by spinning off its minerals business.

headline: Jon Favreau on ‘Chef’
keywords: ['Movies', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The actor and director discusses his film about a popular chef who reaches a turning point in his life.
lead_paragraph: The actor and director discusses his film about a popular chef who reaches a turning point in his life.

headline: Frustration Over Malaysian Flight Turns to Anger
abstract: Insults and water bottles were thrown at Malaysia Airlines staff members in Beijing over the lack of information about what has happened to Flight MH370.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — It was not an easy meeting. The four Malaysia Airlines employees stood with their hands by their sides at the front of a stuffy room in a Beijing hotel on Monday morning, delivering yet more unwelcome news about the missing Flight MH370, and dodging water bottles hurled by irate listeners.

headline: In Latest Metro-North Accident, Worker Is Fatally Struck by Train in East Harlem
abstract: The man was working on the tracks at 106th Street and Park Avenue early Monday morning, according to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
lead_paragraph: A Metro-North Railroad worker was struck and killed by a train in East Harlem early Monday morning, officials said, the latest in a string of devastating accidents for the railroad over the past year.

headline: Boston Plans to Tighten Security at Marathon
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Boston Marathon']
abstract: Security challenges will be immense, as the route covers 26.2-miles in eight cities and towns along a path lined by spectators on both sides.
lead_paragraph: FRAMINGHAM, Mass. — Over the long, cold winter, Boston has been preparing a ceremony to honor those killed and injured in the bombings at last year’s marathon and to stage a race this year that will be one of the biggest — and, they said Monday, the safest.

headline: From Icahn, a Wall Street Billionaire’s Version of Monopoly
abstract: The activist investor posted a photograph to Twitter showing an artist’s rendering of “Icahnopoly: The Activist Edition,” an imagined board game reworking Monopoly. In this version, Park Place becomes Herbalife, and there is no jail.
lead_paragraph: The boardroom battles waged by the activist investor Carl C. Icahn have drawn comparisons to poker. But Mr. Icahn apparently prefers to think of his career in terms of a different game: Monopoly.

headline: Video: Jon Favreau on ‘Chef’ at SXSW
abstract: At the South by Southwest film festival, the actor and director discusses his film about a popular chef who reaches a turning point in his life.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — With his latest film “Chef,” the actor and filmmaker Jon Favreau takes a break from directing large-scale Hollywood films to tell the more intimate story of a popular chef at a crossroads in his life. The movie, which includes a segment shot here, opened the South by Southwest film festival on Friday. In this video interview, conducted at QUI restaurant, Mr. Favreau discusses  the food-related films that inspired him and the hands-on training he received from the chef Roy Choi. “Chef” is set to open nationwide May 9.

headline: First Charges Filed in $30 Billion Coal Scandal
abstract: Navabharat Power, now a unit of Essar Power, and its two former owners are accused of criminal conspiracy in its bid for a coal block.
lead_paragraph: India’s central investigating agency on Monday filed its first formal charges in a $30 billion coal mining scandal in which the government allotted the rights to develop coal blocks to private companies at negotiated prices rather than in an auction.

headline: Russia’s Grip Tightens With Shows of Force at Ukrainian Bases
abstract: In one of several swift but thus far bloodless escalations, Russian forces raided a Ukrainian naval missile base in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: CHORNOMORSKOYE, Ukraine — Russian forces raided a Ukrainian naval missile base here in the darkness of early Monday, scaling its outer walls and outmatching the surprised sailors inside without firing a shot, according to the Ukrainian Ministry of Defense and people familiar with the raid.

headline: EBay Rejects Icahn’s Nominees for Its Board
abstract: EBay said that it had rejected Carl C. Icahn’s two nominees for its board and instead chose to renominate every director up for re-election this year. Separately, Mr. Icahn published another criticism of the company’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: The weekslong battle of words between eBay and Carl C. Icahn has heated up.

headline: Rolled Oats With Amaranth Seeds, Maple Syrup and Apple
abstract: Amaranth and apple contribute texture and sweetness to this morning bowl.
lead_paragraph: Grated apple adds a fresh, zesty dimension to just about any bowl of hot (or cold) cereal. The little amaranth seeds contribute protein, lysine and calcium to this mix. They will soften overnight, but they retain texture, which is one of the things I like about the combo.

headline: Steel-Cut Oats With Amaranth Seeds, Chia Seeds and Blueberries
abstract: Amaranth and chia seeds pump up the nutritional content of this sweet and hearty morning bowl.
lead_paragraph: Fresh blueberries are not in season at the moment, so I put my frozen organic wild blueberries to good use in this hearty mix. The chia and the amaranth pump up the nutritional value of this cereal — both are high in calcium, amaranth is high in protein, and chia seeds are a great source of healthful omega-3s. They also contribute texture. For even more great texture, top the cereal with chopped toasted hazelnuts or almonds.

headline: Oatmeal and Teff With Cinnamon and Dried Fruit
abstract: Cinnamon and dried fruit sweeten this oatmeal/teff mix.
lead_paragraph: I wanted to make a porridge with teff alone, but I just didn’t like the flavor enough. So I added some of those tiny high-protein, high-calcium, gluten-free seeds to oatmeal, along with chopped dried apricots, golden raisins and cinnamon. Chopped toasted hazelnuts are my first choice for topping.

headline: Sweet Oven-Baked Grits and Millet With Pecans and Maple Syrup
abstract: This sweet and grainy polenta makes a delicious brunch dish.
lead_paragraph: This is one of the two longer-cooking breakfast grain dishes this week. It takes about 1 hour 10 minutes in the oven, so it might be more practical for a weekend breakfast. Grits are much like polenta, and traditionally served as a savory dish, often with cheese added. Here I mixed the grits with the higher-protein millet, and liked the texture of the mix as well as the nuttier flavor. I warmed leftovers in my toaster oven and enjoyed this throughout the week.

headline: Breakfast Wheat Berries
abstract: These fragrant Middle Eastern wheat berries can be stirred into yogurt or eaten on their own.
lead_paragraph: Wheat berries sweetened with honey and perfumed with rose water and spices make a delicious breakfast on their own or stirred into yogurt (that’s the way I prefer to serve this). Whether you use farro, kamut, spelt or wheat berries (and whether you are cooking them for breakfast or for dinner) the trick here is to cook the grains for as long as it takes for them to really soften and to splay (that is, to burst at one end).

headline: How Aid to the Poor Is Also an Investment
abstract: Aid to the poor may seem like classic near-term consumption boosters, yet they have have impacts that last into adulthood for children whose families receive them, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: In Our Pages: March 11
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Typewriters and Typewriting', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Blurred ‘E’ Sets Slander Charge

headline: 4 Accused in Law Firm Fraud
abstract: Several former leaders of the once-high-flying law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf apparently violated a cardinal rule that lawyers always tell their clients: Don’t put anything incriminating into an email.
lead_paragraph: Several former leaders of the once-high-flying law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf apparently violated a cardinal rule that lawyers always tell their clients: Don’t put anything incriminating into an email.

headline: Art Matters | San Juan’s New Wave
abstract: Puerto Rico’s capital is emerging as a hotspot for innovative art.
lead_paragraph: If the annual art fairs that zigzag through New York, London, Paris and Hong Kong are now on the verge of being greeted with a collective Champagne-soaked yawn, San Juan has emerged as a breath of fresh tropical air. Despite Puerto Rico’s current economic crisis, a handful of boundary-pushing exhibition spaces are thriving, such as Espacio 1414, housed in a former Royal Tire warehouse; Roberto Paradise Gallery, which is showing the work of the painter José Lerma through April 5; and Galería Agustina Ferreyra, which operates out of a garage. “Art goes beyond geography,” Ferreyra says. “The minute we start thinking about geography, we close each other off.”

headline: 24-Hour ‘Rebrand’ Helps Twin Cities Nonprofits
abstract: An effort to help a local organization compresses a traditional advertising and marketing effort into a 24-hour marathon.
lead_paragraph: A Minneapolis agency that specializes in health care advertising is offering a new perspective on creating pro bono work for nonprofit organizations with an effort that combines elements of all-nighters, hackathons, sleepovers and team-building exercises.

headline: Do Times Journalists Pay Attention to Readers’ Comments?
abstract: Two Times writers – one a columnist, one a reporter – respond.
lead_paragraph: I was struck recently by a statement from Glenn Greenwald, writing about his new venture, First Look Media, in which he said that reader comments are “a vital form of accountability.”

headline: Inside ‘Wired Well’
abstract: From fitness trackers to pet spy cams to judgmental forks, five reporters from our special gadgets for health issue talk about how they got wired.
lead_paragraph: From fitness trackers to pet spy cams to judgmental forks, five reporters from our special gadgets for health issue talk about how they got wired.

headline: Minerals Technologies Wins Bidding War for Amcol International
abstract: Minerals Technologies agreed to pay about $1.7 billion, beating out Imerys of France, after a spirited back-and-forth for Amcol, a producer of specialty minerals and materials based in Illinois.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Minerals Technologies said on Monday that it had won a bidding war for Amcol International, agreeing to pay about $1.7 billion.

headline: False Leads Set Back Search for Malaysian Jet
abstract: Authorities widen the search area after suspected debris and an oil slick turn out to be unconnected to a Malaysia Airlines flight that vanished Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — The mystery of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 deepened on Monday when a sweeping search failed to find any sign of the jetliner near its last known location, leaving experts to puzzle over how a Boeing 777 with 239 people aboard could have vanished without a trace.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: More information on a new Heineken commercial.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: A Dot on the Map, After Scandal, Could Be Wiped Off
keywords: ['Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Embezzlement']
abstract: Hampton, Fla., issued tickets with such impunity it drew scrutiny. Now, a dismal audit has legislators threatening to wipe the city off the map.
lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Fla. — It’s easy for motorists driving down busy Route 301 to miss this speck of a city in rural north-central Florida: Fiddle with the car radio, unwrap a pack of gum, gaze out the window at the sunset and, whoosh, it’s gone.

headline: Counting Syria’s Dead
abstract: How many more Syrians have to die before the slaughter becomes a call to action, instead of a cause for regret?
lead_paragraph: My home in Aleppo is on a quiet cul-de-sac that ends against a large piece of land which, for as long as I can remember, has been a rocky wasteland of patchy yellow shrubs dotted with dirty plastic bags on a ground of dust mixed with broken glass. This triangular plot between residential neighborhoods was zoned to be a park for decades. Like most of Syria, it never reached its promised potential. Last week, I heard that people finally found a use for the wasteland — they have begun to bury Aleppo’s dead in it.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Stars of Vine
abstract: Financiers opening sweet shops. A Colorado entrepreneur sells marijuana-infused products. The buying power of people older than 50.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Remembering the Preschool Trial That Launched an Era of Hysteria
abstract: In 1984, news reports that hundreds of children had been abused at a California preschool helped spread panic across the nation. Despite a lack of convictions , the impact of the case continues to be felt.
lead_paragraph: In 1984, news reports that hundreds of children had been abused at a California preschool helped spread panic across the nation. Despite a lack of convictions and the outlandish nature of some accusations (really now, teachers chopped up animals, clubbed a horse to death with a baseball bat, sacrificed a baby in a church and made children drink the blood, dressed up as witches and flew in the air?), the impact of the case continues to be felt. Read more.

headline: In Annual Letter, G.E. Chief Extols ‘Simplification’
abstract: The company, which has sought to streamline itself in the years since the financial crisis, is emphasizing a “culture of simplification,” its chief executive, Jeffrey R. Immelt, wrote in an annual letter to shareholders published on Monday.
lead_paragraph: General Electric, a century-old industrial company, is taking its cues from the young technology firms of Silicon Valley.

headline: The Challenge of Linking Dewey’s Leader to Possible Accounting Shenanigans
abstract: Emails from leaders at Dewey & LeBoeuf make for interesting reading, but prosecutors may struggle to find enough evidence to link the firm’s leader to accusations that accounting tricks were used to cover up a deteriorating financial position, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.
lead_paragraph: Criminal charges filed by New York prosecutors against Steven H. Davis, former chairman of Dewey & LeBoeuf, describe actions that sound quite similar to the events that led to the collapse of Enron and WorldCom a decade ago. And, as with those earlier cases, the challenge for the government will be finding enough evidence to link the law firm’s head to accusations that accounting tricks were used to cover up a deteriorating financial position.

headline: Now Boarding: Amtrak Writers Residency
abstract: Amtrak is now accepting applications for a new writers’ residency program that includes free travel.
lead_paragraph: The wheels have begun moving on Amtrak’s plan to offer writers a rolling residency aboard their trains. On Monday the company announced that up to 24 writers, chosen from a pool of applicants, will be given a round-trip ticket on a long-distance train, including a private sleeper-car room with a bed, a desk, and electrical outlets. The trains promise the romance. The writers will have to do the rest.

headline: Authorities Give Update on Search
abstract: At a news conference, Malaysian authorities give an update on possible debris fields.
lead_paragraph: At a news conference, Malaysian authorities give an update on possible debris fields.

headline: Snowden Tries to Rally Tech Conference to Buttress Privacy Shields
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden discussed spying by the National Security Agency via videoconference at the South by Southwest conference, and told attendees that they were “the folks who can fix this.”
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Edward J. Snowden wants the technology industry to get serious about protecting the privacy of its users and customers.

headline: Kerry Orders U.S. Diplomats to Press Case for Climate Action
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry makes sure his diplomatic team gets his message on global warming.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, ahead of a round of low-level climate treaty talks that kicked off today in Bonn, Germany, Secretary of State John Kerry sent a fresh signal that he plans to keep global warming at the top of the State Department’s agenda.

headline: Times Minute | Searching for MH370
abstract: Also on the Minute, a generational power divide among Republicans, and the season finale of HBO's "True Detective."
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a generational power divide among Republicans, and the season finale of HBO's "True Detective."

headline: Statement From Gary Melius
abstract: In a video released Monday, Gary Melius thanked his supporters.
lead_paragraph: In a video released Monday, Gary Melius thanked his supporters.

headline: Snap Sketch | Shala Monroque, Anna Dello Russo and the Faces of Paris Fashion Week
abstract: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around Paris.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Damien Florébert Cuypers shares his impressions of the fashion set around Paris.

headline: Times Minute | Searching for MH370
abstract: Also on the Minute, a generational power divide among Republicans, and the season finale of HBO’s “True Detective.”
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Long Island Developer’s Statement on Shooting Is Short on Detail
abstract: Gary Melius, a real estate developer who was ambushed outside his estate last month, thanked his supporters in a video, but did not describe the attack.
lead_paragraph: Gary Melius, a prominent real estate developer who was shot in the head outside his opulent Long Island estate last month, said that he had much to say about what happened — but not yet.

headline: Image of the Day: March 10
abstract: People celebrating Lathmar Holi at the Nandagram temple in Nandgaon, Uttar Pradesh.

headline: Avoiding ‘Lucky Fool Syndrome’
abstract: Knowing when luck, not skill, plays a part in investing can shield us from the mistakes that stem from overconfidence.
lead_paragraph: Watching the Olympics a few weeks ago, I got pulled in to the drama of short-track skating. It has to be one of the more entertaining Olympic events. The races are fast, and almost anything can happen. If you had a chance to watch the women’s 500-meter final, you saw a perfect example of the fine line between skill and luck that drives this sport.

headline: At a Luxury Building on the Upper West Side, the Perks Start at the Curb
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Traffic and Parking Violations', 'Parking', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: The no-parking zone outside 15 Central Park West has become a ritzy, if technically illegal, parking cul-de-sac, but some neighbors don’t welcome the leeway granted by the police.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen Central Park West, home to celebrities and billionaires and an it address of the moment, has a long list of perks. There is the 75-foot sky-lit lap pool, the climate-controlled wine cellar and, for those “desiring anything from a four-course custom menu for 80 guests to an at-home romantic dinner for two,” the in-house chef.

headline: Faulting Army, Judge Puts Off Assault Case
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Courts-Martial']
abstract: The judge said Army officials may not have acted independent of external politics and possible pressure from senior Pentagon officials when they decided to turn down a plea offer.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — The military judge overseeing the court-martial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on sexual assault charges brought the trial to a halt on Monday, suggesting that a senior Army official may have been improperly influenced by political considerations in his handling of the case.

headline: The Pi Machine
abstract: The Greeks never figured this out, but perhaps you can. How can you determine the value of pi using two steel balls?
lead_paragraph: This coming Friday, 3.14 is Pi Day. Let’s celebrate math’s favorite number with a remarkable puzzle suggested several years ago by Alon Amit of Origami Logic. Dr. Amit and I were sitting on a couch in the old Palo Alto Facebook headquarters (Dr. Amit was working there at the time) surrounded by frenzy (the film “The Social Network” had just been released) when he told me something amazing: someone had recently figured out a completely original way to calculate pi. It was also a remarkably simple method, requiring just two balls and a wall. With these you have a pi machine.

headline: When Local Politics Have Global Consequences
abstract: An acquaintance in Beijing recently brought up the discrimination bill and asked me, “Why is Arizona was so un-American?”
lead_paragraph: Colorful deserts, lush mountains, views that go for 150 miles, star-filled skies and beautiful sunsets are all reasons that I call Arizona home. The politics of my state are the reason I sometimes tell people I’m from somewhere else.

headline: Smithsonian Names David Skorton as Its New Director
abstract: Dr. Skorton, who is also a practicing cardiologist, currently serves as president of Cornell.
lead_paragraph: The Smithsonian Institution announced on Monday that it had chosen David J. Skorton, a doctor and university president with a reputation as an energetic fund-raiser and forceful advocate of the arts and humanities as its new leader.

headline: Gun-Toting David Does Not Amuse Italian Culture Officials
abstract: An ad for a rifle that uses an image of Michelangelo’s statue of David prompts an outcry in Italy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian culture officials are furious over a gunmaker’s unauthorized use of the image of Michelangelo’s statue of David to promote a bolt-action rifle and are demanding that the company immediately drop its campaign — but it turns out the company already has.

headline: A Ski Pass for the States — and Japan
abstract: The Epic Pass offered by Vail Resorts includes destinations in Colorado, Utah, the Lake Tahoe region and, now, Japan.
lead_paragraph: Vail Resorts already offers holders of its season Epic Pass access to all 10 resorts it operates primarily in Colorado, Utah and the Lake Tahoe region. Next year the pass will include ski days in a more distant locale: Japan.

headline: Apple Releases First Big Software Update for iOS 7
abstract: Apple on Monday is set to release its first major update for iOS 7, its new operating system for iPhones and iPads. The upgrade improves reliability of the fingerprint sensor in the iPhone 5S and adjusts the way that Siri works, among other changes and fixes.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Added background and analysis on iOS 7.

headline: Tense Moments in de Blasio’s TV Interview
abstract: On MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” Mayor Bill de Blasio faced pointed questions about his stance on New York charter schools and conceded that his public-relations efforts had to improve.
lead_paragraph: Bruised by a controversy over New York City charter schools and seeking to regain momentum on a stalled tax proposal, Mayor Bill de Blasio took to national television on Monday to argue his case for his administration’s top policy priorities.

headline: Boldly Upsetting the Field, and the Establishment
abstract: The mistake Patrick Reed, 23, made in saying he considers himself to be a top-five player on the PGA Tour seems to be not in believing he is one of the best but in merely blurting it out.
lead_paragraph: DORAL, Fla. — The generation gap in golf has never been more pronounced, and not because the average age of the last three winners on the PGA Tour is 24.3 years. Years from now, we might look at the derring-do shown by 24-year-old Russell Henley at the Honda Classic last week and 23-year-old Patrick Reed at the World Golf Championships event Sunday as the beginning of the brash brothers era on the PGA Tour.

headline: Deciding if Inmates Get to Know How They’ll Be Executed
abstract: With a shortage of lethal drugs and recent executions that appear to have gone awry, the Supreme Court will soon consider whether inmates are entitled to know how the government means to kill them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The capital justice system is in turmoil, with drug shortages leading states to use secret and suspect chemicals to execute condemned inmates.

headline: Thai Peanut Sauce Marries Well With Shrimp and Pineapple
abstract: Thread shrimp and pineapple chunks on skewers, then broil and serve with a rich, luscious peanut sauce for dipping.

headline: Sandy Hook Gunman’s Father Says He Wishes His Son Had Never Been Born
abstract: Peter Lanza, whose son Adam committed the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., spoke about his son’s mental health in an article in The New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: Peter Lanza had not seen his son Adam for two years before the day Adam walked into Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., and murdered 20 schoolchildren and six adults.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 94
abstract: The Dutch international midfielder Kevin Strootman sustained a knee injury playing for Roma on Sunday and could miss the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Jordanian Judge Killed by Israeli Soldiers at Border Crossing
abstract: Israel said the man had tried to grab a soldier’s gun and brandished a metal bar, an account that was questioned by Jordanian and Palestinian officials.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli soldiers on Monday fatally shot a Jordanian judge of Palestinian origin at the Allenby Bridge after the man tried to seize a soldier’s gun and then threatened two soldiers with a metal bar, according to the Israeli military.

headline: A New Website Dedicated to Lorraine Hansberry
abstract: A website scheduled to go live on April 1 will offer a wealth of material about Lorraine Hansberry.
lead_paragraph: Lorraine Hansberry has never really left the spotlight.  Her work is widely taught and her most famous play, “A Raisin in the Sun,” is back on Broadway for its second revival.  Now her estate has created the Lorraine Hansberry Literary Trust, a virtual space that will offer all things Hansberry and showcase her as a writer, public intellectual and civil rights activist. The site, lorrainehansberryliterarytrust.org,  is scheduled to go live on April 1, Joi Gresham, the director and co-trustee of Hansberry’s literary trust said Monday.

headline: The Rate-Hiker’s Guide to the Economy
abstract: Ever-changing rationales, never-changing demands.
lead_paragraph: The big headline on the front page of today’s FT — at least in the U.S. edition — goes to this report about the Bank for International Settlements. According to the article, the BIS is warning that “forward guidance” — the attempt to drive long-term interest rates down by promising to keep short-term rates low for a long time — “could endanger the international financial system.” So I thought, typical BIS — the gnomes of Basel have been consistently against anything that might restore full employment, have been into punishment all the way. And I got ready to write a BIS-bashing post.

headline: British Fret About Anemic Results in Champions League
abstract: Some contribute the slide to a decline in the overall quality of English clubs, while others say the English clubs are hurt by the depth of the Premier League and the difficulty of playing in it.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, there was continual consternation among a large cross-section of English soccer fans. For the first time since 1996, no English teams had advanced past the Round of 16 in the European Champions League, a reality that irritated and embarrassed the country’s passionate followers. Probing questions were asked. Strong opinions were offered.

headline: In Store | Cozy Baby Separates Designed by a Rick Owens Alum
abstract: Asha Mines worked with the designer in Paris for 10 years, walked in his fashion show last month, and now brings her own children’s line —made with the same luxe fabrics as her mentor’s collection — to New York.
lead_paragraph: Among the striking array of nonmodels in Rick Owens’s recent fall/winter show — an ode to his extended creative family — was the designer Asha Mines. In the decade since Owens tapped the California Institute of the Arts graduate and prolific seamstress to be his design assistant, Mines’s career has been closely intertwined with that of her mentor. After seven years of working full-time in his studio, Mines went on to help produce his shows and photography; it was she who tracked down the step teams that famously stomped the brand’s spring/summer looks down the runway.

headline: Titans in Russia Fear New Front in Ukraine Crisis
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Business titans face the prospect of losing access to Western finance if the United States and Europe carry out threats of tougher sanctions against Moscow.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — When Vladimir V. Putin returned to the Russian presidency in 2012, one of the first messages he sent to his political elite, many of them heads of banks and large corporations, was that the times had changed: Owning assets outside Russia makes you too vulnerable to moves by foreign governments, he told them. It is time to bring your wealth home.

headline: Rival’s Split May Cast a Shadow on Dow
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: It’s tougher for Dow Chemical to argue against a breakup when the FMC Corporation, a rival with similar growth businesses, is doing the same, Kevin Allison of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Andrew N. Liveris, the head of Dow Chemical, may find it harder to keep his company together now that a smaller rival is planning to break up. Mr. Liveris has resisted the campaign by the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb to split Dow, a $60 billion company, into separate petro- and specialty chemicals groups.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | March 4-10, 2014
abstract: A new SAT, the Paralympics, daylight savings and more: How many of these 10 questions about recent news can you get right?
lead_paragraph: A new SAT, the Paralympics, daylight saving time and more: How many of these 10 questions about recent news can you answer?

headline: Discussion About ‘Bright Lights, Big City’ With Gary Shteyngart
abstract: Gary Shteyngart and Ginia Bellafante discussed Jay McInerney’s “Bright Lights, Big City” with readers as part of the Big City Book Club.
lead_paragraph: 9:35 p.m. | Updated Thanks to all who joined the discussion tonight and special thinks to our co-host Gary Shteyngart. We’ve concluded the live conversation but feel free to leave more thoughts and comments here during the week.

headline: The Failure of ‘True Detective’
abstract: An almost-great show that couldn’t stick the landing.
lead_paragraph: The fact that the internet is full of defenses (or at least quasi-defenses) of the “True Detective” finale today is a testament to the show’s genuinely extraordinary qualities — direction, acting, atmosphere, and (sometimes) writing. But I’m afraid it’s also a testament to the human will to believe, often in defiance of the evidence, and reading the various apologia for the way the detective drama finished up I’m inclined to channel the show’s nihilist-hero’s harsh words about religion: “You gotta get together and tell yourself stories that violate every law of the universe just to get through the [expletive] day? What’s that say about your reality?”

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘A Small Fire’
abstract: Julia McNamara discusses her poster for “A Small Fire,” at Portland Center Stage in Oregon.
lead_paragraph: In Adam Bock’s play “A Small Fire,” a woman’s life unravels after she contracts a mysterious disease that slowly causes her to lose all of her senses except touch. A fire breaks out in her kitchen, but she doesn’t realize it, unaware that her sense of smell has disappeared.

headline: KJ Dell’Antonia on Motherlode
abstract: Motherlode is a destination for information and conversation affecting families. http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/
lead_paragraph: Motherlode is a destination for information and conversation affecting families. http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/

headline: Senate Democrats’ All-Nighter Flags Climate Change
abstract: The 30 or so participants say their objective is to build toward a time when the political landscape may have shifted enough that a bill could pass Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the summer of 2010, it was Harry Reid, the Senate’s Democratic leader, who squelched his party’s efforts to pass a climate change bill, declaring it could never attract enough votes to pass. In the years since, he has rarely spoken publicly about the issue.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Keselowski’s Excellent Vegas Weekend
abstract: Brad Keselowski won Nationwide and Sprint Cup Nascar races; IndyCar revised the Indianapolis 500 qualifying format.
lead_paragraph: Brad Keselowski passed leader Dale Earnhardt Jr. – who ran out of fuel on the final lap – and took the checkered flag in the Nascar Sprint Cup race at Las Vegas Motor Speedway on Sunday. The victory completed a perfect weekend for Keselowski, who had also won the Nationwide series preliminary at the Las Vegas track on Saturday.

headline: Neil Young’s Digital Music System Coming to Market
abstract: Long a critic of digital music formats, Mr. Young has developed PonoMusic in a collaboration with Ayre Acoustics.
lead_paragraph: Neil Young has long been critical of MP3, the popular format that uses digital compression to squeeze music into files small enough to be packed by the hundreds into a portable player. “You are getting less than 5 percent of the original recording,” he complained in a 2012 interview with The New York Times. He has not been a fan of the digital sound of compact discs, either, and he has been at work for several years on a system he calls PonoMusic as an alternative to both. Mr. Young announced on Monday that Pono is ready to hit the market.

headline: As Malaysia Expands Search Area for Missing Jet, Wide Speculation Over Its Fate
abstract: An expert said that if the Malaysia Airlines jet somehow veered off course over the Gulf of Thailand, it could be miles from where its flight data disappeared.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Watching a seat-back display with a plane-shaped icon gliding across the map, it is easy to forget that in true scale, the airplane is very small and the route very large. As the hours and days drag by with no trace of the Malaysia Airlines flight that disappeared over the Gulf of Thailand early Saturday, the world is getting a reminder that if something goes wrong on a jet five miles up in the sky, traveling at 10 miles a minute, it can cover a lot of ground — or water — before it comes down to earth.

headline: Whitney Biennial | Darren Bader
abstract: Scenes from Darren Bader's latest video project, "Things I'm (Probably) Not Going to Get Done for the Biennial."
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Darren Bader's latest video project, "Things I'm (Probably) Not Going to Get Done for the Biennial."

headline: U.S. Sought Port Authority Records Tied to Chairman
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Friday issued a subpoena for information relating to David Samson, then withdrew it — apparently to clear the way for a federal inquiry in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan on Friday subpoenaed the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for records related to potential conflicts of interest involving its chairman, David Samson, a prominent New Jersey lawyer and close political ally of Gov. Chris Christie, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief Calls Bitcoin ‘Surreal’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: James P. Gorman, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, said in a television interview on Monday that he did not have a firm grasp of the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: To its devotees, Bitcoin represents the future of transactions. But the financial establishment is still scratching its head over the virtual currency.

headline: Dispatches From SXSW: Wearable Tech
keywords: ['Small Business', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: A wristband than can authenticate your identity. An app that monitors your health.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. —  Among the hundreds of interesting start-ups trying to get noticed at the South by Southwest festival, quite a few are entering the relatively new realm of wearable tech — wristbands, watches, rings and the like that identify users and collect data about them.

headline: Excerpts From Snowden’s SXSW Speech
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, discussed government surveillance via video conference at the South by Southwest conference.
lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, discussed government surveillance via video conference at the South by Southwest conference.

headline: George Saunders Wins Inaugural Folio Prize
abstract: Mr. Saunders won the award, his second in two weeks, for his story collection “Tenth of December.”
lead_paragraph: Another week, another honor for George Saunders.

headline: A Renewed Emphasis on Bag Size at United
abstract: The airline is reinforcing long-established carry-on bag restrictions, with emails to its frequent fliers and new bag-sizer racks at airports.
lead_paragraph: THERE is a lot of strong opinion about carry-on bags and limited space in overhead bins on airplanes, as I noted when I first reported here about that raging controversy.

headline: Kurt Chew-Een Lee, Singular Marine, Dies at 88
abstract: Believed to have been the first Asian-American officer in the Marine, Major Lee led troops into battle against the Chinese in Korea and was cited for bravery.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Kurt Chew-Een Lee, a Chinese-American who led Marines into battle against the Chinese in the Korean War and was cited for bravery for helping to preserve a crucial evacuation route for 8,000 American troops, was found dead on March 3 at his home in Washington. He was 88.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Women Politicians and the ‘Sense of Pedestal’
abstract: “I’ve twice run against women opponents, and it’s a very different kind of approach,” Mike Huckabee said.
lead_paragraph: Former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee treats his wife differently from his pals. He treats women opponents differently, too.

headline: After Hours | “Sexy Brooklyn Mommy” and the Return of Broadway’s Funniest, Funkiest Storyteller
abstract: After shaking up Broadway with the raucous rock musical “Passing Strange,” Stew returns to the theater district with “The New Stew Review.”
lead_paragraph: In 2007, a droll, bespectacled black man with fluttery hand gestures named Stew turned the New York theater world on its head with “Passing Strange,” his big, raucous rock musical about an arty African-American who finds sexual and artistic freedom in the cafes and art collectives of Amsterdam and Berlin. That may sound like an esoteric envelope for a musical, but Stew, alongside a terrific team of writers and performers, pulled it off with a cycle of open-hearted pop-rock showstoppers, as if James Baldwin had partnered with the Who. Since “Passing Strange,” Stew has mostly played new numbers at small Brooklyn venues like Barbès. But this weekend, he took his “New Stew Review,” featuring a large and exuberant retinue of musicians and guest singers, to the posh 54 Below in Midtown. The staid setting in no way stopped Stew from serving up his special sauce of astute lyrics, gorgeous melodies and funky grooves that nearly lifted the supper-club audience out of its seats.

headline: Esa-Pekka Salonen Wins $100,000 Composition Prize
abstract: Mr. Salonen, a conductor as well as a composer, is the winner of the Michael Ludwig Nemmers Prize.
lead_paragraph: The conductor and composer Esa-Pekka Salonen has been awarded the Michael Ludwig Nemmers Prize in Musical Composition, an award established in 2004 by the Henry and Leigh Bienen School of Music at Northwestern University. The award includes a $100,000 cash prize, a performance by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and a residency of four nonconsecutive weeks over the next two years at the school, in Evanston, Ill.

headline: Boston Marathon to Have More Security
abstract: The Boston Marathon next month will have a number of enhanced safety measures after last year's deadly bombing, including thousands of uniformed and plainclothes officers and bomb-sniffing dogs.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Marathon next month will have a number of enhanced safety measures after last year's deadly bombing, including thousands of uniformed and plainclothes officers and bomb-sniffing dogs.

headline: Organist Introduces New Partner in Concert
abstract: Cameron Carpenter gave the world premiere performance of his custom International Touring Organ on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: Every pipe organ in every concert hall and church in the world is essentially built to order and, of course, immobile. Each is also usually conceived with a specific repertory in mind. Important touring organists must adjust to each instrument and locale, which can be fascinating, frustrating or both.

headline: 1937 Horch Wins Best of Show at Amelia Island
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', "Pebble Beach Concours D'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: A 1937 Horch 853 and a 1958 Scarab racecar took top honors at the Amelia Island Concours d’Élégance; a 1937 Delahaye roadster sold for $6.6 million.
lead_paragraph: AMELIA ISLAND, Fla. — A 1937 Horch 853 and a 1958 Scarab racecar took top honors Sunday at the Amelia Island Concours d'Élégance. The Horch was given the award for elegance, while the Scarab took the trophy for sport machines.

headline: A Mighty Broadway Baritone, Unbound by Stylistic Barriers
abstract: The Broadway baritone Norm Lewis’s show “Who Am I?” was a high point of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: “You are what you sing,” declared the Broadway baritone Norm Lewis from the stage of the Appel Room (the recently renamed Allen Room at Jazz at Lincoln Center) on Saturday evening. This handsome 50-year-old singer was explaining the title of his show, “Who Am I?,” a high point of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.

headline: Idina Menzel Sparks Strong Start for ‘If/Then’
abstract: After a burst of publicity for Ms. Menzel’s performance at the Oscars, the new musical “If/Then” grossed more than $900,000 for its first seven preview performances.
lead_paragraph: Amid an unusual burst of publicity for its star, the Tony Award winner Idina Menzel, the new Broadway musical “If/Then” grossed a very strong $909,159 for its first seven preview performances last week, according to data released Monday by the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

headline: The Spectator as Playmate and Prop Assistant
abstract: In “Thank You for Coming: Attendance,” presented at Danspace, Faye Driscoll explores connections between performers and audience members.
lead_paragraph: “Thank You for Coming: Attendance,” seen on Thursday at Danspace Project, begins the way many participatory performances do: no shoes, no coats, no bags. In dance code, that means you’re going to have to move around.

headline: Art Matters | Darren Bader’s Video Contribution to the 2014 Whitney Biennial
abstract: Every two weeks, T exclusively presents a new installation from the artist’s video series entitled “Things I’m (Probably) Not Going to Get Done for the Biennial.”
lead_paragraph: Nearly three months ago, Darren Bader approached T in the hope that we’d host his off-site video contribution to this year’s Whitney Biennial. The plan, he explained, was to post a series of fake news stories on our website — without attributing them to him or the Whitney, and without even a wink to suggest that something funny was afoot. This idea got shut down. But there were plenty of others. The New York-based artist wanted to produce an editorial that paired celebrities with everyday objects, which echoed a show he staged in Los Angeles last summer at Blum & Poe. “Bryan Cranston and sleeping bag,” was one suggested match. “Patricia Arquette with weather balloon.” Another thought was to photograph things that rhyme, such as boule and stool, or the occult Baal and the actor Nick Stahl. In the end, time and budget constraints forced him to shelve (twelve, helve — the game gets inside you) his original slate of ideas, but Bader made the most of a trying situation. What follows is the first video from his new series, “Things I’m (Probably) Not Going to Get Done for the Biennial.” About the videos, which will run here exclusively through the duration of the Biennial, Bader has this to say: “I have ideas. You have ideas. Maybe some of them are the same.” More likely than not, this last part is untrue.

headline: The Jews, a History in So Many, Many Words
abstract: In Simon Schama’s book “The Story of the Jews,” he writes that Jewish history has survived, thanks to its people’s intense literacy.
lead_paragraph: Simon Schama, the prolific and protean British historian whose topics have included the French Revolution and the history of art, arrives now with a history of the Jewish people, and it’s a multimedia happening: two books and a five-part television documentary being broadcast on the BBC and PBS.

headline: Indelible Arcs, Reverberating in the Air and Memory
abstract: The pianist Murray Perahia performed Bach, Beethoven, Schumann and Chopin in a solo recital on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Murray Perahia took to the stage of Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday for a performance of works by Bach, Beethoven, Schumann and Chopin. It’s a big hall for a solo recital, but Mr. Perahia commands a powerful sound and the ability to spin sustained legato lines that bloom in space as if they were produced by a wind instrument. Above all, though, he is a musician in search of big ideas, and throughout the engrossing performance there was a sense that he relishes the opportunity to air them in a large public forum.

headline: Albums From Aloe Blacc, Sara Evans and Ambrose Akinmusire
abstract: The songs in new recordings from Aloe Blacc, Sara Evans and Ambrose Akinmusire range from nostalgic to vexed to subtly sophisticated.
lead_paragraph: ALOE BLACC

headline: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
abstract: Indonesia and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Indonesia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Flashes of Red Break Through in a Brooding Spanish Landscape
abstract: Eva Yerbabuena starred in two programs at City Center as part of the Flamenco Festival 2014.
lead_paragraph: The most prestigious performer in New York’s Flamenco Festival 2014 has been Eva Yerbabuena, who presented two programs, “¡Ay!” and “Lluvia,” at City Center this weekend. (The festival continues, but at other New York locations, through March 24.) At the end of “Lluvia,” as she danced her long, rich and complex “Llanto” soleá, she proved herself one of the world’s great dancers. Not a moment too soon: All of her first program (“¡Ay!,” on Saturday evening) had been horrid — and the first sections of “Lluvia” (on Sunday night) had been worse.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Indonesia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Indonesia, Nepal, Afghanistan and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Indonesia, Nepal, Afghanistan and India.

headline: Study: Women Who Can Do Math Still Don’t Get Hired
abstract: Managers, of either sex, tended to hire men over women when the criteria was math skills, three business school professor found. It happened even when women had measurably better math skills.
lead_paragraph: The economist Larry Summers famously suggested once that so few women become scientists and engineers because of discrimination, preference and even differences in innate ability.

headline: Rush Limbaugh Needn’t Worry
abstract: Turns out access to free birth control doesn’t encourage promiscuity.
lead_paragraph: In the great culture war over the so-called birth-control mandate, the most notable extra-legal skirmish to date has been between Sandra Fluke and Rush Limbaugh. In 2012 a speech before House Democrats, Ms. Fluke explained why she thought Georgetown University should be compelled to cover contraception, enraging Mr. Limbaugh, who called her a “slut” and a “prostitute” who wanted “to be paid to have sex.”

headline: Event-Free, Sunday Night Still Pulls In Big Ratings
abstract: Even without an awards show or other special event, Sunday night pulled in impressive television audiences, led by the premieres of “Resurrection” and “Cosmos” and the season finale of “True Detective.”
lead_paragraph: Even without a big event, Sunday night remained the main gathering point for television viewers this week, as a host of high-interest shows, led by the finale of “True Detective” on HBO, the premiere of a new “Cosmos” series on Fox and the drama “Resurrection” on ABC, all pulled in impressive audiences.

headline: The Sleeker Side of Floral Prints
abstract: T highlights one seasonal wardrobe staple, worn two ways. This week’s pick: a classic motif, styled to have a modern edge.
lead_paragraph: T highlights one seasonal wardrobe staple, worn two ways.

headline: Anne Rice Reviving the Vampire Lestat
abstract: “Prince Lestat” is set for release in October.
lead_paragraph: Anne Rice announced to her Facebook fans the publication of her next book, “Prince Lestat,” a novel that is set for release in October. “It was such a relief and such a pleasure, at last, to be able to speak about the up-and-coming novel, which I finished some time ago,” Ms. Rice wrote, adding that she had discussed its publication on “The Dinner Party Show,” a podcast hosted in part by her son, Christopher. The book marks the return of the vampire Lestat de Lioncourt, one of Ms. Rice’s creations. She is the author of “Interview With the Vampire,” the first in a series of vampire-theme novels. The book will be released by Knopf.

headline: For Some With Flexible Spending Accounts, Time to Act
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Savings']
abstract: If you have a health care flexible spending account, it may be crunch time: The March 15 deadline to spend any available balance remaining is only days away.
lead_paragraph: If you have a health care flexible spending account, it may be crunch time: The March 15 deadline to spend any available balance remaining is only days away.

headline: The Next Step Is Just Showing Up
abstract: Lindsay Lohan needs a lifeline, and Oprah Winfrey needs someone to save. The result is “Lindsay,” a new docu-series on OWN.
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey, mother confessor of the nation, is nothing without her supplicants. Though she’s no longer the conscience of afternoon television, her benediction is still sought by the unlucky, the needy and the creatively bankrupt.

headline: One Author of a Startling Stem Cell Study Calls for Its Retraction
abstract: A Japanese professor who was on the team that claimed to have found a simple way to make stem cells said he was no longer sure of its conclusions.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — One of the authors of a study that was claimed to have discovered a simple way to make stem cells said on Monday that he was no longer sure of his team’s conclusions, and he called for the study to be retracted.

headline: Blackstone and TPG Said to Plan $5.5 Billion Bid for Gates Global
abstract: The private equity firms Blackstone Group and TPG Capital are said to be teaming up in a planned bid for Gates Global, a maker of industrial and automotive parts.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group and TPG Capital are teaming up in a planned bid for Gates Global, a maker of industrial and automotive parts, a person briefed on the matter said on Monday.

headline: Young Republicans Find Fault With Elders on List of Social Issues
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Marijuana', 'Youth', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The party’s opposition to same-sex marriage and legalization of marijuana is causing a rift along generational lines.
lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — It was difficult to miss Ian Jacobson at the Conservative Political Action Conference. Known as Rooster, he was 33, with an ample beard, earrings and a towering orange-and-aqua spiked Mohawk haircut. But he also sported a pinstriped suit, French cuffs and a natty contrast collar.

headline: Secret Agent, Book Agent, All the Same
abstract: Chris Pavone, a novelist and former nonfiction editor, contends that the sedate book publishing industry can make an exciting setting for a fictional thriller.
lead_paragraph: Thriller writers have a knack for picking settings that are inherently suspenseful. A sinking yacht. The homicide unit of a police department. A secret lair stocked with covert C.I.A. operatives.

headline: No Winner Yet in El Salvador’s Close Presidential Race
abstract: An electoral tribunal said that the narrow margin made it impossible to declare a winner between Salvador Sánchez Cerén and Norman Quijano.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — With only 6,634 votes separating them, both candidates in El Salvador’s presidential race proclaimed victory on Monday, revealing a country equally divided between the political heirs of forces that fought a bloody civil war a quarter of a century ago.

headline: Joseph Sax, Who Pioneered Environmental Law, Dies at 78
abstract: Professor Sax formulated a far-reaching legal doctrine that recognized the environment as a public trust and helped fuel the movement in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Joseph L. Sax, a legal scholar who helped shape environmental law in the United States and fuel the environmental movement by establishing the doctrine that natural resources are a public trust requiring protection, died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 78.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: March 7-9, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: For some reason, Facebook’s recent announcement that it was taking steps to curtail illegal gun sales on its social network has the N.R.A. declaring victory.

headline: Jailed Leaders of Egypt’s 2011 Revolt Describe Beatings
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Political Prisoners', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Torture']
abstract: In a letter smuggled out of Egypt’s Tora Prison over the weekend, a leading figure in the 2011 uprising who was recently jailed for protesting the current military-backed government, reported that prisoners are routinely tortured.
lead_paragraph: Three prominent Egyptian activists who were jailed late last year for violating a new anti-protest law said on Monday that guards had beaten them during their transfer from prison to court for an appeal hearing.

headline: Rewriting the Menu in Tulum
abstract: At Hartwood, a restaurant off the grid in Mexico, local ingredients that are painstakingly procured and cooked over wood fires are the elements of a new cuisine.
lead_paragraph: TULUM, MEXICO — This is not an article about Mexican food.

headline: All the Rage | Faux Jewelry Handcrafted From Dried Flowers, Seeds and Pods
abstract: In Philadelphia, the careful assembly of dried plants tricks the eye into thinking it beholds fine Fabergé eggs or haute joaillerie designs.
lead_paragraph: In the back of the Pennsylvania Convention Center, behind sweeping landscaping displays and salespeople pushing fake paving stones, a group of women swarmed the botanical jewelry exhibition at the Philadelphia Flower Show, a nine-day event that concluded yesterday. Their awe and confusion over the lot of ornate and delicate jewelry — “Can you wear it?” “Are they for sale?” — filled the air.

headline: At SXSW Conference, a Mother Presses Her Son’s Case
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Social Media', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Ross Ulbricht was arrested in October and charged with operating the Silk Road, the online drug bazaar where Bitcoin was the only money accepted. His mother, Lyn, hopes that the crowd at SXSW would be receptive to her son’s cause.
lead_paragraph: Among the tech start-ups pitching their ideas at SXSW this week, there was a mother, advocating not a new company but the cause of her son.

headline: Fruitful but Tough Adventures in the Amazon
abstract: Transportation and terrain were surmountable production challenges for the co-founder of the beverage company Runa.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was younger we went on a lot of vacations, so traveling isn’t new to me. My business partner Tyler Gage and I went to Ecuador and other parts of South America when we were in college, and after taking an entrepreneurship class we started our beverage company, Runa. We work with more than 2,000 guayusa growers who are all members of the Amazonian Kichwa indigenous group. They call themselves Runa, which translates to “fully alive human being.” Guayusa is a caffeinated tree leaf, and we sell it and use it to make our bottled beverages.

headline: Waiting for the Black Box
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Editorials']
abstract: In this era of instant wireless communication, why isn’t black-box data transmitted in real time via satellite? Such technology exists.
lead_paragraph: Days after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 shortly after midnight on Saturday, investigators considering a range of possible causes — mechanical failure, pilot error and terrorism — have yet to turn up solid clues. They don’t even know where the plane disappeared, which suggests that for grieving families this misfortune could remain a mystery until the recovery of the plane’s “black box.”

headline: My Brother, Teddy
abstract: This short film captures a young girl’s love for her brother, who has cerebral palsy.
lead_paragraph: This short film captures a young girl’s love for her brother, who has cerebral palsy.

headline: ‘My Brother, Teddy’
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cerebral Palsy', 'Families and Family Life', 'Birth Defects']
abstract: This short film captures a young girl’s love for her brother, who has cerebral palsy.
lead_paragraph: My daughter Emma was just 3 when Teddy was born, with a viral infection he contracted in utero that caused extensive brain damage. This short film captures her love for Teddy, one not weighted down by disappointment, sadness or a full understanding of all the ways in which he wasn’t “normal.”

headline: Moving From the Trenches to Turmoil at Home
abstract: Gilbert Emery’s 1921 drama “The Hero” finds a family in close quarters, under stress and asking the big questions shortly after World War I.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot to watch in “The Hero.” But the real action is under the surface. This exceptional revival of Gilbert Emery’s 1921 play is steeped in subtext and repressed emotions: confusion, regret, desire and despair. Here, the silent moments are among the most moving.

headline: Search Area
abstract: Flight 370 left Kuala Lumpur International Airport just after midnight on Saturday. The Malaysian authorities announced Monday that they were expanding the search zones.
lead_paragraph: Flight 370 left Kuala Lumpur International Airport just after midnight on Saturday. The Malaysian authorities announced Monday that they were expanding the search zones.

lead_paragraph: Asylum of the Birds : Hundreds of Birds and Somewhat Damaged People

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A reader responds to an Op-Ed essay, “Has Privacy Become a Luxury Good?”

abstract: Robert A. Perry of the New York Civil Liberties Union writes about the accomplishments of David A. Paterson.
