headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food links to celebrate that extra hour of sunlight.
lead_paragraph: The government’s new nutrition labels — the first in 20 years — will let families know whether their food has added sugars for the first time, and reflect more realistic portion sizes.

headline: Smart Scales in the Kitchen
abstract: The Prep Pad is a kitchen scale that connects to a smart phone and measures the nutritional content of your food.
lead_paragraph: The Prep Pad is a kitchen scale that connects to a smart phone and measures the nutritional content of your food.

headline: The Fork Says Slow Down
abstract: Catherine Saint Louis knows she’s a fast eater. She hopes the HapiFork can undo some bad habits.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Saint Louis knows she’s a fast eater. She hopes the HapiFork can undo some bad habits.

headline: Tilda Swinton: 'Only Lovers Left Alive'
abstract: The actress discusses her role as a 3000-year-old vampire in Jim Jarmusch's latest film.
lead_paragraph: The actress discusses her role as a 3000-year-old vampire in Jim Jarmusch's latest film.

headline: Walk at Work
abstract: Is a treadmill desk worth the high cost? A New York Times reporter, Amy Harmon, puts one to the test at work.
lead_paragraph: Is a treadmill desk worth the high cost? A New York Times reporter, Amy Harmon, puts one to the test at work.

headline: Parents, Wired to Distraction
abstract: That digital devices can distract us from the people in front of us is especially important for parents to remember.
lead_paragraph: Every age of parenthood — and parenthood at every age — yields some discouraging metric, some new rating system on which parents can be judged and found wanting. We endlessly jury family dinner rituals, day care and nannies, parents’ readiness to follow schedules, or to ignore the rules and follow their child’s directives. Whatever you are doing is probably wrong. Yes, you, yes, right now. Put down that cellphone and listen to me.

headline: Seeking Serenity on a Screen
abstract: Though smartphones are a source of stress and distraction for many people, apps for meditation have also become popular.
lead_paragraph: For most of us, smartphones can seem more a constant source of stress than a path to serenity. But more and more people are using their Androids and iPhones to find inner peace.

headline: Collecting Data on a Good Night’s Sleep
abstract: New apps and gadgets like Sleepbot, Beddit and Sleep Cycle can track problems with sleep and waking and, ideally, offer insights that can lead to improvement.
lead_paragraph: Computers and mobile devices are enemies of a good night’s sleep, interrupting slumber with text alerts and disrupting natural sleep rhythms with their glowing blue screens. But a new generation of apps and devices may also be the way to improve sleep. Manufacturers are coming out with gadgets like cellphone alarm clocks that wake people at the most opportune point in their sleep cycle and heart rate monitors that people strap on at night, part of a broader movement to improve health by quantifying behavior.

headline: Finding the Right Pace on a Treadmill Desk
abstract: A reporter using a treadmill desk found she burned calories without noticing but had to tinker with pace depending on her task.
lead_paragraph: On Day 3 of my long-coveted trial of a treadmill desk, I sat down.

headline: Gadgets to Boost Bike Safety
abstract: An air-bag scarf that turns into a helmet on impact, a bike horn that mimics a car horn and other marvels of modern cycling.
lead_paragraph: In a widely viewed YouTube video, a cyclist named Casey Neistat, deliberately takes tumble after tumble while trying to navigate obstructed bike lanes in New York City.  The video is funny — it even includes a crash into a parked police car — but it also has struck a chord with bike commuters around the country facing a seemingly endless array of road hazards.

headline: Zombies, Workout Music and Baby Trackers: Health Tech for Everyone
abstract: Amid a deluge of health apps and devices washing over consumers, there are some quirky, intriguing products that may have escaped your notice. Here are the best of them.
lead_paragraph: Amid a deluge of health apps and devices washing over consumers, there are some quirky, intriguing products that may have escaped your notice. Here are the best of them.

headline: Venezuela Goes Mad
abstract: The protests may only invigorate a flaccid dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — THE violent demonstrations that have rocked Venezuela for weeks are threatening to wipe out what little democracy is left here after 15 years of systematic erosion by the state. The government of Nicolás Maduro has responded with massive military force, raiding offices and houses without judicial orders, imprisoning civilians in military compounds and applauding the killing of protesters by paramilitary groups.

headline: Better Eating With Smart Scales and Forks
abstract: A scale that provides calorie counts and a nutritional breakdown for home-cooked food, and a fork that encourages leisurely eating.
lead_paragraph: Some people read nutrition labels with the kind of zeal others reserve for tabloids. The pleasure is in the appraisal. Those crackers in the supermarket with no trans fats? Basket-worthy. A cafe’s peach muffin has one measly gram of fiber? As if.

headline: After Online Dating, Online Making Up
abstract: People have long used technology to find partners. But now technology is playing a growing role in already established relationships.
lead_paragraph: Here is what Steve S. and Sarah B. do when they fight: They take a breath, go to their smartphones, and click on Couple Counseling & Chatting, a free app created by their real-life therapist, Marigrace Randazzo-Ratliff.

headline: Mets Playing It Safe With Return of First Basemen
abstract: The Mets’ general manager and hitting coach said they wanted to ensure Ike Davis and Lucas Duda, who were both injured soon after the start of spring training, were fully comfortable before coming back.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Mets Manager Terry Collins crossed his arms, leaned back in his office chair and sighed. Opening day was about three weeks away, and his first basemen, Ike Davis and Lucas Duda, were hurt. Worse, Collins did not know when they would return.

headline: Check Your Head
abstract: A high-tech tool to combat concussion damage, the Reebok Checklight is a sensor worn under the helmet that lights up upon significant impact.
lead_paragraph: A high-tech tool to combat concussion damage, the Reebok Checklight is a sensor worn under the helmet that lights up upon significant impact.

headline: Do Brain Workouts Work? Science Isn’t Sure
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Brain', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Memory']
abstract: Tools like Lumosity promise to stimulate your mind, though researchers question how much they improve cognitive performance.
lead_paragraph: For a $14.95 monthly membership, the website Lumosity promises to “train” your brain with games designed to stave off mental decline. Users view a quick succession of bird images and numbers to test attention span, for instance, or match increasingly complex tile patterns to challenge memory.

headline: Coal to the Rescue, but Maybe Not Next Winter
keywords: ['Coal', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Clean Air Act', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Energy companies have struggled to meet demand during the coldest winter in recent memory, and they have relied on coal plants that are soon to close.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — When the temperature here dropped into the teens this winter, ice formed on the inside of Ernestine J. Cundiff’s windows in the drafty 50-year-old apartment building where she lives. At 81, with diabetes, poor circulation in her legs and both shoulders damaged in separate falls last year, Ms. Cundiff said wearing leggings and fur-lined slippers was not enough to keep her warm, so she took to using an electric space heater in her bedroom.

headline: Israel Displays Arms It Says Were Headed to Gaza
abstract: In a televised event, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel toured a display of seized weapons and munitions laid out at the naval base in the port of Eilat.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s seizure last week of a merchant vessel said to be carrying an Iranian arms shipment had two goals, according to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu: to prevent the cargo from reaching Palestinian fighters in Hamas-run Gaza, and to expose what he called “the true face of Iran.”

headline: A Concussion Monitor to Measure Hard Knocks
abstract: New impact sensors in helmets promise to warn coaches and parents when a young athlete has sustained a blow that might have caused a concussion.
lead_paragraph: On a frigid night recently in Randolph, N.J., the Jersey Wildcats junior hockey team flew across the home rink during practice at Aspen Ice Arena, sending ice into the air. Hockey is known for its collisions, and concussions aren’t unusual, but the players didn’t seem particularly worried.

headline: Share Your Wired Well Story
abstract: Have you used an activity or fitness tracker? Tell us about it.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Wired Well special section of Science Times explores how you can now easily track and analyze your every move – from the number of minutes spent in REM sleep to the amount of time your heart rate was above 100 beats per minute to the number of steps you took in the office. You can even do that for your dog.

headline: William Pogue, Astronaut Who Staged a Strike in Space, Dies at 84
abstract: Colonel Pogue, the pilot for Skylab’s last manned mission in 1973, went on strike while in orbit to demand more free time to enjoy the view and to think.
lead_paragraph: William R. Pogue was the pilot of a record-setting American mission in space, and one of the very few astronauts ever to go on strike — while in orbit — to demand more time for contemplating the universe.

headline: Activity Trackers Don’t Sense Everything
abstract: The devices can offer insight, but research suggests their accuracy is imperfect. And the larger issue of whether they improve long-term motivation to exercise more remains unresolved.
lead_paragraph: Wearable technology — those wristbands, watches and belt gadgets that track your every move — hold tremendous promise for improving health and physical performance. But as often happens, the technology has outstripped the research, and scientists are still struggling to understand whether the monitors work as promised, how to keep people motivated to use them, and exactly what the devices are supposed to accomplish, anyway.

headline: The Monitored Man
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Exercise', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mobile Applications', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: After six months of heavy use of activity-monitoring gadgets — sometimes wearing four at a time — the author reports back.
lead_paragraph: For years, health advocates have been telling us to move more. But just how much more?

headline: West Virginia: Governor Weighs Abortion Bill
abstract: Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin said he was concerned about the constitutionality of a bill banning abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, which the State Legislature passed over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin said he was concerned about the constitutionality of a bill banning abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, which the State Legislature passed over the weekend. Twelve states have passed similar bans, according to the Guttmacher Institute. But West Virginia will be the first with a Democratic governor and Democratic-controlled legislature to embrace the 20-week limit if the governor signs the bill. Supporters contend a fetus that age can feel pain, although the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists says there is no scientific evidence for that view. The Supreme Court in January refused to hear an appeal of a lower court’s decision to strike down an Arizona law banning most abortions after 20 weeks. In Roe v. Wade in 1973, the high court said women have a right to an abortion until the point of fetal viability, generally seen as 24 weeks. “The abortion bill obviously is one that causes me some concern because even the legislative attorneys and others said they feel this bill is unconstitutional,” Governor Tomblin said in a statement.

headline: Israel Watches Warily as Hezbollah Gains Battle Skills in Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: While the Israeli military used to plan for conventional armored battle, its forces now train to withstand fighters who have antitank missiles and underground hide-outs.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Hezbollah’s distracting and costly engagement in the Syrian civil war has offered some practical benefit to Israelis. It has also been a source of foreboding.

headline: An Officer's Alleged Theft
abstract: Sgt. Scott Greene was arrested after stopping a driver and tucking a $100 bill from an envelope of cash on a car seat into his shirtsleeve. His “victim” was an undercover detective.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Scott Greene was arrested after stopping a driver and tucking a $100 bill from an envelope of cash on a car seat into his shirtsleeve. His “victim” was an undercover detective.

headline: Immigrants, Robbed by the Police
keywords: ['Police', 'Discrimination', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Editorials', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Another blot has been added to an already ugly record of anti-immigrant hatred and violence in Suffolk County on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen Latino men on Long Island have reported being robbed by a Suffolk County police officer, saying he pulled them over while they were driving and stole their money. Sgt. Scott Greene was arrested after stopping a driver in late January, riffling through an envelope of cash on a car seat and tucking a $100 bill into his shirt sleeve. His “victim” was an undercover detective; the incident was caught on camera.

headline: Egypt Tycoon Is Released; 3 Detainees Detail Abuse
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: A juxtaposition of court sessions raised new alarms that Egypt was turning back to its old authoritarian ways.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court on Monday ordered the release on bail of a right-hand man to former President Hosni Mubarak while another court considered a prison sentence recently handed to three young organizers who led the revolt against him.

headline: Harassment of Troubled State Exchanges
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Let’s help states with health care online enrollment problems, not impugn their efforts, as Republicans are doing.
lead_paragraph: Now that the badly botched rollout of the federal government’s health care website seems to be behind us, Republicans have shifted their criticisms to several states that are experiencing problems enrolling people on their state-run exchanges. Their attacks would be more credible if they showed the slightest desire to help fix the problems. But their main goal is to belittle the efforts of states that are working hard to make their systems better, to scare people away from the state websites and to discredit the health care reform law itself.

headline: First Look Media Adds Editor of Gawker
abstract: The online news venture backed by the technology billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar is adding John Cook, the editor of Gawker, to its growing stable of established journalists.
lead_paragraph: First Look Media, the online news venture backed by the technology billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar, is adding John Cook, the editor of Gawker, to its growing stable of journalists, the publication announced on Monday.

headline: At Fordham, Gym Has History if Not Allure
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Draft and Recruitment (Sports)']
abstract: The intimate atmosphere of the 89-year-old Rose Hill Gym may be undeniable, but some Fordham fans say that it is hampering basketball recruiting.
lead_paragraph: Among a growing crop of slick new basketball arenas, Fordham’s 89-year-old Rose Hill Gym is a venerable throwback, one of the few still in use that were built during the lifetime of basketball’s inventor, James Naismith. Its walls, made of sturdy bricks of Manhattan schist, seem destined to withstand all challengers.

headline: House to Investigate Slow Response to Fault in G.M. Vehicles
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Congressional hearings will include General Motors, which learned of ignition switch problems in 2004, and federal safety regulators, who received more than 260 complaints.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A House committee has started an investigation into the response by General Motors and federal safety regulators to complaints about faulty ignition switches that have been linked to 13 deaths, officials said on Monday.

headline: The Democrats Stand Up to the Kochs
abstract: Democrats can’t match the Koch brothers’ unlimited money, but they can use their political pulpits to fight for a few basic principles.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have for too long been passive in the face of the vast amounts of corporate money, most of it secret, that are being spent to evict them from office and dismantle their policies. By far the largest voice in many of this year’s political races, for example, has been that of the Koch brothers, who have spent tens of millions of dollars peddling phony stories about the impact of health care reform, all in order to put Republicans in control of the Senate after the November elections.

headline: Former Rivals Come Together in a Campaign to End Childhood Hunger
abstract: Procter & Gamble and ConAgra, two consumer-product giants that once battled each other for market share, are combining their ad dollars to advance a good cause.
lead_paragraph: CONSUMER-PRODUCT giants that were once fierce competitors are joining forces for a good-cause marketing campaign meant to help a nonprofit alleviate childhood hunger.

headline: We Need More Tests, Not Fewer
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Creativity', 'Education']
abstract: Colleges should measure creativity, emotional intelligence and more.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.H. — LAST week, the College Board announced that it was revising the SAT in an effort to make it more acceptable to test-takers, teachers, college admissions officers and the public more generally. That’s a tough objective. The SAT tells us something about how smart we (or our children or students) are. Test-takers who receive lower scores than they had hoped for are likely to be dismayed at the news — and concerned about their academic future. It’s no wonder that it’s hard to discuss the test dispassionately.

headline: Methodist Bishop to End Trials for Ministers Who Perform Gay Weddings
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The leader of the United Methodist Church in New York essentially freed ministers to conduct the still-prohibited ceremony and dropped charges in one case.
lead_paragraph: The head bishop of the United Methodist Church in New York on Monday committed to ending church trials in his region for ministers who perform same sex-marriages, essentially freeing them to conduct a ceremony still prohibited under his denomination’s laws.

headline: Dispute Over Fate of Mysterious Tanker With Oil From Libya
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Ports']
abstract: The vessel, whose ownership is unclear, is believed to be carrying oil obtained illicitly from militia groups.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A tanker that had been sitting for three days in a Libyan port controlled by a regional militia has what every refinery in Europe wants: some of the highest quality oil in the world, so sweet it needs little refining to process into high-grade fuel.

headline: A Veteran Sticks With the Fastball
abstract: Even at 40, the Mets off-season acquisition Bartolo Colon continues to rely on his fastball more than any starter in baseball.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — No starter in baseball throws his fastball as often as the Mets’ Bartolo Colon. Nobody comes close.

headline: Hotels Moving Into Old Buildings
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: As younger travelers bring an urban sensibility to their accommodations, hotel chains are renovating old office buildings, warehouses and other spaces.
lead_paragraph: Reuse and recycle are taking on new meaning for hotels.

headline: A Not-So-Quixotic Search for Cervantes
abstract: Miguel de Cervantes was buried where he wanted in 1616, but strangely there has been no effort to identify the literary giant’s grave site — until now.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — He may be one of Spain’s literary heroes, but during his life four centuries ago, Miguel de Cervantes could have been considered something of “a loser,” said Fernando de Prado, a Spanish historian. Cervantes, the author of the adventures of the knight-errant Don Quixote, lived in poverty, missed out on a military promotion and was held captive by pirates for five years after his naval ship was intercepted. The recognition and success of his writings came too late to bring him any fortune.

headline: Shoe-Bomb Plot Revisited at Trial of Bin Laden Relative
abstract: A man who said he had backed out of a plan to blow up airplanes testified by video from Britain about Al Qaeda during the trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, Al Qaeda made plans to have terrorists board airplanes and detonate explosives hidden in their shoes. One operative, Richard C. Reid, tried but failed to blow up a flight from Paris to Miami in December 2001. The other man, Saajid Badat, backed out and was later arrested in Britain.

headline: Missing Brooklyn Boy Rode Subway for Five Days
abstract: Kareem Granton, 11, who left his home on Wednesday after a spat over chores, was reunited with his mother Monday after a subway rider flagged down a police officer.
lead_paragraph: The New York City subway is full of people watching people. But even amid the eyes of millions of riders, it is possible to get lost. And as one family learned, it is possible for an 11-year-old boy to drift through the subway system for five days seen by many but noticed by no one.

headline: Icahn’s War of Words With eBay
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, is in a battle with Marc Andreessen, the entrepreneur turned technology investor.
lead_paragraph: It’s a fight that pits Wall Street against Silicon Valley.

headline: The Leaderless Doctrine
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: There has been a shift in Americans’ understanding of the role of the U.S. and the nature of power, with complex and unnerving consequences.
lead_paragraph: We’re in the middle of a remarkable shift in how Americans see the world and their own country’s role in the world. For the first time in half a century, a majority of Americans say that the U.S. should be less engaged in world affairs, according to the most recent Pew Research Center survey. For the first time in recorded history, a majority of Americans believe that their country has a declining influence on what’s happening around the globe. A slight majority of Americans now say that their country is doing too much to help solve the world’s problems.

headline: Home, at the Other House That Ruth Built
abstract: Julia Ruth Stevens, 97, the daughter of Babe Ruth, joined the Yankees in St. Petersburg to celebrate the city’s 100-year anniversary as the birthplace of spring training in Florida.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — The woman pressed her eyes shut to see what only she can see. Macular degeneration has left her legally blind. Still, her vision of a bygone era, and of baseball’s most famous figure, remains focused.

headline: White House Withdraws Plan Allowing Limits to Medicare Coverage for Some Drugs
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: The proposal created political problems for the Obama administration, with some Democrats joining Republicans in denouncing the changes, saying they would harm Medicare beneficiaries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under pressure from patients, pharmaceutical companies and members of Congress from both parties, the Obama administration on Monday withdrew a proposal that would have allowed insurers to limit Medicare coverage for certain classes of drugs, including those used to treat depression and schizophrenia.

headline: After Seeing His Family Crumble, Vindicated Whistle-Blower Has Little to Smile About
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A judge on Friday dismissed all charges against Samuel Kellner, a Hasidic Jew who has lived as an outcast for years after accusing a prominent cantor of sexually abusing his son.
lead_paragraph: To walk the streets free of the shadow of indictment, to hear a Brooklyn prosecutor last Friday describe the extortion case against him as a tree rotted through, Samuel Kellner might be expected to speak of vindication and hope.

headline: Suit Over Inheritance in the Perelman Family Nears Its End in Court
abstract: James Cohen, the head of Hudson Media, is accused by Ronald O. Perelman’s daughter, Samantha, of manipulating his father to funnel hundreds of millions of dollars out of her inheritance.
lead_paragraph: A messy family legal brawl involving the daughter of the financier Ronald O. Perelman is entering its final stages in a New Jersey court.

headline: Sharply Criticized by Government, Head of the Central Bank of Cyprus Resigns
abstract: Panicos Demetriades, chief of the Bank of Cyprus, quit amid tensions with the Cypriot government and an investigation into his handling of a bailout last year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The central bank chief of financially plagued Cyprus resigned Monday, following political tensions with the Cypriot government and an investigation into his role in the 10 billion euro international bailout for the island last year.

headline: Use of Stolen Passports on Missing Jet Highlights Security Flaw
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Passports', 'Airport Security', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: Aviation safety experts said the discovery that two passengers were traveling on stolen passports has revealed a major gap in security procedures developed since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As an armada of ships, planes and helicopters combed the waters south of Vietnam on Monday for any sign of a missing Malaysian airliner, aviation safety experts said the discovery that two passengers aboard the plane were traveling on stolen passports has revealed a major gap in airline security procedures developed since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Washington Businessman Pleads Guilty Over Illegal Contributions
abstract: Jeffrey E. Thompson admitted that he and his companies gave more than $3.3 million in illegal contributions to at least 28 candidates, including to Mayor Vincent C. Gray of Washington.
lead_paragraph: A wealthy Washington businessman who funneled millions of dollars in illegal campaign contributions to local and federal candidates pleaded guilty to two conspiracy charges on Monday, bringing renewed attention to a longstanding corruption inquiry in the nation’s capital and to Mayor Vincent C. Gray’s 2010 election.

headline: Puerto Rico Gets a Break With Rates on Its Bonds
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The commonwealth, which is selling $3 billion in bonds on Tuesday, is also raising concern that it may be planning to revamp its existing debt.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico is expected to sell roughly $3 billion in bonds on Tuesday at interest rates that are considerably lower than many investors in the municipal market had expected, providing a rare bright spot for the cash-squeezed island.

headline: California: Migrants Stage Another Border Protest
abstract: In a protest against deportation policy, about 30 foreigners went to the Mexican border to ask authorities to allow them into the United States.
lead_paragraph: In a protest against the Obama administration’s deportations policy, about 30 foreigners without legal visas who have families in the United States went to the Mexican border near San Diego to ask the authorities to allow them into the United States. The migrants had previously been formally deported or left to avoid deportation, and they asked American border officials to admit them on humanitarian grounds to join close relatives here. It was the third protest since July in which migrants have tried to challenge the administration by attempting to enter without documents through a border station.

headline: Roger Hilsman, Adviser to Kennedy on Vietnam, Dies at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Vietnam War', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Mr. Hilsman helped draft a cable giving tacit American support to a coup against President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, angering some military officials.
lead_paragraph: Roger Hilsman, a foreign policy adviser in the Kennedy administration who helped draft a cable giving tacit American support to a coup against President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 94.

headline: After Students’ Hazing-Related Deaths, Fraternity Eliminates Tradition of Pledging
abstract: Sigma Alpha Epsilon will no longer force aspiring members to endure onerous tasks of the type that have defined fraternity initiations for more than half a century.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — After a string of injuries and deaths at its fraternity houses, Sigma Alpha Epsilon, one of the largest fraternities in the country, said it would no longer permit “pledging” as part of its initiation process for undergraduates seeking to join the organization, and would instead offer new brothers full membership within days of inviting them to join.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 10, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 10, 2014

headline: Wendy Hughes, 61, Actress in Australian Film Surge, Dies
abstract: Ms. Hughes, a film, stage and television star in Australia, was known in the United States and elsewhere for her role in “My Brilliant Career” and other movies.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Hughes, an Australian actress known internationally for her roles in “My Brilliant Career” and other movies, died on Saturday in Sydney. She was 61.

headline: Yen-Pinching Undercuts Japan’s Push Against Years of Deflation
abstract: After years of falling prices, many Japanese have the mind-set that they need to save, not spend, putting a burden on the economy.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The loose change in Yusa Nishimura’s purse could be undermining Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s economic recovery plan for Japan.

headline: Release of Syrian Nuns Was Part of a Hostage Swap
keywords: ['Nuns', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Detainees', 'Hostages', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The Syrian government freed a group of detainees that included women and children in exchange for the nuns’ release by insurgents.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Video of an unusual prisoner swap early Monday between the Syrian government and insurgents appears to confirm what Syrian officials have long denied: that the government has been holding women and children prisoner, including relatives of suspected opposition fighters.

headline: An Alter Ego With Attitude
abstract: In the terrific, scary-funny play “Hand to God,” Steven Boyer is a teenager whose puppetry skills turn into a negative.
lead_paragraph: All of us play unhappy host to a demon or two roosting in our brains, urging us on to bad behavior now and then: a cutting remark, a catty tweet. But after watching the terrific, scary-funny play “Hand to God,” by Robert Askins, I am very glad I don’t own a hand puppet.

headline: A Collaborative Effort
abstract: After my father’s death, his notes were on my desk, his voice in my head, and I was mindful of his specific writerly style and slightly old-fashioned cultural sensibility.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, my family spent several summers in Amsterdam. My mother, sister and I toured the city, wandered along the canals, visited the great museums and sampled the local chocolates. My father, meanwhile, buried himself in Amsterdam’s social history library, studying the papers of the anarchists Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman, known as Sasha. Sasha and Emma had been born in czarist Russia, immigrated to New York in the 1880s as teenagers, joined an anarchist group, and formed a lifelong friendship that remained immutable through protest rallies, bombing plots, prison time, love affairs, deportation, separation and war. My father, Paul Avrich, had been fascinated with them for years.

headline: About to Bloom
abstract: Spring may soon be upon us, as evidenced by this puzzle from Mel Rosen.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s been a while since we’ve seen Mel Rosen. His last New York Times puzzle was the infamous “Question Box” grid, but he’s back today with a puzzle that hopefully will be more reliable in predicting the arrival of spring than Punxsutawney Phil.

headline: Draft Lottery Can’t Come Soon Enough for 76ers
abstract: There was a point when the Philadelphia 76ers were actually feeling great about the season. It was on opening night. Now they’re looking for their first victory since Jan. 29.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia 76ers came to Madison Square Garden on Monday night feeling surprisingly optimistic, at least for a team that had lost 16 consecutive games, the longest streak in franchise history since 1973.

headline: New York State Reports Steep Rise in Housing Costs
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Income', 'Affordable Housing', 'Property Taxes']
abstract: More than three million New York households — over half the state’s renters and one-third of homeowners — cannot afford their homes, the state comptroller’s office disclosed.
lead_paragraph: Housing costs have risen beyond what New Yorkers can afford in many parts of the state, whether they rent or own, an examination released by the state comptroller’s office shows.

headline: A Tip of the Goalie Mask to Rangers Greats
abstract: Goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, who tied the team’s shutouts record and is one win from matching the team victories mark, paid tribute to the men he was eclipsing: Eddie Giacomin and Mike Richter.
lead_paragraph: After Henrik Lundqvist secured a 3-0 victory over the Detroit Red Wings on Sunday, he paid tribute to two great Rangers goalies who came before him: Eddie Giacomin, whose Rangers shutout record he tied, and Mike Richter, whose team victory record is only one win away.

headline: Warily, Europe’s Steel Makers Are Firing Up Their Furnaces Again
abstract: As demand rises again, the big question is whether it will be sufficient to keep all of Europe’s steels mills running.
lead_paragraph: DUNKIRK, France — Steel mills like ArcelorMittal’s 1,200-acre complex here on the French coast are forbidding places, full of incandescent metal and groaning machinery. But longtime industry executives like Henri-Pierre Orsoni, who runs the company’s operations in northern France, relish being around these dusty behemoths.

headline: Daunting Tests Await Admiral Named N.S.A. Chief
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, who currently runs the Navy’s Fleet Cyber Command, has been appointed to navigate a bureaucratic, political and public relations disaster.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is not hard to understand why veterans of the National Security Agency argue that 2013 was the worst year since Harry S. Truman got the place running 62 years ago.

headline: Steel Mills Endure Hard Times
abstract: Though demand for steel in Europe waned during the economic downturn, ArcelorMittal and other mills are starting to experience a revival.
lead_paragraph: Though demand for steel in Europe waned during the economic downturn, ArcelorMittal and other mills are starting to experience a revival.

headline: New Roller Coaster Promises Coney Island a Return of Thrills
abstract: The Thunderbolt roller coaster, which city officials said should be ready by Memorial Day, will be the first coaster in the area since 1910 to hurtle riders upside-down.
lead_paragraph: Fasten your seatbelts. This summer, New York City thrill seekers will be able to experience a 90-degree vertical drop, followed by a 100-foot loop and a zero-gravity roll, along with dives, hills and a corkscrew — all within two minutes.

headline: U.S. and Russia Hit Diplomatic Roadblock Trying to Start Ukraine Talks
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry delayed an anticipated trip to Russia and the two sides issued dueling accounts of their recent diplomacy to defuse the crisis in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s effort to solicit Russia’s help to defuse the crisis in Ukraine hit a roadblock on Monday when Secretary of State John Kerry delayed an anticipated trip to Russia and the two sides issued dueling accounts of their recent diplomacy.

headline: Thieves in Gaza Go Where Money Is, but Hamas Quickly Gets It Back
abstract: Masked gunmen robbed a post office in Gaza City on Monday, stealing what local news reports said was the equivalent of about $500,000.
lead_paragraph: Masked gunmen robbed a post office in Gaza City on Monday, stealing what local news reports said was the equivalent of about $500,000. It was a rare act of criminal violence against a government institution run by Hamas, the Islamic group that controls Gaza. The money was earmarked for about 5,000 beneficiaries of a government unemployment program. But just hours after the robbery, three Palestinian suspects were arrested without resistance and the money was recovered, according to Islam Shahwan, the spokesman for the Hamas-run Interior Ministry.

headline: Can Writing Be Assessed?
abstract: The SAT is making the essay component of the college admissions exam optional. Is this a sign that writing can't be properly graded?

headline: India’s Supreme Court Orders Speedier Trials for Lawmakers
abstract: India’s Supreme Court on Monday ordered lower courts to conclude the trials of lawmakers charged with grave crimes within a year of the date of the charges being filed as a way to reduce the number of politicians who are re-elected during drawn-out trials.
lead_paragraph: India’s Supreme Court on Monday ordered lower courts to conclude the trials of lawmakers charged with grave crimes within a year of the date of the charges being filed as a way to reduce the number of politicians who are re-elected during drawn-out trials. Criminal cases in India often drag on for several years, allowing lawmakers who are charged with crimes to continue to hold their posts and run for re-election. Monday’s ruling is part of a push for electoral overhaul in India. In July, the Supreme Court barred people convicted of crimes carrying prison terms of more than five years from running in elections. On Monday, it ruled that lawmakers who are charged with crimes carrying a punishment of more than two years must have a speedy trial. The Association for Democratic Reforms, a nonprofit group that aims to promote electoral transparency, estimates that 30 percent of sitting lawmakers have criminal charges against them.

headline: Nets Defeat Raptors in a Playoff Atmosphere
abstract: The Nets moved within three games of the Atlantic Division-leading Toronto Raptors with a 101-97 home win on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Paul Pierce sank a 3-pointer with 1 minute 14 seconds remaining in the game Monday night and spent the next several seconds skipping deliberately back to the Nets’ bench — the whole time spinning clockwise with his right hand in the air — as fans at Barclays Center built a wall of noise around him.

headline: Despite Fears, Traffic Flows On After Tappan Zee Ramp Is Closed
abstract: During the evening rush hour on Monday, traffic was flowing smoothly on Route 9, where the ramp is set, and on the bridge itself.
lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — The traffic nightmare did not materialize.

headline: Turkish Court Orders Release of 19 More in Plot Case
abstract: The men were convicted with scores of others of plotting a coup in the Ergenekon case, which the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan used to break the political power of Turkey’s military.
lead_paragraph: An Istanbul court on Monday ordered the release of 19 men convicted with scores of others of plotting a coup in the controversial Ergenekon case, which the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan used to break the political power of Turkey’s military. The court said the men should be released because the Parliament recently reduced the maximum detention period before a conviction to five years, and the prisoners had already been detained longer than that. The court order followed the release of a former army chief last week after the Constitutional Court’s ruling critical of the conduct of the recently abolished Special Court that carried out the Ergenekon trial. The trial, which lasted five years, prompted criticism at home and abroad, with several international organizations describing the prosecution of the more than 200 suspects as unfair, with unnecessary arrests, secret witnesses and disputes over evidence. Some Turkish analysts characterized Monday’s releases as part of a bid by the government to increase its popularity before local elections in two weeks and gain the upper hand in a power struggle with a pro-Islamic network influential in the judiciary and the police.

headline: Patentholder on Breast Cancer Tests Denied Injunction in Lawsuit
keywords: ['Tests (Medical)', 'Breast Cancer', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: A federal judge in Utah refused to prevent a rival of Myriad Genetics from offering offer a test similar to Myriad’s for two genes tied to breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: Myriad Genetics, which lost a closely watched Supreme Court case last year involving the patenting of genes, has suffered another setback in its efforts to protect its main genetic test from competition.

headline: Obama’s New Approach Takes a Humorous Turn
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Youth']
abstract: The president’s interview on “Between Two Ferns,” an online parody of celebrity interview shows, is an attempt to get young people to sign up for health insurance on the government’s website.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In “Between Two Ferns,” an off-color online parody of celebrity interview shows, the comedian Zach Galifianakis has spanked Justin Bieber with his belt, discussed Charlize Theron’s thighs and asked Natalie Portman for her phone number.

headline: Knicks Win 4th Straight, but Phil Jackson Is Main Character
abstract: The specter of Jackson loomed over the proceedings as the Knicks escaped with a 123-110 victory to boost their push for a playoff spot.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks and the Philadelphia 76ers, two teams with unfortunate records, convened at Madison Square Garden on Monday night to play a game that was most notable because of one man’s absence.

headline: For Hateful Comic in France, Muzzle Becomes a Megaphone
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Discrimination', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Despite dozens of charges, French officials have been confounded in efforts to stop the performances of Dieudonné M’bala M’bala, who is seen as anti-Semitic.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Thirty-eight times in recent years the French authorities have charged the comedian Dieudonné M’bala M’bala with violating anti-hate laws. The government has urged cities and towns to ban his performances, and some have done so, canceling his sold-out shows. Senior officials have condemned him as an anti-Semitic Holocaust denier who is inciting hatred.

headline: Post-Fashion-Month Detox Recipes from Downtown’s Hippest, Healthiest Chefs
abstract: The owners of Dimes, a Chinatown cafe favored by the style set, share instructions for making a roasted-mushroom salad and spicy juice blend.
lead_paragraph: Now that fashion month has wrapped, the bi-continental throng is ready to atone for four weeks’ worth of long days and late nights, champagne and catering. If a spa getaway, juice cleanse or boot camp aren’t on the iCal, an equally virtuous (and altogether more convivial) course of action is to dine at Dimes, the pint-sized outpost of chic California-style cuisine in New York’s Chinatown. With their masterfully seasoned produce and inspired juices named after Agnes Martin paintings, the owner-chefs Sabrina De Sousa and Alissa Wagner prove that health and culinary creativity need not be mutually exclusive (at least on the East Coast). An in-house line of organic, aromatherapeutic lip balms and body products — along with decor that feels more Abiquiu than Allen Street — also help to lure a roster of repeat offenders. (Certain stylists, DJs and writers have been known to visit Dimes multiple times per week — even multiple times per day.) “Healthy restaurants get a bad rap,” says De Sousa. “We wanted to bring the idea of wellness into the mainstream with foods that are creative, beautiful and inspiring.”

headline: Even Before Fort Lee Lane Closings, Port Authority Was a Christie Tool
abstract: A review of the Port Authority’s operations suggests that it had been turned into a de facto political operation for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey long before the bridge scandal.
lead_paragraph: For a state that lost hundreds of lives on Sept. 11, the gifts were emotionally resonant: pieces of steel from the ruins of the World Trade Center. They were presented by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to 20 carefully chosen New Jersey mayors who sat atop a list of 100 whose endorsements Gov. Chris Christie hoped to win.

headline: Only 15 Percent of Top Films in 2013 Put Women in Lead Roles, Study Finds
abstract: A study from San Diego State University says women accounted for less than a third of all speaking roles in the year’s top-grossing domestic films.
lead_paragraph: “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.” “Frozen.” “Gravity.” Three of last year’s top 10 grossing films were led by female protagonists, making 2013 a banner year for women in film, right?

headline: Q. and A. on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: Matthew L. Wald, who has written about aviation for The New York Times, answers questions about the communications equipment on the plane, and whether or not we’ll ever know what happened that night.
lead_paragraph: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has left investigators, aviation experts and the authorities in several countries at a loss to explain what happened. And the few slender clues that have emerged only seem to lead to more questions. As the search broadens and the international inquiries continue, Matthew L. Wald, a correspondent for The New York Times, answers some basic questions:

headline: Word of the Day | repeal
abstract: This word has appeared in 466 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: repeal •\ri-ˈpel\• verb and noun

headline: Times Minute | Politicizing 9/11 Rubble
keywords: ['Mexican Food (Cuisine)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (El Rey) FROM DUSK TILL DAWN: THE SERIES The director Robert Rodriguez spins off his 1996 supernatural cult western as the first original scripted series on his new English-language cable channel, aimed at Hispanic audiences. D. J. Cotrona, above, and Zane Holtz star as the violently unpredictable Gecko brothers, on the lam from the F.B.I. and a couple of Texas Rangers (Don Johnson and Jesse Garcia) after a deadly bank heist. Fleeing to Mexico, they cross the border in the R.V. of a former pastor (Robert Patrick). But chaos ensues when a detour to a strip club populated by vampires forces them to fight for their lives until sunrise. “I thought it would be best to start with a property people knew for a network people didn’t know,” Mr. Rodriguez said in a recent interview, about adapting the film, which was written by Quentin Tarantino. As a result, he added, “we have an identity right off the bat.”

headline: Joe McGinniss, 71, Dies; Chronicled Politics and Sensational Crime
abstract: Mr. McGinniss’s books examined political figures like Sarah Palin and Richard M. Nixon and, in ‘Fatal Vision,’ a notorious criminal case.
lead_paragraph: Drawn to the kind of serious subject that had a tabloid sheen, Joe McGinniss, who died on Monday at 71, was a journalist provocateur whose book-length probes into political lives and horrific crimes often triggered controversy, critical debate and mega-sales.

headline: How to Help the Working Poor
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Minimum Wage', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The minimum wage and the earned income tax credit address similar problems differently, and don’t always work smoothly together, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Chinese Satellites Redeployed to Search for Malaysia Airlines Plane
abstract: As China waits for news of the missing Malaysia Airlines flight, most of whose passengers were Chinese, its military said it had redeployed 10 satellites to aid the search.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:12 a.m. ET| China said it had “immediately redeployed” 10 satellites to help in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared early Saturday with 239 people, mostly Chinese, on board, as frustration mounted among families of the missing over the lack of progress.

headline: In Delhi, Hopeful Patients Turn to a Razor Blade for Treatment
abstract: New Delhi is full of world-class hospitals, but for some chronic sufferers, only the ancient medical practice of bloodletting will ease their pain.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On a brisk winter morning, Dwarka Mistry, 61, sat waiting for a doctor, along with four others, on an iron bench behind Jama Masjid, a Mughal-era mosque in the old part of the capital. Despair covered Mr. Mistry’s face as he clutched his knees and thighs from time to time.

headline: Corrections: March 11, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 11, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: Q. & A.: Cmdr. William Marks of the U.S. Navy 7th Fleet on the Search for the Malaysian Jet
abstract: Cmdr. William Marks, the spokesman for the United States Navy Seventh Fleet, calls the search effort a “challenging puzzle” that is getting more complicated as every hour passes.
lead_paragraph: Two United States Navy guided-missile destroyers, the Pinckney and Kidd, are among the dozens of ships searching for the Malaysia Airlines plane that disappeared while flying from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Beijing. The Pinckney has been searching since Sunday, sending out a helicopter that has been scanning the sea for signs of the missing plane and any survivors. A United States Navy P-3C Orion maritime surveillance aircraft has also been participating in the search, flying out from Subang Jaya, Malaysia. The Kidd joined the hunt on Monday.

headline: Test Yourself | History, March 11
abstract: Answer this question about World War II.
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | In a Native American Sport, a Family’s Giant Leap
abstract: How did the Thompsons open the door for other lacrosse players living on reservations?
lead_paragraph: In “In a Native American Sport, a Family’s Giant Leap,” Zach Schonbrun writes about a trailblazing family in college lacrosse.

headline: What Comes After Rich Baby Boomers? Kids With a Big Inheritance
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Baby Boomers', 'Income', 'Income Inequality', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: An enormous, intergenerational transfer of wealth is imminent. What sort of country will it leave in its wake?
lead_paragraph: The Waltons might be the closest thing we have to the Carnegies or Rockefellers today. The heirs to the Walmart fortune occupy six slots on the most recent Forbes 400 list, and just those six Waltons — not counting their lucky progeny — are worth $145 billion. But the Waltons are in the distinct minority on the Forbes list. In this new Gilded Age, rich Americans are more likely to have made their own fortunes than to have inherited them.

headline: Does a Championship Game Always Need to Have a Winner (and a Loser)?
abstract: What’s wrong with everybody being a winner? Does sharing a championship trophy somehow demean the honor?
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, two Ohio high school ice hockey teams walked away as state champions after seven overtimes and a tie score — and the crowd booed loudly and chanted, “Let them play!”

headline: Inside Roger Ballen’s Mind: A Place of Refuge and Madness
abstract: Roger Ballen’s images of hundreds of birds in an abandoned house are both haunting and disturbingly complex — transforming the physical world into the psychological world.
lead_paragraph: An asylum can be either a refuge or a place of madness. In Roger Ballen’s new book, “Asylum of the Birds,” it’s both.

headline: Stolen Passports on Plane Not Seen as Terror Link
abstract: Interpol said that two passengers known to have used stolen passports to board the Malaysia Airlines jet that vanished were unlikely to be linked to terrorist groups.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — Two Iranians known to have used stolen passports to board the Malaysia Airlines jet that disappeared on Saturday were unlikely to be linked to terrorist groups, international police authorities said, echoing an assessment by the Malaysian police that one of them was a 19-year-old who wanted to migrate to Germany.

headline: New York Today: When the Bronx Invaded Manhattan
abstract: What you need to know for Tuesday: an intra-borough border war, balmy weather, and a runaway boy returns.

headline: China Details Plans to Liberalize Interest Rates and Encourage Private Banks
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Analysts welcomed the announcements, which signaled progress in a far-ranging plan of overhauls designed to modernize the country’s financial system.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The head of China’s central bank and other top financial regulators offered new details on Tuesday on the country’s steps toward a more market-driven economy, including plans to liberalize interest rates as early as next year and to allow the establishment of the first privately owned official banks.

headline: Daily Report: Icahn’s Fight Against eBay
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, is in a battle with Marc Andreessen, the entrepreneur turned technology investor.
lead_paragraph: One of the sharper business battles in recent weeks has been playing out between Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, and Marc Andreessen, the entrepreneur turned technology investor. It’s a fight that pits Wall Street against Silicon Valley, Andrew Ross Sorkin reports.

headline: Air Links Are Severed as Russia Tightens Its Grip on Crimean Peninsula
keywords: ['Elections', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Referendums', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Declaring that he remained commander in chief, Viktor F. Yanukovych denounced the West for rushing to recognize the interim authorities and to provide financial assistance.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The airport in the regional capital of Simferopol was closed on Tuesday to all flights except those heading to and from Moscow, in the boldest display yet of Russia’s tightening control over Crimea.

headline: North Korea Ably Evades Its Sanctions, Panel Says
abstract: Recent seizures of banned cargo show that Pyongyang has used increasingly deceptive techniques, the panel’s report to the Security Council says.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Recent inspections and seizures of banned cargo have shown that North Korea is using increasingly deceptive techniques to circumvent international sanctions, a panel of experts said in a report to the United Nations Security Council published Tuesday.

headline: The Surprisingly Large Cost of Telling Small Lies
abstract: A university study about lying did not investigate the number of lies told by entrepreneurs looking for investment capital, but I fear we would top the chart.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I caught up with one of our angel investors for lunch: Peter is a brilliant entrepreneur from England who has lived all over the world. He has built several businesses and now lives a dream life with a house on a harbor, a happy family and a broad smile.

headline: Maoist Guerrillas Ambush Police in Chhattisgarh
abstract: An estimated 100 insurgents attacked police officers who were clearing a road for a construction crew in central India, a state police spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At least 15 police officers and a civilian were killed by an estimated 100 Maoist guerrillas in central India on Tuesday as the officers were clearing a road to allow a construction crew to pass through.

headline: Protests in Venezuela
abstract: Demonstrations are continuing around the country.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrations are continuing around the country.

headline: Western Journalist Is Shot and Killed as Kabul Mourns Official’s Death
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The attack on a Swedish reporter was the first time in years that a foreigner appeared to have been specifically targeted and killed in Kabul.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two men shot a Swedish reporter on a crowded street in Kabul on Tuesday, in a rare assassination-style killing of a Westerner that raised new questions about the safety of the large international presence expected to remain here after American-led combat forces depart this year.

headline: With $21 Billion Loss, Italian Bank Signals Wider Vulnerabilities
abstract: The lender says its holdings are far less valuable than thought, as the European Central Bank plans to scrutinize the books of euro zone banks.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s biggest bank reported a huge loss on Tuesday, foreshadowing the possibility that many financial institutions across Europe could be forced to acknowledge the full extent of their own problems under increased regulatory scrutiny.

headline: Icahn’s Fight Against eBay
abstract: Marc Andreessen has become a target of Carl C. Icahn. | Positive News for Puerto Rico on the sale of roughly $3 billion in bonds. | Chiquita to become the king of bananas with a deal for an Irish fruit company. | The Blackstone Group and TPG Capital are said to be joining forces in a bid for Gates Global.
lead_paragraph: Marc Andreessen, the entrepreneur turned technology investor, has recently been caught in the verbal cross hairs of the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. The war of words stems from Mr. Icahn’s campaign to pressure eBay, the online auction company, to spin off its electronic payment unit PayPal. Among other things, he has accused Mr. Andreessen, an eBay board member, of various conflicts of interest that affected eBay’s sale of Skype in 2009 for $2.75 billion to a group of investors that included Mr. Andreessen’s venture capital firm.

headline: A Less Glossy Take on Teenage Life
abstract: Lorde played the first of three sold-out shows on Monday night at Roseland Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: The most gratifying moment at this year’s Grammy Awards came just after Lorde was announced as the winner of the best pop solo performance, for “Royals.” The camera caught her in a calm inhale, leaning forward in her seat, eyes bugging just a bit: Her demeanor was part shock, part shrug. The observer had become the observed, but she was still keeping a watchful eye.

headline: In Our Pages: March 12
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Arts Minister Asks for Credit

headline: From Acne Studios, Wearable Art by an Abstract-Painting Pioneer
abstract: The Swedish brand releases a capsule collection of pieces bearing the work of the painter and mystic Hilma af Klint.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish design house Acne Studios has a long history of collaborating with artists and designers, including Lanvin, Liberty of London and the jeweler Husam El Odeh. This season, the line’s creative director, Jonny Johansson, enlisted a figure from the past: the artist Hilma af Klint, whose colorful early-20th-century abstract paintings were informed by her studies in mysticism and the occult. Not only did her work provide conceptual and color inspiration for his men’s and women’s spring collections, but he also designed T-shirts, sweatshirts and scarves — available today exclusively at acnestudios.com — that bear prints scanned directly from the artist’s canvases.

headline: After Scandal, a New Name for SAC: Point72
abstract: The firm’s founder, Steven A. Cohen, is hoping the new name will help bring to a close an investigation into accusations of insider trading that has dogged SAC for nearly 10 years.
lead_paragraph: The name of the hedge fund proudly reflected its founder, Steven A. Cohen: SAC Capital Advisors. But eager to put its guilty plea to securities fraud charges behind it, the diminished firm is getting a new name that makes no reference to the billionaire investor: Point72 Asset Management.

headline: Subject, Meet Verb
abstract: Every job has its joyless tasks. It’s time again for one of mine: pointing out that singular subjects should go with singular verbs, and plural subjects with plural verbs, just as singular pronouns should be used to refer to singular antecedents, and plural pronouns to plural antecedents.
lead_paragraph: Every job has its joyless tasks. It’s time again for one of mine: pointing out that singular subjects should go with singular verbs, and plural subjects with plural verbs. A related bit of drudgery is reminding colleagues that singular pronouns should be used to refer to singular antecedents, and plural pronouns to plural antecedents.

headline: Not ‘Looking Backwards’ at Torture, Continued
abstract: The Obama administration is yet again trying to deny a day in court to former Guantanamo prisoners.
lead_paragraph: A recent post by the Editorial Page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, criticized the Central Intelligence Agency’s effort to keep secret two reports on its post-9/11 detention and interrogation practices.

headline: Bangladesh Inspections Find Gaps in Safety
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Textiles', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Nearly a year after the collapse of a factory building killed more than 1,100 workers, reports released on Tuesday detail problems at 10 other factories.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after a factory building collapsed in Bangladesh, killing more than 1,100 workers, engineering teams sponsored by Western retailers have been rigorously inspecting that country’s garment industry, resulting in at least two temporary closings because of safety problems.

headline: Wheelies: The More Hybrids Edition
abstract: Toyota says hybrids may soon account for 20 percent of its global sales; Honda announces the Acura brand’s realignment into a separate division.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Video: Tilda Swinton at SXSW
abstract: The actress discusses her role as a vampire in “Only Lovers Left Alive.”
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The actress Tilda Swinton made her first trip to the South by Southwest film festival with the vampire feature she stars in, “Only Lovers Left Alive.” In that film, the latest from the director Jim Jarmusch, she plays a 3,000-year-old vampire in a very, very long-term relationship. In this video, Ms. Swinton discusses more about the film and how she brought her immortal role to life.

headline: Is It Harder to Write About Happiness Than Its Opposite?
abstract: Leslie Jamison and Adam Kirsch discuss the old saw that says “happiness writes white.”
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Leslie Jamison and Adam Kirsch discuss the difficulties in writing about happiness.

headline: The Read Around: Blake Bailey
abstract: The biographer Blake Bailey tells the story of his own family in “The Splendid Things We Planned.”
lead_paragraph: The biographer Blake Bailey tells the story of his own family in “The Splendid Things We Planned.”

headline: Conflict Erupts in Public Rebuke on C.I.A. Inquiry
abstract: Senator Dianne Feinstein, the chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said the C.I.A. searched computers being used by committee staff members to investigate the agency’s interrogation tactics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A festering conflict between the Central Intelligence Agency and its congressional overseers broke into the open Tuesday when Senator Dianne Feinstein, chairwoman of the Intelligence Committee and one of the C.I.A.’s staunchest defenders, delivered an extraordinary denunciation of the agency, accusing it of withholding information about its treatment of prisoners and trying to intimidate committee staff members investigating the detention program.

headline: A Story of Perseverance
abstract: Each recurrence of cancer seems more dire, and yet after each, Stuart Scott has returned to his high-profile work at ESPN, ensuring that his private fight also has become a very public one.
lead_paragraph: WEST HARTFORD, Conn. — Inside the mixed martial arts studio, Stuart Scott lifted the black T-shirt that read, “Everyday I Fight.” Beneath was a footlong scar that bisected the ESPN anchor’s washboard abs.

lead_paragraph: Slides here (pdf).

headline: Plea Deal Talks Begin After Sexual Assault Trial Against Army General Is Halted
keywords: ['Courts-Martial', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Jurors in the trial of Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair were sent back to their regular duties as lawyers tried to resolve the case.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — In a series of phone calls and emails on Tuesday, military officials and lawyers for Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair began their first full day of negotiations on a plea agreement that would end the sexual assault case against the general, who is accused of bullying a junior officer into sex and threatening her life.

headline: A Kindly Detour From the Bronx
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A young woman guided a newcomer from Italy in the right direction on the subway, leaving a permanent impression.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Video: Blake Bailey on Writing About His Own Life
abstract: The literary biographer talks about his new memoir, “The Splendid Things We Planned.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, the biographer Blake Bailey discusses writing about his own life, including his troubled relationship with his brother, in “The Splendid Things We Planned.”

headline: Globe Theater Draws Criticism for Planned North Korea Trip
abstract: The stop is part of the Globe’s ambitious plan to tour “Hamlet” to every country in the world.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Globe Theater’s plan to take its production of “Hamlet” to North Korea in 2015 has drawn criticism from the human rights group Amnesty International, The Guardian reported. The stop in North Korea is part of the Globe’s ambitious plan to tour “Hamlet” to every country in the world over the next two years; the tour begins in England on April 23, the 450th anniversary of the day traditionally observed as Shakespeare’s birthday, at the company’s home theater here.

headline: Market Report | Grand Prix
abstract: Indulge a need for speed with revved-up watches driven by dashboard aesthetics and racing-color combinations.
lead_paragraph: Indulge a need for speed with revved-up watches driven by dashboard aesthetics and racing-color combinations.

headline: Founder Missing in Men’s Wearhouse Deal for Jos. A. Bank
abstract: Almost accidentally, George Zimmer, through his actions, slapped a red-letter “Sale” sign on the company he had founded..
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | The man who inadvertently lit the fuse that led to the hottest takeover battle in years was left unmentioned in the announcement of a $1.8 billion merger of two once-warring men’s suits chains.

headline: Salesman Swimming With Sharks
keywords: ['Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Interviewing President Obama on the online comedy show “Between Two Ferns” on Tuesday, Zach Galifianakis deployed his signature rude barbs.
lead_paragraph: Trying to explain why young people should buy health insurance, President Obama said his health care plan would cost consumers no more than their cellphone bills. His host, Zach Galifianakis, looked bored. “Is this what they mean by drones?”

headline: Authorities ID Passenger
abstract: Malaysian authorities said one of the two stolen passport holders on the missing flight MH370 is an Iranian who might have been migrating to Germany.
lead_paragraph: Malaysian authorities said one of the two stolen passport holders on the missing flight MH370 is an Iranian who might have been migrating to Germany.

headline: Bitcoin Foundation Bolsters Its Ranks
abstract: Jim Harper of the Cato Institute will act as government liaison, as regulators struggle with how to oversee the evolving world of digital currency. Amy Weiss, a former White House deputy press secretary, was also brought on as an outside consultant.
lead_paragraph: The Bitcoin Foundation is adding to its ranks as regulators around the world struggle with how to oversee the evolving world of digital currency.

headline: Today in Small Business: #Hashtags
abstract: Searching for America’s most social business. A warning for small businesses using Windows XP. Printing Oreos.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

lead_paragraph: A look at the unconventional political tactics in Washington, including President Obama's appearance on a comedy show, a Senate all-nighter and a confirmation hearing.
