lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: N.S.A. Nominee Promotes Cyberwar Units
abstract: Citing cyberattacks on the new Ukrainian government, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, said “cyber will be an element of every crisis.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — All of the major combat commands in the United States military will soon have dedicated forces to conduct cyberattacks alongside their air, naval and ground capabilities, Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, President Obama’s nominee to run the National Security Agency, told the Senate on Tuesday. He said the activation of the long-discussed combat units would help counter the perception around the world that the United States is “an easier mark” for cyberattacks because it did not “have the will to respond.”

headline: The Foreign Currency Fix
keywords: ['Currency', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Regulators say that a group of London traders, known as the “cartel” and the “mafia,” illegally dipped into the $5.3-trillion-a-day currency trade.
lead_paragraph: Regulators say that a group of London traders, known as the “cartel” and the “mafia,” illegally dipped into the $5.3-trillion-a-day currency trade.

headline: Choosing a Preschool: Order Amid Chaos, or Structure Above All?
abstract: My husband and I sometimes found ourselves on opposite sides of questions around structure and child-rearing, and our emotional legacies accompanied us on every preschool visit. Would our daughter thrive amid chaos, or order — or either?
lead_paragraph: The rickety elevator opened into this cluttered loft with hanging papier-mâché legumes and what sounded like 200 screeching children. Jon and I barely removed Zee’s winter layers before she was off to the (what else) doll section, which was mountainous, with a cradle and wooden kitchen. This Bohemian nursery had no formal interview process but instead a wine-and-cheese open house and now, a “family meeting,” with at least 10 families. The school’s curriculum centered on choice: Each day, each child chose whatever activity — music, art, dance — she wanted.

headline: Farewell, Latitude
abstract: With the expansion of The New York Times’s international opinion report, the Latitude blog, which began in October 2011, has been retired.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 31, 2011, The International Herald Tribune started an opinion blog featuring strong views from writers around the world. Over the next two years and two months, each post in this series tried to capture the feel of a place, from a fresh perspective.

headline: France Returns Three Paintings Looted by Nazis
abstract: The French culture minister has returned three looted oil paintings on Tuesday to families who had been pressing claims for years.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A year after France pledged to search aggressively for the rightful owners of art looted by the Nazis in World War II, the French culture minister returned three oil paintings on Tuesday here to families who had been pressing claims for years.

headline: Demand Stronger Than Expected for Puerto Rico Debt
abstract: The commonwealth sold $3.5 billion of debt — more than it originally planned — at an 8.72 percent yield.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:46 p.m. | Faced with strong demand from hedge funds and wealthy individuals, Puerto Rico sold 17 percent more debt on Tuesday than it had originally planned, a sign that the commonwealth still has ample access to the capital markets.

headline: Blackstone to Acquire Cybersecurity Firm Accuvant
abstract: The private equity firm announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in Accuvant, which offers cybersecurity software and consulting services to companies and governments.
lead_paragraph: With the prospect of cyberattacks keeping corporations on edge, the Blackstone Group is investing in a company that aims to counteract such threats.

headline: Bank of England Governor Pledges More Integrity After Currency Inquiry
abstract: Mark J. Carney, the Bank of England’s governor, told lawmakers on Tuesday that the central bank adopted stricter policies. Next week, the Bank of England will also outline plans to revamp its organization.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Bank of England’s reputation is at stake as its independent directors conduct a review into whether bank officials knew of or condoned potential manipulation of the currency markets, Mark J. Carney, the bank’s governor, told lawmakers on Tuesday.

headline: Citing Urgent Need, U.S. Calls on Hospitals to Hone Disaster Plans
abstract: Federal officials are proposing sweeping new requirements for American health care facilities, but the health industry has balked at the hefty price tag associated with the changes.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials are proposing sweeping new requirements for American health care facilities — from large hospitals to small group homes for the mentally disabled — intended to ensure their readiness to care for patients during disasters.

headline: Confusion Over Plane’s Route Frustrates Families and Search
abstract: A Malaysian official said a missing jetliner may have changed its path at the time communications ended, possibly explaining the westward expansion of the search area.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — Malaysian authorities now believe that a jetliner missing since Saturday may have radically changed course around the time that it lost contact with ground controllers, news that added to the air of confusion and disarray surrounding the investigation and search operation. But they gave conflicting accounts of the apparent course change and of what may have happened afterward.

headline: Victory in Florida Race Bolsters Midterm Hopes for Republicans
abstract: The Republican candidate, David Jolly, defeated the Democrat, Alex Sink, to fill a congressional seat on Florida’s Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — In a major victory for Republicans in the battle for control of Congress, David Jolly, a former lobbyist, narrowly won a special election for a House seat on Tuesday in a hotly contested swing district, giving the party an expensive triumph in its fight against President Obama’s health care plan.

headline: Judge Hears Arguments on Subpoenas to Christie Associates
abstract: Two former aides to Gov. Chris Christie have refused to turn over documents related to the lane closings scandal, saying it would violate their right against self-incrimination.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — The questions for Bridget Anne Kelly from reporters were so relentless — Does she have any regrets? How would it hurt her to surrender her emails? How is she holding up? — that her lawyer finally felt compelled to answer.

headline: Freedom From Driving
abstract: More people used buses, trains and subways in 2013 than in any year since 1956.
lead_paragraph: Americans are catching on to the joys of not driving.

headline: Good Irish Coffee Starts With the Cow
abstract: Jack McGarry, bar manager of the Dead Rabbit in New York, hunts down quality cream for its Irish coffee.
lead_paragraph: Craft cocktail bartenders can be quite particular about ingredients. To create the perfect drink, they’ll go out of their way to secure an obscure brand of whiskey or rum, a hard-to-get foreign liqueur, or a fruit or herb available only on alternate Wednesdays at a farmers’ market in Queens. But the Dead Rabbit, a financial district bar that evokes 19th-century New York, may be the first in town to hunt down a special cream for its Irish coffee.

headline: New Skrillex Album Revealed in Phone App
abstract: Skrillex’s new album, “Recess,” was made available on Monday night via a mobile phone app, and can be previewed on iTunes.
lead_paragraph: The D.J. and producer Skrillex, long known for his surprising use of timbres, textures and found sounds – and for unusual release strategies, like giving away his 2007 EP, “My Name Is Skrillex,” on his MySpace page – has found an unexpected way to release his new album, “Recess.” The set was scheduled for a conventional release, on CD and as a download, on March 18.

headline: Image of the Day: March 11
abstract: A woman at an election rally in Balasinor, Gujarat.

headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Look at G.M. Actions on Safety Flaws
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The investigation is the latest in a widening series into G.M.’s handling of faulty ignition switches in its Chevrolet Cobalt sedan and other cars that the company says are linked to 31 accidents and 13 deaths.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation into General Motors’ decade-long failure to address deadly safety problems before announcing a huge vehicle recall last month, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: As Goes Andrew Sullivan, So Goes Pluralism
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Homosexuality', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Further thoughts on religious liberty and same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: In the interests of further clarity, I want to return to the subject of gay marriage and religious liberty, and respond to some comments from Andrew Sullivan on the subject. Answering my original column on the same-sex marriage endgame and its potential aftermath, Sullivan drew a distinction that I think a lot of libertarian-minded Americans would be inclined draw:

headline: Farm-to-Table Living Takes Root
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: Home buyers who crave open spaces, verdant fields and fresh food are flocking to “agrihoods.”
lead_paragraph: GILBERT, Ariz. — In many American suburbs, outward signs of life are limited to the blue glow of television screens flickering behind energy-efficient windows. But in a subdivision of this bedroom community outside Phoenix, amid precision-cut lawns and Craftsman-style homes, lambs caper in common green areas, chickens scratch in a citrus grove and residents roam rows of heirloom vegetables to see what might be good for dinner.

headline: Cyprus Names Its Top Auditor to Lead Central Bank
abstract: Chrystalla Georghadji, who has been the country’s anticorruption watchdog since 1998, had been investigating the central bank governor.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Cyprus on Tuesday appointed Chrystalla Georghadji, an anticorruption watchdog, to replace its central banker, who resigned abruptly a day earlier in the face of tensions with the government.

headline: A Camp for Those With Nut Allergies
abstract: The Medomak Family Camp in Maine will have a nut-free week in June.
lead_paragraph: Medomak Family Camp in Washington, Me., always accommodates campers who have nut allergies, but this year it’s offering a special nut-free week, June 22 to 28.

headline: Barack Obama, Between Two Ferns
abstract: The president can be frustrating, but he’s also funny.
lead_paragraph: As frustrating as President Obama can be (think drones, wiretapping and refusing to get a full accounting of torture and rendition), he can also be incredibly charming and funny. It’s hard to imagine any president (including Bill Clinton) going on “Between Two Ferns” with Zach Galifianakis and doing far more than just holding his own.

headline: Iranian Lawmaker Blames U.S. for Plane Disappearance
abstract: An influential Iranian lawmaker accused the United States of having “kidnapped” Flight 370, saying it was an attempt to “sabotage the relationship between Iran and China and South East Asia.”
lead_paragraph: With the fate and location of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet still unexplained on Tuesday, the police were investigating the possibilities of hijacking, sabotage and possible psychological or personal problems among the crew and passengers, while other agencies in Malaysia continued to investigate noncriminal explanations, as Thomas Fuller, Jane Perlez and Alan Cowell reported.

headline: Keith Richards Is Writing a Children’s Book. Yes, a Children’s Book.
abstract: Keith Richards, a grandfather himself, is writing a children’s book about his own grandfather.
lead_paragraph: It’s not as if Keith Richards has time on his hands: the Rolling Stones, after all, are in the middle of a Far East tour that will take them to Shanghai on Wednesday, then to Singapore and, next week, to Australia. But Mr. Richards, who wrote “Life” (2010), his doorstop of an autobiography, when the Stones were between projects, has another book in the works, this time with an audience of children in mind. Little, Brown Books for Young Readers announced on Tuesday that it would publish Mr. Richards’s “Gus & Me: The Story of My Granddad and My First Guitar,” as both a hardcover book with a CD and an ebook on Sept. 9.

headline: Inquiries to Change Dynamics of Currency Trading
abstract: The heightened sensitivity about fairness to clients will probably see even more foreign exchange business being done on electronic trading platforms, contends Swaha Pattanaik of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Around the world, investigators are trying to find out if the largely unregulated foreign exchange market was manipulated. Even before the investigations are completed, the pace of change will pick up in the $5 trillion-a-day market, in both what moves currencies and the way business is done.

headline: Purim Pastries, a Library Cafe and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of March 11.
lead_paragraph: To Enjoy: For Purim, Triangles With Savory Fillings

headline: Amid Escalating Violence, Israeli Strike Kills 3 Militants in Gaza
abstract: The airstrike and the unrelated crash of an Israeli surveillance drone came amid an increase in cross-border violence that has threatened a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli airstrike in the southeast Gaza Strip on Tuesday morning killed three Palestinian militants who the Israeli military said had fired a mortar at its soldiers patrolling near the border, hours after a pilotless Israeli surveillance drone crashed nearby.

headline: The C.I.A. Torture Cover-Up
keywords: ['Torture', 'Interrogations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Detainees', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Editorials']
abstract: Sen. Feinstein today provided stark evidence that the C.I.A. may have committed crimes to prevent the exposure of brutal interrogation practices.
lead_paragraph: It was outrageous enough when two successive presidents papered over the Central Intelligence Agency’s history of illegal detention, rendition, torture and fruitless harsh interrogation of terrorism suspects. Now the leader of the Senate intelligence committee, Dianne Feinstein, has provided stark and convincing evidence that the C.I.A. may have committed crimes to prevent the exposure of interrogations that she said were “far different and far more harsh” than anything the agency had described to Congress.

headline: Feinstein Questions C.I.A. Search
abstract: Senator Dianne Feinstein states on the Senate floor that the Central Intelligence Agency has accessed the computers of the Senate intelligence committee.
lead_paragraph: Senator Dianne Feinstein states on the Senate floor that the Central Intelligence Agency has accessed the computers of the Senate intelligence committee.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Board Sides With President, Report Suggests
abstract: The Star Tribune reported that the orchestra’s board is backing its president and chief executive, Michael Henson, against the wishes of Osmo Vanska, its former music director.
lead_paragraph: The board of the Minnesota Orchestra is staying silent on its plans to try to recover from a debilitating 16-month lockout, but a report published Tuesday in The Star Tribune suggested it is siding with the orchestra’s president against the wishes of its former music director.

headline: Front and Center in Ukraine Race, a Leader of the Far Right
abstract: When Russia’s politicized state media talks about those who pulled off what the Kremlin calls a coup in Kiev, they have men like Dmytro Yarosh in mind.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — During the Independence Square protests, Dmytro Yarosh made a name for himself as an expert with firebombs. Now, just weeks later, Mr. Yarosh, leader of the right-wing coalition known as Right Sector, says he is running for president.

headline: Helping Families With Chinese Children
abstract: Xiaoning Wang, an immigrant from China based in New York, was inspired to start her company after seeing so many American parents adopt Chinese girls. Her company sells Chinese educational products.
lead_paragraph: Xiaoning Wang, an immigrant from China based in New York, was inspired to start her company after seeing so many American parents adopt Chinese girls. Her company sells Chinese educational products.

headline: U.N. Denies Altering Image of Palestinian Refugees in Damascus
abstract: A United Nations spokesman rejected claims that an arresting image of thousands of Palestinian refugees waiting for food distribution on a ruined street in Damascus recently had been digitally altered.
lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the United Nations agency that provides assistance to Palestinian refugees rejected claims that an arresting image of thousands of people waiting for food distribution on a ruined street in Damascus recently had been digitally altered.

headline: No Questions About I.V.F. in Israel
abstract: I had grown so used to the need to justify my choices about fertility treatments in the United States. In Israel, so many things were just assumed. Of course you want children. Of course!
lead_paragraph: In the 13 years since I had left Jerusalem, souk Mahane Yehuda. which sells fruit, vegetables, spices and household goods, had become a thriving restaurant and night-life scene. A D.J. was spinning in one of the side alleys, 20-somethings were smoking hookahs at a bar, and Solomon and I were meeting some of his friends for some kubbeh in an establishment famous for its bulgar-encrusted meatballs.

headline: Ask Me Anything
abstract: Soliciting questions for a reader Q&A.
lead_paragraph: Well, maybe not anything … but in imitation of my fellow columnist Nick Kristof, who boldly fielded reader questions a few months ago, I’m inviting your volleys this week. The format will be roughly the same as it was with my colleague, with the slight, not-entirely-flattering-to-me difference that he was writing from Kenya and I’ll probably be writing from a coffee shop in Capitol Hill: Readers should post their questions in the comment thread of this post, we’ll sift for a representative selection, and I’ll try to wrap as many answers as possible into a post later on this week. (And, hopefully, contain my prolix tendencies along the way.)

headline: Owners Compare Notes on Expansion and Software Challenges
abstract: “That could completely reinvent the way magazines make revenue,” one owner said.
lead_paragraph: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about new deals, partnerships and software woes.

headline: SXSW Q. and A. | Tilda Swinton
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The inimitable actress discusses her role in “Only Lovers Left Alive,” the new vampires-in-love film by the director Jim Jarmusch.
lead_paragraph: “Will they bite,” Tilda Swinton asks, “or not?” This is Swinton’s distillation of the current tweenish vampire formula, offered without a touch of snobbery. “I am out of that loop just because I’m idle and have other things to do,” she says. “I’m not not interested, I just haven’t seen ‘Twilight.'”

headline: Virtual Exchange Plans Are Sought in New York
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Benjamin Lawsky, the superintendent of New York’s Department of Financial Services, issued his first public order on virtual currencies like Bitcoin, calling for proposals for creating regulated exchanges.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:48 p.m. | At a time when some government agencies are backing away from virtual currency, New York’s top financial regulator is taking a big step forward.

headline: Senators Draft Housing Finance Overhaul
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The plan, from the Democratic chairman and top Republican on the Banking Committee, will seek to make future taxpayer bailouts less likely.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top Democrat and Republican on the Senate Banking Committee said on Tuesday that they had agreed on a plan to overhaul the nation’s housing finance system and eliminate Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage giants that were bailed out by taxpayers in 2008.

headline: The Drug-Fueled Uphill Ride and Headlong Crash of a Secular Saint
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Doping (Sports)']
abstract: In “Cycle of Lies,” Juliet Macur offers a scrupulously reported portrait of Lance Armstrong as not just an incorrigible liar but also a profane bully.
lead_paragraph: Early in her compelling account of the downfall of the cyclist Lance Armstrong, Juliet Macur provides us with a glimpse of just how manipulative he remained, even as his world crashed down around him. Cut loose by his sponsors and steeped in legal issues stemming from the lifetime ban he received for doping, Mr. Armstrong, a record seven-time winner of the Tour de France, invited Ms. Macur to visit him at his Texas estate as he prepared to downsize to less pricey accommodations.

headline: SXSW 2014: Another Year, Even More Sprawl
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: There are more than 2000 acts performing in Austin through this weekend, and at least a few are still hoping SXSW is a gateway to something bigger.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Has it been a year already? I’m back in Austin for the South By Southwest Music Festival, the showcase for 2,000-plus bands that just keeps sprawling further: beyond its Texas roots-rock origins, beyond its rapid spread as an indie and alternative and fringe pop showcase, beyond its geographically particular, you-had-to-be-there status to its Internet incarnation as a web stage for events to be streamed and archived, photographed, Tweeted and Tumblred.

headline: 'Teenage' Excerpt | Bright Young People
abstract: A clip from Matt Wolf’s documentary Teenage.
lead_paragraph: A clip from Matt Wolf’s documentary Teenage.

headline: The Gun Report: March 11, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Make no mistake: Peter Lanza knew his son, Adam, the perpetrator of the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary, was a very sick boy.

headline: Rogers Appears Before Senate
abstract: Vice Admiral Michael S. Rogers testifies at a Senate Armed Services Committee on his nomination to run the National Security Agency.
lead_paragraph: Vice Admiral Michael S. Rogers testifies at a Senate Armed Services Committee on his nomination to run the National Security Agency.

headline: Will the Real Satoshi Nakamoto Please Stand Up?
abstract: Particularly in Japan, those named Satoshi Nakamoto have been garnering a lot of attention as the search continues for the creator of Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Satoshi Nakamoto of Fujisawa, Japan, is a shoe repairman.

headline: The New Big East: In Spartan Offices, an Ornate Vision
abstract: After a drastic realignment and a season of change under Commissioner Val Ackerman, the conference headed into its tournament that begins Wednesday at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: On the 24th floor of the Proskauer Rose law firm’s office in Midtown Manhattan, Val Ackerman greeted a visitor last week for a tour of the temporary headquarters of the new Big East Conference.

headline: Health Care Enrollment Falls Short of Goal, With Deadline Approaching
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The number of people who signed up for private health insurance under the Affordable Care Act in February declined for the second month in a row.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost a million people signed up last month for private health insurance under the Affordable Care Act, federal officials said Tuesday, bringing the total to date to 4.2 million but leaving the Obama administration well short of its original goal, with less than a month to go before the end of the open enrollment period.

headline: Text to Text | ‘The Prince’ and ‘Why Machiavelli Still Matters’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we pair Machiavelli’s “The Prince” with the Times Opinion article “Why Machiavelli Still Matters” by John T. Scott and Robert Zaretsky.
lead_paragraph: The political philosopher Niccolò Machiavelli wrote “The Prince” as a manual on leadership and governing during the late Italian Renaissance, a time of feuding family dynasties and warring city-states. But even though 500 years have passed, and the world is a very different place, “The Prince” somehow feels as relevant as ever in modern culture and politics.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and More
abstract: Japan and Elsewhere — Picture of the Day
lead_paragraph: Japan and Elsewhere — Picture of the Day

headline: C. J. Chivers on Instagram
abstract: The senior correspondent for The New York Times has been documenting the crisis in Ukraine on Instagram and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: The senior correspondent for The New York Times has been documenting the crisis in Ukraine on Instagram and Twitter.

headline: Au Za’atar, an ‘Arabian-French Bistro,’ Opens
abstract: Salwa Fallous, a native of Lebanon, and her son Tarik offer specialties from her homeland and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Pictures of the Day: Japan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Japan, Afghanistan, Istanbul and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Japan, Afghanistan, Istanbul and Israel.

headline: What’s In It | Cookie Dough Oreos
abstract: The makers of Oreo cookies have outdone themselves with their latest attempt to jazz up their icon. But how do they simulate raw cookie dough without using flour or eggs?
lead_paragraph: The makers of Oreo cookies have outdone themselves with their latest attempt to jazz up their icon. But how do they simulate raw cookie dough without using flour or eggs?

headline: There’s a Big Difference Between Union Money and Koch Money
abstract: Two brothers, aided by a small and shadowy group of similarly wealthy donors, spent more in 2012 than millions of union members.
lead_paragraph: For dozens of readers, our editorial this morning on the Democratic criticism of the Koch brothers left out something crucial: the big financial muscle of unions in backing liberal politcians.

headline: A Place to Park and Cook Up a Storm
keywords: ['Food Trucks', 'Street Vendors', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Landowners have transformed spaces into permanent food courts and brought new dining options to commercial buildings.
lead_paragraph: BEND, Ore. — Residents of this mountain town like doing things outdoors, and dining seems to be no exception.

headline: The Cookie Dough Oreo
abstract: This newest version of the Oreo draws on a marketing maneuver that industry insiders call “permission” to evoke the mere impression of cookie dough.
lead_paragraph: MIMICRY IS AN ART FORM in processed foods, and the makers of Oreo cookies have outdone themselves with their latest attempt to jazz up their icon: the Cookie Dough Oreo. The fun in dissecting this marvel of food engineering begins right on the front of the package, which sports pictures of real-looking cookie dough and chocolate chips, though neither is found inside. Instead, this newest version of the Oreo draws on a mix of extra sugar, precision chemistry and a marketing maneuver that industry insiders call “permission” to evoke the mere impression of cookie dough. Its success may be measured less in sales than in the buzz it generates for the Oreo line.

headline: Scoring a Baseball Bargain at Spring Training
abstract: The Frugal Traveler rings up some fun-uncle points by taking his nephews to Florida for a budget-friendly baseball adventure.
lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday morning at JetBlue Park in Fort Myers, Fla., David Ortiz, the Red Sox designated hitter, finished chatting with a few Tampa Bay Rays and lumbered over to a tour group of fans watching batting practice from behind the third-base line.

headline: In 9 Years of Work, Just 3 Public Toilets Go Live
abstract: The Spanish company contracted in 2006 to install public toilets around the city says it must wait for the Transportation Department to approve the sites — a complicated process.
lead_paragraph: For more than a generation, bureaucracy, politics and corruption thwarted three successive New York mayors from modernizing the city’s shabby bus shelters, newsstands and public toilets.

headline: The Intrepid Explorer, Leaping From Lush to Spiky
abstract: The pianist Benjamin Hochman explored the form of theme and variation in four contemporary pieces on Monday evening at SubCulture.
lead_paragraph: A recital by a thoughtful young pianist in a basement performance space that seats about 150 people may not seem particularly significant. Yet on Monday night at SubCulture, as I listened to the pianist Benjamin Hochman’s sensitive, exciting renditions of four contemporary works that explore the form of theme and variation (including one premiere), I kept thinking that classical music doesn’t get better than this.

headline: With High Hopes and Deep Pockets, The Times Gambles on NYT Now
abstract: Developing a new smartphone app involved an unusual relationship between journalists and the business side of The Times.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:15 p.m.

headline: Extended-Stay Hotels Climb in Manhattan
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Corporate or short-term housing units have proliferated across Manhattan, both in buildings dedicated solely to this function or scattered inside existing rentals and condos.
lead_paragraph: A fast-growing class of properties in New York is encouraging people not only to visit, but to stay awhile.

headline: Turning Coffee Into Water to Expand Business Model
abstract: The founder of Toms, a shoe company that donates a pair for every pair bought, is branching out.
lead_paragraph: What do shoes and coffee have in common?

headline: Going Solo Instead of Joining the Chorus
abstract: At Contra, the chefs speak for themselves, not for a city.
lead_paragraph: The outside makes no grand statements. A glass wall stares out at a not-yet-trendy block of Orchard Street. It’s blank except for the small menu posted by the door, offering five courses for the relatively modest sum of $55. Hanging on one inside wall, more art than ad, and almost invisible unless you are walking southbound very close to the window, is the restaurant’s name in red neon script: Contra.

headline: Lips Locked, With Musical Chairs
abstract: The Brazilian dance company Focus Cia de Dança made its American debut on Saturday as part of the Brazil Festival at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: At the Joyce Theater on Saturday, the Brazilian dance company Focus Cia de Dança made its American debut with a work titled “As Canções Que Você Dançou Pra Mim.” The program did not provide an English translation of that title, “The Songs You Danced for Me.” Nor did it offer help with the Portuguese lyrics of the many songs to which the company danced. Yet the most significant separation between an American audience and the work’s meanings was most likely not linguistic.

headline: Beethoven in Broad Strokes, and With Mugging
abstract: Roger Norrington conducted Beethoven’s “Missa Solemnis” with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s and the Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: There seemed ample reason on Thursday evening to look forward to the English maestro Roger Norrington’s performance of Beethoven’s “Missa Solemnis” with the Orchestra of St. Luke’s and the Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Get Out Your Corkscrew
abstract: Come join us as we set out to drink and discuss a different type of wine each month.
lead_paragraph: Wine School, a monthly column, invites you to drink wine with Eric Asimov. In each installment, Mr. Asimov chooses a type of wine for you to try at home.   At the end of the month, Mr. Asimov will address some of the points in your comments and answer questions in a follow-up column. This month’s wine selection: Bordeaux.

headline: New Roots in Carroll Gardens
abstract: A Brooklyn neighborhood rich with brownstones and brick townhouses, and new zoning protects the urban-small-town atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Nick Donovan chose Carroll Gardens twice. When Mr. Donovan, a lawyer who had just married, first moved to this leafy part of brownstone Brooklyn in 1993, it was very much a front-stoop community, where older neighbors, usually Italian-Americans with deep roots in the area, would gather outside their homes to share pastry and news of the day.

headline: Miracles Know No Borders: Upstart Russia Tops Potent U.S.
abstract: Once far behind the Americans and Canadians in developing their sledge hockey program, the Russians proved they were on the right track in a 2-1 upset at the Paralympics in Sochi.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — The men in sleds on the ice gathered and waved their sticks above their heads, swinging them like swords. More, more, more, they motioned, and the partisan fans at Shayba Arena obliged. They waved their flags, stamped their feet and sang in the aisles, surrounding their team in noise and love.

headline: Herbalife Shares Fall as Ackman Makes New Accusations
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Shares in Herbalife were down slightly after William A. Ackman, the founder of the firm Pershing Square Capital Management, called Herbalife’s accounting of its Chinese business as “highly misleading.”
lead_paragraph: Shares in Herbalife fell by more than 2 percent on Tuesday as the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman accused the company, which sells vitamins, shakes and other supplements, of “operating illegally” in China.

headline: Q. and A. | Filmmaker Matt Wolf on the Origins of Teenage Culture
abstract: The documentarian discusses his new project, a collage-like exploration of early-20th-century youth subcultures.
lead_paragraph: A video excerpt from Matt Wolf’s documentary, “Teenage,” features the Bright Young Things of London from the 1920s.

headline: Top Disney TV Official to Step Down
abstract: Anne M. Sweeney, one of the most powerful women in the entertainment industry, will leave in 2015 after 18 years at the company to become a television director.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a move that stunned Hollywood, the television industry’s most powerful woman, Anne M. Sweeney, said on Tuesday that she would step down as president of the Disney-ABC Television Group to become a TV director.

headline: Hotel Discounts for Egencia Users
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Egencia, the business travel brand of Expedia, is offering discounts to users who book through its new Trip Navigator application.
lead_paragraph: An increasing number of travelers are turning to their smart phones and tablets to make travel arrangements on the fly.

headline: An Identity He Won’t Cede That Easily
abstract: The actor Armando Riesco reflects on his run, soon ending, as the war veteran Elliot Ortiz, a role he has played on and off since 2006 in a trilogy of plays by Quiara Alegría Hudes.
lead_paragraph: The line was easy to deliver — “maybe I’m not that brave” — but it rattled the actor Armando Riesco during early performances of “The Happiest Song Plays Last” last month. His character, a young Iraq war veteran named Elliot Ortiz, had faced up to so many traumas already; burdening him with self-doubt at the climax seemed a cruel twist by the playwright.

headline: The Voices of Montserrat
abstract: Europe’s oldest boys choir, the Escolania de Montserrat, has eased its residency requirements to raise enrollment. The move was effective and now they are on their first American tour.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s oldest boys choir, the Escolania de Montserrat, has eased its residency requirements to raise enrollment. The move was effective and now they are on their first American tour.

headline: Park Avenue, the Art Gallery
abstract: The sculptures in Alice Aycock’s art installation “Park Avenue Paper Chase” are, as she had hoped, drawing attention.
lead_paragraph: Alice Aycock, the sculptor, was holding her breath.

headline: N.S.A. Timeline of Surveillance Law Developments
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: A chart, apparently from an internal National Security Agency presentation, lists milestones in surveillance rules over nearly four decades.
lead_paragraph: A chart, apparently from an internal National Security Agency presentation, lists milestones in surveillance rules over nearly four decades.

headline: Traces of Lives, From Scores to Cigarettes
abstract: Carnegie Hall, in its Rose Museum, is hosting an exhibition of objects that relate to musical works being performed in the festival Vienna: City of Dreams.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall, in its Rose Museum, is hosting an exhibition of two dozen priceless musical scores and personal items produced or once owned by composers whose music is being performed in Carnegie’s festival Vienna: City of Dreams. And one out-and-out fake.

headline: Classification Guide for Stellarwind Program
keywords: ['Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A guide to secrecy restrictions for Bush administration surveillance and data collection programs that operated outside FISA rules.
lead_paragraph: A guide to secrecy restrictions for Bush administration surveillance and data collection programs that operated outside FISA rules.

headline: Dancing With Doors and Amid Trash Cans
abstract: Daredevil vignettes devised by Brian Sanders for his company, Junk, rely heavily on props and precarious contraptions.
lead_paragraph: Technical difficulties are bound to crop up in work that relies heavily on props and precarious contraptions, like the daredevil vignettes devised by Brian Sanders for his company, Junk. Since 1998, Mr. Sanders, who is based in Philadelphia, has been integrating found objects — doors, trash cans, bicycle parts — into a kind of grungy blend of Cirque du Soleil, “Stomp” and Momix, the gymnastically inclined company with whom he danced and choreographed for 10 years.

headline: Offering Choral Solace for Composers’ Laments
abstract: The Choir of Trinity Wall Street opened a concert series based on works inspired by the Book of Lamentations.
lead_paragraph: That Ernst Krenek, an Austrian composer of Czech descent, should be moved to write a work based on the biblical Lamentations seems entirely natural, given the personal woes and professional tribulations he faced at the time. A gifted, prolific artist who had mingled with Mahler, Berg and the French upstarts of Les Six, Krenek in 1941 was teaching at Vassar College, exiled by the rise of the Nazis, who had declared his music “degenerate,” and embattled by jealous rivals who sought his dismissal.

headline: Classification Guide for FISA, the Protect America Act and the FISA Amendments Act
keywords: ['Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A guide to secrecy restrictions for various aspects of programs to spy on domestic soil for national security purposes.
lead_paragraph: A guide to secrecy restrictions for various aspects of programs to spy on domestic soil for national security purposes.

headline: Ashcroft Memo on Intelligence Sharing Procedures
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: In August 2002, the attorney general issued new procedures that lowered safeguards on providing information about Americans to foreign governments that was deemed relevant to terrorism issues.
lead_paragraph: In August 2002, the attorney general issued new procedures that lowered safeguards on providing information about Americans to foreign governments that was deemed relevant to terrorism issues.

headline: N.S.A. Memo Expands Access to FISA Information
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: In 2006, the National Security Agency sought to expand access to Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act information to code-breakers around the country.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, the National Security Agency sought to expand access to Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act information to code-breakers around the country.

headline: Celebrating the Pianist Ursula Oppens at 70
abstract: “Happy Birthday, Ursula” featured four pianists at Symphony Space on Thursday, along with an appearance by the woman of the hour.
lead_paragraph: Before playing Frederic Rzewski’s “The People United Will Never Be Defeated!” at Symphony Space on Thursday evening, the pianist Ran Dank spoke about the legacy of Ursula Oppens, his former teacher.

headline: A Relentless Widening of Disparity in Wealth
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The economic forces concentrating more and more wealth into the hands of the fortunate few are almost sure to prevail for a long time, according to a new book by the economist Thomas Piketty.
lead_paragraph: What if inequality were to continue growing years or decades into the future? Say the richest 1 percent of the population amassed a quarter of the nation’s income, up from about a fifth today. What about half?

headline: Chobani Said to Seek Investment That Would Value It at $5 Billion
abstract: Chobani, the fast-growing yogurt maker, is said to be in talks with six potential investors as it seeks more capital to expand internationally.
lead_paragraph: Big investors are vying for a piece of Chobani, the fast-growing yogurt maker in upstate New York.

headline: Q&A: Thomas Piketty on the Wealth Divide
abstract: An interview with the author of a new book, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” on the dynamics driving the concentration of income and wealth into the hands of the few.
lead_paragraph: Income inequality moved with astonishing speed from the boring backwaters of economic studies to “the defining challenge of our time.” It found Thomas Piketty waiting for it.

headline: Talking With Readers About Owen, Disney and Autism
abstract: Ron Suskind responds to reader’s questions about raising a son with autism, the high costs related to his son’s care, sibling issues and more.
lead_paragraph: In last weekend’s magazine, Ron Suskind wrote about learning to communicate with his son, Owen, who developed regressive autism at age 3, through the language of Disney. Readers were invited to submit questions to Suskind about the article, which is adapted from his coming book, “Life, Animated.” Here are his responses:

headline: In Familiar Scene, Bayern Advances and Arsenal Is Out
abstract: It was not a game for the highlight reels, but a drab 1-1 draw against Arsenal gave Bayern Munich a 3-1 victory in the two-game aggregate series.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Inside the shimmering Allianz Arena, there is a sleek and charming museum devoted to all things Bayern Munich. The museum has all types of exhibits, including a new room devoted to the legendary goalkeeper Sepp Maier, a fascinating (if somewhat cringe-inducing) collection of music recorded by Munich players over the years and — of course — a slew of screens showing the best moments from the club’s greatest games.

headline: CFDA Award Nominees Are Announced
abstract: The Council of Fashion Designers of America’s annual CFDA Awards are the de facto Oscars of American fashion. headline: As the Web Turns 25, Its Creator Talks About Its Future
abstract: It has been 25 years since the World Wide Web began. Tim Berners-Lee, its creator, and others are worried that its free and open nature could be in jeopardy as corporations push to control the speed and type of content that is shared online.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, Tim Berners-Lee, a software engineer, sat in his small office at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research near Geneva and started work on a new system called the World Wide Web.

headline: A Turnaround for Bitcoin at SXSW
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Entrepreneurship', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: For Bitcoin entrepreneurs, the rise from scrappy outsiders to tech world insiders has been a bit dizzying.

headline: How a Court Secretly Evolved, Extending U.S. Spies’ Reach
keywords: ['Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'E-Mail']
abstract: Leaked documents add new details to a secret body of law that the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court has developed since it began to broaden its role in 2001.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ten months after the Sept. 11 attacks, the nation’s surveillance court delivered a ruling that intelligence officials consider a milestone in the secret history of American spying and privacy law. Called the “Raw Take” order — classified docket No. 02-431 — it weakened restrictions on sharing private information about Americans, according to documents and interviews.

headline: One Singular Sensation for Award Winners
abstract: A nonprofit organization, the One Club for Art and Copy, is taking a step to reconsider the proliferation of ad industry honors.
lead_paragraph: THE penchant among people who work in advertising and marketing to recognize their own achievements is evidenced by a seemingly endless skein of awards they bestow at dozens of ceremonies each year. How do they love themselves? Let me count the ways: Ace Awards, ADC Awards, American Advertising Awards, Andys, Cannes Lions, Clios, D&AD Awards, Effies, the New York Festivals, Obie Awards, One Show awards, PromaxBDA awards, Reggie Awards, U.S. Hispanic Idea Awards...

headline: Kiev’s Message to Moscow
abstract: Ukrainians want peace, but we will not submit to Soviet-style bullying.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — AT this very moment, in plain view of the entire world, the final demise of the Soviet empire is unfolding. The plan for its resurrection, long in the works at the Kremlin, has failed: Ukraine has proved that it has matured into an independent state that will determine its own domestic and foreign policy.

abstract: Dallas center Rich Peverley, 31, who has a history of heart issues, spent Tuesday at a hospital after collapsing in Monday’s game against Columbus.
lead_paragraph: Dallas Stars center Rich Peverley spent Tuesday at a Dallas-area hospital, undergoing tests to determine what brought on the cardiac event that caused him to collapse during the first period against the Columbus Blue Jackets on Monday night.

lead_paragraph: Three Bronx men who were set free last year after spending nearly 18 years in prison for two murders they say they did not commit are suing New York City and the two lead police detectives on the case, accusing them of deliberately using tainted or false evidence.

Its recent projects include work at the Hudson Yards development, One World Trade Center and the Barclays Center.

headline: The Future of Internet Freedom
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Censorship', 'Computer Security', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: We have the technology to defeat censorship. Do we have the will?
lead_paragraph: OVER the next decade, approximately five billion people will become connected to the Internet. The biggest increases will be in societies that, according to the human rights group Freedom House, are severely censored: places where clicking on an objectionable article can get your entire extended family thrown in prison, or worse.

headline: Penalties for Mr. Putin
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: Russia’s occupation of Crimea, Ukraine, and its phony referendum, demand a strong response from Europe and the United States.
lead_paragraph: It is important at this stage of the confrontation in Ukraine to clarify that the issue is not simply “who owns Crimea.” There is a difficult question there, and as secession-minded people in Quebec, Scotland or Catalonia have shown, there are legitimate ways to raise it.

headline: Fukushima’s Continuing Tragedy
keywords: ['Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Editorials']
abstract: Three years after the earthquake and nuclear disaster, the reconstruction effort by the Japanese government has been insufficient and painfully slow.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday was the third anniversary of the triple disaster that struck the eastern Japanese prefectures of Iwate, Miyagi and Fukushima: the earthquake, tsunami and the nuclear power plant meltdowns in Fukushima. The catastrophe killed 15,884, with 2,636 still missing. The government’s reconstruction efforts have been insufficient and painfully slow.

headline: Removing 9/11 Artifacts From New Jersey’s Nest of Political Patronage
abstract: Steel from the World Trade Center site will no longer be handled by Gov. Chris Christie’s political appointees at the Port Authority, but by the agency’s professional staff.
lead_paragraph: Still up for grabs from the ruins of the World Trade Center are roughly 90 pieces of steel and 200 other artifacts — things like bits of antenna, a wrecked car, turnstiles — recovered after Sept. 11. Remnants of a dwindling inventory, they have been stored in a hangar at Kennedy International Airport for more than a decade, as pieces have been shipped to 50 states and at least seven countries for memorial sites and museums.

headline: A Cardinal’s Inspiration to Move Ahead
abstract: Kolten Wong, 23, gains perspective from his mother’s death as he looks for a fresh start on the baseball field after ending his 2013 season on a game-ending pickoff in the World Series.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The image was heartbreaking, no matter your allegiance. The rookie is alone, on his knees in the dirt. He is looking down, and in his right hand he grips his red helmet, about to fire it to the ground. Beside him, stamped with the World Series logo, is the base he had tried in vain to reach before the tag.

headline: Exploiting California’s Drought
abstract: The crisis can prompt changes in crop selection and water use.
lead_paragraph: The San Joaquin Valley in California can be stunningly beautiful: On a visit two weeks ago, I saw billions of pink almond blossoms peaking, with the Sierra Nevada towering over all. It can also be a hideous place, the air choked with microparticles of unpleasant origins (dried cow dung, sprayed chemicals, blowing over-fertilized soil), its cities like Fresno and Bakersfield sprawling incoherently and its small towns suffering from poverty, populated by immigrants from places as near as Baja, Mexico, and as far as Punjab, India.

headline: Sprint Owner’s New Appeal for Merger With T-Mobile
abstract: Masayoshi Son, the founder of SoftBank, took an unusual tack in a rare address to an American audience on Tuesday, saying that he wants to rescue the United States from broadband oblivion.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American broadband is slow and expensive. But Masayoshi Son wants to help.

headline: Ohio Looks at Whether Fracking Led to 2 Quakes
abstract: Ohio officials said that an oil and gas well near the site of two small earthquakes was undergoing hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, when the quakes occurred.
lead_paragraph: Ohio officials said Tuesday that an oil and gas well near the site of two small earthquakes was undergoing hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, when the quakes occurred.

headline: At Trial of Bin Laden Relative, Witness Describes Meeting 9/11 Mastermind
abstract: An operative for Al Qaeda offered an intimate account of his interactions with Osama bin Laden and Khalid Shaikh Mohammed in the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith.
lead_paragraph: A British operative for Al Qaeda testified on Tuesday that, before abandoning a plot to blow up an airplane, he flew from Pakistan to the Netherlands and then on to Britain while concealing a bomb in his shoe.

headline: U.N. Denies That Syria Image Was Faked
abstract: A photograph of hungry Palestinians in Syria, retweeted more than eight million times, has become an iconic image of the war. Experts said it was real.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations photograph showing a sea of hungry Palestinians awaiting emergency food amid the detritus of their bomb-ravaged neighborhood near Damascus has been retweeted more than eight million times in the past few weeks, becoming such an arresting image of the Syrian civil war that some blogosphere skeptics have suggested that it was digitally faked. The suggestion provoked a passionate denial on Tuesday by the official responsible for distributing the photo.

headline: Sculptures Vandalized at Bellevue Hospital’s Serene Escape
abstract: Some of the animal sculptures in what is known as the hospital’s sobriety garden were smashed, and some lost their heads, but the culprit has not been found.
lead_paragraph: The long-awaited sunshine beckoned, and doctors and staff members at Bellevue Hospital Center wandered out on Tuesday to the small garden that has long been a peaceful escape for those struggling with serious issues inside. But the garden was anything but tranquil. The animal sculptures had been smashed and destroyed.

headline: Mets’ Niese Is Rocked, and Is Happy for It
abstract: Jon Niese, recovering from shoulder discomfort, threw 50 pitches in his first start of spring training, and he did not seem at all concerned about giving up four runs in two innings.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — In his first game action since he felt shoulder discomfort earlier during spring training, Mets starter Jon Niese was shelled by the St. Louis Cardinals on Tuesday, allowing four runs and six hits in two innings of a 9-8 comeback victory. Not only that, his velocity was generally down, which would seem more concerning.

headline: Banamex Fraud Exposes Challenges for Citi in Mexico
abstract: A recent $400 million swindle against a Citibank affiliate in Mexico demonstrates the systemic challenges of finding safe lending clients in regions subject to cronyism and sudden policy shifts.
lead_paragraph: For some top Citigroup executives, it was a kind of little black book: an informal tally of Mexican companies that they feared could imperil the bank’s “crown jewel” — a sprawling retail lender called Banamex.

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has reached into the opposition bench to hire a new adviser, recruiting a well-known Republican strategist to join the governor’s office as other aides leave to plan his re-election campaign.

headline: Sabathia Is Encouraged by an Outing, in Part Because It’s Only March
abstract: C. C. Sabathia pitched three regrettable innings in the Yankees’ 3-2 preseason loss Tuesday, but said he was in a better position at this point in camp than he was last year.
lead_paragraph: VIERA, Fla. — It is not even half past March yet, which means pitching lines and batting averages are written in disappearing ink.

headline: As Homeless Shelter Population Rises, Advocates Push Mayor on Policies
abstract: A record 53,615 people slept in shelters in January, according to the Coalition for the Homeless, which is hopeful Mayor Bill de Blasio will reverse a trend of rising homelessness it blames on his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: The number of homeless people staying overnight in New York City shelters reached a dismal record of 53,615 in January, a new study has found, prompting advocates to press Mayor Bill de Blasio to follow through on promises to undo policies that they say drove the city’s homeless population to skyrocket in the first place.

headline: Fears Spread That Venezuela Is Approaching Bloody Face-Off
abstract: With more than 20 deaths now linked to over a month of protests, people on both sides of the country’s political divide seem increasingly willing to accept violence.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The gunmen descended a street on Monday night toward a park taken over by student demonstrators in the western city of San Cristóbal, the crucible of the protests that have shaken Venezuela. They opened fire, and a 23-year-old student leader, Daniel Tinoco, fell. Hit in the upper body, he died before he got to a hospital, fellow protesters said.

headline: Clinton Aide Linked to Campaign Scandal
abstract: A businessman embroiled in a campaign finance scandal communicated with an adviser to Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton on an illegal canvassing effort to bolster Mrs. Clinton’s 2008 campaign, court documents say.
lead_paragraph: A wealthy Washington businessman embroiled in a campaign finance scandal communicated with a longtime adviser to Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton on an illegal canvassing effort to bolster Mrs. Clinton’s 2008 presidential campaign, according to court documents.

lead_paragraph: Bill McLaughlin, a CBS News correspondent who covered conflicts in Vietnam and the Middle East, the assassination of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games and the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981, died on Friday in Waterbury, Conn. He was 76.

headline: De Blasio Cites Drop in Crime Since Taking Office
abstract: Crime in New York City has fallen 2 percent in the first 10 weeks of this year, compared with the same period in 2013, according to Mayor Bill de Blasio and the police commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who frequently criticized the Police Department in his previous job as public advocate, highlighted statistics on Tuesday showing a drop in crime during his first two months in office, saying that his approach to policing had already paid dividends.

headline: Hunein Maassab, Who Developed FluMist Vaccine, Dies at 87
abstract: Dr. Maassab’s spray used a live version of the influenza virus that had been attenuated, or weakened, so as not to cause the flu.
lead_paragraph: Hunein Maassab witnessed a transformational moment in public health when he was a young doctoral student at the University of Michigan. It happened on April 12, 1955, the day his mentor, Dr. Thomas Francis Jr., announced that he had completed a vast field trial involving nearly two million children to determine the effectiveness of what at the time seemed like a miracle drug: a vaccine for polio.

abstract: News of his death triggered large gatherings in several cities, including Istanbul, Izmir and Ankara, where the police confronted protesters with tear gas and water cannons.

lead_paragraph: After getting pummeled by snowstorms all winter long, Mayor Bill de Blasio emerged from City Hall to bask in Tuesday’s warm and sunny weather, briefly moving the business of governing New York City to the great outdoors.

abstract: China is struggling to find a neutral diplomatic position over Russia’s intervention in Ukraine.

Galante, who is under federal and city investigation for possible misuse of money meant to improve the library’s 62 branches.

lead_paragraph: Seven black students have been offered a chance to start classes at Stuyvesant High School in September, two fewer than received offers last year. For Hispanics, the number has dropped to 21 from 24.

headline: A Sister’s Love, Not Tempered by Expectations
abstract: A mother and filmmaker captures her daughter’s unreserved love for a brother born with cerebral palsy.
lead_paragraph: From the filmmaker, Kelly O’Brien: My daughter Emma was just 3 when Teddy was born, with a viral infection he contracted in utero that caused extensive brain damage. This short film captures her love for Teddy, one not weighted down by disappointment, sadness or a full understanding of all the ways in which he wasn’t “normal.” Read more.

headline: Fund-Raisers and Shopping Fill Obama’s Visit to Manhattan

lead_paragraph: President Obama came to New York on Tuesday to pick up a few sweaters and more than $1.5 million in cash. The sweaters were for his daughters. The cash was for his political allies.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Anti-Migraine Device
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday said it had approved the first medical device to prevent migraine headaches.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday said it had approved the first medical device to prevent migraine headaches. The device, made by a Belgian company, Cephaly Technology, is small, portable and battery powered, and it looks like a plastic headband. It is worn across the forehead and over the ears, and contains a small electrode that applies an electric current to stimulate the nerve that is associated with migraine headaches. A study of 67 people in Belgium found that those who used the device reported significantly fewer days with migraines per month than those who used a placebo.

headline: Obama Adds to National Monument Land
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: President Obama on Tuesday moved to preserve more than 1,600 acres of coastal land in Northern California by declaring them part of a national monument.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Tuesday moved to preserve more than 1,600 acres of coastal land in Northern California by declaring them part of a national monument. Point Arena-Stornetta, a 12-mile stretch of coast made up of federal and state public lands, is about 140 miles north of San Francisco. It will now be part of the California Coastal National Monument, a marine boundary that includes islands, rocks and reefs owned by the United States and within 12 miles of California’s 1,100-mile coast. Point Arena-Stornetta is the first shoreline portion of the monument. “It is a place where scientists do research; where people who just want to experience the great outdoors can take advantage of it,” Mr. Obama said before signing the proclamation. The newly expanded coastal monument is home to a variety of fauna and flora, among them Steller sea lions, Behren’s silverspot butterfly, rare bird species like the black oystercatcher, and a bishop pine forest.

headline: Wanted by Ecuador, 2 Brothers Make Mark in U.S. Campaigns
abstract: Political donations by relatives of Roberto and William Isaias, fugitives from Ecuador who fled to Miami, have raised questions about Washington’s decision making on their fate.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The donations kept pouring in: hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions to President Obama and more than a dozen members of Congress, carefully routed through the families of two wealthy brothers in Florida.

abstract: Even if a higher minimum wage reduces employment, as its critics assert, low-wage workers over all can benefit, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What Running Can Do for the Heart
abstract: Becoming fit as a marathoner doesn’t seem to protect the heart to the extent one might expect, although it may have unexpected benefits for your spouse.
lead_paragraph: An ingenious new study of marathon runners and their non-running spouses should reassure anyone headed for a spring marathon that prolonged training doesn’t damage the heart, a concern that has been raised in previous research. At the same time, becoming fit as a marathoner doesn’t seem to protect the heart to the extent you might expect, although it may have unexpected benefits for your spouse.

headline: In-Depth Report Details Economics of Sex Trade
abstract: The landmark study, commissioned by the Justice Department, has provided a wealth of data on pricing, market structures and sex workers’ motivations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A street prostitute in Dallas may make as little as $5 per sex act. But pimps can take in $33,000 a week in Atlanta, where the sex business brings in an estimated $290 million per year. It is not nearly as lucrative in Denver, where prostitution and other elements of an underground trade are worth about $40 million.

headline: Before Elections, Mumbai Snack Turns Into a Political Hot Potato
abstract: The Shiv Sena, the Hindu nationalist party that dominates the city’s government, is quietly helping voters set up stalls to sell the street food vada pav in return for their support.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — When Arun Garde set out to sell vada pav, the popular street snack of a potato patty in a bun, in south Mumbai in November, the city government closed down his stall before his fourth customer had finished eating. Mr. Garde, 50, watched in horror as his booth, utensils and supplies were thrown into the back of a truck because he was hawking without a license.

headline: Fever Trade Guard Phillips to Mercury
abstract: The Indiana Fever traded guard Erin Phillips to the Phoenix Mercury for forward Lynetta Kizer and a first-round draft pick.
lead_paragraph: The Indiana Fever traded guard Erin Phillips to the Phoenix Mercury for forward Lynetta Kizer and a first-round draft pick. The trade gives Indiana two of the top nine selections in April’s W.N.B.A. draft, with its own pick at No. 5 and the Mercury’s slot at nine. (AP)

headline: In France, a Quest to Convert a Sea Snail Plague Into a Culinary Pleasure
keywords: ['Invasive Species', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Seafood', 'Snails', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The community of Cancale now finds itself torn between disgust and relief at an entrepreneur’s project to fish and sell the sea snails for consumption.
lead_paragraph: CANCALE, France — On this storm-weathered tip of Mont Saint-Michel Bay, the sweeping tides have washed away the line between land and sea. Fishermen drive their wheeled boats straight into the bay to gather their harvest: an assortment of shellfish prized all over France.

headline: Gaza: Explosives in a House Kill 3
abstract: An explosion on Tuesday at a house in Beit Hanoun, a town in the northern Gaza Strip, killed three people and wounded at least seven others, the Gaza Ministry of Health said.
lead_paragraph: An explosion on Tuesday at a house in Beit Hanoun, a town in the northern Gaza Strip, killed three people and wounded at least seven others, the Gaza Ministry of Health said. Officials said the blast had apparently been caused by explosives in the house, owned by a family named Hamdeen. A Health Ministry spokesman said most of the survivors were seriously wounded. Officials did not explain the presence of the explosives in the home.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 93
abstract: The oft-injured midfielder Stuart Holden will miss six to nine months after his latest knee operation, but his news this week wasn’t all bad.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Suit Filed in Haiti Cholera Epidemic
abstract: A class-action lawsuit claiming to represent cholera victims in Haiti and their relatives in the United States was filed against the United Nations on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A class-action lawsuit claiming to represent cholera victims in Haiti and their relatives in the United States was filed against the United Nations on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. At issue is the question of accountability for an epidemic that began in 2010 and has since claimed more than 8,000 lives. In response an earlier claim, the United States attorney in Manhattan, Preet Bharara, said that he believed the United Nations Charter rendered the organization “absolutely immune from legal process and suit absent an express waiver.” Victims’ groups blame United Nations peacekeepers from Nepal, where cholera is endemic. The United Nations has pledged to help eradicate cholera from Haiti.

headline: Nepal: Push to Open Peaks to Climbers
abstract: The government is considering contracts with climbing companies that would grant exclusive access to many of its highest mountains, a spokesman for Nepal’s tourism ministry said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The government is considering contracts with climbing companies that would grant exclusive access to many of its highest mountains, a spokesman for Nepal’s tourism ministry said on Tuesday, as part of an effort to bring more climbers to the Himalayas, the world’s highest mountain range. Nepal has some 3,310 mountains, but only 310 are open to commercial climbing. Since the government determined that it cannot manage all of its peaks, it will soon propose offering 30-year leases on the remaining 3,000 mountains to climbing companies, which would then organize climbs and charge fees. Nepal collects about $2.7 million annually in mountaineering fees, most of which comes from the nearly 35,000 people who visit Mount Everest. Nepal has long been trying to increase and diversify its tourism business, with its extraordinary mountains — 60 peaks higher than 26,000 feet — at the center of those efforts. Nepal is one of the world’s poorest countries, and the country’s youths are increasingly leaving for jobs elsewhere.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) PLEASE GIVE (2010) Two Manhattan families collide in this film from Nicole Holofcener, when Kate and Alex (Catherine Keener and Oliver Platt, above), who run a store specializing in furniture acquired from the apartments of the dead, angle to take over the place of their irascible next door neighbor. She is Andra (Ann Guilbert), who comes with two granddaughters: the spiky Mary (Amanda Peet) and repressed Rebecca (Rebecca Hall). Sarah Steele plays Kate’s teenage daughter, Abby, who wishes her mother would address some of her generosity — she doles out cash to homeless people — toward her. “Few American filmmakers create female characters as realistically funny, attractively imperfect and flat-out annoying,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “You may not love them, but you recognize their charms and frailties, their fears and hopes. They may remind you of your friends, your sisters or even yourself, which makes them attractive and sometimes off-putting, an unusual, complicated mix.”

headline: Wash Your Car to Keep Rust Away
abstract: Cars in Snow Belt states wear a salty film after such a brutal winter. Washing it off is a great way to prevent rust.
lead_paragraph: Although it can’t be said that we’re done with winter, the worst appears to be behind us. If you live where there was a lot of snow – which, this year, seems to have been most places in the United States – your car is no doubt coated with a salty film right now.

headline: Obama Makes Push for Political Solution to Crisis in Ukraine
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama, who met with Ukraine’s interim prime minister Wednesday, was pursuing a diplomatic approach that could deliver more autonomy to Crimea if Russian troops withdraw.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Ukraine’s interim prime minister opened the door on Wednesday to a political solution that could lead to more autonomy for Crimea if Russian troops withdraw, as the United States embarked on a last-ditch diplomatic effort to defuse a crisis that reignited tensions between East and West.

lead_paragraph: In “Obama’s New Approach Takes a Humorous Turn,” Michael D. Shear writes about the interview in this video. Watch the video and read the article to answer the questions below.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Youth Problem
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Start-ups', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Software']
abstract: In start-up land, the young barely talk to the old (and vice versa). That makes for a lot of cool apps. But great technology? Not so much.
lead_paragraph: The Cisco Meraki office in Mission Bay, San Francisco, is 40 paces from the water, and just as nice as Google’s. On a clear winter day in late December, I sat in one of its conference rooms with a company spokeswoman on my right and Sanjit Biswas on my left, peering out through floor-to-ceiling glass. On the other side: brightly patterned furniture, murals and paneled wood, a well-stocked cafeteria, a deck with spectacular views of the bay. Twelve months earlier, in a deal meant to bring fresh edge to Cisco, the networking behemoth bought Meraki from Biswas and two co-founders for $1.2 billion. Now they were making good on their promise — starting with the décor.

headline: Questions About a Popular Heart Procedure
abstract: Transcatheter aortic valve replacement has gained popularity as a less invasive way to mend heart valves in elderly patients, but some experts are not convinced it is better than the traditional surgery.
lead_paragraph: Our great-great-grandparents probably didn’t have to think much about the way the heart’s aortic valve slowly stiffens and narrows over decades, a condition called aortic stenosis. Most of them died before they could experience its distressing symptoms — shortness of breath, chest pain, fatigue, fainting.

headline: Tortillas, Almost From Scratch
abstract: The shortcut: Masa harina.
lead_paragraph: If you’re interested in a serious project, you can make the best tortillas you’ve ever had by soaking and washing dried hominy — corn that has been treated with slaked lime — then grinding it to produce masa, or “dough.” Then you press out small discs and griddle them. Do that, and you’ll have my admiration.

headline: Is Teenage ‘Voluntourism’ Wrong?
abstract: Many teenagers take them — summer or school-vacation trips to other countries to volunteer in some capacity (and, perhaps, build their résumés). But might these trips do more harm than good?
lead_paragraph: Many teenagers take them — summer or school-vacation trips to other countries to volunteer in some capacity (and, perhaps, build their résumés).

lead_paragraph: Online media were abuzz on Tuesday about remarks reportedly made by Wang Qishan, one of China’s highest-ranked political figures, in which he upbraided the Communist Party secretary of Jilin Province for the fault of “formalism.”

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s bid to revive its economy got much-needed backing Wednesday after a group of major exporters said they would raise wages for the first time in years. Still, union leaders warned that a wider recovery hinged on the fate of low-wage, informal workers who make up a growing part of the country’s labor force.

headline: Wages of Fear (Somewhat Wonkish)
abstract: A worrisome campaign against full employment.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom can be a terrible thing. In 2009-10 all the serious people started telling each other that public debt was the number one threat facing advanced economies, and that austerity policies were needed immediately. We know how that turned out. Well, over the past few months I’ve been watching a new conventional wisdom take hold – among a narrower and more technical set of people, but still. According to this view, economic slack is vanishing fast; even though we still have huge unemployment, we’re actually running out of employable workers, and a dangerous acceleration in the pace of wage increases is already underway. Time to raise interest rates!

lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — After four days of reticence and evasive answers, the Malaysian military acknowledged on Wednesday that it had recorded, but initially ignored, radar signals that could have prompted a mission to intercept and track a missing jetliner — data that vastly expands the area where the plane might have traveled.

headline: A Look at Citi’s Challenges in Mexico
abstract: Citigroup’s troubles in Mexico illustrate the challenges of emerging markets. | No mention of its founder in Men’s Wearhouse’s deal announcement. | SAC Capital Advisors gets a new name. | Herbalife shares fell after William A. Ackman accused the company of “operating illegally” in China.
lead_paragraph: In the financial crisis year of 2008, Citigroup severed ties to Mexican companies that it feared could imperil its Mexican affiliate, but it seems that those efforts did not go far enough, Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg write in DealBook. A $400 million fraud at Citigroup’s Banamex unit that was discovered last month highlights the limitations of that kind of culling, and underscores the challenges of finding solid lending clients in a country where the line between big business and political cronyism can become blurred.

lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — For three months, throughout the uprising and upheaval in Kiev, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk was one of three political leaders who appeared regularly on stage in Independence Square, but he often seemed out of his element. A former foreign minister, economics minister, speaker of Parliament and acting central bank chief, he is more at home in boardrooms and in the corridors of power than on the barricades.

headline: An Uncertain Quiet for Crimean Tatars
abstract: More than 20 years after her family returned from decades of exile to their Crimean roots, Emine Ziyatdinova wonders if the upheaval in Crimea will again force Tatars from their homeland.
lead_paragraph: Emine Ziyatdinova’s recent photographs from Crimea sketch the pain that is not far from the tenuous peace. There are images of Russian soldiers and pro-Ukrainian protesters. And just last Sunday, in her family’s home, she photographed her mother crying as she stashed some documents into a bag.

headline: Yet More G.O.P. Hypocrisy on the Minimum Wage
abstract: New research suggests that raising the federal minimum wage would reduce federal spending. But Republicans are unmoved.
lead_paragraph: In an earlier post  on the minimum wage, I pointed out that Republicans who oppose a raise on the dubious grounds that it will reduce employment in the future have had no compunction about cutting food stamps and blocking the renewal of federal jobless benefits — even though doing so is projected to cost the economy  hundreds of thousands of jobs this year alone.

headline: Creighton’s Ethan Wragge Follows Through on Mother’s Lessons
