lead_paragraph: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — The morning before Creighton’s Ethan Wragge made nine 3-pointers in a win against Villanova in January, his mother, Kari, and father, Brad, joined him on the court after the team’s game-day shootaround at Wells Fargo Center in Philadelphia. The mood was light, and they grabbed a ball to take some shots.

headline: A Luxe Leather Bike Designed by Pharrell
abstract: The multi-hyphenate sensation teams up with a pair of French designers to craft a custom ride.
lead_paragraph: Pharrell Williams’s style is almost as popular as his music this year. In January, the Twittersphere buzzed when the artist arrived to the red carpet wearing a Vivienne Westwood hat that looked undeniably similar to the Arby’s logo. A week ago, social media flared up again when Williams walked into the Oscars with his hands shoved into the pockets of a pair of Lanvin tuxedo shorts. And yet somehow, the luxe limited-edition Brooklyn Bike that he created with the Paris duo Bruno Domeau and Philip Pérès and Brooklyn Machine Works — a New York-based bike company that Williams co-owns — is flying just under the trending hashtag radar. Just looking at the bright-yellow water-buffalo leather hand-stitched around its frame makes you feel as happy as Williams’s song of the same name. It’s available exclusively at Atelier Courbet, a new SoHo shop and gallery that represents artisan workshops — like the one run by Domeau and Pérès, who, before setting up shop together, were craftsmen for Hermès. The made-to-order pieces are customized for each client; at $16,500, it is more a piece of art than a way to get around town.

headline: Reducing Early Elective Deliveries
abstract: Induced or cesarean section deliveries at 37 or 38 weeks, usually for convenience, was until recently widely considered benign. It isn’t.
lead_paragraph: How do institutions change their practices? In medicine, the usual answer is “slowly.” Clinical trials can show the efficacy of a new practice — yet, decades later, many physicians still haven’t gotten the message.

headline: SXSW 2014: Jungle Unmasked, Sort Of
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The London R&B group didn’t hide that they are about as Afro-British as the Average White Band was.
lead_paragraph: A mystery shouldn’t have a banal solution. But it did with Jungle, a London R&B group that made its first career moves with determined anonymity: it had said only that its leaders were named T and J, it used dancers (mostly black men) in its videos, and it employed stills from those videos as publicity photos. By the end of the year, the New Musical Express was calling Jungle “the UK’s most mysterious act.”  On tour, Jungle has generally performed in a thick smoke-machine fog.

headline: Inside the Design of Cruise Itineraries
abstract: An executive with Carnival Cruise Lines talks about how to attract customers and choose destinations.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been on a cruise, chances are it was designed by someone like Terry Thornton. For more than 25 years, he has helped create itineraries for Carnival Cruise Lines, the largest of the cruise industry companies, balancing fuel costs with revenue and customer feedback for a 24-ship fleet that regularly loops through ports in Mexico and the Caribbean.

headline: Prone to Seasickness? Distraction Might Help
keywords: ['Motion Sickness', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Cruises', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine']
abstract: From ginger to music, these therapies could help you deal with motion sickness, sometimes by merely distracting you.
lead_paragraph: Few things will ruin a cruise faster than feeling seasick. To help prevent motion sickness, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends staying hydrated, curbing alcohol and caffeinated drinks, eating small meals and limiting external stimuli (closing your eyes, lying face down or keeping your eyes on the horizon). And while some experts say that cabins in the middle of the lower deck of a ship may help temper motion sickness, the C.D.C. has reported that “cabin location on a cruise ship does not appear to influence the likelihood of motion sickness.”

headline: Performance Festival at LaMaMa to Honor Tom Murrin
abstract: The festival, in April, will honor the work of the lawyer-turned-playwright and performance artist, who died in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Tom Murrin, the lawyer turned playwright and performance artist, who often appeared under the names Tom Trash, Jack Bump and Alien Comic, and who died in 2012, will be commemorated in an 11-day Tom Murrin Full Moon Performance Festival at La MaMa in April.

headline: Photos: The Big East’s Garden Party
abstract: The league’s men’s basketball tournament was first held in Madison Square Garden in 1983, and there it has stayed, even as the conference itself has been transformed.
lead_paragraph: The way the Big East tells it, this year’s men’s basketball tournament represents a return to the conference’s roots as a group of proud basketball schools that escaped from under the thumb of all-powerful college football to revel in their sport’s greatness. And they will do it at Madison Square Garden, the conference tournament’s home since 1983. In reality, the Big East’s current membership would stump most “Jeopardy” contestants, and the gathering is certain to feel haunted by the ghosts of departed stalwarts like Syracuse, Connecticut and Pittsburgh.

headline: In Store | Just in Time for SXSW, A Shoppable Home Away From Home
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Friends & Neighbors, a new Austin lifestyle boutique housed in a bungalow, combines New York cool with a welcoming Texas spirit.
lead_paragraph: For a certain type of girl during a certain stretch of the aughts, I Heart — the late, lamented subterranean NoLIta boutique housed in Sonic Youth’s former practice space — was more than a place to shop for night-out looks from under-the-radar designers; it was a second home of sorts, a spot for kicking back, listening to obscure dance records and reading ‘zines. That store’s owner, Jill Bradshaw, recently decamped to Austin, Tex., her old college stomping grounds. Now, just in time for the South by Southwest conference, she has joined forces with two more Brooklyn expats, the restaurateurs Greg Mathews and Jade Place Mathews, to open Friends & Neighbors, an equally convivial concept store housed in a residential bungalow in burgeoning East Austin.

headline: Times Minute | The Search for Flight 370
abstract: A look at the search efforts for the Malaysia Airlines plane that vanished early Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: A look at the search efforts for the Malaysia Airlines plane that vanished early Saturday morning.

headline: Times Minute | The Search for Flight 370
abstract: A look at the search efforts for the Malaysia Airlines plane that vanished early Saturday morning.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: David Jolly Wins House Seat in Florida
abstract: Representative-elect David Jolly, a Republican, spoke after narrowly winning a special election for a House seat in a hotly contested swing district in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Representative-elect David Jolly, a Republican, spoke after narrowly winning a special election for a House seat in a hotly contested swing district in Florida.

headline: Interview: Seth Rogen and Zac Efron
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Two of the stars of “Neighbors” discuss their film.
lead_paragraph: Two of the stars of “Neighbors” discuss their film.

headline: Supporting Start-Ups With Connections, Advice and Caffeine
abstract: The 1 Million Cups program is run by entrepreneurs, and local chapters are springing up across the country.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Cannon was clearly nervous as she started a carefully prepared presentation about her start-up, PackSack, which makes a reusable grocery bag that folds into itself for storing. Just 22, Ms. Cannon was speaking to a forum of 20 entrepreneurs in a conference room at Co-Merge, a sleekly outfitted co-working space in downtown San Diego. She talked about her market research, her decision to manufacture in Mexico and her pricing.

headline: Buffett Shrinks Ties to the Graham Family
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway disclosed that it planned to exchange the bulk of its holdings in Graham Holdings — about 1.6 million shares — for a Miami television station, cash and some shares that Graham holds in Berkshire.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:29 p.m. | In the spring of 1973, Katharine Graham learned that a Midwestern investor had begun amassing a stake in The Washington Post Company, the parent of the newspaper her family had run for decades.

headline: In Performance: Claire Chase
abstract: Claire Chase performs Edgard Varèse's "Density 21.5" on a platinum flute.
lead_paragraph: Claire Chase performs Edgard Varèse's "Density 21.5" on a platinum flute.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Has Its Premiere at SXSW
abstract: The new comedy series from Mike Judge premiered at the festival ahead of airing on HBO.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — With the tech world as its subject, the coming HBO series “Silicon Valley” could only  benefit by holding its premiere here at South by Southwest, home to a huge interactive conference.

headline: A Song-and-Dance Survival Strategy
abstract: “The Pig, or Vaclav Havel’s Hunt for a Pig,” a musical theater piece at 3LD Art & Technology, evokes the use of subterfuge in a mercurial and oppressive society. Pork is served.
lead_paragraph: When I left the 3LD Art & Technology Center the other night, I had half of a pulled-pork sandwich in my pocket, and Vaclav Havel was dancing around the room, singing a rambunctious version of the Velvet Underground’s “I’m Waiting for the Man” to live accompaniment. Such are the happy vagaries of a New York theater critic’s life.

headline: Plane’s Locating Device Went Silent Before Disappearance
abstract: One mystery surrounding the lost Malaysian jet concerns the plane’s transponder, which apparently stopped functioning about 40 minutes into the flight.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One of the mysteries surrounding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 concerns the aircraft’s transponder, which apparently stopped functioning about 40 minutes into the flight, leaving ground controllers in the dark about where the plane was.

headline: Scenes From the Building Collapse
abstract: A gas leak set off a large explosion and the collapse of two buildings in East Harlem.
lead_paragraph: A gas leak set off a large explosion and the collapse of two buildings in East Harlem.

headline: The Other People Are Back. Do They Ever Leave?
abstract: Jean-Paul Sartre’s hellish theatrical metaphor “No Exit” is playing at the Pearl Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: Unlike poor deluded Blanche DuBois, nobody in Jean-Paul Sartre’s bleakly comic existential thesis, “No Exit,” depends on the kindness of strangers. At least not for long. The principal characters in this needling 1944 one-act play, being revived by the Pearl Theater Company, learn the hard way that “Hell is just — other people.”

headline: Scenes From the Harlem Building Collapse
abstract: Multiple fatalities have been reported in the collapse.
lead_paragraph: Multiple fatalities have been reported in the collapse.

headline: Secrets Rooted in a Family Tree
abstract: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins brings up a stew of simmering resentments and unfinished arguments in his play “Appropriate.”
lead_paragraph: In his 2010 play “Neighbors,” Branden Jacobs-Jenkins featured black actors in blackface to grapple with self-loathing among blacks. In his latest work to open in New York, “Appropriate,” he is more subtle: Incendiary visuals are the crux of the plot, but the audience never sees them.

headline: Kerry Plans 11th-Hour Meeting With Russians Over Crimea
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry will meet the Russian foreign minister in London two days before Crimeans vote in a referendum on joining Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry will fly to London to meet with his Russian counterpart in a 11th-hour effort to persuade the Kremlin not to move forward with the annexation of Crimea, American officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Q&A: The Fed Will Manage a Soft Landing
keywords: ['Inflation (Economics)', 'Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy']
abstract: An interview with John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, about recent economic trends and the Fed’s response.
lead_paragraph: John Williams, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, is feeling pretty good about the economy. He is ready to continue the Fed’s retreat from bond-buying and forward guidance. And he says he’s optimistic that this time, the Fed will manage to produce a soft landing. The transcript of our conversation earlier this week has been lightly edited for clarity.

headline: In Performance Video: Claire Chase
abstract: Ms. Chase performs Edgard Varèse’s “Density 21.5″ on a platinum flute.
lead_paragraph: Claire Chase performs Edgard Varèse’s “Density 21.5″ on a platinum flute.

headline: House Hunting in ... Luxembourg
abstract: As a financial center and headquarters for several European institutions, this multicultural nation draws foreign investors from all over the world.
lead_paragraph: A SIX-BEDROOM FARMHOUSE-STYLE VILLA IN MUNSBACH

headline: A New York Artist’s Wartime Childhood
abstract: In “Leaving China,” the author and illustrator James McMullan writes about his childhood in China, India, Canada and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Lush violet shadows, a sense of the page as a deep box — a stage, really — in which a quiet drama unfolds in acute perspective: New Yorkers may recognize James McMullan’s signature watercolors from his posters for Lincoln Center Theater. (His saucy sailor girl, looking back over her shoulder to advertise a production of “Anything Goes” at the Vivian Beaumont, is a particularly well-known example.) New York Times readers may remember the illustrated 12-part series McMullan wrote on the artistic process for the Opinionator blog in 2010. And children and their art-loving parents will recall the many picture books he has illustrated, including the Times Best Illustrated winner “I Stink!” — written by his wife, Kate McMullan — a first-person account of the life of a garbage truck. “Know what I do at night while you’re asleep? Eat your trash, that’s what! See those bags? I smell breakfast!”

headline: Groundhog Days
abstract: Brooks and Collins on whether it will be more of the same, politically speaking, in 2014 and 2016.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins:  David, this will be our last online conversation for a while. But we’ll still run into each other in the hall, right?

headline: New Trips to North Korea and Iran
abstract: Mir Tours, a company that specializes in trips to places that are difficult to reach, now has North Korea and Iran on its itinerary.
lead_paragraph: Over the last three decades, Douglas Grimes, the founder of Mir, a tour company, has built a business around his ability to gain access to destinations that are difficult to reach, and this year he adds North Korea to the list, offering an 11-day tour making stops in Nampo and Pyongyang, as well as Kaesong, in the demilitarized zone.

headline: Ligety, Giant Slalom Specialist, Gains First Podium in Downhill
abstract: Ted Ligety, who won the giant slalom for the United States at the Sochi Games, tied for second in the downhill, a career-best result and a huge step toward competing for an overall title in the future.
lead_paragraph: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland — Three weeks after Ted Ligety of the United States won gold in the giant slalom at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, he notched another first: a top-three finish in the downhill.

headline: Health Mandate Won’t Be Delayed, Sebelius Says
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The deadline for people to sign up for health insurance won’t be extended, the secretary of health and human services said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, said Wednesday that the Obama administration would not extend the deadline for people to sign up for health insurance or delay the requirement for most Americans to have coverage.

headline: Metro-North Service Restored After Explosion in Harlem
abstract: The M.T.A. said Metro-North Railroad service into and out of Grand Central Terminal has been restored. Service was suspended earlier after two buildings collapsed from an explosion in East Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:12 p.m.

headline: Dispatches From SXSW: A Winning Translation App
keywords: ['Chinese Language', 'Mobile Applications', 'Small Business', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Start-ups', 'Translation and Interpreters']
abstract: Waygo lets users get an instant English translation by waving a phone over Chinese or Japanese characters.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night before a packed house at the Austin Hilton Downtown, winners of the SXSW Accelerator Awards were announced. The ceremony is the culmination of a two-day tech competition where some of the world’s most innovative start-ups pitch themselves to a panel of judges including venture capitalists, angel investors and industry executives. Out of hundreds of initial applicants and 48 preliminary finalists, 18 were chosen to return on Sunday and six were named winners.

headline: CBS Signs Up ‘Big Bang’ for Three More Years
abstract: The deal would extend the show, which stands alone as TV’s most popular comedy, through the 2016-17 television season.
lead_paragraph: How important is “The Big Bang Theory” to CBS? Important enough for the network to step up to an unusual order for three more seasons of what is now by far the biggest hit on network television.

headline: Panel Says Yemeni Man Should Stay in Detention
abstract: A parole-style panel at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, said Abdel Malik al-Rahabi should remain there indefinitely to “protect against a continuing significant threat.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A parole-style panel at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has decided to recommend that the military continue to hold a Yemeni man in indefinite wartime detention without trial, according to a military document. The decision is the first of its kind for the Obama administration’s new Periodic Review Board system.

headline: What 1 Million Cups Has Meant to Kansas City
abstract: The organization has helped energize the local start-up community.
lead_paragraph: As Eilene Zimmerman writes in an article we just published, 1 Million Cups has been part of a serendipitous series of events that has helped galvanize the Kansas City start-up community.

headline: Image of the Day: March 12
abstract: A protest march in McLeodganj town in Himachal Pradesh on the 55th anniversary of the Tibetan National Uprising Day against Chinese rule.

headline: Debate on Bourbon St.: Should the Good Times Roll Less Loudly?
abstract: When the efforts to fix a faulty and spottily enforced noise ordinance became bogged down, the New Orleans City Council decided to try to fix what is perhaps the country’s pre-eminent 24-hour street party.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Last Thursday, two nights after Mardi Gras, amid the customary debauchery that is apparently immune to the chill and the Lenten hangover, a tall man with a device resembling a 1980s-era cellphone was going door to door on Bourbon Street.

headline: A Landmark Restored, From Mosaic Marble Floor to Grand Dome
abstract: The Williamsburgh Savings Bank headquarters is now an event space called Weylin B. Seymour’s, for a fictional character whose monogram is everywhere in the building.
lead_paragraph: As sumptuous as a jewel box suspended 110 feet over the mosaic marble floor, and as radiant as a peacock’s plumage, the great dome of the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank headquarters at Broadway and Driggs Avenue once again inspires awe.

headline: F.T.C. Inquiry Into Herbalife Prompts Big Share Selloff
abstract: Shares of Herbalife tumble after the company says it has received a civil investigative demand from the Federal Trade Commission.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission said on Wednesday that it had opened an official inquiry into Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company that has been the focus of a 15-month crusade by the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman.

headline: Resurrecting Republican Populism
abstract: On taxes, Dave Camp and Mike Lee point a way forward — and back.
lead_paragraph: If you want to cut to the heart of what’s gone wrong in the Republican Party over the last two presidential cycles, you could do worse than start with this post from the liberal blogger Kevin Drum, lamenting the weakness of his own party’s pitch to working and middle class voters:

headline: Fannie Mae Investors May Be Using Magic Calculators
abstract: The price of Fannie Mae’s preferred stock is up more than tenfold in 18 months, but even cheerful assumptions suggest its business isn’t worth enough for shareholders to get much if anything back after an overhaul, write Daniel Indiviglio and Richard Beales in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae investors may be using magic calculators. As the latest overhaul blueprint takes shape in the Senate, hedge funds like Fairholme Capital Management have urged Washington to revitalize Fannie, the mortgage finance giant, which along with Freddie Mac was kept alive with nearly $190 billion of taxpayer cash in the aftermath of the financial crisis.

headline: Gel Protects Monkeys From H.I.V. After Sex, Study Finds
abstract: The vaginal gel worked even three hours after exposure, which would be particularly useful for women affected by domestic violence and rape.
lead_paragraph: In another promising development in AIDS prevention, scientists have shown that monkeys can be protected against infection with a vaginal gel even when it is used as long as three hours after sex.

headline: New Book From Oprah Winfrey Is ‘What I Know for Sure’
abstract: The book is adapted from a regular column Ms. Winfrey writes for her magazine. It set for release in September.
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey has written a new book collecting some of her insights about life’s struggles and inspirations, her publisher said on Wednesday.

headline: Arizona Governor With Tough Immigration and Abortion Stands Won’t Run Again
abstract: Even though the Arizona Constitution limits governors to two terms, Ms. Brewer had talked lately about trying to find a way around it.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona, a Republican whose approval of controversial measures on immigration and abortion have repeatedly put her in the national spotlight, announced Wednesday that she would not run for re-election, ending speculation that she might seek a third term.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,850,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a cottage in Venice Beach, Calif.; a brick house in Asheville, N.C.; and a compound in Texas.
lead_paragraph: VENICE BEACH, CALIF.

headline: Atomico Adds to Investment in Brazil
abstract: The venture capital firm led by Niklas Zennstrom, the co-founder of Skype, has led a new round of financing in Bebestore, an online baby and maternal goods company in Brazil that it has backed before. The new investment indicates that e-commerce remains attractive in the country despite many struggling start-ups.
lead_paragraph: SAO PAULO, Brazil — Atomico, the venture capital firm led by Niklas Zennstrom, the co-founder of Skype, is investing in Brazil again, a sign that entrepreneurship continues to grow here even amid a lagging economy.

headline: Gaza-Israel Escalation Threatens Cease-Fire
abstract: The militant group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility for a rocket attack, the most intense barrage since the cease-fire of 2012.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Sixty rockets fired from the Gaza Strip rained down across southern Israel on Wednesday afternoon, sending thousands of Israelis scrambling into bomb shelters, in by far the most intense barrage since a cease-fire that ended eight days of cross-border violence in 2012.

headline: Spurred by Paul, Kentucky Weighs Change to Ballot Rule
abstract: Aides to Senator Rand Paul are seeking a statute clarification that would allow him to run both for re-election and for president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has not said if he plans to run for the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, but his supporters are already backing a bill in his state’s Legislature that would let him appear more than once on the ballot.

headline: Where to Find the Most Inequality
abstract: Trulia used its housing data to identify the cities with the highest, and lowest, levels of income inequality.
lead_paragraph: The gap between the rich and poor has increased in 94 of the 100 largest metropolitan areas since 1990. And the growth in the gap has accelerated in the past few years.

headline: Avid Reader Leaves Library $6 Million in Her Will
abstract: A patron of the New York Public Library, who died last summer, set aside $6 million for the library in her will, the library announced on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Simply because she loved to read, Lotte Fields bequeathed $6 million to the New York Public Library after her death, the library announced on Wednesday.

headline: By Design | Architecture for Living
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The grandson of a master mosaicist pays tribute to his heritage with a new furniture line.
lead_paragraph: The grandson of a master mosaicist pays tribute to his heritage with a new furniture line.

headline: De Blasio on East Harlem Explosion
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said a gas leak caused the explosion that destroyed two buildings in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said a gas leak caused the explosion that destroyed two buildings in Harlem.

headline: A Wild Idea: Making Our Smartphones Last Longer
abstract: Saving money and global resources are just two good reasons not to ditch your cellphone after the traditional two-year cycle.
lead_paragraph: When Apple unveiled the iPhone 5 late in 2012, it was the fastest and most capable smartphone on the market, a highly intricate collection of electronics that had been miraculously forged into a single sturdy slab of aluminum and glass. Unlike most ephemeral gadgets, this phone felt as if it were built to last for ages.

headline: App Smart: Birthdays
abstract: Kit Eaton describes three apps that can help you keep track of the birthdays for the people in your life.
lead_paragraph: Kit Eaton describes three apps that can help you keep track of the birthdays for the people in your life.

headline: Forget a Birthday? Not if the Phone Can Help It
abstract: Some apps will alert a user to the birthdays of friends and family members, while others will help prepare and send personalized greetings.
lead_paragraph: IT’S my birthday this week! It’s a date I am not likely to forget, but I acknowledge that when it comes to friends’ or family members’ birthdays, my memory is awful. Often, I even miss the “It’s X’s birthday” alerts that pop up in Facebook. Beyond simple calendar alerts, many apps can help you remember and celebrate a birthday.

headline: Blast ‘Ripped the Stomach Right Out of You’
abstract: The building collapse in East Harlem instantaneously trapped people in rubble and just as quickly sent residents into the street to help.
lead_paragraph: The explosion was so powerful it lifted Jaye Virgo off her bed and blasted her window fan from the sill. Outside that window was chaos. People lay on the pavement, strewed among shattered glass and parts ripped from cars, the sidewalk dusted in ash.

headline: Jackson Heights: More Space; Hold the Frills
abstract: Jill Schwartzman and Brian Shirey were looking for elbow room in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Jill Schwartzman moved often within Manhattan and Brooklyn, always happy to sample a new location. When she and Brian Shirey met in 2006, he lived in Astoria, Queens. She found the borough interesting, diverse and delicious.

headline: Huge Recall by G.M. Sets Off Painful Questions on Crashes
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Families face new feelings of grief and anger over possibly missed warnings of problems with the vehicles’ ignition switches.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Ala. — The broken windshield and singed grass that have been on the side of State Route 64 since December serve as a daily reminder for the unsettling hunch that nags Steve W. Smith: Something about that accident was not quite right.

headline: Bolshoi Soloist to Debut as Guest Artist With Ballet Theater
abstract: Olga Smirnova, a leading soloist with the Bolshoi Ballet, will make her debut as a guest artist with American Ballet Theater in May at the Metropolitan Opera House, the company announced Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Olga Smirnova, a leading soloist with the Bolshoi Ballet who had a breakout season in London last summer, will make her debut as a guest artist with American Ballet Theater in May at the Metropolitan Opera House, where she will dance in a single performance of “La Bayadère,” the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Mikhailovsky Ballet to Make American Debut at Koch Theater
abstract: The ballet, which canceled an American performance in 2012, will bring Adolphe Adam’s “Giselle” and three other programs to the David H. Koch Theater in November.
lead_paragraph: The Mikhailovsky Ballet, a Russian dance troupe based in St. Petersburg, had planned to make its United States debut in the summer of 2012 but decided to scuttle the visit when the American Ballet Theater exercised a non-compete clause involving two dancers who worked with both companies, Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev.

headline: Elliott Raises Stake in Juniper Networks
abstract: The hedge fund Elliott Management is raising its bet on Juniper Networks after the networking equipment company announced a series of new initiatives.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund Elliott Management is raising its bet on Juniper Networks after the networking equipment company announced a series of new initiatives.

headline: Russian Website Is Reined In Over Article on Ukrainian
abstract: A popular independent online news site, Lenta.ru, got a warning from the government about its Ukraine coverage, and then a new editor.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The retribution against one of Russia’s most popular independent online news organizations, Lenta.ru, was as swift as it was unexpected. And to many it served as an ominous warning about the state of the media today as the conflict over Ukraine deepens.

headline: The Phony Bill to Help Sick Kids Actually Helps Corporations Extend Their Influence
abstract: A bill approved on Tuesday purports to pay for research by eliminating public money for the two political conventions.
lead_paragraph: One particularly effective (and cynical) way to roll back the public campaign finance system is to claim you’re doing so on behalf of some needy group. Republicans do that kind of thing all the time, but Senate Democrats went along yesterday in a particularly unfortunate vote.

headline: On the Street in East Harlem
abstract: A look at the aftermath of the Harlem building collapse.
lead_paragraph: A look at the aftermath of the Harlem building collapse.

headline: Video: Seth Rogen and Zac Efron on ‘Neighbors’
abstract: The two actors discuss their roles in the comdey “Neighbors,” directed by Nicholas Stoller.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — The actors Seth Rogen and Zac Efron brought their coming summer comedy “Neighbors” to the South by Southwest film festival for a premiere screening. The movie, directed by Nicholas Stoller, follows what happens when a college fraternity moves in next door to a couple with a baby. Mr. Rogen and Rose Byrne star alongside Mr. Efron. In this video interview, conducted at an Austin bar that was converted into a makeshift version of a fraternity house, Mr. Rogen and Mr. Efron discuss their characters in “Neighbors” and their approach to the film’s comedy.

headline: The Gun Report: March 12, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday we brought you the tragic tale of Peter Lanza and his son, the perpetrator of the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary. But something good followed the shooting: Fifteen states, plus the District of Columbia, have strengthened their gun control laws in the past year, regulations that cover roughly half of the U.S. population, according to a new report by Johns Hopkins Center for Gun Policy and Research.

headline: Who’s Who Becomes Lethal Guessing Game
abstract: Olen Steinhauer, best known for his Milo Weaver series, has written “The Cairo Affair,” a stand-alone novel with relevance to the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: Olen Steinhauer’s recent three-volume Milo Weaver series was about the Tourists, a top-secret C.I.A. spy unit. Milo was an exceptionally appealing character among black ops types. His personal life was as fraught as his cloak-and-dagger work, and when he wasn’t trotting around the globe, he was apt to turn up in Brooklyn. But by the third installment, after the Chinese had entered the mix, the plot had thickened so much that it bordered on the impenetrable. Only the most seasoned le Carré buffs had the chops to tackle Mr. Steinhauer’s ever more elaborate tricks.

headline: A Study Seeks to Determine What Makes Prekindergarten Successful
abstract: The study will follow 4,000 children to see if curriculum can create lasting improvement in students’ skills and a likelihood to persevere academically.
lead_paragraph: The teacher held up a card with a number on it, then looked at the 4-year-olds waving their hands eagerly in front of her. “Anderson,” she said, calling on a small boy in a blue button-up shirt and a sweater vest.

headline: Personal Mix of Familiar and Fresh, With a Show-Tune Encore
abstract: The soprano Julia Bullock, a Juilliard student, made her New York recital debut as part of the Young Concert Artists series.
lead_paragraph: The young American soprano Julia Bullock won lots of fans in New York last spring for her endearing, vocally radiant performance of the title role in Janacek’s “The Cunning Little Vixen,” presented by Juilliard Opera in an enchanting production. Clearly Ms. Bullock is still faring well in her studies at Juilliard, for late next month, she will sing the title role in the school’s production of Massenet’s “Cendrillon.”

headline: Rainbow-Hued Housing for Gays in Golden Years
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Elderly', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Retirement', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: A small but growing number of subsidized apartment complexes offer a welcoming environment to low- and moderate-income gay seniors, who often face housing discrimination.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — DENISE SAMEN, who is 65 and a military veteran, has not had an easy life. She lost an arm in a train accident, supported herself by working a series of low-paying service and clerical jobs, needs a wheelchair to get around and came of age when homosexuality was considered a psychiatric disorder. And though she has never hidden who she is — she often dresses in men’s-styled clothing — she doesn’t play it up, either.

headline: Skier Taps Natural Terrain
abstract: Skier Tim Durtschi garnered attention for his exploits in ski resort terrain parks and jumps in the backcountry. But he has stepped away from manicured features to ski natural terrain.
lead_paragraph: Skier Tim Durtschi garnered attention for his exploits in ski resort terrain parks and jumps in the backcountry. But he has stepped away from manicured features to ski natural terrain.

headline: Dudley Lashes Out at Banks
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: William C. Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, criticized banks for their “lack of respect for law, regulation and the public trust.”
lead_paragraph: William C. Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, criticized banks for their “lack of respect for law, regulation and the public trust.”

headline: Offering a German Lesson for Asia’s History Wars
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Nearly 70 years after the end of World War II, China and Japan are still verbally and symbolically battling over wartime traumas that have long been resolved in Europe.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Why not let him visit the Holocaust memorial?’’ asked Chan Koonchung, a Beijing-based Hong Kong writer, of President Xi Jinping of China.

headline: New Plays by Donald Margulies and David Auburn in Manhattan Theater Club Season
abstract: “The Country House,” a comedy by Mr. Margulies, will be followed by Mr. Auburn’s “Lost Lake” and a new work by Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan Theater Club will present new works by Donald Margulies, David Auburn and Frances Ya-Chu Cowhig as part of its 2014-15 season, the company announced Wednesday.

headline: Keeping Stand-Up in the Box
abstract: The different styles of the comics Sean Patton and Ted Alexandro also reveal differences between stand-up and TV comedy.
lead_paragraph: Give him a microphone and 10 minutes in front of a live crowd, and Sean Patton, a short, rotund, live-wire comedian, is just about a sure thing.

headline: In Club Hockey League, Meager Funding Doesn’t Kill Appetite for Competition
abstract: The American Collegiate Hockey Association, which just finished its Division I men’s national tournament, consists of a diverse group of 410 programs whose athletes must pay to play.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK, Del. — After 19 games in six days, the American Collegiate Hockey Association’s Division I men’s national tournament ended Tuesday night with a matchup that reflected the breadth of the club league.

headline: Art Sales Grew Last Year, Especially in U.S., Report Says
abstract: A report that reviews art sales around the world says that there was modest growth in the world market and substantial growth within the United States.
lead_paragraph: The sale of art and antiques around the world rose 8 percent last year to $65.9 billion, the highest level since 2007, continuing a recovery in the art market, according to the latest annual report for the European Fine Art Foundation.

headline: Video: Skier Taps Natural Terrain for a Larger Canvas
abstract: In the latest episode of “Behind the Line,” the skier Tim Durtschi steps away from manicured features to ski natural terrain.
lead_paragraph: “Behind the Line” is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: China, With You Behind the Wheel
abstract: Steppes Travel is offering a China trip during which travelers drive through one of the nation’s most picturesque regions.
lead_paragraph: Steppes Travel, a London-based company specializing in high-end cultural and archaeological tours, has introduced a 10- to 15-day trip to China with a self-drive component.

headline: Jefferies in $25 Million Settlement With S.E.C.
abstract: The Jefferies Group, the investment bank and brokerage firm, agreed to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to supervise traders who lied to investors about the price of mortgage-backed securities.
lead_paragraph: The Jefferies Group, the investment bank and brokerage firm, agreed on Wednesday to pay $25 million to settle accusations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it failed to supervise traders who lied to investors about the price of mortgage-backed securities.

headline: Hitting the High Notes in Tribute
abstract: Jarrod Spector, who has portrayed Frankie Valli in “Jersey Boys,” is emblematic of a new breed of vocal shape shifters.
lead_paragraph: What do Freddie Mercury, Jimmy Scott, Frankie Valli and Enrico Caruso have in common? In Jarrod Spector’s highly polished show, “A Little Help From My Friends,” at 54 Below on Monday evening, all were depicted as belonging to a line of tenors stretching into the mists of time. From this perspective, there isn’t much difference among pop, rock, opera or even the blues. All are platforms for tenors and falsettos of every stripe to unleash their high notes.

headline: Text to Text | ‘Is the Wolf a Real American Hero?’ and ‘Hunting Habits of Wolves Change Ecological Balance in Yellowstone’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we examine a shifting understanding, based on new data, of a long-held idea in ecology: that the return of the gray wolf brought stability and balance to the previously elk-dominated Yellowstone ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: Was the reintroduction of wolves to Yellowstone National Park in the 1990s, after they were exterminated earlier in the century, the major ecological success story it has been declared to be by scientists and the media alike? Or, is the story — like ecology itself — much more complicated than that?

headline: Paris Through Eddie Borgo’s Eyes
abstract: The New York-based jewelry designer shares the style-hunting secrets of his recent trip.
lead_paragraph: The jewelry designer Eddie Borgo recently returned from his semi-annual fashion-week trip to Paris, which offered, as usual, a mix of business (sales and press appointments) and pleasure (food, culture and a side trip to Versailles). From moldings to museum shows, the city’s rich trove of decorative arts is particularly inspiring for Borgo’s metier. Here, he shares snapshots and stories from the journey.

headline: Jackson’s Triangle Offense: One Way to Reshape a Knicks Star
abstract: Three people who have worked with Phil Jackson believe he would relish the opportunity to integrate Carmelo Anthony into the offense he used as a coach.
lead_paragraph: When Phil Jackson’s most recent book tour took him to northern New Jersey last spring, he was asked for his opinion of the Knicks’ reigning star, Carmelo Anthony. Seldom shy, Jackson said, “An amazing ballplayer who still has another level to step up.”

headline: In His Second Year, Pope Faces Expectations That Change Is Coming
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Widely praised and globally popular, Francis has raised expectations that he will bring major changes to the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis marks the first anniversary of his papacy on Thursday having become so globally celebrated that he recently felt compelled to deflate his own “superman” aura. He is a star of magazine covers and social media, praised for his welcoming, nonjudgmental persona, his embrace of the poor and his decisiveness in moving to reform an ossified Vatican bureaucracy.

headline: Pharrell Williams’s ‘Happy’ Holds at No. 1; Rick Ross Tops Album Chart
abstract: Rick Ross’s album “Mastermind” handily outsold Mr. Williams’s new album, “G I R L.”
lead_paragraph: Pharrell Williams’s song “Happy” — and that Vivienne Westwood Mountain hat of his — have been ubiquitous lately, including in a performance at the Academy Awards last week. So it is not especially surprising that “Happy” holds at No. 1 on Billboard’s singles chart for a fourth week, with 490,000 downloads and eight million streams on services like Spotify, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: The Gray Jobs Enigma
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Retirement', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Though the number of people working while retired has risen in 20 years, more people give up on the idea, largely because of the difficulty in finding a suitable job.
lead_paragraph: In her years as a probation officer north of Dallas, Patricia Lowell reckoned that she would work until age 65, confident that she could then retire halfway comfortably on her pension and Social Security. After retiring, she thought, she would pick up some extra spending money by working part-time retail jobs during the holiday season.

headline: For Some, Age Is No Obstacle to Entrepreneurship
abstract: According to a study published by the Kauffman Foundation and LegalZoom, about 20 percent of all new businesses in 2013 were created by entrepreneurs ages 50 to 59.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Marvin Gay, 71, a retired accountant, and his wife, Leslie, 61, decided to open a Painting With a Twist franchise in St. Petersburg, Fla., their start-up costs were close to $70,000.

headline: Transferring Old Palm Desktop Data
abstract: Plus, picking a drive for Apple’s Time Machine.
lead_paragraph: Q. I have been using the Windows XP Palm Desktop software for my calendar and contacts even though I don’t use the Palm Pilot any longer. Is there a way to pull the information into Microsoft Outlook?

headline: Classical Playlist: John Adams, Prokofiev, Harrison Birtwistle and More
abstract: Critics for The Times share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: JOHN ADAMS: ‘The Gospel According to the Other Mary’ Los Angeles Philharmonic and Los Angeles Master Chorale, conducted by Gustavo Dudamel (Deutsche Grammophon)This capacious oratorio, with a libretto by Peter Sellars, John Adams’s frequent collaborator, was revised from when I first heard it in Los Angeles two years ago. While it may be a bit tighter, its strengths and weaknesses remain: an enormously creative and confident score and a weak text (drawn largely from modern and ancient poetry) that makes ponderous political points. This is a clearly rendered, strongly sung version. The tenor Russell Thomas still makes a showstopper out of the aria that closes the first act, “Tell Me: How Is This Night Different From All Other Nights?” (Zachary Woolfe)

headline: Candy Crush Maker Picks Valuation From Thin Air
abstract: As King Digital Entertainment, the maker of the popular game Candy Crush Saga, prepares to go public, it is difficult to calculate what it’s worth when its profit can skyrocket 70-fold one year and could collapse the next, writes Robert Cyran in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The maker of the popular game Candy Crush Saga has picked $7.6 billion out of thin air for what it sees as its value after an initial public offering. Its parent company, King Digital Entertainment, uses creative metrics to justify its whopping valuation. But there’s no way to calculate what an enterprise is worth when its profit can skyrocket 70-fold one year and could collapse the next. Zynga’s I.P.O. flub serves as an apt warning.

headline: SXSW 2014: No Lady Gaga Show for Me
keywords: ['Social Media', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Getting a ticket to see the show would have required the kind of social-media shillling that I don’t think anyone’s friends or followers should be subjected to.
lead_paragraph: One thing I won’t be doing at SXSW is attending Lady Gaga’s concert on Thursday night, which is sponsored by a greasy, salty, metallic-tasting, obesity-friendly snack chip that experts could easily condemn on physiological terms.

headline: Pause Is Seen in a Continent’s Peopling
abstract: Linguists have found that a lost language was spoken in Beringia, a plain bridging Siberia and North America, and that its speakers migrated east and west.
lead_paragraph: Using a new method for exploring ancient relationships among languages, linguists have found evidence further illuminating the peopling of North America about 14,000 years ago. Their findings follow a recent proposal that the ancestors of Native Americans were marooned for some 15,000 years on a now sunken plain before they reached North America.

headline: Reviewing Beats Music
abstract: Is the new music streaming service from Beats Electronics a worthy competitor to Spotify and Pandora? Molly Wood gives her verdict.
lead_paragraph: Is the new music streaming service from Beats Electronics a worthy competitor to Spotify and Pandora? Molly Wood gives her verdict.

headline: Beats Hopes to Serve Up Music in a Novel Way
abstract: Beats Music isn’t a Spotify killer, but its emphasis on playlists curated by music industry stars and industry experts is worth a second listen.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S a new subscription music service in town, one that purports to know you and your music tastes better than you know them yourself. One that urges you to forget about what you think you like and surrender to a sea of playlists lovingly created by artists and celebrities far more brilliant and beautiful than you.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from New York, Turkey, Afghanistan and Pakistan
lead_paragraph: Photographs from New York, Turkey, Afghanistan and Pakistan

headline: Those Kings of Southie Unveil Some Princesses
abstract: “Breaking Boston,” starting Thursday on A&E, is a reality series about four young Boston women struggling to get ahead in their relationships and careers.
lead_paragraph: Kristina has been dating Mikey for about a year, but Mikey says she has not yet earned the right to call him her boyfriend. As he puts it, “I’m pretty certain if it keeps going this way, we will have that label.”

headline: New Worlds Open at the Artist’s Easel
abstract: Like some other older people, a former hair salon owner has discovered a talent he didn’t know he had.
lead_paragraph: PAUSING in the middle of a brush stroke, Vincent Cass leans back in his wheelchair — paintbrush in hand — and offers an observation on life and art.

headline: The Science of Older and Wiser
keywords: ['Research', 'Elderly', 'Emotions', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Age, Chronological', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: The definition of wisdom may be hard to pin down precisely, but for those who have it, aging will be a pleasure.
lead_paragraph: Since ancient times, the elusive concept of wisdom has figured prominently in philosophical and religious texts. The question remains compelling: What is wisdom, and how does it play out in individual lives? Most psychologists agree that if you define wisdom as maintaining positive well-being and kindness in the face of challenges, it is one of the most important qualities one can possess to age successfully — and to face physical decline and death.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, Turkey, Afghanistan and Central African Republic.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Turkey, Afghanistan and Central African Republic.

headline: England Takes the Peggy Bayer Trophy
abstract: At the British junior international events in Belfast, Northern Ireland, the Peggy Bayer Trophy was won easily by England.
lead_paragraph: At the British junior international events played in Belfast, Northern Ireland, on Feb. 22 and 23, the Peggy Bayer Trophy (for players born after Jan. 1, 1994) was won easily by England.

headline: Two Buildings Collapse in East Harlem
abstract: Flames and smoke could be seen billowing from the street, and the force of the damage blew out windows in neighboring buildings.
lead_paragraph: Flames and smoke could be seen billowing from the street, and the force of the damage blew out windows in neighboring buildings.

headline: Medicare Changes Prompt Enrollees to Reconsider Plans
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A type of Medicare in which private insurers provide coverage remains attractive to Americans, but proposed reductions in government payments may change the benefits offered.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Don and Elizabeth Dersch, of Chester, Va., both 68, became eligible for Medicare a few years ago, they carefully weighed the costs of traditional Medicare and Medicare Advantage, the coverage provided by private insurers. They chose Medicare Advantage.

headline: ‘Rite of Spring’ as a Rite of Passage
abstract: The Tokyo Philharmonic Orchestra’s centennial concert at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday included works by Western and Japanese composers.
lead_paragraph: After you’ve performed Stravinsky’s brash and fulminating “Rite of Spring” for all it’s worth, what could you possibly do for an encore? The question is usually asked rhetorically, because few would even think of doing such a thing.

headline: What Was Inside the Collapsed Buildings
abstract: Floor-by-floor look of the East Harlem buildings destroyed by Wednesday’s blast.
lead_paragraph: Floor-by-floor look of the East Harlem buildings destroyed by Wednesday’s blast.

headline: In Syria, Questions About News Photographers
abstract: The death of an 18-year-old Syrian freelancing for Reuters has led to questions about the work of local activists the wire service employs there as photographers.
lead_paragraph: The death of an 18-year-old Syrian freelancing for Reuters has led to questions about the work of local activists the wire service employs there as photographers.

headline: Michael J. Fox Says No Series ‘Death Sentence’ Yet
abstract: The future of “The Michael J. Fox Show” does not look good, but Mr. Fox is concentrating on making sure the last seven episodes that were filmed are actually seen by audiences.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Fox does not fold easily. As if there were any doubt.

headline: Annuities Not for Everyone, but They Have a Place
abstract: Annuities — which produce regular, guaranteed retirement income — still have their uses, but may come with hard-to-understand contract riders and high fees.
lead_paragraph: SIMPLE, useful ideas have a way of becoming more complicated — and less useful — as the urge to improve them takes hold. Annuities may have succumbed to this tendency, financial advisers warn.

headline: For the 60th Time, a Visit to the Kingdom of Taylor
abstract: The Paul Taylor Dance Company opened its 60th season with three works, including “Cloven Kingdom.”
lead_paragraph: In Paul Taylor’s still-astonishing 1976 work “Cloven Kingdom,” human beings are shown to exist on several levels at the same time. We see their capacity for impersonal sublimity, their animal energies and their politely civilized behaviors, all overlapping peacefully and yet with disconcerting complexity. On Tuesday, better performed than it has been for many years, the work opened his company’s annual three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater. It’s one of those irresistible, imaginative and profound pieces in which Mr. Taylor proves himself the greatest choreographer alive.

headline: Guardians of Trusts
abstract: Once a staple of offshore trusts, protectors have gained popularity for use in conventional domestic trusts because of the complexity of trust law.
lead_paragraph: THE legacy part of retirement can be unsettling. If you have planned carefully and set up trusts and wills, you still might have some nagging doubts about how your wishes will be carried out after you are gone.

headline: Faith-Based Housing That Meets Evolving Needs
keywords: ['Faith-Based Initiatives', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Elder Care', 'Baby Boomers', 'Religion and Belief', 'Elderly', 'Quakers']
abstract: Faith-based retirement communities that provide a continuum of services, from independent living to skilled nursing care, are attracting more residents as baby boomers retire.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Elaine Daniels turned 60, she made a small deposit on an apartment at Pennswood Village in Bucks County, Pa., knowing that one day she might want to move into the retirement community founded on Quaker values.

headline: Shopping for a Masterpiece (With Help) for $5,000
abstract: A reporter gets tips from three professional guides on how to navigate the marketplace at three of New York’s smaller art fairs last week.
lead_paragraph: Robert Edelman, a private art dealer, was moving quickly down the aisles of Volta NY, one of the satellite art fairs going full blast in New York last week, when he hit the brakes at the booth being run by the Frederieke Taylor Gallery.

headline: In Beijing, Families of Missing Press for Action and Answers
abstract: The relatives and friends of the passengers of the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 are hungry for news of their loved ones, but little has come.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The first waves of shock had passed, and it was not time yet for mourning.

headline: Candy Crush and the Curve of Impressiveness
abstract: How a journalist reconciles his obsessiveness with games like Candy Crush Saga.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2008, I created a theory called the Guitar Hero Curve of Impressiveness. It holds that others’ admiration for your gaming skills follows a bell curve: rising, rising, rising — until it crests over into a loathsome drop.

headline: Brutal Winter, and Painful Rises in Heat Costs
keywords: ['Heating', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas', 'Propane', 'Weather', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The Energy Department detailed how much more it expects consumers to spend this unusually bitter winter.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Opening up heating and electricity bills has been a bit of a shocker in recent weeks. Exactly how shocking became clear on Wednesday when the Energy Department released a report showing just how expensive it was to keep warm and cook dinner this winter.

headline: Older Athletes Punching Above Their Age
abstract: With medical statistics scarce, participants in hockey, long-distance running, boxing and even rodeo play till it hurts, and insist it helps keep them young.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — I DON’T blanch as the guy in the green muscle shirt posts me up, six feet from the basket. He is 30 years younger, four inches taller and 25 pounds of muscle heavier. He gets the ball and goes up for the shot, but my arm flashes in front of him and, somehow, his shot goes awry and I grab the rebound as the game-ending clock buzzes.

headline: Obscurity Is the Lure
abstract: Whether rainbow-hued or glittery, obscure nail polish colors have a devoted following.
lead_paragraph: They call themselves lemmings. And like those mythic rodents, whose herd mentality is said to be so strong as to lead them off cliffs, these women are united in a mission that, to outsiders, may seem baffling and even berserk.

headline: The Rise of Back-to-the-Basics Funerals
abstract: An industry responds to demand for greener and more meaningful send-offs.
lead_paragraph: First there was Slow Food. Now come slow funerals. On a recent frigid Sunday at the Park Slope Food Coop, Amy Cunningham was giving a PowerPoint talk on green funerals to a graying crowd of about two dozen, many of them note-takers. “I think when the baby boom is of age and we’re actively leaving this world, the environmentally friendly approach will be business as usual,” she said. “It will not be the odd thing.”

headline: Albany County Orders a Halt to Growth in Oil Processing
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Ports', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Citing the potential impact on public health, a moratorium was ordered on the expansion of oil processing facilities at the Port of Albany.
lead_paragraph: Citing the potential impact on public health of Albany’s growing role as an oil hub, the county executive on Wednesday ordered a moratorium on the expansion of oil processing facilities at the Port of Albany.

headline: In Their Own Terms
abstract: From art to advertising, and on hit television shows, transgender presence is growing.
lead_paragraph: The first time Rhys Ernst saw Zackary Drucker was in 2005 at a bar in the East Village.

headline: Plagued by Uncertainties, Barcelona Still Dazzles
abstract: Days after a shock La Liga loss to Valladolid, Barcelona advanced to the quarterfinals of the Champions League with a 2-1 victory over Manchester City.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — In recent months, the grace and natural beauty of this city have not necessarily included Camp Nou stadium. A collection of off-field ugliness for Barcelona — including a tax fraud scandal and an under-pressure resignation from the club’s president — was accompanied by a rash of lackluster play on the field. Add in a few injuries and the announcement by the longtime fixture Carles Puyol that he would leave the club after the season, and there was a crisis of confidence among the Blaugrana fans.

headline: Citi Reduces the Pay of Its Mexico Chairman Amid Inquiries
abstract: Citigroup cut the pay of its chairman for Mexico, Manuel Medina-Mora, by about $1.1 million last year from 2012, citing “control issues” at its Banamex USA unit.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup cut the pay of its chairman for Mexico, Manuel Medina-Mora, by about $1.1 million last year from 2012, citing “control issues” at its Banamex USA unit.

headline: Theories Grow Without Facts on Lost Flight
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'News and News Media', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: On news programs and in chat rooms, aviation experts and the less informed tried to explain how a modern jet like Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 could disappear without a trace.
lead_paragraph: It is the talk of lunchrooms, chat rooms and, most certainly, television green rooms across the globe: How and why could a modern passenger jet disappear without a trace?

headline: Sales at Desiron, Ochre, Kartell and Artemide
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Lamps and Lampshades', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Deals on lamps, vases, furniture and more.
lead_paragraph: Desiron is discounting some furniture by up to 70 percent, through Wednesday (the Bowery bench, originally $3,100, is $1,600); 200 Lexington Avenue (East 32nd Street), Suite 702; 212-353-2600, desiron.com.

headline: Woven From the Archives of a Textile Designer
abstract: Blankets originally designed by Alexander Girard for Braniff are part of Herman Miller’s new Objects collection.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Girard, an exuberant colorist and avid promoter of folk art, was the first director of textile design at the furniture company Herman Miller. During his tenure there, from 1952 to 1975, he worked for other clients as well, including Braniff International Airways, which in the mid-1960s hired him to revamp its visual identity. Girard’s designs for the airline included brightly painted airplanes, airport lounge furniture, boarding passes and cheerful throws.

headline: Greasing a Squeaky Wheel
abstract: The “Power of Design” festival starts next week at the Wolfsonian-FIU museum in Miami Beach. Its theme: complaint.
lead_paragraph: The Wolfsonian-Florida International University museum is a bastion in Miami Beach of what it once called “thinkism.” From March 20 through 23, it will host its first Power of Design festival, with big-time thinkers like the computer scientist Jaron Lanier, the author of “Who Owns the Future?,” and Kurt Andersen, the “Studio 360” radio show host. The subject will be complaint as a source of inspiration. “It’s not a gripe fest; it’s a solution fest,” said Cathy Leff, the museum’s outgoing director. “So many people like the TEDs, and the PechaKuchas,” she added, referring to two forms of fast-paced, information-stuffed presentations. Events free and open to the public include a “complaints choir,” on March 20; a show of original posters curated by the graphic designer Steven Heller; and “Prophets of the Digital Age,” a March 22 conversation with Mr. Lanier, the novelist Michael Chabon and the technology writer Clive Thompson: 305-535-2625 or powerofdesign.wolfsonian.org.

headline: A Pizza to Stay, and Make It Special
abstract: Soon to open on Union Square, Pizza Vinoteca, with interiors by the architect James Biber.
lead_paragraph: Pizza Vinoteca, which opens next week at 15 Union Square West, represents James Biber’s return to restaurants. The architect, who did the interiors of Gotham Bar & Grill and Mesa Grill, which is now defunct, created a visual concept for this new chain, owned by Julius Numavicius, a Lithuanian billionaire. Avoiding the primary hues usually associated with fast food, he used black-and-white bar codes as a motif.

headline: The Hole-in-the-Wall Gang
abstract: What you’ll need to repair your walls.
lead_paragraph: What you’ll need to repair your walls.

headline: Blog Cabins: Home Page, Sweet Home
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Books and Literature', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Ellie Tennant on her new book, “Design Bloggers at Home: Fresh Interiors Inspirations from Leading Online Trend-Setters.”
lead_paragraph: The British design journalist Ellie Tennant, 31, made virtual investigations of bloggers’ rooms to find candidates for her first book, “Design Bloggers at Home: Fresh Interiors Inspiration From Leading Online Trend-Setters” (Ryland Peters & Small), just out. A former shopping editor and staff blogger at Ideal Home magazine, she spent about three years on and off determining which personalities behind the keyboards had interiors actually worth documenting.

headline: Is the Wall Cracked, or Am I?
abstract: How hard could it be to fix a little hole in the wall? Plenty hard, experts say. But it might be worth a try.
lead_paragraph: When our plumber spent five minutes replacing a $15 valve in an upstairs bathroom last month, he fixed a mystery leak that we had hunted for a decade. We only knew about the leak because the water had corroded the drywall above our front entrance.

headline: Sebelius Testifies Before the House
abstract: A sampling of the tough questions Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, fielded on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of the tough questions Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, fielded on Capitol Hill.

headline: The Best 401(k)s Set a Higher Bar for Others
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Retirement', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Firms that track benefit plans are finding their terms are improving for many employees, in areas such as company matching, vesting and fees.
lead_paragraph: EVERY December for five years, BrightScope, a financial research firm based in San Diego, has published a list of the top 30 401(k) plans. These standouts provide, among other qualities, generous company contributions, quick access to that corporate money, low fees and a wide array of investment options.

headline: Roll Out the Snow Carpet
abstract: A couple wanted their home to be open to the great outdoors. Their architect took them at their word.
lead_paragraph: “This is where we want to be” was the first thought that Clay Heighten and his wife, Debra Caudy, had when they stepped off the plane at the Jackson Hole Airport eight years ago. As Dr. Heighten said, “Those mountains really make an impact.”

headline: Doormats: No Footprints to Follow
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Keeping floors free of winter slush doesn’t mean that style has to be left outside.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, doormats have gotten a workout this winter. And particularly in New York, where they’ve had it easy for the last few years, repeated snowstorms and freezing rain have taken a toll. By this point, many of those mats need to be replaced.

headline: A Call for a Highly Encrypted Future
abstract: It is an interesting thought. But the best way to protect information from government snoops could conflict directly with the advertising-driven business models of many Internet companies.
lead_paragraph: The future will be encrypted, from the start of a conversation or data transmission to the end of it, if privacy activists and security specialists get their way.

headline: What’s Black and Red and Read All Over?
abstract: Two-colored pencils in an Art Deco-style box evoke the traditional instruments of Italian schoolteachers.
lead_paragraph: The country of Michelangelo and Fellini has long inspired Louise Fili, a New York City graphic designer and author. When creating a line of gift products for Princeton Architectural Press, she found in the 1920s and ’30s pencil cases she collects from Italian flea markets a subject that was perfect, or in this instance, perfetto. Her Perfetto Pencils are double-sided and come 12 to a box. (Ms. Fili, a celebrated riffer on vintage European typography, also designed the Art Deco-themed package.) They have two tones like the pencils traditionally used by teachers in Italy for grading homework, which are red and blue; “red for a minor infringement, blue for a serious offense,” she said. Hers are red and black. The combination, she said, “feels much more Italian, and are the only colors that I wear.” The pencils are about $9 on Amazon. Information: amazon.com.

headline: Long Time Coming
abstract: After years in the business, the men’s wear designer Mark McNairy has arrived. Just ask the rapper Cam’ron.
lead_paragraph: At first, the men’s wear designer Mark McNairy’s fall 2014 show for his New Amsterdam line last month seemed like business as usual. Preppy men, and some women, of varying ages strolled onto the runway in wryly monogrammed grandpa cardigans, cuffed pants and caps before an audience that included Damon Dash and the N.F.L. players Victor Cruz and Mychal Kendricks in the front row.

headline: Comparing Action Cameras
abstract: Roy Furchgott tests the video quality of several action cameras on the market.
lead_paragraph: Roy Furchgott tests the video quality of several action cameras on the market.

headline: Jackbar in Williamsburg
abstract: Arcade games and cheap drinks are the draw for Jackbar.
lead_paragraph: For those whose thumbs aren’t getting enough of a workout with digital games, pinball machines are enjoying a revival at Jackbar, which features a rotating selection of 10 games from the ’90s, and they’re all handily equipped with pint-glass holders.

headline: A Jeweler Changes His Game
abstract: A Brooklyn jewelry designer who has cornered the market on sports-related items is basing his new collection on love letters and a range of heart shapes.
lead_paragraph: Glancing at Gabriel Urist’s kitchen counter, you might think he had a very complicated blender, possibly of Eastern European origin. In actuality it’s a magnetic tumbler. And in place of a toaster and other appliances are hulking metalsmithing and jewelry-making contraptions.

headline: African Oils, Exotic and in Demand

headline: Across Turkey, New Unrest as Teenage Boy Is Buried

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — An enormous outpouring of grief and antigovernment rage during the funeral procession for a teenage boy felled by a police tear-gas canister turned into another mass confrontation with the Turkish authorities on Wednesday as mourners clashed with antiriot squads in Istanbul, Ankara and Izmir. At least one person was killed.

lead_paragraph: PEOPLE go to hospitals to get well. We all know that medical care involves risks, but what patients don’t expect is that the doctors, nurses and other staff members charged with their care may deliberately cause them harm. As an important recent case demonstrates, that’s exactly what can happen without stronger controls.

It was a searing moment that not only cost the Briggs family a father and husband, it also sent Mr. Breckinridge into a spiral of depression and doubt.

headline: Opponent of Mexico’s Cartels Is Detained in Vigilantes’ Deaths

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Hipólito Mora often said that he started the first self-defense group in the Mexican state of Michoacán to end the boundless cruelty of the Knights Templar cartel — the killing, the extortion, and the monopolistic control it exerted over local lime growers.

headline: Fashion Simplicity With Ease in Paris
abstract: For Gilles Garcia, style is about easiness, from shopping to getting dressed.
lead_paragraph: The 16th Arrondissement in Paris is known for its ornate 19th-century buildings, upscale shops and museums, including the Palais de Tokyo. The area is lined with beautiful parks and lively cafes filled with locals, many dressed in refined and classic styles. On a recent afternoon, Gilles Garcia was walking home from grocery shopping in the neighborhood, dressed in a cashmere scarf, which he bought in Spain; a cashmere vest; a button-down shirt; chino pants; and Ray-Ban sunglasses. For him, he said, style is about easiness, from shopping to getting dressed.

headline: Center That Aids Domestic Violence Victims Opens in Manhattan
abstract: The idea behind the center is that battered spouses can speak to a prosecutor about assault charges, and can also receive legal help and counseling on a host of other issues.
lead_paragraph: The lobby of a newly renovated suite in the Manhattan district attorney’s office looks more like an upscale pediatrician’s office than a place where one might discuss filing criminal charges.

headline: U.S. General Warns of Perils in Leaving Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. told a Senate panel that the withdrawal of international forces would result in a resurgent Taliban and the creation of a safe haven for Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The top American commander in Afghanistan said on Wednesday that Al Qaeda would regroup and stage another attack on the West from Afghanistan if international troops completely withdrew from the country at the end of 2014.

headline: Massachusetts: Ex-School Doctor Sentenced for Child Pornography
abstract: A former pediatrician who worked as the medical director of Phillips Academy in Andover was sentenced on Wednesday to six-and-a-half years in prison on child pornography charges.
lead_paragraph: A former pediatrician who worked as the medical director of Phillips Academy in Andover was sentenced on Wednesday to six-and-a-half years in prison on child pornography charges. Dr. Richard Keller, 57, of Andover, pleaded guilty in November to two counts of receiving and one count of possessing hundreds of photos and videos of child pornography depicting boys between the ages of 7 and 16. He was arrested in 2012 and surrendered his medical license after the authorities investigating a Toronto company discovered that he had bought $2,695 worth of child pornography from it. He will be on probation for five years after his release, and he must register as a sex offender and pay a $10,000 fine.

headline: Homework’s Emotional Toll on Students and Families
abstract: Homework dominates the evening for many families, even those with young children. All that time hitting the books (and arguing about hitting the books) takes an emotional toll on parents and students.
lead_paragraph: When your children arrive home from school this evening, what will be your first point of conflict? How’s this for an educated guess? Homework.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — AS night fell on what had been a scorching August day in Hadhramaut, Yemen, in 2012, four large explosions shattered the quiet. When the smoke cleared a few minutes later, Sheik Salem Ahmed bin Ali Jaber, a respected and openly anti-extremist cleric, his cousin, a young local police officer named Waleed Abdullah bin Ali Jaber, and three other men, who have been identified in news reports as likely extremists, lay dead — reportedly by an American drone strike.

abstract: A new study suggests that Alzheimer’s causes six times as many deaths as the official statistics would indicate.

But she was well aware of the significance of the moment she had chosen to throw her punch.

headline: Communism Is the Goal at a Commune, but Chinese Officials Are Not Impressed
abstract: A utopian farming commune in Yunnan Province probably would have pleased Chairman Mao, but the Communist Party has never had much tolerance for independent groups, and the community faces a campaign of intimidation.
lead_paragraph: LINCANG, China — Members of this idyllic utopian commune tucked away in the mountains of southwest China share an agrarian life that would probably have delighted Chairman Mao: Every day they volunteer six hours to work the fields, feed their jointly owned chickens and prepare enough food to fill every belly in the community. The bounty of their harvest is divided equally and apparently without strife, part of a philosophy that emphasizes selflessness and egalitarian living over money and materialism.

headline: Let Me Count the Days

abstract: Nothing says mortality like the realization that you will live only long enough to use up 3.2 percent of your office supplies.
lead_paragraph: By the time we reach our 50s, most of us have experienced a moment when, for the first time, we truly confront our mortality, a moment when it suddenly and forcefully comes home to us that we ourselves personally actually are going to die — as in: be dead — someday. This revelation can be produced under varied circumstances: It happens for one person upon the death of a friend, a contemporary; for another while he or she reads “Four Quartets”:

lead_paragraph: Natural gas meant for residential use is supposed to cause a stink before it causes an explosion like the one that destroyed two buildings in East Harlem on Wednesday.

headline: Columbine Said to Influence Gunman at Maryland Mall
abstract: Darion M. Aguilar, who killed two people at a Maryland shopping mall in January, had visited websites devoted to shootings with mass fatalities, and had acknowledged in his journal a need for psychological help.
lead_paragraph: The teenager who opened fire with a shotgun inside a Maryland shopping mall in January, killing two people, was obsessed with the Columbine High School massacre, and he took a photo of himself with the weapon and uploaded it to a social media site just before he started shooting, the authorities said Wednesday.

abstract: A review of five cameras that are in the same price range but offer different features.

headline: Brittle Beauty Can Be Picture Perfect Until, of Course, It Cracks
