lead_paragraph: Couples in toxic relationships aren’t usually people you would choose to hang out with. Who wants to be caught in the crossfire of flying recriminations and possibly family china?

headline: Kid’s Art Activity
abstract: Scribble in the answers to Alex Vratsanos’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — To whom do you silently give thanks when you solve a New York Times crossword puzzle? Of course, there’s editor Will Shortz; we wouldn’t be having this discussion if he didn’t select seven crosswords each week for us to dig into. I’m talking about those who have taught you the popular and sometimes arcane things you need to know in order to be a decent solver.

headline: Germany: Soccer Star’s Tax Dodge
abstract: Uli Hoeness, the beloved former Bayern Munich soccer player who is now manager of the German club, is under growing pressure to resign over a tax scandal.
lead_paragraph: Uli Hoeness, the beloved former national and Bayern Munich soccer player who is now manager of the German club, is under growing pressure to resign, despite his popularity, after a trial revealed that he had avoided as much as $38 million in taxes through two bank accounts in Switzerland. The trial has been the talk of Germany this week, with a verdict widely expected on Thursday. Mr. Hoeness confessed last year to holding a Swiss bank account, but suggested he had avoided only $5 million in taxes.

headline: Mets’ Wright Waits for His Team to Catch Up
abstract: David Wright signed up to be the bridge to the next winning Mets team. The Mets have staggered through five losing seasons in a row, threatening to waste the prime years of their best player.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The Mets have worn lots of colors — blue, orange, black — but never red. Yes, those were St. Louis Cardinals fans packed into Tradition Field on Wednesday, up from Jupiter to see the National League champions play the Mets.

headline: Germany: Bishops Select Pope’s Confidant as New Leader
abstract: Cardinal Reinhard Marx, 60, the archbishop of Munich, was selected on Wednesday to lead the Roman Catholic bishops’ conference in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Reinhard Marx, 60, the archbishop of Munich, was selected on Wednesday to head the Roman Catholic bishops’ conference in Germany. Known as outspoken, the cardinal is a confidant of Pope Francis, who this month named him head of a new Economic Council at the Vatican. Cardinal Marx succeeds Robert Zöllitsch as the effective leader of Germany’s 24 million Roman Catholics. He is known for emphasizing the need for the church to stand by its teachings and acts, and wrote a book — called “Das Kapital,” in a dig at Karl Marx’s 19th-century treatise — that vigorously warns against the dangers of an unbridled market economy. He has also sought ways to allow Catholics who divorce and then remarry to take Communion. “We cannot treat these people as second-class Christians,” the German DPA news agency quoted him as saying.

headline: The New York Times Hires Critic and Fashion Director
abstract: Vanessa Friedman, the fashion editor of The Financial Times, will lead global fashion coverage on all publishing platforms.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Vanessa Friedman, the fashion editor of The Financial Times, has been named fashion director and chief fashion critic of The New York Times.

headline: Top Yankee Hitter So Far? He’s Fighting for a Job
abstract: Yangervis Solarte isn’t a name that stands out in the crowd of players competing for a Yankees infield job, but the numbers he has put up this spring demand attention.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Darkness blanketed the stadium as the ballplayer arrived at 6:30 a.m. He is usually the first Yankee in the clubhouse, where his locker sits across the aisle from Derek Jeter, maybe five feet away. It might as well be five light-years.

headline: G.M. Reveals It Was Told of Ignition Defect in ’01
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: General Motors said on Wednesday that it had received reports of a safety defect in its cars as early as 2001 — three years earlier than previously disclosed.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Wednesday that it had received reports as early as 2001 — three years earlier than previously disclosed — of a safety defect in its cars that the company has now linked to 12 deaths and at least 31 accidents over the past decade.

headline: Protests in Istanbul
abstract: Thousands of people took to the streets to protest the death of a teenager who was struck by a police tear-gas canister during antigovernment protests last year.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people took to the streets to protest the death of a teenager who was struck by a police tear-gas canister during antigovernment protests last year.

headline: Quiet in Morning, Pierce Erupts at Night to Lead Nets Over Heat
abstract: Hours after Paul Pierce declined to speak to reporters, saying he was in “locked-in mode,” he scored 29 points to lead the Nets to their first win in Miami since 2008.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A group of reporters approached Paul Pierce during the Nets’ shootaround here Wednesday morning, and he got up from his seat and walked away. “I’m in locked-in mode,” Pierce said, apologizing and adding that he would talk after the game.

headline: Vincent's Painting Class
abstract: In 2012, a stroke left Vincent Cass partly paralyzed. Soon after, the 77-year-old took a painting class and discovered a talent he never realized he had.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, a stroke left Vincent Cass partly paralyzed. Soon after, the 77-year-old took a painting class and discovered a talent he never realized he had.

headline: Knicks Enjoy Outcome as They Keep Waiting for Resolution
abstract: With an efficient dispatching of the Celtics, the Knicks won their fifth straight as the wait to hear whether Phil Jackson would join the team continued.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Maybe Phil Jackson should take his time. The longer the suspense lasts over whether Jackson will join the Knicks, the more the team he may one day oversee continues to win in the here and now.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: It’s All About Work/Life  Balance
abstract: As their children grow older and the spy game gets more intense, Elizabeth and Philip struggle to balance parenting and spying.
lead_paragraph: When we last saw them, in Episode 2, Elizabeth and Philip were in mourning. Their friends – and let’s be clear, their only friends – Emmett and Leanne, were murdered, along with the couple’s teenage daughter, Amelia.

headline: Providence’s Inexhaustible Point Guard Almost Never Leaves the Court
abstract: Bryce Cotton is the only player in the nation who averages more than 40 minutes per game, and he has averaged 41.9 minutes in Big East competition.
lead_paragraph: Providence point guard Bryce Cotton almost never leaves the court. A senior, he is the only player in the nation who averages more than 40 minutes per game (40.1), and he has averaged 41.9 minutes in Big East competition.

headline: Interactions of Bin Laden and Son-in-Law Detailed in an F.B.I. Document
abstract: Lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, who is on trial on terrorism charges, sought permission from a judge to present the document, a full summary of his interrogation, to the jury.
lead_paragraph: Osama bin Laden was nothing if not strategic. He recruited a Kuwaiti cleric to become a close associate and to speak to his trainees because he wanted more recruits from the Gulf region. And for that cleric’s fiery speeches after Sept. 11, the Qaeda leader provided the “bullet points.”

lead_paragraph: A video shot by the New York Fire Department shows the destruction that resulted after two buildings collapsed in East Harlem.

headline: Commune Living in China

lead_paragraph: Meng Lichun, a member of New Life Oasis who goes by the name Buddhist Creed, talks about the philosophy behind life at the commune.

headline: Hip-Hop Pioneers Plan a Museum for the Bronx
abstract: Some of the elders of the genre want to underscore its Bronx roots by opening a museum — to be called the Universal Hip Hop Museum — inside the Kingsbridge Armory.
lead_paragraph: Before hip-hop became a musical genre, it was a form of expression — and an escape — for its early creators in the Bronx.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 92
abstract: England Manager Roy Hodgson may not get many more chances to watch his players in the Champions League. Is that a good thing?
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Man Facing Murder Charge in Death of a City Bus Driver
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Buses']
abstract: Domonic Whilby would face 25 years to life in prison if convicted of second-degree murder. A grand jury indicted him on eight other felony charges.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of stealing a truck after a night of drinking and plowing it into a New York City bus, killing a veteran driver, has been charged with second-degree murder, an unusually serious felony for a drunken-driving fatality, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said.

lead_paragraph: To call Eva S. Moskowitz a walking lightning rod is to deeply understate the matter. Electricity all but arcs and leaps off her scalp.

headline: Holder Endorses Proposal to Reduce Drug Sentences in Latest Sign of Shift
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: The United States Sentencing Commission had proposed changing federal guidelines to lessen the average sentence for drug dealers by about one year, to 51 months from 62 months.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. is endorsing a proposal that would reduce prison sentences for people convicted of dealing drugs, the latest sign of the Obama administration’s retrenchment in the so-called war on drugs.

headline: Emergency Rooms Are No Place for the Elderly
abstract: It’s hard to imagine a health care setting more ill suited for the elderly than today’s emergency rooms.
lead_paragraph: The elderly man lived alone in an apartment complex not far from the hospital. A younger neighbor, who’d watched him hobble down the building’s stairwell for nearly a week, insisted on taking him to the emergency room. Doctors there immediately diagnosed an infection in his painful toe and prescribed antibiotics for him to take at home.

headline: More on Social Security Math
abstract: Raising revenue to solve Social Security’s financial woes is one approach, but fixing it by adjusting benefits may be the better political move, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Mets’ Pitching Coach Apologizes for a Slur
abstract: Dan Warthen, the Mets’ pitching coach, apologized for using a racial slur in the team’s spring training clubhouse.
lead_paragraph: Dan Warthen, the Mets’ pitching coach, apologized for using a racial slur in the team’s spring training clubhouse in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

headline: Hal Douglas, 89, Superstar of Movie Trailer Narrators, Dies
abstract: Mr. Douglas was a voice-over artist who narrated thousands of movie trailers in a gravelly baritone.
lead_paragraph: Hal Douglas, a voice-over artist who narrated thousands of movie trailers in a gravelly baritone heard by “audiences everywhere,” as he might have put it, “thrilled by images never before seen ... until now!,”  died on Friday at his home in Lovettsville, Va. He was 89.

headline: Patriots Said to Add Darrelle Revis; the Jets Pick Up Eric Decker
abstract: The Patriots snatched up Darrelle Revis hours after the Buccaneers released him, according to a person in the N.F.L. The Jets agreed to terms with the former Broncos receiver Eric Decker.
lead_paragraph: The Jets cleared significant salary-cap space earlier this week, producing the expectation that they were preparing to splurge on new players. Early in free agency, however, they were largely silent, even as their archrival, the New England Patriots, snatched up Darrelle Revis hours after the Tampa Bay Buccaneers released him Wednesday, according to a person in the N.F.L. who requested anonymity because the deal had not been formally announced.

headline: Court Jails Indian Tycoon
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Money Laundering', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Subrata Roy faces accusations that many of his company’s investment vehicles are illegal and its investors fictitious.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Subrata Roy has long been one of Asia’s most flamboyant billionaires, a bejeweled modern maharajah who lives on an opulent 270-acre estate and presides over the Sahara Group, which is, by its own account, the largest private employer in India. To his allies, Mr. Roy is an up-by-bootstraps hero who built from scratch a sprawling empire that provides vital financial services to the country’s poor.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:30 P.M. (13) DONALD FAGEN, MICHAEL McDONALD, BOZ SCAGGS: THE DUKES OF SEPTEMBER Mr. Fagen of Steely Dan, Mr. McDonald of the Doobie Brothers and Mr. Scaggs team up to create a new group with roots in the R&B and soul music that inspired some of their greatest individual hits. The playlist of this “Great Performances” show, taped at Lincoln Center, includes “What a Fool Believes,” “Lowdown,” “Lido Shuffle,” “Pretzel Logic” and “Reelin’ in the Years. ”

headline: Rangers Sign Haggerty
abstract: The Rangers signed the free-agent forward Ryan Haggerty, a junior at Rensselaer Polytechnic, and he will join the team this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers signed the free-agent forward Ryan Haggerty, a junior at Rensselaer Polytechnic, and he will join the team this weekend. Haggerty, a 21-year-old from Stamford, Conn., had 28 goals this season, which led the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference and was third in N.C.A.A. Division I. He finished his career at Rensselaer with 47 goals and 37 assists in 106 games.

headline: Ophelia DeVore-Mitchell, 92, Dies; Redefined Beauty
abstract: Mrs. DeVore-Mitchell, a former model, agent, charm-school director and newspaper publisher, was a force in opening modeling to African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Ophelia DeVore-Mitchell, a former model, agent, charm-school director and newspaper publisher who almost single-handedly opened the modeling profession to African-Americans, and in so doing expanded public understanding of what American beauty looks like, died on Feb. 28 in Manhattan. She was 92.

headline: As Crews Search for Survivors, They Discover Only More Victims
abstract: Firefighters and emergency personnel on Thursday dug deeply into the wreckage, looking for survivors and possible evidence of what caused the blast.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters and emergency personnel on Thursday dug deeply into the wreckage of two buildings in East Harlem that were leveled in a powerful explosion, looking for survivors and possible evidence of what caused the blast.

headline: When Voting in India, What’s in a Name?
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Letters', 'Search Engines', 'Typewriters and Typewriting', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The author fondly recalls his first campaign experience in Mumbai, which included electoral rolls full of misspellings and typewritten “love letters” to a candidate.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — “Kalomington,” I remember, nearly threw a fit. “Sadoschand” was more forgiving, even able to see some humor in it all. And “Debrokamilm On”? We never found out, because he or she never showed up to vote.

headline: Leaders Deny Report of a Truce in Mideast Violence
abstract: Rocket fire into Israel continued for a second day, jeopardizing the American-led peace talks and a truce that has held for 16 months.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Islamic Jihad, the militant group responsible for firing dozens of rockets into Israel from the Gaza Strip, announced Thursday that Egypt had intervened to restore calm, offering what at first looked like a familiar resolution to an escalation of violence that had shaken both sides of the border.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 13, 2014
abstract: Can you choose the best synonym for “tantamount,” as it is used in the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Lorde’s Take on Teenage Life
abstract: How does this critic describe Lorde and “Pure Heroine”?
lead_paragraph: In “A Less Glossy Take on Teenage Life,” Jon Caramanica, a Times music critic, reviews the singer’s recent show at Roseland Ballroom in Manhattan.

headline: Jet Hunt Shifts as Findings Hint at Longer Flight
abstract: Experts were poring over military radar data that seemed to indicate that the missing Malaysian flight had turned west and stayed aloft long after its last contact with ground controllers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators are examining data that appear to show that the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner was still in automated communication with satellite systems, and may therefore still have been airborne or at least functional, for hours after ground controllers last heard from it, a well-placed official involved in the investigation said on Thursday.

headline: Senator Tom Coburn: ‘Power Is a Tool’
abstract: The Oklahoma politician prepares to leave Washington, and all its temptations, behind.
lead_paragraph: You recently learned you have prostate cancer and announced that you’ll be leaving the Senate next January   two years before the scheduled end of your term. How are you feeling? I’m feeling good. I’m not cured of the disease, but I’m on my way to marked improvement. And they may potentially have a cure. But I’ve got 5 or 10 years in front of me even if they don’t cure it.

headline: Mitch McConnell Is Not as Vulnerable as He Seems
abstract: Senators from the opposing party almost never lose when their state doesn’t like the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It has been a dreadful winter for Democrats as red state incumbents struggle to overcome President Obama’s sagging popularity. But there’s one person in particular Democrats still hope to beat: Mitch McConnell, the Senate minority leader.

headline: The Cold, Hard Lessons of Mobile Home U.
keywords: ['Mobile Homes and Trailers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'United States Economy', 'Affordable Housing', 'Unemployment']
abstract: 1) Raise the rent often. 2) No coin laundry. 3) Don’t be a slumlord.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t get too hung up on appearances,” Frank Rolfe reminded us as our tour bus made its way to the first of several trailer parks we would visit on a bright Saturday afternoon in Southern California. “Remember, you don’t have to live in these homes.”

headline: Should Colleges Ban Fraternities?
abstract: Fraternities have been in the news for problems like racism, sexual violence and hazing-related injuries and deaths. Should they be banned? What would be gained and what would be lost?
lead_paragraph: Fraternities have been in the news this school year for problems like racism, sexual harassment and violence, and hazing-related injuries and deaths.

headline: Reubin Askew, a Progressive Governor of Florida in the ’70s, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Askew, a “New South” Democrat who once sought the presidency, was part of a wave of moderate Southern governors in the 1970s and ’80s.
lead_paragraph: Reubin Askew, a progressive “New South” Democrat who promoted racial equality and ethics overhauls as a two-term governor of Florida in the 1970s and campaigned briefly for the presidency in 1984 and for the Senate in 1988, died on Thursday in Tallahassee. He was 85.

headline: New York Today: Extreme Drop
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: a return to winter temperatures, and the aftermath of a deadly building collapse.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. It’s very cold.

headline: After Fatal Crash, Soul-Searching for South by Southwest
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving']
abstract: When two people were killed and at least 23 injured Thursday after a driver slammed his car into a crowd, it crystallized the question of whether the South by Southwest festival has become too big and too rowdy.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — For nearly 30 years, the irreverent soul of this Texas capital city has been linked with what has been billed as the biggest music festival of its kind in the world — the ever-expanding mash-up of music, culture, technology and buzz known as South by Southwest.

headline: Why Do Men Dominate Chinese Politics? Because They’re ‘Just Too Superb’
abstract: The National People’s Congress has slightly more women than in previous sessions, but women still remain a rarity at the top levels of Chinese politics. This gender gap might be due to a “quality” issue, some female delegates said.
lead_paragraph: Li Yalan, a delegate to the National People’s Congress, looked flustered by a question from a foreign journalist at a news conference for female delegates that had, until then, focused on family values, children, the need for better statistics about women and the economic value of women’s handicrafts.

headline: Danish Outsourcing Firm ISS Surges in I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Outsourcing', 'Private Equity', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The third time was a charm for ISS, which went public on the Nasdaq OMX Copenhagen exchange after planned offerings in 2007 and 2011 were delayed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Danish outsourcing company ISS rose 13 percent in its debut on the Nasdaq OMX Copenhagen exchange on Thursday.

headline: Germany Urges Russia to Help Solve Ukraine Crisis
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel warned that failure to help find a negotiated solution would severely damage Russia politically and economically.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Emphasizing that “the territorial integrity of Ukraine cannot be called into question,” Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany appealed forcefully to Russia on Thursday to abandon what she called the politics of the 19th and 20th centuries, and to find a peaceful negotiated solution to a crisis “in the heart of Europe.”

headline: Its Growth Targets Elusive, China Focuses on Jobs and Quality of Life
abstract: As China’s leader emphasized quality of economic growth over a set target, the government reported poor performance in areas like industrial output during January and February.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s growth engine continued to show signs of weakness on Thursday, underlining the tricky balancing act that Beijing faces as it tries to reform its economy.

headline: Dan Harris, Co-Anchor of ‘Nightline,’ Discusses Multitasking and Meditation
abstract: Dan Harris, a co-anchor of Nightline, has just published a new book that says meditation can make us 10 percent happier and that multitasking in a technology-obsessed world is detrimental to our brains.
lead_paragraph: Dan Harris, a co-anchor of ABC’s “Nightline” and the weekend edition of “Good Morning America,” is the author of a new book, “10% Happier: How I Tamed the Voice in My Head, Reduced Stress Without Losing My Edge, and Found Self-Help That Actually Works — A True Story.”

headline: What North Dakota’s Public Bank Does for Small Businesses
abstract: And would other states benefit from having public banks?
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Brian Brasch, president of Branick Industries, a maker of specialty automotive tools in Fargo, N.D., took a phone call from a stranger. The caller was an auto mechanic in Florida who had an idea for a new kind of drain plug for an oil pan, one with an O-ring that expands to stop oil leaks.

headline: Renaissance Learning Is Sold to Hellman & Friedman for $1.1 Billion
abstract: The education analysis company Renaissance Learning has announced that it has been sold to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman for $1.1 billion. Google Capital, which invested in the company last month, will stay on board.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:02 p.m. | It was only last month that Renaissance Learning raised $40 million from a new Google investment fund, valuing the education analysis company at $1 billion.

headline: This Is the Real Reason Sbarro Is in Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Pizza', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: Sbarro’s strategy of being where the hungry people are fails when crowds thin and rents don’t fall.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get this out of the way first: The food at Sbarro, the pizza-and-pasta chain, isn’t very good. The pizza crust manages to be both thick and limp, the tomato sauce bland, the cheese the victim of sitting for too long under heat lamps.

headline: Egypt’s Ancient Snark
abstract: The people have long known that their strongest weapon is satire.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In 1798, after Napoleon Bonaparte occupied Egypt, some local grandees wanted to get close to him, so they gave him six slave girls. At that time, Egyptians were under the influence of the Turkish taste that considered a fulsome figure a prerequisite of feminine beauty. Napoleon was more fired up by Parisian elegance and refused to sleep with any of the women because they were, in his opinion, fat and reeking of fenugreek.

headline: Bouygues and Altice Raise Bids for SFR, Vivendi’s Mobile Unit
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: With Vivendi’s board expected to meet on Friday to consider the offers for its mobile phone unit, the bidding war is escalating.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:56 p.m. | LONDON – Bouygues and Altice have raised their offers in an escalating bidding war for SFR, the mobile phone unit of the French media conglomerate Vivendi.

headline: Daily Report: Europe Moves to Reform Rules Protecting Privacy
abstract: The provisions, which require approval from all 28 European Union governments, are meant to replace a hodgepodge of privacy rules with a single body of law.
lead_paragraph: The European Parliament passed a strong new set of data protection measures on Wednesday prompted in part by the disclosure by Edward J. Snowden, a former contractor at the United States National Security Agency, of America’s vast electronic spying program, David Jolly reports.

headline: Buddhist Volunteers Aiding Anxious Families in Beijing
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Buddhism', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Philanthropy', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)']
abstract: As relatives in Beijing await news from the missing Malaysian Airlines jetliner, volunteers from the Tzu Chi Foundation, a Buddhist charitable organization headquartered in Taiwan, have been busy offering counseling and other assistance.
lead_paragraph: At one end of the room, Malaysia Airlines employees delivered the latest briefing to relatives and friends of passengers who were aboard the airline’s missing Flight 370. At the other end, volunteers listened from behind tables piled with snacks, waiting to provide counseling, logistical assistance or just hand holding.

headline: WGN America Promotes Original Programming With ‘Upfront’ Presentations
abstract: The cable network, perhaps best known for live baseball games and reruns of broadcast network series, is creating its own shows.
lead_paragraph: Another channel hopes to feed the growing appetite among viewers and advertisers for original programming on cable television.

headline: Take a Breath and Thank a Sponge
abstract: This simple animal played a crucial role in the rise of the animal kingdom by re-engineering the planet with oxygen, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: If Tim Lenton is right, we all owe sponges a deep debt of gratitude. It may be hard to give much credit to these simple animals, which spend their uneventful lives on the sea floor trapping floating bits of food. But Dr. Lenton, an earth systems scientist at the University of Exeter, suspects that sponges played a crucial role in the rise of the animal kingdom.

headline: G.E. Files to Spin Off Retail Finance Unit
abstract: General Electric filed on Thursday to spin off its North American retail finance unit in an initial public offering, taking the next step to reduce the size of the GE Capital division.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:10 p.m. |

headline: Lufthansa Results Suggest Overhaul Is Paying Off
abstract: Amid a cost-cutting drive, the German flagship carrier released an encouraging 2013 earnings report as a new chief executive prepares to take over.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Midway through Lufthansa’s three-year cost-cutting drive, investors and analysts are looking to the incoming chief executive, Carsten Spohr, to keep focused on paring expenses and boosting profits.

headline: Military Repatriates Algerian Detainee From Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The transfer is the first in nearly three months, and it reduces the inmate population to 154, part of an ongoing effort to close the facility.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The military announced Thursday that it had repatriated an Algerian detainee who had been held without trial for 12 years at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. The transfer is the first in nearly three months, and it reduces the inmate population there to 154.

headline: Herbalife Takes a Tumble
abstract: Shares of Herbalife fall on news of a Federal Trade Commission inquiry. | Bank regulators are starting to ask whether there is something rotten in bank culture. | The S.E.C. hits Fabrice Tourre, the former Goldman Sachs trader, with a big fine. | The maker of Candy Crush Saga has priced its I.P.O. in a range that values the company at $7.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: For 15 months, the activist investor William A. Ackman has accused Herbalife of being a pyramid scheme, betting $1 billion on its collapse. Since Mr. Ackman’s crusade began in December 2012, he has lobbied members of Congress to press state and federal regulators, specifically the Federal Trade Commission, to investigate Herbalife.

headline: Remember the Traveling Knish Man
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: In the 1940s, a knish from a mobile vendor was one of the few street-food options for schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Weak European Auto Market in 2013 Sapped Volkswagen Earnings
abstract: VW’s net profit for the year was off by more than half, while its rival BMW benefited from demand for luxury cars in Asia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen, Europe’s biggest carmaker, said Thursday that net profit fell by more than half in 2013, as it earned less from midrange passenger cars and did not have one-time gains that it booked for 2012.

headline: In Our Pages: March 14
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Baseball at Lord’s in London

headline: The Find | Wish You Were Here
abstract: A new book chronicles the kinship between Eva Hesse and Sol LeWitt with the use of personal photos, affectionate letters and, as shown here, postcards from across the globe.
lead_paragraph: Eva Hesse and Sol LeWitt were the closest of friends, their bond informing much of their work. A new book, “Converging Lines,” chronicles their kinship through personal photos, affectionate letters and, as shown here, postcards from across the globe. “Converging Lines” is also the catalog for an exhibition of the same name currently at the Blanton Museum of Art at The University of Texas at Austin.

headline: Fatal Crash at South by Southwest Festival Was a ‘One-Minute Event’
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Video and images shared on social media from Austin, Tex., where two people were killed and 23 others injured after a car crashed through a barricade and struck people attending the South by Southwest festival.
lead_paragraph: Two people were killed and 23 others injured early Thursday morning after a suspected drunken driver, pursued by the police, plowed through groups of revelers attending the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., as my colleagues David Montgomery and Timothy Williams report.

headline: An Online Pioneer Leaves His Mark on a Leading Green Blog
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: An innovative Web journalist leaves a leading green site, Grist.
lead_paragraph: Scott Rosenberg, a pioneering Web journalist and author of “Say Everything,” a history of blogging (if that isn’t an oxymoron), is stepping down after two and a half years leading the blog flow at the green website Grist. In his farewell post, Rosenberg explains that his weekly commutes from his Bay Area home to Seattle weren’t sustainable.

headline: She Loves Thee, Yeah Yeah Yeah
abstract: Billie Joe Armstrong of Green Day helps Yale Repertory Theater give Shakespeare a Beatlesque spin with “These Paper Bullets!”
lead_paragraph: “Let me get this straight,” Billie Joe Armstrong said to the playwright and screenwriter Rolin Jones over drinks last year. “You’re going to rewrite Shakespeare, and I’m going to rewrite the Beatles?”

headline: India Welcomes Dismissal of Visa Fraud Case Against Diplomat
keywords: ['Diplomatic Immunity', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Domestic Service', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'INDIA', 'International Relations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Search and Seizure', 'UNITED STATES', 'United States International Relations', 'Visas']
abstract: The United States District Court in New York dismissed a case against Devyani Khobragade after determining that she had diplomatic immunity at the time of her federal indictment.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Ministry of External Affairs on Thursday welcomed an American court’s dismissal of visa fraud charges against the Indian consular official Devyani Khobragade, whose legal troubles had created tensions between India and the United States.

headline: Helen Oyeyemi: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Mr. Fox” and “Boy, Snow, Bird” considers Dumas’s d’Artagnan a literary hero: “If there’s going to be a fray, I can’t help but approve of someone who enters it headlong.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Mr. Fox” and “Boy, Snow, Bird” considers Dumas’s d’Artagnan a literary hero: “If there’s going to be a fray, I can’t help but approve of someone who enters it headlong.”

headline: Vitamin D May Lower Cholesterol
abstract: A randomized trial has found that vitamin D appears to reduce levels of LDL, or “bad” cholesterol.
lead_paragraph: Many observational studies have suggested that vitamin D may have benefits for heart health. Now a randomized trial has found that vitamin D appears to reduce levels of LDL, or “bad” cholesterol.

headline: For Foreign Journalists in Beijing, It’s All About Asking the Right Question
abstract: A news conference with the Chinese prime minister and foreign journalists each year is broadcast worldwide, but is actually staged, with the complicity of many of the largest news organizations in Western journalism.
lead_paragraph: Go ahead, raise your hand and wave it back and forth like an overeager first-grader. If you think you’re going to be picked to ask China’s second most powerful leader a question, you have another thing coming.

headline: U.S. Criticized for Lack of Action on Mortgage Fraud
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Inspectors General', 'Mortgages']
abstract: The Justice Department has repeatedly and significantly overstated its efforts to prosecute mortgage fraud, an internal watchdog said on Thursday in a report that cited the department’s “disturbing” inability to verify its information.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:00 p.m. |

headline: Russian Troops Mass at Border With Ukraine
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Referendums', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Russia’s troop buildup raised alarms about a possible invasion and drew a sharp rebuke from Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, who said Russia faced diplomatic and economic retaliation.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — With a referendum on secession looming in Crimea, Russia massed troops and armored vehicles in at least three regions along Ukraine’s eastern border on Thursday, alarming the interim Ukraine government about a possible invasion and significantly escalating tensions in the crisis between the Kremlin and the West.

headline: A Getaway Unravels the Ties That Bind
abstract: In “Le Week-End,” Nick and Meg, a long-married couple, revisit Paris to try to put the spark back in their marriage.
lead_paragraph: “You can’t not love and hate the same person,” Nick says to Meg, the woman he has loved for more than 30 years. They are on an anniversary trip to Paris, celebrating a complicated but enduring and affectionate union. Nick’s observation is more wry than anguished, and its implication of melodrama — evoking that famous “thin line” sung about by the Persuaders and the Pretenders — does not seem to apply to him and Meg. Played by Jim Broadbent and Lindsay Duncan, they look like a modest, decent, likably scruffy couple, British baby boomers entering their sunset years with stoicism and good humor.

keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']

lead_paragraph: The aftermath of a car crash that killed two at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex.

headline: At Request of U.S., Austria Arrests Ukrainian Businessman
abstract: Dmitry V. Firtash, an ally of the ousted Ukraine leader Viktor F. Yanukovych, is suspected of bribery. American law enforcement officials had been tracking him.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Austrian authorities have arrested a Ukrainian entrepreneur, Dmitry V. Firtash, on bribery and other charges at the request of American law enforcement agencies. Mr. Firtash has strong connections to the ousted Ukrainian president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, and also conducts extensive business in natural gas with Russia.

headline: Service Announcement | Wrench Not Required
abstract: Thanks to a play on proportion and an unexpected accessory or two, stylish jumpsuits step out of the garage.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to a play on proportion and an unexpected accessory or two, stylish jumpsuits step out of the garage.

abstract: This Poetry Pairing features the poem “Three Six Five Zero” by Conor O’Callaghan and the Bits blog post “Disruptions: Digital Era Redefining Etiquette” by Nick Bilton.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “Three Six Five Zero” by Conor O’Callaghan and the Bits blog post “Disruptions: Digital Era Redefining Etiquette” by Nick Bilton.

headline: 5 Things Teachers Wish Parents Knew: Your Children Can Do More Than You Think
abstract: Teachers have a different perspective on our children — one that can help us to see them differently. They’re capable individuals, they don’t need constant feedback, and they’re learning from what we do (not what we say).
lead_paragraph: This week, I’m turning the tables and giving some space to the “teacher” half of the “Parent-Teacher Conference.” When I ask teachers, “What one thing would you want your students’ parents to know?” the same five points come up over and over again.

headline: College Art Museum Hit With Sanction After Sale of Bellows Work
abstract: The Association of Art Museum Directors has called for member museums to suspend loans and collaboration on exhibitions with the Maier Museum of Art at Randolph College in Lynchburg, Va.
lead_paragraph: The Association of Art Museum Directors, which represents more than 200 museums in North America, has issued a rare sanction against the Maier Museum of Art at Randolph College in Lynchburg, Va., after the museum’s sale of a George Bellows painting to raise money to shore up the college’s operating budget.

lead_paragraph: The Austin police chief, Art Acevedo, told reporters that two people were killed at the South by Southwest festival after a driver slammed his car into pedestrians walking along crowded streets.

headline: High Court Upholds Death Penalty in Delhi Gang Rape Case
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: The judges said a strong message needed to be sent to “the perpetrators of grotesque and ghastly crimes against women.”
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Delhi High Court on Thursday upheld the death sentences of four men who were convicted of gang-raping and murdering a 23-year-old student in the capital in December 2012.

headline: A Blueprint for Ukraine
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Foreign Investments', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Ukrainian business executives say Western aid may prove a Band-Aid unless Kiev faces its structural challenges and sheds its communist past, like Poland did decades ago.
lead_paragraph: LVIV, Ukraine — Every kind of business in this restless pro-European stronghold near the border with Poland has an idea about how to make Ukraine like its more prosperous neighbor.

headline: Gleacher & Co. Plans to Liquidate
abstract: The troubled investment bank Gleacher & Company, founded 24 years ago by the longtime Wall Street deal maker Eric Gleacher, had tried unsuccessfully to sell itself and now plans to close up shop.
lead_paragraph: Gleacher & Company, the troubled investment bank that had tried unsuccessfully to sell itself, announced on Thursday that it planned to liquidate its assets, closing up shop after 24 years.

headline: Poignant in Tooth and Claw
abstract: “Ernest & Celestine,” about a mouse and a bear, offers the childhood comfort of a miniature world.
lead_paragraph: The tiny gray mouse in the bright red coat scampers as quietly as a whisper. She lives in a land under a city of big if not especially bad bears, in a country where wee houses cling to walls, and itty-bitty mice row boats. On an ordinary day in this little land — as seen early on in “Ernest & Celestine” — some mice will be out shopping; some will be riding elevators, and still others building muscles as they raise and lower the metal bars of mouse traps with vigor and precision. Tucked into one street, you’ll find an orphanage that brings to mind Madeline’s boarding school, but one with little mice like Celestine in straight lines instead of little girls.

headline: A Memphis Group Founder Creates Prints for American Apparel
abstract: Nathalie Du Pasquier designed a series of colorful patterns for the basics brand’s summer silhouettes, which hit stores today.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half ago, the French-born, Milan-based artist Nathalie Du Pasquier had never heard of American Apparel. She’s not quite as mature as Jacky O’Shaughnessy, the 62-year-old star of a recent ad campaign for the downtown-L.A.-based brand, but Du Pasquier does prefer to dress her own age (which is 57). Beginning today, though, Du Pasquier’s signature colorful, graphic patterns will grace the 20 newest silhouettes hanging in a select 20 of the label’s many retail outposts. The collaboration came about when the brand’s creative director, Iris Alonzo, approached Du Pasquier about painting prints similar to the iconic ones she produced in the 1980s as an original member of the Memphis Group, the Milan-based collective of designers and architects. “I thought, Why not?” Du Pasquier remembers. “It was the first collaboration with a fashion company in many, many years actually because I am a painter. I have not done that kind of work in a long time.” And how does the artist feel about American Apparel now that it’s emblazoned with work from her own hand? “These?” she asks about the simple frocks, jumpsuits and skirts, minimalist shapes that complement her bright, unruly designs. “I will wear them, yes.” There are shirts for men, too, and more cheerful accessories from the capsule will roll out during the summer months to come.

headline: 36 Hours in Nassau, the Bahamas
abstract: From beaches and birds to conch and cocktails, warm up with a weekend in this laid-back island town.
lead_paragraph: Most tourists arriving in the Bahamas’ capital city head straight across the bridge to the aptly named Paradise Island, where a glitzy resort scene is anchored by the Atlantis megadevelopment, known for its water park rides, casino and celebrity chef restaurants. While the sensory appeal there is undeniable, those looking for a cultural allure that’s subtler than, say, a 200-foot water slide, would do well to venture beyond the resorts. In addition to serving as port of call for cruise lines (and as a rowdy hub for spring breakers), at its heart Nassau is a laid-back island town. European influences blend with centuries-old Bahamian traditions here, anchored by an innovative dining scene, unique small hotels and, of course, miles of white sand beaches.

headline: The Gun Report: March 13, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In Wayne LaPierre’s America, there is no government, no authority we can trust with our lives. There are only guns.

headline: Avinoam Nowogrodski of Clarizen, on the Rewards of Listening
abstract: The chief executive of Clarizen, a work management software company, says leadership is about asking the right questions.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Avinoam Nowogrodski, the chief executive of Clarizen, a work management software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: 6 Trends in Cruising
abstract: From taking it slow to heading far and away, here are half-a-dozen developments to watch in the cruise industry.
lead_paragraph: Cruise lines continue to diversify, with itineraries that seem to offer something for everyone, from steeped-in-the-wild adventure cruises to massive floating resorts. But large or small, eco or culinary, most cruises today strive to connect passengers to local cultures.

headline: Cruise Quest: Keeping the Entertainment Fresh
abstract: What do today’s cruise passengers consider engaging in 0nboard entertainment? Inside the search for answers.
lead_paragraph: As the Celebrity Reflection left port in Miami last month for a cruise of the eastern Caribbean, one of the ship’s activities hosts circulated through the crowd on the pool deck trying to get them excited about the onboard party that was beginning. Despite the pulsating sounds that a pair of D.J.-percussionists on a small poolside stage were pumping into nearby speakers, only a few cruisers were inspired to hit the dance floor. I counted myself among the wallflowers, and it was clear that we nondancers were a majority. It was beginning to feel a bit awkward.

headline: Times Minute | G.M.'s Legal Woes
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Defective Products', 'Automobiles', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The automaker could face damaging lawsuits after a major recall. Also on the Minute, diplomatic efforts ahead of the Crimean referendum vote, and Senator McConnell's re-election fight.
lead_paragraph: The automaker could face damaging lawsuits after a major recall. Also on the Minute, diplomatic efforts ahead of the Crimean referendum vote, and Senator McConnell's re-election fight.

headline: Star-Struck by Alibaba’s Movie Company Deal
abstract: Investors may be betting that Alibaba will move into digital entertainment, but they are too easily excited, contends Robyn Mak of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The e-commerce giant Alibaba’s latest deal shows the extent of investor frenzy for China’s Internet. The company announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy 60 percent of the ChinaVision Media Group, which is listed in Hong Kong, for $804 million. The film company’s market value promptly soared to almost $5 billion. Star-struck investors are too easily excited.

headline: McDonald’s Workers File Wage Suits in 3 States
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Minimum Wage', 'Overtime', 'Working Hours', 'Restaurants']
abstract: The employees charge that the fast-food giant’s practices and requirements reduced their pay below the federal minimum wage of $7.25 an hour.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s workers in California, Michigan and New York filed lawsuits this week against the company and several franchise owners, asserting that they illegally underpaid employees by erasing hours from their timecards, not paying overtime and ordering them to work off the clock.

headline: Scene | "Jimi: All Is By My Side"
abstract: Andre 3000, who plays Jimi Hendrix in this biopic, chats with Keith Richards’s girlfriend, Linda Keith, who is played by Imogen Poots.
lead_paragraph: Andre 3000, who plays Jimi Hendrix in this biopic, chats with Keith Richards’s girlfriend, Linda Keith, who is played by Imogen Poots.

abstract: The company’s plan was the first of what could be a dozen competing proposals for one of four state gambling licenses in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: Empire Resorts, the company that operates a small slot machine parlor at the Monticello racetrack in the Catskills, unveiled plans on Thursday for a $750 million casino resort nearby, the first of what may turn out to be a dozen competing proposals for one of four state gambling licenses in upstate New York.

headline: She Said, She Said
abstract: Stuart Blumberg's short film features Marisa Tomei and Élodie Bouchez as a lesbian couple going through divorce.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Blumberg's short film features Marisa Tomei and Élodie Bouchez as a lesbian couple going through divorce.

headline: Channeling a Breaker of Barriers
abstract: The story of Ira Aldridge, a 19th-century black American actor who sought a stage career in Europe, is told in “Red Velvet,” a play coming to St. Ann’s Warehouse.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The story is gripping. It is the mid-1820s, and a young black American actor improbably moves to London while still a teenager, tours the provinces and gets his big break a few years later, when he is asked at the last minute to replace Edmund Kean as Othello at Covent Garden in 1833. Can he overcome the innate prejudice of his fellow actors, the public and the critics? Will he succeed?

headline: Free Fun: Everything You Wanted to Know About ‘This Is Spinal Tap,’ Plus the Film Itself
abstract: AMC Networks is offering a copiously annotated version of the film “This Is Spinal Tap” for free viewing through April 11.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the 30th anniversary of “This Is Spinal Tap,” Rob Reiner’s satirical documentary about a fictional British rock band – and not incidentally, to promote Yeah!,its year-old streaming movie service – AMC Networks is offering a copiously annotated version of the film for free viewing through April 11. The network’s edition, called “This Is Spinal Tap – The Special Features Version,” can be watched either on the web or through the Yeah! iPad app.

headline: Anger Can Set Off a Heart Attack
abstract: A new analysis has found that outbursts of anger can significantly increase the risk for irregular heart rhythms, angina, strokes and heart attacks.
lead_paragraph: Angry enough to have a heart attack? It might actually happen.

headline: Questions About News Photographers in Syria Arise After Freelancer’s Death
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media', 'Photography']
abstract: The death of an 18-year-old Syrian freelancing for Reuters has led to questions about the work of local activists the wire service employs there as photographers.
lead_paragraph: Late last December, Ahmad Barakat, a tailor turned rebel commander in Aleppo, Syria, buried two sons who died together during a battle with Syrian government troops. The elder son, Mustafa, fought for the Tawhid rebels. The younger son, Molhem, photographed the clash for Reuters.

headline: Bank of England Seeks to Expand Clawback Rules

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Bankers who engage in misconduct could have their bonuses clawed back for up to six years after the improper conduct under a new rule proposed by the Bank of England.

headline: Today in Small Business: Clueless Sales Representatives
abstract: Why celebrities are entering the wine business. And how to manage a budget.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Delphi Says Autonomous Cars Are Coming, but Only in Bits and Pieces

lead_paragraph: Delphi Automotive, a General Motors spinoff that has become a major independent parts supplier, has a forecast for the future of autonomous driving: partly cloudy, with a drizzle of new technology.

headline: Young, Gay and Blaming Myself for Cancer
abstract: Convinced I had brought this cancer on myself, the floodgates of memory and self-blame poured out. My perceived “failings” ranged from being gay to being molested as a child.
lead_paragraph: “I’m scheduling your orchiectomy in two days,” my oncologist told me, only minutes after handing me a diagnosis of testicular cancer. With that, he added a new word to my vocabulary: “Or·chi·ec·to·my: Excision of one or both testicles. Castration.”

headline: Complaints as Amazon Raises Cost of Prime
abstract: The annual fee for Amazon Prime, the two-day shipping service, will jump 25 percent, to $99.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — People like getting their toys fast. They also like getting them cheap.

headline: To Keep Teenagers Alert, Schools Let Them Sleep In
abstract: A movement to start high schools later has gained momentum, bolstered by a growing body of research on the adolescent body clock.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Mo. – Jilly Dos Santos really did try to get to school on time. She set three successive alarms on her phone. Skipped breakfast. Hastily applied makeup while her fuming father drove. But last year she rarely made it into the frantic scrum at the doors of Rock Bridge High School here by the first bell, at 7:50 a.m.

headline: An App to Ditch the Dubious Concert Bootleg
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: A new app from a Seattle startup called Lively is using the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., to get wider exposure for a service it wants to make as essential to a touring band’s toolkit as microphones and amplifiers.
lead_paragraph: The hordes of music fans going to see bands this week at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex., can relive the concerts a couple of ways. They can make recordings of dubious quality using their smartphones.

headline: Ban on Doctors’ Group Imperils Muslim Minority in Myanmar
abstract: The government halted the work of Doctors Without Borders after some officials accused it of favoring the Muslim Rohingya over Buddhists.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Nearly 750,000 people, most of them members of a Muslim minority in one of the poorest parts of Myanmar, have been deprived of most medical services since the government banned the operations of Doctors Without Borders, the international health care organization and the main provider of medical care in the region.

headline: NYT Now: Kerry’s Options for Ukraine
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry explores his options as he goes on a last-ditch mission to stop Russia’s annexation of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry explores his options as he goes on a last-ditch mission to stop Russia’s annexation of Crimea.

headline: Labor Market Slack: A Guide for the Perplexed
abstract: For the first time in years, some Federal Reserve officials and private-sector economists are talking about tighter labor conditions.
lead_paragraph: Central bankers like a little unemployment. They want to keep the labor pool reasonably well stocked so that inflation remains under control. They regard a measure of human misery now as the price of avoiding more misery later.

headline: Three’s a Trend | The Resurgence of Bone China
abstract: New spring objects for the table temper nostalgic porcelain with fresh, modern design.
lead_paragraph: Traditional porcelain tableware has long been a launching point for modern dinnerware design. And recently, three new collections have reinvented nostalgic bone china with fresh styles that feel at once heirloom and avant-garde. The 26-year-old British designer Richard Brendon introduced Reflect, a set of gold-and-platinum teacups from Stoke-on-Trent that he paired with “orphan” vintage and antique saucers sourced through antique dealers on London’s Portobello Road. The metallic cups reflect the pattern of the saucers, and a new match is made. In the hands of Gucci, Richard Ginori’s classic shapes and patterns are given new life and a fresh color palette as seen in the Cartiglio and Oriente Italiano dinnerware, which debuted earlier this year at Maison & Objet in Paris. And the creative team at Seletti blended Eastern and Western design on new asymmetrical cake plates and curiously crafted spoons, which will debut this spring as part of their aptly titled Hybrid Collection.

headline: Have a Layover? Hit the Library
abstract: The Free Library of Philadelphia has opened a branch in the city’s airport.
lead_paragraph: There’s a new library in Philadelphia – and it’s in the airport.

headline: Another Proposal to Repair Relations Between Boards and Investors
abstract: The Conference Board, working with a rival group of Wall Street advisers, has issued recommendations aimed at improving the public’s trust in big business.
lead_paragraph: Increased shareholder activism, lawsuits filed by investors and continued malfeasance by  financial institutions is prompting a renewed bout of introspection by some executives, board members and investors.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s New Spot
abstract: No talking. No text. No policy. Just the senator walking around, shaking hands and signing papers.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday Mitch McConnell’s Senate campaign released a content-free ad. I don’t say that as a criticism, but as a statement of fact. There’s no talking, and no text — just a car-commercial-type soundtrack played over footage of the senator smiling, walking, shaking hands, signing papers, posing for snapshots, and gesturing pointedly.

headline: ‘Dragon Mother’ Emily Rapp: A New Baby Doesn’t, and Shouldn’t, Replace What’s Lost
abstract: I can live with the joy of new motherhood without losing the memory of loving my son for his three short years or the daily painful reminder that I will never see or hold him again.
lead_paragraph: On a cold night in February 2013, my son Ronan died of Tay-Sachs disease. He was nearly 3 years old. During the course of his life he experienced seizures, lost his sight and volitional movement, and finally, his ability to eat. From the time of his diagnosis at 9 months old — the worst day of my life; the day that drew a line between the person I was before I knew he was sick and the person I am now after his death — my ideas about parenting shifted irreversibly. I cast off all notions of what the future might hold for Ronan. I accepted, however reluctantly, that my task was not to prepare my son for his future, but to make each day and each moment count until the day of his death.

headline: Mobile Security Specialist Lookout to Announce New Chief Executive

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Lookout, the mobile security company, will announce on Thursday that it is bringing in a new chief executive.

headline: ‘Good Morning America’ Hits Ratings Milestone

lead_paragraph: “Good Morning America” has ridden spillover from ABC’s Oscar coverage to a new milestone — its biggest weekly audience average since Nielsen began keeping electronic ratings records in 1991.

headline: Draghi Praises European Banks That Are Cleaning Up Their Books
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The president of the European Central Bank said in a speech on Thursday said that just the prospect of scrutiny by the E.C.B. “has already caused banks to raise new capital” and shed unprofitable assets.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The president of the European Central Bank said on Thursday that euro zone banks faced a period of “creative destruction” that would be healthy for the economy, and he praised the banks that were moving more aggressively to deal with their problems.

headline: Chinese Police Detain Activist Who Runs Website

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Huang Qi, a well-known human-rights advocate and blogger, was taken from his home by police officers on Thursday, according to Mr. Huang’s assistant, who had spoken to Mr. Huang’s mother at 3 p.m.

abstract: Plus, reconciling your Picasa photos with Google Plus.

headline: They’d Rather Stay for a While
abstract: Il Salumaio on the Upper East Side opened as an old-world salumeria, but customers clamored for tables.
lead_paragraph: Il Salumaio was not supposed to be a restaurant. It opened last June in Yorkville, on the Upper East Side, as an old-world salumeria with hocks of prosciutto and mesh sacks of soppressata clustered like chimes over monumental cheeses.

headline: Merkel Assails Russia's Actions
abstract: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany criticized the Kremlin’s actions as Russia announced new military operations in several regions near the Ukrainian border.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany criticized the Kremlin’s actions as Russia announced new military operations in several regions near the Ukrainian border.

headline: Flight 370 and the Terror of Being Off the Grid
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 suggests that even in our hyperconnected age, people can still vanish from the earth, apparently without a trace.
lead_paragraph: How can a commercial airliner go missing? How, in this hyperconnected age, could it vanish from the earth, apparently without trace, eluding a nearly weeklong search involving more than a dozen governments and some of the world’s most advanced surveillance technology?

headline: Robert Rickel, a Founder of Hardware Supermarkets, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Rickel and his brothers opened a chain of home-repair stores that offered supermarket-style shopping before Home Depot existed.

lead_paragraph: DENVER — A Colorado law that allows adults to legally possess and use marijuana may now allow some people found guilty of minor marijuana crimes to challenge their convictions in court, a state appeals court ruled on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: A new jukebox musical about the 1960s-era songwriter and record producer Bert Berns, featuring hits including “Twist and Shout,” “I Want Candy” and “Hang On, Sloopy,” will begin a commercial Off Broadway run at Signature Center on June 25 and open on July 21, the producers announced on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio held a news conference on Thursday about the rescue effort after the collapse of two buildings in East Harlem on Wednesday morning.

headline: A Second Embrace, With Hearts and Eyes Open (Updated With Podcast)

headline: Obama Orders Rule Changes to Expand Overtime Pay
keywords: ['Overtime', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Working Hours']
abstract: President Obama, declaring that “Americans have spent far too long working more but earning less,” said millions more workers would be eligible for extra pay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, declaring that “Americans have spent too long working more and getting less in return,” ordered the Labor Department on Thursday to revise federal rules on overtime pay to make millions more workers eligible for extra pay when they work more than 40 hours a week.

headline: Imagine if Companies Had to Ask Before Using Your Data
abstract: Privacy legislation is much further along in Europe than in the United States.
lead_paragraph: If you’re worried about Internet companies using-and-abusing your data, you might want to consider moving to Europe, where privacy legislation is much further along than in the United States.

headline: The Man, Not the Myth
abstract: “Gauguin: Metamorphoses,” at MoMA, is a show that radically reshapes our understanding of that 19th-century painter, but more through prints and objects than through paintings.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s groundbreaking Gauguin exhibition may be the last of its kind. After decades of unstinting curatorial attention to artists from Manet to Seurat, how many more exhibitions can radically reshape our understanding of a major 19th-century French painter?
