lead_paragraph: In a career of reinvention, Emmet Gowin has pondered the unanswerable and worked the margins of understanding. A new monograph shows how.

headline: From No Points the Night Before to the 2 Biggest in a Stunner
abstract: Sterling Gibbs sank a jump shot at the buzzer to beat No. 3 Villanova and send eighth-seeded Seton Hall into the Big East semifinals for the first time since 2001.
lead_paragraph: In a banquet hall in the New York Marriott East Side, Seton Hall gathered for a walk-through at 8 a.m. Thursday, less than 12 hours after leaving Madison Square Garden the night before.

headline: A Mixed Week for Ackman
abstract: William A. Ackman has bet against Herbalife, and its shares tumbled this week. But Mr. Ackman’s firm is also a major stockholder in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, whose shares fell after lawmakers proposed winding down the mortgage giants.
lead_paragraph: From one perspective, the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman had a good day on Wednesday. The Federal Trade Commission announced an investigation into Herbalife, a company that he is betting against, sending its shares tumbling.

headline: Jets Will Need Their Big Catch to Grab His Opportunity
abstract: Wide receiver Eric Decker immediately improves Geno Smith and the Jets, but the deal comes with subtle nagging questions.
lead_paragraph: John Idzik, the Jets’ general manager, has finally dipped his toe into the free-agency waters, and even if his first big splash turns out to be an overpriced belly-flop, it is unlikely that anyone will ever view it as his fault.

headline: Led Zeppelin Album Reissues Will Offer Previously Unreleased Song
abstract: Remastered versions of the band’s first three albums will include an unreleased song, “La La,” as well as alternate mixes and outtakes.
lead_paragraph: The Led Zeppelin catalog has been reissued on CD several times, but the band has always been parsimonious with extras and bonus tracks: a 1990 four-CD compilation of its studio recordings included only one, a stray 1970 B-side. But lately, Jimmy Page, the band’s guitarist and producer, has been rethinking that policy, and when Atlantic/Swan Song kicks off the next round of Zeppelin album reissues on June 3 with remastered versions of “Led Zeppelin,” “Led Zeppelin II” and “Led Zeppelin III,” fans who already own the albums will have reason to considered shelling out once again.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Need for Speed'
abstract: The director Scott Waugh narrates a scene from his film.
lead_paragraph: The director Scott Waugh narrates a scene from his film.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Need for Speed’
abstract: Scott Waugh narrates a stunt sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Scott Waugh narrates a stunt sequence from the racing film “Need for Speed,” starring Aaron Paul and based on the video game of the same name. The scene includes two major vehicle stunts, a double 360-degree-spin at 80 miles an hour, and a 175-foot jump over 4 lanes of traffic. Here, Mr. Waugh offers some insight into how the scene was put together.

headline: Q. and A. | Diane Pernet, the Original Style Blogger, on Fashion and Film
abstract: With her fashion film festival coming to New York for the first time, the Paris-based writer, curator and icon discusses chic cinema and her own inimitable look.
lead_paragraph: The woman behind A Shaded View on Fashion, whose 2005 launch marks it as one of the first fashion blogs, is Diane Pernet, a former New York designer who defected to Paris in 1990 and never looked back. Since then, she’s become a street icon in Paris for her black mantilla, beehive hairdo and voluminous black-and-white-shirts and skirts — a look from which she never deviates, even when running out for a baguette. Schoolchildren in her neighborhood of the Seventh Arrondissement sometimes call her “La Sorcière” (“The Witch”).

headline: Text to Text | ‘A Raisin in the Sun’ and ‘Discrimination in Housing Against Nonwhites Persists Quietly’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we examine a famous scene from the play “A Raisin in the Sun” paired with a 2013 Times article on the persistence of the problem of housing discrimination in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Updated: April 4

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photographs from New York, Germany, Malaysia and India
lead_paragraph: Photographs from New York, Germany, Malaysia and India

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, Germany, Malaysia and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Germany, Malaysia and India.

headline: Moody’s Downgrades Royal Bank of Scotland Ratings
abstract: Moody’s cut R.B.S.’s rating a notch on Thursday in light of the potential difficulties of the British lender’s turnaround plan. The bank reported an £8.2 billion annual loss in 2013 and said it could be three to five years before it recovered.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The credit rating agency Moody’s Investors Service downgraded the Royal Bank of Scotland’s long-term debt ratings on Thursday.

headline: Bill Cunningham’s ‘Facades’
abstract: From 1968 to 1976, the photographer Bill Cunningham shot vintage clothes, modeled by a friend and paired with period architecture.
lead_paragraph: From 1968 to 1976, the photographer Bill Cunningham shot vintage clothes, modeled by a friend and paired with period architecture.

headline: After Stay in Gramercy Park, Calder Sculpture Pops Up in Maastricht
abstract: “Janey Waney,” a standing mobile Alexander Calder made in 1969, is now on display at the European Fine Art Fair in the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands – New Yorkers arriving at the invitation-only preview to the European Fine Art Fair on Thursday afternoon were greeted by a 26-foot-tall Alexander Calder sculpture that might look a bit familiar to some. Before being installed at the fair’s entrance here, the bright-red 1969 standing mobile had been on view in Gramercy Park for the past three years.

headline: Landmarks of Fashion
abstract: “Bill Cunningham: Facades” is the result of a long-term collaboration between the photographer and his friend, Editta Sherman.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham calls himself a street photographer, and in a way he is the innovator and prototype of that calling. Mr. Cunningham is modest and reserved, and street photographer doesn’t fully explain his practice. He isn’t a street photographer in the same sense as Elliott Erwitt or Gary Winogrand. He is not looking for extraordinary happenstance to make a remarkable picture; he is on the street to document the passing parade of fashion where it really lives — and as the public wears it, not as it is presented by editors, stylists and fashion photographers. As Mr. Cunningham has put it, “The fashion show has always just been on the street.”

headline: Juggling, an Unexpected Workout
abstract: At a beginner’s workshop on juggling, learning the ancient circus art involves concentration and breaking a sweat.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY added juggling to the list of physical feats I can perform, along with standing on my head and hula-hooping. I had never fully appreciated how hard — and how much of a workout — it could be until attending a beginner’s workshop on a wintry Saturday afternoon at a studio in Chelsea. Nevertheless, the instructor, Heather Wolf, was confident that by the end of the session everyone would be able to perform this ancient circus art.

headline: Cleaning Tips Mama Never Told You
abstract: In “My Boyfriend Barfed in My Handbag ... and Other Things You Can’t Ask Martha,” Jolie Kerr addresses the care of linens, the de-stinking of gym clothes and the sanitizing of sex toys.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I aren’t much on housecleaning. We don’t let things get foul. But we mostly agree with Phyllis Diller, who said that cleaning your house while your kids are still growing is like shoveling your walk before the snow stops. Plus we have enough animals to outfit a petting zoo.

headline: Joel Brinkley, a Times Washington and Mideast Reporter, Dies at 61
abstract: Mr. Brinkley won a Pulitzer Prize for The Louisville Journal-Courier and had an admired career as a correspondent for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Joel Brinkley, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter who spent more than two decades at The New York Times, where he displayed range, rigor and lucid writing as a White House correspondent, as Jerusalem bureau chief and as an editor, died on Tuesday in Washington. He was 61.

headline: ‘Harriet the Spy at 50’
abstract: The old neighborhood is planning a 50th-anniversary tribute to “Harriet the Spy,” at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: In her review of “Harriet the Spy” in The New York Times in 1964, Gloria Vanderbilt described the young heroine of the title as “delicious, but that’s probably because she hasn’t included us in her spy route — yet.” The 11-year-old Harriet, after all, had announced, “When I grow up, I’m going to find out everything about everybody and put it all in a book.”

headline: Showtime Orders Hedge Fund Pilot Called ‘Billions’
abstract: The drama was co-written by Andrew Ross Sorkin, whose nonfiction book “Too Big to Fail” was turned into a movie for HBO.
lead_paragraph: Showtime announced its first drama pilot order of the season Thursday, a project co-created by Andrew Ross Sorkin, the author and financial reporter for The New York Times.

headline: Keeping the Recipes Within the Family
abstract: Two sons take over a tradition started in the 1970s, serving homey Italian-American food in a small, unassuming restaurant.
lead_paragraph: At one table were two police detectives (the holsters and handcuffs were a tip-off), having plates of pasta early on a Saturday night. In the back corner, one of the children at a family-sized table was still in her Our Lady of Perpetual Help basketball uniform. There was a guy in a Yankees cap and jeans on one side of the room; a few tables away, the fashion call was a suit, no tie.

headline: Operators Are Standing By
abstract: Have you ever wished for a new literary form, impervious to the ins and outs of critical fashion and the latest manifesto? Meet the LitMode 100.
lead_paragraph: Has this ever happened to you? You’re lingering by the canapés at a cocktail party when a stranger comes up and asks, “And what do you do?”

headline: Judging the World
abstract: The first two volumes of the Library of America’s three-volume collection of Bernard Malamud’s work include 36 stories, six of which Malamud himself never saw in print, and five novels.
lead_paragraph: Hart and Schaffner are dead; Marx, ringed round with laurels, has notoriously retired. But the firm itself was dissolved long ago, and it was Saul Bellow who, with a sartorial quip, snipped the stitches that had sewn three acclaimed and determinedly distinct American writers into the same suit of clothes, with its single label: Jewish Writer. In Bellow’s parody, Bellow, Malamud and Roth were the literary equivalent of the much advertised men’s wear company — but lighthearted as it was, the joke cut two ways: it was a declaration of imagination’s independence of collective tailoring, and it laughingly struck out at the disgruntlement of those who, having themselves applied the label in pique, felt displaced by it.

headline: Lions Gate Is Fined for Fending Off Carl Icahn’s Attentions
abstract: The successful movie and television company agreed to admit to wrongdoing and pay a $7.5 million fine for a midnight meeting in 2010 to frustrate Mr. Icahn.
lead_paragraph: Pledging to go after companies that deceive shareholders in the course of fighting off a hostile tender offer, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that Lions Gate Entertainment had agreed to admit wrongdoing and pay a $7.5 million penalty for its actions in fending off a takeover by Carl C. Icahn.

headline: A Wow of a Water Slide
abstract: Schlitterbahn, the Texas water park company, is building a very tall, very fast slide at its new location in Kansas City, Kan.
lead_paragraph: Hold on to your bikini straps. Schlitterbahn, the Texas water park company, is opening its newest location in Kansas City, Kan., this spring, featuring what it claims will be the tallest and fastest water slide in the world.

headline: Ken Okiishi: Reena Spaulings Fine Art
abstract: Mr. Okiishi has used flat-screen monitors as canvases on which to paint attractive, drippy flurries of brush strokes.
lead_paragraph: 165 East Broadway, at Rutgers Street,

headline: Eric Doeringer: ‘Paintings & Sculpture’ and Megan Whitmarsh: ‘Fabricated Revisions’
abstract: Mr. Doeringer redoes Andy Warhol; Ms. Whitmarsh reimagines art magazine covers of the 1960s and ’70s.
lead_paragraph: Mulherin & Pollard

headline: Deducting Your Home Office, Made Simpler This Year
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Telecommuting', 'Small Business', 'Income Tax']
abstract: A new, streamlined option for the home office deduction is available this filing season, and the I.R.S. hopes it will reduce paperwork hassles.
lead_paragraph: If you work at a home-based business, you may want to consider a new, simpler option for taking a deduction for your home office on your federal income tax return this year.

headline: Fallout From Refinancing
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Homeowners who refinanced when fixed mortgage rates dropped below 4 percent will be less inclined to put their homes on the market as interest rates climb.
lead_paragraph: Homeowners who refinanced when fixed mortgage rates dropped below 4 percent will be less inclined to put their homes on the market as interest rates climb. And as a result, the limited property supply already impeding sales in many markets may not ease anytime soon.

headline: Brian Wood: ‘Enceinte’
abstract: Mr. Wood, best known as a photographer, combines that medium with graphite drawing.
lead_paragraph: Church of St. Paul the Apostle

headline: David Goldes: ‘Electro-graphs’
abstract: Mr. Goldes’s abstractions on paper are really circuits, hand-drawn for the express purpose of carrying an electrical current.
lead_paragraph: Yossi Milo Gallery

headline: Rudolf Stingel
abstract: Mr. Stingel’s five giant paintings of Tyrolean Alps in this exhibition are impressively glamorous.
lead_paragraph: Gagosian

headline: Emilia Azcárate: ‘Liminal’
abstract: There’s nothing formally new about Ms. Azcárate’s art, but the potential for hands-on interaction is appealing.
lead_paragraph: Henrique Faria Fine Art

headline: Classy Burgers in Relaxed Settings
abstract: At three new restaurants in Long Island, chefs elevate the fast-food staple.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Perrazzo, 34, trained at the Culinary Institute of America and worked at celebrated restaurants like Jean-Georges in Manhattan, Bradley Ogden in Las Vegas (since closed) and Clio in Boston. Then, six months ago, the Long Island native returned to the North Shore  to heed a new culinary calling: Burgers.

headline: Contemporary Photos Given to National Gallery
abstract: Robert E. Meyerhoff and Rheda Becker have donated 30 photographs by prominent contemporary artists to the National Gallery of Art.
lead_paragraph: The National Gallery of Art in Washington came later to photography than most big institutions. Though its holdings date to 1949, when Georgia O’Keeffe donated 1,270 photographs made by her husband, Alfred Stieglitz, it didn’t set up a separate photograph department until 1990. (The Museum of Modern Art in New York, by comparison, began assembling its photo collection in 1930 and a decade later formed a separate department.)

headline: Fifty-Five Years of Reading Roth
abstract: A look at the Book Review’s assessments of Philip Roth’s work over the decades.
lead_paragraph: Reviewing Philip Roth’s “Goodbye, Columbus” for the Book Review in 1959, William Peden called it “perceptive, often witty and frequently moving.” But first he introduced the author: “An English instructor at the University of Chicago, 26-year-old Mr. Roth has published fiction in Harper’s, The Paris Review, The New Yorker and other periodicals.” Fifty-five years later, Roth has retired after writing 31 books. He talks about his career in this week’s issue.

headline: Letters: Why Pick on M.F.A. Programs?
abstract: Readers respond to recent remarks about M.F.A. creative writing programs, a review of Joachim Fest’s “Not I” and more.
lead_paragraph: Get With the Program

headline: U.S. Agrees to Allow BP Back Into Gulf Waters to Seek Oil
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: Under the agreement, BP will be allowed to bid for new leases as early as next Wednesday, but only as long as the company passes muster on ethics, corporate governance and safety procedures.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Four years after the Deepwater Horizon rig explosion, BP is being welcomed back to seek new oil leases in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Charter Still Hanging Around Time Warner Cable
abstract: Charter has yet to withdraw the full slate of directors that it nominated to Time Warner Cable’s board just one day before Comcast swooped in.
lead_paragraph: In early February, Comcast struck a deal to acquire Time Warner Cable for more than $45 billion, a move that will unite the two largest cable operators in the country if approved.

headline: St. John’s Falls to Providence, Dimming N.C.A.A. Hopes
abstract: The Friars held off the resurgent Red Storm in a Big East tournament quarterfinal that some considered a “play-in” game to the national tournament.
lead_paragraph: In a somber moment outside the St. John’s locker room after a tough loss at Madison Square Garden on Thursday, Coach Steve Lavin quietly made plans for Sunday.

headline: Making Sushi and Friends
abstract: Several culinary schools in New Jersey offer sushi-making classes for beginners that teach rice preparation techniques and knife skills. Socializing with others is part of the appeal.
lead_paragraph: At a sushi-making class last month at Chef Central, a retail store with a cooking studio in Paramus, an informal survey of students revealed a spectrum of motivations: Evan Strassberg, 15, of Glen Rock, came because he is an aspiring cook. Sergio Minervini, 54, of River Vale, said he signed up with his wife and daughter “as a family bonding thing.” And Steve Fleischer, 50, of Suffern, N.Y., reserved two spots at the 90-minute class because he thought it was an inventive place to bring a first date.

headline: Facebook’s Zuckerberg Complains to Obama Over Government Spying
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Social Media', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: In a public post, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, says the U.S. government “should be the champion for the Internet, not a threat.” He said he called the president on Wednesday to complain about the latest revelations of spying by the National Security Agency.
lead_paragraph: Updated | Added a response from a White House spokeswoman.

headline: ‘Degenerate Art’ Exhibit of 1937
abstract: Silent footage of the “Degenerate Art” exhibition in Munich, taken in 1937 by the American filmmaker Julien Bryan. The excerpt, part of a longer film, is featured in a new show at the Neue Galerie.
lead_paragraph: Silent footage of the “Degenerate Art” exhibition in Munich, taken in 1937 by the American filmmaker Julien Bryan. The excerpt, part of a longer film, is featured in a new show at the Neue Galerie.

headline: Bookshelf: Pets
abstract: New picture books include Megan McDonald’s “Shoe Dog” and Jenny Offill’s “Sparky!”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include Megan McDonald’s “Shoe Dog” and Jenny Offill’s “Sparky!”

headline: ‘Degenerate Art’
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A new exhibit at the Neue Galerie is devoted to modernist art seized by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibit at the Neue Galerie is devoted to modernist art seized by the Nazis.

headline: Let Me Show You to Our Worst Table, Madame.
abstract: Sometimes sticking up for yourself is better left to the movies and comics.
lead_paragraph: My friend Herb had a birthday recently, so I decided to take him to one of the nicer places in the neighborhood. We set out in a picturesque Sunday night snowstorm, happy in the warmth and comfort of 40 years of friendship, and a charming young hostess told us she had a lovely table for us and led us to the worst table in New York, in a narrow mezzanine between a service door and a waiters’ station.

headline: Fast Cars, and Racing for Revenge
abstract: Aaron Paul stars in “Need for Speed,” a B movie based on a video game series that might be best seen at a drive-in.
lead_paragraph: Based on a popular series of racing-themed video games, “Need for Speed” sums up its appeal in the title. An energetic, unpretentious B movie — the kind best seen at a drive-in like the one in an early scene — it is devoted, above all, to the delivery of visceral, kinetic excitement. In the game, you are at the wheel. Watching other people drive is never as much fun, so the movie, directed by Scott Waugh from a script by George Gatins, supplies a few passenger seat distractions. In addition to velocity, you may need some emotion.

headline: Your Mother Is Grand
abstract: Addressing matters of a messy family situation, small-town concerns, large facial features and a question of timing.
lead_paragraph: When my husband and I go out of town for long weekends, my mother takes care of our three sons (ages 8, 5 and 3). We appreciate this immensely: it’s free, we trust her, the boys adore her and she seems to enjoy it. The problem is, she leaves our house a mess. It takes me a full day to clean up the toys, half-washed clothing and dirty dishes. Plus, she lets the boys eat ice cream in my car, which creates a sticky mess. Complicating matters, she likes lots of praise and is sensitive to criticism. Next time, may I suggest the children stay at her place and offer to pay for maid service after they leave?

headline: Confident CBS Renews 18 Shows at Once
abstract: The unexpected news came from the shows that were not on the renewal list, including the new comedy “The Crazy Ones.”
lead_paragraph: CBS, which has the most consistent roster of prime-time shows, demonstrated its fundamental stability again Thursday, announcing the renewals of 18 shows at once.

headline: Working With the Teenager’s Internal Clock
abstract: How can parents and schools encourage good sleeping habits in their teenagers?
lead_paragraph: Are teenagers developmentally driven to be late to bed, late to rise? A school board in Columbia, Mo., decided to find out, Jan Hoffman writes, by realigning its first bell with what many parents know as a biological reality. A nearly 20-year movement to start high schools later has recently gained momentum. “In just the last two years, high schools in Long Beach, Calif.; Stillwater, Okla.; Decatur, Ga.;, and Glens Falls, N.Y., have pushed back their first bells, joining early adopters in Connecticut, North Carolina, Kentucky and Minnesota,” she found.

headline: No Pretenses, but Lots of Personality
abstract: Clandestino, a cozy neighborhood bar on the Lower East Side, serves well-chosen tap beers and cocktails that include the D’Amiti and a version of the Whiskey Mac.
lead_paragraph: IN his hilarious 1987 bar guide, “The View From Nowhere,” Jim Atkinson writes about the pleasures of what he calls bar bars, defined as “real bars, bars and nothing else, institutions that exist as a sanctuary for those of us who just didn’t want to be anyplace in particular at the moment.”

headline: First, They Came for the Art
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937,” a show at the Neue Galerie, is one of the few in an American museum in the past two decades to address the Nazi’s selective demonizing of art.
lead_paragraph: “Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937,” at the Neue Galerie, opens with a quietly devastating compare-and-contrast. The walls of the narrow hallway leading onto the first gallery are covered with facing photomurals.

headline: Ancient Prescriptions From Tibet
abstract: Shedding light on Tibet’s healing customs is the goal of “Bodies in Balance,” a new exhibition at the Rubin Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: TIBET’S LONG HISTORY OF ALTERNATIVE MEDICINE

headline: Barbecue With Roots in Several States
abstract: The regional styles of Carolina, Memphis, St. Louis and Texas are all honored at the restaurant.
lead_paragraph: New Englanders tend to feel abashed about their barbecue — geographically disadvantaged, perhaps — yet Connecticut in recent years has seen a proliferation of worthy barbecue venues. The smoky Southern breeze blows especially hard in Windsor, which hosts not one, not two, but three barbecue joints.

headline: The Hamilton Theater’s Changing Act
abstract: Change is afoot for the bedraggled West 146th Street building designed by Thomas Lamb.
lead_paragraph: Broadway above West 135th Street is a tepid stretch of modest five- and six-story apartment houses, but one bright spot, at 146th Street, is the 1913 Hamilton Theater, one of the theater architect Thomas Lamb’s trademark gleaming terra-cotta designs. It’s been bedraggled for years, the cornice sheared off, the window frames rusting, the auditorium a crumbling time warp. Now some of the excitement may be coming back, as a developer seems to be moving toward a fix-up, perhaps a full-blown restoration.

headline: Wheelies: The Governator’s Tank Edition
abstract: Arnold Schwarzenegger uses his M47 Patton battle tank to raise money for charity; companies express interest in buying Cars.com.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Prospect-Lefferts Gardens Is ‘On the Map’
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: A development boom hits a neighborhood once referred to as “Brooklyn’s best-kept secret.”
lead_paragraph: In a city where neighborhoods can transform in the blink of an eye, cranes and glass towers have come to signify areas that developers refer to as “on the map,” and Prospect-Lefferts Gardens and its environs are next in their sights.

headline: S.E.C. Unveils Case Against 10th Former Employee of SAC Capital
abstract: Ronald N. Dennis, who agreed to be banned from the securities industry and to pay $200,000, received confidential tips about Dell and Foundry Networks that “prompted illegal trades.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:59 p.m. | Federal regulators on Thursday announced the latest case to stem from the decade-long insider trading investigation into SAC Capital Advisors, taking aim at a former employee for prompting a number of illegal trades.

headline: Doors That Open to the Art of a Continent
abstract: Asia Week New York, with events at galleries and museums, covers a variety of work from ancient dynasties to the contemporary moment.
lead_paragraph: LAST week’s contemporary art fairs gathered more or less like-minded galleries in concentrated spaces in several New York locations, but the annual Asia Week New York takes a different approach. Spread across 47 galleries, 19 museums and five auction houses, the featured art ranges over millenniums and vast regions. One common thread this year is the fluidity between periods, with traditional works alongside contemporary ones. The focus on traditional Asian forms remains, however, and you will see plenty of ceramics, bronzes, textiles and ink.

headline: A Local Girl Who Made It Returns
abstract: Fans wanted more of the canceled TV show “Veronica Mars,” and with the help of a Kickstarter campaign, much of the old cast, including Kristen Bell, is back in Neptune in a feature film.
lead_paragraph: The current cultural directive to give the people what they want explains the existence of the “Veronica Mars” movie, a likable, unmemorable, feature-length footnote to the admired television series that became a cause when it was canceled in 2007. A sleuth from the fictional, filthy rich town of Neptune, Veronica traversed high school and college for three seasons, solving mysteries while cracking wise about the privileged locals. She looked like a Southern California cheerleader and alternately talked like Sam Spade and Noam Chomsky, a combo that made her television’s very own Little Miss Sunshine and Noir.

headline: A History of New York Fashion and Architecture, Through Bill Cunningham’s Lens
abstract: At the New-York Historical Society, the legendary street-style photographer debuts a unique archival project he undertook earlier in his career.
lead_paragraph: Before Bill Cunningham became a regular presence on the sidewalks of New York — in his trim blue French workman’s jacket, camera slung around his neck, perennially and furiously chronicling the comings and goings of the city’s fashion elite for this newspaper — he embarked on a very different type of street-style assignment. Starting in 1968 and continuing through the mid-1970s, Cunningham undertook a particularly involved project to document Manhattan’s architectural and fashion history.

headline: Clip: 'Ernest & Celestine'
abstract: A scene from the movie.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the movie.

headline: Amid Bitter Rift, Senate Approves Pick for Top C.I.A. Lawyer
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The vote to confirm Caroline D. Krass as the C.I.A.’s general counsel came amid a public battle between the agency and the chairwoman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday voted overwhelmingly to confirm President Obama’s nominee to become the C.I.A.’s top lawyer, as senior lawmakers escalated pressure on the agency’s director to make public a voluminous report on the C.I.A.’s defunct detention and interrogation program.

headline: Obama Seeks Expansion of Overtime Pay
abstract: The president said he directed the Department of Labor to revise federal rules to make more workers eligible for overtime pay.
lead_paragraph: The president said he directed the Department of Labor to revise federal rules to make more workers eligible for overtime pay.

headline: His Swans Are Primal, Yet Very Precise
abstract: Jean-Christophe Maillot, the director of Les Ballets de Monte Carlo, discusses his philosophy as his troupe prepares to dance “Lac,” his reworking of “Swan Lake,” at City Center.
lead_paragraph: MONACO — JEAN-CHRISTOPHE MAILLOT was in full swing. “Précis! Précis! Hold! Stay! Feel where your body is!” he cried in a mix of French and English. Phalanxes of dancers ran and leapt and balanced as Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake” music surged through the air. The desire to please was palpable. Mr. Maillot sighed. “I don’t know why I feel tender towards you today,” he said.

headline: U.S., Rebuffing U.N., Maintains Stance That Rights Treaty Does Not Apply Abroad
keywords: ['Treaties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In making its declaration, the Obama administration rejected an interpretation by the United Nations and a former top State Department lawyer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration declared Thursday that a global Bill of Rights-style treaty imposes no human rights obligations on American military and intelligence forces when they operate abroad, rejecting an interpretation by the United Nations and the top State Department lawyer during President Obama’s first term.

headline: An Intimate Entree, Escorted by Beethoven
abstract: The Russian-German pianist Igor Levit performed late Beethoven sonatas in his superb North American recital debut in the Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Egocentric Americans might assume that no gifted young performer from overseas can have a budding career in classical music without making significant appearances in the United States, especially, let’s admit it, New York. But the success of the remarkable Russian-German pianist Igor Levit proves otherwise.

headline: In Lunging Cowrie Shells, Gods Speak
abstract: DanceBrazil presents two world premieres at the Joyce Theater: “Búzios” and “Gueto.”
lead_paragraph: DanceBrazil, a longtime staple at the Joyce Theater, is wrapping up a festival of Brazilian dance there through Sunday with its primal fusion of Afro-Brazilian movement and contemporary dance. At its core is capoeira, the martial-arts form from which much of the group’s brash power derives. Performers contrast a weighted, rocking connection to the floor with bursts of upward energy: out of nowhere, a whipping fan kick spins into a cartwheel.

headline: The Wisdom in the Middle
abstract: Eagle Academy’s five innovative institutions offer a private school experience but hire union teachers.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, as the debate over education has produced so many glowering expressions on so many faces all over the city, I have heard people say, in a spirit of both bafflement and confession, that they “don’t know what to think about charters.” In one sense, the befuddlement itself is a part of the problem, a suggestion that charter schools, like graphic wallpaper or adventurous restaurants in Brooklyn, constitute a matter about which one should have an opinion.

headline: Close Enough to See the Scriabin’s Colors
abstract: The Russian pianist Evgeny Kissin played a concert of Schubert and Scriabin works on Monday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: It has become common for venues to set up extra chairs onstage whenever the prodigiously talented Russian pianist Evgeny Kissin gives a solo recital. On Monday evening, too, the capacity audience at Carnegie Hall spilled over onto the stage, where it offered Mr. Kissin a welcoming embrace during his mesmerizing performance of works by Schubert and Scriabin.

headline: Senate Deal Is Reached on Restoring Jobless Aid
abstract: A measure, which still faces a battle in the House, would restore assistance for Americans who have been unemployed for a half-year or longer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday reached an agreement to pay for an extension of an unemployment assistance program that expired in December, leaving more than a million Americans who have been out of work for a half-year or longer without support from the federal government.

lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Grandeur, Delicacy and Duels in Nielsen Symphonies
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, under Alan Gilbert’s conducting, continues its exploration of the Danish composer Carl Nielsen at Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: In a much-quoted 1907 exchange, the two most important and influential symphonists of the 20th century expressed opposing views about the nature of that musical form. Sibelius spoke of “deep logic, which requires that all its motifs must be linked to each other.” No, Mahler replied: “The symphony must be like the world. It must encompass everything.”

headline: A Spelling Bee Bully With Decades on His Rivals
abstract: “Bad Words,” Jason Bateman’s feature-directing debut, is a would-be gonzo comedy with a tough exterior and a marshmallow center.
lead_paragraph: For a guy who often plays nice, Jason Bateman sure knows how to wrap his lips around invective. He doesn’t have an especially rubbery mouth, the kind that Jerry Lewis could stretch until it almost snapped, nor does it curl with the puckered elasticity displayed in the poster for “Bad Words,” a comedy about a guy who crashes children’s spelling bees. Sometimes, he just opens wide, and out pops an expletive. At other times, he turns his nice-guy face toward the target, pauses for a beat or two while he sizes up the opposition — maybe sends out a decoy, like a faint smile or a deceptively inviting word — and then he slashes and burns. The kids take it hard.

headline: Press Wars in Ukraine
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']
abstract: As Russian troops moved into Crimea, one of their targets was the army of journalists trying to tell the story.
lead_paragraph: As Russian troops moved into Crimea, one of their targets was the army of journalists from around the world trying to tell the story.

headline: In Snub to Loeb, Sotheby’s Board Nominates 2 Independent Directors
abstract: Sotheby’s nominated Jessica Bibliowicz, a financial industry veteran, and Kevin C. Conroy, a senior executive at Univision, saying that the nominees of the hedge fund manager Daniel Loeb added “no relevant expertise” that its board didn’t already have.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s, the auction house fending off attacks by the activist billionaire Daniel S. Loeb, dug in its heels on Thursday by rejecting his proposal for new board members and instead selected two others.

headline: Jumping Off the Screen
abstract: BBQ Films events are like elaborate theme parties, with movies shown in unusual locations and members dressed as characters.
lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, 30 young professionals crowded into a bare-bones Manhattan office space. It was frigid outside and the workday was long over, but this group was devoted. For nearly two hours, they debated the particulars of time travel, Chuck Berry songs, poodle skirts and the most pressing issue of all: Would they be able to track down a DeLorean?

headline: For Dewhurst, a Familiar Spot Out on a Ledge
abstract: Lieutenant Governor David Dewhurst is where he was two years ago — he is a prominent officeholder locked in a runoff with a populist conservative.
lead_paragraph: It would be interesting to know whether the film “Groundhog Day” is on the “recently viewed” list on David Dewhurst’s Netflix account.

headline: Spare Times for March 14-20
abstract: A listing of author discussions, film screenings, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: SEPHARDIC JEWISH FILM FESTIVAL (Saturday through Thursday) Films of personal triumph and historical significance will be featured at this year’s festival — the 17th — presented by the American Sephardi Federation, with most screenings at the Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, Flatiron district. (Other locations include the JCC in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue, at 76th Street, and the Museum of Jewish Heritage, 36 Battery Place, Lower Manhattan.)

headline: Where Performance Enhancers Are Legal
abstract: A rather dull married pharmacist (Sam Rockwell) and a gorgeous, equally married customer (Olivia Wilde) make for an explosive compound in “Better Living Through Chemistry.”
lead_paragraph: Inside every milquetoast beats the heart of a tiger waiting to be released. All it takes to liberate the beast is a beautiful, seductive woman whose wiles can turn a mouse into a man. So goes the hoary, misogynist pop myth that drives “Better Living Through Chemistry,” a tepid but pleasant comic satire given a shot of contemporaneity by its writing and directing team, Geoff Moore and David Posamentier, and its star Sam Rockwell.

headline: In Laredo, a Quiet Symbol of Closer Ties With Mexico
abstract: A little-known customs agreement between the United States and Mexico removes a major hurdle in how goods move across the border and could be an economic boon to South Texas, trade experts and elected officials say.
lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex. — A little-known customs agreement between the United States and Mexico removes a major hurdle in how goods move across the border and could be an economic boon to South Texas, trade experts and elected officials say.

headline: When Your Twin Is Far More Interesting
abstract: In “Enemy,” directed by Denis Villeneuve, Jake Gyllenhaal plays a history professor who sees his double and starts stalking him.
lead_paragraph: The double is an ancient and irresistible literary theme, especially beloved by philosophically minded scaremongers like Edgar Allan Poe, whose tale “William Wilson” is a concise classic on the matter. The idea of a second self — who might be the manifestation of madness, an allegory come to life or the result of a supernatural glitch in the order of things — is both frightening and fascinating. Movies make the conceit literal with the simple trick of using the same actor in two roles. Who can forget the two Kim Novaks driving James Stewart around the bend in “Vertigo”?

headline: Weakened by Mobile, Desktop Search Advertising Is Declining
abstract: The desktop search advertising business, long the most reliably profitable on the web, will decrease $1.4 billion this year, according to eMarketer, while mobile search revenue will nearly double.
lead_paragraph: In the latest example of mobile phones’ upending of the tech industry, desktop search advertising, perhaps the most lucrative online business, is shrinking.

headline: Chronicler of Presidents Is Bringing Four Together
abstract: Few occasions are notable enough to bring together former and sitting presidents — inaugurations, funerals, the opening of a presidential library. But next month, four presidents will participate in an Austin, Texas, event that goes beyond ceremonial roles. And one man is largely responsible for putting the event together.
lead_paragraph: Few occasions are notable enough to bring together former and sitting presidents — inaugurations, funerals, the opening of a presidential library. But next month, four presidents will participate in an Austin, Texas, event that goes beyond ceremonial roles. And one man is largely responsible for putting the event together.

headline: Why Black Women Die of Cancer
keywords: ['Mammography', 'Breast Cancer', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: White patients with breast cancer receive a diagnosis and treatment much faster.
lead_paragraph: SINCE the early 1970s, studies have shown that black Americans have a higher death rate from cancer than any other racial or ethnic group. This is especially true when it comes to breast cancer. A study published last week in the journal Cancer Epidemiology found that, in a survey of 41 of America’s largest cities, black women with breast cancer are on average 40 percent more likely to die than their white counterparts.

headline: 303 Deaths Seen in G.M. Cars With Failed Air Bags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A safety watchdog says an accident trend went unnoticed by regulators before the recall of two models last month.
lead_paragraph: As lawmakers press General Motors and regulators over their decade-long failure to correct a defective ignition switch, a new review of federal crash data shows that 303 people died after the air bags failed to deploy on two of the models that were recalled last month.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Fear of Wages
abstract: The troubling crusade against full employment raises the question: What’s wrong with rising wages, anyway?
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, some of us watched with a mixture of incredulity and horror as elite discussion of economic policy went completely off the rails. Over the course of just a few months, influential people all over the Western world convinced themselves and each other that budget deficits were an existential threat, trumping any and all concern about mass unemployment. The result was a turn to fiscal austerity that deepened and prolonged the economic crisis, inflicting immense suffering.

headline: Liberty Abandons Plan to Buy Rest of Sirius
abstract: Liberty Media, the company controlled by John C. Malone, announced late Thursday that it had abandoned its plan to buy the shares of SiriusXM that it did not already own as part of a move to set up two tracking stocks to house the company’s assets.
lead_paragraph: Liberty Media, the company controlled by John C. Malone, announced late Thursday that it had abandoned its plan to buy the shares of SiriusXM that it did not already own as part of a move to set up two tracking stocks to house the company’s assets.

headline: Bayern Munich’s Hoeness Sentenced to Prison for Tax Evasion
abstract: Uli Hoeness, the president of one of the world’s top soccer clubs and one of Germany’s most popular figures, received a sentence of three and a half years in jail.
lead_paragraph: Uli Hoeness, the president of the European champion soccer club Bayern Munich, was convicted Thursday of tax evasion and sentenced to three and a half years in prison after a four-day trial that had consumed the country.

headline: Crimean Tatars Face Uncertain Future
abstract: Seventy years after Stalin brutally deported thousands of Crimean Tatars to Central Asia, the descendants of those who returned fear repression as Russia tightens its grip on the peninsula.
lead_paragraph: Seventy years after Stalin brutally deported thousands of Crimean Tatars to Central Asia, the descendants of those who returned fear repression as Russia tightens its grip on the peninsula.

headline: Mindful of Past, Many Tatars Fear a Russian Future
abstract: As Crimea prepares for a vote on Sunday on whether to secede from Ukraine and join Russia, Tatars are plagued by a sense of foreboding and raw memories of Communist-era depredations.
lead_paragraph: BAKHCHYSARAY, Ukraine — Outside the ornate auburn gates of the Khan’s Palace here in the historical capital of the Crimean Tatars, the streets are empty. Many stores are shuttered, their doors padlocked.

headline: Bob Crow, Firebrand at Helm of British Union, Dies at 52
abstract: Mr. Crow, who led the National Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport Workers, was that rare thing in post-Thatcher Britain: a working-class hero.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He called his dog Castro and quit the Communist Party because it was “too moderate.”

headline: A Theory Behind Surge in Xbox One Sales
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: In sales figures for February released Thursday afternoon by NPD, the retail tracking firm, Microsoft’s Xbox One nearly matched the U.S. sales of the PlayStation 4. That was a sharp narrowing of the lead Sony had in monthly sales, leading to speculation that Sony fans are getting tired of hunting for the PlayStation 4, which is in short supply.
lead_paragraph: In January, Sony’s PlayStation 4 walloped Microsoft’s Xbox One console in sales, outselling it in the United States nearly two-to-one.

headline: Eater Hires Three Restaurant Critics
abstract: The food blog will start reviewing as part of an ambitious expansion under its new owner, Vox Media.
lead_paragraph: Eater, the food blog that started in 2005 as a self-proclaimed restaurant rumor mill, has hired three experienced restaurant critics, an ambitious expansion under its new owner, Vox Media, which acquired Eater.com and its siblings Curbed.com and Racked.com in November.

headline: Oil Money, and Where It Flows
abstract: Rachel Boynton’s documentary “Big Men” is about the 2007 discovery of oil off the coast of Ghana and the perfect storm of avarice that develops around it.
lead_paragraph: Not for nothing does “Big Men,” Rachel Boynton’s astonishing documentary about the 2007 discovery of oil off the coast of Ghana, open with a quotation on greed from the economist Milton Friedman. Dropping us into a perfect storm of avarice, this cool and incisive snapshot of global capitalism at work is as remarkable for its access as for its refusal to judge.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 91
abstract: Tickets to the World Cup continue to sell fast, but Americans will have chances to see about a dozen teams before they travel to Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The New York Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.
