abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: New Name and Mission for Taylor Dance Troupe
abstract: The Paul Taylor Dance Company announced that commitments from art sales had given it the money to remain afloat, now as Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance.
lead_paragraph: The Paul Taylor Dance Company announced Thursday that it had commitments of $10 million to reinvent itself next year as Paul Taylor’s American Modern Dance, a center that will perform dances by Mr. Taylor, other modern dance pioneers and contemporary choreographers.

headline: Mae Keane, Whose Job Brought Radium to Her Lips, Dies at 107
abstract: Mrs. Keane, one of the so-called radium girls, was employed at the Waterbury Clock Company in the 1920s when a relatively new material, radium, was used.
lead_paragraph: Like other young women working at the Waterbury Clock Company in Connecticut the 1920s, Mae Keane was taught a specific technique for applying paint to the numbers on wristwatch dials: Put the tip of the tiny brush between your lips to shape the bristles into the finest of points.

headline: A Devils Anomaly: Porous Defense, Potent Offense
abstract: The Devils’ normally solid defense has shown holes lately, but it has not been a problem because the club’s scoring has increased as well.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Tuomo Ruutu almost did not recognize the team for which he was playing.

headline: Former Egyptian General Calls Promise of Free Elections a ‘Farce’
keywords: ['Elections', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Ahmed Shafik, who had supported the military takeover, said the voting would be fixed, an almost heretical expression of cynicism from a member of the military elite.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Critics of the military takeover here often say the generals’ promise of free elections is little more than a bad joke. Now a prominent former military man who cheered the takeover seems to agree: Ahmed Shafik, a former general and prime minister and the runner-up in the last presidential election, has called it a “farce.”

headline: The Black Press During the Civil War
abstract: Throughout the conflict, African-American journalists led a robust debate over the war’s meaning for Black America.
lead_paragraph: Although the Civil War began as a conflict over secession, from the start most blacks saw it as an opportunity to free the enslaved with a Union victory – a theme reflected in the robust black press that prospered across the North.

headline: For-Profit Schools Face New Default Rules
abstract: For-profit colleges would lose all federal student aid, a fatal blow, if their students fail tests of earnings and debt default, the Obama administration will propose Friday.
lead_paragraph: For-profit colleges would lose all federal student aid, a fatal blow, if their students fail tests of earnings and debt default, the Obama administration will propose Friday. The rule would replace one struck down last year by a court. The proposed rule covers about 8,000 professional programs, each rated separately, and currently about 20 percent would fail, Education Secretary Arne Duncan said. Among other measures, a program would fail if 30 percent of former students defaulted on loans. The programs include those that grant certificates in trades, mostly at for-profit schools, and most degree-granting programs at for-profits.

headline: At Spring Training With the Mets, the Good, the Bad and the Apology
abstract: Daisuke Matsuzaka and Noah Syndergaard impressed on Thursday; Ruben Tejada didn’t; and the team moved on after an apology by the pitching coach.
lead_paragraph: VIERA, Fla. — The first batter Daisuke Matsuzaka faced on Thursday, Denard Span of the Washington Nationals, doubled, stole third base and scored on a groundout. It was the only blemish in an otherwise sharp outing for Matsuzaka, who is trying to win a job in the Mets’ rotation.

headline: A Quiet Village in the Catskills Braces for an Influx of Hasidim
abstract: Some residents of Bloomingburg object to a townhouse development, which they say will bring a large concentration of Hasidim and will change the atmosphere of their quiet village.
lead_paragraph: BLOOMINGBURG, N.Y. — Clifford M. Teich came to this rustic village in the foothills of the Catskills 30 years ago to be a country doctor, an internist who would treat his fellow villagers’ aches and pains, and get to know them as neighbors. He occasionally accepts payment in the form of homegrown onions and tomatoes.

headline: Wendy’s Turns Up Volume on Adoption Drive
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Philanthropy', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Foster Care', 'Restaurants']
abstract: Wendy’s has long supported adoption, but now the company is putting it front and center with a national advertising campaign and an adoption hub on its website.
lead_paragraph: DAVE THOMAS, the founder of the Wendy’s Company, was adopted at six weeks old, so it was fitting when the hamburger magnate started the Dave Thomas Foundation for Adoption in 1992.

headline: Soaring Prices Fuel Frustrations Among Weary Argentines
keywords: ['Inflation (Economics)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Interest Rates', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Since the peso was devalued, Argentines have grappled with one of the world’s highest inflation rates, tilling the ground for social unrest, including a strike by schoolteachers and police sit-ins.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Diego Gómez scurried around the food market, a labyrinth of bustling stalls in a gritty neighborhood far from the elegant avenues of central Buenos Aires. He did not stay long.

headline: Iraq: Members of Wedding Party Are Killed in Blast
abstract: A car bomber detonated explosives at an army checkpoint on a bridge in Anbar Province on Thursday, killing at least 16 people, including security officers and members of a wedding party.
lead_paragraph: A car bomber detonated his explosives at an army checkpoint on a bridge in Anbar Province on Thursday, killing at least 16 people, including security officers and members of a wedding party. The groom and his family were on their way to the bride’s house near the town of Rawa when they were struck by the explosion, relatives said. The groom survived but was hospitalized with a head wound, said Ahmed al-Rawi, a relative. “We wanted a wedding so we can party and smile, but instead the wedding turned into a funeral,” Mr. Rawi said.

headline: A Tough Day Being French (She Needs a Cigarette)
abstract: Emmanuelle Bercot’s “On My Way” stars Catherine Deneuve as a woman who goes out for a pack of cigarettes and ends up driving all over rural France.
lead_paragraph: The word that best describes Catherine Deneuve in Emmanuelle Bercot’s likable French road movie, “On My Way,” is unflappable. Her character, Bettie, who runs a failing bistro in Brittany, is a former regional beauty queen in her 60s who lives with her controlling mother, Annie (Claude Gensac).

headline: Scott Brown May Seek Office Again, but in New Hampshire
abstract: The former senator for Massachusetts has been mulling a run against Senator Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — After a year of mulling his political future, Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, has told people on Capitol Hill that he intends to open an exploratory committee and run this year for the Senate from New Hampshire, according to people with firsthand knowledge of those discussions.

headline: At South Jersey Forum, Hecklers Test Christie’s Paramount Rule
abstract: Six critics of Gov. Chris Christie waged a campaign of interruption at an open meeting with the governor in New Jersey on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT LAUREL, N.J. — The foremost rule at a Chris Christie Town Hall is inviolate and oft-repeated: Do not, under any circumstances, shout out questions unless called upon.

headline: The Deepest Self
abstract: The evolutionary view on human nature sells humanity short.
lead_paragraph: There is, by now, a large literature on the chemistry and biology of love and sex. If you dive into that literature, you learn pretty quickly that our love lives are biased by all sorts of deep unconscious processes. When men become fathers, their testosterone levels drop, thus reducing their sex drive. There’s some evidence that it’s the smell of their own infants (but not other people’s infants) that sets this off.

headline: Saving a Future for Those With Disabilities
abstract: A bill to create tax-deferred savings accounts for the disabled would make life more secure for the beneficiaries and for their parents and other caregivers.
lead_paragraph: Back in the old days, when Congress did crazy things like pass legislation, a sensible bill like the ABLE Act might have sailed to the president’s desk. But today, even with a long list of positives — it’s a good idea, solves a pressing problem and has lots of bipartisan support — it’s not a slam dunk, because there’s always a way in Washington to squelch good ideas, especially those that involve tweaking the tax code and spending a little money.

headline: Giants’ Justin Tuck Takes Two-Year Deal With Raiders
abstract: Tuck, a defensive end who was a stalwart of two Super Bowl victories with the Giants, accepted a contract worth $11 million to join a team that finished 4-12 each of the last two seasons.
lead_paragraph: Justin Tuck, a defensive end whose pass-rushing skills and leadership helped the Giants to two N.F.L. championships during his nine-year career, spoke of “winning more Super Bowls” after signing on Thursday with the lowly Oakland Raiders.

headline: Can New York Lead on Campaign Finance Reform?
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is tantalizingly close to making political history and could set an example for the rest of the country.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and lawmakers in New York State are tantalizingly close to making political history by enacting a campaign-finance reform law that not only would weaken the power of special interests and make elections more competitive, but also could set an example for the rest of the country.

headline: El Salvador: Officials Confirm Ex-Guerrilla’s Victory
abstract: El Salvador’s electoral tribunal on Thursday confirmed that a former guerrilla commander during the country’s civil war emerged from Sunday’s presidential election with the most votes.
lead_paragraph: El Salvador’s electoral tribunal on Thursday confirmed that Salvador Sánchez Cerén, a former guerrilla commander during the country’s civil war, emerged from Sunday’s presidential election with the most votes, by a margin of 6,364. But his opponent’s party, the right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance, or Arena, said it would not accept the results without a manual recount. The party said it submitted evidence of fraud to the attorney general’s office. International election monitors and Attorney General Luis Martínez González have said there was no sign of wrongdoing during the election.

headline: U.S. Takes Back Seat in Malaysian Jet Inquiry
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Some of the world’s foremost experts on crash investigations are in Kuala Lumpur, but technically only to assist the Malaysian government, and they are saying nothing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The best information about Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 is probably in the hands of American officials sent to assist in the investigation. But they will say nothing.

headline: Happy Meals, Unhappy Workers
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Editorials', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: Lawsuits alleging wage theft and other infractions were filed against McDonald’s in a bold escalation in the battle by fast-food workers for better pay.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s and several franchise owners were hit this week with seven lawsuits brought by workers in California, Michigan and New York. The details differ, but all the cases charge “wage theft” — the violation of federal labor laws, including failure to pay the minimum wage and time-and-a-half for overtime, denial of meal periods and rest breaks, and mandatory unpaid work.

headline: De Blasio Closes In on Pre-K Funding, but Not From a Higher Tax
abstract: Even as he faces escalating attacks for his stance toward charter schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday neared securing state funding to expand prekindergarten in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Even as he came under escalating attacks from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and the Legislature for his stance toward charter schools, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday stepped closer to securing state financing to expand prekindergarten in New York City.

headline: Ukraine Premier Makes Plea at the U.N.
abstract: The interim prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, sought to rally support for a Security Council resolution criticizing the Russian moves on Crimea.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Ukraine’s interim prime minister, seeking to rally support for a Security Council resolution criticizing the Russian takeover of Crimea, took pains on Thursday to say that his country wanted a peaceful resolution to the crisis.

headline: Trying to Take What Isn’t Theirs
abstract: In “The Art of the Steal,” Matt Dillon and Kurt Russell are half-brothers and part of an art theft ring.
lead_paragraph: Matt Dillon and Kurt Russell may not make the most convincing half-brothers, but “The Art of the Steal” is a fairly amusing heist film with some sibling tension helping the story along.

headline: Fixing Ukraine’s Economy
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Editorials']
abstract: International aid can help, but the country’s leaders still have to end wasteful subsidies and find ways to raise exports.
lead_paragraph: International efforts to provide financial aid to Ukraine offer a chance to fix a troubled economy. But those efforts will help only if the country’s new leaders are willing to end bad policies like wasteful energy subsidies and take steps to increase exports.

headline: No Easy Task in Bid to Find Seats for Pre-K
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s recent announcement of 29,000 possible seats for prekindergarten has run into rules that are different for 4-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: Let us leave Albany to its machinations, and for today’s discussion of universal prekindergarten, turn to the principles of the hydraulic power of toddlers.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 13, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 13, 2014

headline: Are Infrastructure Needs Truly Urgent?
abstract: Does the U.S. need to allocate resources more urgently  to repairing and replacing transmission lines, roads, bridges, etc., or are these concerns exaggerated?

headline: Absence of U.S. Envoy in Dublin Looms Over White House St. Patrick’s Day
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', "St Patrick's Day"]
abstract: The administration has not nominated an envoy to Ireland since the last one left in 2012, and the delay has bruised feelings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Prime Minister Enda Kenny of Ireland presented President Obama with a traditional bowl of shamrocks at the White House on Friday to celebrate St. Patrick’s Day, there was a rare snake lurking at this convivial garden party.

headline: Obama, Citing a Concern for Families, Orders a Review of Deportations
abstract: President Obama told Hispanic lawmakers that he was eager to see whether the nation’s existing immigration laws could be applied in a more humane way.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Thursday that deportations of illegal immigrants should be more humane, and to make that happen, he has ordered a review of his administration’s enforcement efforts.

headline: G.O.P. Moving to Ease Its Stance on Sentencing
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The Senate’s most conservative and most liberal members are finding common ground on criminal justice issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not that long ago, criminal justice reform in a conservative place like Texas meant executing prisoners with lethal injection instead of the electric chair.

headline: Turkish Leader Deplores Unrest, Calling Demonstrators ‘Fakers’
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan accused protesters of trying to stir up chaos ahead of local elections.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Breaking his silence, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan on Thursday condemned as “fakers” protesters who have been demonstrating across Turkey since Tuesday night, when a 15-year-old boy who had become a symbol of civilian resistance died after months in a coma.

headline: A Kiss Is Just a Kiss, Unless It’s an Ad for a Clothing Company
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Online Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Kissing']
abstract: Some experts suggest that a video sensation showing 10 pairs of strangers kissing for the first time could force major fashion designers to rethink how they advertise.
lead_paragraph: The email Tatia Pilieva sent to 21 people Monday morning started off the way such notes usually do when someone wants to get a link on Facebook.

headline: Two Coaches Born Into Fame Earn Respect Themselves
abstract: Dan Hurley, the coach at Rhode Island, is the son of the Hall of Fame coach Bob Hurley Sr., and one of his assistants, Luke Murray, is the son of the actor Bill Murray.
lead_paragraph: When Dan Hurley was the coach at Wagner and his brother, Bobby, was an assistant, their father, the Hall of Fame coach Bob Hurley Sr., would often drive from Jersey City to Staten Island to watch the Seahawks’ morning practices. He saw them steadily improve, from a team that had gone 5-26 before Dan’s arrival to a squad that won a program-record 25 games only two seasons later.

headline: Murder, Mentoring and Masochism in Japan
abstract: Sion Sono’s “Guilty of Romance” looks at three women — a detective, a literature professor and a wife — each with ties to episodes of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: “Guilty of Romance” is a garish-colored noir by the Japanese filmmaker Sion Sono. Black shadows and bright green and pink lights set the tone of this sickening, lush mystery about two female corpses, each partly a severed human and partly a mannequin. (This is seemingly a nod to the real-life 1940s Black Dahlia case.)

headline: In Cambodia, Voicing the Struggle
keywords: ['Radio', 'News and News Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Mam Sonando, described by his supporters as Cambodia’s only truly independent radio broadcaster, says he is fighting to “protect people who have been victimized.”
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — As freedom fighters go, Mam Sonando stands out as somewhat eccentric. The entrance to his radio station, which is described by his loyal supporters as Cambodia’s only truly independent broadcaster, is decorated like a nightclub, complete with colored lights and a disco ball. It also has at least four Buddhist shrines.

headline: Former U.S. Ambassador Confronts Russian Network’s Editors Over Reporting on Crimea
abstract: Michael McFaul, the former United States ambassador to Russia, told the editor of the Russian government’s overseas broadcast network Russia Today, that he refused to keep “pretending that RT is a news organization.”
lead_paragraph: Michael McFaul returned to academic life at Stanford last month after two years in Moscow as the United States ambassador to Russia, but he has continued to engage with Russian critics of American foreign policy on Twitter in lively exchanges across 12 time zones, despite the attendant frustrations.

headline: In Japan, Two Teenagers Bond in a Chaotic, Violent World
abstract: “Himizu,” directed by Sion Sono, is a futuristic, dystopian film set in the present, made soon after the 2011 earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan.
lead_paragraph: “Himizu” is a futuristic, dystopian film set in the present. It was made by Sion Sono in 2011, soon after the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan.

headline: Mutual Self-Interest May Help Advance Deal Allowing Aid to Ukraine
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Republican leaders proposed giving the White House the changes it wants for the International Monetary Fund in exchange for delaying regulations on tax-exempt political organizations, a deal the White House may take.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican leaders have proposed giving the Obama administration the changes it badly wants for the International Monetary Fund in exchange for delaying regulations on tax-exempt political organizations, enraging some members of both parties who say they are holding urgent aid to Ukraine hostage for conservative donors like the Koch brothers.

headline: Big East Tournament at the Garden Lacks New York Flavor
abstract: The Big East could have used a semifinal showdown between Seton Hall and St. John’s.
lead_paragraph: Behind the St. John’s bench, three rows up, Lou Carnesecca rose in protest, along with those around him. From across the floor, you could read his lips.

headline: Russia Blocks Web Content Amid Tension Over Ukraine
abstract: Russia’s general prosecutor ordered three websites and a blog closed, saying they encouraged “illegal activities and participation in public events held in violation of the established order.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian authorities on Thursday blocked three websites and a blog, including platforms used by the opposition figures Aleksei A. Navalny and Garry K. Kasparov, saying that Russia’s general prosecutor had ordered the sites closed because they had encouraged “illegal activities and participation in public events held in violation of the established order.”

headline: In 2 East Harlem Buildings Leveled by Explosion, Lives Entwined as in Bygone Era
abstract: Upstairs residents of the century-old buildings, which had changed little in a neighborhood that has been rapidly modernizing, had close ties to a piano shop and a church.
lead_paragraph: In the three floors above the Spanish Christian Church lived a 44-year-old security guard and a 67-year-old dental hygienist. There was a 22-year-old line cook at a four-star Midtown Manhattan hotel and her mother, who immigrated from Mexico. All were members of the 80-year-old church downstairs.

headline: A Review of Banks in Europe Gets Results
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: UniCredit’s announcement of a 15 billion euro loss is seen as an attempt to get out in front of a European Central Bank review of large banks.
lead_paragraph: What is an asset worth? How much capital does a bank really have?

headline: The Killer Online
abstract: In “The Den,” directed by Zach Donohue, a graduate student researching video-chat culture witnesses a murder online.
lead_paragraph: While the horror film “The Den” indulges in the hoary found-footage conceit and traffics in shopworn genre staples (dank hallways, claustrophobic subterranean lairs), it brings a new player to the party: the online video chat. And the movie, the feature debut of the director, Zach Donohue (who wrote the script with Lauren Thompson), does so with flair.

headline: Swinging at Fighters and Serenading Turtles
abstract: “Rocky,” the mostly torpid new musical at the Winter Garden Theater, counts on its audience’s residual affection for the film on which it is based.
lead_paragraph: The official curtain time for “Rocky,” the new musical at the Winter Garden Theater, is 8 on most nights. But at the risk of promoting tardiness among theatergoers, I feel obliged to point out that the show doesn’t really get started until 10:10 or thereabouts.

headline: The Shorter You Are
abstract: A Friday toughie by Alan Olschwang.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — I’m of two minds about this puzzle. Your mileage may vary. All I can tell you is that this wasn’t my most enjoyable solve.

headline: Young Drifter
abstract: In “The Cold Lands,” an 11-year-old boy flees into the forest after his mother’s death, shunning society until he meets another drifter.
lead_paragraph: Raised off the grid and orphaned at 11, Atticus lives through more than one rough patch over the course of Tom Gilroy’s “The Cold Lands.” This becalmed film, which was partly shot in a woodsy part of New York State, fails to crystallize until Atticus attaches himself to a dude who sells homemade trinkets.

headline: New York City Bar Association Urges Steps to Improve Ethics Panel
abstract: A report criticizes the New York State Joint Commission on Public Ethics as lacking independence from the politicians it is supposed to oversee.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The New York State commission charged with investigating the shenanigans of public officials is being urged to take major steps to shore up its image.

headline: Target Missed Signs of a Data Breach
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Credit Cards', 'Debit Cards', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: The company said it decided to ignore signs of suspicious activity flagged by security software last year.
lead_paragraph: Target acknowledged on Thursday that its computer security system had alerted it to suspicious activity after hackers infiltrated its network last year, but the company ultimately decided to ignore it, allowing what would become one of the largest data breaches ever recorded to proceed without a hitch.

headline: With Gas Explosion in Her District, City Council’s New Speaker Is at Center Stage
abstract: Melissa Mark-Viverito is New York City’s second most powerful elected official but still barely recognized outside her East Harlem district — until now.
lead_paragraph: By midafternoon on Thursday, Melissa Mark-Viverito’s eyes were smarting, her clothes rank with the smell of smoke. But her day was not over. There were more grim conversations to have with the medical examiner’s office, and a prayer circle organized by local pastors to attend.

headline: Interrogation of Bin Laden Relative Is Recounted
abstract: During testimony Thursday, an F.B.I. agent describes the interrogation of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a close associate of Osama bin Laden, as “a respectful, relaxed conversation.”
lead_paragraph: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a close associate of Osama bin Laden’s, told the authorities after his arrest last year that the Sept. 11 terror attacks were a surprise to him, but that he had heard around Qaeda training camps in Afghanistan “that something big was going to happen,” a federal agent testified on Thursday.

headline: A Female Trailblazer’s Next Notch
abstract: Shannon Szabados, who won an Olympic gold medal for Canada, is expected to become the first woman to play in the Southern Professional Hockey League.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga. — At the Columbus Cottonmouths’ morning skate on Thursday, Brad Prefontaine, the assistant coach, opened the door to the practice rink for Shannon Szabados, who squeezed through in her goaltending gear. “This is the last time I’m going to do that for you,” he said, jokingly.

headline: Federal Judge Went Too Far in Lawsuits, a Court Says
abstract: An appellate panel criticized Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. for having his staff members investigate a case concerning legal fees in disability suits outside the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: Something about the cases seemed wrong. The lawsuits, scores of them, accused businesses of failing to provide proper access for disabled customers. Defendants who lost had to pay the plaintiff’s legal fees, and they piled up in case after case. Last year, a federal judge in Brooklyn, citing “troubling litigation tactics,” denied legal fees, based in part on an unusual step by his chambers. His staff members investigated the matter outside the courtroom.

headline: Preserving Culture in the Amazon
abstract: “Xingu” tells how three brothers, hoping to protect indigenous people in the Amazon, helped create a sprawling national park in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: A gripping account of a collision of cultures, “Xingu” tells the inspiring true story of the three Villas Bôas brothers, who became the leading advocates for Brazil’s Amazonian Indians, an effort that culminated in the founding of a mammoth tribal preserve.

headline: Artistic Director of New York Live Arts Leaving for Post in Florida
abstract: Carla Peterson, artistic director of New York Live Arts, will be the next director of the Maggie Allesee National Center for Choregraphy at Florida State University.
lead_paragraph: Carla Peterson stayed in the same building when she changed jobs in 2006, from executive director of Movement Research to artistic director of Dance Theater Workshop, now known as New York Live Arts. Now she is going to need some interstate transport. The Maggie Allesee National Center for Choreography at Florida State University has announced that Ms. Peterson will be its next director, following Jennifer Calienes, who has held the position since the center’s inception in 2004.

headline: Two Stars Longing for Jackson to Return to the Lakers
abstract: As Phil Jackson considers an offer from the Knicks to take over their basketball operations, Kobe Bryant and Magic Johnson weigh the question of whether Jackson could return to the Lakers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The coach-as-imperialist figure is increasingly a relic in the N.B.A., as more teams turn toward low-profile game managers who dutifully carry out the analytics-driven, playing-for-tomorrow plan set out by well-educated executives.

headline: Yankees Head to Panama and a Reunion With Rivera
abstract: A split-squad team will play two games against Miami, do some sightseeing and promote baseball in Mariano Rivera’s home country.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Joe Girardi had barely heard a comment concerning the weather in Panama when he blurted: “Ninety-eight, every day. Friday, Saturday, Sunday. Ninety-eight. The low is 75, and if you look during the middle of the day it’s not humid, but it gets humid at night. Believe me, I checked it out. It’s 98, 98, 98.”

headline: Singapore Government Firm Pursues Buyout of Olam International
abstract: The buyout group, led by Temasek Holdings, Singapore’s government investor, has offered Olam a premium of about 12 percent to where the shares first traded, valuing the company at more than $4 billion.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Olam International, a Singapore agricultural commodities company that has been targeted by the short seller Carson C. Block, said on Friday that it had received a cash buyout offer led by a Singapore government investment firm valuing it at more than $4 billion.

headline: Not Quite Grown-Ups
abstract: The premise of “Teenage” is that the idea of a phase between childhood and adult life came about only at the beginning of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: A lot of intriguing ideas are floated in “Teenage,” a frenetic documentary by Matt Wolf about the creation of the Western concept of the teenager. But the film takes a point of view that leaves all of them underdeveloped.

headline: A Good-Will Trip to Las Vegas for the Mets
abstract: In the midst of Grapefruit League action, the Mets will visit their Class AAA affiliate’s home to play two games against the Cubs as part of an annual big-league celebration.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It is a more or less unwritten rule of spring training: Established veterans are not asked to make too many two-hour bus rides across Florida to play in spring training games. There will be plenty of travel once the regular season begins.

headline: Some Things Go Bump in the Daytime, Too
abstract: “Dark House” is a horror movie with a rural setting by Victor Salva, director of “Jeepers Creepers.”
lead_paragraph: Mere minutes into “Dark House,” it becomes depressingly clear that the deficit of imagination displayed by the title will not be made up for by the content. (One wonders why the makers even bothered to replace the original name, “Haunted.”) Grabbing off-the-rack ideas — the creepy-crumbly mansion in the woods, the “Deliverance”-style locals, the troubled young man with the weird psychic power — the director, Victor Salva, stuffs them into a plot of resounding silliness.

headline: Yankees’ Pineda Makes Impression Against Orioles
abstract: Pineda pitched two and two-thirds innings against the Baltimore Orioles in Tampa, Fla., yielding three hits and a walk and striking out five.
lead_paragraph: After another strong performance, the Yankees continued to be optimistic about Michael Pineda.

headline: L.A.’s Thai Wunderkind Serves Up a Second Course
abstract: Kris Yenbamroong, the 31-year-old chef behind the celebrated pop-up Night + Market, opens his first permanent restaurant in Silver Lake.
lead_paragraph: The peppercorns come back from near the Burmese border in Kris Yenbamroong’s suitcase, wrapped in newsprint. The waterbugs, however, are a little trickier. He buys them frozen in packs of four from a market in the San Fernando Valley, steams them, and grinds them into nam prik, a relish he serves with long beans, cabbage and house-made fermented sausage.

headline: Looking for Love? This New Fragrance Could Help You Find It
abstract: Carole Beaupré and Pauline Rochas, the makers of Le Premier Parfume, claim that wearing it will increase your odds of being asked out.
lead_paragraph: The artists Carole Beaupré and Pauline Rochas started their still-life and beauty photography studio Coolife in 2000, and since then the pair has been conceptualizing bold imagery for clients like Ralph Lauren and Estée Lauder. Now, Beaupré and Rochas — the latter a granddaughter of Marcel Rochas, the founder of theRochas fashion and fragrance house — have broadened their creative portfolio by creating an intriguing new scent, Le Premier Parfum.

headline: How to Shave $1 Trillion Out of Health Care
abstract: Shaving $1 trillion out of health care costs would not reduce health outcomes, but would provide many other benefits, writes an economist.
lead_paragraph: Victor R. Fuchs is Professor Emeritus of Economics and Health Research and Policy at Stanford University, and author of “Who Shall Live? Health, Economics and Social Choice.”

headline: U.N. Envoy Warns Against Syria Elections
abstract: Lakhdar Brahimi, the United Nations special envoy to Syria, warned that holding elections would doom prospects for any future talks between the warring parties.
lead_paragraph: Lakhdar Brahimi, the United Nations special envoy to Syria, warned that holding elections would doom prospects for any future talks between the warring parties.

headline: Ask Well: Laser Treatments for Nail Fungus
keywords: ['Feet', 'Fungi', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Nails (Body Part)']
abstract: Do laser treatments for toenail fungus really work? More than 2,000 Ask Well readers want to know.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Amid Preparations, Mediator Says Syria Vote Would Doom Talks
abstract: Lakhdar Brahimi said there were many signs that Syria’s government was planning an election, though that would be counterproductive for talks.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations mediator who has sought to coax the warring parties in Syria to negotiate an end to the three-year-old conflict said on Thursday that holding elections would doom prospects for any future talks, even as lawmakers in Damascus appeared to inch closer to scheduling national polls.

headline: Word of the Day | parable
abstract: This word has appeared in 148 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: parable •\ˈpa-rə-bəl\• noun

headline: South Korean School for Scandal
abstract: In the South Korean drama “Tabloid Truth,” the death of an actress linked to a married politician is only the start of the action.
lead_paragraph: In “Tabloid Truth,” the director Kim Kwang-sik explores the underbelly of a world that may sound familiar to fans of “House of Cards” or “Scandal.” Here, journalists, political figures and businessmen (yes, all men) collude to shape public opinion and further their agendas. At meetings, they hatch up “news” (accuracy is not a guiding principle) that is disseminated via an exclusive stock market tip sheet, whipping the tabloids into a frenzy.

headline: Emails Link Duke Energy and North Carolina
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Clean Water Act', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Emails indicate that environmental regulators consulted Duke Energy before seeking to exclude citizen activists from talks to settle charges over groundwater pollution.
lead_paragraph: Environmental regulators in North Carolina consulted Duke Energy last year before seeking to exclude citizen activists from talks to settle charges that the utility’s coal ash ponds had polluted the state’s groundwater, newly released email exchanges among the regulators indicated on Thursday.

headline: Matthew Power, Wide-Roving Journalist, Dies at 39
abstract: Mr. Power’s writing took readers from a journey down the Mississippi with modern-day hobos to the scenes of international disasters.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Power, a wide-roving journalist whose writing took readers from a journey down the Mississippi with modern-day hobos to the scenes of international disasters and inside the Lower East Side apartment where Allen Ginsberg spent his last days, died on Monday in Uganda. He was 39.

headline: Times Minute | Flight 370's Pings
abstract: More information on the search for the Malaysian jetliner on the Minute including the United States' silent role in the investigation and withering criticism of Malaysia's political elite.
lead_paragraph: More information on the search for the Malaysian jetliner on the Minute including the United States' silent role in the investigation and withering criticism of Malaysia's political elite.

headline: Times Minute | Flight 370’s Pings
abstract: More information on the search for the Malaysian jetliner on the Minute including the United States’ silent role in the investigation and withering criticism of Malaysia’s political elite.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Peter Callander, Lyricist of Pop Hits in ’60s and ’70s, Dies at 74
abstract: Songs that Mr. Callander wrote or co-wrote include “Billy, Don’t Be a Hero,” “The Night Chicago Died” and “The Ballad of Bonnie and Clyde.”
lead_paragraph: Peter Callander, a British songwriter who provided lyrics for hits of the 1960s and ’70s like “The Night Chicago Died” and “Billy, Don’t Be a Hero,” died on Feb. 25 in Haresfield, Middlesex, England. He was 74.

headline: Their Life Is a Cabaret, With Freedom in Vulgarity
abstract: Eight cabaret performers are profiled in “Exposed,” which features snippets of their performances, merging shock and showmanship.
lead_paragraph: Dancing on the wilder shores of burlesque, the eight performers profiled in “Exposed” practice the kind of subversive cabaret that few non-city-dwellers are likely to have seen. That’s too bad, because these confrontational comedians — however serious the message, it’s always imparted with liberal dollops of humor — are experts at merging shock and showmanship.

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:15 A.M. (TMC) THE COLOR OF MONEY (1986) Paul Newman reprises his role as the pool player Fast Eddie Felson from “The Hustler” (1961) in this Martin Scorsese film, set 25 years after the original. Felson now serves as the manager and mentor of Vincent Lauria (Tom Cruise), a talented but naïve, young pool shark. When a disagreement leads Felson and Lauria to part ways, the stage is set for teacher-student showdown on the green felt. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby described Mr. Newman’s Oscar-winning portrayal as “a wonderfully funny, canny performance, set off by the actor’s intelligence that shines through the character without upstaging it.”

headline: Writing a New Romance
abstract: In “Shirin in Love,” a young Iranian-American journalist who feels lukewarm about her fiancé rushes headlong into a relationship with the son of an interview subject.
lead_paragraph: Dull filmmaking and spiritless dialogue can together feel like a curse that hangs over actors, stifling their every other scene. Nominally a romantic comedy in the ethnic-family subgenre, “Shirin in Love” is a case in point, plodding along with the young Iranian-American writer of the title as she gets cold feet about marrying her fiancé, a surgeon, and pursues the son of an interview subject.

headline: A Marketplace Dispute in Central China Turns Deadly
abstract: News reports said a dispute between two food vendors in Changsha escalated, leaving five people stabbed to death and one man shot and killed by the police.
lead_paragraph: An argument between two vendors in a marketplace in Changsha Friday morning escalated into a fight that left five people stabbed to death and one man shot and killed by the police, a police statement said.

headline: A Documentary on Battling Addiction’s Powerful Pull
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Greg Williams directed “The Anonymous People,” a documentary about the stigma of substance abuse and the barriers to recovery.
lead_paragraph: Joining the stunned conversation surrounding Philip Seymour Hoffman’s recent overdose, “The Anonymous People” could not have appeared at a more opportune moment. But however good the intentions, this sluggish documentary about the stigma of substance abuse and the barriers to recovery never comes close to catching fire.

headline: Compromising Moral Positions
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: With “Crimes and Misdemeanors,” Woody Allen walks the line between comedy and drama and rarely stumbles.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director of more than 40 feature films, Woody Allen is one of the most driven artists in Hollywood history. I’m not sufficiently driven to have seen every one of his movies, but of the three dozen or so I have taken in, one stands alone: “Crimes and Misdemeanors,” newly out in a limited edition Blu-ray from Twilight Time.

headline: Corrections: March 14, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Report Finds Punctuality Trumps Safety at Metro-North
abstract: After a spate of rail disasters, a blistering federal inquiry found that the East Coast railroad had developed a “deficient safety culture” in which workers were rushed and cellphone use was commonplace.
lead_paragraph: The Metro-North Railroad has fallen prey to a “deficient safety culture” that prizes on-time performance at the expense of protecting riders and workers, according to a blistering federal review that was ordered after a spate of rail disasters.

headline: Jet Skids Off Philadelphia Runway After Takeoff Is Aborted
abstract: A US Airways plane’s nose gear collapsed Thursday as its pilot attempted an emergency landing, forcing an evacuation of the plane but no serious injuries, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A US Airways jet en route from Pennsylvania to Florida skidded off the runway during an aborted takeoff on Thursday after the plane’s nose gear collapsed, forcing an emergency evacuation of the disabled plane, officials said.

headline: Social Media App Blocks Prominent Chinese Accounts
abstract: The accounts that have been suspended on WeChat included several that had gained wide followings as independent sources of news and information in China.
lead_paragraph: Several prominent Chinese-language accounts on the social media app WeChat were suspended on Thursday in what users called the broadest clampdown on the service so far.

headline: U.S.-Russia Talks on Ukraine Fail to Ease Tension
abstract: As Moscow ordered more military exercises on Ukraine’s border, Secretary of State John Kerry met the Russian foreign minister but failed to find a solution.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An 11th-hour bid by Secretary of State John Kerry to ease the escalating crisis over the Kremlin’s intervention in Crimea ended in failure on Friday, raising the likelihood of sanctions against Russia and deepening the most serious East-West rift since the end of the Cold War.

headline: Tony Benn, Who Preferred Politics to an Aristocrat’s Title, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Benn, a passionate figure in the Labour Party, renounced a hereditary peerage to remain in the House of Commons.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tony Benn, a passionate orator, prolific diarist and provocative leader of the British left who became the first peer to surrender an aristocratic title to remain in the House of Commons, died on Friday at his home in West London. He was 88.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, March 14, 2014
abstract: Can you identify the literary device in the sentences from the article?
lead_paragraph: Use the following question for practice or just for fun.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Celebrating Pi Day
abstract: How will some people celebrate Pi Day?
lead_paragraph: In celebration of Pi Day, we pose questions that link to Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about pi and Pi Day.

headline: What Qualities Would You Look For in a College Roommate?
abstract: Would you want a roommate who is more similar to you or more different? Why?
lead_paragraph: Recent studies show that the roommate you are paired with in college can affect “everything from academic performance to freshman weight gain.” While you may not have as much say in the matter as you would like if you attend a college away from home, what qualities would you look for in a college roommate?

headline: Emmet Gowin: Loving the Problem
abstract: In a career of reinvention Emmet Gowin has pondered the unanswerable and worked the margins of understanding. A new monograph shows how.
lead_paragraph: The telephone rang in a Pennsylvania home last month and was answered by Edith Gowin, known to many as the subject of her husband’s most striking photographs.

headline: Investment Bank Chief is UBS’s Top-Paid Executive
abstract: After leading a turnaround at the investment bank, Andrea Orcel earned about $13 million in 2013, more than Sergio P. Ermotti, the Swiss bank’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The head of UBS’s investment bank was the company’s highest-paid executive in 2013, earning more than Sergio P. Ermotti, the Swiss lender’s chief executive, according to its annual report released on Friday.

headline: New York Today: After the Frost

headline: Uber Expands Insurance Program for Community Drivers
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Uber, the company that offers a smartphone app for summoning cars for rides, has been under intense scrutiny since an Uber driver struck and killed a 6-year-old girl while he was between fares — raising questions about when Uber is responsible for an accident. Now the company says it is buying more insurance for its drivers.
lead_paragraph: Uber, the maker of a smartphone app for summoning cars for rides, has been under intense scrutiny since an Uber driver struck and killed a 6-year-old girl late last year, when he was between fares —  raising questions about when Uber should be held responsible for an accident.

keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Interest Rates', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hong Kong’s main banking regulator on Friday released the results of an investigation that found that traders at the Swiss bank UBS tried to rig a local benchmark interest rate over a four-year period.

headline: Bayern Munich President Accepts Jail Term for Tax Evasion

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — When all of his cards were played and Uli Hoeness, the Bayern Munich president and German soccer legend, faced the prospect of a protracted and high-profile appeal of his conviction on charges of tax evasion, he chose to take his punishment.

headline: China Puts a Stop to Plans for Virtual Credit Cards
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'E-Commerce', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Credit Cards', 'Virtual Currency']

headline: Who’s More Famous Than Jesus?
abstract: And more questions answered by a just-released interactive catalog of fame compiled by a team of researchers at M.I.T.
lead_paragraph: There are many varieties of fame. Jesus Christ was the first person to achieve it globally, Clive James wrote, “without conquering the world by violence.” The best kind for a poet to earn, W. H. Auden said, is like some valley cheese — “local, but prized elsewhere.” Yet if all fame, like all politics, is to some degree local, how thoroughly it has been transmitted across the planet and through the centuries has been difficult, if not impossible, to quantify.

headline: The I.R.S.’s Final Mandate Reporting Rules? Still Complicated
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Insurance', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: The final regulations have been released, and business groups are complaining that the only streamlining the I.R.S. appears to have achieved is for itself.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, the Obama administration delayed implementing the employer mandate in the Affordable Care Act because, it said, it needed time to figure out how it might simplify the law’s complicated reporting requirements for businesses with 50 or more employees. “We don’t necessarily need to load up the vast majority of companies that are already doing the right thing with a bunch of additional paperwork,” President Obama told The Times in an interview in July, asking, “Are there simpler ways for us to allow them to certify that they’re providing health insurance?”

headline: 15 Power Couples of the Last 6,000 Years
abstract: Of the many categories you can use to sort the giant database of fame that M.I.T.’s media lab put online today — artist, lawyer, philosopher, pirate — one of the most captivating is “companion.”
lead_paragraph: Of the many categories you can use to sort the giant database of fame that M.I.T.’s media lab put online today — artist, lawyer, philosopher, pirate — one of the most captivating is “companion.” It makes sense that in any rankings of cultural production (Dwight Garner has more on how exactly they were produced), some people make the list not for what they’ve done but whom they know. Most of the famous companions are women married to distinguished men, but not all. There’s Joseph Bonaparte, elder brother of Napoleon, who comes in at No. 1,683 (his brother is No. 21), and Al-‘Abbas ibn ‘Abd al-Muttalib (No. 4,519), the uncle of Muhammad (No. 13).

headline: Spring Cleaning Who Has Access to Your Data
abstract: As spring comes into view, it’s time to manage which apps and services have access to your social accounts and can see everything you’re doing.
lead_paragraph: It’s almost that time of year again. Wash off the car. Take the cover off the grill. And figure out who has access to your social accounts.

headline: Time to Adjust Overtime Pay
abstract: Millions of workers who should be eligible for overtime pay are not because rules are outdated and the threshold for the pay has not kept pace with inflation, writes an economist.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Daily Report: Target Missed Warning Signs of Data Breach

Harris and Nicole Perlroth report.

headline: America Exports Democracy, Just Not the Way You Think

lead_paragraph: London — Daniel Libeskind designed a set of steel panels folded like origami, Frank Gehry piled up a stack of timber beams and glass panels, Rem Koolhaas built an inflatable canopy that was described as a “cosmic egg.” Those architects are just three of the famous names who have designed the Serpentine Gallery’s summer pavilion, a temporary structure that has been constructed in Kensington Gardens in London each year since 2000, and which has become a major tourist attraction here.

But for my own edification I wanted to write up a clarification of a couple of technical points.

Icahn in 2010.
lead_paragraph: S.E.C. TAKES AIM AT 10TH FORMER SAC EMPLOYEE  |  The Securities and Exchange Commission’s investigation into Steven A. Cohen’s hedge fund, SAC Capital Advisors, isn’t done just yet. Federal regulators announced on Thursday a civil case against Ronald N. Dennis, who worked for SAC for less than two years, for prompting a number of illegal trades stemming from confidential tips he received about two technology companies, Dell and Foundry Networks, Ben Protess and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. Mr. Dennis, the 10th former employee of SAC to face civil or criminal insider trading charges, settled with the S.E.C., agreeing to be banned from the securities industry and to pay $200,000.

headline: Obama Has Made America Look Weak
abstract: The Crimea crisis offers Americans a chance to restore our country’s credibility on the world stage.
lead_paragraph: Should Russia’s invasion and looming annexation of Crimea be blamed on President Barack Obama? Of course not, just as it should not be blamed on NATO expansion, the Iraq war or Western interventions to stop mass atrocities in the Balkans and Libya. The blame lies squarely with Vladimir V. Putin, an unreconstructed Russian imperialist and K.G.B. apparatchik.

headline: The Blame Game in Venezuela

lead_paragraph: In the month since mass demonstrations began in Venezuela, at least 25 people have died in the protests. No end to the crisis is in sight, and each day the grievances grow, the arrests multiply, positions harden and moderates retreat.

headline: Your Questions, My Answers (I)

lead_paragraph: Earlier this week I invited reader questions, and I’d like to thank everyone who submitted one. Below are my responses to a selection, which have been edited slightly for length (the full versions are available from the link on each questioners name). Since my answers are predictably on the long side, I’m breaking this up into two posts of five questions each; the second will run on Monday. (I might do a third set, but other forms of punditry may end up taking precedence.)

headline: Private Employment Slowly Reclaims Pre-Downturn Peak
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The recent downturn has lasted a grueling six years, and while fewer people are losing their jobs, many who became unemployed in 2008 and 2009 are still looking.
lead_paragraph: TWO presidential elections have taken place since employment by United States businesses hit a peak of almost 116 million workers. This seems likely to be the month when a new high is finally reached, ending a period that featured the largest drop in employment and the slowest recovery of any period since the Great Depression.

The auctioneer announced that there were already 17 telephone and absentee buyers vying for the canvas, made three years ago by Oscar Murillo, who just turned 28.

headline: People Think We’re in a Recession. Don’t Blame Them.

abstract: Most Americans — 57 percent — say the country is still in a recession. It’s not, but they are picking up on two very real and important economic trends.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy emerged from recession in June 2009 and has been growing for nearly five years. Yet this week, an NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll of American adults found that 57 percent still think the economy is in recession.

headline: Basic Training With the New York City Ballet
abstract: A rare glimpse into a windowless theater.
lead_paragraph: Dancers in the New York City Ballet spend their days rehearsing in a large theater that, as legend goes, was designed to be blocked off from natural light for a reason: because it suited the wishes of George Balanchine, one of the company’s founders, who died in 1983. “Apparently Mr. Balanchine wanted it that way so he would have this whole group of girls locked away, out of sunlight, only seen when the curtain rises,” Devin Alberda, one of the dancers, says. Alberda, who joined the corps de ballet in 2006, has been providing a rare glimpse inside this cloistered world, posting pictures of his fellow dancers to Instagram all winter. This is the most punishing time of year, when they work 12-hour days for 14 weeks without a break. Alberda says they struggle with the long stretches of rehearsal indoors, under artificial light. “We really don’t see the sun,” he says. “But there’s also something really spectacular about it.” Julie Bosman

headline: Even Aliens Love California
abstract: Disappearing hares; nachos by any other name.
lead_paragraph: Disappearing hares; nachos by any other name.

headline: Who Made That Corkscrew?
abstract: As bottles sealed with cork became more common, corkscrews did too.
lead_paragraph: For as long as wine was stored in jugs and stoppered with oil cloth and bits of wood, there was no need for a specialized opener. But in the 17th century, as bottles sealed with cork became more common, corkscrews did too. Collectors say that very early versions of the tool were derived from military kits: Soldiers used screw-shaped “gun worms” to pull misfired musket balls from the barrels of their guns. They would drill into the lead and drag the ammunition up and out. The first corkscrews were small and portable, often nothing more than the worm (the screw itself) and a small ring for pulling with your finger. But in the 18th century, people came to understand the benefits of aging wine, and bottles were standardized in a long-necked cylindrical shape suitable for long-term storage. The new emphasis on shelf life necessitated a better cork — and thus a better corkscrew.

headline: The Secret Life of Our Trash Can
abstract: After 15 years, our garbage can was busted. Parting with it wasn’t so easy.
lead_paragraph: Recently there was a snowstorm. When you tried to step outside, it was as if you’d just opened the winning door in “The Price Is Right” and were being barraged by confetti and blowing horns. There were snow plows everywhere, and one ran into our plastic garbage can, cracking it right down its side. When I tried to put a big garbage bag in it, the bag fell out. The garbage can was 15 years old. It was time for it to become garbage itself.

headline: The Death of the Bargain Bin
abstract: We’ve replaced contained chaos with something so vast that we need algorithms to show us our way.
lead_paragraph: Most adolescents reach a point when they realize that they owe their parents something. Many of these young people, including me, will realize that what they owe is essentially boundless and that they’ll spend the rest of their lives trying to pay off this debt. And most start in a way that makes sense financially and lines up nicely with major holidays — because gift-giving is a good way to start chipping away at that whole they-gave-you-life deficit.

headline: The Psychomagical Realism of Alejandro Jodorowsky
abstract: The “father of the midnight movie” is back with his first film in 23 years.
lead_paragraph: In September, on the day of the Paris premiere of “The Dance of Reality,” his first movie in 23 years, Alejandro Jodorowsky, the Chilean-born filmmaker, learned that he was now an asteroid — 261690 Jodorowsky — as the International Astronomical Union had named a three-mile-wide chunk of rock orbiting between Mars and Jupiter. For a man whose life has been defined by cosmic ambitions, the honor seemed almost expected.

headline: The Voiceless
abstract: Daniel Anselme’s 1957 novel of France’s Algerian war.
lead_paragraph: The French writer Daniel Anselme (1927-89) started out as a poet and journalist. He fought with the Communist underground during World War II, and when the Algerian conflict started in the mid-1950s, he turned from journalism to what he called a “mode of action,” by which he meant, of all things, the novel. This was in Paris in the decade of “Waiting for Godot,” when being a “man of action” could mean writing a novel that contains almost no action at all.

headline: Today in Small Business: Was a Viral Video a Fraud?
abstract: It turns out that the “First Kiss” video that went viral was a commercial. Does it matter? Did it increase sales?
lead_paragraph: Editor’s Note: Gene Marks will be on vacation next week. His posts will resume on March 24.

headline: Quiet Desperation
abstract: Philip Schultz’s novel revisits a 1941 massacre in German-occupied Poland.
lead_paragraph: What’s most improbable about “The Wherewithal,” Philip Schultz’s novel-­shaped poem, is that it’s at once a weak instance of each of its genres and a stunning instance of both. Little develops, little resolves. You know less in the end than after the first chapter. Its characters are stock types or caricatures, and its descriptions, sketchy for prose, are almost mock-poetry (“the pitiless turbine / of his thoughts”). There is little rhythm, less meter, less closure that makes sense. There is no catharsis.

headline: Hello, My Lovely
abstract: The Irish mystery writer Benjamin Black, a.k.a. John Banville, finds a new adventure for Philip Marlowe.
lead_paragraph: About two-thirds of the way through “The Black-Eyed Blonde,” Philip Marlowe — that name might ring a bell — tells us he “lit up another cancer stick.” For a novel set in the early 1950s, this sounded anachronistic, so I went online to investigate. While a connection between tobacco and cancer was suggested in the 1930s in Germany, the Oxford Dictionary of Modern Slang places the earliest use of “cancer stick” at 1959 — which is not to say that it wasn’t used before then.

headline: Control Group
abstract: Emboldened by cutting-edge research, a sociologist and father of two explains a series of unorthodox parenting decisions.
lead_paragraph: Parents: You know that dad at the park, the nice guy who sidles up to talk at the swings? He’s laid back, not one of those intense helicopter parents, and soon you’re shooting the breeze, talking idly about when your kid started to walk, or how many words he has. Cool Dad is nodding, and then suddenly he’s telling you about this weird thing he and his partner did that involved green tea and cloth diapers, and now their little guy is getting his postdoc at M.I.T., but hey, that’s awesome that your little Lysander can roll over already!

headline: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Sheri Fink Win Book Awards
abstract: Ms. Adichie’s novel told the story of a young woman who moved from Nigeria to the United States to pursue an education.
lead_paragraph: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Sheri Fink were among the winners of the National Book Critics Circle Awards, named Thursday night in New York City. The awards, given annually to books published in the United States in English, are chosen by a group of nearly 600 critics and editors from major publications that cover books.

headline: SXSW Q. and A. | British Starlet Imogen Poots on Acting Opposite (and Dressing Like) André 3000
keywords: ['Movies', 'Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The fast-rising actress discusses her role in the much-anticipated new Jimi Hendrix biopic, directed by “Twelve Years a Slave” scribe John Ridley.
lead_paragraph: There are two principal thrills in the first act of “Jimi: All Is by My Side,” the Jimi Hendrix biopic written and directed by John Ridley, who just won an Oscar for his “12 Years a Slave” screenplay. The first is the way André 3000 portrays Hendrix, with a mix of looseness and intensity. The second is the 24-year-old British actress Imogen Poots, who plays Linda Keith, the London scenester, Vogue model and daughter of posh parents who disdained both music and the fashion world. “I’m not sure what a good English girl is supposed to do,” Poots says in the film, “but apparently shacking up with the Rolling Stones isn’t it.”

headline: Life Intervened
abstract: Tessa Hadley’s episodic novel follows its heroine from childhood in 1960s Britain to the murky waters of middle age.
lead_paragraph: Any novelist who’s ever stood in a bookstore, watching as someone picks up a copy of her book and pauses before returning it to the shelf, knows there’s no logical explanation for why particular books appeal to particular people. Over time, though, readers do tend to make intuitive decisions. Someone who wants a fast-moving story may seek out what she imagines is a plot-driven novel. Someone who wants to spend time in close quarters, getting to know a person like herself, or perhaps like no one she’s ever met, may choose what appears to be a character-­driven novel. And someone who tends to pepper margins with exclamation points, who calls a friend to shout, “Listen to this line!,” may gravitate toward a book preoccupied with language.

headline: In Our Pages: March 15
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Pope Condemns Annexation

headline: Tech’s Favorite Cartoonist Enters Mainstream Publishing
abstract: The online cartoonist Randall Munroe is about to explore a strange new world — mainstream publishing -– and seek out an audience that doesn’t know its Linux from its Lexus.
lead_paragraph: At 29, Randall Munroe still revels in a recent honor that can resemble a lifetime achievement award — an asteroid in orbit between Jupiter and Mars and once known simply as 4942 was renamed last year by the International Astronomical Union as 4942 Munroe.

headline: New York State of Mind
abstract: Four picture books celebrate the city and its signature sights, sounds and buildings.
lead_paragraph: “Wow . . . New York! Just like I pictured it. Skyscrapers and everything.” So murmurs a presumably wide-eyed newcomer during a spoken-word break in Stevie Wonder’s “Living for the City,” and who among us outlanders and former rubes did not feel that same sense of mingled recognition and awe when we first set foot here? Thanks to movies and TV, magazines, the news, books — iconography in general — all of us, even natives, carry a mental suitcase stuffed with received images of the Big Apple. That’s true of children, too, for whom the city’s superlatives (biggest, loudest, tallest) hold a special fascination. You might even say that New York is to other American cities what dinosaurs are to other animals — minus, one hopes, the extinction event. And if we are — or were — lucky children, picture books play a huge role in how we picture the city, from “Eloise” and “The Snowy Day” to “Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile,” “In the Night Kitchen,” “You Can’t Take a Balloon Into the Metropolitan Museum” and “The Man Who Walked Between the Towers.”

headline: Keys to the Kingdom
abstract: Sally Gardner’s beleaguered heroine inherits an abandoned shop, discovering a magical world she never knew existed.
lead_paragraph: Emily Vole, the heroine of “Operation Bunny,” the first book in Sally Gardner’s “Wings & Co.” series, has had, by the age of 9, the kind of transformative experiences that are possible only in fairy tales. Found in a hatbox in Stansted Airport (the modern-day equivalent of being lifted from bulrushes), Emily is adopted by Daisy and Ronald Dashwood. Dark-eyed and solemn while the Dashwoods are blond and shrill, she is found wanting. “There was no getting away from it. The child just didn’t fit in with the Dashwoods’ ancestral color scheme.”

headline: Come Together
abstract: A picture book about one of the original boy bands, those cheeky lads from Liverpool.
lead_paragraph: What must anyone born this century make of the Beatles? They didn’t command attention by swinging naked on demolition balls. They wrote songs called “I Want to Hold Your Hand” and “All You Need Is Love,” sentiments so quaint they’d trigger thousands of snarky tweets if the tunes were released today. They wore matching suits. Without an accompanying CD, download or hyperlink, how can a book convey the revolutionary impact of their music? How can you present the case, as the husband-and-wife team Mick Manning and Brita Granstrom do in “The Beatles,” that “from boy bands to punk rockers and rap singers, you could say it all began with those fresh-faced, cheeky lads from Liverpool”?

headline: Boy Meets Girl
abstract: In this young adult novel, a freshman wakes up on the first day of high school to discover he’s changed sex.
lead_paragraph: For most of us, high school posed logistical challenges. How, for example, should we behave in order to be perceived as cool by kids who are successfully masquerading as cool? And could anyone cool somehow be hoodwinked into hanging out with us? But it seems we had it easy.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The great independent publisher New Directions, around since 1936, had its first New York Times best seller last month, when Takashi Hiraide’s novel “The Guest Cat” briefly surfaced on the trade paperback list.
lead_paragraph: Top Cat: The great independent publisher New Directions has been around since 1936, offering a home to authors including William Carlos Williams, Muriel Spark and Roberto Bolaño. But it didn’t land its first New York Times best seller until last month, when Takashi Hiraide’s novel “The Guest Cat” — a sweet philosophical story (translated from Japanese) about a jaded couple who embrace life again after a neighbor’s cat adopts them — briefly surfaced on the trade paperback list. “It took everyone fantastically by surprise here,” Michael Barron, the publicity director for New Directions, said via email. “We didn’t think it would do this well. . . . Only a few people seemed interested in reviewing it, but one of those was Juan Vidal, a reviewer for NPR Books. His rave review is a testament to the power of social media — it was posted by NPR Books, and then reposted by the main NPR site, which has over a million followers. It got thousands of likes on Facebook, and was heavily retweeted. That same day it was picked up by NPR, we watched as ‘The Guest Cat’ climbed up and up the Amazon sales list to the top 20 sellers. But the big news was when it hit the New York Times best-seller list, our first book ever to do so, and all because of a single review.”

headline: N.Y.C. History
abstract: New books by Terry Golway, Edward P. Kohn, Joseph Tirella and Kevin Cook.
lead_paragraph: MACHINE MADE  Tammany Hall and the Creation of Modern American Politics  By Terry Golway  Liveright, $27.95.

headline: Jamaican Dancehall Star Is Convicted of Murder
abstract: Vybz Kartel and three associates were found guilty of beating a man to death in a dispute over a missing gun.
lead_paragraph: The Jamaican dancehall reggae star Vybz Kartel and three of his associates were found guilty of murder on Thursday evening, the Jamaica Observer reported. He is to be sentenced on March 27.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE STILL POINT OF THE TURNING WORLD,  by Emily Rapp. (Penguin, $16.) When Rapp’s son Ronan was 9 months old, it was discovered that he had Tay-Sachs disease, an untreatable genetic condition. This grief-filled memoir recounts the months that followed, as Rapp tries to make sense of it all and comes to the gradual realization that “writing would not save Ronan. But, I thought, it might save me.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: REDEPLOYMENT,  by Phil Klay. (Penguin Press, $26.95.) Twelve stories by a former Marine who served in Iraq capture on an intimate scale the ways in which the war there evoked a unique array of emotion, predicament and heartbreak.

headline: 220 Are Detained in Raid on a Thai Jungle Camp
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Detainees', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Those arrested are thought to be Uighurs, a Turkic people from western China who have suffered repression from the ethnic Han who rule China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Thai police officers raiding a jungle camp in the hills of southern Thailand have detained about 220 people suspected of being ethnic Uighurs fleeing China, two-thirds of them women and children, according to a Thai police officer and reports in the Thai news media on Friday.

headline: A Family Bond From Court to Pulpit
abstract: The Atlantic 10 tournament brought St. Louis Coach Jim Crews to Brooklyn, where his son, Todd, is an associate pastor and the leader of the young adult program at the Brooklyn Tabernacle.
lead_paragraph: When Jim Crews coached at the University of Evansville — where he spent 17 years — in the early 1990s, he often picked up his son, Todd, at the nearby Holy Rosary Catholic School.

abstract: An inquiry into Metro-North, known as Operation Deep Dive, was prompted by the fatal derailment on Dec. 1 of a Hudson line train in the Bronx that killed four passengers and injured more than 70 others.
lead_paragraph: An inquiry into Metro-North, known as Operation Deep Dive, was prompted by the fatal derailment on Dec. 1 of a Hudson line train in the Bronx that killed four passengers and injured more than 70 others.

headline: Steampunks at Sea
abstract: In many ways, this seemed like an ordinary, modern cruise to the Bahamas. That is, until you ran into the curiously dressed passengers who appeared to be transported from the past.
lead_paragraph: On the first full evening of last month’s second annual Steampunk cruise to the Bahamas, I found myself — in tuxedo and a World War I-era aviator’s cap — marching in a strange parade past the Deck 5 duty-free shops on the Royal Caribbean cruise ship  Explorer of the Seas. Strolling with me were 62 elaborately costumed Victorian re-enactors, including but not restricted to: a Gypsy minstrel playing the accordion, a princess in authentic Turkoman beads, a Russian submarine commander, an African explorer in safari gear, some mustached gentlemen in John Bull top hats and, in her tiara, a 60-year-old woman dressed up as Her Majesty the Queen.

lead_paragraph: This week, Rebecca Traister and Amy Finnerty.

headline: A President’s Struggles in Clinton-Era Memos
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Additional memos from Bill Clinton’s presidency made public by the National Archives mention Colin Powell, George W. Bush and much advice from aides.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the darkest days of Bill Clinton’s presidency, just after voters repudiated him by handing control of Congress to Republicans in the 1994 midterm elections, the politically wounded chief executive and his team prepared a speech in hopes of getting back on his feet and salvaging his administration. His aides were not impressed with what they came up with.

lead_paragraph: Next time you listen to something on Spotify or Beats or Pandora or Rdio, ask yourself: who’s streaming whom?

abstract: Rohingya Muslims, denied citizenship in Myanmar, pass through Thailand on their way to relative safety in Malaysia or, if they cannot afford to pay unscrupulous brokers, languish there.
lead_paragraph: HAT YAI, Thailand — He had already endured a treacherous journey down the Bay of Bengal, squeezed in the belly of a fishing trawler, then squashed in a pickup truck as it hurtled down Thailand’s southern coast. Malaysia, his final destination, was tantalizingly close.

headline: Hop, Skip and a Jump: Rabbit the Easy Way
abstract: The quick route to rabbit involves pan-searing it in herbs, followed by a brief roast in the oven with wine, lemon, olives and feta.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things that supposedly taste like chicken, rabbit is the most convincing.
