headline: On Boycotting Woody Allen’s Films
keywords: ['Movies', 'Boycotts', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Is watching a movie an endorsement of the person who made it?
lead_paragraph: I was discussing with a friend whether it is permissible to boycott Woody Allen’s films in the wake of the sexual-abuse allegations. We both thought it would be wrong to further empower someone who may have sexually abused a child. But our legal system is built on the principle that the accused are innocent until proved guilty, and preserving that value is important whether or not you believe the allegations. Is it permissible in this case to boycott, or should we presume innocence? J.K., NEW YORK

headline: Settlement Reached in Cy Twombly Foundation Lawsuit
abstract: Two of the foundations four directors will resign their positions.
lead_paragraph: The foundation of the artist Cy Twombly, who died in 2011, has reached a settlement in a bitter legal battle against two of its directors, who were accused in civil court of taking unauthorized fees and of engineering inflated appraisals for artwork to pad their commissions.

headline: High Levels of Pollution Spur Paris to Action
abstract: Unusually high levels of air pollution, which prompted warnings from the Health Ministry, were expected to continue unabated through the weekend.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Parisians taking public transportation to work on Friday were surprised and delighted to find free subways and buses for the next three days, but the reason was a bit less cheerful: Air pollution had reached an unusually high level and was expected to continue unabated through the weekend.

headline: Reminder to Politicians: That Microphone May Still Be Live
abstract: An open mike caught Senator Lindsey Graham telling Secretary of State John Kerry, “Let me know what I can do to help you with Boehner.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham has witnessed enough congressional hearings to know: If you want to have a side conversation, cover that microphone.

headline: A New Brand for Red Roof
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Red Roof Plus+ will offer premium rooms with microwaves, refrigerators, free Wi-Fi and other amenities.
lead_paragraph: Marriott has the Ritz-Carlton. Hilton has the Waldorf Astoria. And now Red Roof Inn has Red Roof Plus+.

headline: The Rock Boat: Booze, Battles and 32 Bands
abstract: On a cruise between Miami and the Bahamas, live music is just the beginning of the fun.
lead_paragraph: On a music cruise, could there be anything better than discovering a great band you hadn’t heard before? Yes, helping that band annihilate a rival rock group in a shipboard soccer game in front of a cheering crowd.

headline: Crocodiles and Culture on a Cruise in West Africa
abstract: Views of wildlife, encounters with locals and connections with history are all part of a boat trip from Senegal through Gambia.
lead_paragraph: The radiant sun was starting its late-afternoon descent, leaving behind pleasantly warm air, and I was gliding on glassy water through a Gambian archipelago of tropical rain-forest islands in a brightly painted boat, a converted ferry with an upper deck and even a soft-drink bar. Propped against pillows with my feet up, I was as comfortable as Cleopatra on her royal barge. Suddenly, Assan, our guide, spotted our goal: a big, black chimpanzee sitting on the wet, brown shoreline, eating fruit. And then there was another one, with a baby chimp swinging from its belly, high up in the trees.

headline: Choose Your Own Cruise

lead_paragraph: Follow our flow chart to see which type of cruise might suit your tastes and needs.

lead_paragraph: Look at the front page of any day’s New York Times  and you’ll find plenty for teenagers to discuss, whether meaty matters of global geopolitics, or lifestyle topics that hit closer to home.

headline: A City of Madness, Bypassed by the N.C.A.A.
abstract: Many college conferences stage postseason basketball tournaments in Las Vegas, but the N.C.A.A., concerned about gambling, has long refused to place any of its tournament games in the city.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — In three arenas strung along a three-mile stretch of Tropicana Avenue, 19 postseason men’s college basketball games were played on Wednesday and Thursday. The games attracted tens of thousands of fans, with many more watching on television. They were played under rules set by the N.C.A.A., college basketball’s governing body.

headline: Movie Review: 'Veronica Mars'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Veronica Mars."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Veronica Mars."

headline: Why Kids Love a (Minor) ‘Crisis’
abstract: When a friend’s car slid off our driveway into three-foot drifts of snow, it was all hands on deck, and a reminder that everyone, children included, likes to be needed.
lead_paragraph: It snowed a little bit here in New Hampshire. A little bit, as in we stopped counting after the first foot and a half, and the children had two days off from school, and the wind blew and the snow piled up and we lost the driveway. One of my 9-year-old daughter’s friends was with us for the duration, but after it was all over, her family’s au pair set off to pick her up on the evening of the second day (both of her parents are doctors with call responsibilities).

headline: USEC Bankruptcy Shakes Up Creditor Line
abstract: The Chapter 11 bankruptcy case of USEC, which processes uranium for power plants, is not strictly following the rule of who gets paid first.
lead_paragraph: There is theory and then there is actual practice. The Chapter 11 bankruptcy case of USEC, which processes uranium for power plants, provides a nice reminder.

headline: Movie Review: 'Need for Speed'

lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Need for Speed."

headline: As Living Standards Fall for Seniors, Some See Signs of ‘Silver Revolution’
abstract: While the seniors rights movement remains relatively muted, intensifying fear about retirement security could spur elderly agitators into the streets.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE Boston police detained Ann A. Stewart last August, she had a clean record. But she vows not to wait long, certainly not another 89 years, to become a repeat offender.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra’s Principal Clarinetist Extends Stay in Los Angeles
abstract: Burt Hara has extended his leave of absence from Minnesota to continue as the principal clarinetist of the Los Angeles Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Orchestra has been working hard to rebuild after a polarizing 16-month lockout that has left it without its renowned music director, Osmo Vanska, as well as several players who have taken leaves of absence, some to try out positions with other orchestras.

headline: For Starters, the Upper East Side
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restaurants', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Low rents draw more young people to the Upper East Side than its stodgy reputation would suggest. Restaurateurs have taken note.
lead_paragraph: Julie Murray shares an apartment with a friend on 95th Street near First Avenue. The building is respectably maintained, it’s true, and the bathroom is a reasonable size. There’s an elevator, and Ms. Murray, 22, a college senior hoping to work in the fashion industry, has her own room.

headline: Instant Replay in Baseball? Stranger Things Have Happened
abstract: Released in October, Steve Rushin’s “The 34-Ton Bat” traces the iconography of our national pastime and shows that the game has always mixed elements of creationism and evolution.
lead_paragraph: Just like the serendipitous collision of peanut butter and chocolate in the Reese’s Peanut Butter Cup ads of the 1980s, two of my favorite things — the magazine’s Who Made That? column and baseball — have met to form a more perfect union. While waiting for the baseball season to begin, I have been thoroughly enjoying Steve Rushin’s “The 34-Ton Bat: The Story of Baseball as Told Through Bobbleheads, Cracker Jacks, Jock Straps, Eye Black and 375 Other Strange and Unforgettable Objects.”

headline: Graham's Hot Mic Offer to 'Help' Kerry
abstract: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina was caught on an open microphone offering to help Secretary of State John Kerry following his testimony at a Senate hearing on Ukraine assistance.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina was caught on an open microphone offering to help Secretary of State John Kerry following his testimony at a Senate hearing on Ukraine assistance.

keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'E-Commerce', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Online Advertising', 'Small Business', 'Social Media']

lead_paragraph: Josh Opperman was a 27-year-old in love, living in New York City, when he realized his pending nuptials were not going to happen. He tried selling his $10,000 engagement ring on eBay and Craigslist but the best offer he got was just 35 percent of the price he had paid.

lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A Chinese activist who fell gravely ill after being detained last fall died Friday of a lung infection, her brother said.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:38 p.m. | The Chinese Internet industry is coming of age, as some of its biggest players prepare to start new chapters as publicly traded companies — in the United States.

abstract: The agreement would bring the college basketball powerhouses Duke, North Carolina and Syracuse to Barclays Center for at least two March tournaments starting in 2017.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Coast Conference will hold its men’s basketball tournament at Barclays Center in Brooklyn in 2017 and 2018, a person with knowledge of the deal said Friday.

headline: Big Ticket | Rupert Murdoch Pays $43 Million for Bachelor Pad
abstract: The newly single media tycoon Rupert Murdoch closes on a downtown triplex penthouse, delivered raw so he can create his own design.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, the newly single media tycoon, has acquired the triplex penthouse that crowns One Madison, the 60-story sliver of bronze glass designed by CetraRuddy, for $43,010,000. A 6,850-square-foot sponsor unit, it was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Together Forever, Hypothetically
abstract: A pair of single New Yorkers on the cusp of 40 play out their visions of long-term love in a breezy musical.
lead_paragraph: The round-robin style of mating dance known as speed dating is the premise for “Date of a Lifetime,” a modest, appealing, two-actor musical that is currently being given a lively production by the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

headline: For Boarding Schools, an Evolving Financial Aid Philosophy
keywords: ['Financial Aid (Education)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Some families making as much as $300,000 are applying for help — and getting it — which shuts out those further down the income ladder.
lead_paragraph: ERIC LONG dreaded answering his phone this week at Tabor Academy in Marion, Mass., while across the country at the Webb Schools in Claremont, Calif., Leo Marshall let the switchboard screen his calls.

headline: In Rare Case, Woman With H.I.V. Infects Female Sex Partner, C.D.C. Says
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Women and Girls', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Health officials said this was the first confirmed instance of such transmission of the virus.
lead_paragraph: The first confirmed case of lesbian transmission of H.I.V. was reported on Thursday by federal health officials, who said the event was exceedingly rare but nonetheless advised lesbian couples in which one partner is infected to take precautions.

headline: Restoration Rings From the Rafters of the Hudson Opera House
abstract: The Hudson Opera House, perhaps the oldest surviving theater in New York State, will begin restoration of the auditorium, its biggest project yet.
lead_paragraph: Gary Schiro, the executive director of the Hudson Opera House, is a confirmed workaholic, often loath to delegate even loathsome tasks. So until the holes in the roof of that Hudson landmark were repaired six years ago, he regularly found himself, net in hand, chasing down pigeons that had made their way into the disused auditorium on the second floor.

headline: Remembering Always to Say What Matters Most
abstract: The couple met while working for Hillary Rodham Clinton.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of their relationship, in Washington, a place where no three words seem ever to be spoken without having been carefully considered beforehand, Lauren Jiloty and Steve Slupski found how easy it can be to fail to communicate simply by neglecting to say what matters most.

headline: A Dragnet at Dewey & LeBoeuf Snares a Minnow
abstract: Zachary Warren, a low-level employee at the once-giant law firm, was the unwitting target of an increasingly common prosecutorial tactic called parallel construction.
lead_paragraph: “You’ve been indicted,” an assistant Manhattan district attorney, Peirce Moser, told Zachary Warren, a 29-year-old magna cum laude graduate of Georgetown Law School with a prestigious clerkship on the Federal Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Memphis.

headline: Witness Accounts and Video of a Deadly Attack by Russian Separatists in Ukraine Undercut Kremlin Claims
abstract: The morning after journalists watched a pro-Russia mob attack peaceful protesters in the eastern Ukrainian city of Donetsk, leaving at least one young demonstrator dead, Russia’s foreign ministry claimed that the exact opposite had occurred.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:49 p.m. | The morning after journalists, including my colleague Andrew Roth, watched a pro-Russia mob attack peaceful protesters in the eastern Ukrainian city of Donetsk, leaving at least one young demonstrator dead, Russia’s foreign ministry released a statement on Friday claiming that the exact opposite had occurred, and warning ominously that Russia “reserves the right to protect” ethnic Russians in Ukraine.

headline: Actors Who Know Cute Is Not Enough
abstract: On TV dramas and comedies alike, young actors are turning in performances that are remarkable for their nuance, comic timing or sheer likability.
lead_paragraph: With all of the fine grown-up acting on television these days, it’s easy to overlook the excellent work being done by the younger set and, in some cases, the considerably younger set.

headline: Despite a Senate Deal, the Jobless Still Wait for Aid
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The deal still isn’t good enough for many House Republicans, and as long as they continue getting re-elected the jobless will continue to wait.
lead_paragraph: For three months, more than 2 million jobless people who lost their unemployment benefits have been watching their wallets shrink as they wait for Republicans to decide whether they are worthy of getting the benefits back. It used to be that extensions of this aid were routinely approved by both parties when unemployment is high, but today’s Republicans have to demonstrate the necessary callousness to the party base before a few eventually do the right thing.

headline: Prewar Apartments from Scratch
abstract: Developers are building entirely from the ground up, in a style harking back to the era before World War II.
lead_paragraph: Developers have long profited from renovating out-of-date prewar apartment buildings to create interiors pleasing to today’s buyers. But many are now building entirely from the ground up, in a style harking back to the era before World War II; the trend is particularly evident on the limestone-clad Upper East Side.

headline: How to Get to Spontaneity? Practice
abstract: A new classical recording invokes the goal of impromptu greatness, but overrehearsal can threaten inspired improvisation.
lead_paragraph: To borrow a term from the Olympics, the technical element of playing classical music demands formidable skills and continual work. The ultimate goal is for an artist to be so assured that a performance exudes spontaneity.

headline: Saved by Martha Graham
abstract: Lloyd Mayor, with the Martha Graham Dance Company, discusses his childhood and his deep connection to Graham in advance of the company’s new season at City Center.
lead_paragraph: No offense to one of the mothers of modern dance, but most aspiring dancers don’t dream of joining the Martha Graham Dance Company. For one, she died in 1991; much of the repertory — some of it timeless, some of it outmoded — dates to the last century. But Lloyd Mayor, born in Geneva to a British mother and Swiss father, is not your typical 20-year-old. “It had to do with the mind,” he said. “The work was really talking about shame and empathy and vulnerability, and they are not to be romanticized.”

headline: Ancient Grains for Breakfast
abstract: I rarely look at the breakfast cereals on the shelves in the supermarket, as it’s easier and cheaper for me to put together my own combos, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this week’s Recipes for Health.
lead_paragraph: I had already decided that this week I would play around with breakfast grains when I noticed that food manufacturers are also coming up with new ideas. I rarely look at the breakfast cereals on the shelves in the supermarket or at Trader Joe’s, as it’s easier and cheaper for me to put together my own combos. But this week, as I reached for a container of steel-cut oats, I noticed several prepared mixes of grains and seeds like oats, quinoa and flax, mostly for hot cereal, that I hadn’t seen before.

headline: Two Exhibitions, From Cover to Cover
abstract: The Westport Historical Society is exhibiting covers of The New Yorker by 17 artists from the town and is examining the 1946 issue devoted to John Hersey’s “Hiroshima.”
lead_paragraph: Perusing her copy of “The Complete Book of Covers From The New Yorker 1925-1989,” Eve Potts of the Westport Historical Society recognized scene after familiar scene.

headline: Kerry Speaks After Talks With Lavrov
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference after his meeting with the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, about the Ukrainian crisis ahead of a referendum on Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference after his meeting with the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, about the Ukrainian crisis ahead of a referendum on Crimea.

headline: NYT Now: Kerry Reviews Talks With Lavrov
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference after his meeting with the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, about the Ukrainian crisis before a referendum on Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a news conference after his meeting with the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, about the Ukrainian crisis before a referendum on Crimea.

headline: Wheelies: The Ford Legacy Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: Ford dedicates $1 million to William Clay Ford design scholarship; G.M. faces three empty seats on its board of directors.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Russia Moves Swiftly to Stifle Dissent Ahead of Secession Vote
abstract: With the implicit threat of force, the Kremlin has succeeded in stifling dissent in the Crimean Peninsula, recreating the constrained conditions of Russia’s own civic sphere.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Early this month, Russian soldiers took up positions at the television transmission center here in the capital of the Ukrainian region of Crimea. Their arrival was part of a broad effort to muffle dissent over the Kremlin-backed project to guide Crimea through a swift secession from Ukraine.

headline: Review: 2014 Ford Flex
abstract: Unapologetically original, the Ford Flex is for families that want a vacation from ordinary vans and crossovers.
lead_paragraph: Unapologetically original, the Ford Flex is for families that want a vacation from ordinary vans and crossovers.

headline: Mammography’s Limits, Seldom Understood
abstract: It was tough to persuade women to begin getting regular mammograms. Decades later, it’s tough getting older women to stop.
lead_paragraph: A sad fact: None of the eight major clinical trials looking at whether regular mammograms reduce a woman’s risk of dying from breast cancer has included women over age 75.

headline: 2 Choices in Crimea Referendum, but Neither Is ‘No’
abstract: The ballot referendum will present two options for the region: joining Russia or increasing its autonomy within the Ukrainian government.
lead_paragraph: Crimea will vote on Sunday in a ballot referendum that leaders of the regional Parliament expect will ratify their decision to break away from Ukraine and become part of Russia. The referendum will offer two choices, neither one of them “no”:

headline: The Struggles Can’t Dim the Sparks
abstract: A couple married at age 58 dealt with their share of medical problems.
lead_paragraph: Mike Riezenman had been making frequent stays in hospitals and nursing homes, sometimes for months at a time, for the last four and a half years. But that did not make his death in January at age 73 any easier to bear for his wife, Paula Riezenman.

headline: A Timeless California Enclave Fears a City’s Sway
abstract: In Wood Colony, descendants of Anabaptist settlers farm in an unspoiled landscape and keep to the old ways. But they fear that is about to change.
lead_paragraph: MODESTO, Calif. — Farmers and other residents of the rural district known as Wood Colony refer to the 110-year-old arboreal landmark in their midst — a gigantic walnut tree of Grimm’s fairy-tale proportions — as, simply, the Tree. To many people in this unincorporated community, settled more than a century ago by a religious group called the Old German Baptist Brethren, the mighty tree is a kind of tabernacle, a living testament to the district’s deep roots, fertile soil and unshakable resolve.

headline: The Journalist and the Public Editor: On Joe McGinniss ‘in the Mix’
abstract: The late author sent plenty of email to the public editor.
lead_paragraph: Often admired, often criticized — but seldom ignored — the distinctive journalistic figure and author Joe McGinniss died this week at age 71.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Board Recommends Shareholders Vote Against Dividend
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Warren E. Buffett prefers to use Berkshire Hathaway’s huge cash pile to buy up companies, rather than return it to shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett prefers to use Berkshire Hathaway’s huge cash pile to buy up companies, rather than return it to shareholders.

headline: Eric Decker Says What He Values Most Is Jets’ Respect
abstract: The Jets won Decker over, he said, by giving him a five-year, $36.25 million contract and penciling him in as the No. 1 receiver, after the Broncos did not re-sign him.
lead_paragraph: After catching 172 passes, 24 for touchdowns, from Peyton Manning in the past two seasons, receiver Eric Decker was a bit baffled that the Denver Broncos did not value his contributions enough to offer him a contract as a free agent this off-season. That is why Decker said he was so won over by the Jets’ pitch for his services. In offering a five-year, $36.25 million contract and penciling him in as the No. 1 receiver, the Jets made him feel valued.

headline: ISS Debut Gives Less-Than-Stellar Return for Goldman and EQT
abstract: The successful stock-market debut of ISS, a cleaning and catering group based in Denmark, has brought a huge return to the Danish family behind the toy maker Lego but not as much for its other owners, wrote Quentin Webb in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Lego has trumped Goldman Sachs in the $1.5 billion flotation of ISS, a cleaning and catering group based in Denmark.

headline: J. K. Rowling Publishes First Part of ‘History of the Quidditch World Cup’
abstract: The author of the “Harry Potter” series posted the first part of a history of the imaginary game to her fan site, pottermore.com.
lead_paragraph: If you were unable to get enough of Harry Potter and his magical world, J. K. Rowling has added just a bit more to the legend – a footnote – on the web page Pottermore.com, which she introduced in 2011. On Friday, Mrs. Rowling posted the first part of her “History of the Quidditch World Cup,” an expansive description of the game that Harry and his Hogwarts colleagues play, using flying broomsticks, throughout the series.

headline: Making It Last
abstract: Paula Riezenman shares some lessons she learned during her 14 year marriage.
lead_paragraph: Paula Riezenman offers some lessons learned about marriage from her more than 14 years with Mike Riezenman, who died in January.

headline: The Gun Report: March 14, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Shyanne Roberts stood up at a New Jersey Assembly hearing yesterday and asserted her right to bear arms. “I am not a gangbanger or domestic terrorist,” she told the Law and Public Safety Committee, speaking against a bill that would limit the magazine capacity of firearms to 10 rounds from the current 15-round maximum. The bill passed the committee 5 to 3.

headline: The Science of ‘Paying It Forward’
abstract: How generosity among strangers becomes socially contagious.
lead_paragraph: ONE morning in December of 2012, at the drive-through window of a Tim Hortons coffee shop in Winnipeg, Manitoba, a customer paid for her order and then picked up the tab for the stranger in the car behind her in line. Then that customer paid the bill for the following customer in line — and so on, for the next 226 customers, in a three-hour sequence of spontaneous generosity.

headline: Refurbishing a Museum Wing and Its Trophies
abstract: The Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum’s restoration of its Stoll Wing has included bear teeth, moose lips and a walrus’s eye, as stuffed animal heads were taken in for repairs.
lead_paragraph: To hear George Dante describe them, you would think the animals whose stuffed heads he carted away in October from the Suffolk County Vanderbilt Museum had been in a rowdy bar fight. The mule deer, he said, had a bashed-in skull and an antler hanging by a thread. The black bear’s teeth were broken. And let’s not even talk about the poor moose with their mangled ears and split lips.

headline: Video: What Is a Ford Flex, Anyway?
abstract: Although the Ford Flex is vaguely defined as a crossover, the roomy, utilitarian wagon doesn’t really fit into any current category.
lead_paragraph: Escape, Fusion, Focus, F-150 and Explorer are Ford vehicles with instant name recognition. Flex? No, I’m not asking you to a yoga class. Flex is a family crossover that needs a new agent.

headline: Please Don’t Call Me Mom
abstract: Perhaps these situations sound familiar. A nurse says to me, “Mom, how many hours does she sleep at night?” An activity leader: “Mom, pick-up is at 6.” A sales clerk: “Mom, do we need another size?” I’m not their mom.
lead_paragraph: Not to be disrespectful (although I’ve started explaining to my children that a statement beginning this way usually is), but it drives me crazy when someone other than my kids addresses me as Mom.

headline: Apartment Hunting With a Mobile App
abstract: The app Movement introduced in May is not a comprehensive listing of New York units, but the results are up-to-date and not from third parties.
lead_paragraph: Movement, an app introduced in May, is the best platform I’ve found for apartment searching on a mobile phone, something that might eventually help to curb the misery of the apartment search experience. I say “eventually” because even as the app has experienced impressive growth since its most recent update, it lacks the kind of comprehensive listings that would make it truly invaluable.

headline: BRIC Arts Center Starts a Cable Channel Focused on Brooklyn
abstract: The programming, which begins Monday, will include arts coverage, public affairs, sports and other shows produced by local residents.
lead_paragraph: Forget about those hours of badly lit, single-camera chat shows set in drab studios, to say nothing of Wayne and Garth partying on in the basement: BRIC, the contemporary arts center in Brooklyn, is introducing Brooklyn Independent Media, a round-the-clock cable channel, on Monday, and its directors promise that it won’t be your grandfather’s public-access station.

headline: Shock as Militants Attack Nigerian Military Prison
abstract: Militants suspected of being members of Boko Haram attacked a military prison in northern Nigeria, freeing some of their comrades but also suffering heavy losses.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Militants suspected of being members of the group Boko Haram carried out a daring daylight raid early Friday on a heavily guarded military prison in northern Nigeria, freeing some of their comrades but also suffering heavy losses, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Hunting Honey, and Trying to Hide
abstract: An ancient tradition of hunting honey on Nepalese cliffsides is in danger of vanishing from excessive tourism — and even photographers.
lead_paragraph: An ancient tradition of hunting honey on Nepalese cliffsides is in danger of vanishing from excessive tourism — and even photographers.

headline: Austria Holds Ukrainian Pending Extradition Decision
abstract: A court ruled that it would continue to hold Dmitry V. Firtash, a billionaire with ties to Ukraine’s ousted president, and set bail at $174 million after his arrest on an American warrant.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — An Austrian court ruled on Friday that it would continue to hold a Ukrainian businessman, identified as Dmitry V. Firtash, a billionaire with close ties to his country’s ousted president, and set bail at 125 million euros, or $174 million, after his arrest this week on an American warrant.

headline: What’s Real Gets More Creative
abstract: Recent documentary films like “The Missing Picture” and “Stories We Tell” are making clear how the form has expanded well beyond journalistic approaches.
lead_paragraph: The very first movies were, in their way, documentaries: snippets that showed the trot of a horse, a smoke-belching train pulling into a station or Queen Victoria’s Diamond Jubilee procession. But the paths of fiction and nonfiction film soon diverged, and they remain distinct today, each with separate standards and expectations and consigned to separate categories at festivals and the Oscars.

headline: A Bandleader and His Repertoire of Songs
abstract: Tommy Mulvihill and his band play four nights a week and know about 2,000 popular songs, but they play only what the audience requests.
lead_paragraph: Minutes into his first set on Monday night, Tommy Mulvihill looked down the long bar and announced, “You can ask us to play anything you want.”

headline: It’s Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to the NYT Motherlode’s first open thread. Got thoughts about news and family this week? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s first open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Greenwich Village: No Dowel Left Unturned
abstract: A gut-renovated Greek Revival-style townhouse is about to enter the market at $14.95 million.
lead_paragraph: A fancifully renovated Greek Revival-style Greenwich Village townhouse, part of a historic enclave of eight brick homes built on a serene stretch of Waverly Place in 1839 by Lambert Suydam, a former president of the Manhattan Gas Light Company and later the New York Fire Insurance Company, is about to enter the market at $14.95 million.

headline: By Any Name, a Doughnut Destination
abstract: Shaikh’s Place, a popular 24-hour doughnut shop, also draws guests looking for company or tacos.
lead_paragraph: There are three types of customers at Shaikh’s Place, a 24-hour coffee shop on Avenue U near the southern end of Brooklyn: those who come for the company, those who come for the tacos and those who come for the doughnuts.

headline: Face to Face With Blog Contributors: Can Familiarity Breed Conviviality?
abstract: A call for blog comment contributors to show their faces.
lead_paragraph: [Production note | I’m taking eight Pace University students to Brazil for 10 days starting tonight (to make a film on tourism and the environment) so comment moderation and posting may be sporadic.]

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Start-Up Seeks to Capitalize on Security Concerns for Bitcoins
abstract: Xapo, a start-up from a tech entrepreneur promises security, backed by an insurer, to store Bitcoins.
lead_paragraph: After living with hyperinflation, currency fluctuations and minimal access to credit in his country, Wences Casares, an Argentine raised on a sheep farm, says he has the vision and team to make Bitcoin more widespread and accepted worldwide.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, London, France and New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, London, France and New York.

headline: SXSW 2014: The Music Plays On After a Somber Scene
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: For a music critic, and for the thousands who came to play and attend shows, the festival had to continue even after a deadly car crash.
lead_paragraph: There’s not much a music critic can say about the car crash that killed two people at SXSW and injured at least 23. A few blocks of Red River Street, where the Mohawk is, hold a long strip of clubs. At 12:30 p.m. on Wednesday night, many of them were busy if not spilling out onto the street, which was as usual blocked off for pedestrians who expected nothing more hazardous than an encounter with a clumsy drunk on foot, when the car crashed through. It could have been any crowded city street with a car out of control, but it was SXSW.

headline: Pharrell’s Phragrance, Karl’s Custom Emojis and Obama’s Shopping Trip
abstract: Plus, Vogue Italia’s controversy-baiting editorial, Tehran goes mad for models and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: Scent of a multihyphenateComme des Garçons announced Wednesday that this fall they will release a unisex scent called Girl in collaboration with the ubiquitous, giant-hat-wearing, perfect-skin-having superstar Pharrell Williams. What will it smell like? Billionaires? Boys? Clubs?

headline: The Celebrity in the Apron at Gato
abstract: Gato, at 324 Lafayette Street in NoHo, is the first new restaurant in New York by Bobby Flay in nine years.
lead_paragraph: With vaulted brick ceilings and big bold lighting fixtures, Gato reveals two notable reincarnations. Bobby Flay, the celebrity chef and brand, has opened a new restaurant in New York for the first time in nine years, and it is in a 100-year-old NoHo space at 324 Lafayette Street that previously housed a Bowery Residents’ Committee treatment center. Now the well-heeled, the early adopters, the neighborhood families and the restaurant industry types mingle at the center bar and on leather banquettes. Mr. Flay, apron-clad, is visible to diners through the kitchen’s glass window. His business partner, Laurence Kretchmer, roamed the brightly tiled floor on Tuesday after a week’s soft opening. The room was humming, at a manageable level. Mr. Kretchmer said they had kept some tables empty so the restaurant could have time to settle. Zesty Mediterranean dishes arrived on plates of various shapes, as the solicitous staff watched Flay fans and old friends digest the novelty.

headline: Search for Bodies Yields to Hunt for a Cause of East Harlem Explosion
abstract: Workers found pockets of up to 20 percent methane underground at the site of the explosion in East Harlem, and Mayor Bill de Blasio said the city would help find prolonged shelter for the dozens of families displaced by the blast.
lead_paragraph: After an eighth body was extricated from the rubble of two buildings in East Harlem that were leveled by an explosion, fire and safety officials began on Friday narrowing in on what caused the blast.

headline: A Fistful of Movie Scores
abstract: Ennio Morricone, who has composed music for more than 450 films, is being celebrated in a three-day program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made of the prodigious musical output of Ennio Morricone, the Italian film composer whose scores have accompanied six decades’ worth of films, from spaghetti westerns like “A Fistful of Dollars” and “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly” to several pictures starring Robert De Niro, like “The Untouchables” and “The Mission.” When asked to pick a favorite among the bunch, he refused, falling back on that old chestnut about them all being his children, so how could he pick just one?

headline: Links to the Past
abstract: The Amelia Island Concours d’Élégance featured antique and collectible vehicles and high-powered racing machines feted over three idyllic days in the Florida sunshine.
lead_paragraph: The Amelia Island Concours d’Élégance featured antique and collectible vehicles and high-powered racing machines feted over three idyllic days in the Florida sunshine.

headline: A Beating Heart, a Social Conscience and a Deluge of Ideas
abstract: New music by Ana Tijoux, the War on Drugs, Tunde Olaniran, the Notwist and the Bad Plus.
lead_paragraph: Ana Tijoux

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin Begins to Look Beyond the Slalom
abstract: Shiffrin, who won a gold medal in slalom at the Sochi Games, wants to compete for overall skiing titles on the World Cup circuit and will next focus on her super-G skills.
lead_paragraph: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland — In the weeks after the Olympic slalom champion Mikaela Shiffrin caps the best season of her young career Sunday, she plans to have her wisdom teeth removed and to visit her grandmother — regular teenager stuff.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg’s Call to Obama Was Not About Privacy
abstract: What Facebook’s founder is really concerned about is Internet security, which also happens to protect the interests of his company.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg is not happy with the way the American government conducts surveillance on the Internet, so much so that he called President Obama to complain about it and then wrote a post Thursday on Facebook to vent his frustration. “The U.S. government should be the champion for the internet, not a threat,” he said.

headline: An Athlete With a Nervous Condition
abstract: With the 2014 CLA45 AMG 4Matic, Mercedes’s in-house tuner shop is working with 4 cylinders for the first time.
lead_paragraph: AMG, the in-house tuner shop for Mercedes-Benz, has consistently found ways to push the performance abilities of production vehicles without betraying their luxurious nature. The AMG machines can be ridiculously powerful, but they’ve also been as fully useful and indomitable as any other Mercedes.

headline: Music-and-Wine Formula, Multiplied
abstract: The live music club City Winery is expanding beyond its flagship Manhattan space, to Nashville, Napa and beyond.
lead_paragraph: As the crowd settled in for a Steve Earle concert at City Winery one night last month, Michael Dorf, the club’s founder, was busy hunting for candles.

headline: Questionable Breeding
abstract: The new CLA250 compact sedan looks like a member of the Benz family, but it’s a mix of royal bloodlines and peasant genes.
lead_paragraph: The new CLA250 compact sedan looks like a member of the Benz family, but it’s a mix of royal bloodlines and peasant genes.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Designers of a Williamsburg Look
abstract: Raúl Arévalo and Bradley Schmidt, the founders of Cadet, a men’s wear company, find life in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, inspiring.
lead_paragraph: When Raúl Arévalo and Bradley Schmidt bought an apartment in north Williamsburg in 2007, they had no aspirations to become emblems of Brooklyn style. They were economic refugees from Manhattan who had discovered they could afford to buy a three-bedroom duplex with a rooftop deck that was a major step up from their previous home in Chelsea.

headline: Under Cover: Illustrating Silicon Valley’s Discontents
abstract: Our interview with Tim Enthoven, an illustrator based in the Netherlands who drew the cover image for this week’s story on the rift between the generations in Silicon Valley’s tech industry.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday’s cover story about the rift between the generations in Silicon Valley’s tech industry was illustrated by Tim Enthoven. I interviewed Enthoven, who is based in the Netherlands and whose previous work for the magazine includes the cover illustration for the Nov. 13, 2011, issue, about his inspiration for the face-off between the middle-aged engineer and the hipster techie.

headline: Scott Brown Moves One Step Closer to a Senate Bid
abstract: After a year of flirtations and coy poses, Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, said he had formed an exploratory committee to prepare a campaign for the Senate from New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H. — After a year of flirtations, coy poses and even a shirtless plunge into frigid waters for a charitable cause, Scott Brown, the former senator from Massachusetts, took his biggest step yet on Friday toward a campaign for the Senate from New Hampshire.

headline: Sushi Restaurant Owner Reconnects With His Italian Roots
abstract: After spending the week at his Manhattan restaurant, Sushi Nakazawa, Alessandro Borgognone returns to his family roots on his day off with an Italian meal.
lead_paragraph: Alessandro Borgognone, 33, comes from a family that runs Italian restaurants, but he took a detour to found Sushi Nakazawa, named for its chef, Daisuke Nakazawa. The restaurant, which opened in August in the West Village, was awarded four stars in The New York Times. Sundays, when Sushi Nakazawa is closed, are devoted to family and the Italian-style feast, which can include roasted peppers, salumi, braciola and pasta, Mr. Borgognone’s favorite. He lives in the Grymes Hill section of Staten Island with his wife, Anna, 33, and their three girls: Patrizia, 8, Olivia, 6, and Stella, who was born in May.

headline: Radar Suggests Jet Shifted Path More Than Once
abstract: A military radar track appeared to show that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 climbed to 45,000 feet after disappearing from civilian radar and altered its course as if still under a pilot’s command.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 experienced significant changes in altitude after it lost contact with ground control, and altered its course more than once as if still under the command of a pilot, American officials and others familiar with the investigation said Friday.

headline: Orient-Express Hotels Gets a New Name
abstract: Orient-Express Hotels is now called Belmond.
lead_paragraph: Orient-Express Hotels, more than decade old,  and with  45 luxury hotels, as well as trains, safari camps and river cruises in its collection, got a new name this week: The London-based brand is now called Belmond.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 14
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes snow removal in Bryant Park, a restored landmark in Brooklyn and the aftermath of an explosion in East Harlem.
lead_paragraph: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Sensors Could Put Cars a Step Ahead of Their Drivers
abstract: A Mercedes project to develop what it calls the predictive user experience will observe how drivers and passengers use a car to anticipate their wants.
lead_paragraph: If a car already knows where you like your seat positioned, what radio stations you favor and how you want the air-conditioning set, would you be more likely to buy it?

headline: Benz on a Budget, Angling for Youngsters
abstract: The Mercedes-Benz CLA250 compact sedan is stylish, but also quite conventional. And don’t be fooled by that $30,000 price tag.
lead_paragraph: If Leonardo Da Vinci had painted dogs playing poker on black velvet, would it necessarily be a masterpiece? It would be a genuine Da Vinci, but not every Da Vinci is the Mona Lisa.

headline: To Change Tunes, a Nod Will Be as Good as a Wink
abstract: Automakers, including Mercedes-Benz and Ford, are cautiously installing gesture sensing systems that read hand and head motions as computer commands.
lead_paragraph: Hand gestures from other drivers are a lot like trash talk at playground basketball games: provocative distractions from an otherwise engaging activity.

headline: In Florida, New Stars on Block
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Auctions', 'Antique and Classic Cars', "Amelia Island Concours d'Elegance (Car Show)"]
abstract: The breakout star at auctions associated with the 19th annual Amelia Island Concours d’Élégance was the 1958 BMW 507, as two models broke records at separate events.
lead_paragraph: AMELIA ISLAND, FLA. — The 19th annual Amelia Island Concours d’Élégance went off largely according to script last weekend, with antique and collectible vehicles, high-powered racing machines and famous personalities feted over three idyllic days in the Florida sunshine.

headline: Vibrations, but Not Good Ones
abstract: Cadillacs with lights that seem to have a mind of their own and Jeep Wranglers that overheat are among the latest technical service bulletins.
lead_paragraph: Cadillacs with lights that seem to have a mind of their own and Jeep Wranglers that overheat are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

headline: Knicks Turn to Jackson to Resuscitate the Team
abstract: The winner of 11 N.B.A. titles as coach of the Bulls and the Lakers, Phil Jackson brings instant credibility to a franchise that desperately needs it.
lead_paragraph: A huge rebuilding project will soon begin in Midtown Manhattan, where the Knicks have turned to Phil Jackson, a former coach with unrivaled credentials, to run the front office and restore order to the shambles at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Scenes From the Streets of Venezuela
abstract: Venezuela is a country divided between Chavistas, supporters of President Nicolás Maduro, and anti-government protesters who have taken their political differences to the streets.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela is a country divided between Chavistas, supporters of President Nicolás Maduro, and anti-government protesters who have taken their political differences to the streets.

headline: SXSW 2014: Lady Gaga’s Keynote Message — ‘Don’t Sell Out’
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: Her own career, she said, had depended on being herself and ignoring frequent advice to conform.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — When Lady Gaga made her entrance on Friday for her keynote appearance at SXSW — a conversation with John Norris of Fuse News at the Hilton Grand Ballroom here — she looked at first glance like a bride in white platform heels and cascades of fabric. On second glance, the flounces were plastic: dropcloths, perhaps.

headline: Finding Beauty in the Sludge
abstract: Steven Hirsch, a photographer, said he saw the Gowanus Canal, a Superfund site in Brooklyn, as a “starting point” for making “something beautiful.”
lead_paragraph: Despite the beckoning townhouses and the waterfront arrival of Whole Foods, the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn remains a haunting place. At any given moment, iridescent bubbles ominously float along its murky green waters, past discarded trash and scattershot debris. Gas plants, tanneries, chemical plants and other industry once lined its banks, and their remnants trouble the water like ghosts. Lurking contaminants include heavy metals, PCBs and coal tar. And for decades, untreated sewage was carried into the canal by city drains.

headline: Devilishly Slashing Narrow Notions of Flamenco
abstract: Both ribald and serious, Israel Galván’s “La Curva” show at the Schimmel Center on Thursday offered an intense reminder of flamenco’s experimental side.
lead_paragraph: With good reason, flamenco is most commonly thought of as an art of suffering. But there are other sides to the tradition. The form known as the “bulería,” for example, is fast and playful. Its name comes from the Spanish for “to mock.” And mockery of some kind is what courses through “La Curva,” a remarkable show by the experimental flamenco dancer Israel Galván that had its American debut on Thursday at Pace University’s Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts.

headline: Fast-Forwarding Through Fashion Month
abstract: Two editors, four cities and a month of fashion shows, all boiled down to one whirlwind video montage.
lead_paragraph: T’s intrepid fashion editors Kate Lanphear and Malina Joseph Gilchrist recently completed a nonstop month in the fashion trenches of New York, London, Milan and Paris, and returned to the office armed with video footage of what they saw from the front row and in the surrounding city streets. The video design team of Rosanna Webster and Charlie Sheppard compiled their material into this impressionistic montage that lets you experience the glamour, excitement and absurdity of a full month of fashion shows, all in two short minutes.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A tour of homes in Somerville, N.J., and Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A tour of homes in Midtown; the Financial District; and Dumbo.

headline: Was There a Gangster Called Oscar the Poet?
abstract: Readers ask questions about a gang leader caught carrying a book of poems as well as the reason for green lights outside police precinct stations.
lead_paragraph: Q. Wasn’t there an old-time gangster named Oscar the Poet? What can you tell me about him?

headline: Frank Relle
abstract: Frank Relle
lead_paragraph: Frank Relle

headline: Sign of a New Spring in Rockettes’ Steps
abstract: Radio City Music Hall’s resident dance company is using its first spring show since 1997 to try a new range of movements beyond its traditional kick lines.
lead_paragraph: If Linda Haberman’s new “Walk the Walk” were a dress, it would be a statement piece: classic, strong, powerful.

headline: Phil Jackson, by the Numbers
abstract: The most N.B.A. championships, the highest regular-season winning percentage and more stats about Phil Jackson, who returns to where his career began, with the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: The most N.B.A. championships, the highest regular-season winning percentage and more stats about Phil Jackson, who returns to where his career began, with the Knicks.

headline: Anxiety Builds as New York City Parks Await a Leader
abstract: The de Blasio administration has not yet hired a chief for the department, leaving some to wonder what the effect will be on longer-term policy issues.
lead_paragraph: One by one, officials have been announced for top jobs in Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration: to oversee the police, schools, housing, criminal justice, aging, environmental protection.

headline: Fighting Over Wood Colony
abstract: The city of Modesto, Calif., plans to bring about 1,800 acres of Wood Colony, a rural district, under city jurisdiction.
lead_paragraph: The city of Modesto, Calif., plans to bring about 1,800 acres of Wood Colony, a rural district, under city jurisdiction.

headline: GoDaddy Is Said to Be Exploring I.P.O.
abstract: The I.P.O. process could pave the way for an eventual exit by GoDaddy’s owners, the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Silver Lake, and a smaller firm, Technology Crossover Ventures.
lead_paragraph: GoDaddy, the online domain registrar known for its racy television commercials, is preparing to file for an initial public offering, a person briefed on the matter said on Friday.

headline: Fed Transferred $79.6 Billion in Earnings to the Treasury Last Year
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Federal Reserve, required by law to put most of its profit in the government’s coffers, has contributed almost $323 billion in the last four years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve paid $79.6 billion to the Treasury Department in 2013 as the Fed’s enormous investment campaign to stimulate economic growth continued to generate windfall profits for taxpayers.

headline: Recovered Enough to Play Hobbled
abstract: Thomas Hampson, sidelined for a while by bronchitis, made his debut in the title role of the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of “Wozzeck.”
lead_paragraph: After missing the first two performances in the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Berg’s “Wozzeck” because of bronchitis, the baritone Thomas Hampson sang on Thursday night, his debut in the title role. As he had made clear in interviews and in posts on his Facebook page, Mr. Hampson is excited to be taking on this “challenging genius opera,” as he called it.

headline: A Double Dribble: 2 Long Looks at the Hoop
abstract: “Summer Dreams” on CBS tracks the progress of participants in the N.B.A. Summer League, while “Requiem for the Big East” on ESPN recalls that conference’s glory days.
lead_paragraph: The sports documentary is not the purest genre. For every “Hoop Dreams” or “When We Were Kings” there are dozens of films whose primary goals are commercial, promotional, jingoistic or tritely celebratory and sentimental.

headline: Lines Meet Atmospheres, and a Visiting Drummer
abstract: Underwater Ghost’s appearance at Seeds in Brooklyn on Wednesday night included a guest drummer, Allison Miller, who folded herself into a band that wasn’t drawn up with drums in mind at all.
lead_paragraph: At the center of Brad Linde’s jazz group Underwater Ghost, which played on Wednesday night at Seeds, the storefront performance space in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is a pair of opposites. It’s the sound of Mr. Linde’s slowly and evenly phrased, swinging and nearly vibrato-less tenor saxophone playing; and then there’s the sound of the guitarist Anthony Pirog’s electric guitar, which involves careful chords and explicit, jazz-related harmonies but also and more often a freaky action-painting of effects and textures by means of a dozen or so digital pedals. While Mr. Linde focused on lines — one of the tunes he played was called “Lines”— Mr. Pirog made atmospheres.

headline: A Medicine of Oneness, Body, Soul and Stars
abstract: “Bodies in Balance: The Art of Tibetan Medicine,” an exhibition at the Rubin Museum, presents art and artifacts from as far back as the ninth century.
lead_paragraph: It’s doubtful that the American Medical Association would choose the beings we see in the Rubin Museum of Art’s remarkable new exhibition, “Bodies in Balance: The Art of Tibetan Medicine,” as guardians. One protectress of the healing arts in a 19th-century painting rides a nine-headed bird through the sky. She has the head of a wolf, the label explains, with three large, round eyes and matted, disheveled hair. She holds a curved knife, a hook and “a freshly severed head with a lasso of intestines.”

headline: Leading Militant Killed in Mali, Military Officials Say
abstract: Oumar Ould Hamaha, known for his red beard, his bloodthirsty statements to the media and his role in kidnapping a Canadian diplomat in 2008, was killed by French forces, the officials said.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — A leading jihadist militant close to top figures in the West African affiliate of Al Qaeda has been killed in Mali’s desert north, two senior Malian military officials said Friday.

headline: Egypt Asks U.S. to Impose Sharp Curbs on Importing of Antiquities
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Egypt’s antiquities minister has asked the Obama administration for fast action to stop the sales of stolen cultural treasures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Egypt’s antiquities minister is asking the Obama administration to impose emergency restrictions on the importing of ancient artifacts from his country, saying that the looting and smuggling of such treasures has been “catastrophic” since the Arab Spring revolt of 2011.

headline: Hot Baton Takes Turn at Festival
abstract: Andris Nelsons, the new music director of the Boston Symphony, led the Vienna Philharmonic in Brahms and Haydn at Carnegie Hall’s Vienna: City Dreams festival.
lead_paragraph: Lovers of great orchestral playing in New York are getting a second bite of a very big apple this weekend. After the Vienna Philharmonic opened Carnegie Hall’s three-week festival Vienna: City of Dreams with two concerts at Carnegie last month — and took part in concert performances of Berg’s “Wozzeck” and Strauss’s “Salome” there with its parent company, the Vienna State Opera — the orchestra fled to sunnier climes in California.

headline: These Kidnappers Hit the Mother Lode
abstract: “Crisis,” a new NBC series on Sunday, pivots on the kidnapping of the president’s son and other children of the rich and powerful.
lead_paragraph: Kidnappings are risky, and not just for the victims.

headline: Oakland’s Surprise: Grammy-Winning Caribbean Sound
abstract: The little-known Pacific Mambo Orchestra, based in Oakland, Calif., surprised the industry when it was awarded a Grammy in the “tropical music” category.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Of all the surprises when Grammys were handed out in January, perhaps the biggest came in the “tropical music” category for salsa, merengue and related styles. Up against stars like Marc Anthony and Carlos Vives, the winner was the virtually unknown Pacific Mambo Orchestra, based here, a continent away from the Caribbean, geographically and culturally.

headline: Blondie on Blondie
abstract: Deborah Harry and Chris Stein discuss the seminal synth-pop group’s fortieth anniversary, their upcoming album and the passing of Lou Reed.
lead_paragraph: At a festival where Blondie imitators (conscious or unconscious) are everywhere, the founders of the genuine article sit in the basement of the Four Seasons Austin, trying to avoid the spotlight. “I don’t have any anonymity,” says Deborah Harry, who removes her massive sunglasses only when there are no civilians in the room. “I’m either in the hotel or I’m at the gig. I can’t go anywhere. It’s kind of awkward.” She and Chris Stein have brought their band to town for a talk and a couple of shows, part of a series of events celebrating Blondie’s 40th anniversary this year. Up next is a Smithsonian Channel documentary on the group, which premieres March 21. The group’s 10th album, “Ghosts of Download,” comes out in May, packaged with a new greatest-hits release, as “Blondie 4(0) Ever.” The duo chatted with T about the new record, Lou Reed’s memorial and what it means to be hip these days.

headline: Embracing the Recital, With Arms Wide Open
abstract: The soprano Natalie Dessay, who is halfway through a recital tour with the pianist Philippe Cassard, performed Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: In recent interviews the 48-year-old soprano Natalie Dessay has spoken of her desire to take a sabbatical from opera, citing her discomfort with portraying teenage heroines. Originally trained as an actress, Ms. Dessay hopes to pursue acting again as well as focus on recitals. She is currently midway through a recital tour with the pianist Philippe Cassard.

headline: U.S. to Cede Its Oversight of Addresses on Internet
abstract: An international group, not yet determined, will take over the task of assigning names and numbers for Internet addresses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States will give up its role overseeing the system of Web addresses and domain names that form the basic plumbing of the Internet, turning it over in 2015 to an international group whose structure and administration will be determined over the next year, government officials said on Friday.

headline: Synagogue, Rebooted
abstract: Amichai Lau-Lavie, a rabbinical student, is leading an effort at Lab/Shul, which meets in Manhattan, to make worship more relevant to people with weak ties to traditional institutions.
lead_paragraph: At a rock club on the edge of SoHo on a recent Saturday, Amichai Lau-Lavie stood in front of two musicians and a set of video screens, bringing a message about counterculture. Mr. Lau-Lavie, 44, descends from at least 37 generations of Orthodox Jewish rabbis. He is also a gay man who lives in the East Village — a fan of the Smiths and Emily Dickinson, a father of three, the creator of a drag character named Hadassah Gross. On the screens was an image of a sacrificial lamb, taken from a Dutch painting.

headline: A Cranky Bonding Agent for Society’s Oil and Water
abstract: Thrown together after their children misbehave in school, five very different women form a support group in “Tyler Perry’s The Single Moms Club.”
lead_paragraph: A movie-length act of affirmation, “Tyler Perry’s The Single Moms Club” saunters through the struggles, hopes, and reconciliations among five mothers making do. Mr. Perry’s latest film touches upon some recognizable and realistic challenges with efficient compassion, but there’s probably more dramatic tension in a car pool than in this film’s collection of predicaments.

headline: If a Book Annoys You, Ridicule It in Song
abstract: “50 Shades! The Musical — The Original Parody” at the Elektra Theater adds R-rated lyrics to E. L. James’s best-selling novel about bondage, but it keeps the nudity PG.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to potential for satire, E. L. James’s she-porn best seller “50 Shades of Grey” seems as easy a target as you could shake a sex toy at. That said, “50 Shades! The Musical — The Original Parody,” an exuberant takeoff now at the Elektra Theater, handily delivers the goods.

headline: Map of Malaysian Air Flight 370
abstract: Latest details on what officials have said is known about the flight path.
lead_paragraph: Latest details on what officials have said is known about the flight path.

headline: Now, the ‘Shut Up Your Mouse, Obama’ Dance Remix
abstract: YouTube video of an Egyptian woman’s rant at President Obama
lead_paragraph: As The Lede reported earlier this week, many Egyptians have embraced a conspiracy theory, borrowed from the American right, which holds that President Obama is a supporter of the Muslim Brotherhood and helped install and prop up the country’s first Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, at least until he was forced from power by the military last year.

headline: A Method That Has Revolutionized Defense
abstract: What is the best improvement in bridge technique in the last 25 years?
lead_paragraph: What is the best improvement in bridge technique in the last 25 years?

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Supersymmetry
abstract: It’s not the same as being alive.
lead_paragraph: This is from the soundtrack for “Her”, also on the album. AF haven’t done many (any? Can’t recall) straight Win-Regine duets; given how lovely and moving this one is, here’s hoping they do more.

headline: Music and Motion as Sliding Screens, Intuitively Calibrated
abstract: Opening a three-week season at the David H. Koch Theater, the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented some cherished hits this week, along with a recent piece of Americana.
lead_paragraph: When André Gide was once asked to name France’s greatest poet, he said, “Hugo — hélas.” Though the line has been both misquoted and misattributed, its central point should be unmistakable: an amalgam of admiration and regret. Those mixed feelings returned to mind this week at Diamond Anniversary season performances by the Paul Taylor Dance Company at the David H. Koch Theater. Mr. Taylor is our greatest living choreographer — alas. You can’t admire his excellences without observing his lapses. And this has been true for decades.

headline: Video Notebook: St. Bonaventure Wins
abstract: St. Bonaventure Coach Mark Schmidt and the guard Jordan Gathers talk about Gathers's game-winning shot.
lead_paragraph: St. Bonaventure Coach Mark Schmidt and the guard Jordan Gathers talk about Gathers's game-winning shot.

headline: Excerpt: 'Crisis'
abstract: Rachael Taylor and Gillian Anderson star in "Crisis," a new hostage thriller on NBC.
lead_paragraph: Rachael Taylor and Gillian Anderson star in "Crisis," a new hostage thriller on NBC.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Veterans', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks on America’s role in today’s world.

headline: Judge Refuses to Alter Pandora’s Payments to Songwriters
abstract: The decision to leave unchanged the streaming music service’s royalties to the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers may lead to efforts to overhaul government music-licensing regulation.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday left unchanged the royalty rate that the streaming service Pandora pays songwriters, a move that may fuel efforts by music groups to change the decades-old government regulation over licensing.

headline: Working (or Not) at 65
abstract: Gary Chaison, a professor of labor relations, responds to an article in the Retirement special section, “The Gray Jobs Enigma.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Debate Over Wolf Restoration and Ecosystems
abstract: Responses to an Op-Ed article, “Is the Wolf a Real American Hero?”

headline: Contaminated Beaches

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Pros Who Help You Move to the Music
abstract: Once the forte of Richard Simmons, dance cardio workouts are back and as varied as their instructors.
lead_paragraph: On a frigid Saturday morning on the Upper East Side, Evren Dogancay, 36, and about 15 other women clad in stretchy pants, sports bras and shoulder-baring loose tops like those on “So You Think You Can Dance,” stood under a giant disco ball at AKT In Motion, a workout studio that opened in November. Led by Anna Kaiser, the owner, a Lilliputian but muscular blonde who wore gold hoop earrings and a lime green bandanna with her athletic gear, they ground their hips and flailed their arms like Britney Spears. “You’ve got an audience!” Ms. Kaiser shouted into her headpiece mike as Rihanna blared. “Feel the music!”

headline: A Los Angeles Gay Landmark Buttons Up
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The San Vicente Inn, long a shabby men-only motel, is upgrading in advance of a $30 million makeover.
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — The infamous San Vicente Inn here, long operated as a clothing-optional, men-only motel with a just-smoke-it drug policy, in many ways epitomizes this city’s past as a live-and-let-live gay ghetto.

headline: Work Like a German
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Disability Insurance', 'Vocational Training', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Germany emerged from recession with lower unemployment. We could learn from that.
lead_paragraph: SOME of our workplace programs, like Unemployment Insurance and Disability Insurance, parts of which date from the 1930s, desperately need updating. The original designers did not envisage such large numbers of people unemployed for long periods of time or living on disability benefits. If we could convert these programs into ladders of upward mobility, they would disproportionately benefit the disadvantaged, as well as strengthen the economy. We need to focus on enabling workers to stay in work — rather than having to compensate them after they have lost their jobs.

headline: Walking the Walk to Increase Diversity
abstract: Bethann Hardison, a fashion insider and activist for diversity on the runways, is to be honored by the CFDA.
lead_paragraph: Bethann Hardison, the fashion industry gadfly, has adopted a slogan: “Activism needs to remain active.”

headline: The West Wing Cast Draws Chatter
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Could Valerie Jarrett, the White House consigliere, and Ahmad Rashad, the sportscaster, be an item? They’re not commenting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On March 8, President Obama urged the French president, François Hollande, the British prime minister, David Cameron, and the Italian premier, Matteo Renzi, to keep a united front during the crisis in Ukraine. He assured nervous leaders of the Baltic States that he had an “unwavering commitment” to their security.

headline: Reduce Gun Penalties
abstract: Mandatory minimum sentences for firearm crimes are too harsh.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — IN May of 2002, a 23-year-old man named Michael Brandon Shuler was sentenced in federal court to 15 years in prison for illegally possessing a gun — something that even the prosecutor acknowledged was a “rather benign act.”

headline: Growing From Song to Spectacle
abstract: A hit or two is nice, but Cyndi Lauper and David Byrne are working on creating hit productions, on and off Broadway.
lead_paragraph: There’s no hiding a rock star. So when David Byrne, the former frontman of Talking Heads, walked into Il Cantinori in Greenwich Village recently, wearing a navy twill jumpsuit and a snow-white puffer coat (and having just arrived on bicycle), the only person who held a candle to his bold chic was Cyndi Lauper, the flame-haired singer who arrived in slim black leggings and top, her hands sprinkled with silver jewelry. They came to talk about their musical pasts in 1970s and ’80s New York, and their shared theatrical presents — she as the Tony-winning composer and lyricist of the Broadway hit “Kinky Boots,” and he as the Obie-winning creator of the musical spectacle “Here Lies Love,” about the former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos, which will resume its run at the Public Theater next month. Over calamari and mushroom salad (for Mr. Byrne) and pasta and arugula salad (for Ms. Lauper), they spoke with The New York Times about artistic growth, recovering from career setbacks and how music can save your life.

headline: Network? Let’s Party!
abstract: Santa Monica and Venice, home to bodybuilders and skateboarders, are attracting start-up founders for whom fund-raising and socializing are all but interchangeable.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It was a Monday night, but Bar Marmont was packed. Women milled about in high heels and cropped fur coats (it was 50 degrees outside, this city’s version of a polar vortex). Hair had been meticulously coaxed into face-flattering waves, makeup freshly applied. “I’m going to get a massage on my lunch break tomorrow,” a woman at the bar told her friend, as she fiddled with a large gold necklace.

headline: Saudi’s Lonely, Costly Bid for Sunni-Shiite Equality
keywords: ['Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Mikhlif al-Shammari has been jailed and even shot by his own son because he holds a very unusual conviction in his deeply conservative country: that Shiites should be treated equally.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Mikhlif Al-Shammari has been jailed repeatedly, declared an infidel, ruined financially and shot four times — by his own son — all for this: He believes his fellow Sunni Muslims should treat Shiites as equals.

headline: Official Targets ‘Russophobia’
abstract: Amid fears of conflict in Ukraine, a member of Parliament proposed a bill to penalize “Russophobic propaganda” in Russia, imposing penalties of 15 days in prison or a fine of about $1,370.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — With the Russian authorities on edge amid fears of conflict in Ukraine, a member of Parliament on Friday submitted a draft bill that would penalize the spreading of “Russophobic propaganda” in Russia, imposing maximum penalties of 15 days in prison or a fine of 50,000 rubles, or about $1,370.

headline: In Land of Elvis, UConn Still Yearns for Broadway
abstract: For 30 years, the Huskies enjoyed the drama and rivalries of a conference tournament at Madison Square Garden. In Memphis this season, they have faced a tough adjustment.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — At an omelet station in the breakfast buffet of the Crowne Plaza hotel in Memphis, the Big East tournament lives on. Here, some 1,097 miles from 4 Pennsylvania Plaza, is a renowned coach in an unfamiliar place, ruminating over games gone by.

headline: Pacifica Radio Fires Its Executive Director
abstract: The dismissal of Summer Reese, who was named to the post permanently in November, is the latest example of tumult at the community radio network.
lead_paragraph: The Pacifica Foundation, a community radio network that includes WBAI-FM in New York, has dismissed its executive director, the latest tumultuous step for an organization that has been plagued by financial problems and acrimonious turnover among its management.

headline: A Store With Media in Mind
abstract: At Story, a Manhattan boutique, products change often and reflect specific themes.
lead_paragraph: At a Manhattan boutique called Story, shoppers can buy delicate lingerie or intricately decorated chocolate, scented candles or underwear made by a Swedish company called Bread & Boxers.

headline: Mayor’s Pre-K Tax Drive: Views Vary on Its Success as Widely as on Its Merits
abstract: Albany may give Mayor Bill de Blasio financing for universal prekindergarten, but the anticipated failure of his preferred revenue mechanism illustrates the limits of mayoral power.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio rose to power with a promise to increase taxes on wealthy New Yorkers to pay for prekindergarten classes, an idea, rich with symbolism, that many hoped would galvanize liberal causes across the country.

headline: Senate Balks at Obama Pick for Surgeon General
keywords: ['Surgeon General (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Gun Control']
abstract: The White House is considering putting off a Senate vote on Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, who has come under criticism from the National Rifle Association, or withdrawing the nomination altogether.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing a possible defeat in the Senate, the White House is considering delaying a vote on President Obama’s choice for surgeon general or withdrawing the nomination altogether, an acknowledgment of its fraying relationship with Senate Democrats.

headline: Study Called an Advance in Stem Cells Had Faults
abstract: The disclosure threatens to discredit a newly acclaimed researcher, Haruko Obokata, whose team found that a simple acid bath might turn cells in the body into stem cells.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A study billed as a breakthrough in stem cell research contained a spliced image, material recycled from the lead author’s doctoral thesis and other mistakes, a Japanese research institute acknowledged on Friday.

headline: Massachusetts College Town Seeks Answers as Festivities Spin Out of Control
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', "St Patrick's Day", 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The arrest of 55 people during a pre-St. Patrick’s Day rite that turned violent has many people wondering how student partying can be controlled.
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass. — This neat college town, home to the University of Massachusetts’s flagship campus, is accustomed to a certain level of rowdiness. In the last decade alone, the local police and university officials have dispersed unruly crowds celebrating New England sports championships or railing against home-team losses, sometimes making between one and two dozen arrests.

headline: N.B.A. Looks to Asia for Next Growth Spurt
abstract: With China as the big revenue prize, the National Basketball Association is steadily stoking interest and wooing fans across the region.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When the National Basketball Association commissioner David Stern spent a week in Beijing in the winter of 1987, he had to plead with China Central Television to broadcast N.B.A. games — and he eventually offered to provide content free.

headline: Doherty Exiting as New York Sanitation Chief
abstract: New York City’s longest-serving sanitation commissioner, John J. Doherty, is retiring at the end of March.
lead_paragraph: There are no snow plows in Aruba.

headline: End of Gulf Ban Allows BP to Expand in Familiar, Lucrative Territory
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The chance to add new drilling sites in the Gulf of Mexico is a milestone in the company’s recovery from the Deepwater Horizon disaster.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Even as drilling for new oil in the Gulf of Mexico has made a robust return since the Deepwater Horizon rig disaster in 2010, BP has been in the unusual position of spectator.

headline: Legislature Rejects Cuomo’s Plan to Use Rebates to Freeze Property Taxes
abstract: New York lawmakers have reservations about the governor’s plan to give rebates to homeowners whose property taxes increase.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In a rare bipartisan rebuke, the New York State Legislature is resisting Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan to effectively freeze property taxes for two years, one of the centerpieces of the budget he proposed in January.

headline: Clinton Archives Collection, Part 2: Foreign Intelligence
abstract: Papers related to intelligence and terrorism from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.
lead_paragraph: Papers related to intelligence and terrorism from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

abstract: Speechwriters’ papers from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.
lead_paragraph: Speechwriters’ papers from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.
