abstract: Papers related to domestic policy and history from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.
lead_paragraph: Papers related to domestic policy and history from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

headline: A Mystery, a Murder Case and an Injustice
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'International Relations', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Much of the news this past week seemed to come from the pages of best-selling thrillers, led by the creepy disappearance of a jetliner.
lead_paragraph: Much of the news this past week seemed to come from the pages of best-selling thrillers. The creepy disappearance of a jetliner over Southeast Asia, with the possibility that it may have kept flying for hours after it broke electronic contact, was the mystery of the week, inflicting agonizing suspense on relatives of the lost passengers.

headline: Clinton Archives Collection, Part 5: 2000 Election
abstract: Papers related to the 2000 presidential election from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.
lead_paragraph: Papers related to the 2000 presidential election from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

lead_paragraph: Papers related to foreign policy from a collection of Clinton White House papers released Friday by the National Archives.

headline: BMW to Introduce X4 Sports Activity Coupe at New York Auto Show
abstract: A cross between a crossover and a sedan, the X4 will be revealed for the first time in New York next month.
lead_paragraph: BMW will showcase several new-to-America models at the New York International Auto Show next month, but the vehicle making its first appearance on the world stage will be the X4 Sports Activity Coupe.

headline: Florida: Sentencing Is Delayed in Case of Shooting Over Loud Music
abstract: The sentencing of Michael Dunn, who was convicted last month of attempted murder for shooting at three teenagers after a confrontation over loud music, will be delayed until after his new trial on the remaining first-degree murder charge.
lead_paragraph: The sentencing of Michael Dunn, who was convicted last month of attempted murder for shooting at three teenagers after a confrontation over loud music, will be delayed until after his new trial on the remaining first-degree murder charge. A judge on Friday in Jacksonville set a trial date of May 5 for Mr. Dunn, 47. A jury was unable to reach a verdict on whether Mr. Dunn fatally shot Jordan Davis, 17, in self-defense or did so intentionally. A retrial will be held on that charge. But it is possible that the trial date could be postponed. Mr. Dunn, who could no longer afford to pay his lawyer, is being represented by someone new. He could waive his right to a speedy trial to give his new lawyer more time to prepare, a move that would delay the trial until later this year.

headline: Metro-North to Study Whether Surge in Riders Affected Railroad’s Safety
abstract: After a tragic safety record, railroad officials will evaluate the role an increase in passengers and trains played in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the Metro-North Railroad’s three main lines achieved their highest ridership ever, carrying nearly 82 million passengers as suburban growth and a stronger regional economy helped fuel unprecedented demand.

headline: Phil Jackson Lands a No-Lose Proposition
abstract: Even if Jackson cannot build the Knicks into a champion, the team’s owner, James L. Dolan, is likely to be blamed for the resulting chaos.
lead_paragraph: When he was coaching in Chicago, Phil Jackson was watching a baseball game one spring afternoon with Jerry Reinsdorf, the owner of the Bulls and the White Sox, who volunteered what Reinsdorf considered an important tenet of proprietary success.

headline: Tennessee: Ruling Favors 3 Gay Couples Seeking Recognition of Marriages
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In the latest challenge to same-sex marriage restrictions, a federal judge in Nashville said Friday that Tennessee must recognize the status of three couples who were married in other states.
lead_paragraph: In the latest challenge to same-sex marriage restrictions, a federal judge in Nashville said Friday that Tennessee must recognize the status of three couples who were married in other states. The ruling is preliminary and applies only to these couples, said Judge Aleta A. Trauger of Federal District Court, pending a broader decision on whether Tennessee must recognize same-sex marriages performed elsewhere. But “all signs indicate,” the judge wrote, that same-sex marriage bans “will soon become a footnote in the annals of American history.” The state did not say whether it would appeal the temporary ruling.

The real fun began after Karl Lagerfeld took his stroll through the market, left, when the more than 2,000 guests got up from their carton seats and thought they had the right to shop, filling their arms with goods. lead_paragraph: Iola Brubeck, who played an important behind-the-scenes role in the success of her husband, the jazz pianist and composer Dave Brubeck, died on March 12 at her home in Wilton, Conn. She was 90.

headline: Israel: Military Fires Into Lebanon After Border Blast
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A large explosive device was detonated against an Israeli Army vehicle patrolling the Israel-Lebanon border on Friday, and the Israeli military responded with tank and artillery fire.
lead_paragraph: A large explosive device was detonated against an Israeli Army vehicle patrolling the Israel-Lebanon border on Friday, and the Israeli military responded with tank and artillery fire against positions held by the Lebanese group Hezbollah near the border, Israeli military officials said. The blast, which damaged the armored vehicle, caused no apparent injuries to the soldiers inside. But the Israelis described it as a serious violation of the cease-fire that ended the 2006 war between Israel and Hezbollah. Lt. Col. Peter Lerner, an Israeli spokesman, said Israel “suspected a Hezbollah connection,” adding that it was reinforcing troops on the border. Israel Radio reported late Friday that an Islamic group affiliated with Al Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attack via Twitter. The reliability of the claim could not be verified.

headline: U.S. Navy Strategists Have a Long History of Finding the Lost

abstract: The Office of Naval Intelligence has refined some of the most creative techniques that have been used to find sunken ships, spent warheads and downed pilots.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE GREAT GATSBY (2013) Leonardo DiCaprio, above, stars as the enigmatic millionaire Jay Gatsby; Carey Mulligan portrays Daisy Buchanan, the object of his obsession; and Tobey Maguire is Nick Carraway, the Midwestern Yale graduate — and, conveniently, Daisy’s cousin — renting the cottage next door to Gatsby’s colossal Long Island mansion in Baz Luhrmann’s stylized musical take on F. Scott Fitzgerald’s novel. “Despite what you may have heard, it is an eminently enjoyable movie,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this Oscar winner for best costume and production design. Still, he asked, is the tale “a credible love story? Fitzgerald himself was not sure, but Mr. Luhrmann, Mr. DiCaprio and Ms. Mulligan make it an effective one. At a crucial, climactic moment — a scene in a suite at the Plaza Hotel — the director mutes his irrepressible circus ringmaster showmanship and plunges into undiluted melodrama. The music stops, and the camera cuts among the assembled faces as the emotional core of the film is laid bare.” That scene, Mr. Scott added, “stands out in a movie that is otherwise gaudily and grossly inauthentic,” like Gatsby himself. “As a character in Nick’s ruminations, in Fitzgerald’s sentences and in our national mythology, he is a complete mess. This movie is worthy of him.”

But two weeks ago, an email appeared in Ms. Leiken’s inbox from her mother, Nancy Mills, 64, that told an entirely new tale:

headline: Capital Crimes, Re-Examined
abstract: Miscarriage-of-justice stories drawn from real life are television slam-dunks, but a new CNN series, “Death Row Stories,” tells them especially well.
lead_paragraph: Miscarriage-of-justice stories drawn from real life are television slam-dunks, but a new CNN series, “Death Row Stories,” tells them especially well. The series, whose second installment will be broadcast on Sunday night at 9, looks at capital murder cases in which questionable evidence or investigative tactics led to convictions of dubious merit. It’s a sure formula for building suspense and outrage as the story goes along.

headline: Becoming French, as Well as ...
abstract: Filmed in Paris’s 10th Arrondissement, Julie Bertucelli’s documentary “School of Babel” observes a “reception class” of immigrant children.
lead_paragraph: Filmed at the Granges-aux-Belles school in Paris’s 10th Arrondissement, Julie Bertucelli’s documentary “School of Babel” observes a “reception class” of immigrant children, ages 11 to 15, who speak little or no French. Ms. Bertucelli, best known for her features “Since Otar Left” and “The Tree,” observes parent-teacher meetings in which family backgrounds and reasons of immigration are revealed. The teacher, Brigitte Cervoni, is patient and gentle with her students, who make their own film about themselves for a student festival. You see firsthand the students dealing with the anxiety about cultural integration. The children come from all over the globe: Ireland, Brazil, China. Rama, the most resistant student, is a Senegalese girl from a troubled family. In some ways, this smart, clear, upbeat movie, which has its final screening Sunday in Lincoln Center’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series, is a documentary equivalent of Laurent Cantet’s “The Class” (2008). (1:30 p.m., rendezvouswithfrenchcinema.com.)

headline: Working Stiffs and Just Folks
abstract: Revisited as myth or seen in close-up, the South looms in concerts this week by Rosanne Cash, on Tuesday, and by Drive-By Truckers, on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Revisited as memory and myth or seen in warts-and-all close-up, the South looms in concerts this week by Rosanne Cash, on Tuesday, and by Drive-By Truckers, on Thursday. Although she is a longtime New Yorker, Ms. Cash’s new album, “The River & the Thread,” grew out of sojourns in Tennessee, Louisiana and Arkansas, where she helped to restore the boyhood house of her father, Johnny Cash. The songs are folksy, lean and aphoristic; they conjure characters real and imagined, all the way back to the Civil War, with laconic grace. (8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, 212-840-2824, thetownhall.org.)

headline: Of a Feather: Audubon’s Birds
abstract: “Parts Unknown,” opening Friday, will display 132 Audubon watercolors, most of water birds or waders.
lead_paragraph: After John James Audubon died in 1851, his widow sold the 435 watercolors he created for his opus, “The Birds of America,” to the New-York Historical Society. Last year, the society presented 200 of those masterpieces of ornithological observation in the first of a three-part exhibition series called “Audubon’s Aviary: The Complete Flock.” The second installment, subtitled “Parts Unknown,” opens Friday. It will display 132 more watercolors, most of water birds or waders. They represent some of Audubon’s biggest subjects, including the great blue heron and the whooping crane. Other species include the Atlantic puffin, which Audubon saw in Labrador; the snowy egret, which he studied in South Carolina; and the golden eagle, in particular a live but injured specimen that he bought in Boston and euthanized so he could paint it. The show will be enhanced by audio of bird calls and songs of each species from the Cornell Lab of Ornithology. (Through May 26, 170 Central Park West, at West 77th Street, 212-873-3400, nyhistory.org.)

headline: Left Coast, Meet Right Coast
abstract: Gustavo Dudamel, the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, brings that adventurous West Coast orchestra to Avery Fisher Hall.
lead_paragraph: At 33, Gustavo Dudamel, the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic and perhaps the most charismatic conductor of the new generation, brings that adventurous West Coast orchestra to Avery Fisher Hall for a pair of enticing programs. On Sunday afternoon, he conducts John Corigliano’s Symphony No. 1 (1989), a work of “rage and remembrance” for friends who died of AIDS, in Mr. Corigliano’s words; and Tchaikovsky’s Fifth Symphony. Monday evening’s program offers the New York premiere of a work by the Icelandic composer Daniel Bjarnason; Rachmaninoff’s Third Piano Concerto, with the young virtuoso Yuja Wang; and Brahms’s Second Symphony. (3 p.m. Sunday and 8 p.m. Monday, Lincoln Center, 212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org.)

headline: Choreographer’s New Landscape
abstract: The last time Beth Gill created a new work, people noticed.
lead_paragraph: The last time Beth Gill created a new work, people noticed. Her 2011 “Electric Midwife” earned three Bessie awards, including one for outstanding emerging choreographer. There aren’t many dance makers of Ms. Gill’s generation (she is 33) working with the kind of clear, penetrating focus that made “Midwife” — a pair of perfectly symmetrical trios — such a transporting meditation on the body, its intricate physics and intrinsic poetry.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking
abstract: This week, Joe ponders the end of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
lead_paragraph: During the height of the financial crisis, mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were bailed out by taxpayers to the tune of $187 billion. Now, more than five years later, they’re on track to pay all that back and more. But then what?

headline: Even With Top N.B.A. Draft Picks, Saviors Prove Rare
abstract: In some ways, the 2013 draft class, featuring Anthony Bennett, Otto Porter and Nerlens Noel, has failed to live up to even humble expectations.
lead_paragraph: As the N.B.A. regular season winds down, losing teams turn hopeful eyes toward the N.C.A.A. tournament and the draft, whose class this season is so packed with talent that it has drawn comparisons to 2003, the year LeBron James, Carmelo Anthony and Dwyane Wade came out.

headline: Obama Factor Adds to Fears of Democrats
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The president’s sinking ratings, a loss in a House election in Florida and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law are complicating matters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats are becoming increasingly alarmed about their midterm election fortunes amid President Obama’s sinking approval ratings, a loss in a special House election in Florida last week, and millions of dollars spent by Republican-aligned groups attacking the new health law.

headline: Jackson the Iconoclast, Coolly Collecting Rings
abstract: As Phil Jackson moves into the front office with the Knicks, it will be interesting to see how his lifelong embrace of the unconventional translates beyond the bench.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Lakers had just suffered a lackluster loss in Chicago. It was Phil Jackson’s final season with them, but not even his presumed last game coaching in a city that held so many memories for him could stir the Lakers from the malaise that afflicts teams, particularly back-to-back champions, during the regular-season grind.

headline: Malaysian Premier’s News Conference
abstract: Prime Minister Najib Razak said on Saturday that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been deliberately diverted from its planned flight path.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Najib Razak said on Saturday that Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been deliberately diverted from its planned flight path.

headline: Where Income Is Higher, Life Spans Are Longer
abstract: As incomes have diverged between the country’s richest counties, like Fairfax County, Va., and its poorest ones, like McDowell County, W.Va., so have the life expectancies of their residents.
lead_paragraph: As incomes have diverged between the country’s richest counties, like Fairfax County, Va., and its poorest ones, like McDowell County, W.Va., so have the life expectancies of their residents.

headline: The Threats That Help PayPal
abstract: EBay’s PayPal is innovating fast, spurred by threats from several directions.
lead_paragraph: The best thing that happened to PayPal in years may also be why it has turned into a Wall Street football: a big upswing in innovation, fed by the prospect of irrelevance.

headline: Shining Examples for Marlins Team Seeking Its Way Back
abstract: Rafael Furcal and Casey McGehee, who both missed the entire 2013 major league season, appreciate the opportunities in front of them, albeit on a team made up primarily of youth.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The Miami Marlins’ franchise started with a knuckleball and has basically behaved like one ever since. From the moment Charlie Hough delivered that first fluttery offering, in 1993, the Marlins have dipped and darted, from the highs of two championships to the lows of cost-cutting trades.

headline: Out of Office, Sarkozy Is Still Front and Center
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Accusations of Libyan campaign donations and secret recordings keep the former French president in the headlines.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The scandal, intrigue and occasional vaudeville of Nicolas Sarkozy’s five years in the presidency made for great headlines, and French journalists once fretted that politics under his successor, François Hollande, who pledged to be a “normal” president, might prove unbearably dull.

headline: Mathematicians Are Hoping Their Calculations Add Up to the Perfect Bracket
abstract: The reason behind their motivation? How about 1 billion of them? That is the number of dollars offered by Quicken Loans for an unblemished result in predicting N.C.A.A. tournament games
lead_paragraph: Typically, when the worlds of math and sports collide, name calling, noogies and maybe even a wedgie follow.

headline: China’s Central Bank Allows Its Currency More Volatility
abstract: The bank doubled the amount by which the renminbi would be permitted to rise or fall each day, making it more responsive to market forces.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — In the latest sign that China is loosening its tight grip over the economy, the government said on Saturday that the value of its currency would now be allowed to fluctuate more widely against the United States dollar.

headline: The Pride of Wichita State, Whatever It May Actually Be
abstract: WuShock is among the most distinctive and odd members of the sports mascot kingdom: It’s an anthropomorphic shock of wheat.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The Wichita State mascot stands around 7 feet tall with a prominent highlighter-yellow head sticking out of a black sweatshirt. The head is streaked with black, the face sports a pronounced nose and angry eyebrows, and atop it all sits what looks like a mop of blond hair in a bowl cut gone awry.

headline: Evolution of WuShock
abstract: WuShock, the mascot for Wichita State, has a long history, and it is one of the more distinctive and odd members of the mascot kingdom.
lead_paragraph: WuShock, the mascot for Wichita State, has a long history, and it is one of the more distinctive and odd members of the mascot kingdom.

headline: Rebuilt Big East Sees Room for a Rival Conference’s Tournament
abstract: The Big East commissioner says an Atlantic Coast Conference tournament in Brooklyn would be good for her league, which is remaking itself after several tumultuous seasons.
lead_paragraph: When Val Ackerman, the commissioner of the Big East Conference, learned Friday that the Atlantic Coast Conference was planning to move its postseason tournament to Barclays Center in Brooklyn in 2017 and 2018, she reacted with quiet confidence.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 89
abstract: Still another potential World Cup player, Spain’s Álvaro Arbeloa, is injured and could miss the tournament.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Map of Plane’s Last Contact With Satellite
abstract: The missing Malaysia Airlines plane may have been over China or west of Australia when it last made contact with a satellite.
lead_paragraph: The missing Malaysia Airlines plane may have been over China or west of Australia when it last made contact with a satellite.

headline: Melba Hernández, a Confidante of Castro From First Volley, Is Dead at 92
abstract: Ms. Hernández became one of the first four members of Fidel Castro’s general staff and helped him during the Cuban revolution.
lead_paragraph: When Melba Hernández met Fidel Castro in the early 1950s, she likened it to a religious experience. “I felt secure,” she said. “I felt I had found the way.”

headline: Industry Behind Anti-Wage-Hike Letter
abstract: The Obama administration’s proposal to increase the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour would prompt price increases or force layoffs, a restaurant association said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Restaurant Association did not disclose upfront its role in helping draft and circulate a statement signed by more than 500 prominent economists, including four winners of the Nobel Prize, urging the federal government to reject the proposal by the Obama administration to increase the minimum wage to $10.10 an hour, interviews with signers of the letter showed.

headline: Israel Reaches Out to the Diaspora
abstract: It feels more comfortable asking for help and more supportive of Jews abroad.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past two weeks, Jewish leaders outside Israel quietly gathered in seminar groups to grapple with a thorny question: how to ensure that Israel is both a Jewish and a democratic state.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 16
abstract: The disappearance of a Malaysia Airlines flight will a big topic of discussion.
lead_paragraph: The mystery surrounding the fate of Malaysian Airlines Flight 370 continues to capture the world’s attention. While nobody knows exactly what happened, that won’t stop the chattering classes more than 9,000 miles away in Washington from weighing in.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor: Is a Career Extender a Performance Enhancer?
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines, including a recent story on Tommy John surgery.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution on Crimea
abstract: Proposed by the United States, the Security Council measure declaring Sunday’s planned secession vote illegal received one no vote. China abstained.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Russia on Saturday vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution that declared a planned Sunday referendum on secession in Crimea illegal, casting the sole vote against it.

headline: Lucrezia Reichlin
abstract: An Italian economist on German lieder, a Twitter mystery and building a business school in Sicily.
lead_paragraph: The Italian economist Lucrezia Reichlin is a professor at the London Business School and was the first female head of research at the European Central Bank. She is best known for developing a system for making real-time assessments and near-term economic forecasts using mind-numbingly large data sets.

headline: How Much Should Hepatitis C Treatment Cost?
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Hepatitis', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new pill to treat the virus raises difficult questions about fair pricing in the United States and in developing countries around the world.
lead_paragraph: A new pill to treat hepatitis C raises difficult questions about fair pricing, not only in the United States and other affluent nations but in developing countries around the world. Hepatitis C, which afflicts some 150 million people globally, often without symptoms for years, can cause fatigue and fever, cirrhosis or liver cancer.

headline: Erin Go Drinking
abstract: Does St. Patrick’s Day merchandise further a “pernicious stereotype,” or is it all in good fun?
lead_paragraph: MONDAY is St. Patrick’s Day, a holiday that seems to last longer than the 40 days of Lent. This provides more than enough time for Irish-Americans to fulfill all that our proud, guilt-ridden tradition requires.

headline: Ohio Mistrusts Democracy
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Absentee Voting', 'Elections', 'Editorials', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Republicans again pass restrictive new laws making it harder for their opponents to vote.
lead_paragraph: Ohio Republicans must not think their political candidates can win a fair fight against Democrats. They’ve decided to rig the state’s election system in their favor, deliberately making voting harder for people who tend to vote Democratic, particularly minorities and the poor.

headline: Go West, Young People! And East!
keywords: ['International Study and Teaching', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Americans Abroad', 'Language and Languages', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Every college in America should make it a requirement to study abroad. Why study Spanish in a classroom in Indiana when you could learn it in Bolivia?
lead_paragraph: I’M delighted to announce that the winner of my 2014 “win-a-trip” contest is ...

headline: Dems in Distress
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Compared to the aloof Barry, desperate Democrats see the triangulating Bill Clinton as Mother Teresa.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Scott Brown, the Republican who admitted he wore pink leather shorts on his first date with his wife-to-be, is back.

headline: The Three Faces of President Obama
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: As Vladimir Putin’s Crimean adventure plays out, what is the West to do?
lead_paragraph: BARACK OBAMA is surely the first president to be accused of acting in foreign policy like Pollyanna, John Wayne and Henry Kissinger in the same month.

headline: The Age of Individualism
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Youth', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Will the millennials come back to community?
lead_paragraph: IN the future, it seems, there will be only one “ism” — Individualism — and its rule will never end. As for religion, it shall decline; as for marriage, it shall be postponed; as for ideologies, they shall be rejected; as for patriotism, it shall be abandoned; as for strangers, they shall be distrusted. Only pot, selfies and Facebook will abide — and the greatest of these will probably be Facebook.

headline: Domestic Violence
abstract: Readers react to Nicholas Kristof’s call for more attention and resources to fight this “scourge.”
lead_paragraph: Readers react to Nicholas Kristof’s call for more attention and resources to fight this “scourge.”

headline: The Incessant Selling of the Self
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Letters']
abstract: Why all the references? Why can’t we let the work speak for itself?
lead_paragraph: YOUNG people have been educated to believe that self-promotion is essential. Being excellent is only part of the scenario, and quick personal advancement is mandatory. Otherwise, all will be lost. All the talent, all the hope, all the achievement. Those things are not meant to speak for themselves: They’re kindling for the fire, and the fire must be breathed out of the mouths of young dragons that have no fear (with tongue piercings removed for job interviews).

headline: Learning From Legos
abstract: Building-block toys resonate in today’s technology-inflected D.I.Y. culture.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a boy, my father, an architect, attempted a no-toy policy, with the significant exception that he’d buy my brother and me almost anything — any birthday, holiday or restless rainy Saturday — as long as it was Lego.

headline: The Apartheid of Children’s Literature
abstract: Too often today’s books are blind to the reality of thousands of children.
lead_paragraph: Of 3,200 children’s books published in 2013, just 93 were about black people, according to a study by the Cooperative Children’s Book Center at the University of Wisconsin.

headline: The Rise of Anti-Capitalism
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: As production costs plummet, the future lies with nonprofits.
lead_paragraph: WE are beginning to witness a paradox at the heart of capitalism, one that has propelled it to greatness but is now threatening its future: The inherent dynamism of competitive markets is bringing costs so far down that many goods and services are becoming nearly free, abundant, and no longer subject to market forces. While economists have always welcomed a reduction in marginal cost, they never anticipated the possibility of a technological revolution that might bring those costs to near zero.

headline: Where Are the People of Color in Children’s Books?
keywords: ['Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: I want to make them human in the eyes of readers — and in their own.
lead_paragraph: Of 3,200 children’s books published in 2013, just 93 were about black people, according to a study by the Cooperative Children’s Book Center at the University of Wisconsin.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Irish Amnesia
abstract: Talking the familiar, heartless language of hunger economics.
lead_paragraph: IN advance of St. Patrick’s Day, I went time traveling, back to the 1840s and Ireland’s great famine. On one side of the Irish Sea was Victorian England, flush with the pomp and prosperity of the world’s mightiest empire. On the other side were skeletal people, dying en masse, the hollow-bellied children scrounging for nettles and blackberries.

headline: A Rare Opportunity on Criminal Justice
abstract: In the current Congress, where almost all legislation goes to die, there is a surprising movement toward sentencing reform.
lead_paragraph: The current Congress is the place where virtually all legislation, however urgent or reasonable, goes to die. Yet out of this stew of partisan mistrust and dysfunction there may come one promising and unexpected achievement: the first major reforms to America’s broken criminal justice system in a generation.

headline: Paralympics, at Peace as Wars Wind Down
keywords: ['Paralympic Games', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The reality of the Paralympics’ rise over the past decade could be seen in the biographies of so many of its athletes: former soldiers gravely wounded on far-flung battlefields.
lead_paragraph: KRASNAYA POLYANA, Russia — A dozen years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan, years of grenades and land mines and roadside bombs, left thousands of American soldiers and their allies without limbs. Many of them regained a sense of self after being introduced to adaptive sports, enjoying life outside the constraints of wheelchairs or prosthetic legs.

headline: Planet Pasta
abstract: A field trip to the world’s largest pasta maker.
lead_paragraph: A field trip to the world’s largest pasta maker.

headline: Behind the Bulls’ Surge, a Center Playing Like Chamberlain
abstract: Joakim Noah may win the defensive player of the year award, but he has also emerged this season as one of the league’s best passing centers.
lead_paragraph: Accused of attempting to tank the season when they traded Luol Deng to the Cleveland Cavaliers for Andrew Bynum, who was immediately waived, and three draft picks, the Chicago Bulls have instead moved steadily up the standings. One major factor in the team’s surge despite a depleted roster has been the play of Joakim Noah. Always a defensive ace, Noah has turned himself into one of the N.B.A.’s great passing centers.

headline: Disdaining Shootouts, General Managers Push an Overtime Turnabout
abstract: The Period of the Long Change refers to the second period of hockey games, when teams defend the end of the ice farther from their benches. The N.H.L. is considering adopting that setup for overtime.
lead_paragraph: The Period of the Long Change sounds like an epoch of upheaval in Cromwell’s England or 20th-century China. But it is the trendy way of referring to the second period of hockey games, when teams defend the end of the ice farther from their benches.

headline: SXSW 2014: Music Three Ways
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The performances of Samsaya, Forest Swords and Phox.
lead_paragraph: Samsaya was born in India and raised in Norway, where she has been releasing albums for a decade. She’s applies a full pop arsenal — short catchy melodies, singalong-ready wordless hooks (“woh-oh-oh-oh-oh!”) and big beats out of hip-hop, punk-pop and Bollywood — to messages of self-empowerment and tolerance. She hit the small indoor stage at Stubb’s as if she were working an arena, with cheerleader energy somewhere between peak No Doubt and Lady Gaga. “Don’t ever fear your difference! Don’t ever let them change you!” she exhorted. “Our strength is our uniqueness!” She was introducing the single “Stereotype,” which insists, “I’ll just dance to whatever I like.”

headline: Russia Seizes Gas Plant Near Crimea Border, Ukraine Says
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Natural Gas', 'Referendums', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: On the eve of a secession referendum in Crimea, Russian forces took a natural gas terminal while Western officials prepared sanctions for Moscow.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — Tensions mounted on the eve of a secession referendum here in Crimea as helicopter-borne Russian forces made a provocative incursion just outside the peninsula’s regional border to seize a natural gas terminal, while American and European officials prepared sanctions to impose on Moscow as early as Monday.

headline: Union’s Hockey Team Turns Adversity to Advantage
abstract: A January brawl in which Coach Rick Bennett and three of his players were suspended ended up being the catalyst in bringing the team closer together.
lead_paragraph: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. — Two years ago, the Union men’s team was college hockey’s Cinderella story when the Dutchmen advanced to the Frozen Four in only their second N.C.A.A. Division I tournament appearance.

headline: Evidence Mounts That Men’s Top Four Tennis Players Are No Longer on Pedestal
abstract: At the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif., five of the top six players in the field, including Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray, failed to reach the quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — A vision of what the future might hold for men’s tennis appeared in the desert last week.

headline: Congrats to my Win-a-Trip Winner! Now, Where Should We Go?
abstract: The winner of my 2014 win-a-trip contest is a student from Notre Dame. So what should we cover?
lead_paragraph: As my Sunday column notes, I have a win-a-trip winner! Congratulations to Nicole Sganga of University of Notre Dame, winner of my 2014 contest. Nicole, 20, is from Cold Spring Harbor, Long Island, and is majoring in political science and film, television and theatre. She is a talented video journalist who has worked for CBS News in Washington and London and received rave reviews from people she has worked for and interned for. After graduating, she wants to cover the world–and I’m sure we’ll hear plenty more from her in years to come. For now, I’m looking forward to seeing her blog posts and videos from our reporting trip together.

headline: Mets Pitcher’s Mechanics Are Perfect; His Pluperfect Is Not
abstract: The Mets are helping Rafael Montero, a top pitching prospect from the Dominican Republic, to learn English.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — On a recent morning, Ronny Reyes sat behind his desk at the Mets’ minor league complex, folded his hands and furrowed his brow. He was concerned about one of his players, the top pitching prospect Rafael Montero.

headline: Waiting for Jackson but Still Winning, Knicks Stay in Race
abstract: A day after persuading Phil Jackson to come aboard and try to save their organization, the Knicks were back trying to save their current season.
lead_paragraph: It was still three days before Phil Jackson’s scheduled introduction as Knicks president, but already his presence was tangible at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Funding the Future
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As government financing of basic science research has plunged, private donors have filled the void, raising questions about the future of research for the public good.
lead_paragraph: As government financing of basic science research has plunged, private donors have filled the void, raising questions about the future of research for the public good.

headline: Billionaires With Big Ideas Are Privatizing American Science
abstract: As government financing of basic research has fallen off precipitously, philanthropists have stepped in, setting priorities and drawing both gratitude and trepidation from scientists.
lead_paragraph: Last April, President Obama assembled some of the nation’s most august scientific dignitaries in the East Room of the White House. Joking that his grades in physics made him a dubious candidate for “scientist in chief,” he spoke of using technological innovation “to grow our economy” and unveiled “the next great American project”: a $100 million initiative to probe the mysteries of the human brain.

headline: Investigators in Jet Search Rely on an Imperfect Tool
abstract: Lacking typical ways like radar and radio reports from the crew to track the missing Malaysian plane, searchers are left with an hourly electronic “handshake” between the plane and a satellite.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The main tool available in the search for the missing jet operating as Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 is imprecise and awkward, and unfamiliar to the investigators using it, but it is all they have.

headline: After 3 Days of Prayers in East Harlem, a Treasure Is Found in the Ashes
abstract: Firefighters recovered a crumpled, but largely intact, Bible belonging to the Spanish Christian Church among the debris of one of the buildings in East Harlem destroyed by a gas explosion.
lead_paragraph: Over three grim and grueling days of digging through the rubble of two East Harlem buildings annihilated in a gas explosion, rescue workers uncovered eight bodies and a catalog of ruined lives. On Saturday, though, they also discovered a small, but precious treasure.

headline: Passengers and Crew of Missing Plane Scrutinized for Aviation Skills
abstract: The focus of the investigation returned to two people on board with expertise — the pilot and his first officer.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The investigation into the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has shifted to include anyone on board with a navigation or aircraft background in response to evidence that the plane was deliberately diverted from its route and, after communication was lost, navigated by someone with deep experience at the controls.

headline: After War’s Agony, a Will to Win
abstract: The Paralympics in Sochi, Russia, included a number of athletes who had been grievously wounded while serving in the armed forces.
lead_paragraph: The Paralympics in Sochi, Russia, included a number of athletes who had been grievously wounded while serving in the armed forces.

headline: In Dream Game for Senegalese Players, St. Joseph’s Reaches A-10 Final
abstract: Three friends from Senegal with similar journeys were at Barclays Center as St. Joseph’s defeated St. Bonaventure to advance to the Atlantic 10 final against V.C.U.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, hours after St. Bonaventure had defeated La Salle in a second-round game at the Atlantic 10 tournament, the Bonnies’ Youssou Ndoye and Jean Yves Toupane had dinner with an old friend from Senegal, Papa Ndao, a junior forward for St. Joseph’s.

headline: On the Wrong Side of Globalization
abstract: Trade agreements like the Trans-Pacific Partnership would make our problems worse.
lead_paragraph: Trade agreements are a subject that can cause the eyes to glaze over, but we should all be paying attention. Right now, there are trade proposals in the works that threaten to put most Americans on the wrong side of globalization.

headline: De Blasio Picks Sanitation Commissioner
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio named Kathryn Garcia to lead the Sanitation Department, replacing John J. Doherty, who was the city’s longest-serving sanitation commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York named Kathryn Garcia, an official of the Environmental Protection Department, to replace John J. Doherty as the city’s sanitation commissioner.

headline: Jackson Offers a Glimmer of Hope at Dolan’s Palace
abstract: Phil Jackson may give the Knicks a chance to play meaningful basketball in June, but it may depend on whether the owner James L. Dolan can leave him alone.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps James L. Dolan has a slyly nasty sense of humor.

headline: Sentence Cut for Bin Laden Figure
abstract: A doctor, convicted in Pakistan of treason for helping the C.I.A. track down Osama bin Laden, had 10 years cut from his 33-year sentence.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A Pakistani official reduced by 10 years the 33-year sentence of a Pakistani medical doctor who had helped the C.I.A. track down Osama bin Laden, local news media reported Saturday.

headline: Two Counties, Separated by Fortune
abstract: Perhaps the greatest distance between the two places is this: Fairfax County is a place of the haves, and McDowell County of the have-nots.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the greatest distance between the two places is this: Fairfax County is a place of the haves, and McDowell County of the have-nots.

headline: Income Gap, Meet the Longevity Gap
abstract: Two counties, separated by fortune and 350 miles, demonstrate the widening divide in life expectancy between affluent and struggling areas of the United States.
lead_paragraph: Fairfax County, Va., and McDowell County, W.Va., are separated by 350 miles, about a half-day’s drive. Traveling west from Fairfax County, the gated communities and bland architecture of military contractors give way to exurbs, then to farmland and eventually to McDowell’s coal mines and the forested slopes of the Appalachians. Perhaps the greatest distance between the two counties is this: Fairfax is a place of the haves, and McDowell of the have-nots. Just outside of Washington, fat government contracts and a growing technology sector buoy the median household income in Fairfax County up to $107,000, one of the highest in the nation. McDowell, with the decline of coal, has little in the way of industry. Unemployment is high. Drug abuse is rampant. Median household income is about one-fifth that of Fairfax.

headline: Teixeira Hopes Recovery Is All a Matter of Routine
abstract: Mark Teixeira is receiving daily treatment on his right wrist to try to return to the form of his first four seasons as a Yankee, when he averaged 34 home runs and 106 runs batted in.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — Yankees first baseman Mark Teixeira picked at the tape wrapped tightly around his right wrist. It was black, much like his mood most of last season.

headline: Charlie Porter, an Adventurer Scaling Rock and Sailing Seas, Is Dead at 63
abstract: Mr. Porter, a self-taught adventurer and climate scientist, was most famous for the climbing routes he devised up El Capitan in Yosemite National Park in the early 1970s.
lead_paragraph: When Charlie Porter showed up in the Yosemite Valley in the early 1970s and started forging new climbing routes up the famously imposing monolithic rock wall known as El Capitan, he was something of a mystery man, a stranger to the clubby group of mostly Californians who had made Yosemite the center of the climbing world.

headline: Two European Events Could Scramble Rankings
abstract: Most of the world’s top players descended on Europe to compete in either the Candidates tournament or the European Individual Chess Championship.
lead_paragraph: Two competitions this month — the Candidates tournament and the European Individual Chess Championship — have the potential to shake up the world chess order.

headline: Celebrity Guest Solver Suzanne Whang: It’s Better This Way
abstract: Celebrity guest solver Suzanne Whang tackles a Jeremy Newton puzzle that had special meaning for her.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, I don’t have to say very much today, because Suzanne Whang, stand-up comedian, actress and host of HGTV’s “House Hunters” for 10 years, is going to tell you about her experience solving today’s crossword puzzle.

headline: Perry’s Exit Leaves a Void for Republicans
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz is not running for election this year, so Dan Patrick and Greg Abbott, in particular, are wedging their way into the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Video Notebook: Papa Ndao
abstract: The junior forward Papa Ndao for St. Joseph's talks about hanging out and competing against the St. Bonaventure junior center Youssou Ndoye.
lead_paragraph: The junior forward Papa Ndao for St. Joseph's talks about hanging out and competing against the St. Bonaventure junior center Youssou Ndoye.

headline: Alamo’s ‘First Lady’ Calls and History Buffs Gather
abstract: At a private party started 17 years ago, the invitees include historians, re-enactors, collectors and others who commemorate the fall of the Alamo at a San Antonio home.
lead_paragraph: The fall of the Alamo on March 6, 1836, is observed each year by a candlelit remembrance in downtown San Antonio. But another, more festive event commemorates the battle’s anniversary: an annual private party in Terrell Hills for the community that has developed around the Alamo mystique.

headline: Honda Recalls 900,000 Minivans
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Minivans', 'Automobiles']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Honda is recalling almost 900,000 Odyssey minivans because of a potential fire hazard.
lead_paragraph: Honda is recalling almost 900,000 Odyssey minivans because of a potential fire hazard, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said in a report posted on its website on Saturday.

headline: Endangered School Says State Standards Hurt Troubled Youths
abstract: A 2013 Texas legislative provision has put six charter schools at risk, three focusing troubled youths, for failing to meet academic or financial accountability guidelines.
lead_paragraph: As a wide-reaching law intended to encourage the growth of high-quality Texas charter schools and shutter underperforming ones takes effect, the state is facing questions over the guidelines used to decide which schools to close.

headline: Syrian Forces Close to Taking Over Long-Held Rebel Town
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Government forces, backed by the Lebanese militia Hezbollah, have spent weeks edging toward Yabrud, a critical transit point for militants, refugees and arms heading in and out of Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As Syrian government forces on Saturday pushed into Yabrud, a town long held by rebels near the Lebanese border, opposition activists said that one of many fighters who fell in battle was a leader of the insurgent group the Nusra Front who had helped negotiate an unusual prisoner exchange last week.

headline: In Husband’s Campaign, a Chance to Make History
abstract: Attorney General Greg Abbott often speaks of the Mexican heritage of his wife, Cecilia Phalen Abbott, a onetime educator who would be the first Latina to be the first lady of Texas if he were elected.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Perry made history with an unprecedented three terms in office. The next administration could make history by just taking office.

headline: Denominations Downsizing and Selling Assets in More Secular Era
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Baptist Churches', 'Churches (Buildings)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: In the 20th century, denominations became wealthier and acquired better holdings, but now are pondering whether some properties “have outlived their usefulness.”
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The American Unitarian Association, peopled and powered by this city’s Brahmin elite, announced its presence here in 1886 with a grand and stately headquarters at the very top of Beacon Hill, right next door to the Statehouse.

headline: A Brazilian Model’s Transformative Role
abstract: Carol Marra is leading a new group of transgender models who are stepping into Brazil’s mainstream fashion industry.
lead_paragraph: Carol Marra is leading a new group of transgender models who are stepping into Brazil’s mainstream fashion industry.

headline: ‘That’s Not My Daughter’
abstract: Carol Marra says she did not grow up thinking she would be a model.
lead_paragraph: Carol Marra says she did not grow up thinking she would be a model.

headline: More Acceptance for Transgender Models
abstract: Carol Marra is leading a new class of transgender models who are stepping out of the alternative scene and into the mainstream of Brazil's fashion industry.
lead_paragraph: Carol Marra is leading a new class of transgender models who are stepping out of the alternative scene and into the mainstream of Brazil's fashion industry.

headline: After 20 Hours in Solitary, Colorado’s Prisons Chief Wins Praise
abstract: Rick Raemisch, whose predecessor was killed by an inmate who had been kept in solitary confinement, spent a night alone in a cell as part of a campaign against the practice.
lead_paragraph: CAÑON CITY, Colo. — The cells where inmates are kept in solitary confinement at the state penitentiary here are 7-by-13-foot boxes arranged in semicircular tiers. When the warden, Travis Trani, heard that Rick Raemisch, Colorado’s new chief of corrections, intended to spend a night in one of them, he had two reactions.

headline: Tensions Flare Over Loyalty to Russia in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: Nationalist and pro-secessions groups clashed in Kharkiv, a major city in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Nationalist and pro-secessions groups clashed in Kharkiv, a major city in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Transgender Models Prosper in Brazil, Where Carnival and Faith Reign
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Models (Professional)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Carnival (Pre-Lenten)']
abstract: Transgender models are enjoying success in Brazil, where crossing gender lines is increasingly accepted, but they say that the nation’s conservatism can also create a hostile environment.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — As a young boy in Brazil’s heartland, Carol Marra watched her parents politely correct strangers who said what a pretty daughter they had. In her teenage years, she coveted the boyfriends of her female classmates and tried out androgynous outfits, dutifully changing back into a young man’s clothes in her car before returning home.

headline: A Star Was (Recently) Born: A Play Boldly Casts Babies
abstract: The Young Vic production of “A Doll’s House” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music has a real baby onstage for an important cameo role.
lead_paragraph: Hattie Morahan, who stars as Nora in the acclaimed production of “A Doll’s House” now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, has won the kind of rave reviews any actor would envy.

headline: Questions as More Wastewater Flows in North Carolina
abstract: State regulators said Duke Energy, a utility already under a federal investigation for pollution, may have illegally released wastewater last week from a second site near of Raleigh.
lead_paragraph: Duke Energy, the giant utility whose spill of toxic waste into a North Carolina river last month is under federal investigation, released wastewater last week from a second site near Raleigh that state regulators said could be illegal.

headline: As Putin’s Popularity Soars, Voices of Opposition Are Being Drowned Out
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media']
abstract: While the world’s attention is trained on Ukraine, the Russian authorities are trying to mobilize support on federal television channels, and have muted independent voices on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — There were two large rallies on Saturday in Moscow. One was a pro-government rally “in support of Crimea and against fascism,” led by a phalanx of husky men in identical crimson jackets, marching military-style in a sea of red. Some held signs reading “No Maidan in Moscow” and “Glory to Berkut,” references to Independence Square, the site of the Ukrainian protests in Kiev, and to the riot police who cracked down on the protesters.

headline: Newfound Assertiveness Sends Romanian Toward Top of Rankings
abstract: Simona Halep has won 57 matches since May and will become the first Romanian player, male or female, to claim a top-five ranking since the mid-1970s.
lead_paragraph: INDIAN WELLS, Calif. — With light, springy footwork and a combination of defensive speed and offensive power, Simona Halep has been moving through courts and draws on the women’s tennis tour with considerable ease in recent months.

headline: David Brenner, Stand-up Comic of the Little Things in Life, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Brenner, a stand-up comic and occasional host of “The Tonight Show With Johnny Carson” whose brand of humor focused on the annoying little details of everyday life, had been a mentor to many rising comedians.
lead_paragraph: David Brenner, whose wry brand of observational humor made him a stand-up comedy star in the early 1970s and kept him in the public eye for more than four decades, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: In Colombia, Two Warring Officials Provide a Portrait of a Nation’s Political Divide
abstract: A conflict that arose after the country’s powerful inspector general ordered the mayor of Bogotá removed from office has captivated Colombians.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — The political battle royale playing out between the mayor of Bogotá and the country’s powerful inspector general, who ordered him removed from office, has been compared to a Latin soap opera. But as it drags on, it more closely resembles an absurdist drama in which two actors alternately fascinate and irritate their audience with squabbling, philosophizing and the occasional kick in the pants.

headline: Kentucky Adds Snarl to Its Skills
abstract: The young and talented Wildcats, criticized as underachievers for much of the season, continued to emphasize toughness as they overpowered Georgia and reached the SEC tournament final against Florida.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — With its collection of heralded freshmen, Kentucky is playing not like an entitled team but like an embattled one. The Wildcats, under harsh criticism for the program’s style of recruiting, have been ridiculed most of the season for not reaching preseason expectations of being No. 1, so now they look desperate, even determined, not to be remembered as underachievers.

headline: Series of Errors by Malaysia Mounts, Complicating the Task of Finding Flight 370
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Radar', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: A week after the plane disappeared, the trail is even colder as the search now sprawls from the snowy peaks of the Himalayas to the empty expanses of the southern Indian Ocean.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — The radar blip that was Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 did a wide U-turn over the Gulf of Thailand and then began moving inexorably past at least three military radar arrays as it traversed northern Malaysia, even flying high over one of the country’s biggest cities before heading out over the Strait of Malacca.

headline: Technical Problem Silences Ending of Met’s Live Simulcast of ‘Werther’
abstract: The death of the title character in Massenet’s “Werther” was silent for opera fans who went to movie theaters across the country on Saturday to see Jonas Kaufmann perform the title role in the Metropolitan Opera’s live high-definition simulcast.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:59 a.m. | It is one of the most wrenching endings in opera: the lingering death of the title character in Massenet’s “Werther.” But it was an accidentally, and frustratingly, silent ending for opera fans who went to movie theaters across the country on Saturday afternoon to see the celebrated tenor Jonas Kaufmann perform the title role in the Metropolitan Opera’s live high-definition simulcast.

lead_paragraph: Because of Purim, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Sunday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Early in the 2012 N.F.L. season, a pivotal, disputed call in Seattle’s last-gasp victory against Green Bay led to a quick resolution of the league’s labor dispute with its officials.

lead_paragraph: The Providence coaches sat courtside to watch Creighton’s win over Xavier in the semifinals of the Big East tournament Friday night, arriving back in their hotel well after midnight. Their night was just beginning.

headline: Alibaba Confirms It Will Begin I.P.O. Process in U.S.
abstract: In a post on its corporate blog, the company said it plans to list on an American stock market to become “a more global company.”
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, China’s online commerce giant, confirmed early on Sunday that it planned to begin the process of becoming a public company in the United States.

headline: What’s On Today?
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (NBC) CRISIS When a busload of teenagers from a Washington high school is kidnapped during a field trip, parents must decide how far they’re willing to go to guarantee the students’ safe return in this new action thriller. Especially when they are the children of business leaders, diplomats, politicians — and the president. Dermot Mulroney, above left, plays a former C.I.A. analyst turned chaperone who is also captured in the ambush. Gillian Anderson is the chief executive of a multinational corporation whose daughter (Halston Sage) could be worth a huge ransom. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said that the pilot, directed by Phillip Noyce, was terrific, noting that it “makes clear that money alone isn’t the driving motive behind the crime, and that high-level conspiracies within the government play a role.” She added: “Motive, however, is almost always the weakest point of a television thriller. The trick for ‘Crisis’ is to keep the action moving so fast that viewers don’t get bogged down in the logic — or lack of it.”

headline: Timing of Report by Flight’s Pilot Focuses Inquiry
abstract: The pilot did not mention any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — A signaling system was disabled on the missing Malaysia Airlines jet before a pilot spoke to air traffic control without mentioning any trouble, a senior Malaysian official said Sunday, reinforcing theories that one or both of the pilots may have been involved in diverting the plane and adding urgency to the investigation of their pasts and possible motivations.

headline: In China, Shaking Up Currency’s Strength
abstract: Recent developments suggest that the renminbi’s day-to-day strengthening is no longer the certainty it once appeared to be.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — One of the surest bets on China is starting to look a bit shaky.

headline: In Our Pages: March 17
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: A New Richard III.

headline: India Suspends Its Search for Flight 370
abstract: After scouring more than 24,000 nautical square miles, India on Sunday halted its search in the Indian Ocean while officials in Kuala Lumpur consider where else to look.
lead_paragraph: PORT BLAIR, India — After scouring more than 24,000 nautical square miles, India on Sunday suspended its search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in the waters around the isolated Andaman and Nicobar Islands chain while officials in Kuala Lumpur consider where else to search.

headline: Shouldn’t the Breast Pump Be as Elegant as an iPhone and as Quiet as a Prius by Now?
abstract: That noise? It’s the motor, not the suction, and a half-ton hybrid vehicle is quieter. And what product designer actually thought women wanted to see their nipples getting sucked into small tubes over and over again?
lead_paragraph: John: I made my way upstairs, drawn by a strange sound emanating from our bedroom. It was rhythmic, like the sound of an old dot matrix printer. As I opened the door, I was confronted with the image of my wife holding two plastic funnels over her breasts with a big frown across her face. I immediately thought of Madonna’s cone-shaped bra from the 1980s and let out a gasp.

headline: Fall Derails Men’s Duel in Half Marathon; Women’s Record Is Set
abstract: Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya became the first man to win the New York City Marathon and the Half Marathon with his victory on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Two days before the New York City Half Marathon, Geoffrey Mutai talked about his strategy against Mo Farah, the Olympic double gold medalist from Britain who was returning to the race he won in 2011.

headline: Crimea Votes to Secede From Ukraine as Russian Troops Keep Watch
abstract: An overwhelming majority voted on Sunday to leave Ukraine in a referendum that Western leaders have declared illegal and vowed to punish with sanctions.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — With thousands of heavily armed Russian troops occupying this perennially embattled peninsula, an overwhelming majority of Crimeans voted on Sunday to secede from Ukraine and join Russia, resolutely carrying out a public referendum that Western leaders had declared illegal and vowed to punish with economic sanctions.

headline: Syrian Government Forces Seize Town in a Deep Blow to Opposition
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Government forces, backed by Hezbollah fighters, took control of Yabrud, a critical transit point for militants, refugees and arms heading in and out of Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When Syrian government forces on Sunday swept into Yabrud, a town long held by rebels near the Lebanese border, it was a symbolic turning point for insurgents and government supporters alike in a conflict now heading into its fourth year.

headline: The Wages of Men
abstract: Mostly falling.
lead_paragraph: For reference: Here are changes in hourly real wages of men, 1973-2012, at different percentiles of the wage distribution, calculated from Census data by the Economic Policy Institute. As you can see, wages have fallen for 60 percent of men.

headline: Don’t Prosper and Die Early
abstract: America: Live free and die?
lead_paragraph: I was pleased to see this article by Annie Lowrey documenting the growing disparity in life expectancy between the haves and the have-nots. It’s kind of frustrating, however, that this is apparently coming as news not just to many readers but to many policymakers and pundits. Many of us have been trying for years to get this point across — to point out that when people call for raising the Social Security and Medicare ages, they’re basically saying that janitors must keep working because corporate lawyers are living longer. Yet it never seems to sink in.

headline: Staying Home, Connected to the World
abstract: There are both gains and losses when so many human interactions are possible through a smartphone.
lead_paragraph: On March 22, 1876, The New York Times reported that a hot new technology, the telephone — not Bell’s, but a device invented by a German — might mean that people would never have to leave their homes again.

headline: Charge of the Right Brigade
abstract: Why does the inflationary canon retain its hold?
lead_paragraph: Canon to right of me, canon to left of me — actually, scratch that, it’s all canon to right of me.

headline: Mitch Leigh, Who Composed ‘Man of La Mancha,’ Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Leigh had been a writer of incidental music for Broadway comedies when he was given the break of a lifetime, going on to win a Tony Award for “La Mancha,” though he never had another Broadway hit.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1964, a New York advertising-jingle composer in his early 30s received an unlikely job offer.

headline: Years After Abduction by North Korea, a Reunion
abstract: The parents of the woman, who was kidnapped in 1977 and is believed to have died in 1994, saw their North Korean-born granddaughter for the first time last week in Ulan Bator, Mongolia.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The parents of a Japanese woman abducted by North Korea in 1977 were allowed to see their North Korean-born granddaughter for the first time last week at a secret meeting in Mongolia, Japan’s Foreign Ministry said on Sunday.

abstract: The runner Mo Farah fell Sunday at the New York City Half Marathon.
lead_paragraph: The runner Mo Farah fell Sunday at the New York City Half Marathon.

lead_paragraph: At a news conference on Sunday, the Malaysian authorities listed possible reasons behind the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, including “sabotage.”

headline: For Free Texting Apps, the Market Is Far From Conquered
abstract: Facebook paid a lot of money for WhatsApp. But as a reporter discovered on a recent trip overseas, the text messaging service has a lot of competition.
lead_paragraph: In late February, while I was in Barcelona at the Mobile World Congress, the mobile phone trade show, I had a bit of a communication problem. To avoid racking up a hefty cellphone bill, I tried to keep in touch with the people I met using WhatsApp, the prominent free text messaging service that Facebook recently bought. But to my surprise, most people I met were using their country’s own flavor of texting app.

headline: 'Danny Boy'
abstract: A song by an Okinawan duo, Isamu Shimoji and Yukito Ara, sung to the traditional Irish tune.
lead_paragraph: A song by an Okinawan duo, Isamu Shimoji and Yukito Ara, sung to the traditional Irish tune.

headline: An Engineering Landmark Faces Demolition
abstract: Architects, engineers and preservationists are fighting to save the Shabolovka radio tower, considered the Eiffel Tower of Moscow and now on track for demolition.
lead_paragraph: One of the great feats of 20th-century engineering, a landmark of modernist architecture is facing demolition. Late last month, the Russian State Committee for Television and Radio Broadcasting agreed to the dismantling of the Shabolovka radio tower in Moscow.

headline: Accusations of Racism in a Brooklyn Lutheran Community
abstract: After the Rev. Samuel Cruz lost an election for a position to represent eight parishes, he discussed a need to address racial attitudes.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Samuel Cruz went into a meeting at his Sunset Park church last month as his bishop’s sole nominee for dean of the southwest Brooklyn conference of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.

headline: The Flute, the Flute Is Calling
abstract: For St. Patrick’s Day, a version of “Danny Boy” from another emerald isle, Okinawa.
lead_paragraph: Except for its deadly snakes, and the warmth of its blue-green ocean, Okinawa might as well be Ireland. It is a chain of emerald isles whose people lived for centuries under the boot of an oppressive empire. (Think Irish-English relations are complicated? Try Okinawan-Japanese.) Poverty drove generations of strivers from its shores — not to Boston or New York, but Hawaii, Peru, Brazil and beyond.

headline: A Rough Weekend for New Movies
abstract: Two holdover titles were the top box-office draws in North America: the animated “Mr. Peabody & Sherman” and “300: Rise of an Empire.”
lead_paragraph: Tyler Perry’s near decade-long run as a supplier of hit movies ended over the weekend, as “Tyler’s Perry’s The Single Moms Club” became his worst-performing release by far. Also disappointing was “Need for Speed,” a car-racing movie designed to start a franchise for Steven Spielberg’s deeply troubled DreamWorks Studios.

headline: Hollywood Conservatives Are Granted Tax-Exempt Status
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Friends of Abe will be recognized by the Internal Revenue Service as a tax-exempt organization. Gary Sinise, Jon Voight and Kelsey Grammer have been publicly associated with the group.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Friends of Abe, a loose fellowship of Hollywood conservatives, will be recognized by the Internal Revenue Service as a tax-exempt organization, a lawyer for the group confirmed on Sunday. “Friends of Abe was recognized as a 501(c)(3) public charity effective as of the date of its formation,” the lawyer, Ofer Lion, said in response to an email query.

headline: Ferlinghetti Travel Journals to Be Published
abstract: Lawrence Ferlinghetti, one of the last living links to the Beat generation, has sold the journals to a publisher that plans to release them in September 2015.
lead_paragraph: The poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti, at 94 one of the last living links to the Beat generation, has sold his travel journals to Liveright Publishing, a division of W.W. Norton, which plans to publish them in September 2015 as “Writing Across the Landscape: Travel Journals (1950-2013).” Sterling Lord, Jack Kerouac’s longtime literary agent and the representative for the Kerouac estate, made the sale to Robert Weil, the editor in chief of Liveright.

headline: Kerry Presses Russia on ‘Provocations’ in Ukraine
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: In his second call in two days to his Russian counterpart, Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concerns about the seizure of a gas plant near the border of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concern in a phone call on Sunday with his Russian counterpart about the Russian military’s seizure of a gas plant near the border of Crimea and what American officials described as “continuing provocations” in Ukraine’s eastern cities.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 88
abstract: The fastest goal in a World Cup final was scored nearly 40 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.
