lead_paragraph: A scene from Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s new play at the Signature Center.

headline: On the Street and in the Pews, East Harlem Mourns
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio and his wife, Chirlane McCray, spoke to two congregations that lost worshipers in the deadly explosion.
lead_paragraph: A Sunday morning in East Harlem means dressing up for church and buying flowers at the Associated supermarket on East 116th Street. It means stopping by the Dunkin’ Donuts down the block or maybe the tamale-and-atole stand on the corner of Lexington Avenue.

headline: Army General Reaches Deal on Sex Counts
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair is expected to plead guilty to sharply reduced charges in the military’s most closely watched sexual assault case.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The senior Army officer prosecuted in the military’s most closely watched sexual assault case, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, has agreed to plead guilty to sharply reduced charges, including that he disobeyed a commander’s order, misused his government charge card and mistreated his former mistress, a captain.

headline: At Shortstop, Red Sox See a Cornerstone Taking Shape
abstract: Xander Bogaerts, the 21-year-old shortstop of the Red Sox, tries to follow the example set by his favorite player, Derek Jeter, right down to the new number on his jersey.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Right through the main clubhouse doors of the Boston Red Sox complex here, in the hallway just off the locker room, is a floor-to-ceiling photograph of the 2013 World Series celebration. Among the revelers is a player wearing No. 72, which seems out of place. Nobody with a number that high usually makes it out of spring training.

headline: Overheated Passion Is a Thing With Feathers
abstract: In the world according to “Lac (After Swan Lake),” by Jean-Christophe Maillot for Les Ballets de Monte Carlo, there are two types of women: the kind you marry and the kind you sleep with.
lead_paragraph: In “Swan Lake,” the timeless ballet about a swan queen, the prince who loves her and the black swan who seduces him, the real tragedy happens when choreographers try to sex it up. The music, the story, the swans: It’s already there.

headline: Red Bulls Rewind: Lights, Camera, Henry
abstract: The Red Bulls’ captain, Thierry Henry, added another chapter to his novel postgoal celebrations when he scored against Colorado on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — As goal-scoring celebrations go, the Red Bulls’ captain, Thierry Henry, has a distinct flair for the dramatic with a flash of cinéma vérité.

headline: Composer’s Virtuosity Captured
abstract: The Composer Portrait series at the Miller Theater continued with a tribute to the award-winning South Korean classicist Unsuk Chin.
lead_paragraph: The musical family tree of Unsuk Chin, who was honored with a Composer Portrait at the Miller Theater on Thursday, has widespread roots. The strongest of them is Gyorgy Ligeti, with whom she studied in the 1980s, but there is also a discernible dose of Bartok in the pugilistic power of her orchestral writing and that of Conlon Nancarrow in the polyrhythmic dazzle of her piano études and electronic compositions. The shimmering sonorities and complex ensemble play of Balinese gamelan music vividly influence works like her Double Concerto for piano and percussion and ensemble, while the musical traditions of Ms. Chin’s native South Korea exert a much subtler pull.

headline: Ballerinas, So Elegant, Take a Moment to Vent
abstract: In new memoirs, the dancers Jenifer Ringer and Misty Copeland chronicle their paths to the upper reaches of the ballet world.
lead_paragraph: When Jenifer Ringer, who retired last month from New York City Ballet after 24 years, watched Darren Aronofsky’s “Black Swan,” she laughed at this thriller on the forces of ballet darkness. But her memoir, “Dancing Through It: My Journey in the Ballet,” does not skimp on what she calls “the crazy side of ballet.” With quiet eloquence and self-deprecating humor, Ms. Ringer suggests how a profession as idealistic as it is hierarchical and competitive might drive a talented young woman to self-destruct.

headline: An Irish Medal at the 1979 European Championships
abstract: Since this is St. Patrick’s Day, let’s have a deal featuring Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Since this is St. Patrick’s Day, let’s have a deal featuring Ireland. It occurred during that country’s third-place finish behind Italy and Denmark at the 1979 European Open Teams Championship in Lausanne, Switzerland.

headline: For the Irish Arts Center, a New Home to Expand
abstract: The Irish Arts Center plans to build a $54 million home around the corner from its cramped quarters on West 51st Street.
lead_paragraph: Aidan Connolly has to employ a multitude of slashes to describe the cramped quarters of the Irish Arts Center, a hearth for Irish culture that he operates from a former Hell’s Kitchen tenement on West 51st Street.

headline: A New Lynn Nottage Play
abstract: The Oregon Shakespeare Festival has announced that the world premiere of a Lynn Nottage play will be among the highlights of its 2015 season.
lead_paragraph: The Oregon Shakespeare Festival has announced that the world premiere of a Lynn Nottage play will be among the highlights of its 2015 season. Ms. Nottage, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 2009 for her drama “Ruined,” visited Reading, Pa., over two years to research her new work, “Sweat.” It follows a group of friends who work in a steel plant. The festival lineup is to include two more world premieres: “Head Over Heels,” an Elizabethan musical comedy that features a book by Jeff Whitty (“Avenue Q”) and music and lyrics from the catalog of the pop group the Go-Go’s, and “Fingersmith,” a play based on Sarah Waters’s 2002 novel of the same name. The festival also announced that it would stage all of Shakespeare’s plays over a 10-year period, starting in 2015 with “Much Ado About Nothing,” “Pericles” and “Antony and Cleopatra.”

headline: St. Joseph’s Rises Above V.C.U. to Take A-10 Title
abstract: Langston Galloway had 19 points, and the Hawks used their height advantage to win their first Atlantic 10 tournament since 1997.
lead_paragraph: Minutes before the Atlantic 10 tournament final at Barclays Center on Sunday, Virginia Commonwealth students began chanting, “This is our house.” Daryus Quarles, the senior forward for St. Joseph’s, shook his head in disagreement.

headline: Art World’s Cream Rises at Maastricht
abstract: The offerings at this year’s blue-chip Maastricht art fair, in the Netherlands, stretch from the ancient to the modern.
lead_paragraph: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands — It seems as if just a moment ago New Yorkers were complaining about fair fatigue after the city’s busiest art week, with its dizzying number of shows, its oversaturation of contemporary art, its proliferating number of collectors and spiraling prices.

headline: Another Taylor Marathon: They Push Dancers, Don’t They?
abstract: “Marathon Cadenzas,” the centerpiece of a program by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Friday at the David H. Koch Theater, dramatizes the dance marathons of the 1920s and ’30s.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Paul Taylor will be 84 in July; his company’s current season at the David H. Koch Theater is its 60th anniversary. His three-page program biography, laden with superlatives, begins with the sentence “Choreographer Paul Taylor is the greatest living pioneer of America’s indigenous art of modern dance.” Though he’s certainly a master, it’s been decades since he seemed any kind of pioneer.

headline: Boy Meets Girl; Boy Must Win Dad Over
abstract: In the Bollywood romantic comedy “Bewakoofiyaan,” a seemingly perfect love story hits the skids when the recession leaves the man jobless.
lead_paragraph: The wages of love — that is, the salaries of people in love — is the most interesting plot hinge in Nupur Asthana’s Bollywood romantic comedy “Bewakoofiyaan” (“Foolishness” in Hindi). This tale of a yuppie couple (played by Ayushmann Khurrana and Sonam Kapoor) flirts with intriguing notions of recessionary struggle, though strained, contrived humor bogs it down.

headline: Barely Treading Water at $9.49 an Hour
abstract: The HBO documentary “Paycheck to Paycheck” follows the ordinary but grindingly difficult life of one single mother over the course of a year.
lead_paragraph: Much of the attention lavished on HBO tends to go to its elaborate fictions: “True Detective,” for instance, which just completed its first season, and “Game of Thrones,” which is about to start its fourth. But fact has a place on the network as well, and you can’t get much closer to the hard facts of everyday existence than “Paycheck to Paycheck: The Life and Times of Katrina Gilbert,” a documentary on Monday night.

headline: The Story of Bridie and Mo
abstract: Two red-haired girls on the Dublin docks, at the end of an Irish boom.
lead_paragraph: ON a visit to Dublin in 2008, just before Ireland’s economic collapse, I took a walk down to the Docklands at the edge of the River Liffey and was astonished to find that what had long been a sooty, rundown port of 19th-century warehouses had become one of the most modern and desirable neighborhoods in Europe — all luxury apartments and upscale hotels bathed in theatrical lighting, a glossy prairie of glass and steel.

headline: The Ugandan Tabloid That Stole Our Pride
abstract: After the Red Pepper victimized my gay friends, I had to sue.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — IN 2012, I was living and working at a nonprofit in rural Uganda, far away from my friends at home. As a single gay man, I longed for community. I contacted Frank Mugisha, the executive director of Sexual Minorities Uganda, an umbrella organization for gay rights groups, after reading an opinion essay he wrote. Through Frank, I met Richard Lusimbo, the nonprofit’s research manager, and then others in the vibrant L.G.B.T. community in Uganda.

headline: In Masochistic Twist, the Faster You Die, the More Popular the Game
abstract: Flappy Bird, Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze, and Dark Souls II are all examples of games in which difficulty is the appeal, and success is measured by delaying failure.
lead_paragraph: The popularity of video games is proof that people enjoy having problems. Apparently life isn’t tough enough for those of us who seek amusement in failure’s premiere form of entertainment. Taxes, relationships and health troubles not stressful enough? Play an arduous video game that you’ll fail at in seconds. Millions of people do. They like a challenge. They like to walk into a bit of trouble.

headline: Room Under the Roof
abstract: The return of John Lieb.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Lest I be further accused of being prejudiced against vowel progressions (you know who you are), I’m going to skip that part of my discussion and just welcome John Lieb back. His last puzzle dribbled people all over the grid, but today’s puzzle is a considerably neater solve. Today, we have a G*M progression.

headline: New York Will Lose Ballet Theater’s ‘Nutcracker’
abstract: American Ballet Theater, which went toeshoe to toeshoe with New York City Ballet, will end its five-year “Nutcracker” run at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: In the end, maybe this town wasn’t big enough for the two of them after all — the two “Nutcrackers,” that is.

headline: Russia Could Still Turn U.S. ‘Into Radioactive Dust,’ News Anchor in Moscow Reminds Viewers
abstract: One of Russia’s most influential television hosts appeared on the evening news Sunday to remind viewers that Russia is still “the only country in the world capable of turning the U.S.A. into radioactive dust.”
lead_paragraph: As the United States condemned a referendum on the future of the Crimean peninsula staged by pro-Russian separatists on Sunday, one of Russia’s most influential television hosts appeared on the evening news in Moscow, before a huge mushroom cloud graphic, to remind viewers that Russia is still “the only country in the world capable of turning the U.S.A. into radioactive dust.”

headline: The Battle Over the MedFly
abstract: In 1981, California tried to stop the Mediterranean fruit fly from infesting crops and threatening the state’s agricultural industry. But it would take more than conventional tools to defeat this bug.
lead_paragraph: In 1981, California tried to stop the Mediterranean fruit fly from infesting crops and threatening the state’s agricultural industry. But it would take more than conventional tools to defeat this bug.

keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Account assignments, executive appointments and miscellaneous news from advertising agencies.
lead_paragraph: Accounts

headline: The Battle Over the Medfly
abstract: In 1981, California started spraying the pesticide malathion to stop the Mediterranean fruit fly, stoking fears and protests among many in the state.
lead_paragraph: Ceratitis capitata. To a Muggle’s ears, it sounds like an incantation from a Hogwarts wizard. If only the matter were whimsical.

headline: Duke Loses Cool as Virginia Wins First Tournament Title Since ’76
abstract: Malcolm Brogdon scored 23 points, including 10 in the final six minutes as Virginia pulled away to beat Duke for its second conference tournament title in 61 years.
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — The swirl of Virginia orange and Duke royal blue in the Greensboro Coliseum stands seemed to rise and fall with each possession, each drive to the basket, each steal, each tie and each lead change in the heart-stopping Atlantic Coast Conference tournament final Sunday afternoon.

headline: Big Money Upends a Festival
keywords: ['Music', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Social Media']
abstract: South by Southwest Music festival, still an indie haven, is now showing the hallmarks of big business and social media.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — I’ve had it with hashtags.

headline: Crimeans, at the Crossroads
abstract: On Sunday, the referendum on the status of Crimea divided the population of the multicultural region.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, the referendum on the status of Crimea divided the population of the multicultural region.

headline: What to Do About California’s Drought
abstract: Readers discuss climate change, farmers’ use of water, desalination plants and fracking.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rangers Lose Game and Their Cushion in the Race for the Playoffs
abstract: The Rangers lost ground in their bid to reach the postseason and Henrik Lundqvist failed to earn a record-breaking win as the team was shut out by the Sharks.
lead_paragraph: Henrik Lundqvist called it painful, and it was — a 1-0 defeat to the San Jose Sharks that further imperiled the Rangers’ already precarious playoff situation.

headline: Undercover TV Reports on School Security Raise Ethical Questions
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'School Shootings', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: School shootings have prompted efforts by news organizations in recent months to assess the effectiveness of safety measures, but some of these reports have gone disturbingly wrong.
lead_paragraph: The three news reports followed the same format: Television reporters walked into schools with hidden cameras, under the premise of testing the security measures. Each time, the anchors provided a sobering assessment of the findings.

headline: When Speech Won’t Come: Understanding Aphasia
abstract: The National Aphasia Association and Dr. Stanley F. Wainapel of Montefiore Medical Center respond to a Sunday Review essay.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Heroin Use in Vermont
abstract: High school students in Bennington object to a news article that suggested rampant drug use in their school.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jail Reform in California
abstract: Californians United for a Responsible Budget responds to an editorial about sentencing reform in the state.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Men's Bracket
abstract: View and print our N.C.A.A. tournament bracket.
lead_paragraph: View and print our N.C.A.A. tournament bracket.

headline: Honor Killings in the West
abstract: The feminist author Phyllis Chesler responds to a front-page article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A New Model for Music: Big Bands, Big Brands
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Music', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: At the South by Southwest festival this year, historically a place of artistic idiosyncrasy, corporate logos were everywhere.
lead_paragraph: I like Doritos as much as the next guy. More, probably. And I admire Lady Gaga for her handcrafted rise to the top of pop culture. In Austin last week, the salty, cheesy wonder of Doritos was brought to you by the sweet, uplifting allure of Lady Gaga. Or was it the other way around?

headline: Palestinians Split in Gaza as Hamas Blocks Fatah Rally
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The conflict is a sign of the enduring schism between Hamas and the Palestinian Authority, a factor that further complicates American-brokered Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, prevented supporters of the rival Fatah party from holding a rare demonstration here on Sunday in solidarity with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority ahead of his meeting with President Obama, which is set for Monday in Washington.

headline: Viral Video Turns Senator Into a Silent Comedy Star
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Footage of the Senate minority leader, posted online by his campaign for supporters to use in ads, has inspired a viral burst of spoofs known as McConnelling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Senator Mitch McConnell’s re-election campaign released two-and-a-half minutes of video footage featuring him wordlessly smiling, it was most likely hoping to provide a friendly “super PAC’ with high-quality images of Mr. McConnell to use in ads.

headline: Los Angeles Times Fires Writer of Articles on College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Newspapers', 'Sex Crimes', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The newspaper said Occidental College had not been required to disclose the accusations of sexual abuse and that a reporter’s relationship with a source was improper.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Times fired an investigative journalist last week, after disclosing errors in articles about sexual abuse accusations at Occidental College and revealing that the reporter had an inappropriate relationship with a source for one of those articles.

headline: Video Notebook: Atlantic 10 Final
abstract: The St. Joseph's coach Phil Martelli responds to a question about comments made by the Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski about the quality of the Atlantic 10 conference.
lead_paragraph: The St. Joseph's coach Phil Martelli responds to a question about comments made by the Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski about the quality of the Atlantic 10 conference.

headline: In Illinois, Republicans See an Office Up for Grabs
abstract: Bruce Rauner, a political first-timer and multimillionaire businessman, is seen as the front-runner in Illinois’s Republican primary for governor.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Democrats have dominated state government here for so long that they even held on to the governor’s office in 2010 as their last governor, Rod R. Blagojevich, was facing corruption charges that would send him to federal prison.

headline: Marlo Thomas Carves a Niche on Internet TV
abstract: “Mondays With Marlo,” a talk show hosted by Marlo Thomas, the actress and activist, has built an audience by addressing the concerns of women over 35.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Danny Thomas was a television pioneer of the 1950s and ’60s. Now, his daughter Marlo Thomas has emerged as an unlikely innovator on Internet TV.

headline: Wave of Sexual Abuse Allegations for Private Boys’ Schools in Britain
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Prompted by publicity surrounding recent child abuse scandals, dozens of British men have come forward about molestation they say they suffered at expensive private schools.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prompted by publicity surrounding recent child abuse scandals involving well-known figures, dozens of British men are breaking decades of silence about molestation they say they suffered as boys at expensive private schools, forcing the schools to confront allegations that in the past might have been hushed up, ignored or treated derisively.

headline: Family Cable Channels Add Original Series
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Television', 'Families and Family Life', 'Cable Television']
abstract: Crown Media Holdings, ABC Family and Nickelodeon Group are among companies that are highlighting original series in upfront presentations, so called because they promote the fall season.
lead_paragraph: CABLE channels that specialize in family programming are adding more original scripted series to their schedules as marketers demonstrate growing interest in such shows while, at the same time, introducing commercials that offer new definitions of what makes a family.

headline: In Two Starts, Tanaka Has Made It Look Easy
abstract: Against established major league hitters, the newly acquired Japanese pitcher was piling up swing-and-miss strikes.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — It is only two starts, and it is only spring training, but like a developing piece of film, a clearer image of Masahiro Tanaka is emerging, and it continues to dazzle.

headline: In Reversal Since the Recession, Some States Give More Money to Public Television
abstract: Funding is still off sharply from the 2008 fiscal year, but 35 states have set aside about $191.5 million for 2014.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana would seem an unlikely candidate to receive an award from the Association of Public Television Stations: In 2005, while in the House of Representatives, he led a failed attempt to zero out federal funding for public media.

headline: Lithium Producer Chases Tesla’s Bold Battery Plan
abstract: The California company Simbol Materials is building a plant that will use a novel extraction process, in the hopes that it can provide the lithium needed for the batteries in Tesla’s cars.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Tesla Motors, the maker of high-end electric cars, announced plans to open the world’s largest battery plant in 2017. The goal is to overcome what it calls the biggest obstacle to meeting increased demand for its vehicles: a reliable supply of the advanced batteries that power them.

headline: Vodafone Agrees to Acquire the Spanish Cable Operator Ono for $10 Billion
abstract: The deal would give Vodafone, flush with cash after selling its Verizon Wireless stake, a way to go head-to-head against Telefónica in Spain.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:23 a.m. | LONDON – The British telecommunications company Vodafone is doubling down on cable.

headline: Canada Explores G.M. Link to Accidents
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Canada is looking into whether a fatal crash last June is related to the automaker’s faulty ignition switches.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — As pressure mounts on General Motors in the United States over its worldwide recall of 1.6 million cars for a defective ignition switch that has been linked to 12 deaths, Canadian officials are starting to take notice.

headline: 2 Oligarchs in $7 Billion Deal for a German Oil Company
abstract: RWE said it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its oil and natural gas subsidiary, RWE Dea, to the Russian billionaires Mikhail Fridman and German Khan for 5.1 billion euros.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The German utility RWE said on Sunday that it had reached a preliminary agreement to sell its oil and natural gas subsidiary, RWE Dea, to the Russian billionaires Mikhail Fridman and German Khan for 5.1 billion euros, or roughly $7 billion.

headline: That Old-Time Whistle
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Medicaid', 'Medicare', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: American conservatism is still, after all these years, largely driven by claims that liberals are giving money away to “those people.”
lead_paragraph: There are many negative things you can say about Paul Ryan, chairman of the House Budget Committee and the G.O.P.’s de facto intellectual leader. But you have to admit that he’s a very articulate guy, an expert at sounding as if he knows what he’s talking about.

headline: Boston’s St. Patrick’s Day Breakfast Breaks Barriers, but Its Parade Does Not
keywords: ["St Patrick's Day", 'Parades', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Elections, Governors', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Even as the breakfast showcased the “new” multicultural Boston, the traditional St. Patrick’s Day parade, which barred openly gay marchers, was a reminder of the “old” Boston that still exists.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A stage filled with many Irish-American politicians, a traditionally male cohort, opened the annual St. Patrick’s Day breakfast in South Boston on Sunday with a jaunty version of “If You’re Irish, Come Into the Parlor,” when someone else burst in — a Haitian-American woman, singing, dancing and electrifying the audience.

headline: Midwest: Transfer and Sidekick
abstract: Rodney Hood left Mississippi State and became the second option to the freshman sensation Jabari Parker on a Duke team now seeded third in the Midwest Region.
lead_paragraph: The fairy-tale moment of Rodney Hood’s young basketball career came when the phone rang in spring 2012 and the voice on the other end belonged to Duke Coach Mike Krzyzewski.

headline: A Constellation of Satellites
abstract: Planet Labs, a San Francisco aerospace start-up, is launching 100 of its small satellites into orbit this year where they will photograph the Earth every single day.
lead_paragraph: Planet Labs, a San Francisco aerospace start-up, is launching 100 of its small satellites into orbit this year where they will photograph the Earth every single day.

headline: Start-Ups Aim to Conquer Space Market
abstract: The start-up Planet Labs is challenging the giants of the space industry by producing dozens of small satellites that are cheaper and quicker to build than traditional satellites.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was party time at the Planet Labs satellite factory, in an unkempt office in the trendy South of Market neighborhood here.

headline: East: Unselfish and Deep
abstract: Villanova has been a nonentity in recent N.C.A.A. tournaments, but this year’s team may have the right mentality and momentum.
lead_paragraph: It has been five years since Villanova Coach Jay Wright and the all-American point guard Scottie Reynolds took the Wildcats to the Final Four — their second appearance in four years. It turned out that 2009 was the apex of a five-year run in which Villanova won at least two N.C.A.A. tournament games four times.

headline: What Would Plato Tweet?
abstract: Probably less about what he had for lunch. And more about justice and wisdom.

headline: West: Leading With Defense
abstract: Arizona, seeded first in the West, will take big-name talent to the N.C.A.A. tournament, but if it wins its first national title since 1997, it will be on the strength of its man-to-man defense.
lead_paragraph: Arizona was locked in a difficult game against Colorado on Friday night in Las Vegas when the Buffaloes’ Xavier Johnson swooped down the lane for a one-handed dunk. But a not-so-strange thing happened on the way to a momentum swing.

headline: As U.S. Looks for Terror Links in Plane Case, Malaysia Rejects Extensive Help
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: With no obvious motive apparent, American investigators are considering a wide range of possibilities but caution that all remain merely speculative.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With malicious intent strongly suspected in the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, American intelligence and law enforcement agencies renewed their search over the weekend for any evidence that the plane’s diversion was part of a terrorist plot. But they have found nothing so far, senior officials said, and their efforts have been limited by the Malaysian authorities’ refusal to accept large-scale American assistance.

headline: States Urge Retail Giants With Pharmacies to Stop Selling Tobacco Products
abstract: More than two dozen attorneys general encouraged five of the country’s largest retailers to follow the example of CVS and stop selling tobacco products in stores that also have pharmacies.
lead_paragraph: More than two dozen attorneys general sent letters on Sunday to five of the country’s largest retailers, encouraging them to stop selling tobacco products in stores that also have pharmacies, which would follow the example CVS Caremark set with its announcement earlier this year that it would stop selling such products in its drugstores.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of March 17
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt, fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday and an auction of 10-year inflation-protected securities on Thursday.

headline: South: Playing With Discipline
abstract: The senior point guard Scottie Wilbekin, suspended to start the season, has steered Florida to a No. 1 national ranking.
lead_paragraph: Scottie Wilbekin’s toes were over the edge of Florida Coach Billy Donovan’s gangplank in June, when Wilbekin was caught violating a team rule for a second time in seven months and was suspended for a second time.

headline: Florida Leads No. 1 Seeds in an N.C.A.A. Bracket Light on Midmajors
abstract: Arizona, Wichita State and Virginia joined the Gators as top seeds in a draw heavy on legacy conference teams.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Gators, who barely held off Kentucky to win the Southeastern Conference tournament championship on Sunday and extend their winning streak to 26 games, landed the No. 1 overall seed when the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament pairings were announced less than an hour after the SEC final.

headline: After Deadly Draft Riots, a Shared Experience Reshaped Families in Manhattan
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Irish-Americans', 'Census', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', "St Patrick's Day"]
abstract: In the late 1860s, scores of interracial couples emerged in the Eighth Ward: African-American men and Irish women who met where they worked and in the crowded tenements they shared.
lead_paragraph: The draft riots exploded on the streets of Manhattan in 1863 when poor Irish immigrants and other whites turned on African-Americans in a bloody spasm of beating, maiming and lynching. Many of us know the story: It was the worst civil disturbance in our city’s history, a bloodletting that left more than 100 people dead and laid bare the tensions between Irish and black New Yorkers who often lived and labored side by side.

headline: West’s Drought and Growth Intensify Conflict Over Water Rights
abstract: The explosive growth of cities is raising the stakes for farmers and industry amid a series of fierce legal and political battles over water.
lead_paragraph: MUMFORD, Tex. — Across the parched American West, the long drought has set off a series of fierce legal and political battles over who controls an increasingly dear treasure — water.

headline: Kansas Has Star on the Court and Maybe One in Reserve
abstract: Andrew Wiggins, the Big 12 freshman of the year, has propped the Jayhawks on his slender shoulders with Joel Embiid, a lithe 7-footer from Cameroon, out indefinitely with a stress fracture in his back.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — There are times when Andrew Wiggins, the versatile freshman guard for Kansas, will scowl, smile and laugh, displaying the usual emotions of a 19-year-old navigating his first collegiate postseason.

headline: Fed to Cut Stimulus Efforts, and a ‘Net Neutrality’ Vote
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee is expected to cut its monthly purchases, and the European Union parliamentary committee will vote Tuesday on telecommunications legislation.
lead_paragraph: FED IS EXPECTED TO CUT ITS STIMULUS EFFORTS FURTHER

headline: Unskilled and Destitute Are Hiring Targets for Fukushima Cleanup
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Nuclear Wastes']
abstract: The operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has left the complex cleanup to a poorly trained work force that has made some dangerous missteps.
lead_paragraph: NARAHA, Japan — “Out of work? Nowhere to live? Nowhere to go? Nothing to eat?” the online ad reads. “Come to Fukushima.”

headline: Hey, Subway Hog
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A sprawling napper insisted to crowded standees that the subway car was his private bedroom.

headline: A Squabbling Family Kept in the Dark
abstract: In “Appropriate,” the playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins brings together dissatisfied relatives for one last angry feast of guilt and recrimination.
lead_paragraph: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins admits he is a thief. This is a refreshing and useful confession. For as you watch “Appropriate” — his very fine, subversively original new play at the Pershing Square Signature Center — you’re sure to find yourself thinking of a host of literary antecedents for this seemingly traditional family melodrama.

headline: Ola L. Mize, Honored for Heroics in Korean War, Dies at 82
keywords: ['Medal of Honor (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: He initially refused the Medal of Honor, the nation’s highest military award for valor, but finally accepted it on behalf of his men, a recognition presented to him by President Dwight D. Eisenhower in September 1954.
lead_paragraph: Ola L. Mize, a sharecropper’s son who was awarded the Medal of Honor for valor after leading his outnumbered men in harrowing combat in the Korean War and single-handedly killing dozens of enemy soldiers, died on March 5 at his home in Gadsden, Ala. He was 82.

headline: Low-Wage Workers Are Finding Poverty Harder to Escape
abstract: For those at the low end of the hourly wage scale, even meeting basic household needs can be a stretch, and roads out of poverty are scarce.
lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At 7 in the morning, they are already lined up — poultry plant workers, housekeepers, discount store clerks — to ask for help paying their heating bills or feeding their families.

headline: Charter Schools
abstract: The mayor has hardly waged “war” on charter schools, but he does need to tone down the divisive rhetoric.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio campaigned on the promise of re-evaluating the practice of co-locating charter and noncharter schools in public school buildings. Critics of charter schools were encouraged; charter enthusiasts feared he would damage schools that served students well.

headline: A Hard Turn
abstract: Now is the time for the mayor to make a full transition from campaigning to governing.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio sailed into office on the winds of a well-run campaign. Then he kept on campaigning, pressing for one overriding goal: a vast expansion of full-day prekindergarten and after-school programs, financed by an income tax on wealthier New Yorkers. Though the tax has always had only a whisper of a prayer of coming true — it needed approval in the State Legislature, and Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Senate Republicans were dead set against it — Mr. de Blasio pushed on anyway, giving no indication of having a Plan B.

headline: Fans and the Foes They Love to Hate
abstract: In an era of freewheeling trades in pro sports and college conferences extending outside of regions, should fans still care about rivalries?

headline: Global Crises Put Obama’s Strategy of Caution to the Test
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Turmoil in Ukraine and Syria is challenging President Obama’s attempts to change the way the United States deals with its overseas adversaries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For five years, President Obama has consciously recast how America engages with the world’s toughest customers. But with Russia poised to annex Crimea after Sunday’s referendum, with a mounting threat to the rest of Ukraine and with the carnage in Syria accelerating, Mr. Obama’s strategy is now under greater stress than at any time in his presidency.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Defense and Military Forces']

headline: Amid Mayoral Missteps and Snubs of Parades, Irish Eyes Are Rolling in New York
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio often celebrates the multiethnic fabric of New York, but for the city’s Irish, his young mayoralty has been perceived as a series of slights and indignities.
lead_paragraph: He wants to close schools for the Chinese New Year, has pledged fealty to an Israeli political group, sprinkles Spanish and Italian phrases into his speeches and speaks frequently of his wife’s Caribbean heritage.

headline: Five Freshmen to Watch in the N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: These freshmen have been billed as making up the best rookie class since Greg Oden and Kevin Durant arrived on campus.
lead_paragraph: Before the season, four freshmen were billed as making up the best rookie class since Greg Oden and Kevin Durant arrived on campus, and the superlatives only multiplied. Then Kansas discovered it had another freshman star, Joel Embiid, who could leapfrog the rest to be the No. 1 pick in the N.B.A. draft in June. But why worry about all that now? Let’s enjoy watching these stars play in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

lead_paragraph: VARANASI, India — In India’s oldest city, the only female gatekeeper of heaven sits in her homespun sari and tends to an open oven in a 14th-century building near the sacred Ganges River.

headline: 59E59 Theaters to Announce Fresh Plans
abstract: A new slate of productions are to be presented on the main stage of 59E59’s three-theater complex, the 196-seat Theater A.
lead_paragraph: The Off Broadway theater company Primary Stages announced in January that it would end its decade-long residency at 59E59 Theaters this spring, moving to the Duke on 42nd Street. 59E59 Theaters has a plan to fill the void: Elysabeth Kleinhans, the artistic director, and Peter Tear, the executive producer, are to announce on Monday that they will introduce 5A Season, a new slate of productions to be presented on the main stage of 59E59’s three-theater complex, the 196-seat Theater A.

headline: Ticket Pricing Puts ‘Lion King’ Atop Broadway’s Circle of Life
abstract: “The Lion King” passed “Wicked” as 2013’s top Broadway earner with help from a sophisticated algorithm that calibrates prices based on demand and purchasing patterns.
lead_paragraph: How did “The Lion King” turn around its once-shaky fortunes and become the top-grossing show on Broadway in 2013, an unprecedented feat for long-running musicals, which usually cool after a few hot seasons? Hint: It’s not because it added performances after 16 years.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:45 P.M. (TCM) THE RISING OF THE MOON (1957) Comprising three Irish tales that were filmed in Ireland with Irish actors, this movie, directed by John Ford, is about as close to the Emerald Isle as American audiences can get without leaving home this St. Patrick’s Day. The first vignette, “The Majesty of the Law,” is about a highly principled man arrested in an assault case; the second, “A Minute’s Wait,” is a farce set on a train; and the third, which shares the film’s title, is based on Lady Gregory’s one-act drama about an Irish patriot. “All in all, Mr. Ford, who made this picture as a personal labor of love, has given us Irish characters as lushly sentimental as the songs that run through his black-and-white idyll,” Bosley Crowther wrote in The New York Times. The film is one of several Irish-centric movies the channel is showing throughout the day, including “The Flying Irishman” (1939), at 9 a.m.; the musical “My Wild Irish Rose” (1947), at noon; and “Finian’s Rainbow” (1968), at 5:15 p.m.

headline: SEAL Team Raids a Tanker and Thwarts a Militia’s Bid to Sell Libyan Oil
keywords: ['Hijacking', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: The American operation saved the fragile transitional government in Tripoli from a potentially catastrophic loss of control over its main source of revenue and last source of power: Libya’s vast oil reserves.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — United States Navy commandos seized a renegade tanker carrying illicit Libyan oil in the Mediterranean southeast of Cyprus on Monday, thwarting a breakaway militia’s attempt to sell the oil on the black market. No shots were fired, no one was injured and the commandos captured three armed Libyans described by the ship’s captain as hijackers.

headline: Hunting Honey, and Trying to Hide
abstract: An ancient tradition of hunting honey on Nepalese cliffsides is in danger of vanishing from excessive tourism — and even photographers.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Newey has made a career documenting vanishing cultures and traditions: Mongolian eagle hunters, ritualistic bull-jumping in Ethiopia and tribal festivals in Papua New Guinea. But the Indiana Jones-ish golden stills of his latest project, “Gurung Honey Hunters,” present a paradox, because photojournalists like Mr. Newey contribute to the tradition’s disappearance in central Nepal’s foothill villages and mountainsides.

headline: Daily Report: Start-Ups Set Their Sights on Space

lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley, not content with changing how retailers, taxi companies and hotels do business, is taking its disruptive ways into outer space. Several young companies with roots in Silicon Valley are trying to elbow their way into a business long dominated by national governments and aeronautics giants like Boeing, Quentin Hardy and Nick Bilton report.

headline: Lawmakers in Crimea Move Swiftly to Split From Ukraine

lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Ukraine — In the face of stern international criticism a day after a disputed referendum, the Parliament of the breakaway republic of Crimea declared its independence from Ukraine on Monday, formally asking Russia to annex it and moving swiftly to cement its rupture with the authorities in Kiev.

headline: Lost Jet’s Path Seen as Altered via Computer
abstract: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The first turn to the west that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its planned flight path from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing was carried out through a computer system that was most likely programmed by someone in the plane’s cockpit who was knowledgeable about airplane systems, according to senior American officials.

headline: Alibaba’s New York State of Mind
abstract: Alibaba confirms it will begin the process of going public in New York. | Vodafone agrees to purchase the Spanish cable company Ono. | Investors are waiting to see the extent of Western sanctions on Russia after Crimea’s vote to secede from Ukraine. | The Justice Department put investigations of mortgage crime on the back burner.
lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group, China’s online commerce giant, says it plans to begin the process of going public in New York, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook. The long-awaited initial public offering could be one of the biggest ever and could eventually raise more than the $16 billion that Facebook secured nearly two years ago. Analysts estimate that Alibaba could reach a valuation upward of $130 billion.

headline: Metro-North: A ‘Severe Assessment’
abstract: A report found that the second largest commuter railroad in the country emphasizes punctuality over caution.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials reported Friday that they found “a deficient safety culture” in the second largest commuter railroad in the country: Metro-North, which connects New York City to its northern suburbs and Connecticut. Every weekday nearly three hundred thousand people depend on a system that, it turns out, poorly trains too many of its employees and emphasizes punctuality over caution.

headline: Putin Recognizes Crimea Secession, Defying the West

abstract: The Kremlin announced that President Vladimir V. Putin would address both houses of the Russian Parliament on Tuesday, when many expect him to endorse annexation.

Putin of Russia signed a decree on Monday formally recognizing Crimea as a “sovereign and independent state,” laying the groundwork for annexation and defying the United States and Europe just hours after they imposed their first financial sanctions against Moscow since the crisis in Ukraine began.
