headline: For Some, Reader Contributions Become a New Reporting Tool
abstract: Direct contact with readers is redefining not just how some stories are received but also how they are reported and written.
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, it happened like this: A newspaper would publish a story. Response came in the form of letters to the editor, or maybe an outraged phone call or two, or a handwritten note to a reporter — or, every once in a while, a lawsuit.

headline: Space Ripples Reveal Big Bang’s Smoking Gun
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Astronomers looking back 13.8 billion years found ripples in the fabric of space-time that support the theory of a universe being wrenched violently apart around its inception.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — One night late in 1979, an itinerant young physicist named Alan Guth, with a new son and a year’s appointment at Stanford, stayed up late with his notebook and equations, venturing far beyond the world of known physics.

headline: Moist Brown Soda Bread Loaf With Oats
abstract: This soda bread is baked at a lower temperature so that it doesn’t develop a hard crust.
lead_paragraph: For years I’ve been trying to make a moist soda bread loaf like the kind I love to eat when I’m in Ireland. Finally I’ve achieved it with this recipe, which is adapted from Bon Appétit’s recipe for Fallon & Byrne Soda Bread (Fallon & Byrne is a restaurant in Dublin). The bread is a whole-wheat loaf with both rolled and steel-cut (pinhead) oats, and does not have the hard crust that round soda breads can have. One reason is that the moist dough is baked at a lower temperature than free-form soda bread.

headline: Fighting Pollution, Paris Imposes Partial Driving Ban
abstract: High pollution levels prompted the authorities to order the limits, and public transport in the French capital remained free for a fourth consecutive day.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With air pollution in and around Paris still unusually high, the government imposed a partial driving ban here on Monday for the first time in nearly 20 years, and public transportation was free for a fourth consecutive day.

headline: Whole-Wheat Soda Bread With Raisins (Spotted Dog)
abstract: A mix of raisins sweetens this brown soda bread.
lead_paragraph: Traditional spotted dog is made with white flour and does not always include an egg. I’ve always preferred brown soda bread made with a mix of whole-wheat and white flour, with more whole wheat than white. For this version, rather than traditional currants or sultanas I used a delicious mix of large golden, flame and jumbo raisins. As always with soda bread, the trick to success is to handle it as little as possible.

headline: Brown Soda Bread Loaf With Caraway Seeds and Rye
abstract: A regional version of soda bread that is dark-brown, grainy and moist.
lead_paragraph: Some regional variations on Irish soda bread, from Donegal and Leitrim, call for caraway seeds. I love caraway seeds in bread, but in my personal food memory bank they will always be paired with rye. So I decided to add a little rye flour to this already dark brown, grainy and moist bread.

headline: Whole-Wheat Buttermilk Scones With Raisins and Oatmeal
abstract: You may be accustomed to the gigantic, sweet scones in coffee shops in this country. They are nothing like the diminutive, light scones that originated in Britain and Ireland.
lead_paragraph: You may be accustomed to the gigantic, sweet scones in coffee shops in this country. They are nothing like the diminutive, light scones that originated in Britain and Ireland. This is a whole-wheat version, only moderately sweet — the way I think scones should be. You can always top them with jam or honey if you want more sugar. The whole-wheat flour brings a rich, nutty flavor to the scones.

headline: Savory Whole-Wheat Buttermilk Scones With Rosemary and Thyme
abstract: A whole-grain scone that pairs well with cheese.
lead_paragraph: These rich, herbal scones are savory like American biscuits, with the added nutty, wholesome dimension of the whole-wheat flour. They’re great with cheese and with salads, soups and stews.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 87
abstract: The re-energized Italian striker Antonio Cassano is campaigning for a spot on Italy’s World Cup roster.
lead_paragraph: He has lost 22 pounds and sworn off bread. Then there are the 11 goals he has scored in Italy’s Serie A this season for sixth-place Parma.

headline: Julia Bullock Wins $15,000 Naumburg Prize
abstract: Ms. Bullock won the competition, held at the 92nd Street Y and Manhattan School of Music.
lead_paragraph: Julia Bullock, a soprano from St. Louis who made her New York recital debut just last week, and is scheduled to sing the title role in the Juilliard Opera production of Massenet’s “Cendrillon” next month, has won the first prize of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation’s international vocal competition. The competition, which the foundation has fielded since 1925, and which rotates focus between different instruments, voice and composition, was held at the 92nd Street Y and Manhattan School of Music, where the winners were announced on Friday evening.

headline: Airline on Plane’s Communication System
abstract: The chief executive of Malaysia Airlines says it is unclear when the missing plane’s communications system, known as Acars, was switched off.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Malaysia Airlines says it is unclear when the missing plane’s communications system, known as Acars, was switched off.

headline: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions on Russia
abstract: President Obama announced sanctions aimed at President Vladimir V. Putin’s inner circle.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced sanctions aimed at President Vladimir V. Putin’s inner circle.

headline: Opposing Testimony Caps Trial of General
keywords: ['Courts-Martial', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In court, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair admitted that he had wronged an Army captain with whom he had an adulterous affair for almost three years.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — At a military courtroom here on Monday, two former lovers, now enemies, told their stories.

headline: Kerry Announces U.S. Representative to Syrian Opposition
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Daniel Rubinstein, a senior foreign-service official, will fill the position vacated by Robert S. Ford, who retired last month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry on Monday named Daniel Rubinstein, a senior foreign service official with long experience in the Middle East, as a new special envoy for Syria.

headline: On Stage, ‘Nirbhaya’ Gives Delhi Gang Rape Victim a Voice
abstract: An award-winning play that aims to break the silence on violence against women is opening in India after drawing strong reviews in Britain.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – When a 23-year-old student was gang raped and brutally assaulted on a bus in India’s capital in December 2012, it provoked an unprecedented wave of public anger in India. But in one Indian woman, the gang rape also brought on a deep sense of guilt.

headline: Weibo I.P.O. Sets a Low Bar for Alibaba
abstract: The growth of the Twitter-like Chinese microblog Weibo comes with some hairy regulatory risks, John Foley of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Imagine the riskiest possible share offering. It would be a new, unprofitable company with rapid and uncertain growth in an emerging market. One whose customers are fickle, which lives under the constant threat of being snuffed out by regulators, and where external shareholders are dominated by insiders. The listing of Sina Weibo fits the bill. The Twitter-like microblog has also set a low bar for the upcoming market debut of the e-commerce giant Alibaba.

headline: Measuring the Facebook Cover Photo
abstract: Plus, how to share iTunes files between computers.
lead_paragraph: Q. What is the size of the space used by the cover photo on the Facebook desktop website?

headline: A Coin Problem
abstract: Using only a fair coin, design a game that you have a 1/3 chance of winning.
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Daniel Finkel of the Seattle-based Math for Love. Our last few from Dr. Finkel traced the path of a traveling nun; this week we transition to new territory with a coin challenge. Here’s Dr. Finkel with —

headline: An Inspired Lunch Puts Brunch to Shame
abstract: Brunch is a misbegotten relic. Wouldn’t you rather have a weekend lunch that celebrates the season?
lead_paragraph: I don’t do brunch, or not if I can help it. Does that make me a traitor, or simply a curmudgeon?

headline: Haste Clouds Long-Term Effort on Mortgage Fraud
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Mortgages', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The prosecution of mortgage fraud requires painstaking investigation over a long period, but the government weakens its position by promising quick results, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: A report issued by the Justice Department’s inspector general, Michael E. Horowitz, underscores the danger of extolling short-term results when it comes to prosecuting white-collar crimes. The report highlights how generating headlines seemed to take precedence over accurate figures in the government’s fight against mortgage fraud.

headline: Obama’s Statement on New Sanctions Against Russia
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Obama’s announcements of new sanctions in response to Russian actions in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Obama’s announcement of new sanctions in response to Russian actions in Ukraine, as provided by the White House.

headline: The Role Orson Welles Almost Played
abstract: The Chilean filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky explains how he convinced director Orson Welles to play a monstrous role in his unseen version of “Dune.”
lead_paragraph: The Chilean filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky explains how he convinced director Orson Welles to play a monstrous role in his unseen version of “Dune.”

headline: Ultranationalist-Turned-Liberal Is Expected to Lead Serbia
abstract: Aleksandar Vucic, expected to be Serbia’s next prime minister, recast himself as a pro-Western liberal in a transformation viewed as remarkable.
lead_paragraph: Aleksandar Vucic, the man expected to be Serbia’s next prime minister, is a former ultranationalist who recast himself as a pro-Western liberal and is determined to shepherd the poor Balkan country toward the European Union.

headline: Judge in Germany Dismisses Hedge Fund Suit Against Porsche Holding
abstract: The decision was the latest in a series of court victories by Porsche Holding over suits filed by hedge funds that lost billions betting against Volkswagen shares.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The former holding company for the automaker Porsche won a victory Monday in its long-running legal battle with a group of aggrieved hedge funds, after a judge in Stuttgart dismissed a suit seeking damages over events leading up to its unsuccessful attempt to acquire Volkswagen.

headline: Memories of ’87 Blast Jarred Loose by Explosion
abstract: The building collapse that killed at least eight people last week has reverberated through a South Bronx neighborhood where an eerily similar accident occurred nearly 27 years ago.
lead_paragraph: The ear-shattering boom came first, just as they walked out of the building. They turned to look back, the smell of gas now mixed with thick smoke, covering all that had once stood behind them.

headline: American Airlines Focuses on the Glory Days of Flying
abstract: The company is highlighting its transcontinental service and the glamorous celebrities who have flown with it.
lead_paragraph: As competition in the United States transcontinental aviation market heats up, American Airlines is running a new advertising campaign highlighting its decades of service on these routes.

headline: Ron Howard, Kevin Spacey and Michael Douglas to Talk at Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: Among the events announced for the Tribeca Film Festival’s Tribeca Talks panel series are discussions with Mr. Howard, Lee Daniels and Mike Tyson.
lead_paragraph: In addition to its roster of movies the Tribeca Film Festival will once again offer plenty of conversation next month. Ron Howard, Kevin Spacey and Michael Douglas will be among those taking part in the Tribeca Talks series, festival organizers announced Monday. As part of the directors series Mr. Howard will discuss his films and his long career in Hollywood. Also as part of that series the Oscar-nominated director Lee Daniels will chat about his filmography, including “Precious” and “Lee Daniels’ The Butler.” Mr. Spacey will be on hand to discuss the documentary “NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage,” about the Old Vic, the London theater company where he is artistic director.

headline: In Our Pages: March 18
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Old Jewelry at London Museum

headline: The Unworried Unwell
abstract: Rarely does the doctor’s imagination outrun the patient’s, picturing imminent catastrophe from untreated conditions. But it does happen.
lead_paragraph: She is an organized, punctual patient who makes appointments and keeps them. He drops in whenever he feels like it. Her visits are short and organized; his seem to drag on forever. The two have nothing in common — except that they both leave the office empty-handed.

headline: U.S. May Quit Giving Aid for Outdated Technology
abstract: Tom Wheeler, chairman of the F.C.C., said Monday that the commission is considering ways to better prioritize the fund, created through a tax on long-distance services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – A federal program that provides money to schools and libraries for high-speed Internet connections is likely to stop paying for outdated services, including pagers, mobile phones for school officials, email, web hosting and 800 numbers, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said on Monday.

headline: New Play by Danai Gurira Among Highlights of Yale Rep Season
abstract: Danai Gurira’s new work, “Familiar,” is one of the three new plays that Yale Rep commissioned and will produce next season.
lead_paragraph: Danai Gurira was an Obie Award-winning playwright (“Eclipsed,” “In the Continuum”) before she shot to wider fame in 2012 playing the sword-wielding Michonne on the hit cable series “The Walking Dead,” becoming one of its most popular characters. But Ms. Gurira never stopped writing: Her new play, “Familiar,” about a Midwestern bride whose family is rocked by her choice of wedding rituals, will have a world premiere production in January as part of Yale Repertory Theater’s 2014-15 season, the theater announced on Monday.

headline: Vodafone-Ono Deal a Big Win for Team of Deal Makers in London
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Vodafone’s board was advised on the $10 billion transaction by the boutique advisory firm Robertson Robey Associates, which features three star deal makers formerly from UBS, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Vodafone-Ono marriage featured many of the investment bank names one would expect in a deal worth about $10 billion.

headline: Times Minute | New Sanctions for Russia
abstract: President Obama announces new sanctions on Russian officials. Also on the Minute, a push for peace in the Middle East and the looming enrollment deadline for the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | New Sanctions for Russia
abstract: President Obama announces new sanctions on Russian officials. Also on the Minute, a push for peace in the Middle East and the looming enrollment deadline for the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announces new sanctions on Russian officials. Also on the Minute, a push for peace in the Middle East and the looming enrollment deadline for the Affordable Care Act.

headline: More Nights to Come for ‘Janis Joplin’
abstract: The musical revue “A Night With Janis Joplin,” with Mary Bridget Davies, will reopen at the Gramercy Theater in April.
lead_paragraph: When “A Night With Janis Joplin” closed at the Lyceum Theater in February, after a four-and-a-half-month run, the show’s producers said that they had a deal in the works that would lead to a quick revival in another New York theater. On Monday, the show’s lead producers, Todd Gershwin, Michael Cohl and Daniel Chilewich, announced the details: in a new partnership with Live Nation Entertainment, the giant concert promoter, they will present what they are calling a new production of the show at the Gramercy Theater, on East 23rd Street. Opening night is April 10.

headline: How Do I Make the Most of My Paternity Leave?
abstract: We’d like to ask dads (and the moms or partners who know them) to share their wisdom about how to have the best possible paternity leave.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, The New York Times Company announced that it would offer six weeks of paid parental leave for all employees. The timing couldn’t have been better for me, because late last year I became a father. I worked out some scheduling with my managers, and my wife, and in one week’s time I’ll start paternity leave with our 4-month-old daughter as my wife returns to work from her maternity leave.

headline: Bookshelf | An Illustrator Captures the Spirit of San Francisco (and an April Bloomfield Recipe)
abstract: On the occasion of the release of her new book, a Bay Area artist and author interprets a dish from one of her city’s food-world luminaries.
lead_paragraph: “My San Francisco is one of 100,000 San Franciscos,” the illustrator and graphic journalist Wendy MacNaughton says. A fifth-generation native of that metropolis, she has paid tribute to her hometown with a collection of watercolor renderings, observations and stories titled “Meanwhile in San Francisco: the City in its Own Words,” which hits bookshelves tomorrow.

headline: Determining the Markup on Municipal Bonds
abstract: Transparency is critical in knowing what you are paying for the bonds you buy and whether the amount is too much, a financial planner writes.
lead_paragraph: Most of the market news you hear tends to be about stocks, but bonds are just as useful a tool for most investment portfolios. One type in particular, the municipal, or “muni” bond, remains very popular. These bonds are issued by local governments, they’re often tax-exempt and they can be relatively low risk. But muni bonds come with a catch: You may be entering a dark and dangerous world when you go through the process of buying one.

headline: At Monteverdi Tuscany, a Celebration of the Composer
abstract: A boutique hotel in Tuscany is partnering with a British conductor on a program focused on the Italian composer Claudio Monteverdi.
lead_paragraph: Monteverdi Tuscany, a boutique hotel and collection of villas in the village of Castiglioncello del Trinoro, Italy, is partnering with the renowned British conductor Sir John Eliot Gardiner from April 22 to 26 for its first Accademia Monteverdi.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: 3 Activists Held in Sri Lanka, Raising Fears of Crackdown
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The detention of three activists in the last few days sent a ripple of dread through Sri Lanka’s human rights organizations.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Fears of a broad crackdown against rights activists in Sri Lanka have been heightened after the Sri Lankan police recently arrested two prominent human rights advocates and a woman who has made a public campaign of finding her missing son.

headline: NYT Now: Obama and Abbas Discuss Israel
abstract: President Obama spoke with the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, on the progress of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke with the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, on the progress of Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.

headline: N.C.A.A. Tournament: Who Do You Hate (and Love)?
abstract: Which team do you think will win? Eh, never mind that. Tell us which teams’ losses would give you the greatest joy, and which team’s success would make you most happy.
lead_paragraph: Which team do you think will win? Eh, never mind that. Tell us which teams’ losses would give you the greatest joy, and which team’s success would make you most happy.

headline: Sorting Out the Risks of Fish
abstract: While advocacy groups are demanding more information on mercury content, some health experts worry that consumers will be scared away from beneficial seafood.
lead_paragraph: Fish is often called “brain food.” It’s an excellent source of lean protein, rich in nutrients like omega-3 fatty acids, B vitamins and iodine, and pregnant women are encouraged to eat it. There’s just one, ah, catch: Fish also may have mercury, which can harm the developing brain.

headline: Manhattan Doesn’t Have to Look Far for Its Talent
abstract: With eight New York City players on the team, 13th-seeded Manhattan, which will open against No. 4 Louisville on Thursday night, is the most New York of the city teams.
lead_paragraph: Like a Williamsburg restaurant getting its lettuce from a Brooklyn rooftop, Manhattan College sourced its men’s basketball team locally.

headline: L’Wren Scott, Whose Designs Melded Daring and Sophistication, Dies at 49
abstract: Ms. Scott, who had a romantic partnership with Mick Jagger, designed fashion suitable for the kind of leggy, statuesque woman she was herself.
lead_paragraph: L’Wren Scott, a fashion designer whose creations were known for their discreet elegance, though with a soupçon of daring and glamour evoking her days as a celebrity stylist in Hollywood and her romantic partnership with Mick Jagger, was found dead on Monday in her Manhattan apartment. She was 49.

headline: A Reflection: Suzy Menkes on the Fashion Designer L’Wren Scott
abstract: Designer L’Wren Scott, whose was found dead in her New York apartment on Monday, started her fashion collection eight years ago, building it on her own elegant and towering self.
lead_paragraph: The designer L’Wren Scott, who was was found dead in her New York apartment on Monday, started her fashion collection eight years ago, building it on her own elegant and towering self. But she never forgot her Hollywood years as a stylist dressing the stars.

headline: Obama and Abbas Confer in Washington
abstract: President Obama spoke with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on the progress of the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority on the progress of the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.

headline: Writer From Zimbabwe Wins PEN/Hemingway Award for First Novel
abstract: NoViolet Bulawayo, author of “We Need New Names,” wins the PEN/Hemingway Foundation Award, given for a first book of fiction.
lead_paragraph: NoViolet Bulawayo has won the PEN/Hemingway Foundation Award for “We Need New Names,” her novel about a 10-year-old Zimbabwean girl who travels to the United States in search of a fresh start. The prize, established in 1976 by Mary Hemingway in memory of her husband, Ernest Hemingway, honors distinguished first books of fiction, and includes a $10,000 award, a one-week residence at the University of Idaho, and a fellowship at the Ucross Foundation, a retreat for artists and writers in Wyoming.

headline: By Design | One-Room Hotels
abstract: When it comes to providing the experience of a home away from home, very little can go a very long way.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to providing the experience of a home away from home, very little can go a very long way.

headline: Something Went ‘Very Wrong’ at G.M., Chief Says
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Mary T. Barra announced recalls affecting 1.7 million more vehicles, and in a message to employees vowed to change internal procedures to address safety issues.
lead_paragraph: Mary T. Barra, General Motors’ chief executive, announced another round of wide-ranging recalls on Monday, a sign that the company was moving with a new sense of urgency on safety problems after it disclosed a decade-long failure to fix a defect tied to 12 deaths.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Rosberg Wins an Eventful Australian Grand Prix
abstract: Nico Rosberg and the Mercedes team made a strong showing in the Formula One season opener; Chip Ganassi’s car won the Sebring 12-hour race in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Nico Rosberg, driving for Mercedes-Benz, handily won the season-opening Formula One race in Australia on Sunday. Over all, it was a strong start for the Mercedes team, as Rosberg’s teammate, Lewis Hamilton, had started from pole. Hamilton, however, retired soon after the start of the race because of an engine misfire.

headline: Rachel Mellon, an Heiress Known for Her Green Thumb, Dies at 103
abstract: A banker’s wife and a drug magnate’s daughter, Mrs. Mellon helped finance John Edwards’s presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Lambert Mellon, an heir to the Listerine fortune and a horticulturalist, fine arts collector and philanthropist who redesigned the White House Rose Garden, died on Monday at the Upperville, Va., estate that had been her principal residence for decades. She was 103.

headline: The Work of L’Wren Scott
abstract: The designer started her fashion collection eight years ago, building it on her own elegant and towering self.
lead_paragraph: The designer started her fashion collection eight years ago, building it on her own elegant and towering self.

headline: Two SAC Capital Traders Jump to Highbridge Capital
abstract: The steady flow of employee defections from SAC Capital Advisors continues with Highbridge Capital Management luring away two portfolio managers from Steven A. Cohen’s firm.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management just lured away two portfolio managers from Steven A. Cohen’s SAC Capital Advisors to manage money for its stock trading funds.

headline: Brooklyn Provides the Secret to Nashville-Style Hot Chicken
abstract: For the first time, Peaches HotHouse is sharing the recipe for its notorious extra hot fried chicken. Have an ice-cold beer ready.
lead_paragraph: At Peaches HotHouse in Brooklyn, a restaurant that specializes in notoriously spicy Nashville-style fried chicken, they are not exaggerating when they say the chicken is hot.

headline: G.M. Chief Updates on Recall
abstract: In a video message addressed to General Motors employees, Mary Barra, the chief executive, said the company had made mistakes and needed to change its processes.
lead_paragraph: In a video message addressed to General Motors employees, Mary Barra, the chief executive, said the company had made mistakes and needed to change its processes.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | March 11-17, 2014
abstract: Flight 370, March Madness, viral videos and more: How much do you know about this week’s news?
lead_paragraph: Flight 370, March Madness, viral videos and more: How much do you know about this week’s news?

headline: In the Air | Masculin, Feminin
abstract: The recent feminization of men’s dressing feels downright manly in its brazen embrace of the softer side.
lead_paragraph: The recent feminization of men’s dressing feels downright manly in its brazen embrace of the softer side.

headline: The Read Around: Helen Oyeyemi
abstract: Helen Oyeyemi, whose new novel, “Boy, Snow, Bird,” was inspired by “Snow White,” says fairy tales allow us to focus on “the nature of stories themselves, and the curious power they have.”
lead_paragraph: Helen Oyeyemi, whose new novel, “Boy, Snow, Bird,” was inspired by “Snow White,” says fairy tales allow us to focus on “the nature of stories themselves, and the curious power they have.”

headline: Future of Fusion, Cancer as Demon Baby, Laughing for Science
abstract:
We look at how far nuclear fusion has come — and how far it has yet to go; contemplating the frightful parallels between a growing embryo and a runaway tumor; what is the science behind side-splitting, tear-inducing humor?
Subscribe to the Podcast »
lead_paragraph:
We look at how far nuclear fusion has come — and how far it has yet to go; contemplating the frightful parallels between a growing embryo and a runaway tumor; what is the science behind side-splitting, tear-inducing humor?
Subscribe to the Podcast »

headline: Billionaire’s Sprawling Compound Challenges a Village’s Mellow Ethos
abstract: A new mansion in Hastings-on-Hudson would seem to be more at home in Westchester County’s highest-rent districts, or in affluent towns like Bedford and North Salem farther north.
lead_paragraph: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — In this comfortable Westchester County community, many residents like to think of their village as the anti-suburb, jokingly calling it the Upper Upper West Side.

headline: All Dressed Up and Nowhere to Go
abstract: With a bit of patchwork, some lace and a pair of exceptionally matronly shoes, the quirky charm of the noble eccentric is only a stop away.
lead_paragraph: With a bit of patchwork, some lace and a pair of exceptionally matronly shoes, the quirky charm of the noble eccentric is only a stop away.

headline: String of High Notes for Pianist
abstract: On Tuesday, the pianist Jeremy Denk will be awarded the Avery Fisher Prize for musicianship and contributions to the musical world.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven are playing Scrabble in heaven. No, it is not the setup of a joke — well, not exactly. It is the first scene of the highly improbable comic opera being written by the pianist Jeremy Denk and the composer Steven Stucky, based on one of the most influential scholarly music books of recent decades: Charles Rosen’s “The Classical Style.”

headline: The Met’s ‘Enchanted Island’ Offers Students a Cultural Refuge
abstract: A group of students from a leadership program organized by the International Rescue Committee got a behind-the-scenes look at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Danielle de Niese was dressed as an antiquated scuba diver when she greeted a group of 10 young guests during intermission at Saturday’s performance of “The Enchanted Island” at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Squeezing the Milky Way Into a Photo
keywords: ['Milky Way Galaxy', 'Photography', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: That picture of our galaxy? It’s not really of our galaxy.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I see a published photograph purporting to be of the entire Milky Way, I wonder, was it really possible for someone to take it?

headline: After Years in Politics and Prison, Louisiana Ex-Governor Will Run for Congress
abstract: Edwin Edwards, 86, raised and rebutted various reasons he should not run, from his age to his criminal record.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — After seven years in Congress, 16 years as governor, eight years in the federal penitentiary and several weeks of coyly prodding the speculation of political reporters, Edwin Edwards, 86, announced on Monday that he would be running as a Democrat to represent Louisiana’s Sixth Congressional District.

headline: Airlines Use Digital Technology to Get Even More Personal
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Social Media', 'Business Travel', 'Privacy', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: To keep tabs on passengers, carriers are using gadgets like Google Glass headsets and systems that monitor social media, raising privacy concerns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the door of his limousine opened outside Virgin Atlantic’s business class lounge at Heathrow Airport one recent afternoon, Declan Jones was startled to be greeted by more than just a smiling face.

headline: Video: Helen Oyeyemi on the Power of Fairy Tales
abstract: Ms. Oyeyemi discusses her new novel, “Boy, Snow, Bird,” which was inspired by “Snow White.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Helen Oyeyemi discusses her new novel, “Boy, Snow, Bird” — which was inspired by “Snow White” — and how fairy tales allow us to focus on “the nature of stories themselves, and the curious power that they have.”

headline: A Tumor, the Embryo’s Evil Twin
abstract: Scientists have been finding that the same genes that guide fetal cells as they multiply, migrate and create a newborn child are also among the primary drivers of cancer.
lead_paragraph: During her first encounter with cancer, Susan Sontag described a tumor as a “demonic pregnancy.” “This lump is alive,” she wrote in “Illness as Metaphor,” “a fetus with its own will.” She could hardly know that the comparison would become more than a figure of speech.

headline: China Releases Plan to Incorporate Farmers Into Cities
abstract: An ambitious government blueprint is the country’s first attempt to broadly coordinate the introduction of hundreds of millions of rural residents into cities.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has announced a sweeping plan to manage the flow of rural residents into cities, promising to promote urbanization but also to solve some of the drastic side effects of this great uprooting.

headline: Following Up on Bag Check Rules
abstract: Readers do their own informal research on how strictly airlines enforce their carry-on baggage size rules.
lead_paragraph: THERE was a lot of response to last week’s column, in which I asked for comment from readers about the move by United Airlines to crack down on oversize carry-on bags by more strictly enforcing size regulations at the check-in areas. I have the space to use only a handful of the responses, alas. But I’ll try to summarize the gist of them.

headline: “Ha!” Takes a Serious Look at Humor
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)']
abstract: Understanding laughter yields insights into how our brains process a complex world and how that, in turn, makes us who we are.
lead_paragraph: So there’s this baby who has swallowed a .22-caliber bullet. The mother rushes into a drugstore, crying, “What shall I do?”

headline: Ha! The Quiz
abstract: Take this quiz to test your knowledge of what humor and laughter says about us.
lead_paragraph: Laughter seems like the most natural response when something funny happens. But why don’t we all laugh at the same thing? How the brain processes humor reveals some interesting truths about human nature. Take this quiz, based on the new book “Ha! The Science of When We Laugh and Why,” by Scott Weems, to find out how much you know about your funny bone.

headline: Privacy in the War Without End
abstract: When the United States ends its wartime military presence in Afghanistan at the end of 2014, President Obama will most likely recast the terms under which the government uses technology to fight terror and spy on people, says a former diplomat. That could matter for privacy laws.
lead_paragraph: How should we think about balancing civil liberties and national security? It may depend on what a speech later this year tells us about how a modern war really ends.

headline: Probiotic Eases Ills in Children
abstract: Researchers testing children in Mexico City found that those who took a probiotic had fewer instances of diarrhea than those in a placebo group.
lead_paragraph: A randomized trial of a common probiotic has shown that a daily dose substantially reduced episodes of diarrhea and respiratory tract infections among children at day care centers.

headline: Best Selling Science Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Science and Technology', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A ranking of titles selected by the science editors from all adult nonfiction books reported to The New York Times for the month.
lead_paragraph: 1 DAVID AND GOLIATH by Malcolm Gladwell. Little, Brown. How disadvantages can work in our favor, from the author of “The Tipping Point” and “Outliers.” (1)

headline: The Gene Behind a Butterfly Disguise
abstract: The gene doublesex is responsible for mimicry in a swallowtail species, scientists have found.
lead_paragraph: A single gene controls all the colors, structures and wing patterns in a species of swallowtail butterfly, researchers say — allowing it to mimic the look of another swallowtail that is toxic to predators.

headline: A Chickadee Mating Zone Surges North
abstract: The so-called hybrid zone where two closely related species of the bird meet and mate corresponds to global warming.
lead_paragraph: In a long, narrow strip of territory from Kansas to New Jersey, two closely related species of chickadees meet, mate and give birth to hybrid birds. Now scientists are reporting that this so-called hybrid zone is moving north at a rate that matches the warming trend in winter temperatures.

headline: A Mythical Director Unveiled in ‘Jodorowsky’s Dune’
abstract: Documentary filmmaker Frank Pavich talks about how fuzzy VHS recordings led him to discover Alejandro Jodorowsky’s moving tale of creative ambition.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro Jodorowsky, the 85-year-old director who was profiled in last weekend’s magazine, describes his 1975 adaptation of Frank Herbert’s unwieldy science-fiction epic, “Dune,” as a psychedelic fever dream. “I wanted to make something sacred. A film that gives LSD hallucinations — without taking LSD,” says Jodorowsky, who never actually read the book. Nevertheless, he spent two years and millions of dollars on his 14-hour passion project, enlisting the special-effects wizard (and future “Alien” screenwriter) Dan O’Bannon and the artist Moebius to oversee the production design; recruiting Orson Welles, Mick Jagger and Salvador Dalí to play monstrous roles; and Pink Floyd to compose the score. But not a single frame was ever shot.

headline: Schizophrenics and Home Care
keywords: ['Schizophrenia', 'Home Health Care', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: A clinical trial of patients in India found that home treatment for schizophrenics was better at getting them to stay on their medications.
lead_paragraph: Home treatment for schizophrenics overseen by local health workers is more effective than institutionalization, a recent large study in India has found.

headline: Out of Control
abstract: Why can pilots still shut off transponders?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — WHEN mass murderers took over the cockpits of four American airliners on Sept. 11, 2001, one of the first things they did was turn off the transponders, so the planes would not register properly on civilian radar.

headline: All Together Now, No Leader Needed
abstract: The East Coast Chamber Orchestra played a wide range of music in its concert at the Tishman Auditorium, including works by Mozart, David Ludwig and Satie.
lead_paragraph: There is a warm glow to the sound of the East Coast Chamber Orchestra, a conductorless ensemble made up of members of a variety of American orchestras and quartets.

headline: Study Questions Fat and Heart Disease Link
keywords: ['Diet and Nutrition', 'Heart', 'Medicine and Health', 'Oils and Fats']
abstract: A team of international scientists found no evidence that eating saturated fat, the kind found in meat, butter and cheese, increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.
lead_paragraph: Many of us have long been told that saturated fat, the type found in meat, butter and cheese, causes heart disease. But a large and exhaustive new analysis by a team of international scientists found no evidence that eating saturated fat increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.

headline: Questions Over Absence of Cellphone Calls From Missing Flight’s Passengers
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Wireless Communications', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Some theorize that the missing Malaysia Airlines jet flight was flying too high for the use of personal electronic devices after it was diverted.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — When hijackers took control of four airplanes on Sept. 11, 2001, and sent them hurtling low across the countryside toward New York and Washington, frantic passengers and flight attendants turned on cellphones and air phones and began making calls to loved ones, airline managers and the authorities.

headline: L’Wren Scott’s Designs on the Red Carpet
abstract: With powerful and body-conscious silhouettes, Ms. Scott’s dresses were popular among Hollywood starlets.
lead_paragraph: With powerful and body-conscious silhouettes, Ms. Scott’s dresses were popular among Hollywood starlets.

headline: A ‘Frozen’ Suite at an Ice Hotel
abstract: The Hôtel de Glace, an ice hotel in Quebec City, has a “Frozen Suite” inspired by the Disney movie.
lead_paragraph: A suite at Quebec City’s Hôtel de Glace brings aspects of Disney’s animated movie “Frozen” to life.

headline: Science Times Podcast
abstract: A look at how far nuclear fusion has come; contemplating the frightful parallels between an embryo and a tumor; what is the science behind side-splitting humor?
lead_paragraph: A look at how far nuclear fusion has come; contemplating the frightful parallels between an embryo and a tumor; what is the science behind side-splitting humor?

headline: A Wintry Mix at the Broadway Box Office
abstract: Ticket sales in March have proven mixed, with several new shows struggling to find a large audience.
lead_paragraph: March is shaping up as a very mixed month for several new Broadway musicals.

headline: A Tribute to a California Pension Fund’s Guiding Hand
abstract: On Monday, Anne Sheehan, a director at the state teachers’ pension fund, eulogized her husband, Joseph Dear, the chief investment officer of Calpers, who died last month. They shared a willingness to shake up corporate America.
lead_paragraph: They were the power couple of California’s pension assets. But their romance was largely a secret, even at the time of their wedding more than a year ago.

headline: Machinery of an Energy Dream
abstract: With one tiny flash, scientists at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and elsewhere are inching closer to fusion’s promise of endless power.
lead_paragraph: LIVERMORE, Calif. — Fusion, the process that powers the sun, is the forever dream of energy scientists — safe, nonpolluting and almost boundless. Even here at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, where the primary focus of fusion work involves nuclear weapons, many scientists talk poetically about how it could end the world’s addiction to fossil fuels.

headline: Myanmar’s Deadly Medicine
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Editorials', 'Buddhism']
abstract: Banning a group that helped Muslim victims of mob violence is a cynical effort to encourage human rights abuses.
lead_paragraph: A cynical decision by Myanmar to ban Doctors Without Borders from the state of Rakhine has left some 750,000 people without medical care since Feb. 28. About 150 people, including women with difficult pregnancies, are estimated to have died since the ban was imposed.

headline: In Performance: Steven Boyer
abstract: Steven Boyer and the puppet Tyrone perform a scene from Robert Askins’s dark comedy “Hand to God,” at the Lucille Lortel Theater.
lead_paragraph: Steven Boyer and the puppet Tyrone perform a scene from Robert Askins’s dark comedy “Hand to God,” at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

headline: A Long-Haul Traveler
abstract: Where do young loggerhead turtles go after they are born? A new study provides some answers.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, researchers have detailed information about the movements and habitats of young loggerhead turtles in the Atlantic Ocean. Tracked by satellite in the open ocean, the turtles traveled 124 to 2,672 miles and stayed mainly near the surface.

headline: American Express to Sell Half of Its Business Travel Arm for $900 Million
abstract: The deal completes an effort begun last year by American Express to trim its exposure to corporate travel, a business that has declined amid cost-cutting efforts around the country.
lead_paragraph: American Express said on Monday that it had sold half of its business travel unit to a group of investors that includes the government of Qatar and the money management giant BlackRock for $900 million.

headline: Seeking Truth in a Counterfeit
abstract: In “Blood Will Out,” Walter Kirn recounts the story of his long, strange relationship with a man who masqueraded as a Rockefeller heir.
lead_paragraph: Walter Kirn’s “Blood Will Out” has a subtitle that bills it as “The True Story of a Murder, a Mystery, and a Masquerade.” It’s got all those things, but it is primarily a tale of seduction. For 15 years, Mr. Kirn allowed himself to fall for the con man then calling himself Clark Rockefeller, certain that if he let their friendship persist, he’d find something valuable at the end of the rainbow. There would surely be a book in it, if not a pot of gold.

headline: On View | Charting the Real Roots of Minimalist Art
abstract: A new show at the Jewish Museum explores the different countries around the world where the genre emerged at the same time.
lead_paragraph: Minimalism is generally thought of as one of the apogees of 20th-century Western high culture. In fact, the movement known for its pure forms and vibrant colors did not originate solely in the United States and Western Europe, but simultaneously in countries throughout the world, especially the southern hemisphere. The new exhibition “Other Primary Structures” at the Jewish Museum gathers Minimalist 1960s sculpture by artists from Asia, Africa, the Middle East, Eastern Europe and especially Latin America, all of which were made before or at the same time as similar work in the Western art world.

headline: A Beauty and a Beast, but This One’s for Adults
abstract: The performance artists Julie Atlas Muz and Mat Fraser unfold a bona fide X-rated fairy tale in “Beauty and the Beast,” at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Grown-ups of New York, are you ready to be told the best bedtime story you’ve heard since you were a credulous tyke? It’s called “Beauty and the Beast.” And yeah, I know what you’re thinking: You’ve heard that one before; your daughter made you watch the Disney movie with her like 28 times; and if you wanted something more sophisticated, you’d just slip on your digitally enhanced edition of Jean Cocteau’s “La Belle et La Bête” from 1946.

headline: Flamenco Proves Contagious for the Ear and for the Eye
abstract: The Flamenco guitarist Tomatito came to the Rose Theater with a solo show.
lead_paragraph: If you put any faith in the notion of mirror neurons with regard to listening — the theory that an empathic region of your brain can make you experience the neural impulse to play the notes that you are hearing someone else play — then you may have been very interested in Tomatito’s performance at Rose Theater on Saturday night.

headline: Returning to the Roots of His Roots
abstract: Skrillex’s first full-length album, “Recess,” moves beyond his trademark sound in small ways, but it falls far short of upheaval.
lead_paragraph: Three and a half years ago, Skrillex released “Scary Monsters and Nice Sprites” (mau5trap/Big Beat), the EP that would transform him from a onetime post-hardcore singer who dabbled in producing electronic music to the savior of dance music in this country. He did it with a particularly mean stripe of dubstep — dirty, aggressive and sometimes grating — that ignored subtlety and demanded dancing with pneumatic intensity, sometimes in complete ignorance of the beat.

headline: Acquiring Status as Big as Their Robots
abstract: The release of Titanfall is one of the rare times loyalty to individual designers’ work done elsewhere is drawing interest to a video game.
lead_paragraph: Video game designers may be the world’s most anonymous creative professionals, at least among the makers of mass entertainment. That’s because game players tend to extend their loyalty to favorite franchises or proven studios rather than to individual designers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and More
abstract: Ukraine and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: The Ukraine Crisis and U.S. Policy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Readers respond to Senator John McCain’s Op-Ed essay, “Obama Made America Look Weak.”

headline: His Fertility Advance Draws Ire
abstract: A scientist’s procedures have shaken up the field of genetics, bringing promise to would-be parents while drawing the ire of bioethicists and the scrutiny of regulators.
lead_paragraph: BEAVERTON, ORE. — To most people, the word “mitochondria” is only dimly familiar, the answer to a test question in some bygone high-school biology class. But to Shoukhrat Mitalipov, the mysterious power producers inside every human cell are a lifelong obsession.

headline: Vienna Love Fest Comes to Sober and Sassy End
abstract: The final Vienna: City of Dreams concert, conducted by Zubin Mehta, felt devised to restore faith in that city’s veneer of urbanity and elegant fun.
lead_paragraph: By now, you might have heard already about the momentous conductor substitution that transpired over the weekend at Carnegie Hall, when the Vienna Philharmonic returned for the last two events of the Vienna: City of Dreams festival. No, not the one Saturday night, when Christoph Eschenbach memorably filled in for an injured Daniele Gatti. I’m talking about Sunday, when, at the end of a long program, Zubin Mehta ceded his baton to the soprano Diana Damrau.

headline: The Pianist Teaches, Too
abstract: The pianist Olivier Cavé played a program at the Frick Collection that was heavy on composers like Bach and Clementi.
lead_paragraph: “I will tell you the story of the piano,” said Olivier Cavé before his recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon. His engaging commentary highlighted the connections among works by Lodovico Giustini, Bach, Scarlatti and Clementi featured on the thoughtful program, called “Il Pianoforte Italiano.”

headline: A Growth Spurt at 1,500 Years Old
abstract: Researchers at the British Antarctic Survey have revived moss that had been lying dormant in permafrost for a millennium and a half.
lead_paragraph: Signy Island, which lies 375 miles off Antarctica, has too harsh an environment to support a single tree. Its mountains are girdled instead by banks of moss.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, China, Afghanistan and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, China, Afghanistan and Israel.

headline: Sleepwalker With Love Trouble Avoids a Rude Awakening
abstract: Mary Zimmerman’s modern-dress Metropolitan Opera production of Bellini’s 1831 romance presents the title character with more good health and humor than vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: The German soprano Diana Damrau balanced on the window ledge of a building high above the streets of Manhattan in the Act II sleepwalking scene of Bellini’s “Sonnambula,” which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Friday evening in Mary Zimmerman’s modern-dress production.

headline: Tuning in to an Earlier Time, When Moving Was Easy
abstract: “The Radio Show,” a dance work by Kyle Abraham, honors a longtime Pittsburgh FM station and draws attention to disparities between youth and age.
lead_paragraph: It helps that the seven dancers who were performing this weekend with Kyle Abraham/Abraham.In.Motion at the 92nd Street Y were all good-looking, well dressed, well lighted and very good movers. The work in which they appeared, Mr. Abraham’s “Radio Show,” featured deliberate ambiguities and tensions that, with other performers, could have easily turned it into a quite different piece. These dancers are so appealing that you’re on their side from the first.

headline: Comment
abstract: Readers respond in letters, comments on nytimes.com and social media to stories from the science and health sections.
lead_paragraph: WIRED WELL

headline: Murdoch Urges Irish to Boycott Guinness Over Its Embrace of Gay Rights
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s call for the people of Ireland and their cousins in the diaspora to defend the honor of the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Manhattan by boycotting Guinness appeared to generate little support.
lead_paragraph: Responding to the news that Guinness had withdrawn its sponsorship of the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in New York over the continued exclusion of gay groups from the festivities, Rupert Murdoch called on the people of Ireland and their cousins in the diaspora to retaliate by boycotting the beer.

headline: A Conversation With Steve Jurvetson, Space Investor and Rocket Maker
keywords: ['Private Spaceflight', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Steve Jurvetson, a venture capitalist who has invested in space start-ups, discusses the future of space, amateur rockets and people living on Mars.
lead_paragraph: Steve Jurvetson is a partner at Draper Fisher Jurvetson, a Menlo Park, Calif., venture capital firm that has invested in SpaceX, Tesla Motors and Planet Labs, a satellite company we profiled in Monday’s newspaper.

headline: State Senate Rejects Bill Granting Tuition Aid to Illegal Immigrants
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Tuition', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The legislation would have allowed students without proper immigration status to receive financial aid through state programs, if they met certain conditions.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In a surprise vote, the New York State Senate on Monday rejected legislation that would have granted state tuition aid to undocumented immigrants, dealing a blow to immigrants’ advocates who had made it their top priority in the capital.

headline: An Inside View of Arab Photography
abstract: Samer Mohdad was once told that “Arab photography did not exist.” This week he is part of an ambitious showcase of contemporary Arab photography at Houston FotoFest.
lead_paragraph: Samer Mohdad was once told that “Arab photography did not exist.” This week he is part of an ambitious showcase of contemporary Arab photography at Houston FotoFest.

headline: The Razor’s Edge
abstract: A trip to the local barbershop, from Beijing to Beirut, gives one man an entree into the customs and people of each country he visits — as well as a smooth shave.
lead_paragraph: A trip to the local barbershop, from Beijing to Beirut, gives one man an entree into the customs and people of each country he visits — as well as a smooth shave.

headline: Cardinal Dolan to Lobby for Tax Credit That Rewards Donations to Education
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: A proposal to create a state tax credit for donations to public schools and nonprofit scholarship funds is gathering steam and turning the archbishop of New York into something of a lobbyist.
lead_paragraph: A proposal to create a state tax credit for donations to public schools and nonprofit scholarship funds is gathering steam in Albany and turning the archbishop of New York, Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, into something of a lobbyist.

headline: A Classical Composer in a Contemporary World
abstract: The British composer Tarik O’Regan’s current work includes projects with the Dutch National Ballet, the Washington Chorus and the Sydney Dance Company.
lead_paragraph: ENJOYING business travel has been the most delightful surprise. I’m a contemporary classical music composer, dividing my time between New York City and Cambridge, England, and am currently working on projects with the Dutch National Ballet, Washington Chorus and Sydney Dance Company, among others.

headline: How to Profit Modestly by Moving to a Nonprofit
abstract: Colleges across the country offer programs intended to prepare unemployed corporate professionals, or those looking to make career transitions, for the expanding nonprofit sector.
lead_paragraph: WHEN he was 5 years old, Steven Elson built pretend skyscrapers out of blocks. It was the start of a love affair with buildings.

headline: What Color Is Your Online Adult Course?
abstract: Massive Online Open Courses had more than 4.5 million students at the end of 2013.
lead_paragraph: AS part of the latest wave of online learning platforms, Massive Online Open Courses (Moocs) have gone viral. They can be useful for certain students, although those interested in changing or enhancing their careers should consider their more intensive sister, distance learning.

headline: A Degree Where Techie Meets Business Smarts
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'ADULT EDUCATION', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Biotechnology', 'Science and Technology', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Young professionals in the coveted STEM fields (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) are discovering they can expand their career future by getting a hybrid master’s degree.
lead_paragraph: DANIEL BRISKER, who graduated in 2009 with an undergraduate degree in biology, likes his job at MedImmune, a Maryland biotechnology company, where he grows and harvests cell cultures, but he also wanted to enhance his professional credentials. So he went back to school for a professional science master’s degree — what some are calling a science M.B.A., a degree combining science knowledge with business skills.

headline: New Health Law Is Sending Many Back to School
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Programs at U.C.L.A. and Columbia keep health professionals and those entering the field up to date on the issues surrounding the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: PROFESSIONAL development classes constantly need to adapt to new realities, and that is especially true now in health care management, with the Affordable Care Act changing the rules for patients, managers, doctors and other health workers.

headline: Culinary Schools Speed the Rise of Hopeful Chefs
abstract: For career changers looking to enter the increasingly competitive food industry, formal training is becoming the fastest and most efficient way to head a kitchen.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Rob Anderson decided last year to pursue a longtime passion for food and open a restaurant in Provincetown, Mass., he left behind a job as an opinion page editor at The Boston Globe and enrolled in the six-month culinary arts program at the International Culinary Center in New York’s SoHo neighborhood.

headline: Many Adults Falling Short of Degrees
abstract: The completion rate for people over age 24 returning to college is 61 percent. Many face financial sacrifice and academic pressure they did not anticipate.
lead_paragraph: TWO and a half years ago, Kristine Rose enrolled full time at Mount Holyoke College and crammed her belongings into a 12-foot-square room.

headline: Earning Their Stripes as Umpires and Referees
abstract: The few who make it to the big leagues or top college levels can make six-figure salaries, while others can make good part-time incomes.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, when David Martinez left a job teaching math at a high school in Bayonne, N.J., to try to become a professional baseball umpire, he understood that the numbers might not add up.

headline: For Aztecs’ Leader, Court Is No Place to Run Scared
abstract: After transferring to San Diego State from Washington State and sitting out a season, Xavier Thames grew into the leader of his new team and never looked back.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The story had to be pulled out of Xavier Thames.

headline: More Information for Women Looking to Get Back in the Work Force
abstract: Job search tips from experts and a sampling of resources, continuing education and re-entry programs.
lead_paragraph: How can women prepare for returning to work after taking a career break to care for children or aging parents? As we reported in the article, “New Programs Help Women Get Back In The Game,” a growing number of re-entry programs are now being offered to professional women on Wall Street and at big law firms. Explaining a career gap on a résumé is not the only challenge women face. We asked Michelle Friedman, Ann Blinkhorn, Carol Fishman Cohen and Vivian Steir Rabin, who specialize in career development, to share their best job search tips and resources. In addition, Ms. Cohen and Ms. Rabin answered questions from New York Times readers on The Motherlode blog. They are the authors of “Back on the Career Track” and founders of iRelaunch.com, which provides extensive resources for women looking to navigate their way back to work.

headline: Helping Women Get Back in the Game
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Sabbaticals and Career Breaks', 'Women and Girls', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Programs to help women return to the work force after a break to care for children or aging parents are increasing in the fields of finance and law.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Chermayeff planned to go back to work when the youngest of her four children enrolled in school last fall. With a Harvard M.B.A. and experience at a private equity firm, she had the credentials to return to Wall Street. The only problem was explaining a 15-year gap on her résumé.

headline: In Eastern Ukraine, the Curtain Goes Up, and the Clash Begins
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Police']
abstract: As pro-Russian demonstrators and the police gathered for a standoff, the future remained uncertain for a region with deep ties to Russia but also many citizens who identify as Ukrainian.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — The opponents arrived in the city’s center and prepared for the coming scuffle with ritualized familiarity.

headline: Triangle Offense Has Its Defenders and Skeptics
abstract: Phil Jackson, who will be introduced Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, took to Twitter last summer in support of the triangle offense, which he could bring to the Knicks.
lead_paragraph: People tend to listen when Phil Jackson talks, or tweets, even in August, traditionally the N.B.A.’s tune-out season.

headline: Rescued Puppies in Gambling Haven Steal Hearts
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'ARSON', 'Dogs', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: A Las Vegas fire in which two people are accused of trying to burn the dogs has become a daily soap opera for residents of the city.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Las Vegas enjoys its reputation as a Sybaritic town, with its heady blend of sparkle, sex and money. It celebrates its history of organized crime with a Mob Museum championed by a former mayor.

headline: German Firm’s Sale to Russians Draws Fire
abstract: An agreement to sell an oil and natural gas unit of the utility RWE to two Russian billionaires stirred criticism.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The announcement of a preliminary German-Russian energy deal sparked criticism on Monday from at least one leading conservative in Germany, who suggested it sent the wrong message as the West was imposing sanctions on Russia for its occupation of Crimea.

headline: Reader Comments and Questions: Helping the Stay-at-Home Parent (and More) Get Back in the Game
abstract: Have you returned to work after taking time off to raise or care for a family, or are you working on relaunching your career? Ask your questions and share your stories here.
lead_paragraph: We’re looking for questions from people looking to rejoin the work force after taking a family-related break, and stories from women and men who have successfully returned to the game. Ask and share here, in the comments, and we’ll come back with expert answers later in the week. Ask today—we’ll close questions by the end of the day Wednesday, March 19, 2014 in order to give our experts time to respond.

headline: Like That Vase on the TV? Click Your Phone to Buy It
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'E-Commerce']
abstract: The moment that products appear on television screens, viewers are encouraged to purchase them on their second screens.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT 87 percent of Americans watch television while using devices like smartphones and tablets, but most of that second-screen usage is unrelated to the show or movie, according to the NPD Group, a market research company.

headline: The Rangers’ Scoring Slump Includes the Player Acquired to Lift the Offense
abstract: Martin St. Louis, brought to the team this month in a trade with Tampa Bay involving Ryan Callahan, has no goals and two assists in seven games.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Martin St. Louis won the N.H.L. scoring title last season with Tampa Bay and had 61 points in 62 games for the Lightning this season. But he has no goals and two assists in seven games since coming to the Rangers in a blockbuster trade March 5, and he is trying not to be weighed down by his lack of production.

headline: Deterioration in U.S.-Russian Relations May Disrupt Coming Talks With Iran
abstract: The second round of negotiations on a nuclear agreement with Iran is set to begin Tuesday and success hinges on solidarity among the members of the United Nations Security Council.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Tensions between the West and Russia over events in Ukraine have cast a shadow over the second round of talks set to begin on Tuesday in Vienna on a permanent nuclear agreement with Iran.

headline: Letter From Nakamoto on Bitcoin Claim
abstract: “I did not create, invent or otherwise work on Bitcoin,” Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto said. “I unconditionally deny the Newsweek report.”
lead_paragraph: “I did not create, invent or otherwise work on Bitcoin,” Dorian Satoshi Nakamoto said. “I unconditionally deny the Newsweek report.”

headline: CNN’s Coverage of Malaysia Flight 370
abstract: A selection of clips from CNN’s nonstop coverage of the mystery surrounding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: A selection of clips from CNN’s nonstop coverage of the mystery surrounding Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: CNN’s Ratings Surge Covering the Mystery of the Missing Airliner
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Television']
abstract: Anderson Cooper’s CNN show at 8 p.m. beat Bill O’Reilly’s highly rated show on Fox News three nights last week in the coveted audience aged 18 to 54. That was a first for CNN.
lead_paragraph: On CNN, the plane rises from misty clouds accompanied by an eerie background score while anchors offer intriguing details — some new, some days old — of the disappearance of Flight 370. The reports, broadcast continually, often are augmented by speculation — sometimes fevered, sometimes tempered — about where the flight might have come to rest. And viewers are eating it up.

headline: Tesla Fights for a Place to Park
abstract: New Jersey is the latest state to bar Tesla’s stores for its electric vehicles under laws that favor independent dealerships.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors, the maker of high-end all-electric cars, has made no secret of its ambitions to transform the auto industry, through methods ranging from the radical design of its cars to its free network of charging stations to repairing its sedans remotely by computer. But now, Tesla’s lofty goals have run into a more ordinary roadblock: the ubiquitous local auto dealer.

headline: A Culture Change Is Coming to the Garden
abstract: After a 36-year absence, Phil Jackson is set to return to the Knicks, and the list of challenges awaiting him is long.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson played his final game for the Knicks on April 23, 1978, going scoreless off the bench as the Philadelphia 76ers closed out a four-game sweep in the Eastern Conference semifinal series.

headline: Hedge Fund Spars With a Nameless Blogger
abstract: The case by David Einhorn’s firm against Seeking Alpha could be a watershed for confidential information being posted anonymously.
lead_paragraph: Who was the leaker?

headline: How Missing Jet’s Debris Could Have Floated to Réunion
abstract: This animation shows where floating debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 could have drifted if experts are correct about where the plane went down.
lead_paragraph: This animation shows where floating debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 could have drifted if experts are correct about where the plane went down.

headline: The Unlikely Road to War
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: What the teenager Gavrilo Princip teaches us about the fragility of peace.
lead_paragraph: A 19-year-old Ukrainian nationalist from a remote farming village, raised on stories of his family’s suffering during Stalin’s great engineered famine, embittered by Moscow’s long imperialist dominion, enraged by the slaying of a fellow student in Kiev during the uprising of 2014, convinced any price is worth paying to stop the Russian annexation of Crimea, takes the long road to Sevastopol.

headline: Clarissa Dickson Wright, Rebel TV Chef in ‘Two Fat Ladies,’ Dies at 66
abstract: Ms. Dickson Wright, a former lawyer, became a middle-aged celebrity on a BBC cooking show that was picked up by the Food Network.
lead_paragraph: Clarissa Dickson Wright, who rose to middle-aged fame as the co-star and co-chef of “Two Fat Ladies,” a popular British television show known as much for the hosts’ irreverence and eccentricity as for their indulgent and sometimes confounding recipes, died on Saturday in Edinburgh. She was 66.

headline: G.M. Saw Cobalt as Its Entry Into a Better Small-Car Market
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: G.M. decided to spend more and aim higher than ever before on a small car when it produced the Cobalt, but one crucial part was carried over from an older car: a problematic ignition switch.
lead_paragraph: When the Chevrolet Cobalt, now at the center of a recall of 1.6 million cars, was being engineered more than a decade ago, executives at General Motors saw it as the beginning of a new era at the automaker.

headline: Bond Insurer Files Suit Against Detroit in Setback for Bankruptcy Plan
abstract: The Financial Guaranty Insurance Company wants to be paid back for the $1.4 billion it claims it loaned Detroit’s pension fund in 2005.
lead_paragraph: A bond insurer on Monday struck a blow against Detroit’s proposal to exit bankruptcy, arguing in a new lawsuit that Detroit’s approach would illegally discriminate against the city’s third-biggest group of creditors — the investors who provided $1.4 billion for its workers’ pensions nearly a decade ago.

headline: Italy Divided Over Rail Line Meant to Unite
abstract: A two-decade debate over a high-speed rail line between Italy and France reveals broad cultural and political differences within Italy.
lead_paragraph: CHIOMONTE, Italy — To get to the site of an exploratory tunnel now being bored into Italy’s northwestern Alps, visitors must first pass through a police checkpoint, then a military one. Tall fences topped with barbed wire roll along the mountainside. Armored vehicles cross paths with jeeps on winding roads lined by vineyards.

headline: Weighing My Words
abstract: I hesitated, surveying options: a dozen paths for every sentence.
lead_paragraph: As a child, I had a relatively unusual speech impediment: I couldn’t form the sounds sh, j or ch properly, and this made a large swath of words difficult to pronounce. The word just would come out sounding like chust or shust; double-whammy words like church never emerged cleanly even if I squared myself and took a good run at them; if I said that I was a Jew someone in earshot might call out “gesundheit!” (everybody’s a comedian), and I dreaded having to speak my own name. An adult’s uncomprehending “Can you say that again?” was a staple of my life.

headline: How Cities Change
abstract: The Newark mayoral race exemplifies the conflict in many American cities between those who are part of the political structure and those who want to change it.
lead_paragraph: Shavar Jeffries was born in Newark in 1975, the son of a 19-year-old mother who was unprepared to take care of him. He spent the first nine years of his life shuttling between different relatives. Then his mother came back into his life and moved him to California.

headline: In Army’s Second N.C.A.A. Bid, a Bittersweet Connection to the First
abstract: The Black Knights, coached by Dave Magarity, earned a No. 13 seed, their first N.C.A.A. berth since 2006, when Maggie Dixon was the coach.
lead_paragraph: Before the N.C.A.A. women’s tournament bracket was revealed Monday night, Army Coach Dave Magarity could not predict the Black Knights’ seed. He did not seem to care, either. All that mattered was that they were in the tournament.

headline: Foreign Investors in Russia Vital to Sanctions Debate
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Foreign Investments', 'Government Bonds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: More than a quarter of a trillion dollars has flowed into the coffers of Russia Inc., part of a broad push by yield-hungry investors into emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: As the United States and Europe move to punish Russia for its conduct in Ukraine and Crimea with official sanctions, a subtle approach could prove more powerful: pressuring large global investors to reduce their sizable holdings in Russia.

abstract: Defense lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith say a statement from Khalid Shaikh Mohammed could exculpate the terrorism suspect.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors asked a judge on Monday to deny a request by defense lawyers to allow a jury to hear testimony from Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-proclaimed organizer of the Sept. 11 attacks.

headline: A Broken Military Justice System
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Courts-Martial', 'Editorials']
abstract: A high-profile sexual assault case shows, once again, the urgent need for reform.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey Sinclair avoided prosecution on sexual assault charges that could have brought him a life sentence. In an agreement with the prosecutor, General Sinclair pleaded guilty to lesser charges, including mistreating his accuser, an Army captain and his former mistress.

headline: Fitting the New Managerial Mold
abstract: Brad Ausmus, Detroit’s new manager, was a catcher for 18 major league seasons and worked in San Diego’s front office, but never managed or coached professionally.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — The desk sits in the same spot as ever, on a blue carpet decorated with orange paw prints, facing the Ty Cobb portrait. But while Jim Leyland wielded Marlboros in his morning session with reporters at spring training, Brad Ausmus, his successor as the manager of the Detroit Tigers, does not.

keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The City Council president announced a plan that would increase affordable housing through new construction and the rehabilitation of city-owned properties.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — As many cities look for ways to house their neediest residents, officials here on Monday announced a plan to increase this city’s stock of affordable housing by using tax incentives and bond proceeds to redevelop 1,500 vacant, city-owned properties over the next two to three years.

headline: Lowering the Deadly Cost of Drug Abuse
abstract: With more people seeing law enforcement's war on drugs as a failure, what are the best, or boldest, ways to deal with the problem?

headline: Three Years of Strife and Cruelty Puts Syria in Free Fall
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: At the start of the fourth year since Syrians rose up in a peaceful movement that turned to arms, a snapshot of the country presents the harsh truth that Syria’s descent is only accelerating.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT — Day after day, the Syrian civil war has ground down a cultural and political center of the Middle East, turning it into a stage for disaster and cruelty on a nearly incomprehensible scale. Families are brutalized by their government and by jihadists claiming to be their saviors as nearly half of Syrians — many of them children — have been driven from their homes.

headline: G.O.P. House Members Plan Tour to Test Alternatives on Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A plan to follow up on the elusive latter part of the longtime “repeal and replace” equation that Republicans have long voiced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior House Republicans — struggling to find consensus for health care legislation to replace the Affordable Care Act — are planning to test ideas in April at town-hall-style meetings that could provide a path toward a long-promised alternative to President Obama’s signature legislative achievement.

headline: Beltran Fights Off Slumps With a Bat at His Bedside
abstract: When worried at night about his hitting, Carlos Beltran finds reassurance in his grip and his stance.
lead_paragraph: BRADENTON, Fla. — There are people who keep a baseball bat next to their beds to fend off potential intruders. Carlos Beltran does so to fend off bad thoughts that have invaded his mind. The thoughts that will follow him home from the ballpark, lying dormant while he is with his family.

abstract: The St. Patrick’s Day parade marched its way up Fifth Avenue in Manhattan past a cheering crowd and protesters.

lead_paragraph: The government on Monday deployed hundreds of soldiers in a part of Caracas where weeks of often violent protests have taken place, and a top official boasted that the area had been “liberated.”

lead_paragraph: Manhattan’s top federal prosecutor filed a civil rights lawsuit Monday against Related Companies, one of New York City’s most prolific builders, charging that the developer had violated the Fair Housing Act by discriminating against disabled tenants in the design of two apartment buildings.
