headline: The Gun Lobby’s Latest Bizarre Crusade
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Surgeon General (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The N.R.A. has attacked President Obama’s nominee for surgeon general, and now Democratic leaders might knuckle under the pressure.
lead_paragraph: The National Rifle Association has mounted an outrageous campaign to torpedo President Obama’s nomination of an outstanding young doctor to be the next surgeon general of the United States because of his attitudes on gun control. The sad part is, the campaign is causing some nervous Democrats whose votes may be needed for Senate confirmation to consider breaking with the president to bolster their own chances for re-election in states where the gun lobby is powerful.

lead_paragraph: The police on Monday identified the final victim who was killed in a gas explosion that leveled two buildings in East Harlem last week.

headline: Geometry Lesson
abstract: The triangle offense, which relies on precise spacing to spread out the defense, was at the core of numerous N.B.A. championships won by the Chicago Bulls and the Los Angeles Lakers under Phil Jackson, who will now try to straighten out the Knicks. So the triangle may be coming to New York, and here is a sampling of how it works.

headline: After a Final Challenge, Election Officials Declare a Winner in El Salvador
abstract: After election officials turned aside complaints of fraud in the March 9 presidential election, Salvador Sánchez Cerén, 69, a former leftist guerrilla commander in the country’s 12-year civil war, was officially declared the victor on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: After election officials turned aside complaints of fraud in the March 9 presidential election, Salvador Sánchez Cerén, 69, a former leftist guerrilla commander in the country’s 12-year civil war, was officially declared the victor on Sunday night. Mr. Sánchez Cerén, of the Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front, will take office on June 1, becoming the first former rebel commander to rise to the presidency. He defeated Norman Quijano, the candidate of the National Republican Alliance, by 6,364 votes, winning 50.1 percent of the three million votes that were cast. Late Sunday, election officials rejected a petition by the National Republican Alliance, or Arena, to annul the results of the election. Mr. Sánchez Cerén has promised to govern as a moderate and help reconcile a nation heavily divided since the end of the civil war in 1992.

headline: Nets Miss Garnett but Keep Winning Without Him
abstract: The Nets easily defeated the Suns for their ninth home win in a row, the longest streak at Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: Life these days without Kevin Garnett has seemed remarkably easy for the Nets and their fans to tolerate. It has been an unexpected but hugely welcome surprise because he may not be returning any time soon.

headline: Malaysia Backtracks on When Airliner’s Communications Were Disabled
abstract: The authorities said Monday that they could not pinpoint precisely when the system was turned off, reversing earlier assertions.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — As the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 stretched into a 10th day, the Malaysian authorities on Monday identified the plane’s first officer as the last person in the cockpit to speak to ground control. But the government added to the confusion about what happened during those key minutes by withdrawing its assertion that the radio signoff had come after a crucial communications system was disabled.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The families gathered in the ballroom at the Lido Hotel wanted answers. Over a week ago, a jet carrying their loved ones vanished, and for a week the airline executives who appeared before them told different, sometimes contradictory, stories.

headline: Samuel W. Lewis, Shuttling Diplomat in Mideast Peace Pact, Dies at 83
abstract: After being instrumental in the accords during the Carter administration, Mr. Lewis was asked to stay on when President Ronald Reagan took office in 1981.
lead_paragraph: Samuel W. Lewis, a former American ambassador to Israel, whose tenure spanned the administrations of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan and the delicate negotiations between Israel and Egypt that led to the Camp David accords, died on March 10 at his home in McLean, Va. He was 83.

lead_paragraph: Early in his career, a scientist named Mario J. Molina was pulled into seemingly obscure research about strange chemicals being spewed into the atmosphere. Within a year, he had helped discover a global environmental emergency, work that would ultimately win a Nobel Prize.

abstract: The retailing giant is expected to announce that on March 26 it will begin allowing customers to convert their old games into credits in over 3,100 Walmart stores nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Walmart Stores has a proposition for anyone with copies of Call of Duty and other old video games lying around the house: Trade them in for store credit to spend on other items.

headline: Joseph Fan Zhongliang, ‘Underground’ Bishop of Shanghai, Dies at 95
abstract: Bishop Fan was arrested in 1955 during a crackdown on Christianity in China and spent more than two decades in prison and labor camps.
lead_paragraph: Bishop Joseph Fan Zhongliang, who was imprisoned for more than two decades for resisting a Chinese crackdown on religion and spent his final years under house arrest after Pope John Paul II named him bishop of Shanghai, died on Sunday at his home in Shanghai. He was 95.

headline: A Campaign Inquiry in Utah Is the Watchdogs’ Worst Case
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Elections, Attorneys General', 'Political Action Committees', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Payday Loans']
abstract: Documents show that a former Utah attorney general sought to transform his office into a defender of payday loan companies that had helped bankroll his election.
lead_paragraph: It is the nightmare scenario for those who worry that the modern campaign finance system has opened up new frontiers of political corruption: A candidate colludes with wealthy corporate backers and promises to defend their interests if elected. The companies spend heavily to elect the candidate, but hide the money by funneling it through a nonprofit group. And the main purpose of the nonprofit appears to be getting the candidate elected.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FOX) GLEE Gleeks, rejoice — the series’s 100th episode will unite current and former New Directions members to perform remixes of the top 10 songs from the past five seasons. Popular guests also reprise their roles, including Kristin Chenoweth as April Rhodes and Gwyneth Paltrow as Holly Holliday; Chace Crawford makes an appearance as a new character, Biff McIntosh. In “New Girl,” at 9, Jess (Zooey Deschanel) and Cece (Hannah Simone) are invited to a party given by the musician Prince. And in “Brooklyn Nine-Nine,” at 9:30, Jake (Andy Samberg) uses his weekend off to try to crack a cold case.

headline: 5 Million Have Enrolled for Coverage Under Health Law, White House Says
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare']
abstract: The White House said Monday that more than five million people had signed up for private health insurance under President Obama’s health care law, an increase of about 800,000 in the last two weeks.
lead_paragraph: The White House said Monday that more than five million people had signed up for private health insurance under President Obama’s health care law, an increase of about 800,000 in the last two weeks. Marilyn B. Tavenner, the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said that some consumers were obtaining insurance for just $22 a month. The six-month open enrollment period ends on March 31, and Philip M. Schiliro, a health care adviser at the White House, said the final enrollment numbers would be “better than many people anticipate.”

headline: China Rules Out Terror Ties Among Citizens on Jet
abstract: As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner spread out across an expanded area, China said that none of its nationals on Flight 370 were terrorists or malcontents who tried to seize the plane.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner spread out across an expanded area nearly the size of the continental United States, the Chinese government said on Tuesday that it had ruled out the possibility that any of the Chinese citizens on the plane — about two-thirds of the 227 passengers — were terrorists, separatists or malcontents who might have tried to hijack or destroy it.

headline: Plenty of Ways to Try for a Billion-Dollar Prize
abstract: A lighthearted look at three distinct approaches to picking the 67 games in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament in hopes of winning a $1 billion reward from Warren Buffett.
lead_paragraph: It is a rite of spring — a pencil, a bracket, a few bucks invested in a pool in the pursuit of picking the Final Four teams and, eventually, the last one standing in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament. None of us have dreamed of filling out the perfect bracket, mostly because obsessing over that feat would be weird, and the odds of actually doing so are essentially impossible: 9,223,372,036,854,775,808 (that’s 9.223 quintillion) to 1.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Undercover Reports on School Security Raise Ethical Questions
abstract: How do you feel about this kind of covert reporting to test the effectiveness of school security?
lead_paragraph: In “Undercover TV Reports on School Security Raise Ethical Questions,” John Eligon writes about recent attempts by news organizations to test school security measures. In “Seeking Exposé, Students End Up in Handcuffs,” a June 2013 article, Al Baker writes about a similar undercover attempt by student journalists.

headline: An Inside View of Arab Photography
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Photography']
abstract: Samer Mohdad was once told that “Arab photography did not exist.” This week he is part of an ambitious showcase of contemporary Arab photography at Houston FotoFest.
lead_paragraph: Samer Mohdad was a 10-year-old boy living in the mountain village of his Druse ancestors when Lebanon’s civil war broke out in 1975. His life changed overnight: His childhood playmates were now his sworn enemies. The traumatic experience of the war, which lasted until 1990, stayed with him and, Mr. Mohdad believes, eventually led him to photography.

headline: Should the School Day Start Later?
abstract: What do you think the most important benefits of a later start time would be? What might the disadvantages be?
lead_paragraph: Could letting teenagers sleep later in the morning do more than just make them happy? New evidence suggests that a later start to the school day could have all sorts of benefits, like better grades and fewer car crashes. But some worry that pushing the school day back might get in the way of after-school sports and jobs, and wouldn’t leave students enough time to finish homework.

headline: Devin Alberda of the New York City Ballet: Behind the Curtain
abstract: An interview with New York City Ballet dancer Devin Alberda about the strains and joys of dancing professionally while capturing images backstage.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend’s magazine features photographs from the New York City Ballet dancer Devin Alberda’s Instagram account, @dalberda, which gives his followers an intimate, behind-the-scenes look at the ballet. Alberda started his ballet training at age 4 and has performed with the New York City Ballet for nine years. Gabrielle Plucknette, the magazine’s photography assistant, interviewed him about the strains and joys of dancing professionally while capturing images backstage.

headline: New York Today: Play (Brrr!) Ball

lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:45 a.m. | LONDON – A committee of Scania’s independent directors said Tuesday that shareholders should reject Volkswagen’s offer to take full control of the Swedish truck maker because the offer undervalues the company.

headline: West Sees Unity on Iran Despite Crisis in Ukraine
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty', 'Nuclear Energy', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Iran called for world powers to fulfill promises as negotiators met in Vienna, under the shadow of international tensions over Ukraine and Crimea.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Talks on a permanent nuclear agreement with Iran resumed in Vienna on Tuesday, heavily shadowed by the Ukraine crisis between the West and Russia. But European and American officials said their differences with the Kremlin had no effect on the unified position they all take aimed at ensuring the Iranians can never make atomic bombs.

headline: Pakistan’s Culture Wars
abstract: A literature festival reflects the battle for Pakistanis’ hearts and minds.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — On the banks of the luminous China Creek, overlooking old mangrove swamps and the shipping cranes at the port, more than 50,000 people flocked to this year’s Karachi Literature Festival, held annually in February when the flowers bloom, the weather is temperate and the city feels alive with possibility.

headline: A Safe Place for Unwanted Babies Is Overwhelmed
abstract: When Guangzhou set up its first “baby hatch,” where parents can safely give away infants they feel they cannot raise, the babies poured in. With more than it could handle, it has temporarily shut down.
lead_paragraph: So many babies poured into a government-run “baby hatch” in the southern city of Guangzhou after it opened in January that the overwhelmed institution has had to stop taking in any more.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 16 in Northern Afghanistan
abstract: The bombing Tuesday, in a bazaar in the capital of Faryab Province, was the latest major attack in the lead-up to presidential elections next month.

headline: A Conversation With Yukari Kane, Author of ‘Haunted Empire: Apple After Steve Jobs’
abstract: In an interview, Ms. Kane talked about the highlights of her new book, and a company struggling to cope with the loss of its visionary founder.
lead_paragraph: More than two years after the death of Steven P. Jobs, Apple has continued to rake in huge profits with record sales of iPhones and iPads. But despite Apple’s ever-growing mountain of cash, some doubt the company’s success will continue without its visionary leader, whose unwavering obsession with quality helped make its products great and innovative.

headline: Starting Up Is Hard to Do
abstract: There is a constant battle between producing quality work and rushing to test. Time is a luxury few start-ups can enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Twelve months ago, we introduced Posse, a “social search engine” that helps users get recommendations for products, places and services from their friends. I prepared for this by attending every start-up conference I could, by reading books and learning concepts. But nothing prepared me for the challenges I have faced in the past year.

headline: New U.S. Ambassador to China Gets a Fast Start

Early Tuesday, he visited the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to present a copy of his credentials, a formality that allowed him to meet with journalists at the United States Embassy in the afternoon.

headline: Many Cars Are Green, but Only a Few Can Be Called Irish
abstract: A quick tour through Ireland’s mostly overlooked automotive history.
lead_paragraph: Ireland’s most significant contribution to automotive history may have been genealogical: Henry Ford’s father was an Irish immigrant, and in 1917 the automaker, already wildly successful, reconnected with his roots by opening a factory in Cork. Although the plant closed in 1984, Henry Ford & Sons still operates there as a sales enterprise for Ford Motor.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Moving to preserve the political and ethnic balance at the top of his government, President Hamid Karzai on Tuesday nominated a prominent former Northern Alliance figure to fill the vice-presidential post left vacant by the death of Muhammad Qasim Fahim last week.

headline: Taking Aim at an Anonymous Blogger
abstract: David Einhorn’s case against the website Seeking Alpha could affect the future of business journalism. | Foreign investors in Russia are beginning to sound the alarm. | A boutique advisory firm played an important role in the Vodafone-Ono deal. | Turnover continues at SAC Capital Advisors.
lead_paragraph: It may seem as though David Einhorn, the outspoken hedge fund manager, wants to have his cake and eat it, too. After an anonymous blogger on the website Seeking Alpha leaked one of his firm’s investments — a stake in Micron Technology — Mr. Einhorn’s firm, Greenlight Capital, asked a court to force the website to identify the writer by name. If Mr. Einhorn — a longtime champion of transparency when he singles out companies and other market participants — were to win, the result could limit the free flow of information to traditional news outlets and require sites like Seeking Alpha to not publish anonymous contributions, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

headline: In Poland, Biden Promises Allies Protection
abstract: In meetings with the leaders of Poland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. aims to shore up the NATO alliance.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — Citing the need for friends to “stand with one another,” Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. reassured Poland and the Baltic states on Tuesday that the United States would protect them from any Russian aggression like the actions the Kremlin has taken in Crimea.

abstract: FiveThirtyEight needs to raise its game.
lead_paragraph: The new FiveThirtyEight is up, and Tyler Cowen is not impressed. I’m sorry to say that I had the same reaction. Here’s hoping that Nate Silver and company up their game, soon.

headline: In Performance: Steven Boyer (and Tyrone) of ‘Hand to God’
abstract: Mr. Boyer and the puppet Tyrone perform a scene from Robert Askins’s dark comedy.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features the actor Steven Boyer — with the puppet Tyrone — in a scene from Robert Askins‘s dark comedy “Hand to God.” Mr. Boyer plays Jason, a troubled Texas teenager who discovers that his hand puppet is possessed by evil. In this scene, Jason and Tyrone discuss what it means to have “devilish thoughts.” The show, which Charles Isherwood called a “terrific, scary-funny play,” continues through March 30 at the Lucille Lortel Theater, in an MCC production.

headline: Close but Not Quite
abstract: In careful writing, it’s not enough to know the general meaning of a word. Precise usage requires knowing exactly how a word should fit into a sentence. If we slip, the meaning may still be clear enough. But errors are distracting and can make our prose seem slipshod — like a faulty translation from another language.
lead_paragraph: In careful writing, it’s not enough to know the general meaning of a word. Precise usage requires knowing exactly how a word should fit into a sentence. Is it typically used with a preposition, and if so, which one? Is a verb transitive — used with a direct object — or intransitive?

headline: Paris Opera Ballet Wins Jerome Robbins Award
abstract: The ballet company Jerome Robbins called his second family wins the $50,000 Jerome Robbins Award for excellence in the arts.
lead_paragraph: The Jerome Robbins Award, an annual acknowledgement of excellence in the arts, will go this year to the Paris Opera Ballet, the Jerome Robbins Foundation announced on Tuesday. The award, worth $50,000, has previously gone to Mikhail Baryshnikov, Robert Wilson, Jennifer Tipton, Stephen Sondheim and the New York City Ballet, among others. It will be presented to Brigitte Lefèvre, the director of the Paris Opera Ballet, on June 19 at the Palais Garnier in Paris.

headline: 45 Years After Woodstock, New Hudson River Festival Is Announced
abstract: The Hudson Project, promising more than 85 musical acts, will make its debut this year from July 11 through 13, and will be held at the Winston Farm in Saugerties, N.Y.,
lead_paragraph: Nearly 45 years after Woodstock, a new festival is going up the country – or, at least, up the Hudson River – to bring a three-day weekend’s worth of music to the New York area. The Hudson Project, a new music and arts festival promising more than 85 musical acts, will make its debut this year from July 11 through 13, and will be held at the Winston Farm in Saugerties, N.Y., its organizers said on Tuesday. The Hudson Project promises four stages’ worth of performances – musicians were not immediately disclosed but are expected to be announced next week – as well as an emphasis on local arts and crafts; gourmet food, wine and beer; and “a wide range of camping choices from top-level luxury accommodations,” according to a news release.

headline: What Would Scott Brown Do?
keywords: ['Elections, State Legislature', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The age of speculation has given rise to a new kind of candidate: The Superhypothetical.
lead_paragraph: In case you weren’t keeping track — don’t worry, that was a joke! — Scott Brown, the short-time Massachusetts senator and shorter-time political celebrity, has relocated to New Hampshire, where he might run for the Senate again. This speculation has been especially rampant among media types who have been tracking such nitty-gritty as: 1) Brown’s tweeting about his performance with the band Cheap Trick last month; 2) the former Cosmopolitan centerfold’s appearing at a midwinter polar-plunge-type event and having his bare torso reimmortalized, this time on the front page of The New Hampshire Union Leader; and 3) his planning to make a trip to Iowa next month, which would be his third in a year.

headline: Beastie Boys and Toy Company Settle Lawsuit Over Ad’s Use of ‘Girls’
abstract: GoldieBlox, a San Francisco-area toy company, settled a lawsuit filed by the band after an online video made use of the band’s song “Girls” without permission.
lead_paragraph: A San Francisco-area toy company that found itself in a public dispute with the Beastie Boys said on Tuesday that it had reached a settlement with that hip-hop group over its use of the band’s song “Girls” in a popular viral video. In November, the toy company, GoldieBlox, gained widespread attention for a video which showed girls building an elaborate Rube Goldberg device and singing a version of that song with alternate lyrics celebrating their scientific achievements. GoldieBlox filed a lawsuit against the Beastie Boys, asserting its right to use the song in its video; the band countered that the video was “an advertisement that is designed to sell a product,” and that it does not allow its songs to be used for such purposes. The band filed a copyright infringement suit in December. On Tuesday, a press representative for GoldieBlox said that suit had been settled, adding in a statement: “That settlement includes (a) the issuance of an apology by GoldieBlox, which will be posted on GoldieBlox’s website, and (b) a payment by GoldieBlox, based on a percentage of its revenues, to one or more charities selected by Beastie Boys that support science, technology, engineering and mathematics education for girls.” A press representative for the Beastie Boys confirmed these details of the settlement.

headline: 350 Rose Petals Packed Into a Single Jar of Moisturizing Balm
abstract: The new Aerin Essentials Collection includes Rose Balm, a super-hydrating product that also serves as the base for a new set of 10 lipsticks.
lead_paragraph: Time and time again, multi-use beauty products — a single liquid, stick or powder that can be used on almost any part of the body, travels well and functions as an objet d’art on the shelf — attain must-have status. And the new hero in the latest collection from Aerin, the eponymous beauty line from Estée Lauder’s impossibly chic granddaughter, is the superhydrating Rose Balm that seems all but certain to become a cult classic. The extract of over 350 rose petals fills each 0.8-ounce jar of the silky stuff, which nourishes everything from eyes and lips to face and hands without a greasy residue. Aerin used the product as a base for 10 colors of lipsticks in the new Essentials collection so that they feel more like a restorative lip balm — slicking it on smooths the surface of the mouth, leaving the pout soft and dewy-looking — than a traditional pucker paint. If anything, stocking up on these gold-cased gems is motivation to kick into spring cleaning and toss any near-empty tubes of gunk from last season. Aerin Essentials Rose Balm, $58, and Lipstick, $30; aerin.com.

headline: New York’s Dream Act Dies
keywords: ['Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)']
abstract: Monday’s vote puts New York behind California, New Mexico, Washington and Texas, all of which provide state tuition aid for their college-bound Dreamers.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Senate on Monday rejected the Dream Act, which would allow undocumented immigrants to receive state tuition aid. The narrow vote — the bill fell two votes short of passage — was a bitter disappointment to immigrant advocates who had hoped the state would help make college more affordable for “Dreamers,” young immigrants brought here illegally as children, many of whom are unable to continue their educations once they leave high school.

headline: Measles Outbreak May Have Spread in Medical Facilities, a New York City Official Says
abstract: A city epidemiologist said that a failure to recognize symptoms and quarantine patients quickly enough may have led to 20 confirmed cases of the disease.
lead_paragraph: A rare outbreak of measles in New York City may have been spread by the failure of medical workers to recognize the disease quickly enough and to quarantine patients so they would not infect others, a city epidemiologist said this week.

headline: Chris Brown Held; Kanye West Pleads; Tyler, the Creator Arrested
abstract: A judge ordered Mr. Brown to be held in a Los Angeles jail until a probation hearing. Mr. West pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor battery charge. And Tyler, the Creator was released on bond after being charged with inciting a riot in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: And now for today’s cultural police blotter:

headline: European Panel Adopts ‘Net Neutrality’ and Mobile Roaming Rules
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Net Neutrality']
abstract: The draft law is aimed at ensuring equal Internet access and lower rates for cellphone use across the European Union, but critics want changes.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A panel of lawmakers voted on Tuesday for tougher measures to promote equal access to the Internet and to cut the cost of cellphone charges across the 28-member European Union.

headline: A Credible Strategy to Fix Barclays
abstract: Barclays’ chief executive needs to pare back in businesses that the bank doesn’t need and shore up several areas that remain, Dominic Elliott writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Barclays’ plan to transform itself needs urgent transformation.

headline: Introducing ‘AnonyWatch': Tracking Nameless Quotations in The Times
abstract: The inaugural edition of ‘AnonyWatch,’ an effort to point out some of the more regrettable examples of anonymous quotations in The Times.
lead_paragraph: This post is the inaugural edition of an effort to point out some of the more regrettable examples of anonymous quotations in The Times. I’ve written about this from time to time, as have my predecessors, to little or no avail.

headline: Pentagon Finds Washington Navy Yard Killings Could Have Been Prevented
keywords: ['Washington Navy Yard Shooting (2013)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A review of the mass shooting at the Washington Navy Yard in September concluded that the Navy did not properly evaluate or report alarming behavior by the gunman, Aaron Alexis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Defense Department review of the mass shooting that killed 12 people at the Washington Navy Yard in September has concluded that the deaths could have been prevented if the Navy had properly evaluated and reported alarming behavior by the gunman, Aaron Alexis, a former Navy reservist.

headline: New York City Settles Lawsuit Accusing Fire Dept. of Racial Bias
abstract: As part of the settlement, which came after more than seven years of litigation, the city agreed to pay nearly $100 million in back pay and benefits.
lead_paragraph: Years of legal wrangling over the racial makeup of the New York City Fire Department has led to a host of reforms, from a court-appointed monitor to a new entrance exam and an influx of recruiters into black and Hispanic neighborhoods.

headline: Search Area Expanded for Missing Plane
abstract: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said countries including Australia, China, Indonesia and Kazakhstan were working together in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said countries including Australia, China, Indonesia and Kazakhstan were working together in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Wheelies: The Jimmy Fallon’s Truck Edition
abstract: The host of “The Tonight Show” wants to buy a pickup; Hyundai apologizes for overestimating the fuel-economy figure for the new Sonata.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Putin Justifies Moves in Crimea
abstract: In his speech in Moscow, President Vladimir V. Putin defended Russia’s actions in Crimea by pointing out past Western “interventions,” including Libya and Afghanistan, at length.
lead_paragraph: In his speech in Moscow, President Vladimir V. Putin defended Russia’s actions in Crimea by pointing out past Western “interventions,” including Libya and Afghanistan, at length.

headline: Profile in Style | L’Wren Scott
abstract: A look back at T’s archives, when we celebrated the chic designer and her many talents.
lead_paragraph: A look back at T’s archives, when we celebrated the chic designer and her many talents.

headline: High Fallutin’ Nazis
abstract: Learning from Ken Langone.
lead_paragraph: Here comes another billionaire who thinks that anyone who talks about income inequality is a Nazi; this time it’s Ken Langone, co-founder of Home Depot. I don’t have anything useful to say about this, other than the observation that there must be a lot of these guys. I mean, there aren’t that many billionaires, so that coming up with multiple examples of the genus who not only believe that progressives are just like Hitler but are willing to say so in public must indicate that a substantial proportion of our billionaires share this belief, but more privately. Luckily, great wealth doesn’t bring great political influence in modern America — does it?

headline: Remembering L’Wren Scott
abstract: We celebrate her remarkable life and career with this playful video from our archives, a tribute to the designer’s vital stats and many hats.
lead_paragraph: Like so many, the staff of T was devastated to learn yesterday about the passing of L’Wren Scott. We celebrate her remarkable life by reaching into our archive for this 2008 Profile in Style, a tribute to the one-of-a-kind designer written by Alex Hawgood, accompanied by this playful high-octane video by the New York design firm Adolescent. She will be deeply missed.

headline: Biden Promises Protection to Poland
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met with Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland in Warsaw to assure allies in Eastern Europe that the United States would protect them against any Russian aggression.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met with Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland in Warsaw to assure allies in Eastern Europe that the United States would protect them against any Russian aggression.

headline: Image of the Day: March 18
abstract: A member of a nongovernmental organization creating awareness among people about votes for sale in the upcoming general elections due in April-May.

headline: Budding Liberal Protest Movements Begin to Take Root in South
abstract: More than a dozen members of Moral Monday Georgia, a liberal activist group that has held weekly protests at the Capitol since January, were arrested.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — There was a son of a sharecropper and an advocate for the homeless, a college student and a great-grandmother, a retired store manager and the senior pastor of Ebenezer Baptist Church.

headline: Dispatches from SXSW: Social Media Start-Ups
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Social Media', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Notes on some of the intriguing start-ups at SXSW that are focused on social media.
lead_paragraph: Predictably, last week’s SXSW Interactive festival featured a host of innovative start-ups focused on social media. Here are a few of the more intriguing ones:

headline: If History Is a Guide, Crimeans’ Celebration May Be Short-Lived
abstract: South Ossetia had high hopes when Russia took control of the enclave from Georgia in 2008, but its economy is stagnant and corruption is rife.
lead_paragraph: ATOTSI, Georgia — As Crimeans danced in the streets this week, giddy at the prospect of being gathered into Russia, few were watching as closely as the residents of the tiny mountainous enclave of South Ossetia, who, five and a half years ago, were similarly ecstatic.

headline: Another ‘Cars’ Movie Is on the Way
abstract: Robert A. Iger, the Disney chief executive and chairman, says a third “Cars” movie is coming from Pixar and a sequel to “The Incredibles” is in the works.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive and chairman, offered a few cinematic news nuggets in the early part of the company’s annual shareholder meeting on Tuesday. Pixar, which is owned by Disney, is working on a third “Cars” movie, he said, and Brad Bird, who directed “The Incredibles,” is working on a story for a sequel to that animated superhero film. (But Mr. Iger notably did not say that Mr. Bird would direct it.)

headline: Confirmation of Shake-Up in China’s Film Industry
abstract: Han Sanping is stepping down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company that supervises film imports to China.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Even more mysterious than the subterranean power struggles in Hollywood are the hidden currents in China’s growing film business. But one mystery clarified itself, at least a little, when Asia Film Business on Monday confirmed what had been widely reported for months: Han Sanping has stepped down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company with duties that include the supervision of film imports to China.

headline: Inquiry Seeks Port Authority Records That Involve Christie Ally
abstract: David Samson, who is an ally of Gov. Chris Christie, voted to award contracts on bridge projects worth $2.8 billion to companies connected to Mr. Samson’s law firm.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in New Jersey issued a subpoena last week to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey seeking records relating to its chairman, David Samson, and contracts on two bridge projects worth $2.8 billion that he voted to award to construction companies with some ties to his law firm, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Blast in Golan Heights Wounds 4 Israeli Soldiers
abstract: An explosive device struck near an Israeli Army patrol, in an attack seen as the most serious in recent weeks on Israel’s northern borders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An explosive device was detonated on Tuesday against an Israeli Army patrol along the decades-old Israeli-Syrian cease-fire line in the Golan Heights, and Israeli forces responded with artillery fire against Syrian military positions, according to Israeli officials.

headline: Major Balkan Drug Trafficker Arrested in Serbia, Authorities Say
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Money Laundering', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: Darko Saric, described as running a drug ring that stretched from Latin American to Europe, agreed to turn himself in, officials said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Darko Saric, described as being among the most feared and wanted drug traffickers in the Balkans, was arrested in Serbia on Tuesday and charged with smuggling more than five tons of cocaine and laundering at least $30 million as leader of an elaborate drug ring that stretched from South America to western Europe, the Serbian authorities said.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Tales From Red Vienna’
abstract: Nina Arianda and Michael Esper in a scene from the new David Grimm play, at City Center Stage I.
lead_paragraph: Nina Arianda and Michael Esper in a scene from the new David Grimm play, at City Center Stage I.

headline: Second Act | Italian Hours
abstract: In Florence, the English entrepreneur Sue Townsend merges the warmth of great English decorating with the spare patina of Renaissance architecture for an interior that is the best of both worlds.
lead_paragraph: In Florence, the English entrepreneur Sue Townsend merges the warmth of great English decorating with the spare patina of Renaissance architecture for an interior that is the best of both worlds.

headline: Music Sales Fell in 2013, Even as Streaming Revenue Increased
abstract: A 4 percent global decline is fueled by a steep dive in Japan, where digital has barely taken hold.
lead_paragraph: Income from online streaming services like Spotify, Pandora and YouTube is growing rapidly, but not enough to lift the music industry into growth over all, the industry’s global trade group reported on Tuesday.

headline: The Red Sauce Juggernaut
abstract: In brash New York style, the ambitious team behind Torrisi Italian Specialties and Carbone aims for culinary conquest.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning it was all about smallness and stealth.

headline: The Search Area West of Australia
abstract: New computer models of possible flight paths suggested that the plane may have gone down in the southern Indian Ocean when it ran out of fuel.
lead_paragraph: New computer models of possible flight paths suggested that the plane may have gone down in the southern Indian Ocean when it ran out of fuel.

headline: Scenes From a Helicopter Crash
abstract: A television news helicopter crashed near the Space Needle in Seattle on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: A television news helicopter crashed near the Space Needle in Seattle on Tuesday morning.

headline: Nominees for James Beard Awards Announced
abstract: Three spots in Manhattan — Betony, Carbone and Estela — helped fill up the Best New Restaurant category.
lead_paragraph: Both veterans and upstarts — in New York and around the country — are among those nominated this year for James Beard awards, which will be handed out at Lincoln Center on May 5.

headline: Hiking and Kayaking in Namibia
abstract: A new trip in Namibia from the tour company Adventure Life will include an overnight hike and sea kayaking in addition to opportunities to see animals like lions and giraffes.
lead_paragraph: As if tracking black rhinoceroses through the African wilderness might not be exciting enough, a new safari from Adventure Life, the tour company, has ramped up its usual tour through Namibia, adding an overnight hike through a desert, sea kayaking in the Atlantic Ocean, options for cooking classes and mountain biking and a meeting with an ancient tribe to the itinerary.

headline: Obama’s Test: Can Penalties Change Russia’s Course?
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: As Russian officials essentially laughed off the initial sanctions over Crimea and a senior American official vowed to “make it hurt,” it was unclear how much more pain the United States could inflict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Russia invaded Crimea, a senior American official vowed to “make it hurt.” More than two weeks later, Moscow has given no sign that it feels any pain, and the challenge for President Obama is whether he is willing or able to inflict enough to change the Kremlin’s calculus.

headline: The Gun Report: March 18, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last week we wrote about how state gun control laws were strengthened in the aftermath of the Newtown massacre. But in some states, gun restrictions are quickly unravelling.

headline: Scenes of Bazaar Bombing in Afghanistan
abstract: A suicide bomber killed at least 16 people in Afghanistan’s northern province of Faryab by detonating a rickshaw filled with explosives in a bazaar.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber killed at least 16 people in Afghanistan’s northern province of Faryab by detonating a rickshaw filled with explosives in a bazaar.

headline: Criminals, All Young, Let Loose Upon Earth
abstract: “The 100,” beginning Wednesday night on CW, sends a contingent of teenagers to a post-apocalyptic earth to test whether humans can survive there.
lead_paragraph: The science-fiction series “The 100,” beginning Wednesday night on CW, is an imagine-the-pitch kind of show. “It’s ‘Lord of the Flies’ meets ‘Lost in Space!’ ” Or, to put it in terms its target audience might recognize, it’s “The Hunger Games” meets “Battlestar Galactica,” with bits of “Terra Nova” and “Lost” thrown in.

headline: The White House Pastry Chef Is Moving to a New Kitchen
abstract: Bill Yosses took the White House from the bottomless cookie plate to a granola bar without nuts, chocolate or white sugar. How does your family balance healthy eating and foods that are fun?
lead_paragraph: Bill Yosses, “the man who made the Hawaiian chocolate-malted ganache for the White House state dinner for France, is now headed to New York with an aim to teach children and adults about eating better,” Marian Burros writes in The Times.

headline: Dirck the Norseman Opens in Greenpoint
abstract: A new-wave brewery also boasts a restaurant offering hearty gastro-pub fare designed to accompany beers.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Tales From Tel Aviv and Upper West Side
abstract: Molly Antopol’s first collection of short stories, “The UnAmericans,” inspired by her family’s background in Belarus, explores the lives of frazzled Jewish intellectuals and others.
lead_paragraph: Molly Antopol’s first book, a collection of stories called “The UnAmericans,” has poise and gravity. It sometimes put me in mind of Allegra Goodman’s work; both writers are adept at auditing the emotional lives of frazzled Jewish intellectuals. At other times, the Old World lefty politics in Ms. Antopol’s stories summoned the memory of Grace Paley, for whom every joke came wrapped around a bony fist of meaning.

headline: Cheese Curds, a Riff on Cronuts, a Paris Ham and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of March 18.
lead_paragraph: To Munch: Any New Yorker Can Be a Cheesehead

headline: Nuzzel Finds the Top Stories in Your Personal Twitterverse
abstract: Your friends may have a good idea of what you want to read. A start-up is leaning on them to help cull through your Twitter feed.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is large and contains multitudes (hat tip to Walt Whitman). Business moguls like Carl Icahn menace corporate bosses on it. Comedians like Jerry Seinfeld crack jokes. Eyewitnesses to riots, invasions and Super Bowl games post live updates as they happen. All told, there are half a billion Twitter messages published every day.

headline: Robert Clergerie Steps Out With A.L.C.
abstract: The L.A. sportswear brand and the storied French shoemaker collaborate on a bold, streetwise sandal.
lead_paragraph: Those of us who stockpile and eBay-stalk the eccentric, refreshingly comfortable footwear of Robert Clergerie consider ourselves an anti-stiletto sisterhood of sorts. (Call it the Clergerie Club, or simply the Clergy.) One card-carrying member, it turns out, is Andrea Lieberman of A.L.C. The Los Angeles-based designer and stylist has been collecting the brand’s platforms, oxfords and crepe-soled creepers since she first discovered them in their heyday during the 1990s. That decade’s favored status in fashion, along with the appointment in 2011 of Roland Mouret as Clergerie’s artistic director, means that the 33-year-old company is lately having something of a moment. For spring, Lieberman created a special limited-edition version of the brand’s Danvin sandal, fabricated with pale-gray suede and black patent-leather straps, and a color- and texture-blocked platform sole. The result is a sturdy but sleek, outfit-making shoe that harmonizes nicely with A.L.C.’s laid-back Left Coast sportswear. “There’s a certain integrity that resonates with a pair of Robert Clergerie shoes,” Lieberman says. “They’re luxurious but cool, edgy but refined.”

headline: Top Technology Officer at Pandora Steps Down
abstract: Tom Conrad, one of the company’s most visible executives, said on Tuesday that he would move into an adviser role for Pandora in the next three months.
lead_paragraph: The top technology officer of Pandora Media will resign and move into a part-time advisory role, the biggest management change at the Internet radio giant since the arrival of its new chief executive last year.

headline: A Bottle of Bandol Begs for Lamb
abstract: A seared and roasted butterflied leg of lamb pairs wonderfully with this intense wine.
lead_paragraph: Provence is not all rosé and ratatouille. Its mistral winds can send you inside to sit by the fire and inspire you to open a bottle of Bandol rouge, an intense wine with dark red fruit and echoes of smoke and herbs that begs for lamb.

headline: Original Review: ‘Of Mice and Men’ (1937)
abstract: Brooks Atkinson’s review of John Steinbeck’s play, which opened on Broadway in 1937 at the Music Box Theater.
lead_paragraph: Brooks Atkinson’s review of John Steinbeck’s play, which opened on Broadway in 1937 at the Music Box Theater.

headline: Taming of the Bestial Bandol
abstract: Bandol, a young tough, can also be nuanced and elegant.
lead_paragraph: Wine is so often typecast. Rosé belongs to the summer, and zinfandel, the all-American wine, to Thanksgiving. We drink white wine with fish.

headline: Further Thoughts on Hedgehogs and Foxes
abstract: Expertise still matters.
lead_paragraph: A few more thoughts on Nate Silver and his attempt to be a fox among hedgehogs.

headline: A Culinary Pilgrimage to Punjab
abstract: The author heads to northern India for a tasting tour of dhabas, casual restaurants famous for their inexpensive and remarkably tasty cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Within five minutes of ordering three deluxe thalis at the large and bustling Bharawan da Dhaba in Amritsar, India, a waiter brought us round steel trays filled with our $3 lunch. There were a half-dozen bowls on each, which included spicy chickpeas with a hint of pomegranate powder, the black lentils known as daal and the Punjabi comfort food equivalents of macaroni and cheese — the creamy mustard greens called sarso ka saag and kadhi, a yellow chickpea flour and yogurt curry swimming with fried onion fritters. Lachedar parantha, whole wheat butter-layered bread, fresh from the tandoor clay oven, was our accompaniment.

headline: In Panama City, Mixing Global and Local Flavors
abstract: Chefs in Panama’s capital are using local ingredients to create dishes influenced by cultures from around the world.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years after the opening of the Panama Canal — which continues to bring in immigrants of different ethnicities whose foods dominate Panama City’s culinary scene — a new Panamanian cuisine is emerging, one that looks inward while embracing its diversity. Panama City, admittedly, has very few original dishes. You are more likely to dine on spanakopita or chow mein than saus, pickled pig’s feet or the chicken stew called sancocho. That’s changing. Everywhere you look, ambitious young chefs and entrepreneurs are adapting local ingredients to global trends, ranging from Southern barbecue to Japanese-Peruvian fusion.

headline: Hotel Review: Hotel La Jolla in San Diego
abstract: Reopened less than two years ago by the Kimpton chain, this property features ocean views, thoughtful service and a location within walking distance of the beach.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Linea Caffe in San Francisco
abstract: The concept: coffee, waffles and salads on the menu and no seating inside. The result: Somehow, it works.
lead_paragraph: The premise of Linea Caffe, which opened last September, sounds as if it came straight out of a late-night brainstorming session without a next-morning reality check. A coffee bar (Linea Caffe) shares a tiny storefront with a waffle counter (Lt. Waffle), which also functions as a salad bar. Click on the salad bar’s website, and you’ll find a statement of purpose that reads like a manifesto: avocado is “the zeitgeist,” and “kale is not a passing fad.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Greece Reaches Deal to Release Foreign Rescue Funds
abstract: Negotiations with foreign lenders had dragged on because of disagreements over the extent of austerity Greece must impose and what relief measures it could offer citizens.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — After seven months of faltering negotiations, Prime Minister Antonis Samaras said on Tuesday that Greece had reached a deal with its foreign lenders on economic reforms necessary to unlock billions of euros in crucial rescue funding. He also pledged to distribute 500 million euros to one million Greeks hit hardest by the country’s economic crisis.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Ukraine, Malaysia and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Ukraine, Malaysia and Afghanistan.

headline: Má Pêche’s Focus Turns to Four Wheels
abstract: David Chang is serving from dim-sum trolleys.
lead_paragraph: As soon as I heard about State Bird Provisions, the San Francisco restaurant where the food comes around on dim-sum trolleys, I hoped a New York chef would steal the idea. Now David Chang has.

headline: West Coast Visitors Arrive, Then Look Back
abstract: The Los Angeles Philharmonic, led by Gustavo Dudamel, arrived at Avery Fisher Hall for concerts featuring works from Brahms, John Corigliano and others.
lead_paragraph: While many American orchestras are grappling with financial challenges and discontent among players, the Los Angeles Philharmonic looks to be a solid success story. Relations between management and musicians seem very positive. A four-year contract signed last fall included slight annual raises in the salaries of the players. Walt Disney Concert Hall, the coolest symphonic performance space in America, remains a big draw. Most important, the charismatic conductor Gustavo Dudamel, 33, now in his fifth season as music director, continues to galvanize audiences in the Los Angeles area while heading the orchestra’s impressive community outreach and education efforts.

headline: It’s Official, Secret Money Corrupts
abstract: An investigation now unfolding in Utah exposes how the non-profit system can be corrupted for the benefit of a single politician, and a single industry.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers of both parties are desperately trying to stop the Internal Revenue Service from interfering with the most powerful political invention that ever fell into their laps: the use of non-profit groups as a source of unlimited and anonymous campaign money. If you want to understand why, consider an investigation now unfolding in Utah, which exposes in remarkable detail how profoundly the non-profit system can be corrupted for the benefit of a single industry and a single politician.

headline: Women Lawyers Climb Top Rungs of Corporate America
abstract: Some 21 percent of the top lawyers at the nation’s Fortune 500 companies are women, an increase from 17 percent five years ago, according to a new tally of corporate counsel ranks.
lead_paragraph: Some 21 percent of the top lawyers at the nation’s Fortune 500 companies are women, an increase from 17 percent five years ago, according to a new tally of corporate counsel ranks.

headline: Ofer Cohen
abstract: Mr. Cohen is the president and a partner in TerraCRG, a commercial brokerage and advisory company focused solely on Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cohen, 43, is the president and a partner in TerraCRG, a commercial brokerage and advisory company focused solely on Brooklyn. Before starting TerraCRG in early 2008, Mr. Cohen was a senior broker at Massey Knakal Realty’s Brooklyn office.

headline: Balancing Act: Building the Village
abstract: A profile of the Jeremiah Program, which tries to help single mothers and their children escape the poverty trap by providing subsidized housing and early childhood education.
lead_paragraph: A profile of the Jeremiah Program, which tries to help single mothers and their children escape the poverty trap by providing subsidized housing and early childhood education.

headline: Spinning a Classic French Tale
abstract: At Rôtisserie Georgette, giving the chicken and quail a whirl.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year Rôtisserie Georgette put a new chef in charge of its spit-roasted chickens and fish, its fries flecked with tarragon and its baby potatoes heavy with meat drippings, and I couldn’t tell the difference. This is meant as praise, and not the damning-with-faint kind.

headline: Program Works to Lift Single Mothers Out of Poverty
abstract: The Jeremiah Program, which offers a support system to help improve the economic prospects of the mothers and their children, is expanding into several cities.
lead_paragraph: Low-income single mothers, a growing demographic group, face a challenging set of responsibilities, with unusually tight resources. They must juggle erratic work hours, inconsistent child care and often (at least if they want to move up the socioeconomic ladder) school programs that are not built to accommodate their work and family lives. With so much economic insecurity, their children also have the decks stacked against them.

headline: Time to Make Up for a Missed Measles Vaccine
abstract: The measles outbreak in New York City offers an opportunity to reach out to families whose children have missed, skipped or delayed the vaccine.
lead_paragraph: WIth 20 confirmed cases of measles in New York City, now is a good time to check your children’s vaccination records, make up for any shots missed because of illness or travel and reconsider any stance your family might have taken on delaying or refusing vaccinations. Writing for The Times, Anemona Hartocollis reports that of the 20 confirmed cases, 9 were children. Of those, 7 were too young to be vaccinated or within the window of 12 to 15 months old when the vaccination is recommended. The other 2 were from families in which the parents refused to allow the vaccination.

headline: Just a Little Bit of Yonkers Goes a Long Way at Iowa State
abstract: The relentless rebounding of Dustin Hogue, a Yonkers native, is a big reason Iowa State won the Big 12 tournament and is a No. 3 seed in the East Region of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The first snip of scissors sliced cleanly through the net at the Sprint Center. But the second? Dustin Hogue of Iowa State, standing on a ladder, needed several tries to finish the job after the Cyclones won the Big 12 tournament championship here, at one point making a face as if somebody had slipped him rubber scissors as a gag.

headline: Rebuilding Detroit, One House at a Time
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A program to renovate homes and provide them to writers is just one of a number of projects aimed at revitalizing the city.
lead_paragraph: The message implicit in the prizewinning documentaries “Detropia” and “Searching for Sugar Man,” in Detroit’s declaration of bankruptcy in 2013 — in even a casual drive along Gratiot Avenue, past mile after mile of burned-out or boarded-up houses and stores — is that Detroit is in a pitiable state.

headline: Leak Found in Main Near East Harlem Explosion Site
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board said the breach was in an eight-inch gas pipe adjacent to 1646 Park Avenue, one of the two buildings that collapsed, killing eight people.
lead_paragraph: Investigators examining the scene of the deadly gas explosion in East Harlem said on Tuesday that they had identified a leak in an eight-inch cast-iron and plastic gas main under Park Avenue between 116th and 117th Streets.

headline: Dream Homes in Kings Point, L.I.
abstract: A Gatsby-esque collection of homes and estates amid tall trees, lushly landscaped lawns and meandering roads at the northern tip of the Great Neck peninsula.
lead_paragraph: Last November, when the youngest of their three children was ready for his own room, Bobby Zargari and his wife, Melissa, moved from a compact home with a postage-stamp-size backyard in Saddle Rock Estates, an unincorporated area, to a sprawling, twice-expanded five-bedroom three-bath ranch on a flat, rectangular 1.25-acre plot in Kings Point, the verdant, affluent village at the northern tip of the Great Neck peninsula in Nassau County.

headline: A Troubled Neighborhood’s Revival in San Francisco
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Bayview Hunters Point is getting a new design and homes that will continue to shelter its current low-income residents.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Three residential towers in the notoriously crime-ridden, impoverished Bayview Hunters Point neighborhood opened earlier this year, the first signs of efforts to overhaul the area.

headline: Update on Our Student Editorial-Writing Contest
abstract: Thank you teachers and students for the record-setting number of submissions. Winners will be announced April 22.
lead_paragraph: Update | April 23: We have announced the winners of the Student Editorial Contest here.

headline: Jemima Kirke’s Paintings of Girls
abstract: The artist, HBO star and bohemian icon Jemima Kirke discusses the paintings in her first solo show.
lead_paragraph: Jemima Kirke is “methodical and serious as a painter, but if Jessa had a show, she might not have shown up,” says Holly Fouladi, the owner of Fouladi Projects in San Francisco, where the British-American “Girls” star will unveil her second solo exhibition of oil portraiture, “Platforms.” Comparisons are easy to make. The 28-year-old shares a number of commonalities with her character Jessa Johansson on the HBO series: a best friend in Lena Dunham (or Hannah Horvath); the flung-on, bohemian insouciance; that penchant for an American Spirit after dinner.

headline: Do Friends Let Friends Sign Their Paychecks?
abstract: “Doll & Em,” on HBO, with Dolly Wells and Emily Mortimer, is about two show-business best friends and was created by two show-business best friends.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a worse premise than an actress and her best friend writing and starring together in a film about their friendship.

headline: Pushing Buttons and Boundaries on Movie Screens
abstract: The New Directors/New Films festival of recent work from around the world continues to push boundaries in film form and subjects.
lead_paragraph: Every spring, New Directors/New Films — a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art — offers a sampler of recent work from around the globe by filmmakers you may not know but should. Last year’s edition included Sarah Polley’s documentary “Stories We Tell” and Shane Carruth’s “Upstream Color,” titles that pushed film form and some filmgoer buttons. This year’s edition features 27 diverse features and two programs of short works that are certain to keep the conversation going long after the festival ends. Here are highlights from the first week.

headline: Video of Putin’s Complete Speech on Crimea
abstract: President Vladimir Putin’s address welcoming Crimea to the Russian Federation, and a subsequent signing ceremony, were broadcast with simultaneous English translation by RT, the Kremlin-funded network.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Steven Lee Myers and Ellen Barry report from Moscow, President Vladimir V. Putin reclaimed Crimea and the port city of Sevastopol as a part of Russia on Tuesday, in “an emotional address before the country’s political elite in the Grand Kremlin Palace.”

headline: De Blasio’s Approval Slips, a Poll Shows
abstract: A Quinnipiac University poll released Tuesday also showed a sharp racial divide in voters’ optimism about New York City’s future.
lead_paragraph: The bumps and bruises afflicting his young administration have lowered Mayor Bill de Blasio’s stature among New Yorkers over the past two months, and there is a sharp racial divide in voters’ optimism about the city’s future, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

headline: North Carolina Beer Month Is Near
abstract: North Carolina Beer Month, which celebrates the state’s breweries, will include beer dinners, new releases, and a sweepstakes.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina Beer Month, celebrating the state’s 100 breweries and scheduled for April, is going to get an early start.

headline: Reviews: Smash Hit, Castlevania, Calculords and Threes!
abstract: New releases include Smash Hit, a guided first-person shooter; the latest Castlevania game; Calculords, a lane-based strategy game; and Threes!, a mobile numbers game.
lead_paragraph: SMASH HIT

headline: Wooing the Public to Recover Art
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A French family is petitioning for a referendum in a Swiss city in its efforts to regain a painting by John Constable that was seized during World War II.
lead_paragraph: LA CHAUX-DE-FONDS, Switzerland — Alain Monteagle unfolded his blue chair and set up a white table at a vegetable market last weekend, covering it with brochures titled “The Looting of Art in War.” As a baker nearby peddled croissants that morning, Mr. Monteagle tried to sell his version of justice.

headline: Unpacking a Family’s Musical Legacy
abstract: The violinist Yevgeny Kutik, originally from Belarus, didn’t take a cookie-cutter path to the concert stage.
lead_paragraph: As a boy growing up in the Berkshires, Yevgeny Kutik paid little attention to the stack of yellowing sheet music that sat on a shelf in his family’s music studio, where he practiced the violin. He had arrived as a 5-year-old in 1990 from the crumbling Soviet Union with his parents, maternal grandparents and two suitcases that were as tall as he was. In those first years, he said during a recent interview over tea, “I was more concerned with making friends, learning English, fitting in.”

headline: Activists Prevail in Campaign to Oust REIT’s Board
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Real Estate Investment Trusts', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: A shareholder vote set in motion a process that will almost certainly result in the ouster of Barry M. Portnoy and his son, Adam D. Portnoy, who control CommonWealth.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:46 p.m. | For more than a year, an activist hedge fund and a prominent real estate developer have pressed for change at a real estate investment trust.

headline: Richard Prince Settles Copyright Suit With Patrick Cariou Over Photographs
abstract: Mr. Prince reached an undisclosed settlement over altered images of Rastafarians that Mr. Cariou had published.
lead_paragraph: In the final, quiet act of a copyright case that riveted the art world for five years, the artist Richard Prince has reached a settlement with Patrick Cariou, a photographer who accused Mr. Prince of violating his copyright protections by using Mr. Cariou’s pictures of Rastafarians as the basis for a series of paintings that sold for millions of dollars.

headline: Returning, in His Own Way, to the Killing Fields
abstract: In “The Missing Picture,” the director Rithy Panh uses figurines and the usual documentary devices to relay his personal story regarding Cambodia’s killing fields.
lead_paragraph: The audacity of “The Missing Picture” — a brilliant documentary about a child who held on to life in Cambodia’s killing fields — is equaled only by its soulfulness. On April 17, 1975, the day the Khmer Rouge seized the capital, Phnom Penh, the 13-year-old Rithy Panh, his family and millions more were driven from that city and other towns and villages and straight into hell. Four years later, many of his relatives, including his father, mother, sisters and a niece and nephew were dead; decades later, Mr. Panh, now a filmmaker, has told his story in a movie in which the act of remembrance serves as a form of resistance.

headline: Free-for-All on the Final Friday of Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: As the presenting sponsor of the festival for the first time, the company is introducing an effort, “Film for All,” that aims to expose the festival to more New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: AT&T has been offering free Wi-Fi in New York City parks since 2011 but now, as part of its sponsorship of the coming Tribeca Film Festival, it will be offering park users a reason to switch off their devices: free movies.

headline: Forget the Triangle: Dolan and Jackson Play a Two-Man Game
abstract: As Phil Jackson was handed the keys to the Knicks on Tuesday, the team owner, James L. Dolan, seemed triumphant and the executive Steve Mills seemed liked a fifth wheel.
lead_paragraph: The introductory news conference for Phil Jackson at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday did not exactly feature the democratic share-the-ball principles of his beloved triangle offense. In a late-morning session with the Knicks’ owner, James L. Dolan, and the holdover executive Steve Mills, Jackson spoke extensively, Dolan waxed triumphantly and Mills never once got a chance to speak.

headline: A Global Boom, but Only for Some
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'North American Free Trade Agreement']
abstract: Globalization improved the lot of hundreds of millions of people in the developing world, but not — as its promoters promised — the living standards of most American workers.
lead_paragraph: Remember when Al Gore took on H. Ross Perot? It was November 1993. Mr. Gore deployed his smoothest scorn to swat down the cantankerous billionaire’s argument that the North American Free Trade Agreement would produce a “great sucking sound” of jobs flowing to Mexico. The agreement, Mr. Gore said, would become an engine of American prosperity.

headline: Harvard’s Latest Basketball Success: Winning Over Its Campus

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Shortly before leaving for Spokane, Wash., and their N.C.A.A. tournament matchup against Cincinnati, the members of Harvard men’s basketball team gathered in the university’s Murr Center to meet the news media.

keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: Bankers are not exactly popular these days, but is it right to let directors escape scot-free when they do wrong and an investment bank pays the bill?

headline: Russia’s Most-Wanted Rebel Is Dead, Website Says
abstract: The site, which represents militant groups in southern Russia, did not say how or when Doku Umarov, a Chechen rebel leader, had died.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The death of Doku Umarov, Russia’s most wanted terrorist leader, was announced Tuesday on a website representing Islamist militant groups in southern Russia.

headline: Memories of a Friend, a Teacher and a Fighter
abstract: Despite her Amazonian height and courtesan-like glamour, L’Wren Scott’s warmth and empathy could rapidly close the distance to another human being.
lead_paragraph: L’Wren Scott was beguiling to her friends, so I can’t imagine what strangers thought of her. There was her height: 6-foot-7 in heels, which made me (5-foot-7) feel like a shrimp.
