keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Poverty', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: An interview with Branko Milanovic of the City University of New York, a longtime development expert at the World Bank, on how globalization has reduced income inequality between nations.
lead_paragraph: Branko Milanovic has been studying income inequality around the world for a long time.

headline: Trial Judge Will Not Allow 9/11 Architect’s Testimony
abstract: A Manhattan federal judge said the testimony of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed would not be permitted at the trial of a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Manhattan ruled on Tuesday that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described architect of the Sept. 11 attacks, will not be permitted to provide testimony in the terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a former top adviser to Osama bin Laden.

headline: Radar on Mainland Too Robust to Miss a Jet, Experts Say
abstract: If Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 flew north over the Asian mainland, it would have had a hard time avoiding detection by Chinese, Indian or American radar, current and ex-military officers say.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — If the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner flew north over the Asian mainland after it lost contact with ground controllers on March 8, it would have had a difficult time avoiding detection by Chinese, Indian or American radar, current and former military officers say.

headline: ‘Diner’ Musical to Open at Signature Theater in Virginia
abstract: Based on Barry Levinson’s 1982 film, the musical has music and lyrics by Sheryl Crow and a book by Mr. Levinson.
lead_paragraph: The bumpy road for the Sheryl Crow-Barry Levinson musical “Diner,” based on Mr. Levinson’s 1982 film, is not leading to San Francisco or New York first (as originally planned) but rather to Arlington, Va., where Signature Theater will stage a world premiere production in December, the theater announced on Tuesday night.

headline: Republican Primary
abstract: Live results from the Republican primary for Illinois governor.
lead_paragraph: Live results from the Republican primary for Illinois governor.

headline: Salvation Army Settles Lawsuit on Religious Discrimination
abstract: New York employees who work in Salvation Army programs that receive government funds will get a document stating that they need not adhere to the group’s religious principles on the job.
lead_paragraph: The Salvation Army on Tuesday settled a decade-old lawsuit that charged it with engaging in religious discrimination by requiring its government-funded social service employees to reveal their beliefs and to agree to act in accordance with the Christian gospel.

headline: Report Issued on War Crimes in Syria
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Investigators told the Human Rights Council that atrocities toward civilians were increasing as the conflict entered its fourth year.
lead_paragraph: Both those fighting for and against the Syrian government are terrorizing the country’s civilian population in defiance of a recent Security Council resolution, a panel of investigators told the United Nations Human Rights Council on Tuesday.

headline: Subway Alarm
abstract: A New Yorker questions whether the alarms on emergency exit doors in the New York subway system are necessary safety measures — or harmful annoyances.
lead_paragraph: A New Yorker questions whether the alarms on emergency exit doors in the New York subway system are necessary safety measures — or harmful annoyances.

headline: ‘Subway Alarm’
abstract: A New Yorker argues that the alarms on emergency exit doors in the New York subway system are harmful annoyances.
lead_paragraph: For a very long time, the blaring alarms at the exits of the New York subway system have driven me crazy. On my daily commute, I ride in the last train car, and at my stop I wait about a minute before heading to the turnstiles. By the time I arrive, the crowd has hopefully gone and the alarm is hopefully silent. But if that approach fails and an alarm is blaring, I’ll stubbornly exit through the revolving doors instead of joining the rest of the crowd in an easy passage through the open “emergency” door. Call me irrational if you want. But I really hate those alarms.

headline: Egyptian Police Officer Gets 10 Years for Detainees’ Deaths
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Detainees', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: A Cairo court sentenced Lt. Col. Amr Farouk in the deaths of 37 people who were arrested for protesting against the military takeover.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A criminal court in Cairo on Tuesday sentenced a police officer to 10 years in jail for manslaughter in the deaths of 37 detainees last August after their arrest for protesting against the military takeover. An official investigation concluded that the detainees had died of asphyxiation in a badly overcrowded police van after officers fired tear gas inside it. A total of 45 detainees had been packed into a van with a capacity for 24, Egyptian state news media reported Tuesday, and investigators discredited initial statements by the police that they were killed while trying to escape.

headline: The Graves of Forgotten New Yorkers
abstract: The public should be able to visit the Hart Island cemetery.
lead_paragraph: ON New York City maps, Hart Island drifts off the edge of the Bronx like an amputated leg. Among overgrown vegetation and ramshackle buildings spread out over 101 acres, about a million bodies are buried — the homeless, the poor, the stillborn, the unidentified and the unclaimed. The island is said to be home to the largest active potter’s field in America. Until recently, it was off limits to all but the most persistent.

headline: Big Banks Fulfill Part of Mortgage Deal
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures']
abstract: The nation’s four largest banks have more than fulfilled their financial obligations toward homeowners under a $25 billion settlement reached in 2012, according to a report.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s four largest banks — Bank of America, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo — have more than fulfilled their financial obligations toward homeowners under a $25 billion nationwide mortgage settlement reached in 2012, the settlement monitor said on Tuesday in a final report.

headline: A Blunder From Beginning to End
abstract: How the Union lost the ill-fated Red River Campaign.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Ulysses S. Grant took control of the Union Army in March 1864, he went on the offensive. Offensives, in fact: With his forces already pressing down into Virginia and Tennessee, he planned to open a new front by attacking Mobile, Ala.

headline: Green, Bayern Munich Striker, to Play for the U.S.
abstract: Julian Green, an 18-year-old striker for Bayern Munich, has decided to tie his international future to the United States national team.
lead_paragraph: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann received a gift on Tuesday only months before the start of the World Cup in Brazil when striker Julian Green, 18, chose to represent the United States men’s national team instead of Germany.

headline: Bad Back Forces Woods From Palmer Event
abstract: Citing back spasms and pain, Tiger Woods withdrew Tuesday from the Arnold Palmer Invitational, his last scheduled tuneup before the Masters.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Tiger Woods’s balky back forced him to withdraw Tuesday from the Arnold Palmer Invitational, imperiling his bid for a fifth green jacket at the Masters in less than a month. On his website Woods said, “Unfortunately, my back spasms and the pain haven’t subsided.”

headline: From Putin, a Blessing in Disguise
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Natural Gas', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Solar Energy', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: If this is Cold War II, let’s make this race an Earth Race.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of people who seem intent on restarting the Cold War — in both Moscow and Washington. I am not one of them. But if we’re going to have a new Cold War, then I have one condition: I want a new moonshot.

headline: A Divide Among Palestinians on a Two-State Solution
abstract: A son of President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority is among those younger people expressing support for the creation of a single state.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — When President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority visited the White House this week, he again heard dire warnings that the current moment could be the last chance for a two-state solution through negotiations with Israel.

headline: Russian Aggression Puts NATO in Spotlight
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Cold War Era', 'International Relations']
abstract: Russia’s moves in Ukraine have revived the North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s role as a counterweight to Moscow, even as it wrestles with its response.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Russia’s annexation of Crimea has suddenly revived the North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s central role as a counterweight to Moscow, and with it questions about the alliance’s options and ability to act.

headline: New Social App Has Juicy Posts, All Anonymous
abstract: Posts on Secret, an app that allows users to upload anonymous messages, can range from benign to inappropriate and are testing the tech industry’s appetite for sharing.
lead_paragraph: From Facebook to Twitter to Instagram and Google, many big Internet successes depend on coaxing people into sharing every last bit of information about themselves and their lives.

headline: When Minimum Wage Rises, Many Are Left Looking Up at It
abstract: Many restaurants treat their workers fairly, but it is not hard for unscrupulous businesses to find people desperate enough to do work for less than what the law requires.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Edgar Juarez, 36, awoke in the two-bedroom apartment that he shares with five other men on 136th Street in Manhattan. His shift in a restaurant on the Upper West Side would begin at 4 p.m., and he would stay until nearly 1 a.m. The job is dishwasher.

headline: Student Deaths Spark Debate Over Hazing at Portugal’s Universities
abstract: Some credit the ritual with building esprit de corps among students, while others say it has grown increasingly dangerous.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — By almost any measure, Portugal’s universities have had a turbulent time. After the end of the country’s dictatorship in the 1970s, public education found itself overwhelmed by soaring numbers of young people seeking degrees. The unmet demand opened a market for private universities, generally regarded as being of lesser quality.

headline: Leucadia Raises Stake in Harbinger
abstract: The share sale is the latest in a series of moves by the embattled hedge fund billionaire Philip A. Falcone to focus on the Harbinger Group after reaching an $18 million settlement with the S.E.C.
lead_paragraph: More than half a year after a landmark settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the embattled hedge fund billionaire Philip A. Falcone, who also heads the publicly traded Harbinger Group, has struck a deal with the Leucadia National Corporation.

headline: Costly Loans Are Drawing Attention From States
abstract: States are increasing efforts to shield vulnerable Americans from short-term loans with interest rates that can exceed 300 percent.
lead_paragraph: Loralty Harden, a 62-year-old retiree, was distressed when the balance on a short-term loan she had obtained to supplement her Social Security income did not budge even though she diligently followed the payment plan that came with it.

headline: Medals of Honor Go to 24 Army Veterans Who Had Been Denied
keywords: ['Medal of Honor (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: They received the recognition after a review determined that some service members had been passed over for the Medal of Honor because of their race, religion or ethnicity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mitch Libman was surprised when his childhood friend, Pfc. Leonard Kravitz, was not selected for the Medal of Honor — the military’s top honor — after his service in the Korean War. Mr. Libman, back in Denver, had received regular updates from Private Kravitz about the fighting. But then Private Kravitz died a hero, with his actions saving his entire platoon in Yangpyong on March 6-7, 1951.

headline: Los Angeles Museum’s Board Elects New and Returning Artist-Trustees
abstract: Reflecting art community support for MOCA’s new director, Philippe Vergne, John Baldessari, Barbara Kruger and Catherine Opie have returned to the museum’s board of trustees.
lead_paragraph: Three of the artists who left the board of the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles in 2012 to protest the leadership of Jeffrey Deitch, then the museum’s director, have been re-elected to their positions at the artist-centered museum.The artists Catherine Opie, John Baldessari and Barbara Kruger left the board, along with a fourth artist-member, Ed Ruscha, complaining that Mr. Deitch was steering the museum’s program too much in the direction of pop culture. Mr. Deitch, who had previously been a New York gallery owner, stepped down from the museum post last year, three years into a five-year contract, and the museum recently chose Philippe Vergne, a longtime curator and the director of the Dia Art Foundation in New York, to replace him.While Mr. Ruscha is not returning, the painter Mark Grotjahn has been elected to take a fourth artist seat on the board, the museum said.The museum, which has one of the most important collections of postwar art in the country but has struggled financially for years and considered merging with other institutions, announced recently that it had secured a combination of commitments and donations to raise its endowment to $100 million, by far the highest in the museum’s history.“I’m very excited about the prospects for MOCA with Philippe leading us and I want to be supportive,” Mr. Baldessari said in a statement.

headline: Republicans Versus an Informed Public
keywords: ['Census', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Answering the American Community Survey is the civic duty of everyone, yet some House Republicans seem to think it should be voluntary. That would make the survey’s data useless.
lead_paragraph: At regular intervals, congressional Republicans take aim at government surveys, vowing to end or curtail them for being too intrusive. The latest target is the Census Bureau’s American Community Survey.

headline: If Not a Cold War, a Return to a Chilly Rivalry
abstract: Tensions over Crimea may not bring a new Cold War, but analysts worry about a long period of confrontation and alienation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A month ago, most Americans could not have found Crimea on a map. But its lightning-quick takeover by Moscow has abruptly redrawn the geopolitical atlas and may have decisively ended a 25-year period of often tumultuous yet also constructive relations between the United States and Russia.

headline: Shortchanging New York City’s Commuters
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s budget proposal would skim $40 million dedicated to providing much-needed dollars to mass transit.
lead_paragraph: Many subway riders in the New York City area sense a certain decay settling in as the system continues to suffer from age, budget limitations and problems related to Hurricane Sandy. The Straphangers Campaign — activists who have been assessing mass transit for 35 years — confirm that unease. The group estimates that the subways have shown a “significant decline” in cleanliness; fares have gone up steadily; crowding is getting worse.

headline: Recalling Success for the Knicks, After Years of Losing
abstract: On Tuesday, even after being burned by James L. Dolan and his team again and again, Knicks fans all across the city quite possibly burst into applause.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson made the task of turning around a moribund franchise sound so easy.

headline: Updating Internet Governance
abstract: Any change to managing web addresses and domain names must strengthen a system used by billions.
lead_paragraph: The technical business of managing Internet addresses and domain names has often taken on geopolitical overtones. About a year ago, some countries including Russia and China tried to pressure the United States into relinquishing management and coordination of web addresses to the telecommunications arm of the United Nations.

headline: Obama Awards Medals of Honor to Veterans
abstract: The president awarded 24 Medals of Honor, 21 of them posthumously, to Army veterans at a White House ceremony.
lead_paragraph: The president awarded 24 Medals of Honor, 21 of them posthumously, to Army veterans at a White House ceremony.

headline: Leaked File Details U.S. Phone Monitoring Abroad
keywords: ['Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The National Security Agency is recording all phone calls and their routing data in one foreign country and retaining that data for a month so that it can be analyzed, according to a report based on a document leaked by Edward J. Snowden.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency is recording all telephone calls and their routing data in one foreign country and retaining that information for a month so that it can be analyzed later, according to a report based on a top secret intelligence document.

headline: Families From Diverse Lands Mourn Victims of East Harlem Explosion
abstract: The bodies of three victims of last week’s gas explosion in East Harlem will return to Mexico; another will be flown to Greece; another victim was Japanese.
lead_paragraph: They lived just steps from one another in two buildings in East Harlem. They were a mother and a daughter, neighbors and friends, whose day-to-day routines intersected for weeks, or even years, in a corner of the city that for some of them was far from their homeland.

headline: Guatemala: Ex-President Admits Taking Taiwan Bribes
abstract: Former President Alfonso Portillo pleaded guilty Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to a charge that he accepted bribes in exchange for diplomatic recognition of Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Former President Alfonso Portillo pleaded guilty Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to a charge that he accepted bribes in exchange for diplomatic recognition of Taiwan. In a plea bargain with federal prosecutors, Mr. Portillo, 62, who served from 2000 to 2004, was extradited to the United States almost a year ago on corruption charges, pleading guilty to conspiracy. He read a statement admitting to taking $2.5 million in bribes, with the proceeds funneled through American banks. Sentencing is scheduled for June 23.

headline: Post-Crimea Relations With the West
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Editorials', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama is right to warn Vladimir Putin that further provocations by Russia could isolate and diminish its influence.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s annexation of Crimea on Tuesday was accompanied by a grand piece of theater in the gilded St. George’s Hall of the Kremlin and disdain for the West and its sanctions and threats. The United States and the European Union are likely to impose added sanctions beyond the measures ordered against a few senior Kremlin officials, but there is virtually no chance that Mr. Putin could be coerced into reversing what the overwhelming majority of Russians and Crimeans seemed to regard as the righting of a historical anomaly. It may also prove to be a watershed in post-Soviet East-West relations, with a lot less for the Russians to celebrate.

headline: When a Hospital Stay Is Not a Stay
abstract: Some hospital stays are not admissions but are done to put the patient under observation, which affects Medicare reimbursement and coverage.
lead_paragraph: If you go to the emergency room and end up staying in the hospital, you may assume that you have been officially admitted. But it turns out that even though you are receiving treatment in a hospital bed, you may simply be under observation, and technically are still an outpatient. That can cost you money if you are covered under Medicare, the federal health plan for older Americans.

headline: Los Angeles Mayor on Airport Report
abstract: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles commented on a report released about the emergency response to last year’s shooting at Los Angeles International Airport.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles commented on a report released about the emergency response to last year’s shooting at Los Angeles International Airport.

headline: Report on Los Angeles Airport Shooting Cites Poor Communication
abstract: A report notes chaos and heroism after the November episode that left a security officer dead and other people injured.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When a gunman opened fire at the Los Angeles International Airport in November, poor communication and coordination among emergency officials led to a chaotic response that left victims waiting for responders and passengers stranded without information, according to a report released Tuesday reviewing the emergency response to the episode.

headline: New Alliances in Battle for Corporate Control
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The abrupt rise and increasing success of activist investors are forcing big money managers to reassess their traditionally passive role as shareholders.
lead_paragraph: For ages, institutional investors like mutual funds and pension funds were content to take stakes in public companies, trust their managements and bet on long-term gains. Companies trusted that these investors would be passive shareholders and not rock the boat.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 18, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 18, 2014

headline: Another Tale of Two Cities
abstract: Democratic mayors on each coast provide a stark contrast in style.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The tremors may have had morning TV anchors diving under the desk, but it takes more than a 4.4 quiver to rattle Eric Garcetti.

headline: In Defense of Anonymous Political Giving
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Corporations']
abstract: The Koch brothers’ historical case for secret donations.
lead_paragraph: The explosion in secret financing of political advertising has turned tax-exempt nonprofit organizations into the weapon of choice for those who want to influence elections without leaving fingerprints.

headline: Full-Court Press Wooed Jackson to Knicks
abstract: Over three months of California cocktail parties and desert excursions, James L. Dolan, the Knicks’ owner, persuaded Phil Jackson to take the reins of a troubled team.
lead_paragraph: James L. Dolan, the owner of the New York Knicks, was riding an all-terrain vehicle near Palm Springs, Calif. It was March 2, and the Knicks were in Chicago for another blowout loss in a season full of them — on national television, no less.

headline: Ukraine's Effect on a Deal for Syria

headline: Warby Parker’s New Uptown Outpost
abstract: This Saturday, the socially conscious eyeglass retailer opens a massive two-story store on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: This Saturday, the socially conscious eyeglass retailer Warby Parker will open the doors to its third New York retail space in what was, for more than a century, the iconic Lascoff Drugs on the Upper East Side. Though the massive two-story store on Lexington Avenue boasts 21-foot cathedral ceilings, the abundant books and stylish frames lining the walls will feel familiar to anyone who has received an eye exam at the company’s bustling SoHo location on Greene Street or shopped for frames at its cozy Washington Street store in the Meatpacking District. Art by Maira Kalman hung alongside the gothic windows that line the perimeter adds a lightness to the space. There are even pneumatic tubes to send glasses through the store, at a speed of 24 feet per second. Shoppers can browse all of the brand’s styles — including the new Spectrum Sun collection of glasses, which made its debut yesterday — and pick up new prescriptions in one of the two exam rooms. Here, a brief look at the do-good company’s new location and its growing product line.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:30 P.M. (IFC) BOILER ROOM (2000) Before Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio adapted the life of Jordan Belfort for the screen in “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Mr. Belfort inspired this fictional tale about a group of young, ruthless stockbrokers who work miles from the trading floor and use nothing but cold calls to relieve unsuspecting clients of their life savings. Giovanni Ribisi (above right, with Ben Affleck) plays Seth, a college dropout who joins the small firm of J. T. Marlin, rising quickly through its ranks, thanks to the no-nonsense tutelage of his possibly corrupt bosses and colleagues (portrayed by Mr. Affleck, Vin Diesel and Nicky Katt, among others). Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film, written and directed by Ben Younger, “reflects the sensibility of the generation it holds up to critical scrutiny, and it’s a cunningly ambiguous act of self-portraiture.” He added that Mr. Younger “presents a world ruled by a gang of lawless, soulless children, like the island of lost boys in ‘Peter Pan.’ But his film also shows us a group of actors, and a filmmaker, with soul to spare and talent to burn.”

headline: What Pakistan Knew About Bin Laden
abstract: Our supposed ally had a special desk devoted to managing Osama bin Laden. How can the U.S. fight extremism when we’re unable to confront it where it really lives?
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks, I went to live and report for The New York Times in Afghanistan. I would spend most of the next 12 years there, following the overthrow of the Taliban, feeling the excitement of the freedom and prosperity that was promised in its wake and then watching the gradual dissolution of that hope. A new Constitution and two rounds of elections did not improve the lives of ordinary Afghans; the Taliban regrouped and found increasing numbers of supporters for their guerrilla actions; by 2006, as they mounted an ambitious offensive to retake southern Afghanistan and unleashed more than a hundred suicide bombers, it was clear that a deadly and determined opponent was growing in strength, not losing it. As I toured the bomb sites and battlegrounds of the Taliban resurgence, Afghans kept telling me the same thing: The organizers of the insurgency were in Pakistan, specifically in the western district of Quetta. Police investigators were finding that many of the bombers, too, were coming from Pakistan.

lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve isn’t going to tell us when it expects to start raising interest rates. It isn’t going to draw a line in the sands of economic data – a minimum unemployment rate, a minimum rate of inflation. It’s done with all of that.

headline: Daily Report: Anonymous Social App Offers a Hotbed of Silicon Valley Gossip
abstract: Posts on Secret, an app that allows users to upload anonymous messages, can range from benign to inappropriate, and they are testing the tech industry’s appetite for sharing.
lead_paragraph: From Facebook to Twitter to Instagram to Google, many big Internet successes depend on coaxing people into sharing every last bit of information about themselves and their lives. But a five-week old social app, Secret, is testing the limits of just how much sharing Silicon Valley thinks is a good thing, because the sharing is done anonymously, Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: On Hiring and Autism
abstract: David Geslak, whose company works with children who have autism, is hesitant to tell parents or children that they have to use “the label.”
lead_paragraph: In a previous post, I wrote about mentoring David Geslak, who owns Exercise Connection, a company in Chicago that works with children who have autism. Dave has discovered that the structure and routine that his students learn from exercise build confidence, which can be a gateway to getting a job. He called me about the job search for one of his students — he calls them “champions” — whose name is Anthony.

headline: Document | The Long Way Round
abstract: A voracious wanderer — and owner of nine passports — shares a few of the pages from his never-ending pilgrimage.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to souvenirs, passport stamps can be as effective as photographs. Such is the case, at least, for Charles Veley, 48, who took an extended break from the tech world in 2000 to become king of the niche pastime known as “competitive travel.” Heligoland? The Johnston Atoll? The island of Diego Garcia? Veley, one of the world’s most extreme travelers, has been to these places, as well as 826 other “countries, territories, autonomous regions, enclaves, geographically separated island groups and major states and provinces.” Here, the voracious wanderer — and owner of nine passports — shares a few of the pages from his never-ending pilgrimage.

headline: Your Questions, My Answers (III)
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Global Warming', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Philosophy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Taxation']
abstract: A columnist faces his readers, yet again.
lead_paragraph: I’m going to do a final round here, since answering reader questions turns out to be easier than figuring out where Malaysia Flight 370 ended up or how to evict Vladimir Putin from the Crimea. As before, these been edited slightly for length, and the full versions are available from the link on each questioners name. And as before, my thanks to everyone who offered questions, and my apologies for only answering a selection of the many that were posed.

Zuma “benefited unduly,” in a manner “inconsistent with his office,” from state-funded improvements worth around $23 million to his rural estate that were supposed to enhance presidential security.

headline: Odd Birds
abstract: Willy Puchner’s “ABC of Fabulous Princesses” imagines princesses as exotic birds, and Kate Samworth’s “Aviary Wonders Inc.” takes the form of a manual for building your own birds.
lead_paragraph: What could be more retrograde than a story about a prince choosing his bride among a batch of eager princesses? In “The ABC of Fabulous Princesses” the Austrian artist Willy Puchner upends expectations in a surprising and delightful way. Even the appearance of the princesses — there are 26 — is probably not what readers will anticipate, for each is an exotic bird, painted by Puchner as a full-page, full-length portrait and wearing a regal gown. And — feminists rejoice! — there are no Disneyish wasp-waists here; these dresses are almost dumpily triangular, to accommodate the bird-shaped bodies. In the tradition of royal portraiture, Puchner paints the princesses accompanied by objects and animals that illustrate their attributes: a peculiar array of walking sticks, Venetian masks, snowy owls and casserole dishes.

headline: Parodist of Goldman Finds a New Publisher
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Grove Atlantic, an independent publisher, has agreed to pay a six-figure advance for “Straight to Hell: True Tales of Deviance and Excess in the World of Investment Banking” by John LeFevre.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, John LeFevre, the author of the Twitter account @GSElevator that parodied Wall Street bankers, was dumped by Simon & Schuster, the publisher that had promised him a six-figure book deal.

headline: Pet Food Good Enough to Eat — Literally
abstract: Lucy Postins sells ‘human-grade’ pet food, meaning you could grab a spoon and eat it with your pooch.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Postins sells ‘human-grade’ pet food, meaning you could grab a spoon and eat it with your pooch.

headline: What Is Mercuria?
abstract: The privately held trading house Mercuria Energy Group, founded by two former oil traders, was already one of the four leading independent commodity traders in the world. And that was before its $3.5 billion purchase of JPMorgan Chase’s physical commodities arm on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Two men set on creating one of the world’s leading commodities trading houses got a little closer to their goal on Wednesday.

headline: A Dual Review of What’s New, Starring Danny McBride and Judy Blume
abstract: Judy Blume and Danny McBride get hopped up on hefeweizen while contemplating pillowcases and backpacks.
lead_paragraph: Danny McBride, actor and foulmouthed comedian who will appear in Cameron Crowe’s next film, and is now writing a new HBO series with the co-creators of his hit show, “Eastbound & Down,” takes on Judy Blume, beloved American writer and tween-whisperer who has sold more than 82 million books. Her 29th, which she is currently working on, involves love and loss in 1950s New Jersey.

headline: Start-Ups Try for a Piece of the Lucrative Industry of Catering to Pets
abstract: A number of trends, including widespread pet ownership and the rising incomes of owners, are combining to spur a growing pet product industry.
lead_paragraph: Alex Stone and his wife, Marissa McDaniel, both work full time. They have two dogs that they miss during the day, and often have trouble getting home to feed them. “Pets are like children and need to be on a schedule,” Mr. Stone said.

headline: Flies That Do Calculus With Their Wings
abstract: Scientists glued tiny magnets to fruit flies to learn about the millisecond aerial ballets required to stay aloft when you’re a tiny insect.
lead_paragraph: There are lots of reasons scientists love fruit flies, but a big one is their flying ability. These almost microscopic creatures, with minimalist nervous systems and prey to every puff of wind, must often execute millisecond aerial ballets to stay aloft.

headline: ScienceTake: How to Fly Right
abstract: The amazing fruit fly’s millisecond maneuvers.
lead_paragraph: The amazing fruit fly’s millisecond maneuvers.

headline: Shouldn’t Your Dog Be Gluten-Free, Too?
abstract: To label its pet food “human grade,” the Honest Kitchen had to demonstrate that it used only ingredients that could go into food eaten by humans.
lead_paragraph: Midwestern beef mixed with papaya and dandelion greens. Line-caught whitefish with sweet potatoes and parsley. These are the meals that Taro and Willow, two Rhodesian Ridgebacks owned by Lucy Postins of San Diego, wolf down on a regular basis.

headline: College Admissions Season: When the Answer Is No
abstract: Some people say that students should entirely drive the college application process. But what parent would let a 17-year-old make such a big decision without help, and what parent wouldn’t share the disappointment when the dream college doesn’t come true?
lead_paragraph: The envelope came on a Friday in March — the last day of the last week of a college acceptance season that had been dragging on since early admissions began in October.

headline: Former Goldman Chief Walks Among Warriors and Dragons
abstract: Stephen Friedman, the onetime head of Goldman Sachs, appears in humble garb during a cameo appearance in the upcoming season of the HBO series “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, Stephen Friedman navigated challenging markets as the head of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Distraught Relatives of Missing Flight 370 Passengers Dragged Away From TV Cameras by Malaysian Officials
abstract: Distraught family members of passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 were forcibly dragged away from reporters after they unfurled a banner accusing the Malaysian government of “concealing the truth” and spoke of their grief.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Chris Buckley reported, distraught family members of passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 were forcibly dragged away from reporters on Wednesday after they unfurled a banner accusing the Malaysian government of “concealing the truth” and spoke of their grief.

headline: Obama’s Bracket: Michigan State vs. Louisville in Final
abstract: President Obama predicted that Michigan State would face Louisville in the final, as part of an ESPN segment called Barack-etology.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama and Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo met in February, the president impressed the coach with his knowledge of the team, its injury woes and style of play. Turns out, he might have just been scouting for his bracket.

headline: Classical Playlist: George Antheil, Haydn, Sibelius and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.

headline: Teaching Children to Calm Themselves
abstract: Experiencing neglect, severe stress or sudden separation at a young age can be traumatizing, and inhibit a child’s ability to make good decisions and work through problems.
lead_paragraph: When Luke gets angry, he tries to remember to look at his bracelet. It reminds him of what he can do to calm himself: stop, take a deep breath, count to four, give yourself a hug and, if necessary, ask an adult for help.

headline: Questions Over Goldman Deal as Investors Sit in the Dark
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: In a fight over a hotel company that went “dark,” investors have accused Goldman Sachs of having conflicting interests, writes Jesse Eisinger in The Trade column.
lead_paragraph: The “revolt of the Muppets” is heating up.

headline: ‘Swiss Ingenuity’ Will Be Focus of Festival in New York
abstract: “Zurich Meets New York: A Festival of Swiss Ingenuity” will take place in May at various sites in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Historians have conflicting opinions about precisely when and where Dadaism got its start – and that is as it should be, given the spirit of the movement, which prized nonconformity. Still, the consulate general of Switzerland in New York is taking the view that it all began in Zurich in 1916, when poets, artists, musicians and novelists fleeing the First World War gathered at the Cabaret Voltaire and debated Dadaism into existence.

headline: Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin to Star in a Netflix Comedy Series
abstract: “Grace and Frankie,” coming to Netflix next year, will feature Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin as rivals who find their husbands are in love with each other.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need a calendar to remind you that it’s been a minute or two since Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin were last working nine to five together. But these two actresses are about to get back on the clock for a new Netflix comedy series that was announced by that streaming video service Wednesday.

headline: Ivan Lendl Will No Longer Coach Andy Murray
abstract: In two years with Ivan Lendl as his coach, Andy Murray turned from a four-time Grand Slam runner-up into a two-time major champion.
lead_paragraph: Andy Murray and Ivan Lendl, the partnership that began the “former champ tutoring the current superstar” trend in tennis, ended rather abruptly Wednesday, with Murray announcing on his website that Lendl would no longer be coaching him.

headline: Being Smart About Phone Fees Overseas
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Wireless Communications', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: What solution is best for keeping data charges in check while traveling abroad? Here’s a guide.
lead_paragraph: YOU WANT TO USE your smartphone while traveling abroad. But choosing an affordable method can seem mind-numbingly complicated. Should you buy an international roaming plan? And if you do, what does 100 megabytes of data get you anyway? Perhaps you need a hot spot pass? Or a SIM card? If you don’t want an eye-popping phone bill, it’s essential to decide before you’re on the plane.

headline: In Rome, an Enclave of Cool
abstract: The Pigneto area feels far removed from the eternal city’s tourist herds and ancient ruins.
lead_paragraph: Pigneto feels a world away from Rome’s tourist herds and ancient ruins, with a soundtrack of electronic pop music that spills out over sienna-hued courtyards, and nary a souvenir shop in sight. By day, locals shop for produce and sip cappuccinos on tree-filled terraces. At night, crowds of tattooed and stylishly top-knotted 20- and 30-somethings flock to open-air bars and upscale restaurants. Street art, like a metal store gate emblazoned with a Beyoncé-esque superhero and a spaceship, seems like a religion. Hotel chains have yet to venture here. A 10-minute bus ride from the arterial Termini station, Pigneto, Rome’s answer to Bushwick, Brooklyn, is an enclave of cool in the eternal city.

headline: On the Final Day of Winter, a Morning of Mayhem
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Subways', 'Winter (Season)']
abstract: In what was perhaps a fitting end to a miserable winter, New Yorkers on Wednesday were greeted with news of car crashes, a four-alarm fire and traffic jams.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow: Spring.

headline: Can You Trust ‘Secure’ Messaging Apps?
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Instant Messaging', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Text Messaging']
abstract: Messaging apps and security are two of the hottest topics in tech. But can you trust the wave of supposedly secure messaging services coming out now? The New York Times’s Molly Wood talks to an expert.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially a post-Snowden and post-WhatsApp world, and my inbox is filled with pitches from companies promoting their secure messaging apps. But can you trust them?

headline: House Hunting in ... the Italian Piedmont
abstract: Many prospective buyers cross-shop in Tuscany, Umbria and Liguria, as well as the South of France. But prices in the Italian Piedmont are much lower.
lead_paragraph: A VILLA IN THE MONFERRATO REGION

headline: Alligators Turn a Couple’s Dream Into a Court Fight
abstract: A couple in Mississippi sued Exxon after discovering that the land they had planned to build their dream house on had been claimed already by dozens of alligators.
lead_paragraph: CENTREVILLE, Miss. — Finding an alligator in your back yard can ruin your day.

headline: I.M.F. Chief Testifies Again About Role in Payout
abstract: Christine Lagarde is appearing before a court to explain her role in a proceeding that led to a payment of over 400 million euros.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Christine Lagarde, the International Monetary Fund chief, was appearing before a French court in a closed session on Wednesday to explain her role in a murky affair involving a government payout to a prominent businessman while she was finance minister of France.

headline: Judge Rebukes Justice Dept. for Requesting Overly Broad Email Searches
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'E-Mail', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy']
abstract: A case highlights the broad authority the government believes it has in searching email accounts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge has admonished the Justice Department for repeatedly requesting overly broad searches of people’s email accounts, a practice that he called “repugnant” to the Constitution.

headline: She Called Her What? Uh-Oh.
abstract: The famous late-20th-century feud between Mary McCarthy and Lillian Hellman will be stirred up again with “Hellman v. McCarthy,” a new play by Brian Richard Mori.
lead_paragraph: The annals of literature contain many a memorable put-down, but few can match the slaying simplicity of the words Mary McCarthy once used in discussing, or rather dismissing, Lillian Hellman. All together now: “Every word she writes is a lie, including ‘and’ and ‘the.’ ” Although she had used the phrase before in an interview, this withering bit of pith became the dis heard round the world only in 1980, when McCarthy trotted it out during an appearance on “The Dick Cavett Show.” A lawsuit from Hellman followed, and soon the literary world was in a fine old uproar.

headline: Wheelies: The Hertz for the People Edition
abstract: Hertz trims its fleet of rental cars and will sell them to customers; Nissan deletes tweet poking fun at Tesla after New Jersey bans direct sales.
lead_paragraph: ■ After its fleet grew 22 percent – to 472,200 vehicles – last year, Hertz Global Holdings decided to reduce the number of cars it owned. Mark Frissora, chief executive of the company, said Hertz would sell many of those vehicles to consumers as the cars were retired from service. Mr. Frissora said the company would make about $1,400 a vehicle in retail sales. (Automotive News, subscription required)

headline: With Russia, as With China, Unnerved U.S. Allies Seek Reassurances
abstract: With tensions still simmering over Chinese claims in the South China Sea, the United States finds itself trying to calm Baltic nations wary of Russia’s moves in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: VILNIUS, Lithuania — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. found himself in a fraught but familiar place this week: holding the hands of American allies fearful of being bullied by a larger, aggressive neighbor.

headline: Porsche to Replace 911 GT3 Engines Over Fire Hazard
abstract: The action comes after a connecting rod fastener caused engine failure, significant oil leaks and fire in two European cars.
lead_paragraph: Citing a concern over fires, Porsche is replacing the 475-horsepower 3.8-liter 6-cylinder engines in all 785 of its 2014 911 GT3 models worldwide, the automaker said in a news release late Tuesday. The replacement includes about 400 vehicles in the United States with about half unsold and still at dealerships, Nick Twork, a spokesman for Porsche, said in a telephone interview.

headline: Rand Paul, Warning About Spying, Faults Obama
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Senator Rand Paul, in a speech at Berkeley, injected the issue of race into the debate over domestic surveillance by saying President Obama should be wary given the government’s history of eavesdropping on civil rights leaders.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, said Wednesday that President Obama should be particularly wary of domestic spying, given the government’s history of eavesdropping on civil rights leaders like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., injecting the issue of race into the contentious debate over surveillance.

headline: Times Minute | Silicon Valley Gossip
abstract: Also on the Minute, ExxonMobil faces a lawsuit over alligators and the television critic Alessandra Stanley reviews the new HBO comedy, “Doll & Em.”
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, ExxonMobil faces a lawsuit over alligators and the television critic Alessandra Stanley reviews the new HBO comedy, “Doll & Em.”

headline: Times Minute | Silicon Valley Gossip
abstract: Also on the Minute, ExxonMobil faces a lawsuit over alligators and the television critic Alessandra Stanley reviews the new HBO comedy, “Doll & Em.”
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Obamas Press for Health Care Sign-Ups
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A selection of clips of President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, urging Americans to sign up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act before the March 31 deadline.
lead_paragraph: A selection of clips of President Obama and the first lady, Michelle Obama, urging Americans to sign up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act before the March 31 deadline.

headline: London’s Former Investment Bankers Are Joining the Start-Up Craze
abstract: In a Canary Wharf high-rise, a cluster of financial tech start-ups are leaning on the financial and tech know-how of the former employees of London’s banks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The marbled floors, luxury stores and corporate skyscrapers of London’s Canary Wharf financial district aren’t the typical surroundings for high-growing technology start-ups.

headline: Administration Plays to Young in Health Push
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Youth', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Obama administration is taking its mission to radio shows, churches and YouTube to urge people to buy health insurance ahead of the March 31 deadline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russian troops were rolling through Crimea when Denis R. McDonough, the White House chief of staff and a foreign policy expert, was deployed on a mission to do media outreach. But the focus of Mr. McDonough’s calls to local talk radio stations was not geopolitical tensions in Eastern Europe, it was health care.

headline: Traders of Tips Meet at Grand Central, and Eat the Evidence
abstract: The government’s case against two Wall Street insiders laid bare an elaborate if somewhat old-fashioned plan, where a middleman would relay tips, written on a Post-it note or napkin, at Grand Central Terminal’s four-faced clock.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:40 p.m. | Secret stock tips scribbled on Post-it notes and paper napkins. Illicit meetings held in broad daylight at Grand Central Terminal. Cover-up efforts that involved chewing, and even eating, damaging evidence.

headline: ‘The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes’
keywords: ['Holmes, Sherlock (Fictional Character)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A traveling exhibition is an ambitious and multifaceted presentation of the most famous detective in English literary fiction.
lead_paragraph: A traveling exhibition is an ambitious and multifaceted presentation of the most famous detective in English literary fiction.

headline: Image of the Day: March 19
abstract: Laborers waiting at a wholesale fruit market on the outskirts of Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: What You Get for ... $800,000
abstract: This week’s homes: A forest view in Colorado, a cottage in the Florida Everglades and a co-op in Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, COLO.

headline: At the Garden, Meet the New Boss (Not the Same as the Old Boss)
abstract: As the Knicks’ new president, Phil Jackson will run the team without interference, according to James L. Dolan, the chairman of Madison Square Garden, who said he would “willingly and gratefully” avoid intervening.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson, corporate savior, towered over his new boss, James L. Dolan, as Jackson, a former Knicks reserve, was introduced as the team’s new president Tuesday in the lobby of Madison Square Garden.

headline: They’re Real and Don’t Care What You Think
abstract: Dan Hoyle’s solo show “The Real Americans” channels America’s just plain folks with compassion and respect, even as it comments on our national inability to understand one another.
lead_paragraph: Fueled by a hefty dose of liberal guilt and propelled by an earnest desire to understand his fellow citizens a young white playwright-performer leaves the comfort of his native San Francisco on a cross-country road trip.

headline: Only Perfect
abstract: Seven Division I men’s basketball teams have finished a season undefeated and capped by an N.C.A.A. title, none since Indiana in 1976. Wichita State enters the tourney 34-0.
lead_paragraph: If Wichita State’s players have been a bit dismissive of their 34-0 record, it is not because they have not accomplished much. An undefeated regular season for a men’s college basketball team is nothing to sniff at. But the Shockers also know the record will fall into the dustbin of history if they do not follow up with an N.C.A.A. title, a midmajor team that could not shake the mid. But if the Shockers win the N.C.A.A. championship, they will join rarefied air occupied by the likes of Bill Russell, John Wooden, Lew Alcindor, Bill Walton, Frank McGuire and Indiana’s most Hoosier-like set of Hoosiers.

headline: Only Perfect
abstract: Seven Division I men’s basketball teams have finished undefeated seasons with an N.C.A.A. championship, starting with San Francisco in 1956 and ending with Indiana in 1976.
lead_paragraph: Seven Division I men’s basketball teams have finished undefeated seasons with an N.C.A.A. championship, starting with San Francisco in 1956 and ending with Indiana in 1976.

headline: A New Cruise on the Loire
abstract: Europe’s booming river cruise industry has set its sights on the Loire in France.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s booming river cruise industry has set its sights on the Loire in France, where the M.S. Loire Princesse, the first riverboat with overnight cabins to cruise this river, will launch next year.

headline: Data Deleted From Flight 370 Simulator
abstract: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said the investigating teams were trying to recover data deleted from a flight simulator built by the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.
lead_paragraph: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said the investigating teams were trying to recover data deleted from a flight simulator built by the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet.

headline: If These Walls Could Talk
abstract: The restoration of a storied French neo-Classical salon reveals as much about polite society as it does about high design.
lead_paragraph: The restoration of a storied French neo-Classical salon reveals as much about polite society as it does about high design.

headline: New York Courts Cut Time Between Arrest and Arraignment
abstract: Since a computer-tracking system spearheaded by a judge went into operation citywide last summer, the average time a defendant waits to see a judge has dropped sharply.
lead_paragraph: For two decades, court officials in New York City have struggled to solve a vexing problem: reducing the arrest-to-arraignment time in its criminal courts.

headline: Labyrinth Announces Readings of Pulitzer-Winning Plays
abstract: The event, called “Pulitzer Fest,” will run April 7 to 13.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Award winner Ellen Burstyn, the Obie winner Eric Bogosian, and other members of Labyrinth Theater Company will take part in a weeklong series of readings of Pulitzer Prize-winning plays in April, the company announced on Wednesday.

headline: Judge Sides with F.T.C. in Payday Lending Case
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Native Americans', 'Payday Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A federal judge has reinforced the Federal Trade Commission’s authority to go after payday lenders that claim their ties to Native American tribes make them immune to laws restricting high-cost loans.
lead_paragraph: A United States District Court judge has reinforced the Federal Trade Commission’s authority to go after payday lenders that claim their ties to Native American tribes make them immune to laws restricting high-cost loans.

headline: Hey, Hey, Hey! Animated Touchstones
abstract: “Funky Turns 40,” at the Schomburg Center for Black Culture, recalls black TV cartoon characters with positive images, from “The Jackson 5ive” to “Fat Albert and the Cosby Kids.”
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the 1970s at opposite ends of New York State, two girls were immersed in all things cool, black and funky.

headline: Two Officers Killed by Militants, Egypt Says
abstract: The killings of the two officers, who died conducting a raid on a rural building believed to be a bomb-making workshop, came amid an escalation of attacks on security forces.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Islamist militants killed an Egyptian brigadier general and a colonel in an early-morning gun battle in the Nile Delta province of Qalyubeya, the Interior Ministry said Wednesday.

headline: Live Blog: Yellen and the Fed
abstract: Live updates on the Federal Reserve’s first policy statement under Janet Yellen’s leadership, and her news conference afterward.
lead_paragraph: Janet Yellen met the media Wednesday for the first time as Federal Reserve chairwoman, after the conclusion of her first meeting leading the central bank’s policy committee. Here is an account of the events as they unfolded.

headline: French Court Upholds Prison Term for Rogue Société Générale Trader
abstract: Jérôme Kerviel said he was nonetheless delighted that France’s highest court had thrown out an order that he pay a record 4.9 billion euros to the bank.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Jérôme Kerviel, the former trader convicted of rogue dealings at Société Générale, was walking through the Italian countryside on Wednesday on his 900-mile trek to Paris when he received a text from his lawyer that a court had upheld his three-year prison sentence for fraud against the French bank.

headline: Discovering Two Screens Aren’t Better Than One
abstract: A once-confirmed two-monitor user decides to turn off one screen and learns how to battle the temptation of email and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: For years, techies have argued that getting an extra monitor or two for your desktop computer is an especially effective way to increase personal productivity. The logic seemed airtight: Two (or more) computer monitors means more room on your virtual desktop, which means more room to do your work. And more room to work would seem to mean faster work.

headline: Scene City: A Dragon Holds Court in Lincoln Center
abstract: Cast of HBO’s “Game of Thrones” premieres fourth season with a flaming museum party.
lead_paragraph: Cast of HBO’s “Game of Thrones” premieres fourth season with a flaming museum party.

headline: The Billion Dollar Bracket Challenge Is Really a Hundred Thousand Dollar Lottery
abstract: The mathematical odds of winning the Grand Prize are 1:9,223,372,036,854,775,808.
lead_paragraph: Technically it’s true that if you register online for the Quicken Loans Billion Dollar Bracket Challenge by March 20, and fill out a perfect N.C.A.A. men’s tournament bracket, you could win a billion dollars—courtesy of Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, which is insuring the prize. But even though it’s sort of free to enter (more on the “sort of” later) it’s not worth your time.

headline: Please Tell Me You Didn’t Cut That Part
abstract: Creators of film adaptations of popular fiction for tweens and teenagers say they while they fend off pressure from detail-obsessed fans, certain elements are vital to a script.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in the 2010 film “The Twilight Saga: Eclipse” in which Bella (Kristen Stewart), the movie’s teenage heroine, gets on the back of a motorcycle owned by Jacob, a werewolf. She does so unprompted, at least in part to get under the skin of her beau, Edward, who is a vampire. In the book, however, Jacob has to persuade Bella to get on his motorcycle, which she does. See the difference? If you’re a young or even not-so-young fan of the wildly popular “Twilight” series, you sure do.

headline: The Pleasures of Plain Rap
abstract: Two West Coast rappers with major-label debut albums, “My Krazy Life” by YG and “Remember Me” by Sage the Gemini, have more in common than the directness of their music.
lead_paragraph: The virtues of simplicity are many, and also too easily dismissed. In hip-hop especially, where complexity is too often equated with progress, the straightforward can get a bad rap. And yet it’s music like this, distilled down to first principles, that moves the genre, and gives it many of its signature moments.

headline: Q. and A. With Fiorentina’s Giuseppe Rossi
abstract: The American-born striker for Fiorentina was in New York recently to visit family and rehab from an injury.
lead_paragraph: Giuseppe Rossi grew up in Clifton, N.J., but never played soccer in high school or college in the United States (or for the United States national team). Instead, he joined the youth academy of Parma of Italy’s Serie A as a 12-year-old. His professional career has taken him to Manchester United (England); Newcastle (England) and Parma on loan; Villarreal (Spain); and back to Italy with his current club, Fiorentina. Before an ankle injury in January, Rossi was leading Serie A in goals. He was back in the United States recently to treat and rehabilitate his right knee and to visit family. He returned to Italy on Wednesday ahead of Fiorentina’s Europa League game against Juventus on Thursday, but not before an interview with The Times.

headline: Protein May Hold the Key to Who Gets Alzheimer’s
abstract: The protein, which switches off at birth, reawakens in some older brains, protecting people from the memory and thinking problems of dementia, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the big scientific mysteries of Alzheimer’s disease: Why do some people whose brains accumulate the plaques and tangles so strongly associated with Alzheimer’s not develop the disease?

headline: Mood Enhancers That Recharge
abstract: A young Indian finds fashion inspiration in a national hero in New Delhi’s artsy Hauz Khas Village neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Hauz Khas Village in New Delhi is a cultural hub filled with 13th-century monuments, bars with local bands playing U2 covers and trendy boutiques. Rahul Kumar was strolling through the neighborhood wearing a red vest inspired by Jawaharlal Nehru, the former prime minister, plus purple pants and lace-up boots. Mr. Kumar said he frequents the neighborhood, which he considers the most stylish in the city, to draw inspiration from locals who mix traditional and modern styles.

headline: Fed Cuts Bond Buying by Another $10 Billion
abstract: The Federal Reserve also signaled its intention to keep short-term interest rates near zero after the unemployment rate falls below 6.5 percent
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve further curtailed its economic stimulus campaign on Wednesday, even as it said the effort would continue for the foreseeable future given the enduring consequences of the Great Recession.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
abstract: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.
lead_paragraph: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.

headline: At Trial, Son-in-Law Recalls a Cave Meeting With Bin Laden on 9/11
abstract: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, Osama Bin Laden’s most senior adviser to be tried in a civilian court, said the former Qaeda leader summoned him on the night of the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: It was some hours after the World Trade Center towers had been toppled when Sulaiman Abu Ghaith was summoned to a meeting with Osama bin Laden. He recalled a three-hour-or-so drive into the night, finding the leader of Al Qaeda in a cave amid the mountains in Afghanistan.

headline: Sundance Institute to Look at the Little Picture
abstract: The Sundance Institute says it will start a workshop for writers and creators of programs for television and online platforms.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – As the creative heart of Hollywood beats ever closer to television, one of the film industry’s most important training grounds – the Sundance Institute’s workshops – is adding a small-screen spinoff.

headline: Two States Win Court Approval on Voter Rules
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Identification Devices', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The federal Election Assistance Commission had denied requests from Kansas and Arizona to add proof-of-citizenship instructions to registration forms.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A federal judge in Kansas on Wednesday ordered federal election authorities to help Kansas and Arizona require proof of citizenship of registering voters, in a decision that could well set a trend for other Republican-dominated states.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Back to No. 1; ‘Happy’ Is Top Single
abstract: The soundtrack album to Disney’s “Frozen” returned to the top spot for a sixth week, as Pharrell Williams’s “Happy” spent its fifth at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: The effect was not instantaneous, but the Oscars that Disney’s “Frozen” won for both best animated feature and best original song (“Let It Go”) seems to have helped push the soundtrack recording back to the top of the Billboard album chart for a sixth nonconsecutive week. (The Oscars were awarded on March 2. The new Billboard chart measures sales for the week ending on March 16.)

headline: The Gun Report: March 19, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: According to a new report by the Center for American Progress, gun violence is devastating millennials. Those born after 1980 are four times more likely to die by gunfire than their counterparts in Canada, seven times more likely than those in Israel, and 65 times more likely than those in the United Kingdom. This, despite the fact that violent crime has declined in recent years.

headline: Flappy Gameplay Beyond the Fourth Wall
abstract: Find out how Alistair Coote made the amazing, WebRTC-backed Flappy Arms.
lead_paragraph: The most obvious problem with Flappy Bird was that players couldn’t flap their arms along with the titular character. Fortunately, NYT developer Alistair Coote is here to help, with his amazing, WebRTC-backed Flappy Arms. Read about how he did it on his blog — and have a go. (Mobile phone not included.)

headline: News Release Distributor to Stop Selling to High-Speed Traders
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The move by Marketwired is another victory in the effort by the New York State attorney general to curb the advantages enjoyed by the fastest traders on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York State attorney general, can count another victory in his quest to curb some of the advantages enjoyed by the fastest traders on Wall Street.

headline: Letters: ‘Peyton Place’ Revisited
abstract: Readers react to recent essays about “Peyton Place,” reviews of Fred D’Aguiar’s “Children of Paradise” and Barry Miles’s “Call Me Burroughs,” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘Peyton Place’ Revisited

headline: A Pet-Friendly Place in Stamford, Conn.
abstract: Kathie Nurena and Mike Taylor sought a dog-friendly house in Stamford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: For Kathie Nurena and Mike Taylor, the decision to move was 100 percent canine-driven.

headline: Suitcase Full of Cash Gives a Youth Program New Life
abstract: Mike George, who won $144,000 on “Deal or No Deal,” put half into a youth team whose alumni include Syracuse’s Tyler Ennis among nine players in this year’s N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 students from Cardinal Newman Catholic School, in Brampton, Ontario, filed into the Canadian Broadcasting Centre to cheer on the popular eighth-grade teacher from Room 26. It was January 2007, and Mike George was about to be on television.

headline: Mining the Past and Sharing the Plenty
abstract: Cassandra Wilson and Black Sun took in many threads of black musical creativity at the BRIC House Ballroom in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Cassandra Wilson, a singer who is not known for indelicate music, put on a bright red electric guitar on Sunday night and played a loud, dissonant solo — gestural, atmospheric, raw, tentative and interestingly brave. It was during an original, riff-driven, North Mississippi kind of electric blues called Black Sun, and she was performing in a band called Black Sun.

headline: Baked to Death on Rikers Island
abstract: An inmate with psychiatric problems died in his cell, where the temperature reached at least 100 degrees.
lead_paragraph: The American corrections system is teeming with mentally ill people who have been arrested for misbehaviors related to their illnesses. Those who present little or no danger to the public — and there are many — belong in psychiatric care instead of jails, where they are at greater risk of suicide and other forms of harm, primarily because the corrections staff is ill-equipped to care for them.

headline: Alter Ego Rattles Author’s Ego
abstract: Preparing for a book tour for “Blood Will Out,” about his bizarre relationship with an infamous impostor, Walter Kirn interviews himself.
lead_paragraph: LIVINGSTON, Mont. — Standing over an open suitcase inside his office here, the journalist and novelist Walter Kirn is preparing for a six-week book tour, trying to squeeze his life inside a carry-on. “The trick is to wear the nicer, costlier items — the ones that need ironing if they get wrinkled — and pack the rest,” he says, rolling up a pair of cotton briefs into a tight, cigarlike cylinder. He sets the undergarment, which is zebra striped, into the case beside three other pairs that range from polka dot to paisley. “I like to wear strong patterns against my skin,” he says, pitching his voice low, as though to share a tip that I don’t recall soliciting. “It gives me a wonderful feeling of inner confidence.”

headline: The Berber Decorative Tradition, an Inspiration to Yves Saint Laurent
abstract: A new show at the Fondation Pierre Bergé – Yves Saint Laurent celebrates the art and objects of the North African tribe.
lead_paragraph: During the decades they spent holidaying in Morocco, Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé became captivated by the culture of the native Berber, or Amazigh, tribe, which has inhabited North Africa for 9,000 years. The extensive collection of Berber art and artifacts the couple acquired from the ’60s until Saint Laurent’s death in 2008 is now housed at the Musée Berbère at the duo’s Jardin Majorelle studio villa in Marrakesh. Beginning Friday, the pieces will appear for the first time in the West — alongside a trove of art and objects from private collectors and the Musée du Quai Branly — in the show “Berber Women of Morocco” at Paris’s Fondation Pierre Bergé – Yves Saint Laurent. More than 600 intricately detailed decorative objects, including headpieces, jewelry, carpets, textiles, furniture, pottery and one spectacular set of handcarved kohl eyeliner pots, will share space with drawings by the French artist Titouan Lamazou and archival photographs of Berber women sporting the tribe’s traditional dress. Those familiar with YSL’s oeuvre will no doubt spot the influence on the designer’s work. But what’s especially uncanny is how on-point the women’s look — layers, volume, insouciant accessorizing — feels today.

headline: Gleaned From eBay, the Artifacts of an Era
abstract: A new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society sheds light on the “Black Five” basketball franchises from the first half of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society sheds light on the “Black Five” basketball franchises from the first half of the 20th century.

headline: Every Dog Has Its Daybed
keywords: ['Cats', 'Dogs', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Pets']
abstract: The Global Pet Expo also offered hand-smocked dresses and anxiety-reducing shirts for dogs. Cats and fish didn’t make out too badly, either.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, FLA. — The takeaway from the Global Pet Expo, at which 985 exhibitors of pet products were spread out over 13 football fields’ worth of real estate in the Orange County Convention Center here, is that Americans really love their dogs. And yet, perhaps as a result of so much love, those dogs are increasingly anxious, bored, overweight, messy and have terrible breath. They suffer from separation anxiety and they worry about thunderstorms, traffic noises, visitors and vacuum cleaners. Their joints ache, and they eat too fast; they chew the furniture and bedevil the neighbors with their barking. Also, drool happens.

headline: In a Show of Early-Music Vigor, a Lofty Commitment Is Confirmed
abstract: The Juilliard School presentation of Bach’s “St. Matthew Passion” included the Choir of Trinity Wall Street and the conductor Gary Thor Wedow.
lead_paragraph: The tremendous improvement in early-music performance in New York over the last decade has tended to come in flashes and bursts. Unevenness has typically remained a part of the package.

headline: Gains Reported in Removing Syrian Chemical Supplies
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The organization helping oversee Syria’s purge said 10 shipments had been exported so far, including all of the country’s deadly sulfur mustard.
lead_paragraph: Nearly half of Syria’s chemical stockpile for weapons use has now been removed from the war-ravaged country, the organization helping to oversee the elimination of the deadly arsenal reported on Wednesday.

headline: Holder Discusses Toyota’s Settlement
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that Toyota had reached a $1.2 billion deal with the Justice Department to settle a four-year criminal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced that Toyota had reached a $1.2 billion deal with the Justice Department to settle a four-year criminal investigation.

headline: A reading of “Icebergs, Ilulissat” by Jean Valentine
abstract: The American poet reads her ode to Greenland.
lead_paragraph: The American poet reads her ode to Greenland.

headline: Russia Takes Crimean Naval Base
abstract: Ukrainian and Russian officials spoke in Sevastopol after militiamen, backed by Russian forces, seized the headquarters of the Ukrainian Navy and raised a Russian flag.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian and Russian officials spoke in Sevastopol after militiamen, backed by Russian forces, seized the headquarters of the Ukrainian Navy and raised a Russian flag.

headline: Does Texting at a Stop Sign Count?
abstract: Even teenagers who say they “don’t text and drive” pull out the phone at every red light, and many of their parents do too. Should you ever touch the phone keyboard while the car is in drive?
lead_paragraph: Most drivers, teenage and adult, have received the message loud and clear: Don’t text and drive.

headline: A Chance to Hear the Music That Louis XIV Used to Eat Breakfast To
abstract: The Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra offered a program of what its music director called “our favorites of the past 30 years” at Zankel Hall on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: When the Tafelmusik Baroque Orchestra, from Toronto, came to Zankel Hall in 2011, it offered as an encore a teaser drawn from the score of Marin Marais’s 1706 opera, “Alcyone”: a frisky Tambourins dance. On Monday evening in the same hall, that tease became an embrace, as the orchestra closed its concert with a full suite of sumptuous music from “Alcyone,” including a honeyed solo in the noble Sarabande from the violinist Jeanne Lamon, the group’s music director since 1981.

headline: Families of Missing Passengers Speak Out
abstract: Relatives of Chinese passengers onboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 demanded answers about the missing plane.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of Chinese passengers onboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 demanded answers about the missing plane.

headline: Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
abstract: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene.

headline: Icahn Calls on eBay to Sell 20% of PayPal Unit to the Public
abstract: The activist investor’s proposal, a retreat from his previous demand that the payment processor be spun out completely from its parent, still calls for a separation of the two businesses.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn hasn’t let up his attack on eBay. But he has modified what he is demanding from the online commerce giant.

headline: An Invisible Boy Keeps His Promise
abstract: The writer, actor and director Zach Braff describes his preparations for his Broadway debut, a musical adaptation of Woody Allen’s “Bullets Over Broadway.”
lead_paragraph: When I was 8 years old, I watched my trial-lawyer father play Horace Vandergelder in the Livingston, N.J., community-theater production of “Hello, Dolly!” He entered wearing an enormous marching-band bass drum (the character is in a parade), and he roared to his sobbing niece, “Dammit! How am I supposed to play ‘Yonkers My Yonkers’ with all that bellowing in my ears!” It was the most exciting thing I had ever seen.

headline: Works of Varied Eras Set Side by Side Onstage
abstract: For its 60th anniversary, the Paul Taylor Dance Company is presenting 23 works, mostly in groups of three, at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: The repertoire of the Paul Taylor Dance Company currently includes 140 works. During its 60th anniversary season, the troupe is presenting 23 of them, mostly three at a time. Each combination exhibits Mr. Taylor’s vaunted range of subject matter, tone and approach, but too many also show a range in quality, setting the unforgettable next to the best forgotten. The two new pieces that Mr. Taylor adds each year are understandably hit and miss, but the misses are recycled along with the hits, mixed in with the misfires and masterpieces. The choices can make for a jolting theatrical experience.

headline: Army General Apologizes to Victims of Misconduct Before Being Sentenced
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Apologies', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair apologized to the women he had wronged and to the Army before a military judge was to begin weighing his sentence.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — On the eve of a decision about his sentence on sexual misconduct and other charges, Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair on Wednesday tearfully apologized to the women he had wronged, and to the Army where he had spent 27 years, saying that he “felt a deep and abiding sense of shame and remorse.”

headline: Doctors Push Scrutiny for Smog Masks
abstract: As Asian cities deal with pollution, health professionals seek more research about devices’ effectiveness and better education for consumers.
