lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When smog descends on Beijing or other Asian cities, people rush to buy face masks.

headline: Biden and Lithuanian President on Russia
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Dalia Grybauskaite of Lithuania gave joint statements at the presidential palace in Vilnius to address Russia’s intervention in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and President Dalia Grybauskaite of Lithuania gave joint statements at the presidential palace in Vilnius to address Russia’s intervention in Crimea.

headline: Mobile Platforms
abstract: For curious investors: two models of how to run a trailer park.
lead_paragraph: Trailer parks are Frank Rolfe’s world. And when you hear about some of the economics lessons being taught at Mobile Home University, the three-day seminars he puts on, you can see why. He and a partner own a hundred such parks in 16 states, and by placing what he calls a “contrarian bet on a poorer America,” they are making $30 million in yearly revenue, half of it profit.

headline: Aretha Franklin to Headline the Blue Note Jazz Festival
abstract: Among the other marquee shows at the festival, which runs June 1 to June 30, is a collaboration between the vocal chameleon Bobby McFerrin and the drummer-bandleader Questlove.
lead_paragraph: The prize headliner in this year’s Blue Note Jazz Festival lineup is Aretha Franklin, who has had her share of dalliances with jazz, though her core and purpose lie elsewhere. She’ll be far from the only artist fitting that description in the festival’s fourth annual edition, running throughout June in more than a dozen spaces around New York.

headline: Billy Crystal Returns to TV With New FX Comedy
abstract: Mr. Crystal is the latest example of a established star who is attracted by the cable television model for making a series.
lead_paragraph: In one more affirmation of the growing appeal of series television, Billy Crystal, who last starred in a sitcom in “Soap” in the late 1970s, will headline a new comedy series on the cable channel FX, the network announced Wednesday.

headline: Busting the Brackets! Mathematics and the N.C.A.A. Tournament
abstract: In this lesson, students apply concepts of probability and explore the scale of extremely large and extremely small numbers by diving into March Madness and bracketology.
lead_paragraph: Overview | What are the odds of picking a “perfect bracket”? How can students put large numbers and small probabilities in context? In this lesson, students apply concepts of probability and explore the scale of extremely large and extremely small numbers by diving into March Madness and bracketology.

headline: Warming Up to the Culture of Wikipedia
abstract: While there used to be innate suspicion toward Wikipedia among museum staffs, even hostility, in recent years there has increasingly been cooperation.
lead_paragraph: IF ever there was the antithesis of the crowd-sourced Wikipedia, it would be a museum, where an expert picks what is seen and not seen, then carefully prepares captions explaining what each piece of art means.

headline: Breaking From Donor Dependence
abstract: Institutions grapple with expanding their profit-making activities as government and private financing dwindles.
lead_paragraph: ONE doesn’t typically think of drawing visitors to a cultural institution with a sheepshearing festival. But that is part of the strategy of Gore Place, a historic house in Waltham, Mass., that also has a working farm.

headline: Exhibition Traces a Career Dedicated to Mutability
abstract: The artist has spent 40 years obliterating boundaries between science, education, politics and people in the hope of “delivering a reality that affects the future of individuals.”
lead_paragraph: ELIMINATING lead poisoning from the lives of children is not a typical goal of art. But for Mel Chin, the borders of art have long extended past the crafting of discrete objects.

headline: The Met’s Director Looks Ahead
abstract: Thomas P. Campbell, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, says technology is the biggest issue facing museums today.
lead_paragraph: IN the five years since Thomas P. Campbell became director and chief executive of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the museum world has had to grapple with declining philanthropic dollars, mushrooming entertainment options and a rapidly developing digital world. But in an interview, Mr. Campbell said he was optimistic about the public’s appetite for museums in general and the Met’s prospects in particular. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: If You Can’t Make It to the Lecture
abstract: Museums expand their reach and try to make their virtual presence a “distinct experience.”
lead_paragraph: JANIS LOEWENGART YERINGTON, an artist from Bolinas, Calif., became a fan of online museum lectures after seeing the touring Vermeer painting, “Girl with a Pearl Earring,” at the de Young Museum in San Francisco.

headline: In Washington, 100 Examples of the Epitome of Cool
abstract: A photographic exhibition in Washington curates cool in America, with 100 cultural icons on display, and an alternate list of 100 who didn’t make the cut.
lead_paragraph: “AMERICAN COOL” is the kind of exhibition many people will find irresistible. This exploration of 100 cultural figures at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington first takes a persona that inspires emulation, and then offers up the avatars in classic celebrity photographs, some by master portraitists like Richard Avedon, Diane Arbus and Henri-Cartier Bresson. And it is the exhibit that keeps on giving. By the time you leave, you’ll have enough material for hours of earnest cocktail party debates over the selection.

headline: Minnesota Makes Do Without a Civil War Battlefield
abstract: No Civil War battles were fought in Minnesota, but many Minnesotans fought in the war. That gave the Minnesota Historical Society an idea: Why not focus on what the soldiers did after the war?
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — THE Civil War seems a long way from St. Paul: 1,100 miles to Manassas; 1,000 miles to Gettysburg. Even the nearest battlefields, in Missouri, are hundreds of miles away.

headline: Entering World of Literature’s Great Sleuth
abstract: “The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes,” now at the Center of Science and Industry in Columbus, Ohio, delves into the world of the famous literary detective.
lead_paragraph: SINISTER blood splatters, concealed clues and murder most foul are just part of the fun at “The International Exhibition of Sherlock Holmes,” now at the Center of Science and Industry in Columbus, Ohio. The 10,000-square-foot traveling exhibition is an ambitious and multifaceted presentation of the most famous detective of English literary fiction, his creator, Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, and more than 125 years of Sherlockian lore.

headline: Monuments Man in War, Conservator in Peace
keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Science and Technology', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Movies', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: George Stout, an early advocate of the role of science in arts conservation, was the inspiration for the role played by George Clooney in the movie. Today his seminal role is remembered mostly by conservators.
lead_paragraph: BY now, much of the moviegoing world is familiar with “The Monuments Men,” an art-historical film that sees George Clooney, Matt Damon and other stars swashbuckling around Europe during World War II, trying to save masterpieces like the Ghent Altarpiece and a Rembrandt self-portrait from bombs and the clutches of German and Russian troops. As the film opens, Mr. Clooney’s character is seen addressing President Roosevelt, trying to persuade him to help safeguard Europe’s cultural patrimony.

headline: Making Devices Child-Friendly
abstract: Molly Wood offers tips for parents to make their tablets and smartphones more child-friendly before handing them over.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood offers tips for parents to make their tablets and smartphones more child-friendly before handing them over.

headline: Is There a Doctor in the Exhibition?
keywords: ['Museums', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Research', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Museums are opening their doors and collections to promote health literacy, research, medical training and disease prevention
lead_paragraph: A POISON of choice since antiquity, belladonna has been linked to witches, sorcerers, kings and queens — all with murder on their minds. Also known as deadly nightshade, it is part of the Medicinal and Poison Plants Tour at the United States Botanic Garden, said Beth Burrous, the tour’s creator.

headline: What Comes Next, After the Troops Are Dismissed
abstract: The Higgins Armory Museum in Worcester, Mass., which specialized in arms and armor, closed at the end of 2013, but much of its collection will stay together in another local museum.
lead_paragraph: THE furor over the possible sale of the collection at the Detroit Institute of Arts — a prospect that seems in abeyance for now — reminds the art world of the flip side of its relentless focus on expansions, additions and growth: Sometimes museums close.

headline: Shedding a Light on Islamic Art’s Great Treasure
abstract: Sabiha Al Khemir, a top curator, is helping transform the Dallas Museum of Art into a leading destination to appreciate Islamic culture.
lead_paragraph: SABIHA AL KHEMIR was visiting a solar energy plant in Spain about four years ago when inspiration struck. Her host, the foundation of a Spanish company with interests in alternative energy, wanted her to conceive an Islamic art exhibition for Seville to recognize Spain’s 800-year history under Moorish rule and ideally to tie her concept into the Seville-based company’s work. Touring the solar plant, the Tunisian-born curator found her organizing principle.

headline: Motown’s Link to Civil Rights Movement on Display
abstract: “The Truth Is a Hit” exhibition at the Schomburg Center focuses on the sociocultural impact of Berry Gordy’s influential label.
lead_paragraph: THE story of Motown Records can be told in many ways. It can be presented as a tale of musical revolution, the creation of a sound steeped in gospel and blues but packed with endlessly inventive pop hooks. There is also the business story of the founder, Berry Gordy Jr.; for a time in the 1960s, Motown was the largest black-owned company in America.

headline: Soliciting Funds From the Crowd? Results Will Vary
abstract: Museums are cautiously turning to crowdfunding — the solicitation of money from individuals online — to finance shows, with varying results.
lead_paragraph: ESTABLISHED museums like the Smithsonian Institution are increasingly turning to crowdfunding appeals to help pay for exhibits and programs that tight budgets might otherwise preclude.

headline: Remembering the ‘Black Fives’ of Pro Basketball
abstract: A new exhibition at the New-York Historical Society sheds light on little-known amateur and professional black basketball teams from the first half of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: ROSENA DISERY, a teenager at the New York African Free School in 1820, surely knew nothing about basketball when she stitched a silk-on-wool sampler with words from the poem “Self-Love and Truth Incompatible.”

headline: After the Exhibition, Finding New Uses for Displays
abstract: Many museums are giving second lives to exhibit materials as various as advertising banners, paint and building materials, and even a huge rotating globe.
lead_paragraph: MAKING what is old new again with fresh displays has long been the province of museums. But what happens to all the stuff left over when shows end? Many museums are going beyond traditional recycling efforts and giving second lives to exhibit materials.

headline: Start-Up Success Isn’t Enough to Found a Museum
abstract: Without a billionaire benefactor, it is a challenging time for aspiring curators to get into the business, consultants say.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the idea for the Museum of Science Fiction struck Greg Viggiano last April, he shot into warp speed. He wrote a business plan, picked Washington as a prospective location, recruited volunteers and produced a video featuring befuddled Imperial storm troopers, armed with maps, searching for the phantom museum near the United States Capitol. Mr. Viggiano used the video as part of a crowdfunding campaign that has raised almost $48,000, an amount he described as a “rounding error in terms of how much we’re going to need.”

headline: In Boston, Altering the Artist-in-Residence Concept
abstract: At the city’s Institute of Contemporary Art, the artist-in-resident Matthew Ritchie is producing several artworks and performances that defy the traditional result of such collaborations.
lead_paragraph: COLLABORATIONS among museums and artists-in-residence typically culminate in a single artwork or event. More unusual is the one between Matthew Ritchie and the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston. During his 18-month residency, he is producing a series of related artworks and performances in and near the museum that weave Boston and the institute into an abstract narrative of past, present and future.

headline: At Play in Skies of Cretaceous Era
abstract: Museums are employing the latest in video-game technology to create interactive exhibitions that draw visitors into unexpected learning experiences.
lead_paragraph: When viewed from Central Park West, where it straddles four blocks like a castle, the American Museum of Natural History can seem like a fusty place — “the neo-Classical idea of the museum,” as David Harvey, its senior vice president for exhibition, put it. In the popular imagination, or perhaps just Ben Stiller’s imagination, it’s a retro-cool place filled with dioramas that are put together by curators who are part-time taxidermists.

headline: Golden Age of Discovery ... Down in the Basements
abstract: In recent years, curators, visiting scholars and even interns have discovered — or rediscovered — a spate of cultural treasures lurking in museum storage areas.
lead_paragraph: GALLERIES usually get all the publicity, but at many museums the biggest news is happening in the basement.

headline: Wooing a New Generation of Museum Patrons
abstract: Museums are preparing for the eventual passing of the baton from the baby boom generation, which has long been the lifeblood of giving and boardroom leadership.
lead_paragraph: Several hundred millennials mingled under the soaring atrium of the Guggenheim Museum on Fifth Avenue one recent frigid February night. Weaving around them were black-clad servers bearing silver trays piled high with doughnuts, while a pixieish D.J. spun Daft Punk remixes.

headline: Only on Reality TV: Old Vaults That Keep on Giving
abstract: Reality television’s quest to open lockers and unearth memorabilia continues in new shows like “The Safecracker,” “Treasure King,” and “Barry’d Treasure.”
lead_paragraph: Apparently all the abandoned storage lockers have finally been opened.

headline: New Insights Into History May Skew the Big Picture
abstract: History — the fullest, richest story we can tell about ourselves and our past — may be beyond the reach of most museums, however much they try.
lead_paragraph: Museums are born to wrestle with history. What else, after all, is a museum but a collection of objects gathered to shape a narrative, to assert an interpretation, to evoke memory and reaction — in other words, to make a history? So when I complain, as I often do in making my critical rounds, about the way history is treated in museums, how could it be otherwise? History — particularly in nonart museums — is the point. And it is bound to be an issue of debate.

headline: Door to Art of the World, Barely Ajar
abstract: When it comes to telling an inclusive story of art, small museums in the West, as well as those in Africa and Southeast Asia, often do a much better job than the largest institutions.
lead_paragraph: On a pay-what-you-wish Saturday evening in late February, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum rotunda was dense with visitors to a new show, “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe.“

headline: For L’Wren Scott, Her Identity Was by Design
abstract: There was more than a famous boyfriend in Mick Jagger and a fashionable life in European shows.
lead_paragraph: It was a crowded cocktail party at the Cafe Royal in London on a balmy February night. As hundreds of people mingled in the ornate, recently renovated space, one of the attendees, an editor who had gone to L’Wren Scott’s fall 2013 fashion show that day, stood in a corner making small talk with Bobbi Brown, the cosmetics entrepreneur, and John Demsey, the president of Estée Lauder.

headline: David Frum to Join The Atlantic
abstract: The conservative writer will become a senior editor with a focus on politics and national affairs.
lead_paragraph: The conservative commentator and author David Frum is joining The Atlantic at the end of the month as a senior editor with a focus on politics and national affairs, the publication announced Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Turning a Tablet Into a Child’s Interactive TV
abstract: The Winston Show, which is an iPad-only program, is an example of the new content types that are possible when a TV is also a hand-held computer.
lead_paragraph: MY son has been having conversations with imaginary characters. I know, because I can listen to some of them, and even see pictures.

headline: NATO Weighs Assistance for Ukraine to Dissuade Further Moves by Moscow
abstract: The secretary general of the alliance said that Ukraine had requested the aid, and that a decision on what to provide would be made at a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in April.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The secretary general of NATO, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, said on Wednesday that the alliance was considering providing assistance to Ukraine to help deter Russia from another military intervention there.

headline: Measuring America’s Shakespearean Devotion
abstract: A new anthology shows how, from colonial times, Americans made Shakespeare one of their own.
lead_paragraph: New York has been handed a surplus of Shakespeare over the last six months. To celebrate the 450th anniversary of his birth, there were eight Broadway and Off Broadway productions on offer — enough, surely, for even the most ravenous Shakespearean appetite. But to a 19th-century American, this stuffed schedule might well look like slim pickings.

headline: Toyota Settlement Blazes Path for G.M.
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The parallels between the handling of vehicle defects by Toyota and General Motors are striking, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Toyota’s settlement with the Justice Department on vehicle defects is yet another example of how covering up misconduct results in far greater penalties than the underlying violation. For General Motors, the settlement provides a template for resolving a growing investigation into faulty ignition switches that caused a number of deaths.

headline: German Energy Push Runs Into Problems
abstract: Berlin's ambition to use renewable power sources without harming its industrial might has gained urgency with new uncertainties about Russian gas.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It is Germany’s national goal: to have the bulk of its energy supplied by renewable power sources by 2050, without endangering the country’s powerful industrial sector or an export-based economy that is the envy of other Europeans.

headline: In Hong Kong, Placing Their Bets on Bitcoin
abstract: A growing field of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene.

headline: If He Says It’s Funny, It’s Funny
abstract: Bob Mankoff’s “How About Never — Is Never Good for You?” is partly a memoir but mostly about what constitutes a good New Yorker cartoon.
lead_paragraph: If anyone is entitled to pepper his memoir with New Yorker cartoons, it’s the cartoon editor of The New Yorker. So Bob Mankoff’s new book is half prose, half illustrations and tirelessly playful. But the artwork and text work together to tell a fizzy, jokey story about a long and busy career. Its title, “How About Never — Is Never Good for You?” comes from a famous Mankoff cartoon that depicts a businessman on the telephone, dodging a lunch date. Now around 70, Mr. Mankoff depicts himself with a big grin and a lipstick mark on his forehead, saying those words to the Grim Reaper.

headline: Some Cold Medicines May Have Higher-Than-Expected Levels of a Decongestant
abstract: A New Zealand drug maker says the combination of the decongestant phenylephrine and acetaminophen can raise blood pressure, but the F.D.A. says it is not a concern.
lead_paragraph: Some widely used over-the-counter cold and flu medicines may be exposing patients to unexpectedly high amounts of one ingredient, revealing a lapse in regulations and perhaps raising safety concerns, a company that develops such drugs reported on Wednesday.

headline: In Words and Photos, Cramming in Life
abstract: Teju Cole, a Nigerian-American author and photographer, is publishing the novel “Every Day Is for the Thief,” written before his acclaimed “Open City,” but available only in Nigeria until now.
lead_paragraph: On a recent visit to the International Center of Photography, the Nigerian-American author and photographer Teju Cole leaned forward to study an image by Robert Capa. It offered an aerial view of the Place de la Concorde in Paris, bustling with traffic, sunlight filtering through a blanket of clouds. Mr. Cole admiringly listed its elements and expressed a preference for expansive photos like this one.

headline: Malaysia’s Deep Political Rifts Exposed Amid Mystery of Missing Flight
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Malaysia’s opposition leaders have strongly criticized the government for focusing public attention on Flight 370’s pilot, an opposition supporter.
lead_paragraph: GEORGE TOWN, Malaysia — Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, missing since March 8, is rapidly becoming a hot political issue in this country, with opposition politicians caustically criticizing the government’s handling of the search for the jet even as the government has focused public attention on the flight’s pilot, a supporter of the opposition.

headline: Art Around the Country
abstract: A sampling of works from current and coming exhibitions at museums in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of works from current and coming exhibitions at museums in the United States.

headline: In the Eye of a Superstorm, Their Close-Ups
abstract: Photographers with work in the “Rising Waters: Photographs of Sandy” exhibition share the stories behind their images.
lead_paragraph: Photographers with work in the “Rising Waters: Photographs of Sandy” exhibition share the stories behind their images.

headline: Nobody Could Have Predicted, Monetary Edition
abstract: Way off (monetary) base, not nothing learned.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong and Josh Bivens send us to a House hearing on monetary policy, in which three conservatives explain why it was totally forgivable for everyone on their side to predict runaway inflation from the Fed’s expansion of the monetary base, and why the failure of that inflation to appear says nothing at all about possible flaws in their approach.

headline: Hurricane Sandy Revisited and Unleashed Through a Photographic Vision
abstract: “Rising Waters” at the Museum of the City of New York exhibits the work of several photographers who captured the storm while braving it.
lead_paragraph: Chris Ozer was watching television and web coverage of the approaching Hurricane Sandy. He did not like the looks of it.

headline: Yellen on Fed’s Stimulus Campaign
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, spoke at a news conference after the Fed announced it would reduce its monthly bond purchases because of the economic recovery’s progress.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, spoke at a news conference after the Fed announced it would reduce its monthly bond purchases because of the economic recovery’s progress.

headline: Exploring Modern Ruins in Southern California
abstract: From the Salton Sea to Sunken City, touring remains of abandoned dreams while catching flickers of life in between.
lead_paragraph: California has always been linked with the idea of American possibility. It’s the sun-drenched place where you go to leave the stuffy, decaying old world for a new life. But not everything here is shiny, new and full of potential. Drive deep into the deserted corners of Southern California and you’ll find dreams that flickered to life briefly and then faded away. Places once destined for greatness that have disintegrated into modern ruins. These aren’t Wild West ghost towns but more recent vestiges of the 20th century.

headline: Judge’s Order on Voter Proof of Citizenship
abstract: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered the U.S. Election Assistance Commission to help Kansas and Arizona enforce laws requiring new voters to provide proof of their U.S. citizenship.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered the U.S. Election Assistance Commission to help Kansas and Arizona enforce laws requiring new voters to provide proof of their U.S. citizenship.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine, the West Bank, Afghanistan and More: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Ukraine, the West Bank, Afghanistan and More: Pictures of the Day

headline: Want to Vote? Show Us Your Papers
abstract: Arizona and Kansas may now insist on proof of citizenship in order to register.
lead_paragraph: There isn’t a state in the country that allows non-citizens to vote. And there is no evidence that people who are in the country illegally want to vote, or have tried in any significant number. But that hasn’t stopped Arizona and Kansas from insisting on proof of citizenship in order to register, knowing full well that the legitimate voters who will have the most trouble coming up with that proof tend to lean Democratic.

headline: The Embodiment of ‘American Cool’
abstract: An exploration of 100 cultural figures at the National Portrait Gallery takes a persona that inspires emulation and offers up the avatars in classic celebrity photographs.
lead_paragraph: An exploration of 100 cultural figures at the National Portrait Gallery takes a persona that inspires emulation and offers up the avatars in classic celebrity photographs.

headline: The Challenge of Pluralism
keywords: ['ACADEMIC FREEDOM', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Liberalism (US Politics)']
abstract: On religious liberty, campus conformity, and the difficult quest for actual-existing pluralism.
lead_paragraph: In a “defense” of religious liberty that’s basically written to reassure liberals that they can support something called religious freedom without conceding an inch to actual-existing dissenters from liberalism’s preferred legal and regulatory regime, Emily Bazelon offers a formulation that hints at why religious and ideological pluralism, so honored in theory, is often hard for people to get behind in practice:

headline: Ways to Apply Fuchsia, the Hot Makeup Color
abstract: A vivid makeup color for the transition into spring.
lead_paragraph: Not quite red and not quite pink, vivid fuchsia is a good (and suddenly ubiquitous) makeup shade for the transition from winter to spring.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Ukraine, the West Bank, Afghanistan and Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine, the West Bank, Afghanistan and Taiwan.

headline: An Unrewarded Leap of Faith
abstract: Shopping at Flight 23 in Midtown Manhattan, where the best Jordans are on the customers.
lead_paragraph: I SHOULD STATE up front that I’m wearing Air Jordans as I write this: black-and-cement retro 3s. Mostly I wear 3s and 4s, though lately I’ve been tempted by 6s, 10s and 12s. I gave up on 1s a few years ago, though that feels foolish to admit. I’ll only end up reclaiming them a few years from now. I firmly believe you can tell someone’s age (and taste level) by which generation of Jordan is the holy grail. (Would a grown-up really entertain, say, 24s?) I have formal occasion Jordans, day-to-day Jordans, Jordans that go with exactly one item of clothing in my closet, dirty outdoor festival Jordans, rain Jordans and house Jordans.

headline: Dustin Yellin: Opening Doors, Opening Eyes
abstract: The artist creates an arts center in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and now nearly everyone in the neighborhood knows his name.
lead_paragraph: There are so many keys attached to Dustin Yellin’s jeans, it’s a wonder he is not a locksmith.

headline: Riding the Wave of ‘Girls’
abstract: Cameos by New York players add an air of authenticity.
lead_paragraph: We definitely have to go dancing tonight. AndrewAndrew is D.J.ing at Greenhouse. — Elijah, to Hannah, “Girls” Episode 3, Season 2.

headline: Spring North American Championships Start in Dallas
abstract: The 11-day event, organized by the American Contract Bridge League, starts on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The 11-day Spring North American Championships, organized by the American Contract Bridge League, start on Wednesday in Dallas.

headline: Beneath Their Feet, a Foundation of Ideas
abstract: The choreographer Wayne McGregor, whose troupe is performing at Montclair State University, packs his artistry with the fruits of his homework in several disciplines.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — It’s too bad the dance detail in Wayne McGregor’s choreography is seldom of any interest because so many surrounding features of his wordless theater are admirable and arresting. He uses new music (live), new lighting, new designs and video technology in combinations that make you want to acclaim him as an heir to Diaghilev. The way he has employed computers makes him sound like the successor to Merce Cunningham. And his collaborations with science and medicine (in experimental psychology, heart-imaging work, creative cognition study, all at university level) could not be more commendable. Also, he is English-born, and his family name implies Celtic stock — so I feel we chaps ought to stick together. But most of his dances, alas, go in one eye and out the other.

headline: Makeup That Addresses the Many Shades of Women
abstract: Broadening the spectrum of foundations.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, when the Somali supermodel Iman started her cosmetics line based on foundations in a broad range of colors, she said she wasn’t interested in ethnicity or race. “The mission statement has not changed,” she said one morning not long ago. “It was for women of skin of color and addressing skin tone.”

headline: Music Has Southern Roots, but Lyrics May Travel
abstract: Rosanne Cash performed all 11 songs from her new album on Tuesday night at Town Hall, invoking Appalachian fiddle tunes, Delta blues, Memphis rockabilly and back-porch country picking.
lead_paragraph: An eight-member band, with as many as four guitars upfront, rarely sounds as serenely contained as Rosanne Cash’s concert did on Tuesday night at Town Hall. Ms. Cash started the concert performing all 11 songs from her superb new album, “The River & the Thread” (Blue Note), her first collection of new material since “Black Cadillac” in 2006. The music is understated; the ideas are large.

headline: At the ‘Game of Thrones’ Premiere, Even the Dragons Behaved
abstract: A premiere with a dragon and whale.
lead_paragraph: As far as events go, you can’t get much worse than the Red Wedding, the infamous climax of last season’s “Game of Thrones,” the HBO fantasy series. Fortunately, the premiere of its fourth season, shown Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall, was cheerier: for one, there were no visible impalings (at least in real life).

headline: Political Views Test the Harmony
abstract: Zubin Mehta, the music director for life of the Israel Philharmonic, is willing to offer his opinion about that country’s issues.
lead_paragraph: Like most seasoned conductors, Zubin Mehta has built his reputation on interpretations of a core repertory, in his case the music of Romantic-era giants like Bruckner, Tchaikovsky and Mahler. But on tour with the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, an ensemble that named him music director for life in 1981, he is increasingly in demand for his exegesis of a long-winded drama fueled by high passions of a different kind: Middle East politics.

headline: Two Bands’ Chances to Show Growth
abstract: Foster the People and Young the Giant aim to show growth on their new releases.
lead_paragraph: Modern mainstream rock is thankless work, an ouroboros of familiar ideas that is notable mainly for managing not to atrophy into total disappearance. It is a space of diminished influence and relevance, a haven for the dull and complacent.

headline: Spring Fashion That Makes a Statement
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Suits (Apparel)', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Pinstripes make a return on and off the runway; small purses are the handbag of the moment; and from Viktor & Rolf, a safety pin earring.
lead_paragraph: Think of it as power dressing with a sense of humor. Pinstripes were taken for a playful spin at the round of fashion shows just ended. The young woman on the left calls to mind a “Blond Ambition"-era Madonna in her double-breasted bustier top and matching pants, which she wore with cold-weather layers and lighthearted accessories. The model and blogger Zanita Morgan wore wide-leg Acne pinstripe pants, with a dark coat and sneakers; the front-row fixture Miroslava Duma was coolly chic in a Salvatore Ferragamo pinstripe suit and a bustier top; and the stylist Ece Sükan wore a pinstripe suit with a turtleneck, the skirt slit up to there. This is a trend just about any woman can embrace. Dig into your wardrobe or invest in new pinstripes, like the smart Acne suit at right — and have a little fun. You can always style your pinstripes more soberly for business hours.

headline: Art Matters | The Thing About Noah and the Ark
abstract: Darren Aronofsky explains why he decided to take on the fantastical Bible story in his new film and curate an art show about it.
lead_paragraph: Darren Aronofsky explains why he decided to take on the fantastical Bible story in his new film and curate an art show about it.

headline: What Lies Beneath
abstract: It can be difficult when reading an opinion from the Supreme Court to understand the real-world context of its decision.
lead_paragraph: I came cold to the Supreme Court’s most recent decision, by which I mean that I hadn’t read the briefs or the argument transcript, let alone attended the argument itself. In fact, I confess to having known nothing about the case, Marvin M. Brandt Revocable Trust v. United States, before I downloaded the opinion from the court’s website.

headline: What Does $1.8 Billion Get You in Men’s Wear?
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Suits (Apparel)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The newly combined Men’s Wearhouse/Jos. A. Bank will trail only Macy’s, Kohl’s and J. C. Penney for volume in men’s wear, according to WWD.
lead_paragraph: A MAN IN NEED OF A SUIT AND TIE has an ample resource just west of Grand Central Terminal. There along Madison Avenue, a men’s wear corridor has taken shape over the years. It is less sexy than stretches of Madison farther north, where Prada squares off against Gucci; more fit for a salaryman than a roué. Down in the East ’40s, a more orderly air pervades. The options are many for the traditionally minded gent. Paul Stuart and the Brooks Brothers are the grand old men.

headline: On Mobile Devices, Narrowing Choices for Your Child
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Children and Childhood', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Computer Security', 'Parenting']
abstract: Methods to protect your pocketbook — and your tech-minded children — from excessive in-app purchases and inappropriate content.
lead_paragraph: TABLETS and phones are increasingly the new television and entertainment devices for our children. But they don’t have to be a free-for-all of screen time, app downloading or inappropriate content discovery.

headline: Suppliers of Jet Parts Require Greater Oversight, Report Says
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Batteries']
abstract: The study, prepared by experts from the Federal Aviation Administration and Boeing, also said that Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner jets were safe and well designed.
lead_paragraph: The major systems on Boeing’s 787 Dreamliner jets are safe and well designed, but federal regulators need to provide more oversight of the far-flung supply networks that are building these and other new planes today, according to a report released on Wednesday.

headline: More Than 2,000 Migrants Rescued Off Italian Coast
keywords: ['Rescues', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Italian vessels rescued about 2,400 migrants coming from North Africa over the past two days, with the number reaching shore in the first months of 2014 increasing tenfold from the same period in 2013.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italian Navy and Coast Guard vessels rescued about 2,400 migrants coming from North Africa over the past two days, the authorities said Wednesday.

headline: Cultural Exchange
abstract: Dinaw Mengestu’s “All Our Names” follows the relationship between a foreign exchange student from Ethiopia and the Midwestern social worker assigned to help him.
lead_paragraph: All three of Dinaw Mengestu’s novels are about people who, for various reasons, come to this country and fashion new lives. But it would be a huge mistake — it would be an insult, in fact — to call him a novelist of “the immigrant experience” or a chronicler of “life on the hyphen” or any of the other shabby, summary clichés deployed to characterize (and too often diminish and even dismiss) authors whose birth certificates identify them as foreign-born. For while questions of race, ethnicity and point of origin do crop up repeatedly in Mengestu’s fiction, they are merely his raw materials, the fuel with which he so artfully — but never didactically — kindles disruptive, disturbing stories exploring the puzzles of identity, place and human connection.

headline: An Asian Pioneer of Free Games Aims for a Bigger Profile in the West
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: Nexon, a pioneer of “freemium” games, is relatively little known in the United States. Now the company is seeking to change that..
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It could be argued that Nexon has changed how games are experienced more than almost any other company. Yet relatively few people in the United States even know it exists.

headline: A Benefit for All Tastes
abstract: Diffa hosts its 17th annual Dining by Design gala with custom tablescapes.
lead_paragraph: Who will create the most evocative dinnertime aura inside the yawning hangarlike space of Pier 94? This weekend, more than 30 designers and their sponsors display inventive dining room installations for the 17th annual Diffa Dining by Design benefit exhibition and dinner.

headline: Sales at Lumens, Property, Roubini Rugs and Others
abstract: Deals on lighting, furniture and carpets.
lead_paragraph: Some lighting and furniture are up to 40 percent off at Lumens, through March 27 (the AJ table lamp by Arne Jacobsen for Louis Poulsen, regularly $1,018, now starts at about $865); 877-445-4486, lumens.com.

headline: Not Big-City Types But Still Sophisticated
abstract: A show and sale of antique rugs opens Thursday at Kentshire Galleries in Manhattan and on 1stdibs.com.
lead_paragraph: The 100 antique rugs and textiles collected for “Art in Bloom,” an exhibition and sale at the Kentshire Galleries in Manhattan and on 1stdibs.com, are “village rugs as opposed to the city rug,” said Peter Pap, the San Francisco-based dealer who curated the sale.

headline: A History of Bath Fixtures, by Appointment
abstract: American Standard has opened a New York showroom to display its DXV collection, whose name and styles refer to the company’s 15 decades.
lead_paragraph: The DXV by American Standard showroom, which opened last week in the Flatiron district, is a bit of a tease. The storefront at 15 West 20th Street offers window displays by local interior designers that change monthly. But you will have to make an effort to view the bath and kitchen fixtures inside — examples of the company’s new DXV collection inspired by the styles of four epochs in American Standard’s 150-year history. The space is not staffed and is accessible by appointment only (send requests to dxvappt@dxv.com). Once granted entrance, should you fall in love with, say, the Fitzgerald Two-Piece Elongated Toilet ($760), from the Golden Era Movement section, you can order it from a distributor. “We want to democratize luxury by making it part of a conversation and engaging the community with this space,” said Jay Gould, the company’s chief executive. Information: 732-980-3040 or dxv.com.

headline: Hand-Dyed Pillows With Reversible Detail
abstract: The designer, Rebecca Atwood, was inspired by the colors of her native Cape Cod.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Atwood is a pragmatist. “I studied painting at Rhode Island School of Design and realized that textiles were the closest thing to painting that I could do as a job,” said Ms. Atwood, a 29-year-old Brooklyn designer.

headline: Yankees Who Speak Cantonese
abstract: Stephen Fan, an architectural designer, shows how Chinese immigrants working at Connecticut casinos have adapted to suburban life.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Chinese immigrants working at southeastern Connecticut casinos have adapted mid-20th-century ranch houses to their native traditions and the demands of communal living. Stephen Fan, 31, an architectural designer who grew up in Norwich, Conn., and runs a firm with projects from New York to Boston, has studied front-yard melon patches, garages turned into sociable sitting porches, and narrow, repartitioned bedrooms for “Sub Urbanisms: Casino Company-town, China-town,” an exhibition at the Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London through May 12. (The museum is publishing a book based on the show, and a related symposium will be held March 29.)

headline: How Can I Update My Kitchen Pass-Through?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Kitchens']
abstract: Expand the hole as much as possible, the taller the better.
lead_paragraph: Q. My kitchen has a pass-through that looks out of date. How can I improve it?

headline: Sectional Sofas: Legos You Can Sit On
abstract: These behemoths are sometimes seen as tacky, but not if you pick the right one.
lead_paragraph: Unlike ordinary sofas, sectionals have a special ability. “They make a space within a space, always,” Adam Rolston said. “They’re the most architectural of interior furnishings.”

headline: The 28-Year Plan
abstract: When they came west in 1984, Jonathan and Wendy Segal had a dream of a house in La Jolla. As developers, they finally found an unused lot and designed a place that made it come true.
lead_paragraph: When Jonathan and Wendy Segal moved to San Diego, it was 1984 and they were both 22, newly graduated from the University of Idaho. They arrived with just $350 between them, in a beat-up 1968 Rambler, one of its doors roped shut. Yet as they drove the winding streets of the city’s affluent La Jolla section, gazing at the grand ocean-view homes, Ms. Segal sang out, “This is it: our dream neighborhood!”

headline: Meet Me in Chicago
keywords: ['Cookware', 'Tableware', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Kitchens', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The International Home and Housewares Show turns out to be the perfect spot for a transcontinental date.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It seemed like such a simple question.

headline: Former Prime Minister Indicted During Raucous Hearing in Bangladesh
abstract: The judge issued his ruling on corruption charges against Khaleda Zia, the leader of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, and eight others after lawyers engaged in a shouting match.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — A former Bangladeshi prime minister and other opposition leaders were indicted on Wednesday during a raucous court hearing in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The indictments, stemming from two long-delayed corruption cases, could further inflame the country’s already tense political situation.

headline: Muscle Head
abstract: A journalist explores the possibility that cognitive exercises improve working memory and problem solving.
lead_paragraph: “Feel the burn!” That was Jane Fonda in 1982, exhorting the viewers of her first-of-its-kind workout video to engage in an exotic pursuit called exercise. In her striped leotard and legwarmers, Fonda led the charge against the generally held opinion that exercise was a weird waste of time. (In those days, lifting weights was for Charles Atlas aspirants, and jogging was for quirky “health nuts.”) The tireless exertions of Fonda — and of tiny-shorted Richard Simmons and toothy Judi Sheppard Missett, the founder of Jazzercise — were ultimately wildly successful, making what was then an eccentric choice into what is now practically an obligation. Today we all exercise, or at least know we should.

headline: After the Protests
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Censorship', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Social media is fueling a boom-and-bust cycle of political activism.
lead_paragraph: LAST Wednesday, more than 100,000 people showed up in Istanbul for a funeral that turned into a mass demonstration. No formal organization made the call. The news had come from Twitter: Berkin Elvan, 15, had died. He had been hit in the head by a tear-gas canister on his way to buy bread during the Gezi protests last June. During the 269 days he spent in a coma, Berkin’s face had become a symbol of civic resistance shared on social media from Facebook to Instagram, and the response, when his family tweeted “we lost our son” and then a funeral date, was spontaneous.

headline: How to Punish Putin
abstract: If the West is serious about Ukraine, it must stop enabling Russia’s corrupt oligarchs.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — AS I write this, I am under house arrest. I was detained at a rally in support of anti-Putin protesters who were jailed last month.

headline: Shopping Openings and Events for the Week of March 19
abstract: A Topshop x Adidas capsule collection in store now; the Nike + R.T. Air Force 1 collection lands at Dover Street Market on Friday and more.
lead_paragraph: Hitting the Racks

headline: Pilot of Missing Jet Expressed Interest in Democracy and Atheism on Social Networks
abstract: Posts on the Facebook and YouTube accounts maintained by Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah support descriptions of him by friends as a man without extremist leanings in religion or politics.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Thursday, 2:06 p.m. | As my colleagues Chris Buckley and Michael Schmidt report, in the absence of any solid information about what happened to the Malaysia Airlines flight that went missing March 8, Malaysian authorities are looking for clues in the deleted memory of the flight simulator that the plane’s pilot, Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah, kept in his home.

headline: Pakistan Vows to Improve Journalists’ Freedom and Safety
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Assaults']
abstract: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said his government would investigate targeted violence, ease visa and travel limits, and review the expulsion of a reporter for The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan promised on Wednesday to improve journalists’ safety and freedom to work, saying his government would investigate targeted violence, ease visa and travel restrictions, and immediately review the blacklisting of The New York Times’s Pakistan bureau chief, according to the Committee to Protect Journalists advocacy group.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 85
abstract: Josip Simunic, a Croatian defender, lost his appeal of a 10-match ban, which means he will miss the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Josip Simunic, a defender for Croatia, will almost certainly miss the World Cup after FIFA upheld a 10-game international ban for leading fans in Zagreb in a pro-Nazi chant.

headline: Wizard of Westwood
abstract: A biography of the coach who led U.C.L.A. to the pinnacle of men’s college basketball.
lead_paragraph: To be a college basketball fan today is to be an initiate in the cult of the coach. With the game’s best players staying in school only one or two years before taking their talents to the N.B.A., it’s the men wearing the sharp suits and pacing the sidelines who are the sport’s constants. They are the faces of their teams, the true stars of March Madness.

headline: U.N. Stymied in Efforts to Take Aid to Syrians
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Food', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Despite a Security Council resolution ordering the unhindered flow of food and medicine into Syria, aid workers are struggling even to get across the border.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In the three weeks since the United Nations Security Council ordered Syria’s warring parties to let aid workers deliver food and medicine, the world body’s relief agencies have suspended their efforts to cross one land border, are waiting to cross another and are facing severe difficulties getting food into a Damascus neighborhood where children are starving.

headline: David Sive, a Father of Environmental Law and Advocacy, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Sive argued precedent-setting cases and helped establish a string of environmental advocacy groups when such issues had barely penetrated public consciousness.
lead_paragraph: David Sive, considered one of the founders of environmental law, who argued precedent-setting cases and helped establish a string of advocacy groups when such issues had barely penetrated public consciousness, died on March 12 in West Orange, N.J. He was 91.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Hurley’s ‘Smarter’
abstract: This week, Dan Hurley talks about his new book, “Smarter: The New Science of Building Brain Power”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jason Zengerle discusses Seth Davis’s new biography of John Wooden; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. John Williams is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.
lead_paragraph: This week, Dan Hurley talks about his new book, “Smarter: The New Science of Building Brain Power”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Jason Zengerle discusses Seth Davis’s new biography of John Wooden; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. John Williams is the host, filling in for Pamela Paul.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Dan Hurley’s ‘Smarter’
abstract: This week, Dan Hurley and Jason Zengerle.
lead_paragraph: This week, Dan Hurley and Jason Zengerle.

headline: Young Golfers Enter Game Outside of Woods’s Shadow
abstract: Over time, Tiger Woods’s physical advantages have been corroded by injuries and technology, most notably the advent of hybrid clubs and drivers with grapefruit-size heads.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Patrick Reed, 23, a two-time winner on the PGA Tour in 2014, is part of the latest wave of young golfers to crash ashore and churn the rankings. The world’s top 50 players include eight under the age of 25, with Reed among them at No. 20.

headline: Ban Lifted, BP Bids $42 Million to Win Gulf Oil Leases in U.S. Auction
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Auctions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Winning so many leases so soon after being cleared to seek new drilling rights was an important milestone in the company’s quest to recover from the 2010 disaster in the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just days after the United States lifted a ban on new oil and gas leases for BP, the company took full advantage of the opportunity. In an auction held in New Orleans on Wednesday, BP was the high bidder on 24 exploration blocks in the Gulf of Mexico for about $42 million, according to the Interior Department.

headline: A Website Asks Readers to Finance Independent Journalists
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'News and News Media', 'Start-ups', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Beacon will be supporting writers with a $5-a-month fee, similar to a Netflix model.
lead_paragraph: With news publications increasingly charging for their once-free websites and apps, they face a critical question: Will readers pay for digital content? Now, one Internet start-up has put a twist on that question: Will readers pay for a journalist?

headline: Plane Debris Would Be Modest Clue Two Weeks After a Crash, Experts Say
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Oceans and Seas']
abstract: If searchers spotted floating debris from the missing Malaysia Airlines jet in the ocean, it would be more dispersed and farther from the wreckage sunk beneath the waves, experts said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even if searchers are fortunate enough to spot floating debris in the ocean west of Australia from the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, it would be only a modest step in locating the rest of the Boeing 777, according to oceanographers and recovery experts. And only then could they dig into the question of why it crashed.

lead_paragraph: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr., the civil rights leader and political activist, appeared at a shareholder meeting of Hewlett-Packard Wednesday afternoon, in what appeared to be the start of a comprehensive campaign to bring greater minority representation to the technology world.

lead_paragraph: In the struggle to break cycles of poverty, experts have been searching for decades for ways to lower America’s astronomical birthrate among teenagers.

lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — Every 10 years, a team built largely by Dan Duquette becomes a powerhouse. The 1994 Montreal Expos had the best record in the major leagues. The 2004 Boston Red Sox won the World Series. Maybe it will be a special season for the 2014 Baltimore Orioles.

headline: Union Leaders Gird for Battle Against Republican Running for Governor of Illinois

headline: Syria: Rebels Seize Southern Prison
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Prison Escapes']
abstract: Rebels took over a prison in Daraa Province on Wednesday, expanding their control near the border with Jordan and freeing hundreds of prisoners, antigovernment activists said.
lead_paragraph: Rebels in southern Syria took over a government prison in Daraa Province on Wednesday, expanding their control near the border with Jordan and freeing hundreds of prisoners, antigovernment activists said. The prison, near the provincial capital of Daraa, fell after a siege by rebel forces that lasted weeks. A video posted online showed a fighter telling a large group of prisoners that they would be taken to a rebel court. Another video showed rebels leading what appear to be more than 100 prisoners from a prison building. It was unclear whether the prisoners were political detainees. The Syrian government did not comment.

headline: Revisiting Gandhi, on the Banks of the Sabarmati
abstract: An old ashram is a place to reflect on a new India of skyrocketing growth.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — As a teenager in the 1920s, my grandfather Prabhudas Kamdar was enthralled with Mahatma Gandhi. He devoured every issue of Gandhi’s magazine, Young India, as soon as it came out and was deeply drawn to Gandhi’s satyagraha movement.

headline: Hurricane Sandy and New Jersey’s Poor
abstract: The Christie administration’s recovery effort was mismanaged from the start and consistently shortchanged poor and minority victims.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is required by law to ensure that states spend federal disaster aid in a fair, nondiscriminatory manner that furthers the goals of the federal fair housing law. But history shows that states sometimes need a push, and the evidence suggests that Gov. Chris Christie’s administration in New Jersey needs one right now.

headline: PETA Accuses Two Trainers of Cruelty to Horses

lead_paragraph: Over a 26-year career, the trainer Steve Asmussen has built one of horse racing’s largest and most successful operations. He ranks second in career victories, with more than 6,700; has earned more than $214 million in purses, the fifth most in thoroughbred racing; and was recently included on the National Museum of Racing’s Hall of Fame ballot.

headline: Russia and the Group of 8

headline: A Wedding in Intensive Care
abstract: Doctors often share their patients’ sorrow, but rarely their joys.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — There wasn’t going to be a happy ending. The patient had metastatic cancer and had just gone through her third unsuccessful regimen of chemotherapy. Now it seemed that everywhere we looked, we found disease. An X-ray of her belly revealed an obstruction in her intestines. A CT scan of her chest uncovered a pulmonary embolism. Her labs demonstrated that she had almost no white blood cells left with which to defend herself.

headline: Tempered Cheers in Ukraine for Ex-Premier, Tied to Political Past
abstract: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, recently released from prison, has emerged as a pivotal, if not beloved, figure in a nation that finds itself directly astride the East-West divide.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Released from prison last month by the rebellious Ukrainian Parliament, Yulia V. Tymoshenko raced to Independence Square in Kiev to join the celebrations. But the appearance of Ms. Tymoshenko, a former prime minister, was curiously subdued, and not just because she was in a wheelchair.

headline: Gang-Related Shootings Decline in Chicago
abstract: The shootings are steadily declining, officials said, citing violence-reduction efforts that prevent gang retaliation and that are prompting the interest of other cities.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Gang-related shootings here are steadily declining, officials said on Wednesday, citing violence-reduction efforts that prevent gang retaliation and that are prompting the interest of other cities.

abstract: Must home renovations always be so rife with emotions?

headline: A Mystery: Who Are the Dewey Secret Seven?

lead_paragraph: They are the mysterious seven: former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf who pleaded guilty to taking part in a four-year plan to manipulate the financial statements of the once prominent law firm, but whose identities and plea agreements are being kept under wraps by New York prosecutors.

headline: Paying Price, 16 Years Later, for an Illegal Entry

lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The cellblock intercom awoke Josue Noe Sandoval-Perez at 1 o’clock on a frigid January morning at a detention center in northwest Missouri: Get your things, get ready to go. Immigration officials were preparing to whisk him away.

headline: Turkey: Corruption Probe’s Details Will Not Be Disclosed
abstract: Parliament voted on Wednesday against the public disclosure of accusations against four former government ministers who have been implicated in a major corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: Parliament voted Wednesday against the public disclosure of accusations against four former government ministers who have been implicated in a major corruption investigation. The governing party contended that the disclosure would violate the secrecy of the inquiry, which was initiated in December. Opposition members of Parliament argued, however, that the former ministers had the right to hear in full detail the allegations against them. Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has criticized the corruption investigation as a “judicial coup,” and he has asserted that it was initiated by a rival pro-Islamic network, led by Fethullah Gulen, a preacher based in the United States whose sympathizers are believed to be influential in Turkey’s police force and the judiciary.

headline: Second Round of Iran Nuclear Talks Ends With Optimism

lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The second round of talks between Iran and six world powers over Iran’s nuclear program ended Wednesday with all parties expressing satisfaction with the discussions, which were the most detailed so far on each of the main issues dividing them.

lead_paragraph: Robert S. Strauss, who rose from the Texas Plains to become an influential Washington insider, leading the Democratic Party and hopscotching among White House posts when not making millions as a lobbyist and deal maker, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 95.

headline: Sixty-Five Minutes
abstract: Victor Barocas is out to get us.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Sixty-five minutes. That’s how long it took me to figure this puzzle out. I did this mainly by staring at the grid, occasionally frowning deeply at it in order to scare it into submission. I worked the clues one at a time, not really sure why some had only dashes (in the print version, these clues are combined), and crawled my way through a Thursday puzzle. Thursday puzzles are supposed to bring light and joy. This puzzle, for me, highlights the observation that some puzzles are experimental, more than anything. Maybe you had better luck.

abstract: Big Blue is extending its analytics business with a fraud detection and mapping group, involving 500 experts, big data analysis and visualization technologies. lead_paragraph: IBM is changing with the crimes. So are other companies, and their collective efforts could affect more than catching tax cheats.

headline: After Serving Six Years, Mobster Receives His Sentence
abstract: Thomas Gioeli, who became an avid blogger and user of Twitter who taunted prosecutors and two mayors, received more than 18 years in prison on racketeering charges.
lead_paragraph: The mob boss had been at the federal jail in Brooklyn longer than any other inmate: four years awaiting trial and, after his conviction in 2012 on racketeering charges, nearly two more waiting to be sentenced. By the time his sentencing date arrived on Wednesday, the mobster, Thomas Gioeli, had been considered for the death penalty, convicted of conspiring to murder three mobsters and acquitted of killing a police officer; he had multiple angioplasties and, with the help of his family, even became an avid blogger and user of Twitter who taunted prosecutors and two mayors.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:05 A.M. (Starz) HIGH FIDELITY (2000) Rob (John Cusack, above) is the manager of a vinyl record store in Chicago. Along with his fellow employees (Jack Black and Todd Louiso), he spends most of his days spouting thematic Top 5 music lists while viewing himself as one of the last great curators of pop music. After his girlfriend, Laura (Iben Hjejle), dumps him, Rob creates a ranking of all his exes (a group that includes women played by Catherine Zeta-Jones, Lili Taylor and Joelle Carter), based on the amount of emotional turmoil they caused and decides to go on a mission to find out what went wrong. Writing in The New York Times, Stephen Holden said that the relationships depicted in this romantic comedy, directed by Stephen Frears and based on the novel by Nick Hornby, “have a pulsing flesh-and-blood reality.” He also wrote, “Even more sharply than the book, the movie evokes the turmoil of urban single life with a quirky mixture of confessional poignancy and dry, self-deflating humor.”
