headline: Hermès, Holding Steady in Luxury Market, Posts Strong Growth for 2013
abstract: The French luxury group has weathered a crackdown on ostentatious spending in China, where customers are coming to prefer its less flashy designs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French luxury group Hermès International on Thursday reported a rise in profit of nearly 7 percent last year, bolstered by strong sales growth in the United States and in China, where many of its larger competitors have struggled to adapt their product lines in response to a government-led clampdown on lavish spending.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 20, 2014
abstract: Can you choose the best synonym for “augur,” as it is used in the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A New Cold War?
abstract: Why do this week’s events in Crimea “threaten to usher in a new, more dangerous era” in the relationship between the United States and Russia?
lead_paragraph: In the News Analysis “If Not a Cold War, a Return to a Chilly Rivalry,” Peter Baker writes about how tensions over Crimea may bring about a long period of confrontation and alienation.

headline: 5 Indian Men Are Convicted in Gang Rapes at Abandoned Mill in Mumbai
abstract: The men faced prison terms of 20 years to life in the rapes of a photojournalist and a call-center operator when sentences are handed down, possibly on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — A court in Mumbai found five men guilty on Thursday on charges related to the gang rapes of a photojournalist and a call-center operator in an abandoned mill building last year. The case has shaken a city that has long prided itself on being relatively progressive and cosmopolitan.

headline: From Chaos and Drought, Commerce and Art
abstract: How did investors turn an arid California county into an agricultural hothouse? By enlisting a photographer to show the triumphs of man-made oases.
lead_paragraph: America’s second most-productive agricultural county receives less rain than the Gobi Desert.

headline: The Scientific Quest to Prove Bisexuality Exists
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Sex', 'Research']
abstract: How a new breed of activists is using science to show — once and for all — that someone can be truly attracted to both a man and a woman.
lead_paragraph: The traffic was bad, even by the warped standards of a Southern California commute. We were headed south from Los Angeles to San Diego on an overcast morning last spring, but we hadn’t moved in 10 minutes.

headline: C.C.R.C. Residents Ask, ‘Where’s the Money?’
abstract: Residents sue a California retirement community after learning that refunds on entrance fees have not been set aside. Similar suits have cropped up elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The way Burton Richter tells it, the house he and his wife had lived in for 40 years needed a fence repaired, and the repairman damaged the pool plumbing. Fixing that messed up the garden’s irrigation system. Soon afterward Dr. Richter had to climb onto the roof to repair a solar panel.

headline: How Concerned Are You About Climate Change?
abstract: How much have you learned about climate change in school? What do you believe about it?
lead_paragraph: This week the world’s largest general scientific society released a stark report on global warming that shows how dire, and how urgent, the problem is.

headline: Russian Forces Release Ukraine Naval Commander, Reports Say
abstract: The detention of the commander reflected the blistering pace of Moscow’s moves to cement Russia’s annexation of Crimea.
lead_paragraph: SEVASTOPOL, Crimea — Russian forces and their Crimean militia allies were reported on Thursday to have released the commander of the Ukrainian Navy, seized in his own headquarters here as Moscow’s annexation of the strategic Black Sea peninsula forced the authorities in Kiev to begin planning for the evacuation of their forces to mainland Ukraine.

headline: Gunmen Attack Luxury Hotel in Kabul Weeks Before Afghanistan Elections
abstract: Four men with pistols opened fire at the Serena Hotel complex, which is popular with foreign officials and prominent Afghans, before being gunned down.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Four men with pistols opened fire inside the luxurious Serena Hotel complex in central Kabul on Thursday night, killing nine people before being gunned down and sowing panic in an exclusive enclave frequented by foreign officials, prominent Afghans and an array of development workers, officials and witnesses said.

headline: New York Today: Dawn of Spring
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: a new season, sunny weather and city life without a cellphone.
lead_paragraph: Updated 10:08 a.m.

headline: Running as Therapy
keywords: ['Dating and Courtship', 'Exercise', 'Medicine and Health', 'Running', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: While pounding out miles in the pouring rain, I was grateful that it was raining so no one could see me cry.
lead_paragraph: I started distance running in 2007 because, in the short space of six months, the person I was dating left me for another woman, I bought a house (a rash decision) and my grandfather died.

headline: Samsonite Takes the Pulse of Chinese Consumers
abstract: The luggage maker says that while China’s economy may be cooling, demand for travel — and suitcases — is growing robustly.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — There are plenty of things to worry about in the Chinese economy — shadow banking, pain in the property sector, flagging growth in industrial output — but the willingness of the Chinese consumer to spend, at least on some things, seems to be holding up.

headline: JPMorgan Commodities Sale Shows Trading’s Opacity
abstract: The lack of financial details makes the price hard to judge, but at $3.5 billion, Mercuria seems to be paying a high one, Kevin Allison and Antony Currie write for Reuters Breakingviews. With commodities under pressure, that’s a bold move.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s $3.5 billion sale of its physical commodities business is a perfect example of just how opaque trading is.

headline: Michelle Obama Stays Connected During Her Visit to China
abstract: On the first lady’s weeklong trip to China, her first ever, her team is harnessing the power of technology to ensure that every step, every impression, is documented.
lead_paragraph: As Michelle Obama kicks off her weeklong trip to China, her first ever, her team is harnessing the power of technology to ensure that every step, every impression is documented. Accompanied by her daughters, Malia and Sasha, as well as her mother, Marian Robinson, the first lady will be blogging, tweeting and Instagramming her way through the country.

headline: Newtown Helps Map Out a New Path to Healing
abstract: The architects designing the new Sandy Hook elementary school have had to contend with the extra burden of the horrific crime that unfolded on Dec. 14, 2012, and they turned to the residents of Newtown, Conn., for feedback.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — The school will be in the woods, away from the parking lot. It will feature a long, curving corridor that the architect likens to arms embracing students as they enter. All classrooms will have natural light and will share treehouse-like spaces where students can work in groups or just reflect.

headline: Why an Atlanta Institution Can’t Seem to Expand
keywords: ['Fast Food Industry', 'Hot Dogs and Frankfurters', 'Restaurants', 'Small Business']
abstract: The Varsity created its own menu language from top to bottom, and that is surely a big part of the reason it has achieved world renown.
lead_paragraph: Here is the thought that flashed through my mind as I washed down my Red Dog (hot dog with ketchup) with an F.O. (frosty orange) and a side of Strings (fries): If the Varsity can sell a thousand Naked Walking Dogs (hot dog to go on a plain bun) every day of the week from a restaurant that has become an Atlanta institution, why can’t it stamp out locations all over the state, region or even country?

headline: Why San Francisco Is Not  New York
abstract: As people debate if San Francisco is the new New York, it seems that San Francisco is just repeating a cycle that’s been going for a very long time.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For some time, people have been saying that San Francisco is transforming into another, different kind of big city.

headline: Intimate Ritual in a Ghostly Abyss
abstract: A production by the British band the xx, in residence at the Park Avenue Armory through March 29, is as much an art installation as it is a concert.
lead_paragraph: A pressurized hush in a cavernous space: That was the sensory impression left by the xx toward the end of its mesmerizing performance at the Park Avenue Armory on Wednesday night. Considering the setting and the band’s trademark sound — its drowsy clarity and terse interiority — the feeling itself wasn’t a stretch. What gave it depth was a larger context that often seemed as much an art installation as a concert, and at every moment like a dynamic, self-aware commentary on the issue of scale.

headline: European Officials Reach Deal on Failed-Bank System
abstract: The agreement, subject to approval by the European Parliament and national governments, would be a big step toward a banking union in the euro zone.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union lawmakers and finance officials reached a political agreement early Thursday on the structure of a system meant to prevent failing banks from unleashing the kind of havoc that has periodically threatened the survival of the euro in recent years.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Seeks to Start $2 Billion Hedge Fund
abstract: The former International Monetary Fund chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking to drum up interest in the DSK Global Investment Fund, a “global macro fund.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:41 a.m. | PARIS – Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking to translate his extensive experience at the top levels of global policy-making into a lucrative career as an investment manager, hoping to raise $2 billion for a hedge fund, one of his partners in the venture said on Thursday.

headline: Daily Report: Entrepreneurs in Hong Kong Place Their Bets on Bitcoin
abstract: A growing number of technology experts, financial players and entrepreneurs believe that mainland China’s unfavorable regulation of Bitcoin has put Hong Kong on the edge of something big.
lead_paragraph: By day, David Shin is an investment banker at a major financial firm. By night and in pretty much every other free minute, he is an entrepreneur looking to break into Hong Kong’s growing Bitcoin scene, Alan Wong reports.

headline: Questioning the Leverage Ratio
abstract: The New York Fed president’s concerns are said to have delayed a banking rule. | Questions about why seven Dewey & LeBoeuf employees who have pleaded guilty have not been identified. | The Federal Reserve is continuing to taper its bond-buying program. | JPMorgan Chase sells its physical commodities unit.
lead_paragraph: Since the financial crisis, William C. Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, has made significant changes to bolster the bank’s supervision efforts. But now, some regulators are blaming him for holding up a proposed rule to make banks safer, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. Mr. Dudley is said to have privately expressed his concerns to senior Fed officials in Washington about the rule, known as the supplementary leverage ratio, frustrating other regulators who see it as a centerpiece of a financial system overhaul.

headline: The Draw of a Mail-Order Art School
abstract: The archives of the Famous Artists School are going to the Norman Rockwell Museum.
lead_paragraph: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. — For more than two decades, the promise of art shined forth from advertisements in the back pages of comic books and magazines. But the ads had nothing to do with beauty or form or eternal verities. They were clip-out visions of art’s more tangible rewards: a paycheck, an escape from the blue-collar grind, maybe even a glamorous career perched at an easel.

headline: Forward Thinking, Backward Mind
abstract: “Robert Heinecken: Object Matter” displays both this photographer’s technically experimental, media-savvy work and his obliviousness to the advent of feminism.
lead_paragraph: The conceptual photographer Robert Heinecken, who died in 2006 at 74, was ahead of his time in some ways — and hopelessly retrograde in others. The technically experimental, media-savvy work he made in the 1960s and ’70s paved the way for appropriation artists like Richard Prince and Sherrie Levine, and for the digital-image samplers who dominate photo exhibitions today. Yet much of it looked, and still looks, oblivious to the advent of feminism.

headline: Confucian Purity, Glacially Formal Yet Glowering
abstract: “Treasures From Korea,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, shows how Neo-Confucianism dictated an austere, highly disciplined aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — If you don’t know much about traditional Korean art, you might be perplexed, as I was, by “Treasures From Korea: Arts and Culture of the Joseon Dynasty, 1392-1910,” at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. With the promise of treasures in mind, I was looking forward to works of spectacular opulence, craftsmanship and imagination among the approximately 150 paintings, sculptures, ceramics, furnishings, robes and more on view. Much to my puzzlement, what I found was an aesthetic and an ethos of sober, even oppressive restraint.

headline: One Man, Two Wheels, 4,122 Miles
abstract: At 57, the reporter Bruce Weber decided to ride a bike from Oregon to New York, a trip similar to one he had made nearly 20 years before.
lead_paragraph: A man in the grip of a midlife crisis often gets himself a new set of wheels: a Porsche or a Jaguar or a Mustang convertible. But at 57, Bruce Weber, the author of the memoir and travelogue “Life Is a Wheel,” opted for a different vehicle, a shiny red custom-made titanium bicycle, which he resolved to ride from the Pacific Coast to the Atlantic.

headline: Remembering a Young Ukrainian Student
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Thoughts as the coffin of a young student passed by, killed in a traffic accident in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Bharatiya Janata Party Announces Second Race For Modi
abstract: The fifth list of candidates for the Indian parliamentary elections has Narendra Modi and a senior leader, Lal Krishna Advani, each running for a seat from the state of Gujarat.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Bharatiya Janata Party’s fifth list of candidates for the general elections confirmed that Narendra Modi, the party’s prime ministerial nominee, would be contesting for a parliamentary seat in his home state of Gujarat, in addition to one in Varanasi. The party also assigned a senior leader, Lal Krishna Advani, to Gandhinagar, in Gujarat.

headline: In Our Pages: March 21
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: The final scene of Richard Strauss’s last opera, “Capriccio,” performed by the Orchestre National de l’ORTF in France, in 1974.

headline: Britain Fines Former Credit Suisse Trader Over Bond Manipulation
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority says the trader, Mark Stevenson, tried to sell British government bonds back to the Bank of England for an artificially high price.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Another day, another iteration of financial fraud innovation.

headline: Harlan Coben: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Missing You” and “Tell No One” says most of his classmates probably remember him “more for the basketball I was dribbling than the book I may have been carrying.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Missing You” and “Tell No One” says most of his classmates probably remember him “more for the basketball I was dribbling than the book I may have been carrying.”

headline: President of Apollo Global to Step Down
abstract: Marc Spilker, 49, who joined Apollo Global Management in December 2010, helped Leon D. Black’s company set up the systems it would need as a publicly traded entity.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:56 p.m. | Marc Spilker, the president of Apollo Global Management, plans to leave the giant private equity firm, according to an announcement on Thursday.

headline: Bloomberg Hints at Curb on Articles About China
abstract: Comments from the chairman of Bloomberg L.P. represent the starkest acknowledgment yet by a senior Bloomberg executive that the ambitions of the news division should be assessed in the context of the business operation.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The chairman of Bloomberg L.P. said in a speech here on Thursday that the company should have reconsidered articles that deviated from its core of coverage of business news, because they jeopardized the huge sales potential for its products in the Chinese market.

headline: Can Sing and Smolder and Play Leading Man
abstract: Steven Pasquale has generated excitement as the kind of bona fide leading man that Broadway perpetually hungers for and has trouble holding onto.
lead_paragraph: When that hunky guy in jeans and cowboy boots sends his bari-tenor soaring at the Schoenfeld Theater, one can’t help wondering: Why hasn’t he been in a Broadway musical before?

headline: Obama Rules Out Military Force Over Ukraine
abstract: President Obama said that the United States will mobilize diplomatic resources “to punish Russia for its seizure of Crimea.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said on Wednesday that he had ruled out the use of United States military force in the Ukraine crisis, and that the international response to Russia’s seizure of Crimea will be limited to diplomacy.

headline: Art Is the Theme at a Cape Town Hotel
abstract: During Cape Town’s turn as a World Design capital, one hotel offers an entree into the arts scene.
lead_paragraph: With its year as World Design Capital 2014 underway, Cape Town’s designers, artists and architects are having a moment in the spotlight.

headline: Sexual Misconduct Case Ends With No Jail Time for General
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'Courts-Martial']
abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, who pleaded guilty to mistreating his mistress and other charges, will not serve time in prison.
lead_paragraph: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — Bringing an end to a closely watched military sexual misconduct trial, a judge on Thursday reprimanded Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair for, among other offenses, mistreating an Army captain who was his mistress, but did not sentence him to jail time and allowed him to remain in the military.

headline: Review: In ‘Divergent,’ Jolted Awake by Fear and Romance
abstract: In its movie incarnation, Veronica Roth’s dystopian novel “Divergent” has high-stakes action, a gutsy teenage heroine who is an outlier, and romance between warriors.
lead_paragraph: Women warriors are on the rise again in American movies, and so, too, are hopes that they’ll be able to strike where it counts: in the industry’s executive suites.

headline: Rare Glimpses of Iran’s Lost Underworld
abstract: Kaveh Golestan’s photographs of prostitutes in Tehran’s red-light district before the 1979 revolution are on view in Amsterdam through May 4.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Kaveh Golestan was 52 on the bright spring day he died. He was killed in a minefield in northern Iraq in 2003 while working as a cameraman with the BBC.

headline: Book on Gettysburg Wins $50,000 Military History Prize
abstract: “Gettysburg: The Last Invasion,” by Allen C. Guelzo, wins the first annual Guggenhiem-Lehrman Prize in Military History.
lead_paragraph: A book about the battle of Gettysburg triumphed over some 100 other nominees to win the first Guggenheim-Lehrman Prize in Military History, which was founded last year to bolster the status of military history and is to be awarded annually.

headline: Corporate Lies Are Increasingly Immune to Investor Complaints
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Corporations', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: A recent court ruling in Germany, along with a pending case before the United States Supreme Court, could make it harder for investors to recoup damages tied to company fraud.
lead_paragraph: Companies do not have a right to lie to their shareholders, a German judge ruled this week. But sometimes, she added, lies are necessary.

headline: Agreement Ends Lockout of M.L.S. Referees
abstract: Major League Soccer used replacement officials for the first two weeks of the season while its referees’ union negotiated a new collective bargaining agreement.
lead_paragraph: The union representing Major League Soccer’s game officials ratified a new collective bargaining agreement Wednesday, ending a lockout that had led the league to use replacement referees and assistant referees for the first two weeks of the season.

headline: Douglas Merrill of ZestFinance: Steer Clear of What You Can’t Measure
abstract: The chief of a big-data company says using processes that can’t be quantified often means you aren’t asking the right questions.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Douglas Merrill, chief executive of ZestFinance, a big-data company that focuses on underwriting, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: NYT Now: Australian Premier on Lost Jet
abstract: Tony Abbott held a news conference after the announcement of the discovery of two objects in the Indian Ocean that may be related to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: Tony Abbott held a news conference after the announcement of the discovery of two objects in the Indian Ocean that may be related to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: The Last of Us Claims a Top Video Game Prize
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Contests and Prizes']
abstract: This somber story of a man and a teenage girl’s trek across a post-apocalyptic American landscape won three awards on Wednesday at the Game Developers Choice Awards, including game of the year.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The Last of Us, the somber story of a man and a teenage girl’s trek across a post-apocalyptic American landscape, won three awards here on Wednesday at the Game Developers Choice Awards, including game of the year. Other games that won multiple awards were BioShock Infinite, which won for best visual art and best audio, and Papers, Please, which won the innovation award and the award for best downloadable game.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Mama Said…’
abstract: This Poetry Pairing features the poem “Mama Said…” by Mary Moore Easter and the article “Oldest Woman in New York Celebrates Birthday No. 114″ by Michaelle Bond.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “Mama Said…” by Mary Moore Easter and the article “Oldest Woman in New York Celebrates Birthday No. 114” by Michaelle Bond.

headline: New Capital Could Raise Airbnb Value To $10 Billion
abstract: The couch-surfing company is close to raising more than $400 million in a new round of financing, which could give it a valuation of more than $10 billion, people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Airbnb is poised to join the 11-digit club.

headline: Port Agency Investigates Boy’s Ascent of World Trade Center
keywords: ['1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Justin Casquejo, 16, slipped past security guards early Sunday and climbed to the top of the tower, which is still under construction.
lead_paragraph: Authorities are trying to determine how a 16-year-old New Jersey boy sneaked past security at 1 World Trade Center and spent two hours early Sunday making his way to the top of the 1,776-foot tower, which is still under construction.

headline: Australian Premier Discusses Search
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia spoke at a news conference and said his government would do all it could to help find the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia spoke at a news conference and said his government would do all it could to help find the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: American Dance Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: The American Dance Festival’s 2014 season, taking place June 12 to July 26 in Durham, N.C., features 24 companies and choreographers, some American, some hailing from as far as Ireland, Israel and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Shall We Dance is not a question; it’s the theme of the American Dance Festival’s 2014 season, taking place June 12 to July 26 in Durham, N.C., on the campus of Duke University.

headline: Obama Steps Up Russia Sanctions in Ukraine Crisis
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: President Obama also opened the door to more sweeping measures against core parts of the Russian economy, including the oil and natural gas industries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama expanded sanctions against Russia on Thursday, blacklisting a bank and several wealthy businessmen with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin, as the United States struggled to forestall further Russian incursions into Ukraine.

headline: German Panel Says Medieval Treasure Should Not Be Returned to Heirs of Jewish Owners
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: A panel in Germany recommends that the Guelph Treasure remain in a museum in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A medieval ecclesiastical treasure acquired by the Prussian state in 1935 and later presented by Hermann Göring to Hitler as a “surprise gift” was legally purchased from a consortium of Jewish art dealers, whose heirs have no rightful claim at restitution, a panel convened by the German government said Thursday.

headline: In Iran, Hopes Fade for Surge in the Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Energy and Power', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Confronted with a lack of funds, President Hassan Rouhani has little option but to take steps that will increase the pain for the voters who put him into office.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Suffering in an economy dragged down by years of mismanagement and the effects of international sanctions, Iran’s increasingly impoverished middle class voted in huge numbers last summer for President Hassan Rouhani, who promised to reignite growth by restoring ties with the rest of the world.

headline: U.N. Warns of Anti-Muslim Violence in Central African Republic
abstract: Navi Pillay, the human rights chief, also criticized the slow international response to what she said was a humanitarian catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Thousands of Muslims in the Central African Republic remain in danger of being slaughtered despite the presence of international peacekeepers, Navi Pillay, the United Nations human rights chief, warned on Thursday, criticizing the international community for a slow and inadequate response to the country’s humanitarian catastrophe.

headline: Ukraine Upheaval Highlights E.U.’s Past Miscalculations and Future Dangers
abstract: The situation has only underscored Europe’s divisions and exposed the chasm between the bloc’s high-minded aspirations and the rough reality of geopolitics.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — When antigovernment protesters first took to the streets of the Ukrainian capital, Kiev, late last year, José Manuel Barroso, the president of the European Union’s executive arm, applauded the demonstrators for “writing the new narrative” for a 28-nation bloc weighed down by economic gloom and growing public skepticism about its purpose.

headline: EchoAge and Other Better Ways to Do Birthday Presents
abstract: EchoAge enables children to get one sizeable cash gift to use for a special birthday present while giving an equivalent amount of money to charity. The catch? You have to let your children ask their friends’ parents for money.
lead_paragraph: Like many of you, I suspect, I’ve long felt a little empty inside when I see the giant pile of presents awaiting children at birthday parties they host for their friends.

headline: New Kyle Abraham Works Inspired by Fights for Freedom
abstract: New York Live Arts will present two weeks of world premieres by Kyle Abraham inspired by the anniversary of the Emancipation Proclamation and by the civil rights movements in South Africa and the United States.
lead_paragraph: New York Live Arts, the Chelsea home of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, will present two weeks of world premieres choreographed by Kyle Abraham, the center’s 2012-14 resident commissioned artist.

headline: In Book, Architect of Health Law Predicts a Shift Away From Employer Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In a new book, Ezekiel J. Emanuel estimates that private-sector workers with employer-provided health care will fall below 20 percent by 2025 from about 60 percent now.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ezekiel J. Emanuel, who helped devise the Affordable Care Act, has a vision for how it will eventually work. Democrats hope it will not materialize anytime soon.

headline: Times Minute | The New Sandy Hook
abstract: A look at the designs for the new Sandy Hook Elementary School. Also on the Minute, General Jeffrey A. Sinclair ‘s sentence for sexual misconduct and museums’ efforts to attract donations.
lead_paragraph: A look at the designs for the new Sandy Hook Elementary School. Also on the Minute, General Jeffrey A. Sinclair ‘s sentence for sexual misconduct and museums’ efforts to attract donations.

abstract: A look at the designs for the new Sandy Hook Elementary School. Also on the Minute, General Jeffrey A. Sinclair ‘s sentence for sexual misconduct and museums’ efforts to attract donations from the millennial generation.

headline: Wheelies: The Baby Engine Boom Edition
abstract: G.M. announces its new generation of small Ecotec engines; BMW says it will increase U.S. production.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Former Naval Academy Football Player Is Acquitted of Sexual Assault
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: A military judge found Joshua Tate not guilty on charges of sexual assault, and Mr. Tate resigned from the Naval Academy in exchange for a withdrawal of a lesser charge of lying.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A military judge on Thursday found a former United States Naval Academy football player, Joshua Tate, not guilty of sexually assaulting a fellow midshipman when she was too drunk to consent, bringing partial resolution to a highly publicized case that has lasted for nearly two years.

headline: $80 Million for 6 Weeks for Cable Chief
abstract: Robert D. Marcus will receive a severance payment that amounts to more than $1 million a day for the six weeks he ran Time Warner Cable before agreeing to sell.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | Robert D. Marcus became chief executive of Time Warner Cable at the start of the year. Less than two months later, he agreed to sell the company to its largest rival, Comcast, for $45 billion.

headline: Former Head of Piper Jaffray Asset Management Switches to Consulting Role
abstract: Brien M. O’Brien, who ran the asset manager Advisory Research, which Piper Jaffray purchased in 2010, will now serve as a consultant to that unit.
lead_paragraph: The investment firm Piper Jaffray has hired its own former head of asset management as a consultant.

headline: Group Suggests New Rules for Further Cuts in Carbon Pollution
abstract: The Natural Resources Defense Council, which has had a strong voice in efforts to shape President Obama’s climate change agenda, sent a proposal to the Environmental Protection Agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An influential environmental group on Thursday released a new analysis suggesting major climate change regulations that could lead to even steeper cuts in carbon pollution than those being considered by the Obama administration.

headline: Old-Meets-New Accommodations at the Hotel d’Angleterre in Copenhagen
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Swimming Pools']
abstract: The historic property was deconstructed, pieced back together and filled with highbrow art. Come for the Warhol, stay for the pool.
lead_paragraph: Sybarites in need of an escape — and a spectacular pool to float in — should consider a visit to Copenhagen’s Hotel d’Angleterre. The historic, centuries-old property was completely taken apart and reconstructed last spring, a two-year undertaking that restored many original details, including Art Nouveau cornices, fireplaces and corridors that were originally built wide enough for ladies in crinolines to pass each other comfortably. A vintage framed oil portrait of the young Queen Victoria, painted by Franz Xaver Winterhalter, hangs in the lobby, while a limited-edition Andy Warhol silkscreen of Queen Margrethe II of Denmark sits perched above the reception desk.

headline: Fred Phelps, Anti-Gay Preacher Who Targeted Military Funerals, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Phelps’s Westboro Baptist Church drew scornful attention for proclaiming in rallies that God was punishing America for tolerating homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — The Rev. Fred Phelps, the virulently antigay preacher who drew wide, scornful attention for staging demonstrations at military funerals as a way to proclaim his belief that God is punishing America for its tolerance of homosexuality, died here on Wednesday. He was 84.

headline: Obama Delivers Statement on Ukraine
abstract: President Obama announced that the United States was imposing sanctions on more Russians because of that country’s actions in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced that the United States was imposing sanctions on more Russians because of that country’s actions in Crimea.

headline: In Shift, Exxon Mobil to Report on Risks to Its Fossil Fuel Assets
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The energy giant has been pressured by shareholders to show how it plans to cope with the risks posed to its holdings by potential limits on greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: Energy companies have been under increasing pressure from shareholder activists in recent years to warn investors of the risks that stricter limits on carbon emissions would place on their business.

headline: WeChat Valuation Is Still Just a Hunch
abstract: While the parent of WeChat has disclosed some information about the messaging and social media service, its true valuation is still largely a matter of speculation, writes Robyn Mak of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Putting a value on WeChat remains an act of faith. Its parent, the Internet giant Tencent, has shed some light on WeChat, the popular messaging and social media service, but sparse details about costs and regulatory risks make future growth and earnings potential hard to pin down. Valuations are still largely based on hope.

headline: The Diminishing Returns of Modern Medicine
abstract: In-hospital mortality after an acute heart attack has dropped 10-fold, from 30 percent to 3 percent, since the invention of the modern cardiac care unit in the 1960s. Can shaving a few more minutes off the time it takes to get hospital treatment possibly yield any additional benefit?
lead_paragraph: For several decades, doctors have taken it as an article of faith that more rapid treatment of an acute heart attack improves patient survival. The treatment of choice today is angioplasty, where tiny balloons and wire-mesh cylinders called stents are used to open up blockages in the arteries that feed the heart. A “door to balloon,” or D2B, time – the period from a patient’s arrival in the hospital to inflation of the coronary balloon – of less than 90 minutes has become a quality metric for American hospitals. “Time is muscle” is the operative mantra, and the shorter the delay, the better.

headline: A New Phantom and Christine Are Coming to the Opera
abstract: Norm Lewis will take over as the Phantom and Sierra Boggess as Christine in “The Phantom of the Opera.”
lead_paragraph: Norm Lewis, who starred as Porgy in “The Gershwins’ Porgy and Bess,” will join the cast of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “The Phantom of the Opera” on May 12, succeeding Hugh Panaro in the title role. At the same performance, Sierra Boggess will take over the role of Christine Daaé from Mary Michael Patterson.

headline: Only Seeding Reminds Virginia of Sampson Days
abstract: Virginia (28-6) is a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time since 1983 on the strength of its team defense, the nation’s stingiest, not on the talents of any one superstar.
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — If Ralph Sampson raised Virginia’s national profile and gave the men’s basketball program its identity in the 1980s, he remains the towering measure of every team that has come through Charlottesville since.

headline: Twitter Rolls Out Easier, Faster Video Playback
abstract: Twitter has begun rolling out a new platform for hosting video that gives iPhone and Android phone users a preview of a video clip in their feeds and allows them to play it with a single click.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, Twitter has worked closely with television networks and other professional video creators to upload and promote thousands of video clips on the service, from sports highlights to previews of coming shows.

headline: Image of the Day: March 20
abstract: The Dalai Lama holding the hand of a leprosy-affected patient in New Delhi.

headline: Koch Group, Spending Freely, Hones Attack on Government
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Americans for Prosperity, backed by the Koch brothers, is using a data-driven approach as it pursues its overarching goal of changing the way voters think about government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans for Prosperity — the group backed by David H. and Charles G. Koch that has been pouring millions of dollars into competitive Senate races to the rising alarm of Democrats — was also among the politically active groups on the ground in this month’s special House election on Florida’s Gulf Coast.

headline: Transparency Comes to the Port Authority, but Not to Christie’s Appointee
abstract: After decades of secrecy about their multi-billion dollar operations, commissioners at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey this week began casting important votes in public.
lead_paragraph: After decades of secrecy about their multi-billion dollar operations, commissioners at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey this week began casting important votes in public. Only at this strange, behemoth of an agency would this be news.

headline: Reid Orders Computer Review to Defend Senate Committee in Rift With the C.I.A.
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Detainees', 'Interrogations']
abstract: Senator Harry Reid said he had ordered a forensic examination of the Senate Intelligence Committee’s computer equipment to answer what he called “absurd” C.I.A. claims.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, said on Thursday that he had ordered a forensic examination of the Senate Intelligence Committee’s computer equipment to answer what he called the C.I.A.’s “absurd” claims that the committee’s staff had hacked into the agency’s network.

headline: Clip: ‘The French Minister’
abstract: A scene from Bertrand Tavernier’s film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Bertrand Tavernier’s film.

headline: Text to Text | Groundbreaking Women, Then and Now
abstract: For this edition of Text to Text, we paired Times articles with two videos from the Makers series from AOL and PBS that we thought worked particularly well together to raise questions about how women’s lives and struggles have, and haven’t, changed over the last two generations.
lead_paragraph: For this edition of Text to Text,  we celebrate Women’s History Month by collaborating with the Makers project, a digital and broadcast initiative from AOL and PBS that showcases stories of groundbreaking women from all walks of life.

headline: Modern Love | Fight or Flight
abstract: As her relationship with her boyfriend was coming to an end, the writer Sarah L. Courteau grasped for a moment of tenderness between them.
lead_paragraph: As her relationship with her boyfriend was coming to an end, the writer Sarah L. Courteau grasped for a moment of tenderness between them.

headline: Malaysia Official on Objects in Ocean
abstract: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said reports from Australian authorities of objects floating in the Indian Ocean were “a credible lead” in the search for the missing plane.
lead_paragraph: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said reports from Australian authorities of objects floating in the Indian Ocean were “a credible lead” in the search for the missing plane.

headline: Lawrence E. Walsh, Prosecutor in Iran-Contra Scandal, Dies at 102
abstract: As an independent counsel, Mr. Walsh exposed the lawbreaking in the administration of President Ronald Reagan that gave rise to the Iran-contra scandal.
lead_paragraph: Lawrence E. Walsh, a former federal judge and a mainstay of the American legal establishment who as an independent counsel exposed the lawbreaking in the Reagan administration that gave rise to the Iran-contra scandal, died on Wednesday at his home in Oklahoma City. He was 102.

headline: An Act of Protection, Even as Things Fell Apart
abstract: His small act of kindness could not be forgotten, though the daily dust of the relationship had settled.
lead_paragraph: Cigarette smoke drifted in the bedroom window. My boyfriend always went outside to smoke, which I appreciated, though lately the smell wafting in had become, more than anything, a reminder of his absence from our bed. I could picture him at the table in our garden, the ashtray bristling with old butts and the red tip of his cigarette hovering over the glow of his phone screen.

headline: Not Giving Up, Bouygues Raises Bid for Vivendi’s Mobile Unit
abstract: The owner of France’s third-largest mobile operator increased its bid despite Vivendi’s decision to enter an exclusive negotiating period with Altice. Bouygues said it raised its bid to 13.15 billion euros, or about $18.12 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Bouygues said Thursday that it had sweetened its offer for SFR, Vivendi’s mobile phone unit, despite Vivendi’s decision last week to enter into exclusive negotiations with Altice for three weeks.

headline: Sadness Is Part of March, Too, as Dayton Upends Ohio State
abstract: Vee Sanford’s shot with less than four seconds left was the difference for Dayton when Aaron Craft of sixth-seeded Ohio State missed as time expired.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Aaron Craft lay on the floor, his arms behind his head, staring up at the arena ceiling, as if the hardcourt were a poolside chaise longue.

headline: TimesTalks: James Franco & Chris O’Dowd
abstract: The actors James Franco and Chris O’Dowd discuss making their Broadway debuts in Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men.”
lead_paragraph: The actors James Franco and Chris O’Dowd discuss making their Broadway debuts in Steinbeck’s “Of Mice and Men.”

headline: Unemployed? You Might Never Work Again
abstract: The long-term unemployed tend to be a little older, a little more educated, a little less white than recently unemployed but there is a good chance they’ll never work again, says a new economic paper.
lead_paragraph: The long-term unemployed “are an unlucky subset of the unemployed.” They tend to be a little older, a little more educated, a little less white – but really they’re not that different from the broader pool of people who have lost jobs in recent years. Except for one thing: There is a good chance they’ll never work again.

headline: ‘Friction’ by Alex Seel
abstract: Edwin David Sepulveda collaborated on a 24-foot-high, 100-foot-wide mural with three artists in Manhattan in November.
lead_paragraph: Edwin David Sepulveda collaborated on a 24-foot-high, 100-foot-wide mural with three artists in Manhattan in November.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: How to let others know that you’re not changing your name, and advice for a family friend who was initially invited to the wedding, then uninvited.
lead_paragraph: ‘I Took My Husband, Not His Name’

headline: After Trailing Early, Wisconsin Goes on 40-6 Run to Rout American
abstract: When Coach Bo Ryan’s Badgers began making shots, any notion of a No. 15 seed beating a No. 2 drifted away in the West Region.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — American provided a little angst early for Wisconsin fans who drove from all around the state to watch the Badgers’ opening game of the N.C.A.A. tournament here.

headline: The Gun Report: March 20, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Some good news: Gang shootings are down in Chicago, according to the city’s police chief. Garry McCarthy said Tuesday that his strategy to reduce gang violence is taking root, and gang shootings now represent less than half of the total number of shooting incidents in the city.

headline: N.C.A.A. Round of 64: The Day in Pictures
abstract: All the action from the first day of the round of 64 in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.
lead_paragraph: All the action from the first day of the round of 64 in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Pistorius Plans to Sell His House to Cover Legal Costs, Lawyer Says
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: As he stands trial for the murder of his girlfriend, Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star, plans to sell the house where he admits shooting her, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: Facing the need to raise money for legal fees as he stands trial for the murder of his girlfriend, Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee track star, plans to sell the house where he admits shooting her, a lawyer said on his behalf on Thursday.

headline: Big Data, the Feature
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Is understanding customer behavior the holy grail of business, or just a feature inside application performance? A company called New Relic thinks that the attributes it shows software developers can be tweaked to say a lot about what consumers are doing, and it can deliver that information without a lot of complex analysis.
lead_paragraph: What if big data, that much-proclaimed multibillion-dollar hope of the enterprise software industry, is just a feature of something else?

headline: Sierra Club Trips for Younger Travelers
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Focusing on those 30 and under, the Sierra Club is offering trips and discounts for younger participants.
lead_paragraph: In order to take more young people into the wilderness and bring them onto its membership rolls, the Sierra Club is offering trips (some with discounts) that it hopes will entice the 30-and-under crowd.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: The Country They Love and Hate
abstract: For our KGB spies, Elizabeth and Philip, American values are seductive and repellant all at the same time.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, for Episode 2, we explored the question of whether Nina would ultimately side with Stan or the Soviet Union. Annet Mahendru, who plays Nina, retweeted the piece.

headline: Trial Lawyer Nominated to Lead Delaware Chancery Court
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Andre G. Bouchard, who has represented both plaintiffs and defendants in corporate battles, was nominated on Thursday to lead Delaware’s Chancery Court, the nation’s leading court for business disputes.
lead_paragraph: Andre G. Bouchard, an experienced trial lawyer who has represented both plaintiffs and defendants in corporate battles, was nominated on Thursday to lead Delaware’s Chancery Court, the nation’s leading court for business disputes.

headline: Pluralism and Power
keywords: ['AMISH', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Education (K-12)', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Does pluralism get easier when the minorities requesting exemptions are weaker?
lead_paragraph: I want to return briefly to the Emily Bazelon piece I discussed yesterday, because I don’t think my comments quite teased out the interesting tangles in her argument, and their potential implications for how debates about religious pluralism tend to play out.

headline: The Latest Flimsy Excuse for Blocking Jobless Benefits
abstract: John Boehner said he would reject the deal because it could increase fraud and abuse.
lead_paragraph: There was never much doubt that Speaker John Boehner would try to block the deal to extend unemployment benefits that was reached in the Senate last week. The only real question was what ridiculous justification he would come up with, and the one he chose on Wednesday exceeded expectations.

headline: Improving a Signal Chain: Part 1
abstract: This recording of a simulation by the company ARUP renders an M.T.A. announcement as normally heard in the subway, before various simulated improvements to the signal chain have been implemented.
lead_paragraph: This recording of a simulation by the company ARUP renders an M.T.A. announcement as normally heard in the subway, before various simulated improvements to the signal chain have been implemented.

headline: Improving a Signal Chain: Part 2
abstract: In this second simulation, improvements have been made to the M.T.A. station’s public announcement system. The booth and microphone have been redesigned to minimize background noise, and better cabling helps remove the hiss. Better loudspeakers and station acoustics all combine to make the announcement more audible.
lead_paragraph: In this second simulation, improvements have been made to the M.T.A. station’s public announcement system. The booth and microphone have been redesigned to minimize background noise, and better cabling helps remove the hiss. Better loudspeakers and station acoustics all combine to make the announcement more audible.

headline: The Search for Silence
abstract: We’re always taking in what our environment looks like, but have we become inured to what it sounds like?
lead_paragraph: There is a brilliant art installation at the Headlands Center for the Arts in Sausalito, Calif. It’s also a working bathroom. The project upends everything we take for granted about a bathroom — something we assume to be pristine, porcelain, private.

headline: Nodding From East to West
abstract: The look at Fung Tu suggests a modern, upscale take on an old-school Hong Kong coffee shop, but the menu goes beyond Western-ish Chinese comfort food.
lead_paragraph: Fung Tu at night is a faint red glow on a block of almost Chinatown on the Lower East Side. Inside, the booths are puritanical, with stiff backs of dark stained wood, overlooked by mirrors and crimson wallpaper in a study of drifting leaves.

headline: Spread No Ill Will
abstract: Addressing matters of discussing a family illness, keeping party leftovers, quieting a colleague and buying secondhand clothes for others.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I recently shared with a small circle of family and friends the news that our young daughter was found to have leukemia. It’s a hard time for us, especially for our little girl, who has started a difficult round of treatments. Most of the people we’ve told have been incredibly supportive, except my best friend, who hasn’t said a word to me. This is making me furious. I would like to be honest with him. (Frankly, I’d like to punch him out.) But I’m not sure that anything is going to repair how I feel about him. So why bother, right? Or not?

headline: Former Aide to S.E.C. Leaders Joins Consulting Firm
abstract: Myron Marlin, a former top aide to the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has joined FTI Consulting, a prominent firm in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Myron Marlin, a former top aide to the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has joined a prominent consulting firm in Washington.

headline: A Graffitist Takes On a Corporate Space
abstract: Edwin David Sepulveda, who for years has painted under the name Don Rimx, has, for the moment, transformed a retail space in Midtown into an art gallery.
lead_paragraph: Since uprooting from Puerto Rico six years ago, Edwin David Sepulveda, 32, has tagged, tattooed and painted in locales from his new home of Bushwick, Brooklyn, to Barcelona, Spain, under the name Don Rimx.

headline: Most Large Banks in U.S. Could Cope in Event of Turmoil, Fed Says
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The Fed, in its latest annual stress test of financial system, said the banks had adequate capital to withstand a severe downturn.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all of the nation’s largest banks have adequate capital to withstand a severe economic downturn and market turmoil, the Federal Reserve has found in its latest annual stress test of the United States financial system.

headline: A Duncan Admirer Leads Pittsburgh’s Rout
abstract: With a game modeled on Tim Duncan’s, Talib Zanna scored 18 points on 6 of 7 shooting and made all six of his free throws to lead Pittsburgh over Colorado in a South Region game.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — As a youngster in Nigeria, Talib Zanna watched an old videotape of a San Antonio game and was inspired by the play of Spurs center Tim Duncan.

headline: Japan and North Korea Said to Agree to Formal Talks
abstract: Japan made the announcement as the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has been trying to score a coveted diplomatic success.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan and North Korea agreed on Thursday to hold formal talks for the first time in more than a year, Japanese officials said, as the government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan tried to achieve a coveted diplomatic success.

headline: Syria Delivers Another Shipment of Chemical Weapons for Disposal
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The shipment to the port of Latakia was the third delivery in a week, further evidence that Syria has stepped up the pace of its efforts.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Syria delivered another consignment of deadly chemical weapons to the port of Latakia on Thursday, the third delivery in a week to be shipped abroad for destruction and further evidence that it has stepped up the pace of shipments after coming under international pressure over earlier delays.

headline: Areas of Search for Malaysian Jet
abstract: Satellite imagery captured near the Australian search areas shows objects that officials said could be related to the missing Malaysian plane.
lead_paragraph: Satellite imagery captured near the Australian search areas shows objects that officials said could be related to the missing Malaysian plane.

headline: A Collector Changes Course
abstract: Sotheby’s will handle the sale of contemporary works by Dan Flavin, Cindy Sherman and others from the collection of Adam D. Sender.
lead_paragraph: WITH LIFE CHANGE, COLLECTOR TO SELL CONTEMPORARY WORK

headline: Following Dylan Thomas in Wales
abstract: A century after the late Welsh poet was born, visiting places where he lived, wrote and stopped in for a pint (or more).
lead_paragraph: Climbing along a steep coastal path through a forest in southern Wales, with russet red and tawny brown autumn leaves crunching beneath my feet, I reached a crest where the trailhead looked back onto a long estuary lined with salt flats. The River Taf ran through the headlands before me, its glacier-cut course unmistakable alongside the grass-covered cliffs on either side. The sea spread out before me, a moody canvas of blues and gray. White-topped gorse and cherry-red currant bushes gave color to my panorama, the plaintive chorus of sea birds the only soundtrack.

headline: Living With Cancer: The Cost of Trials
abstract: A recent CT scan made me realize that the clinical trial extending my life effectively excludes all but the most privileged cancer patients.
lead_paragraph: A recent CT scan made me realize that the clinical trial extending my life effectively excludes all but the most privileged cancer patients.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: sleeping teenagers, house pests and toxic fish. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: sleeping teenagers, house pests and toxic fish. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Obama Imposes More Sanctions on Russia
abstract: The president said the United States is imposing sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in addition to the current sanctions on individuals.
lead_paragraph: The president said the United States is imposing sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in addition to the current sanctions on individuals.

headline: Pursuing Sex With a Bad Boy
abstract: “It Felt Like Love” considers the dangers of teenage desire through the experiences of a coltish 14-year-old girl who randomly fixes on a weed-smoking tough guy.
lead_paragraph: A mood poem to summer loving and sexual awakening, “It Felt Like Love” powerfully evokes a time when flesh is paramount, and peer behavior is the standard by which we judge our own.

headline: Symantec Fires Chief Seen as Too Slow on Innovation
abstract: The board of Symantec, the troubled antivirus company, voted to fire Steve Bennett, its chief executive, in a special meeting on Tuesday evening, citing revenue declines and a diminished focus on new product innovation.
lead_paragraph: Symantec, the troubled antivirus software maker, has fired Steve Bennett, its chief executive, the company said on Thursday.

headline: A Hot Pick, No. 12 Seed Harvard Shows Why
abstract: Harvard, a 12th seed, beat fifth-seeded Cincinnati on Thursday afternoon, a year after beating third-seeded New Mexico in its opening N.C.A.A. tournament game.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Last year was a surprise. This year, even the president saw it coming.

headline: Limits on Ivory Sales, Meant to Protect Elephants, Set Off Wide Concerns
abstract: Several industries say they are frustrated and confused by new regulations that strictly limit the sale of elephant ivory.
lead_paragraph: New federal rules aimed at blocking the sale of ivory to protect endangered elephants are causing an uproar among musicians, antiques dealers, gun collectors and thousands of others whose ability to sell, repair or travel with legally acquired ivory objects will soon be prohibited.

headline: Terrace for Sale, Includes Condo
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Condominiums', 'Balconies and Terraces']
abstract: In a concrete jungle, there is a hefty dollar value attached to having your own garden oasis.
lead_paragraph: After a seemingly endless winter, the first hints of spring have teased us with a day or two of temperatures over 60 degrees. That fleeting glimpse of warmth sent many New Yorkers flying out of doors to enjoy the sunshine. For my part, I sipped my morning coffee at home last week and stared wistfully out the window at a neighbor’s balcony.

headline: Kingmaker’s Death Lays Bare Erosion of Parties’ Authority
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Robert S. Strauss was central to Democratic Party power in the 1970s, a role that has been overtaken by national candidates in recent years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Robert S. Strauss headed the Democratic Party in the early 1970s, he was a man of unusual sway. A phone call could change a presidential campaign, or at times, even the presidency itself. He held the exalted status of wise man in the capital, a kingmaker who helped bring Jimmy Carter to power and Ronald Reagan to recognize the damage from Iran-contra, a man with such inside knowledge of power, politics and relationships that he could make all manner of problems go away.

headline: Golden Gate Buys Stake in Parent of Ann Taylor
abstract: Golden Gate, the private equity firm, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it had purchased a roughly 9.5 percent stake in Ann Inc., with the aim of bolstering the retailer’s stock price.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Golden Gate Capital prides itself on its retail expertise, having helped revive companies like Eddie Bauer and Zale. Now it thinks it can aid the parent of Ann Taylor.

headline: A New Weapon for Bidding Wars
abstract: Some lenders offer “pre-underwriting” to put buyers who must borrow on par with those offering to pay in cash.
lead_paragraph: In response to the fierce competition for homes in healthy metropolitan markets like those surrounding New York City, some mortgage lenders are taking steps to put buyers who must borrow on par with those offering to pay in cash.

headline: Iranian Ship, in Plain View but Shrouded in Mystery, Looks Very Familiar to U.S.
abstract: Iran is building a nonworking mock-up of an American nuclear-powered aircraft carrier that United States officials say may be intended to be blown up for propaganda value.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran is building a nonworking mock-up of an American nuclear-powered aircraft carrier that United States officials say may be intended to be blown up for propaganda value.

headline: A Cop With a Secret
abstract: Cory Monteith plays a street hustler in “McCanick,” the story of a cranky police detective (David Morse) with something to hide.
lead_paragraph: The dour “McCanick” banks way too much on what it is not telling us, making for a movie that thinks it’s being cryptically suspenseful but is really just annoying. The film was one of the last projects for Cory Monteith, the “Glee” star who died of a drug overdose last year, and it would have benefited from more screen time for him and less for its title character, a growly police detective with a dark secret.

headline: Hedge Fund Uses Hitler Parody in Campaign Against Ocwen Chairman
abstract: Glaucus Research, a little-known hedge fund in California, has started an attack on the billionaire William C. Erbey, the chairman of Ocwen Financial, and to publicize its efforts, it has posted a video based on the widely parodied German film “Downfall.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for a little attention, it’s hard to go wrong with Hitler.

headline: Was It Fatal for You, Darling?
abstract: My big anxiety around sex in my 30s was, will he call me? The big anxiety now is, what do I do in the case of cardiac arrest?
lead_paragraph: I have been dating age-appropriate men, and I must tell you that sex with men in their late 60s can make you a nervous wreck.

headline: Get. Arts. Fast.
abstract: New York has a vast tolerance for marathon entertainment. But the city also has a need for speed that only cultural sprints can satisfy.
lead_paragraph: AT the Vineyard Theater on a recent Friday night, the lights dimmed at 8, and Alexandra Silber began singing her heart out. In a set evoking an ordinary middle-class American living room, she sang of love and loss, of her new soldier husband fighting thousands of miles away, of her mother’s many visits to the plastic surgeon, of her pregnancy and of her growing suspicions that her darling husband might be committing atrocities.

headline: Syracuse’s Zone Is Sharp in Opening Win
abstract: Syracuse, which had lost five of its last seven games entering the N.C.A.A. tournament, ran out to a 15-4 lead and had no trouble with Western Michigan the rest of the way.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — There was a thought, by some, that 14th-seeded Western Michigan might have the right formula to topple Syracuse on Thursday afternoon. The Broncos would be prepared for the Orange’s vaunted 2-3 zone. After all, they were familiar with the 2-3 employed by Eastern Michigan, coached by Rob Murphy, a former Syracuse assistant.

headline: Pro-Clinton Group Plans Event Focused on Gay and Lesbian Donors
abstract: A “super PAC” supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton’s possible presidential campaign is reaching out to some of New York’s most powerful and wealthy gay and lesbian donors.
lead_paragraph: A “super PAC” supporting Hillary Rodham Clinton’s possible presidential campaign is reaching out to some of New York’s most powerful and wealthy gay and lesbian donors.

headline: Staging a Rescue From Obscurity
abstract: A New York show on the prominent mid-20th-century sculptor Germaine Richier is evidence that not every artist whose work languishes in obscurity is unjustly ignored.
lead_paragraph: We live in what might be called the era of “no artist left behind.” It’s a period of sometimes exhilarating excavation and rediscovery during which art history has become larger and more inclusive. It encompasses more kinds of people from different parts of the world and all kinds of backgrounds — as opposed to art-school educated white men from the United States and Europe. It also encompasses more mediums, from ceramics to performance art.

headline: What’s in Veterans Affairs’ $164 Billion Budget?
abstract: The secretary of veterans affairs wants the spending to expand health care access and other benefits to veterans, to clear a still-extensive backlog of disability claims and to end homelessness among veterans.
lead_paragraph: The secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric K. Shinseki, last week, outlined President Obama’s 2015 budget for the department before hearings of the House and Senate veterans affairs committees, calling for total spending of $163.9 billion, a 6.5 percent increase from last year. The plan asks Congress to allocate $68.4 billion for discretionary spending, a 3 percent increase from last year, which is largely used for health care, and $95.6 billion for mandatory programs such as disability compensation and pensions for veterans.

headline: Army General Speaks Out After Sentencing
abstract: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair gave a statement outside the courthouse at Fort Bragg, N.C., after the conclusion of the sentencing phase of his sexual misconduct trial.
lead_paragraph: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair gave a statement outside the courthouse at Fort Bragg, N.C., after the conclusion of the sentencing phase of his sexual misconduct trial.

headline: Muppets, a Front for Bigger Schemes
abstract: “Muppets Most Wanted,” an international caper, includes shots at Russians and the sly skewering of our European allies.
lead_paragraph: The United States government today called on Walt Disney Pictures to delay or cancel the release of “Muppets Most Wanted” on national security grounds. Or at least, it should have. Not only might this movie annoy Russia, with whom the American government is already nose-to-nose over Crimea, but it could also cause any European allies being courted by President Obama to unfriend him and the rest of the country.

headline: ‘Desperately Seeking the Exit’ Memorializes a Flop
abstract: Peter Michael Marino’s “Desperately Seeking the Exit” self-deprecatingly memorializes his flop of a musical version of the film “Desperately Seeking Susan.”
lead_paragraph: Coming of age more or less in the mid-1980s, the Miser witnessed firsthand what could only be described as Madonnamania. For several heady years, that pop provocateur reigned, writing the rule book for today’s dynamic divas, from Lady Gaga to Lorde.

headline: Still Doleful, Still Impulsive
abstract: John Zorn introduced 20 new songs, part of the third and ostensibly final collection in his Masada project, at the Town Hall on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Even for a composer as famously prolific as John Zorn, the repertory designated as Masada — a single strand in a multifarious oeuvre — verges on overwhelming. Introduced in 1993, Masada was born of a fairly straightforward idea: wedding the Jewish klezmer style to the rollicking free-jazz ethos of Ornette Coleman.

headline: The Grandest Block in New York
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The grandest block in New York may very well be 91st Street from Fifth to Madison.
lead_paragraph: No one agrees on the “best block” in the city — some people like the crooked alleyways of Greenwich Village, or the picturesque brownstone rows of Brooklyn. Some people like cute little stores; some people like doormen with white gloves.

headline: Facebook’s Hack, a Language of Tech Competition
abstract: The world’s biggest social network introduced on Thursday a new open-source software language that is focused on helping to build interactive web pages. Besides winning geek credibility, it’s the latest version of a decades-old effort in tech to win over as many developers as possible.
lead_paragraph: [ Updated | Added reference to the open source programming language developed in part by Google. ]

headline: Is It Raging Lust, or Youthful Angst? Either Way, She’s Taking a Beating
abstract: In “Nymphomaniac: Volume I,” directed by Lars von Trier, Charlotte Gainsburg plays a woman who endures suffering in the pursuit of sex.
lead_paragraph: Attentive filmgoers who stuck it through Lars von Trier’s 2009 movie “Antichrist” — a deranged heave with a dead child, talking fox (“chaos reigns”) and his-and-her mangled genitalia — might have noticed a strange closing credit for “researcher on misogyny.” It seemed like a joke, especially given that the movie pivots on a crazy woman (Charlotte Gainsbourg) who, consumed by grief, and having made the extremely bad call to undergo treatment by her therapist husband, mutilates them both. Yet several other credits, including researchers on “anxiety,” “theology” and “mythology and evil,” suggested that Mr. von Trier wasn’t kidding even if, oh, maybe he was.

lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: ‘Moderate’ Tag a Label to Fear for Republicans
abstract: In the 1990s, Texas Senate Democrats used “crazy right-winger” to describe incoming Republicans, but now politicians who have been labeled moderates by party mates are fighting to prove their conservatism.
lead_paragraph: Jane Nelson, a Republican of Flower Mound, was considered a “crazy right-winger” when she was elected to the Texas Senate in 1992.

headline: Ukrainian Nationalists Hand Russians Propaganda Coup With Video of Assault
abstract: By recording their own act of violence against a television executive, Ukrainian nationalist politicians delivered a propaganda coup to their enemies in Russia, who claim that mob rule prevails in Kiev.
lead_paragraph: Since a coalition of Ukrainian opposition groups took control of Independence Square in Kiev and held it long enough to undermine the authority of President Viktor Yanukovych, the Russian government and news media outlets under Kremlin control have consistently focused on the part played by far-right, nationalist demonstrators who manned the barricades there during deadly clashes with the police.

headline: Oregon Shuts Down High-Scoring B.Y.U.
abstract: Brigham Young entered the contest averaging 84.2 points per game, third best in the country, but fell to Oregon.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Oregon slowed Brigham Young’s high-powered offense enough to advance in the West Region, getting strong contributions off the bench from the Milwaukee product Elgin Cook and others to win, 87-68.

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 84
abstract: Officials from FIFA were back in Brazil on Thursday to start another round of stadium inspections.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Welcome Home. Just Avoid the Headgear
abstract: “Awakened,” a thriller starring Julianne Michelle, follows a woman who has returned to her hometown to investigate her mother’s death.
lead_paragraph: Superlatively silly in concept and execution, Joycelyn Engle and Arno Malarone’s “Awakened” fully believes that it’s a psychological thriller about a traumatized young woman. In reality, however, it’s a poorly acted grab bag of shopworn ideas and hyperbolic behaviors that not even Ryan Murphy could translate into entertainment.

headline: Deportees as Pawns in a Zero-Sum Tragedy
abstract: The documentary “From Both Sides of the Aegean” revisits the forced ouster of Orthodox Greeks from Turkey and Muslim Turks from Greece in the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: The full title of the new documentary by Maria Iliou, “From Both Sides of the Aegean: Expulsion and Exchange of Populations, Turkey-Greece: 1922-1924,” is quite a mouthful. It not only describes the subject but also gives a sense of the film’s dry, dense and sometimes convoluted style of exploring this otherwise fascinating subject.

headline: Tales of Legends and Curiosities
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company begins a run at City Center with some of its namesake’s Greek-inspired work, as well as a new piece by a Greek choreographer.
lead_paragraph: The Martha Graham enterprise is growing quainter and quainter, though heaven knows it remains earnest. On Wednesday the company Graham founded almost 88 years ago began its season at City Center with a gala celebrating the connection between her and Greece.
