abstract: The town manager discusses efforts to reduce drug use.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Search of a Duck, and a Way Through That Awkward Age
abstract: This coming-of-age comedy, starring Ben Kingsley, is the first feature directed by Rob Meyer.
lead_paragraph: “That’s the great thing about this field,” Lawrence Konrad (Ben Kingsley), a bird-watching fanatic, declares to a group of adolescent followers in “A Birder’s Guide to Everything.” “It doesn’t matter if you’re a high school kid on your bike, or if you’re an egghead like me with a boatload of degrees. Anybody can be a birder.”

headline: Shaker Artifacts Are on the Move
abstract: As the estates of dealers and collectors go to auction, pieces are flying to museums or back to the Shaker villages whence they came.
lead_paragraph: SHAKER ARTIFACTS DOING THE SHUFFLE

headline: A Quick Way to Cut College Costs
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Tuition', 'Parenting', 'Pell Grants', 'Scholarships and Fellowships']
abstract: Congress should slash the amounts parents are asked to pay for college.
lead_paragraph: COLLEGE admission notifications have begun to arrive. With every thrilling acceptance comes something far less welcome: the heart-stopping reality of what it all costs.

headline: Foot Is the New Traffic for Urban Cowboys
abstract: Completed in 2012, the five-acre Klyde Warren Park was built on a platform over the freeway, providing a walkable link between downtown and uptown Dallas.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, a trip on foot over the busy freeway that separates downtown Dallas from neighboring Uptown would have required a bit of courage.

headline: The Cop and the Crook, Brothers at Odds
abstract: Guillaume Canet’s remake of “Les Liens du Sang” follows two Italian-American brothers, on opposite sides of the law, in Brooklyn in 1974.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood gangster movies, especially those directed by Martin Scorsese and Francis Ford Coppola, have conditioned us to expect every film in the genre to follow particular guidelines or risk feeling inauthentic. That’s the obstacle that the French director Guillaume Canet (“Tell No One”) cannot surmount in “Blood Ties,” his laborious, tonally wobbly attempt at an American crime epic. If it’s unfair to expect a reputable European director to follow that template, so be it. But by now, those expectations have been programmed into us. Every wrong note, of which there are dozens in “Blood Ties,” feels almost traitorous.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for

headline: Arkansas Court Reverses $1.2 Billion Judgment Against Johnson & Johnson
abstract: In a fraud case involving Risperdal, the court said the state’s attorney general erred by suing under a law that applied to health care facilities, not drug companies.
lead_paragraph: The Arkansas Supreme Court reversed a $1.2 billion judgment against Johnson & Johnson on Thursday, finding that the state attorney general erred by suing under a law that applied to health care facilities, not drug companies.

headline: Tracing an Activist Through Decades
abstract: In “American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs,” the director Grace Lee chronicles the life of a 98-year-old woman of Chinese descent who shares her name.
lead_paragraph: Plumbing the achievements of a 98-year-old activist, “American Revolutionary: The Evolution of Grace Lee Boggs” also grapples with the daunting challenge of political awareness. The director Grace Lee, who met her subject while making a movie about people who share her name (“The Grace Lee Project”), shadows this variable exploration of identity and engagement with an acknowledgment of generational shifts in sensibility, including her own perspective.

headline: A Long-Overdue Dialogue With Beethoven
abstract: Leif Ove Andsnes is finally taking on Beethoven, making up for lost time with performances including a recital on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Many young virtuoso pianists perform the Beethoven sonatas as a demonstration of their musical depth. But when he emerged as a major young artist, the Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes avoided Beethoven. He thought he should wait until he had “something to say,” as he explained in 2012 in an appearance at the Greene Space in the WQXR and WNYC radio studios.

headline: Nassau County Prosecutor’s Decision to Seek House Seat Is Rooted in Family
abstract: Kathleen M. Rice, who after eight years as the county’s district attorney is seeking the seat of the retiring Carolyn McCarthy, comes from a large family steeped in politics.
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — “Being raised in a family of 10, everything was negotiated, everything was a compromise,” Kathleen M. Rice, the Nassau County district attorney, said the other day in her office here.

headline: Doug Wheeler: ‘LC 71 NY DZ 13 DW’
abstract: Stepping into this all-white, light-and-space installation was akin to moving through a dense cloud.
lead_paragraph: David Zwirner

headline: House Ethics Panel Investigating Illinois Congressman
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The Ethics Committee is focusing on whether Representative Luis V. Gutiérrez, a Democrat, violated House rules when he hired a former aide as a consultant.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Luis V. Gutiérrez, Democrat of Illinois, is the subject of a House Ethics Committee investigation focused on whether he improperly hired a former aide turned Illinois lobbyist as a consultant, using federal tax dollars to pay for the work, the lawmaker’s office confirmed Thursday.

headline: Sarah Lucas: ‘Nud Nob’
abstract: How far can you go with an art career based on limited set of puerile dirty jokes? Pretty far, if you’re Sarah Lucas.
lead_paragraph: Gladstone

headline: Alone Then, Supported Today
abstract: Freida Mock’s documentary about Anita Hill, who accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment during his Supreme Court confirmation hearings, segues from 1991 to the present.
lead_paragraph: With the new documentary “Anita,” the Oscar-winning director Freida Mock (“Maya Lin: A Strong Clear Vision”) brings a fresh perspective to a somber and awkward chapter of modern American politics: the Senate hearings to confirm Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court amid accusations of sexual harassment by Anita Hill.

headline: Israel: Settlement Plans Renew Palestinian Outrage
abstract: Revelations this week over Israel’s continuing construction plans for West Bank settlements renewed outrage among Palestinian leaders.
lead_paragraph: Revelations this week over Israel’s continuing construction plans for West Bank settlements renewed outrage among Palestinian leaders even as the two sides face critical decisions in the American-led peace talks that started last summer. Israel’s Interior Ministry on Wednesday posted online the minutes of a Feb. 19 committee meeting during which more than 2,000 housing units, including 839 in the city of Ariel, advanced through the bureaucratic process, the antisettlement group Peace Now said Thursday. Also on Wednesday, the city of Jerusalem granted building permits for nearly 200 apartments in two Jewish neighborhoods in East Jerusalem, which most of the world considers to be illegal settlements. (About 50 permits for Arab areas were also approved.) “This has to stop,” said Hanan Ashrawi, a member of the executive committee of the Palestine Liberation Organization. “Building is not just building, it’s not something that is so benign. Building is the willful destruction of the two-state solution. It’s a constant act of aggression. It’s a war crime.”

headline: With a French Accent, a Soap Brand Tells a Tale of Well-Scrubbed Lovers
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Sustainable Living', 'Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps']
abstract: Method is introducing a series of quirky commercials that depict a young couple meeting at a party, falling in love, moving in together and having a baby.
lead_paragraph: CONSUMERS making major life transitions are often in the market for big-ticket items, which is why there are so many cap-tossing graduates, newlyweds and newborns in commercials from real estate companies, automakers and banks. But now milestones are at the center of an advertising campaign for a decidedly smaller purchase: household products.

headline: ‘Tibet and India: Buddhist Traditions and Transformations’
abstract: Floating high in a small gallery above the Metropolitan Museum’s South Asian and Southeast Asian galleries is a jewel of a show.
lead_paragraph: Metropolitan Museum of Art

headline: Strangers, but Their Eyes Meet on a Train to Paris
abstract: In “Just a Sigh,” a middle-aged actress traveling from Calais follows an intriguing stranger to a funeral and starts an affair.
lead_paragraph: In “Just a Sigh,” the French star Emmanuelle Devos plays Alix, a rudderless, beautiful, middle-aged actress first glimpsed in Calais waiting to go onstage in a production of Ibsen’s “The Lady From the Sea.” Alix commutes between Calais and Paris, where she lives with Antoine (voiced by Denis Ménochet), her lover of eight years. He is a documentary filmmaker who is unseen in the movie but heard over the telephone.

headline: Syria’s War Fuels Rise of Asylum Seekers, U.N. Report Says
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The number of people applying for asylum in industrialized countries rose in 2013 to the highest number in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The number of people applying for asylum in industrialized countries rose in 2013 to the highest number in more than a decade, increased to a large extent by Syrians seeking refuge in the West, the United Nations refugee agency reported Thursday.

headline: Florida Fends Off Pesky Great Danes
abstract: The Gators, the No. 1 overall seed in the tournament, put away No. 16 Albany with a strong run in the second half.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Florida Gators own the N.C.A.A. tournament’s No. 1 overall seed and have not lost in more than three months. So expectations were rightfully high despite the pressure of facing an overmatched opponent looking to make history.

headline: Events in Connecticut for March 23-29
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: You Load the Uzi, Honey
abstract: Based on real-life events, Raymond De Felitta’s “Rob the Mob” centers on a Queens couple who go on a holdup spree at Mafia social clubs.
lead_paragraph: Real-life tragedy receives a comic-caper makeover in “Rob the Mob,” Raymond De Felitta’s breezy retelling of one of New York City’s more unusual crime sprees.

headline: A Fortuitous Chicken Saves Lives in East Harlem Blast
abstract: The Urban Garden Center in East Harlem, known for its concerts and for taking in fowl, was the subject of a Neighborhood Joint column in Metropolitan in 2012.
lead_paragraph: The chicken that would save their lives was, at first, a concern. It was perched on the netting above a coop at the Urban Garden Center in East Harlem. Someone had tossed the bird over the fence, in a red paper Macy’s bag, and Anthony Douglas and another worker were trying to figure out how to bring it down.

headline: Michigan State Opens With an Easy Win
abstract: Fourth-seeded Michigan State, a team many believe could win the national championship, rolled past No. 13 Delaware.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Michigan State, a team many experts predict could be the rare fourth seed to win the national championship, embarked on its latest quest with a breezy 93-78 win over No. 13 Delaware.

headline: Art Book Depicting Murder Inc. Is No Steal
abstract: The collector’s edition of “The Brownsville Boys: Jewish Gangsters of Murder, Inc.” is lavishly illustrated, printed and boxed, and sells for $4,200 per copy.
lead_paragraph: Not that anyone is out to make a killing, but a new book on the mob hit men of Murder Inc. will cost you.

headline: Wind Industry’s New Technologies Are Helping It Compete on Price
keywords: ['Wind Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: With new technology, the industry has been able to produce more power at lower cost by capturing the faster winds that blow at higher elevations.
lead_paragraph: The wind industry has gone to great lengths over the years to snap up the best properties for its farms, often looking to remote swaths of prairie or distant mountain ridges to maximize energy production and minimize community opposition.

headline: An Irish Romance With an Uncertain Future
abstract: In “Stay,” a young woman living in Ireland gets pregnant and heads back home to Montreal.
lead_paragraph: An expatriate in rural Ireland gets restless in her relationship with an older man and questions her commitment in the light drama “Stay.” Because of the lukewarm scenarios and signpost-filled screenwriting, audiences may well follow suit with their own antsiness.

headline: Amy Arbus: ‘On the Street 1980-1990’
abstract: In the 1980s, when Ronald Reagan was president and Gordon Gekko said greed was good, Amy Arbus photographed New Yorkers who thought fame was better.
lead_paragraph: Leica Gallery

headline: Going Home Again
abstract: Sting reminds us all that sometimes you have to gaze back into the past in order to move forward.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The TED conference is dedicated to innovation. Most of the people who give TED talks are working on some creative project: to invent new bionic limbs for amputees, new telescopes, new fusion reactors or new protest movements to reduce the power of money in politics.

headline: Russia Hints at Using Iran Talks as Leverage
abstract: While the most recent round of nuclear talks with Iran was regarded as productive, Russia suggested that it might impede them later.
lead_paragraph: Despite public assurances by Western officials, concern is growing that the escalating animosity between the United States and Russia over the Ukraine crisis could have a corrosive effect on the nuclear talks with Iran.

headline: The Timidity Trap
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Policy makers have good ideas in principle for tackling terrible economic conditions, yet they consistently go for half-measures in practice and kill all hope.
lead_paragraph: There don’t seem to be any major economic crises underway right this moment, and policy makers in many places are patting themselves on the back. In Europe, for example, they’re crowing about Spain’s recovery: the country seems set to grow at least twice as fast this year as previously forecast.

headline: Mayor Vows Jail Reforms on Rikers Island
abstract: Bill de Blasio called the death of a mentally ill veteran in an overheated cell at the city’s sprawling jail complex “shocking and troubling.”
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday called the death of a mentally ill veteran in an overheated cell on Rikers Island “shocking and troubling” and vowed to make reforms to the city’s sprawling jail complex, where violence has surged in recent years.

headline: If Only Orson Welles Had Starred
abstract: “Jodorowsky’s Dune” is a documentary about the Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky’s efforts in the 1970s to turn the science fiction novel “Dune” into a feature film.
lead_paragraph: A making-of special about a film that was never made, “Jodorowsky’s Dune” details the mid-1970s efforts of the Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky to translate Frank Herbert’s extravagant science fiction novel “Dune” to the big screen.

headline: Israel Confirms Fate of 8 Jews Who Left Iran
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The Mossad intelligence agency confirmed that the eight would-be immigrants were murdered when they disappeared in 1994, but did not say where or by whom.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s intelligence agency announced Thursday it had confirmed the murder of eight Jews who disappeared while trying to immigrate to Israel two decades ago, but it did not say where they were killed or by whom.

headline: Adam Scott Fights an Illness and Ties a Record
abstract: Despite having flulike symptoms, Scott shot a 62 at Bay Hill, where he had struggled in previous tournaments.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Since his victory in the 2013 Masters, Adam Scott has traveled extensively with his size 40 green jacket, eliciting a wide-eyed delight from friends and strangers alike that gives him a joy nearly equal to the win itself.

headline: Netflix Chief Alters View on Net Neutrality
abstract: Reed Hastings said that once Netflix agreed to pay Comcast for a better connection, Netflix customers no longer experienced delays streaming video.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month after Netflix insisted that its deal to pay Comcast to get a more direct connection to the company’s Internet pipes had nothing to do with net neutrality, Netflix’s chief executive, Reed Hastings, said Thursday that, well, yes it did.

headline: An Empty Suit, but Such Fine Material
abstract: In “The French Minister,” Thierry Lhermitte embodies classy chaos in the title role of Bertrand Tavernier’s dry, sly farce about diplomatic life.
lead_paragraph: Whoosh. When the title character slams a door in Bertrand Tavernier’s dry, sly comedy “The French Minister,” the walls shudder, and papers and people go flying. A man on the furious move, Alexandre Taillard de Worms isn’t only the French minister of foreign affairs, with a name that’s a meaningful mouthful, but he’s also a force of nature or maybe of bureaucracy. Sleek, coifed and buffed, with tailored suits and brilliantly shined shoes, he looks like one of the more sober masters of the universe, even if his violent gestures and the wreckage he leaves in his wake make him a closer kin to that old cartoon menace, the Tasmanian Devil, than to one of the boldface names running La France.

headline: Time Inc. May Join Media Exodus to Lower Manhattan
abstract: After being a fixture in Midtown Manhattan for more than seven decades, the magazine publisher is considering relocating to an area that has become a lower-cost alternative for corporations.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc., with its stable of magazines, lavish offices and steady profits, has been a fixture in Midtown Manhattan for more than 75 years and the nation’s premier magazine publisher.

headline: A Singular Trumpeter Unreels His Life
abstract: In the one-man show “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” John Douglas Thompson vividly resurrects Louis Armstrong as he reminisces about a life that spanned a vast cultural divide.
lead_paragraph: There is a wonderful Milt Hinton photograph of Louis Armstrong in 1954, standing by his beloved reel-to-reel tape recorders, which he took with him everywhere to record performances and memories. It’s this Armstrong — relaxed, intimate and gregarious — that John Douglas Thompson vividly resurrects in Terry Teachout’s “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” a one-man show at the Westside Theater.

headline: This Week’s Movies: March 21, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Divergent,” “The Missing Picture” and “Nymphomaniac: Volume I.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Divergent,” “The Missing Picture” and “Nymphomaniac: Volume I.”

headline: On Russia’s List for Sanctions, and Proud of It
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Travel restrictions placed by Moscow on American officials like Senators John McCain and Mary L. Landrieu were accepted as a “badge of honor.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia might have hoped that American lawmakers and officials targeted for “reciprocal sanctions” on Thursday would respond with fear or outrage. Instead, the reaction was more like a synchronized spit-take combined with a bipartisan declaration of pride unseen since President Richard M. Nixon assembled his enemies list.

headline: Mayor’s Ouster Is Approved in Colombia
abstract: Gustavo Petro lost his fight to remain mayor of Bogotá after President Juan Manuel Santos approved an order to remove him and bar him from holding public office for 15 years.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The leftist mayor of Bogotá, Colombia, lost his fight to stay in office after President Juan Manuel Santos approved an order to remove him and bar him from holding public office for 15 years.

headline: Credit Suisse Hires Senior Power Banker From RBC Capital Markets
abstract: Credit Suisse has hired Frank Napolitano as its new head of its power and renewables investment banking group, poaching him from RBC Capital Markets, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse has hired a new head of its power and renewables investment banking group from RBC Capital Markets, the firm announced in an internal memorandum on Thursday.

headline: Complaint Against Kibkalo
abstract: Alex A. Kibkalo has been accused of handing over trade secrets, including prerelease software updates for Windows 8 RT, to an industry blogger while he was employed by Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: Alex A. Kibkalo has been accused of handing over trade secrets, including prerelease software updates for Windows 8 RT, to an industry blogger while he was employed by Microsoft.

headline: Microsoft Software Leak Inquiry Raises Privacy Issues
keywords: ['Privacy', 'E-Mail', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: The company conducted an inquiry by reading through email and instant messages, which may violate its promise of privacy, highlighting the power technology companies have to snoop on their customers.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Technology companies have spent months denying they know anything about broad government spying on people who use their Internet services.

headline: Despite Critics, de Blasio Finds Success in Pursuit of Liberal Agenda
abstract: In fits and starts, the mayor has steadily found ways to impose his liberalism onto New York City.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, these are rocky days for Mayor Bill de Blasio, whose infant tenure has endured impasse in Albany, speeding police escorts, and poll numbers that have rapidly diminished.

headline: Venezuelan Mayors Are Jailed Amid Protests
abstract: The authorities jailed the mayors of San Cristóbal and Valencia, two cities that have seen some of the most intense unrest in the wave of protests shaking the country.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — The authorities have jailed the mayors of two cities that have experienced some of the most intense unrest in a wave of protests that has shaken the country in recent weeks. The arrests came as the National Assembly called for a criminal investigation of a prominent opposition lawmaker on charges related to the demonstrations.

headline: Tough Path for Closer After Liner to the Face
abstract: Reds pitcher Aroldis Chapman was scheduled to have surgery after a line drive shattered bones above his nose and left eye, a play that stirred uncomfortable memories for the Rays.
lead_paragraph: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — The Tampa Bay Rays scurried around their clubhouse Thursday afternoon, tracking the N.C.A.A. tournament and playing a hockey video game. Just one TV, in the corner of the room above Desmond Jennings’s locker, showed baseball highlights. It was best not to concentrate on those.

headline: A Father’s Legs and an Uncle’s Skills
abstract: Nick Johnson was taught by his father, a celebrated leaper, to cultivate the all-around abilities that took his uncle, Dennis Johnson, to the N.B.A. Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Nick Johnson looks familiar, and it goes beyond playing guard for Arizona and being named the Pacific-12 Conference player of the year. It might be his 6-foot-3 build, his eyes and eyebrows, the constellation of freckles across his nose.

headline: Apple After Jobs: Pretty Much the Same as Ever
abstract: A new book on Apple’s state after Steve Jobs paints a dire picture of a company losing its way. Farhad Manjoo disagrees.
lead_paragraph: You could be forgiven, after reading “Haunted Empire: Apple After Steve Jobs,” for concluding that Apple is on the verge of going belly up. In the new book by Yukari I. Kane, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, the company is depicted as having radically declined after the death of its former impresario.

headline: Panel Proposes Changes to New Jersey Bail System
keywords: ['Bail', 'State Legislatures', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: A group led by the chief justice of New Jersey’s Supreme Court called for changes in the state’s bail system and recommended a law setting specific timelines for indictments and trials.
lead_paragraph: Criminal defendants in New Jersey would be held or released based on the risk they pose, rather than merely their ability to pay, under major changes to the state’s bail system proposed by a panel led by the chief justice of New Jersey’s Supreme Court.

headline: ‘The Technology Is Out There,’ but Satellites Don’t Track Jets
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Satellites']
abstract: The airline industry has sophisticated tools to follow planes and stream data from their flight recorders. But given cost and the general safety of air travel, neither the airlines nor regulators have used them.
lead_paragraph: Airlines routinely use satellites to provide Wi-Fi for passengers. But for years they have failed to use a similar technology for a far more basic task: tracking planes and their black-box flight recorders.

headline: Arena’s Meditation Room Raises Its Own Existential Questions
abstract: A new addition at Barclays Center offers a place for quiet reflection during Nets games. One question so far: What is the sound of an empty room?
lead_paragraph: Construction has barely begun on the 2,250 promised affordable housing units. Just one of the 15 proposed towers has even started to take root. The leafy plazas remain mere sketches on paper.

headline: Ukraine Sets Deadline for Militias to Surrender Illegal Guns
abstract: So-called self-defense groups were ordered to disarm by Friday, the same day Ukraine is scheduled to sign the political articles of an association agreement with the European Union.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In an effort to stabilize Ukraine and extend its authority, the interim government has set a deadline of Friday for turning in the illegal firearms that are now carried openly by so-called self-defense groups in Independence Square, the politically important plaza in the center of the capital.

headline: A Livelihood in Nuclear Waste, Under Threat
abstract: The Waste Isolation Pilot Plant, the nation’s only permanent underground repository for nuclear weapons waste, revived Carlsbad, N.M. But it has been closed since a leak.
lead_paragraph: CARLSBAD, N.M. — For 15 years, workers from this dusty New Mexico town have made the 26-mile drive down a series of worn two-lane highways until reaching a strange complex of alabaster buildings in the middle of the Chihuahuan Desert.

headline: PETA Videos Prompt New York and Kentucky to Investigate Horse Trainers
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: An undercover investigator for the animal rights group gathered evidence of mistreatment of racehorses while working for the trainer Steve Asmussen and his assistant Scott Blasi.
lead_paragraph: The horse racing authorities in New York and Kentucky opened investigations on Thursday into allegations of mistreatment of thoroughbred racehorses by Steve Asmussen, the nation’s second-winningest horse trainer, and his assistant Scott Blasi.

headline: The Plot to Cut Food Stamps, Foiled
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Food Stamps', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Republicans are furious that states have decided to be generous to the neediest families.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party has spent years stigmatizing the food stamp program while trying to cut benefits or make them harder to get. In last month’s farm bill, conservative lawmakers thought they had imposed an $8 billion cut in the program. In the last few weeks, though, it has become clear that that cut isn’t going to materialize, thanks to a few states more generous than Congress. And this has infuriated a party that doesn’t believe that poor families should get public assistance in buying groceries.

headline: North Carolina Planner Named to Head New York City Parks Dept.
abstract: The new parks commissioner, Mitchell J. Silver, has extensive New York experience, with degrees from Pratt Institute and Hunter College.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has chosen an out-of-state urban planner to head the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation, an agency that oversees 29,000 acres of parkland and 1,900 parks, according to officials with firsthand knowledge of the decision.

headline: A Fire Department for the 21st Century
abstract: This week’s settlement ends a long, bitter battle, but more fixes are needed for a firehouse culture still rooted in the past.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio acted in the interest of justice when his administration agreed on Tuesday to pay nearly $100 million to black and Latino citizens who were either denied jobs as firefighters or hired years after they should have been based on a screening test that the courts later found to be racially biased.

headline: Battle Lines for Change
abstract: “Witness: Art and Civil Rights in the Sixties,” at the Brooklyn Museum, is a vivid record of a volatile era.
lead_paragraph: “A change is gonna come,” the soul singer Sam Cooke promised in his 1964 hit song. And so it did. Officially, it arrived fast, with the signing into law of the Civil Rights Act that year. In reality, its progress was killingly slow, and by then already a decade old.

headline: Suppressing the Vote
abstract: A misguided federal court ruling opens the door to more anti-voting laws.
lead_paragraph: If a federal judge’s disappointing ruling this week on a voter registration case is allowed to stand, state lawmakers around the country could well make it harder for eligible citizens to register to vote in federal as well as state elections.

headline: The Folly of Thinking We Know
abstract: It’s humbling to see the globe at a loss about the missing plane.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — WE’VE most of us, surely, heard all the figures: Humanity now produces as much data in two days as it did in all of history till the year 2003 — and the amount of data is doubling every two years. In the time you take to read this piece, the human race will generate as much data as currently exists in the Library of Congress. For that matter — yes, your inbox and Facebook page would reflect this — 10 percent of all the pictures ever taken as of the end of 2011 were taken in 2011. Yet as we think about how an entire Boeing 777 has gone missing for almost two weeks now, we’re also painfully reminded of how much we can’t — and may never — know, even in the Knowledge Economy.

headline: Nigerian Army Facing Questions as Death Toll Soars After Prison Attack
abstract: During a jailbreak, many of the fleeing detainees were killed when security forces opened fire, officials said, and the toll could rise to 1,000, making it one of the bloodiest days in the fight against Islamist insurgents.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Well over 500 people were killed in Nigeria last week when security forces responded to what the military portrayed as a jailbreak attempt by the Islamist group Boko Haram, making it one of the bloodiest episodes yet in the military’s five-year counterinsurgency campaign, according to officials in the northern town of Maiduguri.

headline: Health Care Exchange in Oregon Not Meeting High Hopes
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Oregon may have among the most dysfunctional online insurance exchanges in the nation.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — As the federal health care overhaul was rolled out over the last few years, Oregon was invariably the eager overachiever in the first row, waving a hand to volunteer. The governor, John Kitzhaber, a doctor who left the emergency room for politics, made health care his main issue. Fellow Democrats controlling the Legislature went along, embracing ambitious plans to extend insurance coverage and Medicaid to low-income residents.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 20, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 20, 2014

headline: The Health Care Law’s Checkup
abstract: Is the Affordable Care Act working? What needs to be fixed? And what is beyond repair?

headline: Warily Leading Japan’s Nuclear Reawakening
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe could soon return Japan to nuclear power, but first he needs the consent of remote towns like Ikata.
lead_paragraph: IKATA, Japan — To power his plans for Japan’s economic revival, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe could soon return his nation to nuclear power for the first time since the Fukushima accident three years ago. But before he can, he will need the consent of the remote towns like this one that host Japan’s idled nuclear plants.

headline: Debating Fate of Leadership at Minnesota Orchestra
abstract: The Minnesota Orchestra said that Michael Henson, its president, would step down this summer, which could mean the return of Osmo Vanska, the former music director.
lead_paragraph: The day after the Minnesota Orchestra announced the pending departure of its president, who had become something of a lightning rod during a bruising labor battle with its musicians, many orchestra fans in the Twin Cities wondered on Friday if the move might pave the way for the return of the ensemble’s former music director, Osmo Vanska.

headline: After Fires at Golf Courses, Study Suggests Unusual Culprits: Titanium Clubs
abstract: Researchers in California, trying to explain the origin of two recent golf course fires, found that titanium club heads created sparks when they struck rocks.
lead_paragraph: Golf courses are covered in hazards — ponds, bunkers, thick rough — but here is another: the golf clubs themselves.

headline: A Skatepark to Grind and Fly
abstract: At 5050 Skatepark on Staten Island, most of the patrons are on BMX bikes or scooters, and scooter culture rules among the younger set.
lead_paragraph: For the skaters of New York, winter was particularly cruel: Gray snow forming crust on skateable surfaces, railings glazed by ice. And all that wetness just destroys your bearings.

headline: 14-Year-Old Kills Rider on Bus in Brooklyn, Police Say
abstract: A 14-year-old gunman opened fire on a B15 bus on Marcus Garvey Boulevard near Lafayette Avenue on Thursday evening, shooting a 39-year-old man in the head.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old gunman opened fire during a dispute on a New York City bus in Brooklyn on Thursday evening, fatally shooting a 39-year-old passenger in the head, the authorities said.

headline: Sly Alchemy From That Lamp
abstract: The Broadway version of “Aladdin” sticks to the movie’s formula, but also infuses the conventions of the genre with a breezy insouciance that scrubs away some of the material’s bland gloss.
lead_paragraph: If a genie had sprung from my teakettle last week and offered to grant me three wishes, I might impulsively have asked to be spared any more children’s musicals. Since a certain blockbuster feline arrived well over a decade ago, Broadway has been lapped by wave after wave of big, often gloppy songfests adapted from animated movies, mostly from the mother ship, Disney.

headline: Learning How to Refine Oils
abstract: Friday solving fun with Brendan Emmett Quigley.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This, in my opinion, was a nice Friday offering. A bit of a wrestle, a little stretching, a few gimmes, and sooner rather than later the puzzle is solved. Also, Brendan Emmett Quigley makes a clean puzzle and fills it with some very interesting stuff.

headline: A Day of Honors for Women in the Video Game Industry
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Game Developers Conference', 'Women and Girls', 'Xbox (Video Game System)']
abstract: Microsoft’s Women in Gaming Awards began as a series of informal dinners hosted by a group of female developers from the company’s Xbox division.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Female video game designers, producers and directors were honored at Microsoft’s Women in Gaming Awards here on Thursday in an event that has grown substantially in short order.

headline: North Carolina Says Utility Pumped Millions of Gallons of Wastewater in River
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Coal']
abstract: Duke Energy illegally pumped as much as 61 million gallons of coal-ash wastewater into a river from September to last week, North Carolina regulators said.
lead_paragraph: Duke Energy, the electric utility whose massive spill of toxic coal ash into a river six weeks ago is part of a federal investigation, illegally pumped as much as 61 million gallons of coal-ash wastewater into a second river from September to last week, North Carolina regulators charged on Thursday.

headline: UConn Extends Its Redemption Tour
abstract: The Huskies, who were barred from last year’s tournament, rallied past St. Joseph’s to win in overtime.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — The Connecticut Huskies framed their postseason — actually, their entire season — around the fact that last year they watched the N.C.A.A. tournament from home, shut out of the most significant party in college basketball.

headline: Hytner’s Final Season at National Theater to Include New Stoppard Play
abstract: Nicholas Hytner’s last season as the artistic director at the London theater will also include a play by Richard Bean and star turns by Ralph Fiennes and Helen McCrory.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Hytner’s final season as artistic director of the National Theater in London will include new plays by Tom Stoppard (“The Coast of Utopia”) and Richard Bean (“One Man, Two Guvnors”), as well as stars turns by Ralph Fiennes in Shaw’s “Man and Superman” and Helen McCrory in “Medea,” the theater announced on Thursday.

headline: Unions, Harlem and Lindsay, Revisited
abstract: Recently published books take another look at John V. Lindsay’s time as mayor, tour Harlem and examine municipal labor organizations.
lead_paragraph: So far — and it has been nearly a half-century since he left office — history has not been very kind to John V. Lindsay. Joseph P. Viteritti seeks to correct that impression in “Summer in the City: John Lindsay, New York and the American Dream” (Johns Hopkins University Press).

headline: Khushwant Singh, Provocative Indian Journalist, Dies at 99
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'News and News Media', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Sikhs and Sikhism']
abstract: Mr. Singh, a diplomat, journalist and a chronicler of the bloody sectarian strife in India, was also known for his wit and bawdy stories.
lead_paragraph: Khushwant Singh, an Indian diplomat, author and journalist who was one of his country’s best-known chroniclers of strife and slaughter, died on Thursday at his home in New Delhi.

headline: Dayton’s Win Offers Validation for a Former Buckeye
abstract: Jordan Sibert transferred to Dayton after a year at Ohio State during which he clashed with Coach Thad Matta over playing time.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — It took less than two hours for the N.C.A.A. tournament to produce a significant upset: When Dayton’s Vee Sanford beat Ohio State’s Aaron Craft off the dribble and scored on a floater with less than four seconds remaining, the 11th-seeded Flyers were on their way to upending sixth-seeded Ohio State, 60-59.

headline: Davis, Duda or Plan C? Mets Still Don’t Know
abstract: With 10 days before opening day, it is unclear whether either Ike Davis or Lucas Duda, who are competing for the Mets’ starting first baseman’s job, will be ready to start the season.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It has been about three weeks since Ike Davis and Lucas Duda halted their competition for the Mets’ starting first baseman’s job. Davis was sidelined with tight calves while Duda had a tight hamstring.

headline: Ex-Envoy Sees Assad as Staying in Power
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Alawite Muslims']
abstract: The former diplomat Robert S. Ford said he had little hope that diplomacy could solve the long-running conflict in Syria.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The former American envoy for Syria said on Thursday that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria was likely to remain in power for the “medium term” and that a year from now the country would probably still be under the control of competing factions.

headline: House Panel to Hear G.M. Chief’s Testimony
abstract: Mary T. Barra will testify before a House subcommittee as it investigates the response of General Motors to safety problems with the Chevy Cobalt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief executive of General Motors, Mary T. Barra, will testify before a House subcommittee on April 1, and the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration may also go before the panel as it investigates the response of G.M. and the government to safety problems with the Chevy Cobalt, the subcommittee announced on Thursday.

headline: St. Louis Avoids the Upset Bug
abstract: The Billikens were down by 16 to North Carolina State, but a full-court press sparked a rally that turned the game around.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The St. Louis Billikens were in such a downward spiral that an early exit from the N.C.A.A. tournament seemed imminent. They could not crack North Carolina State’s man-to-man defense consistently. They trailed nearly the entire game.

headline: Spare Times for Children for March 21-27
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: THE CATS VS. DOGS FAMILY SCAVENGER HUNT

headline: For One Wolverine, a Sweet Homecoming
abstract: Glenn Robinson III helped Michigan to a victory over Wofford in Milwaukee, where his father played for the Bucks.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Glenn Robinson III remembered coming to Bradley Center as a little boy, watching his father, Glenn, star for the Milwaukee Bucks alongside Ray Allen and Sam Cassell. The chance to play for Michigan in the same building Thursday night thrilled Robinson, who scored 14 points in a tougher-than-expected 57-40 victory over Wofford in the second round.

headline: Russians Take Over Ukrainian Base
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: At the Nakhimov Naval School in Sevastopol, Ukrainian soldiers conducted an official handover and lowered their flag in a tense ceremony, while Russian soldiers stepped in to raise theirs.
lead_paragraph: At the Nakhimov Naval School in Sevastopol, Ukrainian soldiers conducted an official handover and lowered their flag in a tense ceremony, while Russian soldiers stepped in to raise theirs.

headline: Turkish Officials Block Twitter in Leak Inquiry
abstract: Recordings and leaked documents appeared to implicate high-ranking officials and some of their relatives and associates in a widespread corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government blocked Twitter on Thursday night after the social media network had been used to spread recordings of telephone conversations and leaked documents that appeared to implicate high-ranking officials and some of their relatives and associates in a widespread corruption investigation.

headline: Charlotte Brooks, a Photographer for Look Magazine, Dies at 95
abstract: Ms. Brooks gave complexity to the “women’s features” she was assigned to in the postwar years.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Brooks, one of only a handful of women ever hired to work as a full-time staff photographer at Look magazine, the major rival to Life in the heyday of American glossy photojournalism, died on March 15 at her home in Holmes, N.Y. She was 95.

headline: Freshman Comes Off Bench to Seal Upset of Sooners
abstract: After its best player fouled out, North Dakota State beat fifth-seeded Oklahoma in overtime for the Bison’s first N.C.A.A. tournament win.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — North Dakota State’s best player had fouled out, and visions of the university’s first N.C.A.A. tournament victory might have followed his disheartened ramble to the bench.

headline: Spare Times for March 21-27
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, walking tours and other cultural events in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘INVISIBLE MIGRATIONS’ (through Aug. 31) Visual tales of migration and immigration are included in this exhibition of contemporary and late-19th and early-20th-century photographs at the Alice Austen House, 2 Hylan Blvd, at Edgewater Street, Staten Island.

headline: Recalling Jackson’s Detour to New Jersey
abstract: Before he turned to coaching, Phil Jackson dabbled in announcing games on television as an analyst for the New Jersey Nets.
lead_paragraph: Phil Jackson was a television analyst for the New Jersey Nets for one season before he turned to coaching full time.

headline: After World Series Win, Red Sox’ Beards and Memories Are Short
abstract: The World Series champion Red Sox still sport facial hair, but not quite as much as last season’s hirsute bunch.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — They are still a scruffy bunch, happily hirsute.

headline: Times Minute | Will Sanctions Work?
abstract: Expectations for the latest round of sanctions against Vladimir Putin. Also on the Minute, following the money that built the Barclays Center, and who made that standing desk?
lead_paragraph: Expectations for the latest round of sanctions against Vladimir Putin. Also on the Minute, following the money that built the Barclays Center, and who made that standing desk?

headline: In Late-Season Trial, Knicks Have Little Room for Error
abstract: The Knicks face a road-heavy 14-game schedule, with several matchups against strong teams, as they seek to make the playoffs at the expense of the Bobcats or the Hawks.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks’ seven-game winning streak has created a chance, small as it may be, that they can catch the Charlotte Bobcats or the Atlanta Hawks by the end of the regular season and sneak into the playoffs.

headline: Who Made That Standing Desk?
abstract: The antidote to a sedentary life goes back centuries.
lead_paragraph: Standing desks are nothing new. Nor is their use as therapeutics. Recent studies may warn that time spent sitting correlates with heart disease and early death, but such worries go back centuries. “A sedentary life may be injurious,” the Presbyterian minister Job Orton advised in 1797. “It must therefore be your resolute care to keep your body as upright as possible when you read and write; never stoop your head nor bend your breast. To prevent this, you should get a standing desk.”

headline: Beyond the Sea
abstract: The sun-soaked island of Hydra has long inspired artists and intellectuals from Henry Miller to Leonard Cohen, and even today with the influx of art stars and yachting billionaires, its unspoiled charm remains intact.
lead_paragraph: The sun-soaked island of Hydra has long inspired artists and intellectuals from Henry Miller to Leonard Cohen, and even today with the influx of art stars and yachting billionaires, its unspoiled charm remains intact.

headline: To Infinity and Beyond
abstract: This season, fashion looks to the heavens, taking inspiration from both space-age design and the wondrous immensity of the night sky.
lead_paragraph: This season, fashion looks to the heavens, taking inspiration from both space-age design and the wondrous immensity of the night sky.

headline: School Data Finds Pattern of Inequality Along Racial Lines
keywords: ['Equal Educational Opportunities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Minorities']
abstract: Racial minorities are more likely than white students to be suspended from school and be taught by lower-paid teachers with less experience, according data released by the Department of Education.
lead_paragraph: Racial minorities are more likely than white students to be suspended from school, to have less access to rigorous math and science classes, and to be taught by lower-paid teachers with less experience, according to comprehensive data released Friday by the Department of Education’s Office for Civil Rights.

headline: Ask Well: Exercises to Strengthen Bones
abstract: High-impact activities like sprinting and jumping are best at increasing bone density, studies say, but there are benefits from brisk walking and even whole-body vibration platforms.

headline: Idzik Says Jets Seek ‘Sustainable Success,’ Not Quick Fixes in Free Agency
abstract: Jets General Manager John Idzik defended the team’s relative inaction in free agency during a conference call with reporters on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: With the arrival of spring, the Jets are already playing defense.

headline: Taking a Star’s Scholarship Is Creighton’s Secret
abstract: Doug McDermott, Creighton’s best player and the head coach’s son, passed up a scholarship this year so point guard Grant Gibbs could get one.
lead_paragraph: There are 13 scholarship players on Creighton’s basketball team. Its best player, Doug McDermott, is not one of them.

headline: Buzzer-Beater Lifts the Longhorns
abstract: Texas, a seventh seed, won a thriller despite blowing a 14-point lead in the second half.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Cameron Ridley, the 6-foot-9 sophomore center for Texas, said he had never made a game-winning shot before Thursday. Now he has, and a great story comes with it.

headline: Devils Spoil Parise’s Return With Wild
abstract: Nearly two years after leaving the Devils for Minnesota, Zach Parise was greeted with choruses of boos at Prudential Center, and the Wild lost in overtime.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Zach Parise had waited nearly two years for Thursday night.

headline: Chhattisgarh Tests a Green Toilet for Its Poor
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Malaria', 'Population', 'Urban Areas', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Worms']
abstract: The government has seen some success in introducing biodigester toilets in the central Indian state, where three-fourths of the population have no access to latrines.
lead_paragraph: For just 8 cents a day, the slum dwellers on the outskirts of Raipur, the capital of Chhattisgarh State, are able to indulge in what is a luxury to half of India’s population: a working toilet.

headline: Lockout of Officials Ending
abstract: The union representing Major League Soccer’s game officials ratified a new collective bargaining agreement Wednesday, ending a lockout that had led the league to use replacement referees and linesmen for the first two weeks of the season.
lead_paragraph: The union representing Major League Soccer’s game officials ratified a new collective bargaining agreement Wednesday, ending a lockout that had led the league to use replacement referees and linesmen for the first two weeks of the season. The head of the referees union, Steve Taylor, and the organization that provides M.L.S. with its referees said the agreement would allow the league’s regular officials to return to the field this weekend. Terms of the five-year agreement, the first for the officials, were not announced.

headline: Despite Poor Shooting, Villanova Pulls Away
abstract: The Wildcats, a No. 2 seed, missed their first 16 3-point attempts but improved their accuracy in the second half against Wisconsin-Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Villanova endured a nightmarish shooting performance but avoided an upset by 15th-seeded Wisconsin-Milwaukee, 73-53, at First Niagara Center on Thursday night.

headline: Corrections: March 21, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 21, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Nations Start to Collaborate in the Search
abstract: The expansion of the multinational operation off the western coast of Australia illustrates how the hunt for the Malaysia Airlines plane has helped dampen regional tensions.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — China, Japan and Britain joined the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner in the southern Indian Ocean on Friday, while Australian search aircraft used human spotters to scan the waters for floating debris that might be wreckage from the plane.

headline: Trailing With 5 Minutes to Go, Louisville Rallies to Beat Manhattan
abstract: The defending champion Cardinals seemed flustered as the 13th-seeded Jaspers surged ahead, but Luke Hancock scored 8 straight points to help Louisville advance.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — It was hard to fathom that the Louisville Cardinals could have opening-game jitters Thursday night. They were the defending national champions, after all, and if a second straight title was not enough motivation, receiving only a No. 4 seed in the Midwest Region should have certainly stoked their fire.

headline: Stung by an Upset a Year Ago, the Aztecs Avoid Another
abstract: Fourth-seeded San Diego State, which fell to Florida Gulf Coast last March, got past New Mexico State and advanced to play another upstart, North Dakota State.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — San Diego State knew that unsung New Mexico State had upset New Mexico this season. And the Aztecs had spent a year being reminded that they were victims of Florida Gulf Coast’s mesmerizing N.C.A.A. tournament run last March.

headline: China Cuts Tuberculosis Cases by More Than Half Since 1990
abstract: A study credits the decline to a strategy that involves government support of broad detection efforts combined with standardized drug treatment monitored by health care workers.
lead_paragraph: China has cut the prevalence of tuberculosis by more than half since 1990 thanks to the widespread implementation of a World Health Organization-backed control strategy, according to a new research paper. The findings, which were published this week in The Lancet medical journal, found that the prevalence of tuberculosis had dropped to 59 cases per 100,000 in 2010 from from 170 cases per 100,000 in 1990.

headline: U.N. Investigates ‘Intimidation’ of Activist at Human Rights Council
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Kidnapping', 'Political Prisoners']

keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Museums', 'Olympic Games', 'World War II (1939-45)']

lead_paragraph: A museum in Norway co-founded by the Olympic skating champion Sonja Henie has agreed to return one of its signature works, a portrait by Matisse, to the New York family of a prewar Paris art dealer after determining the painting was stolen by the Nazis.

So news is going to be its own offering. It’s a new site with long-form video, short-form video, shows on the environment, economics, conflict.

lead_paragraph: On March 8 a jet carrying 12 crew members and 227 passengers disappeared en route from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Beijing. Since then, the world has followed this news story with both horror and suspense, wondering what could have gone wrong.

headline: Don’t Blame Food Additives for Hives

lead_paragraph: People often blame food additives like dyes, preservatives, emulsifiers and flavor enhancers for chronic hives and other skin eruptions. But a new randomized trial shows that they are almost surely wrong.

headline: Asian Tycoon Sells Stake in Sprawling Retail Unit
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Li Ka-shing, Asia’s richest man, has called off plans for a Hong Kong and London listing of his retail business after striking a deal on Friday to sell a stake in the unit to a Singaporean state investment company for nearly $6 billion.

headline: The Evil of the Outdoor Cat
abstract: Our pets are taking a large bite out of our birds.
lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a time I had a cat named Lucky, and the name fit. She turned up on our doorstep as a stray and stayed with us for 10 years, until her rather gruesome demise. (More about that later.) I liked her because she was a free spirit, and a survivor, going out for two, three, even five days, in all seasons. She’d show up when it suited her, waiting in the dark before dawn till I came downstairs and turned on my desk lamp. Then she’d make her presence known by rising up on her hind legs and gently scratching with her forepaws on my window.

headline: Even With Ping-Pong, a Formal Meeting in China
abstract: On a good-will trip, Michelle Obama was hosted by Peng Liyuan, the wife of President Xi Jinping, on a visit to Beijing that included the Forbidden City.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Michelle Obama, on the first day of a good-will tour to China with her daughters and her mother, tried her hand on Friday at three quintessentially Chinese specialties: calligraphy, table tennis and mathematics.

abstract: Many of its economies are still in trouble, with little sign of sensible policy moves or the energy to implement them.
lead_paragraph: The European financial crisis may have disappeared from the front pages of American newspapers, but the Continent’s economic challenges remain worrisome.

lead_paragraph: Any nascent technology needs a platform in order to be successful. This week, Google gave wearable devices that platform.

headline: In Turkey, Twitter Roars After Effort to Block It

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — It is a sign of the difficulty of banning Twitter in the age of Twitter that within hours of the Turkish government’s attempt to block the social media site, President Abdullah Gul was one of thousands of Turks who protested the ban — using Twitter.

headline: Joining the 11-Digit Valuation Club
abstract: The couch-surfing company Airbnb is close to raising a funding round that would give it a valuation of more than $10 billion. | The chief executive of Time Warner Cable is set to receive nearly $80 million in severance payment. | The Fed released the results of its latest stress test — and all but one of the 30 banks under review passed. | Dominique Strauss-Kahn is seeking to start a $2 billion hedge fund.

Now, the company is close to joining a rarefied group of start-ups: the 11-digit valuation club, Michael J. de la Merced writes in DealBook.

headline: Euro Zone’s Economy Is Still Ailing, but Improving
abstract: Assessing Europe’s economic comeback through car sales, employment and gross domestic product.
lead_paragraph: THE euro zone’s back-to-back recessions may be over. Most economies are growing, and employment totals have begun to inch upward. New-auto sales, which plunged in 2011 and 2012 as the second recession gathered strength, have risen in Europe in each of the last six months.

headline: Mt. Gox Says It Found Missing Bitcoin Worth About $116 Million
abstract: Mt. Gox, the Tokyo-based Bitcoin exchange that collapsed and filed for bankruptcy last month, said it had found 200,000 Bitcoins that were held in an “old-format wallet,” or digital storage file.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:04 p.m. | The seemingly miraculous discovery of about $116 million in missing Bitcoin, or 200,000 coins, late Thursday underscored the rickety early infrastructure that the digital currency is still trying to overcome.

headline: Silent Comic, Finding His Voice
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: “Free and Easy,” Buster Keaton’s maiden outing in sound, has been newly reissued by Kino. Keaton was enthusiastic about working in talkies.
lead_paragraph: “Newcomer Keaton can take a fall and come up swinging for laughs.” So The New York Dramatic Mirror observed in reviewing “The Butcher Boy,” the 1917 Fatty Arbuckle comedy in which Buster Keaton made his screen debut.

headline: Enough With Those Nymphets
abstract: Eliza Hittman talks about her debut film, “It Felt Like Love,” a coming-of-age story set in the farther and darker corners of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The director and writer Eliza Hittman calls her latest character “the anti-Lolita.” On the cusp of puberty, her eyes shielded by enormous sunglasses from the summer sun — and things she shouldn’t want to see at her age — 14-year-old Lila (Gina Piersanti) prowls farthest Brooklyn in search of what in her inexperience seems like romance. Her come-hither gaze is pierced with longing as she targets Sammy (Ronen Rubinstein), older and thuggish. Soon, her sexual anecdotes rival those of her worldlier best friend, Chiara (Giovanna Salimeni). Then suddenly the predator becomes the prey.

headline: Crying on a Public Bench
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: When a woman was crying on a City Hall Park bench, a stranger knew just what to do.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Farewell to Khushwant Singh, as Well as a Celebration
abstract: At the funeral for the author, who died Thursday at the age of 99, many attendees chose to dwell on their happy memories of a man who was known for his acerbic wit and appreciation of earthly pleasures.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Always game for a good joke, the author Khushwant Singh wrote his obituary in 1943, which later appeared in a collection of short stories.

headline: Playful to Tender, Shades of Truffaut
abstract: A full retrospective at Film Forum from Friday through April 17, provides a complete picture of François Truffaut.
lead_paragraph: François Truffaut (1932-84) is often regarded as the sentimentalist of the French New Wave, not as politically radical as Jean-Luc Godard nor as intellectually rigorous as Alain Resnais. The label is not entirely fair: His subjects could also include pathological obsession (“The Story of Adele H”) and dystopia (“Fahrenheit 451”). Tout Truffaut, at Film Forum from Friday through April 17, provides a complete picture, spanning his 21 features, as well as the documentary “Monsieur Truffaut Meets Mr. Hitchcock,” about the 1962 conversation that birthed the classic book “Hitchcock/Truffaut,” and other films linked to him.

headline: South Korean and Japanese Leaders to Join Obama at Meeting
abstract: The leaders of the two countries will meet with President Obama on the sidelines of a nuclear security meeting in the Netherlands next week.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — President Park Geun-hye of South Korea and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan will talk next week after months of tense relations that had blocked them from meeting each other, South Korea’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Friday.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Patricia Briggs, whose fantasy novel “Night Broken” is new at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list, has received praise for her treatment of rape and its aftermath in her Mercy Thompson series.
lead_paragraph: Survivor: “Night Broken,” the eighth title in Patricia Briggs’s series of Mercy Thompson fantasies, is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 2. These books — about a shape-shifting mechanic who consorts with werewolves and vampires — don’t receive much academic attention, but that doesn’t mean literature professors never read them. Last year, in the peer-reviewed journal Femspec (“an interdisciplinary feminist journal dedicated to science fiction, fantasy, magical realism, surrealism, myth, folklore and other supernatural genres”), the Abilene Christian University assistant professor Suanna Davis included Mercy in an article about rape survivors in fiction, making the happy observation that “rape as an acceptable part of power relations has diminished” and concluding that “speculative fiction can help to correct societal misunderstandings of rape, particularly when the events are presented from a survivor’s perspective.” Davis isn’t alone. Briggs’s readers have praised her treatment of the topic ever since Mercy was attacked in “Iron Kissed,” the third book in the series; although she managed to kill her assailant, the psychological and emotional effects still linger.

Koch, the libertarian-minded billionaire brothers who support conservative causes and have already poured millions of dollars into the 2014 midterm elections.

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Social Security (US)', 'Personal Finances']

lead_paragraph: On Dec. 13, 1953, Lawrence Schacht walked into the Cork Club on West 72nd Street in Manhattan and spotted Russell Frink Jr. at the bar. From that moment forward, the two were inseparable.

headline: A Shot of Religion
abstract: Alcohol’s effects on the pious; March Madness itself draws a challenger.
lead_paragraph: Alcohol’s effects on the pious; March Madness itself draws a challenger.

headline: How Did Sleep Become So Nightmarish?
abstract: The mysterious Land of Nod has been colonized by our ambition, and now it’s just an extension of work.
lead_paragraph: My experience with insomnia began when I was 6 or 7, though I didn’t recognize it as such. In those days, I thought of it as a gift. I had a window that faced east, and in the mornings, a sweet, clear light would pour over my bed, rousing me from the middle of my dreams. I went to bed late and woke up early, and when I did sleep, I slept lightly, waking many times in the night to register the clocklike clicking of a raccoon’s claws on the roof, an especially noisy frog or the breathing and muttering of the house as it rolled and shifted position with the temperature, my fellow restless sleeper.

headline: Life in the Group Room
keywords: ['Stroke', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Hospitals', 'Nursing and Nurses', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: My father needed to be around other people. I needed to get away.
lead_paragraph: Everyone was always trying to escape the stroke ward, and who could blame them?

headline: Should We Protect Wild Horses?
keywords: ['Horses', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Invasive Species']
abstract: When all invasive species are not considered equal.
lead_paragraph: Despite their romantic appeal, horses are an invasive species on this continent with few natural predators. In the United States, it’s illegal to kill a wild horse on public lands. Yet wild horses can have destructive grazing behavior, and indigenous grazers and browsers (deer, for example) presumably have to compete with them for land. Advocates for wild horses like to compare the ecological impact of horses with that of cattle, but that’s sort of like saying we should protect the Asian long-horned beetle because it kills fewer trees than lumber mills do. Is it unethical to protect wild horses? T.G., NEW YORK

headline: Reply All: The 3.9.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: SAT OVERHAUL

headline: Tracy Letts Is Still Haunted by His Past
keywords: ['Theater', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Writing and Writers', 'Movies', 'Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Television']
abstract: The Tony-winning playwright and actor on what happens after you write the truth about everyone you know.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Tracy Letts won the Pulitzer Prize and the Tony Award for his play “August: Osage County,” a multigenerational drama presided over by a mother whose cancer of the mouth is both literal and figurative. It is O’Neill for Okies, based on a seminal event in Letts’s own Durant, Okla., family: His maternal grandfather’s suicide (Letts was 10 at the time) and his grandmother’s ensuing drug addiction. Although Letts, 48, has written other successful plays — the violent and misogynistic “Killer Joe” and the paranoid and bloody “Bug” — “August,” three acts that last more than three hours, was epic in every way: its sweep, its humor and its sorrow. (The movie version, released last year, lost plenty in translation, but then again, most movie versions do.)

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5 P.M. (AMC) FACE/OFF (1997) John Woo directed this action extravaganza in which the F.B.I. agent Sean Archer (John Travolta, right) must undergo an experimental facial procedure to assume the identity of his comatose nemesis, an international terrorist named Castor Troy (Nicolas Cage, left), to prevent a bomb from going off. But the bullets start flying after Troy awakes and uses the same method to steal Archer’s face and identity. “Mr. Woo is such an action wizard that he can make planes or speedboats kick box, but his surprising strength this time is on a more human level,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. She added that Mr. Woo “accomplishes something near-impossible. He makes the viewer buy this film’s loony premise, and buy it with a smile.”

headline: Video: Reviews of ‘Divergent,’ ‘The Missing Picture’ and ‘Nymphomaniac: Volume I’

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the action drama “Divergent,” the documentary “The Missing Picture” and Lars von Trier’s drama “Nymphomaniac: Volume I.”

abstract: Royal Australian Air Force members, Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia and the Malaysian defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, gave updates on the search for Flight 370 in the Indian Ocean.
lead_paragraph: Royal Australian Air Force members, Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia and the Malaysian defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, gave updates on the search for Flight 370 in the Indian Ocean.

headline: Inspired by Irish Soda Bread
keywords: ['Bread', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Grain', 'Medicine and Health', 'Recipes']
abstract: Whole-grain soda breads, a staple in Ireland, are a tasty way to celebrate the feast day of that country’s patron saint, St. Patrick.
lead_paragraph: In honor of St. Patrick’s Day, I spent the week working on whole-grain soda breads and scones. Not all Irish soda bread is made with whole-grain flour, but the ones I like the best are. They are one of the reasons I love going to Ireland. I especially love the moist brown pan-baked loaves served with smoked salmon, butter and cheese.

headline: Revelations of N.S.A. Spying Cost U.S. Tech Companies
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cloud Computing']
abstract: America’s cloud computing industry could lose billions of dollars in business because of the government’s surveillance program.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft has lost customers, including the government of Brazil.

headline: Students See Many Slights as Racial ‘Microaggressions’
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Gender', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Blogs, papers and other projects have prompted wider discussion of “microaggressions,” remarks with a basis in racial, gender or other stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A tone-deaf inquiry into an Asian-American’s ethnic origin. Cringe-inducing praise for how articulate a black student is. An unwanted conversation about a Latino’s ability to speak English without an accent.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: COMANDANTE: Hugo Chávez’s Venezuela,  by Rory Carroll. (Penguin, $17.) Carroll spent six years covering Venezuela and Hugo Chávez (1954-2013) for The Guardian of London. He frames this sharp-eyed biography as a study of how the democratically elected strongman rose from poverty and prison to unrivaled influence as president, thumbing his nose at Washington while wielding his country’s oil reserves as a tool for Socialist-inspired change.

headline: The View From Afar
abstract: Young or old, the characters in Molly Antopol’s story collection know the pain of estrangement.
lead_paragraph: Where did it all go wrong? This is the idée fixe of depression, the question that haunts anyone who has ever felt the color drain out of life. This question also underlies much of literature — it can drive writers. And the difference between good writing and a writing exercise is in fact very much like the difference between life itself and its depressive moments: It is in the complexity, the texture, the expansiveness, the lack of desire to fixate on the moment when it all went off the rails.

headline: Above and Below
abstract: An exploration of the Allied bombing of civilian areas during World War II examines those in the air and those on the ground.
lead_paragraph: Outside the Royal Air Force Chapel in central London stands a statue of Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Harris, better known as “Bomber” Harris, the British officer most closely associated with the policy of area bombing German cities in the latter stage of World War II. On the pedestal, in honor of the bomber crews and their commander, is the legend: “The nation owes them all an immense debt.”

headline: Good Sport
abstract: A grieving Italian man discovers the redemptive power of soccer.
lead_paragraph: San Benedetto, the fictional Ligurian hub of Brigid Pasulka’s second novel, “The Sun and Other Stars,” was a cloistered fishing village before an Italian-American Hollywood director fell for a local Venus, posed for the paparazzi and provided the photo’s caption: San Benedetto, a hundred kilometers from Genoa, is “the last spot on earth that is simple and pure.” Here “the light is brought down from on high by angels, and those Italian fishermen, well, they really know how to, you know, live.” Benvenuti, turisti!

headline: Absolute Power
abstract: The ability of one leader to deploy a nuclear weapon is inherently undemocratic, a social theorist argues.
lead_paragraph: The problem posed by nuclear weapons — that they work by holding their possessors hostage, with the threat of catastrophic retaliation if used — has confounded thinking about them since the beginning of the nuclear age. One of its earliest analysts, the American physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, the first director of the Manhattan Project’s Los Alamos laboratory, which developed the atomic bomb, once compared the two dominant nuclear powers of his day and ours, the United States and Russia, to “scorpions in a bottle, each capable of killing the other, but only at the risk of his own life.” Oppenheimer chose not to note that scorpions, a species almost as well known for belligerence as Homo sapiens, would sooner or later take that risk. We humans have not done so, at least not so far. But while circling each other warily during the Cold War, the United States and the Soviet Union occupied themselves with stockpiling enough weapons to freeze out food production with nuclear winter and destroy the human world.

headline: Spyfall
abstract: After a diplomat is assassinated in Budapest, his wife steps into the world of espionage to search for the killer.
lead_paragraph: Spy novels function with our complicity. We know bad things happen in the world; in some ways, they have to happen in order for us to enjoy ice cream sundaes and ham sandwiches and spring mornings in Palm Beach. That’s the unspoken deal we make with ourselves when we accept their premise.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BERNARD MALAMUD: Novels and Stories of the 1940s and 50s and BERNARD MALAMUD: Novels and Stories of the 1960s, both edited by Philip Davis. (Library of America, $35 each.) Malamud’s voice was unlike any other, haunted by whispers of Hawthorne, Babel, Isak Dinesen and even Poe.

headline: Historical Fiction
abstract: New books by Anna Hope, Vivien Shotwell and Kate Alcott.
lead_paragraph: WAKE  By Anna Hope  Random House, $26.

headline: Coach Wooden’s Bookshelf
abstract: John Wooden found inspiration in books about historical exemplars like Gandhi, Lincoln and Churchill.
lead_paragraph: As Jason Zengerle notes in his review of Seth Davis’s new biography of John Wooden, the U.C.L.A. basketball coach originally planned to be an English teacher.

headline: Evolution of an Activist
abstract: A biography of the civil rights firebrand Stokely Carmichael.
lead_paragraph: In the iconography of black American history, Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. have long been understood as dueling poles of identity, one an apostle of contempt, urging a downtrodden race to renounce a nation that had rejected it, the other an exemplar of Christian idealism, committed to the redemptive power of forgiveness and common humanity. The America we inhabit now is both more socially integrated and segregated than it was in the tumultuous days in which the two men lived. A black president coexists with residential and educational patterns that are in some instances more racially separated than they were on the morning of the 1963 March on Washington. This circumstance is not entirely indicative of a failure of will. It’s partly a reflection of the fact that black aspirations for equality were far more complicated than the simple Martin versus Malcolm formulation, just as each man was far more complicated than his public depiction. If those years can be understood as a sort of test, black America looked at the multiple-choice question of identity and answered yes.

headline: Deathly Quiet
abstract: This novel’s criminal defendant won’t speak for himself.
lead_paragraph: In Jesse Ball’s absorbing, finely wrought fourth novel, “Silence Once Begun,” a journalist also named Jesse Ball tells the story of a thread salesman who makes a wager with two people in a bar. Upon losing that wager, he signs an extremely detailed confession to a crime he didn’t commit — the kidnapping of eight people from a Japanese town called Narito over the course of four months. The kidnappings, known to the populace as the “Narito Disappearances,” have spurred a moral panic that demands a scapegoat. A man who would offer himself up as that scapegoat is taking the most desperate of chances, asking all his fellow men for some proof that he should continue to live.

headline: Daughters of Revolution
abstract: Three women negotiate difficult circumstances in this novel set against the backdrop of Somali unrest.
lead_paragraph: In her 2007 memoir “Infidel,” the activist and former politician Ayaan Hirsi Ali related the advice once given to her by her own grandmother in Somalia: “A woman alone is like a piece of sheep fat in the sun,” she wrote. “Everything will come and feed on that fat. Before you know it, the ants and insects are crawling all over it, until there is nothing left but a smear of grease.”

headline: Was It Any Use?
abstract: Many voices build a picture of malaise in rural Ireland.
