lead_paragraph: In Donal Ryan’s compact debut novel, “The Spinning Heart,” effects of the economic downturn ripple through an Irish village whose laborers, flush during the boom, have been left in the lurch now that the local developer, Pokey Burke, has skipped town.

headline: The Walls Are Closing In
abstract: Crises — financial, familial, existential — converge in this novel.
lead_paragraph: Fiction depicting the lives of working-­class Americans has a long tradition. Its practitioners — John Steinbeck, Raymond Carver, Tillie Olsen and Stewart O’Nan, to name a few — aim for a frank portrayal of men and women whose freedom is limited by economic and social realities, and whose American dream is elusive at best. These works often bypass overt lyricism in favor of unadorned prose, to create a kind of literary cinéma vérité.

headline: Points of Departure
abstract: Six loosely linked essays from the author “whose only homeland was on the page.”
lead_paragraph: W. G. Sebald was born in 1944 in Wer­tach im Allgäu in the Bavarian Alps, educated in Germany and Switzerland, taught literature in England for three decades, and between 1990 and 2001 became world famous for “Vertigo,” “The Emigrants,” “The Rings of Saturn” and “Austerlitz” — four novels about Jews, set variously in Vienna, Venice, Verona, Riva, Antwerp, Prague, Paris, Suffolk, Manchester and Long Island. He wrote in German, but was a “German writer” in the same way that Alfred Döblin, Hermann Broch and Stefan Zweig were “Jewish writers”: tragically and by accident. As for what he called himself, he hated the name Winfried Georg, and responded only to “Max.” Shortly after “Austerlitz” was published in English, Sebald died in a car crash. Mortal: the universal identity.

headline: Missionaries’ Kid
abstract: In Megan Hustad’s childhood and youth, her family went where they believed God led them.
lead_paragraph: Early in “More Than Conquerors,” a memoir of her family’s life as Christian missionaries, Megan Hustad anticipates her readers’ expectations. With a wry frankness typical of the book, she writes: “This is not a story of judgmental zealots thumping pulpits. . . . This is not a story about pious blowhards whose unbending conviction alienated their children ­forever.”

headline: The Wolf of Fifth Avenue
abstract: In “Savage Girl,” Jean Zimmerman turns to the Gilded Age for a sweeping narrative that raises touchy questions about what it means to be civilized.
lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, a historical crime novel is bound to drag you down some dark alley and into the nastiest, most lawless precincts of the period. Jean Zimmerman followed this tradition in her first novel, “The Orphanmaster,” a descent into the hellish criminal haunts of 17th-century New Amsterdam. In SAVAGE GIRL (Viking, $27.95), this canny author puts all that aside and turns to the Gilded Age for a sweeping narrative, set within the cloistered ranks of high society in 19th-century Manhattan, that raises touchy questions about what it means to be civilized.

headline: The Cutting Edge
abstract: Physical extremes not only test human limits, according to an anesthesiologist; they also spawn medical breakthroughs.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to forget how amazing modern medicine is.

headline: Skills Practice | Alternative History as Narrative
abstract: What if the British won the Revolutionary War? What if the Cuban Missile Crisis started World War III? What if John Lennon had not died when he was shot? In this skills lesson, students write narratives imagining alternate histories for events of their choice.
lead_paragraph: What if the British won the Revolutionary War? What if the Cuban Missile Crisis had started World War III? What if John Lennon had not died when he was shot?

headline: Advice on How to Have a Good Paternity Leave
abstract: Advice from New York Times readers on how fathers can make the most of paternity leave.
lead_paragraph: When you ask for advice about paternity leave, you learn that a lot of really nice people are out there. Strangers, friends and acquaintances popped up on the Internet and in person to wish me well and share their experiences. There may be a persistent social stigma that discourages many fathers from taking more time at home with their babies, paid or unpaid. But there are also a lot of people who will tell you that you’re doing the right thing, and I hope you’ll hear those voices of encouragement echoed here if you are preparing for parental leave.

headline: Digitizing Those Customer Loyalty Cards
abstract: Plus, printing multiple documents on a Mac without opening each one.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I convert my drugstore rewards card into a digital version I can store on my phone?

headline: Microaggressions: Comments That Sting
abstract: Across college campuses and social media, younger generations have started to challenge those fleeting comments that seem innocent but leave uneasy feelings behind.
lead_paragraph: Across college campuses and social media, younger generations have started to challenge those fleeting comments that seem innocent but leave uneasy feelings behind.

headline: A Doyen’s Rebellion
abstract: The Bharatiya Janata Party senior figure Lal Krishna Advani’s pique over the location of his parliamentary race is a reminder of his ever-worsening relationship with Narendra Modi, his former lieutenant.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Wednesday, the central election committee of India’s opposition Bharatiya Janata Party met to announce the party’s fifth list of candidates for the national elections in April and May. The meeting had one notable absence: Lal Krishna Advani, the party’s doyen and one of its founders.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Nymphomaniac: Volume I’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Nymphomaniac: Volume I.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Nymphomaniac: Volume I.”

headline: Frustrating Black Hair Remark at Harvard
abstract: Kimiko Matsuda-Lawrence, a student who wrote and directed “I, Too, Am Harvard,” a play about feeling marginalized at the university, explains why a compliment can be offensive.
lead_paragraph: Kimiko Matsuda-Lawrence, a student who wrote and directed “I, Too, Am Harvard,” a play about feeling marginalized at the university, explains why a compliment can be offensive.

headline: Looking for Ways to Keep Money From Dividing a Family
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Families and Family Life', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Parenting', 'Wills and Estates']
abstract: It takes careful planning and communication to ensure that younger generations understand finances in general, as well as their inheritance.
lead_paragraph: MARVIN BLUM, a lawyer from Fort Worth, flew to New York last week to visit his daughter, son-in-law and young granddaughter. Staying close to his family is crucial to him. The same goes for seeing his son, who lives in Austin.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Divergent’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Divergent.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Divergent.”

headline: Australia’s Search for the Missing Plane
abstract: Lt. Russell Adams of the Royal Australian Airforce gave a brief news conference after completing a search mission for Malaysia Airlines flight 370.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Russell Adams of the Royal Australian Airforce gave a brief news conference after completing a search mission for Malaysia Airlines flight 370.

headline: Students and Readers Share Their Experiences of Race on Campus
abstract: When is a question not as innocent as the questioner thought? What are the limits of tolerance and the boundaries of ignorance? Readers and students told us their stories and their perspectives.
lead_paragraph: As I report in The Big Topic on Campus: Racial ‘Microaggressions’, “microaggressions” is a term that has long been used by race theorists and sociologists, and is now increasingly popping up in blogs, social media campaigns, art and academic papers. Young people are using the term to describe the subtle ways that racial, ethnic, gender and other stereotypes can play out painfully in an increasingly diverse culture.

headline: Third-Party Hotel Booking Sites Can Mislead Consumers
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Instead of finding a good deal, many travelers wind up feeling duped when reserving a room on a website that only looks as if it is owned by a hotel.
lead_paragraph: THIS is the situation: Customers search for a particular hotel and click on a link. They think they’ve landed on the official hotel website, but unknowingly they really have arrived at an unrelated site of a hotel booking company.

headline: Daily Report: Fallout From Snowden Hurts Tech Company Bottom Lines
abstract: It is impossible to see the full economic ramifications of the spying revelations by Edward J. Snowden but the pieces are beginning to add up as businesses question the trustworthiness of American technology products.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft has lost customers, including the government of Brazil. IBM is spending more than a billion dollars to build data centers overseas to reassure foreign customers that their information is safe from prying eyes in the United States government. And tech companies abroad, from Europe to South America, say they are gaining customers that are shunning United States providers, suspicious because of the revelations by Edward J. Snowden that tied these providers to the National Security Agency’s vast surveillance program.

headline: Cumin Lamb Stir-Fry
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a restaurant-worthy stir-fry using toasted cumin and Sichuan peppercorns for bigger, spicier flavors.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a restaurant-worthy stir-fry using toasted cumin and Sichuan peppercorns for bigger, spicier flavors.

headline: Lamb at Play in a Field of Cumin
abstract: This stir-fried lamb dish is fragrant with the scent of toasted cumin, with the added intensity of Sichuan peppercorns.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to cooking lamb, I lean European. I dream of a Provencal-style roasted leg scented with herbs, or the seared little Italian lamb chops that scorch your fingers when you pick them up.

headline: Obama and Tech Executives to Meet Again on Privacy Issues
abstract: The president held a similar meeting in December and later announced he was taking steps to re-evaluate the breadth of the National Security Agency’s electronic surveillance programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will meet with technology executives on Friday afternoon to discuss “issues of privacy, technology and intelligence,” a senior White House official said, amid growing concerns in Silicon Valley that intelligence agencies’ cyber snooping is steering customers away from buying American technology.

headline: Boardwalk Empire
abstract: The HBO series is shot on the sound stages of Steiner Studios. Video courtesy of HBO.
lead_paragraph: The HBO series is shot on the sound stages of Steiner Studios. Video courtesy of HBO.

headline: In the Heights
abstract: Peter Fine’s investment helped bring the show to Broadway. The original Broadway cast performs “96,000.” Video courtesy of Usnavi Broadway LLC.
lead_paragraph: Peter Fine’s investment helped bring the show to Broadway. The original Broadway cast performs “96,000.” Video courtesy of Usnavi Broadway LLC.

headline: The Last of the Unjust
abstract: The Cohen Media Group distributed Claude Lanzmann’s Holocaust documentary, released last month. Video courtesy of Cohen Media Group.
lead_paragraph: The Cohen Media Group distributed Claude Lanzmann’s Holocaust documentary, released last month. Video courtesy of Cohen Media Group.

headline: The Reluctant General Grant
abstract: Why the Union’s top general didn’t want the job.
lead_paragraph: After his strategically critical victories at Vicksburg and Chattanooga, Ulysses S. Grant was indisputably the Union’s most successful general. By early 1864, it was clear to many observers that the commander of Northern forces in the Western theater would, and should, rise even further in acclaim and power – and they began to plan accordingly, without bothering to ask the brilliant, mercurial leader whether he was even interested.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Simulator Shows Off Safety Technology
abstract: Outfitted with sensors, cameras and computers, Mercedes-Benz vehicles are able to avoid hazards.
lead_paragraph: MONTVALE, N.J. — There is little doubt that Mercedes-Benz is has advanced safety technology, and the automaker prides itself on its ability to offer semiautonomous safety features even on its entry-level models.

headline: Biltmore, in Bloom
abstract: Biltmore, in North Carolina, will celebrate spring with flowers (including thousands of tulips), an Easter egg hunt and a wine tour.
lead_paragraph: Biltmore, America’s largest privately owned home, will celebrate spring ceremoniously with more than 100,000 blooms coloring the estate gardens in Asheville, N.C..

headline: They Kept a Lower East Side Lot Vacant for Decades
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Sheldon Silver and William E. Rapfogel worked behind the scenes to keep low-income housing out of a Jewish enclave.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four decades ago, a new assemblyman named Sheldon Silver and his young protégé escorted Edward I. Koch, then a mayoral candidate, through the Orthodox Jewish enclave on Manhattan’s Lower East Side where the two had both grown up.

headline: ‘Most Advanced’ Gaza-Israel Tunnel Is Found
abstract: A military spokesman said the tunnel, reaching hundreds of yards into Israel, was “the most advanced tunnel that we’ve exposed” and could have been used to attack or kidnap Israelis.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military announced on Friday that it had uncovered a sophisticated tunnel that stretched hundreds of yards into its territory from the Gaza Strip and could have been used to attack or kidnap Israelis.

headline: Charm School for Real Estate Brokers
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Vocational Training', 'Coaches and Managers']
abstract: Coaches are stepping in to help real estate professionals improve their likability.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it seems as if New York brokers can’t catch a break. The stereotype is that members of the species are rude, arrogant, aggressive, and more apt to talk than to listen. While the image may be just that — a stereotype — it clings to the people who help clients buy, sell and rent houses and apartments in this sharp-elbowed metropolis.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Missing Picture’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Missing Picture.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Missing Picture.”

headline: 36 Hours in Mexico City
abstract: Where to begin in the nearly 500-year-old capital? This weekend itinerary can get you started, with stops at museums and markets, bars and bell towers.
lead_paragraph: Built from the rubble of violent conquest, Mexico City has endured both the torment of Pacific Rim fault lines and the explosive force of its own expansion. Now with a greater metropolitan area of 21 million, Mexico’s nearly 500-year-old capital is made of ancient stone and gleaming glass, Old World architecture and indigenous tradition. With its plazas and palm trees, its murals by Mexican masters and its contemporary street art, it is a beautiful city — and one that has been spared from much of the country’s drug war violence. In recent years, the Distrito Federal has been treated to the opening of one art institution after the next, from the Carlos Slim-funded Soumaya Museum, which moved into a $70 million building in 2011, to the new David Chipperfield-designed Jumex Museum, which focuses on contemporary work and opened last November.

headline: In Search of Oxford
abstract: Darting between past and present, the bookish and the bucolic, the author peels back layers of this quintessential college town.
lead_paragraph: When I took off in late October to join my husband, a law professor on sabbatical in Oxford, I thought I knew what to expect, thanks to all the books and movies that have been set in this ridiculously pretty, medieval town in south central England. Evelyn Waugh’s “Brideshead Revisited” — the 1945 novel that grapples with the allure of aristocracy and privilege — had prepared me for the sight of elegant undergrads romping about, perhaps carrying bottles of Champagne, on the vast green meadows of Christ Church college. Colin Dexter’s “Inspector Morse” series (both the books and the television show) had warned me about the dangers of tripping over dead bodies. And that very last bit of the recent film “An Education” prepared me for flocks of students riding bicycles on their way to conquer DNA analysis on the one hand and the liturgical language of Theravada Buddhism on the other.

headline: Real Estate Developers in Movieland
abstract: Some whose day job is putting up buildings have also found their way into show business. And it’s a labor of love.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to a second career, many people daydream about breaking into show business, including some well accustomed to white-knuckle drama and skin-of-the-teeth ventures: real estate tycoons.

headline: Turks Evade Twitter Ban to Mock Twitter Ban, on Twitter
abstract: Turkey’s court-ordered ban on Twitter was widely subverted by many of the 12 million Turkish users of the social network, who found ways to gain access to the platform and posted defiant messages of protest.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:36 p.m. | As my colleagues Sebnem Arsu and Alan Cowell report, Turkey’s court-ordered ban on Twitter was widely subverted on Friday by many of the 12 million Turkish users of the social network, who found ways to gain access to the platform and posted defiant messages of protest.

headline: The Tweets of Melissa Mark-Viverito
abstract: For the City Council speaker, the social media outlet has become something of a public journal.
lead_paragraph: Little has been known publicly about Melissa Mark-Viverito, but as Kate Taylor reports, the City Council speaker provides glimpses into her life and personality through frequent posts on Twitter.

headline: Portals to the Past
abstract: Stepping back in time in Morocco’s medinas.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1930s, when the writer Paul Bowles first visited Tangier, Morocco, where he would end up living for more than a half-century, he described its medina, or old city, as “ancient, its passageways were full of people in bright outlandish costumes, and each street leading to the outskirts was bordered by walls of cane, prickly pear and high-growing geranium.” Today Morocco’s medinas are much the same. The photographer Ambroise Tézenas visited medinas in the Moroccan cities of Tangier, Tetouan and Chefchaouen, which is known for its striking buildings painted bright blue. They “aren’t just tourist playgrounds like you have in downtown Paris,” Tézenas says. “What I was interested in is the fact that it’s not just nice and pretty. You still have people working in little shops. It’s like stepping back in time, and nothing has changed.” Julie Bosman

headline: Reflecting on a Writer’s Walk Through Europe
abstract: Decades after the acclaimed travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor set off on his walk, his biographer talks about the adventure.
lead_paragraph: From the time he was a boy, acclaimed travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor wanted to live like a character in a novel. Somehow, he found out how. During his lifetime, he was stabbed in Bulgaria, car-bombed in Greece, targeted in a blood vendetta, and hunted by German soldiers after kidnapping their commander on the island of Crete and handing him off to a waiting British submarine during World War II. But his story started in 1933, when at 18 he was focused on the single goal of walking across Europe, “From the hook of Holland to Constantinople.”

headline: 4 Dead as Fire Destroys Motel on Jersey Shore Used for Storm Victims
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']
abstract: Flames swept through the Mariner’s Cove Motor Inn in Pleasant Point Beach, N.J., which had been used to shelter people who lost their homes in Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: A fire swept through a motel at Point Pleasant Beach on the Jersey Shore just before dawn on Friday, killing four people and injuring eight others.

headline: A Lens Catches; a Painter Converts
abstract: In “Regrets,” a new show at the Museum of Modern Art, Jasper Johns has based a cohesive group of nearly two dozen paintings, drawings and prints on a photograph of Lucian Freud.
lead_paragraph: What do you do if you’re a busy museum, and an eminent and famously enigmatic artist in late career tells you he’s prepared to go public with new work? You shake up your schedule, clear out some space and move the stuff in, pronto.

headline: Times Minute | Behind the Flight Search
abstract: On the Minute, more information on the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, including the progress, the geopolitics at play and the limits of the plane’s black box if it is found.
lead_paragraph: On the Minute, more information on the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, including the progress, the geopolitics at play and the limits of the plane’s black box if it is found.

headline: Times Minute | Behind the Search for Flight 370
abstract: On the Minute, more information on the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 including the progress, the geopolitics at play and the limits of the plane’s black box if it is found.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Instead of the Poker-Playing Dogs …
abstract: Gifts for art lovers.
lead_paragraph: Gifts for art lovers.

headline: Pay Higher Wages, Earn More Profit
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Tony Schwartz makes an argument in the Life@Work column for paying retail employees more and treating them better.
lead_paragraph: How often do you walk into a retail establishment and interact with a salesperson, stock clerk or cashier? How often do you stop and think about what that person’s life is like?

headline: Lauren Ambrose and Chris Pine to Star in ‘Fool for Love’ at Williamstown
abstract: “Fool for Love,” a 1983 Sam Shepard play, will run July 24-Aug. 3 at the Williamstown Theater Festival.
lead_paragraph: Chris Pine (Kirk in the recent “Star Trek” movies) and Lauren Ambrose (“Six Feet Under”) will face off as the battling lovers in Sam Shepard’s “Fool for Love” in a production this summer at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, the company announced Friday. The 1983 play will be directed by Daniel Aukin (“4000 Miles”) and run July 24-Aug. 3 at Williamstown’s Nikos Stage.

headline: Kronos Quartet’s 40-Year Adventure
abstract: The quartet, which has revolutionized the approach to string quartet repertory, will perform a 40th anniversary concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday.
lead_paragraph: “That sounded massively unmassive,” the violinist David Harrington said during a recent rehearsal of Nico Muhly’s “Diacritical Marks” with the Pannonia Quartet, gesturing energetically to encourage a ponytailed teenager in pink sneakers to create a more dramatic sound on her violin.

headline: Rhyming Wit, Plaintive Sorrow and a Rising Diva
abstract: A look at the debut EP from the duo Marian Hill, Shy Glizzy’s new mixtape, Katy B’s second album and more.
lead_paragraph: Marian Hill

headline: The Historical Becomes Personal
abstract: The historian Simon Schama, whose series “The Story of the Jews” is arriving on PBS, says his documentary breaks “all the historian’s rules about distance and objectivity.”
lead_paragraph: The five-hour PBS series “The Story of the Jews With Simon Schama” sweeps across some 3,000 years of Jewish history. But late last month, when the Center for Jewish History in Manhattan showed excerpts from the documentary, the post-screening questions for Mr. Schama didn’t gravitate toward history, but toward current affairs: the status of today’s Israel and what should the response be to the rise in ultra-Orthodoxy there.

headline: Ha Jin and Wendell Berry Among New Members of American Academy of Arts and Letters
abstract: The American Academy of Arts and Letters names nine new members including the novelist Ha Jin and the farmer/writer Wendell Berry.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Ha Jin, the farmer-writer Wendell Berry and the artist Ann Hamilton are among the nine new members elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters, commonly described as one of the highest honors in the arts.

headline: Chicken ‘Piccata’ With Chard or Beet Greens
abstract: Thin pan-cooked chicken breasts with capers and lemon take only minutes to cook.
lead_paragraph: This recipe, adapted from a Mark Peel recipe for veal piccata, produces pungent, lemony chicken breasts that are among the top 10 dinners in my house. I pound chicken breasts thin, to about 1/4 inch. This way, you can get a good two servings, if not more, out of each boneless, skinless breast. They take minutes to cook, and you can pound the chicken breasts ahead of time and keep them between sheets of plastic in the refrigerator until you’re ready to make dinner.

headline: A Southern Stew of the Self-Taught
abstract: The tensions of “outsider art” will be explored in an exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: “Outsider art” — the catchall term for the work of self-trained artists and a lot of folk art — has always raised more questions than it answers: Outside what? Says who? Why is the distinction necessary? Those questions have been particularly fraught when it comes to the history of work by African-American artists, a tension that will be explored in “When the Stars Begin to Fall: Imagination and the American South,” a show at the Studio Museum in Harlem of 35 artists who share an interest in the South and who often scramble the insider-outsider equation. Setting out to inject “a gutbucket-funky aesthetic into classical, sometimes overwrought, tropes of African Americana — the folk, the down-home, the hailed,” the show, opening on Thursday, will examine “the history of self-taught artists in influencing and defining what black art can be,” the museum says. It will include work by Kara Walker, David Hammons, Theaster Gates and other established stars alongside that of emerging artists and others never before exhibited at the museum, like Frank Albert Jones, who made ecstatic drawings over many years in Texas prisons. (144 West 125th Street, 212-864-4500, studiomuseum.org.

headline: Lemon and Garlic Chicken With Cherry Tomatoes
abstract: A taste of summer that comes from winter-grown cherry tomatoes.
lead_paragraph: This is a summery dish to make in the middle of a cold winter (or early spring), but you can find decent cherry tomatoes even now, from Florida or from Mexico. I marinate the breasts in lemon juice, olive oil, garlic and rosemary before I pound them. This makes them very flavorful, a great savory contrast to the sweet tomato topping.

headline: Lemon and Garlic Chicken With Spiced Spinach
abstract: Subtly spiced spinach is a wonderful match with this chicken.
lead_paragraph: This is a heavenly combination; I’m not sure what I like best, the subtly spiced spinach or the chicken, but they make a great combo. When you add the rinsed spinach to the pan after cooking the chicken it will wilt in the liquid left on the leaves after washing, and it will deglaze the pan at the same time.

headline: Hungarian Strains and ‘Moonlight’
abstract: The British pianist Paul Lewis has proved an elegant and probing interpreter of Beethoven.
lead_paragraph: The British pianist Paul Lewis has proved an elegant and probing interpreter of Beethoven, whose complete sonatas he has recorded for Harmonia Mundi. On Wednesday night at 7:30, he offers the “Moonlight” Sonata alongside the less frequently performed Sonata in E flat (Op. 27, No. 1) or “Quasi una Fantasia." His program at Zankel Hall also includes two Bach-Busoni chorale preludes, three late works by Liszt and Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition.”

headline: Soy-Ginger Chicken With Asian Greens or Arugula
abstract: Salad dressing serves as a marinade for the chicken in this dish.
lead_paragraph: I serve these spicy pan-cooked pounded chicken breasts over a mound of pungent wild arugula or Asian salad greens. Some of the Asian salad dressing serves as a marinade for the chicken.

headline: 2 Prisms for Bach, Classic and Modern
abstract: In “Bach Interpreted,” Emery LeCrone shows how there can be two sides to one piece of music.
lead_paragraph: For imaginative choreographers like the rising talent Emery LeCrone, a challenge is something to relish. In “Bach Interpreted,” Ms. LeCrone shows how there can be two sides to one piece of music by creating a pair of dances, each set to Bach’s Partita No. 2 in C minor, for the Works & Process series at the Guggenheim Museum. One will be based on classical vocabulary, the other on contemporary movement. Fittingly, the designer Yigal Azrouël has created costumes that respond directly to the choreography and performers — an impressive bunch — in each work.

headline: Lemon and Garlic Chicken With Mushrooms
abstract: Mushrooms and white wine deglaze the pan to provide a delicious accompaniment to chicken.
lead_paragraph: In this Provençal rendition of pan-cooked chicken breasts, the mushrooms take on an added dimension of flavor as they deglaze the pan with the help of one of their favorite partners, dry white wine.

headline: What Made Me | Edward Droste
abstract: The founder of the band Grizzly Bear reflects on his musical education, songwriting and the band’s history.
lead_paragraph: The founder of the band Grizzly Bear reflects on his musical education, songwriting and the band’s history.

headline: Who’s the Oddest of Them All?
abstract: “Jim Henson’s Creature Shop Challenge” is the stuff dreams are made of — if your reveries star Yoda, Kermit the Frog and flying purple people eaters.
lead_paragraph: “Jim Henson’s Creature Shop Challenge” is the stuff dreams are made of — if your reveries star Yoda, Kermit the Frog and flying purple people eaters. This competition series, which begins Tuesday night at 10 on Syfy, follows 10 contestants eager to demonstrate their expertise in sculpting, animatronics, full-body design and generally out-imagining their rivals for $100,000 and a contract with Jim Henson’s Creature Shop.

headline: Goodbye, Roseland: Gaga Blows a Kiss
abstract: Rather than playing one big area date on her current tour, Lady Gaga will be performing a series of seven Roseland Ballroom shows beginning this week.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga is certainly the pop star with the most Twitter followers — over 41 million — who may not even really be a pop star anymore. Her 2013 album “Artpop” (Streamlive/Interscope) — only her third full-length — had maybe one and a half hits on it. That’s not a wholly fair metric — the album also included some of her more accomplished songwriting and some successful oddball songs — but it landed with a thud, and disappeared in silence. Being known by as many people as she is means that someday all of those people will forget you.

headline: What’s a Logical Drone Strikes Policy? Hint: Not the Current One.
abstract: The Obama administration’s “targeted killing” policy has been the subject of furious debate that has not nearly been put to rest by the government’s equivocations.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s “targeted killing” policy has been the subject of furious debate that has not nearly been put to rest by the government’s equivocations.

headline: Casual Remarks That Hurt: Microaggression and Adoptive Families
abstract: Adoptive families, and children who were adopted into them, often talk among ourselves about the “dumb things people say” to and about us. Those comments have a name — microaggressions — but there’s no consensus about the best way to handle them.
lead_paragraph: Adoptive families, and children who were adopted into them, often talk among ourselves about the “dumb things people say” to and about us. “Where is her real family?” “Do you know her parents?” It bothers some people more than others, and it bothered Kim Kelley Wagner to the point that she created a photo series about it, of the kind that’s rapidly becoming ubiquitous: images of those spoken about (in this case, her daughters), holding hand-lettered signs with the offensive words that have been directed at them.

headline: Iraq Hit by Wave of Bombings and Attacks
abstract: Violence across the country left 37 people dead, and gunmen kidnapped eight soldiers from their army unit in Samarra, north of Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Thirty-seven people were killed on Friday in a wave of bombings and attacks across Iraq, and eight soldiers were kidnapped, security officials said.

headline: Zimmer Breaks His Silence on Men’s Wearhouse Deal
abstract: George Zimmer, who was ousted as chairman of Men’s Wearhouse, the company he founded, before its takeover battle for Jos. A. Bank, gave the deal a mixed review.
lead_paragraph: George Zimmer, the man who was missing in the merger of Men’s Wearhouse and its chief rival, Jos. A. Bank, has finally broken his silence.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Divergent’
abstract: Neil Burger narrates a scene from his film starring Shailene Woodley.
lead_paragraph: Neil Burger narrates a scene from his film starring Shailene Woodley.

headline: Did You Go to the World’s Fair?
abstract: As the 50th anniversary of the opening of the 1964 World’s Fair approaches, The New York Times is looking for stories and memories from the fair.
lead_paragraph: As the 50th anniversary of the opening of the 1964 World’s Fair approaches, The New York Times is looking for stories and memories from the fair.

headline: Boy, 14, Is Charged With Murder in Stray Shooting on Brooklyn Bus
abstract: The teenager opened fire on a bus in Bedford-Stuyvesant, fatally shooting an innocent bystander, a 39-year-old passenger, in the head on Thursday evening, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: He sat toward the front of the bus, facing forward, immersed in a cellphone conversation, unaware that his life was about to end.

headline: Justice Department Names New Leader for Criminal Division
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)']
abstract: David O’Neil, a longtime Justice Department official, will assume the role of acting assistant attorney general on Monday, overseeing some major investigations into Wall Street and corporate misdeeds.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s criminal division, which oversees some of the biggest investigations into Wall Street and corporate misdeeds, has a new leader.

headline: A Threat to Male Fertility
abstract: Increasing evidence suggests that phthalates, widely used in plastic products, may damage the reproductive system in men. But there are simple measures people can take to reduce their exposure to the chemicals.
lead_paragraph: To study the impact of everyday chemicals on fertility, federal researchers recently spent four years tracking 501 couples as they tried to have children. One of the findings stood out: while both men and women were exposed to known toxic chemicals, men seemed much more likely to suffer fertility problems as a result.

headline: What Made Me | Edward Droste, Musician
abstract: In this second installment of our video series about creative inspiration, the frontman of Grizzly Bear reflects on his musical education.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, Edward Droste started Grizzly Bear as a bedroom recording project after college. Today, Grizzly Bear is a four-piece act renowned for its shimmering brand of harmonic, experimental pop, with an international fan-base and four albums to its name (the most recent, “Shields,” came out in 2012). In the second installment of the “What Made Me” video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, Droste reflects on his childhood musical education on Cape Cod, how he began writing songs as an adult and what it’s like for a band to grow up together.

headline: Books on the New Deal and an Indian Massacre Win Bancroft Prize
abstract: The Bancroft Prize is considered one of the most prestigious honors in the field of American history.
lead_paragraph: Books on racial politics during the New Deal and on an 1864 massacre of American Indians in Colorado have won the Bancroft Prize, considered one of the most prestigious honors in the field of American history.

headline: A Pension Fund Invests Against the Rules, and Wins
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Police']
abstract: While some call its strategy crazy, the Tampa firefighters and police officers pension fund has benefited from ignoring widely embraced investment doctrine.
lead_paragraph: Are the trustees of the Tampa firefighters and police officers pension fund out of their minds?

headline: Timid Analysis (Wonkish)
abstract: When half a loaf is no loaf at all.
lead_paragraph: I referred to this briefly in today’s column, but here’s more.

headline: That Nuisance in the Sky
abstract: The cause of banning horse-drawn carriages landed on Mayor Bill de Blasio’s priority list; some aggrieved citizens might be thrilled if he felt the same about tourist helicopters.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a Quinnipiac poll on Bill de Blasio’s tenure so far revealed, among other judgments, that 64 percent of respondents feel the mayor should not ban horse-drawn carriages, something he has vowed to do, despite disapproval from union leaders and Liam Neeson. It is hard not to admire the ease with which the mayor, standing for the rights of animals, is obviously willing to forfeit any chance of an invitation to the premiere of “Taken 3,” and at the same time it is hard not to wonder whether his passion for ending a particularly self-indulgent mode of sightseeing might extend to curtailing or eliminating other dubious methods of experiencing the city’s landmarks.

headline: Big Ticket | Upper East Side Townhouse for $15.77 Million
abstract: An Upper East Side townhouse, built in neo-Classical style in 1899, has five stories and extravagant backyard gardens.
lead_paragraph: A neo-Classical townhouse on East 64th Street that received its first face-lift in 1910 from John W. Cross, the architect of the Tiffany & Company flagship store on Fifth Avenue, sold for $15,775,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The annual property taxes on the 14-room home are $61,246; the initial 2012 asking price was $19.5 million.

headline: In a Squall of Mayhem, Lines Not Crossed
abstract: Gareth Evans, director of the new movie “The Raid 2: Berandal,” achieves a brutally realistic action aesthetic by deliberately limiting his cinematic tools.
lead_paragraph: Recently, the action-movie genre has evolved into a magpie mash-up of international styles: a no-holds-barred cinema where seemingly anything goes. It’s not just that action films range from the pyrotechnic spectacle of Michael Bay to the ugly realism of indie fight tales, or from the jittery documentary-style realism of Kathryn Bigelow to the superhuman hyperbole of Bryan Singer. Now a single film will often deploy every device at once: hyperfast editing and bullet-time slow motion, fanciful kung fu wire work and gritty mixed martial arts, apocalyptic Imax 3-D destruction and acrobatic parkour. The action-movie director has never had so many tools, a development that has yielded some thrilling spectacles and some incoherent messes.

headline: A Mystery Woman’s Eye on the World
abstract: Vivian Maier, the subject of the documentary “Finding Vivian Maier,” was a first-class shooter and world-class pack rat whose gift went unrecognized in her lifetime.
lead_paragraph: In her self-portraits, the photographer Vivian Maier could be the actress playing herself in the movie of her life. She confronts the camera with utter self-possession. She affects an austere, distancing look. Her medium-format Rolleiflex is ever-present, slung around her neck, cradled at her sternum, capturing the image reflected off a store window or car mirror. Her clothes — broad hats and big coats, calculated to conceal — suggest a secret agent in a postwar film noir.

headline: Kate Bush to Return to the Stage After 35 Years
abstract: The British songwriter announced on Friday that she would play 15 concerts in London in August and September.
lead_paragraph: Kate Bush, the British singer-songwriter known for her invitingly eccentric melodies and lyrics with a flexible vocal style to match, announced on her website on Friday that she would play 15 concerts in London in August and September, her first extensive run of shows since 1979, at the beginning of her career, when she toured with an elaborately staged and choreographed production.

headline: As Malaysia Goes Its Own Way Over Missing Jet, China Finds Limits to Power
abstract: Within China, relatives and friends of the passengers press for answers, but the government finds itself helpless as Malaysia takes the lead in the investigation.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China has not held back in forcing the pace of the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370. It has deployed 21 satellites and a flotilla of naval ships. It has dispatched investigators to Malaysia, run background checks on the Chinese passengers, and scoured radar images of its vast western regions. Every day it has cajoled, chided and criticized Malaysian officials.

headline: Taking More Than Mitts to Australia for Opener
abstract: Tons of material, including clay from California, have transformed the Sydney Cricket Ground into a baseball stadium for Saturday’s season opener, between the Diamondbacks and the Dodgers.
lead_paragraph: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — Grant Balfour’s father, David, played rugby for the Balmain Tigers in Australia. Grant would play rugby, too, but he changed the course of his life with one simple question: “What are you guys doing?”

headline: Image of the Day: March 21
abstract: World Water Day was instituted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1993 and is observed every year on March 22.

headline: Caribbean Flavors, Southern Harmonies
abstract: Although its name evokes memories of a children’s TV show, Alvin & Friends draws an urbane, adult crowd that likes to dress for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Alvin & Friends, a darling of downtown New Rochelle, has moved from its tight quarters on Lawton Street to spacious new digs on Memorial Highway. The place looks like a million bucks, with high ceilings, yards and yards of banquette seating and plenty of elbow room, which comes in handy when you have to fend off companions as they reach for your last morsel of firecracker shrimp or that last lick of ginger crème brûlée.

headline: F.B.I. Agent Is Cleared in Fatal Shooting of Man Tied to Boston Suspects
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)']
abstract: The initial accounts of the shooting, which occurred during an interrogation, conflicted and three inquiries were opened.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. agent who fatally shot a Chechen man in Orlando, Fla., during an interrogation in May about the Boston Marathon bombing suspects has been cleared of wrongdoing by a prosecutor in Florida and by an F.B.I. internal review, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Battle for SFR Puts Vivendi in Driver’s Seat
abstract: The bidding war between two eager suitors for the mobile phone unit SFR gives Vivendi leverage to extract a better deal, Quentin Webb writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The latest pitch by Bouygues for SFR, Vivendi’s mobile phone unit, may still fall short. The French building, TV and telecommunications group has sweetened its offer with 1.85 billion euros more cash and heavyweight backers. That puts extra pressure on the preferred bidder, Patrick Drahi, soon after he began three weeks of exclusive talks to buy France’s No. 2 wireless carrier. But Bouygues still poses greater antitrust risks. It may need to offer more equity in the combined company — and a big breakup fee.

headline: Border Patrol Seeks to Add Digital Eyes to Its Ranks
abstract: The Border Patrol is focusing on concentrating Border Patrol agents, equipped with late-model surveillance tools, in areas of frequent illegal traffic, while using aerial drones to monitor remote, lightly trafficked spots.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Among the federal officials who gathered here this week for a conclave on border security, there was little talk of building a fence along the 2,000-mile Mexican border. Instead, the chatter was all about technology: about concentrating Border Patrol agents, equipped with late-model surveillance tools, in areas of frequent illegal traffic, while using aerial drones to monitor remote, lightly trafficked spots.

headline: New American Amid the Salt Hay
abstract: A farm-to-table restaurant in Carlstadt prepares some of the best locally sourced New American dishes in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: In a tiny kitchen in Carlstadt, a town in southern Bergen County better known for its proximity to the Meadowlands than for farm-to-table restaurants, Todd Villani prepares some of the best locally sourced New American dishes in New Jersey.

headline: Michelle Obama in China
abstract: The first lady began her visit to Beijing, accompanied by China’s first lady, Peng Liyuan.
lead_paragraph: The first lady began her visit to Beijing, accompanied by China’s first lady, Peng Liyuan.

headline: Behind a Simple Storefront, a Standout
abstract: At understated Thai Coconut in Wantagh, the flavors sparkle and diners can weigh their appetite for spice.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, new Asian restaurants on Long Island have resembled palaces, each more dramatic than the last. Thai Coconut is a different story: a modest storefront, set across the street from the Wantagh station of the Long Island Rail Road. The vibrant flavors, tender meats and sparkling seafood, not the setting, are what make Thai Coconut stand out.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Dan Hurley’s ‘Smarter’
abstract: Mr. Hurley discusses his new book about the science of increasing the brain’s power.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Annie Murphy Paul reviews Dan Hurley’s “Smarter: The New Science of Building Brain Power.” Ms. Paul writes:

headline: Wanderlust | Madurai, India, Where Time Stands Still
abstract: For millennia, the city has served as a wellspring of culture in the state of Tamil Nadu. Today, it still offers travelers an immersive history lesson in Indian tradition.
lead_paragraph: Though it’s home to more than a million people, Madurai, the second-largest city in the South Indian state of Tamil Nadu, remains a paradigmatic temple town. Around its ragged edges, Madurai looks much like any other medium-sized Indian city, with its clusters of concrete buildings and traffic-choked streets. But at its center – an elegant arrangement of concentric ring roads surrounding the labyrinthine, 17-acre compound of the Meenakshi Temple, among the holiest in South India – the city feels timeless. You come here not to experience the much-touted New India but the India that has endured for centuries.

headline: Stunned by Duke’s Exit? Mercer Isn’t
abstract: With a senior-laden roster, Mercer, the 14th seed in the Midwest Region, coolly knocked off No. 3 Duke, a perennial power, in Raleigh, N.C.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Four national championships, a Hall of Fame coach, five-star recruits each year and national exposure second to none. That is the Duke men’s basketball program, the envy of most and the measure of just about every team in the N.C.A.A.

headline: Artistic Problems Delay Rockettes’ ‘Heart and Lights’ Until 2015
abstract: The Rockettes’ new high-tech show, “Heart and Lights,” which was supposed to open last week, will be postponed until 2015 because it needs more work, producers say.
lead_paragraph: “Heart and Lights,” a new dance-oriented show featuring the Rockettes, has been canceled less than a week before it was supposed to open at Radio City Music Hall, its producer announced on Friday, saying that “it has become clear that additional work is needed” before the production is ready for audiences.

headline: Home as Scene Stealer
abstract: When the script called for a trophy house, a property in Los Angeles played itself.
lead_paragraph: This particular ode to American exceptionalism came wrapped as a lengthy Cadillac commercial looping throughout the Olympics and the Academy Awards. In it, the actor Neal McDonough portrays a brash, fast-talking cheerleader for capitalism who gets in digs at “other countries” for taking “August off. Off!”

headline: Once a Hit, Its Ratings Make ‘Idol’ An Also-Ran
abstract: On Thursday night, the singing competition sank below the 2.0 ratings barrier, something seemingly incomprehensible even two years ago.
lead_paragraph: The fall of the house of “Idol” continues unabated this season, despite the introduction of improved production values on the show and an appealing new lineup of judges.

headline: Russia’s Shifting of Border Force Stirs U.S. Worry
abstract: The national security adviser, Susan E. Rice, expressed skepticism that troop movements on the border of southern and eastern Ukraine were merely training exercises.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House cast doubt Friday on the Kremlin’s claims that thousands of troops massing on the border of southeastern Ukraine are merely involved in training exercises, deepening fears that Russian aggression will not end in Crimea.

headline: Don’t Worry, Get Botox
abstract: If you can’t frown, it may be harder to be depressed.
lead_paragraph: FEELING down? Smile. Cheer up. Put on a happy face. No doubt you’ve dismissed these bromides from friends and loved ones because everyone knows that you can’t feel better just by aping a happy look.

headline: Another Price Cut for the Xbox One
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'PlayStation 4 (Video Game System)', 'Xbox One (Video Game System)']
abstract: On Friday, Walmart and Best Buy began offering a bundle of Microsoft’s Xbox One and Titanfall, a high-profile science fiction shooter game, for $450, a $50 price cut on the bundle.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Sony‘s pricing advantage over Microsoft for the latest generation of game consoles didn’t last long.

headline: A Long Way From Down-Home
abstract: The name, Eleven14 Kitchen, belies the sophistication and polish of the year-old restaurant in the JHouse Greenwich, a smart-looking boutique hotel.
lead_paragraph: For a restaurant as stylishly handsome as Eleven14 Kitchen in Riverside, the name seems curiously ill-fitting.

headline: Video: Neil Burger Narrates a Scene From ‘Divergent’
abstract: The director Neil Burger narrates a scene from “Divergent.”
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Neil Burger discusses a scene from “Divergent,” the film adaptation of Veronica Roth’s novel, featuring Shailene Woodley.

headline: Reader Questions, Answered: Returning to Work After a Career Break
abstract: Times readers ask career development experts for guidance on returning to the workforce after a break to care for children or aging parents.
lead_paragraph: After we reported this week on new efforts to help professional women find their way back into the work force after taking a break to care for their family, we invited readers on Motherlode, Twitter and Facebook to ask questions about their own efforts to return to work. Here are some answers from Carol Fishman Cohen and Vivian Steir Rabin, co-authors of “Back on the Career Track,” and co-founders of iRelaunch, which provides resources for people looking to return to work after staying home to care for children or aging parents.

headline: Baylor Continues Its Late Run as Nebraska Goes Cold
abstract: Baylor, which lost 8 of its first 10 Big 12 games this season, continued its late-season turnaround, capitalizing on Nebraska’s cold first-half shooting.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Baylor Coach Scott Drew sat in front of an N.C.A.A. banner and acknowledged, with a laugh, how fortunate he was to be doing so. This had all seemed so distant, so improbable, in January, when his Bears were languishing at the bottom of the Big 12, having lost 8 of their first 10 conference games.

headline: The Gun Report: March 21, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: During its latest gun buyback in Newark, N.J., last month, Jewelry for a Cause—which shreds firearms and melts them down into jewelry—collected 185 guns ranging from sniper rifles to assault weapons. Some photos from the resulting “shred” are above.

headline: Finding Each Other, Midlife
abstract: The Bay Area plays a big part in a couple’s romance.
lead_paragraph: Though Stephanie Rosenbaum had led more than 100 food tours of San Francisco, she rarely saw a single man older than 40 take part. Mainly women and couples wanted her insider’s take on the city’s food scene.

headline: New York Owes No Damages in Child’s Death in 2007, a Jury Decides
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The estate of Hailey Gonzalez, a Staten Island girl who was fatally beaten in 2007, will receive no damages, even though caseworkers were faulted.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes in a verdict, a tiny legal point can make all the difference.

headline: Sentimental Journey
abstract: A huge part of the pleasure of travel is seeing how other people live and broadening our understanding of them and, in turn, ourselves.
lead_paragraph: My mother-in-law hates to travel. As a consolation, she’s turned family trips into shopping trips that over the years yielded a staggering collection of quirky egg cups and flower frogs (those things that go inside vases to hold stems in place). The search for these oddities gave her a way to enter strange places on her own terms. They led her into local shops and outdoor markets, introduced her to interesting people and gave purpose to her wanderings when her husband and children decided to hit the second or third major museum of the day.

headline: Skadden to Pay $4.25 Million in Fletcher Bankruptcy Case
abstract: The trustee overseeing the bankruptcy of the investment firm once led by the flashy money manager Alphonse Fletcher Jr. has reached a $4.25 million settlement with the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, which once represented Mr. Fletcher’s firm.
lead_paragraph: The trustee overseeing the bankruptcy of the investment firm once led by the flashy money manager Alphonse Fletcher Jr. has reached a $4.25 million settlement with the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include co-ops in Kips Bay and the Sutton area, and a condo in Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: In Paris, Pictures at an Airport Exhibition
abstract: Espace Musees offers free showcases at Roissy-Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The wait before boarding a plane can feel interminable, but those passing through Paris’s Roissy-Charles de Gaulle Airport have a stimulating alternative to idle perfume-testing in the tax-free zone.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a nine-bedroom 1905 house in Garden City, N.Y., and five-bedroom 1968 home in Cos Cob, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

headline: Tantalizing Matchups in Champions League Quarterfinals
abstract: Bayern Munich, the defending champion, will play Manchester United; Barcelona will face Atlético Madrid; Real Madrid meets Borussia Dortmund; and Paris St.-Germain takes on Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: The draw in Zurich on Friday for the quarterfinals of the Champions League yielded four tantalizing matchups.

headline: Weekend Reading: March Madness, Wall St. Edition
abstract: A number of sides are facing off in our financial coverage of the past week. Since we’ve already blown our NCAA brackets, lets try out the concept with Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: A number of sides are facing off in our financial coverage of the past week. Since we’ve already blown our NCAA college basketball brackets, lets try out the concept with the news from Wall Street.

headline: Legends of the Clipboard
abstract: There is a long line of colorful characters who have given a thumbs up or thumbs down on an evening’s entertainment.
lead_paragraph: There is a long line of colorful characters who have given a thumbs up or thumbs down on an evening’s entertainment.

headline: Playing Poker With the Devil
abstract: “The Seafarer” is working-class-lyrical drama by Conor McPherson about a group of Irishmen who play a card game with an uninvited guest.
lead_paragraph: Maybe this is what an Irish holiday house party looks like outside of the lace-curtain neighborhoods.

headline: Premiums Rise for Long-Term Care Insurance. Keep It or Drop It?
abstract: Even if the premium goes up, it may be worthwhile to keep a current policy, some specialists say.
lead_paragraph: Every day, Jesse Slome says, about a half-dozen people contact his office at the American Association for Long-Term Care Insurance, a group for industry professionals, to complain about premium increases on their policies.

headline: Spring Travel Issue
abstract: T wanders the globe, from the Greek island of Hydra to the Uruguayan fishing village of José Ignacio, checking in on single-room hotels, small museums and unusual barbershops along the way.
lead_paragraph: This spring, T is all over the map. Our travel issue visits the sun-soaked Greek island of Hydra, a place of unspoiled and beauty and automobile-free cobblestone streets that seduced Henry Miller and Leonard Cohen, and that remains a refuge for artists and intellectuals. We head to the sleepy Uruguayan fishing village of José Ignacio, where a small group of locals and expats are preserving the area’s small-town vibe despite its growing reputation as a beach-lover’s paradise. Out of the sun, we share the charms of one-room hotels in four different cities and the Turkish novelist Orhan Pamuk extols the virtues of small museums, like his own Museum of Innocence, that offer an inventiveness and personality not found in mega-institutions. Plus, a writer visits barbershops from Beijing to Beirut searching for both the perfect shave and an unforgettable experience; a 18th-century French salon gets resurrected in San Francisco; and one extreme traveler shares pages from his ink-stained passports. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Brooklyn’s Dance Fever
abstract: A group of artists contort their bodies while performing flex, a Brooklyn dance featured in the film “Flex Is Kings.”
lead_paragraph: A group of artists contort their bodies while performing flex, a Brooklyn dance featured in the film “Flex Is Kings.”

headline: Silk Road Case Began With Hunt for a John Doe
abstract: The criminal case against Ross W. Ulbricht began quietly with an indictment filed in a Maryland courthouse against an unidentified individual five months before the authorities made an arrest.
lead_paragraph: The criminal case against Ross W. Ulbricht, the man who federal prosecutors contend is the mastermind behind the notorious Silk Road online marketplace for illegal drugs and hacked credit card numbers, began quietly with an indictment filed in a Maryland courthouse against an unidentified individual five months before the authorities made an arrest.

headline: They’ve Got Moves
abstract: Flex, which began as a street dance by young people across East New York and Flatbush, Brooklyn, now has fans across the world and is the subject of a film, “Flex Is Kings.”
lead_paragraph: Flex is the dance. Its practitioners tell stories — cinematic slices of street life — gliding, pausing, dropping, shivering, contorting. One moment their movements are smooth and airy, then suddenly they’re violent, sharp like broken glass. Dancers slow time and speed it up. They use props, costumes and illusion. And their faces twist, transmitting fear, fury, love, mockery.

headline: Small Roles Make Big Impressions
abstract: DJ Qualls, Terry Crews, Marisa Ramirez, Silas Weir Mitchell and Joelle Carter are bringing vivid portrayals to series this season.
lead_paragraph: The Method creator Konstantin Stanislavski supposedly said, “There are no small parts, only small actors.” Then again, maybe it was just an agent trying to cheer up an underemployed client. In any case, a number of performers are currently making big impressions with relatively minuscule amounts of screen time.

headline: If Your Chauffeur Needs a Snowplow
abstract: With a serious all-wheel-drive system, 21-inch wheels and winter tires, the Bentley Flying Spur is an unstoppable monster in the snow: a 616-horsepower Zamboni that could glide around the boards at 120 m.p.h.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It started with a few innocent flakes. (Doesn’t it always?) And then a snowstorm barreled into town the night after Christmas, frosting rows of parked cars and smothering the Walter P. Reuther Freeway, an unofficial autobahn where traffic tends to stream at 80 to 85 miles per hour. But not tonight. Confidence plummeted in direct proportion to the snowfall. Drivers picked their way along the freeway’s eerie, white-glowing moonscape like nervous skiers on a powder run.

headline: Wolf for Wall Street
abstract: Bentley’s Flying Spur ultraluxury sedan prevails in bad weather, but not all of its technology is cutting-edge.
lead_paragraph: Bentley’s Flying Spur ultraluxury sedan prevails in bad weather, but not all of its technology is cutting-edge.

headline: The (Door) Man of the Hour
abstract: Bedecked in hats, jewels and other eye-popping finery, Markus Kelle is among the most visible guardians of the gate at New York nightclubs.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to miss Markus Kelle, 24, at the door of Westgay, the scruffy Tuesday night party at Westway on Clarkson Street in the West Village. At midnight on a recent Tuesday, he wore a black snood, clip-on earrings made of old celluloid, blood-red lipstick and a pavement-length silver fox coat.

headline: Hall of Fame Removes Trainer From Ballot
abstract: The trainer Steve Asmussen was removed from the Racing Hall of Fame ballot as three states investigate accusations that he and an assistant mistreated their horses.
lead_paragraph: Steve Asmussen was removed Friday as one of the finalists for the Racing Hall of Fame while three states investigate allegations that he and an assistant mistreated thoroughbred racehorses in their care.

headline: A Cross Between Risotto and Paella, the Catalan Way
abstract: Fideus noodles are first browned in olive oil, then simmered in a rich fish and shellfish broth and topped with mussels and shrimp.
lead_paragraph: One of the best meals I ever had was on a strip of beach near Barcelona’s port, in a seafood restaurant built on stilts. Barceloneta, as the area is called, housed a collection of such places, each with a barker outside and breezy nautical dining rooms looking out to sea. Most had tables set in the sand below, too. (This vanished when the city later remodeled for the Olympics and it became a boardwalk.) All fish, all day was the motto, and indeed it was the very freshest.

headline: Oops, Sorry for Being So Creepy
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Privacy', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: How online and technological gaffes can make us seem unintentionally sinister.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever been unintentionally “cybercreepy”? I have. A few weeks ago, after stashing my bathing suit and towel in my locker at my gym, I reached for my cellphone to check my email. “You can’t have a cellphone in here!” an older gym-goer rebuked me. Thinking he feared I was about to conduct a lengthy phone call about how I like enough mustard on a sandwich such that the salami comes alive but not so much that it becomes a mustard sandwich, I explained to the man that I was only checking my email. “No, it’s not that,” he rightly explained to me. “There are naked people in here.” I apologized and skittered off.

headline: N.C.A.A. Round of 64: The Day in Pictures
abstract: Day 2 of the round of 64 was full of more excitement, including Duke losing to Mercer and Stanford toppling New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Day 2 of the round of 64 was full of more excitement, including Duke losing to Mercer and Stanford toppling New Mexico.

headline: Costume Drama on the Cheap
abstract: The Theater Development Fund’s Costume Collection conducts a semiregular Bag Sale of decommissioned outfits from Broadway performances, giving castoffs a second life onstage.
lead_paragraph: “Man your battle stations!” Around 3 p.m. on a recent Friday, the announcement came over the P.A. system deep inside the basement of the Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens. A jolt of expectation shot through a line of nearly 50 people, who had been patiently waiting in a hallway outside a set of locked doors.

headline: The xx Makes Over the Armory
abstract: The British pop band the xx play on themes of exposure and intimacy in the immensity of the Park Avenue Armory drill hall, inverting almost all of what is expected in rock.
lead_paragraph: The British pop band the xx play on themes of exposure and intimacy in the immensity of the Park Avenue Armory drill hall, inverting almost all of what is expected in rock.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wearing It Forward
abstract: Guests dressed for the fall Dior show on Feb. 28, at the Rodin Museum in Paris, made a loud statement about the diversity of the women.
lead_paragraph: Guests dressed for the fall Dior show on Feb. 28, at the Rodin Museum in Paris, made a loud statement about the diversity of the women.

headline: Credit Suisse Reaches $885 Million Mortgage Settlement
abstract: The Swiss bank says it will take a charge of about $311.5 million to resolve claims it sold questionable loans to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse  said on Friday that it had reached an $885 million settlement to resolve claims that it sold questionable loans to the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in the lead-up to the financial crisis.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wear it Forward
abstract: Guests dressed for the fall Dior show on Feb. 28, at the Rodin Museum in Paris, made a loud statement about the diversity of the women.
lead_paragraph: Guests dressed for the fall Dior show on Feb. 28, at the Rodin Museum in Paris, made a loud statement about the diversity of the women. A highlight: seeing what they had on from the previous Dior show, held last September for the spring line; back then, it seemed like two shows, the first one with all the dressmaker details that customers admire, and the second featuring silver flecked brocades (top left). If the clients in February were a gauge, brocades (top) won out over details (the three women at left). My first Paris Dior show was in 1951, Only couture was presented; ready-to-wear did not exist. Highly styled women went privately, days after the show. Another item from September worn a few weeks ago: a swatch of fabric around the waist (far right), which Raf Simons created by lifting a sash built into a 1949 Dior dress (far right, bottom) and making it an accessory. Will the stoles worn on the arm on the runway a few weeks ago (bottom) end up on clients in September?

headline: Countdown to the 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 83
abstract: It is a list that no player ever wants to see his name on: the best players never to have played in a World Cup. Alfredo di Stefano is at the top.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Remembering L’Wren Scott, Kim and Kanye’s Cover Story and Phoebe Philo’s Crowning Moment
abstract: Plus, Mulberry’s latest loss, Kate Moss’s music review and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Stanford Sends New Mexico to Another Early Exit
abstract: Seventh-seeded New Mexico was upset by 10th-seeded Stanford in the N.C.A.A. tournament, a year after it was stunned by Harvard.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Some teams want to avoid top seeds in the opening game of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Other teams want to sidestep opponents with contrasting playing styles to ensure the best matchup of skills.

headline: The xx’s Armory Show: Step by Step
abstract: The group’s 11-day run is more more ambitious and more intimate than anything it has attempted before.
lead_paragraph: The British electro-pop trio the xx is no stranger to vast concert spaces, having headlined the Governors Ball Music Festival and Radio City Music Hall. But the shows the group is staging in the 55,000-square-foot Drill Hall at the Park Avenue Armory are more ambitious and more intimate than anything it has attempted before.

headline: L’Wren Scott: A Legacy of Elegance
abstract: Ms. Scott favored an elegant, ladylike style often called “Old Hollywood.”
lead_paragraph: IN THE AFTERMATH of L’Wren Scott’s death, media coverage, which was in no short supply, tended to focus on the questions of why and who. Why a woman who seemed to have it all would choose to end her life, and who among her friends, beginning with her partner, Mick Jagger, could explain it. Less attention was paid to what she had created: her fashion collections.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 21
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes a church service after a gas explosion in Harlem, a four-alarm fire in Brooklyn, and a hoarder who was evicted from his Manhattan apartment.
lead_paragraph: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s second official weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s second official weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: I’m Not Getting Better, I’m Getting Older
abstract: An amusing book by Annabelle Gurwitch asks a serious question: How are we supposed to age?
lead_paragraph: “No more prostitutes,” Annabelle Gurwitch says as we swill our pinot grigio in the lobby bar of the Shutters hotel in Santa Monica, Calif. “It’s tragic. Playing prostitutes used to be my specialty.” The actress/author and I are gleefully debating everything in life we must leave behind now that we’re over 50, and everything we must embrace.

headline: An Online Generation Redefines Mourning
keywords: ['Grief (Emotion)', 'Death and Dying', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Youth', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: Expressions of grief take on many public forms in the digital age.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, when Rebecca Soffer’s father died of a heart attack on a cruise to the Bahamas, the condolence notes came pouring in, many in the form of text messages. “I got so many from very good friends,” Ms. Soffer, 37, said from the couch of her Upper West Side apartment not long ago. “They said they were ‘sorry’ or ‘how r u?’ ”

headline: Fresh From a Kentucky Sinkhole, Recovered ’Vettes Draw Crowds
abstract: As a museum recovers Corvettes that fell into a sinkhole, it finds that the damaged cars have become a tourist attraction.
lead_paragraph: Corvettes are built to go fast and stop fast, but they were never designed to free-fall 40 or 50 feet. Yet that is what happened to eight of the Chevrolet sports cars in the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky., when a sinkhole opened in the facility’s Skydome area in the predawn hours of Feb. 12.

headline: Taking Bids for the Next Beast
abstract: With a new president to arrive in 2017, the Secret Service is seeking bids for a new limo to replace President Obama’s 2009 Cadillac.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service is shopping for a new car — something durable and roomy, and unlike anything else on the road.

headline: Sticker Shock From the Options Sheet
abstract: Choosing options was once a normal part of buying a car. But today it’s a luxury experience reserved almost exclusively for high-end machines. And those options have grown ever more indulgent.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF. — Up a flight of stairs from the Porsche Design boutique on Rodeo Drive, in a room of modernist sofas and chairs, low white coffee tables and oversize video monitors, is the Porsche Exclusive-Personal Design suite. Prospective car buyers come to this luxury lounge to optimize their accessories: Here, they can choose precisely the right optional extras to maximize their vehicular happiness.

headline: Evening Hours | Cultural Swirl
abstract: Art, music and dance were the focus of many benefits as winter came to a close.
lead_paragraph: Art, music and dance were the focus of many benefits as winter came to a close.

headline: Earthy, With a Hint of Fiberglass
abstract: Collectors groaned when $1 million worth of Corvettes plunged into a sinkhole at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky.
lead_paragraph: Collectors groaned when $1 million worth of Corvettes plunged into a sinkhole at the National Corvette Museum in Bowling Green, Ky.

headline: Under Cover: Ian Lawrence on Becoming One of the Faces of Bisexuality
abstract: Ian Lawrence, who has been an activist in the bisexual community for 14 years, didn’t hesitate to be interviewed and photographed for Benoit Denizet-Lewis’s article about the quest to prove scientifically that bisexuality exists.
lead_paragraph: Ian Lawrence, who has been an activist in the bisexual community for 14 years, didn’t hesitate to be interviewed and photographed for Benoit Denizet-Lewis’s article about the quest to prove scientifically that bisexuality exists. Still, Lawrence was surprised when he landed on the cover of this Sunday’s magazine. Here’s what he had to say about his family’s reaction and what he plans to do with this newfound visibility.

headline: The Decline and Fall of the ‘H’ Word
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Many gays and lesbians flinch at the word homosexual.
lead_paragraph: To most ears, it probably sounds inoffensive. A little outdated and clinical, perhaps, but innocuous enough: homosexual.

headline: Institutional Memory Onstage
abstract: On Sunday evening, dancers who have worked with the Paul Taylor Dance Company will fill the Koch Theater for an anniversary performance.
lead_paragraph: A choreographer needs a dancer the way a dancer needs a choreographer. It’s an even swap.

headline: In Many States, Few Legal Rights for C.C.R.C. Residents
abstract: Continuing care retirement communities are regulated by a loose patchwork of state laws.
lead_paragraph: “I’m not naïve about the corporate world,” Burton Richter told me when we spoke about the class action lawsuit he and other residents are bringing against Vi at Palo Alto, a very upscale continuing care retirement community.

headline: In the Air | Space Age Style
abstract: This season, fashion looks to the heavens, taking inspiration from both space-age design and the wondrous immensity of the night sky.
lead_paragraph: This season, fashion looks to the heavens, taking inspiration from both space-age design and the wondrous immensity of the night sky.

headline: The Government Is No Drunken Sailor
abstract: One thing you can’t say is that the federal government has been spending like a drunken sailor, writes an economist.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Top-Seeded Arizona’s Road So Far Has Been a Struggle
abstract: Arizona did not play with the sharpness of a top seed, struggling with 16th-seeded Weber State in its opening game of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — When Arizona was delayed by nearly four hours when it traveled here Wednesday night, it might have been a sign that the road to the Final Four would not be as easily traversed as the Wildcats imagined.

headline: The Sinkhole Doubters Emerge
abstract: After several Corvettes fell into a sinkhole in Kentucky, the conspiracy theories began.
lead_paragraph: Was it an inside job?

headline: A Dance Spreads Joy for Mercer
abstract: The Mercer players celebrated their win over Duke with the Nae Nae, a dance that has become a near universally recognized language of celebration the last couple of months.
lead_paragraph: In Mercer’s 78-71 upset victory over Duke on Friday in the N.C.A.A. tournament, the senior guard Kevin Canevari had zero points, one assist and one spontaneous outburst of joy gone viral.

headline: The Tentative, the Vibrant and Then the Impassioned
abstract: The Israel Philharmonic Orchestra’s concert on Thursday night included works by Brahms, Tchaikovsky and the Israeli composer Odon Partos.
lead_paragraph: In its official biography, the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra is described as the country’s premier cultural ambassador. The ensemble’s international tours are also good-will missions. Its current 14-city American tour brought the orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Thursday night for a concert presented by the American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.

headline: How and Why They Are Raising the Bayonne Bridge Roadway
abstract: Diagrams showing the current and planned roadways on the bridge.
lead_paragraph: Diagrams showing the current and planned roadways on the bridge.

headline: Going Up! A Bridge Makes Way for Bigger Ships
abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is undertaking a $1.3 billion project to raise the roadway of the Bayonne Bridge by 64 feet, to a height of 215 feet above the water.
lead_paragraph: When it opened in 1931, the Bayonne Bridge — with its parabolic arch connecting Staten Island and Bayonne, N.J. — was an engineering marvel, boasting the longest unsupported span of any steel arch bridge in the world. But the height of its roadway, at 151 feet above the Kill Van Kull waterway, is increasingly insufficient for the large container ships now calling at the container ports of Staten Island and New Jersey.

headline: After Playing In, Tennessee Plays On
abstract: Jarnell Stokes had 26 points and 14 rebounds on Friday for Tennessee, which beat Iowa on Wednesday in a First Four game.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Those First Four play-in games might be an insult to teams that are forced to compete in an extra contest even after making the tournament field. But maybe they’re not such a bad deal.

headline: ‘The Book of Mormon’ Is to Sell Tickets via StubHub
