abstract: The online ticket marketplace has made a deal with the producers and the ticketing service Telecharge to sell an allotment of premium seats for each performance.
lead_paragraph: StubHub, the online ticket marketplace, has long listed scalped seats for Broadway shows at high prices, to the chagrin of both theater fans and the producers missing lucrative markups. But now those producers are trying to get in on the action.

headline: A Galaxy of Orbs and Novas
abstract: Alonzo King’s “Constellation” features a grid of LED lights designed by the electronic artist Jim Campbell and strung up like a beaded curtain at the rear of the stage.
lead_paragraph: Alonzo King’s “Constellation” features a grid of LED lights designed by the electronic artist Jim Campbell and strung up like a beaded curtain at the rear of the stage. Illumination and color pass across the grid like a pixelated aurora borealis, sometimes outlining what seem to be shadows of birds in flight. But mostly the light is as incomprehensible as a solar flare. Mr. King’s dance, which his Lines Ballet opened  on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, is itself like a string of lights, with 19 shiny sections presented in 75 minutes. Mr. King leaves it to the viewer to connect the dots.

headline: Federal Judge Strikes Down Michigan’s Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A federal judge issued the latest in a string of rulings that say it is unconstitutional to deny marriage to gay couples.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Detroit struck down Michigan’s ban on same-sex marriage on Friday, the latest in a string of court decisions across the country to rule that denying marriage to gay and lesbian couples is a violation of the Constitution.

headline: Brazilian Yearning and Imminent Loss
abstract: At Café Carlyle, John Pizzarelli’s “Strictly Bossa Nova” captures the Brazilian concept of saudade, a longing for the unattainable and an acute sense of the moment slipping away.
lead_paragraph: “The Girl From Ipanema” has been embedded in the world’s consciousness for so long (half a century) that nowadays this seductive Antônio Carlos Jobim melody tends to register as cozy, even annoying background music. Do listeners even look beyond its travel poster image of a “tall and tan and young and lovely” dream girl on a beach, sketched in Norman Gimbel’s English-language translation of Vinicius de Moraes’s Portuguese lyrics?

headline: A Sunrise in the American Southwest Helps Inspire Another Dawning
abstract: Beth Gill’s “New Work for the Desert,” now at New York Live Arts, is partly inspired by a sunrise in the American Southwest.
lead_paragraph: Among the many wonders of Beth Gill’s “New Work for the Desert” is that the dance lasts an hour but seems much shorter or possibly much longer: It alters your sense of time. In this way, it successfully suggests one of its inspirations, a sunrise in the American Southwest. Thomas Dunn’s lighting, gradually brightening, eventually suffuses the white space with lemon and blood orange. But the greatest wonders emerge from Ms. Gill’s choreography and her six dancers.

headline: It Ain’t Over Till the Fat Man Spits: Recalling a Colorful Coach
abstract: “Bum Phillips All-American Opera,” a production at La MaMa, recalls the life of a Houston Oilers coach.
lead_paragraph: “Luv Ya Blue,” an electronic sign reads as you enter the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa for its current show, referring to the defunct Houston Oilers of the National Football League through the color of their home jerseys. The word “Blue” flashes at times, seeming to short out, then morphs into “Bum.”

headline: Detroit Symphony Dives Headlong Into Streaming
abstract: After a bitter strike, the Detroit Symphony has the most ambitious free web-streaming program of any major American orchestra, as it tries to help secure its future.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Orchestras and opera companies in the United States and Europe, facing uncertain futures and rapid changes in how people listen to music, are increasingly making forays into web streaming, taking one of Western culture’s most traditional live art forms out of theaters and concert halls and putting it onto small screens.

headline: Holding a Mirror to Race
abstract: A new website uses vintage photos — presented at first without context — to get viewers to confront everyday assumptions about race.
lead_paragraph: A new website uses vintage photos — presented at first without context — to get viewers to confront everyday assumptions about race.

headline: McDermott Scores 30 as Creighton Advances
abstract: Louisiana-Lafayette, a 14th seed, put up a fight before losing to Creighton in a game that was far closer than the score indicated.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — In assessing its showings at the N.C.A.A. tournament the last two years, Creighton did not feel that it had underachieved so much as failed to maximize its potential. There is a difference. Both times the Bluejays were bounced by a higher seed, the better team.

headline: Outside the U.S., Steps to Track Planes Better
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Since an Air France jet crashed off the coast of Brazil in 2009, some foreign regulators and airlines have moved much faster to advance technology.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Some foreign regulators and airlines have moved much faster than their American counterparts to adopt more advanced airplane tracking technology.

headline: Melodies Steeped in Memories
abstract: Jeffrey Kahane is conducting the New York Philharmonic in a program reflective of the interwar period.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes an outsider is best at showing an institution its own history, and on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Jeffrey Kahane held a striking mirror up to the New York Philharmonic of the 1920s and ’30s.

headline: The Spring North American Championships
abstract: The first national title decided at the Spring North American Championships began last year in bridge clubs across the continent.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The first national title decided at the Spring North American Championships began last year in bridge clubs across the continent.

headline: Pictures of the Day — Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Afghanistan and More: Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan and More: Pictures of the Day

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, Ukraine, Brazil and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, Ukraine, Brazil and India.

headline: Malaysian Opposition Leader Calls Speculation About Pilot of Missing Jet ‘Absurd’
abstract: Malaysia’s opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, dismissed speculation that the pilot of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 , a supporter of his movement for democratic change, might have hijacked the plane for political reasons.
lead_paragraph: Malaysia’s opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, dismissed speculation that the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet, a supporter of his movement for democratic change, might have hijacked the plane for political reasons, in an interview with Britain’s Channel 4 News on Friday.

headline: U.S. Pushes for Wider Recall of Graco Car Seats
keywords: ['Child Car Seats', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: When it issued a recall of 3.8 million child safety seats this year, the company resisted recalling an additional 1.8 million.
lead_paragraph: Graco Children’s Products, which resisted recalling about 1.8 million child restraints earlier this year, has responded to a special order from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration demanding more information about incidents or injuries involving the rear-facing infant restraints. But despite continued pressure from the safety agency, Graco is not saying whether it will remain steadfast in its refusal.

headline: Turkey and Twitter
abstract: What does the attempt to dismantle social media mean for Prime Minister Erdogan and Turkey, his so-called Muslim democracy?

headline: Cooking for Her Men, and Serving the Audience
abstract: A good-natured one-woman show relates the misadventures of a single woman cooking her way through romantic relationships.
lead_paragraph: Well, it’s no “Long Day’s Journey Into Night.”

headline: One Foot in Each of Two Worlds, and a Pen at Home in Both
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The writer Leila Aboulela, who was born in Egypt and raised in Sudan, and has long lived in Scotland, is sometimes criticized for taking a perspective outside of a purely Muslim, Arab or African viewpoint.
lead_paragraph: SHARJAH, United Arab Emirates — WHEN Leila Aboulela arrived at the international book fair here recently, the conference room was packed to capacity with dozens of eager listeners. After she finished reading a passage from her award-winning novel, “Lyrics Alley,” the torrent of questions — some in English, others in Arabic — began.

headline: Walking the Dog to Awaken the Muse
abstract: Lin-Manuel Miranda, who set his hit Broadway musical, “In the Heights” in Washington Heights, is moving there after living in Harlem. No matter the neighborhood, his Sundays have always been about art.
lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda has lived in Greenwich Village, Inwood, Upper West Hell (as he calls a dreary block between the Upper West Side and Hell’s Kitchen) and now Harlem with his wife, Vanessa Nadal, a lawyer, though they are about to move — at long last — to Washington Heights, where Mr. Miranda, 34, set his hit Broadway musical, “In the Heights.” Yet no matter the neighborhood, his Sundays have always been about art. Lately, besides working on “Hamilton,” a rap-infused bio-musical about Alexander Hamilton that will open early next year at the Public Theater, he has been curating a monthly film series at the United Palace of Cultural Arts in the Heights, where “Ghostbusters” is screening on March 23.

headline: Jets Release Mark Sanchez to Make Room for Michael Vick
abstract: The moves raise the question of what the team plans to do with Geno Smith, who will be entering his second season.
lead_paragraph: Jets Coach Rex Ryan once felt so certain of quarterback Mark Sanchez that he repeatedly referred to him as Sanchize and had a tattoo of his wife wearing a Sanchez jersey added to his right arm.

headline: Kansas Closes Out Eastern Kentucky
abstract: The Jayhawks used their depth, superior size and athleticism to avoid a shocking upset.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The Kansas players were aware of what had happened to Duke earlier Friday. The Blue Devils’ loss to Mercer in the Round of 64 was another reminder of the long history of upsets in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and its impact resonated on the Jayhawks’ bench before their South Region opener.

headline: Flowers, Yes, but Figures, Too, at ‘Garden Party’
abstract: A new exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art invites guests to shake off the winter chill and dream of nature.
lead_paragraph: Though the curators of “Garden Party,” the new exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor, could not have foreseen the brutal winter that has preceded their celebration of luscious flora, they nevertheless feel fortunate about the timing.

headline: Should We Welcome Private Science?
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Research', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Science and Technology', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Stakeholders respond to a front-page article, “Billionaires With Big Ideas Are Privatizing American Science.”

headline: Stores With Pharmacies That Sell Tobacco Products
abstract: Readers, including contributors to the 50th Anniversary Surgeon General’s Report, respond to a Business Day article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Betrayals of Paul Ryan
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Timothy Egan, “Paul Ryan’s Irish Amnesia.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nuclear Disarmament
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty']
abstract: A reader says we must continue to cooperate with Russia on nuclear arms control.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Countering the Gun Lobby
abstract: A reader suggests a citizen boycott of states with lax gun laws.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Friday Night Music: The Advantages of Floating
abstract: Somewhere, not here.
lead_paragraph: Not, as it turns out, about currency regimes; but there’s a pretty good exposition of physiocratic economics in there. Inspired, of course, by this morning’s Japan session at Brookings.

headline: Jack Fleck, Who Stole Hogan’s Moment at 1955 U.S. Open, Dies at 92
abstract: Fleck, little known until he defeated Ben Hogan in a playoff at Olympic Club in San Francisco, went on to win only two more events on the regular PGA Tour.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Fleck drove from his native Iowa to Olympic Club in San Francisco for the 1955 United States Open, he was in the midst of a two-year trial run to see if he could make it on the PGA Tour. If not, he would return to Davenport and the life of a professional at two municipal courses.

headline: Beware of Cold-Blooded Americans
abstract: Invasive U.S. turtles take all the good nesting spots and basking sites.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — AMERICANS are predatory. They invade other countries, prey on native populations and exploit their resources. They are typically voracious, opportunistic and highly adaptive. It is said they are filthy; they can tolerate living in polluted areas and can carry diseases to which locals have no immunity. As we speak, they are causing global ecological damage.

headline: Eyes Alighting Between the Canals
abstract: A small but exquisite show at the Bellarmine Museum examines the way Whistler’s unconventional response to Venice influenced other printmakers working there.
lead_paragraph: Ah, Venice. Can anyone go there without wanting to bring home a picture? In the 18th century, travelers bought paintings by Canaletto; today, tourists point and shoot with cellphones and digital cameras, capturing the same grand churches, peeling palaces and shimmering canals.

headline: If Only for a Night
abstract: The following poems about attraction on St. Patrick’s Day were “found” this week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org.
lead_paragraph: St. Patrick’s Day, that annual excuse for overindulgence, would seem — like alcohol itself — to heighten the desire for love while lessening the chance of achieving it. But at least according to the Internet, several revelers managed on Monday to find romance in spite of their intoxication. The following poems about attraction on St. Patrick’s Day were “found” this week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim with only line and stanza breaks added; their titles are the subject headings.Connolly’s St. Patrick’s DayYou told me I’m nice.You stroked my beardand told methat I’m handsomebut you weren’t into facial hair.You told me your nameand you left. Mm, I hope youfind me.4 or 5 Between Wall St & GCSWe shared a few glances,possibly a million miles apartbut I thoughtthere was a spark ofconnection.I was the guy in the greenjacketin a sea of green jackets.Luckily you asked“are you famous?”and we chatted for secondsbefore both getting off at GrandCentral Stationand going separate ways.You’re studying on the 17thas life goes onaround the St Patrick’s dayparade on 5th.Your brown eyes were hypnoticbut I did catch a glimpseof jet black hairand fair/pale complexionbefore having to look awayout of politenessI Told You You Were HandsomeI was waitressing St. Paddy’s....You were a firefighter. Youcame in after the paradeand was surprised Iremembered youand told you were handsome.We live very far apartbut you saidwe “could make it work.”Maybefor a least a night.Holly at Dermotts Today

headline: Unwilling to Allow His Wife a Divorce, He Marries Another
abstract: Protesters hope to free a woman “chained” under Orthodox Jewish law to a husband, even after a civil divorce and his remarriage.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The wedding was a modest affair, held in a reception hall overlooking an artificial lake tucked behind a suburban strip. But just minutes after it ended, the bride and groom hurriedly scurried past dozens of protesters here who were chanting “Bigamist!” and “Shame on you!”

headline: Coping When Not Entering Retirement Together
abstract: Couples nearing retirement must discuss not only whether they have enough, but what will happen when routines are different and less money flows in.
lead_paragraph: FOR Daniel Ryan, turning 40 and 50 came and went. But sometime around his 61st birthday last July, he said he had an “old man crisis.”

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Current Fees on Debit Card Purchases
keywords: ['Debit Cards', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The banks were victorious in the latest round over swipe fees the financial institutions charge retailers.
lead_paragraph: In the latest chapter of the debit card fee wars, the banks and Federal Reserve were dealt a victory on Friday when a federal appeals court overturned a lower court’s decision. The ruling means that the amount banks collect from retailers when consumers swipe debit cards can remain as is, and not be reduced further.

headline: Creativity vs. Quants
abstract: To be original, you need messiness and magic, serendipity and insanity.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how John Lennon wrote “Nowhere Man,” as he recalled it in an interview that ran just before he was murdered in 1980: After working five hours trying to craft a song, he had nothing to show for it. “Then, ‘Nowhere Man’ came, words and music, the whole damn thing as I lay down.”

headline: Highly Enriched Danger
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Uranium', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: The case against using weapons-grade fuel in naval reactors.
lead_paragraph: NEXT week President Obama will join 57 world leaders in The Hague for the third biannual Nuclear Security Summit. The first two summits played a critical role in phasing out the use of highly enriched uranium as fuel in research reactors to prevent its misuse by states or terrorists to make nuclear weapons.

headline: A Record for Tomic, but One to Quickly Forget
abstract: Bernard Tomic lost the fastest match in the recorded history of the men’s tour, succumbing, 6-0, 6-1, to Jarkko Nieminen in 28 minutes 20 seconds on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Many who saw the potential in the young star Bernard Tomic believed he would one day enter the record books in a far different fashion than the way he did Thursday.

headline: A Burst of Spring Blossoms
abstract: The red maple’s spring foliage rivals that of its autumn leaves.
lead_paragraph: The red maple (Acer rubrum) is an attention-grabber in its brilliant autumn guise, but the tree also produces a dazzling spring show for the observant urban naturalist. The tree’s delicate blossoms are as red as its autumn leaves, but they last only a few days.

headline: Lawmakers Attack Cost of New Hepatitis Drug
keywords: ['Sovaldi (Drug)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hepatitis', 'Biotechnology', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The congressmen’s inquiry about the $84,000 price for a 12-week course of treatment spurred a sell-off in biotechnology stocks on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A new drug to treat hepatitis C that costs $1,000 a pill has caused rising concern among insurers and state Medicaid programs. It has now also spurred interest from Democratic congressmen whose queries about the drug prompted a sell-off in biotechnology stocks on Friday.

headline: In Paris Campaign, Left and Right Have One Thing in Common
abstract: Paris is on the eve of electing its first female mayor: Anne Hidalgo of the Socialist Party or Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet of the conservative Union for a Popular Movement.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If cities had genders, Paris would almost surely be a woman. So much about it seems feminine: the sensuous curves of the Seine around which it is built, the ubiquitous concern for the cut of a coat, the elegance of its cityscape. And now, Paris is on the eve of electing its first female mayor.

headline: Sergeant Missing Since 1964 Is Given Funeral
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Vietnam War', 'Missing in Action']
abstract: Nearly 50 years after Staff Sgt. Lawrence Woods of the United States Army disappeared while fighting in the Vietnam War, he was buried at Arlington National Cemetery.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Nearly 50 years after Staff Sgt. Lawrence Woods of the United States Army disappeared while fighting in the Vietnam War, a funeral service was held for him at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: Russian Defiance Is Seen as a Confidence Builder for Syria’s Government
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The prospect of a deal brokered by Russian and American officials to end the Syrian war seems increasingly remote, as bonds deepen between Moscow and Damascus.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — Russia’s growing rift with the West over the crisis in Ukraine has bolstered the confidence of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, pro-government analysts here say, emboldening him to press ahead with plans for re-election despite a three-year insurgency and making Syrian officials doubt that Russia will pressure him to compromise anytime soon.

headline: Mercer Sees Value in Mastering a Simple Task That Foils Many
abstract: The Bears made seven of their last eight free throws to clinch their victory over Duke, but many of the tournament’s best teams struggle at the line.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The Mercer Bears and their unassuming, previously unappreciated band of underdogs — admit it, most of us had no idea where Mercer was even located, much less that great basketball was played there — had the precise ingredients for an upset.

headline: As Listener and Saleswoman, E.P.A. Chief Takes to the Road for Climate Rules
abstract: On trips that are both listening tour and sales pitch, Gina McCarthy, the E.P.A. administrator, is trying to counter a fight against planned rules limiting emissions by power plants.
lead_paragraph: BEULAH, N.D. — Gina McCarthy was deep in enemy territory.

headline: In Reprieve for Restaurant Industry, New York Proposes Changes to Grading System
abstract: Officials proposed tweaks to the current rating system so that restaurants would have more chances to appeal — and in some cases, avoid — financial penalties for many violations.
lead_paragraph: They are one of the most visible legacies of the Bloomberg administration and a ubiquitous presence in the culinary life of New York: the blue “A,” green “B” and orange “C” letter grades that trumpet the sanitary conditions of the restaurant within.

headline: E.P.A. Agrees to Join North Carolina in Reviewing Spill
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Clean Water Act', 'Coal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The federal Environmental Protection Agency will join North Carolina regulators in addressing potential violations of the Clean Water Act at Duke Energy power plants in that state.
lead_paragraph: The federal Environmental Protection Agency will join North Carolina regulators in addressing potential violations of the Clean Water Act at Duke Energy power plants, including a massive spill of toxic coal ash last month in the Dan River, state officials said on Friday.

headline: Blue Devils’ Parker Feels ‘Incomplete’ After Upset
abstract: Taking the loss to underdog Mercer hard, Duke’s star freshman forward now faces a choice: Return to school or go pro.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Eight hundred miles from Raleigh, N.C., where the Duke freshman Jabari Parker played on the biggest stage of his young life on Friday, friends, former teammates and teachers gathered in his high school lunchroom at Simeon Career Academy to watch his latest star turn.

headline: Rhode Island: Raids Target Speaker of State House, but Reason Is Unclear
abstract: Federal and state law enforcement agents raided the office and home of Gordon D. Fox, the speaker of the Rhode Island House, on Friday, but did not disclose what they were looking for.
lead_paragraph: Federal and state law enforcement agents raided the office and home of Gordon D. Fox, the speaker of the Rhode Island House, on Friday, but did not disclose what they were looking for. As news media gathered outside, agents filed out of both locations with boxes and bags. Mr. Fox returned home in the afternoon and said nothing to reporters who were waiting outside. Conducting the searches were agents from the F.B.I., the Internal Revenue Service, the United States attorney’s office and the state police. The surprise searches stunned Providence, sending politicians and reporters scurrying for answers that did not immediately materialize. The information vacuum did not stop some politicians from calling for the speaker’s resignation or others from suggesting they might run for speaker themselves. Mr. Fox, 52, a Democrat, was first elected to the state House of Representatives in 1992 and has been speaker since February 2010. He had planned to run again for his seat this fall and hoped to keep his position as speaker.

headline: Blue-Collar Renaissance: Texas Recalls How to Win
abstract: An N.C.A.A. tournament fixture on the skids, the Longhorns got back to basics in returning to form.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Smiles abounded in the Texas locker room on Friday, not quite 24 hours after the Longhorns won their first N.C.A.A. tournament game in three years. Players who were not interviewed pulled chairs near one another to chat, joke and laugh. And no one signaled disengagement by strapping on headphones or ear buds.

headline: Wheelies: The 20 Million Hondas Edition
abstract: Honda builds its 20 millionth car in the United States; BMW will produce X7 crossovers in Spartanburg, S.C.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Paul Ryan, Culture and Poverty
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Poverty', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Whatever the congressman meant by men “in inner cities,” there is danger where cover is given for corrosive ideas.
lead_paragraph: Paul Ryan continues to be flogged for disturbing comments he made last week about men “in our inner cities” and their “culture” of not working.

headline: U.S. and California Officials Enter Battle Over Facebook Privacy Settlement
abstract: Critics say a judge erred when he accepted Facebook’s argument that a federal privacy law for children under 13 preempted state protections for older children.
lead_paragraph: A couple of government wingmen have joined privacy groups in their legal dogfight with Facebook over the company’s use of teenagers’ likes and comments in advertising.

headline: After Ruling, Alabama Joins 2 States in Moving to Alter Voting Rules
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Alabama officials say a federal court decision in Kansas gives it strong footing to require potential voters to show concrete proof of citizenship.
lead_paragraph: Alabama says it plans to move ahead with a requirement for potential voters to show concrete proof of citizenship, in the first sign of a wider impact from a court decision on Wednesday ordering a federal elections agency to help Arizona and Kansas enforce their own such requirement.

headline: Trip Upstate Takes Coach Back to Roots
abstract: Villanova Coach Jay Wright got his start in coaching as an assistant at the University of Rochester, traveling around the state to recruit players.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — In 1984, Mike Neer, then the coach at the University of Rochester, needed a full-time assistant, somebody to get out on the road and recruit, but the 23-year-old sitting in the interview had experience with neither.

headline: Health Care Caricature
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Hardship exemptions won’t undermine health care reforms, as Republican leaders contend.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders are making preposterous assertions that President Obama has abandoned a centerpiece of his health care reforms — the requirement that most people obtain comprehensive insurance or pay a penalty. In a cartoonish misrepresentation of how so-called hardship exemptions will be determined, the leaders, egged on by their allies in the conservative media, contend that recent steps by the administration undermine the individual mandate by giving virtually everyone who wants one a free pass to escape the penalty.

headline: Gonzaga Is Good Enough
abstract: The Zags won their sixth consecutive tournament-opening game with a choppy victory over Oklahoma State.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — For a good portion of the last three months, Gonzaga guard Kevin Pangos has been troubled by turf toe and a sore ankle. His toe and ankle do not feel perfectly healthy, but at this point in the season he has no complaints.

headline: Turkey’s Move to Silence Twitter
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s assault on free speech reached a self-defeating low this week.
lead_paragraph: The Turkish government’s assault on free speech reached a self-defeating low this week with its order to silence Twitter — an authoritarian move that quickly backfired in the tech-savvy world of social media.

headline: Following Great Score With Good One, Scott Extends Lead
abstract: Bucking a trend on the PGA Tour this season, Adam Scott didn’t experience a major drop-off after his low score of 62 on Thursday, posting a four-under 68 in the second round Friday.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — In the first round of the Arnold Palmer Invitational, Adam Scott posted the 11th score of 62 or better on the PGA Tour this season. Two of the other 62’s — by Tim Clark at Sea Island, Ga., and Zach Johnson outside Palm Springs, Calif. — were recorded in the final round.

headline: Court Orders Rehiring of 2 Brooklyn Teachers in Misconduct Case
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A five-judge panel says that the termination of two Brooklyn teachers, who a custodian said had been undressed in an empty classroom, was “shockingly disproportionate” to their “lapse in judgment.”
lead_paragraph: It was a November night in 2009 when Alina Brito, a Spanish teacher at James Madison High School in Brooklyn, and Cindy Mauro, a French teacher there, went out with a colleague to a neighborhood restaurant for dinner, and a cocktail or two.

headline: As Sanctions Start, Russia Feels a Sting
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: With the onset of sanctions, Russia’s stock indexes opened sharply lower and agencies threatened to cut the country’s creditworthiness, but President Vladimir V. Putin’s oligarchs stood by him.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — American and European sanctions rattled Russia’s economy on Friday, with Moscow’s stock indexes opening sharply lower, rating agencies threatening to reduce the country’s creditworthiness, and hints of trepidation coming from Russia’s tycoons as they concluded an annual conference here.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 21, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 21, 2014

headline: Dying Churches, Revived in a Flash
abstract: Mass Mobs provide a welcome shot in the arm to dwindling congregations.
lead_paragraph: The idea behind Buffalo Mass Mob is simple. Pick an old Roman Catholic church, in one of Buffalo’s hollowed-out immigrant neighborhoods, where the congregation has dwindled to a white-haired few, where the spaces beneath the great stone arches ring with the echo of abandonment. Send the word by Facebook and Twitter to Catholics across western New York: O.K., everybody, let’s all show up there one Sunday.

headline: North Dakota State Thinks Big, Has Fun, Earns Attention
abstract: Every spring, it seems, a little-known team and a big personality emerge from the chaos of the N.C.A.A. tournament to capture national attention. This year, the first candidates are the Bison and their coach, Saul Phillips.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — The fun began long before North Dakota State Coach Saul Phillips, in the middle of a news conference Friday (the man has turned scripted drudgery into performance art), asked his boss for a raise. Phillips joked that he got the job in the first place because he “had pictures” of his boss, the athletic director, who just laughed.

headline: Two Cases, One Conclusion on Military Justice
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes', 'Courts-Martial']
abstract: Critics contend that the verdicts in two highly publicized sexual assault cases this week reflect a military command that bowed to political pressure and brought bad cases to trial.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two highly publicized military sexual assault cases this week appear to strengthen the argument of those who want to take such cases out of the hands of military commanders — but not only for the reason that has been widely debated in Congress, which is that the hierarchy is unfair to women.

headline: Memphis Struggles Past George Washington
abstract: The Tigers got past their first tournament game, which has been a problem for them in recent years.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Memphis arrived at PNC Arena with a résumé featuring a pair of wins over No.-5 ranked Louisville among a handful of head-turning victories this season. Performances like that could give top seeds in the tournament reason to worry.

headline: A Women’s History Museum, at Last?
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Museums', 'Women and Girls', 'Editorials']
abstract: An long-foiled proposal for a national institution suddenly gains traction.
lead_paragraph: It took seven decades before the rudely banished monument to three historic suffragists — Susan B. Anthony, Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Lucretia Mott — was hauled up from the basement of the United States Capitol in 1997 and restored to its rightful place by the rotunda.

headline: After Leaving Victim in the Cold, the Police Work to Make It Right
abstract: Months after Fredrick Brennan had over $4,000 stolen and was stranded in his wheelchair in the snow, he has a new power wheelchair and acts of contrition from New York detectives.
lead_paragraph: When the detectives arrived at Fredrick Brennan’s apartment in Brooklyn in January, it was not to question him about the theft or show him pictures of suspects or return the money stolen from him. That had all been taken care of already.

headline: Signs of Things to Come
abstract: A crunchy Saturday puzzle by Greg Johnson.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, this was a zippy outing. With entries like FLEW BY and RAN ALONG, how could you not solve this puzzle by Greg Johnson at a relatively fast clip?

headline: G.M.’s Bankruptcy Drawn Into Defect Inquiry
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Bankruptcies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Federal authorities are investigating whether the company failed to disclose in its landmark bankruptcy filing the defects that have now led to the recall of 1.6 million cars.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities’ nascent investigation into General Motors is looking in part into whether the automaker committed bankruptcy fraud by not disclosing defects that could lead to expensive future liabilities, a person briefed on the inquiry said on Friday.

headline: Wichita State Is Still Unbeaten
abstract: The Shockers were not pressed by Cal Poly, which has the worst record of any team in the tournament.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Joe Callero, the Cal Poly basketball coach, said he dreamed of his team becoming a 16th seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament so it could make history with an unprecedented upset.

headline: North Korea: Rockets Fired in a Test Land in the Sea
abstract: North Korea test-fired 30 short-range rockets off its east coast on Saturday, the latest in a series of military actions condemned by South Korea.
lead_paragraph: North Korea test-fired 30 short-range rockets off its east coast on Saturday, the latest in a series of military actions condemned by South Korea. The rockets flew about 37 miles before landing in the sea between North Korea and Japan, the South Korean military said. North Korea has conducted a series of tests of short-range ballistic missiles and rockets since late February. On Sunday, the North launched 25 short-range rockets off its east coast. South Korea urged North Korea to stop its “provocative acts,” saying they had raised military tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula. The tests have coincided with the joint military exercises that South Korea and the United States began last month.

headline: Decades Later, the Clave Beat Goes on for Latin Jazz and Jewish Musicians
abstract: A blending of musical styles that emerged in postwar New York is experiencing a revival, and will take the stage with a concert on Sunday at Town Hall in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the late 1940s, two young Latin musicians in New York, Joe Loco and Tito Puente, sat down to compose songs for a new album by the bandleader Pupi Campo. Mostly, they wrote in a language and style intended for the city’s postwar wave of Cuban and Puerto Rican newcomers, the obvious audience.

headline: An Autobiography, Written in Bodies
abstract: Ian Spencer Bell brought his text-choreography performance “Elsewhere” to the Martha Graham Studio Theater this week.
lead_paragraph: Ian Spencer Bell likes to divide his dances into two categories, quiet and talking: those danced in silence and those accompanied by text that he writes and recites. “Accompanied,” though, is not quite the right word. At its best, his movement itself seems to do the talking, physical sentences inseparable from verbal ones — neither upstaging the other — so that what results is not dance and not poetry but some third medium.

headline: Works Seldom Heard, From Haunting to Jubilant
abstract: The American Classical Orchestra performed Handel rarities on Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall, including a semi-staged production of “Alceste.”
lead_paragraph: The motto of the period-instrument American Classical Orchestra, which gave a semi-staged concert of Handel rarities at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening under the direction of Thomas Crawford, is “music as the masters heard it.” But “Alceste,” a Handel adaptation of Euripides conceived as a masque combining music, dance and spoken theater that was intended to be performed at Covent Garden in 1750, never made it to the stage in his time. Beyond a few rehearsals with the singers, the master never did hear the music.

headline: The Sorrows of Hades and the Glories of Spring
abstract: The Boston Early Music Festival presented a double bill of short operas by Marc-Antoine Charpentier at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Early Music Festival presented a double bill of short operas by Marc-Antoine Charpentier at the Morgan Library & Museum on Monday evening, led from within the continuo section by Paul O’Dette and Stephen Stubbs, two lutenists who are the festival’s joint musical directors. The innovative production by Gilbert Blin largely made up for an uneven performance by the vocalists, and an often indifferent one by the instrumentalists. As early-music brands go, the Boston festival has long enjoyed a reputation for combining high musical standards with rigorous scholarship, and there was a solid dose of scholarship in the program notes, which had the length and intellectual heft of two academic papers.

headline: North Carolina Edges Providence in Final Seconds
abstract: James Michael McAdoo made a go-ahead free throw with 3.5 seconds left and a key rebound on the following play to help North Carolina to a narrow victory.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — James Michael McAdoo’s most important contribution for North Carolina was not his go-ahead free throw with 3.5 seconds left Friday night. It was the rebound of his next foul shot.

headline: A Senator on the Stump With a Frank Message: Give Me More Stature
abstract: Paul Strauss is campaigning for re-election as one of the District of Columbia’s two “shadow” senators, and also pushing to have the district recognized as a state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The red-and-white campaign signs are on lampposts across the capital, urging voters to re-elect Paul Strauss as the United States senator from the District of Columbia.

headline: Yankees’ Insurance Policy at Shortstop Has a Physical Problem of His Own
abstract: Brendan Ryan, unable to play because of back spasms, expects to start the season on the disabled list.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Derek Jeter walked past Brendan Ryan in the Yankees’ clubhouse Friday afternoon, jokingly turning his entire body toward his teammate to say hello, moving as deliberately as a robot. Other teammates have called Ryan Robo Cop because his injured back prevents him from moving with any fluidity, and one teammate referred to Carl Pavano, a former Yankees pitcher known for being frequently injured.

headline: Murray L. Weidenbaum, Reagan Economist, Dies at 87
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As chief economic adviser, Mr. Weidenbaum championed a wave of deregulation but quit after a year and a half, unhappy about White House budget-making.
lead_paragraph: Murray L. Weidenbaum, who as President Ronald Reagan’s first chief economic adviser elevated government regulation of business to the forefront of public policy debate, but resigned unhappy about the administration’s budget-making, died on Thursday in St. Louis. He was 87.

headline: Knicks Survive Late Run by Sixers
abstract: The Knicks almost blew a big lead against the dreadful 76ers, who lost their 23rd game in a row.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — If the Knicks lost Friday night, there would have been major explaining to do.

headline: Howard H. Callaway, Strategist Who Helped G.O.P. Rise in South, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Callaway played leading roles in the presidential campaigns of Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford and served as secretary of the Army under both.
lead_paragraph: Howard H. Callaway, a Republican politician and strategist from the South who played leading roles in the presidential campaigns of Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford and served as secretary of the Army under both, died on March 15 in Columbus, Ga. He was 86.

headline: Lopez Still in Plans; Nets Stay on Roll
abstract: Brook Lopez, the oft-injured center, could be a key cog in the Nets’ revamped style, which depends on ball movement and a fluid defense, General Manager Billy King said.
lead_paragraph: Brook Lopez has not been able to do much the past three months but sit around his apartment and heal his ailing body. Lopez, the Nets’ 25-year-old center, has not shaved much, General Manager Billy King joked, and he has allowed his hair to become rather unkempt.

headline: Bridge’s Neighbors Fight Bike Path on Tappan Zee
keywords: ['Tappan Zee Bridge', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Parking']
abstract: At a meeting, opponents said the proposal would invite scores of cyclists’ cars scrambling for parking to their streets, unsettling a quiet neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH NYACK, N.Y. — It seems like a generous gift to the people of New York State: a three-mile path for bicyclists and pedestrians stretching across the silvery waters of the Hudson River on a new Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: New Parks Dept. Leader Shares de Blasio’s Goal of Addressing Inequities
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: In naming Mitchell J. Silver, an urban planner with broad national experience, to lead the parks department, Mr. de Blasio said the agency would do more to “work for all our people.”
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the new commissioner of the city’s Department of Parks and Recreation on Friday, it was not on the well-tended greenswards of Central Park or at Prospect Park’s recently completed high-design skating complex. Instead, he introduced Mitchell J. Silver, a planning official in Raleigh, N.C., and a Brooklyn native, at Seward Park on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, a small patch of green surrounded by tenements and public housing.

headline: Fall Down SoHo Elevator Shaft Injures Girl
abstract: A 12-year-old girl was seriously injured on Friday when she fell about 35 feet down an elevator shaft at a Manhattan co-op.
lead_paragraph: A 12-year-old girl was seriously injured on Friday when she fell about 35 feet down an elevator shaft at a Manhattan co-op, setting in motion a rescue that drew 20 emergency workers, the authorities said.

headline: Staggered by 4-Point Play, V.C.U. Is Sunk in Overtime
abstract: A 3-pointer and free throw with 3.6 seconds left in regulation helped Stephen F. Austin overcome a late 10-point deficit and become the third No. 12 seed to win in this year’s Round of 64.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Havoc is what Virginia Commonwealth does. The word is emblazoned across the backs of the team’s warm-up outfits. It is on the cover of the media guide. And it is liberally dropped into conversation.

headline: Ex-Christie Aides Seek Immunity in Deal for Bridge Scandal Documents
abstract: Bridget Kelly, a former deputy chief of staff to Mr. Christie, and Bill Stepien, his former campaign manager, are refusing to comply with a subpoena.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the two aides dismissed by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey in the scandal over the closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge struck back on Friday at the legislative committee investigating the closings, arguing in court filings that if the panel wanted them to turn over documents, it would have to grant the aides broad immunity against prosecution.

headline: How Much Europe Depends on Russian Energy
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: Map of European energy imports that come from Russia.
lead_paragraph: Map of European energy imports that come from Russia.

headline: Coach Faces Renewed Questions About the N.B.A.
abstract: Florida Coach Billy Donovan said he is “extremely happy” at Florida, and Louisville Coach Rick Pitino, when asked, said Donovan “would never coach the Knicks.”
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The news media interview area at Amway Center here is at the Magic’s practice court, and Florida Coach Billy Donovan’s presence has led to several questions about whether he would consider taking an N.B.A. job.

headline: No. 1 Seed Virginia Survives Scare
abstract: Virginia held off No. 16 Coastal Carolina, pulling away for a 70-59 victory Friday night that was a whole lot more nerve wracking than the final score.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — It took the Virginia Cavaliers 31 years to earn a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament. In 40 minutes, they very nearly blew it.

headline: In Dominating Win, Iowa State Is Dealt a Blow: Niang Is Hurt
abstract: The Cyclones overwhelmed North Carolina Central but will be without Georges Niang, who led Iowa State with 24 points, for the rest of the tournament after he broke his foot.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — When his team’s matchup was revealed last week, Iowa State Coach Fred Hoiberg had but one reaction, he said: “I got a little worried.”

headline: Those Who Stayed With UConn Helped Save It
abstract: After a postseason ban and multiple defections, Shabazz Napier, Tyler Olander and Niels Giffey “saved this program,” the second-year Coach Kevin Ollie said.
lead_paragraph: When the University of Connecticut was hit with a postseason ban before the 2012-2013 season, the men’s basketball team became a house divided.

headline: Next Up for Kentucky: Wichita State
abstract: The Wildcats fended off Kansas State and won the chance to end the Shockers’ so-far-undefeated season.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — The eighth-seeded Kentucky Wildcats set up a Sunday showdown with top-seeded Wichita State, cruising past Kansas State, 56-49, on Friday at Scottrade Center.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Encore) L.A. CONFIDENTIAL (1997) Kevin Spacey, Russell Crowe and Guy Pearce (above right, with Mr. Crowe) are detectives in 1950s Los Angeles who become embroiled in a scandal encompassing three murder cases. Kim Basinger plays a call girl who becomes involved in the investigation. Janet Maslin, in her review for The New York Times, called this film, directed by Curtis Hanson and adapted from a James Ellroy novel, “a tough, gorgeous, vastly entertaining throwback to the Hollywood that did things right.” She added that the Los Angeles depicted is “a film noir paradise of smoldering evil and knee-weakening glamour with a dirty little secret behind every palm tree.” The film won two Oscars: best adapted screenplay for Brian Helgeland and Mr. Hanson, and best supporting actress for Ms. Basinger.

headline: Corrections: March 22, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 22, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: 20 Years Later, U.C.L.A. Knocks Off Tulsa
abstract: The Bruins pulled away in the second half to beat the Golden Hurricanes, who defeated U.C.L.A. in a stunner in the 1994 tournament.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Geography has never been a strong suit of U.C.L.A. basketball players. Before one N.C.A.A. tournament game against Penn State, a Bruin said he thought the Nittany Lions played in the Ivy League. Before U.C.L.A. opened the 1994 tournament against Tulsa — with a 112-102 loss — another Bruin said he did not know the university was in Oklahoma.

headline: Analytics: Grading the Test
abstract: Todd Balf’s article on the SAT overhaul inspired a lively debate online. What do you think? Write your response in the comments section below.
lead_paragraph: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the March 23 issue of the magazine.

headline: As Numbers Swell, Students Pledge to Continue Occupying Taiwan’s Legislature
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Demonstrators angered by moves to push a trade bill with China through Taiwan’s Legislature have called for talks with the government.
lead_paragraph: Students who have occupied Taiwan’s Legislature to oppose the governing party’s efforts to approve a trade deal with China said Saturday that they would escalate their protests after President Ma Ying-jeou declined to meet with them.

headline: A Conversation With Danah Boyd, Author of ‘It’s Complicated,’ About Teenagers Online
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Parenting', 'Privacy', 'Social Media', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: An interview with Danah Boyd, an expert on teens and the Internet and author of the book, “It’s Complicated: The Social Lives of Networked Teens.”
lead_paragraph: Danah Boyd is a principal researcher at Microsoft Research, a research assistant professor in Media, Culture and Communication at New York University, and a fellow at Harvard’s Berkman Center.

headline: Chinese Satellite Spots Object in Search Area for Missing Jetliner
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Satellites']
abstract: The object, which Chinese ships are being sent to investigate, is in the area of one of two possible routes investigators think the plane took.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — A Chinese satellite has spotted an object in the southern Indian Ocean in an area that is the focus of a multinational effort to find the Malaysia Airlines airliner that disappeared on March 8, the Chinese authorities said Saturday.

headline: In Beijing Talk, Michelle Obama Extols Free Speech
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'United States International Relations', 'Social Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The first lady told an audience of mainly students that unfettered expression, particularly on the Internet and in the news media, form the basis for a strong, prosperous society.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — On a visit that was supposed to be nonpolitical, Michelle Obama delivered an unmistakable message to the Chinese on Saturday, saying in an address here that freedom of speech, particularly on the Internet and in the news media, provided the foundation for a vibrant society.

headline: Working for the Owners
abstract: On our way to patrimonial capitalism.
lead_paragraph: I’ve just finished a draft of a long review of Thomas Piketty’s Capital in the 21st Century, which argues that we’re on the road back to “patrimonial capitalism”, dominated by inherited wealth. It’s an amazing book; among other things, it does an awesome job of integrating economic growth, the factor distribution of income (between capital and labor), and the individual distribution of income into a common framework. (It’s all about r-g). One slight weakness of the book, however, is that Piketty’s grand framework doesn’t do too good a job of explaining the explosion of income inequality in the United States, which so far has been driven mainly by wage income rather than capital. Piketty does take this on; but it’s kind of a side journey from the central story.

headline: Sit Back and Soak Awhile in Natural Springs
abstract: An ancient practice is revived by travelers interested in natural treatments.
lead_paragraph: Instead of pushing traditional spa services, several hotels around the world are focusing on expanding natural hot springs on-site as a way for guests to unwind. A recent renovation at Calistoga Spa Hot Springs in Napa Valley, Calif., for example, added four mineral pools with temperatures ranging from 80 to 106 degrees.

headline: For Antigay Church, Losing Its Cause Before Its Founder
abstract: Members of the Westboro Baptist Church plan to keep spreading their antigay message after the death of Fred Phelps, but many of the church’s closest observers say it has lost the cultural battle.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — On the final night of Fred Phelps’s life, as he lay dying in hospice care here, two of his daughters and several of his grandchildren lined a sidewalk in front of an upscale grocery store in Kansas City, Mo., 60 miles to the east, and sang.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, March 23
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “Other car companies should not repeat Toyota’s mistake.”

headline: Life Expectancy and Income
abstract: Readers respond to “Income Gap, Meet the Longevity Gap” (March 16).
lead_paragraph: Life Expectancy and Income

headline: In His Office, a Wide World of Experience
abstract: Ashifi Gogo, chief executive of Sproxil, a technology company, keeps an open floor plan in its main office, as well as reminders of its international reach and his own upbringing in Ghana.
lead_paragraph: Computing and thinking

headline: W-2s, 1040s and Long Hours
abstract: This is the busiest time of year for a tax preparer — but, she says, she still tries not to work on Sundays.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Ogorek, 66, is a tax preparer in Park Ridge, Ill.

headline: She Didn’t Mean to Be Bossy
abstract: A receptionist asks the Workologist how to handle a misunderstanding with a co-worker who handled her duties during a 15-minute break.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Just Don’t Call Them Hearing Aids
abstract: Sound amplifiers, sold over the counter, have high-tech features. But audiologists suggest a doctor’s visit before using them.
lead_paragraph: People who strain to hear conversations in noisy places sometimes shun hearing appliances as telltale signs of aging. But what if those devices looked like wireless phone receivers? Some companies are betting that the high-tech look of a new generation of sound amplifiers will tempt people to try them.

headline: When the Scientist Is Also a Philosopher
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Philosophy', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Minimum Wage', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Economists’ advice on policy is based not just on their understanding of how the world works, but also on political philosophy — their judgments about what makes a good society.
lead_paragraph: Do you want to know a dirty little secret of economists who give policy advice? When we do so, we are often speaking not just as economic scientists, but also as political philosophers. Our recommendations are based not only on our understanding of how the world works, but also on our judgments about what makes a good society.

headline: Tremors in the Palace of the Bond-Fund King
abstract: For Pimco, questions about the flagship fund’s performance and the founder’s management style.
lead_paragraph: Pimco, the giant asset manager, has been attracting attention for all the wrong reasons.

headline: Don Knauss of Clorox, on Putting Your Followers First
abstract: “If you’re going to engage the best and the brightest and retain them,” the chief executive says, “they’d better think that you care more about them than you care about yourself.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with   Don Knauss, chief executive of the Clorox Company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: The Stone Unturned: Credit Ratings
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: As its proposed rules languish, some investor advocates want the Securities and Exchange Commission to start over — and to get tougher.
lead_paragraph: It’s the one question about the 2008 financial crisis that people still ask me more than any other: Why have regulators done so little to rein in the credit rating agencies? Other institutions that contributed to the mortgage debacle have submitted to new rules and compliance requirements, but Moody’s Investors Service and Standard & Poor’s and their peers remained relatively untouched.

headline: Not the Best Way to Sell a Smartphone
abstract: In a brutal global business, marketing missteps inflict much pain. Just ask HTC.
lead_paragraph: As HTC readied a new version of its flagship smartphone, it planned for many challenges. It didn’t know that one of them would be Roshan Jamkatel, a teenager from Schaumburg, Ill.

headline: Israeli Raid Leaves 3 Dead in West Bank Refugee Area
abstract: Three Palestinians were killed at the Jenin camp when Israeli forces tried to arrest a suspected militant in a raid that threatened to upend the fragile negotiations in the region.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli forces killed three Palestinians and wounded at least seven others early Saturday when their attempt to arrest a person suspected of being a militant in the restive Jenin refugee camp erupted into a violent clash.

headline: Variety: A Worldly Acrostic
abstract: A worldly acrostic, by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I like to think of myself as a citizen of the world, not just the United States, so I really liked this quote. If you live in a big city or any other place that has a heterogeneous population, you know what I mean. I grew up in the Melting Pot of all Melting Pots, New York City, and it never occurred to me that people lived in an area that didn’t have residents from all walks of life.

headline: If Fairways Were Roadways, Gridlock Alert Would Be On
abstract: Slow play, the bane of duffers and professional golfers alike, is “a never-ending psychotic phenomenon,” according to the 11-time tour winner Zach Johnson.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — With his starched shirt and his nose for bottlenecks, Mark Russell could pass for a traffic engineer. Instead of watching a bank of monitors in a windowless room, Russell, a PGA Tour rules official, is gazing at the green expanse of Bay Hill Golf Club.

headline: Russian Forces Take Over One of the Last Ukrainian Bases in Crimea
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The assault on Saturday was a larger and more dramatic military operation than at other installations where Ukrainian forces have capitulated steadily in recent days as Russia declared its formal annexation of the region.
lead_paragraph: BELBEK, Crimea — Russian forces pushed Saturday to complete their expulsion of the Ukrainian military from the disputed Crimean Peninsula, smashing through the gates of a base here with armored vehicles, firing weapons into the air and demanding that the cornered Ukrainian soldiers surrender.

headline: Jackson’s Arrival Overshadows Nets’ Selflessness
abstract: The Nets are poised for the playoffs, but the Knicks pulled off a marketing coup with the signing of Phil Jackson last week.
lead_paragraph: Behold Jason Kidd, the rookie Nets coach whose stoic game face remains unchanged but has somehow evolved from the look of being lost to one of being learned.

headline: For Phoenix, Record Guarantees Nothing
abstract: The Phoenix Suns, who have a 40-29 record after a win on Friday, could be on the outside looking in when the Western Conference playoffs begin in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Nothing shows the disparity between the N.B.A.’s Western and Eastern conferences more than the quality of the teams fighting for the last few playoff spots. As three sub-.500 teams vie for two spots in the East, it is all but certain that one team with an impeccable record in the West will not make the postseason.

headline: Au Revoir, Entrepreneurs
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Saying their own country stifles new business, French innovators are finding opportunity elsewhere — especially in London.
lead_paragraph: Guillaume Santacruz, an aspiring French entrepreneur, brushed the rain from his black sweater and skinny jeans and headed down to a cavernous basement inside Campus London, a seven-story hive run by Google in the city’s East End.

headline: From Hawaii to End of Pitt Bench to 56 Seconds in Spotlight
abstract: At 6 feet and 155 pounds, Joshua Ko was not an imposing figure, but his drive endeared him to Panthers fans — and those who root for the underdog.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Pittsburgh led Colorado by 30 points in the final minute Thursday in their N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament opener. The fans waiting to see No. 1-seeded Florida seemed to have fallen asleep when Pitt Coach Jamie Dixon called a timeout with 56 seconds left and sent in Joshua Ko, a slender walk-on freshman guard. The crowd cheered, and the Panthers’ bench perked up.

headline: Really? You’re Not in a Book Club?
keywords: ['Book Clubs', 'Books and Literature', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs']
abstract: You’re gossiping not about people, but characters.
lead_paragraph: “WHAT’S your book group reading?” I say to a friend encountered on the street. Not: “Are you in a book group?” I have no idea whether Clara is in a book group. We’ve never talked about it. All the same, I just know. Why? Because it’s a safe assumption to make these days.

headline: Slides Describe Mission Involving Huawei
abstract: Powerpoint slides from 2010 lay out the National Security Agency’s goals in an effort to break into networks of Huawei, the telecommunications giant.
lead_paragraph: Powerpoint slides from 2010 lay out the National Security Agency’s goals in an effort to break into networks of Huawei, the telecommunications giant.

headline: N.S.A. Breached Chinese Servers Seen as Security Threat
abstract: As the United States made a public case about the dangers of buying from Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, classified documents show that the National Security Agency was creating its own back doors — directly into Huawei’s networks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American officials have long considered Huawei, the Chinese telecommunications giant, a security threat, blocking it from business deals in the United States for fear that the company would create “back doors” in its equipment that could allow the Chinese military or Beijing-backed hackers to steal corporate and government secrets.

headline: Toy Guns for Girls
abstract: Toy manufacturers are selling new lines of toy guns and toy archery sets specifically aimed at girls. Does this make play time more equal?
lead_paragraph: Toy manufacturers are selling new lines of toy guns and toy archery sets specifically aimed at girls. Does this make play time more equal?

headline: Face of the Twins Surrenders His Mask
abstract: Joe Mauer now plays first base for Minnesota after he missed the final 39 games last season with a concussion, which ended his decorated catching career.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — The end of a decorated catching career came without warning, on a Monday afternoon last August, in a makeup game against the Mets at Target Field. Joe Mauer took one foul ball off his mask, and then another the next inning, nothing unusual for his position. He played the rest of the game and flew with his Minnesota Twins teammates to Detroit.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 82
abstract: Jurgen Klinsmann, coach of the U.S. men’s national team, is not happy one of his top players, Clint Dempsey, was suspended for two games by M.L.S.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Jet’s Disappearance Puzzles a World Under Constant Electronic Watch
abstract: The continuing uncertainty, with no evidence of what happened to the plane and the people on it, has tormented relatives of those on board and flummoxed aviation experts.
lead_paragraph: SEPANG, Malaysia — A satellite image of an indistinct, pale object floating in the ocean far off the west coast of Australia, published on Saturday by the Chinese authorities, is the latest of a succession of elusive clues in what has already become one of aviation’s greatest mysteries.

headline: Born in the U.S., Playing for Iran
abstract: Steven Beitashour, an American of Iranian descent, will represent his parents’ homeland at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, which begins in June.
lead_paragraph: TORRANCE, Calif. — Steven Beitashour was 11 during the 1998 World Cup in France, where the United States, the country of his birth, faced Iran, where his parents were born.

headline: Spreadsheets and Global Mayhem
keywords: ['Research', 'Computers and the Internet', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Social Media', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Researchers in several countries are designing mathematical models to predict atrocities and war.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS

headline: Diversity in Kids’ Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Minorities', 'Children and Childhood', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Readers reflect on how we see ourselves and learn about others through what we read.
lead_paragraph: Readers reflect on how we see ourselves and learn about others through what we read.

headline: Pay for Play and Title IX
keywords: ['College Athletics', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'AMATEUR ATHLETICS', 'Editorials']
abstract: Title IX can coexist with the professionalization of college athletics.
lead_paragraph: What if college athletes were paid? A few years ago, it seemed impossible that the National Collegiate Athletic Association’s longstanding amateur system could collapse, but recent high-profile legal actions have taken the possibility of professionalization out of fantasy territory.

headline: The Sequester and the Homeless
keywords: ['Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Affordable Housing', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: Those budget cuts continue to hurt vulnerable families.
lead_paragraph: The across-the-board cuts to federal programs that took effect last spring receded from the headlines after Republicans were shamed into allowing the government to pay its bills. But the cuts, known as the sequester, continue to take a toll on crucial housing programs that are intended to shield the elderly, the disabled and impoverished families with children from homelessness.

headline: Russia Without Illusions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: After Crimea, what’s needed is a more realistic assessment about Russian intentions and Western leverage.
lead_paragraph: SINCE the end of the Cold War, America’s policy toward Russia has been shaped by two dangerous illusions.

headline: Trend-Spotting, With Wink at Mr. Peanut
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Social Media', 'Public Editor (Times Column)']
abstract: A Times item about the monocle’s return draws comment.
lead_paragraph: IF only I were gifted at satire, or even its goofy little brother, parody. Those skills would sometimes make commenting on The Times’s journalism so much more fun.

headline: What I’d Say to My Fat Son
abstract: My weight was a target: My belly was socked, my boy breasts punched and twisted by older, stronger fingers, and torrents of daily verbal abuse were hurled at me.
lead_paragraph: I WAS 7 when I first sprouted a belly. What can I say? I liked food and ate whatever I wanted because it tasted good. I was helped along by an elderly neighbor up the street who thought my little pouch was the most adorable thing she had ever seen. When her grandson stayed with her I’d be invited over to play. Every now and then she’d marvel at my midsection, sometimes giving it a pat, and she’d feed me treats.

headline: This Is What 80 Looks Like
abstract: Gloria Steinem occupies a singular place in American culture as the very face of feminism.
lead_paragraph: ON Tuesday, Gloria Steinem turns 80.

headline: You Sanction Me? No, I Sanction You!
abstract: What more does Putin have planned for Ukraine?
lead_paragraph: The week brought more snow to the Mid-Atlantic region, along with a blast of the Cold War, replete with an exchange of sanctions by Washington and the Kremlin, followed by displays of bravado by the sanctioned. “Big honor for me,” declared Vladislav Surkov, a top Kremlin strategist. “Badge of honor,” came the echo from Senator Mary L. Landrieu, head of the Senate energy committee.

headline: Ghosts of the Displaced
abstract: Across history and changing political borders, the dispossessed yearn for home.
lead_paragraph: MY grandmother lived in three countries without ever moving. The Bengali village where she was born, married, had five children and became a widow saw its political boundaries change from British India to Pakistan to Bangladesh between 1947 and 1971. My grandmother was a storyteller, and when I was growing up in that village, her imagination recreated for me altered allegiances and divided houses.

headline: A Common Core for All of Us
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Should schools protect kids or challenge them?
lead_paragraph: I COULDN’T get a cab. A sketchy-looking guy hunkering around the entrance of the Grand Hyatt in San Diego showed me his bicycle. “Climb on, lady,” he said. “I’ll take ya.”

headline: The Pilots in the Basement
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Pilots', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Computer and Video Games', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL']
abstract: The Malaysia Airlines jet disappearance highlights the world of virtual flight hobbyists.
lead_paragraph: MUCH has been made of the flight simulator found in the home of Capt. Zaharie Ahmad Shah, the pilot of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet. Why would a guy who spends so much time flying real airplanes want to pretend he’s flying a fake one in his off hours?

headline: Palmy Days for Jerry
abstract: Moonbeam through a new prism: A more mellow Jerry Brown gets ready to make California history.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — I ASK Jerry if he’s ready for Hillary.

headline: All Economics Is Local
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Living Wage', 'Minimum Wage', 'United States Economy']
abstract: What really happens when the wage floor is raised?
lead_paragraph: In the face of congressional inaction, the debate on raising the minimum wage is moving to the local level. As more cities and counties consider setting their own wage standards, they can learn from the policy experiments already underway.

headline: The Geography of Fame
abstract: Want to be in Wikipedia? Start by being born in the right place.
lead_paragraph: WHERE do the most successful Americans come from? I was curious. So I downloaded Wikipedia. (You can do that sort of thing nowadays.)

headline: Notable Boomers and Where They Came From
abstract: There are 36,625 Americans born between 1946 and 1964 who warrant their own entry in Wikipedia.
lead_paragraph: There are 36,625 Americans born between 1946 and 1964 who warrant their own entry in Wikipedia.

headline: Pope Names Members of Anti-Abuse Group
abstract: The eight names released on Saturday for a special commission suggested that Pope Francis is deliberately shaking up the usual way of doing things at the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Saturday made his first appointments to a special commission intended to signal the Vatican’s new resolve in tackling the clerical sexual abuse problem, a group that includes an equal number of women and men, more laypeople than clergy and an outspoken Irish activist who was abused by a priest as a child.

headline: Lessons From the Little Ice Age
keywords: ['Ice Age', 'Drought', 'Global Warming', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Famine', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Famine, disease and war marked the 1600s.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — CLIMATOLOGISTS call it the Little Ice Age; historians, the General Crisis.

headline: Top Team Finds That Four Hands Are Better Than Two (on Forehands, Too)
abstract: Peng Shuai and Hsieh Su-wei , both 28, have used their unusual technique — two-handed forehands and backhands — to scale the rankings ladder quickly.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — In doubles tennis, which treasures technique and tradition, Peng Shuai of China and Hsieh Su-wei of Taiwan became the first doubly double-handed pair to win a Grand Slam tournament when they captured the women’s title at Wimbledon last July.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 23
abstract: Russia’s decision to annex Crimea and the still missing Malaysian Airlines flight will dominate the conversation on the Sunday talk shows.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s military occupation of Crimea left Ukraine little choice but to withdraw from the disputed peninsula, officials said Wednesday. President Obama responded to the annexation of Crimea with heavier economic sanctions, including against some of President Vladimir V. Putin’s closest supporters, but some in the White House remain concerned that Russia’s aggression will not stop in Crimea.

headline: Ovechkin’s Value, the Plus and the Minus
abstract: Washington’s Alex Ovechkin leads the N.H.L. with 46 goals but has the second worst plus/minus rating in the league.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to picture an N.H.L. player being the best over an entire season in one category while also being the worst in another. But we may be witnessing that in Alex Ovechkin.

headline: For Gay Couples in Michigan, a Day of Joy Ends in Legal Uncertainty
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A day after a federal judge struck down Michigan’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriages, gay couples raced to clerk’s offices to exchange wedding vows.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — A day after a federal judge struck down Michigan’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriages, hundreds of gay couples raced to clerks’ offices across the state on Saturday morning to exchange wedding vows before an appeals court challenge that could reinstate the ban.

headline: Wave of Appeals Expected to Turn the Tide on Same-Sex Marriage Bans
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Constitution (US)', 'States (US)', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: Legal experts predict that several of the circuit courts, which hold sway over a group of states, will rule that state laws limiting marriage to a man and a woman are unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: With a slew of cases barreling toward federal appeals courts, almost certainly including the decision Friday that overturned Michigan’s restrictive marriage amendment, the legal battle over same-sex marriage is entering a new and climactic phase. Decisions in the coming months will resonate beyond individual states across entire regions and may impel the Supreme Court to revisit the issue sooner than it wished.

headline: The Lost Art of the Unsent Angry Letter
abstract: What you gain by writing down your thoughts and never delivering them.
lead_paragraph: WHENEVER Abraham Lincoln felt the urge to tell someone off, he would compose what he called a “hot letter.” He’d pile all of his anger into a note, “put it aside until his emotions cooled down,” Doris Kearns Goodwin once explained on NPR, “and then write: ‘Never sent. Never signed.’ ” Which meant that Gen. George G. Meade, for one, would never hear from his commander in chief that Lincoln blamed him for letting Robert E. Lee escape after Gettysburg.

headline: He Was Supposed to Take a Photo
abstract: After being forced into child pornography by her parents at age 4, Raven Kaliana is now fighting against child abusers.
