lead_paragraph: ONE of Raven Kaliana’s first, hazy memories is of her parents taking her to a professional photo studio, telling her to be good, and then leaving her with a child pornographer. In front of a camera, a man raped her.

headline: Crying Wolf on Religious Liberty
keywords: ['Religion-State Relations', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Supreme Court should reject the claim of religious infringement in the health care law’s contraception mandate.
lead_paragraph: This week, the owners of two secular, for-profit corporations will ask the Supreme Court to take a radical turn and allow them to impose their religious views on their employees — by refusing to permit them contraceptive coverage as required under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Confronting the Netherworld of Child Pornography
abstract: Readers respond to my column about kids being trafficked into the pornography industry.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at one facet of child trafficking, the child pornography industry. This was largely eliminated by the early 1990’s and then exploded with the Internet, but it’s mostly hidden in peer-to-peer networks and the “dark web” so that few people are aware just how odious it is.

headline: Russian Troops Storm Ukrainian Base
abstract: Russian troops broke an overhead camera as they forced their way into a Ukrainian base in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Russian troops broke an overhead camera as they forced their way into a Ukrainian base in Crimea.

headline: Gambling on Postponing Rockettes Show Rather Than Risking Poor Reviews
abstract: After two years and $25 million, the head of Madison Square Garden Company agreed with the entertainment mogul Harvey Weinstein that “Heart and Lights” needed more work.
lead_paragraph: With one problem out of the way, James L. Dolan quickly turned to another. On Thursday night, just two days after introducing Phil Jackson as the new president of his beleaguered New York Knicks, Mr. Dolan, executive chairman of the Madison Square Garden Company, found himself assessing the performance of another troubled property: the musical extravaganza “Heart and Lights.”

headline: Wilbekin Drives, and Florida Cruises Past Pittsburgh
abstract: The senior guard Scottie Wilbekin led Florida to its 28th consecutive victory as the No. 1-seeded Gators ousted the ninth-seeded Panthers.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Scottie Wilbekin limped slightly as he headed toward the Florida bench. He sat down and was given an ice bag for his bruised left knee, a symbol of sorts for his gritty play and timely leadership that lifted the Gators to a 61-45 victory Saturday over Pittsburgh.

headline: Lee Armstrong
abstract: A plane-finding app founder on reading true war stories and watching “Airplane Repo.”
lead_paragraph: Lee Armstrong is a British computer programmer who co-founded Planefinder, a website and mobile app that allows its five million users to track air traffic worldwide in real time. User activity has surged 300 percent since the Malaysia Airlines jet vanished on March 8. Planefinder gets much of its data from a global network of volunteers who have placed specialized aviation-tracking receivers on their rooftops.

headline: ‘The Whole Year, Nothing Went Our Way’
abstract: For Oklahoma State, a season that began with expectations of a Final Four appearance ended after one game in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The business of redemption, like the art of image reconstruction, is rarely neat or uncomplicated.

headline: Favoring Wealth Over Work
abstract: Who gets the big tax cuts?
lead_paragraph: In my last post I tried to document the extent to which modern Republican rhetoric has already adopted the values of “patrimonial capitalism”, even though America’s top one percent still owes its high incomes largely to compensation rather than wealth. On reflection, I thought I should also document the extent to which the GOP has put its money — or, actually, taxpayers’ money — where its mouth is, with concrete policies that favor wealth over work.

headline: Times Report on Al Qaeda Is Censored in Pakistan
abstract: A large, blank space replaced the article exploring what the country knew of Osama bin Laden’s final hide-out.
lead_paragraph: An article about Pakistan’s relationship to Al Qaeda, and its knowledge of Osama bin Laden’s last hiding place within its borders, was censored from the front page of about 9,000 copies of the International New York Times in Pakistan on Saturday, apparently removed by a local paper that has a partnership to distribute The Times.

headline: At Wichita State, Son Quietly Savors the Sideline
abstract: Kellen Marshall, the son of Wichita State Coach Gregg Marshall, decided the Shockers were going to have a special season and he did not want to miss it.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Kellen Marshall was a 6-foot-3 junior on his high school basketball team in Wichita, Kan., a forward for a squad that won its league the previous season. At 17, he had been steadily climbing the basketball ladder for years, dribbling and shooting in dusty little gyms since before he could read.

headline: Garden Buys Stake in Indie Film Bastion
abstract: A deal will bring together an independent film company and a deep-pocketed sports and live entertainment brand looking to expand.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Tribeca Enterprises, the Manhattan-based independent film concern co-founded by Robert De Niro, has agreed to sell a 50 percent stake to the Madison Square Garden Company in a deal that values Tribeca at $45 million.

headline: N.C.A.A. Round of 32: The Day in Pictures
abstract: Florida opened the first day of the round of 32 with a convincing win over Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: Florida opened the first day of the round of 32 with a convincing win over Pittsburgh.

headline: Defending Champs Have a Pulse, but It’s Not Strong
abstract: The Cardinals seized control midway through the second half and defeated an even more ragged St. Louis squad to advance to the Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Louisville Coach Rick Pitino has lived through enough of these games to understand there are no style points in the N.C.A.A. tournament. So as the Cardinals gathered in their locker room at Amway Center, Pitino looked to the television for part of his pregame motivation.

headline: Vanquished, but Still Eyeing Winner’s Circle
abstract: A few Texas politicians are fighting the odds to prove they can bounce back from election losses.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: What an Electric Current Does Not Flow Through
abstract: An illuminating puzzle from Ian Livengood.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle by Ian Livengood contains one of my favorite quotations, yet I am going to predict that we will have at least a few people who take issue with the fact that THOMAS EDISON is presented as the sole inventor of the INCANDESCENT LIGHT BULB. He patented it, of course, but there are many people who feel that, had EDISON not been a particularly good businessman, Nikola Tesla would have had a much more important place in the light bulb invention section of the history books.

headline: A Prison Alliance: Dog Trainers and Veterans
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals']
abstract: Dozens of inmates at two women’s prisons in Gatesville volunteer for a nonprofit group that trains service dogs for veterans with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: GATESVILLE — Lark Goode, wearing a stark white prison jumpsuit, set a prosthetic leg down on the glazed concrete floor and calmly walked to the other side of the gymnasium. At her signal, Rocky, a black lab mix with a naturally bobbed tail, retrieved the leg and brought it to Ms. Goode.

headline: For Ukraine Military in Crimea, Glum Capitulation and an Uncertain Future
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: Forced to leave their bases, Ukrainians must now decide whether to leave Crimea or join the Russian military.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea — The Ukrainian marines emerged Friday from their barracks juggling awkward armfuls of personal effects: wet-weather overcoats, suitcases, potted plants, even a model ship.

headline: After Gains and Discord, U.T. Chancellor Moves On
abstract: Dr. Francisco Cigarroa, who has maintained his post for five years, will step down to become the head of the pediatric transplant surgery unit at the U.T. Health Science Center.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Cigarroa was not surprised when her eldest son, Francisco, announced in February that he would step down as chancellor of the University of Texas System after five years on the job.

headline: Paul Has Ideas, but His Backers Want 2016 Plan
abstract: Some Republicans note that Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, does not have a political or fund-raising infrastructure to match his emerging national profile. Mr. Paul has been working to change that.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a ballroom at the Olympic Club, a grand, early-20th-century building at the foot of Nob Hill, Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, pitched a gathering of venture capitalists last week in an effort to show them that he may be the next big thing.

headline: The Push to Label Genetically Modified Products
abstract: A small group of farmers and environmental advocates are fighting long odds in Texas against the state leadership and the powerful lobbying of food conglomerates.
lead_paragraph: When Eric Herm heard in 2005 that genetically modified cottonseeds were the latest innovation on the market, he thought he should plant the crop on his family farm near Lubbock, Tex.

headline: Today’s Girls Love Pink Bows as Playthings, but These Shoot
abstract: Inspired by a succession of female warrior heroes, toy makers are marketing a more aggressive line of playthings for girls — even as the industry clings to every shade of pink.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, Grace Maher twirled around the house in Disney princess costumes, a vision of sequins, tiaras and pink.

headline: Computer Play Emboldens World Title Contenders
abstract: Moves discovered with the help of programs have led to lively and decisive matches at the Candidates tournament in Russia this month.
lead_paragraph: Computer programs have changed the pace of this year’s tournament that will select the next title challenger for the world champion, Magnus Carlsen.

headline: A Routine Flight, Till Both Routine and Flight Vanish
abstract: As the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines plane continues, experts and investigators have attempted to construct a portrait of Flight 370 with what is known.
lead_paragraph: The night sky was clear above the clouds, and the last glimmer of a setting half-moon had faded when Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, cruising at 35,000 feet over the Gulf of Thailand, approached the border between Malaysian and Vietnamese airspace on its usual route to Beijing. What happened next should have been routine for a twice-daily milk run between two of Asia’s most important cities. Air traffic controllers outside Kuala Lumpur usually hand the jet off to their counterparts in Ho Chi Minh City as the flight turns northeast toward the Chinese capital.

headline: An Embattled Trainer Fires His Assistant
abstract: The trainer Steve Asmussen broke with Scott Blasi, his assistant for 18 years, on Saturday as the authorities looked into allegations that the two had mistreated racehorses.
lead_paragraph: Steve Asmussen fired his longtime assistant Scott Blasi on Saturday as horse racing authorities and federal agencies investigated allegations that the two had mistreated thoroughbred racehorses in their care.

headline: Gene Feist, Founder of Roundabout Theater Company, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Feist was a playwright and director who worked as a public-school teacher when he started the nonprofit organization.
lead_paragraph: Gene Feist, who brought regular productions of classic theater to New York when he founded what is now the Roundabout Theater Company, a multistage Goliath that is one of the nation’s most important nonprofit companies, died on Monday in Englewood, N.J. He was 91.

headline: With Experiment, Mets Hope to Have Potent Offense Down to a Science
abstract: Manager Terry Collins tried batting the pitcher eighth and an outfielder ninth to get runners on in front of reliable hitter David Wright.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — The Mets signed outfielders Curtis Granderson and Chris Young in the off-season partly to address their lack of power. But a year after the Mets hit .237 as a team, Manager Terry Collins is still looking for ways to lift the offense.

headline: For Columbia, a Milestone Seems to Be Worth the Fee
abstract: The Lions hosted their first postseason basketball game, part of the CollegeInsider.com tournament.
lead_paragraph: A video featured last week on the home page for the CollegeInsider.com tournament showed the jump shot by Columbia guard Maodo Lo that carried the Lions to a 58-56 victory over Valparaiso in a first-round game on Tuesday.

headline: Montana Ex-Guardsman Now Must Fight to Keep Senate Seat Given to Him
abstract: Appointed last month to replace Max Baucus, Senator John Walsh is counting on his military career remaining an asset as he tries to keep the seat Democrats have held since 1913.
lead_paragraph: PABLO, Mont. — After three decades in the Montana National Guard, including a combat tour in Iraq, John Walsh, the state’s newly appointed Democratic senator, still has a brush cut and military bearing and occasionally slips into soldier-speak, referring to the “civilian” world when discussing life inside and outside the political arena.

headline: Pro-Russian and Pro-Kiev Camps Dig In Amid Uneasy Calm in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: The Kiev revolution and Russia’s aggression have fueled a rift among ordinary Ukrainians and among elites, laying bare the difficulties of establishing political order even if the unsteady peace lasts.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — The funeral procession for Artyom Zhudov, 19, was led by a Zhiguli subcompact car bearing the orange-and-black standard of St. George, the distinctive and now ubiquitous symbol of support for Russia here in Kharkiv, the second-largest city in Ukraine.

headline: Point Guard Turns His Life Around, With an Assist From His Coach
abstract: Florida Coach Billy Donovan showed toughness and patience with Scottie Wilbekin, who has emerged as a star for the No. 1 Gators.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Just before the halftime buzzer, Florida point guard Scottie Wilbekin shot a running 3-pointer, leaping high above two Pittsburgh defenders. The ball floated, and then slipped through the net just as the light on the backboard turned red. The thousands of Gators fans in the stands during the N.C.A.A. tournament’s Round of 32 on Saturday went into a frenzy.

headline: Multivehicle Accident in Pakistan Kills More Than 30
abstract: At least 33 people were killed on Saturday in a crash involving two tanker trucks and two buses in southern Pakistan. At least 20 others were injured.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 33 people were killed on Saturday in a crash involving two tanker trucks and two passenger buses on a coastal highway in southern Pakistan, officials said. At least 20 others were injured, many with severe burns.

headline: The Catholic Roots of Obama’s Activism
abstract: In an often-overlooked period of President Obama’s life, he had a small office in a South Side parish and became steeped in the social justice wing of the Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In a meeting room under Holy Name Cathedral, a rapt group of black Roman Catholics listened as Barack Obama, a 25-year-old community organizer, trained them to lobby their fellow delegates to a national congress in Washington on issues like empowering lay leaders and attracting more believers.

headline: After Slow Start, the Aztecs Pull Away
abstract: Xavier Thames scored 30 points as San Diego State secured a spot in the West Region semifinal close to home, in Anaheim, Calif.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Xavier Thames was the best player in the Mountain West Conference, a silky guard who led his team in scoring and made the league’s all-defense team.

headline: Iraqi Journalist Shot Dead by Officer
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Kurds', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Mohammed Bdaiwi, a Radio Free Iraq bureau chief and a professor, was killed by a Kurdish officer in the presidential guard brigade.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — An Iraqi journalist was shot dead on Saturday by a Kurdish officer in the presidential guard brigade in Baghdad, security officials said.

headline: Names of Health Plans Sow Customer Confusion
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: As consumers sign up for health insurance in the final days of open enrollment, many find the names of plans unhelpful, confusing and in some cases misleading.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Americans race to sign up for health insurance in the final days of open enrollment, many consumers and consumer advocates say the names of plans are unhelpful, confusing and in some cases misleading.

headline: Michigan’s 3-Point Shooters Strike Early and Often Against Texas
abstract: The Wolverines made 14 of 28 shots from behind the arc, and 8 of 14 in the first half.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Coming from the Big 12 Conference, Texas had twice played Iowa State this season and was familiar, then, with having to defend four or even five 3-point threats at once.

headline: Scott’s Lead Becomes Slightly Less Comfortable
abstract: Keegan Bradley shot a six-under-par 66 to narrow Adam Scott’s lead to three strokes at Bay Hill with one round remaining.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Adam Scott enjoys playing from ahead. Keegan Bradley prefers being the pursuer. Both will be in their comfort zones Sunday when Scott carries a three-stroke lead over Bradley into the final round of the Arnold Palmer Invitational at Bay Hill Golf Club.

headline: Rhode Island House Speaker Resigns Amid Investigation
abstract: Gordon D. Fox resigned a day after searches at his home and office by the F.B.I., Internal Revenue Service and other federal and state authorities.
lead_paragraph: Gordon D. Fox, speaker of the Rhode Island House of Representatives, resigned his leadership post on Saturday and said that he would not seek re-election in the fall, a decision that came a day after federal and state law enforcement authorities raided his office and home.

headline: $5 Million for Vick? If Smith Thrives, It’s a Steal
abstract: It is altogether possible for Michael Vick to mentor Geno Smith, to tutor him, while every day still approaching his job as if he will start.
lead_paragraph: At one time the Jets were criticized for profligate spending, for overvaluing some of their players and awarding generous contracts to those whose production did not quite seem to merit the reward. On Friday they invested $5 million in a player they hope never takes a snap for them.

headline: Palestinians Criticize Abbas for Public Fatah Feud at Delicate Time Diplomatically
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, has begun a campaign against his onetime ally, Muhammad Dahlan, a former Fatah security chief, at a delicate time in a diplomatic battle.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — When Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, returned to his headquarters here late last week after a quick trip for talks in Washington, the welcome-home reception featuring waving flags, a marching band and posters with his portrait seemed like a forced attempt to boost the spirits of an embattled leader.

headline: Girardi Makes His 1st Successful Replay Challenge
abstract: Manager Joe Girardi’s appeal erased a Minnesota Twins runner at second, helping Masahiro Tanaka to his first spring training victory.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — Yankees Manager Joe Girardi successfully appealed an umpire’s call through television replay for the first time Saturday.

headline: Mercer Coach Says Rankings Are Flawed
abstract: Bob Hoffman, the coach of 14th-seeded Mercer, which upset Duke, said the Rating Percentage Index undervalued strong teams from smaller conferences.
lead_paragraph: Upsets have been somewhat commonplace in this N.C.A.A. tournament: Of the 32 games Thursday and Friday, eight were won by a lower seed. Maybe the seedings were wrong in the first place.

headline: Complexity of Conflict Leaves Donors Wary of Aiding Syrians
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: The frustration of international aid workers is growing as donations to groups helping Syrians have remained paltry during three years of turmoil.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — When an earthquake killed 150,000 people in Haiti in 2010, private individuals donated $20 million to the international aid group Mercy Corps to help victims, most of it within weeks of the disaster. During three years of turmoil in Syria that have produced a similar death toll, the organization has collected just $2 million for Syrians.

headline: Rally Falls Short and Syracuse Is Eliminated
abstract: Tyler Ennis’s attempt before the buzzer clanked off the back of the rim as Dayton, an 11 seed, toppled the third-seeded Orange.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — The night before the first game of the season, Dayton Coach Archie Miller gave his team an order: It would forgo the standard routine during starting-lineup introductions. The team would instead huddle in a circle near the foul line, lock arms and sway.

headline: Reconstructing a Routine Flight
abstract: Tracing the Malaysia Airlines route, from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, that Flight 370 never completed.
lead_paragraph: Tracing the Malaysia Airlines route, from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, that Flight 370 never completed.

headline: Vera Chytilova Dies at 85; Made Daring Films in Czech New Wave
abstract: Ms. Chytilova was known for films that were formally rigorous even by the standards of the Czech New Wave movement.
lead_paragraph: Vera Chytilova, a filmmaker often called the first lady of Czech cinema, whose work — subversive, experimental and strongly feminist — was long banned in her homeland, died on March 12 in Prague. She was 85.

headline: U.S. Emerges as Central Stage in Asian Rivalry
keywords: ['Korean-Americans', 'International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Prostitution', 'Geography', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Asian-Americans', 'Japanese-Americans']
abstract: Experts say that both Japan and South Korea have the same goal: cajoling Washington into pressuring the other to make concessions in their bitter rivalry over history and geography.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The political and historical war of words between Japan and South Korea has found another battleground: the United States.

headline: No Bail for Former I.R.A. Member Charged in ’72 Killing
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ivor Bell, 77, is accused in the abduction and murder of Jean McConville, a mother of 10 who had been accused of spying for the British Army.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A man accused of being a former Irish Republican Army commander was denied bail on Saturday after being charged in connection with one of the most notorious crimes of the conflict in Northern Ireland: the murder of a mother of 10 in 1972.

headline: Countries Divided on Future of Ancient Buddhas
abstract: Thirteen years after the Bamian Buddhas were blasted into rubble, opinion is split on whether to leave them as is, rebuild them, or make copies of them.
lead_paragraph: BAMIAN, Afghanistan — They were the picture-postcard view of a rural and mostly untouched Afghanistan: ancient, towering Buddhas that became a symbol of the Taliban’s religious fanaticism and intolerance.

headline: Bird Strike Shatters Malaysia Jet’s Windshields
abstract: As efforts to find Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 continued, a plane landing in Nepal collided with a flock of ducks.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A Malaysia Airlines plane ran into a flock of ducks late Friday night just as it landed at Tribhuvan International Airport in Nepal, shattering its two right windshields, officials said.

headline: Wisconsin Tops Oregon With Surge in 2nd Half
abstract: The Badgers wiped out a 12-point halftime deficit and hung on to win.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The booing started as soon as Oregon took the court for warm-ups before its N.C.A.A. Tournament game with Wisconsin. Not that the players expected anything else. Bradley Center is about an hour’s drive from Madison, and anyone not wearing Badger scarlet and white on Saturday stood out like an extra from a 1930s gangster film.

headline: Lundqvist Breaks Another Record in a Key Win
abstract: Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist earned his 50th career shutout, a Rangers record, less than a week after setting the team victory mark.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Two great goalies based on each side of the Hudson River, Martin Brodeur and Henrik Lundqvist, met for probably the last time Saturday night, and once again Lundqvist skated away the winner.

headline: Spartans Survive Crimson’s Comeback
abstract: Harvard went ahead for the first time with seven minutes left, but Michigan State used a flurry of its own to escape with a victory.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wash. — Michigan State was coasting eastward, toward the N.C.A.A. tournament’s East Regional at Madison Square Garden, when Harvard ambushed the bandwagon.

headline: The Geopolitics of Name-Dropping
abstract: Moldova to Micronesia. Bombay to Burma. East Timor to South Sudan. For well-traveled sophisticates, the world is an ever-shifting big geography lesson.
lead_paragraph: Moldova to Micronesia. Bombay to Burma. East Timor to South Sudan. For well-traveled sophisticates, the world is an ever-shifting big geography lesson.

headline: Patricia Byrne, Lee Jablow
abstract: The bride is a physician assistant in Philadelphia, and the groom is an intern in Camden, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Grace Byrne, the daughter of Mimi Byrne and Michael J. Byrne of Media, Pa., was married Saturday afternoon to Dr. Lee Michael Jablow, the son of David A. Jablow of Somerset, N.J., and the late Anne Sehring Jablow. James F. McKay III, the chief judge of the Louisiana Fourth Circuit Court of Appeal, officiated at the Peristyle, an open-air pavilion at City Park in New Orleans.

headline: Mara Cvejic, Nitesh Paryani
abstract: The bride and groom are doctors.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Mara Cvejic and Dr. Nitesh Nandlal Paryani were married Saturday at the Players Championship at Sawgrass Clubhouse in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. Pandit Kadambi Srinathji performed the Hindu wedding ceremony.

headline: Christina Stavridis and James Wong III
abstract: The bride is an advertising executive at Google; the groom is a medical student.
lead_paragraph: Christina Anne Stavridis, a daughter of Laura Hall Stavridis and Adm. James G. Stavridis of Bedford, Mass., is to be married Sunday to James Wong III, the son of Dr. Lucy A. Wong and Mr. Wong Jr. of Warren, N.J. The Rev. Milan R. Kralik, a minister of the United Church of Christ, will perform the ceremony at the Coral Gables Congregational Church in Coral Gables, Fla.

headline: Jana Lewis, Joshua Deitch
abstract: The bride is a resident in general surgery at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn; the groom is a managing director and the head of bond sales at Penserra Securities in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jana Lori Lewis and Joshua Reuven Deitch were married Saturday evening at Cold Spring Country Club in Huntington, N.Y. Rabbi Jaimee Shalhevet officiated.

headline: Beth FitzPatrick, Brian Mulherin
abstract: The bride is an associate at a Washington law firm; the groom is an associate director at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
lead_paragraph: Beth Alexandra FitzPatrick and Brian George Mulherin were married Saturday at the Cathedral of St. Matthew the Apostle in Washington. Msgr. W. Ronald Jameson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Meredith Montgomery, Joseph Khawam
abstract: The bride and groom are lawyers in Washington with cabinet-level agencies.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Day Montgomery and Joseph Norman Khawam were married Saturday at the Oaks Waterfront Inn in Royal Oak, Md. Mary A. Tankersley, who was ordained by St. Luke’s Evangelical Church Ministries in Dearing, Ga., officiated.

headline: Yael Kushner and Eliot Heher
abstract: The couple are both doctors in the field of renal medicine.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Yael Batia Kushner and Dr. Eliot Charles Heher were married Saturday evening at the State Room, an event space in Boston. Adrian Robbins-Cole, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with Rabbi David B. Kudan taking part.

headline: Carol Romney, Fernando Leiva Bertrán
abstract: The bride is in real estate; the groom teaches economics.
lead_paragraph: Carol Jane Romney, a daughter of Susan C. Romney and Larry R. Romney of Chino Valley, Ariz., was married Saturday evening to Fernando José Leiva Bertrán, a son of Ricardo A. Leiva of Mendoza, Argentina, and the late Maria Silvia Bertrán. The bride’s father, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Nathaniel Hill II and Cliff Wynne III
abstract: Mr. Hill is an administrator in the Office Support Services unit of the Senate Sergeant at Arms; Dr. Wynne, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist, is a consultant on electronic medical records.
lead_paragraph: Nathaniel Lamar Hill II and Dr. Ernest Clifford Wynne III are to be married Sunday by the Rev. Dr. Jorge Delgado, a Community Church minister, at the Park Hyatt in Washington.

headline: Christie Cunningham and Jonathan McNeill
abstract: The couple are graduate students at the University of Pennsylvania, where the bride is studying for an M.B.A. and the groom for a medical degree.
lead_paragraph: Christie Lauren Cunningham and Jonathan David McNeill were married Friday at their home in Philadelphia in a ceremony held under Pennsylvania’s self-uniting marriage statute.

headline: Catherine Sear and Scott Cantor
abstract: The bride and groom received degrees from Johns Hopkins and work at the World Bank.
lead_paragraph: Catherine Kilbourn Sear and Scott Michael Cantor were married Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House, an event space in New York. Denise L. Cote, a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, officiated.

headline: Amy Bennett, Richard DeFrank Jr.
abstract: The bride books musicians; the groom works in disaster recovery for a bank.
lead_paragraph: Amy Robin Bennett and Richard Alan DeFrank Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Tappan Hill Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y. Elizabeth M. Phaire, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated.

headline: Mary Chapman, Jason Benoit
abstract: The bride teaches English; the groom is an accountant.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jordan Chapman and Jason Matthew Benoit were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Brant S. Copeland at First Presbyterian Church in Tallahassee, Fla.

headline: Megan Chan and Jarrod Stuard
abstract: The bride works in Washington as a senior editor for Politico; the groom is an Air Force captain and a judge advocate general lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Megan Hojing Chan and Capt. Jarrod Hunter Stuard were married Saturday evening at St. Paul’s Chapel at Columbia University in New York. The Rev. Jeffrey White, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Erin Barbach, Scott Silver
abstract: The bride is a social media manager for Ralph Lauren; the groom sells voice and video technologies for Cisco Systems.
lead_paragraph: Erin Nicole Barbach and Scott Kyle Silver are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, N.Y.

headline: Joy Han, Daniel Jones
abstract: The bride is a lawyer and the groom owns a vacation rental properties company.
lead_paragraph: Joy Nova Han, a daughter of Hyuk Koon Han and a stepdaughter Dr. Simon Peter Cho of New York, was married Saturday to Daniel Allison Jones, a son of Margaret M. Kotlewski of Newton, N.C., and Allison Van Lopik Jones of Sarasota, Fla. Mark Giller, an associate pastor of the Sanctuary of the Beloved, officiated in New York at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

headline: A Mystery Writer’s Ulterior Motive
abstract: The couple met at and graduated from Cornell, where they were members of the Big Red Marching Band.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Anne Spindel and Justin Ryan Musaffi were married Saturday evening at the DoubleTree by Hilton hotel in Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Noah Fabricant officiated.

headline: Intervening Before Their Friends Could
abstract: Their friends tried to push them together, but the bride beat them to it.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Liane Slaff, the daughter of Howard B. Slaff and Renée W. Slaff of Wilmington, Del., is to be married Sunday to Dr. David Jay Berman, the son of Debbie H. Berman and Dr. Mark S. Berman of Oradell, N.J. Rabbi Bradley Hercman will officiate at the Helen and Martin Kimmel Center for University Life at New York University.

headline: Napier Takes Center Stage as UConn Upsets Villanova
abstract: The senior Shabazz Napier, the Huskies’ heart and soul, scored 25 points as UConn reached the Round of 16 for the first time since 2011, when it won the title.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Connecticut led second-seeded Villanova by 5 with less than four minutes remaining Saturday, but Shabazz Napier — the Huskies’ best player and the team’s indisputable heart and soul — sat crumpled in a heap on the bench, his face buried in a towel.

headline: Biden Notes Progress in Gay Rights, but Says There Is ‘Much Left to Do’
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said supporting gay rights was “inseparable” from promoting human rights around the world.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As hundreds of gay couples in Michigan flocked to clerks’ offices on Saturday — only to have a federal appeals court again halt same-sex marriages in the state hours later — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. made a forceful case for gay rights, both in the United States and worldwide.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 23, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: More Possible Sightings in Hunt for Missing Plane
abstract: Chinese and French satellites spotted possible debris as the search for the missing Malaysian flight, now in its third week, continued on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PEARCE AIR FORCE BASE, Australia — The search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jet entered its third week on Sunday, as data from a French satellite buttressed the theory that the plane might have fallen into the southern Indian Ocean, far off the west coast of Australia. But the day ended without any possible wreckage being found.

headline: Taiwan President Calls on Students to End Occupation of Legislature
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: President Ma Ying-jeou called the students’ occupation illegal and reinforced his intention to follow through with a trade pact with China they are protesting.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:35 p.m. ET |

headline: I Didn’t Want My Son to Have Dwarfism. Not Really.
abstract: I have rare form of dwarfism, and I never expected to be able to have a child—but once I was pregnant, part of me expected my son to share my condition. I wasn’t sure I’d know how to raise a “normal” child.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant? Me? Not going to happen. Or so I thought.

headline: In Our Pages: March 24
keywords: ['Cancer', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Smoking and Tobacco', "St Patrick's Day"]
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: St. Patrick’s day is celebrated in Cairo in 1914; and a doctor says he can prevent smoking-related cancer in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1914 : Lord Kitchener Hosts Ball at British Agency in Cairo

headline: At Airports, a Misplaced Faith in Body Language
abstract: There is little evidence to support the view that “behavior detection officers” have done much beyond inconveniencing tens of thousands of passengers a year.
lead_paragraph: Like the rest of us, airport security screeners like to think they can read body language. The Transportation Security Administration has spent some $1 billion training thousands of “behavior detection officers” to look for facial expressions and other nonverbal clues that would identify terrorists.

headline: Tarnished Silver
abstract: Data are not the problem.
lead_paragraph: Timothy Egan joins the chorus of those dismayed by Nate Silver’s new FiveThirtyEight. I’m sorry, but I have to agree: so far it looks like something between a disappointment and a disaster.

headline: Name-Calling in the Virtual Playground
abstract: Secret is the latest social media platform to confront the tendency of anonymous chat to provide cover for bad behavior.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley sometimes feels like high school. It has its alpha types and its outcasts, its bullies and its bullied.

headline: The Crime of 2010
abstract: Austerity: even worse than you thought.
lead_paragraph: The most important paper at the Brookings Panel was probably Krueger et al on the long-term unemployed, which basically confirmed what we’re learning from a number of sources: it’s really hard to get employers to look at people who have been out of work for an extended period, so any sustained increase in long-term unemployment tends to become permanent.

headline: Vows: A Mutual Connection
abstract: Live music superfans Amy Bennett and Richard DeFrank danced around each other at concerts for years before unfortunate circumstances brought them together as a couple.
lead_paragraph: Live music superfans Amy Bennett and Richard DeFrank danced around each other at concerts for years before unfortunate circumstances brought them together as a couple.

headline: Turkey Downs Warplane From Syria After Warning
keywords: ['Military Aircraft', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Two planes entered Turkish airspace Sunday, but one turned back to Syria after a Turkish warning. When the other plane did not comply, a Turkish jet shot it down, a military statement said.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkish fighter jets shot down a Syrian warplane on Sunday after it violated Turkish airspace, Turkey’s prime minister said, part of the longstanding hostilities between the two nations over the conflict in Syria.

headline: Crews Work to Contain Oil Barge’s Leak
keywords: ['Oil Spills', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: About 168,000 gallons of oil leaked into Galveston Bay on Saturday from a barge that had collided with a ship.
lead_paragraph: Emergency crews in Texas worked on Sunday to contain 168,000 gallons of oil that leaked into Galveston Bay on Saturday from a barge that collided with a ship, officials said.

headline: Banks Urge Young Analysts to Do the Unthinkable: Take Weekends Off
abstract: In an industry in which grueling schedules are embraced as a badge of honor, efforts to promote work-life balance reflect a significant change in corporate culture.
lead_paragraph: The hard-charging investment banker rolled out of bed at 11 a.m. First on the to-do list? A leisurely cup of coffee and some Greek yogurt while checking out the sports highlights on ESPN. Next up: a two-hour run along Manhattan’s waterfront with a pit stop at Chop’t for a double chicken salad to go.

headline: It’s Really Not That Tough to Backdate Unemployment Benefits
abstract: Maybe John Boehner should tell his unemployed constituents that they can’t get their benefits because it’s too complicated to reprogram a computer.
lead_paragraph: We criticized Speaker John Boehner on Thursday for refusing to bring an extension of unemployment benefits to a vote. Mr. Boehner cited as his excuse a letter from state unemployment agencies that said backdating the benefits to December (when they expired) would be difficult and costly to administer. The letter was signed by Mark Henry, director of the Mississippi Department of Employment Security, who is chairman of the national group of unemployment agencies.

headline: Adolfo Suárez Dies at 81; Led Spain Back to Democracy
abstract: Mr. Suárez, who helped fill a power vacuum left by the death of Gen. Francisco Franco in 1975, was a key figure in the country’s transition back to democracy.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Adolfo Suárez, Spain’s first elected prime minister after the Franco dictatorship and a key figure in the country’s transition back to democracy, died here on Sunday. He was 81.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights for Sunday, March 23.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (NBC) AMERICAN DREAM BUILDERS This competition-style reality show hosted by the interior designer Nate Berkus pits a dozen designers and home builders against one another to see who can pull off the best renovation each week. In the series premiere, the contestants are divided into teams to complete projects in two Tudor-style homes. Judging their work will be Mr. Berkus; Eddie George, the professional football player turned landscape architect; and the interior designer Monica Pedersen (second from left above, with Mr. Berkus at center and Mr. George, second from right). Each week the losing team will vote off a member, with the remaining two contestants facing off in a final home makeover.

headline: Can You Spot the Liar?
abstract: Subjects in a study on body language and lying were asked several general questions — and then told off camera to lie or tell the truth when answering. Can you tell truth from falsehood?
lead_paragraph: Subjects in a study on body language and lying were asked several general questions — and then told off camera to lie or tell the truth when answering. Can you tell truth from falsehood?

headline: Stanford Stymies Kansas and Its Star Freshman
abstract: Andrew Wiggins scored 4 points for the second-seeded Jayhawks, who shot 32.8 percent from the field in their loss to the Cardinal.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Stanford’s plan to stop Andrew Wiggins, the star Kansas freshman, was straightforward: It was the responsibility of every Cardinal player on the court.

lead_paragraph: March 22, 2014

headline: U.S. Intelligence Officials Believe Snowden Is Working With Russia, Lawmaker Says
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Representative Mike Rogers’s assertions about the former National Security Agency contractor expanded on his previous suggestions, for which he has yet to offer evidence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A top congressional intelligence official said on Sunday that American counterintelligence officials are virtually unanimous in believing that Edward J. Snowden is “under the influence of Russian intelligence services.”

headline: Danger Lingers After Landslide Kills 8 in Washington State
abstract: A landslide about a square mile in size left eight people dead and at least 18 missing in Washington State while destroying homes and burying a state highway.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Wash. — A huge landslide that roared down from a rain-saturated mountain slope near here, leaving eight people dead and at least 18 others missing, remained a site of both devastation and continued extreme danger on Sunday, state and local officials said.

headline: A Rocker Never Sure of His Step
abstract: In “A Man Called Destruction,” Holly George-Warren chronicles the uncertain path of the rock singer Alex Chilton.
lead_paragraph: In October 1966, a Memphis pop group known as the Devilles lost its lead singer and had to find a new one in a hurry. An acquaintance of the band recommended a singer who had impressed him at a talent show. This singer was eager to audition, but he asked for a ride, because he was only 15 and didn’t have a driver’s license. No matter: By the time he was 16, the Devilles had become the Box Tops and the kid, Alex Chilton, had sung the lead vocal on “The Letter,” which went on to sell four million copies.

headline: Putting Science What-Ifs to the Demonstration Test
abstract: “None of the Above,” a National Geographic Channel show hosted by Tim Shaw, sets up and explains scientific experiments.
lead_paragraph: The slick “Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey,” with Neil deGrasse Tyson surveying millions of years in dulcet tones, is one way to use television for science education. Or, you could just dress a guy in a chain-mail suit, hit him with a million volts of electricity and see how charbroiled he gets.

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights for Monday, March 24.
lead_paragraph: 11:15 A.M. (Cinemax) TRUE LIES (1994) Helen (Jamie Lee Curtis) thinks her husband, Harry (Arnold Schwarzenegger, above, with Ms. Curtis), is a mild-mannered computer salesman, but no one is what he or she seems in this romantic action comedy written and directed by James Cameron. When she learns that Harry is actually an international spy, Helen gets pulled into a globe-saving mission to stop terrorists with nuclear bombs. “The most engaging part of the film is the long middle section, which toys with marital types,” Caryn James wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Schwarzenegger, she added, is “no Cary Grant, but along with Ms. Curtis, he makes ‘True Lies’ the first successful romantic comedy in which trucks, as well as heartstrings, are blown to bits.” (The movie is repeated at 10 p.m.) On Showtime 2, at 1:35 p.m., Mr. Schwarzenegger stars as John Kimble, an undercover officer in Ivan Reitman’s “Kindergarten Cop” (1990). The search for a drug dealer leads Kimble and his partner (Pamela Reed) to an Oregon school where their suspect’s son is a student. Kimble ends up teaching the class of kindergartners, and though “the film relies on obvious jokes,” Ms. James wrote in The Times, “Mr. Schwarzenegger is so appealing, relaxed and genial in this role that his fans are not likely to ask for more, and even his detractors are likely to be happily surprised.” And there’s one more chance for a dose of Mr. Schwarzenegger before the day ends: On “The Tonight Show,” at 11:34 p.m. on NBC, he will be a guest, along with the television host Carson Daly and the band Vampire Weekend.

headline: James Rebhorn, an Actor Often Playing a Man in a Suit, Dies at 65
abstract: Mr. Rebhorn appeared in dozens of popular movies and television shows and recently starred on the Showtime hit “Homeland.”
lead_paragraph: James Rebhorn, a character actor who appeared in dozens of popular movies and television shows and recently starred on the Showtime hit “Homeland,” died on Friday at his home in South Orange, N.J. He was 65.

headline: Gentler Words About Charter Schools From de Blasio
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in an effort to mend fences on charter schools, emphasized common ground and a desire to “shake the foundations” of the school system.
lead_paragraph: It was perhaps fitting that Mayor Bill de Blasio found himself Sunday at Riverside Church, the neo-Gothic landmark in Morningside Heights: The church was long a cathedral of antiwar sentiment, and the mayor was looking to make peace.

headline: Brass Band of Brothers, a Dad’s Gift
abstract: In Reuben Atlas’s documentary about the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, the band’s musicians grapple with the ideals of the Chicago trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran.
lead_paragraph: Probably the biggest influence on the group in “Brothers Hypnotic” comes from very close to home. In Reuben Atlas’s relaxed documentary about the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, the band’s proudly independent musicians still grapple with the ideals of the Chicago trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran, father to seven of the group’s eight members, their teacher in their formative years and an advocate of black consciousness for alternatives to the establishment.

headline: Extending the Reach of a Long Run, Twists Included
abstract: As demonstrated by the works being performed at the David H. Koch Theater, Paul Taylor’s choreography celebrates the power of a trained dancer’s body as well as an intangible spiritual essence.
lead_paragraph: In “Private Domain” — the autobiography, not the dance — the choreographer Paul Taylor divulges that most of his works begin as a swamp. “The only firm ground seems to be a certain craft that I’ve learned by trial and error, handy to fall back on — a roller to help squish the path dry,” he writes. “But craft is never the heart of the matter. No craft, however finely honed, can disguise a passionless base.”

headline: Lobbyists Set to Fight Royalty Bill for Artists
abstract: Sotheby’s and Christie’s have spent about $1 million in the last couple of years to fight a bill that would give visual artists a cut of the profits when their work is resold at auction.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Sotheby’s auction house paid an unusual visit to a few lawmakers on Capitol Hill this month and brought along some high-powered lobbying muscle. They had come to complain about a new bill that even some supporters acknowledge faces a difficult road in this divided Congress: a proposal to give visual artists — or their estates — a cut of the profits when their work is resold at public auction.

headline: Virtual Reality Is Here. Can We Play With It?
keywords: ['Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Game Developers Conference']
abstract: The Morpheus Project and the Oculus Rift, on display at the Game Developers Conference in San Francisco, are new systems fine-tuning virtual reality in video games.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The notion of virtual reality has been tantalizing since at least the 1980s, when William Gibson’s novel “Neuromancer” and the holodeck on “Star Trek: The Next Generation” popularized the idea of transporting people into a three-dimensional computerized environment. And until recently, it’s been science fiction.

headline: Baby M and the Question of Surrogacy
keywords: ['Surrogate Motherhood', 'Child Custody and Support', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: The custody battle over Baby M was the first time a court considered surrogacy. Today’s families are created in many different ways. But have we resolved the question of surrogacy?
lead_paragraph: The custody battle over Baby M was the first time a court considered surrogacy. Today’s families are created in many different ways. But have we resolved the question of surrogacy?

headline: Illness Sidelines Gregg Allman
abstract: Gregg Allman, the lead singer and keyboardist of the Allman Brothers Band, sat out the group’s last two performances over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Gregg Allman, the lead singer and keyboardist of the Allman Brothers Band, sat out the group’s last two performances over the weekend because of bronchitis. Only four shows remain in the band’s sold-out run at the Beacon Theater before it is scheduled to end on Saturday. Mr. Allman, 66, hopes to recover in time to participate in the remaining shows, although a message on the group’s Facebook page said there were “no guarantees.” Mr. Allman has dealt with health issues in the past, including a liver transplant in 2010 and back problems that caused a Beacon performance to be cut short in 2012. The guitarists Warren Haynes and Derek Trucks both announced in January that they would leave the band at the end of the year.

headline: Curses
abstract: Tom Pepper’s back. Yuck. And we mean that in the nicest way possible.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s really too bad this puzzle didn’t come with one of those wet wipes. Or had WET WIPES in the puzzle, as a kind of anti-reveal. That would have been neat. (See what I did there?)

headline: Baby M and the Question of Surrogate Motherhood
abstract: The custody battle over Baby M was the first time an American court considered the legality of surrogacy. Questions over the practice linger.
lead_paragraph: You could say that the surrogate mother of all surrogate mothers was Hagar, servant to Sarai in the Old Testament. Sarai, later known as Sarah, had fertility woes. So she pleaded with her husband — Abram, before he became Abraham — to lie with Hagar and do what needed to be done. “It may be that I may obtain children by her,” she said, as rendered in the King James Version of Genesis 16:2. Her plan worked splendidly. Hagar conceived a son. Call him Ishmael.

headline: Malaysia’s Mystery
abstract: The struggle to piece together the puzzle of the missing airliner.
lead_paragraph: The struggle to piece together the puzzle of the missing airliner.

headline: ‘Divergent’ Ticket Sales Justify a Franchise
abstract: Summit Entertainment’s film “Divergent” arrived to solid if not spectacular ticket sales at North American theaters, but it generated enough interest to introduce a major new series.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Summit Entertainment’s high-profile “Divergent” arrived to solid if not spectacular ticket sales at North American theaters.

headline: Singing and Playing, With Emotions in Play
abstract: The singer-songwriter Matt Alber performed an emotional, ballad-heavy program as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: How many of us have found ourselves in the position that the West Coast singer-songwriter Matt Alber describes in his anguished folk-pop ballad, “End of the World”? Buckled into a roller coaster alongside a lover with whom he is breaking up, he worries they are climbing to their death. Just before it makes a steep drop, he cries out, “I don’t want to be dangled over the edge of a dying romance.” Then he recognizes that his partner feels the same terror and asks, “Can you tell me why you’re holding on to me like it’s the end of the world?”

headline: I Didn’t Build That
abstract: But I did build the other thing.
lead_paragraph: Update: According to Sutch, the term liquidity trap comes from a 1940 book by Dennis Robertson, and it was popularized by Alvin Hansen in the 1950s. What with secular stagnation and all that, Hansen seems to be having a comeback!

keywords: ['Social Media', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: To deal with car owners’ concerns after a long-delayed safety recall, General Motors is turning to forums like Twitter and Facebook.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If you glance at the Facebook page of General Motors, it seems like business as usual at the Detroit automaker, even though the company is struggling to cope with the recalls of 1.6 million cars that it has linked to 12 deaths.

headline: For Wildcats, Win Over Shockers Is Perfectly Thrilling
abstract: Eighth-seeded Kentucky ended Wichita State’s unbeaten season, rallying in the second half and prevailing when Fred VanVleet missed a 3-point shot at the buzzer.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — With about four minutes remaining in the game and a timeout called, Wichita State and Kentucky slowly began walking off the court like weary heavyweight fighters returning to their corners.

headline: Odes to the Season of Rebirth Surround an Episode of Trauma
abstract: The Martha Graham Dance Company presented a new work by Nacho Duato between Graham’s “Rite of Spring” and “Appalachian Spring” in a program at City Center.
lead_paragraph: The members of the Martha Graham Dance Company are impressive individually and collectively, but they have two main and dissimilar ways of moving. In modern pieces by living choreographers, they look released, motivated, free. In Graham’s own choreography, they look tense, stiff-backed, self-conscious, showy.

headline: For Those Hoping to Lose, a Hard Look in the Mirror
abstract: “All of Me,” a PBS documentary from Alexandra Lescaze, looks at obesity through a group of women in Austin, Tex.
lead_paragraph: Fat people aren’t very visible on American television, and when they appear, it tends to be in one of a few approved roles: comic props in blue-collar reality series, cautionary figures in exploitative medical shows, huffing and puffing contestants in weight-loss competitions.

abstract: The second national championship decided at the Spring North American Championships in Dallas was the Lebhar Imp Pairs.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The second national championship decided at the Spring North American Championships here was the Lebhar Imp Pairs.

headline: Confronting Putin’s Russia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Cold War Era', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: We did not seek this confrontation. This new era crept up on us, because we did not fully win the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: The decision by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to annex Crimea ended the post-Cold War era in Europe. Since the late Gorbachev-Reagan years, the era was defined by zigzags of cooperation and disputes between Russia and the West, but always with an underlying sense that Russia was gradually joining the international order. No more.

headline: Washington Officials Discuss Mudslide
abstract: Washington State officials discussed the mudslide that has killed at least three people.
lead_paragraph: Washington State officials discussed the mudslide that has killed at least three people.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 81
abstract: The roll call of Peru’s great players begins with Teófilo Cubillas, who scored 26 goals in 81 international appearances.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Standoff Over Prisoner Release Threatens Mideast Talks
abstract: Though all parties have an interest in extending peace negotiations, the politics surrounding Israel’s impending release of a fourth batch of Palestinian prisoners may be too much to overcome.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli-Palestinian peace talks revived by Washington last summer are scheduled to continue until April 29, but a showdown — and possible breakdown — is likely this week over the anticipated release of a fourth batch of Palestinian prisoners.

headline: Queen Victoria, Another Maligned Mother
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Parenting', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Why must powerful women be judged and found wanting?
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — IS anyone else bored with the seemingly endless tomes on modern motherhood?

headline: A Pay Strike in Israel Stalls Premier’s Trip to Mexico
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Strikes']
abstract: Foreign Ministry employees announced a general strike over pay and working conditions, shutting down the ministry’s work in Israel and 103 diplomatic missions abroad.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Employees of Israel’s Foreign Ministry announced an open-ended general strike on Sunday over pay and working conditions, an unprecedented step involving a complete shutdown of the ministry’s office here and the country’s 103 diplomatic missions abroad.

headline: Children’s TV Aims to Profit From Award Shows
abstract: For the first time, the Disney Channel is televising the Radio Disney Music Awards as a special in prime time, and Nickelodeon is adding Kids’ Choice Sports.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Awards shows are sprouting like mushrooms across the television landscape as networks try to create event programming. Now even the children’s channels are introducing additional trophy telecasts.

headline: Anger Grows in Taiwan Against Deal With China
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Demonstrators fear President Ma Ying-jeou and his allies reached a trade agreement that will give Beijing too much influence over the island’s economy.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Demonstrators who have occupied Taiwan’s legislature since last week expanded their protest of a trade deal with China on Sunday evening by invading the government building nearby that houses the offices of the prime minister.

headline: Jeter’s Meager Average in Spring Training Does Not Worry Him or Girardi
abstract: Base hits before the season opens are appreciated, but more important to experienced batters like Derek Jeter is progress in their approach and form at the plate.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Games are nine innings in spring training just as they are in the regular season. Three strikes still make an out, and teams still charge dearly for tickets and parking. But for many veteran hitters, like Derek Jeter, much about spring training has nothing to do with the regular season.

headline: Birchbox, Seller of Beauty Products, Steps Out From Web With a Store
abstract: As more stores go from exclusively online to brick-and-mortar, the online beauty subscription company Birchbox is aiming at a full-blown shopping and lifestyle “experience.”
lead_paragraph: A banner for the hair salon that once occupied these quarters still hangs outside an abandoned West Broadway storefront in the heart of SoHo’s main shopping area in Manhattan. Inside, the 4,500-square-foot duplex space is utterly empty, with no hint of what — if anything — will fill it next.

headline: In Hollywood News Wars, TheWrap Rebounds
abstract: The trade news website has set goals of more traffic and better journalism, and has been rewarded with more visitors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Talk about going from fizzle to sizzle.

headline: Rwanda Reaches for New Economic Model
abstract: A country is looking to attract investors, not donors, to transform a tiny rural economy into a financial and high-tech hub for the region.
lead_paragraph: KIGALI, Rwanda — On the 12th floor of the Kigali City Tower, a modern blue-glass office building on the side of one of this capital’s famous hills, the latest endeavor in the effort to transform a tiny rural economy into a financial and high-tech hub is trying to find its footing.

headline: His Future Bright, Dayton’s Coach Focuses on the Now
abstract: Archie Miller was proud of his players’ performances against Ohio State and Syracuse, but he was also focused on extending his team’s success, a path that continues Thursday in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: In the time it took to win his first two N.C.A.A. tournament games, Archie Miller went from relative obscurity to next in line as the prince of men’s Division I basketball. On Thursday, Miller, 35, and his 11th-seeded Dayton Flyers disposed of No. 6 Ohio State, whose coach, Thad Matta, had been a mentor and friend to Miller.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of March 24
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Obama and Allies Seek Firm, United Response as Russia Grips Crimea
abstract: As Russia consolidated its hold on Crimea, President Obama and several allies prepared to meet in The Hague in an effort to develop a strong response despite their diverging interests.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — As Russia consolidated its hold on Crimea, raising its flag over seized military bases and detaining ousted Ukrainian commanders on Sunday, President Obama and his international allies prepared to meet here in an effort to develop a strong, united response despite their diverging interests in dealing with the Kremlin.

headline: Wealth Over Work
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Making America safe for oligarchy.
lead_paragraph: It seems safe to say that “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” the magnum opus of the French economist Thomas Piketty, will be the most important economics book of the year — and maybe of the decade. Mr. Piketty, arguably the world’s leading expert on income and wealth inequality, does more than document the growing concentration of income in the hands of a small economic elite. He also makes a powerful case that we’re on the way back to “patrimonial capitalism,” in which the commanding heights of the economy are dominated not just by wealth, but also by inherited wealth, in which birth matters more than effort and talent.

headline: 3 Presidents and a Riddle Named Putin
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has argued with United States presidents, lectured them, misled them, accused them, kept them waiting, kept them guessing, betrayed them and felt betrayed by them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bill Clinton found him to be cold and worrisome, but predicted he would be a tough and able leader. George W. Bush wanted to make him a friend and partner in the war on terror, but grew disillusioned over time.

headline: America’s Underappreciated Entrepreneur: The Federal Government
abstract: Washington must invest more in science and get a better return.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a world in which the United States government — not the private sector — is the economy’s indispensable entrepreneur, innovating at the frontiers of science and technology, able and willing to take risks and to persevere through uncertainty.

headline: When Nature Looks Unnatural
abstract: Why scientists were so excited about last week’s cosmological announcement.
lead_paragraph: Nothing makes scientists happier than an experimental result that completely contradicts a widely accepted theory. The scientists who first invented the theory might not be tickled, but their colleagues will be overjoyed. Science progresses when a good theory is superseded by an even better theory, and the most direct route to building a better theory is to be confronted by data that simply don’t fit the old one.

headline: City That Squandered Baseball Relishes Brief Return
abstract: A group led by the former Expos outfielder Warren Cromartie has envisioned bringing a major league team back to Montreal after it has gone a decade without one.
lead_paragraph: For the Mets and the Toronto Blue Jays, they are just games at the end of the long spring training schedule, the final chance for the players to work out the kinks and the managers to trim their rosters.

headline: Dispute on Sri Lanka War Crimes Escalates
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A crucial impending vote will determine whether the U.N. will investigate possible war crimes committed by government forces and separatists during a 26-year civil war.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — About 100 government supporters marched to the American Embassy in Colombo, Sri Lanka, last week and smashed coconuts on the embassy’s doorstep in a Hindu ritual meant to curse an enemy. “We will not let them take our president to the electric chair!” the protesters shouted.

headline: Risks Abound as Reporters Play in Traffic
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The availability of ready metrics on content is not only changing the way news organizations compensate their employees, but will have a significant effect on the news itself.
lead_paragraph: It is a dirty secret of the journalism profession that many reporters are bad at math. Many of us ended up typing our way to a living because we had an easier time making words dance than numbers.

headline: Iowa State’s Do-It-All Kane Leads a Rally Over North Carolina
abstract: DeAndre Kane led his team in scoring, rebounding and assists, and he scored the crucial final points for the Cyclones.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Iowa State was undermanned. And undersize. But hardly overwhelmed. Playing without one of their top scorers, the Cyclones still had the do-everything point guard DeAndre Kane, who, again, did everything to propel Iowa State into the Round of 16.

headline: Rhode Island Legislators Vie to Fill Speaker Post After Hasty Resignation
abstract: Two members of the State House scrambled for support to become the next speaker after the sudden resignation of Gordon D. Fox, a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The political world in Rhode Island remained in turmoil on Sunday as two members of the State House scrambled for support to become the next speaker after the sudden resignation of Gordon D. Fox, a Democrat who had held the job since 2010.

headline: Rejuvenated Harlem Building Becomes a Business Incubator for Biotechnology
abstract: Providing start-up lab space, Harlem Biospace is an effort to tap the scientific talent and entrepreneurial spirit of Columbia University and City College.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that Harlem is changing. There is a new Red Lobster, a Joe’s Crab Shack, a DSW shoe store, and soon there will be a Whole Foods on 125th Street. But some of the most interesting changes are not so obvious.

headline: Far-Right Party Stirs Municipal Elections in France
abstract: The far-right National Front party was poised to make a strong showing in the first round of French municipal elections held on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The far right National Front party was poised to make a strong showing in the first round of French municipal elections held on Sunday, showing that the party is thriving on France’s moribund economy and broad dissatisfaction with the two main parties.

headline: Tennessee, With Story of Its Own, Tops Mercer
abstract: Tennessee, the No. 11 seed in the Midwest Region, overpowered No. 14 Mercer on the boards and was never seriously threatened in a victory in Raleigh, N.C.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Ten busloads of fans from Macon, Ga., came to PNC Arena to watch 14th-seeded Mercer in another performance of its role as Cinderella in this N.C.A.A. tournament, a victory against Duke already in the books and a berth in the Round of 16 on the line for the first time in the program’s history.

headline: Urbanizing China
keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'Rural Areas', 'Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: The urbanization plan is intriguing, but the government needs to make sure its ideas are carried out in ways that benefit its people.
lead_paragraph: The plan announced by China’s leaders last week to move more people from the countryside to cities could help raise the standard of living for millions of people. But it does not go far enough to protect migrants and farmers.

headline: Willfully Endangering Drivers
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: Toyota and General Motors failed the American public when they delayed recalls of millions of defective cars.

abstract: Japan will announce Monday that it will turn over to Washington more than 700 pounds of weapons-grade plutonium and a large quantity of highly enriched uranium.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Franklin School stands vacant and crumbling on a corner of 13th and K Streets, near a stretch of glass-fronted office buildings. The Reconstruction-era public high school was the first of its kind in Washington in 1869, and it could soon make a new mark as a kunsthalle, one of just a handful of noncollecting art museums on the East Coast.

headline: Matt Every’s First Win Comes at Event That Was a Boyhood Ritual

While his father planted himself at one hole, Every preferred to follow Mark Calcavecchia, a Florida high school golf standout who went on to win 13 PGA Tour events, including a British Open.

lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — U.C.L.A.’s Kyle Anderson never appears to be in a hurry. When Anderson, a 6-foot-9 guard, carries the ball up the court, with a high, easy dribble, it is at a leisurely pace. With each of his loping strides, his upper body sways back and forth, the carriage of an old man. The long, languid release on his shot is, like most everything about Anderson, done on his own time.

headline: Peter Marino Works His Magic on Bulgari’s Rome Flagship
abstract: The brand hired the famed architect Peter Marino to spruce up its flagship store in Rome, which reopened to the public last Thursday.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate its 130-year anniversary, the Italian luxury goods titan Bulgari turned to a familiar figure in fashion circles: Peter Marino — the architect known for his luxurious retail environments for clients like Chanel and Louis Vuitton — brought his transformative techniques to the brand’s Rome flagship. Sotirio Bulgari, the company’s founder, oversaw the shop’s first ribbon cutting on Via dei Condotti in 1905. At the reopening ceremony last Thursday, which was attended by Bulgari’s grandsons, Paolo and Nicola, it was clear that Marino had sought to recapture the spirit of the original. He has restored the store’s travertine stone slabs, the green African marble cornices and the bronze letters above the entrance doors. “It took all my skills to get a new concept that was as eternal as Rome, as sexy as Bulgari’s clientele,” says Marino, who looked to the boutique’s first architect, Florestano Di Fausto, for inspiration. His goal, he says, was to capture “the Roman-ness of the brand in the neoclassical-baroque marriage — the sun-filled yellow walls, the extraordinary mix of ancient and new.”
