headline: Story of the Century
abstract: Breaking news on Flight 370: Everything is still on the table.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, this is Brian Bowman of CNN on Day X with breaking news on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370: The zombie plane theory still has legs! Some aviation experts say it is gaining steam as the search in the South Indian Ocean, one of the most remote and windy places on the planet, continues in an area somewhere between the size of West Virginia and the United States. Now, what is the zombie scenario? Well, it’s a spooky possibility. That this Triple Seven, after making its famous left turn, flew on autopilot for hours with its crew and passengers incapacitated before crashing into the sea or, if you happen to think the Northern Corridor option is still open, in Central Asia. Of course, there are many theories floating around and vertical gyrations are not an autopilot maneuver and no theory at this point connects all the dots and that is why we have an investigation and why we intend to stay on top of this story.

headline: General Elections 2014: Key States to Watch
abstract: If either of the two national parties wants to form a government in New Delhi, it must learn to find inroads into these crucial states.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In April and May, nearly 814 million voters will make their way to polling booths across the country to cast their votes in the largest democratic elections in the world.

headline: In Battle of Billionaires, Icahn Gains Three Seats on the Herbalife Board
abstract: The nutritional supplements company Herbalife will nominate three directors proposed by Carl C. Icahn, allowing its biggest shareholder five seats on the board.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:23 p.m. | Shares of Herbalife have become a playground for traders speculating on the fate of the supplements company, and the latest momentum seemed to favor its bulls.

headline: Euro Zone Economy Expanded Further in March, With Unexpected Gains in France
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: A Markit survey of purchasing managers indicates continued economic expansion, a strong improvement in France and signs of recovery in the region’s depressed labor market.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The economy of the euro zone continues to expand, with a surprisingly strong improvement in France and signs of recovery in the region’s depressed labor market, according to a private sector survey released on Monday.

headline: Why I Redesigned My Website
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Small Business']
abstract: The first law of website design is that the owners of a company usually hate their new site within 24 months.
lead_paragraph: As soon as you finish your new website’s design, it’s time to start figuring out how to change it. At least, that’s how it has always been for me. But this time around I actually had a good reason.

headline: Quantum Computing Research May Back Controversial Company
abstract: D-Wave Systems has generated skepticism with its quantum computing technology. Now a new paper may lend credibility to work done by the company.
lead_paragraph: In the fight to prove it really has developed a quantum computer, D-Wave Systems may have won a big round.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 24, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Update: March 25

headline: Aid Package for Ukraine Advances in the Senate
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A Senate vote to take up legislation to aid Ukraine showed bipartisan support, but a debate is expected to ensue over whether to overhaul the International Monetary Fund.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Monday to formally take up legislation to aid Ukraine and sanction Russia, beginning what promises to be a heated weeklong debate in Congress over the role the International Monetary Fund should play in the Crimean crisis.

headline: Rabobank Names New Executive Chairman
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Wiebe Draijer will succeed Piet Moerland, who resigned as chairman of the Dutch lender’s executive board last year after Rabobank agreed to pay more than $1 billion for its role in manipulating global benchmark interest rates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Dutch lender Rabobank said on Monday that its supervisory board had nominated Wiebe Draijer to serve as its new executive chairman after the bank’s former top executive resigned down because of a scandal involving the manipulation of global benchmark interest rates.

headline: Kiev Blamed for Blackout in Capital of Crimea
abstract: Parts of Crimea fell into darkness as Ukraine seemed to retaliate against Russia’s annexation of the region even as it withdrew its last remaining troops there.
lead_paragraph: SIMFEROPOL, Crimea — A power failure plunged much of the Crimean capital, Simferopol, into darkness on Monday, the second partial blackout in two days, as the Ukrainian government in Kiev appeared to retaliate against Russia’s occupation and annexation of the peninsula by sharply cutting electricity supplied from the mainland.

headline: Is the World More Depressed?
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Social Media', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Increasing development and urbanization may lead to more suicides.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been in and out of India for years, but on a recent visit to Chennai, in the state of Tamil Nadu, it seemed that suicide and depression had become part of the social conversation in a way that was once taboo.

headline: Daily Report: Online Fiction Becomes Serialized and Social
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'E-Books and Readers', 'Social Media', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: With Wattpad, a storytelling app, the once-solitary writing process has become informal, intimate and highly interactive.
lead_paragraph: The Internet long ago revamped publishing and bookselling. Now technology is transforming the writing of fiction, previously the most solitary and exacting of arts, into something nearly the opposite. It is social, informal and intimate, with the results not only consumed but often composed on the fly, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: Kaffe’s Kaleidoscope
abstract: An exhibition displays the many colors of the textile artist Kaffe Fassett.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition displays the many colors of the textile artist Kaffe Fassett.

headline: GrubHub Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
abstract: GrubHub plans to sell more than seven million shares in an initial public offering at $20 to $22 a share. At the midpoint, that would value the company at more than $1.72 billion.
lead_paragraph: GrubHub, which merged with Seamless last year, is well known to legions of hungry Wall Street workers. On Monday, the online food ordering service took a step closer to actually being on Wall Street.

headline: Japan Lets U.S. Assume Control of a Nuclear Cache
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Plutonium']
abstract: Tokyo announced on Monday that it would turn over to Washington more than 700 pounds of weapons-grade plutonium and a large quantity of highly enriched uranium.
lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — Japan announced on Monday that it would turn over to Washington a large cache of weapons-grade plutonium and highly enriched uranium, a decades-old research stockpile that is large enough to build dozens of nuclear weapons, according to American and Japanese officials.

headline: Ruling Could Have Reach Beyond Issue of Contraception
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: A case before the Supreme Court could lead to broader religious exemptions from laws on health and civil rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday will hear arguments in a case that pits religious liberty against women’s rights.

headline: Thais Detain More Migrants Believed to Be Ethnic Uighurs
keywords: ['Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)', 'Immigration Detention', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The move brings to 409 the number of people stopped by Thailand this month who are believed to be ethnic Uighurs fleeing China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Two groups totaling at least 189 migrants believed to be ethnic Uighurs fleeing China have been detained in recent days by the authorities in Thailand, Human Rights Watch said Monday. The detention of the two groups brings to 409 the number of people thought to be Uighurs who have been stopped by Thai officials this month.

headline: Search List Expands in Washington State Mudslide
abstract: Estimates about the number of people who may have been in the vicinity when a huge mudslide smashed through the community of Oso continued to grow.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Wash. — Estimates about the number of people who may have been in the vicinity when a huge mudslide smashed through the tiny community of Oso continued to grow on Monday, as Snohomish County officials said they had compiled 176 reports of people unaccounted for since the disaster, which killed at least 14 people and wounded at least eight more.

headline: A Top JPMorgan Banker Is Departing
abstract: One of JPMorgan’s top deal makers in China is retiring. | Herbalife is allowing Carl C. Icahn to nominate three more board representatives. | Regulatory changes have been slow to take hold at credit rating agencies. | Pimco has been attracting attention for the wrong reasons. | The Silk Road case began with a hunt for “John Doe.”
lead_paragraph: Fang Fang, one of JPMorgan Chase’s top deal makers in China and a focus of the United States government’s investigation into the bank’s hiring practices in China, is resigning, Neil Gough writes in DealBook. Mr. Fang announced his decision in an internal memo sent to employees on Monday.

headline: Blackstone to Reduce Stake in SeaWorld
abstract: Blackstone plans to sell 15 million shares of SeaWorld in a secondary offering, according to a prospectus filed on Monday. At Friday’s closing price of $33.17 a share, the offering would be worth $498 million.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group is reducing its stake in SeaWorld Entertainment, almost a year after taking the theme park operator public.

headline: Senior Opposition Lawmaker Decides to Run as Independent
abstract: The Bharatiya Janata Party had denied Jaswant Singh the opportunity to run for Parliament in the Rajasthan district he wanted.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Jaswant Singh, a senior Bharatiya Janata Party politician, announced Monday that he had filed nomination papers as an independent candidate in his ancestral-home district of Barmer, in the desert state of Rajasthan, after the party denied him the opportunity to run for the lower house of Parliament there.

headline: Chinese Man, Ostensibly From an N.G.O., Is Barred From U.N. Human Rights Hearing
abstract: The barring from a United Nations meeting of a member of a prominent Chinese non-governmental organization, in reality a group with ties to the highest levels of the government, casts a spotlight on China’s “GONGOs”; government-organized non-governmental organization.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations has barred a Chinese man from attending a Human Rights Council session in Geneva after he photographed at close range a woman who gave testimony about her father who is serving a life sentence in China for his political activities. The United Nations said the photography was “intimidation” and the man was forced to delete the images.

headline: After Reports on N.S.A., China Urges End to Spying
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: The Chinese called on the United States to explain its actions after news reports said that the N.S.A. had hacked into the computer systems of Huawei, a telecommunications company.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese government called on the United States on Monday to explain its actions and halt the practice of cyberespionage after news reports said that the National Security Agency had hacked its way into the computer systems of China’s largest telecommunications company.

headline: Storm Damaged Their Art, and Now It May Take Their Studio Space
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Art', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']
abstract: After Hurricane Sandy flooded studio and storage spaces at Westbeth, a huge artists’ complex in the West Village, a landlord may rent the rooms to a commercial tenant.
lead_paragraph: Christina Maile has lived at Westbeth, a massive artists’ complex in the West Village, for more than 40 years. For about half that time, she worked out of the building’s sculpture studio, a yawning space with whitewashed brick walls and a soaring ceiling that sits just off a large interior courtyard. There, Ms. Maile and a dozen other sculptors used table saws to slice wood and pipe benders to manipulate metal, creating large-scale pieces for galleries and museums.

headline: French Wages Are Not The Problem
abstract: Falling costs aren’t the goal.
lead_paragraph: In yesterday’s Times, Steven Rattner grudgingly admits that expansionary monetary policy in Europe may be a good thing, but bemoans the lack of adjustment, and gives us this chart:

headline: In Our Pages: March 25
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jazz', 'Public Broadcasting']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Nazi Germany’s head of radio broadcasting bans jazz music in 1939; U.S. ambassador Edwin O. Reischauer gets stabbed in the thigh in Toyko in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1939: Nazi Radio Chief Bans Jazz

headline: A ‘Good Wife’ Spoiler Alert — and Explanation
abstract: A major character’s death had to do with the actor’s decision to leave the show, the series creators say.
lead_paragraph: This is your one and only warning that the following item contains significant spoilers about Sunday’s episode of the CBS series “The Good Wife.”

headline: Former F.B.I. Director Joins WilmerHale
abstract: Robert S. Mueller III, who was director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 12 years before stepping down in September, is joining the law firm WilmerHale as a partner.
lead_paragraph: Robert S. Mueller III, who was director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 12 years before stepping down in September, is joining the law firm WilmerHale as a partner.

headline: Charges Carrying Death Penalty Filed in Mumbai Gang Rapes
abstract: It was the first time that any prosecutor in India had invoked Section 376(E) of the Indian Penal Code since it was strengthened last year as part of an overhaul of the nation’s sexual assault laws.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — A court on Monday allowed a prosecutor to file additional charges that could carry the death penalty for three men convicted of gang-raping a call-center worker and a photojournalist on separate occasions in an abandoned mill.

headline: Malaysia Says Flight Ended in Ocean
abstract: The path of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 ended in the southern Indian Ocean, Prime Minister Najib Razak said at a news conference in Kuala Lumpur.
lead_paragraph: The path of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 ended in the southern Indian Ocean, Prime Minister Najib Razak said at a news conference in Kuala Lumpur.

headline: NYT Now: Malaysia on Fate on Flight 370
abstract: Najib Razak, the prime minister of Malaysia, said Flight 370 ended in the Indian Ocean.
lead_paragraph: Najib Razak, the prime minister of Malaysia, said Flight 370 ended in the Indian Ocean.

headline: Baby M Grew Up, but Surrogacy Remains Controversial
abstract: Nearly 30 years after a United States court first considered it, many questions surrounding surrogacy, legal and otherwise, remain unanswered.
lead_paragraph: In New Jersey in 1985, a woman of no great means, Mary Beth Whitehead, entered into a contract with William Stern, whose wife, Elizabeth, had multiple sclerosis and feared she could endure severe health problems were she to become pregnant. For $10,000 (equivalent to about $22,000 today), Ms. Whitehead agreed to be inseminated with Mr. Stern’s sperm, carry the pregnancy to term and then yield parental rights to the more affluent Sterns.

headline: Yigal Azrouël’s Breakthrough Ballet Designs for Emery LeCrone
abstract: To bring the choreographer’s latest piece to life, the ready-to-wear designer created 10 unique costumes for the dancers in her Guggenheim-commissioned piece.
lead_paragraph: When the choreographer Emery LeCrone first approached the designer Yigal Azrouël to design costumes for her, his first response was, “Why me?” But he agreed, with one caveat: “I don’t do tutus.” The result was 10 different pieces for “Bach Interpreted: New Choreography by Emery LeCrone” — commissioned by Works & Process, the Guggenheim Museum’s performing arts series — based on his spring/summer 2014 collection, even using some of the same fabrics.

headline: Yigal Azrouël Designs for Emery LeCrone
abstract: Azrouël created 10 unique costumes for the dancers in LeCrone’s Guggenheim-commissioned piece.
lead_paragraph: Azrouël created 10 unique costumes for the dancers in LeCrone’s Guggenheim-commissioned piece.

headline: In Sarasota, a Glimpse of Japanese History
abstract: An exhibition at the John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota, Fla., focuses on Japan at the end of the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: Even a traveler who has visited Japan dozens of times would have a challenging time imagining life there at the end of the 19th century, when the country was insulated from the world.

headline: A Large Urn
abstract: A simple urn puzzle by award-winning puzzle designer Hirokaza Iwasawa.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge is from Hirokazu Iwasawa’s 2013 book “The Essence of Probability.” Mr. Iwasawa is a mathematics writer and lecturer in Japan whose puzzles have won Puzzle Design Competition awards including Puzzle of the Year (2008), First Prize (2009) and the Puzzler’s Award (2012); I had the good fortune to meet Mr. Iwasawa at last week’s 11th Gathering for Gardner, a biennial celebration of the many interests — including puzzles, magic and philosophy — of the late math and science writer Martin Gardner.

headline: Ailing Dudamel to Miss Concerts With New York Philharmonic
abstract: Gustavo Dudamel, the Venezuelan conductor, has withdrawn from concerts this week with the New York Philharmonic, citing illness.
lead_paragraph: The vibrant Venezuelan conductor Gustavo Dudamel has withdrawn from his concerts with the New York Philharmonic this week – he was to have led the orchestra Thursday through Saturday – because of illness. Manfred Honeck, the music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, will take his place, leading the same program – Bruckner’s Ninth Symphony and Claude Vivier’s “Orion” – that Mr. Dudamel was scheduled to conduct.

headline: U.S. Accuses Rikers Officer of Ignoring Dying Plea
abstract: The charge in the August 2012 death comes as New York City faces mounting scrutiny over conditions on Rikers Island and in particular the treatment of mentally ill inmates.
lead_paragraph: A New York City correction officer was arrested on Monday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with violating the civil rights of a mentally ill inmate who died after begging for medical help from his cell for hours.

headline: In Ohio, a Law Bans Lying in Elections. Justices and Jesters Alike Get a Say.
abstract: In a Supreme Court case over an Ohio law that makes it a crime to lie during election campaigns, a satirist has filed a brief and the state’s attorney general is filing one for each side.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court gives lawyers who argue before it a little guidebook. One tip: “Attempts at humor usually fall flat.”

headline: Eschenbach to Stay as Music Director in Washington Through 2017
abstract: The conductor and pianist Christoph Eschenbach will extend his term as music director of the National Symphony Orchestra and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.
lead_paragraph: The conductor and pianist Christoph Eschenbach will extend his term as music director of both the National Symphony Orchestra and the Kennedy Center in Washington through 2017, the center announced Monday.

headline: Houston Shipping Channel Closed for Third Day After Oil Spill
abstract: The Coast Guard said the petroleum shipping channel may be closed for the rest of the week as crews try to contain a 4,000-barrel oil spill.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen vessels and their crews were trying on Monday to contain a 4,000-barrel oil spill off the Texas coast as the cleanup work kept a major petroleum shipping channel closed for a third day, the Coast Guard said.

headline: Rihanna to Be Honored by CFDA
abstract: The Council of Fashion Designers of America has announced the recipient of this year’s Fashion Icon Award.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it wasn’t just a coincidence that Rihanna was a ubiquitous presence at Paris Fashion Week last month – showing up at Chanel, Lanvin, Christian Dior, Comme des Garçons, Jean Paul Gaultier, Givenchy and Stella McCartney, as well as appearing on the cover of Vogue. (Remember? That was the cover everyone was buzzing about until the conversation moved on to Kimye.)

headline: Seeing Double | Bandanas Go High-Fashion
abstract: This spring, take a cue from the latest men’s wear collections and tie the all-American accessory around your neck or wear it in lieu of a tie.
lead_paragraph: T highlights one seasonal wardrobe staple, worn two ways.

headline: Mexican Authorities Question C.E.O. Whose Company Is at Center of Banamex Fraud
abstract: Amado Yañez, the chief executive of a Mexican oil services company at the center of a fraud investigation involving Citigroup’s Mexican subsidiary, was placed under house arrest on Monday while prosecutors pursue their investigation.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:11 p.m. |

headline: Today in Small Business: From the Web to Bricks and Mortar
abstract: Getting people to read your emails. How G.M. is using social media to manage its reputation. Are you really as busy as you say you are?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Deducting the Costs of a Government Settlement
keywords: ['Fines (Penalties)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: A recent court ruling in a case involving Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, raises the question of how the tax code may be seen as indirectly subsidizing wrongdoing, Peter J. Henning writes in White Collar Watch.
lead_paragraph: Taxes are inevitable, but not so deductions. And that has become an issue of late as the courts weigh in on whether a taxpayer — either an individual or a company — can deduct the costs related to a government enforcement action.

headline: A Haggadah for the Digital Age
abstract: An app paired with “The Bronfman Haggadah,” a hardcover book by Edgar Bronfman, was released earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: The Haggadah, the book Jews have been reading for centuries as they celebrate Passover at the Seder, the festival meal, is getting a high-tech makeover from Bronfman Associates, which markets books by Edgar M. Bronfman, the businessman and philanthropist who died in December.

headline: Rembrandt Recovered in Southern France
abstract: The painting was stolen from a museum in Southeastern France 15 years ago in the midst of a passing military parade.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Investigators have announced the recovery of a Rembrandt painting 15 years after it was stolen from a museum in Southeastern France in the midst of a passing military parade.

headline: Patrick McGovern Dies at 76; Founded Publishing Empire
abstract: The company he founded in 1964, now called International Data Group, or IDG, developed the “For Dummies” instructional reference books and organized technology events, including the Macworld trade shows.
lead_paragraph: Patrick J. McGovern, who started a modest database 50 years ago to track the growing use of computers and went on to build a global publishing empire that has produced scores of successful magazines and websites, including Computerworld and Macworld, died on Wednesday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 76.

headline: Ukraine Marines Leave Ship
abstract: Ukrainian Marines spoke of their next steps after leaving a landing ship blocked by Russian forces in Donuzlav Bay in Crimea.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian Marines spoke of their next steps after leaving a landing ship blocked by Russian forces in Donuzlav Bay in Crimea.

headline: Journalists Group and Internet Lawyers Challenge Turkey’s Ban on Twitter
abstract: The Turkish Journalists Association and two lawyers took legal steps to try to overturn the ban as the government moved to further limit access to the social media site.
lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkey’s leading press organization and two experts in Internet law took legal action Monday to try to overturn a government ban on Twitter, even as the government intensified its efforts to block access to the social media site.

headline: ABC News President to Be Top Disney TV Executive
abstract: Ben Sherwood, who will head the ABC Television Group, has drawn attention for his work at the news operation, notably the rise of “Good Morning America.”
lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company acted quickly to put a new top executive in place at its ABC Television Group, naming Ben Sherwood on Monday to succeed Anne M. Sweeney, who announced her resignation two weeks ago.

headline: Rich Price, Strong Potential in Payments Company Buyout
abstract: There are four reasons to believe leveraged buyouts can generate decent returns in the business of providing financial plumbing, writes Quentin Webb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Private equity has prospered by investing in essential modern infrastructure like cable networks.

headline: Image of the Day: March 24
abstract: World Tuberculosis Day is observed every year on March 24 to raise awareness about the disease.

headline: Fruit of the Bartered Vine
abstract: A small-scale California négociant is making some of the most invigorating, interesting wines in the state today.
lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — Broc Cellars fits hardly anybody’s idea of a California winery. You won’t see any cellars, for one thing, or anything remotely pastoral, like a vineyard. The cellars are a warehouse, on a corner in an industrial district here in Berkeley. Across one street is a cement plant. Across another is a motorcycle-repair shop. The melody of passing freight trains plays every once in a while.

headline: Progress on Epilepsy and Cancer, To Catch a Lie
abstract: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen — and stop them; a new test could help cut down on colonoscopy visits; you may think you can spot someone in a lie, but science says different.
lead_paragraph: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen — and stop them; a new test could help cut down on colonoscopy visits; you may think you can spot someone in a lie, but science says different.

headline: Journalist Receives Big Advance for Jann Wenner Biography
abstract: Joe Hagan, a contributing editor for New York magazine, will have access to the Rolling Stone publisher’s archives to research and write the book.
lead_paragraph: A biography of Jann Wenner, the publisher of Rolling Stone, has been acquired by Knopf for a seven-figure sum, a spokesman for Knopf said on Monday. Joe Hagan, a contributing editor for New York magazine, will have access to Mr. Wenner’s archives to research and write the book, which will be released by Knopf in 2017 in conjunction with Rolling Stone’s 50th anniversary.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 80
abstract: On this day in 1913, the national team of the Netherlands scored an important victory.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: When a Man Loves a Woman … It’s Diversity!
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Michigan’s attorney general wants to keep the state’s ban on same-sex marriage because “diversity in parenting is best for kids and families.”
lead_paragraph: As opponents of marriage equality continue to lose in courts and legislatures around the country, they have trotted out a remarkable array of bizarre arguments.

headline: As N.C.A.A. Basketball Dominates Times Sports Section, What About the Women’s Game?
abstract: Many readers have looked for substantial coverage of the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament, but so far in vain.
lead_paragraph: As March Madness gets crazier, The Times’s coverage of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament intensifies, too.

headline: ScienceTake: Monkey Manners
abstract: Young vervet monkeys watch Mom to learn how to clean their food.
lead_paragraph: Young vervet monkeys watch Mom to learn how to clean their food.

headline: For These Monkeys, Mother Knows Best
abstract: Vervet monkeys in South Africa look to their moms for guidance on how to clean their food.
lead_paragraph: When vervet monkeys confront dirty food — say, grapes covered with sand — most of them clean it, but not all of them take the same approach. And when very young monkeys confront their first sandy grape they watch, and learn.

headline: Deadly Landslide in Washington State
abstract: At least 18 people were missing and 8 were confirmed dead as of late Sunday in Washington State after a huge landslide destroyed homes and buried a state highway.
lead_paragraph: At least 18 people were missing and 8 were confirmed dead as of late Sunday in Washington State after a huge landslide destroyed homes and buried a state highway.

headline: “Caffeinated,” a History of Our Favorite Stimulant
abstract: A new book looks at caffeine, a substance humans have long cherished and now rely on more than ever, in countless forms.
lead_paragraph: One legend says it all began when a North African herder saw his goats eat some wild berries, then frolic with unusual verve. Another story cites a few small leaves blown off a nearby bush into the Chinese emperor’s mug of hot water. Either way, whether caffeine entered the life of man by coffee bean or tea leaf, happiness ensued.

headline: New 9/11 Museum Announces It Will Open May 21
abstract: The directors of the new national 9/11 museum in lower Manhattan have announced that it will open on May 21st.
lead_paragraph: After years of planning, the national museum created to document and memorialize the devastating attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, will open to the public on May 21.

headline: Subway Train Rankings by Riders
abstract: It is easy to criticize a train line for the occasional vomit on the floor or stomach-turning smells, but City Room wants to know why your favorite line deserves praise. Go.
lead_paragraph: The L train was named the cleanest of all subway lines by the Straphangers Campaign, a rider advocacy group. Cars on the D line earned the dirtiest mark, according to the 2013 unscientific survey. In case you’re curious about the method behind the rankings, cars were rated as clean if they were essentially dirt-free or had “light dirt.”

headline: Progress on Epilepsy and Cancer, To Catch a Lie
abstract: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen; a new test to limit colonoscopy visits; and spotting a liar.
lead_paragraph: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen; a new test to limit colonoscopy visits; and spotting a liar.

headline: Afghans Who Helped the U.S. Fear That Time for Visas Has Run Out
abstract: Workers considered under threat for helping Americans during the war face a shortage of visas, despite efforts to address a backlog of applications.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Raiz Ahmad may have the saddest vantage of the United States’ failure to issue visas to thousands of Afghans who put themselves at risk by helping Americans during the war.

headline: The Dreaded Turning-50 Test
abstract: Despite new evidence that colonoscopy is reducing cancer rates, the yuck factor is still high. A new alternative may be a DNA stool test.
lead_paragraph: One of the joys of turning 50 is that your doctor will start recommending a colonoscopy. Many people dread the test, which involves having a tube inserted into the rectum to look for cancers and precancers.

headline: Return to the Rappahannock
abstract: Travis and Ryan Croxton of the Rappahannock Oyster Company are trying to bring a thriving oyster trade back to the Chesapeake Bay.
lead_paragraph: Travis and Ryan Croxton of the Rappahannock Oyster Company are trying to bring a thriving oyster trade back to the Chesapeake Bay.

headline: A Chesapeake Homecoming
abstract: A new generation of watermen is bringing native virginica oysters back to the bay.
lead_paragraph: TOPPING, Va. — When Travis and Ryan Croxton first went to New York City in 2004 to market their homegrown oysters, one of the few seafood places they had heard of was Le Bernardin, so naturally they just showed up with a cooler at the kitchen door.

headline: Moving Past Gender Barriers to Negotiate a Raise
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Gender', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Hiring and Promotion']
abstract: Discrimination persists in the workplace and can emerge when women act as their own advocates to seek a raise, experts say.
lead_paragraph: ASKING for a raise is the type of conversation that can make even the most confident among us uncomfortable. Women, however, may have good reason to feel that way.

headline: Walkabout: Sept. 11 Museum Opening in May; Analyzing Faces at the Airport
abstract: a collection of articles from around the web, culled by Times reporters and editors.
lead_paragraph: Sept. 11 Reflection After several lengthy delays, the National 9/11 Memorial and Museum will open to the public at the World Trade Center site on May 21. (Associated Press)

headline: Egyptians Divided Over Court Decision
abstract: Cairo residents discussed a court decision sentencing 529 members of the Muslim Brotherhood to death on charges of murder and other offenses.
lead_paragraph: Cairo residents discussed a court decision sentencing 529 members of the Muslim Brotherhood to death on charges of murder and other offenses.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | March 18-24, 2014
abstract: A hit movie, a scientific discovery and more details about a missing airplane: How many of the 10 questions in this week’s news quiz can you answer correctly?
lead_paragraph: A hit movie, a scientific discovery and more details about a missing airplane: How many of the 10 questions in this week’s news quiz can you answer correctly?

headline: Jury Says 5 Madoff Employees Knowingly Aided Swindle of Clients’ Billions
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: A federal jury in Manhatttan has found five associates of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff guilty on 31 counts of aiding one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:13 p.m. | A federal jury on Monday found five associates of the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff guilty of 31 counts of aiding one of the largest Ponzi schemes in history.

headline: Guidelines May Double Statin Use
abstract: New treatment guidelines for lowering cholesterol could double the use of drugs by older people, researchers have reported.
lead_paragraph: New treatment guidelines for lowering cholesterol could result in nearly 13 million more adults being put on statins, researchers reported last week in The New England Journal of Medicine. Nearly half of people older than age 40 may end up taking the drugs, roughly doubling current usage.

headline: Oil Spill Delays Cruise Departures
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: An oil spill in Galveston Bay left several cruise ships stuck in port.
lead_paragraph: Several cruises departing ports in Houston and Galveston have been delayed after a barge carrying almost one million gallons of bunker fuel oil collided with a bulk carrier ship in Galveston Bay, near Texas City, Tex., on Saturday.

headline: Easel Turns Tablet Into a Workstation
abstract: The creators of Nimblstand incorporated a design aspect they call gravity nesting, which allows almost any tablet to fit in the stand.
lead_paragraph: Upgrading a gadget can be frustrating because it often means replacing all the accessories you bought for it, too. The creators of Nimblstand share your pain. They say that their accessory, a tablet easel, is future-proof.

headline: Mother Is Charged With Abandoning Infant
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Police', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Child Abandonment']
abstract: The police said a woman left her 6-month-old son alone in a playground. She was charged with reckless endangerment, endangering the welfare of a child and filing a false report.
lead_paragraph: A woman was arrested and charged with abandoning her 6-month-old son in an Upper Manhattan playground Sunday night, the police said on Monday.

headline: A Study of Twins, Separated by Orbit
abstract: Scott and Mark Kelly, who are identical twins, offer the agency an unusual opportunity to study the effects of a long-term stay in space.
lead_paragraph: When Scott Kelly returns to space next year, he will be taking part in what may be the most far-flung twin study of all time.

headline: Layoffs in Maine
abstract: Degrading public education.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written in the past about the damage being done by sharp cuts in funding for public education, which among other things have led to sharply rising tuition, making college unaffordable for poor and even working-class students. It was inevitable that there would also be a degradation in quality — and some friends have asked me to draw attention to an ugly example at the University of Southern Maine, which is laying off a number of faculty, including tenured professors, and in the process effectively gutting several departments, including economics.

headline: In Egypt, One Step Up and 529 Steps Back
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Activists in Egypt and abroad were stunned that 529 people were sentenced to death for the murder of a police officer during clashes in Egypt last summer after the military deposed President Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, a court in the Egyptian city of Minya sentenced 529 people to death on Monday after a hasty mass trial that included no defense, convicting them of murder for the killing of a police officer during rioting by Islamists last summer after the military deposed President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Facts & Figures: The Koch Brothers
abstract: Can Democrats raise more money by criticizing the notorious conservative donors?
lead_paragraph: Slate’s David Weigel looked at fundraising emails from a Democratic campaign and, based on a non-scientific sample, found that criticizing the Koch brothers can triple the haul.

headline: An Implant to Prevent Seizures
abstract: NeuroPace’s RNS system is an implantable device that prevents seizures in patients plagued by epilepsy.
lead_paragraph: NeuroPace’s RNS system is an implantable device that prevents seizures in patients plagued by epilepsy.

headline: Patient Voices: Epilepsy
abstract: Frequent seizures, difficult treatment decisions and social stigma -- what is it like to live with epilepsy? Eight men, women and children speak about their experiences.
lead_paragraph: Frequent seizures, difficult treatment decisions and social stigma -- what is it like to live with epilepsy? Eight men, women and children speak about their experiences.

headline: Easing Epilepsy With Battery Power
abstract: A long-awaited device, implanted in the skull, offers hope of controlling seizures for those who cannot be treated with drugs or surgery.
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, N.H. — For most of his life, Kevin Ramsey has lived with epileptic seizures that drugs cannot control.

headline: China Reports Gains in Fighting Tuberculosis
abstract: Evidence that a relatively low-tech strategy for combating the disease can work well, if it is rigorously applied.
lead_paragraph: China has cut its rate of tuberculosis by more than half over the last 20 years, according to health officials there.

headline: Taiwan Uses Force Against Protesters
abstract: Taiwanese riot police used water cannons on protesters in Taipei as demonstrations continued against a controversial trade pact with mainland China.
lead_paragraph: Taiwanese riot police used water cannons on protesters in Taipei as demonstrations continued against a controversial trade pact with mainland China.

headline: Cisco Bets a Billion on the Cloud
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The biggest name in computer networking announces a plan to link public and private cloud computing systems in a secure and reliable system, the “Intercloud.”
lead_paragraph: Even for the world of globe-spanning computer systems, Cisco is going big.

headline: Ex-Yale President to Join Online Education Venture
abstract: Richard C. Levin will become the chief executive of Coursera, a provider of free massive open online courses, or MOOCs, with an aim of expanding its operations in China.
lead_paragraph: Richard C. Levin, who stepped down as president of Yale University in June, will next month become the chief executive of Coursera, a California-based provider of online academic courses.

headline: Bookshelf | ‘Wordbirds,’ a Fine-Feathered Compendium of Modern-Day Neologisms
abstract: The writer Liesl Schillinger shares the process that produced her illustrated volume of newly minted expressions for describing contemporary life (“cancellelation,” “occuplaytion”), and lists 10 personal favorites.
lead_paragraph: The writer Liesl Schillinger shares the process that produced “Wordbirds: An Irreverent Lexicon for the 21st Century,” her illustrated volume of newly coined expressions for describing contemporary life (“cancellelation,” “occuplaytion”), and lists 10 personal favorites.

headline: Obama and Britain’s Leader on Ukraine
abstract: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain discussed Russia’s actions in Ukraine and the steps they would be taking.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain discussed Russia’s actions in Ukraine and the steps they would be taking.

headline: Smoking Proves Hard to Shake Among the Poor
abstract: A new study shows that affluent counties have experienced the biggest declines in smoking rates, while progress in the poorest ones has stagnated.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, Ky. — When smoking first swept the United States in the early decades of the 20th century, it took hold among the well-to-do. Cigarettes were high-society symbols of elegance and class, puffed by doctors and movie stars. By the 1960s, smoking had exploded, helped by the distribution of cigarettes to soldiers in World War II. Half of all men and a third of women smoked.

headline: Ex-President’s Party Concedes Defeat in Maldives Parliamentary Elections
abstract: The loss by Mohamed Nasheed’s Maldivian Democratic Party cleared the way for a coalition led by the country’s new president, Abdulla Yameen.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The party of Mohamed Nasheed, a former president of the Maldives, on Monday conceded defeat in weekend parliamentary elections, making way for a political coalition led by the country’s new president, Abdulla Yameen.

headline: The Man in the Middle
abstract: Irving Azoff, the music executive who often works behind the scenes, emerged into full view last week by brokering the deal that brought Phil Jackson to the Knicks as team president.
lead_paragraph: After he begins his morning by reading 75 emails, Irving Azoff makes five phone calls to the same five friends. Azoff, a music industry executive, has a reputation as a slick negotiator, but he is also a man of routine. So he picks up the phone and dials.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: March 21-23, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life in armed America.
lead_paragraph: Sales of the Armatix iP1, a .22-caliber pistol that only fires when a passcode is typed into the user’s wristwatch, were suspended in California two weeks ago after the state’s first vendor, the Oak Tree Gun Club outside Los Angeles, experienced an online backlash from gun rights advocates. Why are the N.R.A. and its allies so scared of smart guns?

headline: Having Identified Blogger, Hedge Fund Drops  Lawsuit
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Having discovered the identity of “Valuable Insights,” David Einhorn, head of Greenlight Capital, considers the matter resolved. The firm did not name the blogger.
lead_paragraph: David Einhorn, the hedge fund manager, dropped a lawsuit aimed at unmasking an anonymous blogger on the Seeking Alpha financial website, who had discussed one of his fund’s stock positions before it was publicly announced.

headline: American Patrimony
abstract: The resurgent wealth of the 0.1 percent.
lead_paragraph: One problem the Piketty work I discuss in today’s column may have — at least in America — is the widespread perception, even among those who take inequality seriously, that it’s all about compensation, that wealth inequality isn’t that big an issue, and that inheritance is also not that big an issue. We think hedge fund managers, not Kochs and Waltons.

headline: Teaching as a Second Act, or Maybe Even a Third
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Education (K-12)', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: For those looking for a second or third career, teaching programs offer a variety of preparatory courses at different costs to get there.
lead_paragraph: GAIL R. RUSCETTA changed careers for the first time when she had children. A theater major who bounced between acting gigs in her 20s, Ms. Ruscetta took the kind of leap that overachieving city dwellers often fantasize about: She and her then husband moved to Montana and opened a horse farm and riding school.

headline: In Crimea, Russia Moved to Throw Off the Cloak of Defeat
abstract: In seizing Crimea, Russia made it clear to Washington and its allies that the future of Ukraine and the region will not be decided by the West alone.
lead_paragraph: SEVASTOPOL, Crimea — With a single diesel-electric submarine and a hodgepodge of other aging vessels, Russia’s rickety Black Sea Fleet would be no match for the United States’ Sixth Fleet, based in Italy, which boasts the latest in seaborne military technology and has been running drills nearby.

headline: Insurers Push to Enroll People as Health Care Deadline Nears
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Insurers are hosting events and activities to try to attract hard-to-reach groups and people who had trouble enrolling on their own.
lead_paragraph: It’s last call for health insurance.

headline: House Ethics Panel Releases Details of Charges Against 2 Republican Lawmakers
abstract: The House Ethics Committee will further review allegations that Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers improperly used House resources for campaign work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, Republican of Washington, the highest-ranking woman in the House leadership and a rising star in the party, may have improperly used her House office staff and financial resources to help bolster her political career, the Office of Congressional Ethics has concluded.

headline: Chief’s Update on Washington Mudslide
abstract: Travis Hots, the Snohomish County fire chief, gave a news briefing on the search and rescue operation after a mudslide in the area.
lead_paragraph: Travis Hots, the Snohomish County fire chief, gave a news briefing on the search and rescue operation after a mudslide in the area.

headline: Pritzker Architecture Prize Goes to Shigeru Ban
abstract: Mr. Ban is best known for making temporary housing for natural disaster victims out of transient materials like plastic beer crates.
lead_paragraph: Architecture generally involves creating monuments to permanence from substantial materials like steel and concrete. Yet this year, the discipline’s top award is going to a man who is best known for making temporary housing out of transient materials like paper tubes and plastic beer crates.

headline: Seeking Autism’s Biochemical Roots
abstract: A scientist talks about how his son inspired a change in his own work and in the direction of autism research as a whole.
lead_paragraph: The biochemist Ricardo E. Dolmetsch has pioneered a major shift in autism research, largely putting aside behavioral questions to focus on cell biology and biochemistry.

headline: With Paper Tubes, Building Social Change
abstract: The jury for this year’s Pritzker Prize sent a clear message by recognizing Shigeru Ban and his socially conscious architecture: Good design and good works can both be rewarded.
lead_paragraph: The jury for this year’s Pritzker Prize sent a clear message by choosing Shigeru Ban, the Japanese architect. That the jury did not choose a woman — after much justified protest about its historic indifference to women (only two have been acknowledged), and despite the extraordinary work of so many female designers — suggests that change in architecture remains glacial and needs a shove. But it is happening.

headline: Allman Brothers Postpone Remaining Beacon Shows
abstract: Gregg Allman, who missed shows on Friday and Saturday because of bronchitis, had hoped to complete the run but was unable to.
lead_paragraph: It has to have been a tough decision: The Allman Brothers Band has spent the last couple of weeks playing what it said would be the last of its annual residencies at the Beacon Theater, and fans unable to get tickets to the sold-out run have paid scalpers high prices for the opportunity to say farewell. But Gregg Allman, the band’s keyboardist and lead singer, was sidelined by bronchitis this weekend, and did not appear on Friday or Saturday. At first, he seemed inclined to take his chances on recovering by the end of the run, and the band’s Facebook page offered “no guarantees” that Mr. Allman, 66, would return for the remaining shows.

headline: ‘Of Mice and Men’ Starts Well at Broadway Box Office
abstract: The revival of “Of Mice and Men,” starring James Franco, pulls in nearly 97 percent of its maximum possible gross in its first six preview performances.
lead_paragraph: James Franco may have a new title to add to his multi-faceted, hyper-hyphenated resume: Broadway box-office draw.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: From fast food to fisheries, all the news you may have missed.
lead_paragraph: Health: An exhaustive analysis found no evidence that eating saturated fat increased heart attacks and other cardiac events.

headline: Senate Debates Ukraine Aid Bill
abstract: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, called for bipartisan support to pass a bill providing financial aid to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, called for bipartisan support to pass a bill providing financial aid to Ukraine.

headline: Under the Streets, a Lurking Danger
keywords: ['Explosions', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'East Harlem Explosion (March 2014)', 'Natural Gas', 'Editorials']
abstract: Congress can hasten the effort to repair and replace old, leaking natural-gas pipelines nationwide.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have not yet pinpointed the cause of the gas explosion that destroyed two buildings in East Harlem and killed eight people on March 12. Whether it was the age and decrepitude of gas and water mains, or something else, has not yet been explained. But even without all the answers, there is more that can be done to make New York and other cities safer, starting now.

headline: Restaurants for Robins
abstract: Food availability, and the amount of snow and ice, influence whether robins stay where they are or fly south for the winter.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’ve noticed a lot more robins staying in my area during the winter in recent years. Why do some stay and some fly south?

headline: Video of Witness to Landslide in Washington State
abstract: Raw video in the aftermath of a landslide in Washington State that killed at least eight people.
lead_paragraph: Paulo Falcao de Olivera was driving on State Route 530 north of Seattle to pick up his children two days ago when he watched as a huge landslide buried the road right in front of him.

headline: Which Jazz Greats Were Left Off the Blue Note 100?
abstract: Blue Note Records is rereleasing 100 of its most “essential” albums. Which records should have been included and which should have been left off?
lead_paragraph: Blue Note Records holds a special place in the hearts of jazz fans. Since its founding in 1939, the label has recorded many of the most important names in jazz — a list limited just to saxophonists would include Ornette Coleman, John Coltrane, Dexter Gordon, Joe Henderson, Joe Lovano, Jackie McLean, Sonny Rollins and Wayne Shorter — and chronicled the development of influential movements like hard bop, 1960s avant-garde and, more recently, jazz incorporating hip-hop textures.

headline: A Porpoise With a Big Chin
abstract: A newly identified ancient porpoise lived millions of years ago along the California coast, and had quite an underbite.
lead_paragraph: A newly identified species of ancient porpoise had an unusually long lower jaw, analogous to the human chin. The extinct porpoise, known as Semirostrum ceruttii, lived 1.5 million to 5.3 million years ago along the California coast; its closest living relative is the crown porpoise. Researchers say the porpoise used its “chin” to probe the seabed for food.

headline: These Vultures Get First Dibs on the Good Parts
abstract: An examination of vultures’ feeding patterns in Kenya show that some species show up early, in large groups, and claim the best pieces.
lead_paragraph: The early bird gets the best cut of meat.

headline: No Monkeying Around for These Partners
abstract: Genetic analysis supports what observation had already suggested about the steadfast monogamy of Azara’s owl monkeys in South American.
lead_paragraph: Monogamy is rare in animals. Even among species that pair off, there is often philandering. But a new genetic analysis adds to the evidence that the South American primates called Azara’s owl monkeys are remarkably faithful to their partners.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The Netherlands and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from The Netherlands, Malaysia, China and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The Netherlands, Malaysia, China and Spain.

headline: Pictures of the Day: The Netherlands and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from The Netherlands, Malaysia, China and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The Netherlands, Malaysia, China and Spain.

headline: Reactions
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: GENETICS

headline: Leaving the Comfort Zone to Learn Computer Code
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: Coding instructors say there is a cadre of people in their 40s and 50s who have either grown tired of their current careers or see coding as the way to job security.
lead_paragraph: AFTER eight years, Patsy Price had grown bored of working as a program manager at Google.

headline: Bird’s Extinction Is Tied to the Arrival of Humans
abstract: Scientists have long assumed that humans played a role in the moa’s obliteration. Now there’s inescapable proof.
lead_paragraph: When Maori settlers arrived in New Zealand in the 13th century, they were greeted by some formidable inhabitants: the moa, nine species of flightless birds up to 12 feet tall.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights for Tuesday, March 25.
lead_paragraph: 1:35 A.M. (Encore) SNATCH (2001) A diamond heist by a thief who also happens to be a gambling addict named Franky Four Fingers (Benicio Del Toro) sets off a chain of events in both the organized and the not-so-organized crime worlds of London, with two small-time boxing promoters (Jason Statham and Stephen Graham) and a Gypsy bare-knuckle boxer (Brad Pitt, above) caught in the middle. In his review in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell said that the film’s writer and director, Guy Ritchie, “seizes the bespoke machismo of British gangster movies and gives it an action picture’s ferocity.” He added: “The effort is hyper-real, and he plays it for comic potential. Everything clicks into place by the end, though, in what is literally a shaggy dog story, with a cast of characters with florid names.”

headline: Bohemians in Chaos, With Flair and Drama
abstract: There’s a lot happening onstage in Franco Zeffirelli’s staging of “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: In his book “Opera as Drama,” the musicologist Joseph Kerman, who died last week, defended opera against what he described as “the frankest assault” from “certain dramatic critics of particular literary bent, who tend to question the dramatic efficacy of any nonverbal artistic medium.”

headline: BBC Classical Music Chief Is Leaving the Studio
abstract: Roger Wright will become the chief executive of Aldeburgh Music, the foundation that runs the Aldeburgh Festival.
lead_paragraph: Roger Wright, the director of the BBC’s classical music station, Radio 3 and of the the BBC Proms, will become the chief executive of Aldeburgh Music, the foundation that runs the Aldeburgh Festival, as well as several other programs, including a young artists program and residencies for musicians and composers. The organization was started in 1947 by Benjamin Britten, the tenor Peter Pears and the librettist Eric Crozier. The first Aldeburgh Festival was held the following year.

headline: He Acted Like the Man You Wanted to Be
abstract: The biography “John Wayne: The Life and Legend” looks at the movie star who “found the character the average man wants himself, his brother or his kid to be.”
lead_paragraph: He was the strong, forthright hero: authentic, stubborn, sometimes pigheaded but dedicated to justice and capable of tenderness and sacrifice; a solitary figure, called upon to defend the homestead or rescue the girl, but often exiled, in the end, from the post-frontier civilization that no longer needed his hard man’s brand of competence and courage. Whether he was a gunfighter, a cowboy or a cavalry officer, he became, for many moviegoers, the very avatar of the American frontier: the embodiment of James Fenimore Cooper’s Deerslayer, Emerson’s American Adam or what Garry Wills called fans’ sense of what “was disappearing or had disappeared” from American life.

headline: Ripples From the Big Bang
abstract: The telescopic discovery of gravitational waves believed to have been left from the origin of the universe will reverberate for years to come.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, MASS. — When scientists jubilantly announced last week that a telescope at the South Pole had detected ripples in space from the very beginning of time, the reverberations went far beyond the potential validation of astronomers’ most cherished model of the Big Bang.

headline: Editor Leaves Bloomberg, Citing China Coverage
abstract: Ben Richardson, an editor for Bloomberg News in China, is critical of the way the news agency handled an investigative article that explored the financial ties of the families of top Chinese leaders.
lead_paragraph: Ben Richardson, an editor at large in Asia at Bloomberg News, announced his resignation on Monday, citing the company’s handling of an investigative report in China late last year.

headline: The Work of Shigeru Ban
abstract: Images of the architect’s designs.
lead_paragraph: Images of the architect’s designs.

headline: Smaller Airports Are Being Left Behind
abstract: As airlines rely on sophisticated calculations to harvest every drop of profit, routes from small and midsize city airports are increasingly being dropped.
lead_paragraph: MY son Chris is on a business trip in India this week, and his choice of how he got there from his home in Tucson underscores a reality in air service. More often these days, business travelers will choose to drive a few hours to a bigger airport because airline service is not as convenient at their local airport.

headline: Festival Focus Is on Quality, Not Diversity
abstract: The second half of this year’s New Directors/New Films series seems to have selected works on the basis of merit alone.
lead_paragraph: The second half of New Directors/New Films, the annual spring showcase from the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, comes on strong with a slate that helps make this year’s event one of the best in a while. It’s a nice change for the 43-year-old festival, which in recent years has had a tough time pulling in enough memorable work to justify its two and a half weeks, making memories of emergent masters like Spike Lee and Wong Kar-wai seem very distant. These days, the programmers — Jytte Jensen, Dennis Lim, Marian Masone, Gavin Smith, Rajendra Roy and Joshua Siegel — are selecting titles that may not be to all tastes (a good thing) and that don’t seem to have been primarily chosen for some mechanistic criteria, like national diversity. Here, the work is the thing.

headline: In Photography, Cool Rules
abstract: What good is being cool if nobody knows it? An exhibit at the National Portrait Gallery shows how cool and photography need each other.
lead_paragraph: What good is being cool if nobody knows it? An exhibit at the National Portrait Gallery shows how cool and photography need each other.

headline: Interpretations Looking Back and to the Future
abstract: Colin Stetson and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus performed at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday as part of the Ecstatic Music Festival.
lead_paragraph: Think of Colin Stetson as the Neil deGrasse Tyson of the avant-garde saxophone world: a brilliant adept in a rigorous, esoteric science, but also an adroit communicator with an uncommon knack for making the arcana of his field accessible to the layman. In a concert presented by the Ecstatic Music Festival on Saturday night at Merkin Concert Hall, Mr. Stetson wasted no time in demonstrating his enviable skill as the prime mover in two unorthodox collaborations.

headline: Scare Tactics Over Foreign Drugs
abstract: Frightening people risks leaving them without the medicines they need.
lead_paragraph: ABOUT five million Americans buy medication internationally each year because of high costs in the United States. These drugs are considered “foreign unapproved drugs” by the Food and Drug Administration, and federal law makes it illegal to buy them. Generally, though, purchases go through without a hitch. Only rarely do customs agents seize an order.

headline: Violin Sonatas Suffuse Lent
abstract: The violinist Daniel S. Lee performed as part of Tenet’s TENEbrae series at St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: The Sonata No. 10 “The Crucifixion,” by the 17th-century virtuoso violinist Heinrich Ignaz Franz von Biber, unfolds in a blaze of effects, beginning with slashing chords perhaps intended to depict the nailing of Jesus to the cross.

headline: A Risqué Romp in Any Century
abstract: “Sir Patient Fancy” is the Queen’s Company ensemble’s take on a 17th-century play by Aphra Behn.
lead_paragraph: The Queen’s Company, the all-female downtown ensemble led by Rebecca Patterson, taps its inner swashbuckler (and farceur) with “Sir Patient Fancy,” a work by one of the rare female professional playwrights of the 17th century, Aphra Behn (1640-89). Little is known about Behn except that she was a spy for King Charles II at one point, and that her plays often possess a ribald flair. This one, presented at Wild Project in the East Village, certainly does.

headline: Families React to News About Crash
abstract: Relatives of Chinese passengers aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 reacted with anger after learning that the jet had ended its journey in the remote southern Indian Ocean.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of Chinese passengers aboard Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 reacted with anger after learning that the jet had ended its journey in the remote southern Indian Ocean.

headline: New Music by the Hold Steady, Future Islands, Caetano Veloso
abstract: Stereo matters on “Teeth Dreams,” the sixth studio album by the Hold Steady; “Singles” is the moody, pulpy fourth album from Future Islands; Caetano Veloso ends his trilogy with “Abraçaço.”
lead_paragraph: THE HOLD STEADY

headline: A Side Business as a Way to Gain Financial Security
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Income', 'Careers and Professions', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: A busy working mother uses knowledge gained from years of personal finance reporting to create money planners and a new source of income.
lead_paragraph: IN the height of the recession, as new rounds of layoffs were announced on what seemed like a daily basis, I was grappling with motherhood. Staring at my newborn daughter’s face, I felt overwhelmed with the responsibility. The job market only worsened my anxiety. What would we do if I were to suddenly lose my job, or if my husband were to lose his? How would we care for our child?

headline: Millennials at Work: Young and Callow, Like Their Parents
abstract: In surveys, they’re found to be lazy and disloyal, but young people entering the job force today might, at bottom, not be so different from their parents.
lead_paragraph: THE generation now entering the work force, people in their late teens and early 20s, are consistently panned by many employers as not ready for the workplace. But while there are real differences, their behavior on the job might not be so different from that of previous generations.

headline: Freelancers Piece Together a Living in the Temp Economy
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Temporary Employment']
abstract: A Las Vegas entertainer who works a variety of jobs finds she must reinvent herself.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The photos spread out on a coffee table tell the story of a career. In one, a woman wears a fairy costume and rides a flying horse. In another, the woman lounges on a desert rock at sunrise, in a gold bikini draped with red silk. In a third, she wears an Uncle Sam outfit and poses on three-foot stilts.

headline: Sweet Smell of Money for Plumbers
keywords: ['Plumbing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: While the hours are long and the job can be smelly, fixing pipes and unclogging drains yields six-figure incomes and steady work for many.
lead_paragraph: While working underneath a house, Joseph Rosenblum, a plumber in training in northwest Arkansas, confronted a skunk and discovered a talent that he previously hadn’t been aware of: crawling very quickly.

headline: Older, They Turn a Phone Into a Job
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Careers and Professions', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Telecommuting', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: The Bureau of Labor Statistics says 24 percent of workers in the United States do some or all their work from home.
lead_paragraph: OLGA HOWARD has had a varied career. She worked for Pacific Bell, the California telephone company; reviewed credit card applications for Citigroup; and most recently, taught special education students in Arizona.

headline: Playing With Boundaries
abstract: A close collaboration of Rocío Molina’s dance and La Tremendita’s singing was part of the Flamenco Festival.
lead_paragraph: Flamenco dancers rarely perform without live music. A solo dancer surrounded by singers, guitarists and percussionists — flirtatious interchanges flaring up, various members of the clan staking out or ceding the spotlight — is a familiar image. That dancer-musician banter is a pleasure of the form.

headline: A Freebie That Proved Quite Costly
abstract: In “The Junket,” a solo show at the Lynn Redgrave Theater, Mike Albo talks about a trip that cost him his freelance writing arrangement with The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The life of a freelance journalist is not a pretty one: As described by Mike Albo in his often amusing but slight solo show, “The Junket,” it’s filled with anxiety, insecurity and professional perils.

headline: Discriminate Against the Old? Even the Old Do It
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Age, Chronological', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Baby Boomers', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Academics are increasingly releasing data that they hope will reach those in a position to hire, promote and pay older adults.
lead_paragraph: I AM sitting at my desk, clicking keys on my keyboard as faces with words cross my computer screen rapidly. In my midday slump, I’m more than a bit annoyed. What useful information can anyone glean from how quickly or slowly I decide whether words are happy or sad, even as I am also answering whether a pictured face belongs to a younger or older person?

headline: A Degree in Hand, but a Slow Start Up the Career Ladder
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: College graduates who started careers after the Great Recession are having a hard time finding a good job.
lead_paragraph: THERE were so many low points, it’s hard for Kyle Whittaker to say which was the lowest. Ditching his girlfriend’s broken-down Lincoln at a gas station, because they couldn’t afford the tow? Month No. 3 of living on nothing but angel hair pasta? Or maybe it was the day he realized he might have to move back in with one of his parents.

keywords: ['Bullies', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Identification Devices', 'Mobile Applications', 'Parenting', 'Social Media', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: A number of potentially harmful effects can result from anonymous content online. Specialists and social start-ups share unique insight into the pros and cons of anonymous online sharing.

headline: Fluid Moves, Just Like Pros
abstract: The sophomores, juniors and seniors of Juilliard Dance Repertory performed in a triple bill of modern classics by Twyla Tharp, Lar Lubovitch and Eliot Feld.
lead_paragraph: You might go into a program of the Juilliard Dance Division prepared to see a group of competent dancers in training. The latest edition of Juilliard Dances Repertory, performed by the current crop of sophomore, junior and senior dancers, is a reminder that, at their finest, these students are much more: one of the most vibrant dance companies in the city.

headline: With Start-Ups, Greeks Make Recovery Their Own Business
abstract: Some Greeks have stopped waiting for those in power to put the country back on its feet.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — For Natalie Kontou, 32, Greece’s economic crisis may be a blessing in disguise.
