headline: The Threat to the Palisades
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: LG Electronics USA plans to construct a building that would rise high above the tree line, marring the scenic vista.
lead_paragraph: THE Palisades, a treasured American landmark, are under threat. The consumer electronics maker LG Electronics USA is preparing to construct a towering headquarters building along the Hudson River north of the George Washington Bridge, breaking the natural sweep of parkland and scenic vistas.

headline: Torn Between Two Lands, and Two Suitors
abstract: “Adoration of the Old Woman” finds its 17-year-old heroine shipped off to Puerto Rico to live with her great-grandmother.
lead_paragraph: Woe to the surly, cheaply dressed teenagers of American arts and letters: One after another, these broadly drawn characters are shipped off to remote relatives, the better to find themselves anew.

headline: In N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket, Mathematician Outdoes Matildas
abstract: Tim Chartier, a math professor, has picked 33 of 48 men’s games correctly, with help from his son. They have outdistanced a rotating cast of young Broadway stars, as well as coin flips.
lead_paragraph: Mastering an N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bracket is a tough racket. Ask anyone who had Duke, Kansas and Wichita State making it to the Round of 16 or beyond.

headline: Belgian Paper Apologizes Over Racist Images of Obama Used in Satire
abstract: The newspaper De Morgen apologized to readers offended by a satirical feature that used racist images of President Obama mocking his strained relationship with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Tuesday, 10:34 a.m. | One of Belgium’s leading newspapers, De Morgen, apologized on Monday to readers offended by a satirical feature published two days earlier that used racist images of President Obama to mock his strained relationship with the Russian president, Vladimir Putin.

headline: After the Death of Their Daughter, a Verdict Looms
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'ADOPTIONS']
abstract: An American couple in Qatar are awaiting the outcome of a murder trial in which they are accused of killing their adopted African daughter.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Matthew and Grace Huang spend five hours a day on Skype home-schooling their two adopted sons, now living with Mrs. Huang’s mother back home in the United States. The Huangs are also using the Internet to connect with an American counselor, who is helping them attempt to repair their psyches after nearly a year of separate incarcerations in Qatar’s penal system.

headline: Left Fares Poorly in First Round of France’s Municipal Elections
abstract: Just under 64 percent of registered voters went to the polls, which appeared to hurt the governing Socialists and help the far-right National Front.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The lowest turnout in 50 years in the first round of municipal elections appeared to help the far right to a strong showing and hurt the governing Socialist Party in the country’s first major balloting since the election of President François Hollande in 2012.

headline: Loyalty Programs for One-of-a-Kind Hotels
keywords: ['Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Business Travel']
abstract: Independent hotels have joined to form reward programs that challenge those of the major chains.
lead_paragraph: It’s a decision many business travelers would rather not have to make: stick with the big, predictable hotel chain and accumulate rewards points, or stay at the offbeat independent hotel but give up any rewards.

headline: Closing on Short Notice, Brooklyn Assisted-Living Home Angers Families
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Elderly', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Managers at the Prospect Park Residence in Brooklyn, which is home to about 120 seniors, surprised residents when they announced that financial problems are forcing them to close the building.
lead_paragraph: Outside the elevator doors where residents congregate with their walkers, in the big white dining room and in the floral-carpeted hallways where aides push wheelchairs along, it has been all anyone can talk about.

headline: Encounters With Celebrities and Wild Dogs
abstract: Brian Dunn, the chief executive for performance, reward and talent at Aon Hewitt Consulting, enjoys traveling, but had a scare once in India.
lead_paragraph: AFTER college, my first job was working for my fraternity. It was a dream job and gave me my first taste of business travel. I enjoy the physical sensation of taking off and the freedom to read, rest, watch a movie or just stare out the window.

headline: A Fighter’s Training Pays Off
abstract: The mixed martial artist Johny Hendricks spent months in the gym to prepare for his welterweight championship fight at U.F.C. 171 against Robbie Lawler.
lead_paragraph: The mixed martial artist Johny Hendricks spent months in the gym to prepare for his welterweight championship fight at U.F.C. 171 against Robbie Lawler.

headline: U.F.C.’s Big Daddy
abstract: Johny Hendricks preferred the gentleness that came with being a father, but he set it aside to step into a ring to claim the welterweight title.
lead_paragraph: Most Saturdays, you can find Johny Hendricks spending time with his wife and three young daughters, playing golf or hunting. But once every few months, he steps into a steel cage with an unlucky opponent and becomes “Bigg Rigg” Hendricks, one of the top fighters in the world.

headline: Case Spurs Fan Debate Over Boston Announcer
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Baseball', 'Child Custody and Support']
abstract: A murder case involving Jerry Remy’s son draws attention in part because of the questions it raises about the extent of parental responsibility.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Jerry Remy, the longtime color announcer and former second baseman for the Boston Red Sox, has been a superstar in New England for decades. He owns several restaurants bearing his name and reigns as president of Red Sox Nation, the team’s crazed, irreverent, die-hard fans.

headline: Box, a Cloud Storage Firm, Plans I.P.O.
abstract: Box expects to raise about $250 million in its initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Box, an online storage service that aims to become an essential part of the cloud computing-based business, on Monday released financial data before a public offering.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Busch Wins Kyle vs. Kyle Showdown
abstract: Kyle Busch won the Nascar Sprint Cup race in Fontana, Calif., by a narrow margin; still recovering from a broken leg, Marc Marquez scored a MotoGP win.
lead_paragraph: Kyle Busch held on for a narrow victory on Sunday in the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup race in Fontana, Calif. Busch beat Kyle Larson – the rookie who won the Nationwide Series race on Saturday – on the final green-white-checkered dash to the finish. Larson was trailed by Kurt Busch, Matt Kenseth and Tony Stewart.

headline: Fish Embryos Exposed to Oil From BP Spill Develop Deformities, a Study Finds
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: The study, which examined developing tuna and amberjack, will be used in the damage assessment against BP in the Deepwater Horizon spill.
lead_paragraph: Embryos of tuna and amberjack that were exposed to crude oil collected from the Deepwater Horizon spill developed heart and other deformities that would probably kill some of the developing fish and shorten the lives of others, a new study by a team of marine scientists reported on Monday.

headline: Uganda’s Anti-Gay Law Complicates U.S. Aid in Rebel Hunt
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination']
abstract: President Obama has come under criticism from human rights groups for using President Yoweri Museveni as an ally on security issues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the February day that President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda signed a law making homosexuality a crime punishable by life in prison, the White House sharply criticized the measure as “more than an affront” and warned that the administration would review the American relationship with Uganda in light of the law.

headline: College Basketball Data Aplenty for Those Who Can Afford It
abstract: The costly systems, which can precisely record and index shots, rebounds and passes, are in use in the N.B.A. and have been adopted by Duke, Louisville and Marquette.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — When Butler fell a precious few inches short of winning a national championship in 2010, its players took the court during that season believing they were the most prepared team in the country. That faith rested in the coaching staff’s embrace of new statistical formulas that augmented what showed up on film and offered up ideas on the most efficient path toward victory.

headline: Hurt in Crisis, TPG Pursues Smaller Deals
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The private equity firm is taking a new approach, moving beyond the gigantic acquisitions and, instead, looking more at buying minority stakes.
lead_paragraph: When the financial crisis erupted in 2008, TPG suffered more than most private equity firms, having invested in three of that era’s most troubled deals.

headline: Venezuela Takes Steps to Ease Curbs on Currency
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Black Markets', 'Currency', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Trying to curb a ballooning black market, the government said it will ease currency controls to bring down the cost of the dollar.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Seeking to confront the deep economic problems that have helped fuel weeks of protests here, Venezuela’s socialist-inspired government took a step on Monday toward easing strict currency controls and opened what it says will be a free market for the sale of dollars to Venezuelans.

headline: Lethal Liquid Nicotine
keywords: ['Nicotine', 'E-Cigarettes', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: The United States lags behind other advanced nations in regulating the hazards.
lead_paragraph: As little as a teaspoon of liquid nicotine — the key ingredient in electronic cigarettes — can kill a small child and less than a tablespoon, at high concentrations, can kill an adult. Yet some vendors are offering to sell the lethal product over the Internet by the gallon or barrel, with little control over how it is handled, as reported by Matt Richtel in The Times on Monday.

headline: A Question of What’s a Reasonable Reward
abstract: A money manager claims Coca-Cola allocated as much as $24 billion toward stock-based rewards for its senior people.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Coca-Cola sent out its annual report and proxy statement to shareholders.

headline: Egypt’s Miscarriage of Justice
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Editorials']
abstract: The sentencing of 529 Islamists to death is a shocking example of a judicial system run amok.
lead_paragraph: Egypt has been on an alarming downward spiral ever since the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak in 2011. Even so, the court verdict on Monday that condemned 529 Islamists to death for the killing of a single police officer last summer was a uniquely shocking example of a judicial system run amok.

headline: Keep It Short
abstract: In writing, brevity works not only as a function of space on a page, but the time that an audience is willing to spend with you.
lead_paragraph: In my first daily newspaper job some 25 years ago, I learned a few lessons about brevity that I’m still using today. Back then, among other editorial chores, I contributed to a weekly feature called “Books in Brief.” Each review could be no longer than 200 words — less than a fourth the length of a usual article. Imagine a slender column of type slightly taller than your middle finger, and you’ll get some idea of the word limit.

headline: Obama Juggles Itinerary in Bid to Ease Tensions Between Two Asian Allies
abstract: President Obama will bring together the estranged leaders of Japan and South Korea in The Hague on Tuesday after months of diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama brings together the estranged leaders of Japan and South Korea for a peacemaking session in The Hague on Tuesday evening, it will be the culmination of three months of intense behind-the-scenes American diplomacy.

headline: Lawyers Sum Up Cases at Bin Laden Relative’s Trial
abstract: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, is charged with conspiring to kill Americans and providing material support to terrorists.
lead_paragraph: The video, which showed Sulaiman Abu Ghaith seated beside Osama bin Laden the day after the Sept. 11 attacks, practically spoke for itself, prosecutors argued on Monday — evidence of Mr. Abu Ghaith’s participation in a terrorist conspiracy to kill Americans.

headline: Obama to Call for End to N.S.A.’s Bulk Data Collection
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Under the administration’s proposal, the government would obtain individual orders from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court to obtain only records linked to phone numbers a judge agrees are likely tied to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is preparing to unveil a legislative proposal for a far-reaching overhaul of the National Security Agency’s once-secret bulk phone records program in a way that — if approved by Congress — would end the aspect that has most alarmed privacy advocates since its existence was leaked last year, according to senior administration officials.

headline: Teixeira’s Roundabout Trip to First Proves Right Path
abstract: Mark Teixeira had never played first base until spring training of his rookie season in the major leagues when the Texas Rangers asked him to go there from third. The move turned him into a more well-rounded player.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — At the end of the 2014 season, or perhaps even before that, the Yankees will have to find a new shortstop to replace Derek Jeter, who has already announced that this will be his final season. If the Yankees seek an internal option to replace Jeter and want someone with the potential to hit for power, one outside-the-box choice — all right, way outside the box — would to be put Mark Teixeira back at his original position.

headline: Disney Buys Maker Studios, Video Supplier for YouTube
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The $500 million deal gives the Walt Disney Company an online video company with a subscriber base of 380 million.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mickey Mouse became a YouTube giant on Monday.

headline: Angry Judge Says Sheriff Defied Order on Latinos
abstract: The judge rebuked Sheriff Joe Arpaio and a chief deputy, saying they flouted his court order to stop profiling Latinos.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — A federal judge strongly rebuked Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County and one of his chief deputies on Monday, saying that they had defied and even mocked the judge’s order last year to stop singling out Latinos during routine patrols, traffic stops and workplace raids.

headline: The Smoking Divide
abstract: A new analysis of federal smoking data reveals that although the national smoking rate has been falling, there is a clear geographic divide.
lead_paragraph: A new analysis of federal smoking data reveals that although the national smoking rate has been falling, there is a clear geographic divide.

headline: Matsuzaka Looks Strong in Bid for a Rotation Spot
abstract: Daisuke Matsuzaka struck out the side in the first inning and allowed only one run over six innings in what might have been his final shot at securing the role of the Mets’ fifth starter.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It was perhaps Daisuke Matsuzaka’s last chance to win the fifth spot in the Mets’ rotation, and against the St. Louis Cardinals on Monday, he pitched as well as he had all spring. He struck out the side — Matt Carpenter, Mark Ellis and Allen Craig — in the first inning and allowed only one run over six innings.

headline: Order Signed by Judge G. Murray Snow
abstract: Judge G. Murray Snow strongly rebuked Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., and one of his chief deputies.
lead_paragraph: Judge G. Murray Snow strongly rebuked Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County, Ariz., and one of his chief deputies.

headline: Murray Faces Crossroads After Lendl
abstract: The former tennis champion Ivan Lendl coached Andy Murray to his first Grand Slam titles, but Murray will seek to regain that winning form without Lendl, who remains a supporter.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. —  For Andy Murray, a major change was not immediately visible on the surface.

headline: The Republic of Fear
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', 'Books and Literature', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Poverty']
abstract: For Americans, security is fundamental. But people in places without our inherited institutions live where the primary realities include violence, theft and radical uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: If you’re reading this, you are probably not buffeted by daily waves of physical terror. You may fear job loss or emotional loss, but you probably don’t fear that somebody is going to slash your throat, or that a gang will invade your house come dinnertime, carrying away your kin and property. We take a basic level of order for granted.

headline: G.M.’s Own Findings vs. Drivers’ Experiences
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: A timeline maps internal findings by General Motors and driver experiences.
lead_paragraph: A timeline maps internal findings by General Motors and driver experiences.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 25, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, March 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “This is a remote location, far from any possible landing sites. It is therefore with deep sadness and regret that I must inform you that, according to this new data, Flight MH370 ended in the southern Indian Ocean.”

headline: If Gays Can Marry, and Be Fired for Doing So
abstract: At this odd moment in legal history, does the U.S. need a new approach to nondiscrimination law?

headline: Parachutists Admit Jumping From Trade Center Tower
keywords: ['1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Parachutes and Parachute Jumping', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Three men with parachutes jumped from the top of 1 World Trade Center in September, while another kept watch. The group surrendered to the police on Monday.
lead_paragraph: With concern about security at the World Trade Center tower growing, a group of daredevils who parachuted off the skyscraper last year turned themselves in to the police on Monday afternoon, with one saying that the stunt had exposed the need for more vigilance at the city’s tallest tower.

headline: N.B.A. Denies Clearing Nets to Become ‘Russian’
abstract: The Nets owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov spoke Monday of a desire to turn the team into the legal equivalent of a Russian one, but the N.B.A. denied receiving an application to transfer ownership.
lead_paragraph: The Nets owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov spoke Monday in Moscow about transferring the team to a Russian-based company and his desire to turn the Nets into the legal equivalent of a Russian team.

headline: Absence of Contention at Council Hearing Seems to Shore Up the de Blasio Effect
abstract: Nothing better illustrates the new relationship between the fiercely liberal City Council and the fiercely liberal mayoral administration than the tone of preliminary budget hearings.
lead_paragraph: It may not feel like spring yet, but the atmosphere in the New York City Council chambers, where members are discussing Mayor Bill de Blasio’s preliminary budget, is warmer than it has been in years.

headline: General Motors Misled Grieving Families on a Lethal Flaw
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Despite a 2009 meeting confirming a defect in the Chevrolet Cobalt’s ignition switch, General Motors told accident victims’ families it lacked enough evidence of the issue.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly five years ago that any doubts were laid to rest among engineers at General Motors about a dangerous and faulty ignition switch. At a meeting on May 15, 2009, they learned that data in the black boxes of Chevrolet Cobalts confirmed a potentially fatal defect existed in hundreds of thousands of cars.

headline: Paths That Crossed Cross Again
abstract: In Terrence McNally’s new play, “Mothers and Sons,” Tyne Daly’s character has an uncomfortable reunion with Frederick Weller’s, who was her son’s lover.
lead_paragraph: The curtain rises on two people frozen in what feels like a thaw-proof silence. Their eyes are fixed straight ahead, and the possibility of even their gazes’ intersecting seems remote; forget about a meeting of minds. With these figures implacably embodied by Tyne Daly and Frederick Weller in Terrence McNally’s “Mothers and Sons,” any dialogue that might occur seems destined to be nasty, brutish and short.

headline: Corrections: March 25, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Goodell Holds Off on Discipline for Irsay and Dolphins Players
abstract: Commissioner Roger Goodell said he would not decide whether to punish Miami players accused of bullying a former teammate until doctors determined whether they needed treatment.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Commissioner Roger Goodell said he had not decided whether to penalize the Colts’ owner, Jim Irsay, who could face felony charges of possession of controlled substances.

headline: CBO Secrets
abstract: Always download the spreadsheet.
lead_paragraph: A bit of a utility post. A few people have asked where they can find some of the CBO numbers I cited in today’s column. A general heads-up: when CBO releases a report, you always want to check for the supplemental material. If you look at the big report on income inequality, look off to the right — you’ll see “data underlying select figures”, which has lots of additional numbers — and which is where I got the changing share of business income going to the one percent.

headline: In a Mischievous Manner
abstract: David Woolf gets it in at the last minute.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — This is New York Times puzzle number 2 for David Woolf, although he tells me that it was the first one Will Shortz accepted from him. That can happen sometimes; a constructor submits a number of puzzles in a row and some are accepted, but they might not necessarily run in the order in which they were received.

headline: Biggest Eyewear Company Signs On With Google Glass
abstract: Luxottica Group, owner of brands like Ray-Ban, Oakley and manager of retail chains like LensCrafters and Sunglass Hut, will design, produce and sell frames for Google Glass, the wearable computer.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google on Monday announced a partnership with the Luxottica Group, the largest eyeglass company in the world, to design, manufacture and distribute frames for Google Glass, the Internet-connected eyewear.

headline: Amid Wave of Pro-Gun Legislation, Georgia Proposes Sweeping Law
abstract: The new bill will allow gun owners to carry their weapons in airports and bars, as well as permit some staff members to carry firearms in schools.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Pro- and anti-gun forces do not agree on much, but they do agree on the breathtaking sweep of the Georgia legislation allowing guns in bars, schools, restaurants, churches and airports that is now awaiting the signature of Gov. Nathan Deal.

headline: A Film Premiere Cesar Chavez Would Appreciate
abstract: A worker-friendly premiere for “Cesar Chavez,” the movie about the longtime agricultural labor leader, is set for Tuesday in California’s farm country.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The billboards, with images of labor struggle, are rousing. And the online campaign, aimed at getting support for an official Cesar Chavez national day of service, rings some bells. But Participant Media and its partners on Monday announced the sort of promotional move that the labor activist Cesar Chavez might have planned for his namesake biopic.

headline: 17 Months After Hurricane, Recovery Effort Plods Along
abstract: Few more dramatic governing challenges confront the new mayor than helping those who were affected by Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: To walk east into Far Rockaway, or west along the south shore of Staten Island, is to reach storm-raked lands half healed.

headline: Israel: Reporter Denied Saudi Visa
abstract: The Washington bureau chief of The Jerusalem Post has been denied a visa to Saudi Arabia to report on President Obama’s visit to that country, the newspaper reported on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Washington bureau chief of The Jerusalem Post has been denied a visa to Saudi Arabia to report on President Obama’s visit to that country, the newspaper reported on Monday. The reporter, Michael Wilner, had submitted forms to the White House requesting a visa, the newspaper said. He was scheduled to arrive in Riyadh, the capital, on a commercial flight on Wednesday and to leave with the president on Saturday. On Monday, Mr. Wilner, an American citizen, said he thought his visa request had been denied because of his media affiliation or his Jewish faith. The State Department referred inquiries to the Saudi Embassy in Washington, which did not respond to requests for comment.

headline: 5 Bidders Face Hurdle to Save Long Island College Hospital
abstract: Of the groups that have come forward with proposals to keep the distressed Brooklyn hospital running as a hospital, none have licenses to run hospitals in New York.
lead_paragraph: Five bidders have come forward with proposals to keep the distressed Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn running as a hospital, but none of them have licenses to run hospitals in New York, which could prove a significant hurdle, hospital experts said Monday.

headline: Crash Kills Boy, 11; Stepfather Charged
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: A 65-year-old man was arraigned in Brooklyn Criminal Court on charges including aggravated driving while intoxicated and aggravated vehicular assault.
lead_paragraph: An 11-year-old boy who was critically injured on Sunday in what the police say was a drunken-driving accident that his stepfather caused has died, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: After Honoring Lundqvist, Sluggish Rangers Rally for a Stirring Victory
abstract: Ryan McDonagh scored the winning goal in overtime after Dan Girardi tied the game with 3:28 left in regulation, as the Rangers moved into second place in their division.
lead_paragraph: Alain Vigneault exudes a stately calm, and in that calm, his team is thriving. Vigneault’s Rangers displayed exactly that quality Monday in a wild, stirring and important 4-3 overtime victory over the Phoenix Coyotes at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 24, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: After 5 Years, Nets Have a Player of the Week
abstract: Before Joe Johnson won the honor for the Eastern Conference Monday, the last Nets player to have done so was Devin Harris.

headline: Ebola, Killing Scores in Guinea, Threatens Nearby Nations

headline: Wu Tianming, Who Shaped Chinese Cinema in 1980s, Dies at 74

headline: Joseph Kerman, Colorful Critic of Musicology, Dies at 89

headline: Ex-Bloomberg Editor Tells Why He Left
abstract: Ben Richardson, a former senior Bloomberg News editor based in Hong Kong, was involved in the editing of a story last year on China’s wealthiest man that was not published, following a discussion among the company’s top executives.
lead_paragraph: Below is the on-the-record text of an email message that Ben Richardson, a former senior Bloomberg News editor based in Hong Kong, sent to Jim Romenesko, an American journalist who writes about the news media on his popular blog, jimromenesko.com. Mr. Romenesko reported on Monday on Mr. Richardson’s recent departure from Bloomberg. Mr. Richardson was involved in the editing of a story last year on China’s wealthiest man, Wang Jianlin, the founder of the Dalian Wanda Group, and Mr. Wang’s financial ties to the families of Communist Party leaders.

headline: Who Needs a Boss?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Productivity', 'Income Inequality', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Worker co-ops might be the key to alleviating inequality, if only someone would give them a loan.
lead_paragraph: If you happen to be looking for your morning coffee near Golden Gate Park and the bright red storefront of the Arizmendi Bakery attracts your attention, congratulations. You have found what the readers of The San Francisco Bay Guardian, a local alt-weekly, deem the city’s best bakery. But it has another, less obvious, distinction. Of the $3.50 you hand over for a latte (plus $2.75 for the signature sourdough croissant), not one penny ends up in the hands of a faraway investor. Nothing goes to anyone who might be tempted to sell out to a larger bakery chain or shutter the business if its quarterly sales lag.

headline: A Quiet ‘Sea Change’ in Medicare

headline: In Photography, Cool Rules
abstract: What good is being cool if nobody knows it? An exhibit at the National Portrait Gallery shows how cool and photography need each other.
lead_paragraph: The thing about “cool” is that it shows itself equally in moments of distress or pleasure, driving people indifferently to greatness or stupidity. It comes from gritty streets and prices out the people who live there; it pulls couples together or cleaves them apart. And even as its meaning dissipates from overuse, you still can’t talk about Miles Davis without mentioning it.

headline: What Do You Want to Be Doing When You’re 80?
abstract: Where would you be living? With whom would you be spending your time?
lead_paragraph: When you get to be a certain age, growing older isn’t something you necessarily want to happen — it just happens. But 80 today for many people isn’t the same 80 as it used to be. Some 80-year-olds are still traveling around the world and riding elephants.

headline: Listen Up | The Dreamlike Sounds of S. Carey, Bon Iver’s Secret Weapon
abstract: The Wisconsin-based multi-instrumentalist lets his mind wander on his latest, California-inspired solo effort.
lead_paragraph: “I love California, and I get jealous when other people are there,” says the musician Sean Carey, whose forthcoming solo album, “Range of Light” (out April 1, Jagjaguwar), under the name S. Carey, pays tribute to the American West. Carey, a 28-year-old from Wisconsin who is also the drummer and backing vocalist for the indie folk band Bon Iver, says that yearly trips to California as a child left a lasting impression, later reinforced by playing gigs out west. “We would go hiking and backpacking, and have big family reunions in Yosemite,” Carey says. “On tour, those feelings kind of rekindle.” The trips provided a jumping-off point for the sound of the new album, as well as its title, a term the 19th-century naturalist John Muir used to describe the Sierra Nevada.

lead_paragraph: Signature Theater, the Off Broadway company that has historically mounted a season of plays by a single playwright, will broaden its 2014-15 season to focus on two writers, A.R. Gurney (“Love Letters”) and Naomi Wallace (“One Flea Spare”), the theater announced on Tuesday. Signature will also mount new plays by Athol Fugard and Katori Hall and works by Sam Shepard and Charles Mee.

headline: Sidley Austin Hires Senior Lawyer From General Electric
abstract: Christopher M. Barbuto, one of General Electric’s senior mergers and acquisitions lawyers who helped engineer some of the company’s largest transactions, has joined the law firm Sidley Austin.
lead_paragraph: Christopher M. Barbuto, one of General Electric’s senior mergers and acquisitions lawyers who helped engineer some of the company’s largest transactions, has joined the law firm Sidley Austin, the firm announced on Tuesday.

headline: In Performance: Jonatha Brooke of ‘My Mother Has 4 Noses’
abstract: The singer and songwriter performs a song from her one-woman musical play.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features a musical number from “My Mother Has 4 Noses,” a one-woman musical play written and performed by the singer-songwriter Jonatha Brooke. In the show, directed by Jeremy B. Cohen, Ms. Brooke weaves together storytelling and songs about caring for her mother, a Christian Scientist who suffered from dementia and cancer. In this scene she sings the number “Time,” about being unprepared for her mother’s death. She accompanies herself on a kalimba, an African thumb piano. The show continues through May 4 at the Duke on 42nd Street.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Failure Fetish
abstract: How to start a delivery business. How to find happiness after selling a business. Is a third of all Internet traffic bogus?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 79
abstract: The United States men’s national team received a boost on Monday when FIFA approved the association switch of striker Julian Green.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Spurred by G.M. Recall, Senators Push for Better Auto Safety Reporting
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Law and Legislation', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Legislation to require more information from automakers that could help recognize safety defects was introduced on Tuesday, after the widespread recalls of General Motors and Toyota vehicles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional investigators began poring over boxes of internal General Motors documents on Tuesday, seeking to understand the decade-long failure by regulators and the company to act on reports of a defect in Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars. Also, two senators introduced legislation on Tuesday intended to help identify problems earlier.

headline: Justices Seem Open to Religious Claims by Companies
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Corporations', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Supreme Court on Tuesday wrestled with whether corporations may refuse to provide insurance coverage for contraception to their workers based on the owners’ religious beliefs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a long and lively argument that touched on medical science and moral philosophy, the Supreme Court on Tuesday seemed ready to accept that at least some for-profit corporations may advance claims based on religious freedom.

headline: British TV Host Won’t Be Prosecuted, Police Say
abstract: The North Yorkshire police said they would not proceed with a case against Jimmy Tarbuck, who was arrested last year over allegations of sexual abuse dating from the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jimmy Tarbuck, a British television personality who was arrested last year over allegations of sexual abuse dating from the 1970s, will not be prosecuted, the police said Tuesday. Mr. Tarbuck, 74, an entertainer and quiz show host from the north of England, was never formally named by the police but was widely identified in the British news media after his arrest. In a statement, the North Yorkshire police said that “following a detailed investigation, evidence was presented to the Crown Prosecution Service and a decision was made not to proceed with the case.” Last year, the police said they had made the arrest acting on information passed on from an investigation into Jimmy Savile, another television host, who died in 2011 and who is now linked to hundreds of cases of sexual abuse.

headline: Aam Aadmi Party Leader Declares Candidacy in Varanasi
abstract: Arvind Kejriwal, the former chief minister of Delhi, will face Narendra Modi of the Bharatiya Janata Party, turning the ancient city into one of the most hotly contested battlegrounds for the parliamentary elections.
lead_paragraph: VARANASI, India — It was after sunset on Tuesday when Arvind Kejriwal, the leader of the Aam Aadmi Party in India, asked a field packed with spectators whether he should run for Parliament in the ancient holy city of Varanasi.

headline: Tech Tips, and Warnings, for Budget Travelers
abstract: From putting a hold on a low-cost airfare to using social media wisely, the Frugal Traveler offers guidance gleaned from a recent travel conference.
lead_paragraph: If you’re reading this on any device other than a mobile phone, you’re behind the times. If I can’t persuade you to post this piece on Facebook, I’m doomed to irrelevance. And if you want to tweet a complaint about my bad jokes or ask for a restaurant recommendation in Heathrow, I’d better have a round-the-clock team ready to respond.

headline: From Puff Daddy to P. Diddy and Back Again. Maybe.
abstract: In a promotional video for a new album, Sean Combs is credited as Puff Daddy, a moniker he discarded in 2001.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes even a scorecard doesn’t help. Sean Combs, the rapper and producer known as Puff Daddy at the start of his career, and as P. Diddy since 2001 – with minor variations (just plain Diddy, for example) along the way – has now returned to his original alias, Puff Daddy. At least, that’s the message you take away from the 58-second video trailer for “Big Homie,” which Mr. Comb’s Big Bad Entertainment production company has posted to Vimeo.

headline: Times Minute | Proposed N.S.A. Overhaul
abstract: Reaction to President Obama’s plan to stop collecting data on Americans’ telephone calls. Also on the Minute, teaching toddlers to talk and Monopoly’s new rules.
lead_paragraph: Reaction to President Obama’s plan to stop collecting data on Americans’ telephone calls. Also on the Minute, teaching toddlers to talk and Monopoly’s new rules.

headline: E-Book Settlement Money Is Going Right Back to the Publishers
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Thanks to a $166 million antitrust settlement between five publishers and a group of state attorneys general, Amazon gave me a credit of $10.72.
lead_paragraph: I woke up this morning to an email from Amazon bearing good news. Thanks to a $166 million antitrust settlement between five book publishers and a group of state attorneys general, Amazon gave me a credit of $10.72 for electronic books I purchased between April 2010 and May 21, 2012. I can use the money to buy print or e-books from Amazon.

headline: Obama Dismisses Threat to Russians
abstract: President Obama said there was no evidence that Russians in Ukraine were being threatened, and he dismissed comparisons of Crimea to Kosovo.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said there was no evidence that Russians in Ukraine were being threatened, and he dismissed comparisons of Crimea to Kosovo.

headline: A Ranking of Top Executives by Their Employees
abstract: The chief executives of LinkedIn, Ford Motor Company, Northwestern Mutual, Goldman Sachs and Intuit were among the top scorers in Glassdoor’s ranking of the leaders at 51 big companies. Yahoo and General Electric anchored the bottom.
lead_paragraph: The chief executives of LinkedIn, Ford Motor Company, Northwestern Mutual, Goldman Sachs and Intuit were among the top scorers this year in Glassdoor’s ranking of the leaders at 51 big companies. Yahoo and General Electric anchored the bottom of the list.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Parents, Chill Out
abstract: A mother says too much pressure is put on children to start climbing the ladder to success at a young age. Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Google’s Bigger, Cheaper Cloud
abstract: Google is getting serious about taking on Amazon Web Services, with sharply cheaper prices and new features. Just as important, Google is vowing that prices will continue to fall in line with Moore’s Law. The idea is to win companies for the long term, and let them use Google tools.
lead_paragraph: Google’s cloud computing business has figured out how it’s going to come at Amazon Web Services: lower and simpler prices, predictable services and software innovation. Some of the price cuts are as much as 85 percent. Amazon is expected to soon respond with moves of its own.

headline: New Novel From Shteyngart Will Be an ‘International Thriller’
abstract: The book from Random House, the author writes in an email, is “what happens when a spreadsheet jockey trades in her Excel for a Glock 22.”
lead_paragraph: Gary Shteyngart, the author of “The Russian Debutante’s Handbook” and “Super Sad True Love Story,” is writing an “international thriller” for Random House, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Student Crossword | The Middle Ages
abstract: Test your knowledge of medieval history by playing our crossword — or find many more student crosswords in our archive.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of medieval history by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Image of the Day: March 25
abstract: Children in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, praying for the passengers and crew members of the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370.

headline: NYT Now: Australian Official on Search
abstract: The Australian defense minister said the search for crash debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was suspended due to wild weather.
lead_paragraph: The Australian defense minister said the search for crash debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 was suspended due to wild weather.

headline: NYT Now: Obama on Russia’s Actions
abstract: The president dismissed any notion that Russian intervention in Crimea was justified.
lead_paragraph: The president dismissed any notion that Russian intervention in Crimea was justified.

headline: A Gondola, Bobbing Toward Japan
abstract: Italy flirts with the East on the menu of All’onda in Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Another week, another Japanese-Venetian restaurant.

headline: Charity Drive Aims to Collect Musical Instruments for New York Students
abstract: An effort organized by WQXR aims to collect 1,000 instruments, to be refurbished and used by public school students.
lead_paragraph: The classical music radio station WQXR 105.9 FM has started a musical instrument drive, with the goal of collecting 1,000 instruments from donors in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, to be used by public school students. The station said that the drive was inspired by a similar program undertaken by Colorado Public Radio. The station’s partners in the program are Sam Ash music stores, which will recondition the used instruments that are collected, and the Mr. Holland’s Opus Foundation, which the composer Michael Kamen started in 1996 to distribute instruments to underfunded schools.

headline: Don’t Blame John Calipari if Kentucky Looks Like a Winner
abstract: Calipari’s five starting freshmen, all N.B.A. prospects, flopped in the regular season, and he apologizes for that, but it is ancient history with Kentucky in the Round of 16.
lead_paragraph: John Calipari is in mea culpa mode, apologizing daily for the coaching blunders he has made with his young Kentucky basketball players. That is usually bad news for the rest of the teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: The Great, Fishy Massachusetts License Plate Fiasco of 1928
abstract: A fish swimming the wrong way on the plate may have upset the state’s fishermen.
lead_paragraph: Bad license plate designs come and go, but usually, even if one sticks around, as it has with New York State’s current tags, people resign themselves to it without much furor. But that was not the case in Massachusetts in 1928.

headline: Where’s That Aid Package for Ukraine?
abstract: Never underestimate the ability of Democrats and Republicans to muddy the waters, and imperil priorities, including national security priorities, with ancillary domestic political squabbles.
lead_paragraph: Since Russia invaded and annexed Crimea, a recurring theme in Washington has been that the United States needs to lead the international response and stand up for Ukraine.

headline: Federal Court Rejects Gupta’s Appeal for New Trial
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: A federal appeals court found that there was “ample evidence” that Rajat K. Gupta took part in a wider criminal conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: Rajat K. Gupta, who was one of the world’s most admired corporate executives before insider trading charges derailed his career and threatened his freedom, hit another legal setback on Tuesday.

headline: Q. and A. | Britain’s R&B Wunderkind (And This Weekend’s ‘SNL’ Guest) Sam Smith
abstract: The fast-rising phenom talks about sudden stardom, that time his parents split up on a family trip to New York and why he wants people to think of him as a “male diva.”
lead_paragraph: At 21, Sam Smith is the new golden boy of the British pop scene. He arrived in 2012 after singing on the buzzy track “Latch” by the dance duo Disclosure, and his falsetto has since appeared on two other tunes that have shot to the top of the British charts (Naughty Boy’s “La La La” and his own “Money on My Mind”). This year, he’s already snagged the Critics’ Choice Award at the esteemed Brit Awards, been named the BBC’s Sound of 2014 and sung a duet onstage with Taylor Swift, who called him her “absolute favorite new artist.” This weekend, he will be the musical guest on “Saturday Night Live,” ahead of his upcoming debut album, “In the Lonely Hour.” Here, Smith talks about sudden success, that time his parents split up in New York and why he’d like to be thought of as a “male diva.”

headline: British Government to Sell a Big Stake in Lloyds Banking
abstract: In a sign that Britain’s financial sector is strengthening, the sale of shares will reduce the government’s stake in Lloyds to about 25 percent from about 32.7 percent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government plans to reduce sharply its stake in the Lloyds Banking Group, another sign of the strengthening of the financial sector here.

headline: Activists Crash Deal Makers’ Party
abstract: This year’s Tulane Corporate Law Institute conference for merger lawyers and bankers will likely again see aggressive shareholder activist concerns brought to the forefront, writes Reynolds Holding of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Activists are crashing the deal maker party.

headline: With Mideast Peace Talks Faltering, Kerry Will See Abbas
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry’s visit to Jordan to meet with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority comes at a critical juncture in the American-led peace efforts.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Secretary of State John Kerry plans to fly to Amman, Jordan, on Wednesday and will meet with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, a senior State Department official said Tuesday.

headline: I.R.S. Takes a Position on Bitcoin: It’s Property
abstract: Some financial experts view the move as a way to push Bitcoin away from the fringes and into the mainstream financial system.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:53 p.m. | The Internal Revenue Service may have just taken some of the fun out of Bitcoin. But that may mean that the virtual currency is growing up.

headline: Its Art Elsewhere, a Museum Tries to Stay Relevant
abstract: The San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, closed till early 2016 because of expansion construction, is aiming to keep members during the interim.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tourists are asking why this city’s Modern art museum is closed. Cabdrivers are wondering when it will reopen. Teachers are lamenting the loss of a valuable destination for school field trips.

headline: Unpublished Tennessee Williams Story to Appear
abstract: The story “Crazy Night” recounts a college freshman’s drunken misadventures on the last night of school, after the 1929 stock market crash.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee Williams is known to have had only a few romantic relationships with women in his life. But one of those women, a college sweetheart fleetingly described in his memoirs as “a charming girl called Anna Jean,” seems to have become the inspiration for a previously unpublished story about campus lust and disappointment that has been unearthed in the Williams archive.

headline: Does The Times Take Sides in Venezuela Reporting?
abstract: A reader charges anti-government bias and a reporter responds.
lead_paragraph: Since the round of violent conflicts that began in Venezuela several weeks ago, many readers have written to me to share their views, and many have protested what they see as biased coverage. Most of the complaints say that The Times’s reporting seems to favor the antigovernment opposition.

headline: A Day’s Work
abstract: At a brickmaking factory in Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital, Mamun Sardar works long hours to pay his family’s debts.
lead_paragraph: At a brickmaking factory in Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital, Mamun Sardar works long hours to pay his family’s debts.

headline: Home in the Delta
abstract: Like many of her neighbors, Nasrin Khatun, unrelated to Jahanara Khatun, navigates daily life in a disappearing landscape.
lead_paragraph: Like many of her neighbors, Nasrin Khatun, unrelated to Jahanara Khatun, navigates daily life in a disappearing landscape.

headline: Video of World Trade Center BASE Jump
abstract: Video recorded from the helmet of a man who parachuted off the new World Trade Center tower last September racked up hundreds of thousands of views on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague James McKinley reported, amid growing concerns about security at the new World Trade Center tower, “a group of daredevils who parachuted off the skyscraper last year turned themselves in to the police on Monday afternoon.”

abstract: Marcelo Álvarez sings “Come un bel di di maggio” from “Andrea Chénier.”
lead_paragraph: Marcelo Álvarez sings “Come un bel di di maggio” from “Andrea Chénier.”

headline: Candy Crush Maker King Digital Set to Trade at $22.50, a Midpoint
abstract: It will remain to be seen if investors are convinced that the , valued at more than $7 billion when it starts trading on Wednesday, can come up with new hits.
lead_paragraph: The game maker King Digital Entertainment scored a huge hit with Candy Crush Saga. Now the company will test how strongly public investors believe that it can find a new success story.

headline: App Smart: Messaging
abstract: Several apps, including WhatsApp, Kik and Viber, offer alternatives to SMS for communicating with others from your phone.
lead_paragraph: Several apps, including WhatsApp, Kik and Viber, offer alternatives to SMS for communicating with others from your phone.

abstract: Jesse Schenker has a chance to spread his wings in this new project.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Messaging Services Bypass the Old SMS Route
abstract: A number of alternatives to SMS allow longer messages, group chats and the ability to add photos or videos.
lead_paragraph: “Kik me!” is not a silly note to pin to someone’s back. It’s a request to use the Kik app to chat with someone through mobile instant messaging. Kik is just one of many messaging apps that have arrived recently to rival the humble SMS as a way of rapid text communication from phones. If you haven’t tried any, you may be missing out.

headline: The Gun Report: March 25, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Grace Baptist Church in  Lansingburgh, N.Y., raffled off an AR-15-style rifle to a lucky parishioner. The winner was Ron Stafford, 42, an avid hunter and single father of two who drove in from Schenectady.

headline: A New View in Chicago
abstract: A new viewing chamber at the John Hancock Center in Chicago will tilt out over the street roughly 1,000 feet above Michigan Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Observation towers have been going through an extreme makeover for the past several years.

headline: In Georgia, Carry a Gun, Just Not in the Capitol
abstract: While expanding the right to pack guns in bars, airports and churches, lawmakers made sure to protect their own safety.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of concern about new legislation in Georgia that expands how people can buy, carry and use guns. It reduces some licensing requirements and provides Georgians with a stronger “Stand Your Ground” defense should they feel threatened and decide to open fire. Some critics were calling it the “guns everywhere” law. That’s so unfair. Georgia’s lawmakers are not allowing everyone’s safety to be endangered by gun-slinging people. They are deeply concerned, for example, with their own.

headline: It’s Home, Malevolent Yet Oddly Captivating
abstract: In Teju Cole’s “Every Day Is for the Thief,” a Nigerian studying in New York returns home for a visit and sees everything differently.
lead_paragraph: I have a weakness for fiction writers who give good interviews, who seem to have so many ideas brewing in their heads that they can’t help serving them up, as if they were cocktails, wherever they turn. These aren’t the only kind of real writers, for sure. But we need our headstrong, talky ones, the ones who live to stir the pot.

headline: Judge in Mumbai Rape Case Calls Test on Women Archaic
abstract: The judge complained about the treatment of rape victims, calling a test to determine whether a woman’s hymen has been freshly broken “degrading, unscientific and archaic.”
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — The judge presiding over a gang-rape case here complained in a judgment released Tuesday that outdated practices were still being used in rape investigations, in defiance of reforms imposed last year to make the justice system more sensitive to victims of sexual violence.

lead_paragraph: “Not quite rural but very non-suburban,” is how Lisa Arrigo, a resident of Goldens Bridge, describes this 2.6-square-mile hamlet of rolling hills and densely wooded areas in the town of Lewisboro.

headline: Ralph Wilson, Founding Owner of the Buffalo Bills, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Wilson founded the Bills as an original member of the A.F.L. in 1960 and took them to four Super Bowls in the 1990s as the team’s only owner.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Wilson, who founded the Buffalo Bills as an original member of the American Football League in 1960 and saw them go to four Super Bowls as the only owner in the team’s history, died on Tuesday at his home in Grosse Pointe Shores, Mich. He was 95.

headline: Barbara Blair Randall
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Ms. Randall is the president of the Garment District Alliance, one of 69 business improvement districts in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Randall, 56, is the president of the Garment District Alliance, formerly known as the Fashion Center, one of 69 business improvement districts in New York City. She has led the nonprofit organization, which represents the interests of garment and other businesses in the neighborhood, since its formation in 1995.

keywords: ['Desserts', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Cakes', 'Cookies']

headline: Arguments Against Health Law Subsidies Gain Traction
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Appeals Courts (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Plaintiffs said the tax aid only applied to those who bought insurance through state marketplaces and not to those who purchased it through an exchange established by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two of the three federal judges hearing a challenge to the Affordable Care Act appeared open on Tuesday to the argument that people buying health insurance in the federal marketplace should not be eligible for tax subsidies, the first indication that the White House could be facing another potentially serious legal challenge to a central part of President Obama’s health care law.

headline: A Live String Ensemble, With Death on Its Program
abstract: The Emerson String Quartet drew a substantial audience at Alice Tully Hall in the first of a three-concert series packaging the last five Shostakovich quartets with other gloomy pieces.
lead_paragraph: Death sells, the cliché about media hype goes. But was a program devoted to works on that theme what a substantial audience at Alice Tully Hall was buying on Sunday afternoon? Far more likely, it was life that folks were looking for: meaning the continued hale, hearty existence of the Emerson String Quartet, one of the world’s most respected, appreciated and popular chamber music institutions.

headline: The Casserole Catches Up
abstract: Replace canned soups and gloppy concoctions with fresh ingredients, clever details and vivid flavors for a dish that’s nuanced and urbane.
lead_paragraph: Casseroles have an image problem.

headline: As Basic Cable Finds Legs, a Veteran Show Jumps Off
abstract: Gus and Shawn’s excellent adventure on “Psych,” which debuted in 2006 when original programming on basic cable was still in its infancy, comes to an end on Wednesday on USA.
lead_paragraph: In the beginning, just a short decade and a half ago, was a void. Then came the first signs of intelligent life: odd animated children, a phobia-laden crime investigator, an angry cop. But for a stretch, it was unclear whether these pioneers were the start of a trend or mere aberrations in the emptiness. It took a second wave of shows to prove that basic cable television was a force to be reckoned with. Let’s pause to tip our hats to one of them, “Psych,” whose final episode is on Wednesday night.

headline: A Heretic and Hero Speaks in Many Tongues
abstract: “Uriel Acosta: I Want That Man!,” at Target Margin Theater, draws on past productions of this play inspired by the life of a 17th-century Jewish philosopher and skeptic.
lead_paragraph: You can tell that the conversation had being going on for a long time before you arrived at this party. I mean, a really long time — weeks, months, maybe years. Yet the highly animated people in residence at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City, Queens, show no signs of fatigue. And though you’re not quite sure what they’re talking about, it’s hard not to catch their excitement.

lead_paragraph: Ukraine and More: Pictures of the Day

lead_paragraph: After a mudslide in Washington, the Snohomish County fire chief, Travis Hots, and the county’s director of emergency management, John Pennington, gave updates on the search and rescue effort.

abstract: As the Secret Service shops for a new presidential limousine, here is a look at some past models.

headline: Senate Democrats Drop I.M.F. Reforms From Ukraine Aid
abstract: The move to drop overhauls of International Monetary Fund governance from a Ukraine aid package handed President Obama an embarrassing defeat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats, bowing to united House Republican opposition, dropped reforms of International Monetary Fund governance from a Ukraine aid package on Tuesday, handing President Obama an embarrassing defeat as he huddled in Europe with allies who have already ratified the changes.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Afghanistan, Spain and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Afghanistan, Spain and China.

headline: Six Decades and Counting: A Dance Troupe Recalculates
abstract: Paul Taylor’s 60th anniversary raises questions about that dance company’s future as it rebrands itself and plans to add work by other choreographers to its performances.
lead_paragraph: Currently celebrating its 60th anniversary, the Paul Taylor Dance Company presented a special performance on Sunday at the David H. Koch Theater: a revival of “From Sea to Shining Sea” (1965), a sourly surreal burlesque of American history, and “Esplanade” (1975), the most enduringly beloved work in Taylor history.

headline: Chasing Kurt Cobain in Washington State
abstract: Almost 20 years after the rock legend’s death, visiting spots where he lived, and where he endures today.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Cobain felt bored and old. Teenage angst had paid off well, as the line in the Nirvana song “Serve the Servants” put it, but the fame that came with being the frontman of the seminal grunge band that brought punk to the mainstream was taking a toll. Cobain was considered by many to be the voice of his generation, but he was also battling depression and addiction, diseases that led to his suicide at 27.

headline: How It Happens | Mudslides
abstract: A steep slope, made unstable by rain or fire, can give way without warning, creating a destructive torrent of rock and mud.
lead_paragraph: A steep slope, made unstable by rain or fire, can give way without warning, creating a destructive torrent of rock and mud.

headline: 2 Visions of Bach, Majestic and Wild
abstract: This week the Guggenheim’s Works & Process series presented two pieces choreographed by Emery LeCrone — one classical, one contemporary — both set to Bach’s Partita No. 2 in C minor.
lead_paragraph: In past years, the Guggenheim Museum’s Works & Process series has tried the controlled experiment of assigning the same music to two different choreographers. Sunday featured a new variation: two dances to the same music, but only one choreographer. That was the young, skilled Emery LeCrone. The music was Bach’s Partita No. 2 in C minor, lucidly played by Vassily Primikov.

headline: The Woman Who Gave Up Sex
abstract: A great show like “The Good Wife” isn’t just something you watch. There is ritual, expectations built up over years. Love.
lead_paragraph: Spoiler alert: If you are a fan of “The Good Wife” and haven’t watched the last episode, please read something else.

headline: The Inner Children of Parents-to-Be
abstract: Actors playing gay parents-to-be also play their childlike sides in Paula Vogel’s early work “And Baby Makes Seven,” at the New Ohio Theater.
lead_paragraph: Times and social mores may change, but the sight and sound of grown-ups mimicking high-pitched children will never not get old. This is the main problem bedeviling Paula Vogel’s 1984 play, “And Baby Makes Seven,” which broached the topic of gay parenting a generation ahead of the curve. Ms. Vogel’s prescience has at times been credited for the play’s lack of success; her breakout work, “The Baltimore Waltz,” wouldn’t appear for another eight years. But the revival of  “And Baby Makes Seven”  at the New Ohio Theater, in partnership with Purpleman Theater, offers another reason: The central conceit is reductive, repetitive and extremely off-putting.

headline: How Does a $45 Million Viola Sound?
abstract: David Aaron Carpenter plays Suite No. 3 in C by Johann Sebastian Bach on a Stradivari viola that will have a starting price of $45 million at auction this spring at Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: David Aaron Carpenter plays Suite No. 3 in C by Johann Sebastian Bach on a Stradivari viola that will have a starting price of $45 million at auction this spring at Sotheby’s.

headline: Cruises Resume Out of Texas
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Ports', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Cruise ships are now leaving from ports in Galveston and Houston after a major oil spill on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Cruise ships in the Port of Galveston are getting underway again after a barge and bulk carrier ship collided in Galveston Bay on Saturday, creating a major oil spill and preventing ships from passing through the Houston Ship Channel into the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: For Sale, Playing a Heady Tune
abstract: A Stradivari viola that once belonged to Peter Schidlof of the Amadeus Quartet will be sold to the tune of $45 million.
lead_paragraph: It may well prove to be the most expensive musical instrument in the world — a Stradivari viola, whose asking price will start at $45 million when it is offered for sale this spring — but, just for a moment, it was held up with no hands.

headline: Honesty Is Not the Family Policy
abstract: “Fast Company” features familial dysfunction topped off with con artistry.
lead_paragraph: Carla Ching’s “Fast Company,” at the Ensemble Studio Theater, offers a crafty take on the dysfunctional-family tale. The Kwan siblings manipulate, deceive and forsake one another. But it’s all for the good of the family business. That business? Con artistry.

headline: Classic and Contemporary, Explanation Included
abstract: This week the Artemis Quartet played a program at Zankel Hall that included the work of Gyorgy Kurtag with pieces by Brahms and Beethoven.
lead_paragraph: When a microphone comes out during a concert at Lincoln Center or Carnegie Hall, my heart sinks. If a musician introduces a piece from the stage, the likelihood is that the audience is in for yet another well-intentioned, unilluminating couple of minutes to unwrap cough drops.

headline: Swiss Watchmakers Skeptical of Digital Revolution
abstract: Smartwatches are growing in popularity, but watch industry leaders show little interest in combining diamond bezels with digital wizardry.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A decade ago, Nick Hayek, chief executive of the Swatch Group, and Bill Gates, co-founder of Microsoft, introduced in New York a new kind of watch called the Paparazzi. It was presented as the pioneer of the so-called smartwatch, giving the wearer access to news, stock quotes and other data via Microsoft’s MSN service.

headline: Video: Nancy Horan Talks About ‘Under the Wide and Starry Sky’
abstract: Ms. Horan’s new novel follows the adventures of Robert Louis Stevenson and his wife, Franny.
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Nancy Horan explains her fascination with Robert Louis Stevenson and his wife, Franny, who inspired Ms. Horan’s novel “Under the Wide and Starry Sky.”

headline: A House and Its Perpetual Spring
abstract: Carven is not the place to go for dark droopiness, but rather eyelet and A-lines, florals and perk.
lead_paragraph: LONGTIME NEW YORKERS are accustomed to stepping on blobs of chewing gum, leaning up against fresh paint and occasionally getting pelted with pigeon poop. But the sudden shower of pollen that befouled a new blue dress as I attempted to discard a wilted bunch of calla lilies the other day — that was a new one.

headline: Q&A: A Sociologist on Inequality
abstract: An interview with Lane Kenworthy, a professor of sociology and political science at the University of Arizona, about inequality’s consequences.
lead_paragraph: Is income inequality truly the defining challenge of our time? Should it be the central issue for American liberalism? Lane Kenworthy, a professor of sociology and political science at the University of Arizona, has been thinking about this more deeply than most. Earlier this year, he published “Social Democratic America,” in which he outlined how a strengthened welfare state could deliver broadly shared prosperity. This year, he is writing another — tentatively entitled “Should We Worry About Inequality?” — in which he assesses the damage inflicted by America’s widening income gap.

lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The prosecution rested its case in the Oscar Pistorius murder trial on Tuesday, after three weeks of testimony in which it sought to portray Mr. Pistorius as a spoiled, angry and jealous man whose charming public facade hid a deep and ultimately murderous rage.

abstract: My Labrador goes to PetCare. Sometimes I want to go to PetCare.
lead_paragraph: NELSON’S doctors found the bulge in his abdomen on a Monday. An ultrasound and CT scan showed that a mass was crowding out his stomach and kidneys. It was one of the largest the doctors had ever seen. If they didn’t do something, he’d be dead in a couple of days.

headline: Butter Is Back
abstract: The real villains in our diet are sugar and ultra-processed foods.
lead_paragraph: Julia Child, goddess of fat, is beaming somewhere. Butter is back, and when you’re looking for a few chunks of pork for a stew, you can resume searching for the best pieces — the ones with the most fat. Eventually, your friends will stop glaring at you as if you’re trying to kill them.

headline: Dead Cattle and Greek Fire
abstract: The Civil War saw a surprising number of experiments with chemical and biological warfare.
lead_paragraph: The American Civil War was a conflict that sat astride two phases in military history: It began with generals on both sides employing timeworn Napoleonic-era strategies and ended with horrific trench warfare and violence against civilian populations that foreshadowed World War I. It was also a crucible in which new combat technologies were tested, among them ironclads, machine guns and submarines. And while scientists had not yet fully grasped the germ theory of disease, it was also one of the first conflicts to see chemical and biological agents tested, and even used, as weapons.

headline: Rare Footage of Ruth and Gehrig
abstract: This clip captures a historic day in Yankee history: Babe Ruth’s first game since the “bellyache heard ‘round the world” and Lou Gehrig’s first step in playing 2,130 consecutive games.
lead_paragraph: This clip captures a historic day in Yankee history: Babe Ruth’s first game since the “bellyache heard ‘round the world” and Lou Gehrig’s first step in playing 2,130 consecutive games.

headline: Search for Missing Flight’s Wreckage Is Hampered by a Sea of Detritus
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Oceans and Seas']

lead_paragraph: In recent days, the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines jetliner has focused on blurry satellite images and other sightings of objects floating in the desolate reaches of the southern Indian Ocean.

headline: Detroit Threatens to Cut Water Service to Delinquent Customers
abstract: Nearly half of Detroit’s water department customers are delinquent and owe a total of $118 million, forcing the department to resume cutting service to try to recoup the money.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The city’s water department is looking to recoup tens of millions of dollars by cutting service each week to as many as 3,000 customers who have failed to pay their bills.

headline: Nitroglycerin, a Staple of Emergency Rooms, Is in Short Supply
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Heart', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Medicine and Health', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Shortages', 'Hospitals']
abstract: The shortage is the latest example of how patchy the supply of some of the nation’s most critical drugs has become in recent years.
lead_paragraph: The drug nitroglycerin has long been an emergency room staple, a front-line drug that is often the first thing doctors try when a patient shows up with a heart attack.

headline: B.U. or B.C.? Hockey Star Let Brother Pick
abstract: Boston College left wing Johnny Gaudreau, the overwhelming favorite to be named college hockey’s top player, let his younger brother Matthew decide which university they would attend.
lead_paragraph: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. — The hockey rivalry between Boston College and Boston University has played out on many ice surfaces. Boston University has won more Beanpot championships. Boston College has had better luck lately in the N.C.A.A. tournament, winning four titles in the last 12 years.

headline: Pollution Killed 7 Million People Worldwide in 2012, Report Finds
abstract: A World Health Organization report concluded that more than one-third of pollution deaths in 2012 occurred in fast-developing Asian nations.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — From taxi tailpipes in Paris to dung-fired stoves in New Delhi, air pollution claimed seven million lives around the world in 2012, according to figures released Tuesday by the World Health Organization. More than one-third of those deaths, the organization said, occurred in fast-developing nations of Asia, where rates of cardiovascular and pulmonary disease have been soaring.

headline: A Casino License Bidder With 4 Irons in the Fire

lead_paragraph: In 1999, David Flaum, a developer, bought a 345-acre parcel on a hilltop in Sullivan County, N.Y., where he hoped to build an Indian casino that would resemble the Catskill resorts of his youth.

headline: Giroux Carries Flyers Into Playoff Picture
abstract: Claude Giroux has a team-leading 74 points for Philadelphia, which sits in third place in the Metropolitan Division, a point behind the Rangers entering the teams’ showdown Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — As Claude Giroux goes, so go the Philadelphia Flyers. And Giroux and the Flyers are going well as the N.H.L. playoffs draw near.

headline: Prokhorov Tempers Talk of Nets Becoming Russian

lead_paragraph: The Nets will not become a Russian-based company anytime soon. And on Tuesday, their owner, Mikhail D. Prokhorov, conceded that the unusual changeover may never happen.

headline: On Visit to China, Michelle Obama Eases In Some Political Messages
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']

lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — Michelle Obama’s weeklong trip to China seemed to start as a spring break holiday with her mother and daughters but has turned out to include far more substance — and politics — than the cheerful advocate of fitness and healthful eating she often displays at home.

headline: Protesting in Venezuela, With Antipathy Toward Cuba’s Government
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations']
abstract: Many Venezuelan protesters have also focused their resentment on Cuba’s government, which, they say, has leeched off Venezuela’s oil wealth and grafted its rigid brand of socialism onto their country.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Enraged as they are by their nation’s leaders, many of the protesters who have spilled onto Venezuela’s streets have their eyes fixed on another government altogether, one they resent perhaps just as bitterly as their own: Cuba’s.

headline: Capturing a Piece of Yankee History
abstract: Recently discovered newsreel footage captures the day Babe Ruth returned to the Yankee lineup in 1925 — and the first of 2,130 consecutive games by a guy named Gehrig.
lead_paragraph: The newsreel film from June 1, 1925, animates a historic day for the Yankee franchise: Babe Ruth’s first game of the season since the illness dubbed the “bellyache heard ’round the world” and a pinch-hitting appearance by Lou Gehrig that became the first of his 2,130 consecutive games.

lead_paragraph: The big winners of Facebook’s $2 billion deal to buy Oculus VR, a virtual reality headset maker, include a roster of elite venture capitalists who invested in the company early on.

headline: Obama Says N.S.A. Curbs Would Address Worries
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Privacy', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Terrorism']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday publicly endorsed a plan that Justice Department and intelligence officials have developed for a sweeping overhaul of the National Security Agency’s phone call records program, saying that he believed it would resolve privacy concerns without compromising the program’s utility as a counterterrorism tool.

Cuomo — over tax increases to pay for prekindergarten, charter schools and raising the minimum wage — Mayor Bill de Blasio often pushes back, arguing that he and Mr. Cuomo agree on more issues than they disagree on.

headline: Measured Progress on Nuclear Security
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Editorials', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: There is still a long way to go to address the challenges of a world awash in nuclear materials and weapons.
lead_paragraph: Although the summit meeting was overshadowed by the crisis in Ukraine, 53 international leaders in The Hague this week made important progress on securing nuclear materials around the world and keeping them out of the hands of terrorist groups like Al Qaeda. There is still a long way to go to address the challenges of a world awash in nuclear materials and weapons, but many countries are taking constructive action.

headline: In Second Chance, Pineda Is Named the Yankees’ Fifth Starter
abstract: After sustaining an injury and then dealing with an embarrassing legal issue, pitcher Michael Pineda on Tuesday was named to the Yankees starting rotation.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Michael Pineda had to pause and collect himself as tears welled in his eyes Tuesday. Yankees Manager Joe Girardi had just told him that he had won the competition to be the Yankees’ fifth starter, and now reporters were asking Pineda to express his feelings about it.

headline: After Years in Minors, a Met Has Tenuous Hope of Making the Cut
abstract: Anthony Seratelli, 31, is trying to make the opening-day roster as a utility man, but he has played poorly this spring and faces an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Over the past few weeks, the Mets’ clubhouse has slowly cleared out as players have been sent down to the minor leagues. They get a handshake, collect their belongings and say their goodbyes. Their lockers are emptied, their nameplates removed. By Tuesday, 23 of the lockers were no longer occupied. And more will be vacant soon as the regular season draws near and the Mets get ready to make their final cuts.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Limits on Phone Records

abstract: The president could end the bulk collection himself, immediately, without undermining his proposal to Congress.

headline: Movie Box Office Figures Largely Flat for 2013
