headline: ‘Orange Is the New Black’ Set Recalls Century of Movie Lore
abstract: The City Council has plans to declare the main soundstage at Kaufman Astoria Studio in Queens as the centerpiece of an arts district at the end of the week.

headline: Obama Meets With Asian Allies on North Korea’s Nuclear Plans
abstract: President Obama brought together the sometimes-squabbling leaders of Japan and South Korea on Tuesday for a discussion in advance of his visit to both countries next month.
lead_paragraph: President Obama brought together the sometimes squabbling leaders of Japan and South Korea on Tuesday for a closed-door discussion in advance of his visit to both countries next month. The three leaders met on the sideline of a nuclear security summit meeting in The Hague, emerging from the discussion to declare themselves united in the face of North Korea’s nuclear ambitions and other issues. The fact that the three leaders offered positive comments was significant, given the tensions between Japan and South Korea. The countries’ leaders have been feuding almost since each assumed office, over issues dating back to World War II, including so-called comfort women, the girls and women abducted by the Japanese during the war to work in prostitution camps.

headline: React to the Reality, Not the Image of It
abstract: Sometimes things are much better than they appear, but the truth is we don’t know what’s going on with other people’s finances.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, a friend came home with a new, top-of-the-line road bike. My first thought: How can he afford that? It seemed like such a big purchase based on what I thought I knew. We lived in the same neighborhood, were close to the same age and both had young families. His life looked a lot like mine — at least I thought it did.

headline: Literary City, Bookstore Desert
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The rising cost of doing business in Manhattan is driving out many of its remaining bookstores, threatening the city’s sense of self as the center of the literary universe.
lead_paragraph: When Sarah McNally, the owner of McNally Jackson bookstore in Lower Manhattan, set out to open a second location, she went to a neighborhood with a sterling literary reputation, the home turf of writers from Edgar Allan Poe to Nora Ephron: the Upper West Side.

headline: Property of the First Part
abstract: A puzzling puzzle entry gets expanded upon by Alex Vratsanos.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — I have no quantitative evidence on this, but I think that I probably get more questions about the crossword puzzle entry ATNO than any other. O.K., maybe questions about why we can’t put a tilde on the Spanish word AÑO in a grid comes close, but ATNO definitely sticks out in my mind as a big one.

headline: Judge Imposes 16-Year Term for Manhattan Man in Pipe Bomb Case
abstract: Jose Pimentel offered no apology or explanation for his role in a bomb-building plot in New York City as he was sentenced at his terrorism trial.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan man who conspired with a police informer to plant pipe bombs as part of a jihad against the United States was sentenced to 16 years in a New York State prison on Tuesday at a hearing with little of the theatrics that had accompanied his arrest.

headline: U.S. to Extend Sign-Up Period for Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Obama administration has decided to give people more time to sign up for health insurance if they were blocked by technical problems with the federal exchange.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With less than a week left for people to sign up for health insurance, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it would allow more time for those who had tried to apply but were blocked by technical problems with the federal exchange.

headline: Rhode Island House Elects a Speaker After an Abrupt Resignation
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Nicholas A. Mattiello, the former House majority leader, was elected to the post days after Gordon D. Fox resigned without explanation following a federal raid on his house.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — Nicholas A. Mattiello, who on Tuesday was elected speaker of the state House of Representatives, said he had always wanted to be speaker — he just did not expect it to happen so soon.

headline: Plan Would Add 30¢ Per Ride to Pay for Accessible Taxis
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Disabilities']
abstract: To make half of all New York City’s taxis wheelchair-accessible by 2020, Mayor Bill de Blasio has proposed a 30-cent surcharge per ride.
lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration is proposing a 30-cent surcharge on all yellow and street-hail livery taxi rides as part of a plan to make half of New York City’s taxi fleet wheelchair-accessible by 2020, according to city and taxi officials.

headline: White House Protests Saudi’s Denial of Visa to Journalist
keywords: ['Visas', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'United States International Relations']

headline: Court Hears Appeal by Son of Scholar on Dead Sea Scrolls
abstract: A defense lawyer argues that using pseudonymous characters to disparage rivals was annoying, not criminal.
lead_paragraph: The ancient religious texts have much to say about the divine obligations of a son toward his father, but they are silent on the propriety of using computers, blogs, pseudonyms and Internet sock puppets to fulfill them. For this, there is only the law.

keywords: ['Museums', 'Women and Girls', 'National Mall (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A once-ailing effort to build a national women’s history museum on or near the National Mall has been given new life by a declaration of support from the House majority leader and the ascension of women to key committee posts in the Senate, supporters in both parties said Tuesday.

headline: Knicks Are Routed in a Display That Jackson Calls ‘Awful’
abstract: Phil Jackson, the Knicks president, left Tuesday’s game with 8:54 left, after the Knicks had allowed a Lakers’ franchise-record 51 points in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — With 8 minutes 54 seconds left in the fourth quarter, Phil Jackson had seen enough. He texted his fiancée, Jeanie Buss, and agreed to meet at the loading dock inside Staples Center where their car would be waiting. The Knicks were losing by 26 points.

lead_paragraph: Why isn’t the Republican Party paying a heavy price for its dependence on a shrinking white electorate, its rejection of immigration reform and its “just say no” legislative strategy?

headline: Exercising for Healthier Eyes
abstract: Research suggests that physical activity may protect eyesight as we age.
lead_paragraph: Age-related vision loss is common and devastating. But new research suggests that physical activity might protect our eyes as we age.

headline: Cellphone Bans May Not Prevent Accidents
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Text Messaging', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Bans on using cellphones in vehicles appear to cut usage as people change behavior to avoid fines. But that benefit may be offset by drivers who try to conceal phone use and drive erratically, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What’s On Wednesday

lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Comedy Central) BROAD CITY In this season finale, Abbi (Abbi Jacobson) and Ilana (Ilana Glazer, near right, with Ms. Jacobson) indulge in a fancy dinner at a restaurant to celebrate Abbi’s 26th birthday. Things quickly go awry, however, when Ilana has an allergic reaction to the food, and their seemingly classy waiter (Seth Morris) shows his dark side in the kitchen and argues with the chef (Amy Poehler).

headline: Hopes of Electoral Change Bring Foreigners Back to Indian Markets
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Elections', 'Foreign Investments', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Politics and Government', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Indian stock markets have been hitting record highs as investors anticipate that a business-friendly leader will become the next prime minister, but analysts caution that the outcome of the national elections is far from certain.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Just seven months ago, investors shunned the Indian markets, over growing concerns about the economy. The rupee hit a record low. Stocks plummeted.

headline: In Rowing, Women Catch Up With the Men
abstract: When the Oxford and Cambridge women’s boating teams face off on Sunday on the Thames, it will be the last time they race on a different day and different stretch of the river from the men.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the face of it, the recent unveiling of a new trophy for the Women’s Boat Race, contested annually by the best crews of eight from Oxford and Cambridge Universities, was unremarkable. A new silver chalice was introduced in front of a group of invited guests in the wood-paneled library at the University Women’s Club in Mayfair, and the old trophy — a rather sad-looking wooden plaque — was consigned to the River Rowing Museum in Henley-on-Thames, England.

headline: 7 Arrested on Suspicion of Arson in Protester’s Death
abstract: The police in Shandong Province have arrested seven people after a fire killed a man who had been trying to stop developers from seizing farmland.
lead_paragraph: The police in the eastern province of Shandong have arrested seven people in an arson and murder investigation after a fire killed a man who had been trying to block developers from seizing farmland. Geng Fulin, 63, had been sleeping in a tent when it was allegedly set on fire by four of the suspects early Friday. While three others in the tent escaped, Mr. Geng was killed in the blaze, the Shanghai-based Oriental Morning Post reported.

headline: Extreme Challenges for Investigators

lead_paragraph: Maps showing some of the difficulties in the search for Flight 370.

lead_paragraph: A look at where some of the survivors, deceased and missing from the mudslide near Oso, Wash., had lived before the disaster tore through the area last weekend.

lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: Grandmothers Call for Protection of Children After Kindergartners Are Fed Drugs
abstract: With a fourth Chinese kindergarten found giving children drugs without their parents’ knowledge, grandmothers have called on the government to protect children’s safety, and not to crush their rights as protesters in the interest of “public order.”
lead_paragraph: About two dozen Chinese grandmothers called on Wednesday for the government to protect children, and their families’ right to demand that protection, as a fourth kindergarten was discovered to be administering drugs to children without their parents’ knowledge.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Trying to Close a Knowledge Gap, Word by Word
abstract: Do you think campaigns like Providence Talks and Too Small To Fail will be successful? Why?
lead_paragraph: In “Trying to Close a Knowledge Gap, Word by Word,” Motoko Rich writes about various programs across the country trying to improve the long-term academic prospects of young children of poor and immigrant families.

headline: A Fight Is Brewing
abstract: The creators of some of the most distinctive craft beers in the world are identical twins from Denmark. They also can’t stand each other.
lead_paragraph: Mikkel Borg Bjergso, a 38-year-old former high-school science teacher who runs the Danish brewery Mikkeller, stuck his face into a bag of hops and inhaled deeply. It was a rainy February afternoon, and Mikkel, who makes some of the world’s most inventive beer, was visiting de Proef, a Belgian brewery in the town of Lochristi. The hops had been processed into unctuous pellets that resembled cat food, and they released a ripe botanical stink heavy on lemon grass and cannabis. “That’s nice,” Mikkel said, crumbling a few pellets between his fingers and nodding approvingly at the sticky green smear they deposited on his thumb. They were specimens of a strain called Polaris, developed by growers in Germany, which Mikkel had asked de Proef’s proprietor, Dirk Naudts, to purchase for use in a new Mikkeller beer. “They’re very fatty,” Naudts said.

headline: How Comfortable Are You With Lying?
abstract: Does your body language reveal when you are lying?
lead_paragraph: In the Times quiz “Can You Spot the Liar?,” you can view 10 individuals making statements — and decide whether you think they are lying or telling the truth. Go ahead and take it: Spotting the liar is not as easy as you might think.

lead_paragraph: The women of Morocco who carry large bundles across the border from Spain’s duty-free Melilla enclave.

headline: New Satellite Images Said to Be ‘Credible Lead’ in Malaysia Jet Hunt
abstract: Malaysia’s defense minister said satellite images taken Sunday showed 122 objects floating southwest of Australia.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Satellite sightings of 122 objects floating southwest of Australia are “the most credible lead that we have” in the search for Flight 370, the Malaysian defense minister said Wednesday evening, adding that his country had asked Australia to try to recover the objects and see if they were debris from the missing jetliner.

headline: Obama Renewing U.S. Commitment to NATO Alliance
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In a sharp rebuke, President Obama, in Brussels, denounced Russia’s takeover of Crimea and described Moscow as an out-of-touch power.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — President Obama has spent much of his presidency mired in the challenges of a world well outside the borders of Europe — the turmoil of the Middle East, the power struggles in Asia and the terrorist threats percolating in northern Africa, Pakistan and elsewhere.

headline: With App and Premium Plan, The Times Expands Online Offerings
abstract: Two new subscription plans, including NYT Now, a lower-priced app tailored for a mobile audience, are part of the company’s push to expand its digital offerings and increase its revenue.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company announced two new subscription plans on Wednesday, including NYT Now, a lower-priced app edited for a mobile audience, as part of the company’s push to expand its digital offerings and increase its revenue.

headline: On Eve of M.&A. Conference, Deal Makers Feel Hopeful, but Still Wary of Activists

lead_paragraph: The last two days have certainly given deal makers plenty to discuss at one of the industry’s biggest conferences, the Tulane Corporate Law Institute in New Orleans, this week.

lead_paragraph: Sometimes, the best way to alienate a little company’s early backers is a big payday.

headline: Q&A: Why the Dollar Remains the Reserve Currency
abstract: The world still clamors for dollars and there is no sign this will end, says a Cornell University professor. Even in financial turmoil investors run for cover — right back into the arms of the dollar.
lead_paragraph: Economists called it the “dollar trap.”

headline: Picking a Bag for a Camera
abstract: Once you’ve decided which camera to buy, you’ll have to figure out which bag can fit your camera and maybe some lenses and a laptop.
lead_paragraph: Searching for the right camera is really difficult. Searching for the right camera bag is almost impossible. Some bags are too small, others too big. Some don’t have enough padding, others look  hideous.

headline: Why Employers Will Stop Offering Health Insurance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel makes the case that freeing employers from the burdens of providing health insurance is a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a prediction: By 2025, “fewer than 20 percent of workers in the private sector will receive traditional employer-sponsored health insurance.” The source of this claim? Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel, in his just-published book, “Reinventing American Health Care.”

headline: Daily Report: Facebook to Buy Oculus VR, Maker of Virtual Reality Hardware
keywords: ['3-D Devices and Effects', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Social Media', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: The social media giant is betting that a technology commonly associated with science fiction can help turn social networking into an immersive, 3-D experience.
lead_paragraph: To fulfill its vision of the future of social media — one where it feels like hanging out with friends, rather than staring at their pictures — Facebook announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $2 billion agreement to buy Oculus VR, the maker of a virtual reality headset. It’s a bet that a technology commonly associated with science fiction can help eventually turn social networking into an immersive, 3-D experience, Nick Wingfield and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Britain Pares Its Stake in Lloyds Bank, But R.B.S. Remains a Tough Sell
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The British government sold a 7.87 percent stake in the Lloyds Banking Group for about $6.9 billion. But it seems increasingly unlikely that the government will begin paring its stake in Royal Bank of Scotland anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Now that the British government has successfully sold a second portion of its holdings in the Lloyds Banking Group, the question remains what to do about the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Standard Life to Pay About $645 Million for Asset Manager
abstract: Standard Life, based in Edinburgh, will acquire Ignis Asset Management from Phoenix Group Holdings in a deal that will increase its investment capabilities and broaden its third-party client base.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The investment arm of insurer Standard Life said on Wednesday that it had agreed to pay 390 million pounds, or about $645 million, for the asset management unit of Phoenix Group Holdings.

headline: Russian Oligarch Was Depressed Before Death, Bodyguard Testifies
abstract: An inquest to determine the cause of death of Boris A. Berezovsky, a fierce adversary of the Kremlin, resumed near London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A bodyguard working for Boris A. Berezovsky, a Russian oligarch and fierce adversary of the Kremlin who died a year ago under unexplained circumstances, said at an inquest on Wednesday that Mr. Berezovsky had been “very low” and depressed in the months leading up to his death following his defeat in a multibillion-dollar court case.

headline: Crowdfunding Site CircleUp Raises $14 Million
abstract: The fresh capital underscores the excitement in Silicon Valley over new ways of raising money.
lead_paragraph: CircleUp, a crowdfunding website, has allowed a number of fledgling companies to raise money over the last two years. Now, CircleUp has attracted some additional money of its own.

headline: Britain Fines Santander for ‘Failings’ in Its Advice to Clients
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said the Spanish bank Santander had “serious failings” in how it gave financial advice to consumers in its British branches. Santander has since overhauled its investment services.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain fined the Spanish lender Banco Santander 12.4 million pounds on Wednesday for “serious failings” in the way it offered financial advice to customers.

headline: Pope Accepts Resignation of High-Spending German Bishop
abstract: Francis had suspended the bishop of Limburg, Franz-Peter Tebartz-van Elst, after he spent millions to renovate his home and lost the support of many congregants.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Pope Francis on Wednesday accepted the resignation of Franz-Peter Tebartz-van Elst, the bishop of Limburg, whose extravagant spending on renovations for his personal residence angered his congregation and ran afoul of the pontiff’s message of humility and modesty for the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Putting 2 Sons in Top Posts, Murdoch Guards His Dynasty
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Lachlan Murdoch became nonexecutive co-chairman of the News Corporation and 21st Century Fox, and James Murdoch became co-chief operating officer at 21st Century Fox.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Rupert Murdoch was in retreat. His media empire was consumed by a phone-hacking scandal in Britain, threatening to engulf his son and heir-apparent, James. Family resentments boiled over into public view — he was distanced from both his son Lachlan and his daughter Elisabeth, and, according to friends, his marriage to Wendi Deng was showing signs of stress. Wall Street had grown impatient with his infatuation with newspapers, as had the leadership of the company he built, News Corporation.

headline: Mt. Gox Seeks Advice From Japanese Police
abstract: It is unclear whether the Tokyo police will start a formal investigation into Mt. Gox, the Bitcoin exchange that filed for bankruptcy last month.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO – Mt. Gox, the Bitcoin exchange based here that filed for bankruptcy protection last month, said on Wednesday that it had asked the Japanese police for advice on Bitcoins worth half a billion dollars that the company claims were stolen by hackers.

headline: Activist Investor Calls for Darden to Consider a New C.E.O.

lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:55 a.m. | Darden Restaurants should consider finding a new chief executive and installing an independent chairman, one of the activist investors pressuring the parent company of Olive Garden said on Wednesday.
