headline: Facebook’s $2 Billion Deal for Oculus
abstract: Facebook to buy Oculus, a maker of a virtual reality headset. | A likely heir is leaving JPMorgan Chase. | The maker of Candy Crush is set to trade on the N.Y.S.E. | The Murdochs take a step in succession planning.
lead_paragraph: In a surprise move, Facebook announced on Tuesday that it had reached a $2 billion agreement to buy Oculus VR, the maker of a virtual reality headset, in a bet that technology commonly associated with science fiction can help eventually turn social networking into an immersive 3-D experience, Nick Wingfield and Vindu Goel write in The New York Times. The announcement comes just over a month after Facebook made waves by revealing it would buy the mobile messaging app WhatsApp for up to $19 billion.

headline: Democrats to Try Long-Shot Tactic for House Immigration Vote
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The move, a discharge petition, is intended to spur a House vote on an immigration bill. It would require 218 signatures, but it is rarely successful.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats will carry out a long-shot legislative maneuver on Wednesday that is intended to bring a broad immigration bill to the House floor for a vote — or, at the very least, to increase the pressure on Republicans to move forward on some form of overhaul before the end of the year.

headline: Start-Up Unveils Bitcoin Payments Product
abstract: The payment systems product from the start-up Circle Internet Financial allows consumers to deposit dollars into an account, which converts the money into Bitcoin and stores it remotely.
lead_paragraph: While some restaurants, bars and coffee shops accept the virtual currency Bitcoin, it still exists largely in the province of speculators. One start-up, Circle Internet Financial, is trying to push Bitcoin into mainstream commerce.

headline: Kerry in Jordan for Talks With Palestinian Leader
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, in an effort to salvage Middle East peace talks.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — In an effort to salvage the Middle East peace talks, Secretary of State John Kerry met here on Wednesday evening with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority.

headline: China Export Restrictions on Metals Violate Global Trade Law, Panel Finds
keywords: ['Rare Earths', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Beijing’s reduction in exports of rare earth elements, purportedly on environmental grounds, violated World Trade Organization rules, the group concluded.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — China has broken international trade law by restricting the export of rare earth elements and other metals crucial to modern manufacturing, a World Trade Organization panel said Wednesday. That conclusion opens the possibility that Beijing will face trade sanctions from the United States, which initially brought the case, the European Union and Japan.

headline: Graphic: Tech M.&A. Rises to 2000 Level
abstract: Facebook’s $2 billion deal for Oculus VR, the maker of a virtual reality headset, is the sixth-biggest technology acquisition so far this year.
lead_paragraph: Millennial merger mania may be making a comeback.

headline: Obama Pays Tribute at Graves of World War I Soldiers
abstract: The president laid a wreath and visited the graves of three American privates who died at Flanders Fields in Belgium.
lead_paragraph: WAREGEM, Belgium — President Obama paid homage Wednesday to the American soldiers who died at Flanders Fields in the battles of World War I, which began 100 years ago and took the lives of hundreds of thousands.

headline: Most Anything Is Fair Game in Portugal’s Quest for Cash, Including the Mirós
abstract: Since the onset of the euro crisis, nations have sought to shed state assets. But some see the sale of cultural heritage as a step too far.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Across much of Continental Europe, the euro crisis did in just a few years what political parties in Britain and the United States had been hacking away at for decades: shrink the size of government. That is true perhaps no more so than here in Portugal. Since the onset of the crisis, the government has shed assets including Portugal’s airport management company, a highway operator and the national postal service.

headline: Malaysia Says New Objects Found in Ocean
abstract: Hishamuddin Hussein, Malaysia’s defense minister, said that new satellite images were “the most credible lead” in the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: Hishamuddin Hussein, Malaysia’s defense minister, said that new satellite images were “the most credible lead” in the search for the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Taxes Won’t Kill Bitcoin, but Tax Reporting Might
abstract: In the Standard Deduction column, Victor Fleischer examines how the I.R.S. expects individuals and businesses to treat Bitcoins for tax purposes.
lead_paragraph: Bitcoin is a digital representation of value, not a real currency, according to the latest pronouncement from the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Baritone in a Hurry to Reach Valhalla
abstract: Once a journeyman singer and now a sought-after opera star, the baritone Michael Volle says he is glad he had time to develop his voice to handle demanding Wagnerian roles like Wotan.
lead_paragraph: The powerful German baritone Michael Volle, whose career in Europe has exploded in recent years, was singing — and goofing around a bit with colleagues — at a recent rehearsal at the Metropolitan Opera, preparing for his much-anticipated debut there in Strauss’s “Arabella.”

headline: Another Preseason, With a New Perspective
abstract: After playing in Russia and then Sweden, Yael Averbuch is back in the U.S. preparing for the N.W.S.L. season with the Washington Spirit.
lead_paragraph: “The only real voyage of discovery consists not in seeking new landscapes, but in having new eyes.” — Marcel Proust

headline: Yup, That’s Doogie in Drag
abstract: “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” with Neil Patrick Harris, is one of the most anticipated revivals of the season.
lead_paragraph: If you would have told me in 1998 that Neil Patrick Harris was starring in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” on Broadway, I’m not sure which part of this news would be more surprising: That the actor from the sitcom “Doogie Howser, M.D.” was starring in the musical about a rock goddess who endured a botched sex change, or that this show that began at a small theater on Jane Street was on Broadway. Times have changed. For further proof, I recently saw a tweet referring to John Cameron Mitchell, the original Hedwig who also portrayed the role in the movie, simply as the e-book editor on “Girls.”

headline: Citic Group Negotiating a Listing in Hong Kong
abstract: The Citic Group, one of China’s biggest conglomerates, has signed a preliminary cash-and-stock agreement to sell substantially all of its operating assets to its Hong Kong-listed unit, Citic Pacific.
lead_paragraph: The Citic Group, one of China’s biggest state-owned conglomerates, announced on Wednesday that it was negotiating what might amount to a backdoor listing in Hong Kong in a deal worth tens of billions of dollars.

headline: App Maker Buckles on 1st Day of Trading
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: After pricing at a midpoint that still valued the company at $7 billion, the shares of King Digital had a treacherous first day out, spiraling almost 16 percent.
lead_paragraph: Candy Crush Saga has been a smash hit, attracting tens of millions of players and generating spectacular profits for its developer, King Digital Entertainment.

headline: Google Revamps Election Portal to Encourage Indians to Vote
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Elections', 'Urban Areas', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: The portal features Google Hangouts with prominent Indian politicians, during which users can submit questions, and ranks the politicians by how often they come up on Google Search, Google Plus and YouTube.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Google India introduced a revamped Google Elections hub on Wednesday in an attempt to encourage first-time voters and the growing number of Internet users in the country to engage more deeply with the political process.

headline: Mudslide Rescue Caught on Video
abstract: Footage from March 22 from the mudslide in Oso, Wash., released Wednesday, shows a helicopter hovering over the ground as the crew rescues a young boy.
lead_paragraph: Footage from March 22 from the mudslide in Oso, Wash., released Wednesday, shows a helicopter hovering over the ground as the crew rescues a young boy.

headline: Nissan Recalls 990,000 Vehicles for Air Bag Malfunction
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A software problem in some 2013-14 Nissan and Infiniti models could keep a front passenger air bag from deploying in a collision.
lead_paragraph: In the fifth huge recall for automakers this year, Nissan is recalling nearly a million vehicles, including 544,000 Altima sedans, because the front passenger-side air bag might not deploy in a crash, the company said  in a report to regulators published on Wednesday.

headline: Jurors Convict Abu Ghaith, Bin Laden Son-in-Law, in Terror Case
abstract: Sulaiman Abu Ghaith’s swift conviction is seen as a rejoinder to critics of the Obama administration’s efforts to try terror suspects in civilian courts, rather than before a military tribunal.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen years after the Sept. 11 attacks, a man who came to speak for Osama bin Laden in a series of impassioned videotaped messages that praised the attacks and promised more, was convicted by a federal jury on Wednesday of conspiring to kill Americans and of other terrorism charges.

headline: For Those Who Can Afford It, Christie’s Is Selling Anxiety
abstract: Loic Gouzer, a Christie’s expert, prepares “If I Live I’ll See You Tuesday,” a new auction of darker artworks aimed at a younger audience.
lead_paragraph: Loic Gouzer, a 33-year-old contemporary-art expert at Christie’s, remembers the moment during November’s big sale when “Apocalypse Now,” by the American painter Christopher Wool, sold for $26.4 million. “It was one of the first times a work from the 1980s sold for more than $20 million,” Mr. Gouzer recalled. “It broke the ice. Suddenly, that painting became as important as a de Kooning. We’re talking about the same price range.”

headline: Bruce Lee, Tupac Shakur and Kurt Cobain Walk Into a Bar…
abstract: A Dutch beer ad imagines them on a desert island along with Elvis, John Lennon and Marilyn Monroe.
lead_paragraph: The European sense of humor is a little different, apparently. To advertise its Radler drink –  a beer and lemon-lime soda combination (similar to what the British call a shandy) – the Dutch brewer Bavaria has made a TV ad that, taking off on the old “Elvis isn’t really dead” rumors, proposes that Elvis and other pop idols are actually aging gracefully on a tropical island.

headline: For Striving Students, a Connection to Money
abstract: Americans are highly attuned to the abuse of government benefits, yet the larger scandal is that people don’t use these benefits enough.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after he enrolled at the Borough of Manhattan Community College in January, 2012, to study accounting, Jason aged out of the shelter for youths where he was staying. Jason, who asked that only his first name be used, had recently arrived in New York City from the South, where he said he had endured a childhood that shifted him between relatives who abused him and foster care, where he was molested.

headline: Britain Gains Renminbi Trading Deal
abstract: The agreement by the Bank of England and the People’s Bank of China is the first outside of Asia and a victory for the British government in its efforts to make London a leading Western hub for Chinese trading.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England and the People’s Bank of China reached an agreement on Wednesday to allow the clearing and settlement of renminbi trades in London, the first such arrangement to be struck outside of Asia and another sign of the British government’s determination to make London a leading Western hub for Chinese trading.

headline: Eye Spy
abstract: Two new picture books by the Berlin-based artist Britta Teckentrup prompt children to look carefully at crowded illustrations.
lead_paragraph: The Berlin-based artist Britta Teckentrup has two new picture books, “The Odd One Out: A Spotting Book” and “Busy Bunny Days: In the Town, on the Farm and at the Port.” Both prompt children to look carefully at crowded illustrations. In the case of the first, the challenge is to identify animals that in some way differ from the rest. In the second, children answer questions about specific characters and their doings. Both books are surprisingly challenging, but their different artistic styles make one more successful than the other.

headline: Milton Glaser Critiques Modern Beer Art
abstract: The 84-year-old graphic-design legend who created the Brooklyn Brewery identity weighs in on what craft breweries are doing right and wrong.
lead_paragraph: The 84-year-old graphic-design legend who created the Brooklyn Brewery identity weighs in on what craft breweries are doing right and wrong.

headline: Facts & Figures: Clueless on the ‘Obamacare’ Deadline
abstract: The Obama administration plans to extend the sign-up deadline, which many people don’t seem to even know about.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said yesterday that it would treat the March 31 deadline for enrolling in a health plan somewhat flexibly. Consumers who begin to apply by March 31 will have until mid-April to finish.

headline: NYT Now: New Objects Found in Ocean
abstract: The Malaysian defense minister said new satellite images showed 122 objects, some up to 75 feet in length, floating southwest of Australia.
lead_paragraph: The Malaysian defense minister said new satellite images showed 122 objects, some up to 75 feet in length, floating southwest of Australia.

headline: Minecraft Maker Won’t Work With a Facebook-Owned Oculus VR
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: Like many game makers who were considering working with the Oculus virtual-reality tools, Markus Persson is uncomfortable with Facebook’s ad-driven business model.
lead_paragraph: Some people, it seems, don’t want to live in Facebook’s virtual world.

headline: Dare To Be Silly
abstract: IS-LM leaves out a lot, which is a good thing.
lead_paragraph: The title above was one of the four rules for research I laid out many years ago; it seems worth recalling when reading Lars Syll’s diatribe against IS-LM. I would respectfully submit that Syll doesn’t get what economic modeling is for. And his piece offers an occasion to talk about what it actually is for.

headline: Tinariwen Show Brooklyn What Cool Is All About
abstract: Their North African version of the blues is mystical and strange, rhythmic chants backed by hypnotic percussion and steely guitar licks. Imagine Robert Johnson playing at the crossroads somewhere in the desert between Mali, Algeria and Libya.
lead_paragraph: Some things are just too curious to pass up. So when you hear that a band of nomadic North African bluesmen is playing at a hipster bowling alley in Williamsburg, you go. Because why wouldn’t you? So there we were Sunday night, under a disco ball and posters of Coney Island freaks, to see Tinariwen for the first of two nights at Brooklyn Bowl.

headline: Why Movie Streaming Sites So Fail to Satisfy
abstract: At least until the end of this decade, viewers will have to navigate between multiple streaming services to watch the movie or TV show they want.
lead_paragraph: A team of web designers recently released an astonishingly innovative app for streaming movies online. The program, Popcorn Time, worked a bit like Netflix, except it had one unusual, killer feature. It was full of movies you’d want to watch.

headline: Happenings | ‘Twin Peaks’ Celebrates Its (Fictional) 25th Anniversary
abstract: To mark a seminal occurrence in the show’s final episode, a host of events invite a look back at the cultural legacy of the David Lynch classic.
lead_paragraph: Timelines are slippery, especially in the afterlife. But at some point after dark on March 26, 1989 (or perhaps in the dawn hours of March 27), a blonde teenager named Laura Palmer whispered to Special Agent Dale Cooper, “I’ll see you again in 25 years.” Laura made this vow from beyond the grave, of course, and the unraveling of her murder was the basis for David Lynch’s legendary “Twin Peaks,” which ran for two seasons in the early ’90s (but was set in the late ’80s) and spawned a movie, “Fire Walk With Me”; a host of companion books, faux diaries and audiobooks; two soundtrack albums and a generation of “Peakies” who can still tell you where they were the first time they saw Killer BOB climb over that couch.

headline: Dealing With Online Reviews: ‘You Can’t Take This Personally’
abstract: The founder of a company that helps people and businesses control their online reputations recommends acknowledging errors.
lead_paragraph: In early 2006, Michael Fertik was in Louisville, Ky., finishing a clerkship at the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, when he noticed that people and companies were increasingly being pulled online without their consent, through cyberbullying and theft of personal data. We’re supposed to control our experience on the Internet, Mr. Fertik said he thought, “but instead we’ve become the objects of the Internet.”

headline: Red-Brick Remnant of Manhattan’s Brewing Past Is Unearthed, Only to Vanish
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Beer', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: For a few hours this week, the Yorkville neighborhood had a newly visible, if modest, link to its German heritage, and an era in which the area abounded in breweries.
lead_paragraph: Like a beer drinker’s Brigadoon, a red-brick vestige of the enormous Jacob Ruppert & Company brewery in Yorkville emerged for a few hours this week before disappearing, this time forever.

headline: How Can Bookstores Stay Alive?
abstract: Stores that sell books are disappearing in the face of new technology and online venues. What does this mean for readers and the industry?

headline: After Facebook’s $2 Billion Deal, Some Virtual Unreality in the Stock Market
abstract: Shares of two relatively unknown companies, Oculus Innovative Sciences and Oculus VisionTech, surged on Wednesday, possibly benefiting from a case of mistaken identity among investors.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s $2 billion deal for Oculus VR, a virtual reality headset maker, made a splash in Silicon Valley. It also appears to be sending ripples through obscure corners of the stock market.

headline: What Would You Ask Michael Fertik About Your Online Reputation?
abstract: Here’s your chance to ask (almost) anything about dealing with Yelp and other review sites.
lead_paragraph: The Times has just published a conversation with Michael Fertik, who founded Reputation.com, a reputation management company that helps businesses and people play down their negative search results, protect their personal information, gather positive reviews for their businesses, and in general buff their online image. Since its launch in 2006, Reputation.com has raised $67 million in venture capital and attracted more than 1.6 million customers.

headline: After Mountain’s Collapse, Uncertainty and Loss
abstract: Teams began another day of looking for bodies amid a vast plain of mud and rubble in Snohomish County, Wash., as rain that began falling Tuesday was expected to continue.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Wash. — Pam Sanford was waiting for news about her brother, Joseph Miller, among the missing since Saturday in the Oso landslide, when a police detective called asking for his dental records.

headline: The View From Here
abstract: The Bay Area has a lot of million-dollar views, but even the cheaper ones are pretty nice.
lead_paragraph: The Bay Area has a lot of million-dollar views, but even the cheaper ones are pretty nice.

headline: Manhattan Coach Is Denied South Florida Job After Résumé Check
abstract: Talks ended between Manhattan’s Steve Masiello and South Florida after it was revealed the coach had lied about graduating from Kentucky in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Talks broke down between Manhattan Coach Steve Masiello and South Florida late Tuesday after South Florida officials discovered an inaccuracy on his résumé, which lists him as having graduated from the University of Kentucky in 2000.

headline: Turkish Court Overturns the Government’s Ban on Twitter
abstract: It was not immediately clear whether the ruling would be appealed or circumvented by a new court order.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — A court in Turkey ruled on Wednesday that the government could not ban Twitter, as it sought to do five days ago, and ordered the country’s telecommunications authority to restore access to the service. The action by the government had been met inside and outside the country with an uproar about respect for freedom of expression.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Transfer of Investigation of Uttar Pradesh Riots
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Hinduism', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Police']
abstract: The court criticized the state government for not having done enough to stop the religious violence that erupted last autumn, but said it saw no reason to transfer the investigation of the riots to an independent agency.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Supreme Court of India on Wednesday criticized the Uttar Pradesh government for not having done enough to stop the religious violence that erupted in the state nearly seven months ago, but said it saw no need to transfer the inquiry into the riots to an independent agency.

headline: In Mississippi, It’s G.O.P. vs. Tea Party
abstract: The state has emerged as the last major battlefield in the clash between the Tea Party and the G.O.P. establishment, as Senator Thad Cochran faces a conservative challenge to a seventh term.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — Senator Thad Cochran smiled as placidly as the waters in Mobile Bay behind him, where the Jackson, a $350 million combat ship named in honor of his state’s capital, bobbed gently, awaiting its christening bottle of Champagne.

headline: Suicides Mounting, Golden Gate Looks to Add a Safety Net
abstract: As early as late May, directors are expected to reverse longstanding policy and vote to use toll money and federal and state funds for a suicide barrier.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tourists who lean against the wind as they cross the Golden Gate Bridge may miss the slow-moving woman without a purse or the solo man without a camera or running shoes.

headline: A Look at Global Travel Trends
abstract: The chief executive of the World Travel and Tourism Council talks about everything from growth in China to the state of the travel industry.
lead_paragraph: During a prolonged and grinding recession, the travel industry was one of the few sectors to bounce back early and help buoy the global economy. Last year, the industry accounted for 9.5 percent of the global economy (nearly $7 trillion) and employed 266 million people — about 9 percent of the global work force.

headline: From Airlines to Hotels, a Quest to Help You Sleep
keywords: ['Sleep', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Cruises']
abstract: The travel industry is offering custom bedding, headphones, essential oils and more to aid those who suffer from a sleep shortage on the road.
lead_paragraph: At Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts, new beds allow guests to play Goldilocks and choose one of three mattress toppers, from soft to firm, that feels just right.

headline: Scene City: Gay Marriage in Lights
abstract: Broadway Veterans Attend Opening of Terrence McNally’s “Mothers and Sons.”
lead_paragraph: Broadway Veterans Attend Opening of Terrence McNally’s “Mothers and Sons.”

headline: Restaurant Report: Senator Restaurant in Toronto
abstract: The city’s oldest restaurant underwent a reboot recently, updating the food while leaving the beloved décor alone.
lead_paragraph: A red neon sign warms the facade of the Senator Restaurant, Toronto’s oldest restaurant, just as it did in the days when streetwear meant fedoras and overcoats. Inside, with its vinyl booths, shiny wood counter and huge mahogany mirror, it looks much the same as when it opened in 1929. And until recently, so did its menu. Standards like liver and onions, house-made meatloaf and a B.L.T. kept regulars and tourists happily, if predictably, fed.

headline: Hotel Review: Laura Ashley’s The Manor Hotel in Elstree, England
abstract: This property, reopened last July, offers a taste of the country just a short drive from London.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Shigeru Ban, Paper Master
abstract: Shigeru Ban, who was awarded the Pritzker Prize yesterday and is best known for his temporary shelters made from paper, was profiled in 2007 by the magazine.
lead_paragraph: Shigeru Ban, who was awarded the Pritzker Prize Monday, is best known for his temporary shelters made from paper. They have housed refugees in Rwanda and earthquake victims in Kobe. It may seem odd to construct emergency housing from something so fragile, but as Ban told Michael Kimmelman in a 2007 magazine profile, paper can be a strangely durable material:

headline: What You Get for ...$1,000,000
abstract: This week’s homes include an old stone house in Texas, a saltbox in Missouri and a chateau in Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: FREDERICKSBURG, TEX.

headline: Student Crossword | Stargazing
abstract: Test your knowledge of astronomy by playing our crossword — or find crosswords on topics across the curriculum in our archive.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of astronomy by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Kansas’ Freshman Center Could Be Top N.B.A. Pick if He Jumps
abstract: Joel Embiid’s collegiate career apparently ended early when Kansas lost to Stanford. He is expected to declare for June’s N.B.A. draft.
lead_paragraph: Joel Embiid expected to play this week. All Kansas had to do was beat Stanford on Sunday and advance in the N.C.A.A. tournament, and Embiid, their gifted freshman center who had been out since early March with a stress fracture in his back, would have returned for the Round of 16.

headline: Times Minute | Sale of Miro Paintings Questioned
abstract: Also on the Minute, a $45 million viola and drink coasters as home fashion accessories.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Obama and E.U. Hold News Conference
abstract: President Obama and Herman Van Rompuy, the president of the European Council, spoke at a summit meeting in Brussels.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Herman Van Rompuy, the president of the European Council, spoke at a summit meeting in Brussels.

headline: Times Minute | Miró Sale Questioned
abstract: Also on the Minute, a $45 million viola and drink coasters as home fashion accessories.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a $45 million viola and drink coasters as home fashion accessories.

headline: Today in Small Business: Personalized Shopping
abstract: And will President Obama’s new rules for overtime pay hurt the very people it is supposed to help?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Swiss Financial Regulator Names Former UBS Officer as Chief Executive
abstract: Mark Branson, a former chief financial officer of UBS’s wealth management and Swiss bank division, has been named to the top post at the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority said on Wednesday that Mark Branson, a former UBS executive who is serving as the authority’s interim chief executive, had been appointed to fill the top post.

headline: Madonna Signs to Direct Her Third Movie
abstract: She signed on to direct “Adé: A Love Story,” based on Rebecca Walker’s debut novel.
lead_paragraph: Having directed two films that proved only modestly successful, Madonna is hoping the third time is the charm: she has signed on to direct “Adé: A Love Story,” based on Rebecca Walker’s debut novel, Deadline reported. The novel touches on several themes that Madonna has been attracted to in the past, including sexuality, religion and race.

headline: With Videos, McConnell Finds More Bloopers Than Hits
abstract: A campaign ad for Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky showed a celebrating college basketball team in blue and white uniforms: Duke, not the University of Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell’s re-election team is getting very good at making campaign videos that go viral — but for all the wrong reasons.

headline: New Giant John Jerry Unlikely to Be Barred for Bullying, Coughlin Says
abstract: The Giants signed Jerry, an offensive lineman, last week after four years with the Dolphins, and Coach Tom Coughlin said a suspension was not “in the air” at the owners’ meetings.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — One of the players named in the 144-page report commissioned by the N.F.L. to explore accusations of widespread bullying on the Miami Dolphins is unlikely to be suspended, according to his new boss, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin.

headline: Congress Party Releases Manifesto for Elections 2014
abstract: Releasing its manifesto for the upcoming elections, the Congress party touts its achievements and promises an array of ambitious social reforms should it be re-elected.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian National Congress party on Wednesday released an election manifesto detailing its achievements in central government over the past ten years as well as its future agenda should it be re-elected in parliamentary elections next month.

headline: Data as Slogan, Data as Substance
abstract: In praise of Charles Gaba.
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith has the definitive piece on what’s wrong, so far, with the new FiveThirtyEight. For all the big talk about data-driven analysis,what it actually delivers is sloppy and casual opining with a bit of data used, as the old saying goes, the way a drunkard uses a lamppost — for support, not illumination. Smith:

headline: Classical Playlist: Anna Netrebko, Handel, Schoenberg and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ANNA NETREBKO: ‘Sola, perduta, abbandonata’ from Puccini’s ‘Manon Lescaut’Live from Rome Opera, with the conductor Riccardo Muti(Youtube.com)After seeing the soprano Anna Netrebko’s role debut as Manon Lescaut at the Rome Opera recently, I found it a pleasure to revisit her climactic aria in this pirated footage on YouTube from one of the performances. It’s passionate singing, confident and full of heart, with a dreamy despondency that is nevertheless always clear. The conductor Riccardo Muti has elicited wonderful things from her. (Zachary Woolfe)

headline: Facebook’s Alternate Financial Reality
abstract: A $165 billion market value and dual-class share structure allow Mark Zuckerberg to spend the company’s stock on little more than a hunch, writes Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg is liking a lot of deals.

headline: A Call for Haiku About New York City
abstract: To celebrate National Poetry Month in April, The Times sought original haiku about New York City, but with a twist.
lead_paragraph: Updated, April 5 | The Haiku Challenge is closed to future submissions. The final selection of haiku appeared here.

headline: In Greenland, a Safari-Style Camp
abstract: Natural Habitat Adventures is building an eco-camp in Greenland for travelers interested in exploring remote glaciers and mountains.
lead_paragraph: With few tourist facilities and an ice cap that takes up about 80 percent of its land mass, Greenland is not an easy place to visit. But Natural Habitat Adventures is building a new safari-style camp on Greenland’s east coast, offering a comfortable way to experience the island’s remote glaciers, icebergs and mountains.

headline: Houston Fire Rescue Caught on Video
abstract: Bystanders videotaped a construction worker in Houston being rescued from a balcony of a burning building moments before a section of the top floor collapsed.
lead_paragraph: Bystanders videotaped a construction worker in Houston being rescued from a balcony of a burning building moments before a section of the top floor collapsed.

headline: Cocktail Culture | New Spirits with Split Personalities
abstract: As distilleries get creative in their pursuit of the next best product, a cross-pollination of techniques continues to breed unique flavor profiles.
lead_paragraph: As distilleries get creative in their pursuit of the next best product, a growing cross-pollination of techniques and flavor profiles continues to breed unique, hybrid-like spirits. Here, an array of liquors that may give the impression that your bartender mixed up your order.

headline: Taxpayer Subsidies and Too-Big-to-Fail Banks
abstract: The New York Fed has resisted calls to break up the big banks.
lead_paragraph: There is less than meets the eye in the “too-big-to-fail” study released on Tuesday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Delaware Art Museum Will Sell Works to Pay Off Debt
abstract: The museum said it expects to raise $30 million from selling “up to four works of art” from its permanent collection.
lead_paragraph: Reeling from bond debt after an expansion and renovation in 2005, the Delaware Art Museum announced Wednesday that it had decided “with heavy hearts, but clear minds” to sell up to four works from its collection, to right its finances and save the museum from closing.

headline: Janine Nabers Wins Yale Drama Series Prize
abstract: Ms. Nabers’s play “Serial Black Face” won the award, for an unpublished work, and will receive a reading and a $10,000 prize.
lead_paragraph: Janine Nabers has won the 2014 Yale Drama Series competition for “Serial Black Face,” her play about the relationship between a single black mother and her daughter in Atlanta in 1979, at the start of a two-year spree in which more then 20 black children were murdered in the city. The award includes a reading at the Lincoln Center Theater’s Claire Tow Theater, publication by Yale University Press and a $10,000 cash prize.

headline: Crown Heights, Brooklyn: A Place of Her Own
abstract: While living with her father, Jackie Goldstein saved the money she needed to buy.
lead_paragraph: As a native Manhattanite, Jackie Goldstein knew she was lucky when it came to housing.

headline: Brazilian Telecommunications Deal Clears Hurdle
abstract: Regulators have ruled that Oi can proceed with its shareholder meeting scheduled for Thursday and vote on a capital increase that it says is needed ahead of a planned merger with Portugal Telecom.
lead_paragraph: SAO PAULO — Brazilian securities regulators have ruled that the telecommunications company Oi can proceed with its shareholder meeting scheduled for Thursday in Rio de Janeiro and vote on a capital increase that it says is needed ahead of a planned merger with Portugal Telecom.

headline: Figaro Serves a New Master
abstract: Stephen Wadsworth presents two Beaumarchais plays in Princeton, N.J., set solidly in the late 18th century but adapted to help contemporary audiences understand the times.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — In a theater world that favors aggressive directorial interventions that place “Othello” on a modern military base and Bellini’s “La Sonnambula” in a SoHo rehearsal room, Stephen Wadsworth has long called a different tune.

headline: Image of the Day: March 26
abstract: The Bandra-Worli sea link bridge in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

headline: Search for Lost Jet Is Complicated by Geopolitics and Rivalries
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'International Relations', 'Satellites']
abstract: While the United States, China and others have collaborated in the search for the Malaysian plane, each in its own way has been hesitant to reveal the extent of its surveillance abilities.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The frantic hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 has been, in one way, a nearly miraculous display of international collaboration: 26 nations, many of them rivals, have opened up their territorial waters and airspace or have contributed closely held technology and surveillance data to a search that has riveted the world.

headline: Barclays Works Out Deals With A.C.C. and Atlantic 10
abstract: The Atlantic 10 was to play its men’s basketball tournament in Brooklyn through 2017, but will cede to the A.C.C. tournament in 2017 and 2018 and return for three years starting in 2019.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Coast Conference’s decision to move its men’s basketball tournament to Barclays Center in Brooklyn in 2017 and 2018, which was widely reported two weeks ago, was made official Wednesday.

headline: Outkast and Eminem Top Lollapalooza Festival Lineup
abstract: Other acts will include Kings of Leon, Skrillex and Arctic Monkeys.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the Lollapalooza Festival in Chicago’s Grant Park apparently have enough faith in the festival’s track record – and, perhaps, in rumors and leaks about the lineup, which have proven to be extremely accurate – that by the time the festival announced its lineup on Wednesday, both single tickets and three-day passes were just about sold out, with only travel packages and premium passes remaining by Wednesday afternoon. The festival runs Aug. 1 to Aug. 3.

headline: Rangers’ Kreider Will Miss at Least 5 Games
abstract: A hand injury has sidelined the rookie forward Chris Kreider, whose 17 goals is tied for second on the Rangers, for their upcoming road trip.
lead_paragraph: Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault said Chris Kreider, the top-line left winger, would not accompany the team on its four-game western trip because of a hand injury.

headline: Discovery of Planetoid Hints at Bigger Cousin in Shadows
abstract: Astronomers say they have discovered a second icy world similar to the planetoid Sedna, a finding that may point to an unseen planet several times the size of Earth at the solar system’s distant outskirts.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers have discovered a second icy world orbiting in a slice of the solar system where, according to their best understanding, there should have been none.

headline: Citi Bike System Successful, but Wobbly From the Start
abstract: The New York bike-sharing program, which has gained nearly 100,000 annual members since it began in May, has faced financial concerns and other issues.
lead_paragraph: The hard truth lurked behind the gates of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, where employees of Citi Bike were tasked with testing the program last spring after nearly a year of delays.

headline: Facing a War Crimes Inquiry, Sri Lanka Continues to Vex the U.N.
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The U.N. Human Rights Council will vote Thursday on whether to proceed with an investigation into possible abuses during Sri Lanka’s civil war, a move its government is fighting.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — What to do with Sri Lanka? The island nation, triumphant after nearly three decades of war against ethnic separatists, has vexed the United Nations.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 78
abstract: Leading up to the World Cup, two events in the New York metropolitan area in April will focus on the soccer world.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: ‘Happy’ and ‘Frozen’ Hold Atop the Charts; YG Opens at No. 2
abstract: The Pharrell Williams single and the Disney soundtrack reigned at No. 1; the rapper YG’s album “My Krazy Life” opened at No. 2.
lead_paragraph: On the music charts this week, the unstoppable “Frozen” soundtrack fends off a wave of new albums, and Pharrell Williams’s “Happy” continues its reign as the No. 1 single.

headline: Sweeping Ruling on Domestic Violence
abstract: The Supreme Court considered the meaning of the term “domestic violence,” concluding that it encompassed acts “that one might not characterize as ‘violent’ in a nondomestic context.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday issued a broad interpretation of a federal law that makes it a crime for people convicted of domestic violence to possess guns.

headline: Wheelies: The Fast and Unfortunate Edition
abstract: A police investigation finds that speed caused the deaths of Paul Walker and Roger Rodas; Toyota and Honda to introduce fuel-cell vehicles in 2015.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Racist Satire of Obamas Hits a Nerve in Belgium
abstract: Antiracism groups said that a Belgian newspaper’s images depicting the president and his wife as apes pointed to a normalization of hateful political speech in Europe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The satirical images of President Obama and his wife, Michelle, digitally altered to look like apes, have vanished from the website of a Belgian newspaper, which published them days before the president’s visit to Brussels this week.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Conductor Returns ... For Now
abstract: Uncertainties remain over the return of the Finnish conductor Osmo Vanska, who resigned as the Minnesota Orchestra’s music director in October.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — To the last, the Minnesota Orchestra seems bent on confounding expectations.

headline: Moscow’s Garage Art Center to Transform Into Museum
abstract: The art center, opened in 2008 by the collector Dasha Zhukova, will become a noncollecting museum, aiming to become a permanent part of Russia’s growing art world.
lead_paragraph: The Garage Center for Contemporary Culture, the nonprofit art center opened in Moscow in 2008 by the collector Dasha Zhukova, has decided to transform itself into a museum, a change that will initially involve only its name but that the institution hopes will signal its intention to become a permanent part of Russia’s rapidly expanding art world.

headline: Felicity Jones, Star of the Dark Romantic Drama ‘Breathe In’
abstract: The alluring British actress also has upcoming high-profile roles in this spring’s “Spider-Man” sequel and in “Theory of Everything,” a chronicle of the marriage of Stephen Hawking.
lead_paragraph: The beguiling British actress Felicity Jones, who still looks like she belongs on the Oxford campus she once roamed as an English major, recently turned 30. She claims she’s not bummed out by it. “I feel like you burn through your 20s, and then suddenly, particularly when you turn 30, your priorities change,” she says. “There is so much pressure in your 20s — you don’t know who you are, you’re trying all these things out, and you’re running around probably trying to be someone you’re not.”

headline: Abu Ghaith’s Lawyer on Conviction
abstract: Stanley L. Cohen, a lawyer for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, Osama bin Laden’s son-in-law, spoke after his client was found guilty in a terrorism trial in a federal courthouse in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Stanley L. Cohen, a lawyer for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, Osama bin Laden’s son-in-law, spoke after his client was found guilty in a terrorism trial in a federal courthouse in Manhattan.

headline: ‘In Hindsight, Is Stay-at-Home Parenting Something You’d Recommend?’
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Parenting', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Sabbaticals and Career Breaks']
abstract: Into a field of parents looking to return to the workforce after taking time off for family reasons, a future mother lobs a tough question. Is stay-at-home parenting something you’d recommend?
lead_paragraph: Last week, when we asked readers for advice for people returning to work after a family-related career break, one reader posted a question that jumped out at me:

headline: From France to Midtown, a Rift Rocks La Grenouille
abstract: Charles Masson Jr. has been replaced as general manager by his younger brother, Philippe.
lead_paragraph: For most of the last four decades, Charles Masson Jr. has suavely presided over the old-school French restaurant La Grenouille, training the staff, designing the menus and even arranging the flowers as it became the last of Midtown’s legendary Gallic clubhouses for the well-off and well-known — the likes of La Caravelle, Lutèce and La Côte Basque.

headline: House Oversight Leader Accuses I.R.S. Commissioner of Stonewalling Inquiry
abstract: Darrell Issa, chairman of the House Oversight Committee, complained that the I.R.S. has not turned over all the emails the committee has demanded.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House Oversight Committee on Wednesday accused the head of the Internal Revenue Service of stonewalling the panel’s investigation into the I.R.S.’s treatment of conservative groups.

headline: General Who Led Takeover of Egypt to Run for President
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Elections', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, who pushed President Mohamed Morsi out of office last year, is expected to win and formalize the power he currently holds as the government’s top decision maker.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the defense minister and military officer who led last summer’s takeover of the elected government in Egypt, formally announced on Wednesday that he was resigning from the army and running for president as he moved to consolidate his power.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Alice James Books
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Carey Salerno, executive director of Alice James Books, discusses this publisher’s work.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Carey Salerno, executive director of Alice James Books.

headline: Grading the Curve in Consumer Electronics
abstract: Curved screens are the latest thing in TVs and phones, but while they work brilliantly in televisions, at least one phone model was a disappointment.
lead_paragraph: SUBTLE improvements, overstated innovations and marketing sleights of hand come fast and furious from the makers of consumer electronics. From 3-D TV to every possible permutation of wearable device to Bluetooth toothbrushes, it’s sometimes hard to keep track of what is innovative and what is just money-grubbing.

headline: Curved Screens: Worth It?
abstract: Molly Wood decides whether curved screens on new smartphones and TVs are worth the hype — and the money.
lead_paragraph: Molly Wood decides whether curved screens on new smartphones and TVs are worth the hype — and the money.

headline: The Gun Report: March 26, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: More women are carrying concealed weapons than ever before. A quarter of the one million permits issued in Florida are held by women, many of whom are flooding concealed permit classes.

headline: The Wrong Way to Protect Elephants
abstract: New rules on the sale of ivory do more harm than good.
lead_paragraph: THE year was 1862. Abraham Lincoln was in the White House. “Taps” was first sounded as a lights-out bugle call. And Steinway & Sons was building its first upright pianos in New York.

headline: College Players Granted Right to Form Union
abstract: Northwestern football players are university employees and entitled to a union election, a regional director of the National Labor Relations Board ruled Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A regional director of the National Labor Relations Board ruled Wednesday that a group of Northwestern football players were employees of the university and have the right to form a union and bargain collectively.

headline: Heavenly Voices Proclaim a Faith That Swings
abstract: Singers from New York City high schools collaborated with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Youth Orchestra to perform works by Duke Ellington at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Duke Ellington, a Christian, once said that he’d “be afraid to sit in a house with people who don’t believe, adding that he’d be “afraid that the house would fall down.” But his Sacred Concerts — three large-scale works he wrote between 1965 and 1973 — were nondenominational, fusing elements of jazz, classical, blues, gospel and dance.

headline: House Hunting in ... London
abstract: London’s St. John’s Wood market has seen robust price gains, and buyers have many styles from which to choose, from Regency-era townhouses to Italianate villas.
lead_paragraph: A THREE-BEDROOM APARTMENT IN A ST. JOHN’S WOOD TOWNHOUSE

headline: Citigroup Fails Federal Reserve’s Stress Test for 2nd Time in 3 Years
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Fed’s decision is prompting calls for another round of changes at the top of the bank’s management and questions over whether the bank should break up its far-flung operations.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve dealt an embarrassing blow to Citigroup on Wednesday, attacking the bank’s financial projections for its sprawling operations and denying the bank’s plan to increase dividends and repurchase stock.

headline: T.S.A. Calls for Armed Guards at Airport Checkpoints
abstract: The agency is recommending several new security measures in response to a fatal shooting last year at Los Angeles International Airport.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Transportation Security Administration is recommending that armed personnel be present at airport checkpoints during peak hours of passenger traffic, though airports would be able to tailor the security to their specific needs, according to a report released on Wednesday.

headline: Europe Begins to Rethink Cuts to Military Spending
abstract: Russia’s seizing of Crimea is unlikely to lead to increased military budgets on the Continent, but it may spur a review of how that money is spent.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Obama spent Wednesday in Brussels talking up the importance of the security relationship between Europe and the United States, but it is considered unlikely that Russia’s seizure of Crimea will prompt increased European military spending at a time of economic anemia and budget cuts.

headline: With Spring Fashion, It’s All About Wearing Your Slogan on Your Sleeve
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Slogans and Mottoes']
abstract: With the latest batch of slogan sweaters and tees, next to nothing is left unsaid; Garance Doré hosts a pop-up; a new line of tennis gear to wear on and off the court and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: If you would text it, wear it. With ever-more-micro communiqués being sent by text, Snapchat and WhatsApp, no wonder words and pithy turns of phrase are breaking through the smartphone screen and landing in the wardrobe. With the latest batch of slogan sweaters and tees, next to nothing is left unsaid. And based on the recent fashion shows, there is more to come. Phillip Lim accessorized his fall collection with leather paper-bag totes embossed with “Amaze” and “Cash.” Jeremy Scott, at his Moschino debut, sent out a fur coat that read “Fur Real” on the back. Off the runway, the glamour-puss editor Giovanna Battaglia wore an “I’m a Mess” sweater from Mr. Scott’s namesake collection. Sounds like a weekend pre-brunch message to us.

headline: Official Gets Emotional About Landslide
abstract: John Pennington, the Snohomish County emergency management director, teared up as he talked about the deadly landslide in the region.
lead_paragraph: John Pennington, the Snohomish County emergency management director, teared up as he talked about the deadly landslide in the region.

headline: Antarctica, by Boot and by Board
abstract: Before embarking on an expedition, Jeremy Jones and Xavier de Le Rue tend to have a clear mission. For their trip to Antarctica, however, they simply aimed to explore new terrain.
lead_paragraph: Before embarking on an expedition, Jeremy Jones and Xavier de Le Rue tend to have a clear mission. For their trip to Antarctica, however, they simply aimed to explore new terrain.

headline: Video: Antarctica, by Boot and by Board
abstract: For their trip to Antarctica, the snowboarders Jeremy Jones and Xavier de Le Rue eschewed a clear mission and simply explored the new terrain.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and now “Higher.” These films document his efforts to explore and snowboard mountains under his own power. In this companion piece to its “Higher Unplugged” series, Teton Gravity Research provides a glimpse into “Deeper.”

headline: More Dreaded Chores Outsourced to Robots (They Do Windows)
abstract: From cleaning pools to carrying shopping bags, the dream of robotic servants is edging closer to reality.
lead_paragraph: THE dream: a robot servant to pick up around the house, do laundry, cook dinner and perhaps even go on errands. The reality: cadres of little devices, buzzing like bees as they clean dirt and debris from every imaginable two-dimensional surface.

headline: Pontiff and President Seek Common Cause Amid Prickly Issues
abstract: President Obama will most likely address income inequality in his meeting on Thursday, a topic with similarities to Francis’ anti-poverty economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — They are an unlikely pair with seemingly much in common: an Argentine pope and an American president who each burst onto the global scene as a history-making change agent, each promising to promote a new post-partisan ethos, each having made the cover of Rolling Stone.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: New books by Delphine de Vigan, Tessa Hadley, Michael Parker, Alexai Galaviz-Budziszewski, Dustin Long and Susanna Kaysen.
lead_paragraph: This month, three books — two heavily autobiographical — tell the stories of thoughtful, sometimes troubled women; a short-story writer explores a corner of Chicago; a literary cohort goes in search of an enigmatic author; and a Buick brings two people together.

headline: Above It All Until Her World Turns Upside Down
abstract: In Jean Hanff Korelitz’s novel “You Should Have Known,” a family therapist’s marriage unravels unexpectedly.
lead_paragraph: As “You Should Have Known” unfolds, its heroine keeps discovering secret after gob-smacking secret. This is quite the comeuppance for the ordinarily smug, superior Grace Reinhart Sachs, who considers herself so much smarter than other people that she has even written a scoldy book that bestows her wisdom on them.

headline: Obama Gives Speech in Brussels
abstract: At the Palais des Beaux-Arts in Brussels, the president appealed to Europeans to stand behind the ideals of freedom and human dignity, and deplored Russia’s “brute force” in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: At the Palais des Beaux-Arts in Brussels, the president appealed to Europeans to stand behind the ideals of freedom and human dignity, and deplored Russia’s “brute force” in Ukraine.

headline: Shouldn’t Every Vote Count?
abstract: New York’s legislature overwhelmingly approved a National Popular Vote bill.
lead_paragraph: Americans elect their president and vice president using a bizarre and antiquated contraption called the Electoral College. Created two centuries ago, this system gives each state the same number of votes as it has senators and representatives. That formula is regressive and, in effect, robs many people of their ability to have a say in who runs the country. The College warps the presidential race so badly that is possible for a candidate to get the most votes and still lose the election. (As happened in 2000.)

headline: Carter Says He Would Think About Pardoning Snowden
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter said he would consider pardoning Edward J. Snowden if he was convicted in the United States, but added he was not certain whether he would grant one.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former President Jimmy Carter, on a swing through the nation’s capital to promote a new book, said Wednesday that he would consider a pardon for Edward J. Snowden, the former contractor who leaked classified information about the National Security Agency. But Mr. Carter said that he was not certain he would grant one.

headline: While in Albany, Lawmakers Squeeze Their Stipends
abstract: Some New York legislators, now negotiating the state budget, have been accused of taking advantage of their per diem to pad their paychecks and fund extracurricular activities.
lead_paragraph: GLENMONT, N.Y. — A “Duck Dynasty” marathon provided the soundtrack at Pub 23, a dimly lit tavern off the lobby of the Comfort Inn. A group of electricians doing highway roadwork had just ordered a round of whiskey shots when State Senator Rubén Díaz Sr., clad in a black cowboy hat, sidled up to the bar.

headline: A Bit of Beethoven in a Mix of Modern
abstract: Back-to-back recitals by Jacob Greenberg and Reinier van Houdt put a fastidiously maintained Steinway grand through its paces at Spectrum.
lead_paragraph: Next to Carnegie Hall, perhaps, there might be no finer public space in which to hear a piano recital in New York than Spectrum. A modest Ludlow Street loft that seats fewer than 50 people on sofas and cozy armchairs, Spectrum has recently emerged as a hotbed of new-music activity, showcasing local artists and distinguished visitors. For the pianophile, it provides an uncommon chance to hear a fastidiously maintained Steinway grand in a room selected and designed to suit it.

headline: U.S. in Odd Spot in Case on Protester Rights
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A government lawyer in a case involving the Secret Service was repeatedly attacked for making halfhearted arguments when bolder ones were available.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A government lawyer who seemed poised to win his case by a lopsided margin at a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday found himself in an odd position. He was repeatedly attacked for making halfhearted arguments when bolder ones were available.

headline: Fissures in China’s Ethnic Policy
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Immolation', 'Political Prisoners', 'Uighurs (Chinese Ethnic Group)']
abstract: A spying incident at the United Nations by a representative of a group tied to the Communist Party’s United Front Work Department has cast a spotlight on a turf war over ethnic policy, scholars said.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese man spying on the daughter of a prominent political prisoner at the United Nations in Geneva last week probably didn’t expect to be expelled from the international body.

headline: Danish Zoo, Reviled in the Death of a Giraffe, Kills 4 Lions
abstract: The zoo is the same one where a young giraffe was killed last month, then dissected and fed to lions — among them, the four lions put down this week.
lead_paragraph: Denmark, the land of enchanting fairy tales and liberal social values, is becoming known as the land of dead zoo animals.

headline: Young Designers Reimagine Jewelry
keywords: ['Jewels and Jewelry', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Women and Girls', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Young women emerge as top jewelry designers for their generation.
lead_paragraph: It’s not just about Tiffany, Cartier or Harry Winston anymore. Some of the most covetable baubles these days are made by a new generation of jewelry designers who are shaking up the old craft.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Surviving Jack’
abstract: Christopher Meloni is a gruff father in this new Fox sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Meloni is a gruff father in this new Fox sitcom.

headline: Break a Leg, but Spare Those Eggs
abstract: Casus, an Australian troupe of acrobats, puts its members’ skills to work around a fragile prop, in “Knee Deep” at the New Victory Theater.
lead_paragraph: Before the start of “Knee Deep,” a contemporary circus show now playing at the New Victory Theater, several cartons of eggs wait on the stage. Since “Knee Deep” is by Casus, an Australian troupe of acrobats, those eggs might be in trouble. And, in fact, when the first acrobat (Emma Serjeant) enters, the first thing she does is walk on them. Not a one gets broken.

headline: One Free Spirit Amid the Fog and the Frenzy
abstract: Andonis Foniadakis’s “Glory” is being performed at the Joyce Theater by the Ballet du Grand Théâtre de Genève, the Swiss troupe that George Balanchine once advised.
lead_paragraph: The moment the curtain rises on Andonis Foniadakis’s “Glory,” you have some idea of the melodrama you’re in for: The stage is a swirl of fog.

headline: Isabel Toledo and Lane Bryant See a Plus in Collaboration
abstract: The store and designer try to bring flair to larger sizes.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week has come and gone, but on a mild evening last week, editors from Vogue, Glamour and People StyleWatch were sitting in the front row for another fashion show. Lane Bryant, the plus-size retailer, was presenting a collection designed by Isabel Toledo, a designer probably best known for the lemon-grass wool lace dress and matching coat Michelle Obama wore on the cold morning of the 2009 inauguration. As waiters circulated with trays of Champagne, the editors gathered at the Seagram Building were conspicuously curious about the show.

headline: Big Cash and a Few ‘Cheap Thrills’
abstract: A look at the new movie “Cheap Thrills” and other films with characters who take on big challenges for cash.
lead_paragraph: How far would you go for money? For the characters in the new film “Cheap Thrills” (opening Friday in New York), the answer is: much further than they may have dreamed. The movie, directed by E.L. Katz, follows a family man (Pat Healy) who is strapped for cash and an old friend (Ethan Embry) he encounters in a bar. They meet a couple who offers them easy money to complete a series of dares, slowly raising the payoff and the challenge. How bad does it get? Let’s just say the characters risk life and limb for a chance at big money. It’s a theme oft explored at the movies: the potential for riches at the risk of moral bankruptcy or even death.

headline: Richard Phillips on New York City, Johan Lindeberg and the World’s Best Chocolate
abstract: The artist shares a few of his favorite things with T.
lead_paragraph: Richard Phillips has reached the upper echelons of the art world, in part, by trawling lowbrow culture. His “Most Wanted” series of recent videos and paintings of TMZ favorites such as Lindsay Lohan, the Brazilian supermodel Adriana Lima and the self-styled intellectual porn star Sasha Grey speak fluently to the visual aesthetics of desire. Next month, he will donate art and curate music for a benefit auction of work by Damien Hirst, JR and Julian Schnabel (among others) at Dallas Contemporary, benefiting MTV’s Staying Alive Foundation, which supports research to find a cure for H.I.V. and AIDS. He took a break from his work in the studio to put together a well-considered (and very New York) list of his own favorite things.

headline: On Opening Night, Relishing a Label Debate
keywords: ['Theater', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Terrence McNally’s latest play, “Mothers and Sons,” attracted a spirited Broadway crowd that discussed what to call a same-sex significant other.
lead_paragraph: What do you call the same-sex significant other in your life? Husband or wife? Lover? Partner? The actor Victor Garber said it still leads to awkwardness.

headline: Iraq and Crimea
abstract: President Obama’s speech ran off the rails when he defended the war in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: In his speech in Brussels today, President Obama struck a principled and forceful stand against Russian machinations in Crimea and Ukraine. He spoke eloquently about the history of Europe and European independence movements, and about the role of what we used to call “the West” in opposing Soviet dictatorship, domination and expansion.

headline: Police Scandals Reach Crisis Stage for Irish Government
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Police', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: The police have been under attack for months over allegations of buggings and the cancellation of traffic penalties and fines for the well connected.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A series of scandals embroiling Ireland’s police force in recent months has developed into a full-blown political and legal crisis for the Irish government.

headline: A Charleston Hotel With an Interest in Building
abstract: The Belmond Charleston Place hotel is offering package that includes a hands-on plaster lesson at the American College of the Building Arts.
lead_paragraph: When Belmond Charleston Place invites its guests to get plastered, they’re not talking about hitting the bar.

headline: Titles Decided at Spring North American Championships
abstract: The three-day Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was the third national title decided at the Spring North American Championships in Dallas.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The three-day Norman Kay Platinum Pairs was the third national title decided at the Spring North American Championships here. Richard Coren of Delray Beach, Fla., and Bobby Levin of Henderson, Nev., had two strong sessions on the last day, Sunday, to win by nearly three boards from Thomas Bessis and Cedric Lorenzini of France. Third were Kent Mignocchi and Joel Wooldridge of New York City.

headline: Bank of America to Pay $6.3 Billion to Settle Mortgage Securities Suit
abstract: The lawsuit arose out of troubled mortgage-backed securities that the bank cobbled together and sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in the run-up to the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:51 p.m. | Bank of America is paying $6.3 billion to settle a lawsuit arising out of troubled mortgage-backed securities it cobbled together and sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac in the run-up to the financial crisis.

headline: Fashion in Harlem: A Place of Style and Confidence
abstract: Harlem resident, Tru Osborne, says he is regularly inspired by the legacy of the Harlem Renaissance and by style icons like ASAP Rocky.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, in the neighborhood where Eleanora Fagan became Billie Holiday and where Dapper Dan’s boutique brought designer logos to the streets, Tru Osborne, a longtime Harlem resident, was on his way home from work. Clad in bright layers and even brighter blue Patrick Ewing sneakers easily visible from two blocks away, Mr. Osborne said he was regularly inspired by the legacy of the Harlem Renaissance and by style icons like ASAP Rocky and Pharrell Williams.

headline: Mammy Revealed, and Not Just Her Red Petticoat
abstract: The estate of Margaret Mitchell, author of “Gone With the Wind,” has authorized a prequel, being written by Donald McCaig, called “Ruth’s Journey.”
lead_paragraph: Mammy, the faithful slave in “Gone With the Wind,” may finally get her due — and a proper name.

headline: Of Sojourns Past and Future
abstract: The travel magazine, which ceased publication in 1977, will see a new issue next week.
lead_paragraph: WHETHER OR NOT there are second acts in American lives, it appears there are second acts in American magazines. Holiday, the great midcentury travel magazine, is set to begin publishing once again. Its first home: Philadelphia. Its new home: Paris, where it debuts next week with an installation at the megastore Colette.

headline: When We Were Young, and Dads Were Men
abstract: Christopher Meloni is TV’s latest old-fashioned, non-nurturing father of a child’s memories, on Fox’s “Surviving Jack.”
lead_paragraph: There is a search on for the non-nurturing father.

headline: Two Women of Style
abstract: Michelle Obama and Peng Liyuan show their distinctive flair.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama has spent the last week in China, where she has taken her daughters and her mother on a cultural tour, with time saved for a few impassioned addresses on freedom of speech and minority rights.

headline: Huffington Post Editor Named Director of U.S.C.’s Journalism School
keywords: ['Journalism Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Willow Bay, named to the post on Wednesday, will run reporting and public relations programs at the USC Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Willow Bay, a Huffington Post editor and veteran TV news anchor, was named director of the University of Southern California’s journalism school on Wednesday.

headline: Planet Albany
abstract: The hotel lifestyle of Assemblyman Harvey Weisenberg, who, like many state legislators, commutes weekly to Albany.
lead_paragraph: The hotel lifestyle of Assemblyman Harvey Weisenberg, who, like many state legislators, commutes weekly to Albany.

headline: Etsy, the Makeup Counterculture
abstract: Rejecting the big chain stores in favor of Etsy for natural products that are made at home and that sell for less.
lead_paragraph: When Tara Graff was searching for makeup that would not irritate her sensitive skin, she did not head to Sephora, Macy’s or the cosmetics counter at Bloomingdale’s. Instead, she turned to Etsy.com.

headline: Prosecutors Hear Evidence in Songs
abstract: Across the country, police and prosecutors are introducing defendants’ rap lyrics as evidence against them in criminal proceedings. A selection of cases.
lead_paragraph: Across the country, police and prosecutors are introducing defendants’ rap lyrics as evidence against them in criminal proceedings. A selection of cases.

headline: More Movers to Play With Force
abstract: David Dorfman Dance brought an expanded company to its two works at the Harkness Dance Festival, at the 92nd Street Y.
lead_paragraph: David Dorfman Dance finished this year’s Harkness Dance Festival at the 92nd Street Y by performing the same two works that Mr. Dorfman brought to the festival a decade ago. Or almost the same. This time, there were different dancers, and more of them, and a lot more talking.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Belgium and More
abstract: Photos from Belgium, Australia, Kosovo and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Belgium, Australia, Kosovo and Egypt.

headline: Killing of Afghan Journalist and Family Members Stuns Media Peers
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The attack at the Serena Hotel in Kabul that left Sardar Ahmad, his wife and two of their three children dead has devastated his colleagues and prompted an unusual apology from the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Sardar Ahmad, a warmly admired stalwart of the Afghan journalistic community here, loved to post bits of wisdom from his young daughter, Nelofar, on Facebook.

headline: Seeking an Image, but First, a Dress
abstract: Thousands of designer items, that supplied television series like “Sex and the City” and “Gossip Girl,” are on loan and view in one space in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Most New Yorkers dream of having a little more closet space. If they are dreaming in Technicolor, they might envision the Albright Fashion Library, a 7,000-square-foot space in NoHo that houses some 1,500 gowns among more than 23,000 pieces and has supplied television series like “The Carrie Diaries,” “Sex and the City” and “Gossip Girl” and films such as “The Bling Ring” and “The Devil Wears Prada” with clothes, accessories and jewelry.

headline: A Tortured Policy Toward Russia
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations']
abstract: The U.S. has to stop making threats that it can’t carry out.
lead_paragraph: THE United States has once again twisted itself into a rhetorical pretzel. As when it threatened military action against Syria if a “red line” was crossed, the Obama administration’s rhetoric about Russia and Ukraine goes far beyond what it will be willing and able to enforce.

headline: Crimea and Punishment
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The dance between diplomacy and force, between aggressive responses and appropriate ones, is more complicated than sound bites can convey.
lead_paragraph: The president is trying to walk a tightrope — thin as a thread and dangling over danger — on the Russian invasion and annexation of Crimea.

headline: Sexual Abuse of Girls
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: A reader writes, “Many people do not know the extent of sexual abuse that young girls suffer.”

headline: Children and E-Cigarettes
keywords: ['E-Cigarettes', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Children and Childhood', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

headline: Arresting the Homeless
abstract: The president of the Doe Fund is outraged that a man was arrested, and later died, instead of being taken to a shelter.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Dressed for Spring, in Denial of Winter
abstract: A sampling of spring looks on the streets of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: A sampling of spring looks on the streets of Manhattan.

headline: The Accidental Wanderer
abstract: The artist and illustrator James McMullan on his memoir about growing up on two continents during World War II.
lead_paragraph: James McMullan has painted 80 posters for Lincoln Center Theater, won a New York Times best illustrated book award for “I Stink!” written by his wife, Kate McMullan, and has just written and illustrated a memoir, “Leaving China: An Artist Paints His World War II Childhood” (Algonquin, $19.95). Born in 1934 in Tsingtao (now Qingdao), China, he was 3 when his family moved to the coastal city of Cheefoo (now Yantai). In 1941, three years after the Japanese invaded Cheefoo, Mr. McMullan and his mother took off for San Francisco, while his father joined the British Army.

headline: Pakistanis Said to Meet With Taliban to Lay Groundwork for More Talks
abstract: The meeting at a secret location in the militant bastion of North Waziristan was the first contact since efforts were derailed in February amid a barrage of terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A Pakistani government delegation met face-to-face on Wednesday with representatives of the Pakistani Taliban for the first time since efforts to open talks were derailed in February, officials said.

headline: Making It Fun to Turn on the Lamp
abstract: Fab.com introduces the fanciful Tri Light.
lead_paragraph: Fab.com’s new Tri Light is more flexible and fanciful than first impressions suggest. You can turn it on simply by lifting the LED rod — a little light magic. The mechanism “gives the product character and hopefully a bit of joy for the user,” said its designer, Aaron Leahy, 24, of Perth, Australia.

headline: Decanters to Pop Your Cork Over
abstract: They don’t need to be traditional or even glass. And they’re happy to hold anything in the grape family.
lead_paragraph: Laura Maniec hardly looks old enough to drink legally, let alone hold forth on how to decant wine. Yet she is 34, a master sommelier and co-founder of Corkbuzz Wine Studio, a restaurant in the West Village (a second one will open in Chelsea Market in June) that also offers wine classes.

headline: A Wealth of Ideas
abstract: Michael Walrath, the tech and night-life mogul, had made enough money by his early 30s to settle in. But he’s not the retiring type, and he has myriad projects to prove it.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, at a party at the Crosby Street Hotel in SoHo to celebrate a documentary about childhood obesity called “Fed Up,” the tech and night-life mogul Michael Walrath, one of the film’s producers, spoke briefly to the 60 or so people gathered in the hotel’s Prince Room.

headline: One Singular Sensation
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Joining two apartments and two tastes to make a unified home that plays up his straight lines and her softer edges.
lead_paragraph: For years, Sudhir Gupta and Cynthia Wong and their two cats all lived together in Mr. Gupta’s 550-square-foot, one-bedroom Gramercy Park apartment. And they couldn’t help coveting the apartment next door, a light-filled space with generous exposures on two sides and an owner who spent most of his time somewhere else.

headline: The Ring Cycle: Coasters’ Star Turn
abstract: Once inconspicuous, they are now the high-design, attention- grabbing divas of the table top.
lead_paragraph: Brian Dubois is a Detroit-area designer whose surname means “of the wood,” and it fits. At the Architectural Digest Home Show in New York last weekend, he showed tables of solid walnut with cork embedded in the tops.

headline: An American Makeover for a Classic Chair
abstract: Hans Wegner chairs are covered in Paul Smith fabric to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Danish designer’s birth.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate the 100th birthday of Hans Wegner, a founding father of Danish Modern who died in 2007, Carl Hansen, the Danish furniture company that produces much of his work, teamed up with the American textile manufacturer Maharam to create a fresh interpretation of a handful of classics.

headline: Dashes of Sweetness at Kartell
abstract: After 35 years the Italian furniture company is returning to tableware.
lead_paragraph: The luxurious plastic for which the Italian furniture company Kartell is famous has assumed a new purpose — and an old one. Next month the company will introduce tableware by the designers Patricia Urquiola, Jean-Marie Massaud and Philippe Starck and the Italian chefs Davide Oldani, Carlo Cracco and Andrea Barton.

headline: Sales at DwellStudio, Iittala, Viyet and Evanson
abstract: Discounts on furniture, accessories and glassware.
lead_paragraph: DwellStudio is discounting its Finn dresser by 30 percent, through March 31, or while supplies last (originally $2,850, it is now about $1,995); 877-993-9355, dwellstudio.com.

headline: If the Paper Could Talk About Itself
abstract: From Studio Job, wallpaper with withered flowers, skeletons and other delights.
lead_paragraph: For Viktor & Rolf’s 2013 fall and winter show in Paris, Studio Job created a striking backdrop of withered grayish flowers — a William Morris canvas gone dark. That design and several other graphics created by the Dutch/Belgian design team of Job Smeets and Nynke Tynagel over the years, are being reimagined as wallpaper by the firm NLXL.
