headline: Law Firms Are Pressed on Security for Data
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Legal Profession', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Large American corporations are pressing their law firms to increase cyber security to deter hackers from gaining access to confidential information.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of big corporate clients are demanding that their law firms take more steps to guard against online intrusions that could compromise sensitive information as global concerns about hacker threats mount.

headline: Legal Debate on Using Boastful Rap Lyrics as a Smoking Gun
keywords: ['Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Confessions', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: As prosecutors use boastful rap lyrics to assemble criminal cases, a debate has arisen over whether such songs can constitute evidence of guilt or even the intention of wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. — The case had gone cold.

headline: Shopping Openings and Events for the Week of March 26
abstract: Pop-up stores, openings and new merchandise.
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: Bringing 3-D Power to the People
abstract: By offering everything needed to produce (and sell) a design, one Queens factory hopes to be the Amazon of 3-D printing.
lead_paragraph: The first thing Duann Scott does when he arrives at the Shapeways factory in Long Island City, Queens, is check the bins. They are yellow and stacked in an all-white room that resembles the interior of a spaceship, and they contain the latest prints to come out of the machines, which can really stack up.

headline: Reshaping Design With 3-D Printing
abstract: Industrial 3-D printing facilities, like Shapeways in Long Island City, are revolutionizing product design and manufacture.
lead_paragraph: Industrial 3-D printing facilities, like Shapeways in Long Island City, are revolutionizing product design and manufacture.

headline: Mayor Quits in Charlotte After Arrest Over Bribes
keywords: ['Mayors', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Gifts to Public Officials']
abstract: Federal officials claim that the mayor accepted a trip to Las Vegas, use of a luxury apartment and more than $48,000 in cash in exchange for favors to undercover agents posing as investors.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Charlotte, N.C., resigned on Wednesday after he was arrested on public corruption charges, as federal law enforcement officials alleged that he accepted a trip to Las Vegas, use of a luxury apartment and more than $48,000 in cash in exchange for helping smooth out municipal obstacles for undercover agents posing as investors.

headline: Infections at Hospitals Are Falling, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Federal health officials said the substantial decline is related to the greater role of nursing homes and improved practices at hospitals nationwide.
lead_paragraph: The number of infections Americans acquire during hospital stays every year has declined substantially over the last decade, federal health officials said in a report on Wednesday, as hospitals have worked to improve their practices and nursing homes’ role in medical care has grown.

headline: Pitfalls of Reverse Mortgages May Pass to Borrower’s Heirs
abstract: The loans that promised to help older people stay in their homes in retirement are, in some cases, now pushing their children out.
lead_paragraph: The only solace for Isabel Santos as she spends her evenings huddled over stacks of yellowed foreclosure notices is that her parents are not alive to watch their ranch-style house in Pleasant Hill, Calif., slipping away.

headline: The Certainty of Donald Rumsfeld (Part 2)
abstract: The origins of the phrase “unknown known” are traced in pursuit of meaning or substance.
lead_paragraph: Read Part 1; Part 3; Part 4.

headline: F.D.A. Unveils Deal to Limit Antibiotic Use in Animal Feed
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'ANTIBIOTICS', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Livestock', 'Factory Farming']
abstract: The agency said that 25 of the 26 companies that make the drugs for animal feed said they would remove the words “growth-promotion” from their labels.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday that nearly all drug companies that make antibiotics for use in animal feed had agreed to go along with its proposal to phase out the use of the drugs to make animals grow faster. The agency said that 25 of the 26 companies that make the drugs for animal feed said they would remove the words “growth-promotion” from their labels, effectively making it illegal for farmers and ranchers to use the drugs for that purpose. Some public health experts are skeptical that much will change, saying the industry will use the drugs in the same way but contend that the purpose is to prevent disease.

headline: Court Weighs Delay of Strict Limits to Drug-Induced Abortions in Arizona
abstract: A law set to go into effect next Tuesday would impose the strictest rules in the country over the use of medication to induce abortions during the early stages of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — A federal judge here heard arguments on Wednesday over a law set to go into effect next Tuesday that would impose the strictest rules in the country over the use of medication to induce abortions during the early stages of pregnancy, forbidding the drugs to be used after the first seven weeks.

headline: A TV App From Disney Lets Travelers Browse Its Vacation Offerings
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The app aggregates videos, photographs, interactive theme park maps and other information from the websites of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts businesses and their social media channels.
lead_paragraph: A SMART TV app being introduced by Walt Disney Parks and Resorts on Thursday will let potential travelers use their remote controls to research vacations at theme parks and hotels and on cruise ships and packaged tours.

headline: Target Had Chance to Stop Breach, Senators Say
abstract: Senators John D. Rockefeller IV, and Richard Blumenthal said Target’s failure to heed warning signs of incursions by cybercriminals was the fault of its top executives and board.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two Democratic senators on Wednesday criticized Target’s management for not stopping a huge data breach of its systems, citing several missed opportunities to thwart the attack and protect customer data.

headline: Oklahoma Told It Can’t Shield Suppliers of Execution Drugs
abstract: An Oklahoma judge ruled that the state could not keep secret the identities of the suppliers of lethal-injection drugs.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma judge ruled on Wednesday that the state could not keep secret the identities of the suppliers of lethal-injection drugs, raising doubts about the executions of two prisoners next month and fueling a growing legal battle in several states over secrecy in methods of execution.

headline: Proposed Housing Bill Would Create a Co-op of Mortgage Lenders
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cooperatives', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities']
abstract: The proposal would make the lending system more like a public utility by creating a co-op of lenders that would be the sole issuer of mortgage-backed securities guaranteed by the government.
lead_paragraph: Yet another proposal for winding down Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and overhauling the nation’s housing finance system will be put before Congress on Thursday, this one by Representative Maxine Waters of California, the ranking Democratic member of the Financial Services Committee.

headline: Amnesty International Study Finds Executions Rose in 2013
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Amnesty International’s report attributed most of the nearly 15 percent increase to “virtual killing sprees” carried out by Iran and Iraq, though the group considers China the world’s top executioner.
lead_paragraph: Despite a long-term decline in the number of countries practicing capital punishment, publicly disclosed executions jumped nearly 15 percent in 2013 compared with a year earlier, largely because of “virtual killing sprees” carried out by the authorities in Iran and Iraq, Amnesty International said in its annual report on death-penalty trends.

headline: Guinea: Government Bans Bat Soup to Halt Ebola Outbreak
abstract: The action came after the West African nation’s first Ebola outbreak, which has killed 63 people.
lead_paragraph: To help quell its first Ebola outbreak, the West African nation of Guinea has banned bat soup. Bats are believed to be the natural reservoirs of the filovirus that causes Ebola, and fruit bats are a popular food in West Africa, usually cooked in a peppery soup or smoked over a fire. While boiled bat meat is presumably safe, smoked meat could be dangerous, and butchering bats for the table certainly is. The current outbreak in Guinea has killed 63 people, but the appearance of new cases has slowed significantly, the country’s health ministry said. Most outbreaks are thought to start when jungle hunters eat the flesh of apes that died of Ebola, presumably after eating fruit contaminated by bat feces or saliva. But where bats are in the diet — as they are in parts of Africa, Asia and the Pacific — no intermediary host is needed.

headline: Virginia: Victim in Naval Base Shooting Is Identified
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Navy on Wednesday identified the sailor killed this week in a shooting at a Norfolk, Va., naval base as Petty Officer Second Class Mark A. Mayo, a member of the base’s security force.
lead_paragraph: The Navy on Wednesday identified the sailor killed this week in a shooting at a Norfolk, Va., naval base as Petty Officer Second Class Mark A. Mayo, a member of the base’s security force. Petty Officer Mayo, 24, of Hagerstown, Md., was killed Monday by a civilian who had disarmed a sailor during a struggle aboard a destroyer docked at Naval Station Norfolk, the world’s largest naval base. Petty Officer Mayo had put himself between the sailor and the civilian when he was fatally shot. Security personnel then killed the suspect, whose name has not been released.

headline: The Value of a Life, Though Toxic and Tiny
abstract: We were aware of our responsibility for our pet, yet we failed to take care.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — I waited in the car outside of the school, knowing it was The Day, The Very Momentous Day. She appeared on the sidewalk, holding the box in both hands. Look what I have.

headline: A Nation of Takers?
keywords: ['Welfare (US)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Private Aircraft', 'Taxation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Food Stamps', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Let’s get real about which public welfare programs are wasteful.
lead_paragraph: In the debate about poverty, critics argue that government assistance saps initiative and is unaffordable. After exploring the issue, I must concede that the critics have a point. Here are five public welfare programs that are wasteful and turning us into a nation of “takers.”

headline: Jonathan Schell, 70, Author on War in Vietnam and Nuclear Age, Dies
abstract: Mr. Schell came to public notice in his early 20s with his first book, “The Village of Ben Suc” in 1967. He came to greater prominence in 1982 with “The Fate of the Earth.”
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Schell, a best-selling nonfiction author whose books explored warfare in its myriad 20th-century incarnations, from a scathing indictment of United States policy in Vietnam to a sobering portrait of the world in the aftermath of a nuclear holocaust, died on Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 70.

headline: Settlement Bars Misleading Health Claims by Tanning Salons in New York State
abstract: A settlement with New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, bars the owner of the Hollywood Tans franchises in the state from making health claims or aiming its marketing at high school students.
lead_paragraph: New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, will announce a settlement on Thursday that bars Hollywood Tans NYC, an indoor tanning salon in Chelsea, from making misleading health claims, such as “sunlight prevents skin cancer” and “the American Cancer Society doesn’t want you to know the truth about tanning beds.”

headline: From Field to Video Room: How Baseball’s Replay Review Will Work
abstract: In a demonstration Wednesday, two Major League Baseball officials played the roles of an umpire in Manhattan and an umpire calling from Arizona to report a manager’s challenge to a play.
lead_paragraph: The heart of Major League Baseball’s new instant replay review system is a low-lit operations center, decorated in muted grays, at the Chelsea Market headquarters of MLB Advanced Media.

headline: Deadly Mix of Loose Sediments and Heavy Rain in Washington
abstract: Experts say a combination of factors including steep terrain, complex geology and weather are among the reasons that make the state so prone to landslides.
lead_paragraph: The flow of mud, boulders and trees that overran part of the community of Oso on Saturday was the most lethal slide in Washington in years, but the state is prone to the destructive events.

headline: The Future of Virtual Reality
abstract: In a video for the Founders Fund, a venture capital firm, Palmer Luckey, a founder of Oculus VR, imagined the impact virtual reality could have beyond the world of gaming.
lead_paragraph: In a video for the Founders Fund, a venture capital firm, Palmer Luckey, a founder of Oculus VR, imagined the impact virtual reality could have beyond the world of gaming.

headline: M.L.B. and Players Union Close In on Tougher Drug Penalties
abstract: Major League Baseball and the Players Association are working toward an agreement that would again increase penalties for the use of performance-enhancing substances.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, Fla. — With less than a week to go before the baseball season begins in full, Major League Baseball and the players union are working toward an agreement that would again increase penalties for the use of performance-enhancing substances.

headline: The Season of the Twitch
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'States (US)', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Yes, people, November seems so far away, but the campaign trail at this point is filled with missteps and blunders that are fun to follow.
lead_paragraph: Some of you appear to be very, very worried about which party is going to win control of the Senate in November. Really, you should stop for a while. Take a break. No fretting about undecided voters until there’s at least a minimal chance that the undecided voters know who’s running.

headline: Car Dealers Tilting at Tesla
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles']
abstract: There’s no reason to believe that independent dealerships would be better able to sell or service Tesla cars than the maker itself.
lead_paragraph: Car dealers in New York, New Jersey and several other states are waging legal, legislative and regulatory campaigns to stop Tesla, the fast-growing electric-car company, from selling its vehicles directly to consumers. These moves are little more than attempts to protect an old retail model by limiting consumer choices.

headline: Creator of a Virtual Reality Sensation
abstract: Facebook’s acquisition of Oculus VR has brought attention to its co-founder Palmer Luckey and the Southern California tech scene where his company took root.
lead_paragraph: Palmer Luckey, a baby-faced 21-year-old college dropout, figured out how to build a virtual reality headset so exciting that it became a sensation on Kickstarter, the crowdfunding site, raising a staggering $2.4 million in 30 days.

headline: Crowdfunders of the Maker of Oculus Rift Denounce a Facebook Buyout
abstract: Oculus VR got its start on Kickstarter, raising $2.4 million. Some donors want their money back.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For many of Oculus VR’s early backers, news that the virtual reality start-up was selling to Facebook for $2 billion was a little like watching Bob Dylan star in a Super Bowl Chrysler commercial.

headline: U.S. Announces Further Exemptions for Insurance Enrollment Deadline
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Obama administration said it would grant more time to sign up for health insurance to those people who can prove they began their applications before April 1.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday expanded the list of people who could sign up for health insurance after the deadline, announcing “special enrollment periods” for legal immigrants, victims of domestic violence and tens of thousands of people who experienced various problems trying to complete their applications for coverage.

headline: Mr. McConnell’s Latest Mischief
keywords: ['Coal', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: The ploy from the Senate minority leader to block a proposal by the E.P.A. escalates already dangerous levels of antiregulatory fervor.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican and minority leader, is up for re-election, and he is under pressure to show fealty to his state’s powerful coal interests. To that end, he introduced a resolution earlier this year to block a proposal by the Environmental Protection Agency that would set limits on greenhouse gas emissions from new power plants. As written, the proposal would effectively stop construction of most new coal-fired plants.

headline: Indonesia Candidate Tied to Human Rights Abuses Stirs Unease
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Prabowo Subianto, an ex-special forces commander accused of torture and abductions, has announced his candidacy for president, putting the Obama administration in a difficult position.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Prabowo Subianto, a former special forces commander, kicked off his party’s campaign for legislative elections with a rally last weekend that the local news media characterized as “military style.” He rode into a Jakarta stadium in a jeep to greet the party faithful, mounted a horse to circle the grounds and paraded before uniformed party cadres standing at attention.

headline: Updated Warnings for Generic Drugs
keywords: ['Generic Brands and Products', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: Generic manufacturers should be made responsible for alerting the public to risks discovered after their drugs are on the market.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, the Food and Drug Administration proposed sensible regulations that would authorize the makers of generic drugs to update safety labels independently, without waiting for F.D.A. approval, to warn of newly discovered risks. The change is strongly opposed by the makers of generics out of fear of being held liable for damages to patients harmed by their products. But the change is needed, both to give patients and doctors more timely warning of emerging risks and to enable patients to sue.

headline: Evening news in pictures 26 March
abstract: Evening news in pictures 26 March
lead_paragraph: Evening news in pictures 26 March

headline: Giving Up on 4-Year-Olds
abstract: A report showing the use of excessively punitive policies in public schools against our most vulnerable children should shame the nation.
lead_paragraph: A new report released by the Department of Education’s Office for Civil Rights, examining the disciplinary practices of the country’s 97,000 public schools, shows that excessively punitive policies are being used at every level of the public school system — even against 4-year-olds in preschool. This should shame the nation and force it to re-evaluate the destructive measures that schools are using against their most vulnerable children.

headline: Military Cuts Render NATO Less Formidable as Deterrent to Russia
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: President Obama and European leaders have pledged that Russia would not be allowed to run roughshod, but the military reality tells a different story.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and European leaders pledged Wednesday to bolster the NATO alliance and vowed that Russia would not be allowed to run roughshod over its neighbors. But the military reality on the ground in Europe tells a different story.

headline: German Man to Return Nazi-Looted Art
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Art']
abstract: Cornelius Gurlitt, the octogenarian hoarder of art plundered by the Nazis, will return the paintings to their original Jewish owners or those owners’ descendants.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Cornelius Gurlitt, the octogenarian hoarder of art plundered by the Nazis, will return paintings in the trove his family kept secret for decades to their original Jewish owners or those owners’ descendants, starting with a well-known Matisse, his lawyers said on Wednesday.

headline: Amid New Rules and Scrutiny, Secret Service Confronts Agents’ Conduct
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Questions arise again about whether the agency in charge of the president’s security has fostered a culture of debauchery.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days leading up to President Obama’s trip to Europe, the director of the Secret Service, Julia A. Pierson, sat down with the agency’s senior officials to reiterate a message she had focused on during her first year in the job.

headline: Hanging Stockings, but Expecting Budget Coal
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Vouchers', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Homeless Persons', 'Education (Pre-School)']
abstract: Year after year, there is little or no discussion of the most lucrative items in the budget stocking, but Albany is dancing around a voucher program for working homeless families.
lead_paragraph: There is to state budget time in Albany a delightful sense of anticipation, like that of a child awaiting Christmas morn.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, March 27, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, March 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Russia’s leadership is challenging truths that only a few weeks ago seemed self-evident. That in the 21st century, the borders of Europe cannot be redrawn with force; that international law matters; and that people and nations can make their own decisions about their future.”

headline: A 25-Game Skid, but All Is Not Lost for the Sixers
abstract: With a defeat Thursday against the Rockets in Houston, the Sixers (15-56) would tie the N.B.A.’s longest losing streak of 26 games.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The visitor’s locker room. Where was it? Brett Brown had been inside the AT&T Center hundreds of times over a dozen years as director of player development and assistant coach for the Spurs. But now Brown was head coach of the Philadelphia 76ers, walking an unfamiliar corridor. He had lost his way, not unlike his team, which had been adrift for two months.

headline: Governor Wants to Keep Tax Increase, Setting Terms for Re-Election in Illinois
abstract: Gov. Pat Quinn of Illinois announced his plan to make permanent an unpopular temporary tax increase, stoking a debate that is becoming central to his bid for re-election.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — Gov. Pat Quinn of Illinois on Wednesday announced his plan to make permanent an unpopular temporary tax increase, stoking a debate that is becoming central to his bid for re-election.

headline: Heckling From Egyptian Activists as Military Leader Declares Presidential Ambition
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Defense Minister Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi’s announcement that he will run for president was greeted with anger, dismay and sarcasm online by activists, rights workers and commentators who supported the 2011 revolution.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, the defense minister who led last summer’s takeover of the elected government in Egypt, Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, announced on Wednesday that he was resigning from the army and running for president.

headline: Corrections: March 27, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on March 27, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Diving To Great Depths For a Pal
abstract: In “Jasper in Deadland,” Matt Doyle charms his way into the underworld to find his dead best friend.
lead_paragraph: For a three-headed hellhound with menacing fangs and green-glowing eyes, Cerberus can be surprisingly accommodating.

headline: A Literary Catfight, With Context by Cavett
abstract: Dick Cavett plays himself in “Hellman v. McCarthy,” Brian Richard Mori’s dramatic reconsideration of the Lillian Hellman and Mary McCarthy feud and lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a little odd playing yourself,” Dick Cavett says, after doing so quite convincingly in the new play “Hellman v. McCarthy,” an Abingdon Theater Company production that opened on Wednesday at the June Havoc Theater. Mr. Cavett then jokes, “The funny thing is I was the second choice for the role.”

headline: Back to the Beginning
abstract: Jean O’Conor takes us back to the beginning.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLES — There is a reason why I don’t write Numberplay, the weekly math puzzle blog, but when the math concepts infiltrate my crossword puzzles, I am forced to bite the bullet and do the research. It’s not like I remember these concepts from school. Fortunately, I really liked this puzzle by Jean O’Conor, rebuses and all, so it was well worth my time.

headline: CBS Works to Minimize the Drama After a Dramatic Departure on ‘The Good Wife’
abstract: The CBS efforts to manage the fallout from a character’s surprise departure from “The Good Wife” suggests just how important the show is to the network.
lead_paragraph: This post may contain spoilers.

headline: European Banks Feel Effects of Crimea Crisis, With Austria Bearing Brunt
abstract: Vienna's banks were not alone in staking out the former Soviet bloc. But for reasons of geography and history, they bet big on Eastern Europe.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — After the Cold War ended in the early 1990s, Viennese banks pushed aggressively into the newly open markets of Eastern Europe, as if rebuilding the old Hapsburg Empire one A.T.M. at a time.

headline: Now on Track 30 for a 2-Hour Listening Tour, Metro-North’s New President
abstract: Joseph J. Giulietti was at Grand Central Terminal, where the new president of the railroad discussed safety concerns and long waits for trains with commuters.
lead_paragraph: It is an archetype that seems as old as the hub itself: The aggrieved Grand Central Terminal commuter, muttering about the indignities of the rails to anyone who will listen.

headline: U.C.L.A. Link Stays Intact Over Decades
abstract: At U.C.L.A., the connections among players may be a bit more personal than at other storied programs, and they span generations.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Kyle Anderson was in middle school in New Jersey, he watched U.C.L.A.’s basketball team, with players like Kevin Love and Russell Westbrook, who helped the Bruins reach the Final Four, catching his eye.

headline: ‘Environmental Poisoning’ of Iraq Is Claimed
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An advocacy group said at a congressional hearing that veterans and civilians continued to feel the effects of burn pits used to dispose of military waste, and that Washington must aid sufferers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An advocacy group representing American military veterans and Iraqi civilians arrived here on Wednesday armed with a message for the United States government: Washington must do something for the thousands of people suffering from what the group called the “environmental poisoning” of Iraq during the war.

headline: Ex-Development Official to Direct Hurricane Sandy Recovery
abstract: Amy Peterson, president of an organization which places women in careers in such industries as construction, maintenance and transportation, will be named within days.
lead_paragraph: A former development official who runs an organization that helps place women in blue-collar jobs will be named to lead New York City’s efforts to recover from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: For Connecticut, New York Has Provided a Foundation
abstract: Players from New York have anchored several of Coach Geno Auriemma’s eight national championship teams at the University of Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — Four years ago, during one of the first practices of the season at Connecticut, Coach Geno Auriemma told the freshmen Bria Hartley, of Long Island, and Stefanie Dolson, of Port Jervis, that he hated players from New York.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 26, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 26, 2014

headline: Bobcats Take Another Step Forward and Hand the Nets a Setback
abstract: Charlotte is still in the N.B.A. playoff picture and is fighting to stay there, as Wednesday’s 116-111 victory over Brooklyn attests.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — It’s late March, and the Charlotte Bobcats still matter in the N.B.A. playoff picture. Who would have figured that from a team that set a record for the worst winning percentage in league history just two years ago?

headline: ‘The Americans’ Recap: Philip, the Platinum Spy
abstract: Philip, usually the cooler K.G.B. agent, shows his ruthlessness.
lead_paragraph: There’s something about Elizabeth’s nonspy character that complements her spy character. She’s calculated. That she’s always prepared for violence shows in her expression and walk. Elizabeth is a taut puma (with great hair), ever ready to pounce. Philip is more of an affable house cat. There’s a lot less surface tension, so it’s sometimes a little hard to remember that on some level, he is a seriously cold bastard, and this week’s episode, “The Deal,” was all about reminding us of that.

headline: Leaky Defense Leaves Knicks’ Spirits Sinking
abstract: The Knicks have had a knack for putting up bad numbers this season, but it will be difficult to top the 51 points they allowed the Lakers to score in Tuesday’s third quarter.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — The Knicks have had a knack this season for putting up numbers. Bad numbers.

headline: Oswald Morris, Artful Cinematographer, Is Dead at 98
abstract: Mr. Morris, a British cinematographer, helped redefine the color in Technicolor with filters, fog machines and makeshift devices.
lead_paragraph: Oswald Morris, a British cinematographer who helped redefine the color in Technicolor with filters, fog machines and makeshift devices like the brown silk stocking he stretched over a lens for the life-in-amber look of “Fiddler on the Roof,” died on March 17 at his home in Fontmell Magna, England. He was 98.

headline: Overcoming Latest Adversity, Rangers Win a Possible Playoff Preview
abstract: Chris Kreider’s hand injury and Martin St. Louis’s cold spell are causes for concern, but not for losing.
lead_paragraph: As long as Ryan McDonagh, Henrik Lundqvist and the fourth line continue to work wonders in their respective roles, it almost does not matter what misfortune befalls the Rangers.

headline: Zbigniew Romaszewski, Physicist Who Resisted Poland’s Communists, Dies at 74
abstract: He played an early role in a seminal workers’ rights group founded in the 1970s, which helped establish the Solidarity movement.
lead_paragraph: In the anxious months after Poland’s Communist government declared martial law in December 1981, leaders of Solidarity, the workers’ movement that the government was seeking to silence, were forced into hiding. Even as they eluded arrest, they did not want to lose contact with the movement’s millions of supporters across the country.

headline: A Victory for Athletes as University Employees
abstract: The decision that football players at Northwestern have the right to form a union has pulled back the veil of big-time college athletics.
lead_paragraph: In a groundbreaking decision that acknowledges the special status of the college scholarship athlete, a regional director of the National Labor Relations Board confirmed Wednesday what many of us already know: Athletes running and jumping across our television screens are university employees.

headline: In Astoria Arts District, a Once-Gritty Pocket Will Embody Culture
abstract: An area in Astoria will be designated the “Kaufman Arts District,” an official artistic district whose name is a nod to the Kaufman Astoria Studios.
lead_paragraph: New York City neighborhoods can wax and wane in popularity like a boy band: hot one minute, not the next, and maybe hot again. On Friday, a once-gritty pocket of Astoria, Queens, where a steady stream of cultural and artistic institutions have sprung up over the years and ratcheted up the cool factor, will be designated an official artistic district by the city. The move will codify the cool and, it is hoped, keep the arts mavens and the businesses that cater to them flocking.

headline: Back From Injury, Tampa Bay’s Stamkos Adjusts and Thrives
abstract: In 10 games since returning from an injury that caused him to miss 45 games, Tampa Bay’s Steven Stamkos has scored 7 goals.
lead_paragraph: When the Tampa Bay Lightning star Steven Stamkos returned to the lineup March 6 after missing 45 games with a broken leg, it was as if his whirlwind season were only beginning.

headline: LAFCO Goes Liquid
abstract: The beauty brand known for its bar soaps and scented candles brings its familiar, coveted scents to new liquid soaps and hand creams.
lead_paragraph: Feu de Bois. Marine. Moonglow Apricot. These and five more of the most popular LAFCO New York fragrances are now available in liquid hand soap, arguably a departure for the beauty brand with a cultlike following. The look is aligned with the rest of LAFCO’s House & Home product line — its signature grosgrain ribbon has been silk-screened onto the bottles, which were designed to mimic the brand’s hand-blown diffusers — but the embrace of a liquid formula is a first for the house. Made with natural olive oil, the delicate stuff fits right in at the company’s retail locations, which feel like stepping into an Italian farmacia. Paired with the new Reparative Hand Cream in the same scents, it’s a welcome addition to the most well-appointed bathrooms.

headline: China’s Shadow Banking Malaise
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A severe slowdown in China’s economy would have a modest ripple effect, particularly on global commodity prices, but would not provoke a global crisis, two economists write.
lead_paragraph: Peter Boone is chairman of the charity Effective Intervention and a research associate at the Center for Economic Performance at the London School of Economics. He is also a nonresident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics. Simon Johnson is a professor at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund.

headline: The Workout: A Ref Keeps Up With March Madness
abstract: You think the players get a workout during March Madness? Try being a referee.
lead_paragraph: As the big college basketball tournaments get underway, many eyes will be on the players scrambling up and down the courts in pursuit of a national championship.

headline: Word of the Day | besiege
abstract: This word has appeared in 107 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: besiege•\bi-ˈsej, be-\• verb

headline: Population Growth in New York City Is Reversing Decades-Old Trend, Estimates Show
abstract: For the third consecutive year, the city last year gained more people than it lost, turning around a course that stretched to the mid-20th century, the Census Bureau said.
lead_paragraph: New York City may be an expensive place to live. Jobs are not easy to find, even as the city rebounds from the recession. And the public transit system is not always reliable or comfortable.

headline: In Florida-U.C.L.A. Matchup, a Clash of Tempo
abstract: The top-seeded Gators, who face the Bruins in the Round of 16 on Thursday, have a stingy defense that will try to slow the furious pace that U.C.L.A. employs.
lead_paragraph: The U.C.L.A. men’s team embraces an open-gym culture, playing fast and loose, with few rules. Sometimes the first pass is the last pass, and the pace contributes to U.C.L.A.’s robust scoring average of 81.5 points a game.

headline: Mets Face Outfield Decision: Eric Young or Juan Lagares?
abstract: Eric Young Jr., who led the N.L. in steals last year, could be the Mets’ leadoff hitter, but he will have to get the nod in center over Juan Lagares, a superior defender.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At the Mets’ first full-team meeting of spring training, Eric Young Jr. was presented a shiny championship belt, the kind a wrestler might win, as a trophy for leading the National League in steals last season. His feat had been a bright spot for the Mets in a bad season. He tried the belt on, and the room erupted in cheers.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Encore) UNFORGIVEN (1992) Clint Eastwood returned to the Old West for what has been, so far, his final time, to star in and direct this drama. He plays William Munny, a notorious gunslinger and outlaw who is dragged out of retirement to earn money from a bounty in Big Whiskey, Wyo., despite vowing that he would never kill again. He’s joined by his old riding partner Ned Logan (Morgan Freeman) and the Schofield Kid (Jaimz Woolvett). But Big Whiskey’s sheriff, Little Bill Daggett (Gene Hackman), does not take kindly to bounty hunters. “The center of attention, from the moment he rises up out of a hog pen until the darkest fade-out in western movie history, is Mr. Eastwood,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “This is his richest, most satisfying performance since the underrated, politically lunatic ‘Heartbreak Ridge.’ There’s no one like him.” The film received four Academy Awards, including best picture and best director.

headline: J.R. Smith, With Nine 3-Pointers, Keeps Knicks in Playoff Race
abstract: The Knicks held off a furious rally to beat the Kings, 107-99, and move a game closer to the final playoff berth in the Eastern Conference.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — One day removed from a blowout loss, the Knicks made their way to Sleep Train Arena on Wednesday night for a bit of therapy. That was the plan, anyway. The Kings, a woebegone outfit with zero plans for the postseason, looked to be more punchless than usual without their injured point guard, Isaiah Thomas.

headline: Airline Buckles to Pressure From PETA on Monkey Cargo
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment']
abstract: PETA, the animal welfare organization that has campaigned for years against transporting animals for lab testing, says the change in China Southern’s policy could hamper efforts to use animals from Asia for experiments.
lead_paragraph: After years of protests by animal rights crusaders, a Chinese airline has said it will no longer transport monkeys and other primates used for laboratory experiments.

headline: Tribal Activist Candidate Poses a Problem for Aam Aadmi
keywords: ['Elections', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: In many ways, Soni Sori, who will run for Parliament in the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh, is a natural fit with the Aam Aadmi Party’s populist manifesto, but her candidacy has the potential to divide a party that is still searching for a core identity.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In many ways, Soni Sori, a tribal rights activist from Chhattisgarh, is a natural fit with the Aam Aadmi Party, which recently named her as one of its three candidates for Parliament in the central Indian state.

headline: Times Minute | A Legal Roundup
abstract: Today on the Minute, an analysis of the Abu Ghaith case, a major ruling for college football and rap lyrics used in court.
lead_paragraph: Today on the Minute, an analysis of the Abu Ghaith case, a major ruling for college football and rap lyrics used in court.

headline: Times Minute | A Legal Roundup
abstract: Today on the Minute, an analysis of the Abu Ghaith case, a major ruling for college football and rap lyrics used in court.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Search for Missing Jet Is Moved Nearly 700 Miles, Based on Radar Analysis
abstract: The revision of the search area, based on further analysis by an international team working with Malaysian officials, means that Australia is redirecting the search far from the floating objects seen in the previous search area.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Australia announced on Friday that it had moved the search area for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 nearly 700 miles to the northeast, the latest in a long series of changes by the authorities on where they think the plane might have disappeared.

headline: Test Yourself | English, March 27, 2014
abstract: Can you choose the best adjective to complete the sentence from the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Obama Deplores Russia’s ‘Brute Force’ in Ukraine
abstract: How did President Obama respond to the justifications made by President Vladimir Putin for seizing the Crimean Peninsula from Ukraine?
lead_paragraph: In “Obama Deplores Russia’s ‘Brute Force’ in Ukraine,” Michael D. Shear and Peter Baker write about President Obama’s speech in Europe outlining for Americans back home and for allies around the world why it is crucial to confront President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after his takeover of Crimea.

headline: Have You Ever Posted, Emailed or Texted Something You Wish You Could Take Back?
abstract: Have you ever posted something on a social network that you regretted?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever posted something you shouldn’t have on an impulse, or texted somebody by mistake?

headline: A Look Back at Burt Glinn
abstract: Sarah Stacke, who was hired to help Burt Glinn digitize his vast archives, recalls the lessons he taught her about doing things well and with love.
lead_paragraph: One of my most treasured possessions is a creased and well-handled black-and-white photograph. It lives in my living room in a floating, double-sided frame so that I can view its front and back, both of which I find mesmerizing. The photograph was made in 1957 by the Magnum photographer Burt Glinn and shows the Little Rock Nine, surrounded by armed and helmeted troops, ascending the steps of Little Rock Central High School on its first day of integration. The school’s brick facade fills the frame, evoking a prison, rather than an opportunity. The back of the print features stamps and instructions Magnum used to identify and track its images when there was no other option than to transport physical photographs.

headline: High and Low Views From the Bay Area
abstract: The best Bay Area views aren’t necessarily the most expensive.
lead_paragraph: The Bay Area has a lot of million-dollar views, but even the cheaper ones are pretty nice.

headline: Objects That Make a House a Home
abstract: 7 designers on the most comfortable things they own.
lead_paragraph: As part of Key, our mini-magazine on real estate and design, we asked seven designers to tell us about the most comfortable things they own.

headline: The San Francisco Envy Chain
keywords: ['Jealousy and Envy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Real estate has gone berserk by the Bay, and tech billionaires are building pleasure palaces. But the homes to covet are the ones reminiscent of the city’s more soulful past.
lead_paragraph: When I first walked into Mark Donaldson and Dawn Judd’s loft in San Francisco’s Dogpatch neighborhood, their two daughters were swinging on climbing ropes hung from the rafters, and Mark was weaving between them on a skateboard. All the kinetic energy looked a bit dangerous, but also exhilarating. A pink bicycle perched on its kickstand near a door that led to the patio, and everywhere, about to topple, were stacks of books. The building once served as the Esprit headquarters, where Mark and Dawn both worked in the late ‘80s. Some 20 years later, while at a children’s birthday party across the street, they noticed the place was for sale. Now a bust of a girl with braided hair, sculpted by Dawn’s grandmother, sits in the entryway, and wooden birds float from the ceiling.

headline: Social Gains for Women Linked to Domestic Violence
abstract: A study published on Tuesday in Population and Development Review finds that women who are the sole breadwinners in their household and women who are more educated than their spouses have an increased risk of experiencing domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Indian women who experience economic and social gains in the form of employment and education are often at a greater risk for domestic violence, according to a study released on Tuesday.

headline: Qatar Finds U.S. Couple Guilty in Daughter’s Death
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: An American couple accused of killing their adopted daughter by depriving her of sustenance were unexpectedly found guilty and sentenced to three years in prison.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Matthew and Grace Huang, an American couple accused of killing their 8-year-old adopted African daughter last year by depriving her of sustenance for four days, were unexpectedly found guilty on Thursday and were each sentenced to three years in prison followed by deportation, in a case that has drawn close attention in Qatar and in the United States.

headline: Pretax Profit Slumps 40%  at Raiffeisen
abstract: Raiffeisen Bank’s earnings report reflects the slumping economies of Russia and Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Raiffeisen Bank International, an Austrian lender closely watched because of its extensive operations in Ukraine and Russia, reported fourth-quarter results on Thursday that reflected its mounting number of problem loans in the region.

headline: New York Today: De Blasio’s Diversity
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: the mayor’s diversity record, another cold morning, and the habits of thrifty state legislators.
lead_paragraph: Good Thursday morning. It’s 25 degrees.

headline: Yahoo Japan to Buy eAccess From SoftBank
abstract: The deal for the mobile Internet service provider represents a reshuffling of assets within the corporate family of SoftBank, which owns about 42 percent of Yahoo Japan.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Yahoo Japan said Thursday that it would acquire eAccess, a mobile Internet service provider, from the Japanese telecommunications giant SoftBank for 324 billion yen, or $3.2 billion.

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your Thursday: Obama meets the pope, a huge credit line for Ukraine, and 30 years after the first Mac.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Babcock International to Pay $1.53 Billion For Spanish Aviation Firm
abstract: The British engineering services company will acquire Avincis from the private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Investindustrial Group. The deal includes the assumption of £705 million in debt.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Babcock International Group said Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the Spanish aviation services company Avincis for 920 million pounds from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Investindustrial Group.

headline: Enlisting a Computer to Battle Cancers, One by One
abstract: Once you decode a tumor’s genome, what’s next? Oncologists hope that IBM’s Watson will help them find drugs for patients’ particular brain cancer mix.
lead_paragraph: When Robert B. Darnell was a graduate student in the early 1980s, he spent a year sequencing a tiny fragment of DNA. Now Dr. Darnell is an oncologist and the president of the New York Genome Center, where the DNA-sequencing machines can decode his grad-school fragment in less than a ten-thousandth of a second.

headline: UBS Said to Suspend Six Traders in Currency Review
abstract: The Swiss bank has placed on leave three traders in New York, two in Zurich and one in Singapore as part of its internal review into potential manipulation of the currency markets, according to people familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – UBS has suspended six additional traders on three continents as an investigation into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day currency markets widens, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Criticism, and Rare Words of Support, as China Watches Taiwan Protests
abstract: Hu Jia, a dissident who is under house arrest in Beijing, said he supported the demonstrators in Taipei and urged mainland Chinese students to emulate them.
lead_paragraph: The occupation of Taiwan’s legislature by students protesting the handling of a trade pact with China has been condemned by Chinese state media and in many comments online, but some democracy advocates on the Chinese mainland have endorsed the movement, calling it an inspiration to their efforts.

headline: I.M.F. Prepares $18 Billion in Loans for Ukraine
abstract: The deal is intended to get the new government over a big hurdle of coming debt obligations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After three weeks of urgent negotiations with the interim government of Ukraine and in an atmosphere of great power competition, the International Monetary Fund announced on Thursday an agreement to provide up to $18 billion in loans over two years to prevent the country’s default.

headline: Daily Report: Inventor Behind Oculus Rift, a Virtual Reality Sensation
abstract: Facebook’s acquisition of Oculus VR has brought attention to its co-founder Palmer Luckey and the Southern California tech scene where his company took root.
lead_paragraph: Palmer Luckey, a baby-faced 21-year-old college dropout, figured out how to build a virtual reality headset so exciting that it became a sensation on Kickstarter, the crowdfunding site, raising a staggering $2.4 million in 30 days, Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: Quiet Formula One Cars Spark a Noisy Debate
abstract: New hybrid engine technology reduces the familiar roar at Grand Prix races, but among both insiders and fans, not everyone thinks the silence is golden.
lead_paragraph: As Formula One prepares for its second race of the season on Sunday, the Malaysian Grand Prix in Sepang, it feels like business as usual despite the radical new set of technical regulations introduced by the series.

headline: What I Have Learned About Pitching for Investment Capital
abstract: Before going out this time, I worked with consultants who insisted that I rewrite my deck and adjust my presentation.
lead_paragraph: When I started Posse in 2010, I knew I’d have to raise money, which meant pitching to investors. I attended a few start-up events and watched YouTube videos showing other people pitching ideas. I’d never used PowerPoint, and the night before my first pitch, I called up a friend to find out how it worked. I designed a simple deck and stayed up all night rehearsing.

headline: An Exchange of Views, Some in Accord
abstract: President Obama and Pope Francis on Thursday skirted social issues that have generated tension between some Roman Catholic leaders and the president.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — President Obama and Pope Francis on Thursday skirted social issues that have generated tension between some Roman Catholic leaders and the American president, opting instead for a nearly hourlong discussion that touched on income inequality, the conflict raging in Syria, the persecution of Christians around the world and the elusiveness of global peace.

headline: 529 Reasons to Doubt Egyptian Justice
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Attacks on Police', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: The mass death sentence was at once brutal, tragic, absurd — and most likely futile.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — It was the kind of mass death sentence that seems to come from another time and place. But the news on Monday that an Egyptian judge had handed down a verdict condemning 529 people to execution was all too real, even as the particulars of the case, the trial and the public reaction all conjured a sense of what could be called Egypt’s current brand of magical realism. In the end, Judge Saeed Elgazar’s gesture was at once brutal, tragic, absurd — and most likely futile.

headline: Confrontation Rumors, Easily Debunked, Touch a Nerve
abstract: A fabricated narrative about Michelle Obama’s visit to China has exposed the anti-American sentiment nurtured by many Chinese nationalists, some of whom occupy influential positions in government and higher education.
lead_paragraph: It was just after Michelle Obama, the American first lady, had extolled the glories of free speech, during a talk last Saturday at the prestigious Peking University, that the student allegedly blurted out her sarcastic retort to the guest of honor.

headline: A Failure for Citigroup
abstract: The Federal Reserve rejected Citigroup’s capital plans. | The chief executive of King Digital Entertainment remained optimistic after shares of his company fell nearly 16 percent on their first day of public trading. | Corporations are pressing law firms to tighten their cyber security. | Reverse mortgages are stinging heirs.
lead_paragraph: CITIGROUP FAILS FED STRESS TEST  |  For the second time in three years, the Federal Reserve rejected Citigroup’s plans to manage its capital, an embarrassing blow that could derail the plans of Michael Corbat, the bank’s chief executive, to rehabilitate the bank, Michael Corkery writes in DealBook. Citigroup was the only one of the nation’s top five banks that failed to persuade the Fed to bless its plans for shareholder payouts.

headline: Microsoft to Offer Office for iPad, Maybe a Bit Late
abstract: Owners of Apple’s tablet will be able to use Word, Excel, PowerPoint and other popular productivity tools — but they still may not want to.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of the most lucrative software franchises in history, Microsoft Office, has finally come to the most influential computing device of the last few years, the iPad.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Lenten Song’
abstract: The poem “Lenten Song” by Phillis Levin and the article “An Online Generation Redefines Mourning” by Hannah Seligson appear in this Poetry Pairing.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Poetry Pairing features “Lenten Song” by Phillis Levin and the article “An Online Generation Redefines Mourning” by Hannah Seligson.

headline: Hodinkee, Watch Cheerleader
abstract: Benjamin Clymer launched the watch website Hodinkee in 2008, at age 25, and it has become a hub for fans and advertisers.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Clymer introduced the watch website Hodinkee in 2008, at age 25. It has grown into a hub for fans and advertisers.

headline: Dealing With Unwanted Windows Updates
abstract: Plus, adding shortcuts to Mac programs not on the dock.
lead_paragraph: Q. In Windows 7, the Windows Update service keeps trying to install an “important” security update for Microsoft Office 2007 and then tells me it failed to install the fix. I don’t even use Office 2007 anymore, so how can I stop these failed efforts?

headline: U.S. to Shrink Stake in Ally Financial
abstract: The Treasury Department plans to sell 95 million shares of the former financing arm of General Motors in an initial public offering.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department is preparing to reduce its stake in Ally Financial by more than half, through an initial public offering of stock.

headline: Biking to Dollar Beer Night
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A passenger on a one-speed realized she and her friend were the bicyclists people hated, but she couldn’t help loving the ride.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Baxter to Split Into 2 Health Care Companies
abstract: Baxter International plans to spin off its biopharmaceuticals business to shareholders by the middle of next year.
lead_paragraph: Splitsville has been a popular destination for big United States corporations of late.

headline: In Our Pages: March 28
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Wall street reports a slow day in 1914; British peacekeepers are received reluctantly in Cyprus in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Wall Street Has a Dull Day

headline: Nafta Still Bedevils Unions
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: Unions remain deeply suspicious of trade pacts, which they say exacerbate incentives for local, state and federal authorities to artificially maintain low labor costs.
lead_paragraph: Two decades after its enactment, the North American Free Trade Agreement — better known as Nafta — remains a source of deep disagreement among economists.

headline: Consortium Wants Standards for ‘Internet of Things’
abstract: Some of the largest multinational corporations have formed a global standards body intended to speed the connection of factories, oil rigs and hospitals to intricate systems of sensors and computers.
lead_paragraph: Attention: Internet of Things. For better or worse, big boys are in the room.

headline: Growth in the Fourth Quarter Is Revised Up a Shade, to 2.6%
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Consumer Behavior']
abstract: Gross domestic product in the last months of 2013 was revised up from 2.4 percent, with a 3.3 percent rise in consumer spending brightening the report.
lead_paragraph: The American economy grew by 2.6 percent in the final months of 2013, the Commerce Department said on Thursday, a slight uptick from its previous estimate but still well below the pace of growth recorded in the third quarter.

headline: 3 Things Parents Wish Teachers Knew: We Can Handle the Truth
abstract: Teachers wish parents knew that our children can do more than we let them, while parents wish teachers would be more honest — and understand that homework has real costs.
lead_paragraph: After I wrote “5 Things Teachers Wish Parents Knew,” parents started filling my inbox with the things they wish teachers knew — and why not? The ideal parent-teacher conference is an opportunity to give and take, a time and place for both teachers and parents to share their observations. Here’s what the parents who got in touch wish their children’s teachers knew:

headline: Former Prime Minister Announces Candidacy for President of Ukraine
abstract: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the polarizing former prime minister, has long harbored presidential ambitions and will be the most widely known contender in the election.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the former prime minister, said Thursday that she would run for president in elections to be held in May.

headline: Tweets About Music to Get Their Own Billboard Chart
abstract: Twitter and Billboard plan to create the Billboard Twitter Real-Time Charts: continuously updated lists of the songs being discussed and shared the most on Twitter in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Chatter about music is everywhere on Twitter. Soon there will be a Billboard chart to rank all of it.

headline: Life Is an Audition
abstract: Michelle Williams, a movie star with practically no experience as a singer and dancer, is making her Broadway debut as the world’s best-known second-rate nightclub performer.
lead_paragraph: As she’d be the first to tell you, Michelle Williams, a movie star with practically no experience as a singer and dancer, was not an obvious choice to play the nightclub entertainer Sally Bowles in “Cabaret.” She is making her Broadway debut in the role, at Studio 54, in the Roundabout Theater Company’s resuscitation of its legendary 1998 production, which brings back Alan Cumming in his Tony-winning turn as the Emcee. But she got the job only after Emma Stone (who does have a modest background in musical theater and, because of “The Amazing Spider-Man,” is more recognizable as well) dropped out.

headline: Rain, Heavy at Times
abstract: Russell Crowe stars in “Noah,” Darren Aronofsky’s adaptation of the Old Testament story, which brings blockbuster spectacle and narrative liberties to the story.
lead_paragraph: The information supplied about Noah in the Book of Genesis is scant — barely enough for a Hollywood pitch meeting, much less a feature film — but his story is among the strangest and scariest in the Hebrew Bible. At its center is what appears to be an unnerving example of divine self-doubt. Disgusted with his creation, God decides to wipe the slate clean and start again, only to relent and allow Noah, a 500-something-year-old father of three, to save his family and a boatload of animals.

headline: Obama Meets Pope Francis
abstract: President Obama and Pope Francis met for the first time on Thursday at the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Pope Francis met for the first time on Thursday at the Vatican.

headline: Michelle Obama in China
abstract: She was not as confrontational as Hillary Clinton, who visited Beijing as first lady in 1995.
lead_paragraph: Solo trips to foreign countries by first ladies always draw scrutiny and sometimes controversy. Although Michelle Obama has not escaped some domestic carping for visiting China, she seems to have hit most of the right notes during a week of travel, including emphasizing the importance of human rights and free speech.

headline: U.N. Approves Investigation of Civil War in Sri Lanka
abstract: The agency voted to open an independent international investigation of possible war crimes in Sri Lanka’s brutal civil war with Tamil Tiger rebels.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Overriding fierce objections from Sri Lanka, the United Nations Human Rights Council voted on Thursday to open an international investigation into possible war crimes by both the Sri Lankan government and the Tamil Tiger rebels in the final stages of a 26-year civil war that ended in 2009.

headline: Emma Donoghue: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Frog Music” was happy to hear that President Obama bought her novel “Room,” but admits: “I’m tormented by the notion that it’s still in a groaning pile of books by his bed.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Frog Music” was happy to hear that President Obama bought her novel “Room,” but admits: “I’m tormented by the notion that it’s still in a groaning pile of books by his bed.”

headline: 36 Hours in Jamaica
abstract: Start in Kingston for cocktails and culture, then head north through verdant landscapes to sample Jamaican cuisine and catch some sun by the sea.
lead_paragraph: Sun, sand and sea: a timeless recipe, readily available throughout the Caribbean. But sun, sand, sea — and city? Visit Jamaica to indulge in that one. Sure, the resplendent island has a range of resort areas where one can merrily get one’s beach-bum on. But it’s also got Kingston, a woefully underrated, misunderstood metropolis. Yes, there are slums and there is crime. But there is also cosmopolitan culture, pulsating night life, a booming local music scene and a host of other urban delights. With a new airline (Fly Jamaica), a 130-room Marriott under construction in the island’s capital, modish-yet-playful new lounges in both international airports (Club Kingston and Club Mobay, decked out in sprightly Jamaican colors) and restaurant openings across the island, it’s an ideal time to take a side of city with your sand, and heed the tourism board’s Bob Marley-inspired mantra, trite yet spot on: Come to Jamaica and feel all right.

headline: A Taste of a Denver Art District
abstract: The River North Art District, or RiNO, is not only home to dozens of galleries and artists’ studios, but restaurants, bars and music, too.
lead_paragraph: Warmly embraced by youthful art enthusiasts in Denver, the River North Art District, known as RiNO, is in a former industrial area northeast of downtown. RiNO is the still-gritty home to dozens of galleries and artists’ studios, but the area now has cafes, restaurants, bars, music and a profusion of craft breweries. RiNO landed on the map in 2005, when a group of local artists trademarked the name for their cooperative, and it caught on as a moniker for the neighborhood. A highlight: the first Friday of each month, dozens of galleries open late for patrons (information: rivernorthart.com).

headline: David Chase Will Discuss ‘Sopranos’ at Museum Screening
abstract: The show’s creator will make a rare public appearance at the Museum of the Moving Image.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a dedicated “Sopranos” fan who won’t stop believing in the possibility of getting closure on that influential HBO drama, this may be as near as you’ll come to it. On April 30, the show’s creator, David Chase, will make a rare public appearance at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, where he will present the only two episodes of the series that he directed: the pilot, which introduced James Gandolfini as the emotionally conflicted mob boss Tony Soprano; and the finale, “Made in America,” in which Tony’s story came to an ambiguous ending in a New Jersey restaurant. The museum said in a news release that its screening of these two episodes would be followed by a conversation between Mr. Chase and David Schwartz, the museum’s chief curator, which, with any luck, might fill in a few further details about television’s most talked-about smash-cut to black. Tickets for the event are expected to go on sale Tuesday. For more information, go to movingimage.us.

headline: History Gives Other Cases of G.M.’s Behavior
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Corporations', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A deeper look at the ethics that may make a company behave the way General Motors did in the years before it recalled 1.6 million cars with a potentially deadly defect.
lead_paragraph: Four decades ago, Edward Heath, then the prime minister of Britain, rose in Parliament to denounce “the unpleasant and unacceptable face of capitalism.”

headline: Call to Artists on Crimea Echoes Soviet Ways
abstract: After Russian officials pressured the cultural elite to bend to their demands, opponents of the Crimea annexation derided the move with their own diatribe.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s Ministry of Culture recently called leading artists and intellectuals to suggest that they endorse a petition hailing President Vladimir V. Putin’s annexation of Crimea, setting off impassioned accusations from the literati that the Kremlin was resurrecting repugnant Soviet methods.

headline: Thai Satellite Detects Floating Objects
abstract: The executive director of the Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency, Anond Snidvongs, said that Thai satellites had detected about 300 floating objects in the southern Indian Ocean.
lead_paragraph: The executive director of the Geo-Informatics and Space Technology Development Agency, Anond Snidvongs, said that Thai satellites had detected about 300 floating objects in the southern Indian Ocean.

headline: With Banking, What Happens in Europe Does Not Stay in Europe
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The creation of a Single Resolution Mechanism to resolve a failing bank in Europe is an important step forward, but it faces a number of hurdles, writes Mayra Rodríguez Valladares in an Another View column.
lead_paragraph: Mayra Rodríguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a New York-based capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm. She is also a faculty member at Financial Markets World.

headline: Adviser on Dell Buyout Questions a Tumultuous Process
abstract: At the Tulane Corporate Law Institute, an adviser on Dell’s leveraged buyout wondered whether the myriad steps the board took to ensure the integrity of the sales process could have been improved.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — By the time the sale of Dell Inc. to its namesake founder was completed last October, the computer company’s board felt like it had been through hell.

headline: Report Details Claim by Ally: Christie Knew of Bridge Lane Closings
abstract: An inquiry by lawyers for Gov. Chris Christie found he did not recall the conversation and found no evidence that he was involved in the scheme, which snarled traffic in Fort Lee, N.J.
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority official who directed the shutdown of lanes to the George Washington Bridge said that he informed Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey about it at a Sept. 11 memorial ceremony while the lanes were closed, according to an internal review that lawyers for the governor released on Thursday.

headline: Navin Nagiah of DNN: Intellectual Honesty Is the Best Policy
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Authenticity is important if you want your organization to do well, says the chief of a web content software company.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Navin Nagiah, chief executive of DNN, a web content software company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Internal Review of Bridge Scandal
abstract: The report, commissioned by Gov. Chris Christie’s office after the George Washington Bridge scandal erupted, was made available on Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: The report, commissioned by Gov. Chris Christie’s office after the George Washington Bridge scandal erupted, was made available on Thursday morning.

headline: A Festive Moment When Time Pauses
abstract: Ceremonies, public and private, are one way that people mark the passage of time.
lead_paragraph: Ceremonies, public and private, are one way that people mark the passage of time.

headline: Jobs and Health Bills Make for Busy Day at Capitol
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: A bipartisan compromise is reached in one chamber, while hopes are dashed for agreement in the other chamber.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday voted to move forward with a long-stalled proposal to extend aid to more than two million people whose unemployment assistance ran out late last year.

headline: Today in Small Business: Can Bookstores Survive?
abstract: Etsy collaborates with the enemy. Connecticut raises its minimum wage. How to find the right accountant for your business.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Local-Guide Requirement Considered for Nepal Peaks
abstract: The goal is to increase local employment, and to reduce on-mountain clashes between climbers and Sherpas.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Struggling to cope with a crush of climbers and garbage on Mount Everest, Nepal is also considering a proposal that would require every foreign climber to hire a local guide to ascend the country’s highest peaks.

headline: Tate Pledges to Return Looted Constable Painting to Family
abstract: The decision by the Tate to return a looted paining by John Constable came in response to a report issued by a British government panel.
lead_paragraph: The Tate gallery in Britain pledged on Thursday to return a painting by John Constable to the heirs of a Jewish Hungarian art collector after a government panel concluded that the institution had failed to properly vet the ownership of the 1824 work, “Beaching a Boat, Brighton.”

headline: The Secret History of Homoerotic Illustration
abstract: A new show at SoHo’s Leslie Lohman Museum unearths a trove of little-seen images from underground gay magazines of the 1950s through the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Before Abercrombie & Fitch catalogs and Lady Gaga videos mainstreamed homoerotic imagery, some of fashion’s most talented illustrators had shadow careers from the 1950s through the 1990s drawing for underground gay magazines such as Physique Pictorial and, later, more overt porn glossies such as Mandate, Honcho and Torso. The Internet, with its abundance of porn, killed those titles, but a diverse trove of illustrations from their pages will be on display beginning Friday at the Leslie Lohman Museum of Gay and Lesbian Art in SoHo, in the winkingly titled show “Stroke: From Under the Mattress to the Museum Walls.” Curated by Robert Richards, himself a longtime illustrator of fashion and homoerotic imagery, the show aims to exhibit “quality artwork that had to be hidden away for many years,” says Hunter O’Hanian, the museum’s director.

headline: Intel Exits a Data Analysis Business and Invests in Another One
abstract: The world’s biggest chip company is out of another business, a framework for big data analysis called Hadoop, and refocusing on how to sell more chips.
lead_paragraph: For a company getting out of the data analysis business, Intel is spending a lot of money on a data analysis business.

headline: Wu-Tang Clan Plans to Sell Just One Copy of a New Album
abstract: The group will sell a single copy of a 31-track double album.
lead_paragraph: As any record collector can tell you, rarities – particularly one-of-a-kind pieces like Elvis Presley’s 1954 acetate pressing of “That’s Alright Mama,” or the single-copy 1958 disc containing “That’ll Be the Day” and “In Spite of All the Danger” by the Quarrymen, who became the Beatles – are holy grails, discs that could command fortunes. But those discs acquired their value long after they were made, once the musicians who recorded them became hot properties, with history giving them a special patina.

headline: Vote by U.N. General Assembly Isolates Russia
abstract: A resolution on Ukraine rejecting Russia’s annexation of the Crimean Peninsula as illegal passed overwhelmingly.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — In the first barometer of global condemnation of Russia’s annexation of Crimea, Ukraine and its Western backers persuaded a large majority of countries in the United Nations General Assembly on Thursday to dismiss the annexation as illegal, even as Russia sought to rally world support for the idea of self-determination.

headline: Washington Slope Had a History of Slides
abstract: Aerial photography of the area destroyed by Saturday’s landslide shows how the land has eroded over the years.
lead_paragraph: Aerial photography of the area destroyed by Saturday’s landslide shows how the land has eroded over the years.

headline: Image of the Day: March 27
abstract: India has been formally declared polio-free with no new case of the disease detected in the country in the last three years.

headline: New Mexico Is Reaping a Bounty in Pecans as Other States Struggle
abstract: Thanks to sophisticated irrigation systems and an arid climate that helps ward off crop disease, New Mexico farmers are enjoying a bumper crop and high prices.
lead_paragraph: LAS CRUCES, N.M. — On the edge of this parched southern New Mexico city, Phillip Arnold surveyed his rows of neatly pruned pecan trees with a satisfied smile.

headline: Walk-On Earns His Spot With Virginia
abstract: Jeff Jones said he was O.K. with not being allowed to sit on the bench with his Virginia teammates at Madison Square Garden — his role is to make his teammates better at practice.
lead_paragraph: At four days old, Jeff Jones had brain surgery to relieve a blood clot. While he was in high school, complications from an appendectomy led to multiple follow-up operations and lengthy hospitalizations.

headline: Getting Poetry to the People in Miami
abstract: The O, Miami Poetry Festival has devised some unusual ways to flood the city with poetry.
lead_paragraph: If you live in Miami and you do not read, recite or listen to a poem in April, something has gone seriously wrong. For the third year, the O, Miami Poetry Festival will flood the city with words, using any pretext to accomplish its mission of putting all 2.6 million residents of Miami-Dade County in contact with at least one poem.

headline: Congress Approves Aid of $1 Billion for Ukraine
abstract: The measure passed after the White House dropped efforts to tie it to an overhaul of the International Monetary Fund negotiated by President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House and the Senate voted overwhelmingly on Thursday to approve a $1 billion aid package for Ukraine, but Congress’s near unanimity on its modest package of aid and sanctions on Russia masked deep divisions on what the government should do next to confront President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: TPG Said to Be in Talks to Invest in Chobani
abstract: The fast-growing yogurt maker has reportedly been seeking to raise capital to help it grow internationally. The structure of a potential investment from TPG has yet to be finalized, a person briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: The private equity giant TPG is in advanced talks to invest in Chobani, the fast-growing yogurt maker in upstate New York, two people briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Wheelies: The Empire State Mustang Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Empire State Building (Manhattan, NY)']
