headline: Seeking to Ban Online Betting, G.O.P. Donor Tests Influence
keywords: ['Gambling', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The casino mogul Sheldon Adelson’s drive to outlaw online gambling has divided the gambling industry and has become a test of his clout in Washington.
lead_paragraph: A push by the billionaire casino magnate Sheldon G. Adelson to outlaw online gambling has ignited a bitter civil war in the gambling industry, dividing one of Washington’s most powerful interest groups and posing a major test of the Republican donor’s political clout.

headline: Most Chinese Cities Fail Minimum Air Quality Standards, Study Says
abstract: Only three of 74 cities monitored managed to meet standards set by the government, with most of the polluted cities in northern China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Only three of the 74 Chinese cities monitored by the central government managed to meet official minimum standards for air quality last year, the Ministry of Environmental Protection announced this week, underscoring the country’s severe pollution problems.

headline: It’s All About the Amor
abstract: By some coincidence, March has suddenly turned into Latin pop blockbuster season.
lead_paragraph: March suddenly turned into Latin pop blockbuster season. By some coincidence, arena-filling stars who tend to take years between releases emerged almost simultaneously with new albums: Shakira and Juanes, who are both from Colombia, Enrique Iglesias from Spain and the reggaeton rapper Wisin from Puerto Rico. Romeo Santos, the Dominican bachata singer who was born in the Bronx and was Aventura’s lead singer for 17 years, beat the rush by releasing his second solo studio album in February.

headline: Times Minute | The Papal Visit
abstract: On the Minute, The Times’s White House Photographer Doug Mills reports on the first meeting of President Obama and Pope Francis in Vatican.
lead_paragraph: On the Minute, The Times’s White House Photographer Doug Mills reports on the first meeting of President Obama and Pope Francis in Vatican.

headline: Indonesians in Queens Are Beginning to Learn About Film on Genocide
keywords: ['Indonesian-Americans', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Movies']
abstract: In New York City’s small but growing population of Indonesians, concentrated in Elmhurst, word has been spreading about “The Act of Killing,” a documentary about the nation’s 1965 genocide.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday afternoon, Mas Pratomo, 83, sips tea at Fay Da Bakery on Justice Avenue, in Elmhurst, Queens, and catches up with fellow Indonesians. He never forgets to list the day’s attendees in his journal.

headline: I.M.F. Announces Bailout for Ukraine
abstract: The International Monetary Fund announced an agreement to provide up to $18 billion in assistance over two years to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund announced an agreement to provide up to $18 billion in assistance over two years to Ukraine.

headline: CitizenM Hotel to Open in New York
abstract: A Citizen M hotel in New York will be the chain’s first in the United States.
lead_paragraph: CitizenM, the five-unit Amsterdam-based chain of stylish and affordable hotels, will make its debut in the United States when its Times Square outpost opens this week in New York.

headline: Seamy Side of a Sport: Prodding Horses With Shocks
abstract: The devices, also called batteries or machines, conduct electrical current to shock a racehorse into running faster and have long been part of the sport’s seamier lore.
lead_paragraph: It is called a buzzer, a battery or a machine: It is a device the size of a lighter that conducts electrical current and shocks a racehorse into running faster. It is prohibited at American racetracks but has long been a part of the sport’s seamier lore.

headline: Loggers Join in Search for Washington Landslide Victims
abstract: Amid a vast and unforgiving mud plain, loggers have become a crucial part of the rescue and recovery effort, their presence illustrating the mounting desperation with its pace.
lead_paragraph: DARRINGTON, Wash. — Two days after a giant landslide engulfed the small community of Oso and rescue workers struggled to find either survivors or victims amid the sea of muck, a group of volunteers — many of them loggers — drove along back roads and trails on Monday to reach the site. They immediately began to dig, looking for their neighbors and, in some cases, friends and relatives.

headline: The Bird, and Everything That Comes With It
abstract: The almost-all-poultry restaurant in Harlem has an idiosyncratic lure with the atmosphere of an Old World inn.
lead_paragraph: The first time I ordered cockscomb — that fleshy crest on a rooster’s head whose red flush telegraphs virility — it arrived on my plate at Mountain Bird looking like a tiny deep-fried valentine, with two plump lobes where I had expected a spiky stegosauran frill.

headline: New York City’s Jobless Rate Rises for First Time in Nearly 2 Years
abstract: The city has been steadily adding jobs for more than three years, but that growth slowed in the first months of 2014, according to figures from the State Labor Department.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate rose slightly in February to 7.9 percent, the first monthly increase in nearly two years, according to figures released Thursday by the State Labor Department.

headline: Soccer Tourism: World Comes Out for Clásico
abstract: The crowd for Sunday’s Clásico in Madrid included thousands of foreign fans who bought tickets to the game on the secondary market and spent large sums for travel and accommodations.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Hours before Sunday’s Clásico, the match between Real Madrid and Barcelona, Juan Manuel Alfaro strode into the business lounge of a hotel near Santiago Bernabéu Stadium.

headline: Too Much Faith In Models, Capital Taxation Edition
abstract: Useful assumptions aren’t necessarily The Truth.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday I offered a rousing defense of the use of simplified models in economics. So maybe it’s appropriate that today I offer a caution: you should use models, but you should always remember that they’re models, and always beware of conclusions that depend too much on the simplifying assumptions. And I have a case in point, which ties into one of my other big concerns: the appropriate taxation of capital income.

headline: James R. Schlesinger, Willful Aide to Three Presidents, Is Dead at 85
abstract: Mr. Schlesinger, a tough strategist, served in posts that included the secretary of defense and energy, as well as head of the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: James R. Schlesinger, a tough Cold War strategist who served as secretary of defense under Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Gerald R. Ford and became the nation’s first secretary of energy under President Jimmy Carter, died on Thursday in Baltimore. He was 85.

headline: A Nasty Corporate Divorce, With Insults Traded on Twitter
abstract: The split between Bumi, a London-listed coal company, and its co-founders is turning unpleasant and public, with a war of words hurled across social media.
lead_paragraph: Like divorces by couples, corporate separations are rarely pretty.

headline: Obamacare Fails to Fail
abstract: Don’t tell anyone, but things are looking OK.
lead_paragraph: Update: And exchange-based enrollments pass 6 million. Gaba now projects 6.5 million by 3/31, and with the extensions it will go higher. The original CBO projection of 7 million now looks basically right, despite the website woes.

headline: It’s Crow-Killing Time in Upstate New York, and Elsewhere
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Crows (Birds)', 'Firearms', 'Hunting and Trapping']
abstract: Varied views on a weekend crow-shooting contest.
lead_paragraph: It’s crow-killing time in upstate New York this weekend, and in many places around the country this spring. My friend Suzie Gilbert, a bird rehabilitator and writer (read “Flyaway”), has written a blog post criticizing this form of recreation. [Update, March 28 | She’s added a followup piece that has valuable new elements.]

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: bone-building exercises, smoking rates and norovirus. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: bone-building exercises, smoking rates and norovirus. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: As Rescues Push On, Video of Landslide Survivors
abstract: A 78-year-old man and a four-year-old boy were found alive early in the rescue effort, but emergency responders have said they are not giving up hope of finding other survivors.
lead_paragraph: A 78-year-old man who survived the landslide in Washington described how he called out to his wife, Linda, when they were both buried in the mud and debris, encouraging her to dig. But she never replied to his entreaties.

headline: Doctor Priorities vs. Patient Priorities
abstract: For my patient, his wide-angle lens took in the whole of his life, of which diabetes was one small part. For me, in the 20 minutes allotted, my lens was narrowly focused on the disease that posed the gravest and most immediate risk to his health.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, a middle-aged patient came to my office for a checkup. He cheerfully admitted that he hadn’t been paying attention to his diabetes for the last few years. He’d stopped taking his medicine, stopped seeing his doctors, stopped thinking about the disease altogether. When I checked his blood sugar in the office, it wasn’t just a little elevated — it was four times the normal level.

headline: A Shoe-In for Spring
abstract: The 23-year-old designer Dora Teymur debuts a modernist footwear range that feels just right in an oversaturated market.
lead_paragraph: Couture sneakers, monster platforms, luxury locker-room slides: it’s all too much sometimes. The right everyday shoe — not too basic, not too crazy — is hard to find in today’s overheated footwear market, but the spring offerings from the 23-year-old designer Dora Teymur of Dorateymur stand out for their sculptural quality and ease of wear. The Turkish-born, London-based designer, a recent graduate of Cordwainers at London College of Fashion, calls them “slightly nostalgic shoes that don’t tire your eyes.” He claims not to be influenced by his heritage: “I suppose the only Orientalist element in my work,” he says dryly, “is myself.” And he makes sure to emphasize comfort in his designs for women — “especially,” he notes, “now that I’ve started to wear them.”

headline: All Nippon Airways Splits $16.6 Billion Aircraft Order
abstract: Boeing won about 80 percent of the order with All Nippon Airways of Japan and kept Airbus from encroaching further on its sales of large wide-body jets.
lead_paragraph: Boeing and Airbus each won something to brag about in their latest face-off, as All Nippon Airways of Japan said on Thursday that it would split a $16.6 billion order between the two plane makers.

headline: Letters: Ozick on Malamud
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Bernard Malamud’s work, John B. Judis’s “Genesis” and Blake Bailey’s new memoir.
lead_paragraph: Ozick on Malamud

headline: Our Fifth Annual New York Times Found Poetry Student Contest
abstract: Celebrate the new season with our oldest blog tradition, and one we’re thrilled to see teachers across the curriculum embrace. Poems can come from anything ever published in The New York Times, and are due on April 29.
lead_paragraph: Update: June 3 | Winners have been announced!

headline: James Bond Cars Take Up Residence at London Film Museum
abstract: Several Aston Martins, a couple of BMWs and even a jet pack are among the memorabilia on display through the end of 2014.
lead_paragraph: Beginning last week, the London Film Museum began displaying a number of the cars and other machines featured in James Bond films over the last 50 years. Called “Bond in Motion,” the exhibition had been housed last year in Britain’s National Motor Museum, but now the collection of movie cars, props and memorabilia will be displayed in London.

headline: Conscious Uncoupling for Drug Makers
abstract: In the wake of Baxter’s split, Merck, Bayer and Johnson & Johnson may find it hard not to jump on the bandwagon, says Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Baxter International has put conscious uncoupling on pharma’s radar.

headline: Falcone Accused of Using Company Assets in Cash Crunch
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Faced with a flurry of investor redemptions in the weeks after an S.E.C. settlement, Philip Falcone used his publicly listed company to “bail himself out,” an investor contends in a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: An investor has accused the hedge fund billionaire Philip A. Falcone of using his publicly listed company “to bail himself out” after a reaching an $18 million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: American Couple on Qatar Sentencing
abstract: Matthew Huang, an American sentenced to jail in a case involving his adopted daughter’s death, and his adviser, Eric Volz, spoke after the court’s decision in Doha.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Huang, an American sentenced to jail in a case involving his adopted daughter’s death, and his adviser, Eric Volz, spoke after the court’s decision in Doha.

headline: U.N. Calls Annexation of Crimea Illegal
abstract: Ukraine’s foreign minister, Andriy Deshchytsia, decried Russia’s actions, as Thomas Mayr-Harting, the E.U. ambassador to the U.N., and Samantha Power, the American ambassador, supported the U.N. vote.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s foreign minister, Andriy Deshchytsia, decried Russia’s actions, as Thomas Mayr-Harting, the E.U. ambassador to the U.N., and Samantha Power, the American ambassador, supported the U.N. vote.

headline: Updates on Washington Landslide
abstract: Washington State authorities spoke about the current number of deaths and said that crews were still working to recover bodies after a deadly landslide in Oso.
lead_paragraph: Washington State authorities spoke about the current number of deaths and said that crews were still working to recover bodies after a deadly landslide in Oso.

headline: An Exaltation of Birds and He Who Adored Them
abstract: “Audubon’s Aviary: Parts Unknown” at the New-York Historical Society shows John James Audubon as an established artist-naturalist with the zeal of an amateur and the curiosity of a scientist.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never met an animal I didn’t like. And birds? Bring them on, which is what the New-York Historical Society is doing with a whoosh of wings and cries in “Audubon’s Aviary: Parts Unknown (Part II of the Complete Flock),” the second of three sequential exhibitions of the museum’s complete set of more than 400 paintings by John James Audubon, all models for his grand book “The Birds of America.” It is widely regarded as the most ambitious example of color engraving with aquatint ever made.

headline: Report Says Mother Warned Queens School to Watch Autistic Boy
abstract: The results of an investigation detailed a series of errors and oversights in the disappearance of Avonte Oquendo, 14, whose remains were found in January.
lead_paragraph: The mother of a teenager with autism who disappeared from his school in Queens last fall and whose remains were found in January had warned a teacher that he needed to be watched at all times because he “likes to run” and would leave the building.

headline: Project to Improve Poor Children’s Intellect Led to Better Health, Data Show
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Education (K-12)', 'Babies and Infants', 'Day Care Centers', 'Medicine and Health', 'Longevity', 'Child Care', 'Poverty']
abstract: The Carolina Abecedarian Project, started in 1972, offered full-time day care for babies. Four decades later, those babies had grown up to be far healthier than a control group.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, researchers in North Carolina started following two groups of babies from poor families. In the first group, the children were given full-time day care up to age 5 that included most of their daily meals, talking, games and other stimulating activities. The other group, aside from baby formula, got nothing. The scientists were testing whether the special treatment would lead to better cognitive abilities in the long run.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘The Raid 2’
abstract: Gareth Evans narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Gareth Evans narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: White House Says Health Care Rolls Top Goal: 6 Million
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: With the deadline on Monday, the number of newly covered has exceeded the administration’s goal for enrollment — revised downward from seven million.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House said on Thursday that more than six million people had signed up for medical insurance plans under President Obama’s health care law, exceeding the administration’s revised goal for enrollment by the Monday deadline.

headline: The Gun Report: March 27, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, which frequently splits 5-to-4, issued a unanimous ruling yesterday regarding guns and domestic abuse: People convicted of misdemeanor domestic violence offenses, however minor, are barred under federal law from possessing a gun.

headline: The Avoiding Tough Financing Decisions Act of 2014
abstract: The House passed a bill today that would stave off for another year a drastic reduction in Medicare payments to doctors.
lead_paragraph: In a strong show of timidity, using a voice vote that cloaked the identity of those voting for and against, the House of Representatives passed a bill today that would stave off for another year a drastic reduction in Medicare payments to doctors. The bill now goes to the Senate. It must take action before April 1, or a 24-percent cut in payments will take effect and greatly diminish the willingness of doctors to treat Medicare patients.

headline: At Upfronts, E! Network Again Promises Its First Scripted Series
abstract: “The Royals,” set in modern-day Britain with a fictional royal family, has been introduced to advertisers before. Now the plan is for a debut in 2015.
lead_paragraph: If the E! cable channel were to be graded on keeping its promises to introduce original scripted programming, the verdict would have to be F. Or, to be charitable, I for incomplete, as discussions of adding such series to the channel’s lineup of reality and talk shows date to its 2012-13 upfront presentation.

headline: Where Are the Sony Open Cameras? Mostly Trained on the Men
abstract: By the end of the Sony Open tennis tournament in Key Biscayne, Fla., 71 men’s matches will have been produced for television and streaming, compared with 26 women’s matches.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — At the sun-soaked Sony Open held on this island east of Miami, the women have not been able to shine quite as brightly as the men — at least to those watching on television.

headline: Ex-Finance Director of Dewey & LeBoeuf Says Its Chairman Feared Audit
abstract: Francis J. Canellas, the former finance chief of the bankrupt law firm, spoke to New York prosecutors after pleading guilty this year to taking part in a scheme to manipulate the firm’s financial statements.
lead_paragraph: Francis J. Canellas, the former finance director of the bankrupt law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf, who pleaded guilty this year to taking part in a scheme to manipulate the firm’s financial statements, told New York prosecutors that the firm’s former chairman, Steven Davis, had been nervous before meeting with an auditor to discuss the firm’s 2010 finances.

headline: Anti-Anxiety Drugs Tied to Higher Mortality
abstract: Sleeping pills were also linked to an increased risk of death in a large study.
lead_paragraph: A large study has linked several common anti-anxiety drugs and sleeping pills to an increased risk of death, although it’s not certain the drugs were the cause.

headline: Investigation Report on Avonte Oquendo
abstract: A report by the special commissioner of investigation for New York City’s school system showed a series of errors and oversights on how a 14-year-old boy with autism could leave his school undetected.
lead_paragraph: A report by the special commissioner of investigation for New York City’s school system showed a series of errors and oversights on how a 14-year-old boy with autism could leave his school undetected.

headline: Yoga Classes, Even With a Fused Spine
abstract: The Yoga Union Center for Backcare and Scoliosis in Manhattan was founded in 2007, based on an obvious need: “Everyone seemed to have a back problem,” Deborah Wolk said.
lead_paragraph: I WENT to yoga classes fairly often before I had a spinal fusion at 17. The poses helped with flexibility and relaxation, even if they didn’t have a straightening effect on my S-shaped scoliosis. But yoga didn’t have the same charm after surgery: The long rods and screws in my back kept me from curling like a cat or bending into a cobra pose.

headline: The Colorful Man Behind the Carved Eagles
abstract: A new book and exhibition delve into the persona of John Haley Bellamy, a 19th-century New England woodcarver best known for creating decorative eagles.
lead_paragraph: The 19th-century New England woodcarver John Haley Bellamy, best known for creating aggressive eagles out of pine blocks, has always been subject to conflicting tales. He has been “depicted alternately as a disciplined laborer and a helpless drunkard, a manic inventor and an aloof poet, an irresponsible pleasure-seeker and a devoted kinsman,” the historian James A. Craig writes in a new book, “American Eagle: The Bold Art & Brash Life of John Haley Bellamy” (Portsmouth Marine Society Press).

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘The Raid 2’
abstract: Gareth Evans narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Gareth Evans discusses his ideas behind a scene from “The Raid 2,” a sequel to his 2012 action thriller. This sequence involves a seasoned hitman (Yayan Ruhian) who is ambushed in a nightclub.

headline: A Tune as Parisian as Tin Pan Alley
abstract: While the song “April in Paris” conjures up the rebirth of springtime, its origins are more prosaic — or at least more American — than many might expect.
lead_paragraph: YEARNING for the charm of spring? For a warm embrace? Do you hear the sirens singing “April in Paris,” that old romantic chestnut in blossom?

headline: Appeals Court in Gupta Case Chooses Not to Admonish Bad Behavior
abstract: The court hearing the appeal of Rajat Gupta, former managing director of McKinsey & Company, did not take up the opportunity to make a statement about improper business conduct, David Zaring writes in Another View.
lead_paragraph: It was never going to be easy for Rajat K. Gupta, the former managing director of McKinsey & Company and board member of Goldman Sachs, to overturn his criminal conviction for insider trading. But the opinion of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was muted, suggesting that the judges did not seem to want to use the case to make a statement about the conduct they expect from businesspeople.

headline: Rules of Style | Inès de la Fressange on Dressing for Yourself and Why Bad Fashion Is a Good Thing
abstract: The French fashion icon discusses growing old gracefully and the secrets of her inimitable elegance.
lead_paragraph: While many might consider Inès de la Fressange a style icon, she insists, “I’m like every woman on earth when I wake up in the morning. I have the feeling that I don’t have the right things and I don’t know what to wear. And I feel terrible in everything I try!” Still, the French model, author and onetime muse to Karl Lagerfeld emerges most days with an effortless chic-meets-street look, which is one reason she is so uniquely suited for such varied roles as the brand ambassador for the French accessories house Roger Vivier and a collaborator with the Japanese fast-fashion brand Uniqlo (her collection of charming prints and easy knits arrived in stores last week).

headline: Contemplating Other People’s Pain
abstract: In Leslie Jamison’s new collection of essays, the author does not present herself as a moral role model.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Jamison has a balky heart. The medical name for her condition is SVT, or supraventricular tachycardia. “There was an extra electrical node,” her doctor explains, “sending out extra signals — beat, beat, beat — when it wasn’t supposed to.” She calls this her “tiny rogue beat box.”

headline: NBC News Hires Away Cynthia McFadden From ‘Nightline’
abstract: The long-serving anchor on ABC News will become a legal and investigative correspondent on NBC.
lead_paragraph: NBC News on Thursday plucked a long-serving anchor from ABC News, hiring Cynthia McFadden to be the network’s senior legal and investigative correspondent. She will leave ABC’s “Nightline,” where she has been an anchor for nine years.

headline: Soaking Up Ukrainian Culture in the East Village
abstract: The Ukrainian Museum offers both fine and folk art, archival material and educational programs devoted to Ukrainian culture here and abroad.
lead_paragraph: As the news from Ukraine has gone from bad to worse, the Miser has had to scramble, not just to keep up with breaking events, but also to familiarize himself with the broader historical and cultural forces at play.

headline: Molly Lowe: ‘Sorry, Excuse Me, Thank You’
abstract: Ms. Lowe’s audacious first New York solo is not for the agoraphobic.
lead_paragraph: The Suzanne Geiss Company

headline: Brian O’Doherty: ‘Connecting the...’
abstract: Mr. O’Doherty’s latest solo show is largely devoted to the earlier conceptual and language-based projects he made from the 1950s through the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: P!

headline: William Beckman
abstract: Mr. Beckman’s paintings keep eyes from wandering in several ways.
lead_paragraph: Forum

headline: ‘For Marian’
abstract: Six former protégés of Marian Griffith — the director of the Sculpture Center for nearly two decades — put together a show in which her adventurous taste lives on.
lead_paragraph: FiveMyles

headline: Norbert Prangenberg: ‘The Last Works’
abstract: When it came to making art, Prangenberg was largely self-taught, as demonstrated by this winsome group of small, disheveled ceramic sculptures.
lead_paragraph: Garth Greenan Gallery

headline: Mika Tajima: ‘Negative Entropy’
abstract: To achieve the dense, richly hued woven paintings of her Negative Entropy series, Ms. Tajima recorded the sounds of endangered technologies.
lead_paragraph: Eleven Rivington

headline: Despite Loss, SFX Draws Corporations as Sponsors
abstract: SFX, whose portfolio includes festivals around the world, reported that last year it had $170 million in revenue and a net loss of $119 million.
lead_paragraph: Fans of electronic dance music, get ready for a lot more corporate sponsorship.

headline: Grinding Beans Long Before the Baristas Came
abstract: Peter Longo shares a cup of espresso and the story of his family’s business, the century-old Porto Rico coffee company in Greenwich Village, which has catered to generations of New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: PETER LONGO was sitting in his office making a long story short, or at least he kept promising to. I figured that his sense of time was different from mine because his office, on the ground floor of 201 Bleecker Street, which houses his store, Porto Rico Importing Company, is downstairs from where he was born 62 years ago. I think if you grow up in the building where you were born and work there your whole life, you develop a sense of place the rest of us don’t have. You never have to hurry. You’re already home.

headline: S.E.C. Official Criticizes Proxy Proposals on Social Issues
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Corporations', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Daniel M. Gallagher, an S.E.C. commissioner, argued that the agency must clamp down on the filing of shareholder proposals unrelated to the long-term interests of corporations, such as those relating to climate change or sustainability.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Much of the Tulane Corporate Law Institute this year has focused on outspoken hedge fund managers like Carl C. Icahn and Daniel S. Loeb. But one of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s top officials took aim at a different sort of shareholder activism.

headline: Air Force Fires 9 Officers in Scandal Over Cheating on Proficiency Tests
keywords: ['Cheating', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The officers were fired and their base commander resigned as the Air Force continued to deal with accusations that crew members shared answers on missile proficiency tests.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Air Force said Thursday that it had fired nine officers and accepted the resignation of the commander at Malmstrom Air Force Base in Montana as it continued to deal with a widespread cheating scandal among the men and women entrusted with the launching of intercontinental ballistic missiles.

headline: Government Data Requests Fall at Yahoo But Rise at Google
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Government officials in the United States and overseas made fewer requests for the private data of Yahoo users in the second half of 2013, but such requests continued to rise at Google, the companies said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo saw a significant drop in the number of government requests for data about its users in the second half of 2013, compared with the first half, according to the semiannual transparency report that the Internet company published on Thursday.

headline: Social Analysis From the Edge
abstract: Four exhibitions at the Sculpture Center blend avant-garde sensibilities with a sociological focus.
lead_paragraph: A species of contemporary art embraced particularly by the young and intellectually ambitious combines avant-garde style and social science. Those who do this sort of thing operate like sociologists or anthropologists, investigating and documenting certain real-world human situations. But rather than present their discoveries in clear, straightforward terms, they’ll typically interpret their findings obliquely, often by means of multiple mediums including video, sculptural assemblage and architectural construction.

headline: Works From Scotland Set to Tour America
abstract: Two Scottish national galleries are sending masterworks to American museums, including some paintings that have never been seen here before.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the National Galleries of Scotland sent their prized Titian with other paintings from their collection on a tour that started at the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. The exhibition was a way to raise the National Galleries’ profile in the United States and, for the High, to allow its audience to see rare works from abroad without having to travel overseas.

headline: Players Reach Biggest Stage in Their Second Act
abstract: Programs like San Diego State and Baylor have become havens for those disillusioned by their experiences at larger ports of entry to the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — In 1992, Steve Fisher started five freshmen on his Michigan team, which advanced to the N.C.A.A. tournament championship game. Twenty-two years later, Fisher is running what amounts to a deprogramming center at San Diego State for players who grew up dreaming of instant college stardom.

headline: An Assertive Pasta With Nebbiolos
abstract: Cooking this dish with a risotto-like method allows the pasta to take on great flavor and make its own sauce.
lead_paragraph: With their gentle tannins and earthiness, the delicious nebbiolos we tasted could handle a wide array of dishes. Pasta is a fine choice; I selected an assertive, wheaty variety to combine with sausage. Some of the wines delivered hints of mushroom, so those went into the dish, as did carrots to pick up sweetness.

headline: In India, a New Wellness Resort
abstract: The new Vana, Malsi Estate in India will offer 56 different ayurvedic choices.
lead_paragraph: Ayurvedic treatments are staple options on the menus of resort and destination spas.

headline: ‘Finding Neverland’ to Have U.S. Premiere at American Repertory Theater
abstract: “Finding Neverland,” the new musical produced by Harvey Weinstein, will be presented in July by the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.
lead_paragraph: The new musical “Finding Neverland” will have its United States premiere in July at the American Repertory Theater, kicking off a 2014-15 season there that will also include a new play by Eve Ensler (“The Vagina Monologues”) and a theatrical work starring Mandy Patinkin and Taylor Mac, the theater announced Thursday.

headline: House Payments a Priority Again
abstract: Consumers are once again putting the mortgage before the credit card bill.
lead_paragraph: The recession turned the typical consumer debt hierarchy upside down: Faced with unemployment and plummeting home values, consumers began paying down their credit cards ahead of their mortgages.

headline: Why a Symbolic Democratic Agenda Is Better Than None
abstract: There is a very specific reason why nothing is getting done in Washington: Republican intransigence.
lead_paragraph: A surprising number of Senate Republicans — 10 out of 45! — supported an extension of unemployment benefits in a procedural vote this afternoon. Many of them live in states with large numbers of jobless people, and would have a hard time explaining their opposition to a bill that provides five months of extra aid.

headline: Turkey Blocks YouTube as Audio of High-Level Meeting on Syria Leaks
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Social Media', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: The Turkish government blocked access to YouTube after an audio recording was uploaded in which the foreign minister and senior military and intelligence officials could be heard discussing the security situation in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:55 p.m. | The Turkish government blocked access to YouTube on Thursday, after an audio recording was uploaded to the platform in which the foreign minister and senior military and intelligence officials could be heard discussing the security situation in Syria.

headline: Cynthia Rowley’s Spring Break in the Other Magical Kingdom
abstract: The designer, her husband and their daughters spent 10 days earlier this month in the Kingdom of Bhutan, trekking through the Himalayas.
lead_paragraph: Few schoolchildren have gotten to experience as big an adventure on their March vacation as the one the fashion designer Cynthia Rowley took her daughters on earlier this month. Gigi, 9, and Kit, 14, who have already visited 35 countries and three of the seven wonders of the world, just returned with their mom and dad, the gallery owner and writer Bill Powers, from a 10-day trip to the Kingdom of Bhutan. Rowley says the journey was inspired by a life-changing trip she took to Tibet many years ago, and the familiar itch to find “that place again that was untouched and unspoiled and where the culture’s preserved.”

headline: Playing College Football Is a Job
abstract: If Northwestern and other universities don’t want to deal with unions for athletes, they should stop fighting their players and work with them to improve conditions.
lead_paragraph: Before college is even in session, Northwestern football players spend up to 60 hours a week practicing at a one-month training camp. During the three- or four-month football season, they put in up to 50 hours a week preparing for games. That’s more time than many full-time employees devote to their jobs.

headline: A Painter, Well Aware, Takes Twists and Turns
abstract: “Maria Lassnig” is a survey of the painter’s lengthy career, including her so-called body awareness.
lead_paragraph: Maria Lassnig’s show at MoMA PS1 begins with a standoff. In a large self-portrait from 2005, the artist brandishes two guns: one is pointed at her own head, the other at the viewer. The title of this anxiety-inducing work is “You, or Me?”

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 77
abstract: Brazil’s federation on Wednesday opened the doors to the training center its team will occupy during the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Broken, Not Bound, by an Intimate Tie (Updated With Podcast)
abstract: I was profoundly changed by what was to be my “adventure’ in the Tanzanian countryside.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by America Ferrera, followed by a conversation with the writer, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below.

headline: Traipsing the Terroir of Nebbiolo
abstract: One of the world’s most distinctive grapes has more incarnations than Barolo and Barbaresco.
lead_paragraph: Few places offer so intriguing a concentration of wonderful, indigenous red-wine grapes as the Piedmont region of northwestern Italy. Yet, nobody would dispute the primacy of nebbiolo, the great grape of Barolo and Barbaresco.

headline: Making ‘Much Ado’ About a Fab 4
abstract: With “These Paper Bullets!,” Rolin Jones and Billie Joe Armstrong have broadly adapted Shakespeare’s “Much Ado About Nothing” into a tale of the mod British rock scene of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — All the mod markers have been spruced up and put in place in the freely swinging Shakespeare-inspired romp “These Paper Bullets!” at Yale Repertory Theater here. Cheekily described as “a modish ripoff” of “Much Ado About Nothing,” the production evokes with tangy authority the sights, sounds and styles of London rumbling through the youthquake years. The Vidal Sassoon bobs are spot on; the bowl cuts for the boys raise a smile; A-line miniskirts expose milky thighs above go-go boots snugly hugging calves.

headline: G.M. Sent Letter but Didn’t Issue Recall for Faulty Air Bags
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: The company defended its decision not to recall about 68,000 cars with incorrectly wired air bags, the majority of which G.M. said it had repaired.
lead_paragraph: The 2005 Chevrolet Cobalt is already involved in a high-profile recall that has become a major embarrassment for General Motors. The recall, which G.M. delayed for years, involves a faulty ignition switch that has been blamed for at least a dozen deaths.

headline: English King, Pacific Profile
abstract: The National Theater of China is performing a Mandarin-language “Richard III” at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts.
lead_paragraph: If you believe, as I do, that the core of Shakespeare’s greatness is his language, then any production of one of his plays in translation begins with a serious handicap.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Spain and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Spain, Taiwan, Crimea and Italy.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Spain, Taiwan, Crimea and Italy.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here are some of the things that caught our attention today.
lead_paragraph: Hello from The Times’s newsroom.

headline: Amid Chants of ‘¡Huelga!,’ an Embodiment of Hope
abstract: Diego Luna’s “Cesar Chavez” reconstructs the emergence of the United Farm Workers organization in the 1960s and focuses on the movement’s leader, who died in 1993.
lead_paragraph: “Cesar Chavez,” directed by Diego Luna, is a well-cast, well-intentioned movie that falls into the trap that often awaits film biographies of brave and widely admired individuals. The movie is so intent on reminding viewers of its subject’s heroism that it struggles to make him an interesting, three-dimensional person, and it tells his story as a series of dramatic bullet points, punctuated by black-and-white footage, some real, some simulated, of historical events.

headline: ‘Duck Dynasty’ Ends Season With a Sharp Decline in Viewership
abstract: The A&E reality series drew six million viewers for its finale on Wednesday, down from 8.4 million for the finale in the fall cycle of the show.
lead_paragraph: The duck flock is thinning: The latest season of the A&E hit reality series “Duck Dynasty” showed a sharp falloff in ratings, with the finale Wednesday night coming in at six million viewers, down from 8.4 million for the finale in the fall cycle of the show, and 9.6 million for the finale for the most-watched edition a year ago.

headline: Taxi Dancers to Gaga: Roseland’s Life and Death
abstract: A road through the fabled Roseland Ballroom, which is closing its doors on April 7.
lead_paragraph: For decades, patrons of Roseland Ballroom have walked in past the Wall of Fame, which holds the shoes of famous dancers — Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, Betty Grable, James Cagney — and a plaque with names of couples who met dancing at Roseland and went on to marry. They are relics from the many incarnations of Roseland, a name that has been part of New York City night life since 1919. Roseland, which moved to its current location in 1956 with a vaunted deluxe dance floor — maple over cork padding — is to close on April 7 at the end of a string of shows by Lady Gaga, which begin on Friday.

headline: Comedy Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A selected guide to performances of hip-hop, heavy metal, electronic dance music, techno and more in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: China’s Criticism Over Handling of Missing Flight Stirs Malaysian Backlash
abstract: Many on social media in Malaysia have denounced China this week, noting that Malaysians as well as Chinese died on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The Chinese government’s unrelenting criticism of Malaysia’s handling of the disappearance of Flight 370 and an angry protest outside the Malaysian Embassy in Beijing this week have produced a nationalistic backlash here.

headline: Jazz Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: The Nanny as Sphinx, Weaving Enigmatic Magic on the Sly
abstract: “Finding Vivian Maier” focuses on a mysterious nanny who photographed Chicago scenes in the 1950s and ’60s.
lead_paragraph: An exciting electric current of discovery runs through “Finding Vivian Maier,” a documentary about a street photographer who never exhibited her work. She scarcely shared it even with those who knew her. Then again, many of her acquaintances when she was taking some of her remarkable images, particularly in and around Chicago in the 1950s and ’60s, were the children she cared for while working as a nanny. Later in her life, some of those children took care of her in turn, first by moving her into an apartment and then the nursing home where she died in 2009. What rotten timing: She was on the verge of being discovered, first as a curiosity and then as a social-media sensation and a mystery.

headline: Opera & Classical Music Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Dance Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for March 28-April 3
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Tortured Soul, Golden Touch
abstract: “The Passions of Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, covers the career of this gifted French sculptor and painter.
lead_paragraph: Note the savvy come-hither title of “The Passions of Jean-Baptiste Carpeaux,” the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s latest, unusually swashbuckling foray into 19th-century French art. What better way to attract attention to a sculptor prominent in his own time but not widely known in ours than to promise not just one but multiple passions? And what better way to make this artist memorable than to deliver on almost every front?

headline: Spare Times for Children for March 28-April 3
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘PEACE, LOVE AND CUPCAKES: THE MUSICAL’

headline: Seas of Anger and Innocence
abstract: The pianist Paul Lewis played Beethoven, Bach and Liszt at Zankel Hall on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: In the classical music sphere, as in many genres, a nostalgia-fueled “golden age” is sometimes referenced — an era of superlative artists whose gifts are implied to overshadow those of the present generation. But whatever the undoubted glories of the past, the remarkable pianists who perform regularly in New York prove that the golden age is the one we live in.

headline: Spare Times for March 28-April 3
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘THE ORCHID SHOW: KEY WEST CONTEMPORARY’ (through April 21) A modernist garden from Key West, Fla., was the inspiration for this year’s show — which features floral displays and the verses of writers who spent time there — at the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx River Parkway (Exit 7W) and Fordham Road, the Bronx.

headline: Russian Businessman’s Death Remains Mystery, Coroner Says
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: A British coroner said Thursday that he could not say whether Boris A. Berezovsky, a businessman and power broker, died of suicide or homicide.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British coroner said Thursday that he could not establish whether the mysterious death of Boris A. Berezovsky, a businessman and power broker from Russia, was suicide or homicide.

headline: A Boyhood Summer of Darkness
abstract: Daniel Patrick Carbone’s haunting debut feature offers a dark vision of boyhood adventure in a great outdoors fraught with peril.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Patrick Carbone’s haunting debut feature, “Hide Your Smiling Faces,” evokes a semi-rural 1950s America in which packs of neighborhood boys pass the time riding bikes, exploring the woods and engaging in ritualistic roughhouse games. The mood of the film, shot in areas of Sussex County, N.J., suggests a darker reflection of the same vision of boyhood adventure depicted in Terrence Malick’s “The Tree of Life.” Although the time feels like the 1950s, the appearance of a portable DVD player signals that it is set more or less in the present.

headline: Carnage and Chaos, Heavy on the Gore
abstract: Arnold Schwarzenegger leads a gang of marauding Drug Enforcement Administration undercover thugs in “Sabotage,” and the bodies and bullets fly.
lead_paragraph: Lovers of camp and cannabis are the most plausible audience for “Sabotage,” given the giggle-to-bullet ratio in this extravagantly silly movie about a gang of marauding Drug Enforcement Administration undercover thugs. Scholars of Arnold Schwarzenegger, its big-ticket attraction, may also want to check in, just to see what the governator has been up to in his postpolitical golden years. Let me spare you the change and the suspense: He can still bench-press serious weight, as a narratively superfluous visit to a gym makes clear, and he’s still not an actor, as is evident by the confusingly indistinguishable grimaces, smiles and vacant looks that he’s put into rotation here.

headline: Christie’s Lawyer on Bridge Report
abstract: Randy M. Mastro, the lawyer hired by Gov. Chris Christie to lead an internal investigation into the closing of George Washington Bridge access lanes in Fort Lee, N.J., defended the findings.
lead_paragraph: Randy M. Mastro, the lawyer hired by Gov. Chris Christie to lead an internal investigation into the closing of George Washington Bridge access lanes in Fort Lee, N.J., defended the findings.

headline: Temptation in Suburbia, Amid a Midlife Crisis
abstract: In “Breathe In,” directed by Drake Doremus, a marriage is threatened by a glamorous interloper who stirs up a quietly suffering husband’s deepest longings.
lead_paragraph: The warning notes in the tense marital drama “Breathe In” are sounded during a casual conversation at a suburban outdoor gathering whose hostess breezily remarks that she has been to six divorce parties in the past few months.

headline: Recordings, Posted Online, Rattle Officials in Turkey
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Social Media', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Censorship']
abstract: A recording was posted on YouTube in which officials were heard discussing a plot to establish a justification for military strikes in Syria.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — If any meeting was meant to be private, it was this one: the top spy chief, the foreign minister and his deputy, and a top military official discussing secret plans for possible military action in Syria.

headline: Guns and Alcohol
abstract: A reader suggests a possible compromise for those who favor gun control and the moderates who do not.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Visas for Afghan Allies
