headline: Limiting Ivory, Saving Elephants
abstract: Two wildlife organizations praise U.S. regulations aimed at stopping the slaughter of elephants.

headline: Beekeeping and the Neighbors
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Bees']
abstract: This week’s topics include worries over beekeeping; breaking leases; and liability for water damage in apartment buildings.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A Rock Star and a Roadie, Brothers After All
abstract: A scruffy documentary of the band the National’s 2010-11 European tour is less about the music than about left-field interviews with bemused band members.
lead_paragraph: A tale of two brothers, one band and a boatload of psychological baggage, “Mistaken for Strangers” is, like its maker, scruffy, undisciplined and eager to be loved. The big surprise is how easy it is to comply.

headline: He Died Laughing (Isn’t That Sweet?)
abstract: In “Blumenthal,” family members react less than nobly when a garrulous playwright dies while laughing at one of his own jokes.
lead_paragraph: “Blumenthal,” a chilly Jewish comedy that wraps old jokes in a distinctively young voice, has a brisk cleverness that can cause you to overlook its more unpalatable characteristics. Before those take hold, though, there is much to enjoy in this prickly observation of the familial fallout when Harold Blumenthal (Brian Cox), a bloviating playwright, dies while relishing one of his own jokes.

headline: I.P.O. to Cut Ill-Fitting Ad Business From CBS
abstract: “Outdoor doesn’t quite fit with us because it’s sales, but not content,” said Leslie Moonves, chief executive of CBS. “The synergies didn’t really exist.”
lead_paragraph: When CBS Outdoor begins trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, it will represent not only the dawn of a new publicly traded advertising company in a hot market for initial public offerings, but also the latest step in the evolution of its parent company, CBS.

headline: It’s No Substitute for the Sun
abstract: In order to get through this winter, I invested in a “happy lamp.”
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — MY psychiatrist is a fan of “happy lamps,” lamps that use full-spectrum bulbs to treat wintertime seasonal depression. A really big fan. Opening his office door is like entering a scene in “Poltergeist”: I’m blinded by a powerful glow that emanates from every direction. I must rely on his voice in the distance calling out to me in order to orient myself. This is how our appointments begin: I go toward the light.

headline: Remembering How to Fight Measles
abstract: Outbreaks from New York to California chart the return of a vanquished disease.
lead_paragraph: THE measles vaccine is a victim of its own success.

headline: Facing Eviction, He Can’t Resist a Dare
abstract: “Cheap Thrills” is a dark comedy about two friends who fall into a rough game with a wealthy couple they meet at a bar.
lead_paragraph: The actors play “Cheap Thrills” straight, but you should watch it as a twisted comedy. Those who do will be rewarded, especially by the film’s outlandish final image.

headline: Exploring a New World Every Day
abstract: A Manhattan exhibit celebrates Chang Lee’s 20 years as a New York Times photographer, a career that has taken him around the world and back in time.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan exhibit celebrates Chang Lee’s 20 years as a New York Times photographer, a career that has taken him around the world and back in time.

headline: When a Hot Shower Was a Frill
keywords: ['Bathing and Showering', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The Gertrude Ederle Recreation Center on West 60th Street began life in 1906 as a bathhouse.
lead_paragraph: Cold-weather blahs? It’s not exactly the Caribbean, but the sun-drenched pool at the sparkling, newly renovated Gertrude Ederle Recreation Center at 232 West 60th Street is a sight for winter-weary eyes. Built in 1906 in the Georgian style, the center originally washed the great unwashed.

headline: Is This Listing Real, or Just a Ghost?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: What to do when the listing you love turns out to be a fake.
lead_paragraph: In an era when drop-down menus and mouse clicks are critical tools for a house hunt, one scenario in particular has become all too familiar to some buyers.

headline: Nonstop Carnage, Indonesian-Style
abstract: Neither the undercover drama in “The Raid 2” nor its two-and-a-half-hour length bog down its numerous bracing and bloody brawls.
lead_paragraph: When a prison yard becomes a sloppy battlefield in “The Raid 2,” the mud-covered combatants turn gray, reduced to their essence: bodies smashing together in the muck. The pleasant surprise of Gareth Evans’s sturdy sequel to “The Raid: Redemption” is that neither its undercover drama nor its two-and-a-half-hour length bog down the bracing, and numerous, fight fests.

headline: Ten Key Questions on Health Care Enrollment
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Answers to some key questions about health care enrollment.
lead_paragraph: Answers to some key questions about health care enrollment.

headline: A Tax Notion That Conceals a Math Problem
keywords: ['Property Taxes', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Sales and Excise Taxes']
abstract: The idea of eliminating property taxes can remain popular in Texas as long as it doesn’t encounter the reality of a huge increase in sales taxes.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: She’s Not Heavy, She’s My Bar Pickup
abstract: “Refuge,” starring Krysten Ritter, depicts a young woman who finds a new boyfriend while raising her needy younger siblings.
lead_paragraph: “Refuge,” like a lot of movies these days about young people searching for meaningful relationships, is the old Disney fantasy reimagined for the hookup age. That leaves it feeling just as unsatisfying and unrealistic as a happily-ever-after story about a damsel and a prince she has barely met.

headline: Humans’ First Appearance in the Americas
abstract: In Piauí, Brazil, archaeologists say stone tools prove that humans reached what is now Brazil as early as 22,000 years ago, upending a belief that people first arrived about 13,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: In Piauí, Brazil, archaeologists say stone tools prove that humans reached what is now Brazil as early as 22,000 years ago, upending a belief that people first arrived about 13,000 years ago.

headline: This Week’s Movies: March 28, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics on “Noah,” “Finding Vivian Maier” and “Cesar Chavez.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on “Noah,” “Finding Vivian Maier” and “Cesar Chavez.”

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Settlement in Medicaid Fraud Case Worries Health Providers
keywords: ['Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Carousels', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Inspectors General']
abstract: After an inquiry, the inspector general’s office has settled with a children’s health provider, which will repay the state $3.75 million in Medicaid payments.
lead_paragraph: A major legal settlement with a children’s health provider in hand, a Texas agency investigating health care fraud says its ramped-up efforts to rein in faulty Medicaid charges have started to pay off.

headline: Gang Wars, Iraq Warfare
abstract: “Greencard Warriors” follows a family that will do almost anything for papers.
lead_paragraph: A 14-year-old Latino boy falls in love with an African-American girl, and the neighborhood Latino gang does not approve, in “Greencard Warriors.” The girl is played by Paige Hurd, and Vivica A. Fox does a star turn as her mother. The boy, Angel (Angel Amaral), is vulnerable because his protective older brother, Beto (Mario Ardila Jr.), has just been sent to Iraq.

headline: The Certainty of Donald Rumsfeld (Part 3)
abstract: Could Pearl Harbor be called a “failure of imagination,” and in that sense was it similar to the attacks of 9/11?
lead_paragraph: Read Part 1; Part 2; Part 4.

headline: A Loopy Stalker, Protesting Her Innocence
abstract: In “Nothing Without You,” a delusional woman who stalks powerful men is accused of a brutal killing.
lead_paragraph: Unfolding from the viewpoint of Jennifer (Emily Fradenburgh), a batty erotomaniac, Xackery Irving’s “Nothing Without You” might have had a fighting chance as a skewed study of a sick psyche. But by embedding Jennifer’s mental issues in a murder mystery of unmitigated tedium, this low-budget drama essentially cuts its own throat.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around Texas this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Dreamy Postcards From Limbo
abstract: The director Aaron Schimberg forays into lo-fi anachronism in his new film, “Go Down Death.”
lead_paragraph: Several years in the making and seemingly unfolding some hundred years in the past, Aaron Schimberg’s black-and-white pastiche, “Go Down Death,” is a curious foray into lo-fi anachronism. Shot on 16-millimeter film, this staccato ensemble of vignettes shuffles among the fatalistic inhabitants of a run-down hamlet who have little to cling to but crackerjack philosophizing.

headline: When ‘Egyptian’ Just Meant Egyptian
abstract: The documentary “Jews of Egypt” focuses on a shift from tolerance to harassment and expulsions, starting in 1949.
lead_paragraph: Amir Ramses, the 34-year-old director of “Jews of Egypt,” says in publicity notes for his documentary that “the contradiction between modern intolerant Egypt and cosmopolitan Egypt in the first half of the 20th century” led him to focus on the period from 1949 to 1956, when many Egyptian Jews left or were forced out of the country. The film consists of archival footage and interviews, primarily with people who remember those turbulent years.

headline: Potential Crackdown on Russia Risks Also Punishing Western Oil Companies
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Any stricter sanctions on Russia for its occupation of Crimea would likely be opposed by Exxon Mobil, BP and other companies with projects in Russia.
lead_paragraph: As the United States seeks to strengthen sanctions on Moscow for its occupation of Crimea, energy experts say the powerful Russian oil industry would make a robust target. But any penalties on energy investments, technology transfers and financial transactions would most likely also punish Western oil companies like Exxon Mobil that are investing heavily in Russia.

headline: Candidates’ Views on Drilling Begin With Glance Back
abstract: As Texas deals with a drilling boom that has brought a windfall to its coffers but has strained services and raised environmental concerns, governor candidates have concentrated on bite-size policy questions.
lead_paragraph: Greg Abbott and Wendy Davis have sparred over education. The issues of officeholder ethics and equal pay have also surfaced.

headline: Disabled Borrowers Trade Loan Debt for a Tax Bill From the I.R.S.
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service may count a forgiven debt as income, leaving some disabled borrowers with tax bills they cannot pay.
lead_paragraph: Six months after his wife learned that she had a rare vascular disease of the brain, Frank, now 66, lost his job as director of sales of a telecommunications company. His wife, to whom he had been married for 36 years, died just two months later.

headline: Microsoft Unveils Office App for iPad
abstract: Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, and the general manager of Microsoft Office, Julia White, announced the new Office app for iPad, part of an effort to expand to other devices.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft’s chief executive, Satya Nadella, and the general manager of Microsoft Office, Julia White, announced the new Office app for iPad, part of an effort to expand to other devices.

headline: Iraq: Bombs Kill at Least 33 in Baghdad
abstract: A series of bombings in Baghdad killed at least 33 people and wounded dozens more on Thursday, Iraqi officials said.
lead_paragraph: A series of bombings in Baghdad killed at least 33 people and wounded dozens more on Thursday, Iraqi officials said. At least three of the bombs struck Adhamiya, a largely Sunni neighborhood in northern Baghdad, and killed 22 people, the police said. Other blasts in western Baghdad killed 11 people, officials said. Ghazwan Naji, a resident of the western Baghdad neighborhood of Amiriya, said his 7-year-old son had heard so many explosions that he could distinguish the different kinds of bombs. “We’ve become experts in this, in death,” Mr. Naji said.

headline: Alstom of France Cooperating in U.S. Bribery Inquiry
abstract: Discussions are said to be continuing between the company, an industrial conglomerate and the Justice Department over a possible fine.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Alstom, a French industrial conglomerate, acknowledged on Thursday that it was cooperating with the United States Justice Department. Its stock fell nearly 5 percent in Paris trading after a news report that it was facing a large fine in a bribery investigation.

headline: Jury Has Case in ’08 Killing of Manhattan Therapist
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Schizophrenia', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Conflicting psychiatric testimony surrounds the murder trial of David Tarloff, a schizophrenic who bludgeoned and stabbed Kathryn Faughey, a psychologist, in 2008.
lead_paragraph: There does not seem to be any doubt that David Tarloff is a schizophrenic who sometimes believes he can communicate with God. And no one involved at his murder trial contests that he bludgeoned and stabbed a psychologist to death during a botched robbery six years ago on the Upper East Side.

headline: Human Rights Panel Criticizes U.S.
abstract: A United Nations human rights panel has called for more oversight and transparency in the program of targeted drone strikes carried out by the United States.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations human rights panel has called for more oversight and transparency in the program of targeted drone strikes carried out by the United States and recommended the prosecution of all those involved in unlawful killings and torture overseas, particularly “persons in command positions.” In a report released Thursday, the United Nations Human Rights Committee, a panel of 18 independent experts from different countries, expressed concern that the United States government had not clarified the criteria or legal basis for drone strikes and called for independent oversight of the program. It also drew attention to the limited number of investigations into unlawful killings and the use of torture in overseas operations by the American military and private contractors. It said the responsibility of those who “provided legal pretexts for manifestly illegal behavior should also be established” and urged the government to declassify and release the Senate Intelligence Committee’s investigation into the Central Intelligence Agency’s secret rendition activities.

headline: At Big on Mars, Trying to Get a Handle on Tomorrow’s Tech
abstract: Digitaria is starting a unit devoted to mobile technology in another example of efforts on Madison Avenue to keep up with the fast-changing landscape.
lead_paragraph: A LEADING digital agency is starting a unit devoted to mobile technology in another example of efforts on Madison Avenue to keep up with the fast-changing landscape embodied by the term “the Internet of Things,” shorthand for a world of connected devices, sensors and applications.

headline: Smartphones, the Disappointing Miracle
abstract: People from Earth’s most remote corners have something in common: They all download apps, interacting with the mobile Internet billions of times a day, and they all feel frustration at slow loads and app crashes. A new report shows how much work it is, getting us to this level of frustration.
lead_paragraph: Smartphone users are frustrated and deprived by bad service, including slow application load times and frequent service crashes.

headline: U.S. Investigates Brothers From Ecuador With Ties to Campaigns
abstract: The fugitives are being investigated to determine whether any of the millions the men were accused of pilfering in their home country made it to the United States.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Two fugitive brothers from Ecuador, whose relatives have contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to American political campaigns, are being investigated by the Department of Homeland Security to determine whether any of the millions the men were accused of pilfering in their home country made it to the United States, according to a federal law enforcement official familiar with the case.

headline: Silence Is Deafening in Bridge Report
abstract: Throughout its 360 pages, the report on the traffic jam at the George Washington Bridge never states directly that the chairman of the Port Authority refused to speak with Gov. Chris Christie’s own investigators.
lead_paragraph: The original plans for the George Washington Bridge called for its two mighty towers, each 60 stories high, to be clad with granite facing, but that was deferred to save money. To this day, the steelwork is as bare as when the towers rose above the Hudson in the late 1920s.

headline: Pakistani Gets Death Penalty for Blasphemy
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: A case that set off rioting last year in a Christian neighborhood is now likely to put a spotlight on capital punishment in Pakistan, which has never carried out an execution under its blasphemy laws.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — A court here found a Christian sanitation worker guilty of blasphemy on Thursday and sentenced him to death, in a case that set off rioting and the torching of a Christian neighborhood last year.

headline: A New Facebook Lab Is Intent on Delivering Internet Access by Drone
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Facebook is creating a laboratory to devise a way to provide web access from solar-powered drones or perhaps other “connectivity aircraft.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Watch out, Google. Facebook is gunning for the title of World’s Coolest Place to Work. And its arsenal includes unmanned drones, lasers, satellites and virtual reality headsets.

headline: Conviction of Bin Laden’s Son-in-Law Doesn’t Halt Debate Over Terror Trials’ Venue
abstract: The verdict in the case of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden, has not lessened criticism of the move to prosecute international terrorism suspects in civil court.
lead_paragraph: About four years ago, the Obama administration rescinded its plans to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks in federal court in Manhattan, and left the men in military custody.

headline: A Triple for Baseball Fans
abstract: The apps available to baseball fans in New York City are some of the best around.
lead_paragraph: Major league baseball, with its focus on statistics, a barrage of regular season games and highlights that are easy to follow even on the smallest of screens, is an ideal fit for mobile.

headline: A Fierce Rivalry Divides a Kentucky United by Basketball
abstract: The University of Kentucky and the University of Louisville will meet Friday night in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, gripping the state in an all-consuming fever.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — How deeply is basketball a way of life in Kentucky? Consider Richie Farmer. A star shooting guard for the Kentucky Wildcats in the 1990s, Mr. Farmer was elected state agriculture commissioner, before being convicted of corruption last year. He was to report to prison on March 18, but a federal judge in Frankfort, the capital, granted a one-week delay so Mr. Farmer could watch his son in a high school basketball tournament.

headline: Fate of a Picasso at the Four Seasons Hangs on a Court Case
abstract: The New York Landmark Conservancy owns the artwork and says it is too fragile to remove; the owners of building say repairs are needed and the Picasso must go.
lead_paragraph: They were the best of friends, Aby J. Rosen, the white-haired prince of commerce who stands astride an empire of real estate and art, and Peg Breen, the inexhaustible preservationist who heads the New York Landmarks Conservancy.

headline: In East, Rematch of Classic Is Possible
abstract: If Michigan State and Iowa State win their next games, it would set up a rematch of the 2000 Midwest Region final, in which Cyclones coach Larry Eustachy was ejected.
lead_paragraph: If fourth-seeded Michigan State and third-seeded Iowa State win on Friday, the 2014 East Region final will be a rematch of the 2000 Midwest Region final.

headline: Failing Stress Test Is Another Stumble for Citigroup
abstract: The broader question hanging over Citigroup is one that has dogged it since it was created nearly two decades ago: that the bank may be simply too big to manage.
lead_paragraph: Something didn’t quite seem right to Citigroup earlier this week.The banking behemoth could show that it had enough capital to ride out an economic storm, but a regulator was refusing to approve its plan to increase dividends and stock buybacks, steps intended to please shareholders and build confidence in the bank’s turnaround.

headline: Obama Seeks to Calm Saudis as Paths Split
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s leaders are feeling increasingly compelled to go their own way in dealing with Iran, Syria, Egypt and the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Over seven decades, the United States and Saudi Arabia forged a strategic alliance that became a linchpin of the regional order: a liberal democracy and an ultraconservative monarchy united by shared interests in the stability of the Middle East and the continued flow of oil.

headline: Court Panel Upholds Texas Law on Abortion
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', "Women's Rights", 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling was a victory for anti-abortion groups and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas who said the law did not pose an “undue burden” on women’s rights.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel on Thursday upheld a Texas law that has forced several abortion clinics in the state to shut down, saying the law did not pose an “undue burden” on women’s rights.

headline: Irate Friends See Sexism in Report on Former Christie Aide
abstract: A report that held Gov. Chris Christie blameless for the Fort Lee bridge lane scandal depicted the ex-aide, Bridget Anne Kelly, as duplicitous, weepy and dependent on men for approval and stability.
lead_paragraph: She “seemed emotional.” She was “habitually concerned about how she was perceived by the governor.” A boyfriend had ended a relationship.

headline: Without Tenure or a Home
abstract: Mary-Faith Cerasoli, an adjunct professor who began couch-surfing a year ago after being unable to keep several apartments, is planning a protest in Albany over working conditions.
lead_paragraph: In the classroom, Mary-Faith Cerasoli, 53, an adjunct professor of Romance languages, usually tries to get her message across in lyrical Italian or Spanish.

headline: America’s Taxation Tradition
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Income Tax', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How we got from Teddy Roosevelt to Mitt Romney in our attitudes on wealth and inequality.
lead_paragraph: As inequality has become an increasingly prominent issue in American discourse, there has been furious pushback from the right. Some conservatives argue that focusing on inequality is unwise, that taxing high incomes will cripple economic growth. Some argue that it’s unfair, that people should be allowed to keep what they earn. And some argue that it’s un-American — that we’ve always celebrated those who achieve wealth, and that it violates our national tradition to suggest that some people control too large a share of the wealth.

headline: Welcome Help for Ukraine
abstract: After weeks of crisis, Ukraine got some encouraging economic news that can help the desperate country begin rebuilding its economy.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of crisis in Ukraine — the upheaval in Kiev, the Russian occupation of Crimea, Vladimir Putin’s intransigence — the country just got some encouraging economic news. The International Monetary Fund tentatively approved up to $18 billion in badly needed lending assistance over two years. And the United States Congress, overcoming its habitual dysfunction, voted for a $1 billion package of American aid.

headline: E.U. Tries to Assuage Fears Over U.S. Trade Deal
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The top trade official for the European Union imposed a 90-day period to get the public’s input on protections for companies and investors.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The top trade official for the European Union sought on Thursday to soothe opposition to a planned deal with the United States by imposing a 90-day period for the public to comment on protections for investors and companies.

headline: Determining the Legal Rights of Slaves
abstract: With American independence began a slow, halting improvement in the lives of New York slaves.
lead_paragraph: Q. I recently read the memoirs of a woman who fled the French Revolution, settled for a while in New York State and wrote of what slavery was like there. She said the slaves had rights: For example, if they thought their owner was treating them unfairly, they had the right to demand that they be sold to someone else. Is this true? Did slaves have legal rights in New York?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 27, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 27, 2014

headline: A Whitewash for Gov. Christie
keywords: ['George Washington Bridge', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The governor of New Jersey still has a long way to go to regain public trust and clear his name in the George Washington Bridge traffic scandal.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers hired by Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey at public expense issued their findings Thursday on the traffic jams at the George Washington Bridge in September, apparently engineered as a bizarre form of political revenge. To no one’s surprise, Mr. Christie’s lawyers have found his hands to be clean. He was without fault, they declared. This glossy political absolution cost the taxpayers of New Jersey more than $1 million in legal fees.

headline: Dissent in Milledgeville
abstract: What a fiery speech by Alexander H. Stephens, the Confederate vice president, meant for the crumbling state of Southern politics.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to the particularities of the Confederate Constitution, President Jefferson Davis had no real claim on the loyalty of his sitting vice president, Alexander H. Stephens, who was selected by the Confederate Legislature. Even so, Davis recognized Stephens’s appearance before the Georgia Legislature in early 1864 as an act of utter betrayal – and not only because it fell the day after the Ides of March.

headline: De Blasio Picks 5 Members for Rent Board
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio put his long-awaited stamp on the Rent Guidelines Board, which sets rents for about one million rent-regulated apartments in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday put his long-awaited stamp on the board that sets rents for about one million rent-regulated apartments in New York City.

headline: Christian Charity Backtracks on Gays
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: World Vision U.S. set off an uproar when it announced this week that it would hire Christians in same-sex marriages, a decision it quickly reversed.
lead_paragraph: World Vision U.S., an evangelical Christian charity known for asking donors to sponsor a hungry child, set off an uproar when it announced this week that it would hire Christians in same-sex marriages.

headline: For College Players, Gaining Rights Amid Guarded Words
abstract: A ruling that Northwestern football players had won the right to be considered university employees is not only about money, some college basketball players said.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in his Manhattan hotel room on Wednesday night, the Connecticut senior Tyler Olander saw on television that a group of Northwestern football players had won the right to be considered employees of the university and did a little cheer.

headline: Judge Urges Dismissal of Mortgage Suit Against Bank of America
abstract: The recommendation to toss out a Justice Department lawsuit over a soured mortgage deal at Bank of America could inspire other banks to test their luck in court.
lead_paragraph: A federal magistrate judge on Thursday moved to toss out a Justice Department lawsuit over a soured mortgage deal at Bank of America, dealing a potential setback to the government’s pursuit of Wall Street misdeeds.

headline: Sisterhood of the Noodle
abstract: Late at night, Lower East Side noodleists come to Benkei Ramen, an after-hours pop-up restaurant at Hill & Dale on Allen Street, for cocktails, soup and the bar’s retro, antique-radio vibe.
lead_paragraph: It’s a little before 1 a.m. on a bitterly cold Monday night and you’re suddenly in the mood for ramen. Of course you are. It is a scientifically proven fact that human beings are hard-wired to crave ramen, pierogi, breakfast cereal and Ben Webster records in the wee small hours. But unless you happen to keep a pot of tonkotsu broth simmering on your stove, your options for fresh ramen after midnight are limited. On the Lower East Side, those options now include Benkei Ramen, which earlier this month moved its after-hours pop-up restaurant from SoHo to Hill & Dale on Allen Street, where customers can slurp hot broth and noodles amid Art Deco surroundings from 12:30 a.m. until 4 a.m., or closing, on Sunday through Wednesday nights (that is, Monday through Thursday mornings). On Monday night, a few dozen noodleists came out for cocktails, soup, loudish Ramones and the bar’s retro, antique-radio vibe. It should be noted that only three brayed along with the Black Crowes, but that was plenty.

headline: Deadline Near, Health Signups Show Disparity
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)']
abstract: With the first open enrollment period set to end Monday, the Affordable Care Act looks less like a sweeping federal overhaul than a collection of individual ventures playing out unevenly, state to state, in the laboratories of democracy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The online insurance marketplace in Oregon is such a technological mess that residents have been signing up for health coverage by hand. In Texas, political opposition to President Obama’s health law is so strong that some residents believe, erroneously, that the program is banned in their state.

headline: Scholars, Players and Union Members
abstract: Should student athletes be allowed to organize and collectively bargain with their college?

headline: Soul-Searching as Japan Ends a Man’s Decades on Death Row
abstract: It took the courts nearly half a century to conclude that the evidence against him was likely fabricated by police investigators and to order the retrial he sought.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Iwao Hakamada was a wiry former boxer in his 30s when he was thrown in jail for the killing of a family of four that shocked 1960s Japan. On Thursday, he limped from his cell on death row, a bewildered-looking 78-year-old who, his family fears, may have lost his mind in prison.

headline: College Athletes Aim to Put Price on ‘Priceless’
abstract: A ruling allowing Northwestern University football players to unionize has highlighted the growing battle over how much college players should share in the billions of dollars they generate.
lead_paragraph: If quarterback Johnny Manziel were an employee of Texas A&M, he would be a bargain.

headline: Events on Long Island for March 30-April 5

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

Each flag represented a veteran who had committed suicide since Jan. 1, a figure that amounts to 22 deaths each day.

This year is no different, with several of the Wildcats’ nine freshmen expected to leave after one year.

The bluster quotient has been toned down in Arin Arbus’s thoughtful and affecting interpretation of this most daunting of tragedies, which opened on Thursday night at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: Rate of Diagnosis for Autism Grows
abstract: The rate at which doctors diagnosed autism and related disorders in 8-year-olds increased between 2008 and 2010 in some parts of the country, a report released by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday said.
lead_paragraph: The rate at which doctors diagnosed autism and related disorders in 8-year-olds increased between 2008 and 2010 in some parts of the country, a report released by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday said. The average rate was one in 68 children, up from one in 88 in 2008. The report — based not on direct diagnoses but on a review of records — was not nationally representative and drew on data gathered three years before a significant tightening in the clinical definition of autism. The likelihood of receiving a diagnosis of autism has increased sharply over the past three decades, and no one knows why, or whether the 2010 numbers are currently meaningful.

lead_paragraph: President Obama on Thursday nominated Elliot F. Kaye as chairman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission. He would replace Inez M. Tenenbaum, who was credited with revitalizing the agency during her four-year term, which ended in November. Mr. Kaye is the agency’s executive director and has been one of the forces behind its drive to reduce head injuries in youth football, said the agency’s spokesman, Scott Wolfson.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 4:20 P.M. (HBO2) RUSHMORE (1998) Max Fischer (Jason Schwartzman, above right, with Bill Murray), a high school student and playwright with a proclivity for extracurricular activities, befriends a depressed steel tycoon (Mr. Murray) until they become rivals for the affections of the same woman (Olivia Williams). Directed by Wes Anderson, who wrote the script with Owen Wilson, and complemented by an energetic British Invasion soundtrack, this comedy is “a particular treat for its skewed, hilarious memories of a cutthroat boyhood,” Janet Maslin wrote in The Times. She added: “It’s too smart to be maudlin. Far better to show off Max’s Vietnam play, with real explosives (earplugs and safety glasses available) or let him boast derangedly (in one especially funny dinner scene) about having a hit to his credit.”
