abstract: More on anonymous quotes in The Times, including one that’s acceptable.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:45 p.m.This is the second edition of my effort to track and evaluate anonymous quotations in The Times. I’m appreciative of all the response from readers, many of whom have sent me examples that bothered them. (Others have provided worthy candidates for AnonyWatch in the comments section of my first post. To be mentioned here, for obvious reasons, readers need to provide their full names.)

headline: Newly Released Clinton-Era Papers Show Damage Control During Scandal
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The National Archives made public 2,500 documents from the Clinton White House on Friday, the third installment in the release of as many as 33,000 documents.
lead_paragraph: As the White House was enveloped in the Monica Lewinsky scandal in January 1998, aides offered advice to President Bill Clinton’s speechwriting team on how to use the State of the Union address that month to rebuild public confidence in the president.

headline: Head of Indian Cricket Board Steps Down During Match-Fixing Investigation
abstract: The Supreme Court of India appointed Sunil Gavaskar, the former captain of the Indian cricket team, as the interim head of the country’s governing body for cricket.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Supreme Court of India appointed Sunil Gavaskar, the former captain of the Indian cricket team, as the interim head of the country’s governing body for cricket on Friday after the previous president agreed to step aside while his associates are being investigated for match fixing.

headline: Head of Intelligence Panel in House Says He’ll Retire to Take Job as Radio Host
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Radio']
abstract: Representative Mike Rogers of Michigan made the announcement just days after proposing an ambitious overhaul of electronic surveillance programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Mike Rogers of Michigan, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, stunned colleagues on Friday by announcing he would retire to take a job as a talk radio host, just days after proposing an ambitious overhaul of the nation’s electronic surveillance programs.

headline: Italy’s Anima Receives Regulatory Approval for I.P.O.
abstract: The asset manager expects to issue about 63.25 percent of its share capital in an I.P.O. that could value the company at up to 1.35 billion euros, or about $1.85 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Italian asset manager Anima said Friday that it had received approval from Italian regulators to list on the Borsa Italiana.

headline: Kremlin Finds a Defender in Congress
abstract: Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a California Republican, is speaking up for Moscow with pride.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is a lonely pursuit these days, defending Russia in Congress as outrage over Kremlin aggression grows louder. But Representative Dana Rohrabacher speaks up for Moscow with pride.

headline: Ready for My Haircut, Mr. DeMille
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Blu-Ray Disc', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Cecil B. DeMille’s “Samson and Delilah,” now on Blu-ray, is the kind of blend of sandals, sex and spectacle DeMille perfected in the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: Before show business maestros like James Cameron or Steven Spielberg were crowned kings of Hollywood, there was the producer-director Cecil B. DeMille. And before there was “Quo Vadis” or “Ben Hur” or the other half-forgotten cinematic behemoths of the 1950s, there was DeMille’s “Samson and Delilah,” which opened 65 years ago come Christmas and is out this month on a Paramount Blu-ray.

headline: Consumer Confidence Rebounds, but Uncertainty Lingers
abstract: The Conference Board reported this week that its overall index of consumer confidence climbed to 82.3 in March, the highest reading since January 2008, just as the recession was beginning.
lead_paragraph: THE American economy continues to improve, month after month, according to a survey of consumers.

headline: Vikings in London: Just Like Family
abstract: “Vikings: Life and Legend” is already one of the most successful exhibitions in the British Museum’s history, partly because the British claim Vikings as part of the family.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Viking feasting bucket, one gallon in volume and a millennium old, attracted a noisy debate among visitors in the Sainsbury Exhibitions Gallery of the British Museum one recent afternoon over just how drunk it could make them and how quickly.

headline: The Elaborate Replacement Teddy Bear Hoax
abstract: After my toddler’s bear toppled out of the stroller, I found a replacement and staged the great Rainbow Home for Christmas Spectacular. My daughter wasn’t fooled for a minute.
lead_paragraph: I can’t pinpoint exactly when we lost Rainbow, but it was somewhere along the mile-long trek between home and the playground. It was dark by the time we had gotten back and realized the small pink teddy bear had fallen out of Grace’s stroller. The next morning, I got up early and retraced our route, with no luck. Rainbow was gone.

headline: Economic Realism (Wonkish)
abstract: Pfleiderer,filters, finance.
lead_paragraph: Mark Thoma sends us to Paul Pfleiderer (pdf) on the misuse of economic models. Pfleiderer writes his paper as a condemnation of “chameleons” — of what we might alternatively call three-card-monte economics. Someone markets a theoretical model as something that carries lessons for the real world, but when challenged on the assumptions retreats to claiming that it’s just theory.

headline: Memphis and Cardinals Partner in Deal to Revitalize Ballpark
abstract: The City of Memphis tapped the municipal bond market to finance the $19 million purchase of AutoZone Park, the home of the Memphis Redbirds, a farm team that the St. Louis Cardinals will buy for $15 million.
lead_paragraph: The City of Memphis is inheriting a once-troubled minor league baseball stadium in an unusual deal orchestrated by a New York private equity firm.

headline: British Insurance Stocks Fall on Regulator’s Plans for Review
abstract: The British regulator confirmed that it would conduct a review on how fairly life insurance customers are being treated, a move that sent British insurance stocks lower on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:54 p.m. |

headline: In the Beginning, the Words of Many
abstract: Ed Sylvanus Iskandar needed four dozen playwrights to create “The Mysteries,” almost six hours of brand-new Bible stories based on an English medieval tradition.
lead_paragraph: The show that Ed Sylvanus Iskandar had in mind was a theatrical event of biblical proportions. To make it happen, this director needed four dozen playwrights.

headline: Talk-Show Host Infatuated With Himself
abstract: In “Alan Partridge,” Steve Coogan plays a vain TV and radio host he has played on British TV for years in various series.
lead_paragraph: What the salesman has been to classic stage drama, the talk-show host has been to small-screen satire: an inexhaustibly fertile character with dark depths.

headline: From Divergence, a Thoughtful Calm
abstract: With the expansion of the Clark Art Institute, the architect Tadao Ando and the museum’s director, Michael Conforti, consider how their relationship evolved and affected the project.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — On the snow-covered, bitterly cold museum construction site here, word went out to the assembled crowd: The helicopter had landed.

headline: New York Police Department’s Oversight Office, Fought by Bloomberg, Gets First Leader
abstract: Philip K. Eure will take on an oversight role created last year by the City Council, in response to complaints about the overuse of stop-and-frisk tactics and surveillance of Muslim communities.
lead_paragraph: The Office of Inspector General for the New York Police Department was created over the veto of a mayor, in the face of stiff opposition from a police commissioner and in the heat of a mayoral campaign marked by pitched criticism of police policy.

headline: Shares of CBS Outdoor Rise on Debut
abstract: Shares of the large billboard advertising company trade higher on the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:03 p.m. |

headline: Growth Versus Distribution: Hunger Games
abstract: Surging GDP, stunted children?
lead_paragraph: It’s fairly common for conservative economists to try and shout down any discussion of income distribution by claiming that distribution is a trivial matter compared with the huge gains from economic growth. For example, Robert Lucas:

headline: Student Crossword | Weather
abstract: Test your knowledge of words related to climate and weather by playing our crossword.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of words related to climate and weather by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Noah,’ ‘Finding Vivian Maier’ and ‘Cesar Chavez’
abstract: Critics on “Noah,” “Finding Vivian Maier” and “Cesar Chavez.”
lead_paragraph: In this video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Noah,” “Finding Vivian Maier” and “Cesar Chavez.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: At School, It Matters If You’re Black or White
abstract: Contrary to what some readers believe, districts routinely punish minority students more harshly than their non-minority classmates.
lead_paragraph: Many readers reacted skeptically to Thursday’s editorial, “Giving Up on 4-Year-Olds,” which describes a federal study showing that black school children are disproportionately singled out for suspension. Some readers argued that the disparity might be explained by class rather than race or by the fact that minority children committed more serious, suspension-worthy offenses.

headline: Playing John Wayne
abstract: A biography surveys the career of Marion Robert Morrison, who turned himself into a legend.
lead_paragraph: The first time I met John Wayne was in 1965 in Old Tucson, Ariz., where he was shooting Howard Hawks’s “El Dorado.” They were doing a night scene so the lighting took a long time and, happily, gave me a solid two hours to sit on the set, not in his trailer, and to speak with the Duke about nothing except pictures. I hadn’t directed a movie yet, but I had been approved as a journalist by John Ford and endorsed by Hawks — the two most important directors in Wayne’s career — so he quickly became outgoing and pretty candid. When he was finally called away, he said to me, enthusiastically: “Geez, it was great talkin’ about . . . pictures! Nobody ever talks to me about anything but politics and cancer!”

headline: People of the Word
abstract: Simon Schama’s monumental history of the Jews views the Torah as the key to the community’s cohesion.
lead_paragraph: From generation to generation — l’dor va dor, as the Good Book says (in Hebrew) — there arises a historian who bequeaths unto the world yet another door-stopping history of the Jews. Forty-one years ago, a young history professor at Cambridge named Simon Schama agreed to complete one such work, left unfinished by the great British Jewish historian Cecil Roth when he died. Schama tried to do the job, he really did, but “for whatever reasons the graft wouldn’t take,” as he writes in the foreword of his own “The Story of the Jews.” Now we know why. Roth was a splendid writer with an encyclopedic knowledge of his field, and Schama is a splendid writer with an encyclopedic acquaintance with a wide range of fields. But Roth wrote history from above, chronicling the doings of great men entangled in great events, whereas Schama writes history from below, and from the middle and from other unexpected angles, resurrecting the unrecorded and long-­forgotten, and analyzing the social and cultural forces that shaped his subjects’ lives. Roth’s and Schama’s approaches to history are at least two generations apart, and Schama’s is the more user-friendly (to this reader, anyway). Although his book, which ends in the 15th century, is destined to become part of a two-volume set big enough to prop anything open, there’s nothing thudding about it.

headline: Outsider Art
abstract: The female artist in Siri Hustvedt’s new novel is a creative titan whose career has been blighted by the art establishment’s sexism.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, a series of posters began appearing on the streets of New York. The most arresting one — a yellow-and-crimson image of Ingres’s “Odalisque” wearing a gorilla mask that demanded, “Do women have to be naked to get into the Met. Museum?” — informed the viewer that “less than 5 percent of the artists in the Modern Art sections are women, but 85 percent of the nudes are female.”

headline: U.S. to Recognize Same-Sex Marriages in Michigan
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The announcement by Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. came amid legal uncertainty over the status of same-sex marriages performed in the state.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government will recognize more than 300 same-sex marriages that were performed in Michigan last weekend, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Friday, a day after Michigan’s governor said his state would not.

headline: Tourney Returns to Garden, but 1961 Won’t Be Back
abstract: A look at the sports world in 1961, the last time Madison Square Garden hosted N.C.A.A. tournament games. The drought will end Friday night with two Round of 16 games there.
lead_paragraph: As you will be continually reminded if you watch the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden over the next few days, the tournament has not tickled the Garden’s nets since 1961. Yes, that’s a gap of 52 years — long enough that the Garden wasn’t even the same Garden. That Garden was on Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets — until they knocked it down in 1968 and put the new squatting over Penn Station.

headline: An Avalanche of Latin Pop
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss new albums by Shakira, Juanes, Romeo Santos, Enrique Iglesias, Wisin and Caetano Veloso.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss new albums by Shakira, Juanes, Romeo Santos, Enrique Iglesias, Wisin and Caetano Veloso.

headline: 77,000 Kate Bush Tickets Sell Out in Minutes
abstract: Ms. Bush’s planned concerts in London — now 22, with the addition of seven — are her first extended run of performances since a tour of Britain in 1979.
lead_paragraph: Last week the reclusive singer-songwriter Kate Bush announced that she would play 15 shows in London between Aug. 26 and Sept. 19 – her first extended run of performances since her single tour of Britain in 1979, at the start of her career. Fascination with Ms. Bush, and the prospect of seeing her – the 1979 shows were lavishly staged and choreographed, and her music since then has retained its inventiveness and mystique – was sufficient to crash her website almost instantly. She quickly added another seven shows at the 3,500-seat Eventim Apollo, extending the run to Oct. 1.

headline: Antiviral Drugs Cut Flu Deaths, Study Finds
abstract: Tamiflu and its siblings reduced the mortality rate in hospitalized patients by as much as 50 percent, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: During a recent flu outbreak, use of antiviral drugs reduced the death rate in hospitalized patients by as much as 50 percent, researchers report.

headline: Serial Renters in New York City
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: New York is home to a cadre of renters who move on an annual basis, often with enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: It is generally agreed that moving is a nightmare: Most people would rather lock themselves in and shove the renewal paperwork under the door than pack up and depart for unfamiliar environs and, horrors, new landlords.

headline: Lovely, Lethal and Out of This World
abstract: Scarlett Johansson plays a predatory extraterrestrial in Jonathan Glazer’s art-house science-fiction tale “Under the Skin,” a film with visionary cinematic antecedents.
lead_paragraph: In “Under the Skin,” a mysterious woman drives a van down the streets and byways of Scotland, picking up men. Her friendly manner seems a little off, her intentions murky. Evidence points to her being someone, or something, otherworldly. But from the disorienting rush of the film’s opening montage climaxing with a close-up on an eye, the only clear fact is that we’re in for a strange trip.

headline: Itinerary | Miami Beach’s Quieter Side
abstract: A chic, discreet new hotel and a host of low-key eateries provide a welcome alternative to the glitz of the city’s party scene.
lead_paragraph: It may be one of the world’s most glamorous playgrounds, but Miami Beach comes in more flavors than just plain party. Far from the madding crowds on the Lincoln Road Mall and Ocean Drive and the hubbub of this week’s Winter Music Conference, there’s another Miami Beach, one that’s quiet, chic and even subtle.

headline: Rising Seas + Dams + Aquifer Pumping = Delta Blues
abstract: Dams, water pumping and global warming are combining to threaten crowded delta regions.
lead_paragraph: Gardiner Harris has a comprehensive feature in The Times today taking a close look at the impact of advancing seas and sinking landscapes on Bangladesh, with a related story taking a global look at sea-level rise from global warming.

headline: In Local Election, a Referendum on Turkey’s Leader
abstract: The contest for mayor of Istanbul, to be decided this Sunday, could determine the political future of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — As the campaign bus moved through Istanbul’s traffic, the cityscape blurred: construction cranes, new shopping malls and boutiques, a billboard for the luxury department store Harvey Nichols — all signposts of a city more populous than some European countries, vastly reshaped under the Islamist government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

headline: Odd Man Out When Vote Was 445-1 on Crimea
abstract: The 1 in the Duma’s 445-1 approval of the Crimea annexation is a deputy from Siberia’s largest city who was skewered by Russian social media afterward.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The State Duma, Russia’s lower house of Parliament, is not exactly known as a bastion of independent thinking, so when the final vote approving the annexation of Crimea appeared on two large overhead screens last week at 445 to 1, it caused a stir.

headline: Charter Challenges Comcast-Time Warner Cable Deal
abstract: In a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Charter said the risk of regulatory rejection of the merger made it in the interest of Time Warner Cable shareholders to turn down the deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Charter Communications, which was rebuffed last year when it proposed a merger with Time Warner Cable, then lost out to Comcast in a bidding competition for the cable company, is urging the Time Warner Cable shareholders to reject the $45 billion deal with Comcast.

headline: ‘You Probably Don’t Want to Look in the Crisper’
abstract: Inside the fridges of 11 top New York chefs.
lead_paragraph: Inside the fridges of 11 top New York chefs.

headline: Before Chicago Made ‘Dinner’
abstract: Call it Judy Chicago’s appetizer course.
lead_paragraph: Call it Judy Chicago’s appetizer course. Before “The Dinner Party,” her series of individually symbolic plates, became a feminist touchstone in 1979, Ms. Chicago was experimenting with the kinds of forms that would become that pivotal project. Starting Friday, the Brooklyn Museum, home to “The Dinner Party,” is exploring those early years in this artist’s development.

headline: A New Rameau for Specialists
abstract: The 1745 comédie lyrique “Platée” is considered by many to be one of the French Baroque composer Jean-Philippe Rameau’s operatic masterworks.
lead_paragraph: Blithe, inventive and more than a little meanspirited, the 1745 comédie lyrique “Platée” is considered by many to be one of the French Baroque composer Jean-Philippe Rameau’s operatic masterworks. Yet somehow, Les Arts Florissants, an ensemble virtually peerless in the Rameau canon, has only just come to the work, playing it in a new Robert Carsen production at the Theater an der Wien and the Opéra Comique Paris during recent weeks.

headline: O.K., Singers, Let’s Move Along
abstract: Dancers and musicians will gather in harmony or, if the occasion demands, creative dissonance in three premieres by Miro Magloire’s New Chamber Ballet.
lead_paragraph: Dancers and musicians will gather in harmony or, if the occasion demands, creative dissonance in three premieres by Miro Magloire’s New Chamber Ballet, a troupe dedicated to close unions of dance and live music. Constantine Baecher, a former member of the Royal Danish Ballet, has choreographed “Exultation of Larks,” in which two nimble sopranos, Charlotte Mundy and Kjersti Kveli, move alongside dancers in call-and-response fashion to John Cage’s “Litany for the Whale.”

headline: Piracy 101
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: When can you download copyrighted materials for educational purposes?
lead_paragraph: I am a public-school teacher with a limited budget for supplies. Is it unethical to illegally download copyrighted instructional materials for use in my class? BEN L., BROOKLYN

headline: Cocktail Science, Simplified
abstract: The country’s most inventive bartenders (please don’t call them mixologists) explain how to make their creations at home, even if you don’t make your own bitters or own a centrifuge.
lead_paragraph: One recent night, I walked into Booker and Dax, the cocktail bar of the Momofuku empire, to find a serious discussion underway between a co-owner, Dave Arnold, and a bartender named Austin. They were trying to figure out why their latest experiment, a variation on a Campari and soda, changed character so drastically after aging for a day. What was intensifying the bitterness? Time? Acidity? A component in the liqueur?

headline: Not Enough Cooks in the Kitchen
abstract: Celebrity chefs have made our dining culture better, sure. Just not necessarily our dinner.
lead_paragraph: Last month I ate at Camino, a Cali-Med-Asian (that is, no-holds-barred) restaurant in Oakland, Calif. Camino is funky and open, and its look, which lacks pretense, offers little clue about the delights that await. There are long wooden communal tables for you and 29 of your closest friends, over which hang chandeliers that could pass for medieval drying racks. There’s live fire in a wide-open kitchen. The whole effect is even more casual than the upstairs at Chez Panisse in Berkeley, which was perhaps the original setting for tablecloth-free four-star food. It was also the place where Russ Moore, Camino’s chef and co-owner, worked for 20 years.

headline: How Do You Know When to Go Naked in Germany?
abstract: Mixed messages from inside the Liquidrom.
lead_paragraph: The sun was rising over Big Cabin, Okla., when I pulled up to the drive-through window at McDonald’s and said, “Howdy.” My wife and I were driving north from Texas, and she, a Texan born and raised, could not stop laughing. “ ‘Howdy’?” she said, incredulous. “I’m from Texas, and I’ve never said ‘howdy.’ I’ve never even heard it said. Where does that come from?”

headline: Barbara Ehrenreich Takes a Walk on the Wild Side
abstract: The author of “Living With a Wild God” on her childhood visions and atheist cred.
lead_paragraph: Your new book, “Living With a Wild God,” is quite a departure from the immersive, investigative reporting work you’re known for. It’s about dissociative experiences that you had in your teens. Can you describe them?  When I was 13, I had these episodes where I could just see the world without any words attached to it, without any associations. It was a little bit spooky. A lot of people might have even thought it was pathological. I thought it was interesting.

headline: Taken for a Ride at the Carwash
abstract: Jamie Bell’s past life in dance; Geoffrey Rush vs. King Joffrey.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Bell’s past life in dance; Geoffrey Rush vs. King Joffrey.

headline: A Woman’s Place Is Running the Kitchen
abstract: Barbara Lynch was a pioneer in the macho culture of professional kitchens. Now she’s giving an edge to the next generation.
lead_paragraph: When Barbara Lynch started working at Todd English’s restaurant, Olives, in 1989, it was so popular that people would begin lining up outside in the afternoon. On weekends, as the restaurant endured three relentless “turns,” with one table of diners replacing another, it seemed as if English’s reputation grew in proportion to how overwhelmed his kitchen felt. One evening, the chef was surveying his dining room — checking on tables, glad-handing guests — when a customer signaled for him to come over and inspect the spaghetti alle vongole veraci. Yes, the pasta was perfectly twirlable, and yes, the clams were open, but the dish was compromised by an unwelcome improvisation. English spotted it, snatched the bowl and darted into the kitchen, where the diminutive line cook with thick blue eyeliner and an AquaNet-affixed bouffant cowered behind her mise en place.

headline: Who Made That Chef’s Toque?
abstract: The (literal) rise and fall of kitchen headgear.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve long wondered how to change the way we wear our cotton hats,” wrote the French chef Antonin Carême in his 1822 manifesto on modern cuisine, “Le Maître d’Hôtel Français.” While working for the British ambassador in Vienna in 1821, Carême got the idea to insert a round piece of cardboard inside the floppy cap that was then standard headgear in the kitchen. “A cook should present as a man in good health,” he explained, “and our regular hat suggests a state of convalescence.” His illustration of the new style in his book’s frontispiece had two chefs standing side by side: Both wear floppy hats and double-breasted coats, aprons tied around their waists. On one chef, the headgear seems to have more poof — courtesy of the cardboard insert — but it’s nothing like the pleated toques, at least eight inches high, that have since become iconic.

headline: The Kid’s Table
abstract: Flynn McGarry wants to open the best restaurant in the world. So what if he’s only 15?
lead_paragraph: Flynn McGarry wants to open the best restaurant in the world. So what if he’s only 15?

headline: Can Anyone Save French Food?
abstract: Parisian cuisine is, at long last, showing signs of renewed vigor. But the French can’t take the credit.
lead_paragraph: Last year, outraged headlines worldwide announced that as many as 70 percent of the restaurants in France were using ready-made meals produced offsite at large industrial kitchens. The real surprise was that anyone was surprised. France’s culinary tradition has been withering for decades, the decline reflected in any number of data points — from the disappearance of raw-milk cheeses (less than 10 percent of all French cheeses are lait cru now) to the fall in French wine consumption (down by more than 50 percent since the 1960s) to the fact that France has become McDonald’s’ second-most-profitable market in the world. Since the late 1990s, Paris has come to be regarded as a dull, predictable food city. The real excitement is in London, Tokyo, New York, Copenhagen, San Sebastian.

headline: ‘Conducta’ to Open Havana Festival
abstract: A touching, clearheaded Cuban film about a high-strung 11-year-old boy in Havana opens the Havana Film Festival New York, now in its 15th year.
lead_paragraph: “Conducta,” a touching, clearheaded Cuban film about Chala, a high-strung 11-year-old boy in Havana who supports his alcoholic mother by caring for fighting dogs, opens the Havana Film Festival New York, now in its 15th year. The movie, directed by Ernesto Daranas, examines the healing relationship between the boy and his sixth-grade teacher, Carmela, a wise, caring, surrogate grandmother, who flouts the school’s strict rules to help her students. After she suffers a heart attack, her substitute sends Chala to a “re-education” school, a decision Carmela vehemently opposes, because it would be a black mark on his record. The children, their teachers and their parents represent a lively cross-section of contemporary Cuban society.

headline: A Couple of Nights of Disruptions
abstract: There are two important all-ages shows this week by young female modes of disruption.
lead_paragraph: There are two important all-ages shows this week by young female modes of disruption. Priests, from Washington, is a punk band whose 13 thus-far-available songs give the impression of four people (two men and two women, including the singer Katie Alice Greer) hijacking instruments in a public place — a high school band room? a vegan meet-up? — and pouring out instant songs about the last three things in their heads. The music is simple, strong, unfinished. They play Saturday at Death by Audio in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. (8 p.m., 49 South Second Street, entertainment4every1.net.)

headline: The Chef at 15
abstract: Flynn McGarry designs eight-course tasting menus and interns in three-star kitchens. Now he wants to open the best restaurant in the world.
lead_paragraph: One weekend in February, in the kitschy, barnlike house he shares with his mother and grandmother in the San Fernando Valley, Flynn McGarry was preparing an eight-course tasting menu for 15 guests. The McGarrys’ living room, which is dominated by a gigantic brick fireplace, had been cleared to make room for four tables draped with white tablecloths that his mom, Meg, steamed and pressed before moving on to the silver. “We’re having a ‘Downton Abbey’ moment here,” she said.

headline: Reply All: The 3.16.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: SILICON VALLEY’S YOUTH PROBLEM

headline: Kids, Never Board Strange Spaceships
abstract: Television has been full of serious programs about science and space lately, but Ricky the Rocketship appears not to have been watching.
lead_paragraph: Television has been full of serious programs about science and space lately, but Ricky the Rocketship appears not to have been watching.

headline: Search for Flight 370 Shifts Northeast
abstract: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said that the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been shifted nearly 700 miles northeast.
lead_paragraph: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, said that the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 had been shifted nearly 700 miles northeast.

headline: White House Unveils Plans to Cut Methane Emissions
abstract: The move is the latest in a series of administration actions aimed at addressing climate change without waiting for congressional action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday announced a strategy to start slashing emissions of methane, a powerful greenhouse gas released by landfills, cattle, and leaks from oil and natural gas production.

headline: The Tech Bubble’s Silver Lining: Cheap Services for Everyone
abstract: Box’s documents filed for its initial public offering show that the cloud-storage firm is losing a lot of money. There’s another way to say this: It’s giving customers lots of services for free. And it’s not alone.
lead_paragraph: Box is losing money. A lot of money. In documents it filed for its initial public offering, the cloud-storage firm disclosed this week that it took in $124 million in 2013, but spent $257 million.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Story of the Jews’
abstract: This week, Simon Schama discusses “The Story of the Jews”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Brigid Schulte talks about “Overwhelmed”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Simon Schama discusses “The Story of the Jews”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Brigid Schulte talks about “Overwhelmed”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: A Lethal Prince, Even if a Bit Clumsy
abstract: Pedro Pascal discusses joining “Game of Thrones” as a murderous royal, even though he initially didn’t know he’d gotten the part.
lead_paragraph: When Pedro Pascal won the role of Oberyn Martell on the HBO series “Game of Thrones” last year, it should have been a highlight of his career, and it might well have been, had somebody remembered to tell him. After sending in two audition tapes, he flew to Northern Ireland from his home in Los Angeles at the request of that show’s creators David Benioff and Dan Weiss, nervous about what else he might have to do to secure the part. Then the congratulations began. “I think they were under the impression that somebody had told me that they had stopped looking,” Mr. Pascal said. “I don’t think they knew that I didn’t know.”

headline: Fed by Three Streams, a Creek Rises
abstract: The influential folk bluegrass group Nickel Creek, which broke up in 2007 as its three members pursued other projects, has a new album and tour.
lead_paragraph: Sara Watkins is grinning, her fiddle tucked under an arm. “Sean and Chris and I grew up playing in a band called Nickel Creek together,” she says, indicating the guitarist Sean Watkins and the mandolinist Chris Thile, on either side of her. A small but hearty crowd — packed into the kids’ tent at the 2012 Newport Folk Festival and startled to find itself in the right place at the right time — lets out a whooping cheer.

headline: The Summer Heat of Miles, the Early Cool of D’Angelo
abstract: Vintage concerts from Miles Davis and D’Angelo, new music from S. Carey and Eric Revis.
lead_paragraph: D’Angelo

headline: Hail to the Mischief Maker
abstract: Timothy Simons, whose “Veep” character, Jonah, is so loved and reviled that he has attained a life of his own outside the show, has professional changes coming into his life.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jonah Ryan, the presidential liaison on the HBO series “Veep,” is the insufferable toady you love to hate. Over the course of the show’s first two seasons, his colleagues have coined several unaffectionate nicknames for him, including crude mash-ups of his first name and various parts of the male anatomy. In one episode last season, Vice President Selina Meyer (Julia Louis-Dreyfus) ordered him off Air Force Two, despite the fact that the plane was already taxiing down the runway, or perhaps because of it. “As dysfunctional as Selina and her staff are,” Ms. Louis-Dreyfus said, “the one thing that binds them together is their global disdain for Jonah Ryan.”

headline: Whose Brooklyn Is It, Anyway?
abstract: Spike Lee’s recent comments about the gentrification of Brooklyn and “Christopher Columbus syndrome” were a mixture of hyperbole, provocation and plain truth.
lead_paragraph: In February, at a Black History Month event in Brooklyn, Spike Lee spoke out against the recent transformation of the borough where he grew up and where many of his films — “Red Hook Summer,” “Clockers,” “Crooklyn” and of course “Do the Right Thing” — had been set. His complaints had to do not only with the accelerating gentrification of Brooklyn neighborhoods like Fort Greene and Bedford-Stuyvesant but also with the fact that other historically African-American parts of New York had become whiter and wealthier in recent years.

headline: To Dance, Perchance to Dream
abstract: Shakespeare’s plays, which often deal with young love, magic and the elemental, readily lend themselves to dance, as countless adaptations demonstrate.
lead_paragraph: Romeo and Juliet meet at a dance; Oberon and Titania reconcile with a dance; we’re told how enchantingly Cleopatra once hopped 40 paces down the street; in the final scene of “As You Like It,” Duke Senior addresses the four young couples: “Brides and bridegrooms, dance your happiness away.” In Shakespeare’s plays, dance and movement often recur. (There even are touching moments when characters exclude themselves from dancing. Jaques in “As You Like It” declines to join in: “I am for other than for dancing measures.” In “Romeo and Juliet,” Lord Capulet says to a cousin: “You and I are past our dancing days.”)

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘The Story of the Jews’
abstract: This week, Simon Schama and Brigid Schulte.
lead_paragraph: This week, Simon Schama and Brigid Schulte.

headline: Why Is President Obama’s Foreign Policy Unpopular?
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It’s about outcomes, not ideology.
lead_paragraph: Writing in the Washington Post this week, Robert Kagan highlights what he calls the “paradox” of the current president’s approach to world affairs — namely, that even though Obama has been allegedly giving a war-weary public “the foreign policy they want” (by pulling out of Iraq, opting for non-intervention in Syria, etc.), his foreign policy ratings are currently terrible. Kagan argues, credibly, that these numbers are actually a judgment on the president’s national security stewardship, and not just an extension of public disillusionment with his domestic policy. Then, somewhat less credibly, he proffers this interpretation of the swoon:

headline: Veiled Truths
abstract: Photographs of women in Iran — who still face censure for insufficiently modest dress — through their hijabs.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of women in Iran — who still face censure for insufficiently modest dress — through their hijabs.

headline: Park Avenue: Prewar Bones, Renewed
abstract: A 10-room prewar apartment with a top-to-bottom renovation and open city views.
lead_paragraph: A classically configured 10-room prewar apartment at 911 Park Avenue that has retained but reinvigorated its original bones with sophisticated finishes and an unusual modernist décor is poised to enter the market at $9.5 million.

headline: Visuals: Mixed Media
abstract: “Brian Eno: Visual Music,” “Verve: The Sound of America,” and more.
lead_paragraph: “Brian Eno: Visual Music,” “Verve: The Sound of America,” and more.

headline: Lufthansa Pilots Plan 3-Day Strike for Next Week
abstract: Germany’s flagship airline called for a return to the bargaining table to avoid widespread international travel disruptions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A union representing pilots at Lufthansa, the German flagship airline, has called for a three-day strike in the coming week as part of a protracted dispute over pay and retirement benefits. The airline, seeking to avoid potentially widespread disruptions in international air travel, said Friday that pilots should return to the negotiating table.

headline: Legendary Deal Maker Criticizes Investors With Short-Term Interests
abstract: Speaking at the Tulane Corporate Law Institute, the lawyer Martin Lipton offered a short list of activist investors he likes and doesn’t.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — No discussion of shareholder activism can happen without invoking the name Martin Lipton. He’s the lawyer who has defended corporate America for decades.

headline: Rebels and Radicals
abstract: New books by Robert Hofler, Aram Goudsouzian, Hisham D. Aidi and Sean Strub.
lead_paragraph: SEXPLOSION  From Andy Warhol to “A Clockwork Orange” — How a Generation of Pop Rebels Broke All the Taboos  By Robert Hofler  It Books/HarperCollins, $27.99.

headline: Everybody Loathes Raymond
abstract: A gleefully mean cameraman lands a reality TV assignment on a remote Pacific island.
lead_paragraph: “Like you, I consider myself a reasonable enough citizen,” explains Raymond Gunt, the narrator of Douglas Coupland’s new novel, in the book’s opening paragraph. “You know: Live life in moderation, enjoy the occasional YouTube clip of frolicking otters and kittens, . . . make the effort to try to be nice to the poor.” By the second paragraph, Gunt is comparing himself to Jason Bourne; before a dozen pages are through, he is kicking a homeless man in the shins, unprovoked.

headline: Kid Rock
abstract: A British band is transformed into a toddler sensation in this novel.
lead_paragraph: Among the many things the reader learns about the music business in “Wonderkid” — Wesley Stace’s winningly dry, occasionally hilarious and enervatingly long-winded novel about a popular 1990s rock band for kids — are the ironclad rules of the tour bus: “Sleep with your feet towards the driver, no bowel movements in the toilet and, most importantly, don’t get left behind.” How does the author know? In addition to having written three other novels (all of them set in earlier eras) Stace has cut some dozen albums under the name John Wesley Harding.

headline: Turning a World on Its Ear
abstract: In Murray Bail’s novel, an Australian tinkerer ventures to Europe to revolutionize classical music.
lead_paragraph: Murray Bail is one of Australia’s best living writers, and “The Voyage” is his finest book to date — a rich, sparkling novel that reinvigorates literary modernism and shows a master at work.

headline: Image of the Day: March 28
abstract: One person was killed and three others were injured in a militant attack in Kathua district of Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: TO SAVE EVERYTHING, CLICK HERE: The Folly of Technological Solutionism,  by Evgeny Morozov. (PublicAffairs, $17.99.) Morozov’s first book, “The Net Delusion” (2011), looked skeptically at the belief that social networks were responsible for fomenting political change around the globe. Now he’s expanded that critique to question the digital-age temptation to fix everything — politics, criminology, the quest to lose weight — by quantifying and tracking behavior on the Internet.

headline: ABC News Hires Former New York Police Commissioner
abstract: Raymond W. Kelly, a 43-year veteran of the New York Police Department, will be a consultant and expert commentator for all the network’s news programs.
lead_paragraph: ABC News announced on Friday that it had hired the former New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, as a consultant and expert commentator on law enforcement issues.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Simon Schama, whose “Story of the Jews” enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 9, is also a contributor to a new anthology called “Poems That Make Grown Men Cry.” He chose “Lullaby” by Auden.
lead_paragraph: Start Me Up: Simon Schama enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 9 with “The Story of the Jews,” his sweeping new history covering the two and a half millenniums from 1000 B.C. to 1492. The book contains a lot of praise for the “immense, surprisingly chatty body of Hebrew literature” — but when the editors of a new anthology, “Poems That Make Grown Men Cry,” asked Schama what brings a tear to his eye, he settled not on any Jewish verse but on “Lullaby,” by the deeply (and deeply conflicted) Anglican W. H. Auden. “The poem suspends time and the brutality of the world,” Schama writes, “at the moment of unanswerably perfect love. . . . It is the honesty embedded amidst sheets and on the pillow that makes the eyes prick and the heart knock.” It’s hard to fault his choice. “Lullaby” was written after the Nazis had come to power — as Auden puts it, “fashionable madmen raise / Their pedantic boring cry” — and it makes a strong case for the triumph of romance, no matter how fleeting. One of the great love poems, it’s so solemn and stately and tender you can almost imagine it set to pipe organ. Here’s how it starts:

headline: Today in Small Business: The S.B.A.’s Red Tape Ombudsman
abstract: Facebook’s drones. Why your emails are not getting opened. The least costly city in which to do business.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In India, Some Misgivings About Abstention in U.N.’s Sri Lanka Vote
abstract: The Indian finance minister said he felt that India should have supported the resolution calling for an investigation of allegations of serious violations of human rights during Sri Lanka’s civil war, and a politician in Tamil Nadu accused the central government of abandoning ethnic Tamils.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Several Indian politicians on Friday questioned India’s decision to abstain from a United Nations Human Rights Council vote that approved an international investigation into war crimes committed by the Sri Lankan government and the Tamil Tiger rebels toward the end of Sri Lanka’s civil war.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ALL OUR NAMES,  by Dinaw Mengestu. (Knopf, $25.95.) With great sadness and much hard truth, Mengestu’s novel looks at a relationship of shared dependencies between a Midwestern social worker and a bereft African immigrant.

headline: A Profile in Courage Prize for George Bush (the Other One)
abstract: The John F. Kennedy Library Foundation recognized George H.W. Bush for agreeing to a difficult tax increase.
lead_paragraph: I did a double take when I saw the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation’s 2014 Profile in Courage award winners, announced yesterday. The first one went to former President George Bush. “That guy?” I thought to myself, “His lack of courage was breathtaking.” But then I looked closer and saw that the Foundation was honoring not former President George W. Bush, but George H.W. Bush, who actually did do something courageous.

headline: Wheelies: The Euro-Buick Edition
abstract: G.M. will build Buicks at its Opel plant in Germany; Ford will build its new V6 Ecoboost truck engines at its factory in Ohio.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: The End of a Long Road
abstract: David Brion Davis’s “The Problem of Slavery in the Age of Emancipation” completes a trilogy that he began writing in 1959.
lead_paragraph: David Brion Davis’s “The Problem of Slavery in the Age of Emancipation,” reviewed this week by Brenda Wineapple, concludes a trilogy that Davis began writing in 1959, after he won a Guggenheim fellowship. “I was planning on doing a book on American and British antislavery movements,” he said in an email interview, “but soon found that the first chapter on ‘historical background’ should really constitute a book in itself — ranging from ancient Greece to the late 1700s, with a revolutionary shift in the moral perception of slavery.”

headline: The Price of Slavery
abstract: The final volume of a trilogy centers on 19th-century abolitionism and the origins of the antislavery movement in America.
lead_paragraph: In 1862, when Nathaniel Hawthorne headed south from New England to see the Civil War firsthand, he came upon a group of former slaves trudging northward. “They seemed a kind of creature by themselves, not altogether human,” he wrote, “but perhaps quite as good, and akin to the fauns and rustic deities of olden times.” “Whoever may be benefited by the results of this war,” he added, “it will not be the present generation of negroes.”

headline: More Than a Game
abstract: A study of trends that changed the boundaries for women athletes.
lead_paragraph: If you’d rather spend your Sunday getting shocked by electrodes on a Tough Mudder obstacle course than reading 300 pages of academic writing on sports bras and cheerleading — “couched in the hegemony of heteronormative, patriarchal family relations” — you’re not alone. We are, thank God, at a moment in women’s sports history when lady jocks are running marathons and playing pro basketball instead of being told by the former head of the International Ski Federation that ski jumping “seems to not be appropriate for the ladies from a medical point of view.” This is fantastic — and it is also disarmingly recent (2005). So while it’s safe to say that few will be swept away by the prose in “Qualifying Times,” Jaime Schultz, an assistant professor of women’s studies and kinesiology at Penn State University, has done a service by collecting the history of ponytails, tennis whites, tampons and other topics connected to women and sports into one volume.

headline: On Top of Everything Else
abstract: A journalist, wife and mother searches for answers to our headlong descent into multitasking madness.
lead_paragraph: A memorable moment in American labor history was the 1912 textile strike in Lawrence, Mass., when, according to lore, predominantly female workers marched with signs reading, “We want bread, but we want roses, too.” The apocryphal slogan, revived in songs recorded in the 1970s and ’80s by Judy Collins and John Denver, came to mean, “We need a decent living, but we need a life, too.”

headline: Home to the Strange Familiar
abstract: Teju Cole’s unnamed hero returns to Lagos, hoping to reconnect with the city of his youth.
lead_paragraph: Teju Cole’s “Open City” was one of the most acclaimed debut novels of recent years. The story of a young African wandering the streets of New York City struck out into new territory for what might be termed immigrant fiction. We have become accustomed to a certain sort of narrative about people who come to the metropolis from the periphery. Whether set in New York, London or elsewhere, such fictions tend to present stories of striving and self-invention. We see the new immigrant struggling to make a life in an unfriendly or even hostile environment, overwhelmed by the novelty of sights and sounds, anxious about holding on to culture and tradition, filled with wonder at first-world wealth and consumption. By contrast, Cole’s narrator in “Open City” is a self-assured young cosmopolitan, an educated professional who does not ask permission to explore, describe and pass judgment. His breadth of cultural reference is not limited to the traditions of West Africa. He is a lover of Mahler and Modernist photography. He reads Walter Benjamin and Roland Barthes.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘The Story of the Jews’
abstract: Simon Schama discusses his new book, the first installment of a two-volume history.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Judith Shulevitz reviews Simon Schama’s “The Story of the Jews.” Ms. Shulevitz writes:

headline: Deep Water
abstract: A dam disrupts Appalachian lives in the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: The Tennessee Valley Authority brought change to the heart of Appalachia in the 1930s, forcing locals to relocate voluntarily or linger on the land and be removed by their own government. Though the damming of the river would provide electricity and other conveniences across the region, there were many who were not swayed by arguments of the common good and tried to stay, even as the water rose across their fields and toward the houses. Early on in Amy Greene’s aching, passionate and vivid new novel, “Long Man,” a character stands in the night, surveying all that will be lost to progress. “She had heard about a Depression going on but saw no evidence of it herself. She didn’t understand the power company’s reasoning. She didn’t need electric lights when she could see by the sun and moon. She had the spring and the earth to keep her food from spoiling. She had a washboard for scrubbing clean her dresses. If a person didn’t come to depend on material things, it wouldn’t hurt to lose them.”

headline: An Eden of Reeds
abstract: This fablelike first novel is set on an alluvial plain much like the marshlands of southern Iraq.
lead_paragraph: After several books for young readers, Matthew Olshan’s first work for adults is a fablelike novel set in marshlands very much like those of southern Iraq. A huge waterscape in the desert, this marshland system lies on an ancient alluvial plain Olshan calls “an Eden of reeds and silver waterways, where ruined Bronze Age palaces seemed to doze like exhausted parents, oblivious to the joyful birds that ran riot along their spines.” Its occupants have long been outsiders seeking refuge, often under attack. Over its extensive history a culture and way of life evolved that separated the marshlands from its neighbors and from the world beyond. But no longer. War, occupation and strategic draining have shattered the place, people and environment.

headline: Rights Panel Seeks Inquiry of North Korea
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: In a resolution, the United Nations Human Rights Council urged global powers to back a criminal investigation of North Korea for crimes against humanity and to consider targeted sanctions.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — In one of its stronger resolutions, the United Nations Human Rights Council urged global powers on Friday to back an international criminal investigation of North Korea for crimes against humanity and to consider targeted sanctions against those responsible.

headline: His, Hers, Ours
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Questions about social situations.
lead_paragraph: My 83-year-old father-in-law will soon marry a 70-year-old woman about a year after the death of his wife of 56 years. As a family, we are thrilled that he will have a loving companion. The problem is, we think the happy couple wants to somehow blend his three adult children and our families with her three adult children and theirs. We are all over 50 and we don’t feel comfortable with this idea or think of our father-in-law’s new wife as a stepmother or mother-in-law. What should we do? And how should we introduce her in social situations?

headline: BMW to Expand South Carolina Factory
abstract: The German automaker said on Friday that the expansion reflected the importance of the United States market.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — BMW said on Friday that it would invest $1 billion over the next two years in its factory in Spartanburg, S.C., which will become its largest production site.

headline: Manhattan Real Estate Feels a Russian Chill
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Brokers worry that the growing tensions between the United States and Russia could hurt the foreign-fueled luxury market.
lead_paragraph: Who doesn’t enjoy a good yarn about Russian oligarchs who throw their fortunes at New York real estate? Take the Russian fertilizer king Dmitry Rybolovlev, who is linked to a record-breaking $88 million sale at 15 Central Park West, or the composer Igor Krutoy, who bought three apartments at the Plaza Hotel. Yet these tales of excess could soon fade into memory.

headline: Git Along, Little Dogies
abstract: How bovine ornaments ended up in a lot at Hudson River Park.
lead_paragraph: There they sit on a buckled asphalt lot in Hudson River Park in Manhattan, near 34th Street just south of the New York Police Department tow pound, their bovine eyes staring fixedly ahead, puzzling those who pass by on the pedestrian path, and tantalizing photographers who yearn to get a shot through the chain-link fence.

headline: A Taste of M.F.K. Fisher’s Provence
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The trip “Return to M.F.K. Fisher’s Provence” will be led by the author’s grandnephew Luke Barr and will include a cooking class and tours of local food markets.
lead_paragraph: Fans of food and history will have the opportunity to see Provence as the legendary food writer M.F.K. Fisher did in the company of her grandnephew, author and editor Luke Barr.

headline: Seeking Truth in a Blizzard of ‘Snowflakes’
abstract: In “The Unknown Known,” Errol Morris uses the many memos that Donald H. Rumsfeld buried his staff under as defense secretary as a Rosetta stone to his subject’s character.
lead_paragraph: Errol Morris recalls that when he first met Donald H. Rumsfeld, he asked that former defense secretary for President George W. Bush what he thought of “The Fog of War,” Mr. Morris’s 2003 Oscar-winning documentary about Robert S. McNamara, another towering Pentagon chief toppled by a misguided war.

headline: Listen Up | An Artist Who Brings Background Music to the Forefront
abstract: James Ferraro’s new show at MoMA PS1 turns corporate-style electronic sounds into a curious multimedia experience.
lead_paragraph: In “100%,” his new, multifaceted sound installation at MoMA PS1, the experimental musician and composer James Ferraro unpacks the music of globalization. The project’s sonic environments evoke music most of us don’t think of as music: sound-branding on a corporate website, the soundtrack of an in-flight instructional video, the incidental sounds of a computer. It’s a niche of electronic music with roots in the ambient compositions of the ’70s (Brian Eno famously composed the Microsoft start-up melody) that has evolved over time into a slick marketing sound as risible as advertising jingles. Somehow, though, Ferraro cracks open the genre, runs it back through the machine and arrives at music that turns our ears on where they had been shut off.

headline: Norwegian to Lead NATO as It Is Poised for Bigger Role
abstract: The appointment of Jens Stoltenberg comes as the United States reaffirms its commitment to the Western military alliance as a way of containing an increasingly assertive Russia.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Former Prime Minister Jens Stoltenberg of Norway will lead NATO starting on Oct. 1, the alliance announced Friday.

headline: Times Minute | Gwyneth Paltrow’s ‘Uncoupling’
abstract: A hot phrase emerged this week — “uncoupling” — after Gwyneth Paltrow used the term to describe her breakup with Chris Martin. Also on the Minute, backyard rodeos and the history of the chef’s hat.

headline: Attack at Wrong Door Turns Into Fatal Mistake for the Taliban, Reports Say
abstract: Explosions could be heard afterward at the house used by an American aid contractor, where three Americans and two other foreigners were trapped.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban assailants apparently thought they were attacking an unprotected Christian-run day care center. But they mistakenly burst into the compound next door, where an American government contractor’s employees were heavily armed and ready, according to accounts that the contractor and the Afghan police gave on Friday of a wild four-hour shootout here.

headline: Times Minute | Paltrow’s ‘Uncoupling’
abstract: A hot phrase this week — ‘conscious uncoupling’ — when Gwyneth Paltrow used the term. Also on the, backyard rodeos and the history of the chef’s hat.
lead_paragraph: A hot phrase this week — ‘conscious uncoupling’ — when Gwyneth Paltrow used the term. Also on the, backyard rodeos and the history of the chef’s hat.

headline: ‘Gas Giant,’ by Jacob Hashimoto
abstract: The Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art is hosting an installation of Jacob Hashimoto’s work, “Gas Giant.” The sculpture creates a handmade landscape from paper, wood and string.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art is hosting an installation of Jacob Hashimoto’s work, “Gas Giant.” The sculpture creates a handmade landscape from paper, wood and string.

headline: Video Notebook: Soccer in Swaziland
abstract: The Frugal Traveler plays pickup soccer with kids near Shewula village.
lead_paragraph: The Frugal Traveler plays pickup soccer with kids near Shewula village.

headline: The Self-Drive Safari
abstract: Seth Kugel rents a car and guides himself through the roads of South Africa’s Kruger National Park in search of big game.
lead_paragraph: Seth Kugel rents a car and guides himself through the roads of South Africa’s Kruger National Park in search of big game.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Noah’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Noah.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Noah.”

headline: Video Notebook: Bunny Chow in Durban
abstract: Learning to eat bunny chow, no utensils required, at a Durban restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Learning to eat bunny chow, no utensils required, at a Durban restaurant.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Cesar Chavez’
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Cesar Chavez.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Cesar Chavez.”

headline: Ang Lee and Zhang Yimou on Movies and the China Market
abstract: In a pubic conversation, the two directors discussed the country’s growing industry and its current lack of films “full of imagination.”
lead_paragraph: The crowd of several hundred standing in the cold on an East Village street on Thursday night, mostly young and mostly Asian, could have been waiting for the latest K-pop band or a new Cronut. But what had them excited was the prospect of watching two men with a combined age of 121 talking about movies.

headline: D.I.Y. Africa
abstract: From a budget safari to an urban alternative to Cape Town, the Frugal Traveler cuts his own path through the southern part of the continent.
lead_paragraph: It was a daunting challenge for a lone traveler in the African bush: Using only a tiny $23-a-day Fiat and my wits, I had to sneak around the six sleeping lions blocking the gravelly road ahead.

headline: Popcast: An Avalanche of Latin Pop
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Pareles discuss new albums by Shakira, Juanes, Romeo Santos, Enrique Iglesias, Wisin and Caetano Veloso.
lead_paragraph: Several of the greatest forces in Latin pop around the world have, seemingly by accident, released new albums within a short span of time.

headline: Scenes of India, From a Fort and a Camel
abstract: On an adventure to Jaisalmer and beyond, taking in the view from nearly 900-year-old fort walls and exploring the Thar Desert.
lead_paragraph: The view from atop the nearly 900-year-old walls of one of the oldest inhabited forts in the world was distracting, to say the least. Two hundred and fifty feet below me, the sandstone city of Jaisalmer in western Rajasthan, resembled an earthen cubist painting of angular card-houses, surrounded by an endless sand-and-scrub landscape. Above it all, the evening sky glowed a dusky purple.

headline: Beer, in the Glass and on the Plate, in Brussels
abstract: At these four restaurants in and near Belgium’s capital, beer serves a dual role for diners.
lead_paragraph: Long before the global explosion of interest in good food and good beer, the traditional recipes of Belgium often included a splash of a great local brew. But despite the country’s long brewing history and rich culinary culture, real beer cooking (la cuisine à la bière) remains something of a rarity, at least in the capital.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Finding Vivian Maier’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Finding Vivian Maier.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Finding Vivian Maier.”

headline: A Vision Beyond Cable for Comcast After Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cable Television', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: If its acquisition of Time Warner Cable is approved, Comcast will become much more than a regional cable company, says its chief executive, Brian Roberts.
lead_paragraph: Comcast’s chief executive, Brian Roberts, was stung four years ago when Reed Hastings, chief executive of the then-fledgling Netflix, dismissed Comcast with a rhetorical question: “Why would we want to do a deal with a regional cable company?”

headline: Welcome to Spin Class: You Won’t Last
abstract: Your thighs are on fire and your lungs are about to explode and you are about to pass out. Yeah, it’s that good.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations on signing up for spin class. For building muscles and cardio, it’s the best exercise there is. Good on you. Give yourself a hand. You may find the workouts challenging in the beginning, so for you newcomers, a tip:

headline: Seeking a Town on the Border of Fiction and Reality
abstract: Google recently removed Agloe, N.Y., in the western Catskills, from its map, but how it endured on area charts for so long remains a cartographic mystery.
lead_paragraph: SOMEWHERE NEAR AGLOE, N.Y. — It is one thing to lose your keys or your iPhone, even the love of your life, but to lose an entire town? Yet that is what just happened in upstate New York. Last week, Google did something it almost never does — it wiped a town off its maps.

headline: Shallot Shortage in Your ‘Hood? Sam Sifton Has a Solution
abstract: Last Sunday’s popular recipe for chicken thighs with shallots by Sam Sifton may or may not have caused a shallot shortage.
lead_paragraph: The first tip was a comment from Madeline about Sam Sifton’s recipe for chicken thighs with shallots in last weekend’s magazine:

headline: Jeremiah A. Denton Jr., 89, Dies; With Blinks, Vietnam P.O.W. Told of Torture
abstract: A Navy pilot who endured years in North Vietnamese captivity, he was later prompted by what he saw as America’s moral decline to become a proponent of right-wing Christian groups.
lead_paragraph: The prisoner of war had been tortured for 10 months and beaten repeatedly by his North Vietnamese captors in recent days, and there were threats of more if he did not respond properly when the propaganda broadcast began. Haggard but gritty, Cmdr. Jeremiah A. Denton Jr. slumped in a chair before the television cameras.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: This week’s properties include a four-bedroom in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom in Far Hills, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:

abstract: This week’s properties include a duplex in Greenwich Village; a four-bedroom in Morningside Heights; and a three-bedroom in Park Slope.
