headline: Repelling a Taliban Attack
abstract: Taliban insurgents exchanged gunfire with police in Kabul near a guesthouse used by foreigners in an upscale residential area.
lead_paragraph: Taliban insurgents exchanged gunfire with police in Kabul near a guesthouse used by foreigners in an upscale residential area.

headline: Joan Rivers Back on ‘Tonight Show’ After Decades
abstract: Ms. Rivers made her first full appearance on the show since 1986, when Johnny Carson banned her after she started her own talk show.
lead_paragraph: Joan Rivers returned to “The Tonight Show” as a guest for the first time in 28 years on Thursday evening, long after Johnny Carson declared her persona non grata at the show. And the 80-year-old comedian seemed sufficiently at home with the show’s new host, Jimmy Fallon, to slip quickly into the racier side of her comedy, explaining, for example, that she had brought a round pillow to sit on because she had just gotten a new genital piercing. (She returned to related subjects several times.)

headline: No Easy Way to Restrict Construction in Risky Areas
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Building (Construction)', 'Landslides and Mudslides', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)']
abstract: The government has broad authority to regulate safety in decisions about where and how to build, but it can count on trouble when it tries to restrict the right to build.
lead_paragraph: After disasters like the Oso landslide in Washington State, a common question is why people are allowed to live in such dangerous places. On the website of Scientific American, for example, the blogger Dana Hunter wrote, “It infuriates me when officials know an area is unsafe, and allow people to build there anyway.”

headline: Big Ticket | A Trade-Up With Views for $24 Million
abstract: A seven-room condominium at 15 Central Park West, a limestone fortress renowned for its boldface clientele, was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
lead_paragraph: A seven-room condominium at 15 Central Park West, the limestone fortress renowned for its sybaritic amenities, prewar grace notes and boldface clientele, sold for $24 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Gavin Kaysen to Leave Café Boulud
abstract: The executive chef plans to open his own restaurant, Merchant, in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Kaysen, who has been the executive chef at Café Boulud for the past seven years, will leave the restaurant in June. He will return to his hometown, Minneapolis, where he plans to open his own restaurant, Merchant.

headline: Forced to Slow Down, Dario Franchitti Adjusts to Adviser Role
abstract: After a car crash last fall sent him into early retirement, Dario Franchitti, 40, will stay with Chip Ganassi Racing as an adviser. He will also drive the pace car at the Indy 500 in May.
lead_paragraph: As the IndyCar season begins this weekend in St. Petersburg, Fla., Dario Franchitti is there. When the engines start for the Indianapolis 500 in May, he will be there, too.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 76
abstract: FIFA has instructed World Cup referees to focus on heavy tackles from behind in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Navigating the Logistics of Death Ahead of Time
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Data Storage', 'Wills and Estates', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies', 'Funerals and Memorials']
abstract: The number of end-of-life planning and document storage sites is on the rise.
lead_paragraph: Abby Schneiderman, then a 32-year-old mother and entrepreneur, was getting ready to celebrate her daughter’s first birthday when she received the news: Her older brother had been killed in a head-on collision while driving through East Hampton, N.Y., with his family.

headline: Port Authority Official Is Out Amid Scandal Over Shut Lanes
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie announced the resignation of David Samson, the highest-ranking official to quit during the scandal over the George Washing Bridge lane closings, as Mr. Christie set out to re-establish himself on the national stage.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie on Friday announced the resignation of the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey — the highest-ranking public official to step down during the scandal over lane closings at the George Washington Bridge — as he embarked on an aggressive campaign to re-establish himself on the national stage.

headline: The Season of the Bomber Jacket
abstract: This spring, trench coats make way for the new outerwear of choice.
lead_paragraph: In a season typically associated with trench coats, the bomber jacket stood out as the outerwear item of choice during the spring shows. Beyond the standard fatigues green, designers offered the classic MA-1 style — originally designed for pilots by the Air Force — in an array of colors and fabrications, stripping the timeless silhouette of its military connotations. In combination with a pair of weathered jeans and layered over just about anything, it looks as cool now as it did on Dutch kids at Studio Paradiso in the ’80s.

headline: Bid Adieu to Winter With a Colorful Lamb Stew
abstract: A French braise of lamb shoulder is bolstered by a colorful bouquet of spring vegetables.
lead_paragraph: It would be fair to say that French carnivores are in love with lamb. My favorite Parisian butcher has daily deliveries, and everyone in the neighborhood buys it.

headline: The Week in Pictures for March 28
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the aftermath of a fatal fire on the Jersey Shore, stubborn winter weather and a peek at the tangle of gas pipes under the city.
lead_paragraph: .media.slideshow.in-page-player .headline { display: none; }

headline: Jury Rejects Insanity Defense in ’08 Killing of Manhattan Therapist
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: David Tarloff, a man with schizophrenia whose two previous trials ended without a verdict, was found guilty of murdering Kathryn Faughey on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: David Tarloff, a man with schizophrenia who bludgeoned and stabbed a psychologist to death during a botched robbery six years ago, was found guilty of her murder on Friday by a Manhattan jury that rejected an insanity defense.

headline: BlackBerry Has a New Agenda and a New Dilemma
abstract: While the strategy is far from a sure thing, analysts agree that BlackBerry’s new focus on mobile management software and services is perhaps the company’s best hope of turning itself around. That strategy, of course, has not been lost on others.
lead_paragraph: After four and a half months as the chief executive of BlackBerry, John S. Chen has made its mobile data and identity management software and services businesses a key component of his resuscitation plan for the ailing smartphone company.

headline: Texas Monthly Editor to Lead Times Magazine
abstract: Under Jake Silverstein the magazine will have a closer relationship with the newspaper, The Times’s managing editor, Dean Baquet, said.
lead_paragraph: Jake Silverstein, the editor in chief of Texas Monthly, will become the new editor of The New York Times Magazine, the newspaper announced on Friday.

headline: G.M. Expands Ignition Switch Recall to Later Models
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The move adds 971,000 small cars worldwide, including 824,000 in the United States, that may have been previously repaired with faulty switches.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Friday that it was expanding its ignition switch recall to include an additional 971,000 small cars worldwide that may have been previously repaired with defective switches.

headline: Rihanna’s Icon Award, the Most Expensive Dress of the Season and DVF’s New Show
abstract: Plus, Google Glass’s new look, a debut nail polish from Kiehl’s and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Swinging for the Fences
abstract: Chris Distefano, a comedian who will be a host of MTV2’s new “Off the Bat From the M.L.B. Fan Cave” program, spends his Sundays reveling in brunch, at the batting cage and onstage.
lead_paragraph: Fans of New York sports teams may see athletics and mirth as mutually exclusive, but the comedian Chris Distefano, 29, has found a niche combining the two. Mr. Distefano, a former physical therapist who gave it up for standup comedy, has been a regular on several MTV and MTV2 comedy shows, including “Guy Code” and “Girl Code.” Starting on April 1, he will be a host of MTV2’s new “Off the Bat From the M.L.B. Fan Cave,” a program in which players and celebrities will drop by the Major League Baseball space on Broadway and East Fourth Street. He recently moved to Long Island City, Queens, to a building with a basketball court.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: Pleas by ‘Dewey Seven’ Reveal Details on Financial Manipulation
abstract: The unsealed pleas of seven former lower-level employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf indicate that they came from much different backgrounds than many of the high-powered lawyers at the once-prominent New York firm.
lead_paragraph: The seven former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf who pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme to manipulate the law firm’s finances came from much different backgrounds than many of the high-powered lawyers at the once-prominent New York firm.

headline: Weekend Reading: March Madness, Wall St. Edition II
abstract: This week we look at some second, and third round matches in the Wall street edition of March Madness.
lead_paragraph: This week we look at some second, and third round matches in the Wall street edition of March Madness.

headline: A Romance With Lemon Juice and Two Beach Towels
abstract: Two lives in relief work finally came together.
lead_paragraph: During recent world disasters, Alison Thompson liked to say, she was in the wrong place at the right time.

headline: On Internet Slang, IMHO
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The brevity of modern conversation can prove daunting.
lead_paragraph: This.

headline: Cornmeal Waffles With Bourbon Syrup
abstract: It’s time to pull the waffle iron out of storage. Melissa Clark shows how to make light and fluffy cornmeal waffles with a healthy drizzling of banana bourbon syrup.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to pull the waffle iron out of storage. Melissa Clark shows how to make light and fluffy cornmeal waffles with a healthy drizzling of banana bourbon syrup.

headline: The Gun Report: March 28, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The shootings we cover grip the headlines for a day or two, then fade from memory. But for the victims and their families, the tragedy lingers.

headline: What Umpires Get Wrong
abstract: They call about 14 percent of pitches incorrectly.
lead_paragraph: THIS season Major League Baseball is allowing its officiating crews to use instant replay to review certain critical calls, including home runs, force plays and foul balls. But the calling of the strike zone — determining whether a pitch that is not swung at is a ball or a strike — will still be left completely to the discretion of the officials. This might seem an odd exception, since calling the strike zone may be the type of officiating decision most subject to human foible.

headline: Any Excuse to Eat Waffles
abstract: Sweet or savory, for breakfast or an unexpected supper, well-made waffles are glorious things.
lead_paragraph: A well-made waffle is a glorious thing. Crisp and golden on the outside, steaming and tender within, its pockets hold a mix of melting butter and maple syrup that’s decadently released when you bite down.

headline: Dave Chappelle Set to Perform at Radio City Music Hall in June
abstract: The show is to be the comedian’s first scheduled performance in New York City in a decade.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Dave Chappelle, whose last major public appearance in New York City was at a Brooklyn block party in 2004, will perform at Radio City Music Hall in June, the concert promoter Live Nation announced Thursday night.

headline: U.N. Extends Term of Human Rights Monitor, Angering Iran
abstract: The Human Rights Council, meeting in Geneva, acted after a fifth report by the monitor, Ahmed Shaheed, who has been critical of Iran.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The Iran government’s effort to portray a kinder and gentler image was frustrated on Friday by the United Nations Human Rights Council, which voted to extend the term of a monitor scorned by Tehran.

headline: A Third Party Names Their Split
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The phrase “conscious uncoupling,” coined by a psychotherapist and author, gets a boost from Gwyneth Paltrow.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, Gwyneth Paltrow introduced the world to a new, ungainly phrase: “conscious uncoupling.” Ms. Paltrow unleashed the term when she announced her separation from her husband, Chris Martin, on her website, Goop. The post — headlined, what else, “Conscious Uncoupling” — crashed her website, but it didn’t take long for the news of a celebrity divorce to be quickly eclipsed by that substitute term for the D word, one virtually no one had ever heard before.

headline: Christie Talks About Bridge Scandal
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said that the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, David Samson, had resigned, the latest fallout from a George Washington Bridge scandal.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said that the chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, David Samson, had resigned, the latest fallout from a George Washington Bridge scandal.

headline: A Side Job Goes Well. Too Well?
abstract: “Blue,” the series about a mother’s second job as a prostitute, starts a third season, in longer format, online on Hulu, at the Fox and WIGS websites, but not on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: When Fox Broadcasting partnered last year with the digital producer WIGS, proprietor of a popular YouTube channel, the move was promoted as a way for Fox to get more familiar with online video as a place to develop new shows. In the process, it appears, Fox has decided to get less familiar with YouTube.

headline: Buffeted and Broken, They Try to Pick Up the Pieces
abstract: Suzanne Beahrs Dance presented the premiere of her earnest new work, “Amid,” on Thursday at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: For a young choreographer, finding the right dancers — people with a natural understanding of your movement, who somehow know what you’re looking for, even when you don’t — can take years. New companies (and even established ones) often suffer from a lack of cohesion, not merely in terms of executing steps in unison but on a deeper level of physical intuition.

headline: The Man Behind the Face
abstract: The work of Dr. Fredric Brandt, the cosmetic dermatologist, may be seen wherever the rich and famous gather, as well as when he looks in the mirror.
lead_paragraph: The painting is four panels — two depicting Alfred E. Neuman, the jug-eared mascot of Mad magazine, two picturing Phyllis Diller in characteristic fright drag and clutching an issue of that same magazine. The 2014 picture is by Julia Wachtel, an artist whose work holds up a glass to the fun-house distortions of our culture.

headline: Creativity and Parenting Can Mix
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Child Care', 'Children and Childhood', 'Babies and Infants', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: New York professionals are finding ways to integrate their offspring into their office life.
lead_paragraph: It was a bitterly cold day, but 8-month-old Scarlett Cohen was cozily ensconced inside with her mother, Rebecca Hessel Cohen, a designer. The infant crawled around on a soft white mat in a roomy play area, but the dolls and blocks before her quickly lost their appeal, and she found her way to a large carpeted room where Ms. Cohen sat at a desk sketching dresses for her next collection.

headline: Hinge, a Dating App, Introduces Friends of Friends
abstract: Hinge is a mobile match app that introduces users only to people who share Facebook friends.
lead_paragraph: Mobile dating apps may be all the rage these days, but they’re not for everyone.

headline: An Aid Program Too Often Neglected
abstract: Why don’t more seniors take advantage of food stamps?
lead_paragraph: When Telma Lopez could earn a modest living cleaning houses, she got along without food stamps. But now that she’s 64, suffers from chronic back pain and relies on Social Security disability benefits, “everything is too much money at the supermarket,” she told me.

headline: The Spirit Lives On in a Reborn Body
abstract: The charming new Kia Soul is noticeably more solid-feeling, pleasant to drive and filled with more premium features than the previous model.
lead_paragraph: Like the latest boy band, youth-baiting novelty cars can struggle to sustain a long, relevant career.

headline: Diego Luna on ‘Cesar Chavez’
abstract: The director discusses his new film about the labor leader and activist.
lead_paragraph: The director discusses his new film about the labor leader and activist.

headline: Rat Rod: A Statement Made of Rust
abstract: A man in upstate New York has built a hot rod using a 1946 Chevrolet, a Hemi engine and bits and pieces from other old vehicles.
lead_paragraph: HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y. — The Storm King Highway, a twisting two-lane ribbon carved into a mountainside here nine decades ago, hardly seemed the place to test the roadworthiness of a hot rod that looked to have just escaped the junkyard.

headline: Neglect, Carefully Cultivated
abstract: To Peter Duvaloois, rat rods like his home-built 1946 Chevrolet pickup represent a return to the roots of hot-rodding.
lead_paragraph: To Peter Duvaloois, rat rods like his home-built 1946 Chevrolet pickup represent a return to the roots of hot-rodding.

headline: Peacocks, Rhinos, Chimps: Oh, My!
abstract: For the luxury-minded interior designer Ryan Korban, more (and more) is more.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Korban, an interior designer who has worked with the fashion designer Alexander Wang, the actor James Franco and the model Jessica Stam, does not simply “like” things. Mirrors, for him, are a “sick obsession.” A set of gold-painted wooden torchères are “major.” And when he discovers, as he did on a recent Saturday, that a pair of stuffed white peacocks won’t fit atop two 18th-century English Rococo giltwood brackets in a space he is designing, crisis ensues.

headline: Standing Up to Testing
abstract: A number of parents have taken an activist stance against annual standardized tests by having their children opt out of taking them.
lead_paragraph: In the coming weeks, children in New York City and across the state will begin taking annual standardized tests in math and language that will run over the course of many hours and days, assuming a kind of onerousness once exclusive to the bar exam. Last year, the first in which the tests were aligned with the Common Core, a set of standards intended to determine whether a child is on track to becoming prepared for college, a number of parents, here and nationally, maintained an activist stance against them. About 270 children in the city’s public school system did not sit for the tests, their parents believing that the burdens imposed were hardly offset by the tests’ highly debatable value.

headline: Neighborhood Haunts in Upper Manhattan
abstract: Rusty Mackerel and Indian Road Café have attracted outside attention, but other new Upper Manhattan restaurants and cafes are drawing neighborhood residents.
lead_paragraph: Both Rusty Mackerel (209 Pinehurst Avenue, 212-928-4888; rustymackerelny.com) and Indian Road Café (600 West 218th Street at Indian Road; 212-942-7451; indianroadcafe.com) have attracted attention outside the neighborhood. But other new Upper Manhattan restaurants and cafes are drawing neighborhood residents. Here are a few:

headline: Downtown Food Goes North
abstract: As it has in other parts of New York City, the evolution in the dining scene in Washington Heights and Inwood has been fueled by demographic change.
lead_paragraph: As turning points go, it might seem underwhelming. But there it was, the moment when Frank’s Meat Market, a decades-old, decidedly old-school butcher shop on West 187th Street in Washington Heights, began selling fresh spinach fettuccine in the late 1980s.

headline: Coping Simply With Life Until Ordinary Disappears
abstract: In Beau Willimon’s play “Breathing Time,” at Teatro Iati, some 21st-century trauma impinges on an ordinary workday.
lead_paragraph: Beau Willimon, who began his career as a playwright but is now best known as the man behind the Netflix series “House of Cards,” doesn’t always work in the character-heavy mode of that show. His sparse play “Breathing Time,” now being staged by Fault Line Theater at Teatro Iati, is a simple study in how ordinary relationships can be shaped or put in perspective by much larger events.

headline: Tunes of a Wry Tenderheart
abstract: Elaine St. George transported her audience deep inside Steve Goodman’s world of Americana in a show devoted to his songs at Don’t Tell Mama.
lead_paragraph: Gentle humorous observations from the heartland steeped in whimsy, with a healthy dollop of baseball lore: that only begins to describe the legacy of the Chicago-born songwriter Steve Goodman, best remembered for “City of New Orleans,” a hit for Arlo Guthrie in 1972.

headline: Review: 2014 Toyota Highlander Limited
abstract: Toyota’s three-row crossover becomes less Bert, more Ernie with an injection of some welcome personality.
lead_paragraph: Toyota’s three-row crossover becomes less Bert, more Ernie with an injection of some welcome personality.

headline: Crimea Crisis Has Little Impact Thus Far on Russian Oil Deals
keywords: ['Shale', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Politics and Government', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: The French energy giant Total is in talks with Lukoil to form a joint venture to develop shale oil in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The French energy giant Total is in talks with Lukoil to form a joint venture to develop shale oil in Russia, as Moscow seeks to offset declining production from its conventional oil fields in Siberia.

headline: Traveling Man, Able to Rock Cowbells
abstract: Kevin Johansen’s performance at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday reflected his peripatetic life, his rejection of genres and a fondness for the clip-clop of cumbia.
lead_paragraph: Points of intersection, coincidence and contradiction fascinate and amuse Kevin Johansen, the songwriter who performed at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday. His genial songs reflect a peripatetic life.

headline: Should the Calf Be Put Out to Pasture?
abstract: The idea of men wearing shorts on formal occasions like Pharrell Williams to the Oscars, has some critics shuddering.
lead_paragraph: On the season finale of “Girls,” as several of the characters gathered outside the Belasco Theater before attending Adam’s Broadway debut in “Major Barbara,” Elijah (played by Andrew Rannells), clad in a natty light-blue suit and pocket square, glanced disdainfully over at Ray (Alex Karpovsky), dressed for the evening in an untucked plaid shirt and jeans.

headline: Cavanagh to Receive $39 Million in Pay for Joining Carlyle
abstract: Michael J. Cavanagh, the longtime JPMorgan Chase executive who is preparing to join the Carlyle Group, will make $7 million in salary and bonus, and will also receive restricted stock worth $32 million.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Cavanagh, the longtime JPMorgan Chase executive who is preparing to join the Carlyle Group, will make $7 million in salary and bonus in each of his first three years at the private equity giant, a regulatory filing on Friday showed.

headline: I’m a Cat Lady? Thank You
abstract: The popularity of cats on the Internet helps diminish an old stereotype.
lead_paragraph: Five months ago, in the wake of a breakup, I adopted a 6-week-old stray kitten. I named him Cat Stevens, bought him a cat tepee and began posting pictures of him on Instagram. The move alarmed some friends, who reflexively feared I was resigning myself, at 26, to a life of loneliness.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Korea and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Korea, Afghanistan, Indonesia and Tanzania.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Korea, Afghanistan, Indonesia and Tanzania.

headline: A Free Ride for Hotel Guests on Branded Bikes
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The growing popularity of biking has given upscale hotels a new way to both please guests and extend their brands.
lead_paragraph: Hotels offering bikes to their guests as a way to see the local sights isn’t new, but some are now taking the concept to another level with souped-up versions of standard two-wheelers.

headline: On the Rise, Li Na Aims to Be True Rival for Serena Williams
abstract: Li is 0-5 against Williams with Carlos Rodriguez as her coach, but she has made progress. The two players, Nos. 1 and 2 in the world, will meet in Saturday’s Sony Open final.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Serena Williams, very close to home, drove off in a fancy car in the sunshine after winning her semifinal at the Sony Open on Thursday.

headline: What Made Me | Charles Renfro
abstract: The architect on childhood bullies, Houston skyscrapers and his design philosophy.
lead_paragraph: The architect on childhood bullies, Houston skyscrapers and his design philosophy.

headline: Evening Hours | Spring in the Air
abstract: At the Plaza, at least, cherry trees were in bloom.
lead_paragraph: At the Plaza, at least, cherry trees were in bloom.

headline: Putin Calls Obama to Discuss Ukraine, White House Says
abstract: In a phone call initiated by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, President Obama told Mr. Putin that the United States would like to see Russia pull back its troops from Crimea and not take any further steps into Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia reached out to President Obama on Friday to discuss ideas about how to peacefully resolve the international standoff over Ukraine, a surprise move by Moscow to pull back from the brink of an escalated confrontation that has put Europe and much of the world on edge.

headline: When a Rock Star Hires His Slacker Brother
abstract: The National’s Matt Berninger and his brother, Tom, explain how their film project about the band evolved into a documentary about family and identity.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Tom Berninger had a hard time coming up with a name for his documentary, which ostensibly takes viewers on tour with the National, a rock band fronted by his brother, Matt, but ends up exploring his own slacker identity.

headline: Toyota Recalls Avalon Sedans for Air Bag Problem
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Electrical interference could damage the air bag control module, causing air bags and seatbelt tensioners to deploy inadvertently.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED: March 31

headline: What Made Me | Charles Renfro, Architect
abstract: The partner in the firm of Diller Scofidio & Renfro shares how an unconventional childhood in Houston led him to become the creative force he is today.
lead_paragraph: Charles Renfro joined the husband-and-wife team of Liz Diller and Ricardo Scofidio in 1997, becoming a partner in 2004. As Diller Scofidio & Renfro, the architecture firm has presided over numerous influential projects, including the design of the High Line park and the redevelopment of Lincoln Center in New York, that have reshaped modern-day attitudes about what cities should be. In this latest installment of the “What Made Me” video series by Poppy de Villeneuve, Renfro reveals how a childhood bully helped set him on his life path, remembers his early education gawking at Houston skyscrapers and explains his architectural philosophy.

headline: Boom Box
abstract: Kia’s second-generation Soul has grown and evolved, but without selling out or shedding its funky persona.
lead_paragraph: Kia’s second-generation Soul has grown and evolved, but without selling out or shedding its funky persona.

headline: So, Your Shrink Barks Now and Then. She’s a Pro, Right?
abstract: Christopher Durang’s “Beyond Therapy,” revived by the Actors Company Theater at the Beckett, centers on two people questing for romance while undergoing seriously wacky therapy.
lead_paragraph: She’s wishy-washy. He’s a partial crackpot (self-described). She lives a lonely life with two cats and a ticking biological clock. He leads a lonely life or maybe just an unconventional one with his live-in boyfriend.

headline: Mystical and Searching, and Very Last-Minute
abstract: Manfred Honeck of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra led the New York Philharmonic Thursday night in a program of Bruckner and Claude Vivier after the conductor Gustavo Dudamel became ill.
lead_paragraph: Recently, Gustavo Dudamel, the music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, brought that orchestra to Avery Fisher Hall for two sold-out concerts. He was scheduled to conduct three performances at the hall of a program with the New York Philharmonic starting Thursday night. But last weekend Mr. Dudamel, the charismatic young Venezuelan maestro, came down with severe flu symptoms, which forced him to withdraw.

headline: Speak Loudly, Carry Big Cylinders
abstract: The Triumph Thunderbird Commander is a motorcycle from England with an imposing presence and the power to back up its attitude.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2014 Triumph

headline: Battle of the Dash: Tech Companies Try to Get Their Apps in a Row
abstract: A dashboard donnybrook has erupted among tech companies vying to clean up the clutter of controls in the next generation of connected cars.
lead_paragraph: Will Apple’s CarPlay dominate the dashboards of future cars? Is Ford planning to kick Microsoft out of its Sync system? Are Audi and General Motors going for Google? Or does QNX, a dark horse whose software is already in tens of millions of vehicles, have the cards to trump other high-tech companies?

headline: TV Series Is Criticized in Handling of Deceased
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Television', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'ARCHAEOLOGY']
abstract: National Geographic Channel International is defending the four-part series “Nazi War Diggers” from archaeologists and others who accuse it of unprofessionalism.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists who specialize in excavating battlefields are condemning a new television series from National Geographic, saying the program’s approach to digging up the remains of World War II soldiers is unprofessional and borders on the ghoulish.

headline: Clinton Archives Collection
abstract: The National Archives released about 2,500 pages of previously withheld documents from Bill Clinton’s White House.
lead_paragraph: The National Archives released about 2,500 pages of previously withheld documents from Bill Clinton’s White House.

headline: Man Who Shot Officer in Manhattan Gunfight Is Sentenced to Prison
abstract: The gunman, Luis Martinez, was sentenced to 28 years to life for the 2012 shooting on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: The police officer who was shot on a cold February night two years ago was lucky. The bullet bounced off a spare ammunition magazine on the officer’s belt instead of penetrating his belly.

headline: Few Signs of War Plans in Russian Border Town
abstract: Many residents in Belgorod, Russia, dismiss talk of invading Ukraine as a rumor set to discredit the Russian government.
lead_paragraph: BELGOROD, Russia — On the outskirts of this sleepy city bordering Ukraine, residents were surprised Thursday when a military helicopter lifted off into the dreary sky.

headline: Microsoft to Stop Inspecting Private Emails in Investigations
abstract: Microsoft will instead hand over investigations of stolen property to law enforcement agencies, the company’s general counsel said. The change came a week after Microsoft faced an uproar over the methods it used in 2012 to investigate the suspected leak of software code by a former employee.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft will no longer snoop on customers’ private communications during investigations of stolen property, the company’s general counsel said on Friday.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about today’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Morgan Stanley Nearly Doubles C.E.O. Pay to $18 Million
abstract: James P. Gorman’s pay package for 2013 was $18 million, thanks in part to a hefty long-term incentive award.
lead_paragraph: A hefty long-term incentive award helped nearly double the compensation for Morgan Stanley’s chairman and chief executive, James P. Gorman, to $18 million for 2013.

headline: A Rapper Appropriating Dion’s Cool
abstract: The rapper G-Eazy, who sampled the original “Runaround Sue” to tell his own bad-boy story of misplaced affection, performed at Irving Plaza on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, the rapper G-Eazy found a very effective way to set himself apart, releasing “Runaround Sue,” which was built on a sample of the 1961 Dion anthem of the same name. Of course, it didn’t hurt that G-Eazy, white and lanky and with carefully coifed hair, bore at least a passing resemblance to Dion, or that in the video, he played up the similarity, cavorting around in a letterman jacket while the Sue of his affection ran off with a tough guy in James Dean drag.

headline: Digital Music Pioneer Is Found Liable in Copyright Suit
keywords: ['Music', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Michael Robertson may have to pay up to $41 million in a long-running case involving digital music files.
lead_paragraph: Michael Robertson, a pioneer in the digital music business who has repeatedly clashed with record companies over legal issues, was found liable this week for $41 million in a long-running federal copyright infringement suit.

headline: Bill Cunningham | French Evolution
abstract: Is Paris still the center of fashion?
lead_paragraph: Is Paris still the center of fashion?

headline: Rockwell Mixed Pairs
abstract: The two-day Rockwell Mixed Pairs was won on Wednesday evening in Dallas by Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla., and Richard Coren of Delray Beach, Fla.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The two-day Rockwell Mixed Pairs was won on Wednesday evening by Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla., and Richard Coren of Delray Beach, Fla. They finished about 40 percent of a board ahead of Jean Berry of Livermore, Calif., and Nick Wiebe of Oakland. A husband and wife team, John and Beth Bromberg of Dallas, were third.

headline: Bill Cunningham | French Evolution
abstract: Do Frenchwomen still have an identifying signature, envied by the rest of the world?
lead_paragraph: Is Paris still the center of fashion? Do Frenchwomen still have an identifying signature, envied by the rest of the world? To the discerning eye, they retain a certain understated nonchalance of style that has little to do with the bolder statement of designs for foreign buyers. The buyer for the trendy Paris store Colette is as adventuresome as French style seen today. All the high jinks and daring experiments, and the women draped in fox, are from other parts of the world, in search of what is conceived by many to be French style. This was the identity of Frenchwomen before World War I, vanishing by World War II. Ever since, they have taken shelter in the world of classic, restrained taste.

headline: For Iggy Azalea, Dress-Up Is a Grown-Up Game
abstract: Ms. Azalea has designs on stardom that go beyond her rap career, and she’s willing to dress for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday, Iggy Azalea was hanging out in her room at the Mondrian in SoHo, barefoot in black sweatpants and a heavily embellished Fausto Puglisi bomber jacket, which she said she loved because “it’s so shiny and sparkly.”

headline: Quartets Are Giving Music Stands a Rest
abstract: Chiara String Quartet is one of several ensembles of its kind trying a musical walk on the wild side: playing their highly coordinated arrangements without the aid of sheet music.
lead_paragraph: During a recent rehearsal, Rebecca Fischer, the first violinist of the Chiara String Quartet, played with her eyes half closed as she led her fellow members, the violinist Hyeyung Julie Yoon, the violist Jonah Sirota and the cellist Gregory Beaver, in the simmering slow movement of Brahms’s second string quartet. Ms. Yoon’s gaze was alert, darting back and forth between her colleagues; Mr. Beaver often turned his head fully in expectation of a fellow player’s cue. The one thing nobody was looking at was the music.

headline: Federal Safety Agency Ends Its Investigation of Tesla Fires
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said steps taken by the automaker to better protect car batteries should reduce the risk of fire.
lead_paragraph: Federal safety regulators said on Friday they had closed an investigation into whether the design of Tesla Motors’ all-electric car was making it prone to catch fire, after the automaker said it would provide more protection to its lithium-ion batteries.

headline: Returned From the Front, a Predator Still at War
abstract: In “Don Juan Comes Home From Iraq,” at the Wilma Theater in Philadelphia, Paula Vogel plays with time and surrealism in describing a Marine’s troubled return from war.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Under the destabilizing pressure of his wartime experience, not to mention the cruel workings of his own personal demons, an American Marine disintegrates before our eyes in “Don Juan Comes Home From Iraq,” a new drama by Paula Vogel having its premiere at the Wilma Theater here.

headline: Attack on Pakistani Journalist Kills His Driver
abstract: The liberal Pakistani writer and broadcaster Raza Rumi narrowly survived a gun attack that claimed the life of his driver in the city of Lahore.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Declan Walsh reports on Twitter, a liberal Pakistani writer and broadcaster narrowly survived a gun attack that claimed the life of his driver on Friday night in the city of Lahore.

headline: Under Cover: A Portrait of the Chef, a Young Man
abstract: The food-photography duo Peden & Munk share what it was like to photograph Flynn McGarry, the culinary wunderkind who graces the cover of this week’s Food and Drink Issue.
lead_paragraph: When Taylor Peden and Jen Munkvold (the photography team that goes by Peden & Munk) first met Flynn McGarry, the culinary wunderkind who graces the cover of this week’s Food and Drink Issue, McGarry was just 13, but no less serious about food for that. His room was filled with cookbooks, knives and tweezers, and he plated like a pro. Peden and Munkvold discussed what it was like photographing him for a day.

headline: At Dr. Cuts on Flatbush, Haircuts and Health Advice
abstract: At this Flatbush Avenue shop, customers can get counsel in addition to haircuts.
lead_paragraph: The 10-block stretch of Brooklyn’s Flatbush Avenue from Empire Boulevard to Parkside Avenue is a veritable mecca of beauty. There are multiple wig stores, with shelves of rainbow-colored styles and human hair sold by the ounce; hair salons and braiding shops; several beauty supply outlets; and at least one nail salon for every block.

headline: What I Mean When I Talk About IS-LM (Wonkish)
abstract: Wrong,maybe. Dumb or vacuous, not.
lead_paragraph: Just a brief note: I gather from some comments and emails that there are a few misunderstandings about what’s going on when I talk about the success of the IS-LM model since 2008.

headline: A Life Spent Remembering a War France Has Tried to Forget
abstract: Benjamin Stora, a prolific Algerian-born historian, has become France’s foremost chronicler of his home country’s war for independence.
lead_paragraph: ASNIÈRES-SUR-SEINE, France — Benjamin Stora arrived in Paris in the summer of 1962, a boy exile swaddled in as many layers of clothing as his parents could fit on his little body. He came amid a flood of refugees, one million French colonists, Arabs and Jews fleeing the murderous tumult of revolutionary Algeria.

headline: Friday Night Music: More Lake Street Dive
abstract: All the people live in layers.
lead_paragraph: And I will get to see them in concert!

headline: 3 Retailers Give Aid to Bangladesh Workers
keywords: ['Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Sixteen companies have contributed to the Rana Plaza Donors Trust Fund, which aims to pay lost wages and medical bills for the victims of a garment factory collapse last year.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, Gap and Children’s Place this week became the first three United States companies to contribute toward a $40 million fund for victims of the Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh last April, in which more than 1,100 workers died.

keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Discrimination', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A group of 12 women said they were paid less than men and were sexually harassed while working for the company’s stores, Jared and Kay Jewelers.
lead_paragraph: Among glittering diamonds and shining gemstones, Dawn Souto-Coons loved being in what she called “the business of romance,” selling engagement rings to smiling couples at a Jared jewelry store in Florida.

abstract: A reader discusses income inequality in response to a column by Nicholas Kristof.
