headline: The Russification of Crimea
abstract: As Moscow’s grip on Crimea tightens, ethnic Russians who were born under Soviet rule are eager to recapture their identity.
lead_paragraph: As Moscow’s grip on Crimea tightens, ethnic Russians who were born under Soviet rule are eager to recapture their identity.

headline: This Land Is Islands
abstract: New York City, as depicted in Accra Shepp’s photographs, which are on view at the Queens Museum, can be seen as an amazing archipelago.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers like to think of themselves as distinct. And they are, at least geographically. The Bronx is the only borough connected to the rest of America. Beyond the big three islands — Manhattan, Staten and Long (home to Brooklyn and Queens) — is an amazing archipelago of more than 40 islands and former islands, from Rat Island, a privately owned two-acre speck off the Bronx, to Liberty Island in New York Harbor.

headline: Slowing the Patent Trolls
abstract: The Supreme Court must change how software is protected.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — ON Monday the Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments in perhaps the most important intellectual property case in a decade: Alice v. CLS Bank. Narrowly speaking, the case is a patent dispute over computerized escrow accounts. But more broadly, it offers the court an opportunity to resolve two decades of economically harmful confusion over how the law grants patent protection to computer software.

headline: Matchmakers Help Those Over 60 Handle Dating’s Risks and Rewards
abstract: Relationship coaches can guide those who haven’t dated for decades through the new world of online and offline romance.
lead_paragraph: AFTER Judith Himber’s husband died in 2010, she didn’t know what to do with herself. “It was a stunning loss,” said Ms. Himber, 73, who works full time as a clinical psychologist in Cambridge, Mass.

headline: Start-Up Health Insurer Finds Foothold in New York
abstract: Oscar is Silicon Alley’s challenge to the staid business of health insurance and is trying to use its tech-world skills to provide an easier experience to consumers.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in late March, Kevin Nazemi stood along a wall of the small, sweltering offices of the health insurance start-up Oscar in downtown New York, trying to rally the troops.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Says Eight Board Members Resign
abstract: Eight members of the board of the Minnesota Orchestra have resigned in protest over the impending departure of its president, Michael Henson, The Minneapolis Star Tribune reported on Friday.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Eight members of the board of the Minnesota Orchestra have resigned in protest over the impending departure of its president, Michael Henson, The Minneapolis Star Tribune reported on Friday. Mr. Henson announced last week that he would vacate his position in August.

headline: A Company Aims to Put Good Karma and Energy Close at Hand
abstract: The growth of Alex and Ani, a company whose amulets yielded $230 million last year, poses a question: Is it a capitalist success story, or a church whose tokens happen to generate big sales?
lead_paragraph: CRANSTON, R.I. — Do you want “limitless power, limitless good karma, and limitless wisdom”? Alex and Ani’s promotional material tells you to buy the Buddha Charm Bangle, available for $28. Do you want “divine direction and soulful enlightenment”? They recommend the Saint Anthony Charm Bangle, for the same price. For the union of masculine and feminine energy, Alex and Ani offers the Star of David Charm Bangle, at $24.

headline: The Certainty of Donald Rumsfeld (Part 4)
abstract: The absence of evidence, the evidence of absence, and the Iraq War.
lead_paragraph: Read Part 1; Part 2; Part 3.

headline: The Last Family Rodeos
abstract: Family-run backyard rodeos in Iowa and across the country separate themselves with a blend of competition and camaraderie.
lead_paragraph: Family-run backyard rodeos in Iowa and across the country separate themselves with a blend of competition and camaraderie.

headline: No Anonymous Sources Here
abstract: Market Place Kitchen and Bar, a restaurant committed to using fresh, locally grown food, tells diners where many of its offerings were raised.
lead_paragraph: Market Place Kitchen and Bar opened in Danbury in September 2012 with a stated mission to use fresh, locally grown food, and the menu reflects that, listing the geographical sources of many of the restaurant’s offerings.

headline: First Cases Documented of TB Caught From Cats
abstract: The four human cases were related to a rare cluster of sick cats in southern England, but TB experts reassured pet owners that they had virtually nothing to fear.
lead_paragraph: The first documented cases of people catching tuberculosis from their cats were revealed in England this week, but TB experts there and in the United States reassured pet owners that they had virtually nothing to fear.

headline: U.N. Official Denounces Syria on Aid Access
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Valerie Amos, the head of emergency relief, pointed to the Syrian government’s denials of access and continued use of barrel bombs — both blatant violations of international law.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations chief of emergency relief was unusually forthright on Friday in criticizing the Syrian government’s blocking of humanitarian aid, pointing to its denials of access and continued use of barrel bombs — both blatant violations of international law.

headline: Atop the League in St. Louis, From the Bottom in Buffalo
abstract: The veteran goaltender Ryan Miller is shining for the team with the most points in the N.H.L. after his late season trade to the Blues by the lowly Sabres.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Miller has been to Sochi and back this year, but in some ways that considerable mileage was nothing compared with the distance he covered going from the Buffalo Sabres to the St. Louis Blues. Miller, one of the N.H.L.’s best goalies, was traded from the last-place Sabres to the first-place Blues on Feb. 28.

headline: A Backyard Rodeo
abstract: Informal rodeos held by farmers were once standard entertainment in Iowa. Now they are a rarity, but the Sandburr ranch hopes it can grow the tradition.
lead_paragraph: Informal rodeos held by farmers were once standard entertainment in Iowa. Now they are a rarity, but the Sandburr ranch hopes it can grow the tradition.

headline: Tamer Breed of Backyard Rodeo Finds Itself Endangered
abstract: Family-run backyard rodeos in Iowa and across the country separate themselves with a blend of competition and camaraderie, but they are decreasing in number.
lead_paragraph: DEEP RIVER, Iowa — The tiny cube of a room with walls made of pine is where Sharon Widmer spreads chocolate frosting over brownies, and where the scent of her spicy chili warms the air. It is where one woman talks about finding someone to clean her garage for $21 and another discusses soda can fund-raising drives.

headline: Hagel Seeks Peace Pact for Digital Realm
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said the U.S. does not seek to “militarize” cyberspace, and pledged the Pentagon would show restraint in its global operations — if other nations do the same.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, in his first lengthy comments on the Pentagon’s growing mission in computer-network warfare, said Friday that the United States does not seek to “militarize” cyberspace, and pledged that the Defense Department would show restraint in its global operations — if other nations do the same.

headline: Damning Detail in Bridge Scandal May Be Hard to Confirm
abstract: Whether David Wildstein told Gov. Chris Christie at a Sept. 11 memorial event about lane closings in Fort Lee, N.J., may never be known.
lead_paragraph: There were two white tents not far from ground zero on that day, standing apart in silent testament to the dysfunction of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which had erected them. Some of the leaders of the bistate agency gathered — in separate tents — before the ceremony to mark the 12th anniversary of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and honor those who died.

headline: Improvisations on Small Plates
abstract: Appetites of all sizes can find bold dishes, reasons to linger and a lively beat at Mompou Tapas Wine Bar and Lounge in Newark.
lead_paragraph: So many American restaurants feature tapas these days that traditional Spanish tapas seem new again. A fine place to reacquaint yourself with the more authentically Spanish version is at Mompou Tapas Wine Bar and Lounge in the Ironbound section of Newark.

headline: High Culture and Hard Labor
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Building (Construction)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Art and academic institutions must protect gulf workers’ rights.
lead_paragraph: ACROSS a narrow sea channel from Abu Dhabi’s sleek towers, construction on Saadiyat Island is proceeding at a pace that’s extreme even by the standards of this Persian Gulf boomtown.

headline: Detroit Executive Says That, Yes, Cabrera’s Contract Is a Gamble
abstract: Dave Dombrowski, the Detroit Tigers’ general manager, had the opportunity to explain why he signed Miguel Cabrera to a record-setting deal.
lead_paragraph: LAKELAND, Fla. — Dave Dombrowski, the latest general manager to hand out what amounts to a mind-boggling 10-year contract for a 30-year-old player, was given a chance Friday to explain the deal that he and the Detroit Tigers struck with Miguel Cabrera.

headline: Anti-Semitic Slur by a Westchester Fire Chief Stirs Controversy
abstract: Anthony LoGiudice, a fire chief in Greenburgh, N.Y., used offensive language about the town supervisor, Paul J. Feiner, who is Jewish.
lead_paragraph: The Westchester County town of Greenburgh, a sprawling municipality that has a significant Jewish population, is embroiled in a controversy over anti-Semitic slurs by a local fire chief against the town supervisor, who is Jewish.

headline: Antibiotic Use, and Abuse, on the Farms
abstract: The F.D.A.’s efforts to curb the overuse of antibiotics in animal feed is off to a good start.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration’s efforts to get the voluntary cooperation of drug companies to curb the overuse of antibiotics in animal feed is off to a rousing good start.

headline: Peace Process on Life Support?
abstract: The signs are clear that talks between Israelis and Palestinians are in trouble.
lead_paragraph: After nine months of intensive diplomacy, Israeli-Palestinian peace talks appear to be in a depressingly familiar place: on the brink of collapse. Failure could trigger more violence in an already unstable region.

headline: A Christie Appointee Quits, Finally
abstract: The resignation of David Samson, Gov. Chris Christie’s top appointee to the Port Authority, came too late.
lead_paragraph: The only thing wrong with the resignation announcement on Friday of David Samson, Gov. Chris Christie’s top appointee to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, was that it took so long.

headline: A Week in Search and Rescue
abstract: A look back at the week of search and rescue efforts after a deadly landslide buried the town of Oso, Wash.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the week of search and rescue efforts after a deadly landslide buried the town of Oso, Wash.

headline: Anxious Wait for News Days After Deadly Landslide
abstract: Officials have been slow to update the death toll, even as volunteers at the site in Oso, Wash., reported numerous bodies that had been discovered.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Wash. — The grim work of recovery at the site of last week’s landslide in Oso was compounded on Friday by rain and wind, but also by growing anxiety over how bad the disaster might yet get, as emergency officials declined again to confirm numerous reports by volunteers and families about retrieved bodies.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for March 28, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 28, 2014

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 29, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, March 29, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “There are a lot of places in the world at risk from rising sea levels, but Bangladesh is at the top of everybody’s list. And the world is not ready to cope with the problems.”

headline: An Engineer’s Eureka Moment With a G.M. Flaw
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A $30 replacement part helped set in motion General Motors’ recall of 2.6 million Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars, and one of the gravest safety crises in company history.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Somewhere inside the two-inch ignition switch from the 2005 Chevrolet Cobalt was the clue that Mark Hood was seeking.

headline: Flavors of Spring
abstract: At Park 143 Bistro, an abundance of flavors and a genial staff help break through the enduring cold.
lead_paragraph: I had begun to wonder whether spring would ever come, but as soon as Park 143 Bistro’s grilled rabbit sausage was placed in front of me, I knew that warmth and renewal were on their way.

headline: A Christie Life Primer
abstract: Let’s discuss the lessons learned from the latest on the bridge-traffic-jam episode.
lead_paragraph: Let’s take a minute to search for life lessons in the latest Chris Christie bridge-traffic-jam episode. I believe there are two. First, when the political ship is going down, nobody will bother to rescue the unattached woman and the dork from senior year.

headline: Tennessee Comeback Brewing, Michigan Senior Steps In
abstract: Tennessee whittled Michigan’s lead to 72-71 with six seconds left, but Jarnell Stokes was called for a charge against the senior Wolverines forward Jordan Morgan.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — It was clear that the senior forward Jordan Morgan did his homework over Michigan’s five days of preparation before its N.C.A.A. tournament Midwest Regional semifinal against Tennessee.

headline: Where the Tables Can Play Hard to Get
abstract: The Trattoria in St. James, which accepts no credit cards and has no liquor license, is winning over diners with rustic Italian food, attentive service and moderate prices.
lead_paragraph: The Trattoria in St. James is a quirky little place that accepts no credit cards and has no liquor license. It is also absolutely delightful, winning over diners with soul-satisfying, rustic Italian food, attentive service and moderate prices.

headline: Period Sans Soleil
abstract: Barry C. Silk returns with a challenging, lively Saturday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I love me a Barry Silk puzzle, but when you see his byline on a Saturday you know you’re in for a wild ride.

headline: Massachusetts: Defense Lawyers in Bombing Case Say the Government Is Withholding Information
abstract: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man accused in the Boston Marathon bombing last year, said that the government was withholding information that would show that his brother, Tamerlan, instigated the bombing plot.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man accused in the Boston Marathon bombing last year, said in court papers on Friday that the government was withholding a wealth of information that would show that his older brother, Tamerlan, instigated the bombing plot. The defense lawyers are seeking to show that Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was under the influence of his brother, who was ideologically driven and had a history of violence, and that Dzhokhar should therefore be spared the death penalty. They want the government to release the family’s applications for asylum in the United States as well as documents of F.B.I. contacts with Tamerlan Tsarnaev before the bombing in which, the lawyers said, the F.B.I. asked him to be an informant on the Chechen and Muslim communities. The government has said it has no evidence that Tamerlan Tsarnaev, who was subsequently killed in a police shootout, was solicited to be an informant.

headline: Grand Leaps and Missteps on the Way to a Showdown
abstract: More than any coaches remaining in the tournament, Louisville’s Rick Pitino and Kentucky’s John Calipari represent everything that makes big-time college coaching so convoluted and challenging.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — I had planned to be in New York this weekend when the men’s N.C.A.A. tournament returned to Madison Square Garden for the first time in 53 years. What a great scene: the East Regional semifinals between Connecticut and Iowa State, and Michigan State and Virginia.

headline: Christie Ally Is Undone by Word in an Email
abstract: The word “retaliate” was forever linked to David Samson, Gov. Chris Christie’s appointee to head the Port Authority, when a trove of emails was released about lane closings at the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: His name was well known in courts and in corporate suites across the metropolitan region and revered in the halls of Trenton. But a single imprudent word, written by a subordinate, brought David Samson more notoriety than he could have ever desired.

headline: The Split of the Ages
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Youth', 'Elderly', 'Age, Chronological', 'Voting and Voters', 'Minorities', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: There is a growing divide between America’s oldest and youngest voters.
lead_paragraph: Older voters and younger voters used to be largely on the same page when they went to the polls. No more.

headline: In an Era of Squiggles, You Can’t Tell the Players Without a Handwriting Analyst
abstract: Penmanship seems to be a thing of the past in Major League Baseball, with players often leaving autograph collectors scratching their heads.
lead_paragraph: The walls of the steakhouse at Yankee Stadium are decorated with signatures of past Yankee greats. David Robertson, the team’s young closer, marvels at the fact that he can read the names.

headline: Remembering a Tournament ‘Final’ at the Garden
abstract: The former college basketball star and analyst Billy Packer played for Wake Forest in the last N.C.A.A. tournament game held at Madison Square Garden before this year.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-three years ago, Billy Packer played in the last N.C.A.A. tournament game at Madison Square Garden before Friday’s Connecticut-Iowa State East Region semifinal. A point guard for Wake Forest, Packer did not have a memorable night, as St. John’s Ivan Kovac effectively defended him throughout the game, but the Demon Deacons prevailed, 97-74.

headline: A Flurry of Travel, Across the World and Beyond
keywords: ['International Space Station', 'Elections', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Stops in China, Russia, European capitals and outer space.
lead_paragraph: This was a week in which travels told the tale. President Obama went to Europe and Saudi Arabia to try to shore up old alliances; the first lady, Michelle Obama, and her daughters went east to woo the Chinese; President Xi Jinping of China headed west to be wooed by the Europeans; and Joe Kaeser, the chief executive of the German engineering giant Siemens, went to Moscow to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin, saying that his company’s lucrative relationship with Russia would not be sidetracked by “short-term turbulence.”

headline: New York Sanitation Chief Closes a 54-Year Career
abstract: John J. Doherty, New York’s longest-serving sanitation commissioner, ended his final day on the job with reflections on his decades of serving the city.
lead_paragraph: John J. Doherty, the longest-serving sanitation commissioner in New York, keeps a century-old pith helmet on a shelf in his office, a relic of the White Wings, the first uniformed army charged with cleaning the city’s streets.

headline: Dayton’s Triumph of Togetherness
abstract: The Flyers will face top-seeded Florida on Saturday, and the team’s success so far is being attributed to their camaraderie, which extends to their living arrangements.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — On Caldwell Street, steps from the Dayton basketball team’s practice facility on its campus in southwestern Ohio, the players shuffle in and out of one another’s apartments as if the three-story complex were one grandiose townhouse.

headline: Local Voices Aren’t So Eager to Go National
abstract: Turner and CBS are approaching local radio announcers for alternative, hometown-style broadcasts of Final Four games, but loyalty and corporate obligations are keeping those announcers home.
lead_paragraph: Joe D’Ambrosio has called Connecticut men’s basketball games on the radio for 22 years. He knows the team well. He loves speaking directly to a fervent audience of local fans.

headline: Security Official in Charge at World Trade Center Resigns
keywords: ['1 World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: The chief of security at 1 World Trade Center resigned on Friday after a series of recent breaches raised concerns about security at the site.
lead_paragraph: The head of security for 1 World Trade Center resigned on Friday after a series of recent breaches raised concerns about security lapses at the site.

headline: It’s as if the Huskies Never Left the Garden
abstract: UConn, which has won 60 games at the Garden, seemed to know all of the sweet spots on the floor, while the Cyclones struggled to convert on easy putbacks on their way to a Round of 16 loss.
lead_paragraph: Madison Square Garden, an arena known for its championship prizefights as much as its rich college basketball history, was the site of a highly anticipated East Regional semifinal matchup between Connecticut’s Shabazz Napier and Iowa State’s DeAndre Kane.

headline: Balanced Attack Powers Nets’ 12th Straight Home Win
abstract: Six players scored in double figures to help the Nets bounce back from two overtime road losses and extend their Barclays Center streak by beating the Cavaliers.
lead_paragraph: Returning home seems to solve whatever issues the Nets are having.

headline: Video Notebook: UConn Beats Iowa State
abstract: Connecticut guard Shabazz Napier talks about teammate DeAndre Daniels, who scored a team-high 27 points in the Huskies’ victory against the Cyclones.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut guard Shabazz Napier talks about teammate DeAndre Daniels, who scored a team-high 27 points in the Huskies’ victory against the Cyclones.

headline: Felix Fibich, Dancer and Choreographer, Dies at 96
abstract: Mr. Fibich, at first an actor, went on to specialize in Jewish dance traditions.
lead_paragraph: Felix Fibich, a Polish-born modern dancer, choreographer and teacher who specialized in dances drawn from the Jewish heritage of Eastern Europe, died on March 20 in Manhattan. He was 96.

headline: Jockey Club Wants U.S. Anti-Doping Agency in Charge
abstract: The Jockey Club, one of horse racing’s most influential groups, said efforts at reform from within have moved too slowly and “enough was enough.”
lead_paragraph: The Jockey Club, one of horse racing’s most influential groups, said it would support federal legislation to put the United States Anti-Doping Agency in charge of bringing law and order to a sport that has been unable to eradicate a pervasive drug culture that has put horses and riders at risk and alienated some fans.

headline: Hoping to Hear ‘Play Ball’ in Montreal
abstract: A group called the Montreal Baseball Project, led by the former Expo Warren Cromartie, has been working to bring a team back to Montreal.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Olympic Stadium looked just as it had when the Expos last played, in September 2004. The creaky yellow seats, the concrete concourse and the strange roof remained, conjuring some bad memories.

headline: Historic Double Walkover in Florida
abstract: Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic advanced to the final of the Sony Open without playing a point.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Tennis has had plenty of high-profile days descend into duds through the years because of rainouts, routs or mid-match twists of fate or ankle.

headline: Once a Source of Entertainment, Now a Rival Coach
abstract: The relationship between Wisconsin’s Bo Ryan and Arizona’s Sean Miller goes back to the 1970s, when Ryan was an assistant coach and Miller was a 9-year-old dribbling prodigy.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s Sean Miller and Wisconsin’s Bo Ryan are usually near the top of any list of the best coaches who have never reached the Final Four. But their ties go beyond that.

headline: Strumming Through Four Centuries
abstract: A guitar festival from April 2 to April 6 at L.I.U. Post in Brookville includes both homegrown musicians and talents from across the world.
lead_paragraph: There was some trepidation in the ranks of the Vida Guitar Quartet a few years ago when one of its members, Christopher Stell, announced that he was planning to transcribe George Gershwin’s jazzy symphonic work “Rhapsody in Blue” into a piece for four guitars.

headline: Tatia Pilieva
abstract: The “First Kiss” filmmaker on apple-box furniture and reading other people’s letters.
lead_paragraph: Tatia Pilieva is a filmmaker from the Republic of Georgia, now living in Los Angeles, who gained notoriety earlier this month when “First Kiss,” her short film of 20 strangers, kissing awkwardly and erotically, went viral. She hopes to debut her first feature-length film, “Forever,” later this year.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Sundance) MARGIN CALL (2011) J. C. Chandor wrote and directed this film in which a young Wall Street risk analyst (Zachary Quinto) predicts the 2008 financial crisis, setting off a chain of events at his investment bank, where his superiors (played by Kevin Spacey and Paul Bettany, among others) desperately try to save the company and their own skins. “There are no hissable villains here, no operatic speeches condemning or celebrating greed,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Just a bunch of guys (and one woman, Demi Moore) in well-tailored clothes and a state of quiet panic trying to save themselves from a global catastrophe of their own making.” He added: “Watching them going about their business, you don’t feel the kind of fury inspired by ‘Inside Job,’ Charles Ferguson’s great muckraking documentary on the origins of the financial crisis, but rather a mix of dread, disgust, pity and confusion. And also, above all, admiration for an extraordinary feat of filmmaking.”

headline: Kentucky Ousts Defending Champion, Louisville
abstract: The matchup was billed as Kentucky’s youngsters against Louisville’s experience, and youth took the upper hand as Aaron Harrison made a go-ahead 3-pointer with 40 seconds remaining.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The gauntlet was thrown down early. The run-and-gun Kentucky Wildcats were on the break, and James Young, looking for the 7-footer Dakari Johnson, threw a lob pass. Louisville forward Montrezl Harrell leapt, stretching his hand as far as it would reach. He swatted away the ball, past the Louisville bench and nearly into the first row of the stands. Then he screamed.

headline: With Win Over Virginia, Michigan State’s Izzo Is Again One Step Away
abstract: Every one of Tom Izzo’s senior classes at Michigan State has reached at least one Final Four. With the Spartans’ razor-thin victory over Virginia, this year’s group has a shot.
lead_paragraph: In Tom Izzo’s tenure at Michigan State, the achievement has been as inevitable as a sunrise: Every one of his senior classes reaches at least one Final Four. He discussed it with his team early this season, back before all the injuries and the illnesses, but had not since.

headline: Earthquake Rattles Los Angeles Area
abstract: The magnitude-5.1 quake on Friday night was followed by at least 20 aftershocks, but the Los Angeles Fire Department said there were no immediate reports of significant damage.
lead_paragraph: An earthquake nearly five miles deep shook the Los Angeles area on Friday night, federal seismologists said.

headline: In Hunt for Lost Jet, New Sightings of Debris Are Promising but Inconclusive
abstract: Officials involved in the search, mindful of the amount of detritus adrift in the world’s oceans, cautioned that the sightings are inconclusive so far.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — The hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 resumed in earnest on Saturday as surveillance planes returned to the skies above a newly defined search area in the southern Indian Ocean and spotted floating debris for the second day in a row, and a flotilla of vessels began arriving in the zone to find and identify the objects, the Australian authorities said.

headline: Knicks Are Dealt a Rout by the Suns and a Blow to Their Playoff Hopes
abstract: The Knicks could have pulled within a game of Atlanta for the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference but had another lackluster defensive showing.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — With the Knicks engaged in a playoff chase that has become one of the N.B.A.’s more captivating sitcoms, Coach Mike Woodson needed two sentences to sum up the season before the Phoenix Suns demolished his team Friday night at US Airways Center.

headline: Video Notebook: M.S.U. Defeats Virginia
abstract: Michigan State forward Branden Dawson and guard Travis Trice talk about Trice’s 3-pointer in transition with 9:09 left in the game. The Spartans never trailed again in their victory over Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Michigan State forward Branden Dawson and guard Travis Trice talk about Trice’s 3-pointer in transition with 9:09 left in the game. The Spartans never trailed again in their victory over Virginia.

headline: Baseball Autographs
abstract: A collection of autographs from baseball greats.
lead_paragraph: A collection of autographs from baseball greats.

headline: Obama Ends Overseas Trip With Award for Saudi
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Domestic Violence']
abstract: The brief private ceremony came a day after the president chose not to raise the issue of human rights during a two-hour discussion with King Abdullah.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — President Obama ended his weeklong trip to Europe and Saudi Arabia on Saturday morning with a brief private ceremony in which he presented an International Women of Courage award to a Saudi woman who works to prevent domestic violence in the kingdom.

headline: Analytics: Judging Woody
abstract: Our Ethicist column about whether to boycott Woody Allen’s films put readers in two camps: 55 percent said they would not watch another Allen movie, 45 percent said they would.
lead_paragraph: The following Analytics appears on the letters page in the March 30 issue of the magazine.

headline: Taliban Attack Election Panel Headquarters Before Afghan Voting
abstract: The attack by the Taliban, who have vowed to violently derail the coming election for a new president, was the third in Kabul just this week.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters unleashed a barrage of gunfire and rocket-propelled grenades at the headquarters of Afghanistan’s election commission on Saturday, a week before Afghans are to vote for a new president in an election that the Taliban has vowed to disrupt. There were no immediate reports of casualties.

headline: Cloud Computing’s Watershed Week
abstract: Moves by older incumbents and young giants show that 2014 is the year computing everywhere comes into its own. Now it’s time for big development. Looking for the next frontier? There was plenty of that, too.
lead_paragraph: In the technology world, March 2014 went out like a plan.

headline: 1918: Germany Takes Control of Crimea
abstract: After 13 days of engagements and long marches in 1918, German troops occupied Crimea, the New York Herald reported.
lead_paragraph: BALE — The special correspondent of the “Münchner Neueste Nachrichten” telegraphs from Sebastopol on May 10.

headline: As Diplomacy Steps Up, Ukraine Candidates Narrow
abstract: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov of Russia, who will meet with Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday, said the two sides were narrowing their differences.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A day after the Russian leader Vladimir V. Putin proposed to President Obama that they boost attempts to resolve their standoff over Ukraine, Secretary of State John Kerry scrambled his travel plans to meet with his Russian counterpart in Paris on Sunday, according to a State Department official.

headline: Did Facebook Buy Virtual Reality Too Soon?
abstract: Facebook has an impeccable sense of introducing products that are right for right now. But did the company make a bet on the future that might not pan out with its acquisition of Oculus VR?
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t in the room when Mark Zuckerberg tried on the Oculus Rift virtual reality goggles for the first time, but if it was anything like my experience, I’m pretty sure I can guess how he reacted.

headline: State Budget Deal Reached; $300 Million for New York City Pre-K
abstract: The agreement will finance the expansion of prekindergarten in New York City without the tax increase on high-earning residents sought by Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced on Saturday an agreement on a state budget that would provide $300 million for prekindergarten in New York City, but also undercuts other educational policies of Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has championed prekindergarten while trying to slow the spread of charter schools.

headline: Setback for High Blood Pressure Treatment
abstract: A large study showed that renal denervation, which more than 80 countries have already approved, was no more effective than a “sham” procedure.
lead_paragraph: A promising treatment for severe high blood pressure has failed in a large, rigorous study, doctors reported on Saturday.

headline: The Skills Zombie
abstract: Another serious-sounding wrong idea.
lead_paragraph: One of the most frustrating aspects of economic debate since 2008 has been the preference of influential people for stories about our troubles that sound serious as opposed to those that actually are serious. The reality, all along, has been that our economy is depressed because there isn’t enough spending, and that what we need is something, almost anything, that increases total spending. But policymakers and pundits want to hear about tough decisions and hard choices, and they just recoil from any suggestion that terrible problems might have easy answers.

headline: Variety: A Diagramless Royale
abstract: Ed Stein and Paula Gamache offer us a diagramless royale.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Is it just me, or was this diagramless by Ed Stein and Paula Gamache a bit harder than some of the recent ones we’ve solved? I know where I got stuck, but your mileage, of course, may vary. I don’t follow auto racing, so I was not familiar with A.J. FOYT, so that took a while, but at least the crossings were kind.

headline: The Health Insurance Answer That Took 3 Months
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Consumer Protection', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A couple signed up for insurance at Healthcare.gov, but only the husband’s name made it to the policy. After many unsuccessful calls to fix the problem, they asked the Haggler for help.
lead_paragraph: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

headline: All Public Comments Are Welcome. Then What?
keywords: ['Research', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A new tool tries to determine whether federal agencies are taking citizens’ comments into account when formulating rules.
lead_paragraph: Do federal regulators really pay attention to public comments before they adopt new rules? A group of researchers says it has developed a tool that can answer that question — with the goal of providing an extra layer of accountability in government.

headline: The Mines Have Shut Down. The Miners Haven’t.
abstract: Industrial coal mines of Lower Silesia, Poland, closed in the late 1990s, but the mining has continued in a more secret and dangerous form.
lead_paragraph: Down a homemade mine shaft in southwestern Poland, a would-be comedian sang in the faint glowing light.

headline: Poland’s ‘Rathole Miners’
abstract: Digging coal illegally, often called “rathole mining,” proliferated in the late 1990s in Walbrzych, Poland, after the state abruptly decided to shutter coal plants in the region. It continues today.
lead_paragraph: Digging coal illegally, often called “rathole mining,” proliferated in the late 1990s in Walbrzych, Poland, after the state abruptly decided to shutter coal plants in the region. It continues today.

headline: Warner’s C.E.O. Is Bullish on the Big Screen
abstract: In Hollywood’s sea of bravado, Kevin Tsujihara, the quiet new chief executive of Warner Bros., may seem miscast. But he is already making bold bets to keep the studio on top.
lead_paragraph: When a quiet and courteous DVD executive named Kevin Tsujihara ascended to the Warner Bros. throne last year, Hollywood did not know quite what to make of him.

headline: A Communal Space, but Still My Own
keywords: ['Co-Working', 'Writing and Writers', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Careers and Professions', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Co-working sites offer independent professionals a place to ply their trade creatively, and to find support.
lead_paragraph: In my single years, I was quite content doing a variety of freelance work at home. Some people can’t do it. The temptations of television, the refrigerator or laundry are just too strong to resist. As for me — I’m cool with typing while in my boxers and have no problem ignoring a Pisa tower of grimy dishes.

headline: For a Cattle Rancher, a Legacy on the Range
abstract: Ranching isn’t about living for the present, says Manny Encinias of Clayton, N.M. Rather, “our decisions are based on leaving a legacy for our kids and our grandkids.”
lead_paragraph: Manny Encinias, 40, is an Angus cattle rancher in Clayton, N.M.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, March 29
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “This is the best shot virtual reality has ever had and probably will ever have.”

headline: Economists and Philosophy
keywords: ['Philosophy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Readers respond to “When the Scientist Is Also a Philosopher” (Economic View, March 23).
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: A Lone Ranger of the 401(k)’s
keywords: ['401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: A lawyer’s string of cases highlights a corporate responsibility to monitor the costs and fees in employees’ retirement plans.
lead_paragraph: The arithmetic could not be simpler. The more fees you pay in your 401(k) plan, the less cash you’ll have for retirement.

headline: Tom Erickson of Acquia, on the Philosophy of ‘Ready, Fire, Aim’
abstract: The chief executive of an open-source software company says he wants to hire people “who are going to jump in and own their work, who are going to risk something, and risk failing.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Tom Erickson, chief executive of Acquia, an open-source software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: In Audiences on Broadway, Fewer Guys Among the Dolls
abstract: While a night out at the theater used to be a staple for cultured American men, fewer shows are grabbing them these days.
lead_paragraph: More men are steering clear of Broadway, and not even this spring’s ultimate bro show — “Rocky,” the new musical about the beloved boxing underdog — has found a way to fill seats with them.

headline: In Some Ways, It’s Looking Like 1999 in the Stock Market
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Biotechnology', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Initial Public Offerings']
abstract: A surge in Internet and biotech stock values recalls an earlier bubble. But prices of other stocks seem more tethered to reality.
lead_paragraph: It sure looks like a bubble.

headline: Costs, Benefits and Masterpieces in Detroit
abstract: In deciding the fate of its famous artworks, Detroit is facing a classic question of economic tradeoffs.
lead_paragraph: Most of the paintings on my walls are by artists I know personally. And although some of these works are hauntingly beautiful, they wouldn’t command much on the open market.

headline: Putin’s Reckless Gamble
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions']
abstract: Russia has stirred up passions that are hard to control. Has Putin decided he needs a breather?

headline: G.M. Recall Total in 2014 Reaches 4.8 Million
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker announced that it was recalling about 490,000 trucks and 172,000 small cars in the seventh major recall it has issued this year.
lead_paragraph: General Motors announced on Saturday morning that it was recalling 490,000 trucks and 172,000 compact cars, meaning the automaker has now recalled about 4.8 million vehicles in the United States during the first three months of the year. That is about six times the number of vehicles it recalled in all of 2013.

headline: Found in Mud: Precious Links to Loved Ones
abstract: After a disaster that has left so many missing, ordinary objects have become connections to loved ones.
lead_paragraph: DARRINGTON, Wash. — Gently, Dayn Brunner reached into the mangled car and lifted his younger sister’s lifeless body out of the driver’s seat and onto a waiting tarp. For almost a week, he and his teenage sons had slogged through the muddy catacomb of what had once been a neighborhood, scouring the pulped homes and broken earth for some sign of her. Now, it was time to say goodbye and wait for the helicopter to take her away.

headline: Celebrate? Sorry, We’re Studying
abstract: Wisconsin is heading to the Final Four, but the bookish Badgers have much more than a championship on their minds.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — On the eve of their West Regional final Saturday against Arizona, the Wisconsin players were ensconced in a hotel down the street from Disneyland, in a meeting room with two walls of floor-to-ceiling windows.

headline: Help for Hearing
abstract: A response to “Just Don’t Call Them Hearing Aids” (Novelties, March 23).
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: A Season Opens. But Who Closes?
abstract: Finding a reliable game finisher can be such a hit-or-miss struggle that some teams are opting to limit their investment in the effort.
lead_paragraph: Koji Uehara got the first call to the bullpen for the Boston Red Sox last season — and the last. He retired the side in the sixth inning on opening day, and in the ninth inning to close the World Series. Fenway Park rejoiced, and the St. Louis Cardinals went home.

headline: The Artificial Leaf Is Here. Again.
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'Hydrogen', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Photosynthesis', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: An energy source based on photosynthesis still appears tantalizingly close. But consumers first need to become accustomed to what else is needed for it to work.
lead_paragraph: General Electric is promoting a feel-good collection of videos these days.

headline: How to Harm Investors
abstract: Proposed crowdfunding rules by the Securities and Exchange Commission need to be thoroughly reworked.
lead_paragraph: Before Facebook paid $2 billion last week to buy Oculus VR, a virtual reality headset maker, 9,500 people donated $2.4 million via Kickstarter, the crowdfunding website, to get Oculus off the ground. Those early donors got thank-you notes, T-shirts or prototype headsets, but not a piece of the company. Donations through Kickstarter are just that, donations, not investments.

headline: The Christian Penumbra
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Protestant Churches', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Poverty', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: Is religion good for American society? It depends.
lead_paragraph: HERE is a seeming paradox of American life. One the one hand, there is a broad social-science correlation between religious faith and various social goods — health and happiness, upward mobility, social trust, charitable work and civic participation.

headline: How to Think About the Risk of Autism
keywords: ['Autism', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'News and News Media', 'Statistics', 'Research']
abstract: Hard data can help parents keep a cool head.
lead_paragraph: A  STUDY published last week found that the brains of autistic children show abnormalities that are likely to have arisen before birth, which is consistent with a large body of previous evidence. Yet most media coverage focuses on vaccines, which do not cause autism and are given after birth. How can we help people separate real risks from false rumors?

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Easing Parental Pressure
abstract: Readers respond to a letter lamenting that many parents “see schools less as places for children to learn and grow and more as incubators for college applications.”
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a letter lamenting that many parents “see schools less as places for children to learn and grow and more as incubators for college applications.”

headline: Abstract Ideas Don’t Deserve Patents
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The government has too often given patent protection to inventions that do not represent real scientific advances.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution gives Congress the power to grant inventors a temporary monopoly over their creations to “promote the progress of science and useful arts.” But in recent years, the government has too often given patent protection to inventions that do not represent real scientific advances.

headline: A Mudslide, Foretold
abstract: It is human nature to look potential disaster in the face and see a bright, shining lie.
lead_paragraph: DON’T tell me, please, that nobody saw one of the deadliest landslides in American history coming. Say a prayer or send a donation for a community buried under a mountain of mud along a great river in Washington State, the Stillaguamish. Praise the emergency workers still trying to find a pulse of life in a disaster that left 25 people dead and 90 missing.

headline: Can We Close the Pay Gap?
keywords: ['Bonuses', 'Corporations', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Executive Compensation', 'Income Inequality', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The disparity between a chief executive’s pay and the average worker’s wage is larger than ever. What can be done?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The issue of pay ratios has become the latest front in a worldwide debate about inequality and the widening gap between the top 1 percent and everyone else. In the United States, the financial reforms of the Dodd-Frank Act contained a provision that would force American companies to disclose the ratio of the compensation of their chief executive officer to the median compensation of their employees. Yet fierce criticism from the business sector has succeeded in delaying this measure for four years — and counting.

headline: McDonagh Is on Rise, but Not Yet at Peak
abstract: Ryan McDonagh of the Rangers last week became part of the Norris Trophy conversation. The award is given to the N.H.L.’s top defenseman.
lead_paragraph: Last week a lot of people were saying Ryan McDonagh belonged in the Norris Trophy conversation: his Rangers teammate Brian Boyle, Coach Alain Vigneault, the NBC hockey commentator Pierre McGuire and plenty of local hockey writers, among others.

headline: Halfway Back to Society
abstract: The attorney general’s new requirements for halfway houses are the most recent example of his aggressive push to reform the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, about 30,000 federal prison inmates were released to more than 200 halfway houses around the country. These facilities — where an inmate can serve up to the last year of his or her sentence — are meant to ease the transition back into society by way of employment and housing assistance, drug treatment, and other programs that make it less likely an inmate will end up reoffending and returning to prison.

headline: N.C.A.A. Players Ignore Advice on Mouth Guards, Often at Their Own Peril
abstract: Dentists recommend the use of the guards, which can prevent serious injuries, but the N.C.A.A. does not require it.
lead_paragraph: As one of the three doctors who travel with the U.C.L.A. men’s basketball team, Ray Padilla had a seat behind the bench throughout the Bruins’ run in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: Amid Egypt’s Sweeping Crackdown, North Sinai Residents in Crossfire
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Wreckage from assaults speaks to a crackdown so sweeping that even ardent supporters of the military say it risks spreading sympathy for the militants who are targeted.
lead_paragraph: MAHDEYA, Egypt — Shadi Meneayi left his hometown here in North Sinai more than eight months ago to help lead a campaign of terrorist attacks against Egypt’s new military-led government, his relatives say.

headline: With a Star Back in Form, UConn Women Shake Off B.Y.U.
abstract: Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis recovered from an injury early in the season only to sustain another one and come down with mononucleosis, which shook her confidence.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — Kaleena Mosqueda-Lewis fell on her right elbow and began screaming:

headline: Aftershocks Follow an Earthquake Near Los Angeles
abstract: Seismic activity could continue for weeks, but an official said it should not be a cause for serious concern.
lead_paragraph: A total of 115 aftershocks jolted the Los Angeles area by Saturday morning after a magnitude 5.1 earthquake on Friday night, a federal seismologist said.

headline: When Accountability Is Only a Word
abstract: It’s difficult, if not impossible, to reconcile the words of Manhattan Coach Steve Masiello with his actions regarding a major discrepancy on his résumé.
lead_paragraph: Steve Masiello sat across a table from me before Manhattan’s opening game in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament in Orlando, Fla., and preached the importance of accountability.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Parallel Parking in the Arctic Circle
keywords: ['Submarines and Submersibles', 'Ice', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Global Warming', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: On a nuclear submarine deep under the ice, the view was quite stunning.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. NEW MEXICO IN THE ARCTIC

headline: A Metronome on the Mound
abstract: After their relief pitchers had a 4.12 E.R.A., 26th in the majors, last year, the Angels signed the free agent Joe Smith from Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — In some ways, the hardest part of Jerry Dipoto’s job should be the easiest. Like all general managers, Dipoto, of the Los Angeles Angels, has struggled to predict relief pitchers’ performance from year to year. Yet none of his peers had what he did from 1993 to 2000: a career as a major league pitcher.

headline: Wrigley Field Turns 100, and Other Milestones Arriving in 2014
abstract: Aside from Fenway Park, no other major league ballpark has reached its centennial.
lead_paragraph: For some people, time can become abstract. If you say that Wrigley Field will celebrate its 100th anniversary on April 23, the milestone resonates, but much of the context is lost.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, March 30
abstract: The Obama administration unveiled a legislative proposal to put an end to a controversial bulk phone records program this week, a topic that will dominate many conversations on the Sunday shows.
lead_paragraph: The White House announced a legislative proposal for an overhaul of the National Security Agency’s bulk domestic phone records program. If Congress approves the changes, the N.S.A. would only obtain specific phone records with permission from a judge and would no longer systemically collect data on Americans’ calls.

headline: Is the Lime an Endangered Species?
keywords: ['Limes', 'Shortages', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Citrus Fruits']
abstract: Mexican criminals are making a shortage worse.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — WE’RE used to the elusiveness of certain scarce and seasonal gastronomical treasures like black truffles that are priced and meted out accordingly. But no one could have predicted the strange twist that threatens to turn guacamole, Key lime pie and margaritas into rare delicacies.

headline: The Fight for Wisconsin’s Soul
abstract: Gov. Scott Walker granted a company astonishing latitude to construct a mine and pollute pristine waters.
lead_paragraph: WISCONSIN has been an environmental leader since 1910, when the state’s voters approved a constitutional amendment promoting forest and water conservation. Decades later, pioneering local environmentalists like Aldo Leopold and Senator Gaylord Nelson, who founded Earth Day in 1970, helped forge the nation’s ecological conscience.

headline: Cuban the Firebrand, and the Futurist
abstract: Mark Cuban’s recent comments about the future of the N.F.L. have sparked a reaction and a discussion.
lead_paragraph: Mark Cuban has a way with words, a natural ability to incite with insight. He is a self-made maverick, keeping it real with a well-planned rant.

headline: Free Craft Beer!
abstract: How state distribution laws hurt small brewers.
lead_paragraph: CRAFT breweries may be a big story in the media these days, but they face much tougher challenges than most other small businesses.

headline: How Businesses Use Your SATs
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Grades are to getting in to college as test scores are to getting a job.
lead_paragraph: THE news about the SAT has been confusing lately. On one hand, so many colleges and universities have opted not to require it that the College Board, which administers the SAT, has announced a top-to-bottom revamp because the test is out of step with today’s academic expectations. On the other hand, many employers are still asking job applicants for their test scores, even if they are years out of date.

headline: Why Fund-Raising Is Fun
abstract: Fund-raising can be fun, and good for you.
lead_paragraph: ONCE, I asked a class full of aspiring social entrepreneurs — all with business plans and ambitions to start nonprofits — how many of them were looking forward to fund-raising. Exactly zero hands went up. The consensus was that raising money might be a necessary evil, but it was a distraction from a social enterprise’s “real” work.

headline: When the College Door Shuts, a Minor League Beckons
abstract: P. J. Hairston’s career at North Carolina ended under the cloud of an N.C.A.A. investigation, but he was signed in January by the Texas Legends of the N.B.A. Development League.
lead_paragraph: FRISCO, Tex. — Moments before a recent game here, season-ticket holders for the Texas Legends, an N.B.A. Development League team, gathered in the owner’s box at Dr Pepper Arena.

headline: Dignity Is a Constitutional Principle
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Constitution (US)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Politics and Government', 'States (US)']
abstract: The point was made in the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
lead_paragraph: WITH gay marriage litigation moving forward at warp speed — federal judges have struck down five state bans on same-sex marriage since December — we may soon witness one of the worst shouting matches in Supreme Court history. Passions were already running high last June, when a divided court struck down federal, but not state, laws defining marriage exclusively as a relationship between a man and a woman. Justice Antonin Scalia denounced the majority opinion, which cited the demeaning and humiliating effects of the Defense of Marriage Act, as “legalistic argle-bargle” lacking any basis in our constitutional tradition. Writing for the five justices in the majority, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy countered that the assault on human dignity should be decisive in condemning the statute as unconstitutional.

headline: Civilization’s Starter Kit
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Glass', 'Metals and Minerals']
abstract: What would you need to know, if you had to start over?
lead_paragraph: I’M an astrobiologist — I study the essential building blocks of life, on this planet and others. But I don’t know how to fix a dripping tap, or what to do when the washing machine goes on the blink. I don’t know how to bake bread, let alone grow wheat. I’m utterly useless with my hands. My father-in-law used to joke that I had three degrees, but didn’t know anything about anything, whereas he graduated summa cum laude from the University of Life.

headline: Sunday’s Highlights
abstract: Highlights from Sunday’s N.C.A.A. men’s tournament games.
lead_paragraph: Michigan State, seeded fourth in the East, will be playing in its eighth regional final since 1999 when it goes against No. 7 seed Connecticut on Sunday at Madison Square Garden. The Spartans are 6-1 in their previous appearances.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 75
abstract: FIFA said that more than 2.5 million tickets have been sold for the World Cup, with tickets remaining for only seven games.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: A Quiz: Do You Speak Dictator?
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: After the recent actions of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, it’s time to test your dictator skills.
lead_paragraph: After the recent actions of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, it’s time to test your dictator skills.

headline: World Series Champions Have Surprise Endings With Closers
abstract: The last three championship teams clinched their World Series victories with closers other than those who started the season, underlining the unpredictable world of ninth-inning relievers.
lead_paragraph: The last three championship teams clinched their World Series victories with closers other than those who started the season, underlining the unpredictable world of ninth-inning relievers.

headline: Orioles May Keep Verlander Waiting
abstract: Justin Verlander has been to the World Series only once in his eight full seasons, and the Baltimore Orioles could delay another trip this season for the Tigers.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Tigers have reached the playoffs four times in Justin Verlander’s eight full seasons. Every time, Verlander has helped pitch them into the American League Championship Series.

headline: Serena Williams Falters Early but Captures Title
abstract: With Li Na up two breaks of serve and leading, 5-2 in the first set, Williams proceeded to reel off the next five games to win the set and take utter command of the match.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — As usual, Serena Williams had all the answers against Li Na. But there was at least one question that left her stumped Saturday after her 7-5, 6-1 victory in the final of the Sony Open.

headline: Same Old Cardinals, With New Look
abstract: The Cardinals showed their versatility with a reshuffling in which Yadier Molina is one of just two starting position players returning to the spots they played in for most of last season.
lead_paragraph: This is the power of depth and versatility. The St. Louis Cardinals have just two starting position players, catcher Yadier Molina and left fielder Matt Holliday, in the same spots they held in the majors for most of last season. The team shuffled the other pieces without trading any pitchers from its vaunted postseason staff, or the farm system.

headline: A Passion to Pitch
abstract: Pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, the Yankees’ $155 million import from Japan, grew up in a nation where joining a baseball team was like entering a religious order.
lead_paragraph: ITAMI, Japan — Masahiro Tanaka, the Yankees’ $155 million import, grew up in a nation where joining a baseball team was like entering a religious order. The field was hallowed ground, the equipment sacred gear. Coaches were obeyed with bowed heads.

headline: Ukraine’s Hopes Riding on a Chocolatier
abstract: After a leading contender dropped out of Ukraine’s presidential race, the nation’s hopes and those of its Western supporters are now with the billionaire Petro Olekseyevich Poroshenko.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — After a leading contender dropped out of Ukraine’s presidential race on Saturday, the hopes of many Ukrainians and their Western supporters are now riding on a man known as the Willy Wonka of Ukraine, the billionaire owner of a chocolate candy company.

headline: Seeking Political Revival, Christie Joins ’16 Contenders at G.O.P. Forum
abstract: Amid the bridge scandal in New Jersey, Gov. Chris Christie joined other G.O.P. presidential hopefuls at a meeting in Las Vegas and complained that the country is viewed as weaker since President Obama took office.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Gov. Chris Christie, eager to revive his national political fortunes amid a scandal back home in New Jersey, joined other leading Republicans at a forum here Saturday in complaining that President Obama had weakened the United States’ stature in the world. He bluntly warned that “when America does not play an active and vigorous role in the world, bad people do.”

headline: For 2014 Races, G.O.P. Hunts Its Own
abstract: The Republican establishment remains on the defensive, and without the momentum, against its vociferous challengers from the right.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Musical Interpretation
abstract: Sing along with Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Now this is a clever idea. A lot of people who read Wordplay are also music lovers, so I’m sure you’ll like this puzzle by Peter A. Collins as well.

headline: Howard Schmertz, Millrose Games Director, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Schmertz, a Bronx native, began attending the Millrose Games at the age of 7 and succeeded his father as the meet’s director in 1975.
lead_paragraph: Howard Schmertz, a lawyer who for 29 years presided over the Millrose Games in Manhattan, long one of the world’s most prestigious indoor track and field meets, died on Thursday in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: A Push in Laredo to Raze Abandoned Houses Used in Drug Deals
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Demolition', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The Border Patrol and the Texas National Guard are working with the city of Laredo to demolish structures there that have been identified as stash houses for drug runners.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO — In an unusual partnership, the South Texas city of Laredo is teaming with the United States Border Patrol and the Texas National Guard to help rid itself of abandoned structures that have been labeled eyesores and havens for criminal activity.

headline: Growth Tests San Antonio’s Conservation Culture
abstract: The Texas city is lauded for its water conservation efforts, but it is finding that those are not enough amid explosive growth and dwindling resources.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — To understand the culture of water conservation that this city has cultivated in the last 20 years, consider that a 11-foot-tall model of a low-flow toilet adorns the lobby of its water utility’s headquarters. The toilet recently was the subject of many photo opportunities when a group of more than 80 lawmakers, legislative staffers and water planners toured the city’s water facilities.

headline: An Icon of Football Is the Muse for Arias
abstract: When an opera based on the life of Bum Phillips, the Houston Oilers coach, played in New York recently, it drew friends, family members and former Oiler players.
lead_paragraph: When the legendary coach of the Houston Oilers, Oail Andrew Phillips — everybody knows him as “Bum” — was approached in 2012 with a pitch to make an opera about his life, he responded in trademark fashion, “I can’t sing a lick.”

headline: Court Halts Sale of BlackBerry-Style Keyboard for iPhone
abstract: A federal judge in California has issued a preliminary injunction banning the sale of an iPhone case by Typo Products as part of a lawsuit by BlackBerry.
lead_paragraph: Some early success has come to BlackBerry’s attempts to shut down sales of a case that gives iPhone 5 owners a physical keyboard that looks as if it fell off a BlackBerry.

headline: California Farmers Short of Labor, and Patience
keywords: ['Migrant Labor (Agriculture)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Growers say inaction on immigration legislation is hurting productivity, and a powerful group that represents them says its members may withhold campaign contributions.
lead_paragraph: HURON, Calif. — When Chuck Herrin, who runs a large farm labor contracting company, looks out at the hundreds of workers he hires each year to tend to the countless rows of asparagus, grapes, tomatoes, peaches and plums, he often seethes in frustration.

headline: Mets Pick Mejia for Rotation; Decision Shocks Matsuzaka
abstract: Jenrry Mejia was selected as the Mets fifth starter on Saturday, which did not sit well with Daisuke Matsuzaka, who was sent to the minor leagues.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — The Mets announced Saturday that they would send Daisuke Matsuzaka to Class AAA Las Vegas, making Jenrry Mejia the fifth starter.

headline: New G.O.P. Bid to Limit Voting in Swing States
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'States (US)']
abstract: Already, nine states, under Republican control, have passed measures making it harder to vote since the beginning of 2013.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Pivotal swing states under Republican control are embracing significant new electoral restrictions on registering and voting that go beyond the voter identification requirements that have caused fierce partisan brawls.

headline: South Korea’s Sea Women
abstract: Enduring and tough, the female divers of Jeju Island have been a tradition for centuries. Most are over 60 now, and their numbers are declining fast.
lead_paragraph: Enduring and tough, the female divers of Jeju Island have been a tradition for centuries. Most are over 60 now, and their numbers are declining fast.

headline: Jeter Is Honored as Yankees End Spring Training With a Rainout
abstract: The ceremony at Steinbrenner Field was the first in what will be a string of official goodbyes to Derek Jeter, who will retire at the end of the season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — As some of the darkest clouds settled over the stadium and large drops of rain pelted the field, a member of the grounds crew made a farcical effort to paint the third-base line white. With only a few minutes before the scheduled first pitch Saturday, the Yankees were still maintaining the charade that a game would be played.

headline: Hardy Divers in Korea Strait, ‘Sea Women’ Are Dwindling
abstract: For ages, the sea women of Jeju, off the southern coast of South Korea, have braved treacherous waters for their harvest.
lead_paragraph: HADO-RI, South Korea — On a recent morning, as she has for 60 years, Kim Eun-sil carried her diving gear to a rocky beach on the eastern side of this island to spend the day free-diving in water more than 20 feet deep to harvest seafood by hand.

headline: Debate Over Palestinian Prisoner Release
abstract: Israel has released 78 Palestinian prisoners as part of a deal to restart peace talks. The prisoners are welcomed by many Palestinians as heroes, but many Israelis feel their release is an injustice.
lead_paragraph: Israel has released 78 Palestinian prisoners as part of a deal to restart peace talks. The prisoners are welcomed by many Palestinians as heroes, but many Israelis feel their release is an injustice.

headline: Hailed as Heroes but Facing Challenges
abstract: Palestinian prisoners freed from Israeli jails struggle to rebuild their lives.
lead_paragraph: Palestinian prisoners freed from Israeli jails struggle to rebuild their lives.

headline: Nine in G.O.P. Vie to Succeed Arizona Governor, With Party Identity at Stake
abstract: In the weeks since Gov. Jan Brewer announced that she would not run for re-election, the already crowded field of Republicans looking to replace her has grown noisy.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — State Treasurer Doug Ducey takes every opportunity to highlight his “real-world experience” as the former president of a chain of ice-cream parlors. Christine Jones, a former Internet company executive, says her “technological sophistication” is just what Arizona needs to become more efficient. Al Melvin, a state senator, asserts that the Tea Party “saved the United States as a country in 2010,” when it took control of Congress, and “will save the country again this year.”

headline: Repercussions and Reprieves at Health Insurance Enrollment Deadline
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: After Monday, most people must have health coverage or face a penalty, and the confusion of the last six months appears likely to continue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — America’s health insurance marketplace closes on Monday night, the deadline for most people to obtain coverage or face a penalty.

headline: A Team of Maestros Takes Hold
abstract: After financial setbacks and relying on guest conductors, the Westchester Philharmonic has hired two principal conductors in an unusual arrangement that officials hope will lend greater consistency.
lead_paragraph: In October 2007, Joshua Worby was just a year into his tenure as executive director of the Westchester Philharmonic, and the signing of Itzhak Perlman to a contract as its artistic director occasioned Champagne toasts. This month, a somewhat chastened Mr. Worby sipped water from a paper cup in his modest White Plains office and recalled that, less than three years later and with money running short amid a recession, the contract was dissolved.

headline: Remaking a Life, After Years in an Israeli Prison
abstract: Demonized as terrorists by Israelis and lionized as freedom fighters by Palestinians, prisoners like Muqdad Salah have become a flash point in the troubled peace talks.
lead_paragraph: BURQA, West Bank — Muqdad Salah is a man in a hurry.

headline: Credibility of Afghan Vote in Doubt as Observers Flee Violence
abstract: Many international election monitors curtailed their activities or made plans to evacuate their foreign employees, potentially raising serious questions about the election’s validity.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Usually, an Afghan election — a $100 million, Western-funded exercise — draws foreigners to Kabul like flies to honey, with incoming flights full of consultants, international monitors, diplomats and journalists.

headline: Don Reitz, Who Made Dirt and Salt Into Art, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Reitz was one of a small cadre of midcentury artisans who expanded the medium to include immense, intellectually provocative works of abstract art.
lead_paragraph: Don Reitz, an internationally renowned artist in dirt and salt, died on March 19 at his home in Clarkdale, Ariz. He was 84.

headline: Leo Bretholz, 93, Dies; Escaped Train to Auschwitz
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Reparations', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Mr. Bretholz testified in Congress in 2011, asking that Holocaust survivors be allowed to sue the French railway S.N.C.F. for its role in Nazi deportations to death camps.
lead_paragraph: Schoolchildren sometimes asked him why he did not have a number tattooed on his arm, like other Holocaust survivors who visited their classes. The answer was in the story he was about to tell, Leo Bretholz replied.

headline: Kentucky’s Five Freshman Looking to Separate Themselves From Michigan’s Fab Five
abstract: Kentucky is looking to become the second team to reach the Final Four with five freshman starters, and the first since Michigan’s 1992 team that featured a freshman lineup known as the Fab Five.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — With a win against Michigan in Sunday’s Midwest Regional final, Kentucky would become the second team to reach the Final Four with five freshman starters. The only other team to have accomplished that, of course, was Michigan. In 1992, the Wolverines’ starting lineup included Jalen Rose, Chris Webber, Juwan Howard, Jimmy King and Ray Jackson. Kentucky’s freshmen — James Young, Dakari Johnson, Andrew Harrison and Aaron Harrison and Julius Randle — are familiar with that Michigan team, known as the Fab Five.

headline: Deposed World Champion on Track for a Rematch
abstract: Viswanathan Anand, who lost his title to Magnus Carlsen, held a commanding lead in the tournament to determine this year’s challenger.
lead_paragraph: When Magnus Carlsen sits down to defend his world title this year, it appears that he will be staring across the board at a familiar face: Viswanathan Anand, from whom Carlsen snatched the crown last year.

headline: Poised, but She’s on the Verge
abstract: Point by point, the horrible, heartbreaking truth of the life of the protagonist becomes clear in Sharr White’s high-pitched drama “The Other Place.”
lead_paragraph: Don’t believe everything Dr. Juliana Smithton says.

headline: Death Toll Climbs to 18 a Week After Landslide
abstract: Officials in Oso, Wash., said on Saturday that 18 people had been confirmed dead and 30 others were still missing or unaccounted for.
lead_paragraph: OSO, Wash. — A week after a devastating landslide tore apart this small town, officials on Saturday said that 18 people had been confirmed dead and 30 others were still missing or unaccounted for, with the task of identifying bodies complicated by the condition they were found in.

headline: Florida Tightens Defense to End Dayton’s Run and Reach Final Four
abstract: Dayton, which defeated Ohio State, Syracuse and Stanford to reach the South Regional title game, was held to a season-low 52 points by top-seeded Florida.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — On his way out of FedEx Forum on Saturday night, the college basketball radio analyst Will Perdue looked back out on the floor where Florida had just cut down the nets in celebration of a Final Four berth. He shook his head, marveling over the Gators, and said, “I haven’t seen anybody yet that can beat these guys, not with that defense.”

headline: Despite Conflict and Repression, Creativity
abstract: “Art Amongst War” at the College of New Jersey Art Gallery includes “war rugs,” photographs, a silk-screen calligraphy and more.
lead_paragraph: In assembling “Art Amongst War: Visual Culture in Afghanistan, 1979-2014,” the current exhibition at the College of New Jersey Art Gallery, Deborah Hutton discovered works that evoked feelings ranging from dismay to guarded hope.

headline: De Blasio Announces Push for Hurricane Recovery
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio appointed three officials to lead the effort and said New York City would allocate $100 million in funds to assist homeowners.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York announced on Saturday a major push to assist residents affected by Hurricane Sandy, saying that his administration would cut through the red tape that plagued the recovery process under his predecessor.

headline: Contenders For the Derby Bring Historic Possibilities
abstract: Constitution took the Florida Derby, and Vicar’s in Trouble won the Louisiana Derby. Toast of New York won in Dubai, although his trainer was unsure whether he would travel to Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — Constitution, unraced as a 2-year-old, made up for lost time Saturday, rallying to defeat Wildcat Red by a neck in the $1 million Florida Derby at Gulfstream Park.

headline: Pied Piper Bonds With the Faithful
abstract: Though Lady Gaga’s “Artpop” album was considered a commercial flop, her audience seemed to embrace her on the first night of her “artRAVE: the ARTPOP ball” tour at Roseland Ballroom.
lead_paragraph: Six years into the supernova phase of her career, Lady Gaga is already a nostalgia act. Not in the temporal sense — even in her prime she wasn’t a particularly modern artist, but one bowing at the altar of early 1980s Madonna, toying with the arena camp of the 1970s or winking at 1990s club land — but more in terms of place.

headline: My Quiz on Dictators
abstract: Reader comments on my quiz, and suggestions for themes to cover in Ukraine and Moldova
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column takes the form of a quiz about world affairs, focusing on Putin and various autocrats. It’s also a bit of an experiment, because although I’ve done quiz columns before this is the first time I’ve used an interactive web version. It tells you immediately whether your answer is right or wrong and information pops up depending on how you answer. So let me know what you think of the experiment. I’m always interested in trying new tools to engage readers.

headline: Two Key Contributors Were Teammates Long Before They Were Spartans
abstract: The Michigan State juniors Branden Dawson, a tenacious rebounder and presence around the rim, and Travis Trice, a willing passer with deep shooting range, started playing together in seventh grade.
lead_paragraph: Branden Dawson said he was not surprised when Travis Trice, with no Michigan State teammates near the basket, decided to shoot a 3-pointer in transition Friday night.
