abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: March 29, 2014

headline: Vows: Leader of the Pack
abstract: Raising sled dogs together in Manhattan has taught Samantha Berkule and Scott Johnson to value the bond between them.
lead_paragraph: Raising sled dogs together in Manhattan has taught Samantha Berkule and Scott Johnson to value the bond between them.

headline: Final Shift in Momentum Puts Wisconsin in Final Four
abstract: The teams traded the lead several times in the later stages of the game, but Wisconsin prevailed when Arizona failed to make a shot as time ran out.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The ball was in Nick Johnson’s hands again. Just as he hoped it would be when he and his Arizona teammates were given a late reprieve, a final chance in a game that had been full of missed opportunities.

headline: With Rare Success, 76ers Fail to Break Record
abstract: Although the 76ers had tied the N.B.A. record for consecutive losses at 26, they won with flair on Saturday and failed to set a new mark in futility.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Something strange happened Saturday night in Philadelphia. The 76ers won. In fact, they won easily.

headline: Video Notebook: Bert Miranda
abstract: Bert Miranda had always wanted to see a Broadway show, but found that “Rocky” was easier to relate to than some other productions.
lead_paragraph: Bert Miranda had always wanted to see a Broadway show, but found that “Rocky” was easier to relate to than some other productions.

lead_paragraph: Jim Abate, an audience member at “Rocky,” says that he appreciated the use of props in the show.

headline: Rookie Award for Tanaka
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, a right-handed pitcher, has won the James P. Dawson Award, given annually to the outstanding Yankees rookie in spring training, the team announced.
lead_paragraph: Masahiro Tanaka, a right-handed pitcher, has won the James P. Dawson Award, given annually to the outstanding Yankees rookie in spring training, the team announced. Tanaka, 25, signed in the off-season to a seven-year, $155 million contract, went 2-0 with a 2.14 earned run average over 21 innings. He recorded 26 strikeouts and 3 walks.

headline: Rebecca Frank, Aaron Mehta
abstract: The bride and groom graduated from Tufts, where they met.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Ann Frank, the daughter of Belle Frank and James A. Frank of New York, was married Saturday evening to Aaron Noshir Mehta, the son of Dara R. Mehta and Noshir R. Mehta, of Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi David Saperstein officiated at the Park Hyatt Washington.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Julia Beth Finkelstein and Dr. James Steven Rosoff were married Saturday evening at Guastavino’s, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Mara S. Nathan officiated.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Chen Chen and Yi Zhou were married Saturday at the Harvard Club in New York. Laura Gabriel, a minister ordained by the New Age Fellowship in New York, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Samantha Brooke Berkule and Scott Stuart Johnson were married Saturday evening in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla. Cantor Jill E. Abramson officiated at the Acqualina Resort and Spa on the Beach.

Maroney, a friend of the couple, will lead a ceremony incorporating Jewish traditions at One, an event space in Nashville.

Winkler of Wynnewood, Pa., and the late Dr. Beverly D. Eskreis. Rabbi Abraham A. Levene will officiate at Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., with Rabbi Zev Reichman participating.

lead_paragraph: Chrystie Hale Perry and Kenneth Robert Holmstrom were married Friday evening at the Yale Club in New York. The Rev. Laurie Sue Brockway, an interfaith minister, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Melissa Heather Rooney and Thomas Miles Geggel were married Saturday by Mark Giller, a Sanctuary of the Beloved minister, at the Woodlands at Woodbury in Woodbury, N.Y.

lead_paragraph: Samantha Michelle Ulmer and George Philip Enstad were married Saturday evening at the Knowles Memorial Chapel at Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla. The Rev. Richard Walsh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: Alexis Meredith Weinerman and Jason Ian Fishkind were married Saturday evening at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia. Rabbi Joseph M. Domosh officiated.

lead_paragraph: Amy Lauren Kleger and Jeremy Robert Koven were married Saturday evening at the Le Méridien Philadelphia hotel. Rabbi Lauren G. Herrmann officiated.

Coffin and Kenneth J. Coffin of Bulls Head, Staten Island. The Rev. John Libone, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Aquinas Catholic Church in Dallas.

lead_paragraph: Jennifer Elizabeth Solomon and Joshua Andrew Galiard Alexander were married Saturday evening at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. Rabbi Joshua Strom officiated.

headline: More Ships and Planes Join Search for Jetliner
keywords: ['Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Ten planes and ten ships scoured the latest search area, roughly the size of Poland, and others were scheduled to arrive in the next several days.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — With no trace of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 more than three weeks after it disappeared, the international search effort intensified Monday, with 10 planes and 10 ships expected to scour the latest search area about 1,100 miles west of Perth, Australia, officials said.

headline: In Our Pages: March 31
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A steamer cut in two after a collision at sea in 1889, and an associate of the heavyweight boxer Sonny Liston denies fronting for criminals in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1889: A Steamer Cut In Two

headline: Large Crowds Fill Taipei Streets in Protest Over China Trade Bill
abstract: A pact that would drop barriers to trade in services with China has spurred concern in Taiwan, where student-led demonstrators continue to occupy the legislature.
lead_paragraph: More than 100,000 demonstrators took to the streets of Taipei on Sunday to protest efforts by the government to approve a trade pact with China and to show support for the students who have occupied Taiwan’s Legislature for nearly two weeks.

headline: A Sperm Donor, Uncertain of What It Is to Be ‘Bio-Dad’
abstract: After a request from friends, a 29-year-old gay man explored the possibility of becoming a sperm donor.
lead_paragraph: “But … I’m so short!”

headline: North Korea Vows to Use ‘New Form’ of Nuclear Test
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Tests']
abstract: The North did not elaborate, but Western analysts have long suspected that it is trying to make nuclear devices that could be delivered by intercontinental ballistic missiles.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea threatened on Sunday to carry out a “new form” of nuclear test, a year after its third nuclear test raised military tensions on the divided Korean Peninsula and prompted the United Nations to tighten sanctions against the North.

headline: A Tax Break to Anchor Tech Growth in San Francisco
abstract: Some companies housed in specific low-income areas of San Francisco receive breaks on taxes if they perform tasks that help improve their neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On one side of a long, wooden table at Zendesk’s offices here, 80 software engineers who are collectively worth tens of millions of dollars stood with empty paper plates waiting to be fed.

headline: Review: 2014 Toyota Highlander Limited
abstract: Toyota’s three-row crossover becomes less Bert, more Ernie with an injection of some welcome personality.
lead_paragraph: Many automobile manufacturers have abandoned minivans over the last 10 years because crossovers are where the money is these days. Need proof? Porsche now makes two of them.

headline: Harold Rosenbaum Wins Conductor’s Award
abstract: Mr. Rosenbaum, the conductor of the New York Virtuoso Singers, will receive $5,000 as the winner of the Ditson Conductors Award.
lead_paragraph: The Ditson Conductor’s Award, an annual prize presented by Columbia University for contributions to the advancement of American music, is to be presented to Harold Rosenbaum at a concert by the New York Virtuoso Singers at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Rosenbaum founded the ensemble in 1988, and is also the founder and conductor of the Canticum Novum Singers and the director of the Harold Rosenbaum Choral Conducting Institute, held annually at Columbia and the State University of New York at Buffalo. The award, which was established in 1945, includes a citation and $5,000.

headline: Brazil Moves to Expel Drug Gangs From Rio Slums
abstract: Police officers and marines move through the Complexo da Mare in an early-morning surge.
lead_paragraph: Police officers and marines move through the Complexo da Mare in an early-morning surge.

headline: European Lawmakers Prepare to Vote on ‘Net Neutrality’
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Law and Legislation', 'Net Neutrality', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The legislation, the focus of intense lobbying from all sides, is meant to ensure equitable Internet access for 500 million Europeans.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Vodafone gave Chris Herbert a package deal he found too tempting to turn down.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 3 P.M. (BET) LOVE JONES (1997) The first meeting between Darius (Larenz Tate) and Nina (Nia Long, above, with Mr. Tate) at a Chicago poetry club goes so swimmingly that Darius dedicates his reading to her. They are smitten, and a courtship ensues, with plenty of heat, in this film written and directed by Theodore Witcher. Along the way, it “spins an enjoyable web and suggests that its characters, in addition to knowing how to woo each other, also know how to have other kinds of fun,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times.

headline: Christie Addresses Republicans
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke to the Republican Jewish Coalition on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey spoke to the Republican Jewish Coalition on Saturday.

headline: The ACA Surge Blackout
abstract: Good news you haven’t heard.
lead_paragraph: Update: And the 4th-ranking Republican in the Senate is already accusing the administration of cooking the books. I really think the possibility that the ACA might actually work never occurred to them.

headline: Is Facebook Too Big to Care?
abstract: The social network has made some recent moves that suggest it is determined to follow its own path, regardless of what outsiders think.
lead_paragraph: Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has always followed his own instincts when making decisions about the company he founded 10 years ago. But several events over the last week make you wonder: Has the company gotten so successful that it doesn’t care what other people think about it?

headline: A Movement to Protect Food Markets in the Bronx, and Beyond
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Food', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores']
abstract: In the wake of catastrophes like Hurricane Sandy, a cook-off in Hunts Point is meant to lure locals to get feedback on ways to protect the wholesale markets that feed some 22 million people in the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: Baron Ambrosia, the Bronx’s culinary boulevardier of stout heart and insatiable palate, made the rounds of Hunts Point recently, sweeping into ethnic restaurants to urge people to come to the big table. Granted, some of the joints he visited were barely big enough to contain his oversize persona. But the table to which he was rallying people was one where food was both on the plate and on the agenda.

headline: Promises of Diplomacy but No Advances in Ukraine Talks
abstract: As Secretary of State John Kerry began his meeting in Paris with his Russian counterpart on Sunday to seek a political solution to the standoff over Ukraine, the federalization of the country was likely to be at the core of the discussion.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart agreed on Sunday that a political solution was needed for Ukraine and said they planned to continue discussing ways to de-escalate the crisis over the country’s future and Russia’s annexation of Crimea. But neither side claimed a breakthrough, and Russia did not commit to pulling back the more than 40,000 troops the United States says are massed near Ukraine’s border.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking: March 28, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses sanctions against Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is trying to isolate Vladimir Putin through various sanctions against dozens of politicians and business leaders close to the Russian leader. This week on Money Talking, Rana Foroohar and Joe Nocera consider whether the sanctions are going to have any effect. What would mean if Russian billionaires can’t buy New York City penthouses? Plus, Rupert Murdoch’s plans for succession at Fox and News Corp involves his sons.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 74
abstract: In an unusual move, the Netherlands has announced that Guus Hiddink will replace Louis van Gaal as the coach of its national team after the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: To call Guus Hiddink peripatetic would be an understatement.

headline: ‘Noah’ Is No. 1 Despite Complaints
abstract: The biblical epic directed by Darren Aronofsky raked in an estimated $44 million in domestic ticket sales over the weekend, including $6.2 million from giant Imax screens.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Viewers went to “Noah,” many in pairs, like the creatures in Genesis; but they quickly erupted in disagreement over the film’s action-packed, modernist rendering of the biblical flood.

headline: Connecticut Defeats Michigan State to Advance to the Final Four
abstract: Shabazz Napier scored 25 points to lead the seventh-seeded Huskies past the fourth-seeded Spartans and into to the Final Four, where they will face top-seeded Florida.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Ollie, the Connecticut coach, organized a field trip during his team’s jaunt through Texas in early January. Taking a break from basketball, the Huskies visited AT&T Stadium, the site of this year’s Final Four.

headline: A Case of ‘I’ll Have What They’re Having,’ Even if It Might Be Worse
abstract: “Friends With Better Lives” is a new sitcom about members of a close-knit group who covet something about one another.
lead_paragraph: It’s actually not a bad strategy that “Friends With Better Lives” is employing: Make your first episode so gratingly awful that as the series progresses, you have nowhere to go but up.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 1
abstract: Ranking the top contenders for the Kentucky Derby on May 3 after the first weekend of major prep races.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Churchill Downs adopted a points system to determine the field for the Kentucky Derby, replacing the use of graded-stakes earnings. Points are earned by the top four finishers in designated Derby prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturday’s Florida, Louisiana and U.A.E. Derbies can be found here.

headline: Prevailing at the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams
abstract: The premier event at the Spring North American Championships was played on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, the premier event at the Spring North American Championships here, was played on Sunday between Nick Nickell, Ralph Katz, Bobby Levin, Steve Weinstein, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell; and Team Monaco: Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness. (Pierre Zimmermann and Franck Multon were on the team early in the tournament.)

headline: U.S. Agency Knew About G.M. Flaw but Did Not Act
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A House subcommittee will open hearings on Tuesday looking into why federal investigators never realized there was a problem with certain G.M. ignition systems.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators decided not to open an inquiry on the ignitions of Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars even after their own investigators reported in 2007 that they knew of four fatal crashes, 29 complaints and 14 other reports that showed the problem disabled air bags, according to a memo released by a House subcommittee on Sunday.

headline: Pick Your Weapon, Your Moral Path and the Response of Your Public
abstract: Infamous: Second Son, whose characters are genetically endowed superhumans, flirts with moral ambiguity but winds up fairly black and white.
lead_paragraph: Video game designers like to talk about the verbs in their games, and those verbs — jump, shoot, punch, run, hide, talk, listen, watch — are what give their work meaning.

headline: ‘Vanya and Sonia’ Writer to Take the Stage
abstract: The playwright Christopher Durang, who wrote “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” is set to star as Vanya in a coming production at the Bucks County Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Christopher Durang, who wrote “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” is set to star as Vanya in a coming production at the Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., the producers announced. The comedy, which takes place in Bucks County and won a Tony last year for best play, is scheduled to run from July 17 to Aug. 10. Marilu Henner (“Taxi”) has been cast as Masha, a role played by Sigourney Weaver in the Off Broadway and Broadway productions. Vanya was originally played by David Hyde Pierce. The production is to be directed by Sheryl Kaller (“Mothers and Sons”).

headline: Heidegger’s Notebooks Renew Focus on Anti-Semitism
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Philosophy', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: It has long been one of the most contentious questions in 20th-century intellectual history: Just how much, and what kind, of a Nazi was Heidegger?
lead_paragraph: It has long been one of the most contentious questions in 20th-century intellectual history: Just how much, and what kind, of a Nazi was the German philosopher Martin Heidegger?

headline: Djokovic Dominates Nadal for Sony Title
abstract: With a virtuoso performance, Novak Djokovic captured his fourth title in Key Biscayne and narrowed the gap in his long series with Rafael Nadal to 22-18.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — The ever-lengthening rivalry between Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal has been best defined by sweat and toil, by trophies earned after hours of titanic rallies and risk.

headline: Destination Unknown
abstract: For the characters in Francesca Marciano’s short story collection “The Other Language,” travel is a way of reinventing themselves or shrugging off an identity.
lead_paragraph: Francesca Marciano’s magical, fleet-footed stories leap around the globe, from Rome to New York to Mombasa, from a small Greek village to a remote island off the coast of Tanzania to a fortress on the banks of the Narmada River in India. She has an uncanny ability to conjure specific places — not just the spectacular postcard vistas (a sky that looked like “blue carbon paper,” a moonlit beach, framed with palm fronds, that looked like “an advertisement from the forties for cruises in the tropics”), but also a sense of the daily rhythms of life there (the pots of basil on the windowsills “to keep the mosquitoes away,” the ritual of hanging clothes out to dry in certain neighborhoods in Rome).

headline: Hip-Hop Radio Stars Try TV Comedy
abstract: VH1’s new reality show, “This Is Hot 97,” stars the main on-air personalities of a New York hip-hop radio station Hot 97 in light comedy sketches.
lead_paragraph: “This Is Hot 97” — a charming trifle on VH1 set in opposition to that channel’s other hip-hop-theme reality programming, like the reliably raucous “Love & Hip Hop” and its offspring — is a workplace comedy masquerading as a hip-hop-insider tour masquerading as a reality show, and not particularly successful at any of them. To be fair, though, it’s not trying hard. It has different goals.

headline: Rural Couple
abstract: The return of Robert Cirillo.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — A quick anecdote brought on by 41 Down, before we get into the puzzle:

headline: Highlights and Analysis: Mets Fall on Baseball’s First Afternoon
abstract: Times reporters and editors share their insights and analysis on the coming year while keeping tabs on the first full slate of games of 2014, including the Mets and Nationals live from CitiField at 1:00 p.m. ET.
lead_paragraph: Times reporters and editors shared their insights and analysis on the coming year and kept tabs on the first full slate of games of 2014, including the Mets and the Nationals at Citi Field.

headline: The Shame of the Church
abstract: Sexual abuse in the Catholic Church has been making headlines for years. Some priests have been punished, but what about the bishops who shielded them?
lead_paragraph: Sexual abuse in the Catholic Church has been making headlines for years. Some priests have been punished, but what about the bishops who shielded them?

headline: In an Upper-Crust World, an Ensemble Stays Loose
abstract: The Kronos Quartet’s program at Carnegie Hall, part of the group’s 40-year anniversary celebration, included the variety the ensemble is known for.
lead_paragraph: Forty years. 800 works. There was plenty to celebrate on Friday evening when the Kronos Quartet took to the big stage of Carnegie Hall with a colorful, high-energy celebration of four decades spent at the new-music frontier of the string quartet world. A diverse crowd turned out to cheer the ensemble, which comprises one founding member — the violinist David Harrington — and two longstanding members, the violinist John Sherba and the violist Hank Dutt, as well as the cellist Sunny Yang, who joined last year.

headline: The Fight to Reveal Abuses by Catholic Priests
keywords: ['Priests', 'Sex Crimes', 'Clergy', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Despite institutional promises of change, allegations of sex abuse and coverups continue to plague the American Catholic church.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the former Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, is in no way the principal face of the sexual abuse scandals that have buffeted the church and its priesthood almost without pause for three decades. But he embodies a certain mind-set among some in the highest clerical ranks. It is an attitude that has led critics, who of late include the authors of a scathing United Nations committee report, to wonder about the depth of the church’s commitment to atone for past predations and to ensure that those sins of the fathers are visited on no one else.

headline: Is Canada Tarring Itself?
keywords: ['Oil Sands', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Pipelines', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Environment', 'Global Warming', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Oil development is changing the country’s political life.
lead_paragraph: START with the term “tar sands.” In Canada only fervent opponents of oil development in northern Alberta dare to use those words; the preferred phrase is the more reassuring “oil sands.” Never mind that the “oil” in the world’s third largest petroleum reserve is in fact bitumen, a substance with the consistency of peanut butter, so viscous that another fossil fuel must be used to dilute it enough to make it flow.

headline: Older and Out of Work, but Not Out of Contention
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions', 'Age, Chronological']
abstract: At a seminar for jobless professionals 50 and older, 10 graduates have polished their résumés and their pitches as they renew the hunt for employment.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the 10 graduates celebrated over spoonfuls of yellow cake with chocolate icing. They hugged, cheered and promised to stay connected, fortifying themselves for the rough road ahead.

headline: Winners Named in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions
abstract: Five winners were selected in the finals of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions in New York.
lead_paragraph: This season more than 1,500 aspiring singers participated in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, thought to be the most prestigious voice competition in the field. After auditions in 40 districts and 13 regions in the United States and Canada, it all came down to the Grand Finals concert on Sunday afternoon at the Met.

headline: The Case for Profanity in Print
keywords: ['Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'News and News Media', 'English Language']
abstract: Censoring language deprives readers of news and information.
lead_paragraph: LAST month, Assistant Secretary of State Victoria Nuland made some impolitic comments about the European Union during a phone call with the ambassador to Ukraine. The phone call was leaked, leading to an embarrassing diplomatic incident that was covered in multiple articles in the media. But what, exactly, did Ms. Nuland say?

headline: No. 8 Seed Kentucky, Peaking at Right Time, Tops No. 2 Michigan
abstract: Julius Randle had 16 points and 11 rebounds and Aaron Harrison made two late 3-pointers to lead the eighth-seeded Wildcats, who will face No. 2 Wisconsin in a national semifinal Saturday.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — As recently as a month ago, the Kentucky basketball team was being dissected by its critics, belittled for being an underachiever and for perhaps not being worthy of the mountains of preseason No. 1 hype.

headline: Rattlesnake Wranglers, Armed With Gasoline
keywords: ['Hunting and Trapping', 'Snakes', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Texas’ state wildlife agency may ban the common practice of pumping gas fumes into holes to flush out rattlesnakes.
lead_paragraph: SWEETWATER, Tex. — At the foot of a rocky cliff here, Riley Sawyers knelt down and peered into a small, dark hole, on the prowl for rattlesnakes. One had already lunged at him and bitten his Kevlar-reinforced boot. The venom was still drying, as was the blood on his arm from where the thorny terrain had scratched him, when Mr. Sawyers went to fetch the gasoline.

headline: NBC Sports Hires ‘G.M.A.’ News Anchor
abstract: Josh Elliott ends a three-year run as the ABC program’s news anchor during which the show defeated its NBC-owned rival, “Today,” amid fierce competition.
lead_paragraph: In a move that increases the already intense competition in morning television, NBC Sports has hired Josh Elliott away from ABC’s “Good Morning America,” the show that displaced NBC’s “Today” show as the king of morning programming.

headline: Excerpt: ‘King Lear’
abstract: Michael Pennington plays the lead role in “King Lear” at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Michael Pennington plays the lead role in “King Lear” at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.

headline: A Lively Debate Over Outdoor Cats
abstract: Readers, including two animal welfare organizations, respond to an article that said outdoor cats should become socially unacceptable.

headline: Afghan Couple Finally Together, but a Storybook Ending Is Far From Ensured
abstract: A man and a woman from different ethnic groups have eloped and been married, but now they face threats of death and arrest.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Happy endings in Afghan love stories are vanishingly rare. And for one young couple from Bamian Province, the odds of such a conclusion are getting even longer.

headline: Motorcycle Crew Has One Requirement, and It Isn’t a License
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Miss-Fires, a women-only group, aims to make motorcycles less intimidating; they welcome members without a bike, a license, or much experience.
lead_paragraph: Inside a biker garage in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a red 1981 Moto Guzzi V50 Monza was beginning to draw a crowd.

headline: Hopes Frustrated, Many Latinos Reject the Ballot Box Altogether
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Across the country, immigrant-rights advocates report disillusionment with both parties among Latinos, enough to threaten recent gains in voting participation that have reshaped politics to Democrats’ advantage nationally.
lead_paragraph: AURORA, Colo. — As the weather warms, Lizeth Chacon is anticipating a new season of registering Latino voters — yet dreading experiences like one late last year, when she came upon a skate park full of older teenagers.

headline: Panel’s Warning on Climate Risk: Worst Is Yet to Come
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Food', 'Foreign Aid', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Weather']
abstract: A United Nations report warned that climate change is already having sweeping effects on every continent and is likely to grow substantially worse unless greenhouse emissions are brought under control.
lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — Climate change is already having sweeping effects on every continent and throughout the world’s oceans, scientists reported Monday, and they warned that the problem is likely to grow substantially worse unless greenhouse emissions are brought under control.

headline: ‘This American Life’ Considers Self-Distribution on Radio
abstract: Ira Glass, the host and executive producer of the program, said it would talk with several distributors, including NPR, but “self-distribution continues to be an option.”
lead_paragraph: The announcement two weeks ago that “This American Life” will part ways on July 1 from its distributor, Public Radio International, has set off a scramble among rivals for rights to the program, one of the most popular on public radio.

headline: In Media Moguls’ Rarefied Realm, It’s Like Father, Like Son
abstract: Even a cursory look at the media landscape suggests Rupert Murdoch is far from an outlier in wanting to see a property he built with his bare-knuckled hands land on his progeny.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Rupert Murdoch handed the future leadership of two publicly held companies worth a combined $80 billion to his two sons, almost as casually as if they were the keys to the family station wagon.

headline: Eddie Lawrence Dies at 95; Comedy’s ‘Old Philosopher’
abstract: Mr. Lawrence, an actor, writer and director, was famous for the Old Philosopher, a character and routine he performed on records, commercials and talk shows.
lead_paragraph: When Eddie Lawrence first performed his new comedy routine for his agent and a few entertainment executives, they told him that they loved it but that it was too clever for most people to understand. Mr. Lawrence had more faith in his audience.

headline: Feinstein Gives Tentative Nod to Data Curbs
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: Sen. Dianne Feinstein, chair of the Intelligence Committee, approved aspects of the Justice Department’s plan to constrain the National Security Agency’s collection of telephone data.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A proposal backed by President Obama to constrain the National Security Agency’s systematic collection of Americans’ telephone data drew a cautious welcome on Sunday from a key congressional intelligence leader, but she offered a few significant caveats.

headline: Video Notebook: UConn Makes Final Four
abstract: Connecticut’s Ryan Boatright talks about a trip to At&T Stadium, site of the Final Four, earlier this season. Michigan State’s Travis Trice talks about the seniors’ failing to make a Final Four.
lead_paragraph: Connecticut’s Ryan Boatright talks about a trip to At&T Stadium, site of the Final Four, earlier this season. Michigan State’s Travis Trice talks about the seniors’ failing to make a Final Four.

headline: Kate O’Mara, a Schemer on ‘Dynasty,’ Dies at 74
abstract: The British actress often played beautiful but devious characters, including Caress, the sister of Joan Collins’s character on the 1980s ABC soap opera “Dynasty.”
lead_paragraph: Kate O’Mara, the British actress who played the scheming sister of Joan Collins’s character on the 1980s prime-time soap opera “Dynasty” and another scheming sister on the BBC sitcom “Absolutely Fabulous,” died on Sunday in a nursing home in Sussex, England. She was 74.

headline: Morocco’s ‘Mule Ladies’
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Moroccan women face a dangerous daily toil, carrying large bales of duty-free goods back from the Spanish North African enclave of Melilla.
lead_paragraph: Moroccan women face a dangerous daily toil, carrying large bales of duty-free goods back from the Spanish North African enclave of Melilla.

headline: Yanks’ First Foe Is Happy to Keep Taking Long View
abstract: The Houston Astros expect to be somewhat better than last year, but they are waiting on a stable of minor-league talent for a true payoff in coming years.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees open their season Tuesday in the same place they ended their last one: Minute Maid Park, the home of the Houston Astros. They bring along $470 million in new players and expectations of a pinstriped parade this fall.

headline: For Opening Day, a Campaign to Love Baseball
keywords: ['Baseball', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'News and News Media', 'Online Advertising', 'Television', 'Social Media']
abstract: A salute to opening day will start the effort, by BBDO New York, which will focus on young stars and how attending games can provide lifetime memories.
lead_paragraph: MAJOR League Baseball is entering the new season with a new lead creative agency, BBDO New York, and invoking the L-word — love — to describe how fans feel about the sport, and how everyone else should, too.

headline: WWE Network Is Loud Introduction to the Video Streaming Ring
abstract: World Wrestling Entertainment has positioned itself on the cutting edge of Internet television with its new subscription-only streaming video service.
lead_paragraph: When listing the visionary media moguls of the digital age, Vince McMahon, the professional wrestling impresario, might not immediately come to mind.

headline: A Weight on Moroccan Women’s Shoulders
abstract: At the Moroccan-Spanish border, women known as “mule ladies” carry large bundles on their backs, sometimes earning as little as three euros per trip.
lead_paragraph: At the Moroccan-Spanish border, women known as “mule ladies” carry large bundles on their backs, sometimes earning as little as three euros per trip.

headline: Hollywood’s Antipiracy Efforts Add New Voice
abstract: Ruth Vitale, an independent film executive, was recently named executive director of CreativeFuture, a new force in the copyright wars.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the fall of 2012, Ruth Vitale, a sassy independent film executive, nosed her horse into a badly directed jump and crashed in the mud.

headline: Question Marks Will Head North With the Mets and Punctuate Their Opener
abstract: Beyond David Wright, there are few safe bets on the roster, though one thing is for sure: The star pitcher Matt Harvey won’t be available until late in the season, if at all.
lead_paragraph: Matt Harvey against Stephen Strasburg. One ace against another. That’s the matchup the Mets would have wanted, the one they could have put in lights. That is a matchup worthy of opening day. Instead, it will be the unassuming Dillon Gee opposite Strasburg and the Washington Nationals on Monday at Citi Field. Harvey, of course, will miss most if not all of this season while he recovers from Tommy John elbow surgery.

headline: As Landslide Debris Slows Search, Residents Resolve to Help
abstract: The landslide has claimed more than 20 lives so far, according to an official count from the Snohomish County medical examiner, with many more people reported dead by family members and volunteers.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Wash. — No sounds or signs of life, emergency responders say, have come from beneath a sea of muck and debris for a full week now since a devastating landslide roared down onto the tiny mountain community of Oso. No tale of determination and luck against the odds — an air pocket somehow shielded from the onslaught of earth and rock, or an iron-willed survivor spitting in the eye of fate — has emerged to leaven the gloom of mud and rain and death at what is called “the pile.”

headline: Jobs and Skills and Zombies
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Research']
abstract: Why does the myth of a “skills gap” persist and continue to do harm?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, and Marlene Seltzer, the chief executive of Jobs for the Future, published an article in Politico titled “Closing the Skills Gap.” They began portentously: “Today, nearly 11 million Americans are unemployed. Yet, at the same time, 4 million jobs sit unfilled” — supposedly demonstrating “the gulf between the skills job seekers currently have and the skills employers need.”

headline: Apple’s War on Samsung Has Google in Crossfire
abstract: Apple is seeking about $2 billion in damages from Samsung, which in turn says Apple violated its patents, but the case could also have major implications for Google.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Officially, it’s Apple versus Samsung Electronics in another tech patent face-off in a San Jose courtroom this week. But there is another company with a lot at stake in the case — Google.

headline: Is Belief a Jewish Notion?
abstract: Theoretical views about God may be less important than religious practice.
lead_paragraph: This is the fourth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Howard Wettstein, a professor of philosophy at the University of California, Riverside, and the author of “The Significance of Religious Experience.”

headline: What Lending Rules Should Look Like
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is formulating rules to rein in the payday lending industry, which lures too many vulnerable people into debt traps.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which opened its doors in 2011, has already issued important regulations governing mortgage transactions and has established new oversight of credit reporting and student loans. Now the federal agency is formulating rules to rein in the payday lending industry, which bills itself as offering easy, short-term loans but earns its profits by luring people into debt traps.

headline: Carmakers’ Close Ties to Regulator Scrutinized
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Questions are once again being raised about “an all-too-cozy relationship” between former National Highway Traffic Safety Administration officials and the automobile industry.

Glassman’s name on it discussing life-threatening safety defects and requiring more information from a manufacturer; Ms. Glassman was once chief counsel of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, then deputy administrator, and, briefly, acting administrator.

headline: The Senate’s Discourtesy to Judges
keywords: ['Federal Courts (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials']
abstract: Republican senators are hiding behind a tradition that allows them to block judicial nominees without explanation. Chairman Leahy should put a stop to it.
lead_paragraph: The job of federal judge for the Eastern District of North Carolina has been vacant for more than eight years, one of the longest vacancies of 83 on the federal bench around the country. Last June, President Obama nominated Jennifer May-Parker, a federal prosecutor, for the position, but she hasn’t even received a vote in the Senate Judiciary Committee because Richard Burr, the state’s Republican senator, is blocking her.

headline: Journalists Held by Militants in Syria Reunite With Family
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Kidnapping', 'Hostages', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Javier Espinosa and Ricardo García Vilanova arrived in Madrid a day after Mr. Espinosa called his newspaper to say they had been handed over to Turkish soldiers.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two Spanish journalists held for six months by radical Islamist militants in northern Syria arrived safely in Madrid on Sunday, greeting friends and family in an emotional scene at the airport a day after one called his newspaper to report they had been handed over to Turkish soldiers.

headline: For Californians, 2 Quakes Put Preparedness Back on the Map
abstract: Two decades of seismic calm have undermined efforts to force Los Angeles to deal with what officials describe as potentially lethal deficiencies in earthquake preparation.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It has been 20 years since Southern California experienced a major earthquake, a powerful 6.7-magnitude temblor that rolled through Northridge, killing 57 people. But this stretch of seismic calm, though welcome in obvious ways, has undermined efforts to force Los Angeles to deal with what officials describe as potentially lethal deficiencies in earthquake preparation.

headline: De Blasio Betting on Pre-K to Succeed
abstract: The mayor has placed an increasingly large wager that his early missteps will be forgotten, so long as his centerpiece plan proves a success.

headline: Not on Ballot, Turkey’s Premier Still Gets Push From Party in Local Elections

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Even as he faced sweeping antigovernment protests last summer and a stinging corruption investigation that challenged his rule, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan held close to the notion that voters had put him in office and would do so again.

It’s the sort of display that makes you think about your own inventory of passed-down possessions, of the lives these discarded objects might have led and of the absent owners who once animated them.

headline: The Art of Living
abstract: The Italian design companies Cassina and Nemo bring the work of the French designer Charlotte Perriand, who was known for her understated, functional objects, stateside.
lead_paragraph: Cassina and the Italian lighting company Nemo are adding to their selections of Charlotte Perriand pieces. The French architect and designer was unfettered by expectation or precedent — she famously brought sensual life to Le Corbusier’s sometimes austere ideas — and the new pieces, available in the United States next month, reflect her commitment to functional beauty. They include Perriand’s Indochine swivel armchair, designed in 1943 for her personal use and based on her LC7 metal chair, which caught the attention of the world at the 1929 Salon d’Automne art exhibition; her triangular Mexique tables from 1952, shaped in response to the space constraints of student housing; and a small sconce from 1962, which shows the genius and cheer Perriand could bring to any object, however humble.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: NOON (FLIX) MELVIN AND HOWARD (1980) Paul Le Mat stars as Melvin Dummar, a milkman with big dreams but an unsteady relationship with his wife (Mary Steenburgen, who won an Oscar for her role) and an even rockier financial situation. That is, until he finds out that a vagrant he gave a lift to years earlier was the reclusive billionaire Howard Hughes, who has left him $150 million in his will. The film, directed by Jonathan Demme, is based on the true story of a Utah gas station attendant who claimed to be a beneficiary of Hughes’s fortune in what came to be known as “the Mormon will.” Officials deemed the Mormon will a forgery, “but Mr. Demme and Bo Goldman, his screenwriter, take Melvin’s tale at face value and present the movie as Melvin’s wildest dream,” Vincent Canby wrote in The Times. “The comic catch is that this wild dream is essentially so prosaic. It’s also touched with pathos since Melvin — in spite of himself — knows that it will never be realized. This is the story of his life.”

headline: To Be Poor and Sick in India
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Babies and Infants', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Infant Mortality', 'Rural Areas']
abstract: A new series for India Ink will look at the health care that lower-income patients receive around the country that is not only problematic but also outright lethal at times.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — I first became interested in India’s government hospitals after my son was born last May at Breach Candy Hospital in Mumbai, one of the city’s well-regarded private hospitals. The care was exceptional, but a stay at a private hospital is a luxury that only a small percentage of Mumbai residents can afford. My curiosity about what kind of care existed for the city’s less fortunate babies led me to write about the fight against infant mortality in the Dharavi slum for India Ink in September.
