headline: The Wolf Hunters of Wall Street
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Financial Brokers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: How a band of outsiders discovered that the stock market was rigged — and set out to change it.
lead_paragraph: Before the collapse of the U.S. financial system in 2008, Brad Katsuyama could tell himself that he bore no responsibility for that system. He worked for the Royal Bank of Canada, for a start. RBC might have been the fifth-biggest bank in North America, by some measures, but it was on nobody’s mental map of Wall Street. It was stable and relatively virtuous and soon to be known for having resisted the temptation to make bad subprime loans to Americans or peddle them to ignorant investors. But its management didn’t understand just what an afterthought the bank was — on the rare occasions American financiers thought about it at all. Katsuyama’s bosses sent him to New York from Toronto in 2002, when he was 23, as part of a “big push” for the bank to become a player on Wall Street. The sad truth was that hardly anyone noticed it. “The people in Canada are always saying, ‘We’re paying too much for people in the United States,’ ” Katsuyama says. “What they don’t realize is that the reason you have to pay them too much is that no one wants to work for RBC. RBC is a nobody.”

headline: Paradise in a Pakistani Valley
abstract: A photographer’s at first puzzling encounter with people displaced from their beloved Swat Valley led him to consider what makes a place paradise.
lead_paragraph: It was 2009 and a depleted savings account was all Edwin Koo had to show a year after he left Singapore to work as a freelance photographer in Nepal. Hungry for photos, Mr. Koo joined friends traveling to Islamabad, two hours south of the Taliban insurgency occurring in Pakistan’s Swat Valley. But hundreds of photographs and a handful of interviews with Swati refugees left just three words, repeated over and over, echoing in Mr. Koo’s mind.

headline: Should Employers Be Able to Review Job Applicants’ SAT Scores?
abstract: How much value should employers give to the SAT scores of prospective hires?
lead_paragraph: SAT scores have long been used by colleges and universities to predict the performance of prospective students. Should those same scores be used by those reviewing job applications?

headline: Former Israeli Leader Is Convicted of Taking Bribes
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Politics and Government', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Ehud Olmert, who was prime minister from 2006 to 2009, was accused of accepting money to facilitate the construction of a housing development in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ehud Olmert, the former Israeli prime minister who was forced from office under a corruption cloud, was convicted Monday of taking bribes to ease the construction of a huge housing complex while he was mayor of Jerusalem, dashing his much-discussed dream of a political comeback.

headline: Swiss Regulator Opens Currency Inquiry
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Currency', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Competition Commission says it is investigating possible collusion by eight leading financial institutions, including Swiss, American and British banks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Switzerland’s Competition Commission said on Monday that it had begun a formal investigation into eight financial institutions, including the Swiss banks Credit Suisse and UBS, over potential collusion to manipulate the currency markets.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Carina Chocano on the 15-Year-Old Chef Flynn McGarry
abstract: Carina Chocano, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story on the teenage chef Flynn McGarry. In this interview, Chocano reveals what it was like to profile the young star and eat his food.

headline: Another Worrisome Drop in Euro Zone Inflation
abstract: A rate lower than economists expected adds fire to the debate about whether the euro zone faces a risk of debilitating deflation.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A drop in euro zone inflation, to the lowest rate since 2009, has raised new questions about whether its economy is stuck in doldrums that could last for years and, if so, whether the European Central Bank can or will do anything about it.

headline: Pakistan’s Ex-Ruler Pleads Not Guilty to Treason Charges
abstract: The formal indictment of Pervez Musharraf is a watershed for Pakistan, where no military ruler has ever been tried for abuse of power.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan’s former military ruler, pleaded not guilty to treason charges on Monday after being formally indicted by a special court here, according to lawyers in the case.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
abstract: What you need to know to start your day: a climate doomsday warning, a negative first quarter, and the crack of the bat returns.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Morning Briefing on NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: New York Today: The Mayor’s First Pitch
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: De Blasio plays ball, the rain continues, and it’s the last day to enroll in health insurance.
lead_paragraph: Good Monday morning. It’s a rainy day.

headline: Daily Report: Pro Wrestling Looks to Video Streaming
abstract: World Wrestling Entertainment has positioned itself on the cutting edge of Internet television with its new subscription-only streaming video service.
lead_paragraph: When listing the visionary media moguls of the digital age, Vince McMahon, the professional wrestling impresario, might not immediately come to mind, Seth Berkman reports.

headline: Cultural Exchange, Facilitated by a Bandit
abstract: David Hallberg, the American danseur noble, performed the title role of “Marco Spada” with the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow on Sunday, a casting that would have been unimaginable three decades ago.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — At a time when relations between Russia and the West have become fraught, it’s worth noting that on Sunday night at the Bolshoi Theater, David Hallberg, the American danseur noble, performed the title role of “Marco Spada” with the Bolshoi Ballet. Thirty years ago, such casting was unimaginable.

headline: In Thailand, Some Foresee a Coup by Legal Means
abstract: Several judges and officials involved in cases against Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra’s government have had antagonistic relationships with her party.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Five months of protests in Bangkok have snarled traffic, scared away tourists and deflated the Thai economy, but the thousands of protesters who have regularly descended onto the streets have failed to unseat the government or any of its top officials.

headline: What I Got Out of My Website Redesign
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Small Business']
abstract: The result of these conversations was that our website was designed and written specifically for four types of people.
lead_paragraph: In my last post, I talked about why we decided to redesign my company’s website. This week, I’ll explain our goals for the site and what the results have been.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | March 31, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Update: April 1, 2014

headline: U.N. Court Orders Japan to Halt Whaling Off Antarctica
keywords: ['Whales and Whaling', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The International Court of Justice said that Japan’s “scientific whaling” program in the Southern Ocean was illegitimate.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The decision to ban Japan’s annual whaling drive off Antarctica, handed down by the United Nations’ highest court on Monday, was a hard-won victory for conservationists who long argued that Tokyo’s whaling research was a cover for commercial whaling.

headline: In Scotland, Working Both the Land and a Loophole
abstract: European Union farm subsidies, as practiced in Scotland, are sometimes an example of how the bloc's good intentions can be subverted.
lead_paragraph: INVERURIE, Scotland — At the bustling Thainstone Center market, white-coated auctioneers sell oats, barley and turnips, and hundreds of cattle and sheep.

headline: Palestinian Was Holding Explosive Device When He Died, Czechs Say
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic was killed Jan. 1 in an explosion at the Palestinian mission in Prague. Initial reports suggested a booby-trapped safe had exploded.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — The Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic, who was killed Jan. 1 in an explosion in his new residence here, most likely died after an explosive device he was holding detonated, the Czech police said Monday.

headline: British Financial Firms Expect to Keep Hiring, Survey Finds
abstract: Financial services companies plan to expand their head count rapidly during the next three months, a quarterly study found.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a further sign of optimism about strengthening economies in Europe, financial services firms in Britain said they expected to employ 1.16 million people by the end of the second quarter of this year, adding as many as 26,000 more jobs than in the same period a year earlier, according to a survey released on Monday.

headline: Congressional Report Strengthens Case for Future U.S. Visa for Modi
keywords: ['Elections', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Research', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Visas', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The report said the controversial Bharatiya Janata Party candidate, who was denied entry to the United States in 2005, would be eligible for a diplomatic visa if he becomes India’s next prime minister.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — On Dec. 5, 2012, Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia, stood on the steps of the Capitol in Washington with 25 other members of Congress and urged the United States government “never to grant a visa to allow Chief Minister Modi to visit the United States under any circumstances.”

headline: Daily Report: Apple-Samsung Patent Face-Off Has Google in Crossfire
abstract: A court battle between Apple and Samsung over patents could have a bigger effect on Google’s Android operating system.
lead_paragraph: Officially, it’s Apple versus Samsung Electronics in another tech patent face-off in a San Jose courtroom this week. But there is another company with a lot at stake in the case, Brian X. Chen reports — Google.

headline: British Regulator to Increase Scrutiny of Controls on Benchmark Rates
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Life Insurance', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority says it plans to review how investment banks control the flow of internal information on benchmark rates, potential conflicts of interests within financial institutions and internal controls on traders in relation to global benchmarks.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain said on Monday that it would review the efforts investment banks are making to prevent manipulation of key benchmarks.

headline: In Our Pages: April 1
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: Rebels gain ground in Mexico in 1914; Russia has its eyes on satellites in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Mexican Rebels Gain Ground

headline: Kerry to Visit Israel for Middle East Talks
abstract: The visit by Secretary of State John Kerry aims to address the dispute over the release of Palestinian prisoners and to confer on the Israeli-Palestinian peace negotiations.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Secretary of State John Kerry flew to Tel Aviv on Monday to try to resolve a thorny dispute over the release of Palestinian prisoners and keep the Middle East peace talks he started last summer on track. It is the second time in a week that Mr. Kerry has interrupted European travel to rush to the region to confer on the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, which had been on the brink of breaking down.

headline: Austerity Memories
abstract: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.
lead_paragraph: Preparing for this morning’s class (pdf), I inevitably found myself thinking back to the austerity debate of 2010-2012, which was simultaneously exhilarating and deeply depressing. On one side, the critique of austerity was a classic example of high-quality, relevant economic research done in real time to respond to important issues – and it has left us with much better evidence on the effects of fiscal policy than we had before. On the other side, the nakedness of the way policymakers seized on research telling them what they wanted to hear made you wonder whether economic research can, in fact, actually make a positive difference in the real world.

headline: Philippines and China in Dispute Over Reef
abstract: China accused the Philippines of illegally occupying its territory after a Philippine vessel resupplied a ship that has been stranded on a tiny reef for 15 years.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China accused the Philippines on Monday of illegally occupying Chinese territory after a Philippine vessel outmaneuvered the Chinese Coast Guard and resupplied a ship that has been stranded for 15 years on the Second Thomas Shoal, a tiny reef in the South China Sea.

headline: The ‘Dewey Seven’ Pleas, Unsealed
abstract: The pleas of seven former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf have been unsealed. | Comcast’s chief executive is looking beyond cable. | Is Facebook too big to care? | A lawyer takes on fiduciary failures. | The author Michael Lewis is taking aim at high-speed traders.
lead_paragraph: Seven former employees of Dewey & LeBoeuf who pleaded guilty to participating in a scheme to manipulate the law firm’s finances came from very different backgrounds than many of the high-powered lawyers at the once-prominent New York firm, Matthew Goldstein writes in DealBook. The employees’ guilty pleas were unsealed on Thursday and Friday, revealing that none of the former employees was a lawyer and just one was a certified public accountant.

headline: Morgan Stanley Executive to Join Litigation Finance Firm
abstract: William H. Strong, who is retiring as co-chief executive of Morgan Stanley’s operations in the Asia-Pacific region, plans to join Longford Capital as its chairman. The firm specializes in the budding field of investing in legal disputes.
lead_paragraph: A senior executive at Morgan Stanley is preparing to join the field of litigation finance, a young industry in which investment firms stake millions on the outcome of lawsuits.

headline: Last-Day Rush Causes Another Malfunction of HealthCare.gov
abstract: After the site failed in the morning because of a software problem, a surge of applicants caused a second failure in the afternoon.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a second time on Monday, the federal website where consumers can sign up for medical coverage under President Obama’s health care law unexpectedly stopped taking applications. It is the last day of open enrollment for the year.

headline: Libyan Fund Sues French Bank Over $1.5 Billion in Losses on Derivatives
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Libyan Investment Authority is suing Société Générale and other parties, saying it should be reimbursed for losses from soured derivatives because the bank paid bribes to associates of a son of the former Libyan dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:41 a.m. | LONDON — The Libyan Investment Authority is suing the French bank Société Générale and other parties over losses that it says were tied to tens of millions of dollars in bribes paid to associates of a son of the former Libyan dictator, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: By Plotting Journeys, Providing a Glimpse at Citi Bike Ridership
abstract: A new data visualization project makes clear the degree to which the bike share system has become interwoven into New York City’s transit network.
lead_paragraph: Since its introduction last May, the Citi Bike program has attracted 100,000 annual members but far fewer daily subscribers than expected, a combination that has contributed to the system’s precarious finances as operators look to expand.

headline: Russia Raises Some Salaries and Pensions for Crimeans
abstract: The Kremlin moved to raise pensions and salaries in the annexed territory as the Russian prime minister visited the regional capital.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Moving quickly to envelop Crimea in the Russian bureaucracy and economy, the Kremlin said Monday that it had nearly doubled pensions paid to retirees on the peninsula, raising them to the average levels paid in Russia.

headline: What Happens if You Save for College
abstract: The government’s formulas for what a parent is expected to pay for a child’s college education make some questionable and outdated assumptions.
lead_paragraph: A recent Op-Ed article in The New York Times argued that the cost of college could easily be lowered by cutting what’s called the “expected family contribution.” That is the amount, based on a complicated formula laid out by Congress many decades ago, that parents and students are expected to pay for college.

headline: A Blast and a Wedding
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'AMPUTATION', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Legs', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: A Marine deployed twice to Afghanistan found himself fighting once more as a double amputee to reclaim a life of normalcy.
lead_paragraph: It is 2014, and to America the war in Afghanistan is over. President Obama’s draw-down year is upon us, and as quickly as 2013 ended when the ball dropped, it seems, so did the nation’s memory of its longest running war.

headline: Police Clamp Down on Protest Against Chemical Plant in South China
abstract: The demonstration is the latest sign that Chinese citizens are growing increasingly concerned about the environmental risks that come with industrial development.
lead_paragraph: Residents of a city in China’s southeastern Guangdong Province took to the streets Sunday to protest plans to build a chemical plant, the latest in a series of protests in China over environmental dangers that have accompanied the country’s rapid economic growth.

headline: Yellen Says Fed Is Determined to Improve the Labor Market
abstract: Ms. Yellen’s speech offered a strong reminder of her concern about unemployment, and a rebuttal to economists who fault the Fed’s ability to improve labor conditions.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Janet L. Yellen, the new Federal Reserve chairwoman, devoted more than an hour last week talking by telephone with three Chicago-area residents struggling to find jobs.

headline: U.N. Court Orders Japan to Halt Whaling
abstract: Koji Tsuruoka, an official from Japan’s Foreign Ministry, and Geert Vons, a representative of Sea Shepherd, responded to the International Court of Justice’s order for Japan to halt whaling practices.
lead_paragraph: Koji Tsuruoka, an official from Japan’s Foreign Ministry, and Geert Vons, a representative of Sea Shepherd, responded to the International Court of Justice’s order for Japan to halt whaling practices.

headline: Ordinary Decisions With Not So Ordinary Consequences
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: The collapse of Dewey & LeBeouf provides a good example of how a series of seemingly mundane accounting maneuvers led to guilty pleas and criminal charges, writes White Collar Watch columnist Peter J. Henning.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Prize winning physicist Richard P. Feynman once said, “The first principle is that you must not fool yourself and you are the easiest person to fool.” That notion seems especially applicable to white-collar crimes that are the result of ordinary decisions by people who rarely seem to have recognized the path they were going down because they decided to fool themselves.

headline: Today in Small Business: Killing DailyCandy
abstract: HealthCare.Gov malfunctions on the last day to sign up. The extra perks it takes to hire technology talent. And business owners in Las Vegas share their “goofs, gaffes and miscalculations.”
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Food Curated: Bacchanal Pepper Sauce
abstract: Sonya Samuel’s hot sauce recipe relies heavily on Scotch Bonnet peppers for their heat, but it’s the addition of fruit that sets it apart.
lead_paragraph: Sonya Samuel’s hot sauce recipe relies heavily on Scotch Bonnet peppers for their heat, but it’s the addition of fruit that sets it apart.

headline: Columbia Records Executive’s Archive Headed to New York Public Library
abstract: The personal archives of George Avakian, who oversaw some of the 20th century’s most important jazz recordings, will go to the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, at Lincoln Center, has acquired the personal archives of George Avakian, a record executive and producer who, during his years at Columbia Records, oversaw some of the 20th century’s most important jazz recordings, and his wife, the violinist Anahid Ajemian, a founding member of the Composers String Quartet. The acquisition, which the library announced on Monday, includes more than 160 linear feet of papers, including correspondence with musicians and composers, and recordings of concert performances and studio sessions, including many that have never been released commercially.

headline: Video: Bacchanal Pepper Sauce
abstract: Meet Sonya Samuel, the owner of Bacchanal Pepper Sauce, a Brooklyn-made Caribbean hot-pepper-sauce company.
lead_paragraph: Liza de Guia is a video journalist whose blog, Food. Curated., profiles people who produce interesting food in New York and beyond.

headline: AT&T’s Stock Buyback May Further Signal Waning Interest in Vodafone Deal
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: If there were any doubts that AT&T’s appetite was waning for a takeover bid for Vodafone, the latest announcement by AT&T for a potential stock buyback worth around $11 billion might erase them.
lead_paragraph: If there were any doubts that AT&T’s appetite was waning for a Vodafone takeover bid, the American telecommunications giant’s latest potential stock buyback might erase them.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: March 28-30, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Often when a child is accidentally shot by a friend or family member no one goes to jail, the reasoning being that the shooter has suffered enough. As a result, the penalty for such shootings varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.

headline: Follow The Links (Utility)
abstract: Where to get the sources for my columns.
lead_paragraph: I’ve had some puzzling correspondence, both hostile and neutral, from people complaining that I don’t provide sources for my facts and numbers. All I can guess is that these correspondents don’t realize that there are a lot of hyperlinks embedded in the online version of my column (and of course in all blog posts.) In fact, there’s a link for almost every factual or quantitative assertion — the only exceptions are where the source isn’t available online, which is increasingly rare. In today’s column, for example, following the links will take you to sources for everything.

headline: Bookshelf | A Member of Fashion (and European) Royalty Turns Mr. Manners
abstract: The photographer and Polish nobleman Alexi Lubomirski instructs young men on the lost art of princely behavior.
lead_paragraph: It’s an age-old question: is chivalry dead? On the morning rush-hour commute on the F train, one could wager that it is. But if the noted fashion photographer Alexi Lubomirski — a.k.a. His Serene Highness Prince Alexi Lubomirski of the Polish house of Lubomirski — has his way, perhaps the next generation of boys will grow up to be more gallant. If, that is, such gentlemen-in-training read and abide by the simple affirmations (one per page) he outlines in his new self-published book, “Notes for a Young Prince.” “It’s about all the elements that a prince should have: charm, chivalry, courage, charity, honor, romance,” he says. (The London-born, New York-based Lubomirski learned of his royal status at age eleven — and reacted by saying “awesome!” — though it has never amounted to anything beyond a title.)

headline: Investigation of Flight 370 to Continue
abstract: The Malaysian defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, and Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said there is no time limit on the investigation of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
lead_paragraph: The Malaysian defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, and Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia said there is no time limit on the investigation of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: Flaming Lips Release a Companion to ‘Dark Side of the Moon’
abstract: The band is offering “an immersive companion piece” to Pink Floyd’s 1973 classic.
lead_paragraph: Updated, April 1 | The Flaming Lips announced on Tuesday that the “Flaming Side of the Moon” recording was done as part of an elaborate April Fools prank in collaboration with the website Funny or Die. The original post is below.

headline: Hobie Alter, Innovator of Sailing and Surfing, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Alter used a production line and polyurethane foam in surfboard manufacturing, then created the popular Hobie Cat sailboat in the late 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Hobie Alter, who was known as the Henry Ford of the surfboard industry for his manufacturing innovations and who used his idle time to create the Hobie Cat, the lightweight, double-hulled sailboat that achieved worldwide popularity, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Hobbling Wall Street Cowboys
abstract: “Flash Boys,” by Michael Lewis, traces the dangers of high-speed Wall Street trading and the people who try to set things right.
lead_paragraph: Michael Lewis writes that before he began working on “Flash Boys,” he had little interest in the stock market, “though, like most people, I enjoy watching it go boom and crash.” And like most people, he had an antiquated notion of what the stock market was. At the start of “Flash Boys,” his dazzling, troublemaking new work of reportorial storytelling, Mr. Lewis summons that sweet old image of a trading floor full of screaming brokers, slamming telephones and hysteria-inducing ticker tape. Picture that, he suggests. And then forget it, because it’s gone.

headline: ‘Nashville’ Cast Sets Out on a Short Tour
abstract: The three main men of “Nashville” – Charles Esten, Jonathan Jackson and Sam Palladio – will play three concerts, along with Chris Carmac and Clare Bowen.
lead_paragraph: OMG, Deacon! Avery! Gunnar! Live!!

headline: Ethan Brown’s Magic Square
abstract: A magic square contains rows, columns and diagonals of numbers that all sum to the same value. Can you complete one if given three starting values?
lead_paragraph: What is mathematics? In one sense, it’s working with numbers: We’re standing in the checkout line and realize we have only cash. Do we have enough? We start adding up the prices of the items in our cart. That’s certainly math. But we can also take a different approach, by estimating the number of items in our cart and multiplying by a rough average price. If we’re at Trader Joe’s, we’ll multiply by three; at Whole Foods, we’ll multiply by five. At Costco, we’ll tally up our giant items, all in our giant cart, and multiply by 15.

headline: ‘Imperial Presidency’ Becomes a Rallying Cry for Republicans
abstract: While criticizing President Obama as weak, Republicans are also uniting behind a message of government overreach.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga. — Republicans, poised for strong gains in the midterm elections, are offering starkly conflicting messages about President Obama to rally their voters. In one moment, they say the president is feckless and weak. But in the next, they say Mr. Obama is presiding over an “imperial presidency” that is exercising power that verges on dictatorial.

headline: With the Thrills Come Extreme Risks
abstract: Overconfidence and a lack of training and a habit of not wearing safety gear, especially helmets, help cause more than 40,000 head and neck injuries nationally a year in sports like skateboarding.
lead_paragraph: Despite several well-publicized accidents, like the death last year of the snowmobiler Caleb Moore, just 25, the popularity of extreme sports has soared in recent years. Participants in the X Games and other sporting events regularly perform heart-stopping tricks on skis and snowboards, skateboards and mountain bikes, all of them endlessly replayed on YouTube and television for a growing audience of thrill-seekers.

headline: Bananas Poached in Vanilla-Scented Chardonnay
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Don’t overcook the bananas in this easy dish, and you’ll be rewarded with a fragrant, delicious dessert.
lead_paragraph: I am usually not one for bananas in desserts, but this, if you’re careful not to overcook the bananas, is heavenly. Years ago, in the early days of my career as a vegetarian caterer, I made it often; it was one of my most requested desserts. These days I’m as likely to spoon some of the bananas with their fragrant syrup into a bowl of morning yogurt as I am to serve it after a meal.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Mercedes Sweep at Malaysian Grand Prix
abstract: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg finished first and second for the Mercedes Formula One team; Kurt Busch brought the first Sprint Cup win for the new Haas team.
lead_paragraph: Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg, teammates on the Mercedes-Benz Formula One team, finished one-two in the Malaysian Grand Prix Sunday, continuing the marque’s dominance in the early stages of the battle for the 2014 Formula One title. Hamilton, the pole position starter, led from green light to checkered flag, at which point he was more than 17 seconds ahead of his teammate. Rosberg, who won the season-opening round in Australia this month, now has a sizable lead in driving championship points.

headline: Pears Poached in Red Wine and Cassis
abstract: A classic French dessert with liqueur that adds a deep berry essence.
lead_paragraph: Wine-poached pears make for a classic French dessert. I like to add a little crème de cassis liqueur to the wine, along with honey, vanilla and cinnamon. The cassis, made from black currants, adds a deep berry essence to the syrupy wine. You can serve these pears warm or chilled.

headline: How to Talk to Your Teenager About Pornography
abstract: Even researchers who can’t point to definitive evidence that pornography harms teenagers say parents should talk to their children about what they might see online. What should that conversation look like?
lead_paragraph: In Does Porn Hurt Children in the Sunday Review, David Segal pointed to the absence of definitive research linking pornography exposure during adolescence to negative outcomes for teenagers and noted the ethical impossibility of conducting the kinds of studies that might prove, or disprove, such links. In spite of the lack of evidence of harm, every researcher he interviewed felt uneasy about the messages teenagers might take from pornography and suggested that “at a minimum” parents should be talking with their teenagers about sexuality in general and porn in particular.

headline: Dried Fruit Compote With Fresh Apple and Pear
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: An alcohol-free compote with a variety of dried fruit and a bright flavor.
lead_paragraph: This compote, which I like to add to my morning yogurt, does not involve wine, though you could add some red or white wine for flavor if you wanted to. The sweetness will vary with the type of fruit used. If you use dried sour cherries, don’t use too many, because they will give the compote too strong a sour cherry flavor. Sweet fruit, like dried apples, pears and raisins, will result in a compote with a brightertaste. Apricots are great too, contributing another rich taste layer. I add fresh apple and pear for theirtexture, which remains somewhat crunchy even after they simmer.

headline: Blood-Orange, Ruby-Red Grapefruit and Pomegranate Compote
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A refreshing dessert that keeps well for a few days.
lead_paragraph: I had a similar recipe, inspired by a recipe by Deborah Madison, about a year ago for a blood-orange compote with a delicious caramel-citrus syrup. I use the same technique for the syrup in this mix of ruby-red grapefruit, blood oranges and pomegranate, but I add a little bit of port. It’s a beautiful, refreshing dessert and it keeps well for a couple of days.

headline: Prunes Poached in Red Wine
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Reducing the soaking time in this French bistro classic saves flavor.
lead_paragraph: This is one of those classic French bistro offerings that you still see on dessert trolleys in popular Parisian bistros (I’m thinking Chez Georges, in the Second Arrondissement). Most recipes have you soak the prunes for up to 12 hours before poaching, but I see no need for that, nor do I want to lose the essence of the prunes in the soaking water. I cover them with boiling water for 5 minutes only; then I poach them in wine and let them steep.

headline: College Classes Use Arts to Brace for Climate Change
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Global Warming', 'Air Pollution', 'Books and Literature', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: A growing number of university courses are using the creative arts, including “climate fiction,” to respond to what many students consider one of society’s central challenges.
lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — University courses on global warming have become common, and Prof. Stephanie LeMenager’s new class here at the University of Oregon has all the expected, alarming elements: rising oceans, displaced populations, political conflict, endangered animals.

headline: An Evolving View of Animals
abstract: Tim Flach wants us to look at animals the way we look at people. Not so much to humanize them, but to get humans to consider how they relate to animals.
lead_paragraph: Tim Flach wants us to look at animals the way we look at people. Not so much to humanize them, but to get humans to consider how they relate to animals.

headline: Rights Group Says Data Suggests Mass Shootings in Nigeria
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Amnesty International said it had satellite images that appeared to show mass graves at a military prison in Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The human rights group Amnesty International said Monday that it had satellite images suggesting mass graves in the northeastern Nigerian city of Maiduguri, following what witnesses have described as the large-scale execution of inmates by security forces at a military prison on March 14. The group said the pictures showed shapes often seen in satellite images of mass graves. Its report quotes witnesses who said they observed soldiers conducting mass shootings of frail detainees. The shootings took place after an attempted prison break by the Islamist group Boko Haram. Over 600 were killed that day by security forces, the rights group said, making it what was most likely the deadliest episode in Boko Haram’s five-year insurgency. Amnesty suggested that both the Islamists and the Nigerian Army were guilty of crimes against humanity.

headline: An Owner Asks a Question About Offering Employees a Stipend to Buy Health Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Could replacing insurance with a set sum of cash that employees can use to buy their own insurance lead to accusations of age discrimination?
lead_paragraph: I read with interest Robb Mandelbaum’s post last week in which Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel predicted that employers will stop offering health insurance. In particular, I was intrigued by the following comment from Dr. Emanuel:

headline: Competitive Birding in the Israeli Desert
abstract: Champions of the Flyway, scheduled for Tuesday, is a competitive birding event in the desert in Israel.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, more than 100 competitors will descend into the Israeli desert, armed with binoculars, bamboo whistles and a desire for glory.

headline: Push to Rid City of Classrooms That Are Anything but Temporary
abstract: Over 7,000 city students are learning in trailers, which were intended to be a temporary solution to crowded schools but are a testament to the struggle to keep up with teeming neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: A rotted floor in a trailer-turned-classroom got Scott Cosby his job: When it caved in, swallowing a custodian’s foot, officials at Public School 214 in East New York, Brooklyn, hired Mr. Cosby to fill in.

headline: Want Guns With That? Chefs Find Politics Hotter Than Kitchen
abstract: Some chefs have entered willingly into American social debates while others have found themselves unwittingly caught up in cultural wars.
lead_paragraph: CLEMSON, S.C. — Pete Matsko expected a little pushback when he posted a sarcastic sign banning concealed weapons from Backstreets Pub & Grill, his beer and burger bar in this college town, but he did not expect to become a national target.

headline: Image of the Day: March 31
abstract: A woman in Mumbai, Maharashtra, celebrating Gudi Padwa, which marks the onset of a new year in the Hindu lunar calendar.

headline: Weather Hampers Landslide Search Efforts
abstract: The program manager of the Snohomish County Department of Emergency Management, Jason Biermann, and Lt. Richard Burke of the Bellevue Fire Department explained how the weather has affected the search.
lead_paragraph: The program manager of the Snohomish County Department of Emergency Management, Jason Biermann, and Lt. Richard Burke of the Bellevue Fire Department explained how the weather has affected the search.

headline: All the Rage | Just Wear It
abstract: Nike’s athletic look is now all-black, making the swoosh a sleek look for everyone.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to Nike’s all-black take on athletic style, everyone is once again sporting the swoosh.

headline: When the Unknown Republican Wins
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Polls predicting the behavior of G.O.P. primary voters this far ahead of a presidential election can have a certain humor value.
lead_paragraph: It’s risky to predict the behavior of Republican Party primary voters this far ahead of a presidential election, but that doesn’t stop polling companies from trying to do just that, nor does it interfere with the humor value of the results.

headline: Lufthansa Warns of Disruptions if Strike Occurs
abstract: The German airline said that the planned three-day strike threatened to affect more than 425,000 passengers across its global network.
lead_paragraph: Paris — The German flagship airline Lufthansa warned Monday that a strike planned by its largest pilots’ union this week would probably be one of the most disruptive in its history, threatening to affect more than 425,000 passengers across its global network.

headline: Readers’ Reactions to Funding Tappan Zee Bridge Construction
abstract: An article about the uncertainty of paying for the construction of a $3.9 billion replacement of the Tappan Zee Bridge elicited a striking number of comments from readers, drivers and nondrivers alike.
lead_paragraph: There is something about a toll that can drive drivers and nondrivers alike to, well, intense expressions of fury.

headline: Here’s a Money-Making Strategy: Save More
abstract: Instead of spending time trying to find the perfect investment and market strategy, consider earning, and saving, a little extra.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, I got an email from someone living nearby who wanted to talk about his investment plan. We arranged a time to meet, and I got to spend an hour being a sounding board. It didn’t take long to discover that he was making a common mistake. It’s one I’ve made, too, and continue to make if I’m not paying attention.

headline: Obamacare Lives!
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: We don’t know if the health care law is working, but we know it isn’t doomed.
lead_paragraph: Back when rate shock, website problems and lagging enrollment were threatening to unravel the new health care law before it fully took effect, I concluded a column on Obamacare’s repeated near-death experiences with the following warning to conservatives:

headline: Virginia Woolf Ballet and New Philip Glass Work Highlight Royal Opera House Season
abstract: A new ballet set to a commissioned score by Max Richter is to be based on different texts by Woolf, including “Mrs. Dalloway,” “Orlando” and “The Waves,” and will be choreographed by Wayne McGregor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Some genuine surprises as well as a pragmatic eye to the box office are part of the 2014-15 Royal Opera House season, announced on Monday by Alex Beard, the chief executive of the Royal Opera House; Kevin O’Hare, the director of the Royal Ballet; and Kasper Holten, the director of the Royal Opera.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Two executives and a professor will be inducted into the Marketing Hall of Fame, said the American Marketing Association’s New York chapter.
lead_paragraph: AMBA Communications, Mosman, New South Wales, Australia, was chosen as the representative for Australia by Icom, Rollinsville, Colo., a network of independent advertising and marketing communications agencies.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: Ads promoting the benefits of sports, and a change in the Geico tag line.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Peanuts Come Out of Their Shells by Proclaiming Their ‘Powerful’ Properties
abstract: A new campaign promotes the power of the peanut, with ads online and in print to remind health-conscious shoppers of the protein and other benefits of peanuts.
lead_paragraph: A campaign that promoted peanuts as “energy for the good life” is being replaced with one that strives to be more energetic.

headline: Times Minute | Ukraine’s Constitution
keywords: ['Snakes', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'United States International Relations', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On the Minute, how Ukraine’s new constitution is taking shape with influence from Russia and the United States, a Republican rallying cry, and cultural divisions over rattlesnake hunting in Texas.
lead_paragraph: On the Minute, how Ukraine’s new constitution is taking shape with influence from Russia and the United States, a Republican rallying cry, and cultural divisions over rattlesnake hunting in Texas.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Appeal of Generic Drug Case
keywords: ['Multiple Sclerosis', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Generic Brands and Products', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: The court’s decision could delay competitors’ generic versions of Copaxone, made by Teva Pharmaceutical Industries.
lead_paragraph: As the world’s largest maker of generic drugs, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries has been critical of brand-name manufacturers that try to block generic versions of their high-priced medicines.

headline: Times Minute | Ukraine’s New Constitution
abstract: On the Minute, how Ukraine’s new constitution is taking shape with influence from Russia and the United States, a Republican rallying cry and divisions over rattlesnake hunting in Texas.

headline: Michael Jackson Album to Offer Eight New Songs
abstract: Vocals recorded by Jackson, selected from his archive by L.A. Reid, will be mixed with new material by several producers, including Timbaland.
lead_paragraph: Eight previously unreleased songs recorded by Michael Jackson over the course of his four-decade career have been completed and compiled for a new album, “Xscape,” to be released on May 13, Epic Records announced on Monday.

headline: Panel on U.N. Climate Change Report
abstract: Rajendra K. Pachauri, the chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, and Christopher Field, the co-chairman of the group that wrote the report, discuss its warning.
lead_paragraph: Rajendra K. Pachauri, the chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, and Christopher Field, the co-chairman of the group that wrote the report, discuss its warning.

headline: Japan on Courts Ruling to Halt Whaling
abstract: An official from Japan’s Foreign Ministry responds to the ruling of the International Court of Justice that ordered Japan to halt whaling in the Antarctic.
lead_paragraph: An official from Japan’s Foreign Ministry responds to the ruling of the International Court of Justice that ordered Japan to halt whaling in the Antarctic.

headline: Russia’s Medvedev Visits Crimea
abstract: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia spoke in Crimea where he held a meeting with members of his Cabinet and local officials.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia spoke in Crimea where he held a meeting with members of his Cabinet and local officials.

headline: Made Nervous by the Doctor
abstract: A large review of studies finds that there is truth to the “white coat effect” when it comes to taking a patient’s blood pressure.
lead_paragraph: A large review of studies has found that the “white coat effect” — a rise in blood pressure in a medical setting because of a patient’s anxiety — can be serious enough to affect treatment decisions.

headline: On Canvas, Clues About Air Pollution
abstract: Those gorgeous sunsets captured by great painters are proving to be a new source of information for scientists.
lead_paragraph: Sunsets painted by the great masters are now providing a type of information their creators could never have imagined: important clues about air pollution.

headline: In Extra Rib, a Harbinger of Mammoth’s Doom
abstract: The superfluous bone, seen in fossil samples, was a sign of inbreeding and harsh conditions during pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Many woolly mammoths from the North Sea had a superfluous rib attached to their seventh vertebra, a sign that they suffered from inbreeding and harsh conditions during pregnancy, researchers report.

headline: Converging Interests May Lead to Cooperation Between Israel and Gulf States
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Widespread worry over Iran’s nuclear program and disagreement over American foreign policy have led to a new urgency to find common ground.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Looking for a potential bright spot in the roiling upheaval of the Middle East, American and Israeli officials meeting in Jerusalem on Monday held out the hope of growing security cooperation between Israel and its Arab neighbors in the Persian Gulf.

headline: F.C.C. to Free Airwaves for Wi-Fi and Wireless Broadband
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Radio Spectrum', 'Cable Television', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The commission is trying to ease the congestion that leads to dropped calls and slow loading of online material. It also acted to help curb the cost of cable television service.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission approved measures on Monday that will free up more airwaves for Wi-Fi and wireless broadband. The agency also moved to help curb increasing cable rates for consumers, but in doing so cracked down hard on the ability of broadcast stations to negotiate jointly in competition with cable systems.

headline: Ted Hughes Estate Cuts Off Access, Biographer Says
abstract: Jonathan Bate, at work on a book about the poet Ted Hughes, says he has been barred from archives and that permission to quote from Hughes’s work has been withdrawn.
lead_paragraph: The poet Ted Hughes has long been criticized for burning some of the diaries of his estranged wife Sylvia Plath after her suicide in 1963. Now, the Hughes estate has abruptly withdrawn access from Hughes’s latest biographer, renewing suggestions that there may be secrets the family still wishes to keep hidden.

headline: Sous Vide, Young Man
abstract: As part of our cover story on the 15-year-old chef Flynn McGarry for the Food and Drink issue, we solicited some advice from the pros for a kid just starting out.
lead_paragraph: As part of our cover story about the 15-year-old chef Flynn McGarry for the Food and Drink issue, we solicited some advice from the pros for a kid just starting out.

headline: From Dogs, Answers About Breast Cancer
abstract: Mammary tumors in strays can provide insights about breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: By the time the elderly woman surrendered the 10 dogs living in her mobile home in rural Maryland, the shih tzus were unkempt and full of fleas and had gone years without their shots. A cream- and mushroom-colored female named Akyra, with a sweet disposition and a comical underbite, was in such bad shape that volunteer rescue groups declined to take her in.

headline: The Read Around: Kevin Young
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets']
abstract: Death, birth, rebirth and the afterlife of grief are all present in Kevin Young’s new book of poetry, “Book of Hours.”
lead_paragraph: Death, birth, rebirth and the afterlife of grief are all present in Kevin Young’s new book of poetry, “Book of Hours.”

headline: Health Care Signups Reach Frenzy in Final Day to Enroll
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: HealthCare.gov, the federal website, was temporarily overwhelmed by a rush to sign up, but officials said they were confident that they would reach their enrollment goal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A frenzied last-minute scramble to sign up for health insurance overloaded phone lines and temporarily overwhelmed the website of the federal marketplace on Monday, as hundreds of thousands of people around the country raced to beat the deadline to obtain coverage under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | March 25-31, 2014
abstract: A Supreme Court argument, a Facebook purchase, climate change and more: How many of the 10 questions in this week’s news quiz can you answer correctly?
lead_paragraph: A Supreme Court argument, a Facebook purchase, climate change and more: How many of the 10 questions in this week’s news quiz can you answer correctly?

headline: Losses at Smaller Airports Are Unlikely to Be Reversed
abstract: Small and midsize airports across the country are offering incentives to attract carriers and add routes, but they are in most cases “chasing ghosts,” according to airline industry observers.
lead_paragraph: AIR travel has a lot of new realities: On a cheap coach fare, if you want a seat that isn’t in the middle of a cramped row back by the toilets, you are probably going to have to pay extra. Your frequent flier mileage programs are losing value, especially at the lower elite levels. If you’re flying internationally, you’re probably flying an airline alliance and not a particular airline.

headline: On the Verge | Party Monstre
abstract: Clément Léon, a 31-year-old writer in Paris, has been unofficially elected by his peers to revive the city’s night life.
lead_paragraph: Paris night life’s greatest hope is a bookish bon vivant who’s ready to rage.

headline: Meet These New Snails. Now Say Goodbye.
abstract: Just as several kinds of strikingly ornamented snails are being discovered, they are going extinct.
lead_paragraph: A group of tiny snails with striking, irregularly coiled and ornamented shells are going extinct just as they are being discovered. A new paper reveals 10 new species (and catalogs all 31 species) of the snail, which belong to the genus Plectostoma. Found only in the limestone hills of Southeast Asia, with shells only a few millimeters long, the snails are losing their homes as the limestone is quarried by mining companies.

headline: Reaction to Far Right’s National Front Wins in French Vote
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Local Government']
abstract: The National Front party attained its best result in municipal elections since the late 1990s when it ruled four towns.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – News that France’s far-right National Front party was set to take control of 11 towns across France following municipal elections on Sunday was greeted with a mix of nationalist triumphalism and more than a little fear.

headline: A Proposal Both Original and Cheesy
abstract: Mirra Fine, a documentary filmmaker of the series “The Perennial Plate,” recalls when her husband asked her to marry him while they shot video in Italy.
lead_paragraph: BACK in 2009, my now-husband, Daniel Klein, created a documentary series called “The Perennial Plate,” where we travel around the world filming short stories about sustainable food producers. We’re a two-person team, so we both film, edit and produce each segment. For someone who has never traveled a lot, the last several years have been amazing. When we started doing this, we didn’t have a clue that it would take off, and now our films are not only on our own website but also on the digital network Tastemade.

headline: Video: Kevin Young Talks About Grief and the Poems in ‘Book of Hours’
abstract: Mr. Young talks about the role his father’s death played in shaping his latest collection of poetry.
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors talk about the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Kevin Young discusses how his father’s death and the birth of his son informed his new book of poetry, “Book of Hours.”

headline: Federal Regulator Must Explain Why It Didn’t Investigate G.M. Defect
abstract: Why didn’t it use those tools to get to the bottom of the defect, and how is it going to change its operations in the future?
lead_paragraph: Every week seems to bring more unsettling details about the failure of General Motors and a federal safety agency — for more than a decade — to identify a dangerous defect that has been linked to at least 13 deaths. On Sunday, a House subcommittee revealed that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration failed to open an investigation into the ignition switches G.M. used in several models even though its inspectors were aware of four deaths, more than two-dozen complaints and other reports that suggested a problem.

headline: Auto Safety Agency Ready to Point Finger at G.M.
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: In testimony, a regulator will say that “critical” data from General Motors could have led to earlier detection of ignition flaws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top auto safety regulator will seek to cast blame on General Motors when he testifies on Tuesday before a House subcommittee looking into the ignition problem of Chevrolet Cobalts and other cars.

headline: U.S. Is Weighing Release of a Spy for the Israelis
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States and Israel are discussing the possible release of Jonathan Pollard, an American serving a life sentence in North Carolina for spying for Israel.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is discussing the release of an American convicted of spying for Israel more than a quarter of a century ago, American officials said Monday, as it struggles to avert a collapse in peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Leader of China Aims at Military With Graft Case
abstract: China charged Lt. Gen. Gu Junshan with financial crimes and abuse of power in a case seen as part of an effort to tighten the party’s control over the military.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Prosecutors accused a former senior military official on Monday of a litany of crimes, including bribery, embezzlement and abuse of power, presenting a first glimpse of what could be the biggest corruption scandal to ever engulf the Chinese armed forces.

headline: Airline Blames Bad Software in San Francisco Crash
abstract: The Korean carrier Asiana told the National Transportation Safety Board that inconsistencies with the aircraft’s automation logic were also to blame for the crash.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While the world has been fixated on the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, the Korean carrier involved in the crash of a different Boeing 777, the Asiana flight into San Francisco last July, raised design issues on Monday that put another question mark over the model of jetliner.

headline: MetLife Reaches $60 Million Settlement With New York Authorities
abstract: MetLife is paying a penalty for permitting two subsidiaries to operate without first obtaining the required license to sell insurance.
lead_paragraph: MetLife, one of the world’s largest insurers, is paying a $60 million penalty to the authorities in New York for permitting two subsidiaries to operate without first obtaining the required license to sell insurance.

headline: A Guard in a Center’s Body at Forward for UConn
abstract: A 6-foot-4 sophomore with a 7-1 wingspan, Connecticut’s Breanna Stewart is widely considered the best college player in women’s basketball: a tall forward with the deft skills of a guard.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — It was midway through the second half of a rare game in which Connecticut’s Breanna Stewart struggled to find the basket and her accustomed dominance.

headline: An Outtake From ‘Flex Is Kings’
abstract: Exclusive bonus footage from the documentary “Flex Is Kings” featuring the dancer Storyboard P.
lead_paragraph: Exclusive bonus footage from the documentary “Flex Is Kings” featuring the dancer Storyboard P.

headline: Spite Is Good. Spite Works.
abstract: After decades of focusing on aggressiveness, selfishness, narcissism and greed, scientists have turned their attention to the subtler theme of spite.
lead_paragraph: The “Iliad” may be a giant of Western literature, yet its plot hinges on a human impulse normally thought petty: spite.

headline: Rearview Cameras by 2018 for Cars and Light Trucks
abstract: After delays, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration issued a final rule requiring safety equipment meant to prevent backing into pedestrians.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Congress mandated auto safety regulators to pass a federal standard by 2011 that would help keep drivers from running over small children as they backed up their vehicles.

headline: Building Pterosaurs Down to Their Hairs, William Henry Harrison’s Killer, Medical Device Loopholes
abstract:
A new exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History will feature great reptiles that soared over 60 million years ago; historians may be dead wrong about what killed the shortest-tenured American president; how safe are the medical devices in use in hospitals and doctors’ offices?
Subscribe to the Podcast »
lead_paragraph:
A new exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History will feature great reptiles that soared over 60 million years ago; historians may be dead wrong about what killed the shortest-tenured American president; how safe are the medical devices in use in hospitals and doctors’ offices?
