headline: Earthquake Expert Uses Twitter to Urge People to Be ‘Ready All the Time’
abstract: An earthquake expert for the mayor of Los Angeles turned to Twitter to explain aftershocks and urge people to be prepared for a major earthquake following Friday night’s back-to-back jolts.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Adam Nagourney reported, the new mayor of Los Angeles and his top adviser on earthquake planning are hoping that the back-to-back earthquakes Friday night will create a sense of urgency to address concerns about the city’s lack of preparedness for a major earthquake.

headline: Fewer Helmets, More Deaths
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Helmets', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: More states are being pressured to repeal their universal motorcycle helmet laws. But when those laws are changed, the number of fatalities starts to rise immediately.
lead_paragraph: More states are being pressured to repeal their universal motorcycle helmet laws. But when those laws are changed, the number of fatalities starts to rise immediately.

headline: Obamacare, The Unknown Ideal
abstract: This is what conservative health reform looks like.
lead_paragraph: No, I haven’t lost my mind — or suddenly become an Ayn Rand disciple. It’s not my ideal; in a better world I’d call for single-payer, and a significant role for the government in directly providing care.

headline: Visuals
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', "Alzheimer's Disease", 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Elderly', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A column that looks at the data behind science and health developments.
lead_paragraph: This collection of columns takes a look behind the numbers to show hidden trends and relationships over a range of science and health topics from education to road safety to agriculture.

headline: Hushed or Percussive, It Trumpets an Identity
abstract: Pat Metheny and his Unity Group ranged far and wide in form and presentation at Town Hall, but a unified aesthetic ruled throughout.
lead_paragraph: The smallest moments in Pat Metheny’s sprawling concert at Town Hall on Friday night came at the very beginning and the very end, when he was sitting alone with a guitar. The biggest moments included four additional musicians, straining mightily, along with a partial reconstruction of Mr. Metheny’s orchestrion, the whiz-bang electromechanical orchestra that he unveiled four years ago and has kept refining since.

headline: Replay Review’s First Cases Draw No Complaints
abstract: A call at first base on a double play in the Cubs-Pirates game was the first test of the new system.
lead_paragraph: After months of expectation, baseball had its first regular-season use of the new replay review system on Monday. In a quiet and efficient start to the system, the call on the field of a game between the Chicago Cubs and the Pittsburgh Pirates was upheld, and the process took less than two minutes. Later, a second challenge helped the Pirates win.

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup, Day 73: U.S. Down Two Against Mexico
abstract: The Mexican club Puebla declined to release DaMarcus Beasley and Michael Orozco to the United States national team for Wednesday’s friendly against Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Mexico is preparing for this summer’s World Cup in Brazil only because of a bit of last-minute help it received from the United States national team on the final day of qualifying last year. But to one Mexican club team, that is no reason to help the Americans get ready, too.

headline: Building Pterosaurs, Harrison’s Killer, Medical Device Loopholes
abstract: Models of ancient creatures; what killed an American president?; how safe are medical devices?
lead_paragraph: Models of ancient creatures; what killed an American president?; how safe are medical devices?

headline: Justices Seem Wary of Software Patent Case
abstract: A case over patents to mitigate risks among multiple parties in a transaction has been seen as an indicator of how abstract technical ideas can be to become eligible for patent protection.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a case with the potential to reshape the software industry, the Supreme Court on Monday seemed poised to issue fresh limits on patents for computer-based business methods.

headline: The Line to Kiss Sheldon Adelson’s Boots
abstract: Bowing and scraping before the casino magnate, and his billions, has become a requirement for GOP presidential hopefuls.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a political spectacle more loathsome than the parade of Republican presidential candidates who spent the last few days bowing and scraping before the mighty bank account of the casino magnate Sheldon Adelson. One by one, they stood at a microphone in Mr. Adelson’s Venetian hotel in Las Vegas and spoke to the Republican Jewish Coalition (also a wholly owned subsidiary of Mr. Adelson), hoping to sound sufficiently pro-Israel and pro-interventionist and philo-Semitic to win a portion of Mr. Adelson’s billions for their campaigns.

headline: Gut Reactions to Beneficial Bacteria
abstract: How do probiotic bacteria survive the stomach’s acid bath? And do we need to take supplements to increase their numbers in the first place?
lead_paragraph: Q. When you eat yogurt or take a probiotic supplement, why aren’t the probiotic bacteria killed by stomach acids?

headline: Italian D.J. Fights to Keep Culinary Traditions
abstract: Daniele De Michele, a food activist, is touring Italy to collect working-class recipes and food lore.
lead_paragraph: MINORI, Italy — Daniele De Michele, a bearded and boisterous D.J. and performance artist who is one of Italy’s most inventive food activists, is on a yearlong journey to explore and document the country’s working-class and peasant culinary traditions.

headline: Quick Gains After a Smoking Ban
keywords: ['Asthma', 'Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'Premature Babies', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: Measures of children’s health improved around the world just a year after smoking prohibitions were enacted, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: The number of premature births and children’s hospital visits for asthma dropped significantly in parts of the United States, Canada, and Europe barely a year after they enacted smoking bans, researchers reported in The Lancet last week.

headline: Sharp Truths Only Fiction Can Tell
abstract: In a new anthology, renowned authors of recent decades explore chronic and terminal illness, and the toll that takes on families.
lead_paragraph: In a society where 50 million people are caring for someone with a chronic or terminal illness, there is no shortage of literature on the subject, from academic papers to memoirs to practical guides. But in this new anthology, the first of its kind, the “literature” is really that.

headline: Pharrell Williams to Join ‘The Voice’
abstract: The hitmaker presumably takes the spot left open when Cee-Lo Green said he was leaving the NBC show.
lead_paragraph: Looking to cement its status as television’s most popular music show, “The Voice” on NBC will add one of the hottest stars in the music business, Pharrell Williams, as a coach for its next edition in the fall.

headline: Now Screening | New York’s Latest Dance Craze, From Street to Screen
abstract: A new documentary highlights the colorful characters and eye-popping, special-effects-inspired moves of flex, a new urban dance style out of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Exclusive bonus footage from the documentary “Flex Is Kings” featuring the dancer Storyboard P. The photographer Deidre Schoo was taking pictures of a Harlem variety show in 2008 when she became mesmerized by the work of a Brooklyn performer named Storyboard P, who was described earlier this year in The New Yorker as “the Basquiat of street dancing.” “He calls his dancing animated mutation,” Schoo says, “and he strove to animate every piece of his body — on the table, on the floor, using the entire bar.” Storyboard was Schoo’s entree into world of flex dancing, a new style that originated in East New York and Flatbush, Brooklyn, with a vocabulary of movements that borrows in part from the special effects of movies like “Transformers” and “The Matrix.” “It’s very narrative and cinematic and inspired by Michael Jackson’s videos,” she says.

headline: The Device Makers’ Shortcut
abstract: Manufacturers of medical devices have used a regulatory maneuver to avoid testing product changes on actual patients, sometimes with fatal results.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the Food and Drug Administration announced a stunning recall, saying that electrical wires in some St. Jude Medical heart defibrillators, which were implanted in tens of thousands of people, were defective. It was a rerun for cardiac patients: In 2007, Medtronic recalled its Sprint Fidelis cardiac devices because of faulty wires.

headline: Corrections: March 29, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print for March 29, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Who’s Behind the Cocktail Renaissance?
abstract: We’re living in a Golden Age of creativity for bartenders, many of whom are energetically pushing boundaries both in culinary and scientific ways.
lead_paragraph: We’re living in a Golden Age of creativity for bartenders, many of whom are energetically pushing boundaries in both culinary and scientific ways — as I discovered when I was researching my article “Cocktail Science Simplified” in the latest issue of the magazine.

headline: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Drives the Last Car Driven by Elvis
abstract: Presley’s 1973 Stutz Blackhawk III is used in a promotional event, but some Elvis fans say the car should have stayed at Graceland.
lead_paragraph: Richard Petty may be known as the King in Nascar circles, but to many other Americans that title is reserved for Elvis Presley, the King of Rock ‘n Roll. One of Mr. Presley’s cars, the 1973 Stutz Blackhawk III he was photographed driving not long before he died, on Aug. 16, 1977, has made its way into the Nascar realm as part of a promotion for the Charlotte Motor Speedway AutoFair to be held at the track from Thursday to Sunday.

headline: Democrats Scramble to Stave Off Midterm Disaster
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Party leaders are working to mobilize voter turnout in November, but they face changes in their national coalition that could frustrate their efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If it were only President Obama’s flagging poll numbers, the problem for Democrats of how to mobilize core supporters to vote this fall would be bad enough. Midterm elections for an unpopular president’s party are almost always bleak.

headline: Expansion in Use of Cancer Vaccine
keywords: ['Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Cervical Cancer', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: More than 80 percent of girls in the Americas now have access to immunization, and in the United States, infections have already dropped significantly.
lead_paragraph: Now that Brazil has introduced vaccines against cervical cancer, more than 80 percent of girls in the Americas can get them, the Pan American Health Organization announced last month.

headline: Curry and Coconut Milk Fire Up a Weeknight Basic
abstract: Start with onions and garlic, then add tofu, red curry paste and coconut milk for this Thai-inspired meal.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Frequent Flier Miles, for a Cause
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Philanthropy', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Make-a-Wish America is running a campaign in April to encourage the donation of frequent flier miles.
lead_paragraph: Airlines don’t always make it easy to use their frequent flier miles to pay for travel.

headline: What Really Killed William Henry Harrison?
abstract: The accepted wisdom is that the shortest-serving president developed pneumonia after delivering a long Inaugural Address in cold weather. But that might not be true.
lead_paragraph: Like the Science Times page on Facebook. | Sign up for the Science Times newsletter.

headline: Senate Report Says Caterpillar Used Swiss Subsidiary to Reduce Taxes
abstract: A Senate investigation, ahead of a Tuesday hearing, says the company avoided $2.4 billion in United States taxes over 13 years.
lead_paragraph: Caterpillar, the big American maker of heavy construction and mining equipment, used a subsidiary in Switzerland to avoid paying $2.4 billion of income taxes over 13 years, according to a Senate investigative report released on Monday.

headline: Scene City: MOCA in Los Angeles Turns 35
abstract: Diana Ross, Pharrell Williams and other stars celebrate the “new era” at the Museum of Contemporary Art.
lead_paragraph: Diana Ross, Pharrell Williams and other stars celebrate the “new era” at the Museum of Contemporary Art.

headline: U.N. Climate Report Authors Answer 11 Basic Questions
keywords: ['Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Floods', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Land Use Policies', 'Temperature', 'Weather']
abstract: IPCC scientists answer 11 frequently asked questions about the impacts of global warming.
lead_paragraph: The countries that in 1988 created the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which released its latest report on global warming impacts on Monday, have long neglected to provide resources to enable the panel to effectively convey its findings to the public. One example of that continuing communications gap is this: a helpful, and clearly written, “FAQ” on the new report is largely hidden from view deep on the http://ipcc.ch website.

headline: 3 Jailed Journalists Deny Ties to Brotherhood in Egypt
abstract: Three men who worked for Al Jazeera’s English-language news channel appeared to sway a judge, but their case was suspended and they were sent back to jail.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Three journalists jailed on charges of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood to fabricate news told a judge on Monday that they had no association with the group. One of them even recounted drinking alcohol, which is forbidden in Islam.

headline: Interest Is High in First Preview of ‘Hedwig’
abstract: The first preview performance of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch,” with Neil Patrick Harris, was a high note in a strong week for Broadway ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: The Hedheads – devotees of the cult musical “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” – did not disappointment on Saturday night, packing the Belasco Theater for the show’s sold-out debut on Broadway. For its first and only preview performance last week, “Hedwig” grossed $144,194 and had an average paid admission of $141.92 – high numbers by Broadway standards. The audience surely also included some fans of the musical’s star, Neil Patrick Harris, in his first return to Broadway since 2004. The only show with a higher paid admission last week was the blockbuster hit “The Book of Mormon” at $187.20, according to box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

headline: Opener of Built and Dashed Hopes for Mets
abstract: The Mets held a lead as late as the ninth inning, but the Nationals scored four runs in the 10th.
lead_paragraph: The Mets were one out from a victory on opening day. Dillon Gee, Juan Lagares and Jose Valverde had had star turns. It was one game, but the team could have built some confidence and converted a few doubters. After weeks of spring training and evaluation, it was clear that they were flawed. But they talked about winning 90 games this season. A win Monday at Citi Field would start them on that path.

headline: Detained Journalists in Court in Egypt
abstract: From left, Baher Mohamed, Mohamed Fadel Fahmy and Peter Greste are accompanied by a police officer during their trial. The detained Al Jazeera journalists spoke out in a courtroom in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: From left, Baher Mohamed, Mohamed Fadel Fahmy and Peter Greste are accompanied by a police officer during their trial. The detained Al Jazeera journalists spoke out in a courtroom in Egypt.

headline: A Hungarian Sampler, Lighthearted to Brooding
abstract: The violinist Christian Tetzlaff joined the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra at Carnegie Hall for a program exploring Hungary’s musical heritage.
lead_paragraph: While Liszt was inaugurating the concept of the bravura solo piano recital in the 19th century, the Hungarian-born virtuoso violinist Joseph Joachim took a different approach, pioneering the format of concerts dedicated to string quartets and taking a more ascetic approach to music making.

headline: How Animals Think and Harmonic Stars
abstract: An exhibit that depicts what may be going on behind the scenes of a natural history museum, a show that reveals how animals’ minds work and high-tech music.
lead_paragraph: April events at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Chairman of Tax Panel Won’t Run This Year
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: Representative Dave Camp, a Republican from Michigan who was first elected to Congress in 1990, made the announcement on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Dave Camp, the Michigan Republican who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, announced Monday that he would not run for re-election.

headline: Report Blasts Former Academy President on Pay and Résumé
abstract: A report released by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences condemned its former president, Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, for inflating her résumé.
lead_paragraph: The American Academy of Arts and Sciences issued a report on Monday condemning its former president, Leslie Cohen Berlowitz, for inflating her résumé and influencing the academy’s procedures in order to increase her pay far beyond that of leaders of similarly sized organizations.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, South Korea, Pennsylvania and Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, South Korea, Pennsylvania and Tokyo.

headline: Reactions
abstract: Letters to the editor and online comments.
lead_paragraph: Athletic Training

headline: Ares Management Plans Public Offering
abstract: The private equity firm intends to raise $100 million through the offering, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Ares Management intends to raise $100 million through an initial public offering, paving the way for the firm to join the small handful of alternative asset managers that have gone public in recent years.

headline: Mayor’s Opening Day Toss Is a Winner, but He Misses the Mark With Mets Fans
abstract: Bill de Blasio was a good sport despite being booed by Mets fans, where he paid homage to his favorite Boston Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: The pitch was clean and smooth, if a bit slow, a Sunday-league version of a changeup. Most crucially, the ball made it over the plate, plopping into the glove of Travis d’Arnaud, the New York Mets starting catcher, with a satisfying smack.

headline: Fast on Her Feet, and More Than Willing to Get Dirty
abstract: Everything is a double-entendre on Comedy Central’s sketch comedy show “Inside Amy Schumer.”
lead_paragraph: “Inside Amy Schumer” is a sketch comedy show with more than a few bells and whistles. Sketches are interspersed with bits of stand-up, recalling “Louie” and “Chappelle’s Show,” and Ms. Schumer does street interviews straight out of HBO’s “Real Sex.” Episodes end with a sit-down interview labeled “Amy Goes Deep” — everything on this show is a double-entendre — in which Ms. Schumer might talk to a sex columnist, a phone-sex operator or a pornography cameraman.

headline: Composing and Blending, an Atypical Artist Creates
abstract: Jean-Baptiste Barrière’s penchant for mixing music, theater and literature was on display during his Composer Portraits concert on Saturday at the Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: It makes sense that the French composer and multimedia artist Jean-Baptiste Barrière is best known for his collaborations with colleagues, particularly his wife, the Finnish composer Kaija Saariaho. Mr. Barrière’s work is an omnivorous blend of visual art, theater, literature and music, of live and recorded performance, so it is only natural that he plays well with others.

headline: A Maestro Is Back, His Position Pending
abstract: Osmo Vanska wants to return as music director of the Minnesota Orchestra. The players and the audience want him back, but his status remains in limbo.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Dozens of audience members at Orchestra Hall this weekend waved small Finnish flags or wore variations on the flag’s colors: blue and white neckties, scarves, shirts or dresses.

headline: Presenting Onstage the Sounds (and Faces) of the Future
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions Grand Finals Concert on Sunday resulted in the naming of five winners from nine finalists.
lead_paragraph: Most aspiring opera singers in their mid-20s are still figuring out their voices and learning technique. It is always difficult for the judges to pick the winners of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions Grand Finals Concert. Are they assessing the performances they hear at the concert or the potential of still-evolving young artists?

headline: Starting an Overdue Conversation About Money
keywords: ['Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: If nothing else, virtual currencies like Bitcoin have raised questions about the nature of money and how it might be evolving.
lead_paragraph: THERE is no end to the disagreements about the importance and usefulness of the upstart virtual currency Bitcoin.

headline: Makers of Bitcoin A.T.M.’s See a Not-Quite-Cashless Future
abstract: Several companies have recognized that for the foreseeable future, even virtual currency users still need cash, and they have developed machines that allow users to buy and sell Bitcoin for cash.
lead_paragraph: IN addition to the Glocks and Remingtons that have long been available at Central Texas Gun Works, customers can now buy something new: Bitcoin.

headline: Prime Minister Erdogan’s Revenge
abstract: The threats in Mr. Erdogan’s postelection speech were particularly ominous, as he told his supporters that his enemies will be “brought to account.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey got what he wanted from Sunday’s elections for mayors and other local officials — a strong vote of confidence for his Islamist-rooted Justice and Development Party and its 11 years in power.

headline: Fleshing Out the Bones
abstract: At the American Museum of Natural History, turning the most recent scientific knowledge of long-dead species into life-size models is a demanding but endlessly fascinating job.
lead_paragraph: In a brightly lit production studio at the American Museum of Natural History in February, 12 artists were hard at work, heads down, eyes focused.

headline: New York Philharmonic to Team With Music Academy of the West
abstract: A new partnership will bring students from the academy to study with Philharmonic musicians and Alan Gilbert, the music director, in California and New York.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic and the Music Academy of the West, a music school and festival in Santa Barbara, Calif., have set up a four-year partnership under which student fellows from the academy will train with Philharmonic musicians and Alan Gilbert, the orchestra’s music director, both in Santa Barbara and New York.

headline: Nathaniel Rateliff and Regina Carter Release Albums
abstract: The brooding singer-songwriter Nathaniel Rateliff opens up a little in “Falling Faster Than You Can Run,” and the violinist Regina Carter focuses on her family roots in “Southern Comfort.”
lead_paragraph: NATHANIEL RATELIFF

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here are some of the things that got people talking today.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times.

headline: Big Ears
abstract: Scenes from the festival in Knoxville, Tenn.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the festival in Knoxville, Tenn.

headline: They Heard Whatever They Wanted
abstract: The wide-ranging three-day Big Ears music festival returned to Knoxville after a three-year hiatus, with a range of music that let listeners define it as much as the performers and composers.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — The name should give the answer away, but there is a little bit of shadow chasing in the question of the essence of the wide-ranging three-day Big Ears music festival, which finished up its third edition here on Sunday.

headline: Mathematician and Matildas Humbled by Coin Flips
abstract: Tim Chartier, a math professor, and his son have only Florida alive in their N.C.A.A. tournament bracket. Two of Broadway’s Matildas also have one team left, while coin flips predicted two.
lead_paragraph: Late Sunday, when it was official that an unlikely Final Four was heading to Texas, Tim Chartier wistfully conceded that there would be no March Mathness on display in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament.

headline: Q. and A. | Philippe Vergne, the New Director of MoCA, on the Future of the Museum
abstract: T sat down with the charismatic curator to discuss his plans for the embattled institution and why the L.A. art scene has become so vital.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles celebrated its 35th anniversary with a gala that doubled as the coming-out party for the French-born curator Philippe Vergne, the new director of the embattled institution who had previously worked at the Dia Art Foundation and the Walker Art Center. Unlike fundraisers in the past few years, there were no nude Marina Abramovic-style performers or pot passed around the tables. Instead, the soirée — held in honor of the late Mike Kelley, whose retrospective has just opened at the museum — was all business.

headline: Can a TV Series Get Grimmer Than Zombies? Apparently So…
abstract: Let’s hope “The Walking Dead” lets in some light next season.
lead_paragraph: Spoiler alert!Human beings have a primordial fear of being reduced to meat in the eyes of their fellow men and women. The architects of “The Walking Dead,” the wildly popular television show, have exploited that fear to great effect during the first four years of the series, which focuses on a band of survivors who struggle to reconstruct community in a post-apocalyptic landscape dominated by the lumbering, flesh-eating living dead.

headline: Drug Company Seeks to Be Repaid Legal Fees in SAC Capital Inquiry
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Elan Pharmaceuticals is seeking to recoup the more than $1.5 million in legal fees it paid to comply with document requests by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Elan Pharmaceuticals is seeking to recoup the more than $1.5 million in legal fees it paid to comply with document requests by the federal government in its insider trading investigation of the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: France Overhauls Its Government After Voters Rebuke Socialists
abstract: President François Hollande promised new efforts to revive the economy, including tax cuts, after his party sustained broad losses on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France announced the formation of a new government on Monday, after broad losses by his Socialist Party in recent nationwide city elections that were widely seen as a rebuke to the deeply unpopular president.

headline: Video of Police Shooting Prompts Protests in Albuquerque
abstract: Video from protests in downtown Albuquerque that were prompted by the March 16 police shooting of a homeless man.
lead_paragraph: The police in Albuquerque used tear gas Sunday night to disperse hundreds of demonstrators who marched downtown to protest police shootings, including the shooting of a mentally ill homeless man whose death was captured on video by a camera attached to a police officer’s helmet.

headline: National Geographic Channel Pulls ‘Nazi War Diggers’ Series
abstract: Archeologists said the show, set for May, crossed the line in its handling of human remains.
lead_paragraph: National Geographic Channel said Monday that it would “indefinitely” pull a planned television series on unearthing Nazi war graves after days of blistering criticism from archeologists and others who said the show handled the dead with macabre disrespect.

headline: Egyptian Presidential Campaign Launched on a Bike
abstract: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi was photographed on the campaign trail for the first time since he resigned from the military to run for the presidency, astride a mountain bike. chatting with the public.
lead_paragraph: In a throwback to the Mubarak era, Egyptian bloggers on Monday once again found themselves parsing images of the nation’s most powerful man, released to bolster his popularity, ahead of a presidential election in which the result seems to be a foregone conclusion.

headline: Yellen on Tackling Unemployment
abstract: In her first public speech as the Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen emphasized the steps the Fed has taken to spur economic activity and create jobs.
lead_paragraph: In her first public speech as the Federal Reserve chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen emphasized the steps the Fed has taken to spur economic activity and create jobs.

headline: Pedestrian Bridge in Van Cortlandt Park Has an Obstacle: $7.5 Million
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: After the park was subdivided by highways, park supporters and residents sought a bridge to reconnect a particularly isolated section of the park.
lead_paragraph: Before the dawn of automobiles, Van Cortlandt Park was an unbroken expanse of dense woodlands, steep ridges and meadows, interrupted only by the gentle murmur of Tibbetts Brook.

headline: Macy’s C.E.O. Gives Up Title of President
abstract: Macy’s announced that its chief merchandising officer, Jeffrey Gennette, would become the company’s new president, taking a title the chief executive held until Monday.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s announced on Monday that its chief merchandising officer, Jeffrey Gennette, would become the company’s new president, a promotion that may put him next in line to become chief executive.

headline: Slomo
abstract: Dr. John Kitchin quit a medical career to pursue his passion: skating along the boardwalk of San Diego’s Pacific Beach. He calls himself “Slomo.”
lead_paragraph: Dr. John Kitchin quit a medical career to pursue his passion: skating along the boardwalk of San Diego’s Pacific Beach. He calls himself “Slomo.”

headline: ‘Slomo’
abstract: Dr. John Kitchin quit a medical career to pursue his passion: skating along the boardwalk of San Diego’s Pacific Beach. He calls himself “Slomo.”
lead_paragraph: Slomo came into my life at an opportune moment. Having just rolled into my 30s, I was looking for both a film subject and some wisdom on how to approach the encroaching “middle third” of my life — the years when youthful idealism is so often blunted by adult responsibilities.

headline: Pluto.tv Offers Online Videos as Curated TV Channels
abstract: Pluto.tv is offering nearly 100 video channels that are made up of online video and organized into popular categories like Music, Sports and Comedy. The experience feels more like watching a TV channel than a series of video clips.
lead_paragraph: Navigating video content online is a little like reading a good book on Post-it Notes. Each time you’ve watched something great, you have to plod through a number of other screens to find the next good video.

abstract: Caterpillar, the big American maker of heavy construction and mining equipment, used a subsidiary in Switzerland to avoid paying $2.4 billion of income taxes over 13 years, according to an investigative report released on Monday.
